column2: Charles W. Morse will be recalled to the Grand Jury room to-day and questioned as to whether he knows the present whereabouts of Mrs. Dodge, whom he married after she had obtained a divorce from her first husband, now under arrest in Texas. Mr. Morse was before the Grand Jury last week, and under the advice of counsel refused to answer any questions put to him.

Secretary Rehberger of the Brooklyn Jockey Club yesterday received four declarations for the Brooklyn Handicap, which closed with seventy-six entries, making eight in all. Two of J.A. Drake's horses were among the declarations, High Chancellor and Ort Wells, the latter a full brother of Rome Respess's sensational Western colt Dick Welles.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22. -- International eminent domain on the American Continent was proclaimed by Elihu Root in an address at the Auditorium Theatre before the Union League Club here this afternoon. Mr. Root's subject was "The Ethics of the Panama Question."

A. Royal Guest, who is suing to recover $75,000 from Clarence L. Lowther, formerly his intimate friend, for alienating his wife's affections, while on the witness stand in Part XIII. of the Supreme Court yesterday, was much surprised when Mr. Lowther's attorney, Lyman E. Warren, announced that he intended to produce Mrs. Guest, who has not been seen here since Jan. 10, 1903, when she disappeared, it is alleged, in company with Lowther.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 22. -- The Benjamin C. Cromwell, lost off Bellport, L.I., to-day, was owned by Sargent, Lord Skillings of this city. She was valued at $12,000. She was commanded by Capt. Harvey McClean of South Portland, and her first mate was John McCumber of this city. Her crew was shipped in Portland Dec. 4, as follows:

The temporary sojourners at the country places return this morning and take up the routine. Sewing classes and bridge are among the recreations planned for to-day. Departures for the South still continue in numbers, and nearly all the watering places in the semi-tropics have representative New York gatherings.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Mayor McClellan evidently does not intend to allow the Republicans in the Legislature to avoid the home rule issue. At the Mayor's instigation Senator Dowling to-night introduced in the Senate a bill which removes the charter limitation as to the number of men which may be added to the police force in any one year.

Indications of restlessness appear on the part of minority stockholders of Michigan Central. Many of these have long entertained the opinion that they should share more fully in the considerable prosperity which has come to the company, as they are getting no greater return on their shares than when the road was earning eight million dollars less than the amount reported for the year ending Dec. 31 last.

Mr. Raymond Hitchcock, having fallen from his high estate as Dodo the King, made his reappearance at the Broadway yesterday as Abijah Booze, the lazy and bibulous Yankee Consul of Puerto Plata, Santo Domingo, who gets mixed up in Rikkis, matrimony for revenue only, and a Latin-American revolution.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22. -- The defeat of Tribes Hill, strong first choice in the George Washington Handicap, was a feature of the day's racing. De Reszke, neglected in the betting, won, finishing a neck ahead of Mauser for the prize of $1,455.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Friends of Judge Parker of New York are manifesting interest in his candidacy, and some of them have evidently undertaken to explain the apparent indifference exhibited by the Judge toward the nomination.

Dr. S.P. Hopkins, an old member of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn, but who never had clay target shooting aspirations until about two months ago, gave an unusual performance at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday, and incidentally surprised the shooting experts of the club by his sudden improvement.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The bill introduced by Senator Elsberg at the request of the Law's Delay Commission, relative to the municipal courts in the city of New York, would repeal the New York City charter.

President Mott, of the Bank of Northport, who caused the arrest of Charles F. Broach, ex-cashier of the Equitable National Bank, will appear before the Grand Jury to-day for the purpose of telling how Broach obtained a loan of $3,000 on a certificate of the now defunct bank's stock, alleged to be forged.

The bill to which we have already referred for the retirement of Judges of the Supreme Court and Court of Appeals on half pay at seventy, after sixteen years' service, will come up again to-morrow in the Assembly for reconsideration. We are far from holding that there is only one side to the question involved.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 22. -- In an exhibition fencing contest with foils at the Naval Academy to-day the Midshipmen fencers were easily defeated by the team representing the Turn Verein of New York City. The Turn Verein Club is composed of some of the best fencers in the country, its members having been fencing regularly for the past fifteen years, and they all showed splendid form to-day.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 22. -- Washington's Birthday one year ago saw the lower portions of Hempstead flooded. To-day the same condition of affairs prevailed, only that things are far worse this year than last. For miles in every direction the lowlands are under water and Hempstead Plains is one great lake.

Mrs. Maria T. Kunzmann, forty-two years old, widow of Joseph Kunzmann, who was at one time a law partner of ex-Secretary of War Elihu Root, according to Coroner Scholer, committed suicide in her residence, 896 West End Avenue, yesterday by taking carbolic acid. Financial reverses and chronic melancholia are said to have been the cause of her act.

It was not a pretty picture of the working of woman suffrage in Colorado which we presented from the official testimony in the Shafroth case on Sunday. It sustained in detail the inference that we had made on the first news of Mr. SHAFROTH'S very honorable abandonment of his seat, namely, that women appear to have done in Colorado very much what men did in the way of corruption, violation of the law and cheating.

A.R. Pardington, Chairman of the Racing Board of the American Automobile Association, made a careful inspection of the motor boats in the Sportsmen's Show yesterday, and he intimated that the association was about to take some official action in auto boat matters, particularly as auto boat racing seemed to be attaining great prominence.

Mr. ELIHU ROOT'S rhetoric runs away with his law. He is much too well versed in international and municipal law not to know perfectly well that the discourse which he pronounced in Chicago on Monday would not have been listened to with patience by the Judges of the Supreme Court, nor would he have been so reckless of his professional reputation as to make so unlawyerlike an argument before that tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Justice White of the United States Supreme Court to-day delivered the opinion of that court in the case of W.J. Butterfield vs. Collector Stranahan of New York, involving the constitutionality of the act of Congress regulating the importation of tea. The decision was favorable to the Collector and upheld the law.

E.E. Smathers has entered McChesney, the Western champion, in the Carter Handicap, which is to be run on April 15, the opening day of the Aqueduct meeting. The stake closed Monday at midnight with sixty-two nominations, and the mails for some days to come will bring in additions to the list. There were sixty-five nominations last year, and, judging from the number of entries already received, that figure is to be considerably exceeded this season.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- The Stock Exchange has recovered from the Continental fright, and quantities of stocks thrown on the bands of dealers were fairly absorbed. The settlement is expected to be arranged without difficulty. The failure of the banking firm of Fritz Meyer of Berlin caused a temporary slight relapse. Consols were quietly steady. Home rails were firm.

A rear-end crash occurred at 10:15 o'clock last night on the elevated system of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, at the Van Sicklen station, in Fulton Street, East New York, in which it is believed that twenty persons were injured more or less. Four are known to have been hurt severely.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- It is learned here to-night that Gov. Odell and President Roosevelt have reached an understanding by which they expect to dictate the action of the State Committee Saturday with regard to the fixing of a date for the State Convention.

MENTONE, France, Feb. 23. -- Sir Home Seton Gordon, Bart., became suddenly demented here and behaved in such a manner that he was eventually taken into custody and placed in charge of a doctor. He telegraphed numerous hotels, ordering rooms for 300 imaginary friends, and created a scene at the British Consulate. He sent also a telegram to King Edward and the British Foreign Office complaining of the way he had been treated.

I notice in your issue of the 10th inst. speech by Warner Miller of this State before a Dutchess County society dinner which recently occurred. He states that he is in favor of home rule for New York, but puts the provisor in, whenever they show the capacity to properly exercise that power.

District Attorney Jerome said yesterday that a lengthy confession had bee made to Assistant District Attorney Krotel by Charles F. Broach, ex-cashier of the Equitable National Bank, who is locked up in the Tombs on a charge of forgery, in which Broach tells how he raised the one-share certificate of the bank's stock to ninety shares at the time that Leonard Imboden's note went to protest.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 23. -- Archimandrite Raphael of New York has been raised by the Czar to the rank of Bishop of Brooklyn and Second Vicar of the Aleutian Diocese.

FORT DODGE, Ia., Feb. 23. -- Robert J. Rich was the second son of E.H. Rich, Cashier of the First National Bank of this place. The family, which in point of social position is among the first in Fort Dodge, came here from Richford, N.Y., which town takes its name from that of the family.

From the home in Mamaroneck of Henry Fatton, an importer of ostrich feathers, at 46 East Eighth Street, New York, jewels valued at $15,000 disappeared Monday evening, the evidence pointing to the theory that the house was entered by thieves on the second story. The home of Mrs. Cunningham Hazen, in Pelham Manor, was entered yesterday evening, the thieves carrying away jewelry of considerable value.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23. -- Harry Phillips, Thomas Shields's jockey, signalized his return to the saddle after a two weeks' suspension by a grand ride on Forsight in the third race to-day, beating Ostrich by a length. Both colts are Derby candidates, and both were well backed, the latter being favorite.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 23. -- By the will of Senator Hanna, probated to-day, an estate valued at about $3,000,000 is left to the family.

The annual report of the Lackawanna Railroad for the year ended Dec. 31, 1903, was made public at the company's annual meeting' of stockholders yesterday. It shows that the company had the best year in its history, earning 23 per cent. on its stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- The May option of wheat fell 5 1/4 cents to-day as suddenly as if the bottom had fallen out of the market, and then leaped up and down in spasms that were nerve-racking. Trading was on an enormous scale.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- With a formal reception attended by art critics and amateurs from every section of the country, Boston's Whistler Memorial Exhibition opened tonight under the auspices of the Copley Society. About 150 paintings and 300 lithographs, drawings, and etchings by the dead master, gathered from every important art centre in the world, are shown, among them pictures from the estate of Mr. Whistler, which are now seen for the first time.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The home rule committee will hold its initial meeting to-morrow, the call having been issued this evening by Senator Malby, who is to be Chairman. The other members of the committee are Senators Elsberg, Marshall, and Davis; William Barnes, Jr., Francis Hendricks, and Assemblyman Fish.

Yesterday's stock market verified the opinion of those who on Saturday last claimed that they saw more real selling than had appeared in the market for some time. Yesterday not only was trading more active, but prices declined in a way which seemed very clearly to indicate that the field was held no longer solely by the trader, but that his selling was being reinforced by actual liquidation.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Quiet continues at Peking, says the correspondent of The Times. The Chinese are maintaining order well. They have covered the province with proclamations enjoining the preservation of tranquillity.

Clement A. Griscom resigned yesterday as President of the International Mercantile Marine Company and the Directors elected J. Bruce Ismay, managing Director of the White Star Line, to succeed him. Mr. Griscom was elected Chairman of the board.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the State Controller, in imposing a 1 per cent. tax on the surplus and undivided profits of savings banks under the so-called Odell law of 1901, must assess at the market value of the securities constituting the surplus when the same is quoted on the market below their par value.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 23. -- Foreign Minister Lamsdorff yesterday sent the following circular to Russian representatives abroad:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Senator Hanna's last written words were in the form of a pathetic letter to President Roosevelt, in which he acknowledged, in a way quite characteristic, the President's thoughtfulness in calling at his hotel to inquire about the Senator's condition. The letter was written by the Senator on the afternoon of Friday, Feb. 5, and was the last business of any kind transacted by him.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23. -- The gayety of yesterday continued to-day with many luncheons and dinner parties at the hotels, the club, and Riviera. To-day again, Col. John Jacob Astor lunched a party of young people, and to-night Mr. and Mrs. Nahume Stetson of New York are dining Col. Astor and a few others at the Riviera.

It is not surprising that the business associations of the city are protesting against the action of the Civil Service Commission in practically turning over to the spoilsmen the fifty-five Deputy Tax Commissioners. It is a very bad step. It still requires the approval of the Mayor, who should stop it. If he fail to do so, it should be stopped by the State Commission.

After what President Pulliam of the National League claims to have been sufficient time to hear from President Johnson of the American League, regarding a conference between representatives of the two leagues about non-conflicting dates in New York principally, he issued a call yesterday for a meeting of the National League at the Hotel Victoria, Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street, on Tuesday, at noon.

Police Commissioner McAdoo yesterday signed an order restoring the long coveted three platoon system at midnight on Feb. 29, transferred three Inspectors, eleven Captains, two Detective Sergeants, and two patrolmen, and held a long conference with Mayor McClellan in regard to legislation to increase the force.

The New York City Street Railway Company formerly the Metropolltan, is reported to have sold the block front on the west side of Lenox Avenue, between One Hundred and Sixteenth and One Hundredand Seventeenth Streets, 201.10 by 200, a plot of sixteen lots. Further details of the transaction were not obtainable yesterday at the company's offices.

For a fortnight, practically ever since there has been a surplus of news, it has been as difficult to discover a tendency in the market as to discover a tide in an inland lake. There were those who claimed to discern a tendency toward improvement despite depressing conditions, and there were those who thought they saw signs of decline despite the encouragement apparent to optimists.

Two big Luckenbach barges, the General Knox and the West Point, are adrift somewhere of the Delaware Breakwater with their crews aboard. Helpless barges in a tumultuous sea make life an uncertain quantity for the nine men, so yesterday the ocean-going tug M.E. Luckenbach, one of the most powerful in the harbor, set out from this port to rescue them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- No Information could be obtained from naval officials tonight showing that any unusual orders had been given to Admiral Cotton.

United States General Appraiser Howell sustained a protest yesterday by W. Sloane of New York against the assessment of $1.50 a pound and 15 per cent. ad valorem as silk pile fabrics on certain upholstery fabrics known as silk and metal velours.

It should be gratifying to all mankind that the attempt of the State Department of the United States to limit the conflict between Russia and Japan to those Powers, and to limit it also to the territory in dispute between them, should have been so completely successful The announcement which the department was able to make last Saturday, giving the actual answers of the combatants to the proposal, proves this to have been the case.

It would be interesting to know, if it were possible, what value Senator HOAR attaches to his own opinions. It is only too plain that he cannot get other people to attach much value to them, for the simple reason that he so often destroys one with another, or follows the expression of an opinion by action utterly inconsistent.

The Employers' Association of Chicago, of which the indefatigable Frederic W. Job is Secretary and general executive, publishes an instructive tract Under the title "A Tale of Two Cities" -- which is something of a misnomer in that it is really a tale of one city in two aspects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- John Wesley Gaines of Tennessee got the floor in the House to-day to make a speech on naval improvements at Cavite and Manila, the appropriation bill being before the House. He had a tempestuous time, for he began by saying. "When I was in the Philippines," and the House invariably resents a speech from Gaines that begins with that time-honored formula.

War to the last ditch, says Heinrich Conried, is to be waged next season against the ticket speculators by the Metropolitan Opera Company. The Director announced last night that he had devised a new scheme which he expects will thwart the efforts of the curbstone men. It is too late to put it into effect this season, so Mr. Conried does not want to tell yet exactly what his new scheme is like.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Controller Grout of New York appeared to-day before the Senate Cities Committee in favor of the bill of Senator Dowling, which will prevent any school officers or employes realizing royalties from the sale of school books of which they may be authors or in which they are co-authors or indirectly interested.

-- As might have been expected, the posting by the Corn Exchange Bank of Chicago of a notice to its employes that it would discharge any of them who married on a salary of less than $1,000 a year, except after making a full explanation to the bank officials and obtaining a special dispensation, has caused a lot of excited talk in that sensation-loving city.

More than sixty of the occupants of the block bounded by Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets, held an informal meeting at Delmonico's yesterday afternoon to discuss the recent action of the Trustees of Columbia University in offering for sale the entire block, on which the present tenants have leaseholds ranging from five to fifteen years still to run.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- There is no truth in the rumors of negotiations among the powers concerned respecting the passage of the Russian Black Sea fleet through the Dardanelles, says the Paris correspondent of The Times. The disturbance of the international equilibrium which it might and probably would entail can hardly be a matter of indiffer-

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- A dispatch from Port Arthur, published this morning, denies categorically the reports of a new attack by Japanese torpedo boats, and says they have been repulsed with loss every time they appeared in the roadstead.

The closing sessions in the trial of Sara J.J. McCaffery, Principal of Public School No. 116, on the charges of misconduct and insubordination, were held yesterday afternoon and evening before the Committee on Elementary Schools of the Board of Education. Decision was reserved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Cockran's election to Congress in New York to-day will end an unusual situation. The vacancy made on the Ways and Means Committee by Mr. McClellan's resignation from Congress to become Mayor of New York has never been filled. Such vacancies are usually filled instantly.

We have already given our reasons for believing that resort to The Hague Tribunal, by the suitors whom it was meant to attract, would not be promoted by its decision in the Venezuela case. It may be added that such resort will especially not be encouraged by the extrajudicial remarks, the "obiter dicta" of the Russian member of the tribunal upon the pending war between his country and Japan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- By a vote of 66 to 14 the Senate to-day ratified the Panama Treaty without amendment. This was an unusually large vote, only nine members being absent and not voting. Of these nine six were paired in the affirmative with three in the negative. Had every Senator voted the result would have been yeas, 72, nays, 17.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 24. -- The Rev. T. Priton Rice, a leading Kentucky pastor, to-day announced himself a candidate for Jailer of Tyrone, Wolfe County.

We have more than once expressed the opinion in these columns that States having rivers which have the annual habit of flooding their valleys could do much to minimize this costly evil by a little common-sense engineering in the removal of the obstructions, natural and artificial, that cause freshets at certain seasons of the year.

An unexpected strike of the plumbers in the stations of the subway took place yesterday against Byrne Murphy, who have the contract for plumbing for all the stations, forty in number. The plumbing stage had been reached in twelve of the stations, bringing out about fifty or sixty men and stopping all further progress of work.

Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers, in a decision handed down yesterday overruling a protest by the Perkins Company of New York, decided that the law of Jan. 15, 1903, admitting coal free of duty had no retroactive effect.
There is a note of hearty and hitherto unsuspected good comradeship in the letters that passed between President ROOSEVELT and Mr. HANNA while the Senator lay upon his deathbed.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The Presse, one of the latest newspapers which appears in Paris, says the correspondent there of The Times, states that confirmation has been received at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs from the French Consul at Port Arthur of the Russian naval success reported at St. Petersburg.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Several naval officers connected with the Bureau of Navigation had a lively time last night after going to bed.

The matinee for Miss Marie Tempest at the Waldorf-Astoria will be one of the events on an afternoon which will otherwise be filled in with small luncheons, classes, and bridge. The Thursday Evening Club will meet at Mrs. E.H. Harriman's, and the Whist Club will be entertained at the Waldorf by Mrs. Barrowe.

One of the most famous medical publications in the United States is the "Alkaloidal Clinic," in a recent number of which an entertaining article on coffee by a progressive physician and surgeon is published. In explaining his position in the matter this physician recently said:

A petition asking Secretary Cortelyou of the Department of Commerce and Labor to institute an investigation of the fire insurance situation in the United States was among the more important subjects presented yesterday at the meeting of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation.

The Church Choral Society, which took up its work last Spring after a slumber of several years, carries it on again this season, and is giving two "recitals," as they are termed, with an afternoon and an evening repetition of each one. The first afternoon performance was given yesterday in St. Thomas's Church under the direction of Mr. Richard Henry Warren, conductor of the society.
LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Reuter's Telegram Company has given out an explanation of how the abolition of the censorship in Russia was brought about, as follows:

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 24. -- The will of William C. Whitney was filed in the Surrogate's office here this morning by Harry Payne Whitney, the eldest son, who is named as executor, and Mr. Winthrop of Winthrop Stimson of 32 Liberty Street, Manhattan. The document was executed on Nov. 19, 1902, and is as follows:

Dr. William H. Maxwell was last evening re-elected City School Superintendent by the Board of Education. Of the 40 votes cast he received 36. Two were for Walter B. Gunnison, Principal of Erasmus Hall High School of Brooklyn, the only other candidate in the field. Dr. Maxwell's term will expire March 14, 1910; his salary will be $8,000.

We referred on Monday to the various and probably strong influences that would tend to the preservation of peace in Europe. Since then the situation has changed decidedly for the better. Pressure has been brought on both Bulgaria and Turkey, and both have expressed themselves as determined to work out the Russo-Austrian plan in Macedonia in good faith.
MOSCOW, Feb. 24. -- There is military activity everywhere between Odessa and Moscow. At Vilna the activity is quite feverish.

Handling an automobile for the greater part of a day and then participating in a game of pool, which requires a clear eye and accuracy of stroke, evidently work at cross qurposes, judging from the display of W.A. Tilt in the second game of the pool tournament for the championship of the New York Athletic Club last night.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24. -- Hands Across, whose best races have been run since he passed into Sam Hildreth's hands, suffered decisive defeat in the fourth race, in which he was a strong favorite, to-day.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from St. Petersburg, sent at 11 o'clock last night, says that on Feb. 23 the Japanese attempted to send four steamers filled with explosives among the Russian fleet in Fort Arthur harbor.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Gen. J. Watts de Peyster, to Paterno Brothers, the seven lots at the southwest corner of One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and Morningside Avenue, 104 by 165 by 100 by 191. An eight-story apartment will be erected on the plot, from plans by Schwartz Gross.

The proposition of the National Building Trades Council to label all buildings erected by union labor is novel, but the argument with which it is supported will not bear examination. The statement of the Council respecting it is:

After a gruelling five-set match, Wylie C. Grant yesterday won the indoor tennis championship of the United States for the singles, in the tournament on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. The competition consumed more than three hours of actual play and was very fast from the opening service to the final and deciding stroke.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24.--There is much speculation here about the meaning of that clause of The Hague Tribunal's decision in the Venezuela case which commissions the United States to carry out the award within three months. At the State Department it is said that no interpretation can be given until the text of the decision arrives.

-- Whenever, as this week, there is a wholesale shifting about of the higher police officials, at least a few people find themselves unable to refrain from wondering whether or not this is a good disciplinary device -- if a measure so utterly unlike those to which resort is had in other businesses for similar purposes is the best that could be invented.

Yesterday's Stock Exchange business was almost a replica of Tuesday's, some early strength being followed by later weakness upon continuance of unfavorable foreign news and additions to the list of unsatisfactory domestic influences. The Balkan situation seemed somewhat better, and Japan oversubscribed its war loan.

Does the Republican Party believe that it really needs to add to the number of its titles to public distrust by passing the Gompers bill forbidding the use of the injunction to restrain strikers from committing acts of lawlessness and violence? Will it not be content until it has rifled the Bryan arsenal of all its weapons of assault upon business, property, and the peace of communities?

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24. -- Though there was more or less anxiety in regard to the resumption of business at the Stock Exchange, in temporary quarters in Builders' Exchange, to-day, which has not been open since the great fire here, business was transacted without the appearance of any disturbing factor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 24. -- Gen. Charles Dick was nominated by acclamation for both the unexpired and regular terms for United States Senator, to succeed the late Senator Hanna, at the caucus of the Republican members of the Legislature this evening. The name of Gen. Dick was the only one presented.
PEKING, Feb. 24. -- Admiral Alexieff, the Russian Viceroy of the Far East, has issued the following proclamation to the people of Manchuria:
The special committee appointed by the Board of Education to investigate Controller Grout's charges of extravagance in the conduct of the public schools made its report last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Arrangements for the formal exchange of copies of the Panama treaty could not be completed so that the ceremony could take place to-day. It is expected that this formality will take place to-morrow.

Prof. James H. Stebbins, Jr., Ph.D., a Harvard graduate, who was chemist for the Municipal Gas Company, and is an authority on gas manufacture, talked yesterday on the hearing on Tuesday before the Senate Finance Committee at Albany on Senator Martin's resolution calling for an investigation of the gas situation in New York City.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 25. -- A telegram from Viceroy Alexieff to the Czar says:

In no essential particular did yesterday's stock market differ from that of the previous day. The market opened with the same strength which it had displayed on Tuesday, only to sell off sharply during the afternoon, with the result that in nearly every case prices fell below those of Tuesday.

Under the dictation of the Standard Oil party harmony was restored among the various conflicting interests is the American Ice Company yesterday. A joint Board of Directors to be chosen at the annual meeting March 8 next was agreed upon as representing three out of the four committees that have asked for proxies to vote the stock.

Tammany formally launched its boom for Grover Cleveland as its candidate for the Presidential nomination at a meeting of the General Committee of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District last evening, acting under the direction of Thomas E. Rush, the district leader, who had had a long consultation with Charles F. Murphy first.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Gov. Odell will go to New York to-morrow confident that he will be able to control the action of the State Committee on Saturday and fixed in his determination that the State Convention for the selection of delegates to the National Convention shall be called for a date early in April.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Committee on Ways and Means to-day authorized a favorable report on the Hill bill to provide for the licensing of custom house brokers. Some New York brokers appeared in opposition to the bill, but it was amended to meet their objections before the favorable report was authorized.

CLINTON, Mass., Feb. 24. -- The Clinton Worsted Company, William Rodgers and John Rodgers, Jr., sole owners, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of creditors to Buttrick and George T. Taylor. The schedule of assets and liabilities has not been completed, but the failure is said to be the largest in the history of the town.

A serious proposition has been introduced in the French Parliament to establish a complete system of common schools substantially on the lines of our own. The cost, in the first instance, is estimated at about $13,000,000, and the cost of maintenance at about $1,500,000. That does not seem a very considerable undertaking to any one accustomed to the scale of spending for education in the United States.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The first legislative move against the Shipbuilding Trust will be made in the Senate to-morrow when Senator Brackett will introduce a bill prepared by Frank White, the authority on corporation legislation, to amend Section 6 of the general corporation law.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- The will of James B. Colgate was admitted to probate to-day by Surrogate Silkman. The value of the estate is believed to amount to many millions. Austin Colgate of Orange, N.Y., a nephew, and James C. Colgate, a son of the testator, qualified as executors.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The Home Rule Committee met to-day and appointed a sub-committee consisting of Senator Marshall, Senator Elsberg, and William Barnes, Jr., to make an examination of the New York charter and report just what extension of home rule for that city it would be wise for the Legislature to grant.

Russia was America's friend the same as other neutral powers were our friends in the sense of observing their neutrality. The first of the European powers that showed positive friendship for us during our civil war was Turkey, whose Sultan interdicted the entrance of pirates in the service of the Confederacy in depredation upon the commerce of our country in the ports of the Turkish Empire.

Promising free transfers from its proposed subway to all of the present cross-town street surface railway lines on Manhattan Island, the Metropolitan Traction interests will lay before the Rapid Transit Commission at its meeting this afternoon a tentative plan for a new north and south underground road.

Chief CROKER is entitled to thanks and congratulations for having saved the great gas tanks in West Fifty-ninth Street when the factory opposite them was destroyed by fire on Tuesday. These are structures peculiarly liable to injury from fire, as heat enough to soften or warp the unprotected iron frames in which the bells rise and fall would quickly cripple them and entail great public inconvenience from an interrupted distribution.

PORT ANGELES, Washington, Feb. 24. -- The body of Baron Martin von Schlosser, formerly an officer in the German army and for many years a resident of this city, has been found on the range south of the Hot Springs, near the body of a dead bear. The Baron undoubtedly shot the bear, which killed the nobleman before dying of its wounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- There was a large gathering of representative merchants, manufacturers, and business men from all parts of the country at the hearing given this morning by the House Committee on Judiciary on the pending Anti-Injunction bill. The Chairman of the committee, Judge Jenkins, conducted the consideration of the subject by reading questions propounded by the friends of the bill.

Three hundred men and women, the proprietors of employment agencies of this city, were present last night at a meeting held at the "Tuxedo," at the corner of Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, to protest against what they termed a trust in the form of the Woman's Domestic Guild of America.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- The twentieth annual bench show of the New England Kennel Club closed to-night with a number of keen competitions for special prizes. The feature of the day was the taking of the champion challenge cup offered by the Ladies' Kennel Association of America by Mrs. George S. Thomas of Magnolia, with Wilberforce, an old English sheepdog.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- "Do you mean to say that the Scotch, the Irish, or the English laborers in the shipyards at Glasgow can do 60 per cent. more work with the same tools and in the same time than can be done by American shipyard workers?"

The sale of the Frederick S. Gibbs collection of paintings at Mendelssohn Hall proved much livelier last night than on Wednesday, which was the opening night. The total realized last night was $25,280 as against $15,215 on Wednesday.

Two interesting fly-casting competitions were among the special features yesterday at the Sportsmen's Show in Madison Square Garden. The competitors in the afternoon's event were forced to do their cleverest work, for each contestant was required to send his line under an obstacle thirty feet in front of him, and six feet above the water.

Daniel B. Freedman has resold the plot of about thirteen lots on the west side of Broadway, between Manhattan and One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Streets, which he bought several days ago from the O.B. Potter Trust. The property has frontages of 173 feet on Broadway, 156 feet on Manhattan Street, and 140 feet on One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- Wallace H. Ham, manager of the Boston branch of the American Surety Company of New York, Treasurer of St. Luke's Home for Convalescents, Roxbury, and until recently Treasurer of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in this city, was arrested to-day, charged with the larceny of $104,000 from the American Surety Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- Several months ago Admiral Evans, in passing on a verdict rendered by a court-martial, the members of which had been detailed by him, made criticisms regarding the action of the court that caused a great deal of discussion among naval officers.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- It is reported here to-day that, instead, of Dr. Andrew S. Draper, William H. Maxwell, Superintendent of Schools in New York City, is to be the first Commissioner of Education under the Educational Unification bill, which has just passed the Legislature. It is whispered here that Republican legislators have known for some time that Dr. Draper would not accept the place.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 25. -- Irritation against the United States on account of the supposed unfriendly attitude of that country toward Russia seems to have become daily more pronounced. Since the Vicksburg incident at Che-mul-pho American business men here are alarmed concerning the possible effect upon American trade.

When the stock market opened yesterday with considerable display of strength there were predictions that the day would be a repetition of Tuesday and Wednesday, when, after a strong opening, prices declined sharply. By noon it became evident that the upward movement was to be better sustained than it had been earlier in the week, and this led to considerable short covering by the traders, which helped to keep the market strong until the close.

It is perhaps not surprising that the amazed Korean should construe the American automobile and its tooling chauffeur and strangely clad occupants recently appearing "in his midst" and dashing wildly about the purlieus of his capital as a declaration of war. It is more or less a spectacle of terror even when there is a measured familiarity with its sound and smell and aspect.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 25.--A negro, giving his name as Robert Alexander, and his residence as 158 West Thirtieth Street, Manhattan, confessed to-day, so the police say, to having robbed the residence of J. Fillmore Studwell, at Greenwich, Conn., just across the Bryon River, at an early hour in the morning.

Senator Platt's change of attitude with relation to the date of the Spring State Convention, after he had contended for a late date in April for weeks, dispels the prospect of a fight in the State Committee when it meets to-morrow at 10 A.M. at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. It is now generally agreed that a call will be sent out bringing the delegates together early in April, probably before the 15th.

Complaints to the police of the West Thirtieth Street Station late last evening by occupants of the houses in Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets directly east of Fifth Avenue, led to the discovery that a dozen or more tattered tramps, old and young, have been making their lodging place in a tunnel driven underneath the surface of an empty lot.

The interesting data relative to an auxiliary salt water supply compiled by Mr. FOSTER CROWELL, C.E., for the report of the Merchants' Association on the Water Supply of New York (1890) is very persuasive and almost convincing, but not quite conclusive as to the practicability of the plan.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 25. -- There are suspicions of the motives of Great Britain here, of a character to cause complications in that direction.

The twenty-three-story American Tract Society building, at 150 Nassau Street, caught fire yesterday about 7:30 o'clock, and, although the fire did not amount to much as a fire, smoke and water did $30,000 damage.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 25.--An accident at the Richmond Street Christian Church here to-night resulted in ten children being seriously burned and others painfully injured. Seven of those burned are in the City Hospital, and it is thought that many others may have been hurt.

Whether the bill which has passed the Senate with only nominal opposition allowing the city authorities to erect "temporary" schoolhouses in the public parks of New York, other than Central and Prospect Parks, becomes a law or not, the local administration which avails itself of this privilege would make a political mistake so disastrous that it would serve as an object lesson for a generation.

In my letter, contained in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the 14th inst., I referred to the radiating nature of the trolley railway current, and also its great grounding tendency, which have an important bearing upon the subway traction problem.

If THE TIMES wishes direct and uncontroverted evidence as to the purpose of the Russian fleet which visited the United States during the rebellion it should consult "The Life of Thurlow Weed," Vol. II., Pages 346-7. The language in the first two paragraphs, it should be noticed, is that of Thurlow Weed himself:

The Clothiers' Association of New York held its annual meeting at the Brevoort House last night, and re-elected its old officers and Directors for another year. The officers are Marcus M. Marks, President; Isaiah Josephi, Vice President; Morris Golland, Secretary and Treasurer, and Samuel Fleischman, Actuary.
Three projects for the extension of the rapid transit system in Manhattan and Brooklyn and across the Williamsburg Bridge were brought up before the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday.

The "Viceroy of the Amur" is evidently a fine old Russian gentleman, all of the olden time. There was something really winning in the frankness of the dispatch in which he told the Czar how the Japanese had caught him napping and made "holes" in two of his best ships.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25. -- Advises from Jackson, Miss., indicate that a systematic and determined effort will be made in that State to suppress lynching and to appeal to "God-fearing citizenship to uphold the majesty of the law."

A period in which peace is shouted from the housetops and death-dealing engines are put together in the cellar is disquieting even to such remote and apparently out-of-the-way countries as Morocco. A duel is always quietly in progress concerning Morocco between France and Spain, while England and Italy are fully alive to the situation.

The importance of dealing with the labor situation on broad lines and with great firmness and intelligence is being forced upon the people of Baltimore in a way which invites the prompt creation of a commission with the largest powers the Municipal Government can confer.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- District Attorney Jerome lectured here this evening on "College Men in Politics." President Wilson, in introducing Mr. Jerome, commended him for his recent reform work in New York City. Mr. Jerome said in part:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- Mrs. Thomas Howard, niece of Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt and wife of the manager of Mr. Vanderbilt's large estate at Hyde Park, a few miles north of Poughkeepsie, had a scare Tuesday night when she almost was the victim of highwaymen.

Secretary of the Treasury Shaw came to New York yesterday and spent a good part of the day in conference with bankers in regard to the Panama Canal payments. During the day he saw Hamilton Fish, Assistant Treasurer at New York; James Stillman of the National City Bank, Valentine P. Snyder of the National Bank of Commerce, and Isaac N. Seligman, whose firm is fiscal agent for the United States and for the Navy Department.

Mme. Adelina Patti, who is now making her "last farewell singing tour" in America, has made about $200,000 since she landed here last Fall. Her manager, Robert Grau, is about even now. He has awaked to the discovery that he is dealing with a woman whose business qualities are as fully developed as her vocal powers.

Reports current and generally believed in sporting circles yesterday were that Harry Payne Whitney had decided to sell at auction, if not a majority, a great number of the horses composing the racing stable of his father, the late William C. Whitney. They evoked the following card last evening from Mr. Regan, who was private secretary to the elder Whitney:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- It is a wise man who avoids Latin if he happens not to be cock-sure of his Latin. The other day Senator Mitchell of Oregon was showing a party of friends from his State around the Capitol. They wanted to go down into the bowels of the huge building and explore the cavernous realms of the terrace and the crypt.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25. -- First and second choices divided the honors of to-day's racing. Sadduccee, Maritana, and Arachue were beaten favorites. In the fifth race Bummer II, collided with the fence and Jockey J. Hennessy's left foot was broken. A. Simmons has sold Clonmel to W. Walker for $500. S.C. Hildreth has sold the colt Henry McDaniel to J. Baker on private terms.

Heinrich Conried, importer of voices, was a happy man last night. He strode through the corridor of the Metropolitan Opera House all smiles and affability, listening to the strains of "Parsifal" as it was being performed for the eleventh time. The director had in his hand a little slip of paper, which he twirled in his fingers and looked at every few minutes as if the contents pleased him mightily.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25. -- No official statement of the aggregate losses paid by insurance companies on property destroyed in the great fire, or of losses claimed will be issued. By a vote of 41 to 31 the General Loss Committee of the insurance companies so decided to-day, but no reason is assigned for the action.
ROME, Feb. 25. -- The Pope to-day received in private audience the Most Rev. John M. Farley, Archbishop of New York.

Walter A. Dawson, Treasurer of the New York Housesmiths' Union, was reported yesterday as missing from his home, 678 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, since Tuesday last, and yesterday Charles Maitland Beattie, counsel for the union, requested the police to send out a general alarm for him. Dawson is fifty-three years old, and has been married twice.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- Fifty-one men from the freshman class responded to the call for baseball candidates this afternoon. The number of men who appeared exceeds that of last year by five. The men were given their first practice in the cage at the University Field House. They were divided into two squads, and given light work, consisting chiefly of fielding, under the direction of Capt. C.G. Stevens and Head Coach Hildebrand.

Recorder Goff yesterday decided that Charles W. Morse, the financier, under the subpoena first served on him, need not answer the questions put to him by the Grand Jury concerning his matrimonial tangle, holding that inasmuch as Charles F. Dodge already has been indicted, the Grand Jury is not now engaged in investigating a crime so far as the court knows.

The read to possible success is comparatively easy. If the South and the reorganizers at the North would join hands they might control the next Democratic Convention, defy Bryan, and defeat Roosevelt. Were there any encouragement that the South could be persuaded to do its share, the reorganizers at the North might put their shoulders to the wheel. -- Waterbury (Conn.) American. (Ind.)

Yesterday was a busy one for Lent. With Mrs. Vanderbilt's dinner, the meeting of the Thursday Evening Club at Mr. and Mrs. E.H. Harriman's, and of Miss Leary's Believue sewing class, besides smaller affairs, there was a great deal to do. Friday is not a brilliant day at any time, and the events for to-day are few and minor affairs.

-- It is reassuring to note that The Poughkeepsie Eagle, neither wearied nor discouraged after its vehement efforts to determine the fate of the State canals, has now turned the rays of its powerful mind on the transportation problems of this city -- problems that we and our nearer neighbors have assailed for many a year without arriving at solutions anything like as satisfactory as they have been numerous.

PORT ARTHUR, Feb. 25. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning the Japanese made a desperate attempt to block the entrance of the inner harbor and dock. With this object four merchant steamers, accompanied by torpedo vessels, were sent from two sides toward the entrance of the channel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Committee on Medical Legislation of the American Medical Association has asked the President to appoint on the Panama Canal Commission a representative of the medical profession, and recommending Col. William C. Gorgas, a surgeon in the army, for the place.

President ORR of the Rapid Transit Commission said some time ago that the commission would welcome competition in the bidding for the contemplated extensions of the subway system. The soundness of this view will be borne in upon the mind of every patron of the city's transportation lines by the conditions of the plans and offers submitted to the commission yesterday by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

SANTO DOMINGO, Feb. 22. -- Government forces attacked San Pedro de Macoris last Saturday. They went in in small boats with the intention of landing, but were received with a fusillade from the insurgents which resulted in many being killed or wounded. The gunboat Presidente then bombarded the town and inflicted much damage.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that the Russian Government has recently been very active in arresting persons prominent in the Liberal movement.
Will you kindly give space to a few remarks in regard to a communication in this morning's issue, headed "Threaten to Whip Teachers"?

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Before Gov. Odell left here for New York to-day a definite legislative plan was arranged. The Legislature will not adjourn before the holding of the State Convention, and it is doubtful whether the members of the Legislature will be able to get away from Albany before the last week of April.

The Hon JOHN H. CLARKE of Cleveland, who was named by the Democrats of the Ohio Legislature as their candidate for the United States Senate against Senator HANNA last month, tells the New York correspondent of The Cleveland Plain Dealer that the Democrats of his State are waiting for some sign from New York.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 25. -- Against the earnest protest of Gov. Pennypacker, the Pennsylvania Commission to the St. Louis Exposition, by a vote of 16 to 3, to-day decided to request the municipal authorities of Philadelphia to adopt such measures as may be necessary to insure the exhibition of the liberty bell in the Pennsylvania State Building during the exposition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Heavy purchases of wheat to-day on the probability of the Russo-Japanese war being of long duration sent the price of wheat for May delivery up to $1.09 a bushel. Compared with last night's close this figure showed a gain of 2 1/2c, and is a new high-record mark for that delivery.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The House Committee on Judiciary resumed its hearings this morning on the Anti-Injunction bill.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- The management of the Cornell crews has received word that it will be impossible for Georgetown to enter the Memorial Day second 'Varsity regatta arranged to be rowed on Cayuga Lake. Syracuse has not yet officially accepted the invitation, but it is understood that she will enter a crew.

Augustus C. Buell, in his new historical work, "William Penn as the Founder of Two Commonwealths," which is published this week, gives up much space to Penn's own account of the Colony of Pennsylvania and its Indians, which, Mr. Buell says, "is the only one of his historical writings that may be described as wholly free from a species of cant which his earlier theological career seems to have made second nature with him."

Dr. Lewis O. Brastow, in his new volume of biographical and critical essays on "Representative Modern Preachers," which the Macmillan Company is publishing, deals with Friedrich Daniel Ernst Schleiermacher, Frederick William Robertson, Henry Ward Beecher, Horace Bushnell, Phillips Brooks, John Henry Newman, James Bowling Mozley, Thomas Guthrie, and Charles Haddon Spurgeon.

MR. PETER ROBERTS presents in his volume, "Anthracite Communities," a long and extended history of the anthracite miners of Pennsylvania. The study includes the social, educational, and moral life of these workmen, and the data obtained are of exceptional interest.

Owing to the many strong points in favor of each of the two new rapid transit subway propositions now before the Rapid Transit Commission, the one presented by the Belmont syndicate and the other by the Metropolitan interests, it developed yesterday that the Commissioners may lay out a compromise route with the idea of having both the Belmont and the Metropolitan interests compete strongly for the contract to build and operate it.

The loquacious "International Spy," the cabalistic "A.V." of Pearson's Magazine, tells in the March number all about the assassination of Queen _Draga of Servia. Of course, he was there, though rather as a friend and admirer of the lady than in his official capacity. He could not save her, but did manage to save King Alexander, who is still alive and in hiding.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 26. -- A dispatch received here from Port Arthur, dated to-day, says:
Paul D. Mills of Philadelphia, Guardsman and member of many clubs, was elected a member of the Stock Exchange about a week ago. Yesterday he was "initiated."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A sentence in a London dispatch published in the morning papers of Tuesday last, giving a synopsis of the decision of The Hague Tribunal in the Venezuela case, caused great surprise here, and has led to considerable comment relative to the supposed position in which the United States is placed regarding responsibility for carrying out the decision of the tribunal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Panama Canal treaty was completed to-day by the exchange of ratifications and the issuance of a proclamation by the President making public the convention "to the end that the same and every article and clause thereof may be observed and fulfilled in good faith."

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- For the second time, to-day, Judge Jesse Holdom fined Franklin Union of Press Feeders $1,000 for a violation of an injunction of the court. The injunction was obtained by the Chicago Typothetae, which charged the Franklin Union with interference with non-union employes.

MR. WILLIAM ARCHER'S "Real Conversations" have been collected in book form and published in London. Undoubtedly we shall have the book here in due season. The "conversations" are after the fashion of newspaper "interviews," with Mr. Archer as the interviewer and a person of eminence in some particular field of thought or activity as his victim.

Alberto Santos-Dumont, the Brazilian aeronaut, has written all about his vessels, and the volume will be brought out in March by the Century Company under the title, "My Airships." M. Santos-Dumont writes scientifically about his many daring ascents into the clouds and his descents to earth.
READING the amusing and instructive lettets in your columns regarding "Correct English" tempts me to add my mite. It is an inexhaustible subject and one on which too much cannot be said:

The rumor that the Japanese are making or preparing a land attack upon Vladivostok comes in a very questionable shape. It is, moreover, intrinsically very questionable. It will be quite safe to arrest it on suspicion until something more is known.

WHAT we knew about Korea, in a geographical sense, say, three months ago, was of a schoolboy character. To-day accurate information is desirable, and Mr. Angus Hamilton's book about "Korea" helps us to acquire it. A volume of this special character must necessarily deal much with political matters, past and present, and the various interests of Japan, Russia, France, and England must have their places in it.

The skein of the plot of this novel of Dr. Barry's is somewhat tangled. With the attempt to reconcile Red Republicanism and the love of woman -- woman who is here said to be the very Spirit of Aristocracy -- is allied the curious condition of a lover who woos as a sort of re-embodiment of a husband dead and still adored.

Thus saith John Henry, and in the face of those hundreds of thousands of copies which were sold, criticism quails. In point of fact, however, one does not want to criticise. John Henry is superior to it; he and Peaches and Uncle Peter and Aunt Martha and Bunch Jefferson and all the rest of the "push" are too good-natured to deserve anything but praise.

A defective fire-alarm box, at Ninth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, gave a blaze which started in the five-story brick building which occupied the entire east side of the block on Washington Street, between Thirteenth and Fourteenth Streets, such a big start last night that the structure was destroyed and a loss estimated at $100,000 was entailed.

The two-year-old stakes at Aqueduct have all been filled in a manner which is extremely gratifying to Secretary Rehberger. The Rose Stake, for fillies, closed with 78 nominations as against 50 last year; the Canarsie with 79, as against 57 last year; the Ozone with 86, as against 62; the Woodhaven with 78, as against 58.

John Lane will publish next week in his Crown Library a volume in which is given a picture of the Reign of Terror in the City of Lyons. France. This is the "Memoirs of Mademoiselle des Echerolles." It is translated by Miss Marie Balfour and contains an introduction by George Fortescue. The volume was first published in 1843 under the title "Quelques Annees de Marie," and later as "Une Famille Noble sous la Terreur."

Dodd, Mead Co. will publish next Saturday the "Memoirs of Anna Maria Wilhelmina Pickering," edited by her son, Spencer Pickering. In this volume are lively anecdotes about royalty and nobility, including such personages as Queen Victoria, the Duke of Wellington, and others. Mrs. Pickering, who died two years ago, at the age of seventy-seven, was the daughter of John Spencer Stanhope, a member of a well-known Nottinghamshire family.
TOKIO, Feb. 25. -- The steamship Korea has arrived at Yokohama with a large quantity of corned beef which was intended for Port Arthur.

" The Laws of the State of New York Relating to Banks, Banking, Trust Companies, Loan, Mortgage, and Safe Deposit Corporations," by Willis S. Paine, has reached its fifth edition, (Rochester. N.Y., Lawyers' Co-operative Publishing Company.) The book was compiled by order of the Legislature in 1885.

AMONG the reprints of half-forgotten novels that are now in process of publication is "Caleb Williams." Perhaps it could be more accurately described as a wholly forgotten book. Who of the present generation has read it?

Of course, the Rochester fire is by no means such a calamity as that which has just devastated Baltimore, either positively or comparatively. Happily it has already been got under control, and it seems that we know the extent of it. It is a fire in the "shopping district." But in Rochester we may say that everything is duplicated.

Frank, or, as he was better known, "Biff" Ellison, who was sentenced to Sing Sing in 1893 for an assault on William H. Henriques, a Wall Street operator, and who underwent imprisonment until he was pardoned six years later, died yesterday from pneumonia at his home, 130 West Thirty-fourth Street.

SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 26. -- Fire to-day destroyed the business centre of the town of Nicholson, about twenty miles west of here. Seventeen frame buildings were burned, causing a loss estimated at $40,000. An overheated stove was the cause of the fire.

With Manhattan Avenue as a stage setting to represent Korea, an imitation of the war between Japan and Russia was furnished yesterday afternoon. The "Morningside Gang," composed of the youthful scions of well-to-do families in that locality, furnished the soldiers of the Czar. The "Manhattan Gang," recruited by warriors equally juvenile, fought under the banners of the Mikado.
I have been pained to discern a note of acrimony in the debate on we-all and you-all in THE SATURDAY REVIEW columns. The whole discussion has been of absorbing interest to me.

If District Attorney JEROME'S views of the steps of reform in local, State, and National politics continue expanding, they will need to be writ large, after the manner described in the favorite peroration of WENDELL PHILLIPS, who usually wanted, when celebrating the memory of some hero of his approval, to dip his pen in the sunset and inscribe upon the western sky whatever he deemed it fitting to say.
JUDGE WILLIAM O'CONNOR MORRIS of the Irish Country Bench has undertaken to write a volume on "Wellington" for the Heroes of the Nations Series, published in this country by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The Associated Press is in a position to announce that there will be a dissolution of Parliament within six weeks and that if, as is expected, the Liberals are returned to power King Edward will summon Earl Spencer (Liberal leader in the House of Lords) to form a Cabinet.

Having twenty-eight out of the thirty-seven members at his back, Gov. Odell will to-day attend the meeting of the Republican State Committee with a feeling of absolute confidence in his ability to dominate the committee's action. So certain was the Governor last night that nothing could occur which would upset the programme he has laid out that he did not hesitate to forecast the committee's action with perfect assurance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- After a spirited fight on the armor plate question, which was won by the advocates of the so-called trust, the House to-day passed the Naval Appropriation bill. It was a battle of corporations, in which the Democrats unitedly lined up under the banner of the Midvale Company, while the Republicans stood by what is called the Armor Plate Trust -- the Carnegie and Bethlehem Companies.

Who brought the first sporting dog to the New World? It is wise to gain your information wherever you can, and so Mr. Joseph A. Graham acknowledges his indebtedness to "amateurs, professionals, scientists, market hunters, dog thieves, financiers, jurists, loafers, and clubmen." You who are of the older regime, what do you know about the Laverack setter?
According to Chicago dispatches, it is expected that the independent companies will follow the lead of the National Biscuit Company in raising prices.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- The most disastrous fire in the history of Rochester raged from 5 o'clock this morning until afternoon. Before the Fire Department, assisted by reinforcements from Syracuse and Buffalo, had checked the flames they had swept the retail clothing and dry goods district for a space of three blocks and had inflicted a loss which is now estimated by insurance experts at from $4,000,000 to $5,000,000.

Supreme Court Justice Leventritt yesterday refused to confirm the sale at public auction in Ithaca, N.Y., last September of the five salt plants owned by the National Salt Company to the International Salt Company, and in so doing the Justice severely criticised the method by which the sale was conducted, saying:

The school building for the Society for Ethical Culture at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Sixty-third Street is finished, and the scholars have taken possession of most of the classrooms. In the basement, which is a roomy structure two stories deep, with high ceilings and abundant light, the gymnasium is complete in all its parts; only the Summer garden on the roof awaits the Spring for its last touches.

An oculist of our acquaintance recently raised the question of the motive of the modern practice in placing the numbers of the pages, especially in books with some special pretensions to elegance, at the bottom and near the centre instead, as formerly, at the upper and outer corner, and he expressed the opinion that it was not only an annoyance to some readers but a positive source of injury to the eyesight.

A highly sensational drawing-room farce is Mrs. Burton Harrison's story of "Sylvia's Husband." Here we have the familiar, beautiful wife of a rich though jealous old husband, the inevitable man friend, although when we meet the characters all assembled at a house party at the Irish castle of the rich old husband, Sir Hugh Sargent has already grown weary of Natalie.

In addition to Miss Johnston's "Sir Mortimer," now scheduled for March 17. Messrs. Harper Brothers announce that they will issue during the coming month three other new books. One of these is "Breaking Into Society," a new collection of "fables" in the unbridled vernacular by George Ade.

As usual with most suburban towns and villages, we have in our town a public library, tolerably well stocked with books, fairly well patronized. Works of fiction form the larger percentage of volumes both on the shelves and from month to month acquired by purchase as the funds allow. Newspaper criticism presumably determines whether or not a recent book is of sufficient value or interest to be admitted to the library.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- M. de Lanessan, the ex-Minister of Marine, in an article in to-day's Siecle, refers to the idea of the Russian General Cattianoff that France should lend Russia ships-of-war, say four armorclads and two submarines, for which Russia would pay.

In the case of appointees of the very high personal and professional standing of Admiral JOHN G. WALKER, Gen. GEORGE W. DAVIS, retired; Prof. WILLIAM H. BURR of Columbia University, and Mr. WILLIAM BARCLAY PARSONS, the engineer of the Rapid Transit Commission, this is perfectly true, as anybody can see.

William Michael Rossetti has brought together all of his sister's poetry, nearly a thousand pieces In all. The volume is being published by the Macmillan Company with the title, "The Poetical Works of Christina Georgina Rossetti." Mr. Rossetti has provided copious notes and an adequate memoir.

The annual report of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the year ended Dec. 31, 1903, was made public yesterday. The net earnings show a decrease of $237,818 on the main line to Pittsburg, of $696,119 on the New York Division, an increase of $741,998 on the Erie Division, and an increase of $433,043 on the Buffalo Division, making for all the lines directly operated an increase of $184,000.

Prof. Van Cleve's interesting comment on Lowell's poem illustrates the dangers attending literary criticism based on internal evidence only. He also overlooks the striking internal evidence afforded by the "little shoe in the corner" of the last verse. Scudder tells us that "after Blanche was buried her father took her tiny shoes, the only ones she had ever worn, and hung them in his chamber. There they stayed till his own death."

The significant feature of yesterday's stock market was that all the active stocks declined, while many of the inactive ones advanced, some of them very sharply. The efforts made to support the list by marking up stocks that could be bulled on a few hundred shares had no beneficial effect on the stocks that supplied the bulk of the day's business.

Each of the two large volumes of the autobiography of Herbert Spencer, which D. Appleton Co. positively announce for publication April 1, will contain 650 pages. An American friend of the late philosopher, who has read the work in proof, says:

SEVERAL articles have been published in your paper with reference to the literary style of the late Herbert Spencer. Those who have read his works know that, many years ago, while his own style was formative, he established for himself a theory of the proper method of literary expression. Presumably he tried to adopt it in his writings.

DAPPLETON CO. have received the first part of the manuscript of the second volume of the memoirs of Madame Adam (Juliette Lamber), which will be entitled "My Literary Life." It will be published in June and will be uniform with Vol. I., dealing with "The Romance of My Childhood and Youth."

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Women forming a barrier between a crowd of infuriated men and a swiftly moving freight train alone saved Sedato Dejago, an Italian, from death by a novel form of lynching at the Erie station here to-night.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The Brazilian aeronaut Santos-Dumont's story of his life and his experiments with airships, announced for publication in New York, will appear, simultaneously with its American publication, in Paris and London.

Theodore Roosevelt is essentially a representative American who can be admired by every true-born or naturalized citizen. He has a strong personality, continuity of purpose, a mind well stored and a happy knack of communicating it.
Every severe Winter impresses us with the fact that the cold brings much suffering to all classes of people living in the many suburban places about Greater New York.

Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette" has suffered a worse fate than "Faust" in having to wait till the fourteenth week of the season before it was brought before the subscribers of the Opera House, and its fate as to the kind of performance given it was only little better. It was revived last evening for the first time this Winter before an audience not much larger than would be accounted for by the subscription.

To-morrow, as every day, the readers of THE TIMES can rely on getting the earliest and fullest news that can be relied on from all parts of the world, and especially the news of the war through the peerless service of The London Times, supplementing the very complete and intelligent service of The Associated Pres, now organized on a scale never before attempted.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- This has been a day of social activity, dinners, and teas being numerous.

Speaking of Lafcadio Hearn and his mysterious disappearance reminds me how little one hears of his books nowadays. And yet, are there many who have better divined the true character, both mental and moral, of the Japanese people?

" Proceedings" of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the American Bankers' Association, held at San Francisco, Cal., Oct. 21, 22, and 23, 1903, with the constitution and by laws and appendices and also lists of officers and members of the association is published by the Secretary, James R. Branch.

THE NEW YORK TIMES was made part of the course of study yesterday in the Second Grammar Grade of Public School No. 73, Rockaway Avenue and McDougal Street, Brooklyn, of which Miss Minard is the teacher and Warren H. Hamilton the Principal. For nearly an hour forty pupils, to each of whom a copy of THE TIMES had been furnished, discussed the latest developments of the Russo-Japanese war and the articles on the editorial page.

Yesterday morning Amalgamated Copper and Brooklyn Rapid Transit were both strong, and there was not an office boy in the Street who did not know that it was time to sell the list. Nor was the familiar sign misleading. In the afternoon came the favorable decision in the Amalgamated case, permitting the Boston and Montana dividend to be distributed.

A posthumous volume by Sir Leslie Stephen is published to-day by G.P. Putnam's Sons. It is the last series of the Ford lectures delivered by him at Oxford, and treats of "English Literature and Society in the Eighteenth Century." The first address gives a history of the formative influences of society and literature in England leading up to the eighteenth century writers and their works.

Several hundred members of the various theatrical companies in the city watched an amusing canoe tilting race yesterday at the Sportsmen's Show in Madison Square Garden. The contestants in one canoe represented the "Babes in Toyland" company, while the other boat bore the name of the "Mother Goose" company.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The last ice yacht race of the season for the Citizens' Cup was sailed this afternoon and was won by Charles P. Irwin's Georgie, which covered the fifteen-mile course in 44:49. Charles Burd's Torment was second in 48:01, Newton Doremus's Atalanta was third in 48:12, and Henry Grant's Tyro was fourth in 30:03.
Joseph R. Stein has sold to Jacob Spiro Son, for $85,000, the seven-story business building 133 Mercer Street.

Both William J. Bryan and ex-Senator David B. Hill left the city yesterday for their respective homes. Despite the fact that they both stopped at the Hoffman House, and that close mutual friends did their best to bring about a meeting between them, neither Mr. Bryan nor Mr. Hill had a glimpse of each other.
In the preface to his book on "A Modern School," which the Macmillan Company publish, Prof. Paul H. Hanus of Harvard University gives an idea of the scope of the volume. He writes:

Following a conference yesterday between Vice President Bryan and General Manager Hedley of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and Police Commissioner McAdoo the Commissioner announced that the company had agreed to place special policemen on all of the elevated stations during the rush hours of each day.

Columbia defeated Yale last night in their annual fencing tournament in Earl Hall at Columbia. Columbia had no great difficulty in winning by a score of 6 to 3, although for a while it looked as if the Eli foilsmen might have a chance to win. Columbia began by winning three straight victories, and then the score fluctuated until it stood 4 to 3 for Columbia.

FROM Dr. Alfred Russel Wallace's theory, set forth in his book, "Man's Place in the Universe," that our system is the centre of the universe and our comparatively puny earth the only inhabited planet, Mr. W.D. Howells, in the Easy Chair of this month's Harper's, derives consolation and inspiration for a world but lately afflicted by a sense of its own littleness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Without waiting for any suggestion from St. Petersburg, though that has since come, the Navy Department cabled to Commander Marshall of the Vicksburg at Che-mul-pho, requesting an explanation of the facts connected with the reported refusal on his part to take aboard his ship sailors from the Russian warships sunk by the Japanese.

We hear very much about New Zealand as a successful colony, and in the extended volume, "The Story of New Zealand," the political, industrial, and social development of the Island Commonwealth is described at length. What has been done in New Zealand is expressed with singular force, when a print (Page 654) is looked at.

The recent publication in THE TIMES and other newspapers of the letters and articles relating to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is sure to have good results. They show that the society is not equal to the work before it and that a large number of people are earnestly faithful in their devotion to the cause. Out of these conditions the growth of some improvement is inevitable.

Although not a "problem novel," Anita Vivanti Chartres's "Winning Him Back" has clearly a purpose, which is to amuse. The characters are Grace; Tom, her husband; Fifine, a girl friend; R.B. Wilkins, and the Brat.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- A loss of over 2 cents a bushel in wheat prices caused wild excitement on the Board of Trade to-day. Wheat for May delivery, which closed last night at $1.07 1/2 a bushel, sold to-day at $1.05, and the July option was down 2 1/8 cents, selling at 96 cents. Lower prices at Liverpool were the principal cause of the sharp decline.

A host of defenders will rush gallantly to the rescue of Ellen E. Kenyon Warner, whose use of the phrase, "the children 'got' no primary teaching in grammar," is criticised adversely, in your issue of Feb. 20, by a correspondent from Jackson, Miss. It would be interesting to know wherein this instance offends either as a misuse or an inelegance.

" Taler de Engelsk?" asks the tourist in Norway and Denmark, and almost invariably he gets "Ja" for an answer; in Sweden almost the same phrase is used, and just as successfully. This is especially true of the steamboats and the principal resorts of travelers; just English won't do for a walking trip or for the hunter in the remoter districts.

SEVENTEENTH century Boston is to be the scene of a novel by a new author, Miss Maud Clark Gay, and it is to be published by Messrs. Lee Shepard. The hero is Gov. Bellingham's foster son, Kenneth Brooks; the heroine, one Lady Virginia, wife of one of the Commissioners sent by Charles II. to overawe his unruly colony of Massachusetts Bay.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Henry L. Schwartz of Baker Schwartz, attorneys, was shot and killed in his private office in the Marine Bank building to-day by H.A. Knowles of the dry goods firm of Knowles Gardner. Knowles, after holding the police at bay for a few moments, turned the revolver on himself and blew his brains out.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26.--Ex-Jockey "Tommy" Griffen worked a clever trick on the ring to-day and made what he himself styled the coup of his turf career. Griffen had the filly Sweet Pepper in the second race for maiden two-year-old fillies.

" Harvard," in your REVIEW of Feb. 20, makes some apt and correct criticisms in regard to the "correct English" of some of your contributors. Is not "Harvard" himself at fault in two or three instances? The last two issues of THE REVIEW he characterizes as "the two last issues." Is he not wrong? Can there be two "last" issues?

TOKIO, Feb. 26. -- Vice Admiral Togo's attempt to bottle up the Russian fleet at Port Arthur by sinking a fleet of stone-laden merchant steamers in the mouth of the harbor evidently failed, though the venture caused no loss of life and the vessels lost were not of great value.

The mystery which at present envelops both the civil and criminal proceedings in the Morse-Dodge matrimonial tangle probably will be cleared next week, when the lawyers in the case will explain in detail everything they know about the matter. The District Attorney in the meantime will continue his investigation with a view to indicting others than Charles F. Dodge, believing that a conspiracy existed.
It must be a stolid heart indeed that did not thrill with admiration and sympathy at the story of the life and death of MARK KELLY, Engineer of Engine Company No. 16, who died on Thursday.
