The late Sir Leslie Stephen was a literary man of a type commoner to Great Britain than in this country, commoner perhaps in Great Britain than anywhere else, excepting possibly in Germany. He had never written anything in particular, he was not connected with any particular, "movement," there was no apparent reason why his life should make any stir, or his death any visible void.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The Japanese Legation has received a cablegram from Tokio under to-day's date giving an account of the ineffectual attempt made by the Japanese to blockade the mouth of the harbor at Port Arthur, and also a brief account of the attack by the Japanese on Port Arthur yesterday morning.

HISTORIANS of art have more than once begged the question in failing to designate the exact position of Donato di Betto Bardi, commonly known as Donatello, by complaining that this sculptor composed no treatise on his art, wrote no memoir, and was evidently careless in his business afairs.

" The human race is ill," says Mrs. John B. Henderson. "The human race is anaemic; the world which is a paradise, but by man converted into a hospital, is seen and judged through the eyes of the invalid." The ideal sound mind in a sound body guided by sound moral principles is a thing almost non-existent.
An interesting question of customs law is involved in a case now pending before General Appraiser Sharretts. The principle involved applies equally to all classes of goods.

One of the "principles" to which Mr. BRYAN was wont to attach the most importance was the ileged connection between the price of wheat and the price of silver, and this taking assertion induced a great many simple-minded agriculturists to think that if the price of silver could be forced up by free coinage the price of wheat and other farm products would follow.

Definite plans will be made within a few days by the Automobile Club of America toward securing its Summer clubhouse. The committee in charge of the matter is about to send out circulars to the members asking for an expression of opinion regarding the locality favored for the Summer headquarters.
PARIS, Feb. 26. -- The Foreign Office announced this afternoon that a treaty of arbitration between France and Spain had been signed to-day.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The Times's military correspondent says:
In your issue of Feb. 15 you have an article stating the opposition to the recommendations of the Commission on the Law's Delay with regard to Trial Commissioners in New York and Kings Counties.

To show the modern method of mounting animals, the authorities of the American Museum of Natural History have just put on exhibition a most remarkable series, the first member of which is but a lifeless pile of skin and bones, and the last a finished reindeer, so lifelike that the visitor fears every minute it will leap off the table and make for the woods of the Bronx.

BRIDGE and music, with a little sewing and some literature and lecturing and some churchgoing -- this is the history of the week. One must dine in Lent, as at any other time, and it is much more agreeable to be in company than alone -- hence the number of dinners, particularly on Thursdays and Mondays and Tuesdays when maigre is not necessary. The Florida season is in full

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Plans are already being made for rebuilding the district devastated by fire yesterday. The Sibley, Lindsay Curr Company will hurry the construction of a new building which it had planned. The Rochester Dry Goods Company announces that a new eight-story building will be erected on the site which it formerly occupied.

Two National indoor interscholastic records, smashed to bits, are marked to the credit of M. Sheppard, a Philadelphia schoolboy, as the result of the fourth annual interscholastic games of the Columbia University Track Athletic Association in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon.
PARIS, Feb. 27. -- In explaining the Japanese-Korean treaty M. Montono, the Japanese Minister to France, said to-day:

Safe burglars yesterday morning robbed the cafe and wholesale liquor store of L.C. Faccini, at 1,578 Broadway and 710 Seventh Avenue, the store running through from one street to the other, above Forty-seventh Street. The burglars obtained $534 in currency and rare coins valued at $50.

THE first week in March usually brings the dates for hunting at Meadow Brook and other near-by clubs, but this year everything will be late, owing to the severe Winter and to the present condition of the country, which in many places is a vast swamp. The Hempstead colony proper are at Aiken, where the good hunting and golf have been among the principal recreations at the Southern resort and its two clubs.

The Norfolk and Southern Railway's $225,000 additional first mortgage 5 per cent. gold bonds, listed on the Stock Exchange last Wednesday, were issued for the purpose of general betterments and for the construction of a new line from Mackay's Ferry to Plymouth, Va. The mortgage under which the bonds are put out allows the issuance of $10,000 bonds per each mile of track constructed.

"Losses on fruits and vegetables due to long-continued cold weather will run into millions," said a leading produce commission merchant yesterday. "Every one in the business has suffered. The grower, the shipper, the commission merchant, the wholesaler, and the retailer.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 27. -- Judge H.C. Turley, Postmaster of Natchez under the McKinley Administration and a warm personal friend of the late Senator Hanna, to-day gave out for publication the copy of a letter addressed to Acting Chairman Payne, in which he tenders his resignation as Republican National Committeeman for Mississippi.

The drama opens during the last year of Ivan's life. A slave to his passions, consumed by remorse, humiliated by Batoury's victories, but in no wise corrected by his misfortunes, he is ready on the first favorable change of events to return with redoubled ardor to his former evil existence.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 27. -- After having fasted, the Czar this morning drove to the Anitchkoff Palace to partake of the sacrament. He was accompanied by the Czarina and his daughter Olga, who were dressed in white in honor of the solemn occasion. His Majesty was clad in full uniform.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The opinion expressed by members of the House of Representatives in the debate on the Naval Appropriation bill yesterday that the Midvale Steel Company would not be able to carry out its contract with the Government for 6,000 tons of armor plate, which it took at $398 a ton, is not shared by the officials of the Navy Department.
Appended is a first selection of games played in the recent international sectangular chess tournament at Monte Carlo:

Violent fluctuations in the price of pig iron have been such a marked feature of industrial conditions in this country, ever since the United States became a large producer of iron, that special interest attaches to the efforts that have been made to establish here a system of pig iron warrants similar to that which for more than half a century has been in use in Great Britain.

In your issue of to-day I see dispatch from a correspondent in Portland, Oregon, containing the following remark said to have been made by Dr. Woods Hutchinson, Secretary of the State Board of Health, in an address before the Oregon State Conference of Charities and Correction: "Alcohol," he said, "is a food or harmless luxury for the strong, the vigorous, or the self-reliant, and a deadly poison to the undesirable elements of society."

It is plain enough to any one who reads the Republican press just now that if there is anything that could please it better than the nomination of Bryan in 1896 and 1900 it is the nomination of Hearst by Bryan in 1904. -- Louisville (Ky.) Courier-Journal, (Dem.)

Richard Strauss, the man of the hour in the musical world, who has come to this country in the twofold capacity of orchestral conductor and the prophet of a new evangel in art, made his first appearance last evening in both. He co-operated with Mr. Hermann Hans Weizler in conducting a concert devoted entirely to his own compositions.

MUCH has been heard in recent years of the "American invasion" of Europe, but little has been told of the methods by which the campaigns were conducted. How then do our great manufacturers promote their interests at home and abroad? How do they make their products known? Publicity must be a most effective agent.
RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 27. -- Luther Veaseey, a sixteen-year-old employe of the Durham Hosiery Mills, Durham, N.C., while oiling the shafting to-day, accidentally kicked the stepladder from beneath him.

"If it be not now, yet it will come," might well suit the actual situation of the unfortunate Ministry of Mr. BALFOUR, and there is enough of Hamlet in the philosophic Premier to permit his adding in all sincerity, "the readiness is all. Since no man has aught of what he leaves, what is't to leave betimes?"

Merchants and shippers engaged in the Chinese trade in cotton fabrics, who expected some revival of the demand now that the New Year's holidays in the Celestial Empire are over, have watched the cables in vain for orders or hopeful inquiries.
IN 1900 there were 2,326,000 male voters in the United States unable to read or write -- 11 per cent. of the whole. This is mighty interesting reading for American women.

EVER since the City of Galveston. Texas was nearly destroyed by a tidal wave, the officials there have been perfecting their safeguards against such calamities in the future. The principal one of these is a gigantic sea wall, thicker and firmer than any structure of the sort ever constructed.
WHO was it that said that the law was an ass?

"That must leave Miss Pinkney without a great deal of vacant property," remarked the man who had just heard of the sale of twenty-six lots on Seventh Avenue between One Hundred and Nineteenth and One Hundred and Twentieth Streets, and who recalled several other large transactions in which she has figured the last few years.

An athlete who holds the proud title of world champion in an extremely strenuous specialty -- that of wrestling -- has formulated ten rules of healthful living which are so generally sensible and temperate that we take pleasure in giving them for the information of those for whom they may have interest:
IT has been stated that much of the Japanese success in naval fights around Port Arthur was due to the gyroscope.

Benjamin Steinhardt of Howe Hummel made some interesting statements yesterday in regard to the Morse-Dodge matrimonial tangle. He admitted for the first time that the firm of Howe Hummel had been defraying the expenses incurred in the fight to keep Dodge away from New York.

At a meeting of the League for Political Education at 23 West Forty-fourth Street yesterday morning, where the future interests of the league were discussed. Charles Stewart Smith, as the presiding officer, said of Mayor McClellan:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Augustus Saunders and Miss Mary Ellen King were married here at 8 o'clock to-night, the ceremony being performed by the Rev. Dr. William M. Hughes at the Church of the Redeemer. The marriage will come as a surprise to the friends of the couple, who read in the newspapers a year ago signed statements by Mr. Saunders and Miss King denying that they were engaged to be married.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 27 -- The Czar has received a dispatch from Viceroy Alexieff, dated Port Arthur, Feb. 26, in which he says:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 27. -- The United States Steel Corporation to-day closed a contract with the Bessemer Pig Iron Association for 130,000 tons of pig iron at $13 a ton at the valley furnaces. Directly and indirectly this will employ 3,000 men. The price at which the pig iron was sold is an advance of about 60 cents a ton over the price prevailing in January.

In making public its various reports for the improvement of the city the Municipal Art Society is prosecuting a campaign that its committees say they intend to pursue without let-up, despite the objections from all sides and the claims that their projects are sometimes impracticable dreams.

The variety and beauty of objects of the arts and crafts by Americans are less understood in New York than in other large cities of America owing to the overwhelming foreign population and the number of importers of foreign things. To appreciate a little of what is being done in America one should visit the Taft-Belknap Galleries, 1 East Fortieth Street.

With the rigors of an exceptionally severe Winter but little if any relaxed, the wild beauties typical of distant lands and Summer scenes assembled in their crystal palaces in the New York Botanical Garden have in some mysterious way discovered the approach of Spring and are bedecking themselves anew to befittingly hail her advent.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 27. -- Wisconsin's picturesque State Capitol is in ruins. All that was spared by the devastating flames, which started early this morning, is the extreme north extension, the contents of which are practically ruined by water.

Mme. Calve will sing at the concert in the Metropolitan Opera House to-night, appearing three times during the evening. She will sing in a duet, with Mr. Plancon, Faure's "Le Crucifix." Mr. Plancon and Mr. Burgstaller will also be heard in solos. Miss Hertha von Seldeneck, a young violinist from Carisruhe, will make her first appearance in this country.

The year is still so young that it is not necessary to place much emphasis upon the fact that last week's averages were the lowest for 1904, and within four points of the lowest for 1903, for either railways or industrials. This is so far from surprising that it would be marvelous were it not so, and the causes are not hid under a bushel.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Euclid School of Brooklyn played an important part in the speed skating races at Verona Lake to-day. Morris Wood won the half-mile scratch event, while E.A. Taylor and Gus Stoltz, also of Euclid School, won second and third prizes respectively. It was generally thought that Wood would break at least one of the world's records despite the fact that the ice was in poor shape.

It is neither to be expected nor desired that the report shall come true according to which, if Japan wins a signal victory over Russia, China is to join the winner as a combatant, and bring her banners, stinkpots, and fumigation of devils to the sacred work of expelling the oppressive Russian from Chinese soil.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27. -- The Schreiber cast-off Pretorius, now owned by A.B. Lettellier, won the first race to-day at all kinds of prices. The old gelding opened at 100 to 1, was backed down to 40 to 1 or less, and won cleverly.

Judge Lacombe in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday decided the case of the United States against R.F. Downing Co., in favor of the importers, thereby materially reducing the duty to be exacted on carbons for electric arc lights.

CERTAINLY very few events are worthier of a centennial celebration than the Louisiana Purchase, which is to be celebrated at an expense of several times the purchase money. Fifteen millions is the round sum commonly given as the price, though ostensibly at least it was something more, since, in addition to the sixty million francs in cash, the United States assumed liabilities estimated at $3,750,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Princeton's basket ball team was defeated by Columbia this afternoon by the score of 23 to 18. The play was fast, but too much time had to be taken out for double fouls. Rough tactics were repeatedly employed by both sides, Columbia being the most frequent offender. Columbia's team work excelled that of Princeton, and this, together with Princeton's inability to cover their opponents, enabled Columbia to win.

Seldom in the history of racing in the East have the prospects for the three big handicaps -- the Brooklyn, Suburban, and Metropolitan -- been so satisfactory at this season of the year. A glance at the list of entries, and a review of the declarations indicate a series of contests such as few years have known.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- London elects a new City Government next week, but comparatively few persons living in London seem to know it, and the chances are that thousands will read with astonishment the day after the polling that an entire new County Council has been chosen to manage the affairs of the city for the next three years.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The Munich Authors' and Journalists' Society, after discussing the production of "Parsifal" in New York, adopted resolutions declaring that the present protection for German literary works in the United States was insufficient, and that the treatment of them in America was unworthy of a civilized nation.

HENRY H. SHEARSON of Shearson, Hammill Co., has gone to Palm Beach. On the Cotton Exchange, where he is a familiar figure, it is said that the expenses of his trip are being paid by Daniel J. Sully, who considered Shearson a "Jonah" to the market, and offered to send him South to get rid of him.

The leadership of the Republican Party in the State changed hands yesterday. Gov. Odell is now the undisputed master of the organization. This fact was virtually proclaimed when the State Committee, at its meeting at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, without open opposition set the date for the State Convention for April 12, adopted resolutions commending the Administration of President Roosevelt, and pledged the support of the committee to him for the nomination.

Beginning a four weeks' run at the New Amsterdam. Richard Mansfield will appear day after to-morrow evening in "Ivan the Terrible." This Russian tragedy, by Count Alexis Tolstoi, has never been presented before in English. The translation is by Mme. S.R. de Meissner. The production of the play will be very elaborate.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Col. Mouravieff Amoursky, who was recalled from Paris when he was Military Attache at the Russian Embassy because of reflections cast on the French army, has written a letter to the Gaulois in which he says the war in the Far East will be terrible, but short. It will be a prelude to other wars between the white and yellow races.

A victory for the local club by a score of 24 points to 22 was the result of the dual swimming meet between the New York Athletic Club and the Brookline Swimming Club of Brookline, Mass., held in the tank of the New York Athletic Clubhouse, Sixth Avenue and Central Park South, last night.
PARIS, Feb.27 -- The week has been exceptional for intense cold and frequent sunshine.

To a reasonably intelligent onlooker it would appear that our practical statesmen, who are so active in their field of misrule, were a little premature in the launching their "rural free delivery" substitute for the possibly diminishing pension scheme payments which in the past have so successfully attacked the public treasury.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 27. -Announcement was made at the headquarters of the Catholic Diocese of Newark in Seton Hall College here to-day that Monsignor John Sheppard, Vicar General of the diocese, has declared that the action of the Brooklyn consistory in adopting the suggestion of Pope Pius X, that only boy choirs be used in Roman Catholic churches will not be followed in New Jersey.

The serious schism in the legal commission for the choice of a site for a new Court House at least proves that, under the limitations imposed by the statute under which the commission was working, no site universally or even generally acceptable to the bench and the bar could be found.

SCRANTON, Penn., Feb. 27. -- Another mine cave-in occurred this evening in North Scranton at Court Street and North Main Avenue, which caused an opening in the surface 50 feet in diameter and 10 feet deep. The house of Mrs. Francis Francis was partly undermined and threatened to topple over at any moment.

JACKSON, Mich., Feb. 27. -- John Huddy and his wife are lying dead at the morgue to-night. Yesterday notice of a suit for divorce begun by Mrs. Huddy was served on Huddy and to-day the latter went to the home of his wife's sister, Mrs. George Arnold, where he insisted at the point of a revolver on seeing his wife.

FIFTEEN years ago the Scottish geographer Bartholomew, reviewing the mapping of the world, said that one-eighth of the land surface was still almost wholly unknown: furthermore, enormous territories that had been revealed in broad outline had not yet been studied so far that they could be mapped with any accuracy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- August W. Machen, formerly General Superintendent of the Free Delivery Postal Service; Dr. George E. Lorenz of Toledo, Ohio, and Diller B. Groff of this city, who were convinced yesterday of conspiracy against the Government, to-day were sentenced to two years' imprisonment in the Moundsville (West Va.) Penitentiary and a fine of $10,000 each.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- A number of races under the direction of the North Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club were sailed today. Despite the comparatively warm weather the conditions were ideal for ice yachting. A light breeze blew from the northeast. The first race was for the Frick Cup, and the starters were Newton Doremus's Atalanta, George J. Gillig's Wizard, Charles Burd's Torment, Jacob Cornwell's Aurosa, Charles P. Irwin's Georgie, and Everett Asay's Eagle.

"About 20,000,000 cocoanuts come to New York every-year," said a New York dealer yesterday. "The trade has increased largely during the past few years; due to the fact that manufacturing confectioners, bakers and makers of desiccated cocoanut have greatly extended their business. There isn't much more market for individual use than there ever was.

Financiers behind the proposition of the Metropolitan Street Railway interests to construct the next rapid transit subway on Manhattan Island have unofficially informed the members of the Rapid Transit Commission that they stand ready to build the subway at their own expense without asking the credit of the city, as was the case in building the present subway.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Frederick King, a brakeman on the Mount Hope Mineral Railroad, had a thrilling ride on a runaway car yesterday. The car was standing on a siding at the top of the mountain near the Richard mine. It was to be hauled down to the bottom, but when the train bumped into it for the coupling, the brakes slipped and the car started away.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Liquidation on a huge scale caused a break of 3 3/4 cents today in May wheat. Profit taking, supposed to be for the account of the Armour interest, started the selling. Much of the decline was subsequently overcome, the close being 1 1/4 cents lower than last night's final figures.
"Once upon a time I was a real actor," said Press Eldridge, the vaudeville monologist, a night or two ago. It came about in this way.

GEN. A. C. BARNES, head of the American Book Company, is a Philadelphian by birth. After dining with some friends in the Quaker City the other night he referred to the time when his family moved to New York.

OF COURSE animals talk," said Col. Charles Jesse ("Buffalo ") Jones, who is the notable of the Madison Square Garden Sportsmen's Show, now in progress. "They are just as able to express their needs and convey their warnings and signals to their kind as human beings.

Capt. Kemp, with three of his detectives from the West Sixty-eighth Street Station yesterday afternoon interrupted the seemingly pleasurable occupation of about a dozen women who were jotting down facts and figures on pads of paper in an apartment on the second floor of 100 West Seventy-seventh Street, which to his unsympathetic mind appeared to be nothing else than a woman's poolroom.

The conviction of MACHEN, the head of the Free Delivery Bureau in the Post Office Department, and of his fellow-conspirators is a triumph for decency as well as a distinct political advantage for Mr. ROOSEVELT.

An example of what in recent years has been accomplished in a purely structural and mechanical direction for the alleviation of injury and disease will be revealed to the public, when on March 15 next the new Mount Sinai Hospital, at Fifth and Madison Avenues and One Hundredth and One Hundred and First Streets, will be opened to the public for inspection.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Secretary Taft has sent to the Treasury Department a request for $90,000 for new stables for the White House, declaring that a number of the President's best horses have been practically ruined by being kept in the old stables, which are damp and unwholesome.

The very earliest observers of the stars could hardly have failed to notice that the constellations visible at night varied with the seasons of the year. For instance, the constellation of Orion, which is so beautiful an adornment of the heavens these Winter nights, becomes invisible in the Summer, and the place it occupied is then taken by quite different stars.

ROME, Feb. 27. -- The situation in the Balkans, although it has apparently improved somewhat during the last few days, still occasions considerable anxiety. It is no longer a secret that Boris Sarafoff, the Macedonian leader, came to Italy with the principal object of deciding on a course of action with Ricciotti Garibaldi, who heretofore has not approved of an isolated movement on the part of the Macedonians.

It is about time for some one to protest against the further use of the sabre in Indian warfare. Not in actual Indian warfare, be if understood -- for that weapon is never used -- but in the pictorial and spectacular warfare furnished us by the popular magazines, the chromo dealers, the kinematographs, and the showmen.

AN electric current as an agent for thawing out frozen water pipes seems likely to oust the time-honored plumber from one of his regular functions. First, you call the electrician, maybe the same man who recently fixed your door bell for you. He arrives with a wagon bearing a dynamo and a connecting gasoline engine.

The average woman is not deficient in moral sense, but in the matter of valuations of imports of personal property for purposes of customs appraisement she displays an elasticity of conscience which renders it quite impossible to measure her veracity by the standards usually recognized as normal.

The Metropolitan Branch of the Grant Family Association, comprised of descendants of Matthew and Priscilla Grant, who came from England in 1630 and settled at Dorchester, Mass., held its sixth annual reunion add dinner last night at the Park Avenue Hotel, it being the three hundred and third anniversary of Priscilla Grant's birth.

WITH the first harbingers of approaching Spring comes the desire to cast off the thick garments of Winter and appear in new dress. With the first mental query as to whether the "sap is stirring yet and wintry birds are dreaming of a mate," one paraphrases the old saying and affirms solemnly that in the Spring time a young man's as well as a young woman's, fancy "lightly turns to clothes."

THE kind of Shakespeare production I really prefer," said Mr. Ben Greet, "is neither the bare-stage production nor the production with elaborate mounting." As he and his company are appearing nightly in a professedly archaeological revival of the allegedly bare Elizabethan stage, the statement was well calculated to pique curiosity.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- With the redemption of $10,000,000 in Treasury bills and the distribution of over $10,000,000 in dividends, money was plentiful in the market to-day. Discounts were easier for the same reasons.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Allaire, the deserted village, has been the destination of many driving parties from the hotels this week. Leo Schlesinger, President of the Merchants and Traders' Bank of New York, who has been staying at the Lakewood Hotel, took a large party of friends there.

Saturday's business upon the Stock Exchange amounted to less than 100,000 shares and developed nothing of interest. Pennsylvania was the most active property and rose one-eighth upon its annual report. Eries rose a fraction despite greater precision regarding the decrease in the January net which caused their weakness on Friday.

Mr. Heinrich Conried, director of the Metropolitan Opera House, is making a short trip to Chicago this week. Besides preliminaries for the season of opera that he will give there after the close of the New York season. Mr. Conried, it is understood, will discuss the question of producing "Parsifal" in the Western metropolis next Winter.

R. Bergmann, a real estate dealer of the east side, with offices at 241 Broadway, was arrested yesterday by United States revenue agents on a warrant charging him with being the chief owner of an allicit still captured by the revenue authorities in East Seventy-first Street on Jan. 21 last.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Feb. 27. -- As the result of a fight between officers and bandits on a passenger train of the n Pedro, Los Angeles and Salt Lake Railroad at midnight last night two men were fatally injured and two others seriously hurt.

The Yale and Harvard hockey teams, each backed by 1,000 shouting, flag-waving partisans met at St. Nicholas Rink last night to decide the intercollegiate hockey championship. After a bitterly contested gaine the score stood 3 goals to 3, and three even more bitterly contested extra periods were necessary to decide the game, which Harvard won by a clean goal one minute before the end of the third period.

I HAD two enlightening interviews with Baron Komura, Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan. Baron Komura, being President of the Harvard Association of Japan, has a warm spot in his heart for all Americans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Order of Elks is said to be responsible for the illegal slaughter of the Roosevelt elk, a species distinct from the common elk and named after the President by the discoverer of the species.

Approving the action of the Municipal Civil Service Commission in exempting from civil service requirements and jurisdiction the places of fifty-two Deputy Tax Collectors, Mayor McClellan yesterday afternoon issued a memorandum of his reasons. This is the exemption which was opposed so bitterly by the Civil Service Reform Association both at the hearing before the civil service officials and before the Mayor.

Richard Mansfield and those assisting him in historical researches for "Ivan the Terrible" tell an interesting yarn of the difficulties which beset the path of students of Russian topics no matter how diligently men search.
GUANTANAMO, Cuba, Feb. 27. -- The dispatch boat Mayflower, with Admiral Dewey on board, arrived here yesterday.

RICHARD STRAUSS in one way is especially a representative of the modern spirit in art -- in the vast divergency of his interests, the wide view he takes of life in all its aspects. He would make music all-inclusive in its scope, expressive of everything that comes into the range of human life and experience.

Horseback riding as an outdoor exercise has been practically impossible this Winter. There have not been two weeks all told since Thanksgiving when the roads have been open, and the only exercise the saddle horses owned in Manhattan have had has been on the tan bark, in the rings of the riding schools and clubs.

The dispute over the differentials on grain made in favor of Philadelphia as against New York by two of the trunk lines has called renewed attention to the fact that New York, and to some extent Philadelphia, has been steadily declining in importance as a shipping point for export grain.

For the purpose of raising funds to purchase vines and plants for window boxes in charitable institutions and to plant trees in the streets near these buildings where practicable, the Committee on Flowers, Vines, and Area Planting of the Municipal Art Society has arranged for an entertainment to be given at Carnegie Lyceum Saturday afternoon, March 12.

At the eighth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of Brokers, held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, Police Commissioner McAdoo hinted at Mayor McClellan as a Presidential possibility, and his suggestion was received with a roar of applause by the majority of those present. Controller Grout's statement that equitable taxation could not be had until there should be a Democratic Governor at Albany met with almost equal enthusiasm.

Puzzled by the conflict of views among his comrades concerning Whistler's paintings, an American student o art bethought him of his master, the late Benjamin Constant, and going to him, asked him frankly what one should think of Whistler.

ST. PETERSBURG Feb. 27. -- The Bourse Gazette to-day makes a Washington dispatch saying the United States has undertaken to lay a submarine cable from the Philippine Islands to Japan the subject of a bitter attack upon the Government at Washington "for this new evidence of its breach of neutrality."

What Central Office detectives and the police of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Police Station say is the neatest job of safe-breaking they have seen in recent years was Committed a few nights ago in L.A. Ware's bakery, at 2,268 Seventh Avenue. Mr. Ware has a good-sized safe in the rear of the store.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The advocates of the extension of the coastwise navigation laws to the Philippines had a hearing to-day before the House Committee on Merchant Marine. The only representatives of the opponents of this measure present to-day were Messrs. William O. Smith of Hawaii and W.M. Alexander of San Francisco.

GRADUALLY and through many tribulations am I gaining knowledge," said the dressmaker. "Moreover, I am learning to control my temper. There was a time when it made me fighting mad for a customer to bring a garment back after it had been worn and complain that it didn't fit.

A devout lady, coming from New England for a visit to Brooklyn, recently described her experience at the bridge entrance. "It's terrible!" she said, and then, desiring to more vividly portray her impressions, she added, "Why, it's a perfect inferno!"

FOLLOWING a period of speculation in low -- priced lots, last week's trading in vacant properties was of decidedly better character, and showed a disposition on the part of operators and builders to take up the improvement of some of the choicest vacant parcels in Harlem.
LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Another bit of British humor is recorded in the Morning Leader, as follows:

The keynote in the perennial duet on the school question is in the word "essential" so carelessly used by the critics of progress. The essence of a thing is its spirit, not its form -- its quality, not its material shaping. The essential subjects in education are the thought subjects, not the forms and processes.

The Educational Museum of Teachers College, Columbia University, announces an exhibit illustrative of Japan, which will open Monday and continue daily for a fort-night. The exhibition is intended to represent by means of a large collection of photographs, maps, charts, and objects such topics as the homes; customs, education, Industries and art of the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The orders of Edwin V. Morgan, appointed and confirmed as American Consul to Dalny, to proceed to that post, have been suspended. Mr. Morgan will not proceed until he has received further orders from the department. There is no present intention of trying to force Mr. Morgan upon the Russian Government.

The Rev. Louis Gabriel, rector of St. Joseph's German Catholic Church, in West Hoboken, has disappeared, and his absence has caused considerable comment in Hoboken church circles. He was known as a zealous clergyman, and this fact intensifies the mystery surrounding his strange disappearance.

TOKIO, Feb. 27. -- Naval officers commanded and "jackies" manned the five steamers that were sunk at the entrance to Port Arthur. Merchant sailors volunteered for the dangerous undertaking, but their services were not accepted, as Admiral Togo decided to intrust the perilous mission to regulars.

The high prices reached by wheat last week have raised the question as to how much further the advance could go without forcing the substitution of other food products. Inquiry among experts on this point brought out some remarkable facts. It appears that the present price of wheat is about the highest ever reached by that commodity without the aid of a corner.

Phil Kearney of the New York Athletic Club made a new indoor skating record last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, by going one mile in 2:50 2-5. The old record, 2:51, was also held by Kearney.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 27. -- At the final session of the New Jersey State Bankers' Association to-day the following officers were elected: Uzal H. McCarter, President of the Fidelity Trust Company of New Brunswick, President; Wilbur F. Rose, President of the State Bank of Camden, Vice president; Henry G. Barker of the National Bank of New Jersey. New Brunswick, Treasurer.

The American Ice Company is a sort of prodigal son, returning to its father's house in repentant if not otherwise Biblical fashion. For it the fatted calf appears about to be prepared, under the personal supervision of F.T. Bedford, the most important single stockholder in the Consolidated Ice Company prior to its acquisition by the combination.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 27. -- The sixth round of the international Rice gambit tournament was played here to-day. Mieses won from Fleischmann with the white pieces, his opponent having adopted the Jasnogrodsky defense. Marshall succumbed to Swiderski, while Scheve defeated Marco, the leader, with the Alapin attack.

Emil Totterman, the Swedish sailor, whose real name is Carl Nielson, was convicted yesterday in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court by a jury which had been out four hours.Totterman smiled when the foreman pronounced the words, "Guilty of murder in the first degree, as charged in the indictment."

It will, perhaps, disturb the peace of mind of certain timid people who, through fear of infection, are all their lifetime subject to nervousness, if not bondage, to know that the oyster and clam and the goblet of ice water are no longer solitary in their evil pre-eminence as carriers of the dread infection of typhoid fever.

POINCIANA, PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- The season of big dinners, big balls, and big luncheons has arrived, and many and gay are the various social functions. Naturally, at the season of large social doings, the events out of doors are on the same scale. Golf is rampant. Tennis has its many devotees, while boating, swimming, and shooting draw many enthusiasts.

The average theatregoer is an impressionable being. If he were not he would not be a theatregoer. But how many persons sitting through the average theatrical performance realize upon what subtle things their impressions at times depend? How many, for instance, know that an emotional stirring on their own part is often merely the result of a careful selection of colors in the dress of the performer.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 27. -- The question of Yale's athletic finances has just stirred up new agitation. Yale receives in subscriptions and gate receipts for all the athletic organizations of the university close to $100,000 a year. The yearly expenditures are now $69,096, which does not include the expenses of the smaller teams nor the yearly charges for improvement at Yale Field, where last year something over $22,000 was spent in new football stands.

It is really astonishing not to say amusing, to a student of political economy to see a great newspaper like THE NEW YORK TIMES wrestling editorially and ineffectually with such a simple primary economic problem as the definition of the term "wealth," as used in the economic sense. The fact of the matter is that all wealth is capital and all capital is wealth.

The customary two performances occupied the penultimate Saturday of the present opera season at the Metropolitan. "I1 Flauto Magico" was sung at the matinee, and in the evening "Lohengrin" was given for the benefit of the patrons of the last popular-priced performance.

A conservative platform representing the interest of the people, and an honest, thoughtful, strong man as the champion of those interests, are the only hope of the party for victory. The Democratic Party especially is not a one-man concern, and to acknowledge that its prospects lie in the choice of one particular man, and that there is no other who can represent it, is absurd. -- Birmingham (Ala.) News, (Dem.)

It appears that the jerry builders of this town, though "scotched" by the combined firmness and tact of Mr. DE FOREST, as Tenement House Commissioner, in resisting unfriendly amendments to the tenement house law, are by no means killed. "Sweet blighted lilies," according to the legendary epitaph upon the negro child, "sweet blighted lilies, they are holding up their heads again."

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The stock market has exhibited a good deal of nervousness all the week, attributable in the first instance to the semi-panic which struck the Exchange last Saturday after the news reached here of the excitement on the Continental Bourses. A rally quickly followed Saturday's slump, but the feeling of uncertainty growing out of the war remained, and the effect has been shown in depression in all markets.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The second report of the Lord Esher Committee has been issued, and gives details of the proposed War Office reforms.

In your issue of Monday, Feb. 15, you have an article on the beautifying of the Boulevard, and as the facts stated are so far at variance with what has been done I take the liberty of addressing your paper on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The report of the Special commission appointed by the President on Sept. 16 last to investigate the conditions existing at the Bureau of Immigration at Ellis Island was made public to-day by the Secretary of Commerce and Labor.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 28. -- An official dispatch received from Major Gen. Pflug, Viceroy Alexieff's Chief of Staff, which is dated Feb. 28, says:

A fight with three supposed burglars followed by their escape after a long pursuit caused great excitement last night in the five-story apartment house at 1,266 Webster Avenue. Adolph Wexler of 1,268 Webster Avenue, and John Doyle of 1,266, fought with the intruders near the house they had entered, but were unable to hold them till the police could arrive.

The vanguard of out-of-town American League Club owners, or their representatives, who will attend the annual Schedule meeting of the organization at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, arrived here yesterday. The arrivals were President Ben Johnson. Charles Comisky of the Chicago Club, and Charles W. Somers of the Cleveland Club.

YIN KOW, Feb. 28. -- The first reports by eye witnesses of the engagement at Port Arthur in the early morning of Wednesday last have been received here. They say that one Jpanese coal hulk was sunk and one beached near the Retvizan and that nineteen Japanese in civilian clothes escaped ashore, where they were afterward captured.

Twenty pistol shots were exchanged in the Kill von Kull late Saturday night between the police of the Harbor Squad and six men on two oyster scows which the police were trying to board. After a desperate fight, five of the men jumped into the water. One was captured, together with the man who did not jump overboard; one was drowned, and the other three escaped.

Sons and daughters of Ireland from every part of New York crowded the Academy of Music, at Fourteenth Street and Irving Place, to overflowing last night, to celebrate the one hundred and twenty-sixth anniversary of the birth of Robert Eminet and to listen to a eulogy of his character by William Butler Yeats, regarded as the greatest of Irish poets.

What a notable event is the fact that the leader of Tammany Hall is now esteemed of sufficient importance publicly to make known his views of the merits of Presidential candidates and to express his preference therefor. Also, is not the great publicity given, his recent movements, outside of New York, and his various reported conferences with well-known leaders pertaining thereto, one of the events of the age, when we take into consideration his antecedents?

Permit me to protest against the unnecessary prominence given to the proposition to purchase a warship for Japan from funds contributed by Hebrews. The suggestion emanated from one or two irresponsible persons, and the only service that they have rendered to the community is that they have aroused the condemnation of all thinking Hebrews in this country.

Armed with syphons of seltzer and organized into impromptu bucket brigades, members of the Strollers' Club, 67 Madison Avenue, battled bravely early yesterday morning against a fire which threatened their home. They succeeded in extinguishing the blaze before the arrival of the engines.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 28. -- For the first time in the history of the South a negro murderer was rescued by a Governor from an infuriated mob, and, after an expenditure of $250,000, removed to a palace of safety. This extraordinary work was accomplished to-day by Gov. James K. Vardaman of Mississippi, recently elected on an anti-negro platform, and who declared his approval of the lynching of persons who assaulted women in the South.

Gov. Odell passed a very quiet Sunday. Chairman William Halpin of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee was general emissary for the Governor throughout the day. Halpin reported to his chief three times during the day. Congressman John W. Dwight of Tompkins and Col. George W. Dunn talked with the Governor at one time and another.
CHE-MUL-PHO; Feb. 27. -- The Japanese disembarkations of the last few days have been confined to supplies, transport corps, and ponies, of which there are 4,500.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- Albert Herpin, born in France in 1862 and for fifteen years a hostler in the employ of Freeholder Walter Phares of this city, declares that he has not slept a wink during the past ten years. Notwithstanding this, he is in perfect health, and does not seem to suffer any discomfort from his remarkable condition.

It would be impossible to commend too strongly the clinic for the diagnosing and treatment of pulmonary tuberculosis about to be opened by the Health Department of New York. It will occupy a building on West Fifty-fifth Street immediately adjoining the headquarters of the department, and will include a registration office, two waiting rooms, an X-ray room, a throat department, and two clinics with examination rooms.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -- This has been a quiet day socially in anticipation of a gay week or dinners and entertainments of various sorts.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The President yesterday sent the following letter to Postmaster General Payne:

Frank Damrosch, director of music in the New York public schools and director of the Oratorio Society, the People's Choral Union, and the Musical Art Society, expresses his opinion of the recent letter of Pope Pius X. regarding church music in the current number of The Church Economist, to be published to-morrow.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 28. -- Mail advices from Nome state that Count and Countess Moracewski, formerly of Dawson, have been arrested and taken to Nome charged with an attempt to murder Capt. William Galpin, who was correspondent for The London Times in the Yukon country during the boom days, and later became well known as a mine operator.

PORT TOWNSEND, Wash., Feb. 28. -- After suffering the most harrowing experiences from fire and storm that have ever befallen a craft on the north Pacific coast, the steamship Queen to-day put in here to report the loss of fourteen lives.

Concerning Mr. Frederick W. Seward's valuable contribution to the history of Russia's attitude in the Civil War, as published in your issue of to-day, there are various other authorities on the point within convenient reach, among these being our present eminent Secretary of State, and Mr. Foster, one of his distinguished predecessors.

LONDON, Feb. 29. -- A Russian correspondent of The Associated Press at Port Arthur cabling under yesterday's date, describes a gallant combat between the Russian cruiser Novik and the Japanese squadron on the day before as follows:

Commenting on Commissioner of Police McAdoo's declaration at the banquet of the Real Estate Board of Brokers, in the Waldorf-Astoria Saturday night, that the City Magistrates, acting as he would like to have them act, could make it possible to reduce the police force by one-half, and that the Magistrates have greater power for good or evil than the Supreme Court, Magistrate Ommen said yesterday:
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 28. -- Rules of war were published officially to-night. The most important article is Rule VI., which announces that the following will be regarded as contraband of war:

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 28. -- The Bird syndicate of London, England, has just acquired a large tract of oil lands situated on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, Mexico. MacDonald Bird of London and Capt. A.F. Lucas, the oil expert, who discovered the Beaumont oil field, are on their way home from a visit and inspection of the new field.

TOKIO, Feb. 28.--On account of Vice Admiral Togo's successes at Port Arthur the reopening of the sea to Japanese merchants and the revival of shipping the Japanese Government does not anticipate that it will have further need for the auxiliary cruisers America Maru and Yawata Maru, and they will be returned to their owners, the America Maru resuming her place on the San Francisco line and the Yawata Maru on the Australian run.

Despite the rain and the nasty haze that overhung the city yesterday and gave it a most undesirable appearance, the passengers who arrived on the steamships St. Louis of the American Line and on the Etruria of the Cunard Line were glad to get in. For over a week they had been passing from Europe amid, storms and tempests which raged from every point of the compass.

Last week began with a holiday and ended in inactivity. It therefore comes as a surprise that the volume of business was larger than in the preceding week. The explanation is the activity and depression following on Tuesday and Wednesday the panicky foreign markets on the war factor. The impression of extreme dullness is justified, however, if comparison is made with previous years, instead of with the previous week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 28. -- A dispatch received here from Liao-Yang and dated Feb. 28, says that Chinese on the Yalu River report that an advance guard of Russian cavalry which has penetrated Korea for a distance of about 200 versts (about 125 miles) across the river had an encounter with a detachment of Japanese and that the Japanese were compelled to retreat and fled, leaving their horses, which were seized by Cossacks.

Ten minutes afar being lodged in a cell under arrest on a charge of robbery yesterday afternoon. Hulden Larsen, who said he lived at 243 West Fifteenth Street, committed suicide by hanging himself to the door of his cell, in the West Thirty-seventh Street Station. He had tied his suspenders in a sailor knot for the purpose.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Feb. 28. -- Some leading members of the Mormon Church, who have been summoned as witnesses in the Smoot case, have disappeared. It was hinted before the subpoenas were served that the Church would not permit these men to testify.

" Now, who'll be the Republican candidate for Governor this Fall?" was the question debated in local Republican circles yesterday. "Will it be Nixorr or Woodruff, or Higgins or Knight, or Stranahan" was asked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Some of the Democrats here are feeling blue over the Bryan recrudescence, and are disposed to hold the New Yorkers and some other Eastern men responsible for it. They assert that they had Bryan safely entombed and that New York has revived him. A couple of months ago they thought victory was in sight, but now they are by no means so sure of it.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- During the past week the Stock Exchange was occupied in the settlement. Business was inactive and it is likely to continue so until it is seen whether the settlements in Paris and Berlin reveal further trouble arising from the panic of the previous week, which had a demoralizing effect on all foreign stocks, Spanish, Turkish, and Bulgarian especially being heavily sold.

-- That Brooklyn correspondent of ours who argued for building in the suburbs for people of moderate means better houses than are the large majority of those supplied by the men who build only to sell at as large a profit as possible, presented accurately an existing condition of affairs, but he went astray somewhat in his inferences as to that condition's cause and cure.

LINDEN, N.J., Feb. 28. -- Grove L. Collins, son of Tax Assessor Collins of this borough, was arrested late yesterday afternoon, on the charge of using the mails for fraudulent purposes. He is believed by the authorities to be a member of a gang using the mails to disseminate "green-goods" literature.

Benjamin Steinhardt of Howe Hummel yesterday refused to discuss statements attributed to him in the Sunday newspapers. Mr. Steinhardt was reported as having said that his firm was paying the expenses of Charles F. Dodge in keeping out of the jurisdiction of the New York courts in connection with the Morse-Dodge matrimonial mix up.

HAVANA, Feb. 28. -- The Congressional elections, the first ever conducted entirely under Cuban auspices, were quiet and well ordered. Predictions of disturbances at certain points caused some apprehension, but so far as reported nothing unusual occurred.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 28. -- A report from Gen. Pflug, at Port Arthur, says: "The night of Feb. 27 passed quietly at Port Arthur. The enemy's fleet keeps in this vicinity."
The surgeons of Lincoln Hospital, in the Borough of the Bronx, have succeeded in replacing the scalp on the head of a young girl after it had been torn completely off by a revolving shaft in a mill.

A letter was read at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union from the London District Council of Shop Assistants in reference to the detention of John Turner, the Anarchist, without bail. The letter complained that no reply had been received to two telegrams sent over a month ago from the Council sustaining Turner.

The Mayor has approved the action of the Civil Service Commission of the city in abolishing competition for the place of Deputy Tax Commissioner. We deeply regret the decision, which does away with a real and practical test of fitness for appointment, removes an important safeguard against partisan and personal favoritism, and exposes one of the most important functions of the financial administration of the city to the influence of the spoilsmen.
LONDON, Feb. 29. -- The Times's military correspondent says:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A wealthy Pennsylvania coal merchant, dressed like a hobo, and about to begin a thirty days' sentence at the workhouse, while his family at Palm Beach wondered what had become of him, was the mystery that enlivened Washington police circles to-day.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 28. -- A local newspaper will publish to-morrow a letter from Booker T. Washington, of which a part follows:

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- In reference to the severity of the censorship exercised by the Japanese Government over the news dispatches of foreign correspondents, Baron Hayashi, the Japanese Minister to Great Britain, said to The Associated Press today:

No change in the relative standing of the teams in the Harlem Navy Handball League was made by the games played in the series yesterday, as leaders met tailenders and won by large margins in every ease. In fact, the three leading teams lost but a single game of eighteen played, while the last three teams on the list won but a single game of that number.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 28. -- William H. Cochran, who was arrested in Washington, is the son of Henry Cochran, the founder of the Connellsville coke industry. The family is reputed to be wealthy, and retains large interests in the coke industry.

CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 29. -- Robert W. De Forest of New York, general counsel for the Central Railroad of New Jersey, who is now in Mexico in company with Mrs. De Forest, Lockwood De Forest, Royall Farragut, and Mr. and Mrs. Daniel C. French, is making a study of the Government pawnshops in connection with his work as President of the New York Charity Organization and the New York philanthropic pawnshop.
TOKIO, Feb. 28. -- Detailed official reports show that six distinct operations took place at Port Arthur.

CHEFOO, Feb. 28. -- While the Japanese report that their fleet was unscathed in their latest attack on Port Arthur, they are using every endeavor in attempting to prevent details of any injury to the Japanese fleet from leaking out. Survivors said to be from sunken Japanese transports, who landed here Saturday, are not allowed to see any one.

The opportunity to hear Miss Emma Calve for Sunday night concert pieces was too much for the Metropolitan Opera House patrons to resist. So last night, bad weather notwithstanding, the house was crowded as on a "Parsifal" night, and the enthusiasm was at top pitch.

The extensive preparations which are being made by the State of Louisiana to provide a special rice exhibit at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition are sufficient proof that the industry has grown to such proportions that it is worthy of representation. Not only will rice and rice culture be fully represented, but all the by-products of rice will be fully displayed.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Vladivostok has been blockaded by a Japanese fleet since Thursday, according to a Daily Mail dispatch from Hakodate, which adds that incoming steamers report Russian cruisers on the east coast of Kinkwasan, in the Bay of Sendai, Japan.

After a frenzied jangle of the telephone at Police Headquarters last evening, an excited hysterical feminine voice was heard to ask for an ambulance to hurry to 2,025 Second Avenue, where it was said that a woman was dying from poison. Then the voice broke off as suddenly as it had come.

Clinton Hall, at 151-153 Clinton Street, the new Waldorf-Astoria of the lower east side, was opened last night to the general public by the Social Halls Association, which means to follow with other and similar enterprises.
PARIS, Feb. 29. -- A man having business transactions with Port Arthur tells me that should the Russian communications be cut off there would not be sufficient provisions there for a fortnight.

CAMDEN, N.J., Feb.29. -- The Metropolitan Sugar Refining Company, capital $5,000,000, filed articles of incorporation to-day in the County Clerk's office here. The incorporators are Joseph F. Cotter and I.C. Clow of New York, and George D. Martin of Camden.

Weights for the Metropolitan Handicap, to be run May 5 at Morris Park, were announced yesterday by Handicapper W.S. Vosburgh. McChesney heads the list, in the absence of Waterboy, with 128 pounds. James R. Keene's three-year-old Careless brings up the rear of the lightweights with 87 pounds.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- An increase in Russian shipments of wheat, notwithstanding the war, forced the price for May delivery back past the dolar mark to-day. The market touched 99 3/4, in the midst of excitement paralleling the remarkable scenes which attended the spectacular leap across the line ten days ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The remarkable campaign which Leader Williams of the Democratic Party has conducted in his determination to make the Democratic issue the abandoned Republican policy of reciprocity, with moderate tariff revision, has forced the Republicans to take official recognition of it.

The annual gallery championship match and prize shoot of the Zettler Rifle Club, which began Saturday on the club ranges, 159 West Twenty-third Street, was continued yesterday. E. Van Zandt of Brooklyn finished his string in the championship match and made a score of 2,451, which is the highest in that series. The scores:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Representative Scott of Kansas created a sensation in the House to-day by declaring that the famous White House luncheon at which Booker T. Washington was a guest had a Democratic Cleveland once invited a Kansas negro precedent. Mr. Scott said that Grover named Taylor to luncheon.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day an order was issued for the release of John Turner on bail and setting the hearing of his case by the court for April 4.

One of the most important real estate transactions which has occurred on the upper west side in several years was consummated yesterday when Slawson Hobbs sold for the Realty Company of America to Isaac H. Clothier of Philadelphia the big seven-story apartment house Euclid Hall, fronting on the west side of Broadway, and extending from Eighty-fifth Street to Eighty-sixth Street.

That peculiarly constituted organization known as the Canadian Camp, in which there are no dues and in which anybody who has ever camped in Canada is eligible for membership, pitched its tent last night for its second annual banquet at the Hotel St. Denis.
LONDON, Feb. 29. -- In introducing the naval estimates in the House of Commons to-day Capt. Ernest G. Pretyman, Secretary to the Admiralty, made the usual explanatory statement.

Marion Weed probably will take the part of Kundry in Henry W. Savage's production of "Parsifal" in English. Much interest was shown around the Metropolitan Opera House last night in this piece of news, and it gave strength to the general belief that Heinrich Conried is more intimately connected than he pretends to be with Mr. Savage's venture.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 29. -- Myron McHenry, trotting horse driver, broke out of the maiden class on the running turf to-day when his mare Maritana won the first race for maiden three-year-olds. Wreath of Ivy and New York were the only defeated favorites, and New York's race with Lev Dorsey in the handicap, for which both were heavily backed, was one of the best contests of the meeting.

Utter inability of the local authorities to enforce the present excise law in New York City and social evils that have resulted from the enactment of the law, were the subjects of a talk by District Attorney Jerome in Lotos Hall, at Seventy-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue, last evening. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Citizens' Union, and about fifty persons were present to hear Mr. Jerome denounce the law.

Samuel Untermyer, representing Charles W. Morse, and Abraham H. Hummel, representing Charles F. Dodge, appeared in the Supreme Court yesterday and argued before Justice Truax on Mr. Morse's application to intervene as an injured person in a proceeding to be brought to set aside the order vacating the decree of divorce granted to Mrs. Dodge at the time she sued Dodge in 1897.

Next Thursday and Friday evenings there will be auctions held by Mr. James P. Silo at the Fifth Avenue Galleries, near Thirty-fifth Street. The 130 canvases are by deceased and living American artists, and among them are some excellent works.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The President sent to the Senate to-day the names of the Panama Canal Commissioners, and they were referred to the Committee on Inter-Oceanic Canals. It is expected the nominations will be reported within a few days and that confirmation will speedily follow.

Stock Exchange business is still held in the grip of the war's dead-lock. There was no important news of the campaign yesterday, but business was checked by anxiety regarding the semi-monthly settlement at Paris, in which the war was a controlling consideration. It was characterized by the now familiar phenomenon of a smaller comparative fall in Russians than in rentes.

Several exciting incidents attended a fire at 6 o'clock last night at 113 and 113 1/2 Bowery just below Grand Street. Firemen fought the blaze from the elevated road tracks as they stood alongside the third rail, and they threw water on the burning building from the water tower over the elevated railroad cars.

ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- To-day's events indicate that David B. Hill intended to try to force the Democratic State Committee at its meeting next Saturday to indorse Judge Parker as New York's candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but has changed his mind, either because he feared a trial of strength with Tammany Hall or because of the interests of party harmony.

At the annual meeting of the Trustees of the Grant Monument Association, held at 120 Broadway yesterday, it was decided to petition the State Legislature to appropriate $10,000 with which to install a heating plant in the tomb. The structure is at present heated only by gas, and during this Winter the temperature has never been higher than 30 degrees.

Stockholders of the National Biscuit Company received copies yesterday of the annual report signed by A.W. Green, Chairman of the Board of Directors. Following is the balance sheet at the close of business Jan. 31, 1904:

Clarence H. Mackay, President of the Commercial Cable Company, addressed a circular letter to the stockholders of that company yesterday, inviting the deposit of their stock for exchange for shares in a trusteeship created under the laws of Massachusetts under the name of "The Mackay Companies."

The fight is now on. Mr. Bryan is in the saddle. He has hoisted the red flag, and he declares that he will give his opponents no quarter. It is to be war to the death, so far as he can make it so, whether or not a majority of the Democrats of the Nation are willing to follow his lead and take part in the revolution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- United States Minister Allen cables to the State Department from Soul that in pursuance of an arrangement he has made with the Japanese Minister a returning transport will bring Americans from Ping-yang.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 29. -- Aaron Tustig, who says he lives at 156 Attorney Street, New York, is locked up here on a charge of employing a novel form of the gold brick swindle. Tustig entered the store of Joseph Schwartz, at 17 1/2 Palisade Avenue, this afternoon, and offered to sell what appeared to be 3 1/2 ounces of old gold leaf in scraps.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Feb. 29. -- The Republicans of the Twenty-fifth Congressional District in convention here assembled to-day renominated Lucius N. Littauer for a fifth term in Congress and named Mr. Littauer and Senator Brackett as delegates to the Republican National Convention.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 29. -- A fund has been started here for the family of Engineer Mark Kelly of Fire Engine Company No. 16 of the New York Department, who died of pneumonia as the result of exposure at the Baltimore fire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- The last will and testament of George Washington, which is one of the most celebrated features of the little town of Fairfax Court House, Va., was threatened with burglary last night.

"Bachelor" seems to have put his hand into a hornet's nest. It only emphasizes to my mind that true love should be the one supreme motive for marriage. If it is, married life will be a never-ending day of sunshine and happiness, no matter how heavy the burdens of husband and wife may be.
ALBANY, Feb. 29. -- Superintendent Kilburn of the State Banking Department says in his annual report to the Legislature on building and loan associations:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29. -- Official Washington architecture came in for a plentiful depreciation to-day at the hands of numerous Senators, who promptly became critics of a savage and dyspeptic type when the Senate took up the bill for a new building for the State Department, the Department of Justice, and the new Commerce and Labor Department, all of which departments it is proposed to house together in one structure.

An agreeable and in many ways delightfully artistic talent for Lieder singing was disclosed yesterday afternoon by a singer new to this public. Dr. Theodore Lierhammer, who gave a song recital in Mendelssohn Hall. He is a baritone, a Pole by birth, who claims Vienna as his residence, but who has made most of his career in England, and who comes to this country with little preliminary heralding.

The October report of the Board of Health for the Philippines, just received, contains a curious and interesting example of the difficulties encountered by the sanitary administration of Manila in enforcing the rules necessary for the safeguarding of the public health. Cholera is still prevalent in Manila, and the measures to control it are constantly defeated by the ignorance and superstition of the people.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29. -- Deputy Marshals are scurrying all over the business portion of Chicago to-night trying to-serve over 100 messenger boys with copies of an injunction issued against them to-day by Judge Kohlsaat in the United States District Court. Up to date the boys have been elusive.

Representatives from more than a score of financial and commercial bodies appeared before Mayor McClellan in the Council Chamber yesterday to indorse the plan of establishing an auxiliary salt water fire-fighting system in the business districts of Manhattan and Brooklyn. Only two dissenting opinions were offered, one from ex-Mayor Schieren and the other from ex-Park Commissioner Elijah R. Kennedy of Brooklyn.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 29. -- The seventh round of the international Rice gambit tournament, played here to-day, brought the chess masters together in the following order: Swiderski vs. Mieses, Fleischmann vs. Marco, and Marshall vs. Scheve.
Judge Holt of the United States District Court yesterday granted discharges to the following bankrupts:

It seems quite clear that certain Russian journalists and certain Russian officials are sincerely at a loss to make out why the sympathy of most Americans should go to Japan in the present war. The commercial and social relations between Russia and the United States, though never intimate or important, have never been unfriendly, while the relations of the two Governments have been distinctly cordial.

Details of the transaction in which Isaac H. Clothier of Philadelphia has bought Euclid Hall, a seven-story apartment on Broadway, between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets, 204.10 by 119.6, and has given in payment to the Realty Company of American, Franklin Petit, forty-eight lots on Broadway, the aggregate value of the two properties being $2,500,000, are presented in another column.
LONDON, March 1. -- A dispatch to The Daily Telegraph from Yin Kow, dated Feb. 29, says:

PARIS, Feb. 29. -- The Syndic of the Paris Municipal Council recently invited the Education Department of the Seine to request the teachers to explain to the pupils the alliance between France and Russia and to ask the women teachers and the girls under their charge to prepare lint for the wounded.

-- It took a year for us to recover from the shock that was inflicted when a Kentucky horseman reached, quite unaided, so far as was ever revealed, the conclusion that a horse he had sold to another horseman was not worth the amount he had received for it, and then not only sent all the money back, but told the other man to keep the horse as well.

The proclamation of Gen. STOESSEL, the Russian commandant of Port Arthur, to the troops and inhabitants under his command, is an amazing document. He as good as tells them that they have no hope of reinforcement and no hope of escape, and that, as he will never surrender, their only safety lies in repelling the impending assault of the Japanese.

A Monday night without a novelty, from Third Avenue to Eighth. But the vice of first nighting will not down -- it must be a vice; no virtue could be so persistent. Mr. Donnelly's new stock company at the Murray Hill has shifted from Pinero and modern English comedy to Clyde Fitch and New York.

The Woman's Christian Temperance Union will hear with joy that the Central Federated Union, which is composed of professional workingmen, has adopted with "acclamation" a resolution indorsing "union" whisky, and by implication pledging the members to drink no other.

HODGENVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23. -- Mrs. Sarah Elizabeth Castleman, affectionately termed "Aunt Sallie" Castleman, aged ninety-six years, and who knew President Lincoln, died at her home in the eastern end of Larue County, Kentucky, Feb. 22 of infirmities due to old age. Mrs. Castleman was related to the distinguished family of Helms, of Kentucky, being a close relative of Gov. Helm.

James J. Jeffries, the champion heavyweight pugilist, has at last decided that "Jack" Munroe, the Butte miner, was of sufficient calibre to fight for the championship, and articles were signed by representatives of both men in this city yesterday for a twenty-round contest at the Yosemite Athletic Club of San Francisco during the latter week of May, probably on the 30th, Memorial Day.

PORT ARTHUR, Feb. 28. -- Gen. Stoessel, Commandant of the garrison here, has issued a General Order directing the attention of the troops and inhabitants to the fact that the Japanese intend to land and seize the fortress.

The will of George Washington Egleston, a brother of the late Prof. Howard Egleston of Columbia University, and of William C. and David S. Egleston of this city, was filed for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. In it the testator makes several peculiar bequests and directions, and it teems with interesting comments on affairs of the family and of the business world.

The architect to whom, by the general assent of his profession, was assigned the work of restoring the White House while enlarging and adapting it to modern needs, as to the fittest architect for that particular work, has probably not been much startled or disturbed by finding that there was a certain representation from Philistia in the United States Senate.

There was much enthusiasm and many evidences of friendly appreciation for the Kneisel Quartet at the last concert of their series, which was given last evening in Mendelssohn Hall. The audience was large, as all their audiences have been this year, and let no opportunity pass of manifesting its sentiments toward this organization, which sets sail to-morrow for a series of concerts in Europe.

More than 300 physicians, among whom were eminent practitioners and men connected with institutions of medical learning from almost every State east of the Mississippi and some from beyond, attended a dinner given at Delmonico's last night to honor Dr. D.B. St. John Roosa and to commemorate the twenty-first anniversary of the inauguration in this country of post-graduate medical instruction.

There were times last night at the New Amsterdam when it seemed that Richard Mansfield was increasing by one the meagre collection of modern masterpieces of acting. Never in recent memory has he been so free from mannerisms of voice and gesture, never has his virtuosity seemed more absolute, or his force of imagination more authentic and more pronounced.

A judgment was obtained yesterday by the National Bank of Commerce against the North Shore Building and Loan Association of Staten Island for $5,000. Officers of the North Shore Association said last night:

Folsom Brothers have sold for the Ritter estate to Halprin, Lewin Diamondston 602 and 604 East Sixteenth Street, two two-story brick buildings, 50 by 103.3. The buyers will erect a six-story tenement.

Both the Port Chester and the Westchester companies renewed their applications for permits to cross streets in the Bronx in the construction of an electric railroad at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday.

Unable to face the stifling smoke that rolled up the stairway from a fire on the first floor of the two-story and attic brick house at 180 Forsyth Street, sandwiched between a small carpenter's shop and a big tenement, Mrs. Wolf Rosenbloom, who lived in the attic, took her helpless and crippled husband in her arms and jumped with him to the roof of the carpenter's shop, a few feet below.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Guy at the hearing on the McClellan gas bills, before the Assembly Cities Committee to-day, made an attack on Jastrow Alexander, State Inspector of Gas Meters, intimating that there was collusion between Mr. Alexander's office and the gas companies.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 1. -- A decided change in sentiment on the license question was shown to-day at the annual local elections held throughout the State. Only forty-eight cities and towns, according to returns received at a late hour, voted in favor of liquor selling as compared with ninety-two last year, when the prohibition law of half a century was annulled.
PARIS, March 2. -- The Harbin correspondent of the Matin says that he was fortunate enough to meet the French explorer Chaffaujon and get from him information regarding the Trans-Siberian Railroad.

Elwyn A. Barron, once widely known as the dramatic critic of The Chicago Inter Ocean, who for nine years has dwelt in London and Paris, is now in New York conducting the rehearsals of his new play, "The Ruling Power,' to be produced at tile Garrick Theatre March 14.

ALBANY, March 1. -- The Republican legislative caucus to-night nominated ex-District Attorney Eugene A. Philbin and Edward Lauterbach of New York City to be Regents of the University in place of Carroll E. Smith of Syracuse and Bishop Thomas Hendrick, formerly of Rochester and recently transferred to the Philippines.
BERLIN, March 1. -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were firmer. Exchange on London, 20 marks 46 3/4 pfennigs for checks.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 1. -- Developments at the conference of the miners and operators of the central competitive district to-day made it plain that the danger of another big strike is considerable. In the course of the conference F.L. Robbins, speaking for the operators, said:

James A. Hart, President of the Chicago Baseball Club, was responsible for tying up the business of both the National and American Leagues schedule meeting yesterday. On his way to attend the session of his league, which was called for the Hotel Victoria at noon, he wired President Pulliam that he could get no further than Syracuse on account of snow.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 1. -- T.J. Cornwell, formerly President of the Bessemer Savings Bank, who, while under a charge of stealing $200,000 from that institution, fled to Honduras, arrived home to-day, having voluntarily returned to stand trial.
Recent portraits and a number of landscapes taken in France by Mr. Hubert Vos are shown at the Kraushaar Gallery, 260 Fifth Avenue, where they will remain for a fortnight.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1. -- The passenger train over the Elmira and Cortland Division of the Lehigh Valley Railroad due here Monday morning from Canastota, is stalled near De Ruyter, and will not be able to reach Ithaca for another twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Whether the Beef Trust is violating the injunction resting against it will be made the subject of investigation by the Department of Commerce and Labor, if a resolution ordered reported favorably to-day passes the House.

About 200 motormen and conductors besieged the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station and demanded that Charles Farley, late of 153 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, who had obtained $2.35 apiece from them, be found forthwith. The men were very much excited, and it was some time before Capt. McNally was able to understand their story.
