Another large and much interested audience gathered in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to sit at the feet of Dr. Richard Strauss, to do honor to the composer, and to hear his music through his own interpretation and, upon this occasion, his wife's, Mme. Pauline Strauss-de Ahna. It was a song recital, in which Mme. Strauss-de Ahna sang and Dr. Strauss played the accompaniments.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Russia's charges that Japan won her first naval victory by treachery and committed a breach of international law in attacking before a declaration of war was made are met in an authorized statement given out here to-day by the Japanese Minister. This statement says:

That remarkable deliverance of the commandant of Port Arthur upon the prospects of his command, upon which we have already commented, must have been read with particular satisfaction by the members of the Japanese General Staff. It denoted beyond a doubt that the Japanese tactics were "getting on the nerves" of the Russian commandant.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The case of Postmaster Van Cott engrosses a good share of the Administration's attention just now. According to report, the Inspectors who investigated the New York Post Office have recommended the dismissal of the Postmaster and twelve other officials, although it is said that the charges against Mr. Van Cott do not in any way involve his personal integrity.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Inquiry into the charges against Justice Warren B. Hooker in connection with the Fredonia and Dunkirk Post Office scandals was to-day taken up by the Grievance Committee of the State Bar Association. It was decided to refer the charges to a sub-committee of five, conslating of Chairman Huffcutt, Secretary Bascom, and three others to be appointed by the Chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- A conference took, place to-day between Secretary Hay and Count Cassini, the Russian Ambassador, at which the growing ill-feeling in Russia against America and the continued attacks of certain American newspapers on Russia was the main subject discussed.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 1. -- A Russian correspondent of The Associated Press at Shanghai telegraphs that it is reported at Tien-Tsin that 4,000 additional Chinese soldiers have been posted in Northern China, and that the Chinese Government has recently placed large orders for guns and ammunition.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1. -- This has been a day of golf and water entertainment. There was widespread interest in the golf matches of Misses Mabel Higgins and Grace Ellis, and there were many sailing parties, especially evening parties. The chief of the evening parties was the moonlight sail given to their seventeen dinner guests by Mr. and Mrs. Newbold Leroy Edgar.

It is impossible to take the amazing speech of Mr. DALZELL in the House on Monday as anything but a challenge to the tariff reformers in the Republican Party to abandon their ideas or quit the party. And we see no reason to suppose that this brutal challenge does not represent the dominant sentiment in the party, that is to say, a sentiment which the leaders can count on in the convention.

Our readers will recall the Peking dispatches of THE TIMES before the war was certain, recounting the elements of the military strength of Russia and fixing her actual force in Manchuria at not over 180,000.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Gov. Odell has been summoned to Washington by President Roosevelt. He will leave Albany Friday, and probably will remain at the National capital until Monday. The President did not tell the Governor the object of his summons, and Mr. Odell to-night was disinclined to speculate on the subject.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Leader Williams of the Democratic side called poetry to his aid to-day in the House in his campaign on the tariff and reciprocity issues and satirized Senator Quarles in prose and verse for his recent protection speech at Boston. After he had poked fun in prose at Mr. Dalzell for the latter's official exposition of the Republican reciprocity yesterday, he said:

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- The Columbia basket ball team defeated the University of Pennsylvania five in an Intercollegiate League championship game, played in the First Regiment Armory before a large crowd to-night, by a score of 23 points to 12. The victory assures to Columbia the championship of the league, the team having a clean record of victories.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The monthly comparative statement of the Government receipts and expenditures show that for the month of February, 1904, the total receipts were $45,805,406 and the expenditures $42,634,772, leaving a surplus for the month of $3,240,634. The receipts not only exceed those of February a year ago, but also those of January of this year by more than $4,000,000.

Charles W. Morse, the financier whose matrimonial tangle with the wife of Charles F. Dodge has resulted in court proceedings in many States, was chosen yesterday as one of the panel of forty-eight men from which twenty-three will be selected to act as Grand Jurors for the month of March.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Like Lord Bacon, who some say would not own up to writing the plays of Shakespeare because it would ruin his reputation as a philosopher to be known as a poet, Senator Spooner has always studiously avoided gaining a reputation as a wit because he would rather be known as a lawyer.

The occurrence of a general conflagration in Rochester, recalling that of Baltimore and so closely following it, will doubtless give a powerful impetus to the movement to furnish New York an auxiliary salt water supply for fire protection, street washing, sewer flushing, snow melting, and other purposes requiring water in large quantities, and for which it is assumed that salt water would answer as well as fresh water at much less cost.

"A hold-up" is the vigorous and expressive and substantially accurate term by which the late WILLIAM H. VANDERBILT was used to describe the process of securing differential rates against New York in the transportation of freight on the trunk lines. The actual basis of the rule that compelled New York to pay higher rates was the simple fact that freight could be brought to this port at less cost than to the outports.

MOSCOW, March 2. -- Among thoughtful Russians there is a deepening apprehension of the prospect of Russia's having to encounter the combined opposition of the yellow races, despite the cunning Chinese and Korean declarations of neutrality.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The British Ambassador had a conference with Secretary Hay this afternoon, and it is believed that the question of what is contraband of war was the principal theme. It is probable the Governments of Great Britain and the United States will endeavor to formulate a declaration that will tend to remove points that are in dispute and others that are likely to arise.

ALBANY, March 1. -- The fiercest snowstorm of the season swept over the upper part of this State last night. High winds and heavy snowfalls are reported from all points, and the railroad service for several hours was practically paralyzed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 1. -- The ballotting in the Senate and House to-day insures the formal election of Gen. Charles Dick at the joint session of the Legislature to-morrow to succeed the late Marcus A. Hanna as United States Senator from Ohio.

Prof. Toyokichi Iyenaga, a lecturer on Oriental political science in Chicago University, gave an address last night at the smoker of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District Republican Club, in the Sixth Avenue clubrooms, on "Japan, Old and New." He referred to the war during the lecture. When told about the universal Japanese habit of taking a bath every day, he said that in that respect his countrymen were in marked contrast to the Chinese.

The Easter egg for the children is being brought out in elaborate forms and there are even "Easter egg Christmas trees." These are gift trees, umbrella shaped, from which hang a number of fancy eggs each containing little presents of some kind.
PARIS, March 2. -- M. Hanotaux, ex-Minister of Foreign Affairs, has an article in the Petite Gironde on the Far Eastern policy of the United States.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1. -- The defeat of Floral King, a topheavy favorite in the third race to-day, was a blow to his owner's aspirations in the Crescent City Derby. The colt, always favorite in the betting, led for the greater part of the distance, but failed to respond in the final pinch.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 1. -- Before Judge Jeremiah Tierney, the Rev. A.M. Conway of Yonkers recovered judgment for $157 back salary against the First Baptist Church here. The Rev. Mr. Conway served the church from March, 1902, for a year. The church was struggling, and he accepted a salary of $35 to preach once a Sunday.

Serious difficulties have been encountered by several city departments owing to the incomplete state of the new Hall of Records, which will prevent the Finance Department, the Corporation Counsel's office, and the Register's office from being moved into the building for another year. All the departments in question expected to be housed in the building by the 1st of May, and lease troubles are the result.

Evidence that Senator Patrick H. McCarren will encounter some opposition in pledging the Kings County delegation to the support of Judge Parker as the candidate of the Democratic Party for the Presidency was given at the meeting of the General Committee held in the Jefferson Building, Brooklyn, last night.

LONDON, March 2. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says a report is current that a syndicate of Paris banks, headed by a large and well-known concern, has opened a credit account of considerable importance to Russia, to be drawn in installments. The price of the issue is said to be 92, with 5 per cent. interest.

LONDON, March 1. -- Money was easy, in fair demand, and abundant in the market to-day, $18,750,000 in dividends having been distributed. Discounts were barely steady. A nervous feeling prevailed on the Stock Exchange as to the outcome of the Paris settlement, operators in all directions being unwilling to commit themselves.

Referring to the article in to-day's TIMES headed "Senators Score Mr. McKim," I am moved to observe that Mr. McKim need not be surprised that his labors in the reconstruction of the White House and the planning of a superb scheme for the development of Washington should be made the subject of attack by certain Senators.

Corporation Counsel Delany yesterday instituted replevin proceedings and took possession of sixty manuscript volumes of public records, comprising the original rough minutes of the Common Council, 1809 to 1831, and of the Board of Aldermen, 1831 to 1847. These old records have been missing for some time, and were recently offered for sale by a dealer in old books, who claimed that he could support his title to them by purchase through a junk dealer.

NEWARK, N.J., March 1. -- Ex-United States Senator James Smith, Jr., has purchased the patent and enamel leather establishment of T.P. Howell Co., located at New, Nuttman, and Wilsey Streets, this city. The deal, which has been pending for several weeks, was consummated last night. The exact terms are not made public.

The article signed "New Yorker," in the issue of the 22d inst., meets with the approval of a majority of the members of the New York Bar. It may not be amiss to state that Senator Elsberg has presented a bill in the Legislature to increase the salaries of the Municipal Court Justices from $6,000 to $7,500 per annum.

Years ago Albert G.E. Kribs, then a resident of Germany, took unto himself a wife, and, failing to achieve the bliss he had anticipated, cast about for a method of loosening himself from the ties which he had assumed. The wife, according to Kribs, was on record to the effect that if her husband was ever convicted of a crime she would secure a divorce from him.
The three-platoon police system with which Commissioner McAdoo would "triple rivet the lid" he is trying to keep down went into effect yesterday morning at 8 o'clock.

An original entertainment by amateurs was given last evening at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Hammond, in East Ninety-first Street, for the benefit of the kindergarten of Hartley House, in West Forty-sixth Street. It was a late entertainment, beginning about 10 o'clock, and was completed about midnight, when refreshments were served.

An annual afternoon tea party began at the Masonic Temple, corner of Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, and the regular occupants of the building, recognizing the buzz of feminine voices, knew that the Dressmakers' Protective Association was again in session.

Five men returning from a party attempted to regulate the schedule of the Union Railway Company to suit themselves at an early hour yesterday, and, failing in their effort, inaugurated hostilities which raged at Westchester Avenue and Southern Boulevard until they assumed the proportions of a riot and necessitated the calling out of the police reserves.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday continued under the influence of the foreign situation. The Berlin settlement developed nothing unfavorable, and the Paris settlement nothing worse than the artificiality already noted as being strongest there where it has been expected least.

A number of Inspectors from the Health Department, accompanied by William H. Walker of the Bureau of Public Buildings, made a tour of inspection of the City Hall yesterday to see what it needs to place it upon a sanitary basis. They found the plumbing in very bad condition -- so bad, it is said, that if it were not the headquarters of the City Government certain portions of the building would be closed.

The declared purpose of the Board of Health rigorously to enforce, without further consideration for offenders, the ordinance which forbids spitting in vehicles and public places, will commend itself to all right-minded people who respect themselves and have a proper respect for others.

Appraiser Whitehead was considerably exercised yesterday over the charge made by importers that Assistant Appraiser Hartshorn had arbitrarily advanced the duty on linen scrim from 45 to 60 per cent. Mr. Whitehead issued the following statement:

MINEOLA, L.I., March 2. -- Harry Payne Whitney, executor of the late William C. Whitney, yesterday filed with the Surrogate of Nassau County a provisional estimate of the value of the estate liable to taxation in this State.

The Greater New York Baseball Club will not be allowed to play Sunday games at Ridgewood Park. This will be the decision of Chairman August Herrmann of the National Commission, which will be officially announced at the meetings of the National and American Leagues to-day. Chairman Herrmann takes the stand that the playing of the Greater New Yorks at Ridgewood Park would do the Brooklyn Club a serious injury.

Nothing worth discussing happened upon the Stock Exchange yesterday, but why this was so is well worth consideration. Foreign markets and conditions lost much of their primacy in favor of domestic factors. We have begun to lose currency to the interior, and we are shipping gold to Argentina, but the call money market is a shade weaker, while first-class borrowers pay 5 per cent. on time money.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 2. -- Hill and McCarren will not take issue with Tammany Leader Murphy at the meeting of the State Committee Saturday upon the question of instructing for Judge Parker. Senator McCarren made this announcement to-day. He said he saw no good purpose to be served by a fight to commit the State Committee to Judge Parker's candidacy.

Authoritative information from Cleveland shows that city to be fighting a typhoid epidemic, already serious and daily gaining headway. It had attained the importance of 68 cases in one day on the first of the present month, and the official returns for February show 465 cases reported and 45 deaths.
LONDON, March 2. -- Orders were issued to-day to dispatch 2,000 troops to reinforce the British garrison at Malta.

Mme. Nordica, who is not singing in opera this season, has been moved to return to some of her favorite parts in Wagner's music dramas, so far as it is possible for her to do so upon the concert stage. She has arranged a series of what she calls "Wagner recitals" with the New York Symphony Orchestra, under Mr. Walter Damrosch's direction, the first of which she gave yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 2. -- William A. Wright, a prominent resident of Freeport, L.I., committed suicide by hanging last night. He was discovered when his housekeeper tried to call him this morning. He had tied a cord about his neck, fastened it to the hinge of the door, and thus strangled himself.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2. -- The Morris filly Viperine won her second stake at the meeting to-day, when she galloped home two lengths in front of her field in the Premier Stakes, worth $1,090 to the winner. Sweet Pepper was a strong favorite at evens, backed down from 3 to 2, while Viperine's price receded from twos to fours.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 2. -- An official dispatch received from Major Gen. Pflug, Viceroy Alexieff's Chief of Staff, dated March 2, says:

AUSTIN, Texas, March 2. -- Daniel Cushing, a brother of E.B. Cushing, Superintendent of Maintenance of Way of the Southern Pacific Railroad, was kidnapped last night at a remote point in West Texas by a band of Mexican brigands.

Conferences between Charles F. Murphy and several up-State Democratic leaders at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon and last night resulted in at least five more State Committeemen coming into the Tammany Hall camp. All three committeemen from Erie County -- John J. Kennedy, W.H. Fitzpatrick, and Henry Burgard -- will be with Murphy at the meeting in Albany on Saturday, whereas only two had been counted on the day before.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 2. -- Two apparent attempts were made early, this morning to burn the Morristown School, on the Whippany Road, just outside the city limits, in Morris Township. During the excitement caused by the fires some one entered the office in the main building and stole from the cash drawer in the safe about $600 in money.

MONTE CARLO, March 2. -- The semifinal round of the international chess tournament was played in the Sporting Club today, when Marshall went down before Marco in the Jasnogrodsky variation. Swiderski played against Fleischmann, winning in fine style.

ALBANY, March 2. -- District Attorney Jerome let out more interesting gambling secrets at the hearing to-day before the Assembly Codes Committee on the bill prepared by him compelling witnesses to testify in gambling cases when assured of immunity from prosecution.

George Chittenden Smyth, a grandson of the late Gov. George Chittenden of Vermont, and a member of the firm of Cathrall Smyth of 395 Broadway, committed suicide some time Tuesday night by shooting himself in the head. Mr. Smyth's business, that of a selling agent for cotton woolen yarns, has not been paying of late, and this is believed to be the reason for his act.

R.C. Leonard of Central Valley, N.Y., won the fly-casting competition yesterday at the Sportsmen's Show in Madison Square Garden. The contest was with half-ounce bait for distance and accuracy, each contestant casting at two goals set respectively 60 and 80 feet from the casting mark. Leonard, who is the present champion, won with a total score in points of 175.5.

In Germany they deal with the reckless chauffeur afflicted with motormania in a very practical manner. In the Reichstag one day last week Prince SCHOENAICH-CAROLATH called upon the Government to introduce a bill placing automobilists under the provisions of the statute of 1871, fixing the terms of imprisonment for those committing assaults or manslaughter through carelessness on the public thoroughfares.

It is more than three years since Wall Street had as quiet a day in the stock market as yesterday was. Everywhere the chief topic of conversation in brokerage offices was the lifelessness of the market -- there was little else to discuss in offices where no business was being done, and these were in vast majority.

The letter of your correspondent, Harold Berman, leads me to wonder, not for the first time, what peculiar quality exists in Russia which compels her assailants invariably to take refuge in rhetoric when facts would do just as well, if not better. Why do these gentlemen always assume that whatever is peculiar in Russian life is necessarily wrong?
PARIS, March 2. -- Gil Bias publishes an article referring to the revision of the Dreyfus case, which begins to-morrow in the Criminal Chamber of the Court of Cassation.

ALBANY, March 2. -- The condition of every fire and marine insurance company and Lloyd aggregation doing business in New York State on Feb. 23 that was affected by the Baltimore fire loss is shown in a series of tables given out by the State Insurance Department to-day. These figures were collected by the department on the request of State Superintendent Hendricks for a sworn statement from each company as to its Baltimore loss.

The proceedings to test the original Dodge divorce case will commence to-morrow at the offices of William G. Davies, the referee appointed Tuesday by Justice Truax. Both sides have expressed a willingness to have the testimony taken in public, but this will not be finally decided until to-day.

There was a stormy session of first mortgage bondholders of the Standard Rope and Twine Company yesterday afternoon in response to the call of the Manhattan Trust Company, trustee under the mortgage, to give the bondholders' protective committee, composed of William Alexander Smith, G.W. Montgomery, and G.T. Bonner, an opportunity to air their grievances.

From fear of the clandestine introduction of possibly a few thousand Chinese laborers or mechanics our Government is deliberately employing injury and insult toward all other classes of Chinese that directly imperils trade to the amount of millions and repels trade of still greater value.
Jastrow Alexander, State Inspector of Gas Meters, issued an open letter to the public yesterday, in which he said:

MIDDLETOWN, N,Y., March 2. -- Two large real estate deals were consummated in Orange County this week, in which New York City people were the purchasers. Ex-Representative Henry Bacon, as referee, sold land in Cornwall and New Windsor, aggregating nearly 500 acres, to Franklin H. Head of New York City for $29,000.

FREEHOLD, N.J., March 2. -- Albert C. Twining and D.C. Cornell, President and Treasurer, respectively, of the defunct Monmouth Trust and Safe Deposit Company of Asbury Park, were convicted to-day. They were accused of having presented a false minute of a meeting of Directors on Feb. 9, in which the purchase, unauthorized the State claimed, of $30,000 of bonds, purported to have been sanctioned.

ALBANY, March 2. -- The Sub-Committee on Home Rule, of which Senator Elsberg is Chairman, met to-day and listened to a statement from Mr. Elsberg, who has been making an examination of the New York City charter with a view to ascertaining just what home rule New York now enjoys and what more it would be advisable for the Legislature to grant.

Goldman, Sachs Co. yesterday arranged for the shipment of $250,000 gold to Argentine, and other shipments, in addition to the $500,000 previously arranged for by Muller, Schall Co., were said to be likely. The $750,000 which it has already been decided to ship will go by next Monday's steamer, and it is possible that before the day of sailing the amount may be increased.

We hear from so many sources that Chinese troops are moving into Manchuria from the adjoining provinces that it is difficult to discredit the reports. That the reports are credited at Moscow and St. Petersburg is a fact of curious significance, even if the reports themselves should turn out to be untrue.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The end of the negotiations for the title to the Panama Canal property is in sight. Within thirty days, perhaps in shorter time, the United States will be in full possession of the property and the money consideration will have been paid to both the Republic of Panama and to the new Panama Canal Company.

Gibbs Kirby have sold for Boehm Coon 230 to 238 West Seventy-sixth Street, southwest corner of Broadway, a five-story apartment house, with four dwellings adjoining, on a plot fronting 77.4 feet on Broadway and 94.9 feet on the street. The property has been held at $250,000, and the present selling price is said to be close to that figure.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Pension Commissioner Ware, the poet laureate of the Administration, has written a poem for the celebration of Kansas's semi-centennial at Topeka on May 30. The Kansans expect that President Roosevelt and Secretary Taft will be present. Mr. Ware's poem is to be set to music and sung by the Topeka Choral Society at the ceremony.
The increase in the earnings of the Southern Railway at a time when decreases are beginning to be general excited some favorable comment in Wall Street yesterday. The earnings show:

ALBANY, March 2. -- Bills introduced in the interest of the Interurban Street Railway Company were denounced to-day at the hearing on them before the Assembly Railroads Committee as "grab" measures. Representatives of nearly fifty public organizations and Assistant Corporation Counsel Charles L. Guy, on behalf of New York City, appeared in opposition to the bills.

O.S. Eldridge of the Polytechnic Preparatory School won the one-mile Class A handicap skating race last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn. Eldridge had 90 yards start on Phil Kearney of the New York Athletic Club, who was on scratch. Kearney fell after going 100 yards.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- A row in the Democratic cloakroom to-day was prevented from ending in a fist fight by Representative Champ Clark of Missouri. He dragged Representative Charles F. Cochran of the same State out of the room.

LONDON, March 3. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that Gen. Dragomiroff, ex-Governor General of Kieff and a well-known military authority, was summoned to St. Petersburg to take part in the deliberations in regard to the conduct of the war.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- So far as the House is concerned, the present plan for a new Post Office in New York was blocked to-day in a sensational manner, after an unexpected scene in the room of the Committee on Appropriations. This result was effected by two members of the New York delegation, Messrs Douglas and Dunwell.

The giant steel skeleton of the Darlington Apartment Hotel, which since last Fall has been in process of erection on the north side of Forty-sixth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, collapsed at 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon without warning, carrying with it nearly every one of the workmen engaged on the ten stories that had been raised.

The plans for the merger of the Mechanics' National Bank and the Leather Manufacturers' National Bank are now practically complete, and will be mailed to stockholders within the next few days. It is understood that the combined bank will have a capital of $3,000,000, surplus of $3,000,000, and undivided profits of about $300,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The inquiry which is based on the effort to unseat Senator Smoot of Utah because of his connection with the Mormon Church opened in earnest to-day with Joseph F. Smith, the head of the Mormon Church, as the first witness. The room of the Senate Committee on Elections was not uncomfortably crowded, most of those present as spectators being witnesses from Utah.

The American Society of Civil Engineers last evening, by a vote of 1,139 to 662, decided not to become one of the constituent societies in the occupancy and control of the proposed Union Engineering Building, for the erection of which Andrew Carnegie has promised to give $1,500,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2. -- Stockholders of both the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and the Fairhaven and Westville Railroad Company, which controls all the trolley lines in New Haven, stated to-day that a deal by which the former company acquires the latter has been practically completed.
The statement of your correspondent "F.H." in last Friday's TIMES that "we all know Mme. Ternina's Brunnhilde" will assuredly not be endorsed by the great majority of the operagoers.

Baron Suyematsu, son-in-law of Marquis Ito, and ex-Minister of the Interior of Japan and now Minister of Communication, reached this city on his way to England yesterday. He left Yokahoma on Feb. 10, and came hence from Seattle by the Great Northern route to this city. He is to sail for England on a Cunard liner on Saturday.

Somehow a story got about yesterday to the effect that the Government of Santo Domingo or some faction in that island had offered the managers of the St. Louis Exposition the use as an exhibit of the remains of Christopher Columbus against the payment of a sum of $100,000.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2. -- In celebration of the finish of the women's champion golf tournament a golf ball was given at the Breakers to-night. The decorations were golf utensils. The great piazza at the Breakers was illuminated in a subdued manner, and there in the moonlight supper was served at midnight. The ball was largely attended.

Summoned to the bedside of her fiance, Hobart Moore, who is dangerously ill with consumption at Saranac Lake, Miss Ruth Emmons of this city last Sunday became the wife of her betrothed, although relatives and physicians fear that he can live only a few days at most.

Harry Fisher, manager of the Columbia basket ball team, yesterday received a letter from Walter G. Deering, manager of the five of the University of Minnesota, challenging the local players to a series of games for the National intercollegiate championship. Columbia, by defeating the University of Pennsylvania on Tuesday night, has a clean record of eight games won and none lost, and now has the championship of the Eastern colleges won.

The progress of the campaign seems already to have brought to light the chief weakness of the Japanese Army in comparison with the Russian, its lack of an efficient cavalry. The Japanese infantry may be the nearest approach in the world to "foot cavalry," as "Stonewall" JACKSON'S command was admiringly called.

Two lawyers -- Charles Stein of 320 Broadway and Randolph M. Newman of 132 Nassau Street -- engaged in a heated dispute in the Supreme Court yesterday, and the upshot of it was that Mr. Newman struck Mr. Stein a hard blow in the face. Lawyer Stein hastened into Part II., Special Term, and exclaimed to Justice MacLean:

Word was received in Jersey City yesterday that the State Court of Errors and Appeals had affirmed the decision of Vice Chancellor Pitney ordering Miss Annie Teppin to reconvey to Mrs. Mary Collins, or her legal representative, two buildings known as "The Florida Flats,' 'at Barrow and York Streets, Jersey City, valued at $85,000.

In connection with this agitation for an improved fire fighting service I will venture another suggestion. It will be necessary for successful operation that the water pressure be constant and equal at every point in the mains.

Representatives of the National and American Baseball Leagues practically completes yesterday the business for which they were called together early in the week, all that remains being the adoption of a schedule by the National organization. This will be done at a brief session to-day at the Hotel Victoria.

Sweeping along at a rate varying from forty to sixty miles an hour, a gale created havoc in the city last night and also caused injury to three persons by the blowing down of some window boarding from a building in course of construction at Fourteenth Street and Sixth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Charges that anti-saloon agitators had been guilty of using Government franked envelopes for the circulation of literature designed to create sentiment in favor of a bill to prevent the admission of sealed packages containing liquors in Prohibition States or counties were made to the House Judiciary Committee to-day.

ANNAPOLIS, March 3. -- The Democratic organization measure, a proposed amendment to the State Constitution to regulate the suffrage and admittedly designed to eliminate the negro vote, was passed in the State Senate to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Society was well represented this evening at the "Parsifal" recital by Walter Damrosch in the Lafayette Square Opera House in aid of the Citizens' Relief Association and Firemen's Fund. Mrs. Roosevelt who occupied a box, had as her guests Mrs. Hitchcock, Mrs. Lawrence of Massachusetts, Miss Tuckerman, and Miss Hagner.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- William J. O'Brien, an insane discharged soldier, until recently confined in St. Elizabeth's Asylum, entered the War Department this morning, and, going to the Mail and Record Division, drew a revolver and shot Robert J. Manning, a messenger, and Arthur Wiecker, a clerk.
ALBANY, March 3. -- The Senate Committee to-day gave a hearing on Senator Armstrong's bill forbiding the docking of horses' tails, and advocates and opponents of the measure were heard.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 3. -- During the last forty-eight hours David B. Hill has been marshaling his forces in all parts of the State to determine just what his strength will be in the State Committee at the meeting on Saturday.

Intent on clinching control of the Democratic State Committee at its meeting in Albany to-morrow, Charles F. Murphy within the last forty-eight hours has brought every bit of power to bear on Senator Patrick H. McCarren to induce the Brooklyn leader to abandon David B. Hill and the Parker boom and to stand with Tammany Hall.

Your readers have recently heard so much in regard to Tammany Hall and its determination to push either Judge Parker or your admirable Mayor McClellan for the next Presidential nomination that the official announcement of Tammany's boom for ex-President Cleveland has almost taken the breath away from many of us, and we are instinctively asking, Can it be true?

ALBANY, March 3. -- Gov. Odell will take the chairmanship of the State Committee. He does not want to be National Chairman, and even if the President should urge him to accept that place he will decline the offer.

-- "Mayor McCLELLAN, it is understood, is much incensed at the discussion that has been brought about by this affair." The "affair" to which reference is made in this quotation from our local columns is that of Park Commissioner PALLAS and the Fifth Avenue billboards, but unfortunately our information leaves us in uncertainty as to the object of the Mayor's indignation.
WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Postmaster General Payne to-day admitted that it had been decided to reopen the case of Postmaster Van Cott of New York City.

CHICAGO, March 3. -- Wholesale dumping of May wheat by tired holders caused a break of 4 cents in the price of that delivery to-day. Just before the close the price had fallen to 96 3/4 cents, as against $1.00 3/4 earlier in the day.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3. -- Vice Chancellor Stevenson has appointed Frank P. McDermott receiver for the New York Garage Company of 140 West Fifty-eighth Street, New York City. Peter Fogarty of New York alleged that the liabilities of the concern were $7,198.88 and the assets $9,163.36.

BOSTON, March 3. -- Wallace H. Ham, until recently manager of the Boston branch of the American Surety Company of New York, to-day waived examination on two charges alleging the larceny of funds, and was held in $65,000 for the Grand Jury. Bail was not furnished.

DULUTH, Minn., March 1. -- Chief Wakem-up of the Chippewa band, residing in the territory traversed by the Duluth, Virginia and Northern Minnesota Road, has put in a verbal bill against the railroad company for $20 for a dog which was killed by Henry Starkey of the surveying crew working ahead of the construction.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Remarkable instances of Prince Lieut. Prosper von Arenberg's abnormal cruelty were mentioned by witnesses to-day during an inquiry into his sanity. The Prince is serving a term of imprisonment for murdering a native while commander of a station in German Southwest Africa, where he is said to have been guilty of many cruelties to natives.

Bituminous coal, the market for which had been in a stagnant condition for many months, felt a revival a couple of weeks ago, since which time prices have advanced rapidly. Producers say that this week there has been an advance of fully 25 cents ton.
Joseph Mandelkern has sold for Morris Littman to Tax Commissioner Samuel Strasbourger the plot, 75 by 100, at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Ninety-sixth Street.

District Attorney Jerome received a telegram yesterday from Frank G. Howland, Treasurer of the Adirondack Trust Company of Saratoga, which caused him some amusement. In it he is chided for his remarks before the Assembly Codes Committee on Wednesday concerning certain banking companies, unnamed by him, which were alleged to have handled checks of well-known gamblers.

PARIS, March 3. -- The Criminal Branch of the Court of Cassation was crowded today, when the hearing on the application of ex-Capt. Alfred Dreyfus for a revision of the sentence of the Rennes court-martial was begun.

DALLAS, Texas, March 3. -- Capt. O. Paget of Dallas, commanding Troop B, First Cavalry, Texas National Guards, to-day received a letter from a high Japanese official in the United States in which is stated concisely the attitude of Japan toward the proposed American recruits for her army. Capt. Paget had organized a regiment of 860 rough riders from Texas and Indian Territory, and tendered its services to the Emperor of Japan through his representative.

Ex-President Cleveland's address to the Democracy in a recent number of The Philadelphia Saturday Evening Post again concentrates public attention upon him in a very remarkable manner, in such manner, indeed, as to confirm the belief that the rank and file of the Democracy would like to vote for Mr. Cleveland for the Presidency again.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- In the course of the discussion of the Naval Appropriation bill in the Senate to-day Mr. Hale said there was talk of putting many of the vessels, such as the Oregon, Indiana, and others of the same class on the retired list.

The second concert in the "Strauss Festival" at Carnegie Hall attracted a small audience, although there were on the programme three highly contrasted works of the composer's later period. They were the "orchestral fantasia," as he styles it, on the subject of "Don Juan," of Lenau's German poem, the vast and complex "Don Quixote," "fantastical variations on a theme of a knightly character" and the "tone poem," "Death and Transfiguration."

Shortly before the late Col. Waring left for Havana he sent for me through his brother-in-law, Mr. W.S. Blunt, to explain to him fully my plan for using river water for fire, street flushing, and bathing purposes. Of all the men in public life to whom I have spoken of my plan Col. Waring was the only one who grasped my idea, favored and understood it.

YIN-KOW, March 3. -- On account of the impossibility of defending the coast at Yin-Kow until such time as a thaw permits the construction of intrenchments and forts the Russians have prepared to retire up the main railroad line.

In relation to the statements by your correspondent in to-day's issue, the whole world knows too well what sort of a Government Russia represents, and how she treats her subjects, and neither pretty words nor stories that bear their mark upon them will help convince to the contrary.

It is believed that the Commissioner of Pensions is not proud of the poetic fame of "Ironquill," and, indeed, views the celebration of himself in his character of the laureate of the Great American Desert with apprehension-and alarm. One can readily understand that, not merely in his transient official capacity, but in his permanent capacity of a "serious" lawyer, Mr. WARE may object to being confronted with the outgivings of his candid and hilarious muse.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- There was one hearty outburst of laughter to-day in the Smoot trial. President Smith had said that ex-Apostle Moses Thatcher differed from the other leaders of the Mormon Church and wanted' to go into politics against their judgment and advice.

NAGASAKI, March 3. -- Some of the Japanese refugees from Port Arthur to whom passage was given on The Times's steamer, Hai-Mun from Wei-hai-Wei, give a piteous description of the suffering and indignities inflicted on their countrymen by the Russian soldiery.
NEW ORLEANS, March 3. -- Favorites had the best of the day's racing and the books fared badly. Blue Victor and Count 'Em Out were the only beaten favorites. Weather clear and track fast. Summaries:

Impatient at the delays in carrying out plans to run cars over the Williamsburg Bridge, and at the further delay promised in the Rapid Transit Commission to the plan of Commissioner Best to connect the bridges, Mayor McClellan yesterday ordered Commissioner Best to arrange at once for the construction of a temporary car station at the Manahttan terminal of the new bridge.

MONTE CARLO, March 3. -- The final round of the international Rice gambit chess tournament was played in this city to-day, and when the results became known Fleischmann had gone down before Marshall, Marco before Mieses, and Scheve before Swiderski, the three winners having played the Jasnogrodsky variation, namely, 11 -- Castles; 12 -- RxB, QxP; 13 -- RxKt.,

CITY OF MEXICO, Feb. 20. -- John Butner, a wealthy resident of Montana, has asked permission of the Mexican Government to establish an astronomical observatory on the top of Popocatapeti. In his petition he states that he will bear all expenses attendant on the establishment of the observatory, and will allow the Government to conduct investigations there.

The collapse of the Darlington Apartment Hotel, in course of construction, conceals no mystery. Speculation as to whether the small boiler in the cellar operating the hoisting apparatus exploded or did not explode is unimportant. Had it exploded, the greatest damage which should have resulted might have been repaired for a few hundreds of dollars.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- Admission by Joseph F. Smith, President of the Mormon Church, that to an extent the hierarchy exercises control over political actions of its leaders was one of the features of the Smoot inquiry before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day.

While a definite move will not be taken for some time to come, it is learned that a number of the leading trust companies now clearing through the Clearing House under arrangement with member banks are pretty sure to make a vigorous protest against the regulation increasing the reserve from 7 1/2 per cent. to 10 per cent., due to go into effect June 1 under the existing plan.

Three separate investigations were started yesterday to fix the blame for the collapse of the skeleton frame of the Darlington apartment hotel, in West Forty-sixth Street, on Wednesday afternoon. District Attorney Jerome, Borough President Ahearn, who has direct charge of the Bureau of Buildings, and Coroner Scholer, each was at work on the case, but little had been accomplished by the close of the day in determining the cause of the disaster.

LAWTON, Oklahoma, March 3. -- For hours to-night 5,000 persons fought a great prairie fire which threatened this city. The advance line of the fire was fully two miles in length and came in a semi-circular form. A thousand men turned their efforts to checking the grass borders of the reservation at the city limits.

The most natural question to arise in the discussion of the severity of the past Winter is its influence upon the public health. This is a question difficult to answer. An average of one or two, or even of five or ten, degrees below the normal Winter average would probably not of itself swell the death rate appreciably.

Charles Lasek, a man who had been alive in the ruins of the Hotel Darlington, in West Forty-sixth Street, was taken from the debris at 2:30 o'clock this morning by the force of men who had been working to get at the bodies of the victims who had gone down with the building when it collapsed on Wednesday at 1:30 o'clock.

The announcement that Solomonson, the man who lives on fruits, flowers, and vegetables, would discuss his return to nature attracted a variety of interested folk to the Cosmological Centre, at 36 West Twenty-seventh Street, last night. The lecturer appeared at 8 o'clock with shaggy beard and flowing locks. He was thinly clad in a robe of flimsy material, girdled at the waist.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., March 3.--Patrick Goulding, an aged war veteran and watchman at a railroad crossing in Greylock, has returned from a peculiar trip to Rhode Island, where he turned over to an old comrade whom he had not seen since the civil war, a goodly sum of money, with interest added, which the comrade had given to him on the battlefield to keep for him.
I have studied with great interest the Naval Appropriation bill just presented, and desire to draw the attention of our fellow-citizens to it.

To all intents and purposes the stock market yesterday was as dull as it had been the previous day, the total being within a couple of thousand of shares of the previous day's figures, just enough to save a new low record. Brokers on the floor have become thoroughly disgusted with the situation, and are impatiently waiting for the turn in the market that will bring with it some semblance of activity.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., March 3. -- Entrapped in a dark room, three officers who were trying to arrest Sherman Jamison, near Renova last night, were the victims of a cowardly attack by Jamison and his wife. As a result Constable Joseph Deegan is dying at the Lock Haven Hospital with three bullet wounds in his body, and two other officers, Constables Meyers and Swartz, are wounded.

An unusually large number of contestants in the home trainer events that are being held at the Sportsmen's Show in Madison Square Garden appeared for the trial heats last night. Nine one-mile heats were run off in the competition for the inter-club one-mile championship. The events were held in the concert room, where the bicycle exhibit is placed.

The affairs of the American Ice Company took a new turn yesterday, when it became known that I.O. Blake, a Director of the company and one of the local managers at a salary under the existing regime of $10,000 a year, had succeeded, without waiting for the outcome of the annual meeting, to start a rival concern, to be known as the Crystal Ice Company.

LONDON, March 4. -- The Paris edition of The New York Herald publishes a report from Che-Foo to the effect that six Japanese cruisers, escorting ten transports, have been seen steaming in -- the direction of the Gulf of Liao-Tung.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3. -- The deal whereby the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad will acquire the street railway lines of the Fair Haven and Westville Railroad was officially confirmed tonight. Sufficient stock has been pledged to make the deal a certainty.

MOSCOW, March 3. -- M. Arkounin, an actor, who has returned here from Port Arthur, was an eye witness of events there prior to the outbreak of war. He had been informed that the Chinese would begin celebrating the new year by setting off fireworks and shooting guns, so when firing was heard for the first time from the sea it was supposed to be the Chinese celebration.

For twelve hours yesterday New York was wrapped in a bank of fog such as has not veiled the city for almost seventeen years. At times so thick was the cloud that traffic of all kinds was paralyzed, while shipping was at a standstill. Four collisions with ferryboats on the North and East Rivers were reported.
BERLIN, March 3. -- Emperor William, upon the request of Ambassador Tower, has pardoned Edward Engesser of Buffalo, N.Y., sentenced some time ago at Baden, for desertion, to six months' imprisonment.

Of the round dozen of remedies suggested by the Committee on the Law's Delay for the evil of the vast accumulations of untried cases on the calendars of the courts in New York and Kings Counties, one has been embodied in the form of a bill introduced by Senator ELSBERG on Jan. 27.

The trading stamp craze which prevails in Brooklyn has at last extended to the local burglars Early yesterday morning two thieves broke into the store at 1,384 Broadway, that borough, and made off with 5,000 trading stamps, taking nothing else.

Gen. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers overruled a protest yesterday by B. Illfeider Co. of New York against the assessment of 45 per cent. duty on metal boxes in fancy shapes as manufactures of metal. The importers claimed that they were toys at 35 per cent.

It would be impossible to say just what one really does think of Mr. Bran Stokers "The Jewel of Seven Stars." It is one of those books that challenge the opinion by their very interest. Who dares say that a book has weak points in face of the fact that from the moment he begins to read it he is loath to drop it until the last page?

PATERSONS, N.J., March 4. -- Joseph C. Patterson was Treasurer of General Grant Commandery, Knights of Malta, and a member of the Board of Trustees having charge of Malta Hall, on Market Street. He was a Past Grand Commander in the organization and prominent politically in the Fifth Ward.

The March number of The Bookman, of this city, contains an article by Yoni Noguchi entitled "What English Books Are Known in Japan." He first names certain school reading books. Translations of "Self-Help" by Samuel Smiles, the "Sketch Book" of Washington Irving. Gray's "Elegy," and Goldsmith's "Deserted Village" have long been popular. Longfellow's "Evangeline" has been used as a school textbook twenty years.

There will be no sale of the Whitney horses. The place of the late W.C. Whitney on the Eastern turf will be taken by his son, Harry Payne Whitney, who will keep intact the stable left by his father. "Willie" Shaw will do the riding, and Trainer John W. Rogers will be continued in power. These statements will settle much of the uncertainty which has existed regarding the future of this important stable.

Superintendent James Dunphy of the Gravesend track was yesterday notified that part of E.R. Thomas's string would arrive early next week and take possession of the stable which has been reserved. It is probable that Hermis will come with the list. The Thomas star is reported to have wintered well, and is much further along than he was this time last year.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Senator Scott was advocating increased pensions for soldiers who had lost their eyesight in the service. In the course of his speech he pointed out that the soldier who loses both legs in the service gets a pension of $100 a month. He argued that the man who had lost both eyes was certainly as much entitled to that rate as the may, who had lost both legs.

The letters in your columns discussing correct English have interested me very much, and I was pleased to see "Boston Yankee's" reply to Frances Fisher Byers, as I have lived in Boston for several years and have heard the purest English always spoken by the educated people there.

As if tired of the monotony that it had shown for several days, the stock market yesterday revived a little from its previous, apathy and succeeded in showing a total that fell only a few thousand shares short of 200,000, a record that revived the waning hopes of some who throughout all the dullness have stuck to the ticker.

Retaliating against Senator Patrick H. McCarren for taking sides with David B. Hill against Charles F. Murphy in the fight on an instructed National Convention delegation, the word went forth in Tammany Hall yesterday that Deputy Fire Commissioner William A. Doyle is to be considered the party leader in Brooklyn. Instructions have been issued to ignore McCarren in the future in all matters of patronage and to consult the wishes of Doyle.

PROF. SHALER'S book belongs to the same family with his earlier book, "The Individual,'' and Lecky's "Map of Life." It is philosophical in the good, old-fashioned sense; not metaphysical. It is sweet and mellow, as if the writer had attained "the years that bring the philosophic mind," and the condition wherein --

Charles Scribner's Sons are bringing out the second volume in The Langham Series of Art Monographs, a little square 16mo, in dark green limp leather, on "Color Prints of Japan," by Edward F. Strange, Assistant Keeper in the Victoria Albert Museum and Member of the Japan Society, London, and author of "Japanese Illustrations,"

Herod Antipas was the son of Herod the Great. He was of about the same age as John and Jesus. His mother was a woman of Samaria. Her name was Maithace. He was a man of fine taste, which he displayed in the erection of many costly and magnificent buildings. He was energetic and ambitious, and in general governed his country with prudence and ability.

Another city finds itself threatened with a typhoid epidemic. It is Cincinnati. A casual investigation shows that part of the sewage of the city is emptied into the river just above the intake of the waterworks. That this was not found long ago and stopped warrants the conclusion that the city is very badly governed in matters pertaining to its sanitary administration.

Americana sold well at the French-Chubbuck sale in Boston last week, (Feb. 23-25, Messrs. Libbie's rooms.) The highest price of the sale was $700, which was given by Dodd, Mead Co. for Mourt's "Relation or Journal of the Beginning and Proceedings of the English Plantation Setled at Plimoth in New England," London, 1622.
"An Evans of Suffolk" is a modern variation upon the theme of What a tanle] web we weave, rhen first we practice to clceive.

While the Board of Estimate was in session yesterday, hearing arguments for the Brooklyn Bridge terminal plan proposed by Commissioner Best and Chief Engineer Nichols of the Bridge Department, Controller Grout advanced the proposition that the extension of the bridge be made to Broadway, or even beyond, with an elevated structure.
PARIS, March 4. -- A correspondent of the Journal, writing from Port Arthur on Feb. 8, (the first Japanese attack was that night,) says:

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 4. -- The social wheel has revolved unceasingly to-day. The Fortnightly Club's entertainment, tea parties, and sailing parties made the afternoon gay, and this evening almost everybody dined with some one else.

The flagrant jobbery of Assemblyman THOMPSON'S bill extending the time within which the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company can begin its work of destroying Niagara Falls is equaled only by the impudence of its sponsors and supporters. In a Legislature made up of men fit to represent the people of the Empire State such a measure of flagrant spoliation would never get out of the hands of the committee to which it was referred.

"Howe's Handbook of Parliamentary Usage" (New York: Binds Noble; 50 cents) is a tiny volume about the shape and size of an ordinary business envelope. Within its stiff cloth covers it carries in fifty-six pages a digest of the entire subject of parliamentary procedure. It is arranged for the instant use of legislative and mass meetings, clubs and fraternal orders, teachers, students, workingmen, and all others who meet in formal assembly.

Ernest Everett Day has expanded his short studies on "Following the Master," which were privately published in 1901, into a larger volume, entitled "Seeking the Kingdom," which the Macmillan Company is about to bring out. The former publication was the result of lessons prepared and read each week to a Bible class organized by Mr. Day for the study of the Christian life.

SIR MONTAGU GILBERT GERARD' S reputation as a sportsman must have reached far and wide, for when he was presented to the Emperor of Austria, as far back as the year 1876, his Majesty said to him: "I understand, Sir, that you have killed 150 tigers."

This work by the author of "Genie und Karakter" is peculiar in its scope and manner of treatment. It contains some thirty essays independent of the other on men, morals, and aims of the Renaissance period in Italy. Altogether it is based on authoritative sources, nearly all manuscripts or original correspondence in due Italian tongue.

The securities of the United States Shipbuilding Company were stricken from the list of the Stock Exchange yesterday, after a history that included perhaps fewer sales than that of any issues in the memory of the oldest member. In all, 500 shares of the common stock were sold, the highest price being 4, on May 26, and the lowest 1, on Sept. 17.

Again the usual and harmless accident of the blowing of a fuse on an electric surface car has resulted in a senseless panic with more or less serious injury to those involved who were least able to protect themselves.

IN THE past, as far as medical instruction went, Philadelphia for many years occupied the first place; in fact, there was no second. While Yale and Harvard had no rivals in purely academic studies, to the University of Pennsylvania there came pupils from all parts of the country seeking instruction in medicine.

After holding the championship of the Amateur Hockey League for three consecutive years the team of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn went down to defeat before the Wanderers of Manhattan at the St. Nicholas Rink last night, scoring only a single goal to three made by the new champions.

VLADIVOSTOK, March 2, (via St. Petersburg.) -- According to information received here, forty Japanese transports, escorted by the entire naval fleet, have been energetically landing troops in Korea at Fu-san and Che-mul-pho.

"A Latin Grammar for Schools and Colleges" was written by Prof. George M. Lane of Harvard in 1897. He died the following year, and the publication of the book was carried out by his colleague, Prof. Morris H. Morgan; a revised edition is now ready, the rewriting and extension having been done by Prof. Hanns Oertel of Yale.
LONDON, March 5. -- The Russian Ambassador, Count Benckendorff, yesterday visited King Edward and presented to his Majesty an autograph letter from the Czar.

Had the prayer been addressed to Messrs. McClure, Phillips Co. that they would the "giftie gie us to see oursels as others see us," they could hardly have answered it more aptly than by the republication in this country of the "Letters from a Chinese Official" originally written for the British public shortly after the raising of the siege of the legations at Peking.

Last Tuesday night, at the sale of George M. Williamson's manuscripts and autograph letters, the original manuscript of Robert Louis Stevenson's essay on "Books Which Have Influenced Me" brought only $145. Five years ago it cost Mr. Williamson $250. Hawtherne manuscripts, of infrequent occurrence in the auction room, showed a striking advance.

The Battery Place Realty Company, which owns the Whitehall Building, occupying the block front on Battery Place, between West and Washington Streets, has bought from Richard M.C. and Walter E. Livingston 6 and 7 West Street, running through to 10 Washington Street, four-story buildings, on plot 32 by 179.8. John N. Golding and J. Romaine Brown Co. were the brokers in the transaction.

"Clubhouses established for the purpose of affording a suitable place for meeting for boys of the city and of giving them opportunities for recreation and wholesome amusement, and to surround them with influences that will enable them to become good, intelligent citizens and helpful members of the community," are undoubtedly good things, We do not think they are things that should be provided at the cost of the City Treasury.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., March 4. -- After 100 years' existence as a financial institution, the Marblehead National Bank closed its doors to-day, and its affairs will be liquidated as rapidly as possible. The bank has a capital of $120,000. The institution is paying all obligations in full.

THE end of making novels about Japanese women and even about Japanese men will not come while the present war continues, but "Nami-Ko-San," which Messrs. Herbert B. Turner Co. have in preparation, differs from the usual type in being a Japanese novel written two years ago by a native of Japan for Japanese readers, and already having attained circulation of 80,000 in the vernacular, in which it is called "Hototo-gisu."

ITHACA, N.Y., March 4. -- After being stalled in a snowdrift for four days the passenger train on the Elmira, Cortland and Northern Division of the Lehigh Valley from Canastota arrived in Ithaca last night with a crew nearly exhausted from their trying ordeal.

In the March number of The National Geographic Magazine, published monthly in Washington by the National Geographic Society, there is a very large map of Manchuria and Korea. It runs from Shanghai and the Van Diemen Straits on the south to Blagovestchensk on the north; from Peking on the west to the edge of Japan on the east, nearly twenty degrees each way, on a scale of twenty-five miles to the inch.

It is not every author who harkens to the voice of the carping critic in as kindly a spirit as does Cyrus Townsend Brady. But because one of them, after reading of young love set forth in a previous story of Mr. Brady, said, "Who cares anything about the love affairs of a young man of twenty-two and a girl of eighteen, anyway?"

Here, combined with hints of a story and several episodes quite foreign to the matter in hand, is what purports to be a detailed account of an ambitious and successful experiment in factory-farming by a man who had spent the greater part of his fifty odd years in the practice of medicine. Says the author:

LONDON, March 4. -- King Edward has approved the selection of the Hon Charles Hardinge (Assistant Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs and brother of Viscount Hardinge) to succeed Sir Charles Scott as British Ambassador at St. Petersburg. Sir Charles retires at the end of April.

THROUGH the Duke of Wellington died fifty-two years ago, England never forgets the services rendered by him, and his memory is cherished. All reminiscences of the Duke are greeted with favor by the English public, and the latest is a work by the Earl of Ellesmere, edited by his daughter, the Countess of Strafford.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday made a critical daylight examination of the ruins of the Darlington apartment hotel, the incomplete skeleton of which collapsed on Wednesday. At the close he said he had learned little or nothing to show where the blame lay.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Representative Douglas of New York says that the dispatch printed in Thursday's NEW YORK TIMES describing the hearing, before the sub-committee of the Appropriations Committee on the subject of the new Post Office does him an injustice.

The third and last volume of the new edition of "Chambers's Cyclopaedia of English Literature," which has now been published in this country, completes a work which may be fairly called invaluable. It carries the record of literary production almost to the present hour, and, as a whole, is candid and discriminating. Of course such a work deserves more careful examination than we have yet had time to give this volume.

May I be allowed to suggest that while the average New Yorker is a man of considerable common sense and shrewdness, I do not agree with one of your correspondents, who claims that the said New Yorker is "as near perfection in speech and pronunciation as possible."

PHILADELPHIA, March 4. -- Three match games were played to-day in the preliminary round for the amateur recquet championship of America in doubles, the first being between local teams, while the other two were between Boston and Philadelphia players, in which the visitors were victorious. The first was between George H. Brooke and Robert Kelso Cassatt of Philadelphia, who met Truxton T. Hare and Ralph Townsend of Philadelphia.

THE Saturday Review thinks that we have need of an index expurgatorius in which too familiar tags should be place. Among these it cites, as Mr. Kipling would say, "that is another story." The proposal is certainly an excellent one. The particular Kipling tag has been used so many thousands of times that the public must by this time be as heartily sick of it as it once was of Sullivan's "What, never?"

Charles Carroll Whitney, Secretary of the New York Life Insurance Company, died suddenly in a cab last evening while on his way to his home in Brooklyn from his office in Manhattan. His death was due to heart trouble and was wholly unexpected by his family and friends, as he seemed to be in the best of health and had never complained of heart trouble.

The Board of Managers of the New York Cotton Exchange has approved and posted upon the Exchange bulletin board a proposition to change the by-laws of the Exchange in regard to the settlement of contracts of members of the Exchange who announce their failures. The proposed amendment will make the procedure on the Cotton Exchange the same as that upon the local Stock Exchanges.

Plans for the new edifice for the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, of which the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst is pastor, were filed at the Building Department yesterday by McKim, Meade White, the architects. The new site is directly across the way from the present church, on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street.

Messrs. DOUGLAS and DUNWELL, Representatives in Congress from this city, have incurred a heavy responsibility, which may some day be brought heavily home to one or both. It may very possibly be that the busiest and most profitable Post Office in the United States would not have got from Congress decent facilities for doing its postal business even if its Representatives in Congress had been united.
NEW ORLEANS, March 4. -- Modredlaw and New York were the only winning favorites to-day, and the latter's victory was a blow to the ring, where several books took chances in laying against the colt.

FRANCIS CURTIS, whose "History of the Republican Party" is shortly to be issued by G.P. Putnam's Sons, probably has the largest single collection of books, pamphlets, letters, and miscellaneous documents relating to the Republican Party extant.

Mrs. Cotes's new back, which is certainly clever gives the effect of a sort of Canadian "Cranford," with projections into the field of English imperial politics. The picture of society in the small Canadian town of Elgin, and in the still narrower fold of the Knox Presbyterian Church of that town, is not presented at large, rather in bits and suggestions, but it is presented effectively none the less.

Business upon the Stock Exchange started off so briskly yesterday morning that there was hope of improvement in both volume and tone. At the close, however, it appeared that not 200,000 shares had been sold, and the slight improvement in this respect was matched by an equally slight improvement in prices.

MONTE CARLO, March 4. -- Arnous de Riviere, the manager of the Monte Carlo international chess tournament, has received a dispatch from the umpires appointed by the President, Prof. Rice of New York, settling the dispute between Marshall and Swiderski on the one side and M. Riviere on the other. The dispatch states that in a theoretical tournament no tie match need be played.

Mrs. Van Vorst's new novel, "The Issues of Life," will be published by Doubleday, Page Co. March 17. It deals with the "race-suicide" question, as did her "Woman Who Toils," (written in collaboration with Miss Marie Van Vorst,) which brought from President Roosevelt his vigorous letter, but in the new book, described in the sub-title, as "a novel of the American woman of to-day," the characters are cultivated and intelligent.

ALBANY, March 4. -- To prevent the evasion of the franchise tax law by corporations which manage to get without the jurisdiction of the State just about the taxing period, Assemblyman Dickinson, Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Taxation, to-day introduced a bill which was prepared under the direction of the State Controller.

As a result of the Baltimore conflagration and the Rochester fire, the National Board of Fire Underwriters has decided upon the issuance of a circular to fire insurance interests generally, which are urged to bring about a general advance in rates upon risks in the congested districts of large cities. The National Board says in part:

Charles G. Harper, author of "The Brighton Road," "The Bath Road," $c., in his new book, "The Ingoldsby Country," points out the literary landmarks of the "Ingoldsby Legends," by "Tom Ingoldsby," the Rev. Richard Harris Barham. The latter was born at Canterbury, the capital of the Ingoldsby country, which he created with his legends.

Your editorial in to-day's NEW YORK TIMES on "Steel Frames" evidently has been written or inspired by a person well posted in modern construction, and sums up the cause of the collapse in one sentence, when you state "the building fell because it was not strong enough to carry the load it sustained." You further say, "With a properly constructed steel frame the collapse of a building in this manner is impossible."

When he finished his two-volume autobiography in 1894, the late Herbert Spencer wrote in his preface that he had given a "natural history" of himself to accompany the books which have been the chief occupation of his life to write. He made

PARIS, March 4. -- The hearing of the application for the revision of the Dreyfus case was resumed to-day, the Procureur General, M. Baudoin, continuing his summary of the incidents of the affair and dwelling at great length on the manoeuvres to compromise Lieut. Col. Picquart.

In the third and concluding paper of his series on "The Poetry and Poets of America," contributed to The North American, Mr. Churton Collins drops into our recent poetry in the friendliest possible way. The article is in fact quite a gush of geniality and appreciation. In saying this we do not mean to depreciate it at all, but only to appreciate it.

Mr. Edward Bok has a severe article in The World's Work for March, entitled "Why People Disbelieve in Modern Newspapers." Its statements of glaring inaccuracy in the daily newspapers seem to relate to exceptional cases. Ezra S. Brudno, author of "The Fugitive," has an interesting article on "The Russian Jew Americanized," which is handsomely illustrated from photographs by A.W. Scott.

The story of a deathbed reconciliation of father and daughter is told in the will of Samuel Lyons, one of the oldest dealers in precious stones in the country, which was filed for probate in the Surrogates' office yesterday. Mr. Lyons, whose place of business was in the Diamond Exchange Building, in Maiden Lane, died in the Montefiore Home on Feb. 23 last. He was eighty years old.

ALBANY, March 4. -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day refused to approve the amendment to the New York City civil service rules, placing the positions of sixty Deputy Tax Commissioners in the exempt-from-examinations class, which was proposed by the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

Spring comes slowly up this way, but free trade, we judge, is almost upon us. We are forced to this alarming conclusion by perusal of the columns of our contemporary The American Economist, which is the organ of the American Protective Tariff League. The leading article in the current issue of The Economist is entitled "The Best Editorial Brains."
LONDON, March 4. -- Messrs. G.P. Putnam's Sons will publish here an English edition of the speeches of President Roosevelt.

A collection of two-score paintings which will occupy the galleries of the National Arts Club, 37 West Thirty-fourth Street, until March 15, is composed of canvases by eight painters -- Messrs. Potthast, Moschkowitz, F.D. Marsh, Hawthorne, J.W. Alexander, H.M. Walcott, R.W. Vonnoh, and Tanner. With few exceptions the pictures are figure pieces, since all the artists represented are better known for paintings in which figures enter, or for portaits, than for landscapes or marines.

This is another collection of the German Emperor's more noteworthy utterances since the day he ascended the throne. The translation has been made by a German physician residing in London. It has been put into good English, and is printed in clear type, on good paper. It differs considerably from an English version published last year by the Harpers and gotten up by Wolf von Schierbrand.

NOVELS with a very serious purpose have been appearing in Germany which are shaking the foundations of what the authorities imagine to be the columns that support the Fatherland. And because they are novels they reach every rank of society, whereas scientific essays or elaborate books that appeal to narrow circles never go far.

Desperate because the girl had refused to become his wife, Dominick Autello, an Italian, twenty years old, yesterday morning shot and killed sixteen-year-old Nellie Flanigan in the hallway of her home, at 147 Rockaway Avenue, Brooklyn, and then fatally wounded himself with the same weapon.

Two new volumes are being issued in the new Centenary Edition of the works of Ralph Waldo Emerson (Vol. VI. "Conduct of Life," and Vol. VII. "Society and Solitude." Edited, with notes, by Edward Waldo Emerson. New York and Boston: Houghton, Mifflin Co. $1.75 each.) Vol. VI. includes the essays on fate, power, wealth, culture, behavior, worship, beauty, illusions, and "Considerations by the Way."

G. de Molinari's "La Societe Future" will be published in this country by G.P. Putnam's Sons under the title "The Society of Tomorrow: A Forecast of Its Political and Economic Organization," in a translation by P.H. Lee Warner. It will have a letter to the English publisher, T. Fisher Unwin, from Frederic Passy, and an introduction by Hodgson Pratt.

In an opinion yesterday, Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court. Brooklyn, criticised a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the suit brought by Ella C. Polhemus against Horace G. Polhemus, Herman Steenken, James Parker, E. Dixon Polhemus, wife of Horace Polhemus, and J.A. Ackerman, who comprise the Board of Directors of the John Polhemus Printing Company.

ALTHOUGH no "sinister motive" inspired the primitive notions of "Harvard" on this subject, and his random shots were aimed at no particular target, they evidently have aroused the heavy artillery of the critical champions lying in ambush for a reckless intruder.

"Outlines of Greek History" is intended to form with the author's "Outlines of Roman History" a complete elementary course in ancient history, indicating the relation of history to civilization in general, and referring to the primitive culture with which civilization may be said to begin. It also contains a preliminary sketch of the progress of civilization before the time of the Greeks among the ancient Oriental peoples.
NEWARK, N.J., March 4. -- The striking resemblance between two well-known residents of this city was responsible for a case of mistaken identity that caused considerable confusion on Wednesday.

LATELY some one was lamenting the disappearance of Lafcadio Hearn. We suggested, in noting the lament, that his Boston publishers probably knew his hiding place. A new book from his eloquent pen will soon be published, and as it treats once more of life in Japan it will be "timely," though, presumably, Lafcadio Hearn loathes that word.

THERE is a book that has had a great vogue, and that passes under the name of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden." Concerning it I think that there is something that ought to be said, and for the saying of which by some one else I have long waited in vain. I am tempted at last to say it in myself by your good leave.
LONDON, March 5. -- The Times's military correspondent regards the advice of Gen. Dragomiroff that Russia evacuate Port Arthur as thoroughly sound.

Settlement workers in this city, almost without a single exception, are opposed to the bill providing for the establishment and maintenance of clubs for boys under municipal control and at the city's expense, which was rushed through and passed the Senate at Albany on Thursday. The bill was introduced by State Senator Marshall of Brooklyn.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 4. -- An imperial order has been issued summoning the Reserve Subalterns and firstclass Reserve men of European Russia to the colors for a six weeks' course of training.

In your issue of Feb. 27 your correspondent who calls himself "A Yale Pedant," in making the statement that "Addison's style is sufficiently 'accurate' for him," implies that Addison's style is "sufficiently accurate" for anybody. Now, accuracy implies imitableness, and to consider a style accurate must be to accept as correct every phrase of that style.

The proceedings brought before Referee William G. Davies to determine whether Charles F. Dodge was really served with the papers in his wife's divorce suit, and whether he retained Mortimer S. Ruger to defend him, came to a close yesterday afternoon, after a hearing held at 32 Nassau Street. Charles W. Morse, whose marriage was annulled because the Dodge divorce was vacated, appeared as a witness, having been subpoenaed by A.H. Hummel, counsel for Dodge.

While the patrol wagon of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Station was on its way to answer a call at 11 o'clock last night its horses took fright at an automobile and ran away. Driver John Finnegan and Patrolman John McGrath were both thrown from the wagon before the horses could be stopped, and Finnegan was seriously hurt. McGrath was badly bruised.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Senate Committee on Elections, which is investigating the protests against Senator Smoot to-day confronted President Joseph F. Smith of the Mormon Church with the question whether the Mormons would obey the revelations of their Church when these revelations came in conflict with the law of the land.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 4. -- There exists high authority for the statement that Russia now has reason to feel more tranquil regarding the attitude of Great Britain.

AMONG the men who did the real work of planting the English colonies in America, who came to the new country and toiled with hand and brain for the making of the new community, the most disinterested and not the least able was the founder of the youngest of all the plantations, Georgia.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Senator Dowling introduced a bill in the Legislature to-day amending the New York charter relative to the powers of the Superintendent of Public Buildings, and providing that the Superintendent shall also have power to compel a cessation of work on any building in the course of erection which is being constructed in a manner to endanger public safety.

A recent report of United States Consul Metcalf at Newcastle-on-Tyne, England, contains an article on the English credit and companies system from The Manchester Chronicle, in which the writer bewails the shortcomings of the bankruptcy and companies acts of Great Britain in terms that suggest the chorus of complaint heard on this side of the water whenever the subject of corporate promotions is under discussion.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 5. -- Heavy land fighting in the Far East, upon which the fate of the campaign depends, is not expected much before the end of April.
