PARIS, Feb. 28. -- While the eyes of Europe are anxiously fixed upon the Far East, those French officials charged with the interests of France at the St. Louis Exposition are pushing forward their preparations. Of the European countries now competing in the important market of the United States, England holds the first position, Germany the second, and France the third.

C.W. Farmer, Secretary of the Millinery Merchants' Protective Association, reports that trade in the millinery line this season is a little below normal. The usual number of buyers has not come to town, and those that have come have been a little more conservative than usual in their purchases. It is expected, however, that the trade will all come in a rush at the end of the season.

BERLIN, March 5. -- In the course of a discussion in the Prussian Diet to-day, which followed the introduction of a resolution asking for a reduction in railroad tariffs, Herr Macco, who in 1903 visited the United States to study matters pertaining to transportation, said that the United States was ahead of Germany in many ways, and that transportation in the United States was cheaper than in Prussia.
PARIS, March 5. -- The Criminal Branch of the Court of Cassation to-day granted the appeal of Alfred Dreyfus for a revision of his trial at Rennes.

Senator HALE'S expert statement in the Senate about our navy was startling. He declared that in the effectiveness of ships it was second to that of Great Britain alone, and superior to that of any other Power, and that because we do not carry obsolete craft on our list of effective ships.

There are persons who are inclined to think that because there was such a tremendous tonnage of coal mined last year, there must be a great deal of that same coal scattered around the country yet unconsumed, and to credit these same persons there is nothing of the position which has been taken by some coal owners that this year will be one of great output.

William Ross, a colored laborer, twenty-three years of age, and Miss Issie White, thirty-nine years of age, and also colored, both of 234 West Fifty-third Street, were arrested last night and locked up in the West Forty-seventh Street Station on the charge of having caused the death of Edward B. White, the woman's husband.

WITH little or no change in underlying conditions, dealing continues along the lines which it has followed with little variation for the last three months. A trade of large proportions and some further developments in the colony of apartment hotel projects at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street have been topics of passing interest for those who find a certain fascination in big figures, but to none of these deals can any real significance be attached.

It was stated yesterday that of the nine Directors of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding and Steel Company, as the resurrected United States Shipbuilding Company is likely to be called, five will be the following: Stuyvesant Fish, President of the Illinois Central Railroad; George C. Boldt, proprietor of the Waldorf-Astoria; Max Nathan of the Bondholders' Protective Committee, George R. Sheldon, Chairman of the Reorganization Committee, and J.R. McIlvain, President of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs has made several amendments to the Army Appropriation act which are certain to arouse determined opposition in the Senate, and which, if retained in the bill by that body, will lead to a protracted struggle in the House.

British publications, in contemplating the loss of nearly $10,000,000 that their insurance companies sustained at Baltimore, take a sort of grim satisfaction in reminding their readers that the American companies have lost, by reason of the same great fire, something over twice that amount of money.

ALBANY, March 5. -- After the Hill faction had won its victory in the meeting of the State Committee to-day, Charles F. Murphy, the Tammany leader, authorized Senator Dowling to give out a statement, in the course of which he said:

When February opened with a week of successive daily declines it was said that the market was bound to turn upward for that reason, irrespective of the news, since no market can fall steadily, without reacting. All through the first week of March now until Saturday we have had steadily advancing prices, and the impartial application of the rule would require a reaction downward regardless of the market factors.
The war in the East has affected many lines of goods which are dealt in extensively in this country, and in all cases the effect has been to advance prices.

THE smart woman of to-day has her own special perfume. It is made from a recipe invented to suit her taste. with perhaps the odor of her favorite flower as a foundation, and the chemist is bound to keep the secret inviolate and dispense the preparation to no other customer.

A LONG Maine's broken coast line there is no point more conspicuous than Owl's Head, where a new attraction has been discovered by William F. Norcross, a Rockland business man. Clambering to a seldom frequented part of the Government land, he saw outlined against the sky a remarkably clear profile.

The full annual report of the Pennsylvania Railroad which was made public last week is a very voluminous document of thirty-nine pages, but, in spite of its size, the information which it conveys is by no means proportionately large. Among the things which it does not show is the exact nature of the disposition made of the large sums of money raised during the year either through loans or issue of new stock and bonds.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Peter Van Vlissingen, his leisure secured by the possession of some millions of dollars, has bent his mind upon sociological problems. As a result of one of his experiments, John Wiltrax, who is serving a long term in prison for the murder of four-year-old Paul Paszkowski, may be set free.

WHEN lovely woman stoops to folly and joins a Federated Club, will all be well 'twixt Sue and Polly, or will they quarrel? There's the rub. The clubland of women in New York has undertaken a task that would make the clubland of men rush helterskelter to the woods. All the women's clubs are going to consolidate.

Recent Wall Street experience furnishes but one example of the official passing of a dividend or interest payment and its subsequent declaration by the Directors prior to the date on which the payment fell due. Such an incident is supplied by the payment on Tuesday last of the interest on the second income bonds of the Texas and Pacific Railway Company, which previously had been officially passed by the Board of Directors.

Judge Byron S. Waite of the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest against the assessment of 1 cent a pound and 35 per cent. ad valorem as "comfits" on broken-chestnuts in syrup, which are used by bakers and confectioners as an ingredient for cakes, B. Shackman of New York, the importer, claimed that they were dutiable at 1 cent a pound as nuts.

It is announced that Mayor MCCLELLAN approves and will do what, officially, he can to confine the use of the East River Bridge during the rush hours to shuttle trains only. Passengers would take the various lines of the Brooklyn surface system at the plaza, which is to be used for a great terminal.
West Point's annual "Hundredth Night Celebration" last evening was distinguished by a musical comedy, of which the book was written and the music composed by members of the first class of cadets.

What promises to develop into some of the most sensational relay racing ever witnessed in this city will be decided at the carnival of sport held under the auspices of the New York Athletic Club at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday evening. In addition to these interesting races, Arthur F. Duffey, the champion sprinter of the world, has entered for the sixty-yard dash, a handicap, along with a number of other speedy runners.
One of the free classes of the First Aid to the Injured Society was in session.
I HAD a lot to learn. Well, I think I have learned my lesson."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 5. -- In April will occur the first of a series of Spring weddings of great interest to Morristown society, that of Miss Louise Scribner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scribner, to George R. Schieffelin, Jr. This will be followed a week later by the wedding of Miss Florence Vanderbilt Twombly to William A.M. Burden.

The advantage of location is in Judge Parker's favor, but he is not so well known as a Democratic statesman in the rest of the country as Mr. Olney, and ability and tested Democracy should determine the nomination, and not the question of locality. In a Presidential canvass location soon loses its significance, and the question turns absolutely on the man and the principles he stands for. -- Pittsburg (Penn.) Post, (Dem.)

THERE is a piscine fowl, despised of anglers, known as skate or ray, which, properly cooked, is a marine delicacy of the first class. Its market price is now 12 cents a pound, hut in full Summer season those who have not cultivated a taste for its table merits cast it aside in ill-temper as not worth the lure that covered the hook that snared it.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 5. -- Mystery still surrounds the disappearance of Victor R. Stowe, a wealthy New Yorker, who left his apartments at a local hotel twelve days ago. He left behind numerous letters and documents showing that he came here from St. Louis.
HANOVER, Prussia, March 5. -- Field Marshal Count von Waldersee died shortly after 8 o'clock this evening.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 5. -- This region is threatened with the worst flood in many years, and every precaution is being taken for the protection of life and property. In this city the lowlands are submerged and the Court House has been thrown open for the shelter of those who have been compelled to leave their homes.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 5. -- Although it is but mid-Lent. Lakewood has begun to take on the activity of Easter. March storms have sent New Yorkers and New England folks scurrying to this sheltered spot in great numbers. The weather is very pleasant at Lakewood now. Warm rains have taken the frost out of the ground and the golfers are happy once more.

STAGE realism, carried to a high point, will mark the presentation of "The Ajax of Hophocles," for which rehearsals have been under way now several weeks, and which is to be set forth in the new east side resort, Clinton Hall, on March 24, 25, and 26. The play is to be acted by Greeks recruited from the local colony, and efforts are in the making for a scenic environment that will reproduce classic tradition.

Recorder Goff, responding to the toast "Experts in Criminal Cases," at the twenty-second annual dinner of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence at the Hotel Savoy last night, reminded his hearers to bear in mind that urging the appointment of a Board of Expert Examiners was to say in effect that single experts hitherto had lied.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- That the United States may need to use force to carry out Secretary Hay's policy of the open door in China was asserted by Senator Depew to-day in the debate on the naval appropriation bill. The possibility of this country becoming involved in the Russo-Japanese war was freely discussed. Senators showing a wide divergence of opinion.

In the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on Friday Controller GROUT suggested that the relief of the East River Bridge terminal be in part effected by extending it to and across Broadway, and beyond, if necessary, by an elevated structure. This was substantially the conclusion reached by the commission of engineers which in 1902 investigated the subject very carefully.

PARIS, March 5. -- Reports received here confirm those which have reached Washington and other capitals -- that the Chinese troops are showing much activity in Northern China and along the Manchurian border. They also indicate that bands of Chinese brigands are taking advantage of the present opportunity to resume their depredations and raids through Manchuria.

The Rev. Father Herman J. Ernst, assistant pastor of St. Patrick's Church, Radde Street and Paynter Avenue, Dutch Kills, Long Island City, was burned to death in a fire which gutted the rectory at an early hour yesterday morning. Mary Brady and Margaret McCue, two domestics who occupied a room on the fourth floor of the rectory, also perished in the flames.

Secretary of War William H. Taft was present, and spoke at the annual meeting of the University Settlement Society of New York, held at Sherry's yesterday afternoon, and received a little boom as a Presidential possibility in a speech delivered by President John H. Finley of the College of the City of New York.

Permit your reader to take exception to the mass of remarks in your columns which so rabidly denounce Russia and everything Russian. I refer specially to the article in to-day's paper signed by Henry S. Morals.

A bill has been introduced in the Assembly at Albany amending the New York charter in its provisions relative to the Superintendent of Buildings, and empowering him to compel a cessation of work on any building which is being erected in violation of the requirements of the building code.

Wrought up to a high pitch of indignation by what appeared to be a case of extortion, Magistrate Ommen ordered a complaint drawn up against Lawyer Abraham Pearlman in the Essex Market Court yesterday morning, and also said that he would make a complaint against Detective Sergeants McCarty and Sugden to Commissioner McAdoo.
Following are the scores of another selection of games played in the recent international chess masters' tournament at Monte Carlo: ...

The new race course at Belmont Park, Nassau County, which is being constructed by members of the Westchester Racing Association of Morris Park, has not advanced much toward completion during the Winter, but sufficient progress has been made since ground was first broken, on March 28 of last year, to indicate that it is the purpose of August Belmont and his associates to establish what will probably be the best-appointed racing grounds in the country.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President Smith's temper gave way to-day as a result of the long series of searching and personal questions to which he has been subjected in the progress of the Reed Smoot inquiry. Being questioned by Senator Bailey as to his own course in violating the State law by living with plural wives, he broke out:
The next matinee for the students of the Wheatcroft-Stanhope Dramatic School will be given at the Manhattan Theatre Thursday afternoon, March 17. Several new plays will be presented.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- By a rare coincidence the Government has within the space of a week twice been saved by a majority of fifty-one. This is less than one-half their normal figure. Regarded strictly as a numeral 'twill serve. It is eleven more than that by which, in his last Ministry, Gladstone carried the Home Rule bill in the face of a resolute Opposition, behind him a following whose acquiescence at best was sullen.

IF SILICON had been a gas," said Whistler, alluding to a certain fatal examination at West Point, "I should have been a soldier." The conclusion may be questioned; but there is little reasonable doubt that if Count Alexei Tolstoi's "Ivan the Terrible" had been a drama Mansfield would have given us a masterpiece of creative acting.

Mrs. John Woolsey, who said she lived in Henry Street, Brooklyn, yesterday called on George E. Maes, a Justice of the Peace at 8 Oakland Avenue, Jersey City, and asked him if he had married her son, J. Henry Woolsey, and Lillian E. Martin last October. Reference to the Justice's records showed that he had married the couple on Oct. 17, 1903.

Under ordinary conditions the weekly statements of the great European banks are of comparatively little general interest in this market. This week, however, the completion of the settlement in Paris which had been looked forward to and dreaded ever since the bad break on the Bourse a week ago, awakened considerable interest in the changes reported by the Banque de France.

A BIG man, with a hundred thousand horse power inside him; a masterful man, with twenty-five thousand men directly under his leadership; a man who controls whatever he touches; an absolute ruler, as absolute as the Czar. George Westinghouse is a trained engineer, an inventor, a manufacturer, and a financier. The combination is unique.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- The worst panic which the Paris Bourse has known since the Franco-German war occurred yesterday. Since the opening of hostilities between Russia and Japan there has been a tendency downward, but the drop yesterday amounted to a real "Krach." French 3 per cent. rentes, which were at 97.52 on Feb. 6, closed at 93.55 yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- At the hearing before the House Civil Service Reform Committee to-day Secretary Moody remarked that, in clerical work, the element of experience was important. Mr. Pou of North Carolina responded that every two years the House of Representatives underwent a change in membership that brought in new material to the extent of 25 or 33 1-3 per cent., yet Congress ran along very smoothly.

BERLIN, March 5. -- I learn that the Vienna and St. Petersburg Governments are fully prepared for an uprising in Russian Poland. The Poles of Russia, Austria, and Germany are eagerly awaiting news of a disastrous Russian defeat in the Far East in order to take warlike steps.

In some of the articles concerning the disaster to the Darlington, the tendency is to blame the Department of Buildings. This is generally the case when anything goes wrong. The department has but a limited force, and the inspection it can give to any set of plans or any building must in most cases be superficial.

Nobody can fail to recognize the frankness and candor of the head of the Mormon theocracy, the only successful union in this country of Church and State on any considerable scale. JOSEPH SMITH is the witness and the chief agent of the theocracy, both in spiritual and temporal affairs; REED SMOOT is the candidate of the theocracy for the representation of its State of Utah in the Senate of the United States.

AN actor never wore a crown so expensive or made under such peculiar conditions as the one which Richard Mansfield wears nightly in "Ivan the Terrible." It is somewhat grandiloquently styled "the crown of the Monomachs," since it was to that dynasty that Czar Ivan belonged.

The transformation of the Thirty-fourth Street block, shown with owners' names in the accompanying diagram, from a residence street into a crosstown business thoroughfare of the first importance, has been one of the most striking bits of real estate development witnessed within the last two or three years.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 5. -- When the Grand Jury of Union County meets here to take up the case of James H. Shippie there will probably be a parade of deserted wives that will astonish the natives of this staid old town. Shippie, who is a car conductor, employed by the Public Service Corporation, was arrested here to-day at one of his homes, 58 Jackson Avenue.

Such is the title of what may be called a sermonlet in The Critic by President ROOSEVELT. To the casual reader it will not seem a very informing message. It was not to a President of the United States, but to one of the minutest of creatures, that Dr. HOLMES remarked:

WHEN rumors got abroad a year or so ago that Dr. Richard Strauss was at work on a new symphonic tone poem to be entitled "Symphonia Domestica," and dealing, it was said, with family life, with a day's doings of "Papa, Mamma, et Bebe," they were treated as a joke.

Policeman Palmer, who is detailed at the door of the District Attorney's office, was approached by a young woman yesterday who asked him if he knew a good way to trap a bigamist. Palmer referred her to Assistant District Attorney Krotel, and in Mr. Krotel's office she explained that she was Mrs. William Ottowa Dougall of Sedgwick Avenue, William's Bridge.

" Given a fair chance, would the brute animal's inclination lead him to become a drunkard?" is the latest scientific problem that "Tody" Hamilton, the press agent of the Barnum Barley Circus, has evolved from his fertile brain. To watch the solution of this question, "Tody" on Friday invited a dozen newspaper men and some friends up to Winter quarters of the show, at Bridgeport.

Coroner Scholer said yesterday that the man most wanted in connection with the Hotel Darlington disaster was John Schwandtner of the firm of Pole Schwandtner, the contractors who had charge of the ironwork of the wrecked hotel. A warrant has been issued, it is said, for Mr. Schwandtner's arrest, but he has not been found.

The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Joseph H. Hobbins, a dry goods merchant and Treasurer of St. Alban's Protestant Episcopal Church, in the Bronx, was solved yesterday by the finding of his body in Cromwell's Creek, near One Hundred and Sixty-first Street, by Policeman Edward Mann.

Producers and dealers of goods sold under a trademark, in all lines of trade, are much interested in three bills now before Congress, all providing for the amendment of the trademark law. The important features of the two earlier bills are embodied in the last one introduced by Senator Platt of Connecticut, and this is the bill that has received the general indorsement of commercial interests everywhere.

E.A. Taylor of Euclid School made a new indoor skating record for one mile last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, covering the distance in 2:49 3-5. Phil Kearney of the New York Athletic Club, who finished second in the record mile race, made the distance in 2:50 2-5 last week.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., March 5. -- Mrs. Mary Keefe, a widow, aged fifty years, who conducts a little candy and notion store in Hawley, Wayne County, Penn., was brutally attacked by an unknown man yesterday afternoon, and is still unconscious as the result, with but slight hopes of recovery.

THERE is the universal plaint which always comes at this dull time of year. Lent is a time of rest and meditation. and bridge. Perhaps this Spring -- it is not authoritatively Spring, by the say, until the end of the month -- fewer fashionables than usual have taken advantage of the attractions of the Winter resorts, and many have stayed quietly in New York.

The work of excavating the site for the new Stock Exchange at Baltimore will be begun on Tuesday. The walls will be run up as rapidly as possible, and the building will be the first to be completed in the zone which was destroyed by fire last month. The Board of Governors of the Exchange hope their enterprise will stimulate other financial institutions and business houses to start rebuilding without delay.

THE western and southern Tibetan frontier has been well named the roof of the world. The tact that the highest peak on the globe, Mount Everest, 20,002 feet, is there by no means describes the wonders of the region. There are many other mountains ranging in height from 20,000 feet to nearly that of Everest, and even the valleys are higher above the sea than the summits of the tallest mountains in Europe.

PARIS, March 5. -- The situation of the French Government is highly insecure. In spite of the optimism of Premier Combes, who professes absolute belief in the fidelity to the Government of the "bloc" majority, there is a very strong conviction among well-informed politicians that a crisis may easily arise in a few days.

N.L. McCREADY purchased last week the yacht Enchantress. She was over here several seasons in commission. Mr. McCready belongs to the New York Yacht Club, but never has taken a very conspicuous part in yachting affairs, although by inheritance he should be very fond of the water.

DULUTH, Minn., March 5. -- Feeling runs high in this section over what are described locally as the swamp-land frauds, through which the State and the railroads have reaped rich benefits. The Government may be asked to investigate.

ALBANY, March 5. -- Tammany Leader Charles F. Murphy met defeat to-day in his contest with David Bennett Hill for the control of the Democratic State Committee. The rout of the Tammany forces was complete.

THE little odds and ends of men's attire are frequently those which demand the greatest attention, and which often decide the status of an individual. The French have a rule demanding good hats, good shoes, and good gloves. The rest, they say, amounts to little, but these three are essential to help denote a gentleman.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 5. -- Pinehurst's guests are reveling in the joys of early Spring, and social pleasures and sports are at their height. Waiting lists are now the rule at nearly all the hotels, and the time when it will be difficult to provide for all is not far distant.

One woman was burned to death, another had both of her ankles fractured, three men were nearly suffocated, and a fireman was badly burned in a fire that partially destroyed the small four-story flat house at 223 1/2 East Twenty-third Street last night. The woman who lost her life was Mrs. Louise Gebhardt, who lived on the third floor.
As a result of meetings to be held tomorrow the National Citizens' Bank, 407 Broadway, will absorb the Central National Bank, 320 Broadway. The shareholders of each bank will meet at noon.
Secretary of War Taft was the guest of honor and made the principal speech at the annual banquet of the Ohio Society, which was given last night at the Waldorf-Astoria.
War to the knife has been declared between Charles F. Murphy and Senator Patrick H. McCarren for the control of the Democratic political situation in Brooklyn.
PARIS, March 5. -- After a week of bitter frost the weather is now much milder, almost Springlike.
MONTE CARLO, March 5. -- Most of the masters engaged in the two international chess tournaments here have departed for their homes.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- One of the strenuous sides of Franco-American life in Paris is supplied by the many American girls who are studying art in this capital of aestheticism. The American Woman's Art Association was formed to enable these young women students to come together and to have an opportunity of exhibiting their work and submitting it to the criticism of the press and the public.

The terrible disaster on Forty-sixth Street, the collapse of the Hotel Darlington during the course of erection, and the consequent loss of life serve to bring clearly before the public one fact which stands out alone beyond all others, viz., the use of cast iron beyond the limits of its reliability in place of the use of steel.

There will be no automobile endurance run this year. The National Association of Automobile Manufacturers, which has formerly conducted the endurance contests, has decided to eliminate that event and work in harmony with the American Automobile Association in contributing to the success of the big National club run to St. Louis, the detailed plans of which have just been outlined.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 5. -- The "Stand Patters" controlled the Polk County convention this afternoon and dealt a blow to the "Iowa idea" by unanimously indorsing the "Stand Pat ticket" for delegates at large to the National Convention and indorsing the principle of protection with a back-handed slap at Gov. Cummins's scheme for Canadian reciprocity.

SHE had experienced the common agonies in grappling with the "servant question," and now that the family had finally moved from the metropolis to New Jersey these had multiplied, of course, many fold. For few and far between, indeed, are the damsels of domesticity who will "take a place over the ferry."

CHICAGO, March 3. -- The business interests of the Mormon Church have set on foot a scheme to induce business houses with whom they have commercial relations in various parts of the country to bring influence to bear upon United States Senators to the end that Senator Reed Smoot of Utah may not be deprived of his seat in the Senate as a result of the inquiry now proceeding at Washington.

Sufficient attention is rarely given to the unconscious sympathy that exists between the imperial houses of Russia and Germany and the upper or noble classes of the two countries. Especially are Russia and Prussia drawn together by the similar situation of their ruling classes, and this underground sympathy is reinforced by a good deal of racial identity which makes for the subtlest, most intangible bonds.

The ancient peoples of the world, some of them clever enough vocally according to the record, but assisted by poor instruments, had various ideas about music, mainly tending to exaggerate its powers. Thus the lute of Orpheus is said to have made the trees rise as in dance and wheel in stately minuet marchings to its cadences.
PARIS, Feb. 16. -- The Anarchists are in mourning, for they have lost the most eminent exponent of their theories and the most respectable and charitable of their "compagnons."
IN the "Diary of a Dog," wherein the four-footed friend makes wise remarks in re things in general, he is careful to insert and even to emphasize:
Your article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 3 has been read by me, and it is so absolutely foreign to the true facts in the case that I desire to endeavor if possible to give you the real position.

Gov. Odell's health did not permit of his starting for Washington yesterday morning to see the President. He left for Albany shortly after noon, and so far as known the Washington expedition is off indefinitely.

THE shapes and combinations obtaining in the new Spring hats and toques are not at all likely to continue through the Summer, for the hats now shown are being purchased for wear at Southern resorts or for the Spring season in town. By the time hot weather arrives the fashionable world will have tired of the present modes.

THE New York firemen who went to Baltimore to help check the great fire were distinguished from their brothers of other cities by their methods of work as much as by their uniforms and badges. Although certain general rules concorning fire fighting are recognized in all cities, there are many minor details which differentiate the service of one place from that of another.

Although a guest in your country, I venture to write of a delight and a disappointment I experienced at one of your beautiful new theatres on Monday evening, where I went to see your Mr. Richard Mansfield in Alexis Tolstois "Ivan the Terrible." And, in passing, let me give testimony to the enterprise of an American artist who has anticipated our English actor-managers in placing on the stage Russia's most popular historical drama.

LONDON, March 5. -- There has been another dull week on the Stock Exchange, with practically no business going on and none in sight. Would-be investors are timid and speculative dealings few and of small volume.

J.B. Taylor, the speedy colored runner of the University of Pennsylvania, won the one-mile intercollegiate relay race at the first annual athletic games of the Spanish War Veterans at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory last night in sensational style, beating Cates of Yale by ten yards. The latter defeated Adams of Columbia for the place by fully thirty yards.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5. -- A romance that had its beginning at a circus performance over a year ago resulted in a wedding to-day in Justice of the Peace Bosset's office, when Miss Katherine Hendricks of Morristown became the wife of William A. Ryan of Evansville, Ind. According to Justice Bosset there was to have been a double marriage, but one of prospective bridegrooms at the last moment refused to go on with the ceremony.

By comparison with recent totals yesterday's trading in the stock market seemed large, and coincidentally prices declined more or less sharply. Twice earlier in the week had the transactions on a full day fallen below yesterday's total, and it was pointed out as significant that those were the days on which prices were rising, while yesterday much of the improvement recorded earlier in the week was lost.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 5. -- After conferences lasting all day, the soft-coal miners this afternoon rejected the ultimatum of the operators. The 800 miner delegates will meet Monday morning in National convention, when a statement of their position will be made.
' Leslie H. ~Vebb has been appointed Cleveland agent of the Federal Union Surety Compa~Y of Indianapolis.

An unusually large crowd attended the Sportsmen's Show at its closing day yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The number of children was particularly noticeable and the little launches on the lake were busy every minute of the day and evening carrying parties across the small sheet of water.

Recent large increases in the surplus reserve held by the New York banks have carried the figures to the highest point reached in several years and have brought prominently forward the question of the desirability of a surplus much in excess of legal requirements. To begin with, Wall Street was well pleased with the increases in the cash held by the banks.

A very choice and instructive exhibition of rare manuscripts of the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries may be seen in one of the rooms of the library at Columbia University, thanks to a number of collectors who have placed their costly uniques for several weeks in charge of the Curator, protected of course by showcases, and under proper guard.

Lena Fassnecht, the common-law wife of Carl Muhlbach, a manufacturer of enamel letters, reached her home on the top floor of the tall tenement at 343 East Eighty-fifth Street about 2 o'clock yesterday morning and found Muhlbach waiting up for her. The couple had been quarreling all week, so the other tenants in the house paid little attention to the loud talking in Muhlbach's rooms after the Fassnecht woman was admitted.

AMONG the most interesting institutions in this city are the Tire Department's big hospital and training stables in West Ninety-ninth Street. Here, the world famous New York fire horse passes his examination and is accepted and gets his first lessons in the art of fire fighting. Here he is brought when scorched or bruised, or cut or sprained, to be doctored and nursed back to strength and usefulness.

BOSTON, March 5. -- United States Secret Service officers made five arrests here last night and to-day of members of an alleged gang of banknote counterfeiters. The prisoners are: Robert Thompson, a physician; his wife; Dr. George S. Hatch, Patrick J. Gallagher, and Hyman Cohen.

NEW ORLEANS, March 5. -- Ostrich's performance in the Oakland Handicap to-day, when he ran second to Tribes Hill, the favorite, and forced him out to the last ounce, gave the talent a line on the colt's chances in the Crescent City Derby. It was a race from beginning to end, and the mile and a quarter was covered within a fifth of a second of track record time.

BALTIMORE, March 5. -- A child's shrill cry of fire startled a large audience, composed mostly of women and children, in Ford's Opera House, at the matinee this afternoon, during the first act of "Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch," and only the prompt action of the theatre employes and the calmness of several men in the audience prevented a tragedy.

THE old cry of "there is nothing new under the sun" might well be made now, for while new goods, new trimmings of every sort, and Spring coats and costumes, to say nothing of those for Summer wear, are either under way or already finished, no one is wearing them. March in town is a dies non sartorially, so far as novelty goes.

HUNDREDS of men and women suffering from pneumonia, grip, and consumption, and unable to pay for medical attendance, have been turned away from the New York public hospitals this Winter to die in the tenements and cheap boarding houses.

The plans for the special cycle of "The Ring of the Nibelung" at the Metropolitan Opera House were rudely interrupted yesterday by the havoc played with the voices of some of the principal singers by the New York climate. The second drama of the series, "Die Walkure," set down for last evening, was to bring forward Mme.

MIDWAY ISLANDS, Jan. 30. -- Of course all of our party here, fourteen in number, are very proud of this section of the United States, possibly the two Chinese members of the community excepted. But even they have some cause for congratulation, as they are the only China pebbles allowed on the beach -- the Exclusion act barring out their countrymen.

It appears that in rejecting the proposition to take the Deputy Tax Commissioners out of the competitive class the State Civil Service Commission weighed with equal care the arguments based on the law and those based on the policy of the change. It was to the former point that the reasoning of Mayor MCCLELLAN was directed.

In the annual tournament of the Harlem Navy Handball League, which was continued yesterday on the courts of the competing clubs, the Union Boat Club won six games from the Dauntless Rowing Club, at the Dauntless house, the Wyanoke Boat Club won six from the Crescent Rowing Club at the Wyanoke house, and the Metropolitan Rowing Club won four of six games, with the Lone Star Boat Club at the Lone Star house.

Have the Democrats of this State and country become so accustomed to defeat and disaster that they are willing for the third time to be blown out of the small end of Mr. Bryan's horn? If so, a notice on Democracy's door that she has "gone out of business" would certainly be in place.

The Committee on Differentials of the Merchants' Association has received replies to protests made Feb. 29 in letters to Presidents and Traffic Managers of various railroads against differential rates, which, it was claimed, discriminated against New York and injured the city's trade.

It is really a matter of no consequence whether the Democrats of New York hold their State Convention in this city or in Albany. Whether the delegation to the St. Louis Convention be instructed or uninstructed is not of vital importance. Nor did the fate of this Nation hang upon the election of a State Committeeman from the Forty-eighth Senatorial District.

K. Okakura of the Bijitsum or Hall of Fine Arts of Tokio, T. Yokeyama, landscape painter; S. Kishida, and Shisui Rokaku, a notable worker in laquer, have arrived in this city from Japan via Seattle and were present at Mme. Nordica's concert in Carnegie Hall yesterday in the picturesque old-time costumes of their native land.
LONDON, March 6. -- It is reported that German bankers offered a loan to Russia on favorable terms, but that the offer was not accepted.

Extreme congestion obtains daily at the Cortlandt Street Station of the Ninth Avenue elevated line. This letter points out a simple means of providing a large degree of relief at Cortlandt Street until complete relief is provided by means of additional stairways.

The series of Sunday night concerts at the Metropolitan Opera House was brought to a brilliant finish last night. Altogether these offerings have been more satisfactory this season than for many years past. Mr. Conried as a rule has been generous in presenting his stars and the conductors have introduced many novelties in their programmes.

PARIS, March 7. -- The correspondent of the Matin at Tokio says that at a banquet given last Thursday to the American war correspondents the Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, in thanking the American Nation for the support hitherto given to Japan, declared that the Government reckoned upon receiving even more effective assistance from the United States in the future.

OSWEGO, N.Y. March 6. -- The general office building of the New York Central Railroad was entirely destroyed by fire to-day involving a loss estimated at more than $100,000. The building contained, in addition to the general offices, the ticket office, baggage room, the American Express Company's office, four retail, stores, and the Lake Shore Hotel, which was recently vacated.

The report emanating from New Haven. Conn., that the Knights of Columbus, because of conspicuous failure on the part of some of the members to abide by well-known rules of the Roman Catholic Church have openly incurred the Church's displeasure, has aroused no little surprise and discussion among the knights in this city.

Considerable activity in the matter of improvements to the houses of the boat clubs in the new "Scullers' Row" along the water front of Macomb's Dam Park is likely to result from the intimations which several of the clubs have received from the Park Department that their houses are not sufficiently ornamental, and that various alterations, such as the addition of porches and balconies, together with a liberal use of new paint, will be welcomed.

VLADIVOSTOK, March 6. -- A fleet of five Japanese battleships and two cruisers appeared off this place at 1:25 o'clock this afternoon and bombarded the town and shore batteries for fifty-five minutes.

-- We earnestly advise all the Brooklyn teachers who are pleading or clamoring for a revival of corporal punishment in the public schools -- and teachers of the same sort elsewhere, if there are any -- to buy or borrow a copy of last week's issue of The New York Medical Record and carefully read an article therein entitled "Concerning the Proposed Introduction of Whipping Into the Public Schools."

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Chief John E. Wilkie of the Secret Service has given an interesting detailed account of the work done in detecting the silk frauds, the apprehension of the New York firm of Rosenthal Co., and the prosecution and conviction of Martin L. Cohen, a member of that firm, and of Charles C. Browne, a Customs Examiner, of conspiracy to defraud the Government.
Three more bodies were found in the ruins of the Darlington Hotel yesterday. This brings the number of dead discovered so far up to twenty.

In a discourse on "The Ethics of the Immigration Problem" at Temple Emanu-El yesterday the Rev. Dr. Silverman said that the only restrictions upon immigration should be moral ones and that America's place in the world is as a harbor for the distressed and oppressed of tyrannical monarchies.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt, Justice Brewer of the United States Supreme Court, Senator Dolliver of Iowa, the British Ambassador and Lady Durand, and many other persons prominent in official, diplomatic, and social circles, attended the service to-day in commemoration of the one hundredth anniversary of the British and Foreign Bible Society at St. John's Episcopal Church.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 6. -- Answering an inquiry concerning the fate of Baron Toll, the explorer, who was recently reported to have perished in the Arctic Ocean, M. Doubrovin, Secretary of the Academy of Sciences, says that he has not received a word of news for some time. Another expedition is now searching for him.
PEKING, March 4. -- I have just returned from a tour of inspection of the railway outside the Great Wall between Shan-hai-Kwan and Niu-Chwang and the railway branch to Sin-sin-Tun.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A large number of applications already have been received by Admiral Walker, President of the Panama Canal Commission, for employment on the Isthmus. Engineers, physicians, draughtsmen, men with experience in the handling of large gangs of laborers, mechanics, clerks. and accountants are represented in the letters that have already come to hand.

LONDON, March 7. -- A Daily Mail correspondent, under date of Ping-yang March 3, describes the great difficulties to be met with on the road from Soul. He says that recent thaws broke up the roads, which again have become frozen over, while from time to time there are severe snowstorms.

Leon Melles, a theatrical manager, twenty-eight years old, who is known to the profession as "Lance de Melles," died yesterday afternoon in his father's apartments in the Parthenion, 400 Manhattan Avenue. Dr. C.W. Buffum, who attended him, said that death was the result of narcotic poisoning. Coroner Scholer, who was called into the case, thinks Melles was the victim of knockout drops.

To those of our readers who happened not to see THE TIMES yesterday we venture to remark that they lost a number of extremely interesting features, which, taken together with the usual variety of current news and comment, made a paper that we think compared favorably with any published in the city.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 6. -- Official dispatches received here concerning the bombardment of Vladivostok do not mention any Russian losses, but private advices say that five were killed, four sailors and the wife of an engineer.

District Attorney Jerome made a speech last Monday night at Lotos Hall, in which he said that the present excise law, or that part of it which applies to Sunday, was unenforceable by the local authorities. A TIMES reporter yesterday asked James C. Carter his opinion of the status of the law, and Mr. Carter said that he agreed with Mr. Jerome.

Philip Kelly, delegate of the Theatrical Protective Union; who is known to be a Tammany man, caused a sensation at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union by an arraignment of Mayor McClellan in reference to the closing of theatres declared to be unsafe. These theatres were closed as a result of an investigation into the safety of the theatres in New York, prompted by the Iroquois Theatre disaster in Chicago.

NEW ROCHELLE, March 6. -- The Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford in the People's Forum delivered an address on "Some Points On Which Employers and Labor Unions Ought to Agree." The Public Library Hall, which the forum calls its home, and which holds about 1,500 persons, was packed to overflowing with men and women.

In order to set aside any doubt as to the outcome of the second revision of the case of ex-Capt. DREYFUS, which has now reached an important stage, it is only necessary to remember that the decision of the Cour de Cassation in 1899, which sent the prisoner before a second court-martial, indicated obviously enough that the Judges were convinced of his innocence.

The volume of business in stocks last week was under a million shares, hardly more than half the previous week's business, and not much more than a good day's business when it is brisk. The business in the bond market, on the contrary, was larger than in the previous week, although scarcely more than half of the corresponding week in 1903.

A few days ago Judge HOSEA, sitting in the Superior Court of Ohio, at Cincinnati, made permanent a temporary injunction against the Journeyman Plumbers' Association and the Building Trades Council of that city, forbidding them from interfering in any way with the master plumbers or their employes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 6 -- President Mitchell said to-night that the situation between the miners and operators of the central competitive district had not changed since the adjournment of the joint conference yesterday.

We have not the slightest desire to discourage the utmost reasonable conservatism in the methods or theories of banking, but we cannot accept as a contribution to such conservatism the article in The North American Review by F.A. CLEVELAND, Professor of Finance in New York University, under the title of "Elasticity and Sound Banking."

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 7.--Fire supposed to be of incendiary origin started in the Lyceum Theatre at 11:15 o'clock last evening, and soon the entire block was a mass of flames. At 2:20 o'clock this morning the Realty Building, in an adjoining block, was apparently doomed.

PITTSBURG, March 6. -- It is said here that the soft coal miners, who failed to reach an agreement with the operators at yesterday's conference in Indianapolis, now will appeal to President Roosevelt to aid them in their attempt to secure better terms from the mine owners.
It became known yesterday that the aged woman who was removed on Saturday from 241 West Sixty-first Street was the wife of James J. Kelley, who years ago was a well-known minstrel.

For some time past the local Republican organization has been considering plans for strengthening the party in New York County and for having legislation enacted at Albany which would represent the particular work of the county organization -- "the committee's measures," in a word.

ALBANY, March 6. - That there is no just principle of taxation in this and other States, so far as personal property is concerned, is pointed out in the annual report of the State Board of Tax Commissioners. "The personal property situation is anomalous," says the report, "much depending, apparently, upon the Sherlock Holmes qualities of local Assessors.

It was announced at the meeting of the Trustees of Columbia University yesterday that the gift of $300,000 for the erection of a dormitory to be known as Hartley Hall, made by Mrs. Helen Hartley Jenkins, and Marcellus Hartley Dodge of the Class of 1903, had been increased by them to $350, 000.

ALBANY, March 7. -- Dr. Andrew S. Draper, President of Illinois University, will be elected by the Legislature Commissioner of Education in joint session on Thursday, and will accept the position. The new board of eleven Regents, which, with the Commissioner of Education, will administer the educational system of the State after April 1, will be as follows:

TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- Trenton is to-night facing the worst flood in the history of the city. Under the influence of the heavy rains of the last two days, the ice up the river is breaking and carried down on the flooded river is piling up behind the ice jam at Terriwig Bar.

ALBANY, March 7. -- With the assistance of four Democratic Senators, McCarren, Burton, and McCabe of Brooklyn and Bailey of Suffolk County, the Elsberg Coroners' bill was passed by the Senate to-night by a vote of 28 to 13. The bill would have failed if it had depended on Republican votes.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The report of Charles J. Bonaparte and Clinton R. Woodruff on their investigation of the alleged abuses and irregularities in the public service of the Indian Territory under the control of the Interior Department was submitted to Congress to-day by the President.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Mr. Lilley of Connecticut introduced a resolution in the House providing for an investigation into the cause of the present high prices of printing paper, and directing that the investigation shall be made by the Secretary of Commerce. The resolution, which went to the Committee on the Judiciary, follows:

The unexpected seems about to happen in the arising of the long-looked-for French Ministerial crisis, not about the large question of secular against religious education, but about the minor question of the personality of M. PELLETAN. Our special dispatches from Paris, in Sunday's paper, put our readers in possession of the facts.

OMAHA, Neb., March 7. -- A few days ago a local paper printed an item to the effect that the Rev. Charles W. Savidge, pastor of the People's Church, had performed 1,000 marriage ceremonies in his lifetime.

After making, for the first time, a public declaration of the fact that she was the wife of Joseph R. Wallach, who died a few weeks ago, Mrs. Sarah E. Wallach fainted in Surrogate Thomas's court yesterday. Mrs. Wallach applied to the court to have revoked the letters of administration which had been granted to Abraham R. Wallach, her late husband's brother, on the ground that she had been disregarded.
TOKIO, March 7. -- The Russians continue to push southward along the coast from Possiet Bay toward Song-Ching. The Vladivostok squadron is apparently covering their communications with Vladivostok.

The message sent by Gov. ODELL to Mr. CHARLES SPRAGUE SMITH and read at the meeting of the People's Institute, in Cooper Union, on Sunday evening, will reassure many persons who may have been in fear that the efforts of the owners of unreformed tenement houses, and of the speculative builders, to "take the starch" out of tenement house reform might be successful.

George H. Secor, who for almost twenty-five years was cashier of the freight department of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was lodged in the Tombs yesterday charged with embezzling $10,166 of the company's funds.
ALBANY, March 7. -- A bill which is understood to have been suggested by the Morse-Dodge divorce case was introduced in the Assembly to-night by Mr. Ellis.

The twelfth game in the pool tournament for the championship of Greater New York was played at the Broadway Billiard Academy. 1,947 Broadway, last night between J. Maturo and Thomas Burns, resulting in a victory for the former player. To-night's game in the series will be between Charles Otis and C. Grogan. The scores of last night's match follows:

About 3,000 bricklayers' laborers, belonging to the Laborers' Protective Union, went on strike yesterday morning a little ahead of the building season against a new rule of the Mason Builders' Association. This, if the day had not been so wet and stormy, would have thrown 3,090 bricklayers idle, but yesterday was a day on which little building could be done anyway.

LONDON, March 8. -- The Times says it has received from a trustworthy source the following translation of the text of a resolution carried by 215 votes to 40 at a meeting of the Institute of Mining Engineers at St. Petersburg on Feb. 23:

District Attorney Jerome's investigation of the causes that led to the collapse of the Darlington Hotel, on West Forty-sixth Street, last Wednesday, assumed true legal form yesterday. John Doe proceedings being commenced to fix the blame. Assistant District Attorney Train examined a number of witnesses in his private office.

Despite his check in the State Committee, Charles F. Murphy is going ahead in his effort to control the State Convention on April 18, and hopes to head off any instructions for the New York National delegation. He spent the afternoon at Tammany Hall with various district leaders and many of his closest advisers. In the evening, at his house in East Seventeenth Street, he saw many visitors, especially summoned to consult with him.
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the estate of Henry Honlein to Abraham Ruth the plot, 128.4 by 100.11, on the south side of Ninety-eighth Street, 96.8 feet west of Second Avenue.
PARIS, March 7. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch gives an interview with M. Kokovsev, the new manager of the Russian Ministry of Finance.
NEWPORT, March 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt have returned from New York.

M. Charles J. Murphy evidently thinks it to be his duty to defend Russia at all costs. This proves that he sees something to defend and that there is something wrong with Russia. Mr. Murphy contemplates the Russians through good-natured spectacles, evidently because of his prejudice in their favor and not on account of facts.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- The Smoot trial passed on to-day from the statement of President Smith, the head of the Mormon Church, to the story of a young woman who was the victim of the system of plural marriage since the Woodruff manifesto of 1890, which the Church claims has the force of a divine revelation forbidding polygamy.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 7. -- Eliza, probably the oldest and undoubtedly the most highly esteemed hen in New York State, is dead at the age of nearly seventeen years. She was hatched May 2, 1887, and had all her life been the special pet of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Harding.
BERLIN, March 7. -- The failure of Brendel Co., the oldest banking house in Berlin, was announced to-day. The firm was established in 1778.

BOSTON, March 7. -- It is learned here that Judge Aldrich of the United States Circuit Court has decided to grant the petition of Gardner Hall and others, bondholders in the White Mountain Paper Company, to be allowed to intervene in the suit of the North American Trust Company of New York to foreclose the mortgage under which the bonds were issued.

BOSTON, March 7. -- No effort will be made by American tennis players this year to recover the Dwight F. Davis International Challenge Cup, won last year by the Doherty brothers, and now held by the English Lawn Tennis Association.

The announcement wag made yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building that Mrs. Clemence Dodge would voluntarily go before the Grand Jury to-morrow. That decision was reached by her when she learned that so tangled had her matrimonial case become that ex-Justice Fursman had been impelled to rise in court and explain her position.

I read with some amusement a letter signed "A Priori," which appeared in your issue of to-day. He ventures to say "that there is not one Irishman in a thousand in this country who is not in favor of Russia in the present war." Now, this is his assertion, but where is his proof? Probably he is so impressed with himself that he is under the impression that he could alone constitute "a thousand."
WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Communication with New York to-day over the telephone was at a premium, especially between noon and 2 o'clock.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the International Salt Company was held yesterday. Frank D. Patterson of Philadelphia was elected a Director to fill a vacancy. Mortimer B. Fuller, Treasurer, stated at the meettn that the receivers of the National Salt Company have been diligently at work during the past year endeavoring to wind up the company to the best advantage, but have not yet completed their task.

LONDON, March 8. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the Novoe Vremya's approval of the decision of Russia in regard to privateers is given in the form of a fresh display of animosity toward Great Britain and America, who are represented as playing off against each other for selfish ends two dangerous powers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 7. -- A furious mob of 1,500 men to-night battered down the doors of the county jail, broke into the cells, and dragged a negro prisoner, Richard Dixon, who murdered Policeman Collis yesterday, into the jailyard, where he was shot to death, nine bullets being lodged in his body.
NEW ORLEANS, March 7. -- Aules, which won the fifth race by a head in a drive, was the only winning favorite to-day. The card was ordinary.

Considering the natural public interest in the subject, it is a disappointing answer to Controller Grout's suggestion that sewing, cooking, weaving, nature study, and other non-essentials be eliminated from the course of study in the public schools, which the special committee of the Board of Education makes when it says: "Such a proposal is revolutionary in its character and cannot be entertained for a moment."

Last night was model night at the corset show in Masonic Building, and men were admitted. Miss Elizabeth A.C. White, who tells women how to be beautiful, whether they were intended to be that way or not, had four living models whose figures, she said, were just what they ought not to be. Classified, they were the stout, the medium, the thin, and the "ingrowing."
Forbes Robertson's Hamlet was seen last night at the Knickerbocker, and was accepted, as it has been accepted by intelligent playgoers everywhere, as the one truly great Hamlet of the modern stage.
LONDON, March 8. -- Dispatches from Tokio speak of the sacrifices being made by the Japanese nation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 7. -- The United Mine Workers in National convention, before adjourning to-day, voted to refer the final decision as to accepting the wage offer of the operators to the locals.

Nearly half of yesterday's total transactions in the stock market, amounting to 290.936 shares, was recorded during the first hour. At the opening the market was sold rather freely by London and by local traders, in anticipation of the handing down of the long-delayed Northern Securities decision, and during the first half hour prices yielded readily to this pressure.

ALBANY, March 7. -- Senator Raines, when asked to-night what reply he had to make to the interview published with James C. Carter in THE TIMES, in which Mr. Carter gave it as his opinion that the Raines excise law could not be enforced, said:

TRENTON, N.J., March 7. -- Misappropriation of trust funds belonging to Miss Wilhelmina Weiters of Pennington, and a graduate of Pennington Seminary, is alleged in a suit for an accounting against Dr. Israel Hart of the same place before Vice Chancellor Reed in Chancery this morning. This complainant testified that the sum of $15,000 was left to her by her father in the year 1890.

ALBANY, March 7. -- "The first person to suggest to Charles F. Murphy the advisability of starting a Cleveland boom was none other than David B. Hill. I had this information from Mr. Hill himself in his own office."
ITHACA, N.Y., March 7. -- About forty Cornell freshmen appeared on the campus to-day bearing on their faces curious insignia placed there Saturday in connection with the first-year banquet.

The Presidents of three of the railroads concerned have replied to the committee of the Merchants' Association charged with the duty of securing relief for New York from the discrimination in freight rates against the city. On the whole their views are favorable to a reform, though they take somewhat conflicting positions as to the facts.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 7. -- "There is imminent danger of another great flood in this region," said Weather Observer De Main to-night. "The north and west branches of the Susquehanna and the Juniata Rivers are rapidly rising, and the indications are we will have the highest stage of water ever known in this locality.

WASHINGTON, March 7. -- Admiral Walker and Gen. Davis of the Canal Commission attended the meeting of the Senate Interoceanic Canal Committee to-day and gave their views on the bill of Mr. Kittredge, which places the civil control of the canal strip in the hands of a Board of Governors.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 7. -- Viceroy Alexieff has telegraphed the Czar from Mukden, under to-day's date, as follows:

Officers were elected and committees appointed for the coming year at the annual meeting of the Harlem Regatta Association, held at the Pabst in Harlem last night. It was decided to hold the annual regatta of the association on the Harlem River on May 30, as usual, and to also have a formal opening of the season in May, probably on Sunday, May 8.

Pro-Japanese sentiment characterized the speeches at the first annual dinner of the Wisconsin Society of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, the diners cheering loudly every mention of Japan. A live badger was stationed behind the speakers' table in honor of the State.

BERLIN, March 7. -- Sensational speeches regarding the Socialists and the army were made in the Reichstag to-day. Herr Riepenhausen (Conservative) openly discussed the possibility of a Socialist revolt against the Government, and congratulated the majority on having such an able War Minister as Gen von Einem.

A sad story was told at the American Theatre last night, when "Out of the Fold" was presented for the first time in New York. It concerns a young stranger with a past, Helene Grey, (Sylvia Bidwell,) who when the first act begins has settled down to practice virtue in a small country town.

There was much complaint yesterday at the calling of the Board of General Appraisers' March calendar by lawyers and importers against the working of Secretary Shaw's new rules for the government of the board. Notices were sent out seven days ago that 300 cases would be called. Only the Collector's members and the General Appraisers' members were given a description of the cases, and the lawyers had to spend several days establishing their identity.
ALBANY, March 8. -- The Educational Unification bill was signed to-day by Gov. Odell.

Applauded by more than 1,000 Brooklyn Democrats who crowded the gallery and floor of the little auditorium in the Thomas Jefferson Building last night, the stand taken by Senator Patrick H. McCarren against Charles F. Murphy was unanimously indorsed by the Executive Committee of the Democratic General Committee.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 8. -- The whereabouts of Capt. Reitzenstein's Vladivostok squadron is carefully guarded by the military authorities, but there is a strong impression here that when the seven Japanese warships appeared off the harbor Sunday and yesterday, the Russian squadron was outside.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- In a report to the Navy Department received to-day, Lieut. Frank H. Schofield, commanding the Supply, from Guam for San Francisco, tells of the observance on Feb. 28 last of three meteors which he says appeared near the horizon and below the clouds, traveling in a group directly toward the Supply.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The authorities of the Carnegie Public Library in this city have been called upon for a decision as to whether the works of Paine, Voltaire, and Ingersoll shall have a place on their shelves. A few days ago a committee representing the Washington Secular League waited on the Librarian and inquired whether books would be accepted from persons who desired to donate them.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 8. -- "The labor union is as much a menace to the community at this time as is the man who will corner some necessity of life and fix the price to suit himself regardless of the people," declared Judge C.C. Kohlsaat of the United States District Court, Chicago, to-night in discussing organized labor.

John A. Henneberry, Jr., twenty-two years old, son of J.A. Henneberry, Sr., Chief Clerk to District Attorney Jerome, killed himself in his bedroom at 171 East Ninetieth Street last night. The family says the young man accidentally shot himself while examining a revolver.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Denial is made, in a statement issued at the instance of his Government by the Japanese Minister here, of violations of international law alleged by Russia.

United States General Appraiser Fischer yesterday overruled a protest by Adolf Kraut of New York against the assessment at 35 per cent. on printed paper bags as manufactures of paper. The importer was also overruled on a protest against the classification as articles in chief value of metal, of metal foil lined paper bags. He claimed in each case that the goods were dutiable at 25 per cent. as printed matter.

There was another clash yesterday before the Board of United States General Appraisers over one of Secretary Shaw's new rules, for the government of the board. The objectionable rule this time was that requiring that samples be furnished by the importer every time a protest is suspended.

MOSCOW, March 5. -- (Delayed in transmission.) -- Russia's new strategical plan is much discussed, and the scheme of concentrating well back into Manchuria is regarded as eminently expedient, in view of the advanced condition of Japan's plans.

The brutal and cowardly murder of a negro prisoner in Springfield, Ohio, permitted by a pusillanimous Sheriff and an inefficient or faithless police force, might well be compared with the recent treatment of a like crime threatened in Mississippi to the sore discredit of the Northern community.

Cooper Union was crowded to its doers last night by men and women from all parts of the city who had come to participate in a mass meeting to honor the memory of Peter Cooper and to hear from such distinguished men as Bishop Potter, Andrew Carnegie, Recorder John W. Goff, and Edward M. Shepard something of the character and deeds of the founder of the institution.

So much criticism has been made of late regarding our public school system, the course of study, the methods employed, the immense amount of work imposed upon both teachers and pupils, that I feel constrained to add my voice to the general protest.

ALBANY, March 8. -- When Gov. Odell to-day saw in the Washington dispatches that he had been included in the list of the Congressmen and others who had figured in alleged Post Office "graft" he was highly indignant.

Mrs. Dodge-Morse-Dodge, who intended to go before the Grand Jury to-day for the purpose of telling all she knew about the Dodge-Morse matrimonial tangle, changed her mind yesterday, and now will not take any proceedings to interfere with an arrangement by which she will once more become Mrs. Charles W. Morse.

The now very general acceptance of the principle that taxation of real estate mortgages is an unsound practice is one of the most gratifying evidences of the spread of economic truth. A few years ago it was quite impossible to make legislative headway with a measure exempting mortgages from taxation.

The New York Produce Exchange Bank, which owns the property at the northeast corner of Broadway and Beaver Street, has bought the adjoining parcel, 12 Broadway, and will incorporate it in the site of its new building, work upon which will be begun on May 1. With this additional lot, which measures 23.6 by 68, the bank controls a plot fronting 73 feet on Broadway and having an average depth of about 50 feet.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Richard Canfield will be safe from further prosecution for any offense against the gambling law heretofore committed if the action of the Senate Committee on Codes on the Dowling bill is ratified by the Legislature.

Adele Quintera, a pretty little eleven-year-old girl, is missing. She disappeared on Monday, Feb. 29. She is described as a brunette, with brown eyes and curly brown hair, and at the time of her disappearance was wearing a green dress with a red velvet yoke and a mixed coat. Information in regard to her is solicited at Room 702, 93 Nassau Street.

Coadjutor Bishop Innocent of the Russian Orthodox Church, who was recently appointed to his position on this continent, arrived here on the North German Lloyd steamship Kaiser Wilhelm II, yesterday. Bishop Innocent will take charge of the Diocese of Alaska which, up to the present time has been part of the Province of North America.

I am surprised that from all the numerous letters you have received regarding the definition of wealth, there should be none more worthy of consideration than the contemptible one you have crucified for our amusement.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 8. -- Lieut. Commander Cutler, in charge of the Porto Rico Lighthouse Service, was arrested yesterday on complaint of the former crew of the lighthouse tender Nina, charged with false imprisonment and intimidation.

LONDON, March 9. -- Commenting editorially on the Far Eastern conflict, this morning The Times says: "The situation doubtless is continuing to develop as rapidly as the season, considerations of prudence, and the delays inseparable from a movement of troops on a great scale in countries where there are few practicable roads admit, but the military authorities on both sides are in the enviable position of being able to exercise a censorship unusually efficient.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 8. -- Threats throughout the day and this evening to burn the "levee," the negro district of the city, have confirmed Mayor G.J. Bowlus in his belief that more trouble is brewing to-night.

The American Locomotive Company has purchased the Locomotive and Machine Company of A'Iontrea. l, Limited, for $1,500.(KI0. Two-thirds of this will be paid in cash and $500,000 in 4 per cent. bonds. The financing of the purchase will be accomplished by the issue of $1,500,000 of 4 per cent. bonds by the Xmerican Locomotive Company.

Mr. ISAAC A. HOPPER, Superintendent of Buildings for Manhattan, has made a public declaration which it gives us sincere pleasure to record. It is: "No one will be permitted to violate the law with my knowledge so long as I am in this office."
BERLIN, March 8. -- In the Reichstag to-day Georg Ledebour (Social Democrat) in a spirited attack on the Conservatives, said:

Influences are being brought to bear on Gov. Odell to name Carlos C. Alden to be City Court Judge to succeed the late Judge Fitzsimons. Mr. Alden and ex-Judge William S. Bennet are candidates for the place.

-- That correspondent of ours who viewed with entire equanimity the fact that the Miller Gas bill, if passed, would necessitate the appointment -- and payment -- of a lot of new meter inspectors, expressed the confident opinion that, even if there were 500 of them, the difference an effective performance of their duties would make in the gas bills of consumers would leave to the latter a big profit after the salaries were paid.

Apparently the stock market has resolved to hibernate until it gets the Northern Securities decision. Weakness on Mondays, and inactivity and unimportant transactions in the intervals, have now become such a settled routine that something startling is required to alter it.

MORGANTOWN, West Va., March 8. -- The financial troubles of the Morgantown Tin Plate Company of this city came to a head to-clay when a petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed against the company by creditors.

Mr. Sam Franko brought to its close yesterday afternoon his series of three concerts devoted to orchestral music of a previous age in the new Lyceum Theatre. These concerts have all offered something of exceptional interest and value to lovers of the older style of music that never appears on the modern concert programmes.

It is unnecessary that the story about the Czar's desire for the mediation of some foreign Power to end Russia's war with Japan should be followed by any denial. The report carries its own denial and correction. Neither belligerent would ask for or accept mediation at the present stage of the conflict.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 8. -- At a meeting of the Athletic Executive Committee held last evening, L. Irving Beichner, '94, of Philadelphia, and Tracy H. Harris, '86, of New York City, were elected to serve on the Graduate Advisory Committee for another term of three years.

It was revealed yesterday by the report of State Appraiser William C. Wilson that Robert L. Cutting, supposedly a millionaire, was penniless when he died, on Jan. 13, 1894, at his Fifth Avenue residence. Not only was Mr. Cutting penniless, but he owed $150,000 to the estate of his father, about $17,000 to his brother, William Cutting, and $5,000 to his wife.

The many theories which have been advanced to explain the collapse of the unfinished Darlington apartment house in West Forty-sixth Street represent a great deal of wasted ingenuity. Among the explanations which have been suggested and have enjoyed brief acceptance among those not satisfied with the simple explanation that a building falls when it is not strong enough to hold itself up are the following:

There seems to be no question that we have now become a world power, not a plain, ordinary world power such as Great Britain, France, or Germany, but the kind of a world power such as has not been seen since the Roman Empire, with the possible exception of France under Napoleon I.

The colony of art dealers on Fifth Avenue is about to lose one of its members. Mr. Edward Brandus, who has imported many remarkable paintings by recent and old masters for his well-known gallery on that avenue, near Thirty-seventh Street, has met with an accident and determined to close his business, preparatory to a trip abroad to recover his health.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 8. -- At a meeting of the State Executive Committee of the Democratic and Conservative Party of Alabama action was taken permitting the name of Richmond Pearson Hobson on the official ballot for the primary of April 11.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 8. -- Viceroy Alexieff has sent the Czar the following message:

Commenting upon THE TIMES'S remark that Utah must either be demormonized or go without representation at Washington, The Hartford Courant inquires of us how, then, about the constitutional provision that no State shall be deprived of its equal suffrage in the Senate without its own consent.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 9. -- As an outcome of Monday night's lynching a mob of white men at 11:20 last night set fire to the saloon of "Les" Thomas, in the levee district, inhabited by negroes.

A spectacular raid was made yesterday afternoon on an alleged poolroom in One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, by Capt. McGlynn of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station. The evidence had been gathered by Detective Sergeant G.F. Darrow of Inspector Smith's staff.

LONDON, March 8. -- Directly after the outbreak of the war, says The Times's Russia correspondent, Russia found it necessary to allot 170,000 to strengthen the Department of Police. At Warsaw the Russian system of employing house porters as supplementary to the police was introduced on account of anti-Government protests connected with a demonstration in favor of the war which the Government attempted to organize Feb. 21.

Dr. W.G. Douglass and C.H. White were the winners in the amateur fourteen-inch balkline games played in the Fifth Avenue Hotel tournament yesterday afternoon and evening. In the afternoon Dr. Douglass at times played brilliantly in his contest with E.O. Presby, while in the evening game C.H. White was in excellent form and defeated F.M. Canda by a score of 300 to 215.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The most significant feature of the Smoot inquiry to-day was the discharge of President Smith and Apostle Francis A. Lyman as witnesses. The importance of this lies in the fact that thus far no witness has been asked any question bearing on political matters in Utah, Wyoming, or any of the inter-mountain States where the Mormons have strength of numbers.
PARIS, March 8. -- At the Saint Ouen races to-day the Prix Barfleur was won by William K. Vanderbilt's Quos Ego.

NEW ORLEANS, March 8. -- Favorites to-day had much the worst of a very ordinary day's racing. Stella Allen, who started for the first time in her new owner's colors, and New Mown Hay being the only successful first choices. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

In a recent issue of your paper there was published an account of an interview with Mr. Conried regarding ticket speculators. I am under the impression that Mr. Conried made the statement that he had done everything in his power in the matter and had encouraged his patrons to apply for tickets by mall.

LOCKHAVEN, Penn., March 9. -- Sherman Jamison, who is sought for the murder of Constable Deeman, was overtaken at an early hour this morning by a posse of officers, and a pitched battle ensued. Jamison escaped amid a shower of bullets.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 9. -- The race war situation early this evening was considered by the authorities to be more threatening than at any time since the beginning of the present race troubles. While Gov. Herrick has not proclaimed a state of martial law, such a condition practically exists in the down-town districts.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Mr. Harrison (Dem., N.Y.) has introduced in the House a bill containing fifty-four sections, providing for the construction of the Panama Canal and the government of the strip.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 9. -- As a direct result of the action of the Mexican Government in placing a duty on steel rails and other steel products, the great Hercules Iron Mines, situated in the State of Chihuahua, are to be developed.

Recorder Goff was not only amused but astounded yesterday when a prisoner for whom he had acted as counsel took the witness stand and confessed his guilt. The case in which this peculiar incident occurred was that of Siev Rief, the Bowery shawl peddler who was tried on a charge of smashing a window in a Bowery jewelry shop and stealing three imported clocks.
