ALBANY, March 9. -- District Attorney Jerome, at the hearing before the Assembly Codes Committee on the Prince bill to amend the Penal Code with relation to bribery of representatives of labor organizations, said that if the Prince bill became a law he did not think employers would take any chance in carrying walking delegates on their rolls or in bribing them to work injury to their competitors in business.

The annual meeting of the New York Civic Federation was held yesterday in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation, Oscar S. Straus, presiding. The following general board of officers was elected: Charles A. Moore of Manning, Maxwell Moore, President; William H. Farley of the Tile Layers' Union, First Vice President; Everet Macy, capitalist, Second Vice President; James P. Archibald of the Brotherhood of Painters, Secretary, and Cornelius N. Bliss, Treasurer.

LONDON, March 9. -- Considerable anxiety regarding Mr. Chamberlain's condition is being manifested on account of the circulation of reports among members of the House of Commons that he is suffering from an incurable mental affliction.

Miss N.H. Bennett, a trained nurse, who was attending the son of Charles K. Schumacher, at 110 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Tuesday afternoon went into a room on the second floor and saw a man's feet protruding from under the bed. The bed was disarranged, and she made it as if in ignorance of the man's presence.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- News from Washington of the appearance of Japanese forces at Feng-Wang-Cheng, about forty-five miles northwest of An-tung, in Manchuria, and Ta-shan, a few miles inland from the mouth of the Yalu River, is regarded as most important.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Representative George W. Croft of the Second Congressional District of South Carolina is so ill at his home here that hope for his recovery has been abandoned.
Secretary Taft in his speech at the dinner of the Ohio Society Saturday night used an argument hardly to have been expected from a Republican. He said:

Barring the inactive issue's, yesterday's trading in the stock market resulted in only very slight changes, the stocks in which the totals were largest varying a half a point or less from the closing prices of Tuesday. Prices declined a little, and then advanced a little, with the net results on the side of losses in most cases, but of such small proportions that the fluctuations were practically without significance.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 9. -- The five New York National League Baseball Club players, Bowerman, Mathewson, Gilbert, Minnehan, and Lynch, who left New York on the steamer City of Memphis last Saturday, arrived here at 5 o'clock this afternoon. The Memphis encountered a terrific storm off Cape Hatteras, and was driven out of her course three times.

Two well-played and interesting games were the result of the fourteen-inch balk-line billiard contests in the Fifth Avenue Hotel tournament yesterday afternoon and evening. In the afternoon the large attendance of enthusiasts were quite surprised at the defeat of F. M. Ganda by L. A Servatius, but in the evening contest E. O. Presby justly earned the decision over J. M. Millete.

ALBANY, March 9. -- The woman suffrage question had a legislative field day to-day before the Senate Judiciary Committee in the hearing on the concurrent resolution of Senator Stevens, which would give to the Legislature the power to grant to women in the cities the right to vote on school officers and to make them eligible for School Trustee or Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- A Democratic resolution for a full investigation of the postal scandal will be passed to-morrow by a Republican House that has run away from its leaders. It will be an investigation that will be thorough and merciless. The humor of the House is savage.
ROME, March 9. -- Upon the recommendation of Archbishop Farley, the Pope has conferred honors upon the most distinguished prelates in the Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The contested appointment of Gen. Leonard Wood to be Major General of the army was taken up to-day in executive session of the Senate, and, after listening to a brief prepared by the late Senator Hanna, summing up the testimony which had been given in the hearings before the Committee on Military Affairs, and several affidavits obtained since the hearings closed, the Senate adjourned.

In the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night James P. Silo sold at auction sixty-seven paintings from the collection of Edward Brandus, who is about to return to France. The total amount realized by the sale was $22,790.

DALLAS, Texas, March 9. -- Mme. Patti this afternoon canceled her date to sing at Dallas to-morrow night. She gave no reason and simply had telegrams sent from Louisville, Ky., that she was on her way East to catch an eastern-bound steamship at New York on Saturday next and would sing no more in America.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 9. -- The north branch of the Susquehanna River is a vast lake, sweeping in its path whatever there is to invade, and the scene is even more terrifying than on Tuesday. Industries all along the stream from Pittston to Nanticoke are closed down on account of the high water, and in many places water is flowing into the mines.

Raw silk statistics for the season from July 1, 1903, to Jan. 31. 1904, were given out yesterday by the Silk Association of America. In this period the exports from Milan to America amounted to 4,095 bales, each bale weighing 100 kilograms.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 9. -- Favorites had the best of the day's racing, the first four events falling to their share. The Messenger, who won the fifth, was a strong second choice. The weather was clear and the track fast.

William Schrieber, fifteen years old, a butcher's delivery boy, of 341 West Thirty-eighth Street, was run over by a heavy truck on which he was stealing a ride and crushed so badly about the head, at Forty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, that he died in a drug store before the arrival of an ambulance called from Roosevelt Hospital.
Chicago dispatches state that the mills controlled by the Paper Products Company have been allowed to resume operations after several weeks' shut-down.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 9. -- An attachment was issued here last night at the instance of the Chicago and Alton Railroad against the box office receipts of Weber Fields Company. They had contracted to take the company to St. Louis over that road, the officials claim.

Ferdinand Bonn is at the Irving Place Theatre again -- that supremely gifted character actor who has mistaken the versatility of his kind for universal genius, and goes wasting his time and our patience with Hamlet, fiddling, and playwriting. His present vehicle, however, is well within his powers -- which is about all that can be said of it.

Coroner Scholer selected a jury yesterday for the inquest on the bodies of the victims of the Darlington Hotel collapse. After the jurymen had viewed the ruins in Forty-Sixth Street, near Sixth Avenue, the Coroner dismissed them until 3 o'clock Monday, when the taking of testimony will be started in the West Side Court.

Unless some friend with doubtful kindness will take the trouble before breakfast this morning to send an inside tip from New Orleans to the Rossmore Hotel in this city that a certain horse is going to win, it is likely that Edward E. Gifford and his artificial leg, which for three days has been in a Third Avenue pawnshop, are likely to come together again.

Petitions are in circulation addressed to the National Conventions of the two political parties asking them to pledge their constituents to secure to the people of the Philippines independence upon terms similar to those under which Cuban independence was established. The committee that is circulating these petitions has adopted the name of "The Philippine Independence Committee."

BOSTON, March 9. -- Charles Thomas, aged twenty, and Eugene Stearns, aged twelve, runaways from New York, who were arrested, together with George Murphy and Levi Hogue to-day, charged with vagrancy, were thereby prevented, the officers claim, from attempting a robbery on Pearl Street.

Seeking to end all Tammany opposition to the candidacy of Judge Parker for the Presidency, friends of ex-Senator Hill and of Judge Parker are making overtures to Charles F. Murphy. Within the last forty-eight hours Mr. Murphy has been asked to co-operate with the Hill-McCarren forces for Parker.
BELVIDERE, N.J., March 9. -- The Rev. John W.K. Cline and his sister, Ruth, died yesterday from pneumonia within two hours of each other.

It is now said that Hill will name Grout for Governor to punish Tammany, if Parker be nominated for President. Instead of frittering away the State in this foolish fashion, it would be better for the Tammany and Hill forces to get together by compromising on Cleveland for President and Parker for Governor.
ALBANY, March 9. -- Politicians here see behind a bill introduced by Assemblyman Metcalfe to-day an attempt to Tammanyize the Board of Education.
TOKIO, March 9. -- Japanese warships bombarded the forts at Ta-lien-Wan (Dalny) last night and then attacked Fort Arthur.

Deputy Commissioner Henry F. Haggerty is expected to sever his connection with the Police Department before the close of the present week owing to serious differences between him and Commissioner McAdoo. Whether his resignation is already in the hands of the Police Commissioner was not learned last night, owing to the refusal of the Commissioner to discuss the matter.

While the north tube of the Hudson River tunnel, from Morton Street, New York, to Fourteenth and Henderson Streets, Jersey City, is practically completed, there remained yesterday about three feet of silt and sand between the shield face advancing from Jersey City and the bulkhead of masonry and timber built at the end of the New York boring, which extends 180 feet west of the bulkhead at Morton Street.

Mrs. Margaret Stonninger of 217 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street had a desperate fight with a sneak thief yesterday afternoon, and not only succeeded in forcing him to give up his booty, but drove him off minus his overcoat and inside coat.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Senator Tillman of South Carolina is ill with throat trouble.

VLADIVOSTOK, March 9. -- The Czar, in a message congratulating the defenders of Vladivostok, expressed his conviction that they would all make a rampart of their bodies to protect Russia's stronghold against the attacks of the enemy.

BOSTON, March 9. -- In the suit to invalidate the consolidation of various local gas companies, Robert Winsor of Kidder, Peabody Co. testified that his firm got a commission of $250,000 for its part in achieving the consolidation. He thought it would take $20,000,000 of stock to pay for the four Boston companies' stock and the expenses of the purchase.
ALBANY, March 9. -- Amendments to the five Interurban Railroad bills were to-day given to Chairman Bedell of the Assembly Commission on Railroads by Paul D. Cravath, the attorney for the company.

" For embalming and burying the body of Miss Agnes Fenton -- $1,080," is the substance of a bill against Victor R. Stowe which William J. Daregon, an undertaker of 954 Amsterdam Avenue, is seeking to recover by an action which he has brought in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Senate Committee on Inter-Oceanic Canals is considering the question of providing for the Government of the Isthmian Canal strip over which jurisdiction has been ceded to the United States by the Republic of Panama.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 9. -- A tennis match for $1,000 a side was played to-day between George McFadden of Philadelphia and Edward Crowninshield of Newport. The game was the outcome of a series of close matches between the two players. A large number of bets were made by the onlookers. Oliver Campbell, the ex-lawn tennis champion, was umpire.

Upon the call of Mayor Mark M. Fagan of Jersey City several New Jersey Mayors met at his office in the City Hall yesterday to take steps to keep up an agitation for equal taxation till a law compelling the railroads to pay the same rate of taxes with the adjoining property owners had been passed.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Owing to the fact that various witnesses, members of the Mormon Church, who were summoned to appear at the Smoot investigation failed to do so, the prosecution in the effort to unseat the Utah Senator has for the time being closed its case.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Senator Depew, in his speech on the Navy Appropriation bill, in advocating the policy of increasing the number of fighting ships, declared that we could raise an emergency army in a month, but it took five years to build a navy. In illustration of this he related the following incident:

In a runaway yesterday on the extreme west side, Mrs. Carrie J. Andrews of 540 West Forty-second street was killed and her daughter by a former marriage, Lottie V. Duncan, eleven years old, was injured, perhaps fatally. The horse in the fatal runaway was owned by Fullorede Luedecke, grocers, of 423 West Forty-eighth Street.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 9. -- Three swimming records were broken to-night at the Public Baths when the Brookline Swimming Club had its first open meeting of the season. Harry Le Moyne, the Harvard athlete, a member of the Brookline Swimming Club, defeated C.M. Daniels of the New York Athletic Club in the fifty-yard scratch race, winning in 0:27 1-5, and breaking the record by four-fifths of a second.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Ex-Senator John Ford to-day submitted to the Assembly Railroads Committee a bill which is a consolidation of the Elsberg Rapid Transit bill and the bills which the Rapid Transit Commission asked Senator White to introduce.

Flushed with preliminary victories, Japan's statesmen are doubtless dreaming of a great Mongolian empire in the Far East; but Russia's enormous reserve strength, which her diminutive but plucky antagonist cannot match, must win in the end, even if by the "attrition" tactics, so much relied upon by Gen. Grant in the American civil war.

ALBANY, March 9. -- District Attorney Jerome did not hesitate to express to-day his chagrin over the action of the Senate Codes Committee in amending the Dowling Anti-Gambling bill so as to prevent the reindictment of Richard Canfield for an offense heretofore committed.

The fact that the joining of the opposite ends of the Hudson River tunnel, if not already accomplished, is imminent, will perhaps surprise a great many people who have not followed the progress of this work during the past year. It is not long since the opening of communication under the bed of this great river would have been an event of momentous local significance.

Frequenters of the Bowery Mission, at 55 Bowery -- men who, for the most part, are glad of a place to sleep and a square meal, heard last night a lecture on the wonderful achievements and possibilities of modern psychology in its application to workingmen.

Because the pastor insisted on admitting a wine dealer to membership the congregation of the Lewis Avenue Church is split and the associate pastor of the church has resigned. The man whose admission has caused all the trouble is George E. Dewey, a wholesale dealer in American wines, whose place of business is in Manhattan.

Charged with the larceny of $20,000 worth of optical goods from the establishment of Emil B. Meyrowitz, 104 East Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, William J. Cooper, thirty-eight years old of 954 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, was arrested by detectives from the Adams Street Police Station, that borough, last night.

Feeling that the music-loving parents owe much to you and Prof. Edward C. McDowell for the stand taken in the musical profession, I wish to call their attention to the truth of the statement which he makes: "Until preparatory schools include music in their curriculum as one of the regular necessary studies, the education of the pupil will remain neglected."
LONDON, March 10. -- An extraordinary scene disturbed the customary decorum of the House of Lords this evening.

NEW ORLEANS, March 10. -- Curate's easy win in the race for the Bush Cup, worth $1,465 to the winner, was the surprise of to-day's racing. Major Mansir, bought some months ago by S.C. Hildreth with a view to winning the cup, was favorite and backed from twos to 7 to 5, while Curate was never better than 8 to 1 in the betting.

VICTORIA, B.C., March 10. -- Port Arthur is the main object of Japan's operations, according to Capt. Hill, who took the Japanese cruiser Nisshin from Genoa to Yokohama. Capt. Hill, who arrived here from Japan to-day, tells of a long conversation he had with the Japanese Admirals when in Japan.

In considering some of the phases of the delay in trying cases in this county, as presented by the report of the commission, it is interesting to note that the Federal courts here are much more expeditious than the State courts and compare favorably with the English courts.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Representatives of the State Niagara Reservation Commission and the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society and New York City business associations appeared to-day before the Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations opposed the Thompson bill to permit the Niagara, Lockport, and Ontario County-Power Company to get more power from Niagara Falls.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 10. -- On his return from New York to-day J.M. Guffey denied an alleged interview with him in New York in which Mr. Guffey was made to declare in favor of the nomination of Grover Cleveland for the Presidency.

BANGOR, Me., March 10. -- The Holiness Society's ministers, whose revival services on Beal's Island, in the coast town of Jonesport, have stirred the inhabitants to insane frenzy and the verge of murder, have been banished from the island by the Sheriff. He interfered just as the slaughter of children as sacrifices seemed imminent.
That the attendance upon church service is decreasing there is no doubt. We are therefore ask the question: Is it entirely the fault of the people, or are the clergy also responsible?

Suit has been instituted by Norman W. Halsey of the bond house of N.W. Halsey Co. against the Merchants' Trust Company of 320 Broadway, to recover on a block of five hundred debenture bonds of the Richmond Passenger and Power Company, which, the plaintiff claims, were surrendered by the trust company to G.E. Fisher in violation of trusts of which it had notice.

General plans for extension of the rapid transit subway were considered by the Rapid Transit Commission at a public hearing held yesterday afternoon in the board rooms, at 320 Broadway. The rival applications of the Metropolitan and Belmont interests for subway franchises occupied the bulk of the time, but several South Brooklyn people also were heard and sought to have the commission consider an extension in their direction.

When Second Deputy Police Commissioner Henry F. Haggerty was seen yesterday afternoon at his office, 16 Court Street, Brooklyn, he responded as follows to questions with reference to his reported resignation: "I am not going to resign, I am going to stay. I have had no thought of resigning." Not another syllable would the Deputy Commissioner utter.

As might have been expected, there is more rejoicing by the opponents of woman suffrage over the one woman who stuffed the ballot box in Denver, Col., than there is over the ninety-and-nine who cast their honest votes for pure government.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- An order was issued to-day by the President directing that all officers of the Government shall refrain from discussing the merits of the war between Japan and Russia and from saying or doing anything in connection with the war calculated to cause irritation.

Three Amateur Athletic Union championships will be decided within the next three weeks. On March 28 the boxing competitions will take place at the home of the Boston Athletic Association, the swimming championships of the Metropolitan District on March 19 at the New York Athletic Club, and the basket ball contests of the Metropolitan Association during the latter part of this month at the National Athletic Club of Brooklyn.

Two articles concerning the work of sending a trained nurse into the homes of the poor which have appeared in your valuable paper recently have attracted the attention of a lately organized body of women of the Abyssinian Church of this city, 242 West Fortieth Street. They are known as the Morris Association, and have organized for the same grand work.

ALBANY, March 10. -- After waging bitter political warfare on each other for years, David Bennett Hill and ex-Senator Edward Murphy of Troy met at Democratic headquarters in this city to-day and agreed to patch up their differences. Ex-Mayor Conway of Troy, who has fought Mr. Murphy in Troy politics in the past, but who has been on cordial relations with him of late, was also a party to the conference.

The Rapid Transit Commission is the best judge of the amendatory legislation needed to authorize the extension of the subway system. The commission has the confidence of this community. Not for a generation at least has any single body of public servants exhibited the qualities of ability, sound judgment, and efficiency in as high a degree as they have been shown by this board.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 10. -- An appeal to soft-coal miners to accept the proposed wage reduction and not strike is made in a circular letter signed by President Mitchell, Vice President Lewis, and Secretary Wilson. The referendum vote will be cast by the local unions Tuesday. The letter says in part:

JACKSON, Miss., March 10. -- Deputy United States Marshals to-day rescued James Griffin, a negro farmhand, at the point of their revolvers, from a state of peonage in Kemball County and removed him to Jackson. The Federal authorities had been informed that prosperous farmers in that section were holding negroes against their will and compelling them to remain on the cotton plantations, working like slaves.

TOKIO, March 10. -- The report of Vice Admiral Kamimura, in command of the second naval squadron, which bombarded Vladivostok last Sunday, reached the Navy Department here early this morning. It evidently came by way of Gen-san, where the squadron was expected to call upon its return.

For the golden wedding special preparations are made. There are different articles for the "fifty-year service," which have the outward and visible signs of gold, as a veneer, over silver, or in silver gilt. There are beautiful things in these pieces, and one may pay any price for them. None of them is unduly low in price, because they are made of the best of silver, in charming designs, and overlaid with 14-carat gold.

Senator RAINES of Canandaigua made rather a sorry spectacle of himself yesterday. It is difficult to characterize politely his denial of the statement of Senator DAVIS of Buffalo, that "the Raines law is responsible for the increase in the number of disreputable hotels." Every inhabitant of New York knows the statement to be true.

BUDAPEST, March 10. -- The obstructionist member of the Hungarian Diet have given up their fight, and the business of Parliament will be permitted to proceed. The scene in the lower house to-day when the hatchet was at least temporarily buried was extraordinary.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 10. -- At the Rhode Island Democratic State Convention held here to-day the Presidential candidacy of W.R. Hearst received a considerable impetus, six out of the eight delegates chosen to represent the State at the St. Louis Convention being Hearst men. Rhode Island is the first State to choose delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

ROME, March 10. -- The Giornale d'Italia asserts that the Holy Office, whose members are bound to the strictest secresy, has decided upon the excommunication of Abbe Loisy, who has refused to renounce his methods of Biblical research.

ALBANY, March 10. -- delegation of city officials and other citizens of Rochester appeared before the Barge Canal Advisory Board to-day and urged that a modification of the route of the proposed canal through that city be made so as not to include a part of the city park. A general discussion was had, and the board decided to visit Rochester and examine the territory before arriving at a final determination.

On Jan. 10 THE TIMES published a letter from Philip Rosenthal criticising one which I wrote to THE TIMES on Jan. 9 on the education of the children in the public schools, in which he says that everything under the sun has departed from the original intention. There is no question about that. The world keeps on moving.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 10. -- The Czar has received the following message from Viceroy Alexieff, dated Mukden, March 10:

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- President Roosevelt is taking a hand in the postal scandal in Congress. At his request Speaker Cannon, Chairman Overstreet of the House Post Office Committee, and Senator Penrose of the Senate committee visited the White House and talked over yesterday's development in the situation.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 10. -- The reports that the Japanese have entered Manchuria west of the Yalu River and have reached Feng-Wang-Cheng, on the Peking Road, which is the Russian line of communication to the Yalu, cannot be confirmed.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10. -- The worst rain and windstorm in thirteen years swept over this city and along the Pacific Coast to-day, doing much damage to shipping, railroads, and frame buildings throughout the State. The storm extended from San Diego to Vancouver's Island, and it is feared that many marine disasters have occurred along the coast.

" We rather expect a little better prices to-day and to-morrow, but confess we have no special reasons for it." This was one of the bulletins issued to their customers by Charles G. Gates Co. yesterday morning. It was a fairly good prediction. The market did go up a little, though just why it chose that rather than the opposite course no one knew precisely.

Americans will find particularly mystifying that dispatch from St. Petersburg, published here, and doubtless in every capital in Europe, yesterday, which sets forth that Russian diplomatists find our diplomacy mystifying. The statement to this effect has the form of a "communique" which in this case seems to mean a disavowable official communication.

There is no mistaking the intention of the Democrats of the South to let thrashed-out issues alone and go into this campaign on a platform that will stand some chance of winning. From all over the South the signs are that the Democracy is bent on cutting itself loose from a leadership that has been found wanting.

The feature of the Eleventh annual wrestling competition for the championship of the New York Athletic Club, which was decided in the gymnasium at the clubhouse, Central Park South and Sixth Avenue, last night, was the excellent work of Fred Narganes, who won first place in both the 145-pound and the 158-pound classes.

PARIS, March 11. -- In spite of official reticence and denials from the Japanese Legation here, it is again affirmed that a non-commissioned officer named Martin, who was employed in the Ministry of Marine, and who is now under arrest, attempted to sell French naval secrets to a Naval Attache of the Japanese Legation.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The March report of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture shows the amount of wheat remaining in farmers' hands on March 1 to have been about 132,600,000 bushels, or 20.8 per cent. of last year's crop, as compared with 24.5 per cent. of the crop of 1902 on hand on March 1, 1903, and 23.2 per cent. of the crop of 1901 on hand on March 1, 1902.

Although no formal action was taken yesterday, the members of the Plan and Scope Committee of the Rapid Transit Commission, at a meeting held at the board room, practically decided to reject Commissioner Best's plan for an elevated railroad to connect the Brooklyn. Williamsburg, and Manhattan Bridges.
PARIS, March 10. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch gives curious particulars in regard to the turn taken by Russian official Anti-Semitism in the war preparations.
PHILADELPHIA, March 10. -- President Cassatt to-day made a statement regarding the exact status of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's expenditures for improvements. President Cassatt said:

There was not a single transaction yesterday among a score of ordinarily active stocks. Among them were Louisville and Nashville, Wabash, Chesapeake and Ohio, Reading, and others equally or better entitled to be considered market leaders. The business done deserves even less attention than the business not done, for what was done was perfunctory, while what was not done challenges attention as a record.

PIERRE, S.D., March 10. -- The Coroner's jury which has been investigating the death of Miss Rena Nelson, who died from the effects of poison send to her in a box of candy, reported to-day as follows:
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10. -- The golf tournament and the shoot at the Gun Club attracted society to-day, while sailing and tea parties occupied many.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 10. -- Cornell's basket ball team was defeated by Princeton to-night by the score of 50 to 16. The play was fast throughout, but Cornell was clearly outclassed. Cornell played a very clean game, the work of Beesley deserving great credit. Vanderbilt excelled for Princeton. Batten played an exceedingly rough game.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for the City Real Estate Company 42 and 44 West Ninety-eighth Street, two five-story triple flats, each 25 by 90 by 100.

The fact that the companies engaged in the development of the telephone business are devoting a great deal of effort and money to the perfection of the automatic central switchboard indicates a belief on the part of those who are best able to form an intelligent opinion that a revolution is imminent which will dispense with human agency in connecting and disconnecting the instruments.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 10. -- The tenth event in the Winter's series of trap shooting tournaments, shot to-day, developed a close contest between Arthur C. Ketcham of New York, J.D. Wescott of Union City, Penn., and C.A. Lockwood of New York.

-- An unimportant, but none the less curious and interesting, feature of the Harrison bill for the administration of the Panama zone is its choice of the terms "Prefect" and "Sub-Perfect" as titles for the officers who are to do things -- or see that they are done -- for us in that region.

William H. Taft, Secretary of War, held a conference in this city yesterday at the offices of his predecessor, Elihu Root, at which were present at various times during the day a dozen or so of prominent financiers. The object of the conference was to ascertain how far the capitalists of Wall Street could be induced to assist in the development of a railroad and street railway system in the Philippine Islands.

LONDON, March 11. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that demonstrations in favor of the war, which were at first encouraged by the Russian Government, are now prohibited because it was found that they provoked counter-demonstrations.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10. -- The entire afternoon session of the House was taken up with a discussion of Assemblyman Miller's bill providing that suits in the name of a corporation shall not be instituted except with the consent of the holder of 20 per cent. of the capital stock of the company.

When on the French liner La Lorraine started on her voyage to Havre yesterday she carried among her passengers M. Bunau-Varilla, the retiring Minister from Panama to Washington, together with Mme. Bunau-Varilla and her two children. M. Bunau-Varilla said on the steamship that the end toward which he had been striving for ten years, the assurance of the building of the Panama Canal, was now gained.

While many suggestions are being made with reference to the construction and inspection of theatres and halls and churches the thought in my mind is that of equal importance with these safeguards is that of the instruction of the-audience. Panic comes through the ignorance of the audience as to the exact situation, and through an uncertainty as to what should be done.

The sale of the works of art of the collection made by Edward Brandus, which was begun on Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, was continued there last night by Auctioneer James P. Silo. Sixty-eight paintings were sold, bringing a total of $50,725 for the night, which, with the amount realized by Wednesday night's sale, brings the total up to $78,515 for 135 pictures.

Mr. ALFRED MOSELY, who is a sort of twentieth century Columbus, setting out from the port of London, to discover or explore the continent of American industry and education, has done us the honor to include us in the list of "prominent American newspapers" whom he has questioned as to the correctness of his views on the United States tariff.

CENTRALIA, Ill., March 10. -- The Democratic County Central Committee of Marion County met at Salem to-day to instruct for a candidate for State Senator. Then the convention proceeded, without the least shadow of right, to name Marion County's ten delegates to the State Convention and to instruct them for Hearst for President.

In speaking of the amendment to his bill directed against Richard Canfield, District Attorney Jerome said yesterday that he was unable to find how the members of the Senate Committee voted on the matter. "To my surprise," he said, "I found during my visit to Albany that the vote of committees of this sort is kept secret.

Had the trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday been conducted under the Marquis of Queensberry rules it would many times during the the five-hour session have been counted down and out. Repeatedly the tape was idle for minutes at a time, and the trading could lay no claim to being in the continuous performance class unless perchance it resembled those "turns" known to the initiated as "chasers."

At a meeting of the Stewards of the Jockey Club held yesterday afternoon, W. Shaw was granted a jockey license. That his application for a license would receive favorable consideration was practically guaranteed in advance by the provisional contract which the rider had signed with the late Mr. Whitney.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Senate to-day passed a bill authorizing the location of a light and fog signal, a lighthouse, and a light vessel at the entrance to Ambrose Channel, New York Harbor.
Developments during the last week or two in the cotton market have led to a great stiffening in the prices of cotton goods, and a sharp advance is expected Within a few weeks.

Magistrate Barlow was on the bench in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday when Policeman Ryer of the Church Street Station escorted a sad-eyed young man to the bridge. He said that his name was Thomas Kinney, and that he was employed as a guard on the elevated railroad.
MOSCOW, March 10. -- The Novoe Vremya condenses a fair amount of Russian opinion in regard to British neutrality in a single sentence.

Might it not be well for R.E.K., whose letter in your paper of to-day is headed "Women and Diplomacy," to study a little history before he makes such a statement as the following: "England for centuries, in the long chain of her history of wars, has never fought openly and single-handed another nation of her size, without a host of allies."

VIENNA, March 11. -- Count George Napoleon Csaky, Vice Secretary of the Hungarian Ministerial Bureau here, in a fit of insanity this evening jumped from a street car in the most frequented section of the Ringstrasse, and with a revolver shot a woman near him, wounding her dangerously. He was immediately arrested.

The press has already called attention to the bills introduced by the Committee on Railroads of the Senate, at the request of the City (Interurban) Street Railway Company, through its counsel, Messrs. Guthrie, Cravath and Henderson, and Lemuel E. Quigg.
NEW ORLEANS, March 11. -- Favorites were in good form to-day. Sharp Bird and Roue being the only ones to suffer defeat. In both of these races the winners were well-backed second choices.

BRIDGETON, N.J., March 11. -- The headless body of a woman, found incased in a cake of ice in the bay here yesterday, was identified to-day as that of Mrs. Martha C. Brennan of 397 Bridge Avenue, Philadelphia. The body of the man found in the bay by a posse sent out to look for the woman's head has not yet been identified.

In his "Principles of Wool Combing," which is being published by the Macmillan Company, Howard Priesiman tells how wool is washed, tested and softened, carded, combed, balled, etc. In his first chapter he describes the two divisions into which wool is divided -- that including the various classes suitable for the worsted trade and that containing the wools used in the clothing or woolen trade. Concerning these divisions the author writes:

A correspondent in New Orleans puts the case for the opposition very cleverly as regards the value, ethical and otherwise, of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden." The point of view being styled "curious" by the editor, I deem it may not be unimportant to state that I know of others so impressed by the faulty moral atmosphere of the little book as to prize its virtues of style lightly.

The January bulletin of the Massachusetts Bureau of Statistics of Labor gives in a discussion of the eight-hour day digest of the enactments of the various States, a summary of legal decisions upon these and related statutes, and an account of the experience of some Massachusetts cities and towns that have accepted the eight-hour day on public works.

" Copyright," forming Pages 889 to 976 of Vol. IX. of the Cyclopaedia of Law and Procedure, has been bound separately and issued by the editor of the article, Mr. Edmund Wetmore, sometime President of the American Bar Association. (American Law Book Company.)

ALBANY, N.Y., March ll. -- Norman P. Heffley, Charles Herman, F.L. Mark, E.J.Colcord, and B.M. Heffley are constituted a corporation to be known as the Brooklyn University, for the purpose of promoting literature, art and science, in a bill introduced by Senator Whitlock. The university is to be located in Brooklyn, and shall be subject to visitation by the State Board of Regents.

" The Sign of Triumph" is a romantic, historical novel. Its author aims to give a picture of that strange crusade of little children which in the first half of the thirteenth century sought to accomplish what the best warriors of Christendom had failed In -- the redemption of the Holy Sepulchre. This mad mediaeval thing left a trail of small whitening bones behind it and looked always in front for a miracle.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 11. -- Gen. B.F. Tracy, Secretary of the Navy under President Harrison and for a number of years a prominent breeder of trotting horses, has disposed of all his racing stock and retired permanently from the business. Gen Tracy, it is understood, has had this move in contemplation for a long time owing to the fact that it required more of his attention than he felt able to give.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 11. -- Boxing, Japanese wrestling, fencing, club swinging, and bar and flying ring performances formed the programme to-night of the most interesting gymnastic exhibition that has ever been held at Harvard. The exhibition was a dual meet between Harvard and Columbia.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 12. -- The Emperor has received a message from Viceroy Alexieff which says:

The "Hearst delegates" chosen by the Democratic Convention in Rhode Island on Thursday may become the supporters of some other candidate before they get to St. Louis. In the convention which selected them there was a contest, not at all over Mr. HEARST, but over the State patronage and for the control of the Democratic machine.

Speaking in her prefatory note to Janet Penrose Ward's translation of the second edition of Prof. Adolf Julicher's "Introduction to the New Testament," which G.P. Putnam's Sons have in preparation for publication next week, Mrs. Humphry Ward says:

Record-breaking prices for the season marked the close last night of the sale of ancient and modern paintings, comprising the collection of Edward Brandus, which was begun on Wednesday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by Auctioneer James P. Silo. The sixty-eight paintings sold last night brought $131,620, making the total proceeds of the sale $205,135.

I am surprised to reader in your issue of March 5 the following obiter dictum from your London correspondent, Mr. Alden "The only natural history any man ever wrote of himself was Ronsseau's Confessions." How about Benvenuto Cellini's personal memoirs, which I would place in the front rank of autobiographies?
URUMIA, Persia, March 11. -- News has reached here that Dr. Labori, (Labaree?) an American missionary, has been killed on the road to Khoi.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 11. -- The Michigan poison drinking experiment has ended, and the authorities announce that the four co-eds and eleven boys who drank an unknown poison in the cause of science are so far none the worse for their experiment.

THAT learned but dogmatic English student of literature, John Churton Collins, persistently holds to the idea that Shakespeare was reasonably proficient in Latin and Greek. In his newly published book of essays, "Studies in Shakespeare." which has not yet reached this country, he reiterates this theory.

" An Essay in Historical Social Psychology" is not, on its face, an attractive description of a book, especially one in a foreign tongue. But those who will take the trouble to read with any care the volume thus described by Louis Cazamian, (from the "Bibliotheque de la Fondation Thiers,") will find it amply repaying.

The Syracuse Journal has compiled some figures which, if correct and of current date, are certainly of much interest as bearing upon the provision of fire protection in cities. The number of hydrants, sometimes called fire plugs, per miles of main in twenty-eight cities is given as follows:

MR. FRANCIS W. HALSEY of the publishing house of Messrs. D. Appleton Co., has prepared a small book entitled "Of the Making of a Book," which is designed to instruct authors in the purely mechanical requirements of authorship, the preparation of manuscript, the correction of proofs, and the like.

" Conversational French" is especially intended for self-instruction, schools, families, or "Americans desirous of becoming French teachers." In the introduction the writer endeavors to show the best manner of studying French and his reasons for considering his plan the best. His method is to supply the pupil with two copy books, one entirely for French, the other entirely for English.
Mayor McClellan declared himself plainly yesterday as in favor of the proposed legislative bill making it a felony for any telegraph or telephone company to serve poolrooms with the results of races.

A new series of books for boys, to be called the Spanish Conquerors' Series, is to be written by Frederick A. Ober for E.P. Dutton Co. The books will be both biographical and historical in nature, and will tell the story of America's conquest by the Spaniards, with all the interesting incident, from the beginnings of the European invasion of the New World to the establishment of cities and governments.

BOSTON, March 11. -- William Monroe, President of the Custom House brokerage firm of Stone Downey of this city, the largest house of its kind in New England, was indicted by the Federal Grand Jury to-day as an accomplice in the alleged lace smuggling cases which Government officials have been investigating some months.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- With frantic shouts and wild cheers the House of Representatives to-day launched a Presidential boom for Speaker Cannon. It come as a climax to a savage debate on the postal scandal, in which attacks were made on the President by name.

MISS SINGLETON, who, in her "Furniture of Our Forefathers," established a criterion of choice for the collector and a guide which the connoisseur should be glad to avail himself of, has in her latest book presented a phase of her special theme, the utility of which is broader and the artistic function of which is much more comprehensive.

TACOMA, Washington, March 11. -- It is believed that the earthquake which devastated Lima, Peru, recently played pranks on the western Washington coast north of Gray's Harbor. Word comes to-day that the bed of Queet's River has risen about thirty feet, causing the river to form a new channel and making a big lake out of adjoining ranches that were formerly on high ground.

F.W. Parsons, in the current number of the Catholic World, adds his contribution to the never-ending discussion about "The Portraits of Dante." The article is well illustrated. Other noteworthy articles in this number are "The Early Bards of Ireland," by Robert M. Sillard, and "The English Bible Before the Reformation," by the Rev. George Joseph Reed.

EVIDENTLY Mr. Lafcadio Hearn intends that all the feminine readers of his "Kevaidan," or "weird tales," shall learn Japanese. He sets two vermilion characters on his title page and on each page of the "Kevaidan," and two more on each page of the three "Insect Studies" with which the book closes, and he says nothing at all, and this is alarmingly significant.
I find in this library two considerable books with the ex cathedra and uncompromising title "How to Study Shakespeare," by a Mr. (I suppose) W.H Fleming. Here are some extracts:

BALTIMORE, March 11. -- Cardinal Gibbons to-day came out vigorously against the "Jim Crow" car bill which the Democratic members of the Legislature now propose to make applicable to the Baltimore street railways as well as the steam railroads on the Eastern Shore. The Cardinal said:

In an address on "Suggestion and Crime" delivered before the members of the Patria Club in the Hotel Savoy last evening President Henry Hopkins of Williams College declared that the prevalence of crime in this country was greater at the present time than ever before, and that the very foundations of the National life are seriously threatened.

A. Rossi, Inspector of the Royal Emigration Department of Italy, who is now in this country, has written to Eliot Norton, President of the Society for the Protection of Italian Immigrants, an interesting-letter showing what the Italian Government is doing to control and regulate these immigrants.

In the fastest and hardest hockey game of the present season the Wanderers of this city, champions of the Amateur Hockey League of the United States, and the Victorias of Montreal, the second team in the Canadian championship series, played a tie game at the St. Nicholas Rink last night, the final score being 8 to 8.

In a recent public address Dr. V.C. VAUGHAN, Dean of the Medical Faculty of the University of Michigan, gives the following instructive account of how a threatened epidemic of typhoid was averted at Ann Arbor, which we commend to the consideration of college and university authorities in all parts of the country:

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Senaorial inquiry instituted at the request of Senator Dietrich of Nebraska into the bribery charges dealing with the appointment of the Postmaster at Hastings, Neb., and under which the Senator was indicted last Fall began to-day, Senators Hoar, Platt of Connecticut, Spooner, Cockrell, and Pettus constituting the investigating committee.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Senate to-day, in executive session, considered the nomination of Gen. Wood at length. Two set speeches were made in opposition to Gen. Wood's confirmation, the speakers being Senators Scott and Blackburn.

" A Greek Primer," by Clarence W. Gleason of the Roxbury (Mass.) Latin School, is published by the American Book Company. The author admits that there is no workless Greek book, even in this age of horseless carriages and wireless telegraphy; to attain the little knowledge requisite to carry on the study of Greek in school or college careful attention, common sense, and some study are necessary.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- E.B. Critchlow, formerly Assistant United States District Attorney for Utah, who was the only witness at to-day's session of the Reed Smoot inquiry, gave some testimony that shed an interesting light upon the relations of the Mormon Church to business enterprises in the State of Utah.
As the author of "Essays in Political Economy," dedicated to Cardinal Gibbons, I am greatly interested in your editorial: "What is Wealth?"

There is a considerable agitation in the literary circles of London about a Shakespeare memorial in that metropolis. Considering the ill-success of most of the Shakespeare memorials erected elsewhere in England, the attempt to get something seemly and appropriate out of a memorial in London is not promising.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Representative Cooper of Wisconsin was explaining in the House to-day the difference between his attitude on the Bristow report now and his attitude Wednesday. Then he was denouncing the report as an assault on the reputations of Congressmen and demanding an investigation. Now he was taking a different view and was explaining that his remarks of Wednesday were humorous.

This volume on the French Revolution ("The French Revolution," by W.E.E. Lecky, 12mo. cloth, Pp. 585. New York: D. Appleton Co. $1.25 net) is made up of the three chapters from Lecky's "History of England in the Eighteenth Century." He discusses the causes of the French Revolution and describes its progress until the outbreak of the war with England.

New Mount Sinai Hospital was thrown open for inspection to the press yesterday. The buildings, with the air space courts, occupy every inch of the block extending from Madison to Fifth Avenue, and from One Hundredth to One Hundred and First Street, ten buildings in all, connected by corridors on the ground floor, with the exception of the isolation house, designed for the accommodation of persons suffering from contagious diseases.

The "Letters from England, 1846-1849," by Mrs. George Bancroft, fragments of which have appeared in Scribner's Magazine, will be brought out in book form by Charles Scribner's Sons March 26 with twenty-four full-page illustrations. This new collection recalls Mme. Waddington's "Letters of a Diplomat's Wife," published last Autumn.

BOSTON, March 11. -- Franklin T. Hammond of this city was appointed receiver of the Atlas Mutual Fire Insurance Company to-day by Justice Barker of the Supreme Court. The receivership is a result indirectly of losses aggregating about $70,000, entailed by the recent Baltimore and Rochester fires.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The Cabinet to-day discussed the press reports that Capt. Sawyer of the United States gunboat Helena, now in mud dock at Niu-Chwang, has protested against the sinking by the Russians of junks at the entrance of Niu-Chwang Harbor.

A pretty romance translated from the Swedish of Viktor Rydberg is the story of "Singoalia." A legend preserved from the days of the armored knights, it may also be vested with that allegorical significance that envelops most legends. The young knight Erland, wandering through the woods surrounding his father's castle, meets and loves a beautiful gypsy girl.

The reviewer who stares at the ocean of modern poetry is occasionally visited by a shock of wild surmise when something that seems to be of -solid worth looms upon the lonely horizon. The first poem, entitled " In Saecula Saeculorum," of a small volume of "Random Verse" by Hermann Knickerbocker Viele causes that welcome sensation.
LONDON, March 12. -- The Times's military correspondent, discussing the situation in the Far East, says:

Mayor McClellan of this city lately wrote to its President. John B. Adger: "It is a privilege to testify to the work of the Young Men's Christian As[ sociations in all Darts of our country.
Replying at some length to our recent remarks upon REED SMOOT'S case, The Hartford Courant observes:

I notice that Assemblyman Perham has introduced a bill in the Assembly, ostensibly to lessen the law's delay, providing for the appointment of three Commissioners in the First Judicial District, which is New York County, Who are to hear appeals from the decisions of the City Courts of New York.

There are also two new books this week treating of the life and labors of Leo Tolstoi. Mr. T. Sharper Knowlson is the author of "Leo Tolstoi: A Biographical and Critical Study." His aim has been "to trace the development of Tolstoi's ideas and to examine them in the light of modern knowledge." He thinks that the prevalent conception of his hero in England is that of "a great man gone wrong."

I SEND herewith a list of book on the Far East, all or any of which will be of interest to the general public at the present time, and can be obtained at most any of the public libraries The Queens Borough Library has them all, and it is likely that all of the circulating libraries have them also:

English is a grammarless tongue, according to the latest pedagogues. Prof. William Nicholas Hailmann and Frederic Manley have written a text book on "The English Language" based on this idea Prof. Hailmann has been for many years at the head of German-American schools in Milwaukee, Detroit, and other Western cities.

NINETY-FIVE years after the death of the famous English soldier, Sir John Moore, his diary has been brought to light and published by a distinguished military critic. A copy of the diary was found among the papers of Sir William Napier, in the handwriting of Lady Napier, who was Caroline Fox, niece of the statesman.

ALBANY, March 11. -- A State Board of Expert Sanity Inspectors, to be stationed at Ellis Island, to inspect immigrants as they land, with a view of detecting those in such stages of mental decline as would lead to their becoming a public charge, is provided for in a bill to be introduced to-day in behalf of the State Commission in Lunacy.

The Very Rev. Thomas Joseph Shahan, D.D., J.U.L., etc., professor of church history and patrology and lecturer on Roman Law, at the Catholic University at Washington, author of "The Blessed Virgin in the Catacombs," "Giovanni Battista de Rossi," etc., has with Longmans, Green Co., a volume entitled "St. Patrick in History." in which he expresses himself in fine Irish eloquence concerning the saint's position in history, legend, and myth.
LONDON, March 12. -- The Tokio correspondent of The Standard says refugees from Niu-Chwang report that the Japanese are landing at a small bay on the Liao-Tung Peninsula.

Four men played at cards for gold, or was it five men? A beautiful lady was present. One of the men accused another of the men, who happened to he the lady's father, of cheating: then shot him dead. Next, the murderer tried to carry off the lady. But the other three men with one accord fell upon their knees and offered the lady their hands and fortunes.

THE purpose of this book is to prove that expansion is writ large on every page of American history and that individuals or parties who oppose our recent annexation schemes are either densely ignorant or willfully captious.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 11. -- These charters were secured at Dover to-day:

The patient, tender strength of Martin Heritage, the reverent conscientiouness of his work, and his fervent Methodism suggest a composite photograph of Adam and Seth Bede, while we cannot held discerning in the shallow Susan, enamored of her own beauty, a distant kinship to Hetty Sorrel.

Just as the Chicago Limited of the Pennsylvania Railroad was about to leave Jersey City yesterday at 5:15 P.M. a young man boarded the rear car. Rushing up and down the aisle, he warned the passengers to leave the train at once.
LONDON, March 12. -- Cabling from Yin-Kow, a correspondent of The Daily Mail says the British and American gunboats at Niu-Chwang have received orders to sail as soon as the river opens.

Ex-Mayor Smith Ely has sold the plot of about six lots on the south side of One Hundred and Second Street, beginning 570 feet east of First Avenue and extending to the marginal street along the Harlem River. Ex-Mayor Ely bought the lots at auction several months ago.

Arrangements were perfected yesterday by which Wilson P. Foss will visit Paris to play a match game for the world's championship at 18-inch balk-line billiards with Rerolle, the match to take place March 28.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- James M. Burke, who says he is a minority stockholder in the Hawthorne race track, has filed a bill in the Superior Court asking for the appointment or a receiver for the Chicago Racing Association, and for an injunction restraining the selling of pools and betting on races at the track.

There is a sneaking fancy in the reader's mind after finishing "The Woodhouse Correspondence" that the authors would "hold, as 'twere, the mirror up to nature," and with these studies in conceit and selfishness "pluck off our beards and blow them in our faces, tweak us by the nose," and show us ourselves for what we are.

LONDON, March 11 -- There has been much curiosity about the first novel of Gilbert K. Chesterton, the brilliant, if paradoxical, essayist and biographer. Its title, "The Napoleon of Notting Hill," was announced some time ago.

IT is charming, in its leisurely way, and most unmistakably English, this book of meanderings and memorabilia in Sussex. Doubtless to the discerning British eye, (even quite unaided by outside knowledge and plentiful admissions in the text.)

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Representative Malcolm R. Patterson of Tennessee, in speaking to-day on the Democratic Presidential situation, said: "While it is apparent that Mr. Hearst has some friends in the South, I would regard his nomination for President as a great mistake, as his defeat would be certain and inevitable.

TACOMA. Washington, March 11. -- An epidemic of Post Office burglaries in Western Washington has startled Federal officials. Great efforts are being made to locate and capture the band of daring men who are making specialty of carrying away Post Office safes.

A decision rendered yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirms an order of the Surrogates' Court permitting the administrators of the estate of George F. Gilman to compromise and settle a claim against the estate made by Mrs. Helen Potts Hall. The claim was compromised at $60,000, of which $20,000 was to be paid in cash and the balance in shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.
Will you permit me to correct a mistaken impression that is contained in your editorial article this morning on rapid transit legislation?

Mr. Linn Bruce, who was Chairman of the Republican County Committee during the last campaign, told the New York alumni of Lafayette College at their annual reunion at Delmonico's last night that they were living in the best city and under the best government in the world.

Probably nothing will be looked forward to with greater interest in Herbert Spencer's "Autobiography." to be published within the fortnight, than what he has to say in regard to matters of religion. The following paragraphs, the closing ones of the work, although but a crumb from the banquet gone before, serve to show the attitude of mind with which he approached this greatest of questions and the result of his lifelong search for truth:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 11. -- Charles W. Morse, who has been staying at the Lakewood Hotel since Thursday afternoon, hastily departed for Philadelphia on the late afternoon train to-day after a long talk over the telephone with Lawyer Untermyer in New York. He said he was going to spend a few days in Philadelphia.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 11. -- The fencing team from Columbia was badly beaten by the Cornell swordsmen here to-night, the visitors winning only two out of the nine bouts.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., March 12. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dwyer received a cable dispatch from Port Arthur to-day informing them that their son Thomas had been injured and would not live throughout the day. The young man was employed as a tankbuilder, and left here three years ago. It is supposed he was injured during the Japanese bombardment of the city.

Yesterday's stock market was of the sort with which this season's Saturdays have familiarized Wall Street's habitues. In part it was a reflection of disagreeable anticipations of Monday's bringing the Northern Securities decision. And in part it was a somewhat excessive open-mindedness toward the unfavorable suggestions always put about when the market is in this temper.

Now is the time for all sane Democrats to take a firm hold on some good anti-panic remedy. There will not be the slightest reason for alarm if they do, for in that case neither of these two men will be nominated. The only possible chance for either of them is from a demoralized leadership, and that hasn't appeared yet.

Sympathy must flow out freely from the most stony-hearted to the poor Consoliadated Tobacco Company, which has been obliged to pass its dividend, and to its dozen or two of stockholders. Last year they received 20 per cent. on the, $30,000,000 that they had invested, and this year they have received -- up to the present time -- nothing on $40,000,000.

The letter of "O.T. Alp," which you so thoughtfully published for our instruction and delight to-day, makes the writer think of the time when he really read such complaints seriously and was, consequently, always very much worried. The man with a grievance -- or is it a woman? -- is sure of finding some kindred souls who sympathize with him.

If Ban Johnson, President of the American League and Frank Farrell, Treasurer of the New York American League Baseball Club, met yesterday to have a conference regarding the change of the opening date of the New York Club in this city, the meeting was of the "gum shoe" order. To inquiries at the hotels most frequented by both gentlemen the clerks' response was "Not here."

Following the resignation of Third Deputy Commissioner John F. Cowan, rumors that First Deputy Commissioner Thomas F. McAvoy and Second Deputy Commissioner Harry F. Haggerty would also resign in the near future were persistent at Police Headquarters yesterday, although they could not be confirmed.

Many of the diners at Delmonico's Fifth Avenue restaurant yesterday noticed, that Giacomo Imperatori, the young leader of the orchestra who had waved the baton there every afternoon and evening during the last two years, was not in his accustomed place in the balcony, and that another was in charge of the music.

WHITE HOUSE, N.J., March 12. -- The mystery surrounding the poisoning twice within a few days last January of the family of Postmaster J. Van Nest Stillwell has been dispelled by the confession of Alice Price, sixteen years old, a colored servant employed by the Stillwell family. Mr. Stillwell yesterday found a box of rat poison in a different place from where he usually kept his supply, and his suspicions were aroused.

CHICAGO, March 12. -- An explosion in the Police Department is expected when the findings of the New York detectives who shadowed the Chicago patrolmen on their beats to learn to what extent they neglected their duty, are made known. Within ten days a complete report will be made to the City Club, under whose auspices the investigation was carried on.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The London Sun's "Man in the Street," impatient with some of the editorial comment on the war says: "I remember an action in which the counsel concerned were the late Samuel Banks Waddy, K.C., and the late learned Seymour, K.C., whom the learned Waddy would insist upon calling 'Mr. Saymore.'

In the interest of the traveling public who for years must use the Williamsburg Bridge there should be a concerted effort by all public-minded citizens to prevent the blunder in terminal arrangements which has proved a crying disgrace at the City Hall terminal of the old bridge. Women and children are trampled on at the trolley ioops every evening, and the press and the pulpit have agitated in vain for improvements.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 12. -- The New York National League baseball team had a batting matinee in to-day's practice contest against the local Young Men's Christian Association team that would have given Polo Grounds "fans" something to talk about for many days if displayed at home.

PARIS, March 12. -- An informal suggestion that France and the United States act jointly as peacemakers in the Far East has been made within the past week, and, although the officials consider that any peace overtures would be futile at the present stage of the conflict, yet the suggestion leads to the belief in very high quarters that France and the United States will become the eventual peacemakers.
TIEN-TSIN, March 12. -- The first credible reports of the effect of the bombardment of Port Arthur from midnight on Wednesday to past noon on Thursday which have been received here arrived to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 12. -- Six of the eight delegates to the St. Louis Convention chosen at the Democratic Convention on Thursday formally organized today. Resolutions were adopted supporting William R. Hearst of New York for President and declaring in favor of the "unit rule" in voting at St. Louis.

PARIS, March 1. -- In the ordinary course of events one would hardly look for so great a functionary as the Prefect of Police at the bottom of a well, yet that is exactly where the remarkable activity of M. Lepine led him one morning this week.

William F. King of the firm of Calhoun, Robbins Co., who returned last week from a Southern trip, during which he visited Palm Beach, Jacksonville, Miami, and Nassau, and during which he talked with business men from all sections of the country, declares that all those whom he met are unanimous in declaring that the country was never in better shape for business than it is to-day.

Payne is busy getting more "orders" for the theatre. In his next letter, of the Wednesday following the previous note, he mentions four tickets "and more, if possible. Use the orders, or give them away, whichever you may find most agreeable." He continues:

One of the witnesses before the Senate committee which is considering the case of REED SMOOT testified that there were 10,000 "Elders" in the Mormon Church. That is a startling figure. Because a Mormon Elder is to a great degree what is known in ecclesiastical language as a missionary, and in secular language as a "drummer."

MOBERLY, Mo., March 12. -- A peculiar deed recently discovered conveys 120 acres of land near Darksville, Randolph County, to Jesus Christ. The deed was made in 1850 by Johnson Wright and Eliza Jane Wright, his wife, and has never been contested. The descendants of the couple have held the property "in trust" and have thrived upon it.

In a posthumous work of Charles Waldo Haskins -- "Business Education and Accounting," just issued by Harper Brothers, about a year after the death of its accomplished author -- are found data somewhat scattered, but available if sought, respecting the methods of accounting and bookkeeping of ancient and primitive peoples.

BERLIN, March 12. -- The Spanish Queen Mother wrote to the Emperor recently saying that she very much wished to present her son to him, and the Emperor accordingly, while on his way to the Mediterranean, will receive the young King on board the Koenig Albert at Vigo, to which place King Alfonso will go on a yacht.

As a consequence of the practical concession by Tammany men yesterday that David B. Hill would have nearly two-thirds of the delegates to the Albany State Convention April 18, it was declared in seemingly authoritative quarters that what might be called an understanding between the supporters of Chief Judge Parker and Charles F. Murphy was definitely in sight.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., March 12. -- Wolverine, the ice yacht owned by Commodore D.C. Olin of this city, captured the two remaining heats in the Stuart International Trophy race at Gull Lake to-day. The race was over the twenty-mile, two-point course, and the times for the two heats were 61 and 42 minutes, respectively.

DOYLESTOWN, Penn., March 12. -- Rev. R.M. Labaree, pastor of the Presbyterian Church here, and son of Dr. Benjamin Labaree, said to-day that he had not received official notice of his father's assassination, and knew nothing of the tragedy but what he saw in the newspapers. He said that his father had been a missionary for a great many years, and never held a charge in any American church.

As a result of lack of finances, Ward 111, the female surgical ward of Roosevelt Hospital, has been closed. This makes the third ward to be closed in large hospitals in this city within a short time. The New York Hospital was compelled to close a ward, and recently the Manhattan Eye and Ear Infirmary closed a pavillion on account of lack of funds.

SUCH marvelous achievements as the measuring of candle light six miles distant or the splitting of a human hair into a thousand widths are among the accomplishments of the Government's Bureau of Standards, recently established at Washington, to supersede the Office of Standard Weights and Measures.

A MID-LENTEN wedding is certainly a novelty in society, and no one invited on Monday at noon to the ceremony that made Mrs. Pauline Cory Gallatin Mrs. Joseph S. Ulman neglected being present in St. George's Church. The bride, a slender and pretty young woman, chataigne in coloring, wore a broadcloth gown of very pale bluish gray.

Mayor McClellan anounced his appointments yesterday to fill the Municipal Beautification Commission, which is to devise a plan for the grouping of city buildings, the laying out of parks and boulevards, arrangement of streets, and the improvement of the aspect of the water front.

LONDON, March 12. -- Absence of activity and lack of public interest continue to characterize the stock market. Business this week was extremely light and price changes almost devoid of significance. As a rule steadiness pervaded the several departments.

We have at last passed through two months of weather the most unfavorable imaginable for railroading, and the net earnings for the first month -- January -- are at hand. Under the influence of temporarily demoralizing conditions, a decrease in net earnings has been scored, as large as the increases used to run in the times of unmixed prosperity a year or so ago.

Recent agitations at other colleges over the honor system of conducting examinations have caused Columbia's students to consider the project as a serious need to fair and hottest work in the examinations on Morningside Heights, and meetings of the different classes have been held all during the past week to discuss the plan.

Attention was drawn to the extent of the trade in American wines by the organization a few days ago of the American Wine Growers' Association at a convention held in the Astor House. Representatives of the leading wine growers of the United States were there, and the most notable feature of the convention was the decided stand taken against the practice of selling wines grown in America under foreign labels.

That it has been a remarkably severe Winter no one will deny, and the rubber shoe men are hugging themselves with satisfaction. The fact that for more than three months there has been almost continuous snowy or wet ground has meant millions of dollars to the makers and handlers of rubber shoes and boots.

Since DARWIN propounded the theory that we are descended from the monkeys such occasional evidence of the intelligence of that animal as may have turned up has been received with satisfaction as giving token of the superior mental powers of our ancestor.

It is more than likely that the patrolman who answered Mrs. Charles F. MacLean impertinently, apparently secure in the belief that nobody would ever hear of it, will regret his conduct, for instead of continuing on her journey she took the pains to go to Police Headquarters and accuse him of "unbearable insolence."

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- E.B. Critchlow, formerly an Assistant United States Attorney in Utah, again took the stand when to-day's session of the Smoot inquiry opened, and testified regarding Mormon dictation in State and National politics.
LONDON, March 1. -- " Pardon me," said the man who sat next me at the Shire Horse Show on Wednesday, "if I yield to the temptation to tell you of a discovery I have just made.
T WASN'T really my own idea to play Hamlet," said Mr. Forbes Robertson.

TRENTON, N.J., March 12. -- The Jefferson Democratic Club of this city celebrated the anniversary of Jefferson's birth tonight. The feature of the affair was a letter from the leader of the Democratic minority in the National House of Representatives, John Sharp Williams of Mississippi. Mr. Williams said:

It is not at all surprising that the President of Williams College, surveying his country from the window of his study in the tranquil Berkshires, by the more or less uncertain light of the daily or weekly, especially weekly, newspapers, should take a gloomy view of the advancing tide of crime and vice of which he has access to the partial record.

Importers of St. Gall embroideries and laces held a meeting early in the week to consider the new plan of the Treasury Department for fixing valuation of goods sent by the foreign manufacturers to their selling houses in this country. There being no selling price abroad, the practice has been to add to the actual cost of manufacture 5 per cent. for general expenses and 8 per cent. for profits on staple lines of goods.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 12. -- Small dinner parties are the most fashionable form of Lenten entertainment at Lakewood just at present. These parties usually consist of three or four guests -- never more than six -- and the Lakewood Hotel's big dining room is always crowded in the evening.

The proposition contained in the bill of Congressman Lewis of Georgia to allow National banks to loan on real estate to the amount of 25 per cent. of their capital is by no means new, but in its various forms it possesses an apparent attractiveness to certain interests strong enough to demand for the measure quick condemnation by any one who has an eye to preserving the health of the National banking system.

IT HAS been "deadly" dull the past week. New York society is scattered, and many of its representatives are in various parts of the South. This year new resorts and new excursions have been discovered, and although it has been an excellent year for Florida, Cuba, Mexico, Arizona, and the Antilles, and even South America, have had visitors from the North.

THE doors of the Metropolitan Opera House have finally closed upon the first season of Mr. Heinrich Conried's management, after the usual number of lingering "last" performances -- the last subscription night, the last matinee, and finally the completion of the special cycle of "Der Ring des Nibelungen" that brought the end of things over into the week just past.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 12. -- Gen. Kuropatkin, accompanied by his entire staff, left here at 6 o'clock this evening on a special train for the Far East, where he will take command of the Russian Army.

The strike of the bricklayers' laborers reached a stage yesterday which threatened to make its effects very far reaching. In anticipation of a possible struggle involving the entire building industry, notwithstanding the arbitration agreement, the Building Trade Employers' Association is preparing to strengthen its organization by bringing in the employers in the States of New Jersey and Connecticut.

AMONG the queer tricks played by flashes of lightning is that of photographing a steamboat on a plate-glass mirror. The mirror was sent from Chattanooga, Tenn., to Decatur, Ala., by way of a Tennessee River boat, and during the night a heavy thunder shower came up.

BOSTON, March 12. -- Charles Osgood of the cutlery importing house of Osgood, Bray Co. was arrested to-day, charged with defrauding the Government in connection with the payment of duties on consignments of merchandise from Germany.

WEN geographers affirm, as they are now doing, that there is no longer any doubt of the existence of the antarctic continent, they do not mean that explorers have followed all its coast lines, determined its exact shape, and crossed it from side to side. This work has not yet been done; and it will be a task of such enormous difficulty that it may not be achieved for many years.

Does the Legislature intend to deprive this city of the very great and manifest advantage of beginning, not next year but now, the work of extending its underground rapid-transit system? Two bills prepared by the Rapid Transit Commission have been introduced in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- It is said here that while no orders have been issued from the Navy Department to Capt. Sawyer, commanding the gunboat Helena, to withdraw from Niu-Chwang, it may be that Admiral Evans, commanding the Asiatic station, has given such orders.

Considerable excitement was caused yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building when a strange man with a mysterious-looking package tiptoed into the County Detective Bureau until he reached the desk of County Detective Edward J. Reardon, who is ex-Superintendent of the Goddard Anti-Policy League.

At the general meeting of the shareholders in the National Telephone Company, Limited, London, the Chairman said the board, in connection with its consideration of the subject of the development of the company's business, sent the general manager (Mr. Gains) and the engineer in chief (Mr. Gill) to the United States during the Christmas holidays to examine into the condition of the telephone system there and acquaint themselves with the latest improvements and inventions.
IT is as trite as the eternal hills to say that there are no longer any old maids. But one has occasionally to revive the trite in order to make the necessary background for the new.

President William G. McAdoo of the New York and New Jersey Railroad Company yesterday personally conducted a party of newspaper reporters and artists through the recently completed northern heading of the new North River tunnel. The little party entered the cavernous passage on the New Jersey side shortly after 3 o'clock in the afternoon.

NEW ORLEANS, March 12. -- The closing honors of the Crescent City Jockey Club's meeting fell to the Eastern contingent when Ostrich, owned by G.L. Richards, landed the prize of the season, the six-thousand-dollar Crescent City Derby. The Eastern colt's only rival in the betting was Capt. S.S. Brown's Auditor, 6 to 5 being laid against the former and 7 to 5 against the latter.

That a break had occurred between Gov. Odell and President Roosevelt was credited generally among Republicans yesterday. When Senator Platt and Col. George W. Dunn passed several hours together it was regarded as specially significant, for the reason that they were understood to be deliberating whether they could put up a respectable fight for control of the new State committee.

Renewed efforts are being made to raise money to complete the fund for the erection of a monument upon the grave of Rear Admiral James J. Jouett. United States Navy, at Arlington Cemetery. A committee consisting of Rear Admirals Benham, Clark, Chester, and Watson, and others has the matter in charge.
