A recent correspondent has said in your columns that the new tenement house law was a "curse" to tenants, because it has resulted in raising their rents over what they were paying before the passage of that law. From the side of the landlord the case seems different.

SEVERAL transactions of the week, such as the sale of 136 Fifth Avenue and that of an upper Broadway apartment house at Eighty-seventh Street, have been more along the lines of what might be expected at this season, but the great mass of dealing has witnessed no favorable change, and there is little upon which brokers are willing to base an opinion as to what the Spring market is to bring forth.

A WESTERN paper prints a statement to the effect that five gowns ordered by Miss Gulfs Morosini, a daughter of Giovanni Morosino, the banker, to wear at last November's Horse Show, cost $3,000 each. Now $3,000 is a rather high figure for even the wealthiest of women to pay for a single frock, let alone $5,000.

The bank statement showed decreases in all items except United States deposits, which were $397,800 larger than last week. The big increase in United States deposits in preparation for the Panama payments will hardly upper earlier than March 26.

The difficulty of teaching the average undergraduate to think was considered in an address delivered yesterday before the School Teachers' Association in the rooms of the New York University Law School, by Prof. George P. Baker of Harvard University.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The fight for an investigation of the Post Office Department by Congress has not ended. In fact it has just begun, although there is little prospect that the investigation can be secured. The House machine has headed off the danger with the McCall resolution.

Twenty years ago "PATTI'S farewell" was already a joke in New York. At present it is a rather pathetic reality. Mme. PATTI has left these shores, never to return, in the character of a public singer, unless she should encounter some manager of a more credulous and optimistical turn of mind than, in the light of her, and his, recent experience, seems probable.

GREEN peppers are now so fine -- and innocent of acute mordant vice -- that they are acceptable table delicacies. Stewed or stuffed, they furnish a palatable and stomachic entree. For stewing, take the seeds out of a dozen and boil them half an hour in water with just a suspicion of salt. They are done when as tender as a cooked string bean.

Criticism by lawyers and importers of Secretary Shaw's new rules for the government of the Board of United States General Appraisers has been growing louder than ever during the last two weeks. It was predicted when they were first announced that they would prove impracticable, and now it is alleged, after they have been in operation for a month, that the business of the board is becoming involved in a hopeless tangle.
PORT ARTHUR, March ll.--Last night passed without incident. The Japanese squadron, which disappeared after yesterday's bombardment and naval fight, has not returned.

A new trolley line is to be constructed by the Long Island Railroad Company along the Boulevard from Far Rockaway west to the newly developed section known as Bell Harbor. The main object of this is to divert traffic from the steam, tracks, over which the Rockaway trolley line now runs, and thus secure a greater degree of safety for the passengers.

CLEVELAND, March 12. -- "If the President really said that in all future Ohio appointments Senator Foraker would have to be looked to, I consider it an affront to every friend of Senator Hanna in this State."

Within three weeks from now the foreign chess champions entered for the international masters' tournament to be held at Cambridge Springs, Penn., will be en route for the scene of their contests. Upon their arrival in New York they will he entertained by the Manhattan Chess Club and other local organizations.
THE valiant old cup challenger Shamrock I. is rapidly being broken up in Hawkins's shipyard, at City Island, preparatory to being sold for old iron.
BERLIN, March 12. -- Business on the Boerse to-day improved on Paris advices.

So many baseball teams have been formed in the various city departments in years gone by that the baseball enthusiasts in the municipal government have organized a Municipal Baseball League for the coming season. The promoters of the league held a meeting in the Controller's office yesterday, at which their organization was effected.

Record-breaking weight throwing by John Flanagan, in which the champion increased his mark for the 56-pound weight from 28 feet 5 inches to 29 feet 6 1/2 inches, and the defeat of the University of Pennsylvania relay team by Yale's runners, were the features of the athletic carnival of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association at the Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, March 12. -- A repetition of the attack made recently in the Senate upon the work done by Charles F. McKim, the New York architect, in designing improvements to the White House and the President's office, was narrowly averted to-day.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12. -- There were several surprises in the golf tournament to-day. In the morning David T. Dana of Lenox was beaten in the semifinals by C.C. Mason of Brooklyn. In the afternoon C.C. Mason continued his good work by defeating C.B. Cory by 2 up and winning the cup. E. Longley won the consolation cup. The results:

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12.--The Grand Duke of Oldenburg and Baron von Plettenberg started for Washington to-night at 8 o'clock in a private Pullman car on the Pennsylvania special. They are due at Washington at 8.46 o'clock to-morrow morning.

IT IS unquestionably a fact," said a retired army officer now doing business in this city, "that plans of every important fortress in this country are in the possession of the General Staff of more than one foreign Government. Our Government, in turn, has plans of the fortifications of every nation with which we are likely ever to go to war.

The junior fencing team of Yale University won a decisive victory in the foil competition last evening at the Fencers' Club for the J. Sanford Status medals. The teams represented were those of the University of Pennsylvania, Columbia University, the New York Turn Verein the Brooklyn Fencing Club, and the New York Athletic Club.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. -- Twelve witnesses from Dover and Wilmington, Del., left this city to-day for San Francisco, where they will appear in the second trial of Mrs. Cordelia Botkin, charged with poisoning Mrs. J.P. Dunning and Mrs. J.D. Dean of Dover by means of a box of candy sent through the mails.

William Nelson Cromwell, counsel for the Panama Canal Company, sailed for Paris yesterday on the American Line steamship New York, to effect the transfer of all the property of that company to the United States Government. On his return to New York he will in person turn over to a representative of the President, the Attorney General, and the Secretary of the Treasury the deed of the Panama Canal Company.

ROME, March 12. -- The Most Rev. John M. Farley, Archbishop of New York, was to-day received by the Pope in farewell audience. For half an hour the Pope held the Archbishop in affable and friendly conversation, seated by his side.

It would be useless to expend ingenuity in detailing the dullness of last week's business on the Stock, Exchange. The listless days have passed without altering anything except prices, and those only fractionally. Nobody has had to sell, and nobody has wanted to buy. If the Exchange had been open only for its first and last hours daily there would have been ample time for all the business which has presented itself.

COLUMBIA students in tarletan skirts, with flowing blond curls and tripping in the trimmest of French boots, will hold forth to-morrow night at Carnegie Lyceum, the stamping ground of college dramatics, in their annual "'Varsity Show." There is to be a week's run. Fathers, mothers, sweethearts, and sisters will be out in force, and the patronage of a large number of prominent women will make the affair quite a society event.

PARIS, March 1. -- The debate on the naval budget having been adjourned in spite of M. Doumer's sensational threat to institute an inquiry into the state of the French Navy by the Budget Committee, M. Combes, the Prime Minister, has coolly assured his adversaries that they will not succeed in upsetting his Cabinet before he has carried out his anti-Clerical programme.
PARIS, March 12. -- The weather is still very unsettled, intense cold succeeding the mild, Spring-like temperature.
WASHINGTON, March 12. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the following nominations:
ST. PETERSBURG, March 12. -- It is understood that another official dispatch concerning Thursday's fight at Port Arthur has been received.

JOSEPH H. GERHARD recently received from Egypt a letter asking him what method he used in straightening the immense chimney of the Narragansett Brewing Company last Fall. Mr. Gerhard is the Providence engineer who was called in to restore the leaning chimney to plumb. The Egyptian Government's Building Inspector wrote that a tower under construction in Cairo was settling in much the same way, and he wanted to know how to save it.

LONDON, March 12. -- The continued existence of the present Government after the past eventful week in Parliament creates surprise even among its most faithful supporters. Premier Balfour kept the Cabinet in power by a majority of 46, gained at the expense of what is universally admitted to be a personal defeat for the Premier.

Much food for thought is offered to those interested in the welfare of shareholders by the manner in which the annual meetings of two corporations were held last week. One of the companies whose stockholders were supposed to meet for their annual conference was one of the biggest railroads in this country, the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The second annual report of the United States Steel Corporation was made public yesterday. It is a voluminous document, full of detail, and besides the operations for the year ended Dec. 31 last it gives information on a number of matters which have not been made public heretofore, though they date back to the beginning of the corporation's existence.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 12. -- The plans of Architect J.M. Huston of Philadelphia have been formally adopted by the Board of Semi-Centennial Directors. These designs are for the main arch and Court of Honor at the City Hall. Estimates for the cost of two other arches, one at Maryland and Atlantic Avenues in front of the Elks Hall, and the other at Michigan and Atlantic Avenues, will also be asked for.

According to dispatches from Montreal, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company of Boston will subscribe to $1,200,000 of the new stock issue of $2,000,000 of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada.
BERLIN, March 12. -- The Oldenburg newspapers voice the general indignation felt in the Grand Duchy at the entirely unexpected trip of the Grand Duke to the United States.

PARIS, March 12. -- Pierre Giffard, writing to the Matin from Dalny, says the city appears to have died before it was fully born, and to have been deserted by its parents. He describes it as having a desolate appearance.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 12. -- A unique feature of the week was an invitation leap year cotillion at the Carolina, at which men were mere accessories. Not only did the young women insist in leading in the first dance, but they seated their partners during the entire evening, and some even carried the matter so far as to serve them with refreshments at intermission.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The return of the Prime Minister to the House of Commons arranged for Monday is looked forward to with satisfaction in both political camps. It is not merely a matter of personal liking, though in the case of Mr. Balfour that feeling is strong. What has become insupportable is a condition of affairs in which the ship drifts ahead without a Captain on the bridge.

Not many of the net changes in yesterday's stock market amounted to very much. Most of them were declines, but the exceptions were so striking that they gave the list an appearance of weakness out of proportion with the average loss of the day. It was in the stocks of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company and the Metropolitan Securities Company that the heaviest losses occurred.

After fifteen months of falling prices in the American iron market trade authorities are beginning to take a more hopeful view of the outlook, and claim that they see signs of improvement. Many times during these weary months predictions have been made that the discouraging conditions confronting iron producers were about to change.

After fifteen months of falling prices in the American iron market trade authorities are beginning to take a more hopeful view of the outlook, and claim that they see signs of improvement. Many times during these weary months predictions have been made that the discouraging conditions confronting iron producers were about to change.

" The most sweeping, phenomenal, radical, and unprecedented piece of legislation yet attempted," is the definition that John G. Milburn gives to the Niagara Power Company's alleged "grab" bill, which has passed the Assembly and is now before the State Senate. Mr. Milburn is from Buffalo.

EARLY in April the first railway train will run from the southern-most point of Africa -- Cape Town -- to Victoria Falls, 1,700 miles north, at the heart of the continent. So far has Cecil Rhodes's great plan worked itself out -- the line from the Cape to Cairo. And northward, ever northward, the line is being pushed till one day it will meet the line coming southward from Khartoum.

According to a report lodged last night with Sergt. Wolf of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station by Samuel M. Daniels of 108 West One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, it cost Mr. Daniels at times during the past two weeks just about $47 to be told by a stranger that he had fallen heir to $7,000 through the death of a friend.

The dullness of last week's market was so often spoken of that it will surprise some to learn that the total of the week's business after all exceeded a million shares by almost as much as the previous week's business fell below a million. The total of approximately 2,000,000 shares for the fortnight must be pretty near a record.

Speaker CANNON probably knows that an internecine war is one that is mutually deadly, and it is not to be wondered at that he "sprang to his feet with his lips set tight and his eyes flashing and crashed his gavel down with all his strength" when that kind of a fight was started in the House on Friday and his name was used as a battle cry.

While it is apparent that Mr. HEARST has some friends in the South, I would regard his nomination for President as a great mistake, as his defeat would be certain and inevitable. -- Representative MALCOLM R. PATTERSON of Tennessee.
-- One line in our report of the Brandus picture sale read as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- To have transformed a bucking, stampeding mob into a disciplined and soldierly army -- to have transformed that which for six years was the Democratic minority in the House into that which is the Democratic minority to-day -- is a feat of political generalship which must excite interest in the man who performed it.

Acting Upon a suggestion made by a joint committee appointed by the ministers' meetings of various denominations where the matter had been discussed, more than a score of clergymen protested from their pulpits yesterday against the proposed legislation to legalize the sale of liquors in restaurants on Sundays.

The privilege of the floor was given at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union to Anarchist John Turner, who has been released in $5,000 bail, pending an appeal in his case to the United States Supreme Court. He was received with a round of applause, and began by thanking the central body for its co-operation with the Free Speech League in securing his release on bail.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- When the McCall Committee begins its investigation of the charge made in the Bristow postal scandal report there are several individuals who will not be able to step up and draw "a certificate of health," as Mr. Swanson of Virginia calls it.
I have read in your issue of to-day a letter dealing with Irish sympathy for Russia signed "An American of Irish Descent."

In a Government like ours it is absolutely necessary to its permanency that there should be some intelligence among the voters. With the exception of "criminals and women" -- ominous conjunctions -- every one has a voice in the Government, and if it were possible at this late day to do so, the ability to read and write the English language should be the only qualification.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman, preaching in Temple Emanu-El yesterday on the subject of "The Jews and the Missionaries," observed that Christianity was a missionary religion "par excellence," and thrived in proportion to the proselytizing zeal that developed in its ranks. Speaking of the work of missionaries in America he said:
PORT ARTHUR, March 13. -- Everything is quiet here to-day.

Will you permit me through your columns to say a few words in grateful acknowledgment of that splendid institution, the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary? In the year 1882 I was afflicted with that most painful, distressing, and extremely dangerous eye disease known as "rheumatic iretus."

Police Commissioner William McAdoo will be at his office early this morning, and he will have some news to be made public before the day is over. He made this statement yesterday afternoon; but positively declined to forecast the character of the news he will give out. "I can only say," he said, "that the Police Department is in a state of transition. There may be developments in the situation throughout the week."

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Charles M. Pepper, appointed by President Roosevelt as commissioner to carry out the recommendations of the second international American conference held in Mexico two years ago with regard to the, Pan-American Railway, has submitted his report to the State Department.

In his sermon yesterday morning the Rev. Dr. Lindsay Parker, rector or St. Peter's Protestant Igpiscopl Church, Brooklyn, eriticised tile recent attempt of certain members of tim Lewis Avenue Con~ gregati0nal Clmrch, that borough, to keep a wine merchant out of their church. He aid in part:

Madison Square Garden was formally taken possession of yesterday morning by the wild birds and beasts and reptiles that constitute the menagerie of the Barnum Bialey Circus, which on Saturday evening next will begin a five weeks' engagement there.

Recognizing the great historical value of the editorial, "Gldastone vs. Gladstone," in your issue of Feb. 21, and also the interview with Frederick W. Seward, published on Feb. 22, may I ask enlightenment on the following questions?

ROCHESTER, N.Y. March 13. -- George Gath, an engineer on the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad, was held up and assaulted at 2 o'clock this morning, receiving injuries which may prove fatal. Gath was on his way to work when the assault took place, near Lincoln Park, on a large tract of vacant lots.
It seems to me there is a great deal of thoughtless sentiment expressed in the American press on what is called the "yellow peril."

SEOUL, March 11, via Wei-hai-Wei, by The London Times's steamer Haimun. -- As I suggested in a previous telegram, the rapid development of Japanese sea supremacy may be considered responsible for the present apparent delay in the military operations.
I have read in your issue of to-day an interesting letter entitled "Cause of Empty Churches," and signed O.T. Alp.
Says THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an editorial referring to the existing political situation as it applies to the Democratic Party:

NORFOLK, Va., March 13. -- After a test under decidedly adverse conditions to-day the trial of the Virginia Beach strand to ascertain its suitability as a course for the automobiles which will participate in the international cup contest ended abruptly this afternoon, and the party returned to New York to-night.

The debate in the Senate on the purchase of a site for a building to house the Departments of State, Justice, and Commerce showed one thing: an amazing ignorance on the part of distinguished Senators of the necessity of paying architects of repute as much as they earn when designing and superintending the erection of great buildings for private corporations.

A burglar alarm rang from the jewelry store of N.L. Rogers at 479 Sixth Avenue late yesterday afternoon, and Special Policemen Lefevre and Alkin ran there, meeting Policeman Colyer of the West Thirtieth Street Station on the way. They captured two young fellows, looking like college students, descending through a hole in the glass flooring to the cellar, with their pockets filled with jewelry and a bag of it on the floor.

Many of the farmers of Michigan are condemning a proposition that started at a meeting of the Michigan Horticultural Society to kill off robins as pests. It came from some of the fruit men, but the farmers generally say that the robin earns all the cherries he eats, not only by his cheerful notes, but by destroying destructive worms.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- "When harmony can be had only on terms of abject submission it is not helpful," said Senator Foraker, replying to a statement that Gov. Herrick of Ohio and Senator Dick proposed to "wipe him (Foraker) off the face of the earth" so far as delegates to the Chicago Convention are concerned. Continuing, he said:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 13. -- The Rev. Dr. William A. Robinson, pastor of the First Congregational Church, surprised his congregation to-day by handing in his resignation after thirty-nine years' service in the ministry. He said he was sixty-four years old, and as army officers were retired at that age he thought he would retire.
TOKIO, March 13. -- Vice Admiral Togo's report on the fourth attack on Port Arthur reached Tokio late yesterday. It is as follows:

Alleging that if he had been allowed to continue his work grave consequences would have ensued, engineers of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company yesterday morning caused the arrest of a subway contractor's foreman and his arraignment before Magistrate Baker in the Harlem Court.

Friedrich August, Grand Duke of Oldenburg, whose unceremonious departure from European shores did not meet the approval of his loyal subjects, who are clamoring for him to hurry back home, has returned to this city, having accomplished the object of his journey across the Atlantic, which was to gaze upon the wonders and beauties of Niagara, the magnificence of which he heard his friend Prince Henry describe.

ORANGE, N.J. March 13. -- The old Dodd homestead, on Dodd Street, East Orange, the home of one of New Jersey's foremost families, and said to be the birthplace of Northern New Jersey's applejack, is soon to be demolished to make room for a big addition to the Bethel Presbyterian Church.

Just after alighting from an Eighth Avenue car at Central Park West and Eighty-third Street yesterday, Mrs. Virginia Burkholder, a magazine writer, was run down by an automobile driven by Lewis P. Lasher, a lumber merchant, with a place of business at Eleventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street, and living at 212 Jane Street, Weehawken, N.J. The injured woman died in Roosevelt Hospital.

TRENTON, March 13. -- Bishop McFaul of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Trenton criticised labor unions yesterday as they are being conducted in this country. He did not spare the capitalists, whose "grasping greed" he declared was it no small measure responsible for unsettled social conditions.

Until the Supreme Court has handed down its decision in the Northern Securities case, and it may be handed down to-day, the public will have no certain knowledge whether the decision of the Circuit Court declaring the so-called merger to be a violation of the anti-trust act will be sustained or reversed.
Easter ducks and chickens, the genuine article, stuffed, can be had at reasonable prices -- 23 cents each, and some of them with an Easter greeting in the bill.

Those New Yorkers who have regarded Mormonism hazily as restricted practically to the rolling prairies and snow-capped mountains of Utah and contiguous States will be surprised to know that the Mormon Church has title to consideration as an established institution in this city.

WEI-HAI-WEI, March 12. -- Since my last visit the appearance of Che-mul-pho has greatly changed. Where previously the anchorage was crowded with transports, there are now barely a dozen vessels, of which eight are warships.

The bill which recently passed the Assembly giving powers of an extraordinary nature and extent to the Niagara Power Company needs investigation. None is needed to show its outrageous character. That is plain on the face of it, and was exposed in THE TIMES shortly after the bill was introduced.

In accordance with the decision of the Holy Synod at St. Petersburg, a third Bishop was added yesterday to the Russian Orthodox Church in America, his ordination and consecration being in St. Nicholas Church, 301 Pacific Street, Brooklyn. The services of the nomination were held Saturday night in St. Nicholas Church, East Ninety-seventh Street, Manhattan.

May I be permitted through the medium of your paper to appeal to the Irish people in America for a share of their charity on behalf of an undertaking which would, I think; recommend itself to them were they better acquainted with the necessity for it? I speak of the fund for the establishment of district nurses in the poorest parts of Ireland which has been in existence for nearly a year.

MANILA, Jan. 16. -- Before the American occupation of Manila the Spanish had an exposition of Philippine products and ethnological specimens. This was housed in a series of buildings now known as the "Exposition Grounds and Buildings." The specimens have long since departed, but the buildings remain and are now converted to the uses of a trade school.

ST. LOUIS, March 13. -- It is announced that St. Louis is to have a Woman's Hall of Fame. The proposed institution will be established in the Woman's Building at the World's Fair. It had its inception at a society of well-known New York people. The project was given the approval of the Board of Lady Managers at a recent meeting.

I do not know that you mean to play the part of a "bandillero" in a Spanish bullfight, whose function it is to stick small flags with sharp points and firecrackers into the side of the bull as he enters the arena. But as the effect is similar, I trust you will allow the animal fair play.

In the annual tournament games of the Harlem Navy Handball League yesterday the Wyanoke Boat Club won six from the Dauntless Rowing Club at the Dauntless house; the Union Boat Club won six from the Metropolitan Rowing Club at the Union house, and the Crescent Rowing Club and the Lone Star Boat Club each Won three and lost three at the Lone Star house.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah. March l3, -- Ex- United States Senator Joseph L. Rawlins to-day sent the following dispatch to Chairman Burrows of the Smoot Investigation Committee relative to the testimony of Judge Ogden Hiles of this city before the committee yesterday:

Fair weather and the recent announcement by the Pastime Athletic Club of an open handicap run on Easter Sunday, April 3, caused the local cross-country runners to bestir themselves yesterday, and several spirited competitions were held over the roads in the upper part of the city. Of these the largest was that of the Pastimes, entries for which had been vigorously recruited at the games in the Madison Square Garden on Saturday evening
LONDON, March 14. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tokio says:

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 18. -- Conservative Iowa Democrats fear the control of the delegation to the National Democratic Convention will fall into the hands of William Randolph Hearst. The activity of the Hearst people in perfecting an organization has led to several conferences of the conservatives, the last one being held in this city to-day.

Notwithstanding the fact that he is charged with the murder of his wife, Thomas C. Smith, a negro, of 403 West Twenty-ninth Street, was permitted to attend her funeral yesterday afternoon in the custody of two policemen, after which he was taken to the Tombs prison and placed in a cell.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Senator Tillman, who for a week has had serious trouble with his throat, is reported to be very much improved to-night. The improvement is due to the relief experienced from the lancing of another abscess, which operation was performed to-day.

In an article in THE TIMES of March 7, under the above heading, Mr. Carter is quoted as saying that the particular point which most interested him in the speech of District Attorney Jerome at Lotus Hall "was the evidence which Mr. Jerome presented of the fact that the law was really unenforceable."

Two important golf tournaments have been announced for this month. They will both be held next week, one being the annual open Spring tournament of the Atlantic City Country Club, which has been fixed for March 24, 25, and 26, while the second event will be the tournament of the Palmetto Golf Club, at Aiken, S.C.

ALBANY, March 12. -- In his third annual report, which Labor Commissioner John McMackin will transmit to-day to the State Legislature, he recommends a stricter control over employment offices, "a certain class of which," he says, "exploits the poverty of the poor by extorting fees for positions which are never obtained."

The National Rifle Association of America has issued invitations to the riflemen of the world to compete in the annual match for the Palma Trophy at Sea Girt, N.J., about the first of next September. This trophy, which is emblematic of the military team championship of the world, was won by the American team at Bisley, England, on July 11, 1903, in competition with teams representing Great Britain, France, Norway, Canada, Australia, and Natal.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Congress has been saved the necessity of abrogating the treaty with the Sultan of Sulu. The President and Secretary Taft have decided that the so-called Bates treaty of Aug. 20, 1899, which provided salaries for the Sultan and certain of his dattos and at the same time, it is said, sustained polygamy and slavery, was simply a modus videndi and an executive agreement.

Judge Byron S. Waite and Gen. Thaddeus S. Sharretts, the members of the Board of United States General Appraisers, who were summoned to Washington on Saturday to discuss the criticism of the new rules recently imposed on the board by Secretary Shaw, returned to their duties in New York yesterday.
LONDON, March 14. -- Money was plentiful in the market to-day, and the demand was light. Discounts were easy.

The Missouri Society, composed of those who find living in New York more pleasant than in Missouri, held its fourth annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria and incidentally celebrated the birthday of Missouri's great man, Thomas H. Benton. Joseph C. Hendrix presided, and the Presidents of the Illinois, North Carolina and Maryland Societies were guests of honor.

Although Schreyvogel, Russell, and others have followed Frederic Remington in the picturing of Indian combats, of cowboys and soldiers, of trappers and bad men of the plains, this artist maintains a lead by the number and variety of his scenes from the vanishod life of the Far West. The little exhibition at the Noe Galleries, 368 Fifth Avenue, adds a half-dozen novel compositions to the long list.

Mr. Bryan was in Detroit yesterday, and in response to a question as to whoso nomination he favored said: "I am simply insisting that the Democrats nominate a candidate in sympathy with the Democrats who vote the ticket, and not one in sympathy with the Democrats who bolt the ticket and vote with Republicans."

----- While it was probably a tactical error to give Mr. JOHN TURNER an excuse for posing as a free-speech martyr before those with very vague and inaccurate ideas as to what is meant by "free speech" in civilized countries, there was nothing in the remarks he made Sunday before the Central Federated Union to indicate that anything more becomes Mr. TURNER than does a gently assisted silence.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Justice Harlan writes the opinion subscribed to by four out of the five Justices who constituted a majority. After announcing the origin and the purpose sought to be accomplished by the suit Justice Harlan reviews the facts as disclosed by the record in the case, showing that it had grown out of a combination of the Great Northern Railway Company and the Northern Pacific Railway Company into the Northern Securities Company.

WINSTED, Conn., March 14. -- Two men, who said they were Charles Chatfield and Charles Thayer, held a mock court at police headquarters here to-day while under arrest. Chief of Police Wheeler had taken them into custody, saying that he wished to learn whether either of them was acquainted with two men wanted for robbing a house in Waterbury and the railroad station in East Litchfield last January.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- David J. Brewer, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, while concurring in the judgment ordered in the Northern Securities case by Justices Harlan, Brown, McKenna, and Day, and forming with them the majority which affirmed the decision of the United States Circuit Court against the railroad combination, did not accept in all points the reasoning of Justice Harlan, who wrote the prevailing opinion.
PARIS, March 14. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch quotes ex-Minister of Finance Witte as follows:

There has been a great deal lately in your paper regarding "Why men do not marry," and I should like to tell a few plain facts "Why women do not marry." In most instances the men who have written place all the blame on the female sex. What a vote of thanks the men should give to Adam, that he ever had Eve to blame for his weakness.

Charged with having entered the room of T.F. Seacoll of Toledo, Ohio, at the Waldorf-Astoria on March 5 and stealing $600 worth of jewelry, a young man who said he was William Schwartz, twenty-three years old, of 44 West Fifty-first Street, was arrested yesterday in a Sixth Avenue pawn shop by Detective Sergeants Boyle and Charlton of the Central Office.

James C. Carter, the retired corporation lawyer, whose long career as an active practitioner included participation as leading counsel for the Traffic Association in the cases of the United States against the Trans-Missouri Traffic Association and against the Joint Traffic Association, was seen last night at his residence, 277 Lexington Avenue.

It is to be hoped that the recent report from Paris of the purchase by a French syndicate of four steamships to carry a filibustering expedition to the territory lying between the rivers Oyapoc and Araguary will not prove to be the forerunner of international complications.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 14. -- The Democratic State Central Committee voted to-day to hold the State Convention for the choice of delegates to the National Convention on May 5 and 6 in Hartford. The convention for the nomination of candidates for State officers will be held later.

TOKIO, March 14. -- Viceroy Alexieff's report stating that a Japanese torpedo boat destroyer was sunk and the cruiser Takasago heavily damaged by the shell fire of the Russians in the fourth attack on Port Arthur is officially pronounced untrue.

PARIS, March 14. -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day, by 318 to 231 votes, adopted the first section of the bill prohibiting members of religious orders from giving any kind of teaching, primary, secondary or superior.

Although the transitory stage which Commissioner McAdoo alluded to on Sunday as applicable to the Police Department was not materially altered yesterday, the resignation of Deputy Commissioner Haggerty of Brooklyn was not announced, as was expected, and the Commissioner's promised statement concerning the situation was deferred, the day was fraught with a good deal of suspense and interest at Police Headquarters.

SEOUL, March 12, via Wei-hai-Wei, by The Times's Steamer Haimun. -- The civil influence which Japan has brought to bear in Korea is not less remarkable than the military precision for which it paved the way. From Che-mul-pho to Soul every controlling influence is Japanese -- railway, police, telegraphs.

WINSTED, Conn., March 14. -- Two novel contests -- one for young women at sawing wood and one for young men at trimming women's hats -- were the features of the "reception night" entertainment given by the John Brown Club in Torrington Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Chief Justice Fuller and Justices White, Peckham, and Holmes, who dissent from the prevailing opinion in the Northern Securities case, present two opinions giving their reasons for not agreeing with the majority of the course in the decision reached. The first of these was delivered by Justice Holmes, and the second by Justice White.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The month of March thus far has distinguished itself by being particularly bad here from a meteorological standpoint. In fear that the 4th of March, 1905, may not be an improvement, the agitation for moving inauguration day on toward the days of settled weather has been revived.

Bishop William Benjamin Derrick, who for the past four years has been the Presiding Bishop of the New York Diocese of the African Methodist Episcopal Church and for the past twenty-five years one of the most aggressive and active men of the colored race, is tired of America and yearns for the land of his forefathers in Africa.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14. -- Vice Chancellor Emery this afternoon handed down a decision in the habeas corpus proceedings by Chester M. Demarest and his wife, Annie, of Elizabeth, to secure possession of their seven-year-old daughter Dorothy. He ordered the child, which has been in the custody of the Elizabeth Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children since last December, turned over to the father.

Before leaving town for Washington yesterday President Johnson made the announcement that in two or three days the headquarters of the American League, like those of the National League, would be in New York. Offices have been secured on the seventh floor of the Fuller Building, Twenty-third Street and Broadway, and all the principal business of the League will be transacted at that place.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The official reception of the news that the United States Supreme Court had sustained the Government's contentions in the Northern Securities case was enthusiastic. There is no doubt that the Republican Party will claim the credit for it for campaign purposes.
Money on call loaned at 1 3/4@2 per cent., with the last loan at 1 3/4 per cent. Most of yesterday's loans were made at 1 3/4 per cent.
HAMBURG, March 14. -- The annual report of the Hamburg-American Steamship Company, published to-day, shows a net profit for the year of $5,500,000.

The Supreme Court, expressing its opinion by the pen of Justice HARLAN in the Northern Securities case, makes a fetich of competition and in effect declares that the strong arm of the Federal Government should be stretched forth to interpose the shield of the law wherever a community finds itself "at the mercy" of a single railroad corporation which has obtained an uncontested supremacy in the inter-State commerce of that region.

VINELAND, N.J., March 14. -- Miss Teresa Secchi de Casali, a wealthy Italian woman, was found burned to a crisp at her home here to-day, and the authorities claim that it was a case of suicide or murder. It first was thought that the woman's clothes had caught fire from a near-by oil heater, but later it was found that the stove had not been lighted.

Tammany has called off the fight on Senator McCarren in Brooklyn for the remainder of the present week at least. Charles F. Murphy will return from Atlantic City some time to-morrow, and Senator McCarren, who went to Albany yesterday, will return then also, when friends of both hope to bring them together and effect a resumption of harmony between the boroughs.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Representative Malcom R. Patterson of Tennessee to-day delivered a speech in the House which aroused widespread comment on the Democratic side. It was a flat-footed declaration that the time had come when the South should cease to play second fiddle in the Democratic Party, and that a Southern candidate for President would have as good a chance in the North as any one else.

Your demonstration that "the yellow peril" is a mere bugaboo is not conclusive. The present incapacity of the Chinese for fighting may be conceded. But their capacity for learning how to fight is overlooked, though this capacity is latent in the mildest of living creatures, and stress of circumstances never fails to develop it in greater or less degree.
It's not easy to keep up when coffee has so ruined the stomach that food won't digest.

On the heels of the departing company of the Metropolitan Opera House the New York public is invited to witness three weeks more of lyric drama given by the French Grand Opera Company, which opened its season at the Casino last evening. This company comes by way of several Western cities from New Orleans, which boasts, and has boasted for many years, the only other operatic establishment in this country.

The sketch given in THE TIMES yesterday morning of Mr. WILLIAMS of Mississippi, the Democratic leader of the House of Representatives, reveals much more than an interesting personality and a man exceedingly tactful in his dealings with men. It discloses an active and vigorous and trained mind, dealing carefully with large questions, attaining a true perspective in complicated and obscure situations, and pursuing a worthy, definite object patiently, skillfully, and loyally.

Mrs. Clemence Dodge-Morse-Dodge has gone to Europe, and Charles W. Morse is to sail in a week or ten days, ostensibly to meet her there. This was the news learned yesterday when Mr. Morse returned from Philadelphia, where he had been since Friday night, having gone there for the purpose of holding a conference with Mrs. Dodge before she sailed.

ALBANY, March 14. -- An investigation of the Shipbuilding Trust by a special Grand Jury, to be called by the Governor, is now a certainty. The only question about the matter is whether the prosecution on the part of the State shall be conducted by District Attorney Jerome or by the Attorney General.

The Board of United States General Appraisers took testimony yesterday in the featherstitch braid case, which has been reopened by the Treasury Department, after a decision by the courts in favor of the importers. The question is whether the goods are dutiable at 60 per cent. as braids or at 45 per cent. as bindings.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 14. -- Gov. Odell is not worrying over the prospect of Senator Platt putting up a fight to recover his lost laurels. In fact, so sure are the Governor and his friends that they now have a hold on the organization which cannot be shaken that there is talk of an adjournment of the Legislature early in April.

The Assembly at Albany hastily passed a bill giving to a water-power company the practically unrestricted right to take water from the Niagara River above the falls, and authority to take without limit the lands needed for their purposes. The Commissioners of the Niagara Falls Reservation say that this act threatens the destruction of the falls.

Two firemen were overcome by gas and two more slightly burned in a fire to which they were called early yesterday morning at 803 Ninth Avenue. The house was the home of about twenty families. Smoke from the blaze, which started in the cellar, poured through the house and made egress difficult for the residents. Many had to be carried out by firemen and policemen.

Charles Littlefield, the veteran trainer, will arrive at Sheepshead Bay to-day with thirty of the horses of J.B. Haggin. This shipment of racers will come from the Elmendorf Stud in Kentucky, and with a few three-year-olds, the greater number will be fashionably bred youngsters, who have been liberally engaged in all the rich stakes.

A few days ago a letter reached the Brooklyn Post Office from Oneonta, N.Y., addressed to the "Rev. Diet Hillis, Brooklyn, N.Y." The clerks supposed that the letter was meant for the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, but not caring to take any chances they sent the usual card to the sender of the letter, asking that the proper street and number address be supplied, if possible.
LONDON, March 15. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the Russian press has received a number of circulars indicating the course to be observed in regard to the war news.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day handed down an opinion in the merger case of the United States versus the Northern Securities Company sustaining the contention of the Government that the railroad merger was illegal and affirming the judgment of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 14. -- While her father was hurrying to Brooklyn to prevent her marriage, Miss Anne S. Safford, formerly of this city, more recently of the Bronx and now once more of New Rochelle, was married here Saturday evening.

NEW ORLEANS, March 14. -- Unfavorable weather and a heavy track made the opening of the new Louisiana Jockey Club's Spring meeting anything but auspicious, and a general upset of the favorites did not add to the pleasure of the day. The Morris filly Viperine was the medium of the heaviest play of the day, and at 9 to 20 she was liberally played to win the Crescent Stake, the feature of the programme.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 14. -- A decision dismissing the appeal of Camille Weidenfeld in the case of Peter Power against the Northern Pacific Railway Company was handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to-day.

Warren Skillin, in conjunction with Nichols Lummis, have sold for Mrs. C.M. Silverman to an investor the six-story elevator apartment house known as the Miltona, at 28 and 30 West One Hundred and Thirty-first Street.

" None of these things move me," said St. Paul on his way to Jerusalem and to unknown trials. The Northern Securities decision is now no secret, and the market is as little moved as was St. Paul. The local tractions suffered more than railways supposably obnoxious to the principle of the Northern Securities litigation.

Controller Grout made public yesterday afternoon the text of a letter which he had received from District Attorney Jerome regarding Eugene Comisky, the man who, it has been charged, is connected with a poolroom syndicate while being carried along on the roster of employes in the Finance Department.

There have been times during the past Winter when it seemed as if Mr. Sydney Rosenfeld's Century players were fated to be of the twenty-first century; but, after something less than the wanderings of Ulysses, they last night opened to the metropolitan public, at the rehabilitated Princess Theatre, in "Much Ado About Nothing" -- which the vile have already modernized into "Nothin' Doin'."

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The Russian Ambassador and Countess Marguerite Cassini entertained at dinner this evening, when their guests included the French Ambassador and Mme. Jusserand, the Ambassador from Austria-Hungary, and Baroness Hengelmuller, the Swiss Minister, Senator and Mrs. Depew, Senator and Mrs. Cullom, Gen. and Mrs. Draper, Mrs. Longsworth, Miss Louise Jones, Miss Patten, Baron Bussche of the German Embassy, and M. Desportes of the French Embassy.

LONDON, March 15. -- A correspondent of The Daily Mail at Niu-Chwang says that after the removal of the battleship Retvizan four Russian steamers, the Harbin, the Hailar, the Ninguta, and the Sungari, were anchored at the mouth of the entrance to Port Arthur in proper position and sunk, leaving only a small channel available, Vice Admiral Makaroff having previouly ordered the whole fleet to remain outside with steam up, economy in coal being unnecessary.

In your issue of yesterday in reference to certain views expressed by Mr. Davitt as to the relations which should subsist between this country and England, you make the following statement: "The best minds in England are laboring patiently and in good faith to atone for the past, but such incidents show how long and hard the full performance of the task will be."

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- When the Fortifications Appropriation bill was taken up in the Senate to-day, Mr. Berry made a point of order against the appropriation of $250,000 for the purchase of a submarine torpedo boat to be used by the School of Submarine Defense for experimental purposes.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 14. -- Though Senator-elect Dick refuses to answer publicly the statement made by Senator Foraker Saturday, when the latter declared war to the knife, there is all kinds of excitement in the Cox-Dick-Herrick camp.

TRENTON, N.J., March 14. -- Gov. Murphy sent to the Legislature to-night the report of the special commission appointed a year ago to investigate the proposed abandonment of the Morris Canal. This commission is composed of ex-Govs. Werts, Griggs, and Voorhees and favors the abandonment of the canal, on certain conditions.

" The Isle of Illusia" was presented last night by the students of Columbia University at the Carnegie Lyceum to a delighted and sympathetic audience of alumni and undergraduates. They were accompanied, of course, by the mothers, wives, sisters, and sweethearts, who made it worth while to be applauded.

The extremely interesting reports from Soul and Tokio which we printed yesterday inculcate the same lesson, and that the same which all the events of the war thus far have inculcated. That lesson is that the Russians were entirely unprepared for war, even after the representatives of Russia in the Far East had done everything in their power to provoke it.

ST. LOUIS, March 14. -- Weights are announced for the fifty-thousand-dollar World's Fair Handicap, to be run Saturday, June 25, at the course of the St. Louis Fair Association. This stake, one of the richest ever raced for, is of the greatest importance both East and West, and its winner will surely be crowned best of the year.

A crusade against the Mormon Church and its missionaries in this and other cities throughout the United States was launched yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the New York County Woman's Christian Temperance Union, held in St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue.

Noticing in your influential paper from time to time letters from various correspondents containing covert and open attacks on the people and Governments of the United Kingdom, will you kindly insert a retired merchant's remarks on some of these aspersions? Having exceeded the threescore years and ten, one hopes the following will be accepted in good part as founded on a long experience, dating in business from 1845 in Britain and on this continent:

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- In the Supreme Court to-day the United States Government, through Attorney General Knox, applied for a writ of mandamus to compel Judge Francis J. Wing of the United States District Court of the Northern District of Ohio to take what it is maintained is legal action with respect to certain Chinese exclusion cases.

A conference called by the Woman's Municipal League yesterday discussed the bill introduced in the Legislature by Assemblyman Edward R. Finch for the regulation and control of employment agencies. Miss Greler, Chairman of the league's Legislative Committee, presided, and there were present representatives from many philanthropic bodies.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 15. -- As the result of a sensational chase by the police for violating the speed laws, J.E, Doorhoefer, son of a Louisville tobacco manufacturer and bookmaker at the Fair Grounds, and Col. "Billy" Thompson, manager for Barney Oldfield, formerly holder of the mile automobile record of America, were arrested here to-day.

The fact that the Judges composing the majority of the Supreme Court in the Northern Securities case were Republicans, and that the Democratic members of the court all dissented, does not show at all that the court divided on party lines as such. It simply illustrates the fundamental difference between the two parties.

Somebody is likely to get into trouble over the shooting that took place in the American Theatre on Monday night, and it is not the "tall, dark man sitting in the left stage box." It is generally thought in theatrical circles that the firing of two shots from a revolver in the midst of the third act was the result of a "press agent" scheme.

The Northern Securities decision continued to be the topic of greatest interest in Wall Street yesterday, but the discussion did not centre so much on what the decision meant as on what the men who controlled the company intended to do. On this point the air was full of rumors, but no suggestion came from any official source which would give the slightest indication that they had prepared any plan of action.

Shelving tile application of the New York and Port Chester Railroad, and again favoring that of the rival New York. Westchester and Boston Company for permission to cross streets of the Bronx in the construction of an electric railroad, the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday made a report to the full board sending the application to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to have that body fix the compensation to the city.

General Appraiser De Vries sustained a protest yesterday by J.H. Thorp Co. of New York, and in doing so raised a novel point in customs law. The protest was against the assessment of 50 per cent. duty as a manufacture of silk and cotton, silk chief value, on colored cotton cloth, into which silk had been introduced to form a figure.

LONDON, March 15. -- Rates for money and discounts were a shade firmer in the market to-day, the condition of the Paris cheque leading to some discussion as to how much gold is likely to go there. But the position of the Bank of England is considered too strong to allow much nervousness on the subject.

Transactions in the stock market yesterday were again fairly large, measured by recent standards, but there was very little increase in the commission business. In other words, while the market for the past two days has shown transactions in the neighborhood of 500,000 shares, the increase has been due almost entirely to more extensive operations by the traders.

Henry E. Pollock, who said he was an insurance man residing at 210 West Forty-fourth Street, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Barlow, in the Centre Street Court, on a charge of having attempted suicide. A policeman from the City Hall Police Station told Magistrate Barlow that Pollock had walked into the station Monday night and asked to be locked up, explaining that he was afraid he would kill himself if not restrained.
Money on call loaned at 1 3/4 per cent.

ALBANY, March 15. -- A new move to preserve Niagara Falls from the injury which it is feared will be wrought if the Thompson bill be enacted was made to-day in the Senate by Senator E.R. Brown, who introduced a concurrent resolution memorializing Congress to negotiate a treaty with the Dominion of Canada to prevent the diversion of the waters of the Niagara River and the destruction of the cataract.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 15. -- Love, a runaway marriage, forgiveness, and happiness briefly tell the romantic story of Harvey Anderson and Rena Ashman, prominent young people of Monroe, aged respectively seventeen and eighteen. Rena, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Ashman, attended the high school, and, seeing her pass on her way to the school, young Anderson fell in love.

ALBANY, March 15. -- Denunciation of District Attorney Jerome and the charge by Senator Malby that the Codes Committee had reported a bill the amendments to which seemed designed to afford protection to Richard Canfield marked the consideration to-day by the Senate of the measure introduced by Senator Dowling to amend the Penal Code with regard to the privilege of witnesses.

McChesney will not start in the Metropolitan Handicap. The E.E. Smathers champion was yesterday declared from the opening stake of the Westchester Racing Association by Trainer Frank Taylor, and it is not thought likely that the big chestnut son of Macduff and Manola Mason will be seen until late in the Morris Park meeting.

NEW ORLEANS, March 15. -- Leo Dorsey again demonstrated that he is one of the most consistent horses that have raced here this Winter by running away with the mile and a sixteenth handicap to-day. He was giving away weight to everything in the field, and merely romped the distance, going to the front in the first sixteenth.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Gov. Odell's request that Col. T.W. Symons of the Engineer Corps be allowed to serve on the Advisory Canal Commission of New York was refused to-day by the House Committee on Military Affairs. The vote was 5 to 4.

The recent rumors to the effect that Second Deputy Police Commissioner Henry F. Haggerty, in charge of Brooklyn was to resign or be obliged to submit to the forcing-out process, were borne out yesterday by the announcement that he had been removed from office by Commissioner McAdoo.

PARIS, March 15. -- Telegrams from St. Petersburg to the Paris press represent rumors of mediation, which in one instance are called "a feeler coming from Berlin," as finding no echo whatever in Russia. "Indeed," one correspondent says, "all idea of foreign diplomatic intervention is as distasteful to Russia now as it would be after the war."

Through all Brooklyn this query was ringing last night, and none was there found who could answer it. With but four days between him and eviction with his 200 prisoners from the oft-condemned lockup in Raymond Street, Sheriff Hesterberg was not so cheerful that one could notice it.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- One of the first reforms for the Post Office Department brought out in the legislation of this session appears in the pending Post Office Appropriation bill in creating the new office of Purchasing Agent for the department, at a salary of $5,000 a year.

Now that the Supreme Court has declared the sweeping application of the anti-trust law to all combinations having for their object not merely the actual restraint of trade between the States or with foreign countries, but even the attainment of the ability and opportunity to restrain such trade, we shall expect to see President ROOSEVELT denounce the combine which keeps up the absurd and oppressive tariff.

Rudolph Christians, the young matinee idol (so to speak) of the Royal Playhouse in Berlin, last night signalized his return to America by appearing at the Irving Place Theatre in Paul Lindau's German rendering of Jose Echegaray's modern Spanish tragedy, "El Gran Galeotto," and was enthusiastically welcomed by an audience that cared for a great tragedy ably acted.

Through the suggestion and generosity of Andrew Carnegie this city is soon to have a great central home for engineering. On Monday last Mr. Carnegie, who is to sail for Europe next Saturday, addressed the following self-explanatory letter to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the American Institute of Mining Engineers, the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, and the Engineers' Club of New York:

ST. PETERSBURG, March 15. -- From the highest official quarter The Associated Press has received information that there is absolutely no foundation for the rumors persistently sent out from Tokio that the Russians are abandoning Port Arthur.

THE TIMES asserts that "the belief is general that if Mr. Cleveland were the nominee he would be elected." On what does your great newspaper base the assertion? Is Mr. Cleveland more popular with Democracy after two elections and one defeat than Gen. Grant was with Republicans after two elections to the Presidency?

PARIS, March 15. -- A Tien-Tsin dispatch to the Journal says the Norwegian Colonel Munthe, aide de camp to the Viceroy of Chi-li Province, and Dr. Laville, a Frenchman who is Councilor for Foreign Affairs of the Viceroy, are going on an official mission to Admiral Alexjeff. They made the following statement to-day:

Net earnings of the Sloss-Sheffield Steel and Iron Company for the year ended Nov. 30 last, after allowances for depreciation, extraordinary repairs, and other items, were $1,795,640, an increase of $457,250 over the earnings of the previous year. Interest on bonded debt for the year amounted to $210,000, and dividend on the preferred stock of the company to $469,000, leaving a surplus for the year after the payment of dividends of $1,116,640.
It was dollars to cents that before the subway excavations were filled in some other project would crop up to open the streets again, and we have it in the salt water mains project already.
BERLIN, March 15. -- On the Boerse today international securities were firm upon London and Paris, giving strength to domestic industrials.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 15. -- State Senator Arthur P. Gorman, Jr., representative of his father in control of the Democratic organization, and his associates in the Legislature are greatly disturbed to-night over information that Gov. Warfield, acting upon advice of Attorney General Bryan, will veto the machine's negro disfranchisement amendment.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 15. -- So far W.R. Hearst, aided by the Tom L. Johnson element of the Ohio Democracy, is having easy sailing in this State. He has now secured the delegates from three Congressional Districts, all that have held conventions.

The annual election of the West Side Republican Club, composed of Republicans of the Nineteenth, Twenty-first, Twenty-third, Thirty-first, and Seventeenth Assembly Districts, was held last night at the clubhouse, on Broadway, near Eighty-third Street. There were three tickets in the field. The "organization" ticket was overwhelmingly beaten.

In a speech brimful of optimism, ringing with defiance, and greeted with deafening applause by members of the Republican Club and their guests, before whom it was delivered, ex-Secretary of War Elihu Root called upon Republicans in this State last night to forget factional differences and present a united front in the coming Presidential contest. The occasion was the complimentary dinner given by the Republican Club to Mr. Root.

ALBANY, March 15. -- After the hearing before the Senate Cities Committee to-day on the Remsen Fire Department Two-Platoon bill, Senator White, Chairman of the committee, said the bill would not be reported unless further arguments were adduced in support of it.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- Senator Foraker declares that he fully approves the statement attributed to Gov. Herrick to the effect that the Federal patronage in Ohio should be divided between the two Senators. According to Mr. Foraker, little attention and no patronage worth speaking of has been extended to him during his service of seven years in the Senate.

LONDON, March 15. -- The Balfour Ministry was to-day defeated in the House of Commons by the combined Liberal and Nationalist vote. This reverse was due to the prohibition by Mr. Wyndham, Chief Secretary for Ireland, of the teaching of Gaelic in the junior grades of the Irish nationalist schools.

Postmaster August Hauser of Hicksville, a wealthy and prominent resident of that town, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Morle in the Federal Building, Brooklyn, yesterday, charged by Post Office Inspector Charles E. Crowell with having appropriated to his own use $344.67, receipts from the Money Order Department. He was held in $1,000 bail.

CHICAGO, March 15. -- Three persons, two of them boys, were killed and eight others employes were injured to-day by an explosion of toy pistol caps, which completely demolished the two-story brick manufacturing plant of the Chicago Toy Novelty Company, at Western Avenue and West Eighteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 15. -- The Senate to-day completed the Fortifications Appropriation bill. As passed by the House the bill carried $7,131,192, to which the Senate added $832,000, making a total of $7,963,192.

Eugene C. Allison, Secretary of the Allison Realty Company, owners of the Darlington Hotel in West Forty-sixth Street, occupied the stand during the greater part of yesterday's hearing in the inquest into the collapse of that structure before Coroner Scholer and a jury of building experts in the West Side Court.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 15. -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. James H. Tillman, recently acquitted of murder for the killing of Editor N.G. Gonzales of Columbia, S.C., announces his candidacy for Congress in an interview in The Augusta Chronicle. He will stand for the seat vacated by the death of Col. G.W. Croft.

In his comment upon the Supreme Court decision in the Northern Securities case, Attorney General KNOX said: "During the trial and argument the Government paid no heed to defendants' contention that the make-up of substantially all the great American systems of railroads was on trial.

PITTSBURG, March 15. -- Red fire, cowbells, and rockets closed the wedding of Archibald Cohen of Cincinnati at the Concordia Club in Allegheny last night. Previous to the ceremony making Miss Edna May Klein his wife, Mr. Cohen indulged in a little boasting of his ability to take care of himself and bride, and dared any of his friends to play a practical joke on him.

At the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Basket Ball Association two amendments were made to the Spalding playing rules. Hereafter all baskets must he backed up by wood, instead of some by wire and some by wood, so that visiting teams will not be at so great a disadvantage. The latter is to furnish an official, who will act as referee during one-half of the game and umpire the other half.

Dr. Walter G. Douglas won third prize last night in the 14.2 handicap billiard tournament that has been in progress in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He defeated L. H. Servatius in the final match to determine the triple tie for third place, and as he had previously beaten J.M. Millette, Dr. Douglas took third place in the tournament.
Your ill-tempered and unjust criticism of William R. Hearst's candidacy in to-day's editorial leader must prompt dissent on the part of those of your readers who are in favor of the Congressman.

Charles Fox has returned from Memphis and was a visitor at Sheepshead Bay yesterday. He said that at Montgomery Park all the horses were in excellent condition, and that many now galloping there would ship East at the close of the meeting.

Nothing could be easier or simpler than to describe yesterday's stock market. Everything rose, with just enough exceptions to prove the rule. Perhaps the average advance is about two points, and all classes participated. Railways improved no more than industrials, and the Northern Securities group was as strong, but scarcely stronger, than others not obnoxious to the principles declared by the Supreme Court to be the indisputable law of the land.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 15. -- The Republicans carried the village election here to-day by a majority of over 100. E.L. Hopkins was elected President of the village over William C. Fignor by 122 majority. William Fitzsimmons, Republican, was elected Receiver of Taxes by 104. Chief of the Fire Department Mayhew W. Bronson ran on all tickets for Trustee, as did Joseph Bird for Treasurer.

Was not the editor of the interesting Payne-Shelley correspondence published in last Sunday's TIMES sadly in error in reporting that Washington Irving suffered the pangs of disappointment in having vainly loved "the lovely Rebecca Gratz, feeling his position too keenly to have thoughts of another"?

CHICAGO, March 15.--A series of riots occurred to-day between striking employes of the American Can Company and union teamsters who had refused to quit work in sympathy with the strike, the girl strikers taking prominent parts in the trouble. The first disturbance occurred on the north side of the city at once of the stables of the can company, a number of men being injured and two pickets arrested.

The decision of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Maryland, sitting in Richmond, on the famous "rupee case," which was rendered on Monday, is a severe blow to Secretary of the Treasury Shaw's claim to control over the Board of United States General Appraisers. Copies of the decision were received yesterday by Albert Comstock of 56 Pine Street, counsel for Whitridge, White Co. of Baltimore, the appellees.

MADISON, Wis., March 15. -- The Republican State Central Committee will meet in Madison Thursday of this week to fix the time and place for holding the State Convention to elect the four delegates at large to the Republican National Convention.

ALBANY, March 15. -- By a bare majority the Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision in favor of the plaintiff in the action of Henrietta Meyer of New York against the Supreme Lodge, Knights of Pythias, which involves the question of "privileged testimony." The point of difference was whether the testimony of a physician who declared that the plaintiff's husband, Emanuel Meyer, committed suicide should be excluded.

Perhaps the very commonest of the current comments of "the man in the street" upon the war between Russia and Japan is that, although the gallantry and enterprise of the Japanese are admirable, and although Japan may go on for a while conquering and to conquer, yet the resources of Russia are so vast in comparison with those of Japan that the Muscovite Empire must win in the end.

The first annual banquet of the Hide and Leather Association, held last night at the Drug Club, 100 William Street, was attended by a large and representative body of men of the trade. Eugene H. Conklin, resident of the association, presided.

Bernard Smyth Sons have resold for the Sonn brothers to Charles M. Rosenthal and I.M. Borenstein the plot of eighteen lots on north side of One Hundred and Tenth Street (Cathedral Parkway) extending through to One Hundred and Eleventh Street, 200 by 90.11, on One Hundred and Tenth Street, and 250 by 100.11 on One Hundred and Eleventh Street, beginning 200 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.

On the face of it, the decisive action of Commissioner MCADOO in dismissing his Brooklyn Deputy, Mr. HAGGERTY, shows that the crisis in the Police Department is becoming more acute. "Difference of opinion as to policy," "which is neither political nor personal," is publicly declared by the Commissioner to be the cause of his action, and he adds that it was taken only after the Deputy had refused to resign when requested.
WASHINGTON, March 15. -- A fight is to be made in Indiana to have the delegates to St. Louis instructed for Judge Parker.

The annual report of the Texas and Pacific Railway for the year ended Dec. 31 last was made public yesterday on the return of President George J. Gould to this city after his trip to the Pacific coast. The condensed general balance sheet shows:

CHICAGO, March 16. -- The petition of Mrs. Annie Murphy to be declared the lawful daughter of the late Baron von Glahn was denied to-day by Judge Orrin H. Carter. Mrs. Murphy was contending for a reduction of inheritance tax, she having been bequeathed $10,000 by the Baron.

The twenty-fourth annual banquet of the Friends of Ireland was given last night in Shanley's restaurant. Forty-second Street and Broadway. A feature of the dinner was the presentation of a large cut-glass punchbowl and a cabinet filled with cut glass to Corporation Counsel John J. Delany, the President of the society.

The cotton market experienced a sharp reaction yesterday. The decline, which amounted to nearly sixty points in the near months from the closing prices of Tuesday, was due to heavier receipts at interior points, coupled with a sharp and ominous failing off in exports and the refusal of spinners to buy at the prevailing prices.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The granting of subsidies to railroads for carrying the mails was vigorously opposed by Mr. Robinson, (Ind.,) who characterized them as a stain and blot upon the Post Office Appropriation bill, which was under consideration in the House to-day.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 16. -- Official orders were published to-day relieving Vice Admiral Stark from the command of the Port Arthur Division of the navy, ostensibly on account of illness. No successor will be appointed, Vice Admiral Makaroff having determined to serve as squadron commander as well as Commander in Chief of the entire Russian naval forces in the Far East.

As a rule people who fled from their own country to escape military service, particularly in time of war, would form a class of immigrants not desirable by any other country. Whatever their physical and financial position, it could fairly be inferred that their instinct of patriotism was ill-developed if not altogether wanting, and that in moments of National emergency they would be likely to prove most untrustworthy citizens.

General Appraiser Howell sustained a protest by the Leon Rheims Company of New York yesterday against the assessment of 44 cents a pound and 60 per cent. ad valorem on "chapeaux crin," which are described as hats of horsehair. The Collector classified them as wool wearing apparel.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The case of Miss Todd, the Delaware Postmistress who was removed on the allegation that she allowed politicians to congregate in her office and plot political work against Senator Allee and John Edward Addicks, has come to the surface again through a report by the Civil Service Reform League.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 16. -- Fifty women voted at the school election in North Brunswick Township yesterday afternoon, and defeated the regular ticket. Judge S.W. Vandervoert of the opposition had arranged for the women to appear at the polls in a body just before the time of closing, and then cast their ballots in such numbers that the other side would not have a chance to gather their forces to overcome them.
Money on call loaned at 1 3/4 2 per cent, with last loan at 1 3/4 per cent. The majority of the business was done at 1 3/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- No incident of this campaign has created more of a stir among the Democrats than the unexpected appearance here to-day of William Jennings Bryan. Whether he came to Chicago for the expressed purpose of meeting William Randolph Hearst could not be learned, but it is known that soon after his arrival at the Sherman House Mr. Bryan joined the candidate for President and they were together a long time.

Merchants who wish to rebuild in the burned district of Baltimore are becoming impatient at the many delays which confront them. The various committees, commissions, and municipal departments, it is reported, are working at cross-purposes, and, while all desire that the city be quickly rebuilt, no agreement by those in authority as to how the many problems are to be attacked is in sight.

Commissioner McAdoo made a trip to the Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon and delivered a half-hour business talk to all the Inspectors of that borough which apparently made them feel rather uncomfortable. It was closed with an injunction to each to give the screws of "the lid" an additional turn or two in the right direction.

BERLIN, March 16. -- Letters from German Southwest Africa have arrived here giving details of the ghastly treatment of German settlers, 113 of whom were killed outright or tortured to death in the district of Okahandja alone.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16. -- With every favorite beaten to-day, the racing was not very entertaining to the speculators. Two of the most pronounced upsets of the day were the defeat of Balm of Gilead and Vestry. Balm of Gilead was conceded to be the best in the mile and a sixteenth, and was played from 9 to 5 down to 6 to 5.

As The News has said before, there will be a time when the South may reasonably demand that a Southern man head the Presidential ticket, but that time has not yet arrived. What chiefly concerns the South at this time is to have a nominee and a platform that can beat Roosevelt.-- Birmingham (Ala.) News, (Dem.)

BOSTON, Mass., March 16. -- The Hearst men got little comfort from to-day's meeting of the Democratic State Committee, for the doors were shut and locked against them so far as it was possible to do so.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Senator Depew to-day gave an authorized interview on the merger decision to The Newark Evening News, in which he said:

More housesmiths whose work had reached the limit of three stories above the fireproofing were laid off yesterday, owing to the strike of the bricklayers, and, excepting on a few non-association contracts, not a housesmith was working.

Gen. Thaddeus S. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday announced his decision in the reappraisement of a large shipment of mahogany lumber by Moffet, Robbins Co. of Havana to Moffet, Malley Robbins of Cleveland. The lumber was shipped to New York, there divided into lots of different qualities and shipped to Albany, Philadelphia, and Boston, where each lot was entered at the average value of the whole.
PARIS, March 16. -- Count Nelidoff, the Russian Ambassador in Paris, said today:

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Attorney General Knox's declaration about the Supreme Court decision in the merger case will be the Democratic issue on the trust question. The Democrats will hold that it is the duty of the Administration to prosecute other trusts, and that if it does not do so it will be convicted of singling out one trust to prosecute so as to have a campaign issue.

It will be a source of great gratification to all who are interested in the progress of engineering science to learn that the decision of the American Society of Civil Engineers not to participate in the enjoyment of the liberality of Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE has not deprived those who are desirous of availing themselves of these facilities of the advantages of Mr. CARNEGIE'S offer.

Patrolman O'Shaughnessy, attached to the West Thirtieth Street Station, was standing at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street last night when he saw smoke coming from the chimney of the Calumet Club, on Fifth Avenue, in great volume. The smoke was filled with sparks, so O'Shaughnessy ran to Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street and turned in an alarm.

Yesterday's stock market was in some respects a reversal of Tuesday's. Instead of being characterized by strength rather than activity, as on the previous day, and instead of growing stronger as the day progressed, it was rather more active than strong, and deteriorated in both respects as the day wore along, except for the usual closing rally.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Commissioner of Pensions Ware, with the approval of Secretary Hitchcock, to-day promulgated the most important pension ruling that has been issued in a long time.
