WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Navy Department publishes a report from Admiral Evans in which he invites attention to the record made on the recent trip of the squadron from Yokohama to Honolulu and thence to Cavite, covering a distance of 8,500 miles in midwinter. The Admiral says:

NORRISTOWN, Penn., March 16. -- Although married sixteen years, Charlotte J. Smith of Norristown never knew it, and passed as a single woman until recently, when D. Nelson Long, a son of David Long of Upper Merion, came from Nebraska to Norristown after a protracted absence in the West and produced evidence that Miss Smith was his wife.

Peter Forrester, a broker, fifty-five years old, residing at 11 East One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street, was arraigned before Judge Foster, in General Sessions, yesterday, on three indictments, charging him with the larceny of the estate of Lucinda Dougherty, amounting to $40,000. Forrester was an executor of the estate, Judge Foster fixed bail at $10,000 in the case, and as Forrester was unable to furnish this amount, he was locked up in the Tombs.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Counsel for the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad appeared before the Joint Committee on Banks of the Senate and Assembly to-day and vigorously protested against what they termed a proposal on the part of the Legislature to discriminate against that railroad and to reflect upon the value of its bonds for purposes of investment.

The lives of many children who were on their way to Public School No. 16, in Wilson Street, Williamsburg, were imperiled yesterday by a runaway horse, which ran madly along Marcy Avenue, and before it was caught had crashed into two trolley cars and knocked down and seriously injured C. Oscar Snyder, a Park Department employe

TRENTON, N.J., March 16. -- The Senate to-day passed an amendment to the Child Labor bill reducing the age limit from sixteen years to fourteen years. Senator Ferrell of Gloucester, who was in his early days a glassblower, made a speech saying that the amendment was essential to the glassblowing industry of South Jersey.

Paul Schwandtner, builder of the Darlington Hotel in West Forty-sixth Street, which collapsed recently, and who has been sought ever since the disaster by Coroner Scholer, appeared at the continued inquest in the West Side Court yesterday and was surrendered by Ignatius Weltner, his counsel.

Secretary S.C. Mead of the Merchants' Association said yesterday that a number of communications have recently been received from other commercial bodies indicating their sympathy with the movement to have an investigation by the Inter-State Commerce Commission of the question of differential railroad rates.

The ex-Secretary of War is prudent. In his speech of Tuesday evening he advised his admiring and sympathetic hosts at the Union League Club to pay as little attention as possible to anything the Democrats might say and to stick to the record the Republican Party had made outside of the country.

DOVER, Del., March 16. -- John Edward Addicks's followers in convention to-day announced that they were the Republican Party of Delaware and that all Republicans in the State must enroll under the Addicks banner or be considered bolters.

BERLIN, March 16. -- Thirty Russian students, several of them women, have received notices of expulsion from the police in consequence of their participation in a meeting held on Saturday to protest against the Government's action in permitting Russian police agents to watch Russian residents in Germany.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 16. -- The Republican County Committee of Seneca County met in Waterloo to-day and agreed upon a new Republican County Convention, to be held March 29 for the purpose of electing a new set of delegates to the Congressional and other conventions.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- United States Minister Allen has cabled the State Department from Soul, under to-day's date, that the Cincinnati arrived yesterday at Che-mul-pho, with twenty-three Americans from Chi-nam-pho.

The French Opera Company gave two performances yesterday at the Casino that were of varying degrees of demerit; though neither had the vital elements that their version of "Carmen" had on Tuesday. In the afternoon "Mignon," which has not been heard in New York for a number of years, was given.

Papers were drawn yesterday by Assistant United States District Attorney Houghton asking for the extradition from Boston to this city of R.P.H. Wolle, arrested in the New England city a few days ago charged with selling counterfeit United States stamps.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. John R. McLean will go to Atlantic City to-morrow.

Several declarations have been made from stakes of the Coney Island Jockey Club, to be run at the June meeting. From the Great Trial, for two-year-olds, the withdrawals are: S.S. Brown's Heir at Law, W.B. Jennings's Laidlaw and Francis Trevelyaan, J.R. Keene's Wild Mint, W.B. Leeds's Merry Lark, J.E. McDonald's Sergeant Cram, Andrew Miller's Dazzle, Oneck Stable's Modest, A.R. Peabody's Toyland, J.W. Schorr's Uncle Charley, Lady Maneuse, Lucius, Fine Cut, and Normandy.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16. -- A report of the formation of a powerful protective coalition by Brazil, Bolivia, Argentina, Ecuador, and Chile against the United States reached here to-day from sources said to be authentic.

Spring vegetables are out for place cards. They are the ordinary printed cards in colors, but cleverly done originally, and on each vegetable is a face. They are the root vegetables as a rule, a couple of radishes with the leaves down for legs, the faces on the radish part that is up. There are turnips in pairs.
I have seen in one of the New York papers lately a communication anent the unfortunate statue of Sunset Cox, which is now being held "in durance vile" in Astor Place.

UTICA, N. Y., March 16. -- Miss E. Gertrude Graves of Jordan, N. Y;, has brought suit seeking $50,000 damages against Samuel N. Wood of Denver, Col., for alleged breach of promise. The complaint and answer, a general denial, were filed in the United States Circuit Court here to-day. Wood is wealthy, and he is now in Vienna, Austria, under treatment for deafness.

OMAHA, Neb., March 16. -- When the Democratic State Central Committee decided last night in favor of calling the State Convention for June 1 instead of April 1, it turned Mr. Bryan down flatly. This is acknowledged to-day by Mr. Bryan's friends. The strength shown by the antiBryan men was a surprise and a disappointment to Mr. Bryan and his supporters.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 16. -- O.B. Colquitt, member of the Texas Railroad Commission, said to-day that under the decision of the Supreme Court in the Northern Securities Case, the Southern Pacific and the Rock Island could be proceeded against by the Attorney General for violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust act, as they were both purely holding companies.
WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Senate to-day in executive session confirmed the following nominations:

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- " Attorney General Knox's statement that the Administration does not propose to run amuck among trusts now that the merger decision has been rendered," said Representative Williams to-day, "reminds me of a conversation I had once with an old Confederate officer.

The sympathetic strike of the bricklayers in Manhattan and the Bronx on account of a grievance of the Laborers' Protective Association looks very much like the beginning of the end of the agreement between the unions and the Building Trades Employers' Association. This agreement possessed none of the elements of permanence, and cannot until the unions recognize, as they do not and never have, the nature and binding character of a contract.
TRENTON, N.J., March 16. -- The will of the late Miss Helen Griswold Green, daughter of Mrs. Charles Ewing Green, who died a few weeks ago in New York, has been probated.

LONDON, March 16. -- Details of the initial Japanese attack on Port Arthur that have not been permitted to pass the Japanese censor are given by The Times's correspondent in Tokio in a letter dated Feb. 19. He declares that the Japanese officers found the Russians less efficient than the Chinese in sea fighting and that the Russian projectiles and explosives were inferior. The letter says:

CHICAGO, March 16. -- Judge Kavanagh to-day declined to order a woman to prepare her husband's meals. Paul Bakos not only wanted his wife ordered to attend to the preparation of his food, but he asked Judge Kavanagh to restrain her from leaving his home. Judge Kavanagh said:

Yesterday was the third consecutive day of activity in the stock market, and the total was larger by nearly 100,000 shares than on either Monday or Tuesday. The opening was an interesting one. Instead of the featureless openings to which Wall Street had been accustomed for many weeks, there was a sharp advance throughout the whole list, the first sales showing gains of from half a point to a point over Tuesday's close.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Adjt. Gen Henry received notification to-day from the War Department that the Federal Government is ready to supply the National Guard of New York with the Krag-Jorgensen rifle, with peep sights. The guardsmen feel that they are especially favored by having the peep sight pattern issued to them.

The determination of Health Commissioner DARLINGTON to enforce the provision of the Sanitary Code which forbids the beating of rugs and carpets and the shaking of dusty fabrics from windows in any part of New York will no doubt be the subject of much complaint from housewives who find themselves committing misdemeanors in the performance of the usual functions of the Spring housecleaning.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16. -- While in a cage with three lions this afternoon, Alfred J.F. Perrins, the animal tamer, suddenly became insane. Soon after he entered the cage Perrins struck one of the lion's a vicious blow and cried, "Why don't you bow to me, I am God's agent."

Is THEODORE ROOSEVELT as President of the United States governed by other or different rules of conduct than those which guided him when he was Police Commissioner in New York City? On June 20, 1895, Mr. ROOSEVELT, then President of the Police Board, made the following statement:
Isaac M. Bernstein has sold the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Seventh Street, about 200 feet east of Broadway, 100 by 100.11, to a builder for immediate improvement.

TOKIO, March 16. -- The Cabinet, after a conference with the Elder Statesmen and other political leaders, has decided to submit proposals for the extension of the tobacco monopoly, so as to include manufactured tobacco and the creation of a salt monopoly to a special diet convening on Friday next.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 16. -- The Emperor this morning, receiving the German Attaches, Lanenstein and Tettau, who are to leave for the front on Friday, said, among other things:

James J. Hill, President of the Northern Securities Company and of the Great Northern Railroad, yesterday expressed himself as favoring the nomination and election of Grover Cleveland as candidate of the Democratic Party for the office of President of the United States. It has been known for some time to the friends of President Hill that he believed the renomination of Mr. Cleveland would mark the reestablishment of the Democratic Party in the White House.

NEW BRUNSWICK, March 16. -- The Middlesex and Somerset Traction Company, which has fifty miles of track in Middlesex and Somerset Counties, has been sold to the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey for $2,250,000.

LONDON, March 16. -- Money was fairly plentiful in the market to-day, and the rates were easy through indications that the supplies would again be affected by the revenue collections. Discounts were steadier.

ALBANY, March 16. -- Judge Alton B. Parker may himself undertake to bring about a harmonious understanding between Hill and Tammany Leader Murphy. There is talk among influential Democrats who occupy a neutral ground, as between Hill and Murphy, of urging the Judge to this course.

Dr. William Frederic Holcombe died yesterday morning in the Presbyterian Hospital, where he had been ill for several days. Since 1861 he had been identified with the medical profession in this city, and he was connected with many of the leading medical societies of the country. For the last ten years he had not actively practiced his profession, but treated a few of his older patients.

At the National Arts Club, 37 West Thirty-fourth Street, the Municipal Art Society of New York held its annual dinner last evening, the occasion also being the opening of the exhibition of the society. Calvin Tomkins, President of the society, presided at the after-dinner speaking, and in the course of his introductory remarks said:

All suggestions of peace or of even a temporary truce between Tammany Hall and the McCarren organization in Brooklyn disappeared yesterday following the return of Charles F. Murphy from Atlantic City and of Senator McCarren from Albany.

Although Mayor McClellan's suggestion of an auxiliary water Supply for fire-fighting purposes will be carried out in its essential details, and speedily, there is little chance that salt water will be utilized, although there will be connections with the auxiliary mains which will permit the use of salt water if desired far an emergency.

I have just perused the second annual report of the United States Steel Corporation sent to me. As far as I can judge the business appears to have been ably and fairly managed, with one exception. It is the item of $17,234,128.58 in the balance sheet, "charged off for expenditures made since April 1, 1901, from surplus, for construction and for payment of capital liabilities."

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- It was hinted in the House debate to-day that the Post Office Investigating Committee is attempting to hush up scandals in other departments than that of the First Assistant Postmaster General, against which the Bristow investigation was directed. During the examination of Mr. Bristow by the Post Office Committee, a vain attempt was made to get Mr. Bristow to connect the President with the special postal scandal report.

The question of what will be done by the Building Trades Employers' Association regarding the strike of the bricklayers will only be known after to-night. The laborers have been directed by an order of the Joint Arbitration Board of the Mason Builders' Association and the bricklayers' unions to return to work pending arbitration of all disputes, and the order of the mason builders cutting off the overtime has been rescinded.

When the gas and electric light companies are in imminent peril from municipal competition they are ready to give any assurances required of them, (not in writing.) As soon as the danger passes, or they think they have the legislative committees "fixed" for another year, their point of view changes.

BOSTON, March 17. -- To-day's hearing on the Bay State Gas Company's litigation in the Supreme Court took a somewhat sensational turn when H.H. Rogers of New York, one of the Directors of the Standard Oil Company, was threatened with contempt proceedings because he refused to produce certain letters called for by Sherman L. Whipple, counsel for George W. Pepper, receiver of the Bay State Company, and the complainant in the suit.

ALBANY, March 17. -- District Attorney Jerome appeared to-day before the Senate Committee on Codes and made a successful and sensationally vigorous plea for the bill which he had introduced in the Legislature for the specific purpose of enabling him to convict Richard A. Canfield of running a gambling establishment in New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Representative Gaines of Tennessee was impressing upon a fifteen-year-old acquaintance the advisability of cutting loose from "Old King Brady" and "Nick Carter" and going in for a higher class of literature. The boy protested that he did read better books and Mr. Gaines undertook to cross-examine him.
OMAHA, Neb., March 17. -- Major William H. Bean, United States Army, committed suicide to-day by shooting.

NEW ORLEANS, March 17. -- De Heszke, M.L. Hayman's good sprinter, won the St. Patrick's Handicap to-day at 6 to 1, from a field of good horses. The five-year-old son of Lamplighter ran the six furlongs in 1:13 1-5, and was pulling up at the end, four lengths before his field. Morning Star was the public choice, but was never prominent in the running, and he finished in the ruck.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Senator Bacon of Georgia thinks the Democrats have a good chance to win the coming election, and he says that conservatism should rule not only in the making of the platform at St. Louis, but in the selection of the candidate. He said to-day:

LINCOLN, Neb., March 17. -- H.C. Lindsay, who probably will succeed W.S. Summers as United States Attorney for Nebraska, is at the City Hospital here, too sick to hear the news of Summers's promised removal. Lindsay is Senator Dietrich's candidate for the office.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- The Republican leaders of Congress regard the order issued by the Commissioner of Pensions yesterday, providing for pensions for veterans of the civil war who have reached the age of sixty-two years, as making a service pension. This was made clear to-day, when the Republican Steering Committee of the Senate met to decide upon an adjournment programme.

Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by Alexander Murphy Co. of New York, in which alleged illegal action by a General Appraiser was made the basis of the claim.

That lion-hearted foe of corporate privilege, the Hon. CHAUNCEY M. DEPEW, approves and applauds the decision of the Supreme Court in the Northern Securities case. "It is a good thing both for the people and the corporations," said Senator DEPEW, "because it quiets popular apprehension, which was very great, and might have resulted in dangerous and unnecessary legislation."

Our stock market seems to be playing at cross purposes with itself and with the other Exchanges of the world. Wednesday their tone was better than that here. Yesterday the London market lost its tone upon talk about further capital applications and political preoccupations.

Throughout her reign Queen VICTORIA never forgot the advice given to her by the Iron Duke at the beginning of it: "Whatever you relinquish, keep the army in your own hands." She followed it by advancing first her cousin, the Duke of CAMBRIDGE, who has just died, and then her son, the Duke of CONNAUGHT, more rapidly than their professional merits would at all have justified.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 17. -- The rivalry between Rodney Smasher and Taysand for the blue ribbon for bulldogs was the feature of to-day's judging in the dog show. The former is owned by C.G. Hopton and the latter by the Earlington Kennels, both of New York City. Rodney Smasher obtained the award.

Appraiser Whitehead yesterday made public the new schedule which has been adopted as a basis for arriving at market value on St. Gall embroideries, consigned without purchase, which has been adopted at a conference in his office, at which several importers and the United States Consul General at St. Gall were present.

Technical detail occupied much of the attention of Coroner Scholer and the expert jury at the inquiry into the collapse of the Darlington Apartment Hotel in Forty-sixth Street on March 2, which was continued at the West Side Court yesterday. Evidence was presented indicating that Eugene C. Allison, Secretary of the Allison Realty Company, the owners, had received ample warning that the structure was in a dangerous condition days before it fell.

Art and commercialism came in conflict at the Casino Theatre last night, and the money spirit came out an easy winner. Because they were about six weeks behind in their pay and had heard that their manager had suddenly left the town, the members of the French Grand Opera Company refused to sing "Cendrillon."

Now that the discussion of increased rapid transit facilities is again before the public, I would like to make a suggestion whereby the present service of the Manhattan "L" would be greatly increased at comparatively little cost.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 17. -- Theodore G. Croft has been nominated by the people of Aiken, S.C., for the unexpired term in Congress of his father, who recently died. Mr. Croft has accepted, and will begin a canvass of the district. Col. James H. Tillman and several other candidates have withdrawn, and will throw their influence to Mr. Croft.

It is not a matter of controlling importance whether the delegates from New York to the Democratic National Convention go uninstructed or go with instructions to advocate the nomination of Judge PARKER. It is important, though, that the Democratic Party begin forthwith to declare something more than a general intention to oppose the Republican candidate. The leaders and the masses of the Democracy in every State need the rallying power of a name.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 17. -- The Minnesota State Republican Convention met to-day and adopted a platform indorsing the Roosevelt Administration and calling for President Roosevelt's nomination.
DENVER, March 17. -- While on his recent trip to the West George J. Gould took a fancy to a sightly slope which overlooks the Hotel Colorado and the surrounding country at Glenwood Springs, and said:

ATLANTA, Ga., March 17. -- H.H. Cabaniss of Augusta, Ga., made public today a letter from United States Senator Clay, who is in Washington, in which the latter deprecates the Hearst movement and advises the nomination of Judge Parker by the Democrats. Senator Clay says, in part:

TRENTON, N.J., March 17. -- Builders from Jersey City, Newark, and Paterson are opposing the passage of the proposed Tenement House bill now in the Senate. They argued before the Committee on Judiciary that if the proposed bill became a law it would increase the cost of buildings 25 per cent.

There were as many Russian flags in the parade of the Ancient Order of Hibernians yesterday as there were green ones with the harp in the centre, though the flags of the Czar were small cotton affairs, while most of the green flags that had floated in many past anniversaries of the day were of satin and silk.

BUFFALO, March 17. -- Herman Heimberger, seventeen years old, one of the four boys who on Jan. 22 killed Bernardo Balzano, a Walden Avenue grocer, was tonight found guilty of murder in the second degree. The only punishment provided by law is life imprisonment. Trueman, Draper, and Rousselet, the three lads who were indicted with Heimberger, will be tried next month.

KANSAS CITY, March 17. -- The jury in the case of State Senator Jesse L. Jewell, on trial on charge of soliciting a bribe of $9,000 to influence his vote and that of two other members of the Legislature to repeal a Baking Powder bill, disagreed this afternoon and was discharged.

CHI-NAM-PHO, March 16, via Weihai-Wei, March 17. By The London Times's steamer Haimun. -- I arrived at Ping-Yang Inlet on the 15th and proceeded to Chi-nam-pho. Navigation is still difficult, and the natural difficulties are increased by the drift ice floating down in large quantities.

Robert D. Vroom -- "Pop" Vroom the curb calls him -- who has been a dealer in stocks and bonds since 1870, says Russell Sage owes hom $25,000 on a deal which he put in the financier's hands on May 9, 1901, that memorable day when the stock market fluctuated as never before and the Street nearly went crazy.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra is on its last visit to New York this season, and began its proceedings here last evening with its concert in Carnegie Hall. The programme was made up of music long familiar to New York audiences, with the exception of one number. There were Schumann's first symphony in B flat, Tschaikowsky's B flat minor piano concerto, played by Miss Aus der Ohe, and the prelude to Wagner's "Die Meistersinger."

ST. PETERSBURG, March 17. -- The first headquarters of the Manchurian Army after Gen. Kuropatkin's arrival will be at Liao-Yang, the General having selected that point, instead of Mukden, whence to direct the operations.

F.R. Hitchcock was yesterday elected to the Presidency of the Saratoga Association for the Improvement of the Breed of Horses, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William C. Whitney. For the office of Vice President Harry Payne Whitney was chosen to succeed Mr. Hitchcock, while Clarence H. Mackay was elected to the Directorate.

WASHINGTON, N.J., March 17. -- A tramp got an unexpected reception to-day at the home of John K. Risler, a merchant living in Youmans Avenue. When Mr. Risler left the house after dinner the fellow, who had been watching, made for the house. Mrs. Risler saw him coming and observed that his pockets were bulging with packages, evidently containing victuals.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 17. -- Gov. Herrick admits that he has sent a letter to President Roosevelt asking the Chief Executive not to interfere in the bitter factional contest now on between Senators Foraker and Dick.

If James Longworth had just sawed wood and said nothing he would not have been arrested yesterday by the officers of the Charity Organization Society. They had known him under the name of Longquill and also under the name of Longwill. He made it a practice to obtain a position as a hotel waiter and would make note of the names of guests and speakers at various banquets.

ALBANY, March 17. -- An Election bill which was sent to Albany by the New York County Republican Committee was rushed through the Senate to-day on an emergency message of the Governor in the interest, it is understood, of Senator McCarren.

ALBANY, March 17. -- Without a dissenting vote the Senate to-day passed the concurrent resolution introduced by Senator Brown memoralizing the President to open negotiations with Great Britain for the purpose of framing a treaty which shall "prevent any diversion of waters of the Niagara River injurious to Niagara Falls as they now exist."
In a talk to newspaper men, Commissioner McAdoo yesterday declared war on "graft" in the Police Department and expressed his determination to suppress it.

CHE-FOO, March 17. -- Viceroy Alexieff, in a dispatch, confirms previous accounts of the damage done to Port Arthur during the bombardment of March 10, but he says the story of a great fire there is a base fabrication.

When one comes to consider the action that has been taken by the Secretary of the Interior and the Commissioner of Pensions, and the reasons which they give for it, the attempt to grant a "service pension" by proclamation may well seem one of the most remarkable and impudent usurpations of power ever witnessed in the United States.

A New Jersey Senator, who was once a glassblower himself, has persuaded a majority of his fellow-Senators that the existence of the glass industry in their State would be seriously imperiled, if not immediately brought to an end, if the manufacturers were not allowed to employ children less than sixteen years of age.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Senator Depew entertained at dinner this evening in honor of the Speaker of the House, and had as his additional guests Representatives Alexander, Babcock, Bradley, Dalzell, Douglas, Draper, Flack, Foss, Gillet, Grosvenor, Hemenway, Hull, Hepburn, Olmstead, Otis, Overstreet, Payne, Perkins, Sibley, Southwick, and Vreeland; Charles G. Bennett, the Secretary of the Senate; William Barnes, Jr., of Albany, and ex-Representative Lemuel E. Quigg of New York.
Details will be found in another column relative to the sale of the old Broadway Tabernacle property at the northeast corner of Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street.

LONDON, March 17. -- Money was plentiful in the market to-day and in fair demand, owing to the payment of $10,000,000 Treasury bills. Discounts were easy. The general impression is that money will be distinctly easier after the month-turn.

The Special Committee of Twenty named by the National Board of Fire Underwriters after the Baltimore and Rochester fires, has decided to levy a small assessment upon the companies in order to spend the greater part of the year in procuring such specific information as will enable local rating boards to establish uniform fire insurance rates in the larger cities of the United States.

Beautiful forms and colors most delicate, fragile-looking objects, and those that seem as enduring as the bronzes they imitated may be seen just now in the American Art Galleries, Madison Square South. The larger of two collections of porcelain, pottery, and other Chinese pieces will be sold on the afternoons of to-day and to-morrow, and the smaller on the following Monday afternoon, March 21.

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Senatorial dignity received a shock to-day, when the spectacle of gray-haired members of the upper house wildly swinging rackets in their hands to illustrate how the game of jai-alai is played, was witnessed on the Senate floor. Protected by the closed doors of an executive session, the members of that august body amused themselves thus for more than an hour, and the liveliest interest was manifested in the sport.

In THE TIMES, Sept. 8, 1902, appeared a communication from me to the effect that "the time has come when a Southern Democrat should be selected by the Democratic Party as the standard bearer for the Presidency, and the most available Southern Democrat is Gov. Benton McMillin, who has been before the public many years, and was for a considerable length of time the most forceful Democratic member of the National House of Representatives."

Dr. Richard Strauss appeared in a concert of his chamber compositions last evening in Mendelssohn Hall with the Mannes Quartet, it being the second concert in the series of that organization. His work in this department had not been unknown here before his coming, though it has not filled a large place in the programmes devoted to this kind of music.

Street-paving contracts let in the Borough of Brooklyn under the last administration caused some lively talk in the Board of Estimate yesterday. The outcome was the passage of a resolution calling upon the Commissioners of Accounts to investigate the matter. A communication from Borough President Littleton requested an issue of corporate stock to provide for the payment of these contracts, given out by Borough President Swanstrom.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 18. -- Concerning the loss of the armored cruiser Boyarin at Port Arthur, a private letter received here says that the vessel was struck by a floating mine dropped by the Japanese. Naval engineers are preparing to raise the Boyarin, though it is considered doubtful if she will be fit for fighting purposes.

Why are not the bridge towers available for use in supplying the City of New York with an abundant quantity of salt water? They are nearly three hundred feet high, admirably located, and abundantly strong. Their use for this purpose would not interfere with their beauty or utility.

Charles Wagner, whose book "The Simple Life," brought from President Roosevelt the comment that he wished it might be used as a tract throughout the United States, will have a new book published by McClure, Phillips Co. March 28. It will bear the title "By the Fireside," and deals with family life and the relations of the members of the household.

WILLIAM PENN, a great colonizer and a great Quaker, has not suffered from lack of biographers to hand down his name. The Quakers who have undertaken this task have generally been so partisan that their work is unreliable.

LONDON, March 19. -- The Standard's Tien-Tsin correspondent says that Paul Lessar, Russian Minister to China, has renewed his protest against the dispatch of Chinese forces outside the great wall, and intimated that unless they are withdrawn Russia may be compelled to act on the assumption that China is abandoning her neutrality in favor of Japan.

The Macmillan Company is publishing this week "Letters of Lord Acton to Mary Gladstone," by Mrs. Drew; Palgrave's "Golden Treasury of Songs and Lyrics." In Macmillan's Pocket Classic Series; "The Philosophy of Education," by Herman H. Horne, Ph. D.; Vol. III, of "The Dictionary of Painters and Engravers," and new editions of Wirt Gerrare's "Greater Russia,'' Mrs. Hugh Fraser's "Letters from Japan,'' and Archibald Colquhoun's "Mastery of the Pacific."

David Stewart has sold for the Fort George syndicate, composed of Adolph M Bendheim, Jacob Hirsh, Nathan Wise, and Max Marx, the plot of twenty-nine lots, having a frontage of 708 feet on the north-side of Wadsworth Avenue, beginning 90 feet west of St. Nicholas, or Eleventh, Avenue. The buyer is Daniel F. Lewis, as President of the New York and Long Island Realty Company.

CELINA, Ohio, March 18. -- After gaining admission to the hall of the Fourth District Republican Congressional Convention today, the Foraker faction bolted that body and nominated an independent ticket.

MRS. THEODORE THOMAS has written a book which is said to be something in the vein of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden." It is to be entitled "Our Mountain." and is the narrative of several seasons spent by the eminent impresario and his wife at their Summer home, Felsengarten, near Bethlehem, N. H.

ALBANY, March 18. -- State Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks, in his annual report to the Legislature, made public to-day, has some harsh things to say about the methods of certain Lloyds insurance companies, which, he says, are still transacting business in violation of the law, despite the efforts that have been made to stop them.

Mrs. John Van Vorst, joint author of "The Woman Who Tolls," has done well to call her new book "The Issues of Life." It is full of issues, and any one of them would give an ordinary novelist sufficient material for a book. There is subject matter in this one volume for at least five problem stories of American life and one French novel.

There were broad grins on the faces of the dozen or more Italians now confined in the Ludlow Street Jail, charged with violations of the naturalization laws, last evening when United States Marshal William Henkel walked into the prison, having with him as a prisoner E.C. Benedict Peeke, the former Secret Service operator and special agent of the Department of Justice.

A collection of lectures which have been delivered by Dr. Brastow to divinity students at Yale, are published in book form in order to stimulate in the minds of young theologians and intelligent laymen a proper appreciation of good preaching and of its value to mankind.

Until the announcement of the suspension of Daniel J. Sully Co., which for a short period unsettled the stock market, the trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday presented, generally speaking, the same characteristics as on the earlier days of the week. The shorts, to all appearances, were still the principal buyers, although in some quarters a slight improvement in the outside demand for stocks was noted.

Since the letter carriers were placed under the merit system we think that it is the general judgment of every community that they are an unusually faithful, efficient, and hard-working class of public servants. In the larger towns they are not paid what their work is really worth, not merely as compared with other public employes, but as compared with men in other callings requiring equal exertion and imposing equal responsibility.

Some schoolbooks tell about the amount of royalty earned by Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe as the result of the sale of "Uncle Tom's Cabin." There never was any royalty paid, and the true story is as follows: "Uncle Tom's Cabin" was first published as a serial story in The National Era, an anti-slavery paper published at Washington, D.C.

ANECDOTES OF SPENCER -- With all Spencer's ingenuousness, he accepted the fact of his own greatness as he accepted sunshine, and his consciousness of the one seems no more obtrusive or persistent than of the other.

The death of W.C. Hayes's old jumper Draughtsman has been announced. This old gelding was in his eighth year, and for his past two seasons of racing he failed to win a purse. He was named in several of the steeplechase fixtures for this season.

That was an incredible rumor which came to us, and which we printed yesterday, about the intention of the Russian ships which were lately at Vladivostock, but the present whereabouts of which is not publicly known, to make their way back to Europe, there join the Russian fleet in the Baltic, and with this reinforcement make their way back to the Far East and overwhelm the navy of Japan.

SAYVILLE, L.I., March 18. -- Farmer Walter Kessing of Holtsville, L.I., had a city friend visit him, who yesterday expressed a desire to partake for once in his life of a genuine Long Island rabbit dinner. The old farmer assured his friend that his desire should be granted and with gun in hand was soon lost in the adjacent woods.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- By a vote of 45 to 16, the Senate, in executive session, to-day confirmed the nomination of Gen. Leonard Wood to be a Major General. He takes the rank from Aug. 8, 1903, the day President Roosevelt made the appointment.

Two local trains collided shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning, just south of the New York Central tunnel, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets. The accident resembled the one which occurred in nearly the same spot about two years ago in some particulars, but in the accident of yesterday nobody was seriously injured.
The officials of the Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital declared yesterday that there was no intention or no probability of the closing down of any of its wards for any purpose whatsoever.

We should like to find some more respectful form of words than "stupefying impudence" in which to characterize the grant by Executive order of a service pension which Congress has refused to grant by the only lawful method. We are unable to do so. In fact, the impudence of the performance, so far from being dissembled, is made more glaring by the "reasoning" by which it is most imprudently accompanied.

This addition to the already long list of books which have served to endear the name of Mrs. Miller to all lovers of birds must strike any intelligent reader as being first a remarkable record of patient, although interesting, endeavor. The author may quote Emerson, but the fact remains that these observations of feathered friends (some of whom are to be seen all too seldom) were made by no "lubberly member of an awkward race."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 18. -- Secretary William K. Devereux of the New Jersey Democratic State Committee this afternoon issued a call for a meeting of the committee at the Jeffersonian Club in Newark on Thursday next, for the purpose of fixing the date for the New Jersey State Democratic Convention, which will name delegates to the National Convention, to be held in St. Louis.
Secretary Franklin Allen of the Silk Association of America will return to his duties to-day, after a two weeks' vacation. The annual meeting of the association will be held next Tuesday.

The Stock Exchange resumed business yesterday with a continuance of the strong and cheerful sentiment which has characterized it ever since the Northern Securities decision. Opinions have differed regarding the genuineness or artificiality of the improvement, but its existence is the chief characteristic of the week.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 18. -- With a nine composed of its own recruits and utility men of the New York American League team, the Atlantas this afternoon engaged Clark Griffiths's regulars, and the result was a close contest, ending in a score of 8 to 7 in favor of New York. The feature was the excellent batting of Unglaub and a sensational stop by the same player of a swift grounder over second.

The collapse of DANIEL J. SULLY is not surprising, even if not expected. It does not in the least change the statistical position of cotton in the relation of supply to consumption. But it does show that to corner a great staple and hold its price above the level which such relation would establish is a greater undertaking than the most skillful manipulator is capable of carrying out.

MR. GEORGE MOORE is more than usually interesting in his contribution this month to The Pall Mall Magazine. Mr. Moore is full of opinions. They are mostly wrong, but at least they interest one. He informs us that the English novel began with Fielding and ended with Jane Austen.

IT is rarely the fortune of even the ablest and most earnest of reformers to be so promptly rewarded as Mr. Amery for his efforts to attract attention to and correct great and perilous public evils. In endeavoring to obtain an understanding of the danger to which Great Britain has awakened, it is only necessary to remember the very recent plight in which the United States found itself.

A perfectly typical Senatorial quarrel over the distribution of Federal patronage is now raging in Ohio and in Washington. Senator FORAKER announces that he has demanded of the President fair recognition for his friends in appointments to office in the State of Ohio, and of the proof that he is getting it he exhibits the nomination of three of his friends to Postmasterships.

I wish you would editorially call attention to the tremendous power which in this country lies in the mere opinion of one man. Vast consequences, affecting the rights and interests of millions of people may flow from the Northern Securities decision of the Supreme Court.

This little volume has a purpose. It sets out to tell briefly certain facts about the lives of certain Southerners who have written poems, and to quote some of the poems by these hands. Some of the poems are vastly better known to the miscellaneous public than are the names of the poets. That very fact is ample excuse for the book itself Who wrote those lines beginning.

There was an affecting scene in the little chapel of St. Martha at Morris Park Avenue and Graham Street, Borough of the Bronx, last evening, when a brass altar cross, bought with the pennies of the Sunday school children, was unveiled in memory of a boy hero who gave his life to save his two brothers.

Prof. A.B. Hart, who occupies the chair of American History at Harvard University, in a lecture on "The Diplomacy of the Panama Canal," delivered last night under the auspices of the People's Institute at Cooper Union, defended the policy of the Roosevelt Administration, and afterward was called upon to answer many questions.

LONDON, March 19. -- The military correspondent of The Times says that the hour for decisive action by the Japanese land forces is at hand, and his expectation is that a forward move toward the Yalu will be made when the concentration in that quarter of Korea is complete.

Contradictory evidence as to the amount of iron on the top floor of the Darlington Hotel skeleton when it collapsed and killed twenty-one men on March 2 has heard by Coroner Scholer and his expert jury at the continued inquest in the West Side Court yesterday.

During the hearing before the Aldermanic Committee on Railroads, held yesterday afternoon on the application of the Union Railway Company for additional Bronx franchises, plea was made by Alderman Sullivan for a transfer interchange between the Metropolitan lines in Manhattan and the Union lines in the Bronx.

Bernard Schuelbach, two years old, who lives with his father and mother at 608 East Fifth Street, had a piece of custard pie for his breakfast yesterday morning, and he washed it down with milk. Two hours later, at 9 o'clock, he was seized with convulsions. Dr. Morris Rosenbaum of 540 East Fifth Street was called, and prepared to administer chloroform.

SEOUL, March 18. -- The United States cruiser Cincinnati took to Che-Foo the Korean General Yi Hak Kyumen and Chamberlain Haik Sang, both advocates of the declaration of the neutrality of Korea submitted to the powers in January, the effect of which would have been favorable to Russia.

In your issue of Saturday 1 notice that the "List of Books Dealing with the Far East" (Page 170) omits "China and the Chinese," published in 1902 by Herbert A. Giles, LL. D., Professor of Chinese in the University of Cambridge.

"A History of the Ancient World," by Prof. George S. Goodspeed of the University of Chicago, is in preparation at Charles Scribner's Sons. Although a textbook, primarily for the High School, this will be, it is said, of interest to the maturer student and reader. The theme is the unity of ancient history.
Concerning general trade conditions, Dun's Review says in its issue of to-day:

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- The creation of a service pension law by Executive ruling is to be seized upon by the Democrats as a fresh illustration of President's Roosevelt's encroachments upon the legislative branch of the Government, and his effort to break down the Constitutional barriers between the different branches.
LONDON, March 19. -- Writing under date of Feb. 19, the Tokio correspondent of The Times gives the details of the second torpedo attack on the Russian fleet at Port Arthur on Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Two Wisconsin members of the House were discussing the "indictment" and the unhappy effect it seemed to have on the estimate that members of the House have of Postmaster General Payne. One of them referred to the hard row that Mr. Payne has had to hoe since he entered the Cabinet.

Preparatory to the intercollegiate championship gymnastic meeting to be held at New York University next Friday evening, two joint gymnastic competitions were held in this city last night, Columbia, Yale, and the University of Pennsylvania competing in the Columbia gymnasium, while New York University and Princeton met at University Heights.

United States General Appraiser Fischer yesterday overruled a decision by F. Behrend of New York against the assessment of 45 per cent. duty, as manufactures in chief value of metal, on evaporating pans of metal and earthenware. The importer claimed that they were dutiable at 25 per cent. as earthenware.
WASHINGTON, March 18. -- House Committee on Elections No. 1 declined to pass on the validity of the laws of South Carolina whereby, it is alleged, the negro is disfranchised.

CHICAGO, March 18. -- "Presidency and President are distinct terms," said Gen. Fred D. Grant to-day when asked if he had been correctly understood when it was reported of him that he declined to toast the President of the United States at the St. Patrick's day banquet of the Irish Fellowship Club.

An introductory note by the publishers explains that this book, compiled by them from a series of talks with Dr. Rainsford in his study, (he did not actually write the volume himself,) tells the story of the transformation of a despondent and a dying church into a living and most active agency for good in one of the most congested sections of the city.

Dodd, Mead Co. have secured for Fall publication new novels by Amelia E. Barr, author of "The Bow of Orange Ribbon," "The Maid of Maiden Lane," , and George Barr McCutcheon, author of "The Sherrods," "Graustark," The former will be entitled "The Belle of Bowling Green," and will deal with old New York in the stirring times of the war of 1812.

Whether the building industry will again be paralyzed and from 40,000 to 100,000 people thrown idle now depends on the bricklayers. The laborers left the entire matter with the bricklayers' unions yesterday, and agree to abide by any decision the bricklayers come to, whether for peace or war.

THERE have been many old books, and there are several new ones treating on the boy, and so it is probable that these will multiply in number, Three such volumes have just been taken from the press, bound up and thrust upon the market, all with a ray of hope.

Dr. Leo Selling of 234 East Eighty-seventh Street was summoned to the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning, on complaint of an Assistant Superintendent of the Consolidated Gas Company, who would not give his name, and who charged that the physician refused to permit the gas company's agent to examine his meter.

-- First of the correspondents to attempt our enlightenment as to why anybody should pay $7,900 for a picture of a brown and white cow is one who gets both the color of the cow and the price of her picture wholly wrong in his statement of the problem, so it's no wonder that his theory of values leaves us quite unconvinced.

"Humanism, Philosophical Essays." by F.C.S. Schiller, published in London by Macmillan Co. last Fall, is one of the most stimulating and original volumes of philosophical essays that I have read in several years, being worthy of comparison with James's "Varieties of Religious Experience" and Howison's "Limits of Evolution."

IN YOUR SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS March 12, under a caption, "Shakespeare Commentary,'' is a communication signed "B. Frank Carpenter, New York Public Library, March 7, 1904," in which the writer gives some "extracts" from my book, "How to Study Shakespeare."

I find in Niedersachsen the following notice by Ernest Mangold, Munden: "In 1776, at the time of the selling by Frederick II, of Hesse-Kassel of his country's children for heavy money to England, the poet Johann Georg Seumme, whose 'Where there is singing make thyself at home" and 'The Savage' are to this day sung by everybody, was also seized by Hessian recruiting officers.

Herbert Thurston's volume on "Lent and Holy Week: Chapters on Catholic Observance and Ritual," to be brought out immediately by Longmans, Green Co., is a "popular" account of those external observances by which the season of paschal preparation is marked off from the rest of the ecclesiastical year. The author treats fully of the discipline of fasting, the Lenten liturgy, and the ceremonies of Holy Week.

ALBANY, March 18, -- Senator Platt is not to give up the Republican leadership without a determined struggle to regain control. He has sent telegrams to his friends all over the State requesting them to meet him in New York for a conference.

THE death of M. Sabatier, in 1901, excited through a wide circle a profound sentiment of regret, especially as it was feared that we should get nothing further from his hand. His "Outlines of a Philosophy of Religion Based Upon Psychology and History" attracted much attention, and if not equal admiration, a great deal.

NEW ORLEANS, March 18. -- The announcement of the failure of Daniel J. Sully, the "Cotton King," of New York, created the greatest panic ever seen on the floor of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange. Prices melted away until they were $9 and $10 a bale lower than yesterday's close, and every moment the fear was that local firms would go to the wall.

In your issue of March 12 I find a review by Mr. William E. Dodd of my book, "A Century of Expansion." The space and place which it fills are flattering to me, and, however much Mr. Dodd's opinions and judgments differ from my own, I have no disposition to take exception to them. It is the privilege of the critic to criticise as much as of the author to write.

ALFRED RUSSEL WALLACE will have his "Autobiography" published in the Autumn by Dodd, Mead Co. He is the author of "Darwinism," "The Wonderful Century," and other books. Dr. Wallace a few years before Darwin, formulated a theory of evolution which is substantially the same as Darwin's.

ALBANY, March 18. -- In the annual Supply bill, presented to-day by Mr. Rogers, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the Assembly, is a clause reappropriating $100,000 of the State's money left over from the Buffalo Exposition for the purpose of erecting at Buffalo a monument in memory of President McKinley.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 18. -- A correspondent who has just visited Port Arthur telegraphs to-day from Mukden as follows:

On the subject of natural biographies the following, from the preface to Charles Godfrey Leland's "Memoirs," has some bearing. Leland wrote: "It happened once in Boston, in the year 1861 or 1862, that I was at a dinner of the Atlantic Club, such as was held every Saturday, when the question was raised as to whether any man had ever written a complete and candid biography.

The extraordinary legislation (?) about pensions for civil war veterans was the text for one of the most admirable of your characteristic editorials. You hammer wrong, no matter who needs the correction for perpetrating it. I would like to ask if this age pension is to be general -- to supplement any other pensions for disabilities as hitherto construed?

I have held the opinion that any law or combination which prevented fair and open competition in business was a public injury. It seems that I was mistaken. Here are two railroads having the same terminus. If they are under one management, how much better it would be for their own business, and how much more easily could they fleece the public.

PARIS, March 19. -- There comes from St. Petersburg the report of an interesting conversation with Gen. Dragomiroff, the hero of the Russo-Turkish war. This officer spoke with much less assurance than some other Russian officers on the outcome of the war with Japan.

The suit brought by Robert D. Vroom against Russell Sage to recover $23,000 on a stock transaction which he ordered the financier to make for him on May 9, 1901, the day of the memorable panic in the local market, ended yesterday in a verdict of $14,603.50 for the plaintiff. Mr. Sage's counsel will appeal the case.

At the suggestion of Controller Grout at the Rapid Transit Commission meeting yesterday a resolution was adopted to put before the people of New York the question whether they want the tunnels which are to be built hereafter not only to be constructed but operated by the city in case an acceptable tenant cannot be found.

ALBANY, March 18. -- Judge Parker's friends are becoming alarmed over the success which is attending the efforts of the Hearst workers to secure delegates to the State Convention. Yesterday Hearst captured the delegates from Cattaraugus County, and reports from Rochester and other points where the Hearst campaign is being most actively waged are that Hearst is making surprising headway.

District Attorney Jerome returned to his office yesterday completely satisfied with the way things were going up at Albany. He said he would return to Albany on Monday to be present Monday night, when he believes his bill to enable him to convict Richard A. Canfield of running a gambling establishment in this city will come up in the Senate for its third reading and passage.

Those many hyphened names, with the stale, flat ring of the tin pan in their syllables, which stare at us all from the inkiest headlines of all the newspapers look out of the pages of this book with an odd sort of familiarity. Here a man neither hostile nor Japanese lands at Che-mul-pho, and thence proceeds to Ping-yang and to many other places in the Land of the Morning Calm, euphemistic for Korea.

There seems to be among certain of your contributors to this page a desire for knowledge of really readable fiction. It is rather late for a word of commendation for "The People of the Whirlpool," but busy women cannot always read works of fiction when first published, nor are they, as your contributor puts it, always on the shelves of country libraries.
Daniel J. Sully, the "Cotton King," went down to bitter defeat yesterday when he was forced to announce his suspension on the floor of the Exchange which had been the scene of his many triumphs.

In early Spring, when the precocious sparrow builds his nest while snow flurries are in the air, determined, like the clever little Britisher he is, to get the better by several months of any indigenous bird, in the Spring, just before the Society of American Artists opens its annual exhibition, the Ten American Painters make their communal nest in the Durand-Ruel Gallery and line it with the products of their fancy.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 18. -- The effect of the Sully failure was not seriously felt here. It is said that none of the local brokerage firms suffered to any great extent by the sensational decline in to-day's market.

It is about time that some action was taken to compel the Metropolitan Traction Company to remedy the wholly unnecessary and fearful noise made by its cars. I am glad to notice that THE TIMES is giving space in its columns to complaints against the company. The cars that run through Manhattan Avenue have such badly constructed running gear that they pound and rattle in a way to suggest a boiler shop and rapid-fire guns.

LONDON, March 18. -- Messrs. Hodder Stoughton will publish "The Way of the Sea," by Norman Duncan. Concerning this new writer, Frank Bullen says that, with the exception of Joseph Conrad, no writer about the sea ever probed its mysteries so deeply and faithfully.

PARIS, March 18. -- The perilous state of European politics makes the question of the maintenance of the present French Government one of such great importance that the Combes success of yesterday, even by the narrow majority of three, which was exclusive of the votes of the Ministers themselves, is a matter for congratulation.

It is about time that some action was taken to compel the Metropolitan Traction Company to remedy the wholly unnecessary and fearful noise made by its cars. I am glad to notice that THE TIMES is giving space in its columns to complaints against the company. The cars that run through Manhattan Avenue have such badly constructed running gear that they pound and rattle in a way to suggest a boiler shop and rapid-fire guns.

An extremely interesting feature of The Delineator for April will be the first installment of "Round the World in Eighty Pictures," a series of letters describing a long journey, the first stage of which begins at Montreal and ends at Vancouver. The pictures are capital. This will be an Easter fashion number, with suitable articles on dress in New York, London, and Paris.

"That's good work, Jimmy," said Robert, approvingly. "It sounds uncommonly like a limerick, though." "It is a limerick," replied Jimmy. So it is. "The Gordon Elopement" is a limerick in prose. Nobody can beat Carolyn Wells when it comes to a limerick in verse; we may take that for an axiom. If you find it difficult to understand what a limerick in prose and 235 pages may be, read this book.

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- Chairman Overstreet of the Post Office Committee to-day saved the cause of better postal facilities for New York from shipwreck. It had an exceedingly narrow escape, however, and at one time seemed hopelessly gone.

Plans are being gradually perfected for the great hill-climbing contest up Mount Washington, in the White Mountains, this Summer. The arrangements have already progressed so far that there is practically no doubt of its complete success. The main difficulty has been to get permission to use the mountain road for such a purpose.

THIS is a collection of essays, published, all except the last, during the past two or three years, in The Atlantic Monthly. The subjects are: "The Foe of Compromise," "A Defense of American Parties," "The Task of the American Historian," and "Great Occasions of an American University."

WASHINGTON, March 18. -- There was a brilliant gathering of prominent society people this morning at the residence in Lafayette Square of Representative Henry Kirke Porter of Pittsburg, to meet Dr. Booker T. Washington of Tuskeegee Institute. Among those present were Mme. Jusserand, wife of the French Ambassador; Mrs. Depew, Mrs. Hobart, Mrs. James R. Garfield, Mrs. Edward Everett Hale, Morris K. Jesup, Mrs. Eustis, and Mrs. William Slater.

When the members of the Grand Jury filed into Part I. of the General Sessions yesterday Judge Foster stated that he intended to reply to a communication which he had received from the jurors, who protested against one of the rules made by the Grand Jury Board, requiring Grand Jurors to answer roll call in court to insure the certification of their presence in doing jury duty.

Thomas Whittaker has just put out a reissue of a volume of sermons by the Right Rev. Dr. Greer, Bishop Coadjutor of New York, entitled "From Things to God," and the ninth edition of "The History of the Episcopal Church in America," by the Rev. Dr. S.D. McConnell, rector of All Souls' Church, this city.

NEW ORLEANS, March 18. -- With only one more day of racing to the long meeting the scramble for winners was a disastrous one this afternoon, only two of the six choices finishing in front. The weather was cloudy and disagreeable, and the track deep in mud. This condition was considered to particularly favor Fred Foster's filly, Mrs. Frank Foster, and she was the most heavily played starter of the day.

Mr. Charles Bloomingdale, Jr., ("Karl") ought really to have called his new book "The Yellow Streak" after the third story in the collection rather than "A Failure," for there is an unmistakable streak of yellow running through the book from cover to cover. The first story, which is the longest and most pretentious, is the story of a boy who from babyhood was what the world called a failure.

THERE could be no better introduction to the "Memorials of Mary Wilder White," no foreword which could offer more inducements to the readers to take up the book than the frontispiece portrait of its heroine.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 19. -- All the hotels have very large Easter bookings, and all indications are that Eastertide will be a record breaker this year. The fine weather of the past week has filled all the leading hotels, and the Boardwalk has been crowded daily with promenaders from all sections of the country.
WAS there ever before a contest, either of mind or matter, for a prize of millions?

WHILE John Hamilton Brown, inventor, is busy in the mechanical den at his residence in Reading, Penn., the sturdy iron and steel workers in the historic Scott Foundry of that city are busy perfecting his now famous segmental wire-wound gun. Mr. Brown is a citizen of New York, but as his guns are being made in Reading, he and his young wife and baby are living there temporarily.

BOSTON, March 19. -- Mrs. Francis Bates-Batchelder has received numerous offers to enter upon a professional musical career, and when she does so her voice will be heard on the concert stage for the first time since its owner left Boston for Italy two years ago.

CARMEL, N.Y., March 19. -- The Carmel County Republican Convention, held here to-day, unanimously renominated Assemblyman John R. Yale and nominated E.W. Addis for District Attorney. William H. Weeks and A.V. Porter were chosen delegates to the New York Convention for the selection of delegates to the Republican National Convention John R. Yale, E.C. Weeks, and William M. Benjamin were chosen as delegates to the State Convention for the nomination of a State ticket.

GOTHAM'S GOWNS continue to show evidence of the transition state between cold and warm weather fashions. Spring hats, which are by no means similar to the chapeaus that will be purchased in April, are seen in conjunction with Winter frocks and those of the previous Autumn.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 19. -- The whereabouts of the Vladivostok squadron is a profound official secret, but there are those here who believe that the Japanese may wake up some morning to find that the two divisions of Russia's Pacific squadron have effected a juncture.

WHILE carrying on a series of experiments in his laboratory with chicken life during the embryonic stages, Dr. Counter, a young dentist of Toledo, succeeded in hatching a chicken by means of an ordinary steam radiator. The egg was placed in a small paper box and hung from the radiator during the period of incubation.

The wandering sinner seeking means of grace, so far as Derby, Connecticut, is concerned, is cordially invited into the tabernacle, but is admonished, when necessary, that the invitation does not include the privilege of sitting down in the lap of the first deaconess whom he chances to discover at her devotions.

The firm of Daniel J. Sully Co., which suspended on Friday, made an assignment yesterday. As Mr. Sully had given assurance, particularly to the members of the Cotton Exchange, that the suspension would be only temporary, the announcement of the assignment caused almost as much astonishment as the announcement of the suspension had on the day before, and the immediate effect was to cause the cotton market to sell off again.

IT is but seven days to Palm Sunday and the beginning of Holy Week. Lent is nearly over and yet Mi-Careme, which is at best but a legend, has just been celebrated. Mi-Careme, after all, is really St. Joseph's Day, the 19th of March. The Roman Catholic Church allowed weddings to be quietly celebrated on that feast, and hence the tradition.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., March 19. -- Policemen had to interfere to-day to stop a free fight in the church here of the Seventh Day Aventists, the largest denomination in Southern Michigan, one of whose peculiarities is that they eschew all meat, subsisting on vegetables.

A WRITER in English Country Life describes a curious timepiece which a friend of his picked "out of a deal of old iron." It is a brass circle of about two inches diameter. On the outer side are engraved letters indicating days and the months with graduated divisions, and on the inner side the hours of the day.

FROM the electric light bulb back to the candle molds is a big jump. The careful housewife of eighty years ago had just as definite a way of making lights as we of to-day, and she had her troubles, too. Though the hot tallow did not kill, it left a bad burn when, in filling her molds, she let it drip over the edge.

The discussion of the "mixed goods" bill at the recent convention of the National Wool Growers' Association at Portland, Oregon, has started the woolen goods trade to talking about the use of shoddy in the construction of fabrics. New York is the centre of the manufacture of clothing, and some of the cheapest clothing, too, that is made in the country.

ROME, March 19. -- King Victor Emmanuel visited the Forum to-day to inspect the vases which have recently been discovered concealed in the foundation stone of the famous equestrian statue of Emperor Domitian.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19. -- Albert M. Wilson, a negro, who had been connected with the University of Pennsylvania in various menial capacities for almost fifty years, died to-day of pneumonia.

A bill appropriating $20,000 for the erection of a monument to the late Gov. William Goebel was passed by the Legislature of Kentucky at its session just closed. It passed the House by a strict party vote of those voting, but several Democrats refrained from voting.

Timohty L. Woodruff's boom for Governor of the State of New York was launched last night at a dinner given in his honor by the Invincible Club in the clubhouse, Herkimer Street near Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn.

IT IS no exaggeration to say that the civilized nations find themselves today in the presence of a terrible evil that is beginning to oppose a powerful barrier to their colonial enterprises in tropical Africa. A malady which up to the present time has been sure death to every person attacked by it has been making fearfully rapid progress.

Because the city authorities have refused to consent to the closing up of an unused street the Burlington Road has put off its plan of building a $1,000,0O0 roundhouse at Cicero, one of the suburbs of Chicago.

ATTENTION was directed in a striking manner last week to the necessity of greater care in the preservation of old New York City records. Through the energy of the Corporation Counsel's office sixty-one volumes of Common Council records, running as far back as 1809, were rescued from the book store of A. S. Clark, at 174 Fulton Street, where they had been advertised for sale for the round sum of $1,000.

LONDON, March 5. -- The retirement of Sir William Harcourt from Parliamentary life has an interest beyond the purely personal. That of itself is considerable. For more than thirty years Sir William has been a leading figure alike in the House of Commons and on the public platform.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 19. -- From the banks of the Danube to the shores of the Great Salt Lake, Nicola Naronovich has been tracked by the brothers of the girl he slew in Austria, and is now in jail. He is charged with murdering Eva Mikandra, his sweetheart, in Wrabatz, Austria; Nicola Gagula, his rival, at Barlit, Austria; Rade Vidovac, and Tony Galovic, in South Chicago, Ill.

After a conference of over two hours' duration with Senator Platt Gov. Odell came down into the corridor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel at 11 o'clock last night, and when asked whether there was to be war or peace between the Senator and himself replied:

THE combination of absolute fearlessness with unusual cleverness and quickness to learn which marks the Japanese soldier has been noted by all who have written of him. But few Americans have knowledge of the severe course of training, for officers and men alike, which produces soldiers capable of responding to any demand and personally contemptuous of death.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 19. -- The New York Americans played their second game with the Atlanta Southern League team this afternoon, winning by a score of 5 to 0. Powell was in fine form not allowing a hit; Wolfe was found for three singles. The feature of the game was a home run by Beville in the fourth, when he put the ball over right field fence.

Workmen on the west side branch of the rapid transit subway broke through the headings of the Fort George section yesterday afternoon, and Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons crawled through the aperture. That marked the completing of the opening of the tunnel on both branches from the City Hall to the northern terminals.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 19. -- William Sullivan, better known as "Yank Hudson," risked his life early yesterday in the icy waters of the Rockaway River in order that he might rescue a dog, a yellow dog at that. "Yank" lives at Rockaway and has to cross the Rockaway River to and from his work.

WIRELESS telegraphy is not the only sort that does away with the expense of stringing wires to convey the electric current, but probably most people don't know that this item of original expenditure was removed, so far as short lines were concerned, more than ten years ago, and the method then employed is as feasible to-day an it was then.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 19. -- So quiet and sedate an observance of Lent by Lakewood society people as this has been is quite in contrast to previous Lenten seasons here. There have been no gay functions or pretentious entertainments, and as Holy Week approaches there is little likelihood of any relaxation toward gayety by the cottagers.

PROF HOFFMANN, whose book on "Later Magic" has just been published in this country by E.P. Dutton Co., 31 West Twenty-third Street, is a conjuror better known in England than in America. The translator of the works of that prince of conjurors, Robert Houdin, he has himself written two octavo volumes on the art of deception in addition to the one just issued.

Armed with axes, a force of detectives from the Mercer Street Station swooped down on the Alden Social Club on the second floor of an Eighth Street house, not far from Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon and cornered -200 men Their advent was so sudden and unexpected that a man on guard at the outer door of the house was captured before he had time to give an alarm.

The new edifice of the First United Presbyterian Church, which is being erected on Central Park West, between One Hundred and Seventh and One Hundred and Eighth Streets, from plans by Cotton Wallis, is to combine several unusual features of construction, not the least of which will be three great windows with combined open space of more than 2,500 square feet.

OF COURSE I can identify myself. The very idea! You come down stairs, and I'll show you my horse and buggy," The tall man waxed indignant as he stood at the cashier's window in the money order department on the second floor of the New York Post Office. The blue slip of paper had been politely handed back to him with a question as to his ability to furnish proper identification.

Dr. Richard Strauss, the composer, was the guest of honor at a dinner given last evening by the members of the Lotos Club, in their house at Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. About two hundred diners were present, and every mention of the name of the guest of the evening was the signal for enthusiastic applause.

IF there is any limit to the present movement in small investment properties there is nothing in current reports to indicate it. It was buying of this sort that swelled last week's news budget to considerably over 200 transactions -- a circumstance which, even a year or two ago, would have been regarded about as probable as that ten million shares should be dealt in on a single day on the Stock Exchange.

THE success of "The Secret of Polichinelle" in New York comes from very different lines of thought and appreciation here than it did in Paris. The points which receive vociferous approbation in Paris are passed unheeded in New York and vice versa.

NEWARK, N.J., March 19. -- Miss Emilie Ball, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Ball, and Frederic Wheeler Dodd of this city were married in St. James's Episcopal Church here this afternoon in the presence of only the immediate relatives and a few friends. The bride, who was unattended, was given away by her father, while the officiating clergyman was the Rev. Cyrus B. Durand, rector of the church.

" When I accepted the Police Commissionership," said Commissioner McAdoo, as he leaned back in his big desk chair at Headquarters the other day. I thought I knew as much about the Police Department as the average New Yorker, and a little more. I did, but looking back at the fund of knowledge which I brought with me into the office I now see that I was absolutely ignorant of actual conditions.

THERE have always been people who like to get married in queer places. There are those who have the ceremony performed on the stage of a theatre, others select high belfries or the top of a skyscraper, some choose to be united in a police station, while others take the fatal step in a lion's cage with only the minister's gown between them and the beasts.

NEAR the famous and erratic geyser of Waimangu, in New Zealand -- so whimsical in its spoutings and times of quiet that the oldest Maori in the region can give the visitor no schedule of these performances -- there has lately been born a new geyser. A few hours before the birth a passer-by had stopped to look at a placid little lagoon ringed about with gentle green slopes.

With the blare of music, the grunting of the elephants, the "hullo-allo-allo-allo" of clowns and the shrill laughter of children, the Barnum Bailey circus opened in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

K. Takahashi, Vice President of the Bank of Japan, which is the official banking institution of the Japanese Government, is in New York and yesterday took occasion to deny all reports that a war loan was being negotiated or the negotiation contemplated by Japan in the market of New York, or of any other financial centre of the world.

Mrs. Tryphosa Bates-Batchelder, a wealthy society woman of Boston, will sail in April for London, where she purposes making her debut as a concert singer. She is the only child of Theodore C. Bates of Worcester, Mass.

Last week prices regained what they had lost in the previous three weeks. That is to say, the list as a whole is now almost precisely where it was a month ago. Industrials have still a couple of points to go before reaching January's high record, and railways are five points below their best of the year. The chief stimulating factor has been that from which disaster had been feared.

The people of this city will show themselves heedless of their own interests if they fail of admonish the Legislature that it disregards alike its duty and the welfare of four millions of persons in refusing to pass the bills sent to Albany by the Rapid Transit Commissioners.
Mr. BALFOUR will join battle with his opponents to-morrow on a formal motion of "want of confidence" on the issue of Chinese labor in South Africa.
IS THERE an aristocracy of the theatrical profession?
WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Russia will be asked by the United States to treat kindly the Japanese non-combatants who have been left in Siberia and to enable them to make their way back to Japan.
BERLIN, March 19. -- It was recently reported that several officers of the Crown Prince's regiment had been transferred to Berlin regiments, and that others had been sent to Darmstadt.

CLEVELAND, March 19. -- Wild scenes of disorder marked the opening of the Twentieth District Republican Congressional Convention here to-day, as a result of a fight between the Dick and Foraker factions.

POPE PIUS X. has ordered that the music now in use in the Catholic Church be superseded by Gregorian music, or music which approaches in movement, inspiration, and savor the Gregorian form. His instructions provide that the change be made as quickly as possible, and the necessary steps to carry out instructions emanating from such a source may not be dilatorily taken.
" The Truth About the Trusts. A Description and Analysis of the American Trust Movement." By John Moody, editor of "Moody's Manual of Corporation Securities."

Doubtless those who are most interested in the scheme of replanning the city have been most disappointed at the composition of the commission selected to that end by the Mayor. The technical members of the commission, excepting, of course, Mr. PARSONS and Mr. FRENCH, are far from being of the first authority.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19. -- Women fencers from New York Annapolis, and this city met here to-day in a contest for the Tri-City Cup offered by a number of fencers in this city. The women from the New York Fencers' Club won the trophy after a close competition, leading Annapolis by 2 1/2 points.

It is the plan of the Sullivans, according to a competent authority, to have a general shake-up "down town" this Fall with reference to offices more or less in their control. It is conceded that the First, Second, Third, Sixth, Eighth, and under certain conditions the Fifth and Seventh Districts, would be with the Sullivan element in Tammany Hall on most any proposition.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The mystery of the missing wills of George Shehan, a wealthy resident of Washington, has been partially cleared up. The lost documents have been found misplaced among other papers in the office of the Register of Wills.

EVERY country has its national game. With Americans it is baseball. The Koreans prefer stone fighting or throwing. Travelers soon learn of the art acquired by stone fighters, though there is but one day in the year given over to it. If any one offend a Korean, he answers with a stone.
PINEHURST, N.C., March 19. -- The demand for accommodations here still continues, and is made even greater by the annual influx of guests from resorts further South, which is well begun.

A DEBATE recently took place in Paris between a brain specialist and an eminent physician as to the effect high-speed auto racing had upon the brain. There was a marked disparity in the views set forth, and this has led to much discussion on the subject.
