ELIZABETH, N.J., March 19. -- Fire started at 11:30 o'clock last night in the cooperage and barreling establishment of the Bayway Refining Company, at Elizabethport, and spread to the buildings owned by the Pennsylvania and Delaware Oil Company, and both plants were destroyed. The combined loss to property is in the vicinity of $100,000.

In a leader entitled "Duke of Cambridge" which appeared in your paper of this morning comparisons are made in the present tense between the aristocratic officers of the German and Austrian Armies and the aristocratic officers of the British Army, to the disadvantage of the last named.

Since the protective committee of minority stockholders of the National Salt Company recently had the sale of the company's plant set aside the International Salt Company has offered to receive additional stock, not originally deposited, with it on condition that the stock be deposited with the New York Security and Trust Company with a fee of $1 a share at the time of deposit and $2 a share additional to be paid when called.

A sudden decline in the price of apples after many months of high values has demoralized the market somewhat. Notwithstanding reiterated reports to the contrary, last year's crop was a large one. Accurate statistics are impossible, but the best information obtainable gives 45,000,000 barrels for the United States and Canada as an approximate figure.

Russians are so poorly informed by their press that it is no wonder they are amazed at the coldness of Americans toward the war of aggrandizement the Russian Government has courted in Korea and Manchuria. They feel themselves aggrieved, they are hurt in the house of their friends.

TOKIO, March 19. -- The British Minister refuses to indorse the application of H. Hales, the correspondent of The London Daily News, for permission to accompany the Japanese army, giving as his reason that the reports Mr. Hales sent from the Transvaal during the Boer war were slanderous of the British army.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 19.--Pitcher Leon Ames, who was discovered by Manager McGraw of the New York Nationals last season, had a busy time during the five innings he pitched in to-day's exhibition game between the New Yorks and the local Southern League team. While the visitors won by the goodly measure of 12 to 7 tallies, Ames fell from grace.

There is a curious parallel in the recent history of the two Powers locked in what for one at least is accepted as a life-and-death grapple in the Far East. Each has been impelled toward foreign war by the expansion of its population, the need of new fields of activity, and secular tradition as to adjacent territory, and they have now met in pursuance of forces which each deems irresistible.
BERLIN, March 20. -- Emperor William and King Alfonso figure as life savers in a story told in Das Kleine Journal.

THE story of an American's wonderful work abroad, and how all England, from King to carpenter, from The London Times to The Tinman's Chronicle -- if such a sheet there be -- got to talking of it, is worth the telling. The man is James C. Stewart of St. Louis and Pittsburg, constructing engineer, and the work -- but the story should begin in this way:
HOW tired the housewife grows of objects d'art!

PARIS, March 19. -- It is the expectation in official quarters that France and the other signatories of the Berlin treaty will unite in emphatic representations to Turkey against carrying out the Sultan's plans for the suppression and probable extermination of a considerable portion of the Armenians.

IN THE past quarter of a century the wave of enthusiasm for sport which has swept over this country from England has brought many bitterly vexed questions, but curiously enough the point at which the development of athletics in America has been on the whole most vulnerable has seldom or never been raised.

FOUR fine private palace cars, furnished as luxuriously as the lavish expenditure of money permits, were within a few feet of one another in the shed for outgoing trains at the Grand Central Station last week. Within the hour each of them was to start on a transcontinental journey to occupy from six to eight weeks. One was bound straightway for the Pacific Coast, thence by more leisurely stages to the frozen mountains of Alaska.

PORTSMOUTH, March 19. -- The British submarine boat, No. A1, which was run down by the Donald Currie Line steamship Berwick Castle, yesterday afternoon, near the Nab Lightship, off the east coast of the Isle of Wight, still lies under 100 feet of water off the lightship.

The discussion aroused last week by the Northern Securities decision eclipsed somewhat the interest in the annual statement of the United States Steel Corporation which was published last Sunday morning. But with the first excitement over the decision passed away, the Steel report will probably, come in for a little more consideration than it has received, but which it is deserving of.

Wholesale and retail stationers in all the important cities of the country have united in a movement to form a National association of stationers. The convention to perfect the association will be held in Chicago in October. One of the principal objects of the organization will be to secure more consideration from manufacturers with regard to prices.

Two women who sell newspapers at the Manhattan end of the Bridge were arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday on a charge of disturbing the peace by quarreling near the north roadway. Policeman O'Neill of the Oak Street Station told Magistrate Whitman that they quarreled there so often that they even stopped automobiles and blocked traffic on the Bridge.
CY WARMAN tells a story of Judge Thomas P. Macon, a member of the Denver bar and a typical Southerner of the old school.

Every citizen interested in the welfare of his country must regret the recant publication by THE TIMES of an editorial, apparently intended to be an answer to the admirable address of President Hopkins on the "Moral Condition of Our Society." It makes light of the whole subject on the ground that perhaps things are not as bad as they are painted.

In The Contemporary Review a writer with a taste for actuarial inquiry, Mr. T.P. WHITTAKER, gives some figures of unusual interest which tend to show that of men in good health and of good general habits, admitting of classification as "selected lives," the expectation of life is greater among total abstainers than among those who use alcohol moderately.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Opponents of the Panama route for the canal brought up the Bohio dam question again when Admiral Walker. President of the Canal Commission, had a hearing to-day before the House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce.

THIS strange thing of wood and iron, with the look of a combination chafing dish and sieve, is a bi-metallic three-legged stove. It belongs to a collection of curios owned by a man in Tarrytown, and was used by the old Knicker bockers to light their pipes. They called it a "comforter."

WILMINGTON, Del., March 19.--In attempting to save the life of his friend, William Maxwell of Baltimore, who had sprung in front of an approaching train, Frank Suydam of Middletown, Del., was crushed to death with him this evening before the eyes of a score of spectators at the Middletown station.

Henry Wollman, the well-known corporation lawyer, in discussing the effect of the Northern Securities decision so far as actual tangible results are concerned, expressed the following views for THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ST. PETERSBURG, March 19.--The Government's private information is not completely reassuring as regards China's sincerity in observing a neutral attitude. Secret advices indicate that at least a powerful party in the Chinese Government is abetting the Japanese.

ONE of the most fascinating lines of work in which women are engaged is that of art metal work. This department of art work at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, is going to send a fine exhibit to the St. Louis Exhibition, and after that there may be a deluge of young women gold and silver smiths.

ALBANY, March 19. -- Fifteen delegates to the Democratic State Convention which will elect delegates to the National Convention were chosen in five Assembly Districts in this State to-day. They are the first State delegates to be elected in the State and are all Parker men.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Major Theodore A. Bingham was graduated at West Point in 1879. He was Military Attache at Berlin from 1890 to 1892, and Superintendent in charge of Public Buildings and Grounds in Washington from 1897 to 1903, with the rank of Colonel. Since May 1, 1903, he has been in charge of the engineering work at Buffalo, including works on Lake Ontario and Lake Erie.

Harry De B. Parsons, the engineering expert employed by District Attorney Jerome to ascertain the causes which led to the collapse of the Darlington Hotel, yesterday submitted his full report. The engineer says the primary cause was "faulty design and carelessness and neglect in the erection of the members."
BERLIN, March 19. -- Col. Leutwein (the Governor of German Southwest Africa) reports a German reverse on March 13. The Germans were forced to retreat.

J.K. Armsby, head of the J.K. Armsby Company, Chicago, is in town for a few days. His firm is the selling agent of the Alaska Packers' Association, the largest salmon canning firm in the world, excepting the Pacific Packing Navigation Co. He confirms the statements previously made of the large sales of cheap salmon to the Japanese Government, and adds that Japanese speculative purchasers have also been active.

C. M. Daniels, a seventeen-year-old school boy and a member of the New York Athletic Club, made a remarkable performance in the swimming championships of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, held at the New York Athletic Club last night, winning every event in which he competed, including the championship at 220 and at 440 yards, and making new American record of 6:02 4-5 in the latter race.

The building strike did not show any encouraging signs to the mason builders yesterday. The bricklayers sent a committee early yesterday morning to Otto M. Eidlitz, President of the Mason Builders' Association, with a proposal indicating that they meant to keep up their support of the laborers to the last, arbitration agreement or no arbitration agreement.

The McEwan bill now before the joint Committee on Banks of the Senate and Assembly at Albany, seeking to limit the investment of savings banks in the securities of the Rock Island system to the first mortgage sixes and the general mortgage fours, brought out last week an interesting contest between the allied savings bank interests of the State, represented by John Harsen Rhoades, President of the State Savings Banks Association, and the railroad company.

The war between Russia and Japan has had the effect in London and in the larger cities of America of cultivating socially the Japanese and of giving to Japanese art and to Japanese methods of life a revival which is much stronger than the first craze during the infancy of the aesthetic movement.

There was a surprise in store for the audience of the last Boston Symphony concert when it gathered in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. A change in the programme was made necessary by the serious indisposition of Miss Muriel Foster, the English contralto singer, who was to make her first New York appearance at this concert, and little printed slips at the door told that Mr. Rafael Joseffy would be the soloist in her place.

That John Granter, forty-nine years old, captain of the lighter Nestor, owned by B.A. Hart Co., agents for the Clyde Line, which is lying at Pier 45 North river, did not lose his life in a fire last night, was due to the pluck of John Reynolds, the watchman employed on the pier.

Nine college teams will meet on Friday night in the gymnasium of the New York University, at University Heights, to contest for the intercollegiate gymnastic championship and for individual and all-around championships in the several events. Six events are to be decided -- horizontal bars, side horse, flying rings, parallel bars, tumbling, and club swinging.
Baron Kentaro Kaneko, who left Japan Feb. 28 and arrived here Friday, urged the cause of his country yesterday before a gathering of newspaper men in his apartments at the Holland House.

One of the worst blockades in years on the Brooklyn Bridge occurred during the "rush" hour yesterday morning, the train service being tied up for an hour, and thousands of passengers who were unable to board the already crowded trolley cars being compelled to walk across the structure from Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Chicago's Police Department has never received such an unmerciful raking in its history as is contained in the report of the investigation of local conditions made by Capt. Alexander Piper, formerly Deputy Police Commissioner of New York, which was submitted to the City Club to-day at its regular meeting.

The volume of Saturday's market was full, and the tone was strong, the combined influences carrying the list to the highest prices of the week. Between Monday, when the Northern Securities decision was announced, and Saturday, when the effect of the Sully failure was felt in full, nothing else of importance happened; but industrials rose something less than three points, and railways something more than four points.

THE infrequency with which Charles Frohman submits to the interviewer lends added interest to the opinions which he expressed to a representative of The London Telegraph immediately upon his arrival in England.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 19. -- The University of Michigan freshman shot-putter, Ralph Rose, again demonstrated his powerful ability to-night by smashing the world's record for the 12-pound shot by one foot one and one-half inches. The feat was accomplished at the meet between the Michigan freshmen and the Detroit University School teams.

About fifty textile manufacturers of Berlin and other German cities will sail April 19 for New York, their purpose being to see the St. Louis Exposition and look into the possibilities of further development of their trade in this country. Nearly all these manufacturers already have representatives here, so that the expedition is not designed so much for the acquirement of new markets as to give an impetus to business already established.

JAPAN says little, very little, but we feel the war deeply. For some time all social gayety has ceased -- balls, parties, receptions. The theatres are closed. The greatest economy is being practiced among the wealthy classes throughout the empire. All conditions of natives are making heroic sacrifice to contribute to the war fund."

LIVERPOOL, March 19. -- The cotton market here this morning presented a lively appearance in view of the Sully crash in New York, which was not announced until after this market had closed yesterday. The galleries and balcony of the Exchange were filled with onlookers, and in the ring the brokers were waiting until the opening bell rang.

Sleepy Sam, a big green frog that for more than a year has occupied one of the exhibition tanks on the ground floor of the Aquarium, is nursing a sore leg, a misfortune that Sam can blame only on himself, since he chewed the leg while laboring under the delusion that that important part of his anatomy was a killie.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 20. -- The handsome new chapel of St. John's Church, which was built on Brighton Avenue, East Orange, at a cost of $20,000, was formally dedicated to-day, the Rev. M.J. McDonald having been delegated by Mgr. John A. Sheppard, Acting Bishop of the Newark Catholic Diocese, to conduct the service.

Sunday, usually a dull day about training establishments, was a decidedly busy one yesterday, and all during the morning hours the Boulevard at Brooklyn was crowded with galloping thoroughbreds. The weather conditions ware ideal, and a crowd of spectators along the roadside thoroughly enjoyed the forenoon exercises.

CHICAGO, March 20. -- John Mahnken, charged with claiming the body of Mrs. Frank R. Greenwald, an Iroquois fire victim, and burying it as that of his aunt, has been arrested and locked up at the Central Station. It is alleged that he assumed the name of John Kounthes and was preparing to sue the theatre company.

In the brooks of Long Island there are hordes of hungry trout, eager for the good things that come down in the way of grub worms, washed out from the banks with the Spring freshets. They are not lean. In fact, they are very fit through their Winter sojourn under the ice in the places where there is much to eat along the bottoms.

The notion of Mr. ROOSEVELT that it will contribute to an enlightening campaign if Congress adjourns the last of April and its members take up public discussion from political platforms, is not a sound one, or one that the opposition should consent to. It is a part of the policy of dodging the real issues and trusting to partisan cries.
So sang the springiest of all Spring poets, Bliss Carman, and so everything seemed to sing in Central Park yesterday afternoon, for the breath of April was upon the land.

ALBANY, March 20. -- The fiscal year closed Sept. 30, 1903, was marked in the State of New York by greater industrial disturbances in the way of strikes, lockouts, and labor disputes generally than any previous year, with the possible exception of 1886. There were in that period 192 labor troubles, in which 117,000 employes were concerned, and 3,900,000 work days lost.
Isn't it about time the ticket speculators were squelched for good and all?
" E.O.H.," who appeals for some protection for the truck horse in your edition of this date, certainly sounds a note that should bring forth a loud response.

BOSTON, March 20. -- The climax to a kidnapping case will come this morning when Mrs. Charles C. Hendricks, wife of Dr. Hendricks, prominent in the famous Laura Bigger case, will appear before Judge Baker, in the Supreme Court, to lay claim to her son Thomas, whom she found in Boston Saturday, after a search of three months.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 20. -- A dispatch from Grenada, Miss., says:

It seems quite evident that in the present factional crisis it is as easy to mix castor oil and water as it would be to harmonize Bryanism and Clevelandism in one political party. Such being the case, it is idle to exert any fruitless efforts and waste precious time in that direction.

The mild weather of yesterday resulted in the informal opening of the local rowing season at an unusually early date by the appearance upon the Harlem River of half a dozen crews from some of the rowing clubs along "Scullers' Row." The Metropolitan Rowing Club had the largest number of boats afloat, being represented by two quadruple sculls, a triple sculls, two doubles, and several singles.

Mr. James C. Carter thinks that when a large majority of people in a certain locality are opposed to a law which they claim cannot be enforced it should be repealed. He cites no precedents, probably because there are none, or few, if any. On the contrary, there are plenty of precedents pointing the other way.

The wine growers of the United States have formed an organization which commends itself to the approval of every public-spirited American citizen. Whether it shall continue to merit such approval will depend upon the zeal and honesty of the association referred to in carrying out the objects for which it is formed.

WITH THE JAPANESE FLEET, March 20. -- Admiral Togo has been comparatively passive since Feb. 25, and a respite has been given to Port Arthur, although the cruisers and destroyers are keeping a close blockade.
I wish to thank "E.O.H." for his letter in this morning's TIMES on the abuse of the truck horse. But there are other horses.

Policeman Hugh J. Enright, one of the younger men of the force, was killed and Patrolman Joseph Bachman was seriously wounded early yesterday morning in a running fight with a burglar on East Fifty-fifth Street, between Second and Third Avenues. The burglar, Jacob Huter, is in Bellevue Hospital suffering with a self-inflicted shot in the forehead, which will probably not prove fatal.
SEOUL, March 19. -- The Marquis Ito held a large reception to-day, which was attended by the foreign legation officials.

NEW ROCHELLE, March 20. -- President J.G. Schurman of Cornell University addressed the People's Forum here to-day on "The True Element of National Greatness," touching in the address on current issues. He picked from history, times, and peoples examples of the dominating power of force, right, ideas, and ideals, dwelling at some length on the fact that this Nation should be distinguished for the latter qualification.

The Japanese are taxing the ingenuity of the St. Petersburg experts to account for their movements, or, rather, for their ability to move. It is only fair to observe that these experts are of the "homekeeping" sort who traditionally have "homely wits." It is quite possible that the responsible naval men of Russia in the East are equal to the solution of a puzzle that baffles the bureaucrats at home.

The exercises in connection with the sixth anniversary celebration of the People's Institute, held last night in Cooper Union, were halted long enough to allow for the adoption of the following resolution:

PHILADELPHIA, March 20. -- There was a quiet wedding at the Continental Hotel to-night when Miss Virginia Anna Arlund of St. Paul was married to Atkins Lawrence, an actor, seventy years of age, by Magistrate Frank S. Harrison.

Not for a long time has there been so cheerful and congenial task as the present review of last week's stock market. The accustomed formula has been to specify an advance or two and to say that the rest fell. Last week there was not a single decline among the dozen most active and representative properties.

Although the writer has been greatly averse to your unjust, bitter, and incessant criticism of our good, honest President, he is only too ready to co-operate in commending such an editorial as appeared in a recent issue of your valued paper, entitled "The Philippines for the Filipinos."

LONDON, March 20. -- The Stock Exchange has been much more active and stronger, especially in the early part of the week, owing to the cheapness of money and the absence of serious news of the war in the Far East.

TOKIO, March 20. -- With stately ceremony the special session of Parliament convened to provide the money needed to wage the war against Russia was opened this morning. The Emperor drove to the Parliament House, and personally read his address to the peers and Representatives. For the first time the Crown Prince attended the ceremony.

Commissioner MCADOO, in the very frank statement made to a representative of THE TIMES, and published yesterday, touches the worst spot in the police system of the city when he says that almost any improvement would be possible if dishonesty were regarded by the policemen with the same scorn they visit upon cowardice.

Expert accountants were at work all yesterday in the offices of Daniel J. Sully Co., endeavoring to find out where the firm stood. Late last night Joseph H. Hoadley, Mr. Sully's assignee, said that the accountants had not finished their work, but that he was certain that they would be in a position to give out a definite statement as to the condition of affairs some time to-day.

PITTSBURG, March 20. -- Victor Herbert, who closed his engagement here yesterday, is angry because some of his players signed an option on their services for the season of 1904-5 to the Pittsburg Orchestra.

I was much interested in O.T. Alp's article on "The Cause of Empty Churches." His criticism of "cold, formal, artificial service" is sadly true in many places, and this does partly account for depleted church services. But the criticism concerning the collection is questionable.

Backed up against the wall of a saloon at One Hundred and Eighty-seventh Street and Arthur Avenue, Detective Sergeant Loewer held a mob of Italians at bay last night with his revolver. Three times they tried to rush the detective. Twice he fired over the heads of the assailants, but the third time he fired point blank and one man fell, probably mortally wounded.

The London County Council is now "considering" the results of a census made by direction of its Public Health Committee, which showed that on the night of Jan. 29 about 2,000 persons were homeless in London. On that night 23,442 persons slept in the common lodging houses of the city.

-- Why not be a butcher? This question, earnestly addressed by one of our correspondents to boys who are looking for chances to enter a business that gives some little promise of a "future" not composed entirely of wages by day or week, is interesting for several other than directly practical reasons.

The Central Federated Union was thrown into a state of excitement yesterday by a statement made by J. Hand, delegate of the Standard and Eccentric Engineers' Union, that thousands of school children were in danger because licensed engineers were not attending to the boilers. He said that his association was getting a bill drafted providing that nobody but licensed engineers should attend to the boilers in the public schools.
In their efforts to find a sane, safe man upon whom all factions of the party can unite, the present drift of the Democratic leaders seems to be toward Judge Parker. -- Atlanta (Ga.) Journal, (Dem.)

When the eliminating automobile trial tests are held on the Ormond Beach, Florida, next month, to determine the fitness of the American representatives to compete in the Gordon Bennett international race to be held this year in Germany, there will probably be a number of other automobiles at Ormond than the three machines that are entered for the big event.

Collectors of old paintings in this country have been so partial to masters of the Netherlands that an exhibition exclusively confined to early Italians comes as a surprise. Such a show is to be seen at the Enrich Galleries, 8 West Thirty-third Street, where it will remain for the next fortnight.

SOUTHAMPTON, March 20. -- The American Line steamship New York, Capt. Young, from New York March 12 for Plymouth, Cherbourg, and Southampton, met with two mishaps to-day, grounding off Cape la Hague, France, in the early morning and later coming into collision in the English Channel with the Peninsular and Oriental steamship Assaye, under contract to the British Government, and used as a troopship bound for Bombay with 500 troops on board.
A first selection of games, played in the recent international Rice gambit tourney at Monte Carlo, is hereby appended:

VICTORIA, B.C., March 20. -- Two Jewish merchants, refugees from Vladivostok, arrived here to-day on the Boston Steamship Company's steamer Shawmut, from Manila via China and Japan. They are August Libby and Cornelius Hoff.
WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The foreign crop as given by the Department of Agriculture is as follows:

PORTSMOUTH, March 20. -- Attempts were made to-day without success to raise the British submarine boat No. A1, which was run down by the Donald Currie Line steamer Berwick Castle Friday afternoon. The principal damage appears to have been done to the conning tower, which shows the marks of the collision.

This is the alliterative war cry proposed by Gov. VAN SANT of Minnesota for the Republicans in the approaching campaign. We doubt if its artful aid to the fortunes of the candidate will amount to much. The two terms of the resounding phrase are almost mutually destructive. Mr. ROOSEVELT is no friend of reciprocity, or, what is worse, he is a recreant friend who has abandoned the cause.

The case of Rhode Island furnishes a good illustration of the injury done to the Democratic Party by Mr. HEARST'S active chase after delegates. Mr. HONEY, a true Democrat and a trusted leader of true Democrats, lost the control of the Rhode Island Democratic State Convention the other day.

PATERSON, N.J., March 20. -- The little mining village of Sterling Junction, N.Y., is at present speculating as to what is going to happen to Antonio Colone, six years old, who is lying in a serious condition in his father's hut near the iron mine there. Last Thursday Antonio ate a stick of dynamite.

Timothy Driscoll, posted as a deserter at Fort Schuyler since December, walked up to the sentry there last Monday and surrendered Courtmarshaled on Friday he told a story for which only his splendid record earned attention. "As you know," he said, "I left the fort on leave Christmas Eve.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- War has been declared between the Department of Agriculture and the entire body of outside agricultural scientists of the country. The cause of this widespread controversy is a bulletin issued by the Bureau of Soils which combats the time-honored theory of the utility of fertilizers in crop production. A demand has arisen throughout the country for the removal of the experts who wrote the bulletin.

Saturday being the anniversary of the forming of the Army Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, Miss Helen Miller Gould gave a reception at her home, 579 Fifth Avenue, which was attended by nearly 100 soldiers, members of the Army Branch and representing various departments of the service, and quite a number of contributors and friends of the organization.

Our dispatch from The London Times's correspondent with the Japanese fleet not only gives the details of several interesting minor engagements, but pretty clearly disposes of the story that Admiral MAKAROFF'S fleet has escaped from Port Arthur and has joined or is trying to join the Russian Vladivostok squadron.

Adherents of Senator Platt gathered in numbers yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Hotel in response to a general call sent out by the Senator. Followers of Gov. Odell were not so much in evidence, and the Governor conferred with the entire Platt camp alone.

PARIS, March 20. -- The Russian Embassy has received from St. Petersburg and has handed to Foreign Minister Delcasse for transmission to the French Minister at Tokio, who is intrusted with the protection of Russian interests in Japan, a protest against an alleged infraction of the laws of war.

TACOMA, Wash., March 20. -- Indians arriving to-day at Hoquiam on Gray's Harbor bring news of strange happenings along the shore of the Pacific Ocean north of Quinault Indian reservation from earthquake. They declare that last Wednesday night's shocks threw several rivers out of their channels, forming several large lakes on the adjacent lowlands.

From the United States census taken in 1900 we learn that there were then living in this Republic 424,372 native-born Russians, 154,424 Russian Poles, and 63,440 Russian Finns, or a total from Russia of 642,236. There were also 685,360 born of Russian parents and 400,000 in round numbers born of Polish parents from Russian Poland, or a grand total of 1,727,596 of Russian descent direct.

Gov. Odell has done more real good for the people of this State than any one since the days of De Witt Clinton. The discovery of America by Christopher Columbus and the discovery of Odell by Mr. Platt are great events of history. But who discovered Mr. Platt on the tail of a United States Express wagon and made him Senator?

BOSTON, Mass., March 21. -- An earthquake this morning caused a tremor throughout the entire eastern section of New England. Beginning at St. John, N.B., the seismic vibrations traversed the State of Maine, causing some slight damage to buildings in Augusta, Bangor, and Portland.

Charles L. Eidlitz, President of the Building Trades Employers' Association, denied yesterday that there was a tendency among the individual members of the association to break away on account of the strike of the bricklayers and laborers, and start up work for fear the building season would be lost.

Detectives Fry, Kuhn, and Donahue of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station yesterday made a raid on what they say was a woman's poolroom in West Thirty-ninth Street. When the police forced an entrance every woman in the place made a wild dash for the rear door or windows, and about fifteen of them succeeded in escaping.

Permit me through the columns of THE TIMES to call to the immediate attention of your readers the provisions of the so-called "Niagara bill." By its provisions the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Company is given the power to acquire land in any part of the State for its purposes without just compensation to the people of this State. Not only this, but such power is given them in perpetuity.

Paul Schwandtner of 243 East Seventy-ninth Street, contractor for the skeleton of the collapsed Darlington Hotel, told his story for the first time yesterday at the inquest commenced a week ago by Coroner Scholer and a jury of building experts. The sessions have been transferred from the West Side Court to the Coroners' Court in the Criminal Courts Building.

BALTIMORE, March 21. -- As a consequence of the financial troubles of the City Trust and Banking Company of Baltimore, the Miners and Merchants' Savings Bank of Lonaconing, Md., closed its doors to-day. The bank was an offspring of the City Trust.

ALBANY, March 21. -- The Anti-Gambling bill advocated by District Attorney Jerome will be a special order in the Senate tomorrow morning. Action leading to this result was taken at to-night's session of the Senate immediately after Senator Elsberg had reported the bill from the Codes Committee, but it was not taken until the opponents of the measure had put up a fight.
LONDON, March 21. -- Money was in active demand in the market to-day, owing to the Irish land loan. The applications will probably result in increased scarcity for a few days.

More than twenty years ago Richard Strauss's symphony in F, the work of an unknown young German composer, was first brought before the world by a performance in this city. Last night the latest composition of Dr. Richard Strauss, the foremost man of the day in music, his "Symphonia Domestica," was also given its first public performance here.
When Detectives Gallagher and Deevy arraigned two tramps in the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning, the policemen disclosed a story that set even Magistrate Whitman laughing.

There is no disguising the fact that Democratic interest is daily turning more and more to the Sage of Princeton. For our part, we have little doubt that Mr. Cleveland would bring out a tremendous vote should the convention forget 1896 and 1900. Whether the convention will forget is a very different matter. -- Washington Post, (Ind.)

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 21. -- The New York National League team had two hours of what Manager McGraw considered the most profitable kind of Spring training practice in to-day's exhibition game with the local Southern League nine. At the close the New Yorks were victors by a score of 9 to 3.

Legal technicalities are the only things that stand in the way of a complete settlement with the creditors of Daniel J. Sully Co., the cotton brokers, according to a statement made last night by Mr. Sully. He said:

PHILADELPHIA, March 21. -- Frederick Zerega Co., cotton merchants of Liverpool, who trade through George H. McFadden Brother, this city, have obtained a foreign attachment against Daniel J. Sully Co. The purpose of the attachment is to restrain McFadden Brother from turning over any balance they might have due Sully Co.

Transactions yesterday reached a larger volume than any shown during the present movement, but the bulls were somewhat disappointed in the action of the market. Early in the day dealings showed decided strength, and there was considerable talk of the part which the public was beginning to take in the trading.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 21. -- It is announced that a conference will be held in the City of Mexico this week between James Speyer of Speyer Co. of New York, W.G. Raoul, President of the National Railroad of Mexico; J.G. Metcalf, President of the Mexico International Railroad; James Stewart Mackie, Vice President of the latter road, and the chief officials of the Mexico Inter-Oceanic and National Tehuanteper Roads.

I do not know whether the gas companies of New York and Brooklyn are consolidated or not, but from the fact that our elder brother is a bit grasping, and his knowing full well the virtue of gas, we must believe he has his talon on the inflated balloon of this poor country lad, Brooklyn, or else this same lad is imitative, for his methods are identical with those mentioned in THE TIMES this morning.

United States Commissioner Shields went to Atlantic City on Sunday, and yesterday his son, John A. Shields, Jr., and Clerk Donovan spread a big black cloth over the flat-topped desk used by the Commissioner to keep the dust from the many legal papers piled there. The cloth was new, and was of a dull finished goods, instead of the usual black muslin used for such purposes.

The last of the ante-season handicap weights were given out by Handicapper Vosburgh yesterday when he announced the imposts in the Excelsior Handicap of the Metropolitan Jockey Club. This stake is at one mile and a sixteenth, with $5,000 added money, and is to be run at Jamaica on April 25.

Yesterday's stock market illustrates once more how narrow and technical it is. Bad news does not depress the hardened professionals who allow prices to run off as far as suits them and no further, and good news does not entice any but the most limited buying by those outside the initiated few.

Three flat cars, heavily laden, broke from the rear of a work train which was being hauled up the incline in the New York Central Railroad yard, at Forty-sixth Street, late yesterday afternoon. Gathering speed every foot of the journey, they tore through the "fetch up" at Forty-fifth Street, hurdled an embankment, smashed a great hole in the high fence which shuts off the yard, and crashed into a house across the street.

In our issue of Saturday we printed a statement from a representative member of the Bricklayers' Union giving in temperate language and very clearly the facts of the situation as they appear to the striking bricklayers. Elsewhere in this issue we print an instructive letter from Mr. THOMAS O'REILLY of Norcross Brothers Company, challenging the correctness of the statements referred to and putting the action of the employers in quite a different light.

I have been for many years and am now a constant reader of your valuable paper, and I was very much surprised to find a leading article in your issue of this morning on the bricklayers' strike at the present time, which in small type gave the public what purported to be a correct statement of the matter from a prominent official of the Bricklayers' Union; following this a very lengthy comment as an editorial.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 21. -- Official advices report the concentration of armed Mongolians disguised as pilgrims at Van Kuren, south of Lake Baikal and a few miles from the Russian frontier.
Laurus Loomis of Catlin Co. returned yesterday from a trip to the Southern cotton mills, whose selling agent in New York he is, and will be at his office to-day.

BOSTON, March 21. -- H.H. Rogers of the Standard Oil Company was again a witness to-day in the suit brought to invalidate the consolidation of the Boston gas companies. In the course of his testimony Mr. Rogers gave some interesting testimony with reference to his relations with Thomas W. Lawson, J. Edward Addicks, and the organization of the Bay State Gas Company.

Referring to your editorial of yesterday as to the best policy for insurance companies to adopt to diminish the disastrous number of fires, permit me to suggest that one of the best methods to apply would be the gradual reduction of the standard of indoor artificial heat in Winter. By far the greatest number of fires occur in the Winter months, and this fact shows that our heating arrangements are responsible for them.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 21. -- A telegram has been received from Medical Officer Trepoff, at Chita, Eastern Siberia, saying:

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at dinner this evening, when their guests were Mr. Justice Day, the Secretary of the Interior and Mrs. Hitchcock, Senator and Mrs. Aldrich, Senator and Mrs. Foraker, Lieut. Gen. and Mrs. Chaffee, Mrs. Leonard Wood, Commander Takeshita, the Rev. Dr. Peabody, Mrs. Peabody, the Rev. Roland Cotton Smith, Mrs. Smith, and Mrs. Tuckermann.

William J. Bryan is not always right, but he never said a truer thing than that Mr. Cleveland could not carry a single State if renominated for the Presidency. Mr. Cleveland may be and doubtless is quite acceptable to Wall Street, but what is specially good for Wall Street is not necessarily the best thing for the industrial interests of this great country.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- The House Committee on the Judiciary to-day voted to impeach Judge Charles Swayne, Federal Judge for the District of Florida. The committee reached this conclusion at a session lasting from 2 until 6 o'clock. The vote and the details of the charges which will form the ground of the impeachment the committee agreed to withhold until the report on the case has been completed for presentation to the House.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 21. -- Abner W. Colgate was one of the wealthy residents of this city. His home was one of the finest on Madison Avenue, the fashionable thoroughfare. He is a member of the Colgate family of New York, Robert Colgate of that city being his brother.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, March 21. -- The American Line steamship New York, Capt. Young, from New York March 12 for Plymouth, Cherbourg, and Southampton, which grounded yesterday off Cape La Hague, near Cherbourg, France, and afterward collided in these waters with the British troopship Assaye, will go into dry-dock at midnight.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, March 21. -- A called meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company here to-day was attended by Vice President Henry Mather, Secretary-Treasurer George H. Crosby, and Assistant General Counsel Robert Walker.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 21. -- Commodore Morton F. Plant, owner of the schooner yacht Ingomar, who has been in this city inspecting the work on his new estate at Eastern Point, announced that the date of sailing of the Ingomar for Europe to contest in ocean races had been fixed for April 15.

Even in this country of self-made men, of great business houses, and of great fortunes, the career of ex-Mayor WILLIAM R. GRACE was a conspicuous one. It is only through the possession of inborn qualities that men rise as he rose, from the position of a lad destitute alike of fortune and of powerful friends to become the organizer and head of a great mercantile house.

The new building of the Young Men's Christian Association, on West Twenty-third Street, near Seventh Avenue, was impressively dedicated last evening. A large audience, about equally divided between women and men, was present, among them being Cleveland H. Dodge, the Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler, the Rev. Dr. Donald Sage Mackay, Miss Helen Gould, Major E.W. Halford, United States Army, and the Rev. Dr. John Lloyd Lee.

There is a bill before the present Legislature which makes it the duty of the Superintendent of State Prisons to return the photographs and measurements of any person taken while such person was confined in a jail, penitentiary, or State prison, where the judgment of conviction of such person has been reversed and set aside and the person has been acquitted of the charge.

No new propositions were made by the bricklayers to the Mason Builders' Association yesterday, and unless by to-morrow night there is a change in the situation the Board of Governors of the Building Trades Employers' Association will be called on to act under the arbitration agreement. President Otto M. Eidlitz of the Mason Builders' Association said yesterday:

LOWELL, Mass., March 21. -- Superintendent William B. Moffett of the Police Department, with a squad of a dozen officers, is scouring the woods in the vicinity of East Billerica, four miles from this city, in search of a Deputy Sheriff from New Jersey and Edward Sanborn, who is wanted by the authorities of Mount Holly, N.J., on a charge of incendiarism.

Ex-Secretary of War Elihu Root appeared before Justice Truax in Special Term, Part III., of the Supreme Court, yesterday and argued against the effort of the West Side Electric Company to obtain permission for an extension of its lines in ducts controlled by the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company. William D. Guthrie appeared as counsel for the West Side Company.

PARIS, March 21. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch says that Admiral Avellan, Russian Minister of Marine, in an interview expressed great admiration for the prodigious rapidity with which the Japanese had constructed a navy, and praised their spirit, enterprise, and progress.

ALBANY, March 21. -- It is learned here to-night on excellent authority that Senator Platt and William Barnes, Jr., with the sanction of the President, as it is understood, had, before Sunday's "harmony" conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, arranged a very spectacular programme to end the sway of Odell over the organization.

By a unanimous vote the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, at the regular March meeting held last evening, at the Arena, 46 West Thirty-first Street, decided to adopt the principle of measurement embodied in the New York Yacht Club rule. The representatives were practically of one mind in the matter, as there was very little discussion of the recommendation made by the Executive Committee.

If an earthquake came to New York the huge steel structures like the Flatiron Building and the Park Row Building would be the least to suffer, while the cheaper buildings, such as apartment and tenement houses, would in all probability receive the most damage, according to Prof. James Furman Kemp, head of the Department of Geology in Columbia University, in a statement made by him yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Senor de Aspiroz, the Mexican Ambassador, is to be recalled, probably in June. It is understood that it is the purpose of the Diaz Government to appoint him Minister for Foreign Affairs.

A well-known lady of Carthage, Mo., says: "Although I do not drink tea or coffee myself I have had a most interesting experience in my family, for about a year ago my husband began to fail in health. He would get so very nervous at times he would have to give up his work and come home.

LONDON, March 21. -- Premier Balfour's Government won a decisive victory in both the House of Lords and the House of Commons to-night. In the Commons Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman's motion censuring the Government for the introduction of Chinese labor in the Transvaal was lost by a vote of 299 to 242, a Government majority of 57, while in the House of Lords a similar motion by Lord Coleridge was voted down by 97 to 25.

An exodus of non-union labor to the Louisiana Purchase Exposition is planned by an agency in the offices of the St. Louis Reliance Company, at 61 Park Row, with branches in Boston, Chicago, Indianapolis, Milwaukee, and St. Louis.

It was learned yesterday that Gen. Sharretts of the Board of General Appraisers will render his decision soon on the protest of T. Jefferson Coolidge of Boston against the assessment of 60 per cent. duty on a lot of thirty pearls of various sizes, which he brought over from Germany about two months ago.

-- Whatever may be the lessons which the naval experts are learning from the progress of events in the war between Japan and Russia, the civilian observer is most likely to be impressed by the fact that a very large part of the effective work seems to be done by the torpedo boats and the so-called torpedo-boat destroyers.

CHICAGO, March 21. -- Weber and Fields are to separate. The reason is the engagement of Louis Mann, at a very high figure, and an iron-clad contract. Fields is to take out a company of his own next season and Weber will open a music hall in Chicago. The partners keep up a semblance of friendship, but the Mann contract has split them and each blames the other.
LONDON, March 22. -- A number of rumors are printed in the newspapers here this morning, but they must be accepted with great reserve.
The purchase of the North River Insurance Company's property at 84 William Street by the Queen Insurance Company is detailed in another column.

Max Cohen, fifteen years old, of 909 Sixth Avenue, was shot in the back and slightly wounded yesterday morning by Patrolman Finley of the West Forty-seventh Street Station while trying, with three other boys, to escape from the house at 233 West Fifty-first Street. David Cohen, eighteen years old, his brother, and Robert McKinley, seventeen years old, of 796 Sixth Avenue, were arrested with him.

Into the Tenderloin police station last night was ushered a small boy clad in an ancient gray tweed suit two sizes too large, a red shirt, a pair of battered shoes, and a skull cap through the top of which flaxen hair sprouted. He described himself to the police as Willie Butler, thirteen years old, (although he could not have been more than ten,) an orphan, and homeless.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 21. -- President Eliot of Harvard was cheered by an excited multitude of more than 2,000 graduates and undergraduates at a mass meeting in the Harvard Union this afternoon in honor of the seventieth birthday of the university's executive head.

How may poverty-stricken and helpless women, widowed mothers with little children, wives of sick husbands, old, broken-down grandmothers be saved from begging on the streets or from being sent to the almshouse on the Island?
ST. PETERSBURG, March 21. -- A Russian officer who commanded a battery on Electric Hill during a bombardment of Port Arthur has written the following vivid account:

Some comparative figures as to the financial operations of the United States Steel Corporation and the Government of the United States were given in THE TIMES of Sunday. They are striking enough in their showing of the extraordinary scope of the latest and largest combination of capital in American industry to justify again calling attention to them.

BOSTON, March 22. -- Interesting details concerning the manner in which the arrangement was made with Thomas W. Lawson by which he was to keep his hands off the gas reorganization undertaken by Kidder, Peabody Co. were brought out to-day in the Supreme Court.

LOWELL, Mass., March 22. -- Edgar Sanborn, who was admitted to Harvard fourteen years ago but who was too poor to go, went insane from overstudy on a farm a few years later, and turned burglar after escaping from the State Asylum in Worcester, was taken by the police in the village of East Billerica this morning after he had escaped from a Deputy Sheriff.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The McCall committee to-day continued its investigation of the "indictment" of members of the House by the Post Office Department. First Assistant Postmaster General Wynne, Charles N. Waters, who succeeded Mr. Beavers as Superintendent of Salaries and Allowance Division, and Charles P. Cranfield, Assistant Superintendent of that division, were before the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Col. Thomas W. Symons, Superintendent of Public Buildings and Grounds, said to-night that he will decline a compromise reached by the House Committee on Military Affairs granting him permission to become a member for one year of the New York Canal Commission which is to enlarge the Erie Canal, but with loss of his army pay.

NEWPORT, March 22. -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt is increasing his holding of farm lands near Newport, and will soon be the largest owner of real estate on the island. He has just purchased the Slocum farm, containing forty-five acres, directly opposite Oakland. It extends more than half a mile on Sandy Point Road, running to the easterly boundary of the farm of Reginald G. Vanderbilt.

Mrs. Mary Schuitze and George Borchardt were found dead yesterday at 10:30 A.M. in a squalid room in the rear of a lock-smith's shop kept by Borchardt at 635 Newark Avenue, Jersey City. The woman had been shot in the left temple, and also through the head near the nose. The man was shot in the right temple.

If this should meet the eye of Mrs. William Smith, late of Asbury Park and now of No. 45 -- Street, Brooklyn, will she be good enough to come over to Park Row and take her husband home, and, incidentally, fill in the name of that blank street in Brooklyn which he has forgotten?

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Capt. Royal Bird Bradford, commanding the battleship Illinois, is warmly commended in the findings of the court of inquiry which investigated the collision of the Missouri and Illinois off Guantanamo, for his fine seamanship, which, the report says, saved the Illinois from what would almost inevitably have proved her total destruction had it not been for the excellent judgment shown by her Captain at several critical moments.

District Attorney Jerome is pushing certain amendments to the commercial laws of the State which have been prepared by James, Schell Elkus, counsel for the Merchants' Protective Association, at the request of that organization. The amendments are designed to facilitate prosecution of dishonest debtors who dispose of their stocks in bulk, conceal their assets, or make away with their books on the eve of failure.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 22. -- The Emperor has received the following telegram from Viceroy Alexieff, telling of a renewed attack on Port Arthur:

Senator Depew presided last night at the eighth annual banquet of the Transportation Club, held in its quarters on the thirteenth floor of the Hotel Manhattan. The Senator availed himself of his opportunity to make a speech before introducing the other speakers, with the result that the evening devoted to the praise of the automobile as a means of transportation was rather a long but pleasant journey through the pleasant fields of oratory.

ALBANY, March 22. -- The Elsberg bill, abolishing the office of Coroner in New York City, had a public hearing in the Assembly Cities Committee to-day, as also did the bill of Mr. McManus reducing the number of Coroners to one in each borough.

New York had two Mayors yesterday, and City Hall was much astonished and puzzled thereat. The question was also opened as to the validity of certain city bonds signed by Mr. Fornes as Acting Mayor, while Mayor McClellan had, by the signing of official papers under the same date, proclaimed himself the chief civic dignitary of the city.

DETROIT, Mich., March 22. -- Assistant Prosecuting Attorney Wurzer to-day finished his opening argument in the trial of Edward E. Farley, the horseman, on the charge of "ringing" the mare Aimless as Sarah Black at the Grosse Point running meeting June 16 last.

WASHINGTON, March 21. -- Representative Bede of Minnesota delivered an address last night at a Congregational Church celebration at which "The Home" was the topic for discussion. In illustration of the value of the home life Mr. Bede said:

ATLANTA, Ga., March 22. -- M.S. McDonough of Chicago, Southern representative for the American Hotel Supply Company, was arrested this afternoon for being drunk and disorderly. It is alleged that he beat his wife in a carriage while driving along Peachtree Street, Atlanta's fashionable thoroughfare.

At 12:20 o'clock this morning the Coroners' jury in the case of the Hotel Darlington collapse found that Eugene C. Allison and the contracting firm of Pole Schwandtner were grossly and criminally negligent.

Charles E. Ackron, who has been experiencing a run of troubles since he gave up the "Tivoli" resort in the Tenderloin and opened a road house and casino in East New York, was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn on complaint of Frederick Brandt of 209 West Broadway, Manhattan.

In discussing the New Jersey Child Labor bill in to-day's issue you make reference to a well-known fact that there are "manufacturers of one sort and another who are eager to get as many and as small children at work for as many hours a day and for as small wages as they can."

ALBANY, March 22. -- Frank M. Baker's nomination as Railroad Commissioner to succeed himself was sent to the Senate today by Gov. Odell. Senator Grady asked that the nomination be referred to the Committee on Railroads and that an opinion be requested from the Attorney General as to whether the rejection by the Senate of Mr. Baker's nomination last year did not preclude the Governor from again sending in Mr. Baker's name.
President MELLEN of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad takes a rather gloomy view of the general business situation in New England, and says:

ALBANY, N.Y., March 22. -- The Hill Automobile bill is in such shape that it will probably pass the Legislature. What is expected to be a final draft of the measure was agreed upon to-night by Senator Allds, representing the sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Roads and Bridges, on the one side, and representatives of automobile clubs and of manufacturers on the other.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 22. -- Harry Le Moyne, Harvard's famous freshman athlete, will not be allowed to compete in the intercollegiate championship track games at Philadelphia this year because he unwittingly broke the intercollegiate rules while a student in Stone's School, Boston, last Winter, by participating in an open athletic meet in the Cambridgeport Young Men's Christian Association gymnasium.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 22. -- The feud which has existed for a long time past between "Jeffries" and "Corbett" is likely to end in the death of one or the other of them or of their owner, Robert Tweedy. "Jeffries" is an Indian game cock, vicious and wicked, while "Corbett" is a brindle bull terrier.

DALLAS, Texas, March 22. -- The Republican State Convention to-day indorsed President Roosevelt and selected Cecil A. Lyon and R.B. Hawley, white, and Charles M. Ferguson and M.M. Rogers, colored, as delegates-at-large to the National Convention.

The long-expected statement regarding the future of the Northern Securities Company was finally made public late yesterday afternoon. It is in the shape of a circular to stockholders, and is signed by James J. Hill as President, and Edward T. Nichols as Secretary.

TRENTON, N.J., March 22. -- A visit paid by ex-United States Senator James Smith to the Legislature at its reconvening for the last week of the session last night has revived the story that he is planning to make ex-President Grover Cleveland the Democratic candidate for Governor at the approaching State Convention.
ALBANY, March 22. -- Four Assembly District Conventions held to-day elected twelve delegates to the Democratic State Convention, all pledged to Parker. The delegates elected were:

CHICAGO, March 22. -- The features of the fiftieth convocation of the University of Chicago to-day were a letter from President Roosevelt, a message from Emperor William of Germany, and the conferring of the degree of Doctor of Laws upon the German Ambassador to the United States, Baron Speck von Sternburg, Ambassador Tower, and upon five professors of German universities.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 22. -- Owing to the very severe Winter many colonies of bees have been exterminated, with the result that honey will be scarce and high this Summer. Willis Andrew, who lives at Leamington, thought he would take a look at the colonies on Monday, and out of the twenty-four hives he found but five living bees.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- President Roosevelt sent to the Panama Canal Commission to-day a letter in the nature of instructions that is regarded as an extraordinary document and in many particulars without precedent.

Gov. ODELL has kept his promise to the ear of Mr. PLATT by reappointing FRANK M. BAKER as a State Railroad Commissioner, but he has altogether broken it to the hope of Mr. PLATT by causing to be introduced by the hand of Assemblyman BEDELL a bill increasing the number of Railroad Commissioners from three to five, which would give him the control of the board.

CHICAGO, March 22. -- To search for the scarlet fever germ in a series of experiments on apes is the object of a trip to Europe about to be undertaken by Dr. Ludwig Hektoen, head of the McCormick Memorial Institute for Infectious Diseases. The institute was endowed by Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. McCormick, who lost a son through scarlet fever.

Not a single local union last evening had called off the strike of the bricklayers, which has tied up work throughout the city, and to all appearances yesterday it was likely to continue until the first open rupture in twenty years between the Mason Builders' Association and the bricklayers takes place.

Owing to the overwhelming importance of the trading in Union Pacific and other issues concerned in the movement in that stock, relatively little attention was given yesterday to the general list. Outside of the very active railroad properties, the transactions were relatively small, many of the issues appearing in the list of sales showing totals of less than a thousand shares.

When Daniel J. Sully stepped out of his office yesterday afternoon, leaving receivers in possession of all his property, his light jolly manner had disappeared and had given way to a feeling of bitterness, anger, and disappointment. The knowledge that those who had benefited from his advice had betrayed him he had been able to bear, but the belief that some of his friends had proved treacherous was too much for him.

Ethel Barrymore is coming back to the Hudson Theatre in "Cousin Kate" a week from next Monday. This is Miss Barrymore's third engagement in New York in this play of Hubert Henry Davies. It will last only two weeks, after which she will sail for London to make her appearance at the Duke of York Theatre.

Charles B. Van Valen has sold for J.V. and H.V.D. Black to the North River Insurance Company, 93, 95, and 97 William Street, a nine-story building, on plot 61 by 85. The buyers will make extensive alterations to the structure, and will ultimately occupy a considerable portion of it. This company sold its building at 84 William Street to the Queen Insurance Company a few days ago.

Worn and ill from anxiety for her husband, whom she believes to have been shanghaied a few hours before he was to sail for Honolulu as Chief Engineer on the American Line steamship California, from South Brooklyn, Mrs. Henry Shearer of 1,112 East One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street again appeared at the Morrisania station last night to ask whether there was any news from him.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- The House to-day added two amendments to the Post Office bill which are regarded as clearing the way for new Post Offices in New York City. One, offered by Mr. Moon of Tennessee, reduces the term of the lease with the New York Central from fifty to twenty-five years. The other, offered by Mr. Douglas of New York, authorized the Postmaster General to lease the Pennsylvania site.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 22. -- The New York American League baseball team defeated the Atlanta Southern League nine this afternoon by a score of 3 to 0. The game was the fastest played this season. It abounded in snappy plays, which delighted the large crowd of spectators. The work of Pitcher Griffith for the Americans was easily the feature.

The necessity of improving the Raymond Street Jail, in Brooklyn, was brought before the Board of Aldermen yesterday, when that body was asked to approve a resolution apropriating $20,000 for the jail improvements.

The remarkable rise in the Stock Exchange prices yesterday of Great Northern, Union Pacific, and Southern Pacific, and in the price of Northern Securities in the curb market, might lead to the inference that restraint of trade thrives on adverse decisions and prohibitory decrees of the courts.

BERLIN, March 22. -- A missionary in Southwest Africa has written to the Reichsbote defending the Hereros against the charges of massacring women, children, and men. Native Christians, the missionary adds, assisted a number of women and children to reach the military stations safely.

Both within and beyond the British Empire the decision of the British Government to authorize the importation of contract labor will be held to denote that the mysterious influence of "the Chartered Company" is as great now as it was when the trial of "Dr. JIM" became the rendezvous of fashionable London.

SEOUL, March 22. -- An interesting feature of the situation in Korea is the vigor with which the Japanese are working on the railway designed to join Soul and Wi-ju. The immediate object is the construction of a light military railway as far as Ping-Yang, which subsequently will be made permanent and extended to Wi-ju.

KANSAS CITY, March 22. -- Missouri Republicans, in State Convention here to-day, named delegates-at-large to the National Convention at Chicago and instructed them to vote for Theodore Roosevelt for President and Cyrus P. Wallbridge of St. Louis for Vice President.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22. -- To save the life of Benjamin Johnson, a barber who was shot last week in a quarrel, Dr. Stephen W. Stafford of the Charity Hospital removed a part of Johnson's spinal cord, performing the delicate operation after observation by the X-Rays.

The Trustees of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine adopted a new charter yesterday at the regular monthly meeting held in Mendelssohn Hall, in West Forty-fourth Street. It will become operative Dec. 27, St. John's Day. Meantime the present board will hold over.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 22. -- A bill for divorce which will cause a widespread sensation was filed here this afternoon by Mrs. Alice Fitts Hill Taylor against Robert L. Taylor, who has three times served Tennessee as Governor, and is now regarded as being sure to go to the United States Senate.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 22. -- A dispatch received from Ashkabad (the capital of the Russian Trans-Caspian territory,) says a rumor is current there that the Ameer of Afghanistan has been poisoned.

Prosperity is a hindrance to changes in National politics. There is a well-known and striking coincidence in the disappearance of mortgages in Nebraska and Kansas and that of Mr. BRYAN as a Presidential candidate. The price of the Southern staple, cotton, though not so intimately and obviously connected with the operation of the voters' minds -- which are influenced in that section by some other and powerful factors -- is still of considerable importance.

Booker T. Washington, President of the Tuskagee Normal and Industrial Institute at Tuskagee, Ala., addressed the Methodist Social Union of New York City last night at its meeting in the Hotel Savoy on "The Success of Negro Education." J. Edgar Leaycraft, President of the union, acted as Chairman.

PITTSBURG, March 22. -- The statement made last night by Walter Damrosch, that he had an offer of $15,000 a year from the Pittsburg Orchestra, has displeased the Or chestra Committee of the Art Society thoroughly. A long meeting was held this afternoon, which resulted in a statement being prepared for the papers.

Patrick H. Cunningham, known among his friends as "Harry," who lives at the Morton House, is missing. Several persons want to find him. The last heard of him he was in a lachrymose state, beseeching every one he met to find a policeman whom he had lost. The fact that the policeman had him under arrest did not make Cunningham any less sorry that he had lost him.
NEW ORLEANS, La., March 22. -- Baxter Martin, a young married white man of Augusta, Ga., compelled a negro to shoot him twelve miles from Berwick City, La., yesterday, to escape lynching.

ALBANY, March 22. -- District Attorney Jerome called on Supreme Court Justice Herrick to-day and, it is understood, asked him whether he would preside over a special Grand Jury called to consider the Shipbuilding Trust case. Mr. Jerome would neither admit nor deny that such was the purpose of his call, and Justice Herrick refused to discuss the matter.

Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers, whose recent controversy with President Roosevelt on the negro question attracted National attention, issued a statement yesterday attacking Secretary Shaw for his attitude toward the Board of Appraisers and calling upon the Finance or Judiciary Committee of the Senate to make a thorough investigation of the whole subject.

BALTIMORE, March 22. -- The earthquake that shook New England early Monday morning was separate and distinct from the one that affected Baltimore. Dr. H.F. Reid to-day developed the film of the seismograph at Johns Hopkins University and found a record of a ten-minute shock that started in this vicinity at 2:30 Monday morning.

John Pope Hodnett, for years a familiar character to lawyers, politicians, and public men generally in Brooklyn, was taken yesterday afternoon to the Kings County Hospital for observation as to his mental condition. Hodnett appeared in the Adams Street Police Station and excitedly informed Capt. Harkins that a woman had tried to poison him.

There was an abrupt ending yesterday afternoon, in Trial Term, Part III., of the Supreme Court, of the suit which Samuel McFadden of Rutherford, N.J., brought against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to recover $50,000 for alleged personal injuries. His action was non-suited, and Justice Bischoff directed that the plaintiff be arrested and indicted on a charge of perjury, in pursuance of what appears to have been a conspiracy to defraud.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 22. -- The following dispatch has been received from Viceroy Alexieff, dated Mukden, March 22:

Paul Schwandtner of Pole Schwandtner was arraigned before Coroner Scholer yesterday on a warrant issued after the jury at the inquest into the Darlington Hotel disaster had brought in a verdict holding Schwandtner, his partner, and Eugene C. Allison of the Allison Realty Company responsible for the catastrophe. Schwandtner was committed to the Tombs in default of $5,000 bail on a charge of homicide.

No statement of the assets and liabilities of the failed Sully firm was obtainable yesterday. It is known that a rough statement was submitted to the creditors at the first meeting which estimated the liabilities at $3,500,000, but this estimate is considered very liberal. It is probable that the liabilities will not exceed $3,100,000, and may be as low as $2,500,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Ban B. Johnson, President of the American Baseball League, has sold the Washington Baseball Club to Thomas C. Noyes and William J. Dwyer, both of this city. Negotiations looking to this end have been in progress since last Fall. The new owners of the club have secured a lease of the grounds at Seventh Street and Florida Avenue, formerly occupied by the National League Club.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- To-day's local market was the most active of the year, the sales aggregating 49,143 shares and $137,080 bonds. It was the arbitrage stocks, however, which made this record possible, as they furnished 39,975 shares of the day's total, leaving only 9,168 shares as the total for the purely active stocks.
TOKIO, March 23. -- The special session of the Diet to-day entered upon the business for which it was called.

Following the rout of the bears in Union Pacific Tuesday, there was heavy short covering yesterday in a number of stocks in no way directly connected with the Northern Securities group. The transactions considerably exceeded in volume those of the previous day and were, in fact, larger than on any day since early in 1903.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Representative Weisse, the Democratic member from Wisconsin, is serving his first term in the House and has been congratulating himself that he had no record for getting salaries of Postmasters in his district increased or the rentals of Post Offices raised. To-day, however, the scent of scandal fastened itself on him with a vengeance.

LONDON, March 24. -- The Times publishes from a correspondent some observations on the Japanese campaign plans. The correspondent speaks of himself as one who had much experience of Japanese tactics in the war with China.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 23. -- In a speech which he delivered this evening before the Young Men's Republican Club, Leslie M. Shaw, Secretary of the Treasury, attacked the record of ex-President Cleveland on the subject of trusts.
The first authentic information of the death of Leonidas Hubbard, Jr., the magazine writer, who starved to death in the interior of Labrador in October last, was received in this city yesterday.

That the "yellow peril" was a mere myth, meaning one thing at St. Petersburg and another thing at Berlin, and that European aggression in Asia if not checked would bring about the most disastrous war among civilized powers that the world has ever known, were statements that stood out saliently in an address delivered before the Unitarian Club last night by Frederick W. Seward.
ALBANY, March 23. -- The lobby which is working for the East River Gas Company bill followed up its victory in the Assembly yesterday by a victory in the Senate today.

When the candidacy of Judge PARKER has been under discussion Democrats in other States and in this State have been heard to say that they knew very little about him. Was he a strong man? Was he able, safe, conservative, and the master of his own mind and acts? What were his views upon public questions? These are some of the questions that have been asked by Democrats.

Daniel B. Freedman has bought, through E.H. Ludlow Co., from the Cromwell estate, the old Carlton House property, now a vacant plot, at 200, 202, and 204 William Street, and 18 and 20 Frankfort Street, 79 by 57. The property adjoins the Brooklyn Bridge along its northerly side and faces the open space formed by the junction of William, North William, and Frankfort Streets.

ALBANY, March 23. -- Some excitement was caused among members of the Assembly during the morning session by the actions of a young woman who made the threat within the hearing of several that she intended to shoot on sight Victor Shanley, who has been in Albany recently acting as a lobbyist to promote legislation in which New York City employes under the civil service are interested.

Dr. George R. Parkin, the representative of the Trustees of the Cecil Rhodes Scholarships, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse to make arrangements for the holding of preliminary examinations in the United States and Canada. The examinations will be held simultaneously in this country and in the Dominion on April 13 at places selected by the various committees in charge in this country, composed of the Presidents of universities and colleges.

The following authoritative statement of the position and purposes of the Northern Securities Company and of those who have been chiefly concerned in its promotion has been supplied to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

In an opinion written by General Appraiser Lunt the Board of United States General Appraisers overruled a protest yesterday against the assessment of one-fourth of a cent a pound and 10 per cent. ad valorem on certain orris root "fingers" imported by McKesson Robbins of New York.
BOSTON, March 23. -- "It is probable that man gets nearer his lost paradise when he is dancing than at any other time."

In regard to the limitation of trade with the Philippines solely to American vessels, the policy suggested by Secretary TAFT in the hearings that have been held before him is wise and practical. It has already been agreed that the law making the inter-island trade coasting trade after July 1 cannot be applied because there is not American shipping enough to do the business and enough cannot possibly be supplied.

Gross earnings of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the year ended Dec. 31, 1903, were $16,545,632 and its net revenue $10,564,665, as compared with $7,835,272 for 1902. Dividends for the year amounted to $8,619,150, and there was carried to reserves $728,139 and to surplus $1,217,374.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 23. -- Plans for the annual rowing races between Yale and Harvard, to be held on the Thames River June 30, were arranged to-day by Julian W. Curtiss, graduate manager of the Yale Navy; F.T. Dodge and W.S. Cross, also of Yale, and R.F. Manning and H.G. Dillingham of Harvard.

Florian Tobias lost his first game last night in the 14.2 billiard tournament for the championship of the Amateur Billiard Club, West Seventy-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue. He was beaten in an ordinarily played game by Dr. A.B. Miller by 230 points to 191. Tobias had formerly held a clean record of five games won.

Senator McCarren has carried the war into his enemy's camp with an earnestness that has surprised staid old Brooklyn. He did a thing last night heretofore unheard of in the political history of Kings County. For the first time since the days of John Y. McKane's downfall a political meeting was held in Coney Island by the opponent of those who carry the vote of that resort in their vest pocket.

Mourners for William R. Grace crowded St. Francis Xavier's Church, in West Sixteenth Street, to the doors at the funeral services yesterday morning. A feature of the attendance was people in humble life who numbered three-fourths of those who were present. Half of them were women, many of them nuns of various orders.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 23. -- Even with McGinnity, the "Iron Man," pitching the New York National League team narrowly averted defeat at the hands of the Birmingham team this afternoon. Both teams were on their mettle, and the fielding was of a high order.

Thirteen of the eighteen charges preferred against Justice Herman Bolte of the Second District Municipal Court, in the application of District Attorney Jerome for his removal from office are sustained by Referee William H. Willis in the report which he submitted to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday.

Beyerlein's "Zapfenstreich," the latest anti-military sensation from Germany, was given for the first time here last night at the Irving Place Theatre. It was greeted with enthusiasm that reached great heights at the end of an almost perfect third act, which afforded Bonn and Christians an admirable opportunity for individual effects and gave scope besides to one of the most perfect pieces of ensemble acting ever seen at this home of well-rounded art.

All overtures of peace had been rejected by the bricklayers when the Board of Governors of the Building Trades Employers' Association met last night at the Townsend Building. The board has now decided to take up the fight, and it is admitted by the National Fireproofing Company that it will continue its efforts to wrest from the mason builders a share at least of the installation of the material it manufactures.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- With cloudy threatening weather to-night and a heavy, holding track at Bennings there is some fear that the opening day of the Washington Jockey Club meeting may lose some of its attractiveness. It can hardly lose interest, for the city is already full of racing folk from both East and West, and never before in this particular did a meeting hold out more promise.

TRENTON, N.J., March 28. -- The wildest sort of excitement was occasioned at this evening's session of the Legislature by a manifesto issued by Republican Mayor Mark M. Fagan of Jersey City to Gov.
