Among the varied phenomena of the recent money market there are two which furnish the basis for an interesting study of the relations of the conditions maintaining in New York during the year's round to those determined by the business of the country at large. These are:

Politics as practiced in the County of Westchester was the defendant before a tribunal of five which held the first of a series of sessions at White Plains yesterday. It was freely charged that money was used for political purposes more flagrantly than in any other county in the State.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The bill for the advancement of Brig. Gen. Sternberg, late Surgeon General of the Army, is not favored by the War Department.

Yale was defeated yesterday by the Fordham College baseball team by the score of 6 to 3 on the grounds of Fordham College. The local team and their adherents were wild with joy, for it is the first time that Yale has ever been beaten by Fordham. The ground was wet, and sawdust was sprinkled freely about the bases and the infield.

It was quite evident from the remark made by Dr. PARKIN the other day, after his return from touring the British dependencies in the interest of the Rhodes scholarships at Oxford, that he takes his stewardship very seriously. It was equally evident that ha expects great benefits to come from the establishment of the scholarships.

LONDON, March 26. -- While missionaries were petitioning President Roosevelt and Secretary Hay at Washington to intervene on behalf of the natives of the Congo Free State, Capt. Henri de Keyser, an ex-officer of the Congo State, was suing Capt. Guy Burrows in an English court for libel in connection with the alleged atrocities.

WHAT is said to be the largest elm in New England and one of the greatest trees east of the Rocky Mountains is in the historic little town of Wethersfield, famed for its onion gardens and its prison. The elm stands on the lower end of the old town square, opposite the Smith house, still occupied by descendants of John Smith, who planted the tree over 170 years ago.

Now that last week's tumult and shouting are over it is curious to look back and see how little there really has been to agitate anybody except the captains of finance. The entire range of average prices for this year, with all its exceptionally disturbing occurrences, has been for industrials 4 per cent., and for railways 8 per cent.

PRIZES of $25, $15, and $10 respectively are offered at the New York Botanical Garden for the best three essays on the most effectual means of preserving native plants from destruction at the hands of ruthless collectors who gather wild flowers with a reckless greed which threatens the total destruction of many of the most delicate or beautiful of the native plants.

JAMES E. HOOPER, formerly President of the Mount Vernon-Woodberry Cotton Duck Company, is going to return to the cotton mill business. It is understood that he will be independent of the United States Cotton Duck Company, which is the so-called Cotton Duck Trust.

NEWARK, N.J., March 26. -- Several young men were taken into full membership and four aged clergymen were placed on the supernumerary list at to-day's session of the Newark Methodist Conference. Local Deacons also were appointed.

THE blossoms of the sehubertia, a plant found in Central America, form the exact counterpart of the features of an old man. The illustration may be considered an imaginary sketch grossly exaggerated, but this is not so. Exaggeration is out of the question, and is altogether unnecessary and superfluous.

In defending himself from a crowd of men who were trying to take a prisoner away from him, at Tenth Avenue and Fiftieth Street just before midnight last night Policeman John Gilligan of the West Forty-seventh Street Station shot and possibly fatally injured James Melaney, of 534 West Fiftieth Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 26. -- Some excitement attended the election of delegates to the Democratic State Convention here to-day in both Assembly districts of Dutchess County. In both conventions resolutions were adopted instructing the delegates to vote for delegates to the National Convention pledged to the nomination of Judge Parker.

William Muirhead, said to be the manager of the Globe Security Company at 150 Nassau Street, was arrested yesterday by Detective Sergeants McConville and Clark, charged with usury. The warrant was issued by Justice Wyatt of the Court of Special Sessions. Justice Deuel held the prisoner in $1,000 bail for examination on next Tuesday. Cash bail was furnished.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Latest reports from the Adrirondack guides partially discredit the stories that large numbers of deer are dying in the North Woods. The guides say that the greater number of deer dying from starvation was in and through the country traversed by railroads.
THE effect of long on the actors engaged in a play is not infrequently a source of speculation on the part of people who go to the theatre.

From early in the afternoon yesterday there was an almost continuous stream of carriages up to the door of the Waldorf-Astoria, and almost every second vehicle contained all aristocratic dog, which was tenderly conveyed by the footman up to a bed of roses in the banquet hall, to be displayed at the first annual dog show of the Toy Spaniel Club.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 26. -- The whole city is talking about the recent midnight drive of the young Empress around the capital.

BOSTON, March 26. -- The corporation of Pettingill Co., conducting a newspaper advertising agency, announced to-day that it had placed its affairs in the hands of its creditors. Counsel for the company states that the liabilities may reach $1,000,000, with assets possibly one-quarter of that amount.

From time to time various charges have been preferred against our currency, either that there is too much of it or too little of it. (the latter complaint is the more frequent,) or that it lacks that somewhat vague but evidently most desirable quality of "elasticity." But now a new charge is made against it.

Mrs. Katharine Cheatham-Thompson (the Kitty Cheatham of Daly's some years ago) will give a recital of songs in French and English, mostly new, and some written for her, children's songs, and genuine darky melodies but slightly related to the ragtime songs of the music halls, at the Gerrit Smith Studio, 142 East Thirty-third Street, Tuesday afternoon, April 5. This will be Mrs. Cheatham-Thompson's first public recital in New York.
PHILADELPHIA, March 26. -- The long-rumored engagement of Miss Elsie Whelen and Robert Goelet was formally announced to-day by Miss Whelen's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Whelen of 1,709 Locust Street.

Two weeks from next Thursday the championship season of both the National and American Leagues will be under way, and all indications point to a brilliant and aggressive campaign. Nearly all the clubs are in better shape than ever before, so far as the complexion of teams is concerned, and it now depends upon the progress the players have made in the preliminary training as to the standing of their organizations at the finish.

WHAT was in many respects the most significant part of last week's business was that involving property beyond the Harlem River. Not only was there an increased amount of dealing in improved properties in the Bronx, but half a dozen large purchases of vacant land, in some instances by operators and in others by builders themselves, have gone far toward justifying predictions that the coming season will witness much new construction in the Twenty-third Ward.
RUTH ABBOTT WELLS is the highest paid child model in the United States, and probably in the world.

MISS ANNIE DE WOLF GIBSON, whose engagement to Alfred Hopkins of Washington was announced a short time ago, is the second sister of Charles Dana Gibson and lives in Flushing, L.I., where her mother, Mrs. Gibson, and her younger sister, Miss Josephine Gibson, make their home.
LONDON, March 26. -- Money was in strong quarter-end demand in the market to day.
COME, take a beer with me, old man," said Mr. Bain to his chum, waving his hand toward a saloon.

In your editorial on "Negroes and the Pullman Cars," in your issue of the 12th inst., despite your apparent fairness, I fear that you do not quite understand the situation in regard to the abominable "Jim Crow car" system and its attendant circumstances. In fact, the majority of writers and speakers on the negro problem are either woefully ignorant of the situation or else willfully pervert the truth.

Permit me to say a word in behalf of an excellent bill now pending in the State Legislature. I refer to the bill giving the Normal College a separate Board of Trustees. This bill was drawn by members of the alumnae who have been working to the past four years to create public sentiment in favor of this change.

THE boy's definition of the way to build a cannon -- "Take a hole and put some iron around" -- is not altogether unlike the methods used by the "interior decorator" who erects a mansion about his furniture. The building of a palatial residence from the inside out is becoming more and more general according to both the decorators who do this work and the architects who denounce it.
WHAT has taken the place of corporal punishment to punish disobedient children in the public schools of New York City?"

TO the down-town business woman the lunch question is one of serious importance. If she happens to have Delmonico tastes and a quick lunch pocketbook, she will usually compromise her inclinations with her income by bringing a sandwich or two from home, which she secretes somewhere about her person, and these, supplemented by a banana from an itinerant fruit vendor (and possibly a few caramels) constitute her mid-day meal.

PITTSBURG, March 26. -- At a meeting of the Orchestra Committee this afternoon Emil Paur of Vienna was elected conductor of the Pittsburg Orchestra. Mr. Paur has accepted the position by cable and the official announcement was made to-night by George H. Wilson, the manager, who said:

LONDON, March 26. -- Public interest continues keen in the extraordinary developments following the suicide of a man named George Crossman. On the night of March 23 Crossman killed himself to avoid arrest by the police, whose suspicions had been aroused regarding the contents of a trunk which the man was sending away from his house.

Three wills of Col. James Fairman, artist, art critic, musician, lecturer, and writer, have been filed for probate in the Surrogate's Court. One of them is offered by a woman who asserts that she is Col. Fairman's widow, but her claim to that title is disputed by the testator's children. Surrogate Thomas will appoint a trust company temporary administrator pending the settlement of the contest.

ST. LOUIS, March 26. -- The case of United States Senator Joseph R. Burton of Kansas, who has been on trial in the United States District Court here since Tuesday, on a charge of having illegally accepted fees from the Rialto Grain and Securities Company of St. Louis, was given to the jury to-night.

There will be a big split in the Intercollegiate Gymnastic Association if Columbia's team keeps its threat to leave the association unless the Executive Committee gives another hearing on the disqualification of two of the Blue and White's point winners in the championship meeting at New York University last Friday night.

Twenty firemen were incapacitated for duty by being caught in a sudden back draught laden with deadly gas fumes at a two-alarm fire which occurred at 2 o'clock yesterday morning in the five-story brick building at 205 Duane street. Nine of the firemen, who were seriously but it was thought not fatally affected, were removed to the Hudson Street Hospital.

WHO has it? If you possess a Columbian half dollar, if you have been carefully pocketing it as a souvenir and can look back over a trail of inconceivable hard luck, then rid yourself of the coin and witness your rise into a normal condition of life.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The Senate District Committee to-day gave a hearing on the subject of a proposed crosstown railway on M Street. Many of those who appeared protested vigorously against giving the trolleys any more streets.

FROM the ordinary walks of commercial life to theatrical management is a transition not often made with success, for if there is one business more than another that would seem to demand the special knowledge due to long experience it is that of exploiting stage people.

"Fruits of Industrial Training" was the subject of a lecture delivered yesterday by Dr. Booker T. Washington, under the auspices of the League for Political Education, at the People's Institute, on West Forty-fourth Street. Dr. Washington said, in part:

NEW BRUNSWICK, March 20. -- As a result of several tests made under the supervision of Prof. E.B. Voorhees of the Agricultural Experimental Station here, it has developed that H.D. Roe of Augusta, N.J., has a Holstein cow that now holds the world's record for producing milk. The record shows that in seven days the cow gave 620.95 pounds of milk and 26.87 pounds of butter fat, which produced 34.32 pounds of butter.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 26. -- The young ladies' cooking class, which has been meeting weekly for the past three months at the home of Mrs. Willis K. Howell on Elm Street, had its last meeting this week, and the work is over for the season. The class was organized to help the work of the Young Women's Christian Union at the Market Street Mission, and $75 was cleared for this work.
IN Revolutionary days the farmers and business men of the back country in Pennsylvania used the goosebone for their weather indications instead of the family almanac.

ALBANY, March 26. -- John McCullagh, sometime resident of Goshen, Orange County, ex-Chief of Police of New York, and ex-Superintendent of Elections, is understood to be the choice of Gov. Odell to succeed George Wilson Morgan, present Superintendent of the Bureau of Elections for the metropolitan district.
ST. PETTERSBURG, March 26. -- The Emperor has received the following telegram from Vice Admiral Makaroff, under date of Port Arthur, March 26:

LINCOLN, Neb., March 26. -- The friends of the University of Nebraska have raised the third of one hundred thousand dollars which John D. Rockefeller said must be a condition under which he would give the other two-thirds for a university temple.

Mr. Frank Damrosch brought his series of Young People's Symphony Concerts to a close yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with a programme illustrating modern opera. The series has had a historical purpose in view, which has afforded a glimpse into some of the principal periods of the development of music, from the early practice of the art in the middles ages down to the present time.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 26. -- Four miners were instantly killed to-day at the Dorrance Shaft, operated by the Lehigh Valley Coal Company. They fell to the bottom of the shaft and were instantly killed.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., March 26. -- After ten years, incessant labor Mrs. Lizzie Hoffman of Anthony has finished what is probably the oddest bedquilt in the country. It is a patch quilt made of 14,600 pieces of silk of all kinds and colors, and every piece of silk came from a different bride's hat.

Daniel J. Sully yesterday carried out his promise to give to his creditors a complete statement of his relations with Edwin Hawley and Frank H. Ray. He appeared before the creditors' committee at a meeting held in the offices of one member of the committee in the Cotton Exchange Building, and told them the history of his last disastrous pool.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., March 26. -- Railroad traffic through the Mohawk Valley was entirely suspended this evening because of washouts and high water at Fort Plain and Ilion, and the valley is threatened by one of the greatest floods in its history. It is necessary to send Central and West Shore trains from Oneida to Albany by way of the Ontario and Western to Sydney, and thence over the Delaware and Hudson tracks.

PARIS, March 26. -- The protest which the French Government submitted to the Vatican can against the recent utterances of the Pope regarding France was not in the form of an official note, but was verbal protest by M. Nisard, the Ambassador of France at the Vatican, to the Papal Secretary of State, Cardinal Merry del Val.

The trap shooting members of the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn wound up the season at the Bay Ridge grounds yesterday with a number of interesting competitions, at fifteen, twenty-five, and one hundred targets. The latter event was the last one on the programme, but after shooting at ninety targets the contestants were obliged to stop, the supply of "clays" being exhausted.

THE Ashantee baby rides astride his mother's hip secured by a bandage around him and her waist. Note how this one stares at the camera, Babies of uncivilized races are more attentive and inquisitive than ours. Their senses are naturally more acute and are further sharpened by their rough-and-tumble existence.

BERLIN, March 26. -- It is learned on excellent authority that as soon as the reinforcements arrive in German Southwest Africa Major von Glasenapp, who led the recent reckless attack on the Hereros, will be relieved of him command and court-martialed.

William Jennings Bryan made a hurried visit to New York yesterday on his way from Lincoln to New Haven. While in the city, however, Mr. Bryan took occasion to indulge in some decidedly antagonistic remarks to the candidacy of Judge Parker for the Presidency. He was seen late yesterday afternoon, just before he left the Victoria Hotel, where he was stopping, for New Haven.

Nothing in the administration of justice is more important than the character and qualifications of the Magistrates of limited and, either technically or practically, of summary jurisdiction. By the nature of their functions their decisions are rarely reviewable. Great learning in the law is not required of them.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- Secretary of War Taft was the guest of honor at a reception given this evening by Senator Foraker at his Sixteenth Street home, when about 400 guests enjoyed the hospitality of the Ohio Senator. The house was profusely decorated, American Beauty roses and delicate green follage being most in evidence.
WASHINGTON, March 26. -- This was a day of favorites at Benning, five of them passing under the wire first, while a second choice won the other event.

THE question of the protection of life and property from the fire fiend has given the city authorities more concern than any other problem since the days when Gov. Stuyvesant and his Municipal Council of Burgomasters and schepens framed an ordinance providing for 150 leathern fire buckets, and the formation of the "Rattle Watch" to protect the streets at night.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 26. -- The mobilization of the Manchurian army is now complete. Gen. Kuropatkin stopped at Harbin to visit the fortress there. He will reach Mukden to-morrow.

Three sledgehammer raids on poolrooms in the Tenderloin last evening was the reply of Police Commissioner McAdoo to the declaration of war on his "lid" policy by gamblers, poolroom keepers, and certain district leaders in Tammany Hall.

NEW ROCHELLE, March 26. -- Miss Elizabeth Emmet made her debut as a professional actress at the New Rochelle Opera House this evening, appearing in the support of Miss Clara Bloodgood, in Charles Frohman's production of Clyde Fitch's play, "The Girl with the Green Eyes." The house was crowded, and the entrance of Miss Emmet was the occasion of an outburst of hearty applause on the part of scores of her friends.

MANY women with a literary bent and a surplus of spare time are now discussing Shaw instead of Ibsen or Browning, and great are the conclusions at which some of them arrive. The "prefaces" are considered quite too cabalistic for anything, and occasionally Arnold Daly himself is called upon to decide the knottiest points.

By accepting the Chairmanship of the Republican State Committee while continuing to hold the office of Governor, BENJAMIN B. ODELL will make a considerable contribution to the defeat of President ROOSEVELT. Short of open treason to his party we do not know how he could make a larger contribution.

Policeman John Gilligan of the West Forty-seventh Street Station, who late Saturday night fought thirty men who attempted to wrest from him John Whiston, whom he had arrested for disorderly conduct, told a graphic story in the West Side Court yesterday morning of the fight and explained how it was that he had been compelled to fire into the crowd.
Richard Dickson has sold for John D. Creamer a lot at the southeast corner of One Hundred and Seventy-eighth Street and Clinton Avenue, 25 by 100.

A rampant trolley pole, which tore down a mass of power-carrying wires, caused a complete tie-up of trolley traffic on the Brooklyn Bridge for about three hours yesterday afternoon, resulting in a big jam of Sunday travelers in the Park Row terminal.

Miss Florence G. Maas, who lived with her mother, Mrs. Sarah H. Maas, at the Hotel Endicott, yesterday morning received injuries in an automobile accident in Central Park which resulted in her death. Solomon M. Stroock, a lawyer, of the firm of Platzek Stroock with an office at 320 Broadway, and who lives at 132 West Eighty-sixth Street, had his collarbone broken in the same accident.
Major Wheatley, erstwhile warrior, now married, but still well known along the Rialto, had a surprise in store for him on Broadway the other night.

George F. Slosson gave the most wonderful display of billiards in his long and eventful career at his academy, 948 Broadway, last evening, and incidentally broke the world's record, with a run of 291, at the style of playing. The ex-champion is rarely out of form, but last evening it seemed as though no shot was too difficult for him to execute.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 27. -- Eighteen well-known horses are carded to start in the Montgomery Handicap, the rich all- aged event, at one mile and a sixteenth, the opening day of the Memphis Jockey Club's Spring meeting to-morrow. Top weight is assigned to S.C. Hildreth's mare, Witfull, and she will probably be first choice in the betting, although the race is regarded as an open one.

This will be an important week in automobile circles. Of first importance will be the announcement of the entries for the service test of commercial vehicles which will be held next week under the auspices of the Automobile Club of America. Secretary S.M. Butler of the club hopes to have the entries classified so as to give them out to-day.

LONDON, March 28. -- The Times publishes an article in which the writer discusses the conditions in Russia with reference to the oft-repeated suggestion that an episode of the Far Eastern war may be a revolution in Russia and the overturning of the Government.
CARRUTHERSVILLE, Mo., March 27. -- A tornado swept the country, twenty miles north of here last night, causing a great loss of life and destroying thousands of dollars worth of property.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 27. -- A university student, on returning to his dormitory to-night, saw a figure which looked to him like that of a negro with his throat cut lying across the bed. The student rushed out to look for some one to tell about the apparent murder, and met Mr. Mershon, a university official, who returned to the scene.

Yachtsmen are now beginning to look forward with interest to the coming racing season. Last year was generally considered a dull season in yacht racing, but in so far as Long Island Sound is concerned, it was dull only in comparison with the two or three preceding seasons. The fleets in the open races of the principal clubs were fairly large.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Anti-Smooting, as the late Henry L. Merrick used to call it, has served one purpose besides holding Mormonism up by the scruff of the neck to the eyes of a surprised and not enthusiastic Nation. It has furnished Senator Hoar with his biennial place in the centre of the stage at the first session of a new Congress.
McKEESPORT, Penn., March 27. -- Alderman L.N. Morgan was asked last evening by Thomas R. Danforth, a McKeesport business man, to take an anti-poker pledge.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- William J. Bryan delivered an address this afternoon in the Hyperion Theatre on "The Prince of Peace." He inveighed against the present war between Japan and Russia, saying that he hoped there would be a general demand made to find out the cause of that warfare.

In the presence of several men of science, chroniclers of the news of the day and freaks, strength tests between men and various kinds of animals were held yesterday afternoon in the arena of Madison Square Garden, here Barnum Bailey's "Greatest Show on Earth" is entertaining the public.

We fully sympathize with the feeling expressed by the report made to the New York Board of Trade and Transportation from its Railway Committee on "the differentials against New York." We are not so sure as the committee is that the rights of New York in the premises can best be secured by absolute refusal of arbitration or its equivalent through the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

That we have never been able to find ourselves in agreement with the conclusions of the Chief Engineer of the Department of Water, Gas, and Electricity as to the proportion of the total per capita consumption to be charged to underground leakage is a fact we have stated with regret on more than one occasion when the subject was under discussion.

Chester Howard, nineteen years old, of 213 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, was found unconscious shortly after midnight this morning on the steps leading from Morningside Park to the Heights, near One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, with three bullet wounds in his body. Near him lay a revolver.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- A panic occurred at the morning service in St. Michael's Italian Church, in Wooster Street, to-day, at which a score of persons were injured. Four -- two women and two children -- were taken to the New Haven Hospital, but it is not believed that the injuries of any are fatal.

Michael Brusch, who shot and killed Policeman Hugh J. Enright of the East Fifty-first Street Station on the morning of Sunday, March 20, and seriously wounded Policeman Jacob Bachman of the same station while they were chasing him through East Fifty-fifth Street after he had attempted to commit a burglary at Scheel's bakery at 901 Third Avenue, talked freely of his case in Bellevue Hospital yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Domestic manufactures exported in February, 1904, were greater in value than in any preceding February, and formed also a larger per cent. of the total exports. For the eight months ended with February the total manufactures also exceeded the total in the corresponding eight months of any earlier year.

So many mistakes have appeared in many of the newspaper accounts of the primary contest between the Plaza Central Park Republican Club and the so-called "regular Republican organization" in the Twenty-ninth Assembly District that we respectfully request you to publish the following facts:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 27. -- Mrs. Fannie Watrous, who formerly lived here, but who had lately lived in Maine and New Hampshire, burned herself to a crisp to-day at the home of her mother-in-law, Mrs. Charlotte Watrous, 68 Clinton Avenue. She came here two days ago and had acted very queerly.

The conjecture that Judge PARKER is in some way subject to the influence and control of ex-Senator HILL lacks the basis of evidence. It is very generally believed that two years ago Mr. HILL prevented the nomination of Judge PARKER for the Governorship. It is known to everybody that Mr. HILL would not listen to the suggestion of Judge PARKER'S name, and that he insisted on the nomination of COLER.
It was reported among her friends in this city yesterday that Miss Annie Russell, the actress, and Oswald Yorke, the actor, had been married in the course of the day.

August Waldinger, Sergeant at Arms of the Central Federated Union, caused a sensation at the meeting of that body yesterday by announcing that he had been informed by delegates that detectives in plain clothes were present at its last meeting.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Special franchise valuations in New York City, as computed by the State Tax Commissioners, and on which the corporation franchise tax is levied, increased $16,363,725 over the aggregate for the previous year, the grand totals being respectively $235,157,725 and $251,521,450.

READING, Penn., March 27. -- Bound hand and foot, with a box of pepper in his mouth, which gave pain to every breath, and with his feet, wrists, and chest terribly burned. William McNeight, a junk dealer, seventy-four years old, lay for 108 hours on the floor of his cabin, the victim of three masked burglars, who had tried to force him to disclose the hiding place of his savings.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Information received at the Navy Department to-day from Admiral Wise at Guantanamo indicates that the Morales Government is making headway in the contest in Santo Domingo, the Admiral reporting that it is now in possession of all the ports of the island except the small one of Monte Cristi, on the north coast.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Judge Swayne impeachment case threatens to prolong the session of Congress. The Senate does not wish to be detained here to listen to the trial, but the House is in the mood to vote for impeachment, and the spectacle of an impeachment trial running along for the next six weeks is imminent.

Palm Sunday was celebrated with appropriate services in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue. The early masses at 6, 7, and 9 o'clock were well attended, and an unusually large congregation was present at the 11 o'clock services, where solemn high mass was celebrated by the Very Rev. Vicar General Lavelle, rector of the cathedral.

Booker T. Washington yesterday morning talked to an audience which tested the capacity of Carnegie Hall on the "Results of Negro Education." The lecture was delivered under the auspices of the Society for Ethical Culture.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Representative Gregg of Texas describes an inscription on a tombstone which he saw in an Arkansas graveyard. It reads: "This stone is sakred to the memry of William Hardy who comes to his death by fooling with a Colt revolver, one of the old kind brass mounted, and of such is the Kingdom of haeven."

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 27. -- The city street railway and interurban system are without power because of the flooding of the powerhouses near White River. Communication with North and West Indianapolis is cut off by the flood, which has swept away bridges. The city is still without water, owing to the flooding of the waterworks pumping station.

A spectacular fire which lighted up the Hudson River occurred last evening in Hoboken. While the flames were raging there was a collision between two loaded trolley cars ascending the long inclined railroad trestle rising from the ferry to Jersey City Heights. The collision was directly due to the fire, as the motormen were running blindly through the dense smoke.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 27. -- An official dispatch sent from Port Arthur to the Emperor by Vice Admiral Makaroff says that at 1 o'clock this morning the Russian searchlights discovered four large merchant steamers making for the entrance to the harbor, supported by six Japanese torpedo boats, evidently with the purpose of blocking the inner roadstead.
LONDON, March 27. -- It is officially announced that Baron Curzon of Kedleston, Viceroy of India, has been appointed Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports, in succession to the late Marquis of Salisbury.

To a large audience gathered in Carnegie Hall Mrs. Isabella Charles Davis of the International Order of King's Daughters and Sons yesterday afternoon made an appeal for funds with which to establish a farm colony on Long Island for the redemption of victims of alcoholism and the drug habit, and backed up her plea with figures showing the ravages of these habits, which caused a sensation.

ROME, March 27. -- Newspapers here publish an interview with M. Combes, the French Premier, in which he says that the forthcoming visit of President Loubet to Rome is not only a courtesy from the President of the French Republic to King Victor Emmanuel, but that it is a visit "from a friend called France to a friend called Italy," the relations of which countries are now as close as possible.

It is probably not generally known that during recent years Japanese contributions to science have been numerous and important. The most conspicuous successes of its original investigators appear to have been in the field of biological research, a study demanding great patience, manual dexterity, and a refinement of technique which are quite characteristic of the people who are now occupying so large a share of the world's notice.
BEREA, March 27. -- Rocky River for eight miles is a stream of fire, the surface being covered with burning oil.

We have been expansionists as well a Russia. Nations cannot become great without territorial aggrandizement, and in the spreading process fine distinctions between meum et tuum have perhaps not been more closely observed by ourselves than by our Muscovite confreres. Russia is a Continental empire.

Fire Commissioner Nicholas J. Hayes has submitted plans to Mayor McClellan and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, in which he requests an appropriation of $2,000,000 for the establishment of a number of new engine and hook and ladder companies. In his application the Commissioner says that the location of the new companies has been selected by Chief Croker, and that work should, if possible, be begun within the year.
ON BOARD THE HAIMUN, March 27. -- The Japanese fleet attacked Port Arthur early this morning.

Last week's market is a curiosity. For concentration of business, for wideness of range in the active stocks, and for inactivity outside the galvanized circle the week is a terrible example of artificiality. Only seventy-two stocks moved so much as a point, although 4,427,254 shares were dealt in.

That the Universalist Club, an organization composed largely of ministers and laymen of the Universalist Church is to have headquarters in the heart of the Tenderloin, on Thirty-eighth Street, near Broadway, was decided after a runner of the club at the Hotel St. Denis last evening.

WHITE PLAINS, March 28. -- At the second session of the Committee of Five which is investigating the internal condition of the Democratic Party of the County of Westchester, held this afternoon at the Elberon Hotel here, ex-Mayor Michael J. Dillon of New Rochelle and ex-Mayor Edwin W. Fiske of Mount Vernon testified and entered a general denial of the allegations of H.C. Henderson.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Little Woods was the sensation at Benning to-day, and when Michaels was first home, in a rattling finish it marked a coup of considerable proportions. It was the first start for the Flambeau colt, but he had been carefully prepared by "Billy" Garth, and a select few pounded the price from 30 down to 22 to 1 at post time.

It is related of Ibsen that at a rehearsal in Germany he took up his hat and stick and left the theatre with the remark: "The Directors have announced a play by me, but it pleases the ladies and gentlemen of the company to perform the work of some other person." History repeated itself last night at the Princess.

Six months on the Island was the sentence imposed yesterday on Marion Francois Leon D'Este, forty-one years old, who though fashionably dressed had been living in Bowery lodging houses. He was arraigned before Magistrate Mayo, in the Jefferson Market Court, on a charge of swindling Samuel V. Hoffman of 4 Warren Street, a son of the late Dean Hoffman, out of $35.
PARIS, March 28. -- A St. Petersburg telegram says the Russians are less optimistic concerning the war, in anticipation of approaching events of a decisive character.

Daniel J. Sully took another step yesterday in his efforts to get rehabilitation on the Cotton Exchange. With John R. Dos Passos, his counsel, he appeared before a meeting of the committee of creditors, held shortly after the close of the Exchange in the office of Reinhard Seidenburg, Chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- In the Senate to-day there was a discussion on the recent order of the Secretary of the Interior and Commissioner of Pensions making eligible to a graduated pension all surviving Federal soldiers of the war of the rebellion who have reached the age of sixty-two. The debate proceeded on a resolution introduced several days ago by Senator Carmack.

LONDON, March 28. -- After several years' tenure of the amateur indoor tennis championship, Eustice H. Miles to-day lost the title, being beaten by V. Pennell by three games to two in the regular five-game contest.

RICHMOND, Va., March 28. -- After an acquaintance of fifteen years, J. Wesley Sargeant, a contracting plumber, of Richmond, and H.A. Belles, late of Brooklyn and Rochester, retired to sleep Friday night in Campbell's theatrical hotel.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., March 28. -- The National Fireproofing Company has issued orders closing six of its factories and throwing 700 men out of work. The existing conditions in the building trades in New York are responsible for the order, which is to take effect April 1.

ALBANY, March 28. -- What is understood to be a plain of Col. Michael J. Dady to widen the breach between the Brooklyn Democratic organization and Tammany, is contained in a bill introduced to-night by Assemblyman Remsen.

Seeking to obtain the use of some available ground in Central Park for a Summer parade ground for the city's National Guard regiments, several officers of the local militia have called the matter to the attention of Mayor McClellan, who is now seriously considering the advisability of adopting the suggestion.

Miss Eleanor Anderson, the telephone operator who says James N. Abeel led her to believe that he was J. Ogden Goelet, Jr., yesterday recovered a verdict of $75,000 -- the full amount she sued for -- against Abeel for breach of promise to marry. The verdict was rendered by a Sheriff's jury after listening to the young woman's story of the deception of which she was the victim.

The snowstorm which surprised New Yorkers yesterday afternoon -- that is, presupposing that anything in the weather line can surprise nowadays -- wasn't a marker to the one which raged on the stage of the New Amsterdam Theatre last night. And by the same token that stage storm was as a gentle zephyr compared to the hurricane which roared throughout the big auditorium as the pitiful tale of those "Two Orphans" was unfolded.

One of the earnest and influential advocates of the nomination of Judge PARKER for the Presidency says of him: "He does not represent the past factional fights of his party. His nomination, therefore, would not be a challenge to any but Republicans." That is an argument of no little weight and moment.

PARIS, March 28. -- By the decisive majority of 316 to 269 the Chamber of Deputies to-night passed the Government bill for the suppression of all forms of teaching by the religious orders. This supplements and completes the work begun by the ex-Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, in 1901.

As a result of the substitution of the firm of Carrere Hastings in place of Henry F. Hornbostel as the architects for the new Manhattan Bridge, which was announced yesterday by Commissioner Best, the two architectural firms may have to settle the question of interests in the courts, although Mr. Hornbostel said yesterday that it might not be necessary to go so far in the matter.
IRKUTSK, Siberia, March 28. -- Smallpox has become epidemic in the interior of this province.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was brisk enough at times, but numerous intervals of dullness kept the total for the day below 300,000 shares. Most of the stocks which participated to any great extent in the day's transactions showed net gains, but there were few or no signs of betterment in the way of general interest in the market.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 28. -- A peculiar story is told in connection with the Dodge-Morse case. It is that Charles F. Dodge, for whose extradition the State of New York has been fighting for three months, is engaged to marry a wealthy Georgia widow.

A report was widely circulated yesterday in the woolen district that Charles Fletcher's Mills, near Providence, would be consolidated with the Atlantic Mills of A.D. Juilliard Co., the latter firm to have the management of the combined plants.

BOSTON, March 28. -- The sensation of the day in the gas hearing was the testimony of Thomas W. Lawson to the effect that Henry H. Rogers of the Standard Oil Company had received stock of the New England Gas and Coke Company representing a par value of $1,000,000, which W.L. Elkins and others of the New England Gas and Coke people expected was going to Lawson, but which he says he never received.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 28. -- On the face of unofficial returns, Gov. Jefferson Davis has carried enough counties to give him 222 delegates in the State Convention, that being the number necessary to secure the nomination.

When Dock Commissioner Featherson opened the bids yesterday for the construction of the five new ferryboats for the Staten Island service, it was found that even the lowest of the three bidders, who could do only one-fifth of the work, was fully a third higher in price than it had been estimated that the boats would cost.
Secretary Shaw has ordered appeals to the courts from two recent decisions written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville of the Board of United States General Appraisers.
WASHINGTON, March 28. -- A new cause of friction between the executive and legislative branches of the Government has arisen.

-- We find considerable difficulty in sharing the indignation expressed by City Magistrate HIGGINBOTHAM against the policeman who arrested a Williamsburg butcher Saturday evening for a clear violation of the Sanitary Code, and, regardless of the offender's plea for delay on account of the particularly heavy trade of that evening, marched him off to the police station.

With numberless others I read in your Sunday issue the editorial on hospitals. As it happens, the question is one which touches my interest nearly, and as I have come closely in contact with one phase of the work I ask your space that I may demonstrate in a public way some of the matter I have at heart.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The McCall Post Office Investigating Committee met in open session to-day to continue its hearings on the "charges concerning members" regarding heir connection with Post Office leases and increases in clerk hire.
PESHAWAR, India, March 28. -- The Ameer of Afghanistan, who was reported to have been killed by poison, is quite well.

When the conditions in certain parts of Colorado, brought about by the pernicious activity of professional labor agitators, reached a point of acuteness which the people considered intolerable, a number of troublesome persons were summarily banished. As they had what amounted to a choice between leaving the State and remaining to be dealt with by a vigilance committee, they prudently left; but it does not appear that peace followed their going.
HAVANA, March 28. -- A rumor which has been circulated in the United States that the Northern Securities Company would attempt to domicile itself in Cuba came as a surprise to President Palma.

ALBANY, March 28. -- The second Senatorial conference on the Finch bill for the pensioning of Judges heid to-night took an interesting turn when it was stated that since the passage of the bill in the Assembly, Assemblyman Finch had received a lucrative appointment as an appraisal Commissioner from the Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28. -- Lawrance D'Orsay, who is starring in "The Earl of Pawtucket," was attacked with acute indigestion at the Chestnut Street Theatre to-night during the first act, and was obliged to leave the theatre.

At the invitation of the People's Institute, Cooper Union was filled to the doors last night by a mass meeting that denounced separately and emphatically those measures now before the State Legislature whose peculiar features in regard to franchises and other privileges have earned for them the name of "grab bills."

The Commissioner of Bridges seems to have undertaken a serious responsibility respecting the Manhattan Bridge. The substitution of eye-bar chains for wire cables was made by Mr. LINDENTHAL as a means of hastening and cheapening the construction of the bridge. The change had not only the engineering authority of the Commissioner of Bridges himself, but he convoked a council upon it of unofficial engineers of the highest authority, who unanimously approved it.

There was hesitation in the general market and in special securities at intervals upon the Stock Exchange yesterday, but the result of the day's business was encouraging to advocates of higher prices. Among fifty active properties there were more than a dozen advances of a point or more, and not one decline exceeding a fraction.

WASHINGTON, March 28. Senator Burton is the first United States Senator ever convicted of a crime, and his is the first conviction under the statute which forbids a Senator or member of the House to act as attorney or be interested in any way in any business in which the Government is interested.

Frank Croker, for whom Charles F. Herreshoff has designed a very fast forty-three-foot auto boat, has been challenged by the S.F. Edge Company of London, the builders of the fast Napier launches. A Napier boat won the Alfred Harmsworth International Cup for motor boats last July.
TIEN-TSIN, March 28. -- Lloyd's agent at Niu-Chwang telegraphs:

Philip Daly, Jr., was placed on trial yesterday in the General Sessions before Judge McMahon and a jury on an indictment charging him with maintaining a gambling house at 107 West Forty-fifth Street. Assistant District Attorney Lord, in opening the case for the prosecution, declared that Daly was one of the big gamblers in New York who generally escape punishment.
NIU-CHWANG, March 28. -- American and British flags were to-day removed by the Russian military from the property of citizens of American and British nationality.

On the editorial page of yesterday's TIMES, under the heading "Roman Church and Marriage," I find a letter signed "James Bishop Thomas, Curate of Trinity Church, New Haven," in which the following occurs: "The Roman Church recognizes only the validity of its own sacraments.

Eighteen entries have been received by the Automobile Club of America for the service test of commercial motor vehicles which is to be held under the auspices of the club next week. The contest will begin Monday and will continue throughout the entire week. The machines that have entered will be weighed by the club officials on Saturday and will receive their proper numbers.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 28.--Before one of the largest crowds that have ever gathered at Montgomery Park and on a track lightning fast, the four-year-old colt, Little Scout, owned by George C. Bennett Co. of Memphis, to-day easily won the Montgomery Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth.

Between forty and fifty of the leading horse dealers of Greater New York assembled at the Hotel Cadillac last night and organized The Horse Fair Association of New York. The principal object of the association is to hold a horse show annually at which exhibits will be sold at private sale, and the first show has been scheduled for April 25, 26, and 27 at the Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, March 28. -- Gov. Odell to-day received a committee of the Merchants' Association, who called on him to discuss the so-called railroad "grab" bills. The delegation consisted of S. Christy Mead, H.D. Dumont, and F.B. De Berard.

In inviting the Pope to "denounce" the concordat, with the distinct intimation that the French Republic will do so if the Vatican does not. M. COMBES has injected an entirely new issue into French politics. As to this proposition, he cannot pretend to have a popular mandate.
Coroner William O'Gorman, Jr., distinguished himself last evening by holding up a train.

The Building Material Dealers' Association has come into the fight between the bricklayers' unions and the Mason Builders' Assocition, and is prepared at any time to call a general shut-down of building material, including brick, lime, sand, gravel, plaster, and rough lumber throughout Manhattan and the Bronx until the bricklayers call off their strike.

OAKDALE, L.I., March 28. -- Carloads of materials for the new buildings on W.K. Vanderbilt's Idle Hour arrived at Oakdale Station on Saturday. Among the Idle Hour improvements will be the building of a young men's den, to be attached to the Idle Hour mansion for the exclusive use of the "boys," who are always found among the invited guests at all the Idle Hour social functions.

ST. LOUIS, March 28. -- Joseph R. Burton, senior United States Senator from Kansas, was convicted by a jury in the United States District Court to-day of having accepted compensation to protect the interests of the Rialto Grain and Securities Company of St. Louis before the Post Office Department. The jury deliberated forty-one hours before arriving at an agreement.

RICHMOND, Va., March 28. -- Thomas Sharkey, the pugilist, lost in a wrestling match with M.J. Dwyer here to-night by failing to throw his antagonist twice in one hour. He secured one fall, but was unable to repeat the performance.

City Superintendent Maxwell has sent a communication to the District Superintendents, under the direction of the Board of Superintendents of the Department of Education, which places the part-time system devised by Dr. William Ettinger, Principal of Public School No. 147, on trial generally throughout the city.
LONDON, March 29.--The Times's military correspondent says:

The Rev. Dr. W.P. Thirkield of Cincinnati, Corresponding Secretary of the Freedmen's Aid and Southern Education Society, addressed the Methodist preachers' meeting at 150 Fifth Avenue yesterday on "Recent Phases of the Race Problem."

ALBANY, March 28. -- At a conference with members of the Merchants' Association held with Gov. Odell to-day it was agreed that the Bedell bill providing for two additional members for the Railroad Commission should be allowed to slumber, and that the Wallace bill, introduced at the suggestion of the Merchants' Association, should be put through with some amendments.

The pastor of Trinity is treading on very dangerous ground, and should know better than to deduct such far-reaching assertions from an utterly false premise. He says that Catholics only acknowledge the validity of their own sacraments and tries to show that therefore only persons married by the Catholic Church are really and truly married.

ALBANY, March 28. -- An order issued today from the Adjutant General's office announces that the following organizations are designated to perform a tour of State field or camp service during the coming season: The First and Second Companies of the Signal Corps, Squadron A, Troops B and C, First, Second, and Third Batteries, Eighth, Ninth, Twelfth, Fourteenth, Twenty-third, Forty-seventh, Sixty-ninth, Seventy-first, Seventy-fourth Regiments, and the Seventeenth Separate Company of Infantry.

Bernard Smyth Sons have sold for John ]q. A. (3riswold to Mayer S. Auerbach the plot of over four lots at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and l'qlnety-ninth Street, with frontages of 106 feet on the former and 116 feet on the latter.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 28. -- Flood conditions in the Grand River Valley have greatly improved in the last twenty-four hours. Since morning the river has lowered nine inches from high-water mark of 20.15 feet. To-night the water is stationary. At Ionia it has fallen eighteen inches, and at Lowell fifteen inches.

A.V. Cisco, sixty years old, and his wife, Annie, fifteen years his junior, were found dead yesterday morning in their room at 27 Duane Street. They had been asphyxiated by gas, and the police theory is that they committed suicide.

Poolrooms and gambling houses are open all over town, and any one who is in the habit of gambling, and who knows somebody close to the owner of a place, will find no difficulty in gaining admittance. This was the statement made yesterday by Police Inspector Walsh, whose inspection district includes the new and the old Tenderloin precincts and a big slice of New York's aristocratic section.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 28. -- Gen. Kuropatkin left his train at Mukden last evening and is proceeding to Liao-Yang, whence it is now believed he will proceed to the front for an inspection of the troops, his visit to Port Arthur being temporarily postponed.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles sent a letter of regret to the Democratic Club of Grand Rapids, Mich., which was to have given a banquet at Grand Rapids this evening, but owing to the floods in that region the banquet was abandoned. He said, in part:

Magistrate Seward Baker, an appointee of Mayor Low, was served with a summons just as he was entering the West Side Court Building last night which ordered him to appear before the Appellate Division of the First Department April 8, which is the next scheduled motion day, and there show cause why the court should not take such action as in the judgment of said court justice requires.

ALBANY, March 28. -- The National Art Theatre Society was incorporated to-day to promote the building and maintenance by private endowment and personal subscription of a theatre of the highest class in New York City, to be devoted to the presentation of classic and standard plays, American and foreign, and to the "maintenance of a conservatory of acting and the theatric arts."

LACROSSE, Wis., March 29. -- As a result of the alleged attack by Charles Powers, a Milwaukee road brakeman, upon Inez Drake, aged ten years, at Lanesborough, Fillmore County, Minn., a mob of 200 infuriated citizens to-night stormed the village jail in an attempt to lynch him.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The Japanese Legation has received from Tokio an official report made by Admiral Togo respecting the second attempt to "bottle up" the Port Arthur squadron. In the report Togo says:

While Commissioner Woodbury of the Department of Street Cleaning was in Albany yesterday to urge the passage of a bill to increase his department powers and the salaries of many of the men employed in it, Mayor McClellan declared that if the bill should contain any abridgement of the powers of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, or any restriction of the home rule policy, he would veto it.

In the current number of McClure's Magazine LINCOLN STEFFENS bases on his study of corruption in Missouri a striking article on "The Enemies of the Republic." He writes with the utmost plainness. He uses the names of prominent men in polities and in business. He gives numerous specific instances of bribery, defining the purposes, and stating the amounts, the givers, the takers.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Secretary Hitchcock of the Interior Department today sent to the Senate a communication in response to Senator Overman's resolution directing the Secretary to furnish the Senate a copy of the order issued by the department enlarging the Pension act of June 27, 1890, and amendments as to the disabilities of applicants for pensions, and to report by what amount the order will increase pensions annually.

Republican and Democratic primaries were held in every Assembly district in Greater New York yesterday for the election of delegates to the several Republican Assembly and Congress District Conventions, and to the Democratic Assembly District Convention.

Acting under instructions from Judge McMahon, in the General Sessions, yesterday the jury in the case of Philip Daly, Jr., returned a verdict declaring Daly was not guilty of maintaining a gambling house or "public nuisance" on West Forty-fifth Street.

The steady improvement in the quotations for the stocks of the Detroit and Mackinc Railroad Company for several months past, caused by quiet absorption of large blocks of stocks by interests closely allied with the company, has been explained by the fact that the earnings for the present fiscal year will be about 10 per cent. on the common stock, according to a Director of the company.

That Herr Alois Burgstaller was one of the biggest plums in the "Parsifal" pudding has never been denied, not even by Herr Burgstaller. But the tenor's atttraction for the thousands who paid $10 a seat to hear him, and the affection which he inspired among the flower maidens was as nothing to his popularity in Hoboken. In New York the people went to see "Parsifal." Hoboken went on its knees to Burgstaller.
LONDON, March 29. -- The Times's military correspondent says:

NEWARK, N.J., March 29. -- More than one hundred changes were made by the Newark Methodist Conference which adjourned to-night. Charles N. Anderson of Westfield was elected presiding elder of the Jersey City district, to succeed John R. Wright. The other presiding elders were re-elected. The list of pastors is as follows:

The Morris estate has sold the plot, 200 by 500, at the northwest corner of Morris Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-seventh Street, to the Morris Avenue Realty Company. The property will be improved with four-story flats.

GALVESTON, Texas, March 29. -- The fatal shooting of Sidney Stewart and the wounding of two of his companions at Silsbee Monday night by negroes have precipitated a race war which threatens the extermination of the negroes in East Texas.

PARIS, March 29. -- The expected attack upon M. Pelletan's administration of the navy began to-day in the Chamber of Deputies, and in consequence of a dispute in the course of the session, M. Decker-David (Republican) challenged M. Thierry (Republican) to a duel.

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Weights for the $15,000 Harlem National Handicap at one and three-sixteenths miles, to be run at Harlem June 4, were announced to-day, McChesney carries top weight, 129 pounds. Gold Heels comes next with 125 pounds, while Dick Welles, holder of the world's record for a mile, made last year while a three-year-old colt, will carry but 123 pounds. The weights for the other 109 nominations follow:
The first sentence of an editorial article on Sir Edwin Arnold, in a late issue of THE TIMES, is as follows:

DETROIT, Mich., March 29. -- In a sweeping decision handed down to-day by Judge Brooke of the Wayne Circuit Court, the Riverside Club and Plumbers' Exchange of this city, organizations of plumbers against which proceedings were brought by Prosecutor Hunt on the ground that they were organized to fix prices and stifle competition, were restrained from continuing business, which the court holds to be "an unlawful enterprise inimical to the public welfare."

ST. PETERSBURG, March 29. -- Gen. Kuropatkin in his first report to the Emperor from the scene of war announces that offensive land operations took place yesterday against the Japanese upon the sixth anniversary of the occupation of Port Arthur by the Russians.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 29. -- The Democratic Party in Vermont, although in a hopeless minority in State affairs, will divide into hostile camps in National affairs, and at present is very much in doubt as to the proper man to head the National ticket. Interviews with prominent Democrats show that Olney of Massachusetts is the favorite here, but they do not expect that he will be strong in the National convention.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Senators Platt and Depew have decided to support the House plan for the improvement of New York's postal facilities. This involves the leasing of the New York Central's site at $90,000 a year, and the leasing of the Pennsylvania's site at $75,000.

TACOMA. Washington, March 29. -- The Democrats of Washington are not well organized. and there is no well-defined feeling in favor of any particular candidate for the Democratic nomination for President. Ex-Senator George Turner, on his return from New York and Washington, came out for Parker.
"Charity suffereth long and is kind," but Sennett Bestwick was tired of dispensing it when last night on Broadway he met the man who had abused his confidence, so he had the fellow arrested.

The Russian procedures at Niu-Chwang seem to have produced more excitement, both in this country and in Europe, than the facts warrant. When we proposed the neutralization of China, and all the Powers agreed to it, including the belligerent Powers, Manchuria was manifestly and necessarily excepted, being in the possession of one belligerent which it was the aim of the other to drive out.

Detective Michael McNally of Jersey City died last night from blood poisoning at his home, 101 Magnolia Avenue. Drs. Dickinson, Kirby, and Culver of Jersey City, and Dr. Smith of the Pasteur Institute attended him.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 29. -- The New York National League team won another brilliant victory over the local club to-day, the score being 11 to 2. McGraw's men hit and played like champions. The score:
In an editorial Friday, March 25 last, you ask, "Has the ordinance which requires surface cars to stop upon the near side of the street any friends or defenders whatever?"
WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs to-day authorized a favorable report on a bill placing George F. Phillips on the retired list of the navy as a warrant officer.

Yesterday was a proud day for the newsboys all over the city when they were notified by the "boss newsboy," Jack Sullivan of Park Row, that a club charter had been granted to the "Newsboys' Association of Greater New York," which has been fighting for recognition ever since the beginning of the year.

District Attorney Jerome is of the opinion that Mayor McClellan, Commissioner McAdoo, and Leader Murphy will succeed in ousting the gamblers from New York, and that great political possibilities lie in a regenerated and reformed Tammany Hall.

Traffic on the South Ferry branch of the east side elevated roads was delayed about fifteen minutes last evening by a brief but spectacular fire which burned out the two upper floors of the four-story brick and stone building, 34 New Bowery, occupied as a wareroom by Martin T. Garvey, dealer in second-hand store and barroom fixtures.

ALBANY, March 29. -- At the same time that he moved for the advancement to third reading of four of the street railway bills which have been the subject of denunciation on the part of many of the civic organizations of New York, Chairman Bedell of the Assembly Railroads Committee to-day announced the withdrawal of the fifth bill, known as the Transfer bill and generally considered the most objectionable of the lot.
BOSTON, March 29. -- The Boston Record this afternoon published the following:

While the rush to swear off taxes was at its height yesterday in the department's offices, in the Stewart Building, an extremely mild-mannered and soft-voiced young woman was ushered into the office of Commissioner Brady. She said she had received a notice to the effect that she was down in the tax books for a personal property assessment of $22,000 which she had received from an estate.

PARIS, March 29. -- The United States leads in the first evening's play of the billiard match at eighteen-inch balk line, two shots in, Wilson P. Foss, the acknowledged amateur champion of the United States having scored 400 points to 338 made by Lucien Rerolles, the French amateur champion.

At the invitation of the Emergency Committee of the Employers' Association a conference took place late last night at the Building Trades Club between this committee and the Greater New York Executive Committee of the bricklayers' unions. The conference was called in order if possible to reach some basis of settlement of the strike of the bricklayers and laborers.

General Appraiser Fischer yesterday sustained the advances recently made by Appraiser Whitehead on the values of enameled ware imported by Stransky Co., about which there has been much controversy between the importers and the customs officials. Stransky Co. allege that on those goods the export price in Europe is higher than the home market price.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The talent Scored heavily at Benning to-day. Favorites won in each of the six events. The track was considerably improved, and several local records were broken, but generally the finishes were not exciting. There was a good attendance, and the weather, though cool, was pleasant.

Predatory gangs of boys have established a reign of terror in the fashionable residential section between the Boulevard and Riverside Drive, Eighty-ninth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets. They are stoning residences and traffic, breaking windows, molesting small shopkeepers, and committing all sorts of outrages; and dwellers in the neighborhood declare that the police, though doing their best, seem altogether unable to meet the situation.

A meeting of the Finance Committee of the United States Steel Corporation was held yesterday, at which it is understood action on the declaration of the quarterly dividend of the corporation which is to be taken by the Directors next week was discussed. It is known that the board has been divided on the policy of continuing full dividends ever since last November.

WEI-HAI-WEI, March 29. -- I have just returned from a cruise I took with the object of verifying the truth of a report brought by a Chinese junk that the Russian and Japanese fleets had been in contact on the high seas. I covered 190 miles, but found no evidence of either fleet, though the watch reported flash signaling for a short period about 4 this morning.
LONDON, March 29. -- Premier Balfour administered a severe snubbing in the House of Commons to-day to Winston Spencer Churchill, (Conservative.)

CHICAGO, March 29. -- Justice David J. Brewer of the United States Supreme Court delivered an address here to-night under the auspices of the Municipal Lecture Association. Justice Brewer's theme was "Obedience to Law the First Civic Duty." and his discourse was listened to with marked interest by an audience that filled the Auditorium Theatre. Speaking particularly of laws operative only within the city, he said in part:

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- The report of the court of inquiry, of which Rear Admiral Wise was President, on the investigation of the collision between the battleships Missouri, commanded by Capt. W.S. Cowles, and Illinois, commanded by Capt. R.B. Bradford, was made public to-day. The court recommends no further proceedings.
LONDON, March 29. -- Rates for money were stiff in the market to-day, and the demand was strong, for Stock Exchange payday, Easter, and quarterly requirements. Discounts were easy.

Heavy purchases of Union Pacific stock which have been going on for several days were declared yesterday to have been made for the account of William Rockefeller and the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, which is known as a Rockefeller property.

Sixteen Democratic Senators voted to ratify the Panama treaty, thereby affirming and approving everything done by the President on the Isthmus. But that is no reason why the Democrats of the House should bow in supine acquiescence to the President's decision to exercise in his own person the supreme powers of Government within the canal strip.

PITTSBURG, March 29. -- Because of trouble over salary John T. Kelly will probably leave Weber Fields's company at the end of this week. The trouble is that, now that the company has returned to the East, Weber Fields want to reduce Kelly's salary to the name figure it was in the music hall in New York.

Passengers on a local train on the Suburban Branch of the New York, New Haven and Hartford, as it approached a bridge at One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street last night, were alarmed when they heard several rifle shots outside, and at the same moment three of the windows in one car were shivered, the fragments of glass flying in many directions, but fortunately harming no one.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 29. -- Philo S. Bennett's will was admitted as a competent document for probating by Judge Edwin B. Gager of the Superior Court as the result of the first day's hearing in the appeal of William J. Bryan from the decision of the Probate Court, which disallowed the "sealed letter" found with the will and which gives Mr. Bryan $50,000.
Two good games were played last night in the 14.2 billiard tournament at Daly's Broadway billiard rooms in the interborough championship series.

If a casual billionaire who had taken a fancy to a seat in the United States Senate, or the female members of whose family had taken it for him, as he or they might have taken it for a steam yacht, or an opera box, or a thousand-horse-power automobile, had accomplished his desire, he would be sure of receiving the right hand of fellowship from the other members of that body, at least in public.

In THE TIMES of this date, under the heading "Invoice Values Advanced," it is said that General Appraiser Fisher "yesterday sustained the advance recently made by the Appraisers on values of enameled ware imported by Stransky Co."

ALBANY, March 30. -- After a hot fight on the floor of the Senate to secure a recess in order that the Judiciary Committee might act on Senator Brackett's judiciary pension bill, the recess was secured, and the committee reported the bill, Senators Davis, Hill, and Brackett uniting with the Democratic members of the committee to bring about this result. The proceedings were attended by much acrid debate between the Raines and Brackett factions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30. -- Judge Gager of the Superior Court to-day delivered a rebuke to William J. Bryan in the course of the hearing on the admissibility as part of the will of Philo S. Bennett of the so-called "sealed letter" by the terms of which $50,000 was to go to Mr. Bryan.

Transactions in yesterday's stock market amounted to 725,230 shares, or nearly 200,000 shares in excess of the previous day's total. At the same time the business was somewhat better distributed, although the number of issues appearing in the list of transactions, which supplied very little trading, was still sufficiently large to indicate that general interest in the market had not broadened to the extent which might be inferred from the volume of the trading.

A bill introduced in the State Senate last month should be followed up and saved from the fate that usually befalls legislation attempted to be carried through in the face of powerful enemies. It is an amendment to that law of 1890 concerning highways, which allows owners of property at their own expense to locate and plant trees along roads adjoining their land.

Mrs. Vertie Fysh, wife of Capt. John Albert Fysh, formerly of the British Army, died yesterday afternoon in her apartments at 521 West One Hundred and Eleventh Street, under circumstances which indicated suicide. Coroner Scholer and Assistant District Attorney Garvin are making a rigorous investigation.
LONDON, March 30. -- Charles W. Macara, President of the Federation of Master Cotton Spinners' Associations, to-day issued an exhaustive statement on the situation of the cotton trade.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The feature of the sport at the Benning track to-day was the victory of Tribes Hill in the last race, he be may the only winning favorite. In a held of seven he got away very poorly, but gradually worked his way to the front and won by a length.
ALBANY, N.Y., March 30. -- "The trail of Richard Canfield is covered with ruin and not a little blood."

NEWARK, March 30. -- Ex-Senator James Smith, who is the recognized leader of the Democratic forces in New Jersey, in an interview to-day repeats his preference for the nomination of ex-President Cleveland for the Presidency. The ex-Senator is to sail for Europe April 22, and the State Convention for the selection of delegates to the St. Louis Convention was fixed for a date early in April so that he might attend it before sailing.

NEWARK, N.J., March 30. -- Thomas A. McDonnell of 533 Bank Street is the owner of a pearl a little larger than a pea, and said to be worth about $150, which he found last Friday while opening oysters bought from Michael Dougherty of 538 Bank Street.

Theodore H. Price, formerly of the firm of Price, McCormick Co., which failed in 1900, it was learned yesterday, has paid additional sums to certain of his creditors. Knowledge of this action on the part of Mr. Price leaked out on the Cotton Exchange and caused a good deal of discussion.

Urging the installation of a combined fresh and salt water high pressure fire service in the business districts of both Manhattan and Brooklyn, not only as a desirability, but as an absolute necessity, the Board of Engineers named by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment made its report to Mayor McClellan yesterday.

The evidence continues to accumulate that the Mayor and the Police Commissioner are standing together with increasing firmness against the pressure of the poolroom owners and their allies in the "organization."

Charged with murder in the first degree Patrolman William H. Bosse of the Clarson Avenue Station, Brooklyn, was arraigned in the Myrtle Avenue Court yesterday afternoon. He was arrested by Detectives Cosgrove and Carroll on a warrant charging him with being responsible for the death of Patrick Farrell, a bartender in the saloon at 242 Myrtle Avenue, that borough.

The Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday, in a decision written by General Appraiser Lunt, denied a protest by the Stone Downer Company of Boston, declared that the importation in question was an attempt to evade the payment of duty and to defraud the revenue, and disposed of the question as to whether wool could be mixed or not to take advantage of a lower rate of duty.

At a conference held last night at the Building Trades Club at 1,123 Broadway, at which seventeen members of the Greater New York Executive Committee of the Bricklayers' Union and the Executive Committee of the Laborers' Protective Union, the members of which are now on strike, an unsuccessful attempt was made to come to some understanding so that work might be resumed on buildings in course of construction throughout the city.
TOKIO, March 29. -- The special Diet concluded its labors to-day, finally passing the series of war tax and financial measures proposed by the Government.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Hearst movement seems to have had the effect of solidifying the Democratic members of Congress for Judge Parker.

Miss Maud Ingersoll, a middle-aged woman, said to be a relative of the late Robert G. Ingersoll, was temporarily in Bellevue Hospital yesterday for observation regarding her sanity. She has been living recently with Miss Helen Tinkham of 304 West One Hundred and Twelfth Street. About 10 o'clock yesterday morning Miss Tinkham called in Bicycle Policeman Ennis and asked him to take charge of her guest, who she seemed to fear had become irresponsible.

TOKIO, March 30. -- Vice Admiral Togo reports that at 3:30 o'clock on the morning of March 27 four steamships, escorted by eleven destroyers and six torpedo boats, approached Port Arthur and were successful in getting within two miles before they were discovered. Then they were met by a fierce cannonade from the forts on both sides and the enemy's destroyers on guard.

BERLIN, March 30. -- A giant three-cylinder locomotive which it is the intention to exhibit at the St. Louis Exposition, was tested on the military railroad to-day in the presence of a large company of civil and military personages.

Detective Garrick of Hoboken and Court Officer William Wagner of the West Side Court late Tuesday night arrested Patrick H. Cunningham, the son of James Cunningham and executor of the large estate bequeathed by his father. The young man was charged with being a fugitive from justice.

Consternation was general in the Police Department yesterday when it became known that Commissioner McAdoo had re-instituted the system of detailing Roundsmen to act as "shoo-flies" in watching policemen in precincts other than their own. The men detailed were Roundsmen McCullough, Londregan, Schmidt, Maher, Scanlan, and Herrigan.

In the Democratic State Convention which meets at Albany on April 18 more than two-thirds of the 450 delegates will favor the nomination of Judge PARKER. His friends and supporters will have it in their power to pass a resolution of instructions to the New York delegates, and that power they will undoubtedly exercise.

LONDON, March 31. -- The Daily Telegraph says the Japanese authorities have refused to allow to correspondents the use of the field telegraph lines, and that all dispatches must be sent to Tokio by mail. The paper further says that there is no sign that any foreigners will be permitted to go to the front, though the native newspaper men will be allowed to do so.

ALBANY, March 30. -- As a result of the primaries held yesterday, and from his knowledge of the conditions which prevail in the sections in which primaries are still to be held, ex-Senator David B. Hill estimates that 309 of the 450 delegates to the Democratic State Convention will vote to instruct the delegates to the St. Louis Convention to cast their ballot for the nomination of Judge Alton B. Parker for President.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 30. -- But for Ames's effort to get the kinks out of his high-priced pitching arm in to-day's exhibition between the New York National Leaguers and the local Southern League team, there would not have been much to say about the game. The visitors had a walk-over up to the seventh inning, when Ames relieved McGinnity, and proved to be so bad that he was soon forcing runners over the plate.

In a report made to the Legislation Committee of the City Club, Lawrence Veiller, the Secretary of the club, calls attention to some forty-seven bills that have been introduced in the Legislature at Albany to increase salaries in the City of New York. If these bills were enacted into law, they would saddle upon New York City an annual increase in salaries of $1,018,280.
Mr. Hearst's candid proposal of himself as a radical labor candidate for the Presidency should evoke a candid examination of himself, (so far as known,) his principles, and his methods.
SHANGHAI, March 30. -- The Japanese Consul General having verified the completion of the disarmament of the Russian gunboat Mandjur, the Japanese cruiser will leave Shanghai to-morrow.

A former employe of Alfred R. Goslin went on the witness stand yesterday at the regular weekly hearing in the bankruptcy proceedings against the American Finance and Mortgage Company that are being conducted by Referee J.J. Townsend in his office, 45 Cedar Street, and swore to Goslin's connection with the concern.

Gov. Odell arrived in the city yesterday afternoon for the first time since the peace conference of March 20 at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, when all his plans with reference to the meeting of the State Convention next month were ratified unanimously by the Platt men.
