PARIS, March 30. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the campaign of the Opposition against M. Pelletan, Minister of Marine, failed to shake the position of the Government, which obtained a majority of 80 on a test vote.

Unique not only in name but in some other respects is what The Ends of the Earth Club, which held its first dinner at the Hotel Savoy, proved to be, when the diners, after their cigars and coffee, began to explain it last night. It is an organization that boasts of no officers, and which is composed of men who have been to or near to the various ends of the earth.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- After agreeing yesterday afternoon to those provisions of the Post Office Appropriation bill relating to the Post Office in New York City the Senate Committee having charge of that measure subsequently struck out that paragraph providing for the lease from the Pennsylvania Railroad of a building at Seventh Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street.

The Broadway after-theatre crowd last night was treated to the unusual sight of a well-dressed young man, who said he was Joseph D. Thomas, a student of the University of Pennsylvania, trying to walk on his hands along the Rialto.

The fire in lower Broadway on Saturday last again called attention to the fact that a large part of New York is without a water supply adequate in volume or pressure to deal with a serious conflagration. Had the direction and force of the wind favored its spread westward among the old and insecure buildings of that district, a loss comparable to that of Baltimore might have resulted.

At sunset last evening the Jewish people throughout the world began the celebration of the festival of "Pesach," or the Passover. This festival was instituted to celebrate the deliverance of the children of Israel from their long bondage in the land of Egypt, and, lasting for eight days, is a season of peculiar observances.

DENVER, Col., March 30. -- John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers of America, will appeal to the United States Supreme Court for an order, restraining Gov. Peabody from enforcing and maintaining martial law in the Trinidad district.

The North German Lloyd liner Prinzessin Irene, from Naples and Genoa, with Archbishop Farley on board, was sighted off Nantucket Lightship at 3:15 yesterday afternoon. She will reach Quarantine at about 5 o'clock this morning.
LONDON, March 31. -- The Times's Russian correspondents quote an article in the St. Petersburg Viedomosti, which reports considerable distress in Siberia in consequence of the war.
GAETA, Italy, March 30. -- Emperor William, on board the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, left here to-day for Messina, Sicily, escorted by the German cruiser Prinz Friedrich Karl.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30. -- Superior Judge Cook announced this afternoon from the bench that an attempt had been made to tamper with the jurors in the Botkin case. He declared that he would, therefore, discharge the jury to-morrow morning and begin the trial of the case anew. Mrs. Botkin is charged with the murder, by poisoned candy sent through the mail, of Mrs. John P. Dunning of Wilmington, Del.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 30. -- Proceedings have been brought in the Dutchess County Surrogate's Court to ascertain whether John F. Halstead, a wealthy retired business man of New York, is liable for a deficiency of $130,000 in certain trust funds held by him and the late Robert F. Wilkinson for the benefit of Charles Buckingham of Poughkeepsie and Martha H. Wood of New York.
CHRIST CHURCH, New Zealand, March 31. -- The British antarctic expedition which sailed on the steamer Discovery from London July 31, 1901, has signaled that it is returning.

In answer to "Horseman," whose letter appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES, I would say as long as he is willing to held along a movement for a new society for the prevention of cruelty to animals, if he will address Mrs. L.G. Allis, Far Rockaway, L.I., he will learn that there is under way now a movement to that effect.

The March Grand Jury, after exonerating all those on whom the responsibility had been fixed by the Coroner's jury at the inquest into the Darlington Hotel disaster, with the exception of Eugene Allison, one of the owners, yesterday made a presentment, severely censuring the Building Department.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- "Virginia" Bradley kept up his winning streak at the Benning track to-day and captured two of the six purses offered with Peter Paul and Boney Boy. Incidentally the day marked the first victory of old Boney Boy through the steeplechase field. He was never headed, and won by ten lengths from Agis, the second choice. Chivington, making his first effort of the season, was third. Four other starters fell.

MANCHESTER, N.H., March 31. -- Mrs. Delana B. Curtis has filed a bill of particulars in her suit against the estate of the late Frank Jones, brewer and Democratic leader in this State, for $400,000. The case will be tried in April, and is one of the most interesting ever known in New Hampshire.

Among the passengers arriving yesterday on the Deutschland were John D. Crimmins, his son, and his daughter, who have been in the South of Europe for several months. Mr. Crimmins said that he had become well acquainted with many of the members of the American colony in Rome, none of whom could understand the sympathy for the Japanese which is expressed by the American public.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company recently applied to the courts of Connecticut to have condemnation proceedings instituted against the one remaining residuary stockholder of the New Haven and Derby Railroad, a small branch line of the Consolidated System. This proceeding has hardly attracted the attention it deserves, for the attempt to enforce the right of eminent domain against minority shareholders is of rather unusual occurrence.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 31. -- The story of how Robert F. Wilkinson deceived his co-Trustee, John F. Halstead, a wealthy retired New York business man, and misapplied trust funds under their joint control to the extent of $130,000, belonging to Charles Buckingham and Martha V.B. Wood, after which he went abroad and died in London before the defalcation was discovered, was told by Mr. Halstead on the witness stand in the Surrogate's Court to-day.

Business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday lost half of its volume and yet retained most of its strength under conditions which were not stimulating, and given such disposition, might have been made depressing. There was scarcely more dullness than was fairly attributable to the fact that after adjournment there would be no business on foreign Exchanges until next Tuesday.

BOSTON, March 31. -- Papers in the suit of Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, against Gertrude Lamson, professionally known as Nance O'Neill; McKee Rankin, and John B. Schoeffel, manager of the Tremont Theatre, have been filed in the Superior Court and served upon the defendants.

Gov. Odell conferred with most of the local leaders yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. While he was in the rear corridor Senator Platt arrived from Washington. It was expected that the Governor would at once go up to the Senator's apartments, but not a step did he move. He merely said that he would see the Senator in the morning.

All the playing rules under which the National and American Leagues and the National Association of Professional Baseball League will be governed during the coming season Were carefully scrutinized at a two days' conference between President Pulliam of the National League and his staff of umpires at Philadelphia this week.

The minerals collected during the work of excavation for the subway are to be exhibited by the Rapid Transit Commission at the St. Louis Exposition. The collection, which is ready for shipment, is classified as follows:
Stenography as a profession, let me advise the one perplexed, if the executor of the profession be a Stenographer, and not what I would term a "Tiddlewink," is in most cases a well paying profession.

The case of MICHAEL FARLEY is one which should give the intelligent wage earner a topic for profitable thought. He was a skilled workman, with especial experience in operating the hoisting machinery for lifting steel shapes and other structural materials to the upper floors of high buildings.

The class handicap straight rail billiard tournament of the New York Athletic Club ended last night in a victory for C.D. Colman, who won first prize, with Dr. Walter G. Douglas second, and A. Vogel third. The success of Colman was almost entirely due to his small handicap, which was unavoidable, owing to his playing qualities being unknown.

SAYVILLE, L.I., March 31. -- Horse thieves operating in Manhattan and selling their plunder on Long Island have been so active of late that about twenty such animals have been found near here, and it is believed that there are at least fifty more, with many wagons and much harness, in Suffolk County, in all worth $10,000.

TACOMA, Wash., March 31. -- E.S. Reader, Superintendent of the Canton and Hankow Railway, now building with American capital, was a passenger on the steamship Shawmut, arriving this week. Regarding the Canton and Hankow Railway, Mr. Reader says:

High art in the form of "Rosmersholm," as administered by Sydney Rosenfeld's Century Players, suffered a relapse yesterday. The regular Thursday matinee was not given at the Princess Theatre. Everybody who braved the gloomy weather in the hope of seeing a gloomier Ibsen play was told at the box office that there would not be any more performances by the Century Players this week.

The wind and the rain were doing skirt dances through the skyscraper canons yesterday morning, and the shivering group on the sidewalk at Chambers Street and Broadway waited impatiently for the big policeman to give the "all clear" signal. A covered truck, east bound, approached rapidly.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The four bills in the interest of the Interurban Railroad were debated to-day for several hours in the Assembly. At the conclusion of the debate it was agreed to allow the bills to go to the Rules Committee without being advanced. That committee, if it decides in favor of the bills, will report them out on order of second reading, and an opportunity to offer amendments will then be afforded.

I desire to bring to your notice what I consider one of the greatest outrages perpetrated on the public, especially that part of the public who, at some sacrifice to themselves, wish to give a little amusement to their children by taking them to the circus. As everybody knows, this circus is an event that the children look forward to with a great deal of delight, and no parent likes to disappoint his children.

Appropriations aggregating nearly $10,000,000 were approved by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in executive session on the bond budget yesterday, the amounts authorized including $5,425,400 for the high pressure auxiliary water supply for fire fighting, and $3,000,000 for street paving in the five boroughs.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst was asked yesterday afternoon if he had any opinion to express with reference to the action of the Assembly Codes Committee in reporting out Senator Dowling's bill which would enable Diistrct Attorney Jerome to call witnesses in a case he desires to prosecute against Richard A. Canfield.

PARIS, March 31. -- The First Civil Tribunal of the Seine to-day decided the case of the Republic of Colombia against the Panama Canal Company in favor of the defendants. The decision condemns the plaintiffs to pay the costs of the action.

In a decision written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday decided that rossed pulp wood is free of duty as paper stock. This case has involved more labor than any other that has come before the board for a long time, on account of the bitter fight made by the paper manufacturing companies which have rossing plants in the United States to keep out the Canadian rossed wood.

TRENTON. N.J., March 31. -- Primaries for the election of delegates to the State Convention to select delegates to the Democratic National Convention were held in this county to-night. There are contests in nearly every ward in the city, which will be settled to-morrow.

While the Building Trades Employers' Association was trying to strengthen itself yesterday for any unexpected developments in the building strike, the Arbitration Board of the bricklayers' unions got a new proposition from the laborers to submit to the mason builders. It was not accepted.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Western Senators -- Clapp of Minnesota and Patterson of Colorado -- gave the New York Post Office plan a sharp set-back to-day. On their objections the amendments to the Post Office Appropriation bill providing for the purchase of the Pennsylvania Railroad site and the lease of the New York Central Railroad building went over for further consideration, when the matter came up in the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Official society is more than a little exercised over the lawn fete which the Countess Cassini, niece of the Russian Ambassador, is planning for May 6 for the benefit of the Russian Red Cross Society.
The end of the current week will see the passing of several plays, each of which, for a greater or lesser period of time, has enjoyed the favor of New York playgoers.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 31. -- Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt to-day recovered a diamond bracelet and pendant valued at $6,000, one of her wedding gifts, which it was supposed had been lost on the road between Bellevue Avenue and Sandy Point Farm.

In the City of New York there were, in 1903, 388 deaths traced by the Coroners to illuminating gas. Of these, 258 were reported as accidental and 130 as suicidal. The number since the 1st of January has not yet been tabulated for all the boroughs, but it would represent more than a quarter of the 1903 total.
In to-day's (Wednesday's) issue of THE TIMES you say:

BRISTOL, R.I., March 31. -- The remodeled racing schooner yacht Ingomar, which is to compete in English waters, was launched at the Herreshoff yards to-day. The yacht, which has been changed from a centreboard to a keelboat, will be commanded abroad by Capt. Barr, late of the cup yacht Reliance, and will sail for Southampton about April 20. The Ingomar is owned by Morton F. Plant of New York.

It has been said with much truth that this is "a strike of the leaders." It brings grave anxiety to the rank and file of the union membership and consternation to the hearts of those who have the welfare of the local organizations at heart. The Bricklayer and Mason, the official journal of the International Union of America for those trades, says with characteristic directness:

SCRANTON, Penn., March 31. -- Six persons are known to have been killed and five fatally injured by an explosion in the factory of the Dickson Squib Company at Priceburg, near here, to-day. The dead are Lizzie Bray, Priceburg; Beckie Lewis, North Scranton; Lizzie Matthews, Olyphant; George Callahan, Priceburg; Teresa Callahan, Priceburg, and one other.

The property facing Long Acre Square at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street, acquired originally by Kirke La Shelle as a theatre site, has been leased, through Brokers N. Brigham Hall Son to Felix Isman of Philadelphia for a term of twenty-one year at an aggregate net rental of $300,000.

Surely the dark ignorance of your correspondent "Perplexed" should, if posible, be illuminated, but there is better reason for this reply, namely, correction of those errors which seem to beset the general but scantily informed intelligence.

Public opening exercises of the Ethical Culture School were held last night in the Gymnasium Hall of the building, Sixty-third Street and Central Park West. The new building was open for inspection, and the equipment for the manual training schools, the modern gymnasium, the classrooms, and the perfection of arrangement excited enthusiastic commendation.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31. -- The United States Steel Corporation to-day filed in the Court of Chancery a demurrer to the bill of Alfred Stevens of Newark, who sued the corporation because of its passing of dividends on the common stock.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., March 31. -- After contesting his wife's will, which cut him off with $50 and left $50,000 to European relatives, and winning the suit two weeks ago for $25,000, John Thornberg rejoiced to such an extent that he broke his leg. He died to-day from blood poisoning.

AT SEA IN KOREA BAY, March 31. -- After his bombardment of Port Arthur on the 22d, Admiral Togo waited for an improvement in the weather before putting into execution his bold scheme for effectively blocking the entrance to the harbor.

Details will be found in another column relative to the leasing of Kirke La Shelle's property at Broadway and Forty-seventh Street to Felix Isman of Philadelphia, through N. Brigham Hall Son. The sale by John N. Golding of the property on Seventy-second Street, near Third Avenue, formerly owned by St. James's Church, is also referred to in more detail elsewhere.

ALBANY, March 31. -- By a unanimous vote, the Assembly Codes Committee to-day reported favorably the Dowling-Wainwright Anti-Gambling bill, which was introduced at the instigation of District Attorney Jerome for the avowed purpose of enabling him to put Reginald Vanderbilt on the stand to give testimony against Richard Canfield.

PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, March 31. -- The Tenth District Republican Convention to-day nominated Henry T. Bannon of Portsmouth for Congress on the twenty-seventh ballot. Lawrence County withdrew the name of A.R. Johnson in Bannon's favor, and the remaining counties rapidly fell into line.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 31. -- The Federal Trust Company to-day made an assignment to the Guardian Trust Company. The action is said to have been taken as a result of the disappearance of a prominent official of the Federal Trust Company and the discovery of a shortage of about $20,000.

Your article in to-day's paper describing the lawlessness that now prevails in certain sections of Riverside pictures a condition that exists in nearly every part of the city. Morningside Park and its vicinity, from One Hundred and Tenth to One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, are in possession of gangs of vicious and dangerous young men and boys.

ALBANY, March 31. -- Three home rule bills were introduced in the Senate to-day by the Committee on Cities. The most important of them was a bill giving additional powers to the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to issue bonds for public improvement.

When such Senators as Messrs. HALE and LODGE, who, whatever their political aberrations may be, are commonly supposed to be at least highly civilized persons, took ground against the carrying out of L'ENFANT'S plan of Washington, as adopted and made his own by WASHINGTON himself, people interested in such things might very well feel alarmed for the beauty of the capital.

Archbishop John M. Farley of this diocese arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Prinzessin Irene from his first visit to the new Pope, Pius X. A party of fifty prominent Catholic priests and laymen, including several of the newly created monsignori, attached to the new archiepiscopal court, went down the bay in the steamboat Favorite to greet him.
TANU, March 31. -- News has been received here of severe fighting, the Tibetans having attacked the British mission under Col Younghusband.

So an old song has it, and judging from the condition of risibility to which Margaret Winn has reduced herself and every one with whom she has come in contact in the last six weeks, the song is right.

The writer has been considerably interested in reading the various somewhat excited protests which have appeared recently in THE TIMES, Post, , against granting permission to the various National Guard organizations in the city to drill in Central Park certain afternoons of each week.

TOKIO, March 31. -- At a meeting of Americans and Japanese held in this city to-day in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the signing of the Perry treaty between Japan and the United States, an American war charity, called the Perry Memorial Relief Fund, was organized with much enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The House to-day adopted an amendment to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, providing that no appropriation shall be made to any State or Territorial home for soldiers that maintains a bar or canteen where intoxicating liquors are sold.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The "joker" which Senator Dowling discovered in a Buffalo election bill introduced by Senator Davis several days ago, and which permitted a board consisting of the Attorney General, the Secretary of State, and the Chairman of a proposed State voting commission, to saddle voting machines on the City of New York without the consent of the city authorities, reappeared to-day. The joker meant the mandatory expenditure by the city of $730,000.

The Hearst movement is a natural incident of Democratic convalescence from a prostrating attack of Bryanism. For four years, from 1896 to 1900, the party was sick unto death. It rallied after the second defeat of Mr. BRYAN. It was expelling the poison from its system, and has been visibly getting stronger everyday.

MILWAUKEE, March 31. -- "The Shogun," a new comic opera by George Ade and Gustav Luders, was produced for the first time, under Henry W. Savage's management, at the Davidson Theatre to-night. The opera proved a pronounced success. The scenes are laid in Korea, and the production is well staged.

I have been interested in reading, what a few of your corespondents have had to say about excessive gas bills. I submit the following, at the risk of suggesting what may already have been suggested, and, for all I know, somewhere adopted.

The subject matter of the article "Enemies of the Republic" is of transcending importance, and the readers of THE TIMES are under obligation to you for reproducing in part the views of Mr. Steffens thereon, as expresed in McClure's Magazine.

Even though it be official, one has to view with suspicion that dispatch from Vladivostok telling how a whale ran into one of the harbor mines, which thereupon vindicated its efficiency by comminuting the whale. It is doubtless true that a whale, if he pressed against a submarine mine, with the weight and momentum of an average battleship, say with intention to relieve an itching under-surface, might explode that mine.

The subject matter of the article "Enemies of the Republic" is of transcending importance, and the readers of THE TIMES are under obligation to you for reproducing in part the views of Mr. Steffens thereon, as expresed in McClure's Magazine.

Even though it be official, one has to view with suspicion that dispatch from Vladivostok telling how a whale ran into one of the harbor mines, which thereupon vindicated its efficiency by comminuting the whale. It is doubtless true that a whale, if he pressed against a submarine mine, with the weight and momentum of an average battleship, say with intention to relieve an itching under-surface, might explode that mine.

ALBANY, March 31. -- An extraordinary occurrence took place here to-day in the arrest by the Sheriff of Albany County of four short-term prisoners from the Albany County Penitentiary, in a house on Clinton Avenue.

The officials of the Pacific Express Company have been victimized by a gold brick. For a week the company has been guarding at its main office, 414 North Fourth Street, what it supposed to be a genuine gold brick. It came invoiced as "one gold brick." On this evidence the train messenger saw it safely into the train safe and saw it locked up in the burglar-proof vaults at headquarters.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The home rule bill giving to the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the right to issue bonds for a municipal ferry service, for a telegraph system for the use of the Police and Fire Departments, and for maps of all of the territory embraced in the boroughs of the city, is said by Democrats to contain a neat little Republican joker.

FORT SMITH, Ark., March 31. -- Judge Rogers of the Federal Court to-day, upon application of Judge James H. Read of this city, counsel for John Degeoijen of Holland appointed Leo Haight receiver of the Southwestern Portland Cement Works, situated at White Cliff, Ark.

BOSTON, March 31. -- The protected cruiser Denver, which was built by Neafie Levy of Philadelphia, had been second Government speed trial over the Cape Ann course to-day, and again failed to reach her contract requirements of 17 knots per hour, her average speed being 16.70 knots.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 31. -- Col. George R. Fearing arrived here to-day.

A leader, not a cause, is the greatest need of the Democratic Party to-day, and of all the prominent men in that party two alone are marked by the possession of this quality -- Mr. Cleveland and Mr. John Sharp Williams. Mr. Parker has never led anything, Mr. Olney does not possess the necessary magnetism, Mr. Bryan has had his day, and Mr. Gorman is discredited, while Mr. Hearst can only head backwards.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Secretary Hay has received a personal note from Herbert W. Bowen, the American Minister at Caracas, briefly recounting a recent experience he has had with President Castro.

Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE, now safely ensconced, it is to be presumed, in his more or less ancestral Skibo, has no doubt been cheered by the tidings that HERBERT SPENCER posthumously agrees with him about the demerits of the Iliad. For the frank Philistinism of his avowal of heresy on this point, Mr. CARNEGIE received various missiles from a ribald American press.

Three hours were consumed yesterday afternoon in rounding the Deutschland into her dock at Hoboken. As the steamship reached the end of her pier the tide was running out strongly, and before the fleet of tugs could push her into her berth, left the liner stranded on the mud bank, where she had to remain until the returning tide lifted her off.

BOSTON, March 31. -- Hetty Green, by a decision of the Supreme Court, is the defendant in a suit in Suffolk County in which the plaintiff is the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company. The action is one to recover $1,105.88 said to have been paid by the plaintiff for taxes on land of the defendant.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- A trophy which will be competed for each year by the vessels of the navy has been received by Secretary Moody. It is in raised gold, and shows two battleships in action.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 31. -- A finding that the sealed letter by which Philo S. Bennett expressed a wish that $50,000 should be given to William Jennings Bryan and his family was not a part of the last will of Mr. Bennett was returned by the jury to-day in the Superior Court in the trial of Mr. Bryan's appeal from the decision of the Probate Court.

Much alarm has been occasioned by the rapid approach of a peculiar epidemic which, in fact, is really a plague. The danger is acknowledged to be greater in big cities where the heterogeneous composition of a large boarding house population and the close contact of great numbers of persons, very differently constituted in down-town business offices, contribute largely to the spread of the malady.

Upon his return to England after a year spent in the United States, the well-known British artist succumbed to the temptation to write a book. But by so doing he did not deliver himself into the hands of his enemy. On the contrary, these notes and impressions of America should make for him many friends.

Now that the seventh and final volume has been added to a series of school readers published by D.C. Heath Co., with the title "The Heart of Oak Books," the general public may be surprised to learn that the editor is Prof. Charles Eliot Norton of Harvard, although this fact must have been well known to those whose duty it is to select books for juvenile instruction.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 1. -- The Associated Press is officially informed that up to the present the Government has received no news to confirm the statement sent by a new agency from Tokio that the Japanese made another attack on Port Arthur during the night of March 30 and 31.

McClure, Phillips Co. are publishing this week "By the Fireside," by Charles Wagner, author of "The Simple Life "; "The Picaroons," by Gelett Burgess and Will Irwin, joint authors of "The Reign of Queen Isyl "; "Susannah and One Other," by Mme. Maria Albanesi, and "Daughters of Desperation," by Hildegard Brooks.

Ernest H. Wallace, the Republican Assemblyman from the Thirty-first Assembly District, and the father of the Wallace Transfer bill, which relieves street railroads from giving transfers at corners where many people meet, attended a meeting of the Republican Club of his bailiwick, at 320 Lenox Avenue, last night.

TROY, Ohio, April 1. -- The Miami River to-day reached a higher stage than ever known before. About noon the levee above the State Dam broke under the heavy strain, and the water came rushing down upon the city without a moment's warning. That section of Troy known as Nineveh was soon inundated, and the water to-night stands from four to six feet deep in the streets.

Because Mrs. Annie Roberts of 146 West Twenty-seventh Street objected to borrowing a neighbor's tub in which to do the family washing, her husband, William Roberts, a janitor, caused her to be arraigned before Magistrate Barlow in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

THE AUTHOR, a little paper established by the Society of Authors, as its official organ, made a suggestion the other day to the effect that the income of authors ought not to be subject to income tax. Says The Author, when a man builds and sells a house, his income tax is not assessed on the full amount of the money which he receives, but only on the profits he has made by the transaction.

Doubtless the Secretary of the Navy is simply falling into line in declaring that "The Star-Spangled Banner" is the National air of this country, and in consequently de-officializing "Hail, Columbia!" It is rather a pity, too. "Hail, Columbia!" is at least an American tune, which the other is not.

ALBANY, N. Y., April 1. -- For the first quarter of this year there were 1,181 new stock corporations formed under the laws of New York. This is the record for any quarter, and is larger than the total number for an entire year under the old law. 'The companies incorporated to-day are as follows:
Anent the little girl saving the lives of others at a fire by means of a lie.

Nobody smoked gift cigars yesterday, for the date seemed to glare on every band. The explosive cheroot was not much in evidence, however, because the joke was too old, and the vendors foresaw that. But, nevertheless, the fiend of April 1 was in the land with jokes that were new, tricks that were old, and fool games that were simply rehashed.

LONDON, April 2. -- The India Office has issued long dispatches sent by Col. Younghusband, commanding the British mission to Tibet, through Lord Curzon, the Viceroy of India, which confirm the story of The Associated Press concerning the engagement between the British and Tibetans near Guru yesterday.

Those who were interested in the Attempt when the Record was first published fifteen years ago, will be pleased to know that it has succeeded at least to the extent of justifying a second edition of the book, with a short preface telling in a few words the story of the period which has elapsed.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1. -- The Democratic primaries in this city to-night to elect delegates to the State Convention that will name delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis resulted in the signal defeat for the supporters of William R. Hearst. The Hearst people carried but one of the fourteen wards.

In the preface to his new two-volume history of England during twenty-five years, Sir Spencer Walpole gives his reasons for naming it "The History of Twenty-five Years, l856- 1870," and not the "History of England":

With a step as light and springy as that of a youth, his cheeks tanned and with the ruddy glow given them by a Southern sun, Hugh McLaughlin returned to Brooklyn from an extended vacation in Florida last night. He was as full of war as ever - "fit for the fight of my life," as he expressed it.

Dr. J.N. Larned's "History of the United States for Secondary Schools," (Houghton, Mifflin Co., $1.40,) is a worthy successor of his well-known "History for Ready Reference" that is found in every library in the country. This schoolbook has been prepared in full accord with the views set forth in the report of the "Committee of Seven," appointed by the American Historical Association in 1896 "to consider the subject of history in the secondary schools."

The examination of Edwin Hawley and Frank H. Ray as witnesses in the bankruptcy proceedings against Daniel J. Sully Co. was begun yesterday before Thomas Alexander, United States Commissioner, sitting as a Special Examiner in the United States District Court. The courtroom was filled with an interested crowd, consisting mainly of creditors, newspaper reporters, and clerks for the principals in the proceedings.

Historical novels most worthy the name are seldom those built upon the records of a remote past, and attempting to reconstruct a period and a society imperfectly apprehended. They are those which seize history in the making, telling their stories as Aeneas related his, or gathering them from a generation not yet departed.

One of the most popular and most prolific of the modern Spanish authors is B. Perez Galdos. His dry wit, his wonderful command of the language, and his frequent use of old proverbs, all tend to put him in the first rank. Among his works, one of the most interesting is "Dona Perfecta." The story is laid in a small village of Spain.

In this last novel by Mrs. Craigle, as in the one bearing the name of John Oliver Hobbes which immediately preceded it, one may look in vain for the clever epigrams and the witty dialogue which were so frequent in the earlier works of this author. It may be that the Book of Job, which was the power to kindle in the case of "The Vineyard," was also the power to restrain.

In our classified lists of Spring books the preponderance of works of American writers in the department of fiction is a significant feature. The vogue of the native novel seems to be increasing rather than diminishing. One prominent publishing house the fiction list of which used to contain 95 per cent. of English novels to 5 per cent. by American writers has just reversed the proportion.

ODESSA, April 1. -- Odessa to-day enthusiastically received the survivors of the gunboat Korietz and the cruiser Variag, which were destroyed by the Japanese in the battle of Che-mul-pho. The Russian steamship Malaya with the survivors aboard came in sight this afternoon, and the salvo from the great guns announced the fact.
Since there is a movement on foot among literary men to suppress the use of certain title phrases which have become tiresome, would it not be well to include "He who runs may read" in the list?

THE John Murray edition of Byron, latest to be published by that great house which has first and last put forth so many, comprises thirteen volumes. Its reprint here by Charles Scribner's Sons is completed in the seventh volume of the poetry.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Senate spent Good Friday in a political discussion which hinged upon the so-called service pension order of Secretary Hitchcock and the irregularities in the Post Office Department, but had comparatively little to do with either of these subjects, touching more vitally upon the rival Democratic and Republican candidates who are to run for President.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, April 1. -- Capt. R.F. Scott, R.N., of the Discovery says that the Winter of 1903 passed pleasantly and that the members of the expedition enjoyed much greater comfort than in 1902 Sledging operations began in September under severe conditions, owing to extremely low temperatures, which frequently fell to 60 degrees below zero.

PARIS, April 1. -- Bonaparte Wyse, the original concessionaire of the Panama Canal, in an interview to-day criticising the Panama Canal decision, says he has been moved by the loftiest motives, mainly to prevent the new company from absorbing three-quarters of the payment to be made by the United States, and thus depriving the old company of its just share.

A volume of short stories is shortly to be brought out in this country by John Lane, entitled "The Saint and the Outlaw and Other Stories," by Michael Wood. These tales are an exposition of mental phases, said to be unfolded in a way to interest everybody. The opening story, which gives the book its title, deals with conscience.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1. -- Floriana Belle, quoted in some books at 100 to 1, took the last race at Oakland to-day. There was a quiet play on the filly at 50 to 1 when the field went to the post. She got away well, and at once went to the front. Ebony passed her before the stretch was reached, but he tired and stumbled, losing much ground.

Our neighbor The Sun thinks there is "a lesson of profound significance in the comments of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S special friends in the press upon the prospect that Judge PARKER will be the Democratic nominee." As it becomes more and more probable that Judge PARKER will be nominated "the satisfaction of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S friends becomes more joyfully manifest."

The volume of "Lectures on Commerce," which the University of Chicago Press is issuing, is a description of the practical working of several departments of modern business by well-known men. It is made up of papers read before the College of Commerce and Administration in the University of Chicago, and treats of subjects of value to economists, railroad men, investors, and commercial educators.

GOV. ODELL indicated this morning the sort of campaign that will be made in this State against Judge PARKER if he is nominated for President. When the Governor was asked: "How do you like the prospect of a fight against PARKER?" he replied: "There is too much Hillism in the Parker movement to have a healthy growth."

The building situation was further complicated yesterday by a strike of the Elevator Contractors' and Millwrights' Union, notwithstanding the fact that it had accepted the arbitration agreement of the Employers' Association. The union demands an increase in wages from $4.25 to $5.25 a day, as well as other changes in the present condition.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Charles P. McClelland, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by Tiffany Co. against the assessment of 20 per cent. duty on fifteen Russian sable skins imported Oct. 21, 1902. The skins had been subjected to a dressing process, but when about to be made up into garments had to be undressed.

THIS instructive and entertaining book on the standard of pronunciation in English, albeit it is less pretentious in point of interest and scholarship, deserves to rank with Prof. Lounsbury's learned and voluminous "Studies in Chaucer," which appeared more than a decade ago.

THIS volume is one which afforded the reviewer unmixed pleasure to read. He read it with untiring interest from cover, and did not find a dull page in it. The average reader will find in it both instruction and entertainment.

A man who gave his name as Frank Smith walked into the Adams Street Police Station, Brooklyn, a little while before midnight last night, and asked to be locked up, saying that he had killed a man. In his pocket was found the card of Arthur Benson of 420 Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, who has been missing for a week.

CONTRARY to our expectation the interest of this second volume of Mr. Villard's Memoirs is equal to that of the first; but it is charactered on different lines, once we have got beyond Book VII., with which Mr. Villard's relation of his experience of wars and fighting comes to a sudden close.

After all the sane Democratic voters shall have eliminated from their lists of candidates for the Presidency the clowns and demagogues, and shall instruct the delegates to the convention for any true and respectable Democrat, the chances for a Democratic victory have never been better than this year.
LONDON, April l. -- Arthur Golding's translation of Ovid's "Metamorphoses," which first appeared in 1567, and has been out of print about 200 years, is to reappear as a volume of the Temple Classics.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 1. -- Although no official expression regarding the victory of the British expedition to Tibet is obtainable to-night, it is certain that the matter will not attract the attention which it would have attracted before the outbreak of the war with Japan.

In what school did Dr. PARKHURST learn his morals? His manners, we assume, are largely his own. Nothing but stubborn idiosyncracy could have kept them what they are during his many years of habitual association with people of ordinary kindliness, decency, and self-respect.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 1. -- "The history of this concern forms one of the blackest chapters in the financial experience of this county," said Senator Edgar T. Brackett to-day concerning the United States Shipbuilding Company, at a hearing given before Justice D. Cady Herrick of the Supreme Court.
Mr. Johnson's vigorous objection to my review of "A Century of Expansion" prompts me to ask space for a word in response.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 1. -- The Novoe Vremya, referring to the visits of the Kaiser and President Loubet to Italy, declares that the connecting link between the Triple and Dual Alliances is the sincere sympathy with Russia cherished by the States composing the two alliances.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1. -- John H. Fimple, Assistant Commissioner in the United States General Land Office, testified in the Hyde-Diamond land fraud case to-day. He is a witness for the prosecution, but was called, under protest, by the attorneys for the defense. He stated that about fifty-three forest reservations, comprising 2,000,000 acres, had been created under the act of March 30, 1888.

A BOOK by Dr. Edward Moore of the Precincts, Canterbury, is always an event for Danteists. It comes as a new revelation to a cult from its most profound, distinguished, and respected teacher and prophet.

Senator Platt and Gov. Odell held a two-hour conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon and decided upon the men who are to be temporary and permanent Chairmen of the Republican State Convention. Several other subjects were taken up and thrashed out. Such things as were not settled, Senator Platt declared, would be when "he returned from Washington."

THE cause and cure of Irish ills are not chiefly political, broaden or narrow our conception of politics as we will; they are not chiefly religious, whatever be the effect of Roman Catholic influence upon the practical side of the people's life; they are not chiefly economic, be the actual poverty of the people and the potential wealth of the country what they may.

JOHN LANE will publish here this Spring a new novel by Charles Kennett Burrow, author of "Asteck's Madonna," "Patricia of the Hills," "The Lifted Shadow," It will be entitled "The Yeoman," and is the story of a man's love for his ancestral home.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The Treasury statement for March shows that there has been an increase in the available cash balance since March 1 of $1,631,490, that balance now standing at $224,699,996. A decline in disbursements compared with February 1904, and with March, 1903, explains the gain in the cash balance.

JOHN DAVIDSON is an English poet of good parts, a contriver of melodious lyrics who has also produced some lofty measures, a poet with a taste for the drama rather than a knack of dramatic construction; a writer of lucid and agreeable prose.

All of the commercial motor vehicles that have entered for the service test to be held next week under the auspices of the Automobile Club of America are expected to appear to-day at a garage at Eighth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, to be weighed and receive their official numbers. Eighteen machines are entered in six different classes.

Sidney Johnston Haydon, a well-known railroad man, who for the last year and a half lived in the Holley, an apartment hotel at 36 Washington Square West, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by jumping from the twenty-first story of the new "Forty-two Broadway" Building.
On the subject of trade conditions Dun's Review says in its issue of to-day: ...
The editor of "Christabel" in the Aldine edition seems just in this predicament, missing the under-nose meaning that a schoolboy in one of my classes detected at once.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The fight against the new Post Office for the City of New York, conducted by Congressmen who know little of the needs of New York City, and whose personal interest in the matter is rather difficult to explain, was continued to-day in the Senate, where, the opposition from Senator Patterson having carried the discussion to nearly 6 o'clock, several Senators demanded that the vote should not be taken until further debate.

I was glad to read your tribute to the extraordinary ghost story by Henry James, "The Turn of the Screw," which is by all odds the greatest tale of the supernatural in the English language, and makes commonplace such stories as F. Marion Crawford's "The Upper Berth" and other conventional "hair-raisers."

THE editorial notice of the late Sir Edwin Arnold in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 25, while granting to him the full measure of praise as a journalist and a scholar, may, it seems to me, challenge debate in its estimate of his poetry.
The Keramic Studio is published monthly in Syracuse, and contains handsomely illustrated articles of interest to the amateur potter and decorator.

Horace C. Polhemus was examined before Justice Gaynor in the Motion Term of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday in a suit brought by Else Polhemus to compel the return of moneys paid to him by the Directors of the John Polhemus Printing Company when they bought the plant of the Excelsior Press. The amount paid by the Directors was $16,000.
A movement is on foot among prominent silk importers at this port toward effecting, if possible, an increase in the force of United States Examiners who handle silks.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 1. -- Harvard's 'Varsity crew has been seriously handicapped by the loss of three of its best oarsmen. Capt. Dillingham, who has been laid aside with a felon, and Lawson and Filley, who have the grip. The absence of these men from practice even for a short time will prove a big obstacle in the development of the crew.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 1. -- The New York National League players were in great batting form to-day and they easily defeated the Nashville team of the Southern League, the score being 17 to 9. Eighteen singles, with a total of thirty-two hits, including three home runs, two three-base hits, and two for two bases, was the record of the visitors.

Charles Scribner's Sons have made arrangements to bring out in their Library of Art, edited by S. Arthur Strong, fourteen or fifteen new volumes, beside "Romney," by Humphry Ward and W. Roberts, and "Impressionist Painting: Its Genesis and Development," by Wynford Dewhurst, to follow the three volumes that have already appeared -" Donatello," by Lord Balcarres; "Michelangelo Buonarotti," by Charles Halroyd, and "French Painting in the Sixteenth Century," by L. Dimier.

-- Those confident predictions to which we referred yesterday, that the backers of what for convenience is called the Westchester trolley scheme were about to give up their fight for Aldermanic favor and leave the field clear for the Port Chester people, seem to have been made without consultation with those upon whose purposes the fate of the predictions depend.

That story is a little disquieting which sets forth that the lady who is the chatelaine of the Russian Embassy in Washington has announced her intention to give some sort of entertainment for the benefit of the Russian Red Cross Society, and that some ladies of the Cabinet and of the President's family have announced their intention of assisting at this function.

The action of the Grand Jury in the matter of the Darlington collapse is something of a surprise. That ALLISON, the manager of the syndicate of owners, should have been deemed primarily culpable was to have been expected. The building seems to have been as he wanted it.

SANTOS-DUMONT'S story of his career as an enthusiast of aerial, navigation makes, especially in the earlier portion of the narrative, very good reading. Much of what he says has about it the air (no word-play is intended) of the man who does things.
