SACRAMENTO, Cal., April 1. -- Three masked men have held up the Oregon Express, south-bound, on the Southern Pacific Railroad, at Copley, near Keswick, killed W.J. O'Neil, the express messenger, and carried off the contents of the express box.

Very appropriately are crossed rapiers the cover decoration of "Sir Mortimer," for in this novel, even more than in its predecessors, "Cut and Thrust" are its author's favorite heroes. Love, passionate, pure, unswerving, runs like a golden thread through the story. The life and color of "the spacious times of great Elizabeth" glow upon its pages.

Unlike Mr. Hamilton Wright Mable, in his "William Shakespeare: Poet, Dramatist, and Man," Mrs. Boas does not attempt by sheer dint of visualization to present an imaginative illusion of the past. She confines herself to records and to contemporary historians and biographers, and despises neither the intelligence nor the imagination of her reader.

The singularly unenlightened opposition of the rural members of the Assembly has finally killed for this session the Bostwick bill for a uniform registration tax on mortgages. We do not see how they could figure out anything but advantage for their constituents from the operation of the bill, but they were apparently animated by a feeling of jealousy toward the capitalists of the cities, and with such a feeling it is hard to reason.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The report of Lieut. C.L. Hussey, who commanded the naval escort which accompanied Consul General Skinner on his diplomatic expedition to Abyssinia, made public at the Navy Department to-day, gives interesting details.

Two new books dealing with the Dantesque theme are announced for early publication; a new translation of Dante's "De Monarchia," by Aurelia Henry, and "Dante's Influence on English Poetry," by Oscar W. Kuhns of Wesleyan University. Prof. Kuhns has been highly praised by Prof. Pio Rajna of Florence, whom Florentines delight to call the greatest living Danteist.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Honors were pretty well divided at the Benning track to-day, two favorites, two second choices, and two outsiders winning. Paul Clifford, the favorite in the fifth race, won his third victory of the meeting, with Jockey Burns up. Burns also rode Scotch Thistle, the winner in the last race.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- "Hello, hello! Is this the Highlands apartment house?" asked a voice over the telephone yesterday.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 1. -- Lieut. Commander Edgar Townsend Warburton, Chief Engineer of the battleship Maine, now at Pensacola, sent a bullet through his brain to-day, death resulting almost instantly. His fellow-officers are at a loss to understand his reasons for the act, as he has been in good spirits since the arrival of the ship at Pensacola.
The scope and aim of "Mankind in the Making," the new book by H.G. Wells, author of "The War of the Worlds," "Anticipations," , is set forth in his preface as follows:

The walls occupied not long ago by the Portrait Show at 6 East Twenty-third Street, are now held by a collection which might seem at first glance an exhibition of old painted likenesses. It is, however, a collection of pictures from the galleries of two leading art dealers, one being the New York branch of Messrs.

Senator PATTERSON was amply justified in demanding that Senator CLARK of Wyoming should give the name of the man who, he declared, had boasted at a public banquet of contributing $25,000 to promote the passage of a land bill through Congress. We do not see how Mr. CLARK can decently decline to give the name and also the name of the "ten-thousand-dollar lobbyist," who, he said, was in charge of the interests of certain railways.

For any readers, if any there be, who desire to make a return upon their former, or present, judgment, of Walt Whitman and his pretensions as poet and proser, the current Atlantic provides an opportunity. Those who find the inducement not sufficient, considering the shortness of life, may be consoled by the assurance that they do not lose much by not reading that article -- or this one.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Senator Clark of Wyoming declined to-day to name the men whom he stated before the Senate yesterday were employed as a lobby at Washington to bring about a repeal of the land and homestead laws. Senator Clark says, however, that he will privately give the names to any Senator who wants them.

Declarations from the Carter Handicap of the Queens County Jockey Club became due yesterday, and an early count showed that eighteen horses had been withdrawn. This list will be swelled considerably when the mails are received, and of the seventy-eight entries, most of the top weights will doubtless be absentees.

THOMAS E. WATSON, particularly remembered by his "Life of Napoleon" and "Story of France," if not on account of the controversy aroused by his "Life and Times of Thomas Jefferson," has written a novel which will be published in the late Spring by D. Appleton Co.

Mr. Alden's London letter of last Saturday mentions as "something quite new" a very recent suggestion in a London newspaper "that one's brain may inherit a memory of something known only to the brain of an ancestor."

Beginning with a bare mention of the fact that it was French Catholics who first preached the Christian faith in Western New York, the Rev. Hr. Hayes tells here the story of Anglican missionary effort among the Mohawks and Oneidas in the last years of the seventeenth century, and progressively till the Revolution, Indian missioning in that time giving place gradually to the establishment of churches for the settlers who were taking the Indians' lands.

IN the eloquent and excellent "Introduction" which Mr. Steffens prefixes to these articles of his on municipal corruption, (reprinted from McClure's Magazine,) he dedicates the volume, "a record of shame and yet of self-respect," to "the accused -- to all the citizens of all the cities in the United States."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 1. -- S.D. Barstow, Superintendent of the Western Division of Wells, Fargo Co., said to-day that there was not much money in the express safes blown up by the robbers at Copley. There were no valuables from the East in the car.

BANGOR, April 2. -- A few years ago, when some one suggested the construction of an electric railway from Moosehead Lake up the Allegash River, through the very heart of the Northern Maine wilderness, there was scarcely a man in the State who believed that such a thing would be possible, and the would-be promoter of the wildwood trolley scheme was ridiculed into silence.

This behavior of the market has been made the subject of a lively controversy in the press. The anti-Bourse newspapers make it the basis for an attack upon the Bourse itself; while the press of the commercial and financial classes point out that the phenomenon complained of is to be attributed largely to Germany's unfortunate Bourse legislation.

Business on the Stock Exchange on Saturday was about what might have been expected of a half holiday, coming between holidays on both sides of the ocean. The volume shrunk to 119,000 shares, and among fifty active stocks changes were about equally divided between advances and declines, with only one exceeding a point.

The market has not yet shaken itself free from Northern Securities influence. The decision dissolving the concern dominated one week; the company's plan of liquidation dominated its successor; and last week the market had for its chief topic some rearrangement of relations between other companies in similar economic relation.

IN recent years pessimists of the male sex have complained bitterly that women were invading the business occupations of men and have predicted that sooner or later men would need to go out of their natural sphere to find profitable employment.

West Point won the intercollegiate fencing team championship at the New York Athletic Club last night, largely through the excellent work of F.W. Honeycutt, Captain of the team, who was the only one of twenty-one competitors to win all his eighteen bouts. This gives the Military Academy the possession of the Racquet and Tennis Club trophy for the coming year, while Honeycutt wins the gold medal for the best individual work.
CHICAGO, April 2. -- A special cable from a Chicago Daily News staff correspondent from Tokyo says:

LONDON, April 2. -- Operations on the Stock Exchange this week were confined to the four days preceding Good Friday and were concerned for the most part in arranging for settlement. Dealings in securities were on a very limited scale. Prices, however, were generally firm, buoyed up, no doubt, by holes of cheaper money after the holidays and an early reduction in the bank rate.

Something of a stir was caused last week among the litigants in the American Malting suit for the recovery of dividends alleged to have been paid out of capital, and in other suits in which it is charged that dividends had been improperly paid by Directors, by the bill introduced at Albany last Monday by Senator Brackett, amending the provisions of the New York statutes concerning the liabilities of Directors in such cases.

PARIS, April 2. -A. L.' Drummond[, exChief of the United States Secret Service, to-day arrested Iakc Nebenzahl of New York, on a requisition from the State Department at WVashington, on the charge of embezzlement.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 2. -- Representative Jesse E. Overstreet, Chairman of the House Committee on Post Offices, was renominated this afternoon by the Republicans of the Seventh District by acclamation. Delegates to the National Convention were instructed for President Roosevelt.

COURAGE mounteth with occasion," wrote William Shakespeare; and numberless instances both before and since the writing have proved the statement true. But the honors for the fittest exemplification of the poet's words -- at least within the present age -- must fall to a colony of wealthy young men who are adding to the fame of Hempstead, L.I., through their deeds of Spartan bravery.

CINCINNATI, April 2. -- It is believed that in the arrest of James Taylor here to-day the police may solve the mystery of the big theft of jewels worth $5,000 from the Palm Beach Inn, at Palm Beach, Fla., several weeks ago, in which New York society people lost diamonds and other valuables worth thousands of dollars.

LONDON, April 2. -- The slaughter in Tibet has roused much feeling in Great Britain, and it is possible that Col. Younghusband will not be allowed to proceed further with the expedition. He has seventy-five miles more to travel before he reaches Gyangste, where he has been ordered to stop and parley before actually demanding entrance into ancient Lhassa, distant another 160 miles.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 2. -- The opening of the lacrosse season here to-day in the first of the intercollegiate series between teams of Johns Hopkins and Columbia Universities was as interesting as perfect weather, fine playing, and a large crowd could make it. Columbia was easily defeated by the score of 7 goals to 1.

NEW BRUNSWICK, April 2. -- Articles of incorporation for the New Jersey Short Line Railroad Company were filed at the office of the Secretary of State at Trenton this morning. The object of the company is to extend the electric line of the Trenton and New Brunswick Railroad Company from their present terminus at Milltown to Elizabeth.

Cold bleak weather and the players wholly out of shape were the conditions under which the lacrosse season was opened yesterday by the Crescent Athletic Club team and the representatives of the College of the City of New York. Only four or five of the champion twelve presented themselves upon the field for the first time this year, and naturally there were some misgivings as to their chances of winning.

ALBANY, April 2. -- Gov. Odell intimated to-night his confidence that the so-called grab bills are unlikely to be enacted into law. In speaking of the approaching end of the Legislature and the agitation over the "grabs," the Governor said:
MRS. ALTON B.B. PARKER, wife of the Chief Justice, is a direct descendant of one of the early Dutch settlers of New York State.

LOOKING over some pictures at a bric-a-brac shop a visitor was attracted by a nice little landscape, rather messy, but pleasant in tones, and found it signed, by a name that ended in "uf," as if it were Russian or Polish. Looking closer, the visitor asked the man in charge:

As an indication that the New York Lawn Tennis Club intends to foster the sport among women players, it is building a fine and commodious clubhouse especially designed for women on the grounds at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. This new house is 35 feet long by nearly 20 feet in width, and is equipped with a dainty reception room and adequate locker space.

Your editorial in to-day's issue and most of the discussion appearing from day to day in the press on the subject of the bricklayers' strike seems to me to miss one important point. The National Fireproofing Company is seeking to secure control of the setting of its own material for the very commendable reason that better results will thus be obtained.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 2. -- Mrs. Samuel Goodman, wife of Samuel Goodman of the New York Central Railroad, had a narrow escape from death this morning while driving near the railroad station at Irvington.

A BLAZE of scarlet and a dash of emerald green brightened James Henry Smith's four-in-hand coach as it was tooled swiftly up Fifth Avenue at noon one day last week. On the box seat by Mr. Smith sat Mrs. William Rhinelander Stewart. Her oval black hat had a scarlet crown and her loose black coat a wide collar to match the crown.

Endangered. The recent decision against the Northern Securities Company under which it has been made impossible to combine two competing railroads in a holding company was followed last week by some curious developments in the stock market. There was for several days heavy buying of the shares of various Western railroads, including Union Pacific, Atchison, Missouri Pacific, and Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 2. -- Gen. Levaskoff, Director of Military Communications of the General Staff, talking about the Russian line of communications, says:
KING EDWARD, like many another sensible man, occasionally takes great pleasure in telling a joke on himself. This is his favorite:
What the Return of Its Original Holdings of Northern Pacific Would Mean to Union Pacific in Annual Revenue.

ST. MARY'S, Ohio, April 2. -- Great alarm was caused here to-day by a strong southwest gale that dashed the waters against the eastern bank of the Grand Reservoir in its weakest places. The water broke through at different places, but not in an uncontrollable manner in any one place. Every little leak or overflow was at once taken in charge by a gang of men.
BERLIN, April 2. -- While foreign newspaper reports of the condition of the Kaiser's health are exaggerated, they have a basis of truth.
PARIS, March 18. -- Spiritualism and hypnotism are out of favor in Paris just now, for another case of gross swindling has been brought to light.
A PROFESSIONAL woman who was going up town the other night from Park Row heard an amusing conversation between a couple of her own sex, who got on the car chattering and oblivious to eavesdroppers.

WHILE Maine has a number of sturdy, fearless men patrolling the forests and streams to detect violations of the fish and game laws, none is more useful than the special official known as "Lobster Warden," who is employed by the State to protect one of its choicest industries. Like the big game of Maine, the lobster was threatened at one time with extinction.

Navigation having opened on both the Hudson and Hackensack Rivers it is possible for brick manufacturers to begin again to do business. With only about one-third as much surplus on hand as they usually have at this season, dealers and makers have been more anxious about the opening of navigation than they usually are.

ALBANY, April 2. -- Gov. Odell returned to Albany to-day from his talk with Senator Platt, and is understood to be in a more friendly mood toward the suggestion of the candidacy of Elihu Root for Governor than has heretofore been his. If the nomination should be offered to Mr. Root it is not expected that Mr. Root would stand on his declaration that he would not again enter public life.

DURING the three months that Mayor McClellan has been in office he has changed somewhat. He has aged little, but it is a very kindly aging, just that which comes to a man who has bartered, enthusiasm and hope for realities and fruition.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 2. -- Judge Samuel Utley, in the Central District Court, created a stir this forenoon by denouncing in unmeasured terms the Rev. Roland A. Nichols, pastor of the Highland Street Church of Christ in this city, and members of his congregation, who had appeared in court this morning to testify in a suit growing out of an oil stock venture of Mr. Nichols.

A man who said he was Charles Hoffman of 404 Eighth Avenue was arrested in a Sixth Avenue dry goods store yesterday afternoon and was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station on a charge of forgery. The police say that the man's name is Carl Fiess, and that they have been trying to catch him for two months.

When the monarch of old placed his chair by the sea and commanded the waves not to wet his feet, he did so to demonstrate the supremity of nature. When Daniel J. Sully nailed the price of cotton to the clouds and dared any one to pull it down, he did not see those old-time brothers Supply and Demand climb on each other's shoulders to take his dare and prove his folly.

In April our Spring really begins, and however worn and wrinkled old Father Time may appear at other seasons, in the Springtime he always seems to renew his youth and be young again. The month of April brings us the opening buds, begins life, as it were, with a frolic, as it enters laughing.

Judge Alton B. Parker was present at a lunch and conference held at the Manhattan Club yesterday afternoon, at which Justice Charles H. Truax and Harry D. Macdona were conferrees among others. Immediately following the breaking up of the conference Judge Parker hastened away from the city, to which he had come to attend the funeral of the son of Justice Morgan J. O'Brien.

Great curiosity has been shown recently by yachtsmen and automobilists who are interested in motor boats regarding the actual speed that the fastest of the new auto boats now being built will be able to attain this season. Extravagant statements have undoubtedly been made concerning the high speed that will be made by these boats, and many practical yachtsmen have thus far given no credence to these claims.

ONE day I sent to the editor of an illustrated London paper, which is almost as well known in America as in the land of its nativity, a brief and popularized account of an important new invention. The narrative was accompanied by a photograph which I had taken the day before showing two distinguished men, one of whom was Lord Kelvin, experimenting with the then new but now well known device.

THE impression you receive on meeting for the first time Judge Alton Brooks Parker, Chief Justice of the New York Court of Appeals and now a leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency, is likely to be that the Judge's personal appearance does not suggest his temperament or career.

We have happened to come across, in one of the magazines, the advertisement which is so much resented by a young woman of Rochester that she has taken steps to prevent the continued use of it. It represents a woman, of whom only the face and one arm are visible, parting the curtains of a circular screen standing in a bathtub, and looking out toward the spectator.

A party of New Yorkers is at present on its way to Mexico to make final arrangements for the purchase of three of the largest tobacco factories in that country. The price for the three factories is said to be in excess of $7,000,000. The largest of the three, the Bueno Tono, made net profits for 1903 of more than $600,000 on a paid up capital of $4,000,000.

CLARENCE CARY, who has been an ardent student of languages as well as a litterateur and a traveler, is perfecting himself in Japanese, Russian, and Chinese this Spring. He has professors for all three languages, and has been taking notes of their instructions with phonographs.

IN Jamaica, the most beautiful of the West Indian Islands, there slumbers beneath the smiling exterior of things a volcano of dark superstition and savage fanaticism, which occasionally becomes active with deadly results. The high priest of Obi, or the obeahman, as he is more commonly called, wields a power in the land that the stringent measures adopted against him by the British Government have been unable to put down.

Chairman Francis K. Pendleton of the City Beautiful Commission, which, by the way, now has changed its name to the New York City Improvement Commission, announced yesterday the list of his appointments to the committees of the main body. They are as follows:

MANCHURIA, the stake of the Russo-Japanese war, is the cradle of the Ta-Tsing or Holy Pure reigning family of China. Of its three provinces -- Mukden, or Shingking Kirin and Tsitsihar -- the Mikado's troops have invaded the first two. The plan seems to be the same as that worked out by Japan in the country three times before -- to half-circle the southern provinces and cut off the enemy's supplies.

There is a noteworthy tone of mildness in the comments of the English press on the statement from St. Petersburg via Paris concerning a possible understanding between Russia and Great Britain. This is matched by the St. Petersburg press in its discussion of the Tibet expedition.

A few minutes after the Scandinavian- American Line steamship United States reached her dock at Hoboken yesterday morning Emma Petersen, twenty years old, of Endelaven, Denmark, became the wife of T.E. Nielsen, chief machinist at the Washington Navy Yord. Miss Petersen came over here for just that.
TUNA, Tibet, April 2. -- The Tibetan General, the whole of his personal escort, and five high Lhassa officials were among the hundreds killed in the fighting of March 31 at Guru.

A State Appraiser's report, filed yesterday in the Surrogates' Court, shows that Leonard Lewisohn left an estate of $12,029,213 when he died on March 5, 1902. Of this $11,706,547 was personal and $322,666 real property. Deductions of funeral expenses, commissions of the executors and trustees, and stocks that had not been delivered at the time of his death brought the total down to $11,706,547 net.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 2. -- The result of the Democratic primaries in the fourteen districts in the town of Oyster Bay shows to-night that the Parker people carried the town. The Parker supporters were led by Senator Norton, while the unpledged voters were led by Congressman Scudder. In the Seventh District there were two sets of tickets in the field.

The work undertaken by Police Commissioner McADOO appears to represent the effort of a conscientious official toe establish the supremacy of law and to discharge as well as he is able the duties assumed by him when he took his oath of office. This is not a purpose to be trifled with or spoken of slightingly as if he were playing the bewildering game of "pigs in clover."

THE residents of Southern California have gone into partnership with the sun. There the sun is more plentiful than coal. and so they put the former to work, utilizing the heat rays for many purposes, one of which is known as the "solar water heater."

When a musical play calls itself "Piff! Paff!! Pouf!!!" and subjoins that it is a musical cocktail, one is prepared for the worst. The new play at the Casino last night was redeemed from that only by Eddie Foy, who was amiable, amusing as ever, and the so-called "original" English Pony Ballet, which made the hit of the evening and at one point raised a furore.

NEW YORK has the tea room habit. Not only the women but men find time for afternoon tea drinking in a quiet place with a few congenial friends, at an hour which does not interfere with the late dinner.

NASHVILLE, April 2. -- The New York National League team won another game from the local Southern League nine today through its superior ability to hit the ball and run the bases. The score was New York 9, Nashville 3, and it was the swiftest exhibition McGraw's men have put up on their practice tour.
BERLIN, March 23. -- Ernest von Hesse-Wartegg, the famous German traveler, husband of Minnie Hauck, relates some interesting facts on Korean life.

TALK about your training schools for policemen, firemen, soldiers, and sea fighters! Talk about the dangers or delights of co-education in schools and universities! In West Fourteenth Street there is a training school where one hundred or more young men and women, living under the same roof, are kept rigidly apart, except when called together for instruction in the art of courtship and marriage.

Two points on this oblate spheroid which we inhabit remain unknown and inaccessible, locked up from human curiosity by unknown leagues of impassable ice. Of the North Pole we know all that we would be likely to know if an explorer stood upon it and saw Polaris straight in front of him.

IN this age of transitions few institutions in America have changed more than the law office. The business of the lawyer of to-day isn't what it used to be -- and this is not written in the deprecating spirit in which certain "old timers" are wont to speak of "the good old days" of a generation ago.

AMONG the recent arrivals on the Pacific Coast from the Philippine Islands is a certain Lieutenant of infantry whose life story, stranger than any in fiction, is that of a man whose exploits in late years have won for him the cognomen of "The American Strickland." There are some who hold that Kipling's Strickland was an apprentice at the trade in which Rafferty excels.

Closely to follow the suit now pending in Massachusetts courts, in which Receiver Pepper of the Bay State Gas Company of Delaware seeks to have set aside the long series of transactions which he claims were responsible for the wrecking of that corporation and its dependencies, there is scheduled another that will be of even greater personal interest than the present one.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- A conspicuous feature in the Senate Chamber to-day was a large easel bearing upon it a series of pictures showing the effect of irrigation and the Wyoming tract of irrigated land which has been the subject of controversy in connection with the debate upon Mr. Gibson's bill for the repeal of the land laws.

Wearied with the day's business, I fell into my chair and mused. Yes, the rector read the Fourth Commandment with his wonted impressiveness, his frame thrilled while he said, "Thou shalt not do any manner of work thou, thy man servant, nor thy maid servant." I must have fallen into a doze, for I found myself walking down the leading avenue, somewhat before church time on Easter Day.

IT is rather difficult to get frank expression of opinion from actresses as to the merits or otherwise of their profession as a field for feminine employment. In most instances where the question is asked, "Should a woman adopt the stage as a career?" the answers deal in glittering generalities and an avoidance of the main issues is the common result.

OH, WONDERFUL child that can amaze its own mother! "As I turn over the pages of this book again," says Mr. Owen Wister in his preface to the theatrical edition of "The Virginian," an excerpt from which his press agent has distributed, "it seems impossible that any play at all could be made from a story which, by a long-cherished plan, was so deliberately picaresque.

Manufacturing clothiers are busy now preparing their sample garments for the Fall trade. The salesmen will start on the road with them about May 1. So far on account of the unseasonably late Spring, reorders on Spring and Summer goods have been light.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Chairman McCall, Representatives Hitt, Richardson of Alabama, and Bartlett went to the Arlington Hotel this morning and discussed with Postmaster General Payne at his bedside the special report involving members of Congress in the matter of clerk hire and leases at third and fourth class Post Offices.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -"It was just after the war," said Senator Carmack, who was discussing the race problem with several other Senators and some Representatives. "The Democrats in my neighborhood had hired a negro to campaign for them among his own race. He was addressing them with much fervor on the issues of the day and was denouncing the Northern radicals for their treatment of the Southern whites.

A new arrangement of the places for trading in a number of stocks on the floor of the Stock Exchange will be put into effect to-morrow, in line with a decision reached by the Exchange authorities late last week. The stocks at Posts 2 and 3 will be reversed, so that Metropolitan Street Railway and Rock Island will be bought and sold where in the past has centred the trading in the gas stocks.
PARIS, April 2. -- Jorge Holguin, financial agent of Colombia, who was behind the recent suit against the Panama Canal Company, said to-day:

The annual convention of the National Clothiers' Association will meet at 10:30 o'clock to-morrow morning in New Mercantile Hall, Philadelphia. Delegates from twenty of the leading clothing markets of the United States will be present, to the number of about 100 in all.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The feature of the racing at the Benning track to-day was the fifth Spring Hunters' Steeplechase, which was won handily by Tom Cogan, the professional riders landing one, two, three. The rest of the card was only fair in quality. Mr. Madden's City Bank made his first appearance of the year and ran disappointingly.

BOSTON, April 2. -- Thomas W. Lawson issued a statement to-day regarding the developments in the Boston Gas Consolidation suit, in which he says that he would have been well within the truth had he estimated the profits of a certain deal in which he and H.H. Rogers of the Standard Oil Company were interested at $66,000,000 instead of at $46,000,000.

THERE is an odd old gentleman living in Central Park West who has been going to the circus since the days before his prosperity, when he used to sneak in under the tent for a furtive view from beneath the seats, gazing thence at the elephant's huge legs until driven out with his comrades by the terrible man employed by the circus people to eject just such boys.
THE HAGUE, April 2. -- Queen Wilhelmina and her husband, Prince Henry, start April 4 for Italy, where they will spend a month for the benefit of her Majesty's health.

Brooke, declared to be the smartest of all parrots, whose home is in the office of the Supervisor of Castle Williams, the military prison on Governors Island, will celebrate the fifth anniversary of his captivity in America this week. It was just five years ago that Col. William F. Cody, otherwise "Buffalo Bill," presented Brooke to Gen. Nelson A. Miles.

EASTER DAY, with its triumphant anthems, its first promise of Spring, its wondrous story of a glorious Resurrection, and its deep significance to all who for generations and generations, centuries and centuries, have observed the rites of the Paschal time! This is one interpretation, but to the fashionable world it means a return to the gayeties which were given up on Ash Wednesday.

Columbia's track management has arranged a new system in developing the 'Varsity team. Manager R.H. Bradley has decided to request graduates who were prominent in track athletics in their student days, as well as some of the more experienced men now on the team, to drill the new candidates in the events in which the amateur couches were specialists.

YONKERS, April 2. -- Mayor John E. Andrus of this city, who was elected on the Republican ticket last Fall, has started in to rid Yonkers of the nest of gamblers who have infested the city for two years. The new Police Board appointed by the Mayor is dead-locked, and Mayor Andrus had to go outside for help.

IT is a well-known fact that in the South of Ireland the pig often shares the house with its human inmates, but that is from necessity. How many know that there is one country where the porker is made a pet and has the freedom of the house, just as cats with us.

I notice that the bids for Staten Island ferryboats were considerably in excess the designer's estimate. Now I see it is proposed to modify the boats and make what will be a cheaper, and consequently slower, boat. The best interests of the city and of this borough will be served by the best type of boat available.

AFTER the lapse of a century and a quarter since the mysterious disappearance of the vast treasure of gold, silver, and precious stones, once the property of the Incas of Peru, a portion of that treasure has been found near the City of Chililaya, on the southeast shore of Lake Titicaca, and not far west of La Paz, once a great city of the Incas.
CHICAGO, April 2. -- (Copyright, 1904, by The Chicago Tribune Company) -- Two weeks ago thirteen negroes were lynched in St. Charles, Ark.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 2. -- The greatest Easter crowd in the history of this resort is now filling the hotels here. The parade to-morrow morning on the Boardwalk, if fair weather continues, will be a record-breaker in point of numbers.

THERE is much incense, of one kind and another, in Japan. Fuji has not smoked in some time, nearly a century, but once it poured out vast volumes of vapor that floated lazily skyward. Japan has been called by many names, including "The Land of the Rising Sun." The Japanese themselves call it Nippon -- compounded of Nitsu, meaning "the sun," and hon, menning "beginning" or "origin," and themselves Nihongins.

Chicle, from which chewing gum is made, has advanced lately in price, and is now 10 cents higher than it was a year ago. There are five grades, corresponding to as many kinds of trees from which the gum is extracted, much the same as rubber is obtained from the rubber trees.

In a Connecticut town the other day a lady adopted, a homeless street cat, hiring a street boy to carry it to her, abode, where it was immediately pampered with milk and improvised cat's meat to such a degree that it forgot its old penury and down-trodden state and began to "boss" the house up stairs and down stairs and in my lady's chamber.

That was a clever move of Kaiser WILHELM to dangle the lure of a marriage with his eldest son before the eyes of the Duke of CUMBERLAND, whose father was King of Hanover up to 1866. The Duke and his wife and their daughter ALEXANDRA still consider themselves and are considered by thousands of Hanoverian and Brunswickers the King, Queen, and Princess of Hanover.

While the contracts of the members of the Mason Builders' Association have been tied up by the present strike of the bricklayers and laborers, independent contractors all over the city have been rushing work. Some of the contracts now going on are very large ones, and yesterday the Borough Board of the Bricklayers' Unions made public a long list of contractors whose work is proceeding.

Several Eastern shoe manufacturers have of late turned their attention to the possibilities of further development of the export trade to South America. A gratifying measure of success is said to have rewarded the efforts of a few to introduce new lines of footwear in the countries south of the equator, with the result that other makers of shoes are likely to engage in similar enterprises.

Some of the contracts now going on are very large ones, and yesterday the Borough Board of the Bricklayers' Unions made public a long list of contractors whose work is proceeding.

Several Eastern shoe manufacturers have of late turned their attention to the possibilities of further development of the export trade to South America. A gratifying measure of success is said to have rewarded the efforts of a few to introduce new lines of footwear in the countries south of the equator, with the result that other makers of shoes are likely to engage in similar enterprises.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 3. -- Every resident in the aristocratic part of the village known as Putnam Avenue West is sleeping to-night with a revolver under his pillow, for burglars are about. At 8 o'clock this evening the Summer residence of Mrs. Fannie Harrington, a New York artist and Christian Scientist, was entered, but the burglars, who numbered two, escaped.

LONDON, April 4. -- The correspondent of The Daily Mail at Christchurch, New Zealand, has had an interview with Capt. R.F. Scott, royal navy, who commanded the Royal Geographical Society's antarctic expedition steamer Discovery.

Six men and one woman, working overtime on rush clothing orders, narrowly escaped being cut off by flames last night in the seven-story brick business building at the southeast corner of Bleecker and Mott Streets, 318 to 322 Mott Street and 26 to 30 Bleecker Street.

THOMASTON, Conn., April 3. -- Boring by muskrats at the base of the big dam at Fenn's Pond, in this place, situated on a hill north of the village, caused the dam to give way early to-day and almost every gallon of water in the pond, which covered four acres of land, rushed down the hill and settled through the main street of the town, flooding many cellars.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- "To relieve the wounded of friend and foe alike left on the battlefields of the war." In these words the Countess Marguerite Cassini, the daughter of the Russian Ambassador, described to-day the object of the fair which, under her direction, will be held in Washington on April 27 in aid of the Russian Red Cross Society.

As a daily reader of your paper I see with the greatest satisfaction that we in our district are not the only ones who have fullest ground for complaint against noisy cars. I live on Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, and I indorse every word of what Mr. Wharton says about noisy cars and flat wheels.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 3. -- The Novi Krai of Port Arthur describes the scene on board the cruiser Bayan during the recent bombardment, as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- Thomas Emerson, the negro who was stabbed in the heart about three weeks ago and was treated at Jefferson Hospital by Dr. Stewart, who closed the wound with six stitches of silk, will leave the hospital in a few days none the worse for his injury.

When the throng was the largest in Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon a carriage ran over a boy on a bicycle near Thirty-first Street. The driver attempted to escape by whipping up his horses and speeding toward Broadway. A man following in a hansom, however, went in pursuit, and the driver was overtaken. He was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Police Station.

The suggestion of "W.G.S." that the police be authorized to act as Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals agents is good, if it can be done; but who is to authorize them? The Commissioner of Police might instruct them to arrest persons for cruelty to animals, which is perhaps equivalent.

NYACK, April 3. -- The Republican primaries of Rockland County were held last night, and after a lively fight Judge A.S. Tompkins, ex-member of Congress, beat ex-Senator Clarence Lexow by an overwhelming majority. Out of the 98 delegates elected, Tompkins got 80 and Lexow 18. This is the first time the Republicans made use of the primary system.

CAPE HAITIEN, April 3. -- A dispatch received here from Monte Cristi, Santo Domingo, reports that Gens. Epifanio Rodriguez and Clena Navarro attacked that place, and that Gen. Jiminez, being without ammunition, abandoned the town and embarked on the German steamship Hispania for St. Thomas. This news is confirmed by the Dominican Consul here.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The announcement of prize winners in a competition to test the taste of audiences, promoted by the Washington ymphony Orchestra, of which Reginald De Koven is Director, was made to-night at Chase's Theatre, where the orchestra gave its tenth Sunday concert.

BOSTON, Mass., April 3. -- There is a ray of light in the mystery surrounding the murder of Miss Mabel Page in Weston last Thursday afternoon. Four men agree in describing a strange man, who was seen going toward the Page house prior to the murder, and coming from the direction of the house subsequent to the hour when it is agreed that the crime was committed.
As in your issue of to-day a victim asks that gas consumers be able to read their own meters, permit me to relate my own experience.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 3. -- The newspapers continue to discuss the British expedition to Tibet and the speech of the Viceroy of India. Lord Curzon of Kedleton, March 30 at Calcutta, (when he reviewed the Last five years of Indian administration and referred to the Government's watchful policy,) but most of them in a singularly dispassionate tone.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- "Uncle Joe" Cannon has been having his picture painted, an operation which all good Speakers must undergo. He has submitted to it with stoical resignation, knowing that it is part of the job he holds; and he has uncomplainingly suffered himself to be led to various photograph galleries and "taken" in statesmanlike poses.

The "Tramp Evangelist," after long wandering, arrived hero yesterday morning as "blind baggage." He crawled out of a freight car on the outskirts of the city just as the sun of Easter morning was chasing away the shadows from the Palisades. With him was a ragged boy who needed several stretches and many yawns to realize that he was awake after a several days' journey from the South, where he had been wintering.
PATERSON, N.J., April 3. -- It is persistently reported here that the American Locomotive Company has obtained a controlling interest in the Rogers Locomotive Works of this city.

-- Admirable as undoubtedly are the intentions underlying the work of the Red Cross organization, and, in themselves, the results of that work, the fact that it has to be done in almost all cases by "branches" distinctly national in character is calculated constantly to cause embarrassments like that created by the niece of the Russian Ambassador in Washington.

One man was overcome by smoke and several persons were rescued in the course of a fire that started just before last midnight in the four-story building at Hudson and Broome Streets, numbered 248 Hudson Street and 590 Broome Street. Damage to the extent of $3,000 was done.

The Central Federated Union was thrown into a state of white hot excitement yesterday by a letter from J.K. Rosenberg, Secretary of Local No. 4 of the United Garment Workers, charging that headquarters had been established in the University Settlement Building, where the Central Federated Union meets, for the hiring of non-union men.

The first general strike of the season will start to-day a little ahead of time, when seven hundred members of the Asphalt Workers' Union will quit work on every contract for asphalt paving in Manhattan and the Bronx to enforce a recognition of the union. The strike, started on Saturday, but that being a short day the action takes effect to-day.

The Rev. John L. Gay, Episcopal minister, who died Tuesday of old age at St. Luke's Hospital, was the great-great-uncle of Richard Henry Gay, son of Mr. and Mrs. C.L. Gay of Rockport, Pike County, Ill. Master Gay is three-years old, and is unusually well blessed with aged relatives, having nine grandparents, as well as a large number of great-great-uncles and aunts who are upward of seventy-five years old.

Watertown, N.Y., is the latest municipality to furnish an instructive object lesson in the value of measures for preventing what may be cured only at great cost. The beginning of its typhoid epidemic is somewhat in doubt. The number of cases was only approximately known, and no systematic Board of Health work had been undertaken to check the spread of the disease.

In a recent number of your paper was published a letter to Mayor McClellan, signed by the Hon. Bird S. Coler, in which he joined the opposition to the bill now pending in the Senate of this State, introduced by the Hon. John T. Smith, to prevent the taking of the water of two streams in this county for the use of the City of New York.

The English journals opposed to the protection scheme of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN are calling attention to the chronic tendency toward extravagance resulting from the extreme protective tariff of the United States. The warning is certainly plain enough, and the situation from which it is drawn is simple enough.
WEI-HAI-WEI, April 2. -- I returned here to-day from a cruise that lasted four days, having visited one Japanese base and, yesterday, passed in view of Port Arthur.

LONDON, April 4. -- The Daily Telegraph, discussing the altered tone of the Russian press toward the United States and Great Britain, and the possibilities of a rapprochement, in an editorial which probably represents the Government view, says:

It is good of your Roman Catholic correspondents to enlighten me and others with me as to the true attitude of the Roman Church on marriage, and especially gratifying is the conciliatory spirit of him who signs himself "Convert," As a great moral issue is involved of wider than sectarian interest, I venture to seek still further enlightenment on this important question.

TOKIO, April 3. -- The advance guard of the Japanese Army in Northwestern Korea occupied the town of Seng-Cheng yesterday afternoon without opposition. Seng-Cheng is on the Peking road, eighteen miles west of Chong-Ju, and about forty miles south of Wi-ju.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., April 3. -- Two memorials were unveiled at the Easter services at the St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church here to-day. The ceremonies were conducted by the rector, the Rev. Henry Chamberlain. One of the memorials consists of a white marble altar, flanked with reredos of Caen stone.

PUEBLO, Col., April 3. -- Living alone in a dugout north of this city is Henry J. Ackerman, who is said to have been once a well-to-do yachtsman and resident of Brooklyn, N.Y., who went away to live alone because he was disappointed and tired of his friends. None of his relatives know where he is, and he has no desire to enter into communication with them.

Police Commissioner McAdoo has said that he would do what of course he ought to do -- enforce all the laws. Apparently Mr. McAdoo is making an effort impartially and thoroughly to enforce some of the laws, especially those against keeping gambling houses; but there are some laws which the police make no effort or practically no effort to enforce, some of them being among the best laws on the statute books.

Who shall be the "New York girl" in London? Before he sends "The Prince of Pilsen to England in May, Henry W. Savage must find a satisfactory answer to that momentous question, and he has hit upon a plan to reach a decision.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 3. -- In the last game of the series New Orleans defeated the New York Americans to-day by a score of 2 to 1, because the visitors could not hit the ball opportunely. A north wind was blowing, but the weather was not responsible for the defeat. New York suffered a bad let-up, and when they failed to connect safety with Breitenstein and Herr, the locals had an easy time.

In a recent debate in the French Chamber of Deputies on the policy of the Ministry in forbidding teaching by the Catholic orders, the fact was clearly brought out that the majority thoroughly believe that their constituents are heartily with them in support of the Ministry.

VIENNA, April 3. -- An official telegram from St. Petersburg states that in view of disquieting rumors, in circulation among the Jews in Southern Russia, and reproduced in many foreign newspapers, the Russian press has been warned to publish nothing that is likely to arouse popular passion or to incite one portion of the people against another.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 3. -- The new wing of Rideau Hall, the official residence of the Governor General, was destroyed by fire to-day. Some anxiety was at first felt for the safety of Lady Minto, who was lying in one of the apartments with a fractured leg, but her removal was accomplished without difficulty.

The great 100-yard swimming race "among the ice floes of Sheepshead Bay," arranged by Magistrate James G. Tighe of Brooklyn, which had been postponed from time to time during the Winter because of the continued presence of ice floes in the bay, came off at last yesterday afternoon, and that without anybody having to be thrown bodily into the water to start the contest.

The body of Mrs. Matilda Waldner, fifty-four years old, of 142 Meserole Street, Brooklyn, was found yesterday afternoon by Augustus Boeltes of 73 Moffett Street, Brooklyn, lying on the grace of her husband, Frederick W. Waldner, in the Lutheran Cemetery, Newtown, Queens Borough.

Last week's business was of a cheerful sort. Among the dozen most active and representative properties not one declined. Among all stocks which moved a point or more 45 advanced and 13 declined. Among the bonds there were 25 advances to 6 declines. The reverse of this roseate epitome is that the business was too highly concentrated to indicate any very general improvement among properties, or any wide interest outside of professional circles.

In connection with the system of auxiliary salt water mains which has been provided for by the five and a half millions appropriation, it becomes the duty of the New York City Improvement Commission, through its Committee on Highways and Parks, to move without delay in the matter of pipe galleries for the streets to be occupied by the new mains.

RICHMOND, Va., April 3. -- In the name of the Democracy of Virginia W.E. Abernethy of Chase City, Va., an admirer of Grover Cleveland, wrote to the ex-President a few days ago making inquiries. Under date Princeton, March 27, the following reply has been received:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3. -- The only interest in the second series of games to-day at the Olympic Club Court for the handball championship of the world between Champion "Mike" Egan of Jersey City and James Fitzgerald of this city centred in the question whether the latter could pull out at the start and gain.

It is stated that the New York, Westchester and Boston Road is on the point of withdrawing from the Board of Estimate and Apportionment its application for a permit to cross the streets in the Borough of the Bronx. The fact is that no such purpose has even been considered by those interested in and controlling this company.

None of the financiers and railroad men who have been identified with the history of the Northern Securities Company would talk yesterday about the suit of E.H. Harriman to recover the holdings in Northern Pacific which he turned over at the time of the Northwest merger.

ALBANY, April 3. -- From a source so close to ex-Senator Hill that it may be understood as representing Mr. Hill's own views, it is learned that it is intended by Mr. Hill that the New York State delegation to the Democratic National Convention at St. Louis shall be positively instructed in favor of Judge Alton B. Parker as New York State's choice for the Presidential nomination.

In this morning's "Topics" you advance -- but only tentatively -- the proposition that "the end justifies the means," and invite a defense of it. The misuse of this phrase has brought it into disrepute, and yet, properly interpreted, it furnishes the only guide for action. There is no test of the wisdom of methods except their result.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 3. -- Mayor Rose spent a busy day to-day speaking to meetings held in the Polish parochial schools on the south side, which had been announced at morning services by priests from their pulpits, Archbishop Messmer, when told that politics had been discussed in churches and schools, said:

Those who braved the wind and drove to the Speedway yesterday were agreeably surprised to find a smoothly harrowed surface and the road in almost perfect condition for fast work. Here and there were heavy places that need another day of sunshine for improvement, and in the shadow of the bridges there still lingers mud in which the horses sink fetlock deep.

The annual handicap cross-country run of the Pastime Athletic Club, held over the Jerome Avenue course yesterday afternoon, proved the largest event of the kind of the present season, both in the number and in the quality of the entries. There were fifty-four starters, representing all the principal local athletic clubs, forty-three of whom completed the six-mile circuit.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 3. -- E.H. Harriman and Winslow S. Pierce, acting as Trustees for the Oregon Short Line, began proceedings in the United States Circuit Court late yesterday afternoon, asking the court to direct the Northern Securities Company to return to the original shareholders the Northern Pacific stock exchanged for Northern Securities stock at the time of the formation of that company.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- When the late A.H. Garland was Attorney General during Cleveland's first Administration he brought from Arkansas an old friend named James H. Ward, who was made watchman and placed in charge of the building at night.

If "conscience is the accumulated experience of thousands of years, teaching man that he may not gratify his passions or act on big own ideas of right to the hurt or loss to his fellow-man," then surely the little girl at the fire was fully justified in her known misstatement of fact.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day received from the Baltimore Chamber of Commerce a letter expressing its acquiescence in the investigation of the freight rate differentials to Atlantic ports.

ALBANY, April 4. -- After a spirited debate, in the course of which the Corporation Trust Company of New York was bitterly attacked, the Senate to-night adopted an amendment to Senator Brackett's bill amending the Penal Code with respect to fraudulent insolvencies by corporations, specially prohibiting the use of the word "trust" by corporations not under the banking law.

The great farce of the Latin American revolution, of which THE TIMES was the Christopher Columbus, has been pre-empted by Mr. Richard Harding Davis, and is on view at the Criterion, where it is exploiting, and being exploited by, Mr. William Collier, the admirable Edward Ables, and an able company.
A bill has been introduced in the Iowa Legislature to render void that clause in life insurance policies which exempts companies from liability in the event of suicide.

A little exhibition at the Clausen Gallery, in Fifth Avenue, has the personal charm of sketches made by a tourist during a stay in the West of Ireland, sketches to accompany letters or a diary. They might be those of an amateur who is not without all knowledge of the poster art of France and may even look back on some short acquaintance with Paris studios, but is a Briton for all that.

District Attorney Jerome said yesterday that he believed some action would be taken in the Assembly to-day or to-morrow on his bill concerning witnesses in gambling cases. He added that if there was much more delay he would go again to Albany to find what the legislators meant to do.

Justice Truax yesterday confirmed the report of Referee William G. Davies, in the Dodge-Morse-Dodge investigation, which report was that Dodge had been properly served and had authorized Mortimer A. Ruger to represent him in the action for divorce brought by Mrs. Dodge. Therefore, the divorce which Mrs. Dodge obtained is held to be legal.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 4. -- The New York National League team had to play a ten-inning game to win a victory over the local Southern League nine in to-day's contest, the score being 9 to 8. McGinnity injured a finger in the first inning in trying to field a bunt. It was the finger he uses most in curving and the injury stopped his effectiveness.

The first call of the calendar of suspended cases by the Board of General Appraisers under the new rules occurred yesterday. The entire system broke down when it was found that it would be a physical impossibility to send out the required notices to the importers and the lawyers interested, and a compromise was arrived at at an informal conference between Judge Byron S. Waite the President of the board, and the lawyers.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- Charges recently published to the effect that influences from high official quarters at Washington intervened with the naval court that inquired into the cause of the collision between the battleships Missouri and Illinois, was the subject of a conference to-day between the President and Secretary Moody.

The dispatch from Copenhagen on Sunday regarding the prolonged stay of King EDWARD at the Danish capital -- he is to remain until the 18th -- his conference with the Premier, and his desire to promote peace, is certainly significant; it may prove to be extremely important.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 4. -- As the time approaches for the opening of land operations on a large scale, the Russian authorities are exercising greater vigilance to prevent news of their plans for the movement to and the disposition of troops in the theatre of war from going abroad, where they might be of service to the enemy.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The New York Post Office amendments passed the Senate to-day, notwithstanding the opposition which for three days held them up.

The extent to which Wall Street was dominated by a single topic yesterday is reflected in the fact that one-third of the day's business was in Union Pacific. Adding Southern Pacific and St. Paul, it appears that over one-half the day's dealings was in the group recently associated with each other. But yesterday they parted company.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 4. -- After a wonderful display of coolness and "horse sense," a horse saved its own life in an accident last night, and then, the danger being over, it became so excited that it jumped through a plate-glass window in a store, badly injuring itself.

ALBANY, April 4.--Senator McCarren to-night introduced a bill to provide for the construction and operation of a municipal elevated railway on Willoughby Street, Fulton Street, the New York and Brooklyn Bridge and its terminals, Centre Street, Delancey Street, the Williamsburg Bridge, South Fifth Street, Union Avenue, Throop Avenue, Willoughby Avenue, and under Fort Greene Park, and to provide for the appointment of a commission to construct it.

Whatever motive Mr. Murphy may have in opposing an instructed delegation from this State, it is obvious that in so doing he is playing directly into the hands of W.R. Hearst. If there is one thing that at the present time would infuse new life into the fading candidacy of the "yellow peril" it would be an uninstructed delegation from New York to the Democratic National Convention.

Persons in the vicinity of Greeley Square, Broadway and Thirty-second Street, were startled yesterday morning about 10:30 o'clock by a terrific explosion, followed a moment later by a shower of broken rock, logs, and other missiles that demolished over a dozen windows and did other damage to the buildings at 1,270 to 1,274 Broadway, just across the way from the scene of the explosion.

It took just an hour last night for fire to do $100,000 damage to the factory building at 440 to 444 Canal Street, running through to 12 to 16 Vestry Street. Pearl goods and knitted and worsted goods were the chief articles burned up. Eight hundred men and women will be thrown idle by the fire.

PITTSEURG, Penn., April 4. -- The nail department of the American Steel and Wire Company's plant at Rankin was burned down to-day, causing a loss of from $175,000 to $200,000. In the building were 250 nail machines, as well as 8,000 kegs of nails, which were more or less damaged. The origin of the fire is unknown.

ALBANY, April 4. -- There is a lively fight in prospect over the proposed legislation to increase the State Railroad Commission by the appointment of two additional members and the conferring of power on the commission to enforce its recommendations.

NEWTON, Mass., April 4. -- Charles L. Tucker of this city was late to-night taken to the headquarters of the Police Department in West Newton, where he is being subjected to a searching examination regarding his movements on the day of the murder of Miss Mabel Page at Weston last week. The examination was long but at its close it was stated that Tucker had established an alibi, and he was allowed to go.

ALBANY, April 4. -- David B. Hill was flooded with telegrams from friends of Judge Parker in various States to-day, asking what truth there was in the intimation of Justice Charles H. Truax that the delegation from the State of New York to the St. Louis Convention would not be instructed for Judge Parker.

LONDON, April 4. -- The suggestion that King Edward, while at Copenhagen, will make an effort to bring about peace between Russia and Japan and that the prolongation of his stay at Copenhagen until April 18 is connected with a peace-making campaign is not considered seriously here.

BOSTON, April 4. -- The plaintiffs in the litigation growing out of the consolidation of the Boston gas companies closed their case late this afternoon, and when court adjourned the first witness for the defense was upon the stand.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The case of the Inter-State Commerce Commission vs. Baird, commonly known as the anthracite coal case, was decided by the Supreme Court of the United States in favor of the contentions of the commission, the decision of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New York being reversed.

As it is the boast of this country that all men are free, I would endeavor to raise my voice, however feeble, against an instructed delegation. Although I believe Judge Parker to be a very able man and well fitted for the high position of Chief Magistrate of this country, I do not consider it right that a delegation should be tied down to vote for any candidate "first, last, and all the time."

The eleven-story loft building to be erected by Jacob Rothschild at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixteenth Street will cover, besides the lot on the immediate corner, the two adjoining lots, 79 and 81 Fifth Avenue, and the adjoining parcel at the rear, 4 East Sixteenth Street, making in all a plot with frontages of 106 feet on the avenue and 158 feet on the street.

In compliance with the last wishes of her husband, Col. Henry C. Nevins, Julie F.H. Nevins, in her will, which was filed for probate yesterday, sets aside about $1,000,000 for the establishment and maintenance of an institution to be known as the Henry Coffin Nevins Home for the Aged and Incurable.

The Fireman's Herald, a journal which watches closely and with intelligence all municipal movements looking to the provision of better facilities for fighting fire, is unable to understand the request of Commissioner HAYES of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for an additional appropriation of $2,000,000 with which to establish thirty-three additional companies and provide for the purchase of apparatus for them. It says with much truth:

It was on Saturday, June 1, 1901, that Wall Street, after that period of great distress and much moral and financial shivering which followed the Northern Pacific scare, read with deep and sincere satisfaction the official announcement, "An understanding has been reached between the Northern Pacific and Union Pacific interests under which the composition of the Northern Pacific board will be left in the hands of J.P. MORGAN."
BALTIMORE, Md., April 4. -- The firm of Taylor Levering, one of the leading coffee importing houses south of New York, made the following announcement to-day:
NIU-CHWANG, April 3. -- The press boat Fuhwan, placed under arrest yesterday, was released to-day by order of Gen. Kuropatkin.

SHANGHAI, April 4. -- A letter received here from Kobe says the Japanese Government has 260,000 troops in motion and fully 60,000 more under arms in garrisons and at the depots. These numbers are exclusive of the Third Reserves, numbering 120,000, which have not been called to the colors.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 4. -- Freddie Fillwook of Findlay, ten years old, died at that place to-day after suffering the greatest agony for several days.
WASHINGTON, April 4. -- "Who is that little Senator, with the touseled hair and the sarcastic smile, with his under lip stuck out?" asked a New York woman visitor in the Senate gallery.

There was a continued hearing before the Aldermanic Committee on Railroads yesterday on the application of the Union Railway Company for a franchise to extend its system in several new directions in the Bronx, including the crossing of Washington Bridge, the new Fordham Heights Bridge, the Willis Avenue Bridge, and the One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street Bridge over the Harlem.

WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The feature of the sport to-day at the Benning race track was the Easter Monday steeplechase, in which there were five starters. Thomas Hitchcock, Jr.'s horse Jim Newman, which won in Saturday's steeplechase, duplicated his victory to-day, when as second choice he took first money.

Charles S. Daub, of 220 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, a juryman in the case of John Bruno, better known as "Little Chink," yesterday inadvertently caused considerable trouble for two Judges in the Criminal Courts Building. Bruno's trial was before Judge Newburger, and when court adjourned for recess at 1 o'clock Daub went out to get his luncheon.

Transactions in Union Pacific and Steel preferred represented about half of all yesterday's trading in the stock market, and it might be said that these two issues, each of which was prominent for reasons in no way associated, but directly affecting the stocks in question, made the day's market.
The Grand Jury that censures the Building Inspector of the Darlington affair, to my mind, does so unfairly and without a proper investigation as to the facts.

An order signed by Judge Holt in the United States District Court yesterday disclosed the fact that a warrant had been issued for Thomas J. Loftus, ex-President of the W.C. Loftus Company, tailors, but that the marshal had been unable to find him. Mr. Loftus has been adjudged guilty of contempt of court, and a process has been issued against him.

BOSTON, April 4. -- Judge Barker of the Supreme Judicial Court to-day appointed Samuel W. McCall and Charles F. Choate, Jr., receivers for the Union Trust Company, which closed its doors on Thursday last. Bonds were named at $50,000 each for the receivers. The trust company's liabilities are placed at $1,600,000.

It was not gratifying to discover that there were Senators of the United States who found it useful to them in their business to attempt to hamper the public business, when that business happened to be transacted in the City of New York, or to prevent the passage of a measure for the facilitation of that business because it would necessarily facilitate the work of "the railroads" which are the chief carriers of the mails.

A vivid recollection of the first banquet of the Poe Society is likely to be retained by some of those who attended that interesting affair. The dinner was announced to take place at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the tenth floor of the Mills Building, at 15 Broad Street.

The St. Nicholas Society of New York held its pass festival last night at Delmonico's. Pass, as translated by the Hollanders, signified the Feast of the Passover, or Easter Monday. The banquet table was decorated with rabbits bursting forth from Easter eggs and champagne bottles. There was the customary procession bearing in the old weather cock, which tradition says was preserved from the old Town Hall and presented to the society by Washington Irving.

Gold to the extent of $600,000 was engaged for export to Paris yesterday for shipment by Thursday's steamer, the transaction having been made by the agency in this city of the Royal Bank of Canada. This starts the gold export movement about which there has been so much discussion for two or three weeks past, and which is thought likely to assume large proportions.

The Journeymen Bricklayers and Masons' International Union has decided to take a hand in the present trouble between the bricklayers and laborers and the mason builders. William Bowen, President of the International Union, called at the Townsend Building yesterday afternoon and had a conference with the Emergency Committee of the Employers' Association.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- Reciprocal relations have been established between the Western Jockey Club and the Pacific Jockey Club, and the two organizations will aim to control all race meetings hereafter between the Allegheny Mountains and the Pacific Ocean.

Nearly 800 evictions are impending on the east side because of the advance in rent, and concerted action on the part of tenants to oppose the summary action of landlords both to theatened enforcement of the dispossess processes as well as the general advance of the rents, which are declared to be intolerable, has already been commenced.

Wall Street came to the conclusion yesterday that it had at last solved the mystery of the heavy buying of Union Pacific stock when it was learned from the highest authorities that the larger part of the stock purchased during the last few days had found its way into the strong box of John D. Rockefeller.

A correspondent calls our attention to the fact that in our remarks on the case of the young woman in Rochester whose photograph had been used without her consent to advertise a shower bath, we overlooked that the Legislature had in this case corrected or supplemented the action of the judiciary.

Much curiosity was felt by lovers of old tapestries to know who it was that bought the grand series of eight seventeenth century pieces formerly in the Barberini Palace and lately in the Blakeslee Galleries; which were described some weeks ago in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The price is stated to be $100,000; the buyer is Mr. John R. McLean of Washington, proprietor of The Cincinnati Enquirer.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 4. -- The stockholders of the Knoxville, Lafollete and Jellico Railway to-day authorized the Directors to sell the road to the Louisville and Nashville. This link connects the seventy-mile gap in the Louisville and Nashville line between Cincinnati and Knoxville, and is a step toward the completion of the road to Atlanta.

MEMPHIS, April 4. -- The Tennessee Derby was run to-day at Montgomery Park before a record-breaking attendance, but there was not a spark of enthusiasm, the result being a foregone conclusion. The only point of speculation was the distance the third horse would finish from the leaders, and the time for the mile and an eighth.

The strikie of the asphalt workers for recognition of their union went into effect as scheduled yesterday, but the companies were prepared and began early in the forenoon to fill the places of the strikers with non-union men. The strikers were mostly Italians, with a small proportion of colored men, and the men engaged in their places were Irishmen, who will not be intimidated into quitting work, the employers say.

CHICAGO, April 4. -- The Chicago Journal has been purchased by John C. Eastman, who has been since its inauguration business manager of Hearst's American. Formal transfer was made to-day by George G. Booth of Detroit and Ralph H. Booth of Chicago. The sale of the property was arranged by Charles M. Palmer.

The hall at 42 Second Avenue, the abode of the Tammany Club of the Tenth Assembly District, and the headquarters of Julius Harburger, presiding genius of the club and the district, was crammed to the doorsteps last night with those who came to hear the Police Commissioner make a speech to them.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The Senate to-day passed one of the increase-of-salary bills for New York City opposed by the City Club and other organizations. It is Senator Grady's bill for an additional Fire Commissioner at a salary of $5,000. Under Senator Grady's bill one of the Deputies shall be in Brooklyn and one in Manhattan, but the Brooklyn Deputy shall not have the power of the Commissioner in case of the latter's absence.
The purchase of 668 Fifth Avenue, by William K. Vanderbilt, is referred to in more detail in another column.

Whether or not it has been preconcerted, there seems to be no doubt that the raising of rents on the east side has been general and systematic. Various explanations of it are given. One is that owners who wish to sell desire to make the largest possible showing of income, and show their rent roll as an index of the value of their property.

The general arbitration board of the Building Trades, representing the majority of employers and skilled workmen in the building industry, adopted a resolution at the Building Trades Club meeting last night which provides that all striking bricklayers and laborers, 16,000 in all, are to return to work, pending arbitration.

After having been prisoners in the Statue of Liberty, two young girls, Grace Felicia Tojetti of 60 West Seventy-fifth Street, and Johanna Luehrs, a stenographer at Ellis Island, were returned in safety yesterday morning, the one to her anxious mother, and the other to her notebook and typewriter.

Tandem driving, an exhibition of four-in-hands, and women handling their own horses in the ring were among the features last night at the opening of the thirteenth annual horse show in the Durland Riding Academy, West Sixty-sixth Street. Seven tandem teams entered the ring, among the men drivers being Stuart Duncan, W.M.V. Hoffman and Charles Baudoine.

RICHMOND, Va., April 5. -- Both Morgan and Walters were batted heavily in today's game between Brooklyn and Montreal, but the National Leaguers developed a batting streak in the eighth inning and won. With three men on the bases in that inning, Lumley made his first and only hit of the game, a three-bagger, and another hit and an error piled up two more runs, making a total of five. The score:

There was little reduction yesterday of the interest felt in the mystery connected with Union Pacific's activity and strength, and there was even less light thrown upon its relation to the Northern Securities liquidation problem. Those topics remained before Wall Street's attention, but the stocks did not monopolize the market as on Monday.

Three more matches were played yesterday in the National indoor court tennis championship tournament at the Racquet and Tennis Club, West Forty-third Street, completing the first round and finishing two of the four contests in the second round. The victors were Austen Potter of the Boston Racquet Club and E.A. Thomson and J.H. Morgan of the New York Club.

Public interest, concentrated upon the Northern Securities case, seems to have missed entirely another decision, handed down during March by a divided Supreme Court, which is important as an interpretation of the Constitution and affects, indirectly at least, a mass of securities whose face value is greater than that involved in the Northern Securities decision.
I can't think of reading any other daily paper with satisfaction except THE NEW YORK TIMES -- all the news that's fit to print, and reliable.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Judge Alton B. Parker will not break his silence upon political subjects until after the St. Louis Convention. The report that as soon as the State Convention instructed for him he would take occasion to make his views on National issues known can be authoritatively denied.

William K. Vanderbilt, according to credible report, has bought the property 668 Fifth Avenue from the Coe estate for $250,000. The house which is of the four-story brownstone-front type on a lot 25 by 100, adjoins the similar dwelling No. 666, which Mr. Vanderbilt bought about five years ago from the Joseph Main estate, and which, in turn, adjoins Mr. Vanderbilt's mansion, at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

BERLIN, April 5. -- Mattasich, the ex-Lieutenant in the Austrian army, whose intrigue with the Princess Louise of Coburg caused her husband, Prince Philip of Coburg, to have her detained in a private asylum for the insane at Coswig, a suburb of Dresden, made an unsuccessful attempt to rescue the Princess several days ago.

JACKSON, Miss., April 5. -- Gov. Vardaman received a telephone message to-night from Judge Sam Cook, who presided over the Special Circuit Court term at Sumner. Tallahatchie County, that Arthur Baldwin, the negro murderer of Engineer Thomas Fogarty of the Yazoo and Mississippi Valley Road, had been brought to that place by Major Gen. Keesler and his Greenwood military company.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Representative Serene E. Payne is to be permanent Chairman and Senator Chauncey M. Depew temporary Chairman of the Republican State Convention, which meets in New York City April 12.

Serious charges have been laid before Commissioner of Charities Tully against Dr. Wolfram E. Dreyfuss, chief chemist of the department, who formerly was a Professor of Chemistry at Columbia, and who was appointed by ex-Commissioner of Charities Homer Folks. His salary is $5,000 a year, and he has general supervision over all drugs, chemicals, and surgical appliances for the city hospitals.

It appears to be the settled policy of Tammany Hall to maintain an attitude of opposition to the Democrats of the rest of the State. Under the leadership of JOHN KELLY and of RICHARD CROKER Tammany was almost continually at war with the Democracy north of the Harlem. Mr. MURPHY, the present Tammany leader, follows the tradition and keeps up the practice.

Arrangements for the annual regatta of the Hudson Regatta Association, to be held on the Harlem River on May 30, were completed at a meeting of the Regatta Committee of the association, held at the Pabst, on West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, last night. It was decided that the regatta should consist of the following fifteen events:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 5. -- The dispute between Leonard Jacob and the town of Oyster Bay as to the ownership of East Beach, which has been going on for a year and which last Summer and again this week caused armed men from both sides to hold possession of the property, is now in the courts.

The question as to whether American food is nutritious and palatable to a Chinese girl was brought up in the Tombs Court yesterday in the case of Moy Heung, who is alleged to have beei abducted by Mrs. Josephine Toy, janitress of the Morning Star Mission, and Lee Hoy, a Chinese merchant, of 16 Mott Street.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The anti-gambling bill introduced by Senator Dowling at the instigation of District Attorney Jerome was to-night reported by the Rules Committee of the Assembly, and will go on the Assembly calendar for to-morrow.
LONDON, April 5. -- Frances Power Cobbe, the author, is dead.

Billy Wells, the "Hard-headed Man," came near meeting his end in the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. It is his function at every performance to let brawny young men place rocks on his head and burst them with a sledge hammer, which Billy provides for the purpose. But heretofore he has not allowed lead-filled rocks to be used.
