It is not true that the accord reported to have been virtually arrived at between France and England disposes of all the questions at issue between the two Powers. But it does seem to eliminate from them all any elements they contain dangerous to international peace. Since both nations unquestionably desire peace, with each other and with all the world, this result was to be expected.

It required no extraordinary powers of perception to see that the indignation aroused by the evictions following the wholesale raising of rents on the lower east side of this city yesterday was at a high pitch. The City Marshals were busy all day serving dispossess papers, and they say that never in their career have they been called on to undertake so stupendous a task as the present.

DALLAS, Texas, April 5. -- James and Walter Herring, sons of B.H. Herring and connected with the most prominent families of Henderson County, were killed at their homes, near Athens, last night, while resisting arrest. Their father committed suicide in the Athens jail in 1897, and sensational feudist conditions have existed since.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Another fight on the Brackett bill prohibiting the use of the word "trust" by corporations not under the banking law is now certain. Senator Brackett, by a vote of 23 to 16, was successful this afternoon in securing the adoption of his motion to reconsider the Elsberg amendment, which practically robbed the measure of its effect and protected the Corporation Trust Company of New York.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Pitcher Crumley was invincible to-day in the Georgetown University game with Yale, the latter not scoring a run. Apperious made a home run. Score by innings:

The decision of the Supreme Court in the suit brought by the Inter-State Commerce Commission at the instance of Mr. HEARST will compel the anthracite coal-carrying roads to produce their contracts with the coal companies. Through ownership of the mines and agreements with each other the anthracite roads have established a combination as, to which the public is entitled to larger knowledge than it now possesses.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5. -- This was as lively a day at the State Home for Girls as that rather bothersome institution has witnessed in many a day. The new Board of Managers met and organized, the reign of Mrs. Myrtle B. Eyler terminated, and thirty-four of the girl inmates escaped. The latter occurrence took place just after the change was made and before things had gotten in running order.

-- Talk about the weather, though usually held to be the sign of a mind temporarily or permanently vacuous, constitutes so large a fraction of human conversation in all parts of the world that its intrinsic interest and importance must be much greater than people are accustomed to admit.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5. -- "Kid" McCoy won his fight to-night with Herr Placke, champion of Holland, in less than two rounds, and in barely four minutes of fighting. Placke made a sorry spectacle of himself. Standing six inches taller and weighing nearly eighty pounds more than his opponent, he was beaten almost insensible in a remarkably short time.

The Manhattan Railway Company's purchase of the properties 56 to 64 Trinity Place, just north of Rector Street, and running through to Greenwich Street, is believed to have been made with a view to the erection of a big building, designed primarily for the accommodation of the offices of both the elevated and the subway systems.

LONDON, April 5. -- With the opening of the month rates for money were easier. The disbursement of the April dividends materially increased the supplies. Further cheapness is regarded as certain, entailing a possible early reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount and the opening of the way to the flotation of a number of new loans.

Acting favorably on the suggestion of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, the Board of Aldermen yesterday, on motion of Vice Chairman Timothy P. Sullivan, approved a resolution changing the name of Long Acre Square to that of Times Square. President of the Interborough Rapid Transit Commission to name the Forty-second Street and Broadway station of the rapid transit subway the Times Station.

CAPE MAY, N.J., April 5. -- The forest fire which started at Risley, a town thirty miles north of here, yesterday afternoon, still continues to burn without interruption, and there are about two square miles of undergrowth and stunted growth destroyed, while the immense volumes of smoke can be seen for fifteen miles.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 5. -- While the Montgomery team of the Southern League made a good showing against the New York Nationals for a few innings to-day, McGraw's men batted lively in the sixth inning, and after that victory for the New Yorkers was no longer in doubt. The latter played a perfect game in the field, but, like yesterday, they found the Montgomery team the fastest pacemakers they have met on their Southern tour.

ALBANY, April 5. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision in favor of the Medical College Laboratory of New York City in its contest with New York University over the ownership of real estate which the former institution occupies in that city.
SEOUL, April 1, via Shanghai, April 5. -- The Japanese First Army, consisting of 45,000 men, which had been concentrated at An-ju, is moving on Wi-ju by three routes.
There were sales on the Stock Exchange yesterday of 150 shares of Bank of Commerce, in small lots, at 202 1/2@203.

There was a tempest in a teapot in the Board of Aldermen yesterday over the inadvertent granting by the board of the $370,000 appropriation to Commissioner Woodbury of the Department of Street Cleaning for his "chateau" or stable and administration building in Brooklyn. In the printed calendar for the meeting yesterday appeared the resolution of the Board of Estimate making this appropriation.

Aided by Republican votes, the Tammany members of the Board of Aldermen, together with the three Doyle Democratic members from Brooklyn, yesterday defeated the McCarren candidate for the vacancy caused by the death of Alderman Arthur Guthrie, and elected William C. Boerner by a vote of 44 to 9.

ALBANY, April 5. -- Senator Elsberg to-day presented to the home rule conference a report concerning the little amount of home rule which the Republican leaders have concluded it is advisable to grant.

CHICAGO, April 5. -- In the municipal election to-day the Republicans elected eighteen Aldermen and the Democrats sixteen. One independent Republican who repudiated the "machine" in the Sixth Ward, was chosen a member of the Council.

TRENTON, N.J., April 5. -- Henry Tatnall, receiver of the Asphalt Company of America and of the National Asphalt Company, filed his last report to-day, and in it declared that he could not see his way to enforcing the $40 call on each $100 of stock from the shareholders who transferred stock in the Asphalt Company of America to the National Asphalt Company.

After months of secret preparation, involving the bringing together of all street railway employes of Greater New York into one mammoth organization, plans are now being perfected for a big strike which, if carried into effect, is destined to tie up not only every surface and elevated line in the Borough of Brooklyn, but which may even extend to the elevated system in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx.

ALBANY, April 5. -- At the instigation of New York associations, Senator Burton in the Senate to-day made a fight for an amendment to the Forest, Fish and Game Commission's bill making appropriations for continuing the acquisition of lands in the Adirondacks and Catskills.

A somewhat difficult task confronts the reviewer who would do justice to everybody concerned when considering such a production as that of "The Shepherd King," presented at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night. It was obvious at the outset that a very large sum of money had been spent and that those who made the venture did so in confidence, staking much on the result.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 5. -- With bands playing "The Star-Spangled Banner" and "Dixie," and 30,000 people cheering her godspeed, the battleship Virginia left the ways at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company to-day. The launching was without a hitch. Miss Mathilda Gay Montague, daughter of Gov. Montague, was sponsor for the ship.
In common with a great many readers of THE TIMES, as I believe, I was greatly pained at the bitterness of your editorial against Dr. Parkhurst.

PENNINGTON DEPOT, N.J., April 5. -- Three girls, Anna Monday, Elnora Hatfield, and Anna Gordon, of the many girls who escaped from the State Home for Girls at Trenton this afternoon, walked to this place, arriving at 7 P.M., and created great excitement through the town by their shouts and queer actions.
WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The labor troubles on the Isthmus of Panama growing out of the strike of the employes of the Panama Railroad Company have taken a serious turn.

Barney Oldfield, the racing automobilist, who holds the world's record of 0:35 for a mile on a circular track, was disqualified, together with E.C. Hausman, at a meeting of the Racing Board of the American Automobile Association, held at the headquarters, 753 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, by the passage of the following resolution:

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 5. -- Twenty of the corporations in this city engaged in the manufacture of print cloths, controlling sixty-five mills, have entered into an agreement to curtail production by shutting down two days a week. The action is due to unsettled conditions in the cotton and cloth markets.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- Representative Wade of Iowa made a Democratic speech in the House to-day. He wanted to know why Attorney General Knox, after successfully prosecuting one trust, refrained from prosecuting any more, and announced that he would not "run amuck."

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The extortions of the Paper Trust were the subject of a hearing given to-day by the House Judiciary Committee on a resolution introduced by Representative Lilley of Connecticut. This resolution provides for all investigation of the Paper Trust by the Department of Commerce.

WINSTED, Conn., April 5. -- Burton H. Mattoon, formerly State Senator and ex-Treasurer of the Watertown Savings Bank, pleaded guilty in the Superior Court this afternoon to four charges of making false entries in the books of the savings bank. He will be sentenced next Tuesday.

The special organ of the protected interests takes exception to the opinion recently expressed in our columns by Mr. MOSELY of London that the question of protection is a closed one in the United States. Its view is that so long as there are active opponents of special legislation for private interests among the leaders of the Democratic Party, like Mr. WILLIAMS of Mississippi, the question must remain open.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The card was an ordinary one at Benning to-day. St. Juvenal was the only favorite to win, the remaining events going to four second choices and to an outsider. Mrs. Frank Foster, always a popular entry at Washington, won her first race of the season. City Bank, that is entered for some of the big handicaps in the East, showed considerable improvement over his previous running here.

ALBANY, April 5. -- By a vote of 25 to 13 the Senate to-night refused to strike out the enacting clause of the Thompson bill extending the corporate existence and increasing the powers of the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company. The principal fight on the bill will be made when the measure comes up on the order of final passage.

A man came to New York to spend a few days. He had pecuniary experiences as follows: A railroad cabman wanted 85 cents for bringing him to his hotel; proper charge, 35 cents. The hotel newsstand wanted 10 cents for a newspaper; proper charge, 3 cents. Fee to waiter for dinner, 15 cents; waiter grumbled and was reported.

NEWPORT, April 6. -- Charles Astor Bristed is here to arrange for the opening of his villa on Wickham Road, and will arrive the latter part of the month with his family to occupy the place for the Summer. Mr. Bristed purchased the villa a year ago, but did not occupy it last Summer.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The Navy Department to-day received a cablegram from Commander Mason of the Cincinnati, at Shanghai, announcing the arrival there this morning of the gunboat Helena from Niu-Chwang.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 6. -- Senator Joseph R. Burton of Kansas to-day was fined $2,500 and sentenced to six months' imprisonment in jail for using his influence before the Post Office Department in behalf of the Rialto Grain and Securities Company of St. Louis, and for having received payment from the company for his services.

So great are the inroads that have been made during the last few days into the forces of Senator Patrick H. McCarren in Brooklyn that grave doubts were expressed last night both in Tammany and Brooklyn Democratic circles as to whether McCarren would be in control of the Kings County delegation to the State Convention on April 18.

The report of Mr. Veiller to the City Club and the letter in your columns signed "X.Y.Z.," both attacking a bill in the Legislature affecting the Inspectors of the Health Department, are calculated to disparage the efforts of a body of men to better their condition and to prejudice the public against them.
Details will be found in another column relative to purchases by the United States Express Company, at Rector and Trinity Place.

A further step in the policy of retrenchment inaugurated by President Ismay of the International Mercantile Marine on his return to this country was taken yesterday, when the private telegraph service of the American and Red Star Lines between their respective offices and piers here and in Philadelphia was discontinued and the employes discharged.

ALBANY, April 6. -- District Attorney Jerome's Anti-Gambling bill, the object of which is to compel Reginald Vanderbilt and Jesse Lewisohn to testify in proceedings to be begun against Richard A. Canfield, was passed in the Assembly to-day after a debate of over four and a half hours by a vote of 93 to 47. The bill now goes to the Governor.

Charles E. Sand and Joshua Crane, Jr., were the victors yesterday in the two matches that were played in the Racquet and Tennis Club, West Forty-third Street, in the National indoor court tennis championship tournament. The semi-finals will be completed to-day, but the results are not expected to make any difference in the opponents who are regarded as sure to be competitors in the final match on Saturday.

Poisoned candy rabbits and candy tops, it was discovered yesterday, caused the death of two children and made another so ill that he may die. The dead children Were Peter Farrel five years old, of 533 West Thirty-fifth Street, and William Haugh, two and a half years old, of 137 East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street.

Agnes Pemberton, a chambermaid, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by jumping from a tenth-story window of the Hotel Willard, at 252 West Seventy-sixth Street. She landed on a dome over the office at the second floor and was almost instantly killed. A porter was cleaning the stained-glass windows of the dome when the body fell at his side and stunned him.

ALBANY, April 6. -- "The promoters of this bill could afford to pay $20,000 a vote for its passage through this body," Senator Grady declared when the Carpenter-Wainwright White Plains Boulevard bill was up before the Senate for final passage to-day.

Accusing Joseph H. Hoadley of seizing all the assets -- more than $1,000,000 worth -- that Cyrus Field Judson retained after the sensational collapse in 1902 of the famous "International Power pool," counsel for Judson's creditors argued yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Davis against the motion of Hoadley's lawyers to Set aside the order which had been issued commanding Hoadley to open his books for inspection.
BERLIN, April 6. -- Prices on the Boerse to-day in most departments were weaker, but iron and coal shares were higher.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 6. -- The scheme for retrenchments in expenditure in consequence of the war was gazetted to-day.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., April 6. -- John McFarland, Chief of Police of North Fork, and J.A. Ballard, merchant, capitalist, and lumberman, are dead as the result of a pistol duel, which followed the Republican District Convention there last evening. The convention was for the purpose of selecting delegates to the McDowell County Convention, held at Welch to-day.

The dispatch we published yesterday morning regarding the efforts of King EDWARD to promote a settlement of the war in the East shows the feeling on this subject in the capitals of Europe. It was a telegram from Berlin to the Soir of Brussels, a paper having the reputation of being unusually well informed as to matters of high importance in European politics.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6. -- It was fortunate local houses had the arbitrage shares to fall back on to-day, otherwise the trading here would have been dull indeed. Cambria Steel improved fractionally in sympathy with the rise in United States Steel issues. Electric Storage Battery was up 1/4 and Huntington and Broadtop preferred 1/2. These were the extreme changes.

The market kept its headway remarkably yesterday. Active stocks did not show a single decline exceeding a fraction, and but few of them, while among fifty advances there were a dozen of a point or more. The volume of business was but a trifle smaller than on Tuesday, and the distribution continued to show improvement, many into the ten-thousand-share class.
BERLIN, April 6.--Fabulous swarms of locusts have devastated the Valley of the Usumbara, in German East Africa. They were first noticed coming from Wombo on Feb. 22.

Commissioner of Charities Tully conducted a hearing yesterday afternoon on the charges against Dr. Wolfram E. Dreyfuss, the chemist of the department. There are five specifications in the charges that Dr. Dreyfuss is called upon to answer.

The New Jersey Mayor's Equal Taxation League met at the office of Mayor Fagan in Jersey City yesterday. For the first time there was a division of sentiment. Heretofore all the Mayors who joined the league have been in favor of continuing the fight for equal taxation until a victory is achieved or defeat assured.

The strike of the bricklayers and laborers was called off officially yesterday by the strike leaders and the strikers were ordered to report for work to-day on all the contracts of the Mason Builders' Association pending arbitration of all points in dispute. The joint arbitration board of the Mason Builders' Association and the bricklayers' unions will meet to-day to settle the disputed points.
LONDON, April 6. -- Major Seely (Independent) was re-elected without opposition yesterday to represent the Isle of Wight Division of Hampshire in the House of Commons.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6. -- The rival Philadelphia teams of the National and American Leagues played another game to-day, and the Americans made more runs in one inning than "Hughey" Duffy's men made in the entire game. Score by innings:

I have just read in your issue of to-day the cable dispatch giving an account of the butchery by an armed "English mission" of a camp of Tibetans on their own soil, which has filled me with horror and indignation. A more cowardly massacre and anti-Christian outrage was never perpetrated on the face of the earth since Christ was born.

The statement of the United States Steel Corporation is likely to be considered favorable or otherwise according to the ability of the person who studies it to read its figures in the light of a good knowledge of the general situation of iron and steel and the statistical outlook in this line of business.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Eugene G. Hay the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a ruling by the Surveyor at Kansas City, Mo., in which a royalty was made a part of the dutiable cost of an importation. The facts are as follows:
ALBANY, April 6. -- The Judges' Pension bill passed the Senate to-night by a vote of 32 to 16.

Never was the importance of the telephone system to the modern business life of the city brought home more forcibly than yesterday, when one of the largest ganglia of wires in the subway at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fulton Street was burned away by the careless handling of a gasoline torch.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Honors went to three favorites at the Benning track to-day the remaining prizes being captured by a second choice and outsiders. There was a good crowd present, and the track was fast. In the two-year-old selling event the result was unsatisfactory owing to the erratic running in the stretch of Metallic which interfered with three or four horses, and, after finishing second, was disqualified for fouling.

Why the indignant Aldermen should describe as a "chateau" the building which Commissioner WOODBURY has persuaded himself and the Board of Estimate that he needs in his official business in Brooklyn is more than we understand. The building is to be devoted in part to stables and in part to offices, and neither of these requirements indicates a "chateau," nor even a "schloss."

Through the medium of your paper I desire to give wide publicity to a criticism of an article printed in The Independent of March 3, written by one William Thorp, entitled "Santo Domingo, the 'Isle of Unrest,'" which has just been brought to my attention.

OSWEGO, N.Y., April 6. -- Urged on by over a thousand citizens, the Superintendent of Streets and a gang of men, headed by Mayor Mansfield and several city officials, to-night tore up the Delaware, Lackawanna, and Western tracks from the Water Street crossing, regarded as the most dangerous in the city.

LONDON, April 6. -- There was a plethora of money in the market to-day, but there was a moderate demand, owing to the consols settlement, while heavy repayments were made to the Bank of England. The issue of u2,000,000 of new Treasury bills on April 11 will, it is expected, reduce supplies and have a steadying effect on discounts.

Perry Belmont was re-elected President of the Turf and Field Club at the annual meeting of that organization on Tuesday night at the Union Club. All of the other officers were also re-elected as follows: Vice President--Brayton Ives; Treasurer--Francis R. Appleton; Secretary--E.C. La Montagne; Assistant Secretary--Algernon Daingerfield.

We suppose Mr. ARTHUR BRISBANE'S letter about the Presidential ambition of Mr. HEARST, published in The Herald yesterday, must be accepted as the best justification of the Hearst candidacy that can be made. Mr. BRISBANE is the editor of Mr. HEARST'S newspaper, The American.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 6. -- Ex-Attorney General John P. Elkin of Indiana County was nominated unanimously for Supreme Court Justice to-day by the Republican State Convention. Gov. Samuel W. Pennypacker, James Elverson of Philadelphia, O.D. Bleakley of Franklin, and Francis L. Robbins of Pittsburg were elected delegates at large to the National Convention, and instructed to vote for the nomination of President Roosevelt.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., April 6. -- Alderman Joseph Gilbert, who was known throughout Northern Pennsylvania as the "marrying Alderman," died at his residence in this city this afternoon from pneumonia.
ALBANY, April 6. -- Frank M. Baker's nomination as Railroad Commissioner was to-day confirmed by the Senate by a vote of 30 to 18.

With Bishop Edward G. Andrews presiding, the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church opened its one hundred and fifth session yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. W.F. Brush was elected Secretary, A.A. Walker Statistical Secretary, Arthur Thompson Treasurer, and R.L. Ross Postmaster.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 6. -- Charles Murphy, William Brace, and Edward Wright, according to reports in Bradley Beach and the vicinity of Shark River, were drowned in that river Monday morning.
ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, April 6. -- I have been cruising since I sent the last message.

SALT LAKE, Utah, April 6. -- Just before the large congregation attending the final session of the semi-annual conference of the Mormons was dismissed this afternoon. President Joseph F. Smith, the head of the church, read a manifesto repudiating plural marriages. He said:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 6. -- Will Carleton, the ballad poet, and Miss Fannie Crosby, the blind poetess, are fighting each other in the courts. Miss Crosby has instructed her attorneys to bring suit against Carleton to force him to make an accounting to her of the sale of a certain book called "Fannie Crosby, Her Life Work," also to bring an injunction to restrain him from continuing its publication.

While attempting to save a woman from being killed in the Melrose yards of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad yesterday afternoon John Haverly, a brakeman, twenty-four years old, of 653 Courtlandt Avenue, had his left leg cut off clean, close to the hip and also sustained serious internal injuries.

RICHMOND, Va., April 6. -- The New York American League team played an errorless game to-day, and defeated the Montreal team by 4 to 0. Chesbro and Hughes, who pitched in four and five innings each, were batted for four singles each. Ganzel made the only two-base hit of the game, in the third inning, when two of New York's four runs were made.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- A curious occurrence at the White House which happened ten days ago came to light to-day. It has been kept dark for some reason by everybody concerned, and was revealed to-day by Representative Baker of Brooklyn.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 6. -- The Cornell 'Varsity crew and the two junior 'Varsity eights rowed to-night for the first time this year on Cayuga Lake. Coach Courtney followed the men in the launch, and made them pull to Crowbar Point and back, a distance of twelve miles. The oarsmen have been rowing on the inlet for nearly two weeks, and stood the hard practice well, although all were tired when they reached the boathouse.

Antonio Ferratti of 118 Mulberry Street, better known as "The Passionate Antonio," on account of the fervor with which he grinds "Hiawatha" and "Bedelia" from his street piano, has met with a sad misfortune. His sole means of livelihood -- the piano -- has been ruined forever by the eccentricity of a horse which he purchased to drag the instrument through the streets. The horse is dead too, and that augments Antonio's grief.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- The expectation that there might be, based on the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of South Dakota vs. North Carolina, an effort to enforce the payment of a large amount of Southern State and Confederate bonds which for many years have been considered worthless, does not receive much encouragement iron lawyers here who are conversant with the facts in the case in question.

WASHINGTON, April 6. -- Bishop Spalding of Peoria, a member of the Anthracite Coal Strike Commission, to-day urged the plan of arbitration contained in the Foss bill before the House Committee on Labor. The bill provides for a permanent Board of Arbitration, to which shall be referred disputes between labor and capital.

Further details which came to light yesterday regarding the large purchases of real estate at Rector Street and Trinity Place disclosed the plans of the United States Express Company to erect a large office building on the site, which will be occupied jointly by that corporation and the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

Mrs. Anna Roberts of Eighth Avenue and One Hundred and Eleventh Street was the victim of a bold highway robbery on the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street station of the west side elevated roads at 1:30 o'clock this morning.

The stock market yesterday met every reasonable expectation. That is to say, although there was some loss of buoyancy, except in restricted cases, there was an increase of activity, and, although there were a few more fractional declines and limitation in the number and extent of the advances of a point or more, nevertheless maintained strength was the day's characteristic, and was all the more remarkable because occurring on four consecutive days.
WASHINGTON, April 7. -- A representative and distinguished company attended the dinner of the Periodical Publishers' Association of America given at the New Willard Hotel to-night.

On Easter Sunday my mother, while returning from the Church of the Transfiguration, was run down by a boy on a bicycle, while crossing Fifth Avenue, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets. She was getting out of the way of a carriage, when run into by the boy on the bicycle, and was thrown backward, striking on the back of her head.

It was inevitable, but all the same it is depressing, that the general raising of rents upon the lower east side should bring out in force the Socialist and the "crank." These have been very much in evidence at the meetings held to protest against the increase. But it is reassuring to learn that these mischief-making agitators have not succeeded in making much mischief among the class to which they appeal.

CHICAGO, April 7. -- A special car containing sixty-three Indians belonging to Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show was smashed in a collision between the Oregon Express and a fast mail train on the Chicago and Northwestern Railway near Maywood, Ill., to-day during a fog. Both trains were east-bound.

While testifying in his own behalf, during his trial on the charge of perjury in connection with an alleged fraudulent bail bond before Recorder Goff and a jury in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, Herman Froelich of 1,877 Third Avenue, a professional bondsman, by his own admission, declared that he had divided the fees for his services with four Police Sergeants.

DEDHAM, Mass., April 7. -- The divorce libel of Mrs. Augusta Partridge against the noted sculptor, William Ordway Partridge, was heard before Judge Wait in Norfolk County Superior Court to-day. There was nothing sensational brought out and no contest. Mr. Partridge was present with his counsel, but took no part in the proceedings.

Your issue of this morning contains an item which I should like to correct, for the information of my friends in Greater New York and elsewhere, who have aided me in my labor of love for Mrs. Van Alstine, (Fanny Cosby.)

The voters or Chicago probably supposed that they had before them on Tuesday the clear issue of municipal ownership and operation of street railways. The vote of 120,000 to 50,000 in favor of the proposition that the city at once take the street railways into its control may be accepted, therefore, as a fair measure of the strength of the municipal ownership movement in that city.

ALBANY, April 7. -- The plans of Dr. Andrew S. Draper, the new Commissioner of Education, for the unification and organization of the State Educational Departments, were submitted by him to-day to the Regents of the university in their first meeting as recreated under the unification law, and were unanimously approved.

BOSTON, April 7. -- A dispatch from Providence says that Addison's disease has caused the death there of Miss Violetta M. Potter, a beautiful young society woman, who lived with her parents at 746 North Main Street.

Bridge Commissioner Best has altered his plans for a Brooklyn Bridge terminal and forwarded a communication to that effect yesterday to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, where the matter will be taken up to-day. The Commissioner now advocates the cutting down of the bridge terminal so that it will extend north only to Duane Street, instead of to Worth Street, as first planned.
The ambition of Lincoln Mason of 435 Eighth Street, Hoboken, to be a second "Volo, the Wizard Volltant," was nipped in the bud yesterday at the Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, April 7. -- Representative W.S. Cowherd of Missouri was elected Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee without opposition to-night.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The Senate to-day listened to eulogies of the late Senator Hanna by Messrs. Foraker, Scott, Cockrell, Platt of Connecticut, Cullom, Blackburn, Elkins, Fairbanks, Daniel, Perkins, Depew, Beveridge, Dolliver, Kearns, and Dick.
NATCHEZ, Miss., April 7. -- A violent storm, which in some districts reached the proportions of a tornado, swept over parts of Mississippi and Texas to-day.

ALBANY, April 7. -- This was a field day for the so-called "grab" bills. Several of the most favored of the measures were passed and several more were advanced. The principal "grabs," passed by either one body or the other, were the Niagara Power bill, the Merritt Water Storage bill, and the Ramapo Water bill.

With only a single dissenting vote the Chamber of Commerce at its regular monthly meeting yesterday adopted resolutions requesting Commissioner McAdoo to establish in the Police Department a Bureau of Street Traffic for the particular purpose of regulating the matter of sidewalk obstruction by merchants through an ordinance proposed by the Chamber.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- It is no uncommon thing for a member of the House to be a prominent Presidential possibility, but it is a very unusual thing for a Congressman to be thus vividly in the limelight and yet for so little to be known about his work in Congress as is the case with William Randolph Hearst.

ALBANY, April 7. -- The Hill Automobile bill passed the Assembly to-day without discussion. It regulates in detail the registration and identification of motor vehicles and the use of the public highways by such vehicles. Display of registration numbers on aluminum seals affixed to the vehicle and chauffeurs' licenses and registration are prescribed in detail.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 7. -- After all, it appears that the beautiful place at Morristown, N.J., known as Erin Farm is not the property of Hubert M. Hartigan, who was coachman for Granville W. Garth and who has been the reputed owner. A deed was placed on file with the County Clerk to-day conveying the property from Hartigan to Mr. Garth's widow.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 7. -- Three favorites again finished in front at the Benning track to-day, but May Holladay, a 20 to 1 outsider, produced consternation in the ranks of the talent by defeating City Bank in the third race, at six furlongs, John Madden's colt showed a complete reversal of form.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The Census Bureau to-day issued a bulletin which gives the estimated population of the United States for 1903, exclusive of Alaska and the insular possessions of the United States, as 79,900,389. This is an increase of 3,905,814 since the census of 1900.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7. -- Detective James Tate, Jr., and William Laycock, a jeweler of this city, left here to-day for Washington to bring Back George J. Engleman, the diamond thief who was arrested there last night and is wanted here for robbing Mr. Laycock of $2,500 worth of diamonds.

ORANGE, N.J., April 7. -- Residents of Orange were treated this afternoon to the novel spectacle of a graveyard ablaze. The firemen were called out and it was fully half an hour before the flames were controlled and extinguished.
The grounds at Olympic Field were in such bad condition yesterday that the game between Yale and Manhattan College nines had to be postponed. Both teams were on hand and ready to play.

PACIFIC GROVE, Cal., April 7. -- Miss Nathalle P. Schenck of New York was married about 9 o'clock this morning in the Episcopal Chapel, attached to the Del Monte Hotel, to Capt. Glen Colins, who served with the British Army in the Boer war.

LONDON, April 7. -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day and was plentiful and cheap, though there were indications that the supplies were being reduced. The issue of 2,400,000 of Cape Treasury bills, together with the announcement of the issue of 2,000,000 of new British Treasury bills on April 11, strengthened discounts.

Collector Stranahan announced yesterday that he had appointed a commission consisting of representatives of the Chamber of Commerce, the Merchants' Association, the warehouse interests of this city, and the customs service to revise the schedules of charges for storage, labor, and cartage on general order goods.

LIVERPOOL, April 7. -- At a meeting to-day of the Cunard Steamship Company the Chairman, Lord Inverclyde, warned the dock authorities that if they continued to hamper the company's operations by increased charges the transfer of the Cunard ships to another port would result.

Two soldiers confined in the guardhouse at Fort Wadsworth sawed their way to liberty yesterday afternoon and escaped. They were Thomas Cushman and William Waddington. Both were privates in the Fiftieth Company, Coast Artillery. Six months ago, less five days, Waddington was sentenced to six months in the guard house for technical desertion -- that is, he had overstayed leave of absence, but returned voluntarily.

The indignation of the Ghetto against the east side landlords, which has gathered force and spread, like an angry wave, through that densely peopled district because the tenants cannot longer pay their higher rents, began to crystallize yesterday in measures for relief.

All sorts and kinds of things are being made for the pocket or shopping bag. One of these is a Small pair of scissors, which is put up in a flat metal case like those in which the vest pocket pencil is carried, a trifle more than three inches long. They cost 50 cents.

ALBANY, April 7. -- Railroad attorneys and lobbyists became thoroughly alive today to the fact that it was they and not the Merchants' Association who had "bought gold bricks" in the amended mandamus feature of the bill for two additional Railroad Commissioners, introduced by Senator Wilcox at the instigation of the Merchants' Association.

WESTON, Mass., April 7. -- So extraordinary is the case of the murder of Miss Mabel Page judged to be that to-day State's Attorney General Herbert Parker visited the scene of the crime to make a close scrutiny of the premises and to examine personally the members of the Page household. Such action by an Attorney General is unprecedented in the history of the Commonwealth.

WASHINGTON, April 7. -- The House Committee on Labor to-day decided to refer the eight-hour bill to Secretary of Commerce and Labor Cortelyou with a request for a report on the following points to be made to the committee at the next session of Congress:

NORFOLK, Va., April 7. -- The Brooklyns did not find things so easy to-day against the Norfolk team as they did yesterday, winning by only 7 to 5. All but one hit of the visitors was made off Jones in the first four innings. Score by innings:

WICHITA, Kan., April 7. -- The Democratic State Convention to-day elected twenty uninstructed delegates to the National Convention. The delegates-at-large are W.A. Harris, H.T. Farrelly, David Overmyer, J.G. Johnson, S.I. Hale, and J.F. Haymaker. The delegation, according to personal preferences, will stand six for Hearst and fourteen against him, it is said.

RICHMOND, Va., April 7. -- The New York American League team gave the Montreals of the Eastern League another drubbing to-day, and for the second time the Canadians were unable to score a run. Powell had the Montreal men at his mercy, while the Americans had no trouble in batting the three opposing pitchers. The fielding of the New Yorkers at times was sensational, The score:

ALBANY, April 7. -- Feeling ran high between majority leader Rogers and minority leader Palmer to-day when Assemblyman McKeown blocked for a time Assemblyman Prentice's efforts to have his anti-policy bill, defeated a few days ago, amended to meet the objections of some of his Republican colleagues.

As a result of the first night's sale of the Dowdeswell Dowdeswell, and the Blakeslee art collections at Mendelssohn Hall last night, eighty-three pictures brought $57,825. The sale was under the auspices of the American Art Association, Thomas E. Kirby being the auctioneer. Though the bidding was often spirited and good prices were usually realized, yet the hall with its gallery was not even comfortably filled, the company being largely professional.
Details will be found in another column relative to the purchase by the American Society of Civil Engineers of property on West Fifty-seventh Street adjoining their present clubhouse.

PARIS, April 7. -- A Parisian who has just returned from St. Petersburg tells me it is the impression there that the war will continue certainly for two years. There are, he says, only about three months in the year during which military operations can be carried on without obstacles due to the elements.

Miss Annie Miller of 342 East Forty-seventh Street was boarding a west bound car at Thirty-fourth Street and Second Avenue, on her way to work, yesterday morning when a man who later said that he was John Kenny, but who is known to the police as John Connelly, alias Carey, brushed past her on the step.
An excited Italian dashed into the Fifth Street Police Station at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Republican conventions were held in all the Assembly districts of Manhattan and the Bronx last night to name delegates and alternates to the State Convention, which will meat in Carnegie Hall next Tuesday. In only eleven of the thirty-five districts were the delegates instructed for Roosevelt for President, although in many more of the districts resolutions were passed indorsing the administration of the President in such terms as to be almost equivalent to instructions.

HOUSTON, Texas, April 7. -- Cecil A. Lyon, State Chairman of the Republican Party and next National Committeeman from Texas, does not favor William Randolph Hearst for President, but hopes to see him nominated for that office by the Democrats.

PARIS, April 7. -- The Russian naval plan for retrieving the reverses at Port Arthur and Che-mul-pho has been communicated to one of the embassies through official channels having access to the highest naval authorities at St. Petersburg. The plan is explained as follows:

Joshua Crane, Jr., the present holder of the indoor court tennis championship, and Charles E. Sands, the runner-up last year, won their matches yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club, West Forty-third Street, in the semi-final round of the National tournament which will determine the champion for the coming year.

Edwin Hawley had an interesting time of it yesterday on the witness stand in the examination before Commissioner Alexander, which Elihu Root conducted in the interest of the creditors and the receivers of Daniel J. Sully Co., the failed cotton firm. Mr. Root tried to induce Mr. Hawley to tell what he thought a joint account was, and Mr. Hawley's answer caused laughter among those of Mr. Sully's creditors who were in court.
PARIS, April 7. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes:

ALBANY, April 7. -- The three Rapid Transit bills to-day passed the Senate under an emergency message from the Governor. The two bills which were introduced by Senator White at the request of the Rapid Transit Commission were put through with very little opposition, and the Elsberg bill had no opposition at all.

John Strange Winter is almost as industrious as the indefatigable Mr. Brady. "Cherry's Child," the latest issue of her fertile brain, is a story of the love difficulties of a beautiful young thing of seventeen whose real name is Geraldine, but whose father prefers to call her Nell, out of compliment to his first love, who was not Cherry, his wife, and the girl's mother.

LONDON, April 9. -- The Anglo-French colonial treaty was signed at the Foreign Office here yesterday. It comprises three separate instruments, the main features of which have been outlined from time to time in The Associated Press dispatches.

THE publisher have evidently given up all hope that better times will ever come. The Spring publishing season, with a war in the East and a general election close at hand, ought to be a very dull one, but the publishers have decided that they might as well ignore war and elections and send out the books that they have been hoping to publish in a more favorable season.

Both of the New York teams of the National and American Leagues arrived home from their Southern trip yesterday, and a month's practice has put the men in excellent physical condition. Some, however, are not in the form they displayed last year, but it is expected that by the time the championships began on next Thursday all will be fit for one of the liveliest baseball seasons in years.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8. -- Frederick D. Kilburn, State Superintendent of Banking of New York, spoke here to-night before the American Academy of Political and Social Science on the control of trust companies. He described the management of the Trust Company of the Republic in connection with the United tSates Shipbuilding affair, and said that the promotion of questionable enterprises should be made a penal offence.

There was a hot time yesterday among the striking asphalt workers over the attempts of the companies to put new men to work. A riot involving about 100 Italians occurred early in the day at Orchard and Grand Streets, between employes of the Uvalde Asphalt Paving Company and seventy-five strikers.

In yesterday's issue Mr. John K. Hoyt points out the common misquotation, "He who runs may read," contrary to the authorized version, "He may run that readeth it." Mr. Hoyt explains the passenger as "a distinct warning to run away from impending danger."

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Replying to a criticism of the use of the naval steam yacht Mayflower, filed in the House for reproduction in The Congressional Record by Representative Williams of Mississippi, in the form of a newspaper clipping, Representative Foss, Chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, to-day filed, also to be printed in The Record, a letter from Secretary Moody, giving a detailed history of the use of the Mayflower by the President.

THIS world is described as "a book of great value to the merchant, manufacturer, banker, broker, commission merchant, credit man, real estate broker or agent, fire insurance broker or agent, contractor and material man, landlord, tenant, partner, executor or administrator, guardian, trustee, and all persons engaged in business or interested in estates."

" The Middle Kingdom," by the late Dr. S. Wells Williams, deserves a place in every list of books on China. It has been regarded as an authority for many years, and has passed through several editions. Archibald Little's "Through the Yang-tse Gorges" and his wife's "Intimate China" should find room there also, the latter having been highly praised, I am told, by the Chinese Ambassador in London.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8. -- Success at last has crowned the efforts of the surgeons of the University Hospital to graft a nose on the face of Oscar Leonard. After three attempts had failed through the patient's inability to stand the fearful agony of the operation, the fourth has now proved entirely satisfactory to the surgeons and Leonard alike.

A heroine, young, beautiful, modest, and pure; a hero, manly, brave, courteous, devoted, heroic; a villain, white-livered and cowardly; a woman scorned; a maiden aunt, an a bachelor uncle; a valet prompt to act, and of wooden imperturbability of countenance, and various other "odds and ends " -- these are the dramatis personae in the story of "The Bride of Glendearg."

" The snob," says Mrs. Atherton in her new novel "Rulers of Kings," which Messrs. Harper Brothers publish in this country April 14, and the Macmillans simultaneously abroad, "is a man who furnishes comedy for others and tragedy for himself." This may serve to show that in her forthcoming adventure in international fiction Mrs. Atherton has not ceased her coinage of epigrams.

BOSTON, April 8. -- A plal for the reorganization of the Fore River Ship and Engine Company has been agreed upon. It is proposed to issue $4,800,000 in stock, equally divided between common and preferred, and to raise $1,250,000 of new money by assessing the bondholders 40 per cent. and the old preferred stock 33 1-3 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 8. -- The Baltimore Eastern League Club defeated the Brooklyn National League team in an exhibition game here to-day by a score of 9 to 4. The Brooklyn pitchers were batted for ten singles, four doubles, and two three-baggers. Sheckard hit the hall over the right field fence for a home run.

Ancient evils die hard. The demand for the abolition of the useless office of Coroner, which has no place in the present system of the administration of criminal law and serves no better purpose than to obstruct justice, has been emphatic for many years and has had the approval of public-spirited citizens and all interested in the administration of the laws for the ends for which they are designed.

ALBANY, April 8. -- Only through an agitation in New York, the force of which shall be irresistible, can the Elsberg Rapid Transit bill be passed. That it is the present purpose of those who now control the fate of the bill not to let it out of the Assembly Rules Committee can be said with absolute authority.

An open-air school for burglars and murderers has been discovered in the Tuileries Gardens, Paris, by two special detectives appointed to watch all suspected persons in that place. While walking near the ornamental plot where the bird-charmer, M. Pol. feeds sparrows daily, the detective observed a curious-looking old man sitting on one of the seats, and conversing in a most serious manner with two youths of seedy and disreputable appearance.
BERLIN, April 8. -- The influence of forests upon climate was the subject of discussion at the annual meeting of the German Meteorological Society here yesterday.

Again a modest collection of fragments of rural tragedies, framed in a mystic religious atmosphere, discoverable suggestions at once of Hardy and the Morte D'Arthur, as Tennyson writes it. There is the good lady, a widow, whose only son is a highwayman; filial piety is used to decoy the young man to his death.

This story of Spanish America, of the Incas, of the Conquistadores, of Spanish tyrannies, of bloody and treacherous dictators and Governors, of the "liberators," Miranda, Bolivar, and San Martin, was published in 1898 and designed by its own profession as all "introduction" to popular knowledge of the southern continent.

Postmaster Van Cott, half a dozen Post Office Inspectors, and the Superintendent of the High Bridge Station spent a very busy afternoon yesterday as the result of a report that $25,000 in gilt-edged railway bonds had gone astray after having been delivered by mistake to W.S. Reid of 537 West One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street, and returned by him to the letter carrier.

-- There is great interest, and for several reasons, in the news that Dr. GEORGE T. MOORE of the Department of Agriculture has "dedicated," by which we understand has given, to the people of the United States a patent taken out by him on a process of producing the microbes that enable leguminous plants to absorb nitrogen from the air, for use later by other plants unable to do, this even with bacterial assistance.

George H.F. Nuttall, M.A., M.D., Ph. D., University Lecturer in Bacteriology and Preventive Medicine, Cambridge, England, has collected the researches he made in the Pathological Laboratory of Cambridge University during 1902 into a volume entitled "Blood Immunity and Blood Relationship: A Demonstration of Certain Blood-Relationships Among Animals by Means of the Precipitin Test for Blood."

Six arrests were made yesterday in connection with the mysterious death of "Boston Frank," a hanger-on about the saloon of Herman Wasser, 147 Attorney Street, Thursday night, in the room of Annie Kriepzick of 149 Attorney Street.

Generals are not such awe-inspiring perons. Even in the stress of war they sometimes have leisure to concoct little practical jokes with the staff officers. Such a little Joke is the essence of Mr. Brady's latest -- or is it his latest? -- story.

MR. ALEXANDER INNES SHAND'S "Memories" of The London Times in this month's Cornhill Magazine is one of the most entertaining features of a number of that long-established English monthly, which is unusually full of good literary entertainment, from Frederic Harrison's article on Sir Leslie Stephen to Judge Prowle's on "Old-Time Newfoundland," including Henry W. Lucy's bright chapter on Washington in the present hour and Andrew Lang's "Strange Case of David Dunglas Home."

Prof. Borden P. Bowne of Boston University was, by the unanimous vote of the committee appointed to try him, acquitted yesterday of the charges of heresy preferred against him by the Rev. George A. Cooke of West Medford. Mass., before the New York East Conference. All of the members of the conference broke into prolonged and enthusiastic applause at the announcement.
CHICAGO, April 8. -- In an interview relating to Northern Securities matters a local newspaper quotes James J. Hill, who was in Chicago to-day, as follows:

BOSTON, April 8. -- Mrs. "Jack" Gardner was to-day mulcted in the sum of $1,892 for the ill behavior of a dog which she contended was not hers, although it had belonged to her but a short-time before it bit ten-year-old Mary Callahan, who was playing in the vicinity of the Fenway palace.

The chief general interest attaching to this story of the life of a woman medical missionary among the Koreans in the years since 1888 Mes of course in the light it throws upon the attitude of the Koreans themselves toward the two nations who are now making their country a battle-ground.

Although Clement A. Griscom, Jr., and Samuel Bettle have not as yet tendered their resignations from the service of the International Mercantile Marine, there are increasing indications of the activity on the part of the combine's new President, J. Bruce Ismay, in reorganizing the executive force of the company.

PERHAPS one does not get a perfectly true picture of Japan and the Japanese from Mrs. Fraser's letters thus opportunity republished. One must think that the letters are a refracting meadium distorting rather than reflecting faithfully the actual, for Mrs. Fraser is a woman and a sentimentalist, but nobody can read them at this time without interest and profit.

A Baltimore correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS reiterates the claim made by William Morton Payne, that Messrs. Woodberry and Moody are the greatest living American poets. He also cites the authority of Dr. Henry van Dyke, who is said to have expressed the same opinion in an interview last December.

The "Village of the Day Before Yesterday" is certainly fast fading from memory, and yet to most of us who are not city bred it rises up a lovely skeleton of past joys to haunt us. That is why so many people are going to thank Mrs. Sara Andrew Shafer for replacing flesh on those dried bones and making the village live again.

The rapidly increasing mass of fiction -- below the order of mediocrity -- inflicted upon a long-suffering reading public has aroused a considerable measure of adverse criticism of late, to which THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW has contributed, as evidenced by the editorial comment contained in the issue of April 2. Well-timed, indeed, is the protest.

The letter of Mr. John I. Platt, published in THE TIMES of April 4, is very interesting. Mr. Platt defends the bill introduced by Assemblyman John T. Smith and designed to prevent the City of New York from taking water from the two most important streams in Dutchess County from the imputation that the bill is in the interest of the Ramapo Company.

By the action of the Board of Aldermen, made effective yesterday by the signature of the Mayor, the open space formed by the intersection of Broadway and Seventh Avenue, and extending from Forty-second to Forty-seventh Street, hitherto popularly known as "Long Acre Square," received the name of Times Square.

The editor of the Temple biographies introduces Prof. Dowden's "Browning" with a quotation from Gladstone: "In the case of those whom the public has learned to honor and admire there is a biography of the mind that is a matter of deep interest." The volume thus introduced aims and purports to be such a biography.

The New York State Library's list of books of the year, just published, contains 784 titles. These were chosen from 7,865 books published last year. The list was then, as usual, submitted to the librarians of this State, and other persons, for a vote as to which are the best 50 for the uses of a village library.

The creditors of Daniel J. Sully Co. had a lively session late yesterday afternoon. They had been called to meet at the instance of their committee of five to hear the report regarding its efforts to bring about a favorable settlement.
LONDON, April 9. -- The Times's military correspondent, in discussing the apparent slow progress of the war, says:

GOUVERNEUR MORRIS, who will be recalled to the reading public as the author of "Tom Beauling" and Aladdin O'Brien," although remembered in New York society for other reasons, has written a new love story, which will appear as a Summer serial in The Century before its publication in book form in the Autumn.

Trouble which has been brewing for weeks between Controller Grout and President Littleton of the Borough of Brooklyn, and which has come to the surface in the course of almost every meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, reached its height at yesterday's session when the Borough President challenged the Controller's veracity.

Mr. Brett, the President of the Macmillan Company, who has just returned to New York from a business trip to London, announces that arrangements have been made for the issue of Mr. Maurice Hewlett's new novel May 20. "The Queen's Quair" has been in great part rewritten since its serial appearance in magazines.

McClure, Phillips Co. report that August Sabatier's "Religions of Authority" has gone into a second edition: the third edition of Rose E. Young's "Sally of Missouri," which, by the way, will shortly be published in England, and that Edgar Jepson's amusing story, "The Admirable Tinker," and Mrs. H.A. Mitchell Keays's divorce novel, "He That Eateth Bread with Me," have been called for by Australian booksellers.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Senator Burton returned here this morning and spent the day at his office in the Maltby Annex. He did not appear in the Senate chamber and made no statement. Two or three Democratic Senators called on him and expressed their sympathy.

A decision important to linen importers by the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday partially sustained a series of protests by Dunham, Buckley Co. of New York and others. It was written by General Appraiser Marion De Veries.

PARIS, April 8. -- According to private information I have received from St. Petersburg, the powers that be in Russia manifest increased concern as to the sequel to the war, that is to say, the possibility of being hampered by the interference of foreign powers in the conclusion of peace.

In view of the fact that builders of fine residences are seeking more and more the territory east of Central Park, yesterday's announcement that John Innes Kane will erect a handsome dwelling at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street was one of special interest.

ALBANY, April 8. -- The bill providing for the appointment of trial Commissioners in the First Judicial, Department, which was introduced by Senator Brackett, was passed in the Assembly this morning by vote of 81 to 88.
SEOUL, April 8. -- The steamship Suminoye Maru called at Che-mul-pho to-day to take on board 300 men belonging to the First Division.

" Bayard's Journal," sometimes called "The Lost Bradford Journal," being William Bradford's first publication in New York, ("A Narrative of an Attempt Made by the French of Canada upon the Mohaque's Country." New York: Dodd, Mead Co.,) is reproduced in fac simile from the edition of 1693, printed in this country.

Both Gov. Odell and Senator Thomas C. Platt recahed New York last night, and conferred at the Fifth Avenue Hotel over the plans for the Republican State Convention to be held on Tuesday next in Carnegie Hall.
Your editorial of the 28th inst., regarding leakage of city water, is what is needed to stimulate the Department of Water Supply to get down to business.

In The Dial of Chicago Mr. H.W. Boynton writes with intelligence and feeling of the differences between the work of the reviewer of current books and the critic whose function is "agreeably limited to the walled gardens of literature." Mr. Boynton thinks Jules Lemaltre's dictum that "criticism of our contemporaries is not really criticism, hut simply conversation," altogether too sweeping, as it "fairly asperses the value of any sort of individual judgment."

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- With fields of good size in several of the events, the racing at Benning to-day was interesting, the finishes being quite exciting. Although it rained during the afternoon the attendance was unusually large.
ALBANY, April 8. -- Among the bills passed by the Senate to-day were the following:

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 8. -- Wilson P. Durbrow, a wealthy resident of this village, whose home is in Charleton Avenue, a few weeks ago went South with his family, after notifying the police and his neighbors, that his house would be closed until he returned. Consequently when John Mills passed by this morning and saw a strange man and woman standing in an upper window he rushed for the nearest telephone.
LONDON, April 8. -- The demand for money was quiet in the market to-day. The supplies were fairly plentiful and the borrowings from the Bank of England were liquidated.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 8. -- The four home rule bills relating to the City of New York, introduced by the Senate Committee on Cities and which passed the Senate yesterday, were reported out of the Assembly Rules Committee to-night and will come up on the calendar to-morrow morning.

Charles Scribner's Sons are bringing out the fourth edition, enlarged and revised, of J. Dyer Ball's "Things Chinese, or Notes Connected with China." This is a cyclopaedia, the result of nearly forty years spent in observing and studying the Chinese in their own land in almost every as pect of their life and character.

ALBANY, April 8. -- The Remsen East River gas "grab" bill went through the Senate to-day. The vote was 35 to 12, and Senators Elsberg and Marshall were the only two to raise their voices in protest, and even their protests were feeble.

THE book on "How to Know the Butterflies," which D. Appleton Co. will publish very shortly, is by John Henry Comstock, Professor of entomology in Cornell University, and Anna Botsford Comstock, Lecturer in Nature Study, Cornell. It is a companion volume to Chapman's "Bird Life," and designed as a general treatise on butterflies and a manual of the species of the United States east of the Rockies.

The revised "New Modern Webster Dictionary of the English Language," by E.T. Roe, compiler of "Webster's New Standard Dictionary," is handy for grammar, high school, and general use. All the words are sanctioned by good authority, including technical and scientific terms that have passed into our everyday speech.

The police of the Tenderloin station are much perturbed these days. Until yesterday no outsiders knew the cause of the worried lines upon the faces of the Sergeants, Roundsmen, and patrolmen or of the interest which they suddenly displayed in the ribbon and lace windows of the Sixth Avenue department stores.

A VOLUME containing the signature of "Wm. Shakespere" will be offered for sale in London in the Sotheby auction rooms Thursday, April 21. The signature is said to be Shakespeare's, but the majority of collectors will doubtless question its authenticity.

The reflection is forced upon my mind as to why THE TIMES enlarges in so many issues on "the question of lying," whereas most of the other daily papers are shy and evade touching such a delicate subject.

I am a "constant reader" of THE NEW YORK (Saturday) TIMES, as well as of numerous other Book Reviews. My one criticism is that few reviews review. Nine out of every ten notes and comments are identically the same thing. Of course, synonyms are used, or the fifteen-two puzzle arrangement of words is possible, but the underlying thought (or lack of it) is the same.

THE ENGLISH BOOK TRADE. -- It is usually held that such events as a big war or a general election interfere seriously with the general sale of books. A great public crisis is believed to drive the reading public to the daily and weekly papers and away from any books save those which directly deal with the crisis in question.

Some time ago Dr. Rowland published some short stories of men no better than they should be -- adventurers of the Eastern seas. Now Dr. Rowland gives us a novel. It is the history of a big New Englander who built ships and sailed in them in order to pay his way through Yale and get the diploma of a Doctor of Medicine.

WITH a broken and a contrite heart I confess at once that I regard my own judgment as worse than useless regarding latter-day fiction. Time was when I laid the flattering unction to my soul that I knew a good novel from a bad one -- on sight. It did not seem necessary, in those halcyon days, to literally read every page before gaining an impression.

No one who admires the greatness of Washington and the simplicity of his character can fail to be interested in anything that concerns the mother, Mary Ball Washington, to whom America owes his birth and early training. One of the most charming books of the season is "The Mother of Washington and Her Times," by Mrs. Roger A. Pryor of New York City.

Mr. ROOSEVELT touched an essential element of the question of international relations when he said to the publishers: "Individual courtesy is a good thing and international courtesy is quite as good a thing." And he was right in saying that the forces of steam and electricity, with the spread of the press, which have brought all the peoples of the earth so much nearer together, make the duty of international courtesy more obligatory.

Even in this isolated corner of creation the criticism by Miss Stone of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden," which was printed in your issue of March 5, was read with much relish and enthusiasm, and the many replies it has called forth with equal interest.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 8. -- Coley Hayden, nineteen years old, was shot at the State College Baseball Park to-day by Lee Anderson, a State College student, who was acting as guard at the park. The bullet entered Hayden's left shoulder and inflicted a serious wound.

In your article on "Ghost Stories," in THE REVIEW of March 26, 1904, Page 202, you are correct in saying that the first of the stories desired by your correspondent is "What Was It?" but the second story desired is not a "Terrible Night," but another story, "Horror: A True Tale," published in Harper's Magazine for March, 1861.

Of tragic ghosts of old Japan, stately, armed, and splendid, proud and cruel and passionate, or humble and faithful merely, Mrs. Fraser has made the persons of this story. There is, first, Jito, most glorious Empress-mother of the Infant Son of Heaven, and there is, second, haughty Kashima, war lord or Daimyo, who impiously loves the Empress and as impiously burns the palace and steals both Empress and Emperor.
PARIS, April 8. -- The Anglo-French colonial treaty was signed in London to-day.
In your issue of March 26 the literary specialist who reviewed my novel, "In Passion's Dragnet," under caption of A Book of Strong Emotions," has this to say:

The sale of the nothesast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street by George C. Boldt and the purchase of the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street by John Innis Kane, are referred to in more detail in another column.

We observe with interest that the Republican National Committeeman from Texas has found a new source of Presidential unavailability for Congressman HEARST. "NO man," says this authority, "who parts his hair in the middle can ever carry Texas for the Presidency."

Although a jury in Part 13 of the Supreme Court yesterday returned a verdict pronouncing James H. Temple, ex-President of the bankrupt William Campbell Wall Paper Company, not guilty of converting to his own use some $40,000 of the funds of the company, Temple had to go back to Ludlow Street Jail, where he has been confined since early in January in default of $25,000 bail.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 8. -James Barry was frightfully burned and torn and his eleven-year-old daughter was killed this morning by an explosion of dynamite in Woodbridge Township, near Rahway. The accident, it is thought, was due to carelessness, and Prosecutor Berdine is making an investigation of the case.

Mrs. Eggleston describes his latest work as "a story of adventure and success," and this is exactly what it is, with the addition of a little advice concerning means of achieving success. But this advice is so deftly woven into the story that boy readers will absorb it unconsciously and without feelings of resentment toward the adviser.

LONDON, April 8. -- Henry Frowde is about to publish "Queen Victoria and the Levant Company," which sets forth the details of the curious diplomatic and literary incidents developed in establishing British trading relations in Constantinople.

There was some news of specific application yesterday, but none of deep or general interest. The market, therefore, lacked reason for movement as an entirety, and was in general left more to itself than it has been for several days. Under these conditions there was a loss of activity and strength, and a more moderate price movement, which was not altogether favorable.

The peaceful nature of the title of Mr. Burrow's latest novel, "Who Yeoman," hardly prepares one for the distressing states of mental agony into which most of its characters are plunged at the earliest possible moment, only to be extricated in the last two chapters, and then at the expense of two more or less tragic deaths.

WHEN persons whom one regards with esteem and affection are attacked by adverse criticism, the impulse to go to their defense is well-nigh irresistible, and the same is true when those books which have become endeared to us are subjected to unmerited censure.

The Baker Taylor Company has made arrangements with Edgar Stanton Maclay to write a series of books on the Unknown Heroes of Our Navy. Mr. Maclay will tell about the work of the United States's maritime forces in the Revolution and during the war of 1812. The first book will be "Moses Brown, Captain U.S.N."

George C, Boldt has just completed another successful real state operation by the sale of the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street, facing the new Public Library. The property consists of a six-story building, on a lot 23 by 100, with stores on the street floor and apartments above.

Here is an ideal book for the young person" -- that inexorable critic whose judgment is rarely swayed by any of the finer or artistic settings of a story. To "the young person" a book is either "good" or "bad," and surely few will be inclined to class Mrs. Cutting's "Heart of Lynn" with the latter.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Four men were killed and one fatally injured in an explosion to-day at the Pintsch Gas Compressing Company's plant in Southwest Washington.

Intended for the illumination of the young, this little book is made up of a series of papers on the various departments of the General Government of the United States. The first paper, on the Presidency, was written by Mr. Roosevelt himself, but at a time when he could not be supposed to speak with anything like Presidential authority, his office being that of Governor of New York.

The "Issues of Life," by Mrs. John Van Vorst, reminds one of an occasional scene in the country when the bees have swarmed and the family beats violently on tin pans to make them sit down and be good. Its author is like a would-be ornithologist who catches a bat, and immediately proceeds to write a book on mistaken ideas regarding the plumage of birds or the sweetness of their various songs.

The recommendations of the Chamber of Commerce on sidewalk obstructions show an unwarranted amount of selfishnes, as well as ignorance, on the subject. Before these gentlemen try to regulate other persons' uses of the walk, it would look better for them to comply with the law themselves.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision reversing the judgment of the trial court in a case brought by Patrick W. Cullihan, as State Commissioner ofo Excisee, to revoke the liquor tax certificate of Ernest Rorphuro, and to recover on his bond given by the Fidelity and Casualty Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The Cabinet today thoroughly discussed the Chinese exclusion question. China has denounced the existing treaty, which will expire by limitation next December. It has been the hope of China to negotiate a more favorable treaty than that, which is now in force, but an intimation has been conveyed to the Chinese Government that it is improbable that such a treaty would be ratified by Congress.

IN order to observe -- in all its oddity -- the spectacle of 200 millionaires whose aggregate wealth is estimated to be $300,000,000, bending under the weight of the authority exercised by a country-lawyer, one must go to the town of Greenwich, Conn.

Saturday's market was active for a half holiday, but not remarkable upon the proportion of the week's earlier days. There was no particular tone to the day's prices, advances and declines being pretty well divided between rises and falls and limited to fractions for the most part. Among fifty active stocks the only advances of a point or more were 1 3/8 for Brooklyn Rapid Transit and 3 for Metropolitan.
MOST of us are familiar with hospitals and retreats where life and health may be restored to human beings and animals, but a new and interesting phase is a sanitarium for grain.

A BEAUTIFUL custom springs out of the mire of oppression of the European Continent. It is the public honor done to poets who are beloved of their followers. In the general struggle and sordid conditions of life on the lower east side, time and enthusiasm have been found recently for such a celebration.

Secretary Shaw's statement that he did not know when the Panama payments would be made seems to have encouraged the large expansion of loans, making new high records for that item and for deposits also.

S.A. Rothermel, Chicago manager of the Traders' Insurance Company, has been appointed a member of the Committee on Fire Protection Engineering of the Western Union (fire underwriters) to fill the vacancy due to the death of Judge Eugene Cary.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Undismayed by the two body blows given their scheme by the vigilance of Senator Dowling, who helped to find two "jokers" in the Davis Voting Machine bill, the interests behind voting machine legislation had reported out of the Assembly Rules Committee to-day the O'Neill voting machine measure, which contemplates even more radical things than did the Davis bill.

Fur manufacturers are now busy preparing their stock for next Winter's use, and their salesmen will start on the road with samples in two or three weeks. All the manufacturers expect an excellent season, and base their hopes on the fact that furs will be much cheaper this year than last year.

Col. William C. Greene, ex-ranchman and Indian fighter, now millionaire President of the Greene Consolidated Copper Company, yesterday added to his varied experiences an escape from death that was quite as close as that of the day years ago when he was picked up for dead after hours of fighting with the redskins on Arizona plains.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 9. -- Now that the Lenten season is passed, one and all at the shore are awakening to the fact that the Spring session has suddenly burst upon the resort, with it glorious sunshine, warm, balmy days, and the hundred and more merry attractions that make life in this city memorable.

PARIS, April 10. -- According to the St. Petersburg correspondent of the Journal, a large number of armored automobiles, manufactured in Germany. France, and Belgium, will leave there for the front on Monday.

It will hardly be contended, even by the able committee of the Chamber of Commerce which proposed it, that the plan of controlling traffic in the streets urged by the Chamber is adequate and complete. But it clearly does provide for substantial improvement and points the way to further improvement.

That the Grand Circle was destined to become one of the city's greatest centres of activity was recognized over twenty years ago by no less shrewd buyers of real estate than George Ehret and the late Amos R. Eno, but it has been within the last five years that the property on its borders has experienced its greatest increase in value.

A large safe in the butter and egg market of W.H. Kerby Co., at 1,674 Broadway, Brooklyn, was blown open with dynamite early yesterday morning and $60 in silver were taken from it. The safe was in full view of the street.

THE Russo-Japanese war, according to the words of a woman whose first exhibition is now "on" at East Fortieth Street, was planned and carried through just to give her a chance. "Of course," she laughingly remarked, "people may talk about its being the independence of Korea and the aggression of the Russians, and all that.

Nearly five miles of good steady pulling was the task set for Columbia's crew candidates yesterday afternoon. Most of the men were out on the Harlem early, and until the fog began to settle down, the air was biting cold. Coach Goodwin has shifted the men about in the different shells so that the make-up of each shell has been changed.

PARIS, April 9. -- The political lull induced by the Parliamentary vacation is the reason for the lack of interest with which the publication of the new Anglo-French agreement has been received in commercial and industrial circles.

ALBANY, April 9. -- The Judges' Pension bill has encountered in the Assembly Committee on Rules what appears to be a stone wall. The surprise at anybody daring to hold up this bill, for which many Judges, it is said, lobbied for days and days, is great.

Possibilities of further development of the export trade in cotton fabrics are being studied by Consuls of the United States, in pursuance of instructions recently sent out from Washington. Several of the Consuls have already submitted reports upon this subject. They agree that American manufacturers are not doing abroad nearly as much business as they could if they would make more serious efforts in this direction.

IN these days of progress when so much is being said and written about the extravagant use and waste of water in our municipality, when our eyes are turned longingly toward the waters of the Catskills, it is of more than passing interest to see what has been and is being done in the Valley of the Croton to save the millions of gallons of water that now run to waste.
