PARIS, April 9. -- Ex-queen Isabella of Spain, grandmother of King Alfonso, died here at 9:45 o'clock this morning of influenza with complications.

LONDON, April 9. -- Canon Henson, one of the chief dignitaries of Westminister Abbey and a Select Preacher of both Oxford and Cambridge Universities, has raised a storm of criticism by an article in The Contemporary Review, in which he enters into the question of the future of the Bible.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Announcement was made at the Navy Department to-day that a cablegram received from Rear Admiral Evans six weeks ago giving the scores of the target practice on that station was misinterpreted.

Although fire drills were introduced into the public schools several years ago, the first attempt to make a code of directions that could be applied generally has just been made by the Board of Superintendents of the Department of Education. This general system has been made up largely from suggestions given by the Principals of the schools.

THE electric farm is present-day realization of dreams of scientists of the past, but its fullest possibilities are not measured by any achievements so far obtained. In the effort to increase the yield of our crops attention has repeatedly been drawn to the wonderful effect of electricity in stimulating growth of plants; but the experiments made in the early part of the present decade justified no extensive use of this agent in ordinary agriculture.

The friends of Japan all over the world are warning her against intoxication with success, and particularly, as one of them, the military correspondent of The London Times, puts it, against "seeking to penetrate into the recesses of Asia, in chase of a receding will o' the wisp."

BERLIN, April 10. -- Special dispatches to the Lokal Anzeiger from a correspondent in German Southwest Africa describe the encounter of Major von Glasenapp's column and a force of Hereros at Okcharui on April 2, while the German column was on the way to Oniatu. The road traverses thorn thickets.

THE much-vaunted Spring season has resolved itself -- as do all Spring seasons in New York -- into weddings and a few belated dances and meetings of dancing classes. Nearly all the young people who were at home for the Easter holidays have returned to school, and Lent, although only a week past, seems to have been ages ago.

Already the effect of Capt. Cottrell's order that the police of the Tenderloin Station must supply pillow shams for their dormitory is being felt. "We'll have refinement here or break a leg." was the commander's declaration to his men on Friday, and now the most popular books in the precinct library are Lord Chesterfield's letters and a bound volume of Godey's Lady's Book for 1840.

The state sentiment in this is somewhat divided between Grover Cleveland an Judge Alton B. Parker as Democratic nominee for President. The South has been the backbone to Democracy for many, many years, and I think it is about time that she should meet with a reward from her sister States in the North, East, and West.

TRENTON, N.J., April 9. -- Trenton now has a divorce case which in several points closely resembles New York's Dodge-Morse case. Vice Chancellor Pitney has announced that he has decided to set aside the divorce obtained by Howard Watkinson of 205 Spring Street from his wife, Adele Louise Chapman, daughter of former State School Superintendent E.O. Chapman.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Esperance, backed from 10 to 1 down to 4 to 1, won the maiden race at five furlongs to-day at the Benning track, creating the feature of the day's sport. The horse was heavily backed, particularly by her owners, and they took about $4,000 out of the ring. Esperance ran against the biggest field of the season in a maiden race, and won in fine style.

The students of Stevens Institute of Hoboken, N.J., made a hard fight against the Crescent Athletic Club in a game of lacrosse at Bay Ridge yesterday, but when the conflict was over the Institute boys were overpowered by a score of nine goals to three. Although it was their first game of the season, and with only four of last year's players remaining on the team, they gave a creditable exhibition.

The report of the work of the Board of United States General Appraisers for the quarter ended April 1, just issued, shows a great gain in the amount of work turned out by the board during that period over the quantity turned out during the similar period of 1903. It also showed, however, a great gain in the volume of work demanded, and a consequent gain in the number of undecided cases.
The International Paper Company (incorporated in 1898) shows that in the period of its existence to June 30, 1903, as per their annual reports:

YEAR after year there crop out printed tales of the sartorial splendor of the so-called Easter Parade on Gotham's most fashionable thoroughfares, Fifth Avenue. As a consequence, hundreds of people from the suburban towns pour into New York, wander up and down, and visit the fashionable churches, filling the latter to the extent of most disagreeable crowding among the standees.

WATERBURY, April 9. -- Four boys, Edward Blodgett, sixteen; Edward Weimer, nineteen; Samuel McCormick, eighteen, and Henry Platt, twenty, were arrested in Waterbury to-day on suspicion of having robbed Henry M. Davis, the "Lanesville miser," of $12,000 on Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The announcement that Bourke Cockran would make his promised speech on the service pension order drew a big crowd to the House to-day. The applause when Mr. Cockran arose was loud and long, and was not confined to the Democratic side. Throughout he received constant tributes of applause, and when he concluded it took the Speaker five minutes to restore order.
ALBANY, April 9. -- Among the bills passed by the Assembly to-day are these:

The dispatch from St. Petersburg to the effect that an epidemic of cholera and typhoid is threatened at Harbin, the Russian military base in Manchuria, is surprising only by reason of the fact that it was permitted to pass the censorship. Even during the peaceful conditions of last year zymotic disease was sufficiently prevalent to call attention to the existence of causes which at any moment might become extremely active in inducing a disastrous epidemic.
If it is necessary to increase the city water supply for better protection against fire, it is certainly equally important to improve its quality for domestic purposes.

T.W. Birdsey of Birdsey, Somers Co., corset manufacturers, will leave about the end of the month to attend the opening of the Connecticut building at the St. Louis World's Fair. Mr. Somers is one of the Connecticut Commissioners.

Two preliminary medal play rounds, to be followed by the usual match play round, were adopted yesterday as the method of conducting the coming amateur golf championship of the United States, which will be played during the week of Sept. 5 at the Baltusrol Golf Club, Short Hills, N.J. This novel method was adopted at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association, held yesterday at Delmonico's.
LONDON, April 9. -- The Associated Press learns that the exact status of the much-heralded Anglo-Russian understanding is as follows:

At the Democratic Assembly District Conventions, which were held last night in every one of the twenty-one districts in Kings County, for the purpose of electing delegates to the State Convention, Senator McCarren did not raise the issue of instructing for Judge Alton B. Parker for President. In not one of the conventions were resolutions presented favoring Parker instructions.
THE most beautiful of created beings! Madam, I must paint your portrait. It shall make us famous forever!"

WTH the "ponies" back in the North and the lid supposed to be tightly closed, poolrooms in some parts of town are making a strong bid for business. A man who has "played the ponies," and again wishes to try his luck, has no trouble in finding a place where he can lay his money.

WILLIAM H. CRANE and Willis P. Sweatnam met the other day for the first time in years. In a quiet, dignified, and severely earnest manner, they began to tell things to one another. Mr. Sweatnam took umbrage at a remark Mr. Crane made regarding his youthfulness.

A test of the policy adopted by Secretary Shaw about a year ago, when he set out to discourage the importation of diamonds at any port but New York, will be made in June in the United States District Court for the District of Minnesota, when the case of the United States against Buckstrap comes up for trial.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., April 9. -- A laugh has won an estate worth a million for John Donahue, a well-known resident of Tremont. Several years ago, while he was prospecting in the Cumberland Mountains of Bell County, Ky., he met a man named Bowman, who owned a large tract of land. Bowman had a quarrel with desperado, and the latter had drawn a gun to shoot, when Donahue laughed a loud, hearty laugh.

Word to the effect that ex-Senator David B. Hill and Chief Judge Alton B. Parker have split seriously over the sort of a platform to be adopted at the Democratic State Convention in Albany on April 18 was brought to the Hoffman House last night by prominent Democrats and also by members of the Legislature returning to the city.

MISS GRACE ATKINS DOBSON, the Boston girl whose engagement to ?gllson Shannon Dunn of New York has been announced, is the fortunate possessor of a unique combination ring and bracelet, a glft from Lady Cecilla Rose, daughter of the Earl of Cathcart. Lady Cecilia and Miss Dobson were visiting in the same Long Island country house several years ago.

COLCHESTER, Conn., April 9. -- After twenty-four hours' search for John Marks, the farmer on whose premises the dismembered body of Joseph Pavoll was found in a bag yesterday, Sheriff Jackson and his assistants were still keeping a vigilant watch for the fugitive to-night in the southern part of the town.

NO really good flowers come from the so-called 'land of flowers,' " remarked a florist the other day when some one asked him "how roses that come from the South were packed." This florist, who is one of the most experienced and wealthiest in New York, is very much disgusted when people say anything about his or anybody else getting flowers "from the South."

IN the opinion of many artists a department store picture gallery lacks atmosphere. Possibly it does, reckoning from a National Academy standpoint, but they manage to sell pictures there, and thus create another kind of atmosphere which the most finical artist cannot afford to despise.

LONDON, March 26. -- As far as the week has sped it will be marked with a red letter in the Government calendar, since it has been unruffled by defeat in the division lobby. Once the majority, which still nominally exceeds 100, was run down to 16, a circumstance that suffused the Irish camp with joyful light.
EX-GOV. WINTHROP MURRAY CRANE of Massachusetts and Clarence W. Mackay, President of the Mackay Companies, have been elected to the Directorate of the Manhattan Trust Company.

The Representative in Congress from the Eleventh District of New York has sat in the House -- or has been supposed to sit there -- for just 108 working days. The paucity of references by The Congressional Record to his presence and legislative performances during this period of five months is shown in the subjoined summary:

IT was only a very few seasons ago that there was some ripple of excitement at the wedding of as exalted a church personage as a Bishop. To-day, In looking over the rostra of the Protestant Episcopal Church In the more fashionable parishes, one finds that there remain few unmarried clergymen.

IN a bird store of the theatrical district a Kiwi-kiwi, or dancing bird, recently created a sensation. She had been brought to the city by an Australian sailor, a cast-off from one of the fruit ships docking in port.

The present struggle in the Far East has naturally drawn the attention of every one to the resources of each of the combatants, and the possibilities of each to prolong a war that must inevitably result in enormous expenditures of money, and strain in a greater or less degree the resources of the belligerents.

LEANDING woman to three prominent American stars in one season is the rather exceptional record of Miss Dorothy Hammond, the young English actress, who is about to succeed Cecelia Loftus as Perpetua in support of E.H. Sothern in "The Proud Prince." Miss Hammond came to this country last season under contract to Richard Mansfield.
LONDON, April 9. -- The demand for money slackened in the market to-day and the supplies increased. Discounts were weak.

It is an excellent idea of the Census Bureau to publish each year a bulletin giving the actual population of the Union and of its States and cities as nearly as this can be estimated from the data at its disposal, and this is only one of the many advantages to be secured from a permanent bureau.

Wall scaling as a competitive sport does not apeal strongly to the general athlete, but by the National Guardsman it is practiced with unlimited ardor, and in the annual indoor athletic meetings is recognized as one of the special features. Always picturesque and thrilling, wall scaling combines agility and strength, principally, and a considerable amount of skill, and in competition the well-trained team is quickly distinguished from the men lacking the above-named attributes.

Two matinee performances are the only dramatic "events" schedule for this week. One of them is "The Pillars of Society," by Henrik Ibsen; the other "Love's Pilgrimage," by Horace B. Fry. In the latter Miss Carlotta Nillson will appear next Thursday afternoon at Wallack's Theatre.

To-day is the Russian Easter. By a strange and horrible perversion of the spirit and meaning of the day, it is upon this day, or at least at this season, that murderous outbreaks of Russian bigotry against the Jews are most anxiously apprehended. The inhuman circular which we printed the other day from Odessa fixed Eastertide as the date for a repetition in Odessa of the horrors of Kishineff.

The rumor that the Mexican Central was about to be reorganized cropped out again last week. It is authoritatively stated that while the necessity for a reorganization exists, no plans looking to such an event have yet been discussed.

Having discussed in a previous article the course that the loans made by the National banks of New York City have followed during the six years past, it now becomes pertinent to make inquiry along the same line for the banks of the remainder of the country, to discover whether there exist some basis of comparison that throws light on the conditions here.

Figures presented in the annual report of the Deutsche Bank of Berlin for the year 1903 show that the business of the bank during that period was larger by u140,000,000 than in any previous year. The net profits amounted to u1,215,380, and the dividend on the bank's stock was 11 per cent., which rate has been maintained since 1899.

William G. Toepfer, seventeen years old, of 876 Park Avenue, an errand boy, who has been an attendant of the Sunday school class of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., at the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, and Martin Johnson of 266 West Forty-third Street, also an errand boy, were locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station last night.

In the opinion of a large number of the important manufacturers of rubber goods crude rubber has been cornered. This opinion is in a measure borne out by the statistical records. More rubber is arriving in the United States than ever before, but in spite of this fact the price is steadily advancing.

The old parish house of St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church, at Sixteenth and Grove Streets, Jersey City, which Father Boylan, the rector, offered to the people of that city as first prize in a church lottery, passed into the possession of the parish again yesterday.

BOSTON, April 9. -- A secret hearing took place to-day at Young's Hotel in a suit which is brought by James Clark and Count Reginald Ward of London, formerly of Brighton, of the former firm of Clark, Ward Co., against J. Edward Addicks, the gas magnate. The suit has no direct connection, however, with the litigation in which Thomas W. Lawson, Henry H. Rogers, Robert Winsor, and other well-known capitalists are involved.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 9. -- Harvard's racing season on the water opened to-day with the first of the inter-class club races between the Weld and Newell sophomores. The race was one mile ad seven-eighths down stream in the Charles River Basin, and was won by the Weld Club in the time of 11:20.

In a great measure to create the opportunity for the teachers of the evening schools to express their views on better recognition which they feel they ought to get from the city for the work they do, about one hundred teachers, members of the School Teachers' Association, were present at a banquet at the St. Denis Hotel last evening.

It is difficult to understand why Mr. THOMAS W. LAWSON should have taken the public quite as fully into his confidence as he has concerning the Amalgamated Copper deal, and manifested so much readiness to go on the witness stand and make a clean breast of it, unless his conscience has been troubling him o' nights.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 9. -- The best informed military circles no longer anticipate a Japanese landing at the head of the Liao-Tung Gulf. They believe the Japanese have missed their opportunity, the Russians being now too strong.

Joshua Crane, Jr., of Boston won the indoor tennis championship of the United States yesterday for the fourth successive time, beating, in the final round of the National tournament, held at the Racquet and Tennis Club, West Forty-third Street, Charles E. Sands, of the home club in three straight sets. Contrary to expectations, Crane won with the most apparent ease.

The Regatta Committee of the Larchmont Yacht Club has announced the schedule of racing fixtures for the coming season. There will be twelve race days, as usual, and the season will open with an open regatta, for all classes, on Saturday, June 18, and will close with a race for the Larchmont Schooner Cup and races for sloops of the 80-foot, 70-foot, and 43-foot classes on Saturday, Sept. 10.

DREAMS of utilizing the sun's rays direct instead of through the medium of coal have been realized at last. What might be termed a triumph is a novel and extremely clever motor operated by the heat of the sun, and used to pump water at the ostrich farm in South Pasadena, Cal. It was successfully installed there last November, and since that time its operations have been witnessed by many thousands of visitors.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 9. -- The first delegates from Indiana to the Democratic National Convention were selected to-night by the Seventh District delegates to the State Convention. They were instructed to vote for the nomination of Judge Alton B. Parker of New York for President. They are the first delegates selected in the United States that have been instructed for Parker.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 9. -- Society has awakened from its Lenten lethargy and it has been every bit as gay this week as it was during the holidays. One of the jolly events of the week was the leap year party given by a score or more of the young women of the cottage colony. Each of the guests received as souvenirs dancing programmes painted in water colors by the young women.

ONE who wishes to see the marvels which electricity can perform, to note the industrial revolution which it is producing, and at the same time to see the biggest and most up-to-date printing office in the world should visit the Government Printing Office in Washington, whore all of these things are combined.

Nothing could be more satisfactory than the ending of the negotiations between France and England. The case was indeed one of those in which well begun is half done. The very purpose of settling all the outstanding questions between the two nations of which any might at any time become threatening or troublesome, when taken up in good faith on each side, almost insured its own fulfillment.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 9. -- E.H. Harriman, President of the Union Pacific Railroad, and John P. Roosa, Jr., were elected delegates to the National Convention by the Republicans of the Twentieth Congressional District, in spite of the fact that friends of President Roosevelt wanted Congressman Thomas W. Bradley in Harriman's place.

A dense fog which overhung the harbor all day yesterday, and which extended several miles out to sea, badly crippled all shipping, and even delayed the arrival here of several of the big liners from transatlantic ports. About the local waters pilots were put at a great disadvantage, and many accidents were narrowly averted.

Lawyers were much interested yesterday in the action of Supreme Court Justice Rogers in setting aside the verdict of a jury for the defendant in the suit brought by Receiver Howell of the William Campbell Wall Paper Company against James H. Temple, ex-President of the company, for conversion. Not a few of them went to their books to ascertain under what authority the action had been taken, so unusual was it.

Last week began with another phase of the Northern Securities incident. The principals in the community of interest in the Northwest attacked one another's interests in the friendliest manner, suggesting a parallel to the insinuating jest of the statesman of the East Side who left these scenes last week.

John Philip Sousa will give his second Spring concert to-night at the Metropolitan Opera House. He will then take his band to the St. Louis World's Fair, where he will play during the first month of the Exposition. Mr. Sousa will present a new instrumental soloist, Jean H. Moeremans, a saxophonist of some reputation here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- Persons living in less favored cities, such as New York and Chicago, where trolley conductors and passengers are each other's natural enemies, find it difficult to understand or believe in the millennial conditions existing here.

YOU would think a bird the last thing in the world to be faked, wouldn't you?" queried one of the guides in the Zoo at Bronx Park, "but it isn't so. Come with me. I'll show you the queerest sight in New York. It is in the diving tank house, not far from the flying cage."

There were forty applications for positions in the Fire Department of New Haven, Conn., and only eleven met the requirements. Nine failed on the mental examination and sixteen on the physical, and four would not take the latter.

PARIS, April 9. -- Although the Anglo-French colonial treaty just signed makes no specific reference to any protectorates, it is now recognized that between the lines the treaty means the establishment of a French protectorate over Morocco, similar to the present protectorate of France over Tunis, and that it makes permanent the British protectorate over Egypt.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9. -- At the evening session to-day of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, James M. Beck, ex-Assistant Attorney General, and who made one of the arguments for the Government before the Circuit Court in the Northern Securities case, delivered an address upon "The Federal Power Over Trusts."

The ending of the bricklayers' strike has done much to promote a more hopeful feeling in the real estate market, and it is likely that the buying of vacant property for improvement will soon be undertaken on a large scale. Recovery from a setback of this sort will not be experienced in a day, and there may be some disposition on the part of builders to hold off until differences have been finally arbitrated.

THE recent death at an advanced age of a lady of the family of Delmonico and of John Alexander Longhi, a relative, and for sixty years connected with its business concerns, practically wipes out the famous old dynasty, leaving none of the name of whom the public at large has any knowledge.

This soldier's tale of food is interesting. During his term of service in the 17th Infantry in Cuba and Philippines, an Ohio soldier boy contracted a disease of the stomach and bowels which all army doctors who treated him pronounced incurable, but which Grape-Nuts food alone cured:

A truce, enforced largely by the fact that the courts were closed, was in effect yesterday among the warring landlords and tenants in the lower east side. The courts of Justices Rocsch, Sanders, and Hoffman, in the heart of the district most keenly affected by the advance in rents, were closed.

Because President Roosevelt once upon a time appointed a Democrat, who happens to reside in the same district as himself, to a four-dollar-a-day Federal position, the Republicans of that district -- the Fifth District of Oyster Bay -- refused to hold a primary on April 1.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 23. -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, the big Canadian concern that is installing the great water power and electric transmission plant in the State of Puebla, ninety miles from this city, has just completed moving a town of 1,000 population.

The ending of the bricklayers' strike has done much to promote a more hopeful feeling in the real estate market, and it is likely that the buying of vacant property for improvement will soon be undertaken on a large scale. Recovery from a setback of this sort will not be experienced in a day, and there may be some disposition on the part of builders to hold off until differences have been finally arbitrated.

THE recent death at an advanced age of a lady of the family of Delmonico and of John Alexander Longhi, a relative, and for sixty years connected with its business concerns, practically wipes out the famous old dynasty, leaving none of the name of whom the public at large has any knowledge.

This soldier's tale of food is interesting. During his term of service in the 17th Infantry in Cuba and Philippines, an Ohio soldier boy contracted a disease of the stomach and bowels which all army doctors who treated him pronounced incurable, but which Grape-Nuts food alone cured:

CITY OF MEXICO, March 23. -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, the big Canadian concern that is installing the great water power and electric transmission plant in the State of Puebla, ninety miles from this city, has just completed moving a town of 1,000 population.

When THE TIMES announced last week the publication of the story of Judge Alton B. Parker, leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, the readers of your valuable paper felt satisfied that now at last they would be informed by the strongest and ablest advocate of his candidacy of the position of that candidate on the leading issues of the campaign.
TRENTON, N.J., April 10. -- Albert Herpin, Trenton's "sleepless wonder," who declares he has not slept for ten years, has had fourteen leap year proposals up to date.

The Whistler show, at Copley Hall, Boston, has justified the believers in Whistler in so far as public interest for the exhibits can prove it. Mr. Holker Abbott, President of the Copley Society, states that $16,200 is the sum taken for entrance fees, against which about $9,000 must be charged for expenses, leaving a substantial sum for the reduction of the society's debt.
WASHINGTON, April 10. -- It is expected that the report of the McCall committee on the Bristow report regarding the postal scandal will be presented this week.
WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The South as a mission field is the subject of chief discussion at the conference of missionaries of the Catholic Church in progress at the Catholic University.

The announcement made by cable some two weeks ago and since confirmed by mail that the Cunard Company, with the approval of the Admiralty, has decided to propel its new ships with steam turbines is of great interest. Some time ago the matter was referred to a committee for consideration and report, and the action of the company has been taken on their recommendation.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 10. -- Frederick Pearson, fifteen years old, was killed this afternoon while jumping off a slow freight train on the Harlem River Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, near Pelham Manor.

In the British House of Commons some interesting discussion was excited by the figures quoted by Mr. RUNCIMAN showing the cost of repairs lately ordered to certain naval craft, in relation to the cost of original construction. For example, on the Circe, a torpedo boat, which originally cost 65,000, one job of general repairs cost 52,000.

The two-men-team tournament of the Harlem Navy Handball League was decided yesterday on the courts of the New Polo Athletic Association, and was won by the Union Boat Club team, which defeated the Metropolitan Rowing Club pair in two straight games in the final match. As the Unions also won the five-men-team tournament which was concluded a week ago, they now hold the championship of the Harlem Navy with both two and five men teams.

There was the liveliest sort of a row last night at a meeting held at McKinley Hall, in East Fourth Street, by the residents of the lower East Side who have been trying to perfect an organization to fight the landlords' raise in their rents. As the result of trouble over the custody of $200 contributed by William R. Hearst, the tenants separated into two bodies and elected separate officers.

Solomon Seligman, dealer in pictures at 10 East Tenth Street, holds himself so much aggrieved by a judgment rendered against him by Justice Roesch, in favor of Salvatore Sardofontuna of the Academy of Milan that he is determined all the world shall know his story.

Both McCarren and Doyle claimed last night the control of the Kings County delegation to the State Convention. McCarren declined to predict how the delegates would vote in caucus on the subject of instructions for Parker. Doyle, on the other hand, declared that the sixty-three votes would be cast under the unit rule in opposition to sending an instructed delegation to St. Louis.

With the rising yesterday morning of the dense bank of fog which overhung the harbor and extended for miles out to sea, twenty-three steamships and innumerable sailing vessels which for two days had been trying to make this port were able to pick up their anchors from the mud banks of the lower harbor and to proceed to their piers.

LONDON, April 10. -- Capt. Howard of the British steamer Turquoise, from Cienfuegos via Bermuda to Liverpool, while passing Old Head of Kinsale, on the Irish south coast, to-day, signaled that he had endeavored to assist the disabled Furness-Allan liner Damara, which, as before reported, had broken her shaft at sea when about 190 miles from Queenstown, while bound from Liverpool to St. Johns, N.F., and Halifax, N.S.

MONTREAL, April 10. -- Three thousand people in the village of Verdun, adjoining the western limits of the City of Montreal, and to-night living in the upper stories of their houses, while several thousand more, who reside in that section of the city known as Point St. Charles are in danger.

I have been a stenographer for sixteen years, in all that time have worked in but three places, and am to-day receiving a salary of between $1,200 and $1,300 a year, which it may be possible in time to increase to $1,500. This is certainly only a fair salary, and small enough for a man with a wife and two children to support.

Gov. Odell spent practically all of yesterday again at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, straightening out Republican district differences and completing preliminary arrangements for the Republican State Convention which meets to-morrow in Carnegie Hall. He made a change in the slate for alternates at large which was regarded as favorable to the Gubernatorial aspirations of Mayor Erastus C. Knight of Buffalo.

A record-breaking attendance for so early in the season greeted the New York baseball nine at Ridgewood Park yesterday afternoon upon its first attempt to play Sunday ball at home. The Americans had no specially prepared attraction for the occasion; they were simply to play the Ridgewood team, an aggregation of semi-professionals that represents the Ridgewood Park Exhibition Company.

TRENTON, N.J., April 10. -- When the liner Cedric reaches Quarantine next Thursday morning Michael E. Fitzgerald of Trenton will be detained on a charge of abduction. He is charged in a cable message from Mrs. Thomas Bater of England with the abduction of her two daughters, Catherine and Margaret, who sailed with Fitzgerald from Liverpool on the Cedric last Wednesday. Mrs. Bater, in pursuit of the trio, sailed yesterday from Liverpool aboard the Campania.

PATERSON, N.J., April 10. -- The surrender of William MacQueen will result in saving for his bondsman. Philip Geyer, $6,500, less the costs to which Geyer has gone in getting MacQueen back to this country. Mr. Geyer went on the bond of Anarchists MacQueen and Grossman in the sum of $13,500.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10. -- Dr. Simon N. Patten, Professor of Political Economy in the University of Pennsylvania, who is accounted one of the leading thinkers on economic questions in the country, believes that the wife should be a wage producer as well as the husband. Dr. Patten builds this view not as a theory, but as a basic principle of economy.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 10.--The War Ministry has granted the petition of Mme. Pousep of Riga, daughter of Col. Maxiowcondurow, who desired to be enrolled in a Cossack regiment.

Before imposing fines on two persons in separate cases for carrying concealed weapons, Magistrate Crane, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, made some forceful remarks against the practice of carrying revolvers and suggested needed legislation on the question.

C. Andrews, a member of the Xavier Athletic Association and a novice runner with the limit handicap allowance of seven minutes, won the second big open handicap run of the season, held by the Mott Haven Athletic Club on Jerome Avenue yesterday afternoon, beating M. Spring of the Pastime Athletic Club by three yards.

William MacQueen, the Anarchist, who was convicted for inciting the silk trade riots in Paterson, N.J., in June, 1902, and who jumped his bail while under a five-year sentence for that crime, arrived yesterday morning on board the American Line Steamship St. Paul, from Southampton, traveling incognito.

THE TIMES and Herald have published many strong letters in regard to the neglect of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and it is fair to presume that they have received many more which they have not published.

A young negro, yelling like madman, drove a horse attached to a light wagon at breakneck speed on Boston Road in the Bronx on Saturday night, and spread terror among pedestrians and other drivers. Policeman Frazer jumped into a grocer's wagon and induced the driver to chase the young negro's wagon.

NEWARK, N.J., April 10. -- Six persons were injured, one man so badly that he had to be removed to a hospital, by a rear-end collision between two trolley cars at the foot of the high trestle that crosses the Lackawanna tracks on the Kearny turnpike, near the Hackensack River.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 10 -- A high military authority in conversation with The Associated Press, explained why Gen. Kuropatkin's plan of campaign does not contemplate a heavy resistance to the Japanese advance at the Yalu. He said:

Anecdotes of Timothy J. Campbell are being recalled by his friends, and one told last night at the Hoffman House deals with the time when Mr. Campbell was a member of Congress and W.C. Whitney was Secretary of the Navy. The New York delegation, or perhaps only the Democratic part of it, was invited one day to a luncheon at the home of the Secretary on I Street.

CHICAGO, April 10. -- The controversy over racing dates, which for a time threatened to put a stop to racing in Chicago this season, was satisfactorily settled to-day, and as a result the Worth track will open April 30. According to the agreement Worth will accept the dates awarded by the Western Jockey Club this year.

Before an audience that filled Mendelssohn Hall on West Fortieth Street to the doors, Booker T. Washington, Principal of the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, discussed the negro question last evening. He spoke under the auspices of the Broadway Tabernacle, which is temporarily worshipping in Mendelssohn Hall.

After a half-mile cross-country chase that ended in a desperate fight, Thomas Holden, twenty-three years old, said by the police to be a clever pickpocket, was captured last evening in Willetts Place, Borough of the Bronx, by a crowd of two hundred men aand boys.

ROME, April 10. -- Signor Tittoni, the Italian Foreign Minister, in an interview to-day, said that he and Count Goluchowski, the Austro-Hungarian Foreign Minister, were entirely satisfied with their meeting at Abbazia yesterday, the result of which he would communicate to Parliament.

PARIS, March 11. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of the Petit Parisien cables an interview which he had with Rear-Admiral Rojestvensky, Chief of the General Staff. of the navy, in the course of which the Admiral admitted that he had accepted the command of the Baltic Squadron, adding that he was not certain whether the squadron would go to the Far East.

MALTA, April 10. -- Emperor William read Divine service on board the Hohenzollern this morning, after which he received the Captains of the British fleet. He then landed and visited all the places of interest.

Peter Isman of 50 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, was walking past the corner of Newark Avenue and Grove Street in that city, last night, when he was jostled by two strangers. In the quarrel that followed one of them gave him a push and he fell into the street and partly under a trolley car bound for Hoboken.

This being a Presidential year, I suppose we shall have to suffer the infliction of stump speakers and tub orators. Before the storm breaks is it not possible to protect the beautiful green turf in Madison and Union Squares from the tread of cruel feet?

A linen importer said yesterday that business in his line seems brisker than in cotton goods. Yarns are higher than they were, and the weavers having used up low-priced yarn have been obliged to pay the higher prices.

CINCINNATI, April 10. -- Last Thursday Charles Weissmann, a young druggist, had a warrant issued charging Dr. Charles Ferris and his brother, physicians of good standing, with attempting to poison him by putting in a glass of beer which he drank a large quantity of cocaine.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 11. -- The Associated Press has received special reports from all the Jewish districts of Russia regarding the happenings of Easter Sunday.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 10. -- This city to-day, was en fete, and was given up to Easter rejoicing. The long Russian feasts, which began after midnight and continued almost to daylight, were scarcely ended before the round of Easter visits commenced.

BRISTOL, April 10. -- The schooner yacht Ignomar, being fitted for racing abroad, is now nearly rigged in the slip at the Herreshoff shops. The topmasts are on end and stays and running rigging are all in place. The craft is being fitted out with the greatest care, and when she sails, on or about April 20, it is generally believed that nothing will be wanting to make the voyage a successful one.

Whatever may be the extent or nature of a difference of opinion between Judge PARKER and ex-Senator HILL as to the platform of the State Democratic Convention, as reported in our columns yesterday morning, there can be no doubt that the general views attributed by his friends to Judge PARKER are sound.

WEST NEWTON, Mass., April 10. -- A knife and a knife sheath bearing indentations supposed to have been made by a person's teeth are in possession of the police, who regard them as very valuable clues in the Page murder case.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 10. -- Bruinsky, the Russian bear mascot of the cruiser Columbia, was released yesterday for an airing. The first thing he did was to kill a Japanese dog in the League Island Navy Yard.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- It is the purpose of the Republican leaders in Congress to discourage any legislation other than appropriation bills during the remainder of the session. These bills are in a fair way of early completion.
BROOKFIELD, Mass., April 10. -- James Joyce, sixty-five, of West Brookfield, left his home Friday to come to Brookfield. He has not returned. Friday night he was seen in the road between the towns.

DETROIT, Mich., April 10. -- W.J. Snyder, Secretary of the Detroit Driving Club, has announced the entries received for the five early closing events offered for the Blue Ribbon meet of the Detroit Driving Club, July 18-22. The historic $10,000 Merchants and Manufacturers' Stake for 2:24 class trotters has been patronized more liberally than the other events, 31 horses being named.

There are two measures of prime importance concerning the Philippines pending in Congress. One postpones the application of the coasting laws to the trade of the islands. If it be not passed all the traffic between the islands and the United States must be carried on American ships after the first of July.

BALTIMORE, April 10. -- "Never provoke your congregations to laughter and keep your names out of the newspapers," was the advice given by President Little of the Maryland Methodist Protestant Conference to the young ministers who were ordained to-day. Continuing, the President said:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 10. -- John Thomas, the night watchman at the Houston Club of the University of Pennsylvania, which is situated on the campus in the heart of the university's group of buildings, was murdered this evening on the bowling alleys in the basement of the clubhouse. The motive is believed to have been robbery. Two hours after the murder was discovered a negro was arrested on suspicion.

Matthew McConville, Delegate of the Safety Engineers' Union, made a report to the Central Federated Union yesterday as to the action of his organization in supporting the striking asphalt workers. After stating that his union had decided to support the asphalt workers, he made an attack on the companies, and charged that politics had a good deal to do with the present attitude of the asphalt companies.

While he was being hurried to Roosevelt Hospital, four-year-old Adam Petroski of 619 East Sixteenth Street died yesterday afternoon in the arms of Mrs. Kate Laird as the result of a fall from a third-story window of the tenement house at 552 West Fifty-fourth Street to a courtyard.

Mayor McCLELLAN is entirely justified in his intention to address the Governor in opposition to the Smith bill, which, if it becomes law, will prevent the City of New York from drawing its water supply from the east side of the Hudson, and will by that much make it more necessary to have recourse to the sources of supply still under the control of the Ramapo clique of unsavory memory.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 10. -- The brethren of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Evanston, are so far from dwelling together in harmony that the rector, curate, bible class leader, and six teachers have resigned.

Lawyers throughout the city yesterday continued to discuss the course pursued by Justice Rogers of the Supreme Court in setting aside the verdict of a jury in favor of James H. Temple, ex-President of the William Campbell Wall Paper Company and defendant in the suit brought against him by Receiver Howell of that company for conversion.

Capt. White of the Bergen Street Station, Brooklyn, at the head of a squad of police, raided the private stable of Robert A. Pinkerton, head of the Pinkerton Detective Agency, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, interrupting a cocking main which had already cost the lives of four birds.

Over 7,000 persons attended the opening cycling race meet at the Vailsburg track, Newark, N.J., yesterday, and the throng overflowed the grand stand and bleachers and encroached upon the track, requiring constant vigilance on the part of the officials to prevent accident. It was a good-natured and highly appreciative crowd which welcomed all the favorites of former years with noisy enthusiasm.

-- In these days, when conviction in any of the lower courts is so often merely a formal preparation for appeal after appeal and retrial after retrial, old ideas as to "presumption of innocence" are thrown into confusion, and the "suspension of judgment" which the layman always found so difficult has become a next to endless task.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10. -- The Pittsburg National League baseball team defeated the Kansas City American Association team here to-day. Score:

Carrying an incased bass viol almost as big as himself, a portly German squeezed aboard a well-filled Ninth Avenue train at One Hundred and Fortieth Street in the rush hour Saturday morning, and, finding two unoccupied seats by the door of the car, deposited himself in one and his giant fiddle in the other.

The Bennett Building at Nassau, Fulton, and Ann F. Streets, sold under foreclosure yesterday in the Real Estate Salesroom by Auctioneer Joseph P. Day, was bid in by the New York Life Insurance Company, the plaintiffs in the proceedings, for $907,000. The mortgage under foreclosure was an old one made by John Pettit, who owned the property for some time prior to his disappearance in 1897.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 11. -- The village hackmen are not to have an opportunity to exhibit their horses at the open-air show of the Country Club of Lakewood next month.

ESSEX, Conn., April 11. -- Deputy Sheriff Huntley of this place arrested a man this afternoon whose description tallies almost identically with that of John Marx, who is suspected of the murder of Joseph Pavoll, the farm hand, whose mutilated body was found in an old excavation on Marx's farm, at Colchester, last Friday. The man arrested says he is seventy years old, and that his name is Jacob Sweitzer.
ROME, April 11. -- For the first time since his coronation, Aug. 9, 1903, the Pope this morning went to St. Peter's to say mass in celebration of the thirteenth centennial of St. Gregory the Great.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 11. --- A vigorous discussion as to the character and business ability of Charles Parkhurst, editor of Zion's Herald, occupied most of the energies of this morning's session of the New England Methodist Conference.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 11. -- The Democratic Convention for the First Chautauqua District to-day elected without instructions anti-Hill delegates to the State Convention.

OIL CITY, Penn., April 11. -- Mrs. Luke Gough, aged twenty-seven, became insane on religion a week ago, and this afternoon, obeying what she believed to be a Divine command, she sat her daughter Harriet, aged eight mouths, on top of a hot gas stove, and before the other children could bring assistance, cut the girl's right hand off at the wrist with a blunt paring knife.

At a meeting of the Speedwell Society for Sick and Convalescent Children at the residence of Miss Helen Miller Gould, 579 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, it was announced that Mrs. Andrew Carnegie had promised to duplicate the largest donation made for the benefit of that organization. It was also announced that Daniel G. Reid of the Rock Island Company had promised to be one of twenty to contribute $5,000 toward a fund of $100,000.

Sub-Board No. 2 of the Board of United States General Appraisers began the call of its calendar of suspended cases yesterday and made fair progress. Under the agreement arrived at last week, by which the cases are called by subjects, there was no friction.

The People's Choral Union, which is exhibiting more than its usual activity this Spring, gave another concert last evening in Carnegie Hall under Mr. Frank Damrosch's direction, and exhibited again its title to be considered one of the most potent and vital musical influences at work in New York. The principal number upon the programme was Max Bruch's cantata, "The Cross of Fire."

ST. PETERSBURG, April 11. -- The reports that M. Lessar, the Russian Minister at Peking, made strong representations to the Chinese Government on the subject of the Japanese military instructors in the service of China and the Japanese officers with Gen. Ma's army, demanding the issuance of orders for their dismissal, are confirmed here.

PARIS, April 11. -- The Russian Ambassador, M. Nelidoff, acting on instructions from the Russian Foreign Minister, Count Lamsdorff, has expressed to the French Foreign Minister, M. Delcasse, the satisfaction of Russia at the conclusion of the Anglo-French colonial treaty. This is accepted as Russia's answer to the reports that the Anglo-French treaty was indirectly hostile to Russia.

Richard P.W. Wolle, who, according to the police, has a long string of aliases, was arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday for selling counterfeit stamps to stamp dealers. Experts who have examined his work say that it is excellent in its way, and that the counterfeiting might not have been discovered if Wolle, in affixing an alleged valuable and old stamp to an envelope, had not used mucilage of an inferior quality.

It is rather melancholy to read that Commander ZULEZICKI of the Russian Navy has reported favorably upon the feasibility of getting the Russian Baltic fleet, including half a dozen vessels still unfinished, from the Baltic to the North Pacific by way of the Arctic Ocean and Bering Sea to the Korean Gulf and the Gulf of Liau-tung, and that he thinks the voyage may be accomplished by the end of August.
That dull, heavy feeling from coffee may not amount to much in itself, but it's a great obstacle in the way of fame and fortune, for it kills ambition and makes one lazy and finally sick.
TELLURIDE, Col., April 11. -- When Gen. Bell was informed to-day that Judge Stevens had ordered himself and Capt. Wells confined in the Ouray County Jail for contempt, he said:

The trial of the suit for $25,000 instituted by Olga Lansdorf, an actress, against Franklin W. Olds, a retired Newark lawyer, for breach of promise, was resumed yesterday morning before Judge Wallace and a jury in the United States District Court. The morning session was taken up almost entirely by the direct and cross-examination of Miss Lansdorf, and in the afternoon she again took the stand.

When the first championship game at home is played by the New York National League team against the Philadelphias on April 21, the Polo Grounds, remodeled in many particulars, will undoubtedly be one of the handsomest and best appointed ball fields in the country. The 2,000 persons who were present yesterday to witness the game between Manager McGraw's men and the champion Jersey City team of the Eastern League saw changes on every hand.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Culberson amendment to the Post Office Appropriation bill, providing for a commission to investigate the Post Office Department, was before the Senate all of to-day, and after being ruled out of order was pending in modified form when the Senate adjourned.

"Times Square will be the Piccadilly of New York -- the very heart and centre of the city. Because I believe this, I have advertised the fact that my property between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, on Seventh Avenue, which formerly was offered at $350,000, cannot now be purchased for less than $400,000."

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 11. -- Fear is felt here of an attack by numerous Haitien exiles organized by Gen. Jiminez, ex-President of the Dominican Republic. The exiles now are gathered in Dominican territory.

The Morris and Essex Canal has received so little care and attention in the past few years that its usefulness is apt to be underestimated and the question of its abandonment treated as a matter of very small consequence.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The War Department has received no advices of the reported assassination of Capt. C.E. Young at Ludlow, Miss. There is no Capt. Young in the Engineer Corps of the army nor any officer by the name of Young. Neither is there in any branch of the army an officer bearing the name of C.E. Young.

According to the officials of the Brooklyn Club, Frank Dillon, the first baseman who has been the subject of much dispute between the Los Angeles Club of the California League and the Brooklyn Club, is on his way to report to Manager Hanlon. Dillon signed two contracts, with Brooklyn and Los Angeles, but it was contended by the Brooklyn management that Dillon had first signed with them.

Thus far Mr. HEARST has not secured a single delegate out of the 450 who will sit in the Democratic Convention at Albany next Monday, and less than a dozen district conventions remain to be held. The "Hearst boom" in this State has been a thing without substance, a hollow pretense, a sham from the beginning to the end.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- Not over a thousand persons saw the game to-day between the rival Philadelphia clubs of the National and American Leagues, which proved to be one of the hardest fought contests played in this city in a long time. For seven innings not a run was scored, but in the eighth the American League team secured two runs and won the game.

Only through diplomacy on the part of Police Sergeant Bauer of the theatre squad was danger of a stampede averted outside the New York Theatre yesterday afternoon during the benefit for the widow and children of Policeman Hugh Enright, who was shot by burglar. It was when Mrs. William G. McAdoo, wife of the Police commissioner, arrived that the Sergeant had all opportunity to show his resourcefulness.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 11. -- In the presence of about 300 of her own race and a thousand other curious women, Mother Sibbie Riley, Queen of the Harrison-Cooper-Stanley tribes of gypsies, was buried this afternoon in Hillside Cemetery.

The opening of business yesterday showed indifference to the bank statement's unfavorable features and reflected good buying from London. The tone was strong, if not buoyant, and nothing worse than some uncertainty was shown later under the influence of continued gold shipments and unfavorable anticipations of the crop report, which was not a factor during business, not being announced until after the close.

All the preliminaries for the Republican State Convention, which meets at noon to-day at Carnegie Hall, were settled yesterday, according to the desires of Gov. Odell. The power of the Governor in the organization was very much in evidence at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where the members of the Republican State Committee and politicians from all sections of the State assembled.
SEOUL, April 7. -- Recent reports in regard to the possibility of internal troubles in Korea have been much exaggerated.

An archaic Avenue B horse car was bumping along over the maze of rails opposite the Post Office, in Park Row, yesterday afternoon, when one of the horses tumbled headlong into the subway, a part of which still remains unclosed at that point. The horse, its forelegs in the opening, stuck at the shoulders.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 11. -- F.P. McDonald, a well-known young man of prominent family, who has killed two men and figured in several sensational shooting affairs, was shot and instantly killed by Alexander Lawson, an employe of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, in a street fight to-night.

WITH THE JAPANESE HEADQUARTERS, April 11. -- At present information from the land front must be belated owing to the distance existing between the sea base and the advance guard, but this will be remedied shortly.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 11. -- County officers armed with warrants charging violations of the excise law descended upon several alleged "speak-easy" resorts in the village early this morning and made six arrests. The raid was made as the result of evidence obtained by agents of the Law and Order League of Camden.
PARIS, April 11. -- A St. Petersburg telegram contains an account of an interview with Admiral Rojestvensky, Chief of the Naval Staff.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 11. -- Representative Bankhead, after the most strenuous fight in his life, appears to have carried the day in his fight for renomination in the Sixth District over Capt. Richmond P. Hobson of Merrimac fame. To-night Hobson's campaign manager conceded Walker County, which was regarded as certain for Hobson.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day handed down an opinion in the case of the State of Minnesota vs. the Northern Securities Company and the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railway Companies, involving the validity of the merger of the two railroad companies, holding that the Circuit Court was without jurisdiction and reversing the opinion of that court. The opinion was written by Justice Harlan and was unanimous.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- At the Catholic Missionary conference to-day Father Lesner of Lyons, France, who is engaged in Catholic missionary work in Liberia, read a paper on his experiences there.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 11. -- Exceptionally reliable information regarding the Russian military plans confirms the repeated announcements made by The Associated Press that these plans will not mature until late in the Summer. They are of far greater magnitude than is generally believed abroad, and take into account all possible contingencies.

Those who expected that yesterday would be a day of rioting by the tenants of lower east side tenements were disappointed. Although sunrise yesterday morning marked the expiration of the time limit on hundreds of dispossess warrants which had been held back over the Jewish holidays, there were no unusual scenes resulting from evictions.

Special Treasury agents connected with the Custom House yesterday made a large seizure of tobacco from the North German Lloyd steamship Brandenburg, from Bremen on its way to Baltimore, in this harbor.
Samuel Mandel has sold the property 82 and 84 Washington Place, known as the Washington Square Apartments, to W. Bloomfield for about $127,500. The brokers in the deal were Feinberg Levin.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt was a visitor to the Benning race track to-day with a party of friends. Much interest in her presence was taken by persons who recognized her because it was her first visit to the track since a report was published that she had been banished to New York because she had placed bets on races.

If Speaker NIXON were fully informed as to the extent to which public opinion approves the bill providing pensions for Supreme Court Judges on retirement we feel sure that he would at once have the bill reported for passage from his Committee on Rules.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Dr. George T. Moore, head of the Laboratory of Plant Physiology in the Department of Agriculture, who some time ago devised an agent for killing off the green, slimy algae that develop in ponds and stagnant bodies of water, says he has discovered that its action was also fatal to the germs of typhoid and cholera.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Honors were evenly divided at the Benning track to-day, three favorites and three outsiders winning. In five of the races the fields were small. The last race was the best of the day, and there was a good finish in the two-year-old event.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- The mystery surrounding the murder of John Thomas, the aged night watchman at the Houston Club of the University of Pennsylvania last evening, was cleared up to-day by the arrest and confession of Lawrence Gibson, alias John Oakley, who was for a number of years employed as a utility man at Houston Hall.

The news from England, lately printed in your paper, that the House of Commons had voted in favor of granting full Parliamentary suffrage to women by an overwhelming majority -- 182 to 68, is a very encouraging sign that the principles of justice are being recognized by the right-thinking men of England.

WALTHAM, Mass., April 11. -- Charles L. Tucker, charged with the murder of Miss Mabel Page at Weston March 31, is in the Middlesex County Jail at East Cambridge, having been committed without bail to that institution by Judge Luce of the Waltham court, after a brief hearing to-day.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 11. -- President J.J. Hill declared to-day that behind the Harriman petition to intervene in the Securities case is a scheme of far wider significance than appears on the surface. He said:

BARRE, Vt., April 11. -- A general lockout of all the granite cutters employed by members of the Barre Granite Manufacturers' Association in this city, East Barre, Montpelier, Northfield, West Berlin, and Williamstown, was declared this noon at a meeting of the association held here. Three thousand men are thrown temporarily out of employment.

In its evident anxiety to bring Judge PARKER'S methods of interpreting the law into harmony with principles of judicial interpretation that have recently found high acceptance, our neighbor The World has been betrayed into a misunderstanding of one of Judge PARKER'S decisions rendered in 1896, when he was on the Supreme bench assigned to duty in this city.

The action of Judge Rogers in ordering a new trial in the face of an acquittal by a jury is a blow at the jury system which it eminently deserves. I haven't a doubt -- judging from my own experience on juries -- that Judge Rogers is absolutely correct. Our jury system in practice is about as poor a way of settling legal matters as could be devised.

Returning from Atlantic City yesterday forenoon, Charles F. Murphy went to work last night to prepare his plan of action for the State Convention on Monday next. Although silent on the subject of politics, he returned determined to carry on his opposition to Parker instructions to the end and will also carry the fight against Parker into the National Convention, even in the event of New York sending an instructed delegation to St. Louis.
LONDON, April 11. -- Money and discounts were easy in the market to-day.

The William Randolph Hearst Club of the Fifteenth Assembly District held a meeting in the rear of Michael J. Rush's cafe at Tenth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street last night. The meeting was scheduled to begin at 8 P.M.

After chatting over the tea cups in exclusive drawing rooms all afternoon, and talking over highballs and fizzing liquids all evening in the fashionable clubs, Brooklyn society last night reached the conclusion that the cocking main as a social function, having attracted the vulgar attention of the police, was to be discouraged in future.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 11. -- Capt. S.S. Brown's filly Audience, a 1 to 4 favorite for the classic Tennessee Oaks, at one mile, won the stake in a gallop to-day. There were only four starters. Audience took the lead at the quarter pole and never afterward was in danger. Jockey Helgensen had no occasion to urge the filly and had her under restraint nearly all the way.

At the meeting of the Board of Trustees of Columbia University yesterday it was announced that Dr. William T. Bull, the noted surgeon, had tendered his resignation as Professor of Surgery at the university, to take effect June 30, 1904. The resignation was accepted, and a resolution was adopted expressing regret at Dr. Bull's action.

The "time-limit" rule which was adopted by the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in 1900 and which allows a minister to remain in a church for only a year, instead of five, as before, caused some rather warm discussion at the meting of the New York Conference yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., April 11. -- Recorder James F. Kelly reserved decision until Saturday in the cases of William Green and the thirteen laborers charged with breaking up the streets of Kearny early Sunday morning.

Various of The Chronicle's exchanges have had something to say about the offer made them by Mr. Hearst's campaign managers to supply them free with plate matter bearing on the campaign, for the good of the Democratic Party. The Chronicle has been overlooked in the proposed distribution of these favors.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 11. -- The local police were joined to-day by Miss Clara Steadman of Troy in their efforts to unravel the mystery of the disappearance of George Weed, a Greenwich dairyman, who has been missing since April 4. Miss Steadman is Mr. Weed's fiancee, and they were to be married June 10, she declares. She is aged eighteen and Weed twenty-two.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 11. -- Capt. C.E. Young, engaged with the United States Engineering Corps in deepening the channel at Gulfport, Miss., was assassinated by James Fitzhugh and Walter McDuff at Ludlow, Miss., last Saturday night as he emerged from the Ludlow High School's entertainment. The men had been ejected from the school for disorderly conduct. Details of the crime did not become known until to-day.

Official tares have been revised by the drug trade section of the Board of Trade and Transportation, and yesterday copies of the new pamphlet, which is to be the standard all over the world in trade transactions relative to drugs and chemicals, were sent by Secretary William F. McConnell to all shipping points.

VINELAND, N.J., April 11. -- The second anniversary of the Glass Bottle Blowers' Association strike against the George Jonas Glass Company, at Monotola, occurred on April 9. This has been one of the most remarkable struggles in the history of labor in New Jersey. The cost has been many thousand dollars.

ROME, April 11. -- Miss Humphreys of New York, while guiding a motor car in which were St. John Gaffney and Miss Tupignac of New York and Capt. the Marquis Paolucci, although going at a slow rate of speed, ran over two children today, injuring one somewhat seriously.
WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The following bulletin was posted at the War Department to-day:

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The monthly report of the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture will show the average condition of Winter wheat on April 1 to have been 76.5, against 97.3 on April 1, 1903; 78.7 at the corresponding date in 1902, and 84.1 the mean of the April averages of the last ten years.
BERLIN, April 11. -- The Foreign Office received to-day the following dispatch from Col. Leutwein, the Governor of German Southwest Africa.

OURAY, Col., April 11. -- District Judge Theron Stevens to-day declared Adjt. Gen. Sherman M. Bell and Capt. Bulkley Wells to be in contempt of court for not complying with the writ of habeas corpus which required the officers to bring before the court to-day Charles H. Moyer. President of the Western Federation of Miners, whom they are holding in confinement at Telluride.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- In an opinion by Justice Brewer, the Supreme Court of the United States to-day sustained and affirmed the opinion of the Circuit Court of the United States for the Southern District of New York in the habeas corpus proceedings of George W. Beavers, late Chief of the Salary and Allowance Division of the Post Office Department, vs. William Henkle, United States Marshal.

Not alone their own meetings, but the figures of every harness meeting of last year are surpassed by the record-breaking entry list for stakes just received by the management of the Empire and Brighton Beach tracks for their Grand Circuit meets during the two weeks from Aug. 8 to 20.

Action toward the establishment of the often-proposed and much-discussed National Amateur Driving Circuit was taken at a meeting of the League of Amateur Driving Clubs, held at the Hoffman House yesterday afternoon, when eight of the leading driving clubs of the country, represented by delegates or proxies, decided to begin the holding of a series of inter-city races during the coming season.

Clad mainly in American manufactured underwear several members of the royal family of Patagonia arrived here yesterday on the steamship Celtic. They did not occupy the royal suite aboard the steamship, but were quartered under an open hatch in the steerage, where they received plenty of fresh air, which they need. But even in their lowly quarters they showed their royal blood by keeping aloof from the other passengers during the voyage.
LONDON, April 12. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that the Russian Government is having difficulty with the Buriats, the aboriginal inhabitants of Transbaikalia.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 11. -- James W. Hinkley, President of the United States Casualty Company of New York, and for a number of years prominent in Democratic State politics, died suddenly to-night at his home, Eden Hill, in this city, of apoplexy.

Henry Stedeker was placed on trial yesterday afternoon before Judge Newburger in General Sessions on the charge that he had been running a poolroom at 65 Broadway. Capt. Burns raided the place Dec. 3 on information furnished by Policeman Butts of the West Thirtieth Street Station, who was selected for this work because of his youthful appearance, he having been on the force less than a year.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- A report from the House Committee on Banking and Currency recommending the passage of the bill "to improve currency conditions" was filed in the House to-day by Chairman Fowler.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The latest idea for the benefit of American ships and shipbuilders is to extend the navigation laws to Panama. Senator McComas to-day introduced a bill, which was referred to the Committee on Commerce, and an amendment to the Interoceanic bill soon to come up embodying the same matter.

At the annual meeting of the Portia Club, held yesterday afternoon in the Buckingham Hotel, the members listened to addresses as to the value of their law studies to themselves and the community at large.

Society turned out in full force yesterday to witness the wedding of Miss Florence Vanderbilt Twombly, the eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly, and granddaughter of the late William H. Vanderbilt, and William A.M. Burden, the second son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Townsend Burden.

Mr. WILLIAM MACQUEEN, Anarchist, some time a fugitive from justice, who has finally surrendered himself to justice, although he calls it injustice, is an interesting psychological study. Every Anarchist is so, but the English-speaking Anarchist most of all. The Anarchist of Spain, the Anarchist of Italy, the Continental "red" in general we can at least partly understand.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The books of the Red Cross Society will be taken to the Capitol on Thursday, where they will be examined by a committee of inquiry appointed to look into the affairs of the society. The committee then will engage an expert accountant to examine the hooks.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- At to-day's session of their eighth annual convention, the National Association of Clothiers adopted plans for the establishment of a National Labor Bureau to enforce the open-shop principle and resist union demands. In the new constitution adopted by the association its views of several objects of the labor question are thus stated:

NEW BRUNSWICK, April 12. -- No Hearst delegates were elected at the primaries held in New Brunswick to-night to the State Convention at Trenton on Thursday. The delegates from Middlesex County will be anti-Hearst, probably solidly so. The Home News to-day states that Hearst's efforts to capture the delegation in the State of New Jersey to the National Democratic Convention have almost completely failed.

Directing them to vote for President Roosevelt's nomination, the Republican State Convention, which met yesterday at Carnegie Hall, named the following as delegates and alternates to the Republican National Convention to be held in Chicago on June 21:
LONDON, April 13. -- An official circular recently issued in Russia, say The Times's Russian correspondents, manifests a more lenient disposition toward the Jews.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- Herzog was arrested in Philadelphia three weeks ago and locked up on the charge of taking a $100 bill from the purse of a Miss Hershey of Bethlehem, with whom he had been shopping. Miss Hershey withdrew the charge later, saying that Herzog's family had restored the money stolen from her.
TOKIO, April 12. -- It is believed here that fighting has commenced on the Yalu River. It is known that the Russians occupy the right bank of the river in force.

Rumors to the effect that many of the members of the Union Club are decidedly dissatisfied with the arrangement of the interior of the new structure have been rife ever since the building was completed, and now a story is being circulated that an extensive remodeling of the interior is being seriously considered.

Charles A. Bigelow began rehearsals yesterday on "The Man from China," which will be presented at the Majestic Theatre on May 2. The initial presentation will be made at Ford's Theatre, in Baltimore, a week from next Monday. Miss Stella Mahew and Miss Aimee Angeles have been specially engaged to support Mr. Bigelow.

The proudest man in Williamsburg to-day is undoubtedly John Fasel of 246 Varet Street, who is going around showing his friends an X-ray photograph which brings out in bold relief the extraordinary amount of tin tacks, scrap iron, pen knives, and miscellaneous nails which he swallowed one night last week, and which the doctors are now planning to remove.

Judge Adam, in the United States District Court, yesterday signed an order authorizing the Guarantee Trust Company to turn over the 3,000 bales of cotton held by it to the receivers of Daniel J. Sully Co., Henry W. Taft and David H. Miller.

BOSTON, April 12. -- The Democrats of Massachusetts held caucuses to-day to choose representatives to the State Convention, which next week will elect delegates to the National Convention of the party. On the results of the caucuses depends the issue of the fight between the Olney men and the Hearst men for the Presidential nomination.

As we have already pointed out, in the case of the Democratic Party, the nomination of a candidate from this State would almost necessarily imply that the declaration of principles made by the party in this State should foreshadow the National platform. The same is true of the Republican Party.

Mr. Salter of Iaplewood has made a suggestion in this morning's TIMES on the benefit of fresh air in the treatment of consumption which I wish to second and commend. Every word of his is true -- a 'medicine cheap and palatable.

No important currency legislation is possible this session, or, for that matter, desirable. But there are certain changes involving no principle that any one disputes, which have been recommended by the House Committee on Banking and Currency, and which it ought to be feasible to adopt before adjournment.

A recreant American was remarking the other day that this country had never done anything -- such was his strong expression -- in science, properly so called. The most, according to this critic, that the inventors of his country could claim was that they had handy minds, and could turn to speedy practical account such really scientific discoveries as were made elsewhere.

Mr. MURPHY'S opposition to the sending of a delegation instructed for Judge PARKER does not spring from a desire to help the Hearst candidacy. That suspicion exists up the State, and to some extent in the South and West. But the Hearst label appears to irritate the Tammany cuticle.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- F. Ambrose Clark, stepson of Bishop Potter and known to patrons of racing as one of the most skillful and daring amateur steeplechase riders of the metropolitan turf, earned his first triumph of the season at the Benning race course to-day, when on his own horse Stroller he captured the Amateur Cup, the feature event of the afternoon's programme.

So many little ones gathered at the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon to see the Barnum Bailey Circus that for every two seats there were three children. This did not seem to interfere with their comfort and enjoyment, however, for they fairly gurgled with delight through the whole performance.
WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The Post Office Appropriation bill, which has been under consideration by the Senate for two weeks, was passed to-day by that body after an exciting debate.

Urging the veto of the Smith bill, which, if approved, would prevent the City of New York from going into Dutchess County for any part of its additional water supply, Mayor McClellan last night forwarded a letter to Gov. Odell at Albany. The Smith bill is the one which had been vigorousyl attacked on the ground that it was in the interests of the Ramapo Company.

LONDON, April 13. -- The budget is to be introduced by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Austen Chamberlain, on April 19. The Government supporters make no secret of the fact that they anticipate serious difficulty in carrying it.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 12. -- The motion of E.H. Harriman and Winslow S. Pierce for leave to file an intervening petition in the settlement of Northern Securities affairs recently ordered by the United States Supreme Court, the manner of such settlement being left to the order of the United States District Court here, was heard before the full bench of the District Court to-day.

The suggestion of "A Victim" in a recent issue, that gas companies should be compelled by law to print directions for reading meters on the backs of bills, is a good one. I learned to read meters from the back of bills of the Boston Gas Light Company of that city.

Any one who is familiar with the conditions under which the letter carriers work in cities will not be surprised to learn that they have petitioned Congress, through Postmaster General Payne, for a modest increase in their salaries. In this movement they have the support of all their old friends in the House, and have made many new ones.

Announcement was made yesterday that the Rock Island Company had placed a loan of $5,000,000 with the First National Bank. The loan is made on one year 4 1/2 per cent. notes, which were taken at par without commission. The notes are secured by $7,500,000 of first and refunding mortgage bonds.

Electric lighting companies have at last won their contest upon the question of the proper duty on carbons, a decision having beeen made yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals. As a result, the duty on nearly all carbons used in this country for lighting purposes will be reduced.

Years ago, when the project of the Episcopalian Cathedral was younger, Bishop POTTER, if we remember aright, suggested that the ring of chapels that were planned to surround its apse might be made to serve an excellent public purpose if each were devoted to the religious uses of some colony of non-English-speaking residents of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- An attack on ex-President Cleveland's veracity was made to-day in the House by Representative Scott (Kan.) in reply to Mr. Gilbert, (Ky.,) who had alluded to President Roosevelt and the so-called Booker Washington incident at the White House. It was Mr. Scott who some time ago charged Mr. Cleveland with inviting to luncheon while President a Kansas negro named C.H.J. Taylor.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 12. -- Gen. Kuropatkin, in a dispatch to the Emperor bearing to-day's date, says that Gen. Krasnalinski on the night of April 8 ordered a detachment of sharpshooters to cross to the left bank of the Yalu, opposite Wi-ju.
