Egan Hallecy, builders, have bought the southwest corner of Audubon Avenue and One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Street, a plot 75 by 100, upon which they will erect two five-story apartment houses -- the corner one 35 feet front and the inside one 40 feet. Architects Neville Bagge are preparing the plans.

-- Owing to the widespread disinclination for jury duty, there is, of course, room for suspicion whenever a talesman called to serve in a murder case declares that he has "conscientious scruples" against the infliction of capital punishment, and so conveys, or tries to convey, the impression that he might not be able to reach a conclusion based entirely on the evidence.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--Friction, it is learned, is again developing between Great Britain and Nicaragua over the Mosquito Coast, which since the early sixties has been a matter of contention between the two Governments.

In going back to see that she had forgotten nothing in the moving Mrs. Agnes Wigley of 2,760 Eighth Avenue caught her foot in a loose board in the kitchen floor. By attempting a rescue George Watson, the driver of the moving fan, also put his foot in it--in the purely figuratively sense--and barely escaped a severe beating at the hands of Mrs. Wigley's well-meaning but unappreciative neighbors.

Electors for the thirty-seven Congressional districts to be voted for on the Republican ticket this Fall were elected yesterday at the State Convention. Two Electors at Large were also elected. They are George Urban, Jr., of Erie, an ex-State Committeeman, and Charles A. Schieren, ex-Mayor of Brooklyn.
BOSTON, April 12. -- A recent interview with Thomas W. Lawson, in which he unbosomed himself with frankness regarding "modern finance," caused The Boston Post to allude to him as a "buccaneer."

BARCELONA, April 12. -- Premier Maura was attacked and slightly wounded to day by a would be assassin as he was leaving the palace of the Council General, after accompanying King Alfonso on a visit to the Poorhouse.

The New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church finished its last session yesterday with the announcement of the appointments of the ministers by Bishop Andrews. There were over eighty shifts in the pastorates of the Conference, most of them being in connection with small appointments.

BOONTON, N.J., April 12. -- Held fast by the leg at the mouth of a rushing sluiceway seventy feet beneath the surface of the great Rockaway River Reservoir, one mile southeast of this place, lies the armor-clad body of William Hoar, thirty-two years old, a diver. He has lain there since 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and to-night no one knows whether he is alive or dead.

" Verdant Green," in to-day's TIMES, asks, Why are the trees on upper Broadway unprotected from the teeth of horses thoughtlessly tied to them? While the injuring of trees on our streets, thoughtlessly or otherwise, is specially interdicted by law, the police appear to give very little attention to the matter, and the ordinary everyday citizen as well, it may be added.

TACOMA, Wash., April 12. -- Another strange lake has been formed in the Olympic Mountain range by the disappearance of part of Queets Valley. This occurred three weeks ago at the time of the recent earthquake, which created much excitement among the Indians on the west side of the Olympic Mountains, bordering on the Pacific Ocean.

The participants in Brooklyn's Sunday morning's, cocking main waived examaination before Magistrate Naumer yesterday morning, and were held in bail to appear for trial at the Court of Special Sessions. George F. Elliott, counsel for the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, said:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 12. -- Counsel for Mrs. Grace Imogene Bennett appeared before Judge Cleaveland in the Probate Court to-day with a petition that William Jennings Bryan be removed as the executor of the estate of the late Philo S. Bennett, the chief allegation being that he is dissipating the funds of the estate in his legal actions in attempting to secure the probating of the "sealed letter" as a part of the will.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The news of the death of Admiral Makaroff caused a profound sensation in naval and military circles here. He was probably better known in America than any other Russian naval officer. This was because he had more than once visited the United States, and had also commanded the Russian North Pacific Squadron, which brought him into frequent contact with American naval officers.

With August Belmont, John B. McDonald, and officials of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company on board, the first train, drawn by an engine made a trip through the subway yesterday afternoon. The party started from the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street station, and went to City Hall.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 13. -- The battleship Petropavlovsk was to-day sunk by striking a mine in the outer roadstead of Port Arthur. She heeled over, turned turtle, and went to the bottom.

BOSTON, April 13. -- The trial of the suit to have the Boston gas consolidation declared invalid, which has been pending in the Massachusetts Supreme Court for six weeks, was closed to-day by Judge Barker after counsel had finished their arguments. The Judge did not announce his decision, and declared that he did not know when he would do so.

TRENTON, April 13. -- Five students, three from Rutgers College and two from Princeton University, to-day took the examination in the Free Public Library here for the Cecil Rhodes Scholarship at Oxford, England. The examination is being conducted under the direction of Profs. W. A. Magee and William Gellespie of Princeton.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 13. -- Accident has brought into possession of Mrs. John Robinson of this place a time-stained document which, in spite of its faulty construction, is regarded as South Carolina's original Ordinance of Secession from the Union. Mrs. Robinson found the paper under the backing of a picture frame she bought at a recent sale.

M. L. Hess have sold for Henry Corn the eleven-story building at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, on a plot of over 11,000 square feet, formerly the site of Chickering Hall. The buyers are Frederick Potter and Clarence H. Kelsey, Trustees of the O.B. Potter Trust.
The Russian battleship Petropavlovsk was sunk yesterday in the outer roadstead of Port Arthur.

ALBANY, April 13. -- Senator Patrick H. McCarren is to be made National Committeeman, to succeed Norman E. Mack. Senator McCarren is anxious for the place, and has received Senator Hill's assurance that he will get it.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 13. -- The United States Steel Corporation to-day notified the Mahoning and Shenango Valley furnace operators that the option secured on 60,000 tons of pigiron will not be taken up. The same company also canceled an order for 30,000 tons of pigiron placed with the Bessemer Pig Iron Association and 15,000 tons ordered from W.P. Snyder Co. at $13 per ton.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 13. -- The decision of the United States Circuit Court as to the right of E.H. Harriman and Winslow Pierce, as Trustees for the Oregon Short Line, to file a petition in the case of the Government against the Northern Securities Company and others will be handed down to-morrow morning when the court meets.

As the principal speaker in a symposium on "Jeffersonian Simplicity," the after-dinner topic at the Jefferson banquet of the Thirteen Club last night at the Hotel Gerard, Robert B. Roosevelt, uncle of the President, despite his own Democratic politics, took up the cudgels on behalf of his nephew and by implication at least defended the methods observed now at the White House.

OFF PORT ARTHUR, on Board The Times's Steamship Haimun, April 13. -- The Japanese torpedo craft attacked Port Arthur early this morning and the fleet later shelled the forts. The bombardment began at 9:45 o'clock.

In its issue of to-day The Iron Age calls attention to the large increase in the production of pig iron and comments on the declination of the United States Steel Corporation to exercise its option on 40,000 tons of Bessemer pig. It says:

It is perhaps to be regretted that the joy-imparting if nefarious industry of manufacturing rare stamps for the benefit of dealers and collectors has been interrupted. From what appears the art is a very simple one, though requiring a certain skill and dexterity in penmanship.

The Governor of the State of New Jersey having vetoed the Good Roads Appropriation bill, thereby impairing or preventing the improvement of one method of transportation in his State, he is now seeking to still further impair the interests of his State by destroying another means of transportation, namely, the Morris Canal.

TOKIO, April 13. -- An official telegram from Wi-ju says that a company of Russian troops attempted to cross the first stream of the Yalu River west of Wi-ju yesterday morning, and that a company of Japanese attacked and drove the Russians back.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13. -- When the Democratic State Convention to name delegates to the National Convention to St. Louis is called together to-morrow morning by Chairman Gourley, the Hearst men will bolt, go over to Masonic Hall, and elect a full set of contesting delegates. This was determined to-night by Albert Dulin, in charge of the Hearst boom here.

The decision of the Board of Sinking Fund Commissioners that in the meaning and intent of the law an automobile is an animal, and that fines collected for speeding these road locomotives must be turned over to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, is not so surprising as it might seem at first glance.
Harry Clark, infielder, and Catcher Slattery have been purchased by the Milwaukee American Association team from the Chicago Americans.

CHICAGO, April 13. -- Ways and means to bring success to the Democratic Party in the Presidential campaign this Fall were discussed by prominent Democrats representing every part of the country who attended the Iroquois Club banquet at the Auditorium to-night in celebration of Jefferson's birthday.

Police Commissioner McAdoo announced yesterday that, when the occasion arose, he would not hesitate to invoke the aid of the power vested in him to issue what is known as "Commissioner's warrants." These warrants, which may be issued on affidavits subscribed to by any two householders, entitle the police to force entry into any house in which it is suspected that the law is being violated.

At the annual banquet of the New York Association of the Alumni of the University of Virginia, held last night at the Hotel Manhattan, about one hundred New Yorkers, principally alumni of that institution, paid high tribute to the memory of Thomas Jefferson, who founded the university in the early part of the last century.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 13. - In an editorial headed, "The Truth of History," Henry Watterson takes issue with purported declarations of Don M. Dickerson that the defeat of Grover Cleveland in New York in 1888, when David B. Hill was elected Governor, was due to the nefarious campaign carried on for Mr. Hill by Judge Alton B. Parker.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13. -- A fire engine which is used to pump out basements after a fire is at work to-night trying to empty the basement of the home of United States Senator Dryden at 1,020 Broad Street. The house has been closed since the Senator and his family have been at Washington.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 13. -- Mrs. George K. Davis, wife of the wealthy coal operator of this city, who is now suing for a divorce here, and who was before marriage Miss Helen C. Gallatin of New York, to-day told why she has commenced proceedings. She said:

ALBANY, April 13. -- The Carpenter White Plains Roads bill, which, according to its opponents, contemplates a raid upon the New York City Treasury of $1,500,000 and by which it is alleged four well-known attorneys will benefit to the extent of $300,000, went through the Assembly to-day by a vote of 81 to 52.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- President Roosevelt had a conference to-day with Senator Penrose, Chairman of the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, and, subsequently, one with Senator Aldrich, the Republican floor leader of the Senate, as to the proposition, that the Senate provide for an investigation of the affairs of the Post Office Department.

Dr. ANDREW S. DRAPER, the new Commissioner of Education, has at once won the applause and the confidence of the friends of education, but the politicians must be dumfounded when they hear him proclaim such doctrines as this: "The sound principle has been declared that the educational organization of the State shall be as free from all political, all un-educational, influences as is the judiciary."

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- When the House Committee on Appropriations reported the General Deficiency bill to-day, with its provision of $4,000,000 for pensions, a great part of which is needed to meet the drain caused by Secretary Hitchcock's much-criticised service pension order, the minority of the committee made a sharp protest and threat to fight the service pension proposition.

The report of the House committee on the charges and intimations of Assistant Postmaster General BRISTOW as to improper conduct of Congressmen in seeking favors from the Post Office Department is a marvel of naivete. "Nothing," it declares, "has appeared that would justify the finding that any member has done anything that did not appear to be within the line of his official duty according to long-established custom."

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 13. -- The fates seem unpropitious in the matter of the tour of inspection which President E.H. Harriman of the Southern Pacific and Union Pacific Railroads is making over his lines. Yesterday at Memphis one of the party, R.W. Goelet of New York, while driving his automobile on Union Avenue, collided with the automobile of George C. Bennett, the Memphis turfman.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- A tiny colored boy about seven years old was standing on the rear platform of a street car. A party of Congressmen got on and took places on the same platform. There were so many of them that the platform was uncomfortably crowded, and one of them, Representative James of Kentucky, who is a giant in size, stood in front of the little colored boy.

Coroner Brown and a jury investigated yesterday the cause of the death of Ludwig Knack of 166 East One Hundred and Tenth Street. Knack died at the Manhattan State Hospital for the Insane at Ward's Island. The death certificate gave pneumonia as the cause, but an autopsy showed that the man had twelve broken ribs.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- C.W. Lyman, Vice President of the International Paper Company, entered a general and specific denial before the House Committee on the Judiciary to-day of the charges against the paper "trust," recently made before the committee by Don C. Seitz and John Norris, representing the American Newspaper Publishers' Association.
The Cleveland interview can in nowise injure Judge Parker.

As a result of the fight made against the continuance of the "near-side stop" ordinance for the regulation of street car traffic the Board of Aldermen yesterday passed Alderman Doull's resolution repealing this provision of the rules of the road and sent it to Mayor McClellan for action. The repeal was brought about largely through the efforts of President Fornes of the Board of Aldermen, who has repeatedly urged that the Doull resolution be passed.

The Government is to be congratulated on the decision of the Supreme Court sustaining the Post Office Department in its rulings as to second-class mail matter, and Mr. CHARLES EMORY SMITH, who as Postmaster General first made these rulings, is to be especially congratulated.

Twenty minutes was the time allowed yesterday by Mayor McClellan for the hearings on ten bills which had come down from the Legislature. Every one desiring to be heard was heard in the time specified, too, but only one of the ten bills brought out anybody to speak.

" The stars in their courses fought against SISERA." That will be the reflection of the world at large upon learning of the horrible disaster which has come upon a Russian battleship. The Petropavlovsk was not only one of the finest and most formidable of the Russian battleships.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 13. -- Justice A.B. Wallace, acting as Coroner, held an inquest to-day on the body of the woman who was found dead Monday afternoon in the woods south of Greenfield Cemetery, and his investigation developed the strong belief that murder had been done.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 13. -- It appears from the returns from all over the State that William Randolph Hearst's Alabama boom has died in the primary. He made a special effort for Dallas County and got one delegate to the State Convention out of twenty-five. In Jefferson County, which has thirty delegates, his ticket does not win a man.

WASHINGTON, April 13. -- The news of the disaster on the battleship Missouri at Pensacola was a severe shock to the Secretary and the naval officers of the department. No such accident has before occurred in the history of the new navy.
LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., April 13. -- Ex-Senator Titus Sheard of this place died suddenly at his home this morning of heart disease.

Mayor MCCLELLAN'S vigorous protest to the Governor against the Remsen Water bill cannot very well be disregarded unless Mr. ODELL is willing to have it understood by the people of this State that he is subservient to the interests of the Ramapo conspirators. Mayor MCCLELLAN says with much force:

The obnoxious "near-side" street-car ordinance has been repealed. Now, after due notice, the surface cars will stop on the far side of the street, where they should never have ceased to stop. The public convenience will thereby again be served, and the cause of much public annoyance will have been removed.

As the guests of Senator Thomas C. Platt, the members of the Republican Editorial Association wound up their annual meeting last night by a dinner which was held in Parlor DR of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The veteran Senator and leader acted as toastmaster, and, in a speech which he delivered, talked freely on the political situation.

After the first hour yesterday's trading in the stock market was exceedingly quiet, and while prices recovered somewhat during the inactivity of the afternoon it was very evident that the traders had again adopted a waiting policy, and once more it was the Northern Securities Company that brought the market to a sudden halt.

A badly scared nine-year-old boy, Joseph McDonnell, rushed into the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station yesterday afternoon and dropped a suit case on the floor in front of Sergt. Totten.

The telephone played an important part in the capture of a man, believed to be a clever professional bank swindler, which was brought about yesterday by the Pinkerton Detective Agency and the Hackensack police. The man arrested is said to have operated with varying success during several months under the aliases of John D. Lothrop, Jr., Thomas G. Cook, Walter C. Lewis, and Arthur H. Lee.

Eight candidates for the honor of representing New York State as Cecil Rhodes scholar at Oxford University took their qualifying examinations at Columbia University yesterday, and will continue their tests to-day. The examinations were held in Earl Hall, under the supervision of Prof. Thomas Scott Fiske.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 14. -- What has been the issue of the combat between Rear Admiral Ouktomsky and the Japanese fleet, or whether a fight has actually taken place, is not known in St. Petersburg. At 2:30 o'clock this morning the Commission of Censors adjourned, after announcing that no further news had been communicated.

Several lots of the stock of the Federal Bank sold at the Muller auction sale of securities yesterday at prices which attracted considerable attention because of the falling off from recent quotations. The first lot was of 200 shares, on which the assessment of 20 per cent. had not been paid, and it went for $10 a share.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 13. -- By the explosion of 2,000 pounds of powder in the after twelve-inch turret and the handling room of the battleship Missouri Capt. William S. Cowles, brother-in-law of President Roosevelt, commanding, twenty-nine men were to-day instantly killed and five injured, of whom two will die.

The wife of the Rev. Willis P. Odell, until recently pastor of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, left a will in which she bequeathes her estate, known as The Laurels, at Sandow, N.H., to the New Hampshire Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, after the death of her nephew, George Willis French, and her husband, who are made life tenants.

Lewis Stuyvesant Chanler was a voluntary prisoner yesterday before Judge Newburger, in General Sessions. Mr. Chanler had been adjudged in contempt of court in that he had refused to continue as attorney for Martin Conlon, a lawyer, because he objected to rulings of the court.
LONDON, April 14. -- The House of Commons yesterday, by 270 to 61 votes, adopted a resolution sanctioning the employment of Indian troops for the protection of the "political mission to Tibet."

LONDON, April 14. -- In an editorial article to-day on the sinking of the Petropavlovsk The Times expresses doubt as to the correctness of the Russian account of the disaster. It considers it more probable that the vessel was sunk by Japanese torpedoes than by a submarine mine.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 13. -- Gov. Van Sant issued a statement to-day with reference to the recent decision of the United States Supreme Court in the case of the State of Minnesota against the Northern Securities Company. The Governor intimates that no further legal proceedings will be taken by the State unless the attempt to consolidate the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Roads is renewed.

Lynn Council, No. 1,029, of the National Union, which is made up of the employes of John Wanamaker in this city, gave an elaborate entertainment and reception last night at the Harlem Casino, One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue.

More than 100 representative citizens of New York were the guests of Gen. Stewart L. Woodford last evening at a dinner given by him at the University Club in honor of Baron Kentaro Kaneko, an ex-Gabinet Minister of Japan, who is making a tour of the United States for the purpose of studying economic conditions.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The first of the several notable international marriages announced for the Spring season took place to-day at noon at the Dupont Circle residence of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Patterson, when their only daughter, Miss Eleanor Medill Patterson, became the bride of Count Joseph Gizycki of Poland. The Rev. Thomas S. Lee, rector of St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church, officiated.

Mr. Horace B. Fry has earned the gratitude of all good theatregoers by his one-act tragedy "Little Italy," which Mrs. Fiske and Mr. Frederic De Belleville some years ago enveloped in an atmosphere of consummate naturalistic acting, and Miss Carlotta Nillson lately showed herself similarly deserving by her tense emotional performance as Mrs. Elvsted in Mrs. Fiske's production of Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler."

TRENTON, N.J., April 14. -- Vice Chancellor Reed to-day filed an opinion in Chancery Court dismissing the former order which restained William H. and George P. Butler of Newark from negotiating certain bonds of the Universal Tobacco Company.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 14. -- News of two fresh disasters to the Russian fleet in the Far East reached here to-day, and the official bulletin conveying the intelligence was almost as severe a blow as the news of the loss of the Petropavlovsk yesterday. It plunged the whole town anew into grief.

With $52,000 cash and a variegated loan account of $600,000 standing as its entire assets against a supposed capital of $250,000, surplus of $50,000 and deposits of $350,000, the Federal Bank at 590 Broadway, of which David Rothschild of Globe Security-Oriental-rug fame was formerly President, was closed yesterday by order of State Banking Superintendent Frank D. Kilburn.

With Admiral Dewey, a graduate of the class of '55, as its principal guest of honor, the New York Association of Norwich University Alumni and Past Cadets last evening celebrated its sixth annual dinner at the Everett House, Seventeenth Street and Fourth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Senator Dietrich of Nebraska has been declared by a special committee of Congress to be not guilty of any violation of the statutes of the United States or of any corrupt or unworthy conduct relating either to the appointment of Jacob Fisher as Postmaster at Hastings, Neb., or to the leasing of the building in that city to the United States for a Post Office.

She stepped out of a hansom in front of the Broadway Theatre last evening. He got out after her. That was not gallant. They were both well dressed, he, immaculate in evening dress and silk hat, she, seraphic in a cream something or other, trimmed with shimmering mysteries.

ALBANY, April 14. -- While David B. Hill and Senator McCarren are of one mind with respect to having the State Convention instruct for Judge Parker, and while they are in accord in not favoring the nomination of Mayor McClellan for Governor, they disagree with respect to the Gubernatorial aspirations of District Attorney Jerome. This information was obtained to-day from absolutely reliable sources.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The following telegram has been sent by the Secretary of the Navy to the widow of Lieut. W.C. Davidson, United States Navy, and a similar telegram has been sent to the families of each of the officers and enlisted men who lost their lives in the Missouri explosion:
WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The nomination of Col. A. L. Mills to be Brigadier General was favorably reported to the Senate to-day by the Military Committee.

Third Deputy Police Commissioner Harris Lindsley, who heard a number of police cases in the Bronx on Tuesday, yesterday presided at the trials held at Police Headquarters in Manhattan. Thirty-eight complaints were held, and in every case a decision was reached promptly, judgment being rendered in a manner which precluded any further discussion.

"Monk" Eastman was found guilty of assault in the first degree yesterday by a jury after his trial before Recorder Goff in the Court of General Sessions. He will be sentenced on Tuesday, the maximum penalty for his crime being ten years in the State Penitentiary.

In your issue of yesterday I read with uncomfortable surprise of the insurrectionary attitude taken by the Governor of Colorado in openly defying the authority of civil law in his State. I have no sympathy with lawless miners, but I have still less with lawless Governors and army officers. I presume the miners are largely ignorant foreigners.

About 100 descendants, relatives, and friends of James Seligman, the veteran banker, of the firm of J. W. Seligman Co., joined in the celebration of his eightieth birthday, held at the home of his son-in-law, Benjamin Guggenheim, at 15 East Seventy-second Street, yesterday.

Republican conventions were held last night in each of the eleven Congress districts of Manhattan, Bronx, and Richmond to elect district delegates to the National Convention, which will meet in Chicago in June. In every district the "slate," which was sanctioned by Gov. Odell last Monday, was put through, although in one district, the Fifteenth, a bitter though fruitless fight was made with ex-Congressman Lemuel E. Quigg as the target.
Julius Bonam of 144 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, was arraigned before Police Justice Higgins yesterday, charged with failing to provide for his wife and three-year-old son.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 14. -- Spirited sport and one of the largest and most enthusiastic attendances of the meeting marked the close of the Spring racing at the Benning track to-day. Both of the feature events of the programme produced good contests, the second part of the Benning Handicap going to Graziallo, owned by a popular Washington stable, and the handicap steeplechase going to Charles O'Malley.

TRENTON, N.J., April 14. -- The followers of William Randolph Hearst to-day were completely snowed under by the conservative Democrats who ran the State Convention. These selected a delegation which will be favorable to the candidacy of Judge Alton B. Parker of New York.
TOKIO, April 14. -- Japanese journals welcome the Anglo-French agreement as contributing to the peace of the world and as affording further security that France will not interfere in the present war.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 14. -- It is James J. Hill's position that, in forming the Northern Securities Company, he was acting not only for the protection of his own great railroad system, but even more directly for the protection of the vast territory which it serves.

The tide in Jamaica Bay and two Brooklyn Rapid Transit trolley cars were the heroes of a $25,000 fire which threatened Bergen Beach with destruction yesterday afternoon, the cars making it possible for the fire engines to get to the place, and the tide accommodatingly coming in to provide them with water to fight the flames.
Details will be found in another column relative to large purchases by the New York Life Insurance Company on Leonard, Centre, and Worth Streets.

BOONTON, N.J., April 14. -- John Ride, a diver, to-day undertook a task which William Hoar considered more dangerous than that at which he was at work when he was caught and held fast at the entrance of the sluiceway from the Rockaway River Reservoir dam. Ride descended into the flume shaft and, after remaining there in the rushing current of the drain for over six hours, almost completed the repair of the deranged valve.

ALBANY, April 14. -- If Judge Parker is nominated for President and resigns his position as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, which it is understood he is certain to do in the event of his nomination, there is said to be a strong probability that Supreme Court Judge D. Cady Herrick will receive the nomination to succeed him.

Resolutions indorsing the Presidential candidacy of Judge Alton B. Parker were put through the Brooklyn Democratic Club at last night's meeting, but only after a spirited fight, many of the members opposing any move to place the club on record at this time.

James B. Taylor, brother of Talbot J. Taylor, who as head of the former firm of T.J. Taylor Co. several years ago acquired control of the Rubber Goods Manufacturing Company, yesterday retired from the Board of Directors of that company together with Milton S. Burrill, Lewis D. Parker, and H.C. Winchester.

The Chicago Board of Health has a statistician who is unusually endowed with imagination. It has frequently been pointed out that the statistician needs imagination, but whether he needs quite as muolf of it as the vital statistician of Chicago possesses is a question concerning which somewhat wide differences of opinion may exist.

ALBANY, April 14. -- Encouraged by the demonstration made over him at the Republican State Convention Senator Platt has renewed his fight on Gov. Odell. He is making a determined fight against the consummation of the Governor's plan to secure control of the Railroad Commission by the enactment of legislation which would give the Governor authority to appoint two additional Commissioners.

Wonders grow stale by repetition. To the common, or average, man they thus cease to be wonders at all. But only consider such a piece of news as THE TIMES had the pleasure of presenting to its readers yesterday about the Japanese attack on Port Arthur.

OMAHA, Neb., April 14. -- As the Union Pacific train from the West came into the Omaha station this morning B.F. Munroe, a wealthy stock broker of New York City, having offices at 80 Broadway, suddenly became temporarily deranged, and, jumping from the train, rushed into the station, declaring he would go no further eastward. He was taken in charge by the trainmen, and later induced to continue his journey to New York.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 14. -- Mrs. George J. Gould returned this afternoon to Georgian Court from the Gould town house, where she has been ill for a fortnight. She was accompanied by Mr. Gould and her daughter Marjorie, and had to be supported during the few steps from the train to her carriage.

A throng of persons estimated at over 15,000 witnessed the opening of the championship baseball season at American League Park yesterday. Considering the wintry weather it was a surprising attendance, and enthusiastic to a degree. A snowstorm in the morning was not what the officials of the club expected on their opening day, but although cool the afternoon was clear and the wintry weather had no deterrent effect upon the crowd.
BOSTON, Mass., April 14. -- The Democratic organization has so fixed things that Hearst may not get a single Massachusettts delegate, even though his friends carry district conventions.

The New York Life Insurance Company has purchased through John N. Golding, the property adjoining its annex building at the southwest corner of Elm and Leonard Streets. The purchase gives to the company the ownership of the block front in Leonard Street, south side, between Elm and Centre Streets, and of the block front on Centre Street, west side, between Leonard and Worth Streets.

The statue of FREDERICK the Great for Washington irritates a good many thin-skinned patriots. They should feel comforted to learn that a statue of KOSCIUSKO is to be erected in Cleveland, for it was a Prussian King who defeated KOSCIUSKO by an overwhelming force in June of 1794, while it was an enormous Austrian army in the Autumn of that year which caused the penning of the famous line:

Cut-fate theatre tickets will be hard to buy after Aug. 1 if the plans of New York's theatrical managers turn out all right. They are determined to stop free tickets as nearly as they can. At a meeting yesterday afternoon the Association of Theatre Managers of Greater New York passed a rule forbidding all members of the organization to use certain forms of advertising which are now paid for in tickets.

The cotton bears, who, since the elimination of Daniel J. Sully, have been running the market to suit themselves, had a bad scare yesterday afternoon, when word came from New Orleans to the effect that there had been heavy sales of spot cotton for expert in that market.

The action of the National Association of Clothing Manufacturers at their Philadelphia meeting in making a flat and unmistakable declaration for the open shop is extremely significant. As we are advised, the issue has not been raised on any question of wages or of hours, but has been precipitated by the increasing reluctance of union cutters and tailors to render a fair equivalent in work done for wages paid.

We refuse absolutely to give credence to the statement that the platform adopted by the Republican Convention held in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday was submitted to President ROOSEVELT and had received his approval. THEODORE ROOSEVELT is a man of truth and honor. He would not set the seal of his approval upon a political declaration that contained in its very beginning a flagrant falsehood.

It was a great day yesterday for baseball, and particularly for the New York teams, for in this city the American Lague team defeated Boston, the championship holders, in easy fashion, while at Brooklyn the National League team triumphed over the local team by the one-sided score of 7 to 1.

LONDON, April 14. -- The announcement was made officially to-day that the stewards of the Jockey Club had withdrawn their ruling, under which the American jockey, Letter Reiff, was warned off the turf.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- It is learned from unofficial information that previous to the accident to the gun On board the Missouri there had been no flame blown back whatever; that the rapidity of the fire of all of the Missouri's guns had been relatively very slow, in fact only half as rapid as that of the Alabama. The turret roof was not injured, but one man was blown overboard from the turret top.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14. -- At a meeting held this evening the Hartford Yacht Club voted to have an ocean race open to yachts enrolled in the clubs of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound. There will be classes for boats of thirty-six feet and less in length over all and for boats of from thirty-six to fifty feet over all.

GYANGTSE, April 12. -- By dispatch rider to Chalu, April 14. -- The Tibetan Commandant and the Chinese General surrendered Gyangtse Fort this morning without resistance, the Chinese General stating that, the soldiers having fled, no other course was open to him.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 14. -- That the newest battleship of the navy, the Missouri, had a narrow escape from being blown to pieces by the explosion of a magazine and also being beached came to light to-day.

In an instructive article contributed to The Independent, Mr. GEORGE P. UPTON, perhaps the best unofficial authority in this country on the subject treated, shows that within the past thirteen years 77,617 people have committed suicide in this country.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Marion de Vries the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Lamb, Finlay Co. against the assessment of 45 per cent. duty on an importation of vestings, which were returned by the Appraiser as manufactures of flax. It was shown that they were of cotton, and dutiable at 35 per cent.

ALBANY, April 15. -- Four Elsberg law's delays bills met with some opposition in the Assembly this morning, and one -- the so-called "sham answer" bill -- was beaten. The municipal court bill passed with 96 affirmative votes, and the bill providing for the appointment of thirty Supreme Court Commissioners for Manhattan and Brooklyn went through by 90 to 40 votes.
WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama can be facetious and satirical at times.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Secretary of the Navy Moody to-day transmitted to the House a request for a $10,000 appropriation to provide for the proper care of the remains of the victims of the explosion on the battleship Missouri.
Many years ago, July, 1875, I read a magazine story that I have since been unable to locate. You may be able to recall it. If you will I shall be greatly obliged.

Miss Brown's title as applied to her volume of short stories would be somewhat mystifying were it not illuminated by her motto "from the Persian " -- " One instant only is the sun at noon." Each of the dozen tales tells of some culminating moment in a woman's life -- a moment so brief and so elusive that the reader, if "a mere man," will scarcely grasp its significance ere it is gone.

LONDON, April 15. -- William Heinemann announces a book on Japan written entirely by Japanese. Baron Sannomiya, head of the imperial household, writes of the royal family; the Marquis of Ito of the Constitution of the Japanese Empire; the Marquis Oyama of the army: Admiral Saito of the navy, and M. Yamamoto, Governor of the Bank of Japan, on banking.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- In the course of the Cabinet meeting to-day, the President called attention to the messages of condolence he had received from resident Ambassadors regarding the accident on the battleship Missouri. One of these was received last evening from Count Cassini. Incidentally, it refers to the loss of the Petropavlovsk. Count Cassini's note is as follows:

MILWAUKEE, April 15. -- Mrs. Mary Barbean of 529 Lapham Street has a picture of the Virgin Mary in which the figure is thought to move at times. Hundreds of people crowd the woman's home daily, and many claim to have seen the miracle.

While the receivers of Daniel J. Sully Co. have not yet made public any statement of assets and liabilities, it was learned yesterday that they have submitted a statement to the creditors according to which, after throwing out several claims, among them one of the Reynolds Company and one of Mrs. Sully, the liabilities foot up exactly $3,000,000.

Packed in a small cigarette box, wrapped about with coarse manila paper, as if they had been trifles of no value, except that they were sent by special delivery, diamond, pearl, and sapphire rings, brooches, and pins of beautiful design and setting, were sent through the mail yesterday to Capt. Cottrell of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station. The jewels are believed to be worth $2,500.

Tammany conventions were held last night in each of the thirty-five Assembly districts of Manhattan and the Bronx for the purpose of electing delegates and alternates to the State Convention, which will meet in Albany next Monday. Charles F. Murphy will head the delegation and cast its 105 votes as one under the unit rule, Mr. Murphy was elected a delegate at the head of the trio from his own Eighteenth District.

A special meeting of the Board of Managers of the New York Cotton Exchange has been called for next Monday, and at that meeting action will be taken on the application of Thomas J. Majors of New Orleans, who desires to become a member of the New York Cotton Exchange.

" In Famine Land," the author, the Rev. J.E. Scott, tells his readers, is a work not written "to gloat over unprecedented human miseries," or with a desire to hold up the horrors "to a benevolent and sympathetic people, but to tell in plainest language what famine is in India." As Chairman of one of the relief committees, Mr. Scott had the fullest opportunity of studying the sad subject.

Thee men dressed in overalls and greasy coats walked into the areaway of a privae dwelling in Eighty-fourth Street, betwen Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, yesterday afternoon. One was puffing a cigar and strode with all the hater of a boss plumber. The other two carrid kits, in which tools jingled as they walkd.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 15. -- Mrs. Julia Vatrial, forty-five years old, a widow employed on the farm of Henry Hillman, in Garfield, Bergen County, was shot and instantly killed this evening by Stephen Birkner of 110 Third Street, this city, who was also employed on the farm.

Our idea of a recurrence of interest in the ghost story, which was editorially expressed some weeks ago, has been amply justified by the large number of communications on this subject from readers of THE BOOK REVIEW which our remarks have called forth. We print this week an uncommonly interesting and suggestive selection of letters on famous tales of this description.

YOUR BOOK REVIEW of April 9 contains a letter from "Librarian," Knoxville, Tenn., giving a list of ghost stories that he is familiar with, and also asking for more. "Librarian" does not give his list of stories in the order of their merit; he is also wrong about the title of Bulwer Lytton's story.

PENSACOLA, April 15. -- The twelve-inch gun crew of the battleship Texas now holds the world's record for fast and accurate work, snatching the laurels from the battleships Wisconsin and Alabama, between which ships there was a dispute as to the championship.

The new edition of Sarat Chandra Das's "Journey to Lhassa and Central Tibet," which E.P. Dutton Co. are publishing, is made from entirely new plates, and contains new pictures. It is edited by W.W. Rockhill, author of several works on Oriental subjects, who, during 1888-92 made two journeys of exploration in China, Mongolia, and Tibet; was Charge d'Affaires in Korea in 1886-7, and was with the United States Legations in Peking.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The Cabinet to-day discussed a communication received by the State Department from Count Casini, the Russian Ambassador, which apparently means that the Russians intend, if they capture any press correspondent using wireless telegraphy either near land or on the high sea, to treat him as a spy and hang him.

While conversing with a friend some evenings ago, a chance remark that there was a great amount of fraud perpetrated nowadays, which in the eyes of the perpetrators was quite justifiable, called forth the following remarkable statement from my friend: "Why, in my business competition makes it impossible for a single firm to exist if it did not adulterate its goods."

The suits brought by Gardiner Hall, Jr., and others, holders of mortgage bonds of the White Mountain Paper Company, against the North American Trust Company to recover the amounts aggregating several hundred thousand dollars which the plaintiffs had invested, have been settled through the purchase by the defendant of the bondholdings on which the suit was brought. The price was not made public.

Susannah is the material of which the incorruptible British matron is made. In this story she is caught young. She is serious, honest, shy, misunderstood, patient, longing to be loved, eagerly responsive, but instinct with the conventional moralities, suspicious of evil after the fashion of good people. She has a sister who is quite otherwise and a mother addicted to gambling.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 15. -- Thomas Ray and Walter Edwards were arrested here yesterday at a house once the home of Chauncey M. Depew, on a charge of passing counterfeit fifty-cent pieces.

" George Frederick Watts, R.A.," is the subject of the latest volume in E.P. Dutton Co.'s Library of Art. It is by G.K. Chesterton, author of "Robert Browning,'' The little volume contains thirty-two illustrations in half-tone from Watts's paintings, including portraits of the artist, Carlyle, Lord Lytton, Browning, John Stuart Mill, and others, and reproductions of his "Love and Death," "Hope," "Eve Repentant," "The Habit Does not Make the Monk," and several others.

BY THIS time the death of Sir Edwin Arnold must have-been fully discussed by the American press. I wonder, however, if any mention has been made of his unique courtesy as an editor? He may not have been a great poet, and there certainly have been greater journalists, but he was beyond doubt the pearl of editors in the opinion of those who had business relations with him.

A NEW novel is announced by Thomas Dixon, Jr., author of "The One Woman" and "The Leopard's Spots." It is said to be, in a way, a companion to his first book, and is entitled "The Clansman." Mr. Dixon's purpose here is to show that the original formers of the Ku Klux Klan were modern knights errant, taking the only means at hand to right wrongs.

I read with sincere sorrow an announcement of the death April 6 of my dear friend Miss Frances Power Cobbe. I suppose her last contribution to literature was her "Introductory Notice" prefacing my little book, "Consecrated Womanhood."
ST. PETERSBURG, April 15. -- The naval staff has no information confirming the rumor that the Japanese have succeeded in blocking the entrance to the Harbor of Port Arthur.

Park Commissioner John J. Pallas began to feel the difficulties of his official position yesterday as arbiter of the claims set forth by the Daughters of the American Revolution and the Colonial Dames of America. A delegation of the Daughters, consisting of Mrs. Samuel J. Kramer, Mrs. William Cummings Story, and Mrs. N. Taylor Phillips, presented a formal petition to the Commissioner, asking for the custody of the Roger Morris or Jumel mansion.

Zolton Doeme, the Hungarian tenor, through his attorney, George G. Hastings, has begun proceedings in the Supreme Court to have the divorce decree which Mme. Nordica got from him last January set aside. One of the grounds is that it was obtained by fraud and collusion, and it is declared also that the court that granted it had no jurisdiction because neither plaintiff nor defendant was a resident of this State.

At the annual meeting of the City History Club in the Vaudeville Theatre yesterday afternoon Dr. T.B. Kelly told its members and guests that forty classes had been in session during the year; that there were nearly 2,000 members of these, and that the average age of the students was thirteen, but that they ranged from seven to seventy.

The extracts which we give, in advance of a regular review, from Herbert Spencer's autobiography will doubtless depress some readers, while some other readers will be elated by them. These latter, however, are either not readers of Spencer, or else they have reasons of their own for not wishing to think well of him and for wishing to have those reasons fortified.

Acting upon information furnished by Dr. J. McP. Scott, Secretary of the Board of Examiners of Maryland, from his headquarters at Hagerstown, the Medical Society of the County of New York late last night caused raids to be made on two of the three offices of "Dr." Charles Conrad, who has recently been an extensive advertiser in the newspapers.

MR. PARSONS calls his book on "Landscape Gardening" a series of "simple desultory talks," and his professed design is to induce "increased enthusiasm for lawnmaking among men of moderate means." The illustrations, which are attractive, are drawings of trees, flowers, shrubs, and vines, and reproductions of photographs taken in various parts of Central Park, besides some diagrams and a complement of ornamental headpieces.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 15. -- "There is nothing in it. I am opposing nobody and do not expect to take a very active part in political matters." This answer, said to have been given by E.H. Harriman when asked as to his reported opposition to President Roosevelt's nomination, has carried consternation into the camp of the Republicans of the Twentieth Congressional District, and incidentally those higher up are much exercised.

At the suggestion of several distinguished scholars, The Oxford University Press is printing a fac simile reproduction of the First Folio of Chaucer, edited by W. Thynne in 1532. It will be edited, with an introduction, by the Rev. Prof. Skeat, Litt. D., , and reproduced in the photographic department of the Oxford University Press from the copy in the British Museum Library.

Chairman A.R. Pardington of the Race Committee of the American Automobile Association stated yesterday that a meeting of the Racing Board would be called early next week to consider the Barney Oldfield case. Oldfield has made a formal request to the committee for reinstatement. He has been in the city for the last few days.

Mark Twain's "Extracts from Adam's Diary" (Harper's) is a revised and improved version of one of his earlier flights of humorous fancy. There are only 89 pages of large print in the little book, not counting the pages devoted by Mr. Strohmann's droll illustrations. Probably the first entry in this diary is as good in its way as anything else Mark Twain ever wrote:

Said Florence Nightingale, "A flood sick cook will save digestion half its work." It is perfectly true, too, that "invalid cookery should form the basis of every trained nurse's education." It is not only a necessity that a nurse should know how to serve food for the sick, but that she should also be thoroughly acquainted with the character of the nourishment she serves.

There is trouble between the Board of Trustees of the First Moravian Church, at New, Dorp, Staten Island, and Samuel J. Ostrander, who for forty years was Superintendent of the church cemetery, because he refuses to turn over to his successor the keys of the office and the combination of the safe, although he was deposed in March. He says that he was not properly deposed.

A NOVEL which has been quietly making its way among the readers of The Century Magazine during its serial publication will be presented in book form by the Century Company April 20. It is called "Four Roads to Paradise," these roads being trod by as many American types of character which are well worth following.

THOMAS SMITH, the subject of Mr. Burton Alva Konkle's biography, was a Pennsylvania member of the Continental Congress, and occupied, both as counselor and Judge, an important position in the history of our country. Thomas Smith was born in 1745 in Aberdeenshire, Scotland.

Observations made as traveling correspondent of The London Times in the Far East, as well as surveyor of a very large portion of China through which it was planned to build a railroad, have convinced the author that the great drama of the twentieth century will be that played for the mastery of the Pacific Ocean and the control of the markets which are found in the countries which are washed by its waves.

The refinement that came into the lives of the Tenderloin police with the advent of pillow shams in their dormitory was almost forgotten last night in the excitement of exploring a heretofore neglected field of knowledge. Discussion as to color effects in bed linen, which had excited laughter on the part of Jim, the doorman, was dropped, but he was not left without an object of discussion.

It would have been a very sad anticlimax if it had really appeared that the Russian flagship, gallantly steaming out Port Arthur to engage the enemy, had fouled one of the Russian mines laid for her protection. The catastrophe would have denoted a more than Chinese, a more than Spanish, incompetency to battle.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 15. -- Senator J.W. Bailey of Texas has resigned as Director of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association. He gave no reason for his action.

FATHER TABB, (John Banister Tabb,) priest, poet, and pedagogue, of St. Charles's College, Ellicott City, Md., writes to us in regard to the many replies he has received from all over the country to his request in the Queries Department of THE BOOK REVIEW for varied information concerning an ancient rhyme of the people:
Charles H. Bartlett opens his volume of "Twelve Tales of Kankakee Land" with a description of the place where the scenes of the stories are laid.

" The Darrow Enigma" is a detective story with some striking variations from the long-established formula of such stories. An elderly man, seated just at dark of a Spring evening, in room with four others, one of them his daughter, who is singing and accompanying herself on the piano, suddenly cries out that he has been murdered, and falls on the floor, dying few minutes later.

The letter from New Orleans in its clear-minded criticism of "Elizabeth and Her German Garden," was timely. "M.E." ask, "Do only selfish and ill-mannered persons find pleasure in reading 'Elizabeth'?" What gentle-mannered person can be in sympathy with Elizabeth's treatment of an invited guest? To indorse her actions seems a proof that they would do likewise in similar circumstances.

Whenever the writer of "Topics of the Times" sees fit he refers disparagingly, not to say contemptuously, to Prof. Oscar Lowell Triggs. Frequently he goes out of his way to drag in the name of one who is more sinned against than sinning. It is obvious that he is unacquainted with Prof. Triggs's real merits. Relying on whatever adulterated news comes to hand, he perpetuates every misrepresentation he can conveniently recall, regardless of their falseness.

PARIS, April 15. -- A leading article in to-day's Figaro by Baron Pierre de Coubertin discusses the possibility of an improvement in the relations of England and Russia, to be accomplished possibly through France as an intermediary.

WE hope to publish next week a review by Mr. Joseph O'Connor of "The Autobiography of Herbert Spencer," to be published April 25 by Messrs. D. Appleton Co. Meanwhile the following passages taken in advance from this remarkable work need no introduction. They well indicate the independence of Spencer's mind:

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 15. -- It was made known here to-day that Andrew Carnegie has created a fund of $5,000,000 for the benefit of "the dependents of those losing their lives in heroic effort to save their fellow men or for the heroes themselves if injured only." Provision is also made for medals to be given in commemoration of heroic acts.

The "Librarian" of Knoxville, Tenn., is only on the verge of a well-peopled country, since the majority are there. Our early magazines teem with reprinted ghost stories of the first quality out of Colburn's, Bentley's, Ainsworth's. The Metropolitan, Some of the choicest are collected. Wilkie Collins wrote "A Terribly Strange Bed."
I see you refer editorially to the loss of Admiral Makaroff and the Petropavlovsk as curiously like that of the Royal George and Kempenfelt more than a hundred years ago.
NO DOUBT one of the best ways to see Spain, or any other country, if you have the courage and the energy, is to do it as Mr. Kennedy did it -- on foot, with only a knapsack for your luggage.

LONDON, April 16. -- The Times's military correspondent says the importance of the Russian naval disaster cannot be overestimated. Its immediate result is that the Russian Pacific squadron has ceased to exist as an effective sea-going force.
It is one of the many pleasant National traits of Americans that they are as a rule not people who complain easily and grumble about trivial matters.

The twelve lectures on "Foundations of Modern Europe," delivered by Dr. Emil Reich, the well-known Hungarian author and lecturer on history, at the University of London during the Lent term of 1903, are now together in one volume. Dr. Reich says in his preface:
The advantages of foreign travel were demonstrated yesterday afternoon when Hink Siddons, ex-man-o'-war's man, saved the talent of the Helping Hand Benevolent and Athletic Association from disaster.

Sophia Yhlen-Olsen Bertelsen, M.A., has translated Prof. Otto Jespersen's "How to Teach a Foreign Language" into English, which the Macmillan Company publishes. In the course of the first chapter the author tells us why we learn foreign languages:

I waited anxiously for abler pens than mine to take up the cudgels in Elizabeth's defense, and I have not "waited in vain," and though it is true, as one says, that Elizabeth needs no defense. I still have a desire to hit back too, when the attack still continues.

Mr. Edward Peple has the trick of expression. He writes cleverly, with a certain poetic touch, which is yet not poetry. It is a style suited to his story, full and voluptuous, and the persons and things with which it deals are of the same type. Mostly it deals with the demi-monde of Paris during the reign of one of the Louis -it matters little which.

PARIS, April 15. -- The notorious Princess Radziwill, who was imprisoned some time ago in Cape Colony for forging the signature of the late Cecil Rhodes, has been living for some time in Paris under the name of Mme. Wyunewski, and has again got into trouble.

An entomological expert employed by nature to investigate the status and outlook of the boll weevil scourge in the cotton belt reaches disquieting conclusions. It is a Mexican insect, and did not cross the Rio Grande in numbers sufficient to be of concern to the cotton grower until it had practically destroyed the cotton industry of that country.

" The Essential Kafir," which the Macmillan Company publishes in this country, is described by the author, Dudley Kidd, in his preface. He does not, he writes, look at the Kafir from the point of view of history, sport, travel, social problems, economic questions, , but "everything that is of broad human interest takes precedence of departmental aspects of the subject."
BERLIN, April 15. -- Prices on the Boerse to-day were weak. Americans were lower.

Yesterday's business upon the Stock Exchange was characterized by a smaller volume and by decreased interest, with no discoverable tendency of prices in general. The leading speculative or investment properties moved only by fractions, and that irregularly, but there were several considerable alterations among specialties for reasons affecting them individually.

BERLIN, April 15. -- In the Reichstag today, Count von Kanitz, the Agrarian leader, referring to the report of Foreign Secretary von Richthofen on the progress of the commercial treaty negotiations, asked how matters stood with the United States.

A large package containing 135 copies of a farce entitled "Mr. H., or Beware a Bad Name," published by M. Carey in 1813, was lately disovered by an itinerant book hunter in the cellar of an Italian junk dealer in this city, who sold the entire lot for $2. The copies were all in good, sound condition, being the original sheets, simply folded and stitched, but the edges were untrimmed.

The overcrowding of trains on the Manhattan Elevated Railway continues to be a cause of complaint among those who find themselves under the necessity of traveling during the rush hours. Let us, however, be patient, in view of the fact that in a given time the elevated railroad system of Manhattan carries more passengers than all the long-distance railroads of the United States combined.

The names of men prominent in New York financial circles as Directors of the reincorporated Corporation Trust Company of New Jersey, have attracted much attention in Wall Street since the company, by taking out a new charter with $100,000 capital, announced its intention to comply with the recently passed amendments to the New York banking law.
For whatever time the court may decide that the ruffian EASTMAN shall be confined, the mere fact of his falling into the clutches of the law will be gratifying to all decent men.

The racing season of New York State, and thus of the Eastern turf, was opened at the Aqueduct race course yesterday afternoon in the presence of a crowd that astonished the track managers even more than it did the patrons of racing who come under the head of "regulars" and professionals.

Judge Alton B. Parker spent several hours in this city yesterday in consultation with William F. Sheehan and others, discussing principally the draft of the platform which has been prepared by ex-Senator David B. Hill for adoption at next Monday's Democratic State Convention.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Eugene G. Hay, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Edward S. Walsh of New York against the assessment of 20 per cent. as a non-enumerated manufactured article, on Chinese wax. The importers claimed free entry for it as a vegetable wax.

MR. HENNRY GREENLEAF PEARSON'S "Life of John A. Andrew," just published by Messrs. Houghton, Miffiin Co., contains little that is to be found in the biographies of Andrew's friends and contemporaries.

The White Star liner Cedric, in yesterday from Liverpool, brought a large number of passengers, and also an interesting story of a game of bridge whist, in which four passengers are said to have exchanged a large amount of money.

With hundreds of wild and tamed animals, birds, and snakes on board -- the biggest cargo of the kind ever transported across the Atlantic -- the Hamburg-American liner Bethania reached her pier in Hoboken yesterday morning.

The old Adelphi Hall property at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-second Street, 75 by 75, has been sold by Lee Shubert to William E. Finn. The recent report of the sale of this parcel to the Municipal Realty Corporation was based upon a provisional contract, which has since been canceled.

In the study of" William H. Prescott," by Rolio Ogden, published by Houghton, Miffiin Co. a few days ago, is presented .much material from letters and note books which has not previously appeared. Mr. Ogden explains that one of his objects has been to humanize the popular conception of Prescott, which has come down to us through the austerities of the earlier formal, biography by George Ticknor.

You are entirely right in your editorial of April 14 on the "near side ordinance." THE TIMES is entitled to the gratitude and thanks of the community for its persistent effort and final success in getting the uncalled for and obnoxious ordinance repealed.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- The rapidly growing share of the United States in the commerce of Japan is illustrated by a statement just prepared by the Department of Commerce and Labor through its Bureau of Statistics.

" Famous Women Described by Great Writers" is the title of a new volume compiled by Esther Singleton, author of "A Guide to the Opera," "Japan," "London," , which Dodd, Mead Co. will bring out in the Fall as a companion volume to Miss Singleton's "Great Pictures," "Historic Buildings," and other volumes containing the impressions of great writers.

THE history of mediaeval Italy is primarily one of families and individuals. Through a mistaken idea of educational convenience many scholars have tried to relate its episodes, express its life, and define its culture in local civic histories.

In The Hibbert Journal, an English quarterly dealing chiefly with theology and philosophy, Mr. Andrew Lang writes of the late Frederic W.H. Myers's "Theory of the Subliminal Self." His article, which is argumentative, not to say contentious, is of purely literary interest only when it comes to Mr. Myers's idea of accounting for genius by applying his theory of a "subliminal self."

In her newest book Mrs. Atherton boldly settles the destinies of Europe and divides the world between William of Germany and a young American millionaire of her own imagining. Plainly Mrs. Atherton admires the Hohenzollern; she makes her millionaire say William's mission is to smash the other monarchs and monarchies, unite Europe into one empire, and thus clear the way for an inevitable Socialistic republic.

ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, off the Coast of Korea, April 15. -- The following interesting story, while giving evidence of the character of the Japanese seamen, also indicates the position of the Japanese advance in Korea:
Charlotte Perkins Gilman, author of "Women and Economics," "Concerning Children," and "The Home," writes in the preface to her new volume, "Human Work":
We think that the opposition was badly advised in its solid vote against the bill for the amendment and improvement of the law regulating the civil government of the Philippine Islands.

ALBANY, April 15. -- The session of the Legislature of 1904 ended to-day. The feature of the closing hour was the successful filibuster in the Senate against the Goddard society policy bill. This bill provides that half of the fines imposed against violators of the anti-policy law should go to the society.

THIS handsome volume raises high the expectation of the musical amateur historically inclined. The history of music in America has long been waiting for a thorough and perspicacious historian. There have been made some excellent studies of portions of it: but much has remained to be done.

WASHINGTON, April 15. -- Filippo Costagini has died before he finished the famous fresco frieze in the rotunda of the Capitol. For twenty-five years it had been his ambition to spend a lifetime painting the great historical facts of American history into the frieze, and he came very near succeeding.
IF YOU are out of an evening, doing the town with those who know how to do it, as it gets near to dinner time you may hear one of the party say to another:
THE chief Sabbath attraction in an uptown church recently was a pyramid cactus. It held the most conspicuous place on the altar, and scores of strangers visited the church to see it.

If you will spare me a little space I should like to call the attention of your readers to the work of the Society for the Protection of Italian Immigrants, which is not so well known to the general public as, in my opinion, it deserves to be.

From the point of view of the depositor in that or any other bank, it would appear a little unnecessary that the assets of an institution nominally under the supervision of the State Banking Department should be reduced to the point reached by those of the Federal Bank last Thursday morning, before its function of accepting people's money over its counter was stopped officially.
IT IS said that when publicity is given to anything, the thing becomes popular and ceases to be unique. It is said, also, that when a mosquito dies, it gives birth to a thousand little mosquitos.

National Guardsmen in Brooklyn were much interested yesterday afternoon in an announcement to the effect that Gen. Alfred C. Barnes, Colonel in command of the borough's crack regiment, the Twenty-third, was to retire from the Guard about the first of May. It was stated that he had expressed his intention of retiring from the command of the regiment at a dinner party on Wednesday night.
LIAO YANG, April 2. -- (Delayed) The outside world does not know how near Russian and Chinese troops were to a clash on the border of Manchuria.

Capt. Cottrell of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station believes that he has found the owner of the gems, worth about $3,000, that were mailed to him on Friday, in Mrs. Sarah S. Kimball of 303 West One Hundred and Fourth Street. Mrs. Kimball is a dealer in rings at 1 and 3 Union Square. She has described the articles in detail, and the description corresponds with the gems that were mailed to Capt. Cottrell.
SOUTHERN negroes still believe in "conjure doctors," especially in the rural districts. The "Jack," the "conjure bag," the "conjure bottle," and the "conjure box" work many wonders.

Although the New York police have had nothing to do with the mystery surrounding the body of the unidentified woman found at Hempstead, L.I., by a letter received yesterday they are working on one phase of the case. The Hempstead police are undecided as to the cause of the woman's death.

I HAVE as much faith in my infallibility as a compounding chemist as most men in the business," said a Columbus Avenue druggist, "but you couldn't hire me to take a dose of my own medicine about which there had been a complaint. Most druggists do, I know. They consider it the ethics of the trade to prove by example that what won't kill them can't kill anybody else.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 16. -- Mayor Edward Everett Bruen of East Orange announced to-day that he would serve as President of the Globe Security Company if that concern is allowed to continued in operation. The Mayor says that the position was offered to him two weeks ago, when he says, William Muirhead, the President, announced that something was "going to drop."

ALBANY, April 16. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed, Senator White's bill allowing the erection in cities of the first class of nonfire-proof tenement houses of seven stories in height when the ceiling of the first story or basement extends no more than six inches above the highest point of the curb level in any street having a grade of more than four feet in one hundred.

It is stated that with the opening of Spring the Illinois Central will resume work with several hundred men along the line of the road for a distance of fifty miles east and west of Iowa Falls, Iowa, and continue the heavy work, interrupted last Autumn by cold weather, of reducing grades. Between Fort Dodge and Waterloo the company is spending hundreds of thousands of dollars.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Representative Patterson Tennessee to-day delivered in the House a remarkable speech arraigning President Roosevelt -- not he explained, Roosevelt the President, but Roosevelt the candidate. Its novelty consisted in the fact that Mr. Patterson painted a picture of Mr. Roosevelt from the latter's own historical writings.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Father Mackin of St. Paul's Catholic Church, this city, relates an amusing incident that came to his notice while walking recently near his parsonage. Father Mackin in his walk chanced to meet three lads, two of whom were altar boys at St. Paul's and who were dragging the third toward the priest, "Father," said one of the altar boys, "this kid wants to be an altar boy like us."

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., April 16. -- Ocean Grove's official programme for the Summer of 1904 has just been completed. A feature of the new programme is the prominence given musical events. These include "Walk and Talk" concerts, the cantata, "The Rose Maiden," and the oratorios "Stabat Mater," "Fall of Babylon," "Elijah," "The Holy City," "The Creation," and "The Messiah."

A CITIZEN of Bogota once told an American visitor that the civil code of the United States of Colombia was in every way the equal of the historic "Code Napoleon." Be this as it may, Colombian law in practice infrequently varies considerably from Colombian law in theory.

The Greater New York team was again beaten yesterday by the champions from Boston, the score being 12 to 6. Much of this result was brought about by the terrific batting of the Bostons for four innings, during which they amassed ten of their total of fourteen hits off Hughes, who was totally unable to place the ball where the visitors could not land on it.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Rear Admiral Taylor, Chief of the Bureau of Naviga-Chief Naval Constructor Capps, who recently was ordered to Pensacola to inspect and report upon the condition of the battleship Misouri as affected by her recent collision with the Illinois, and also by the more recent disastrous powder explosion in her aft gun turret.
STERLING, Ill., April 16. -- A feud of six months' standing has broken out afresh in Harmon, and to-night prominent citizens are carrying firearms, as they are in peril of their lives.

ROME, April 16. -- The Vatican this morning presented a spectacle unprecedented for centuries, when Pope Plus, the Cardinals, other dignitaries of the Church, the members of the Papal Court, the "Black" aristocracy, and three hundred other guests, including the Pope's sisters, assisted at the performance in the Sala Regla of the Abbe Perosi's new oratorio, "The Last Judgment."

Policemen Daniel J. Mulcahy and James Leslie Hunter of the West Thirtieth Street Station went off duty at midnight on Friday night and walked over, in full uniform, to Otto Diefenbacher's saloon, 228 West Twenty-seventh Street. Mulcahy had plenty of money and he bought several drinks for himself, the other policeman, and the saloon keeper, with whom he was on terms of intimate friendship. Mulcahy is regarded as very handsome.
ALBANY, April 16.--The advance guard of the State Democracy, which is to meet here in convention Monday to elect delegates to the National Convention, came in to-night.

Despite conditions which in a general way seemed to require a considerable outflow of gold from this city to Europe, the shipments of the precious metal to Paris during the past week amounted to only $1,500,000. Sterling exchange was firm, but at no time during the week sold above the previous high point of 4,8445.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 16. -- To the splendid bravery of Seamen McDade and Welles is due the fact that the battleship Missouri was not blown to destruction during the fire which raged in the turret and handling room and cost thirty-one lives. These two men are now in the hospital, and will receive recognition for valiant service from the Navy Department.

Because of its policy of using surplus earnings for improvements to the exclusion of dividends on the common stock, the management of the International Paper Company is incurring the displeasure of some of the common stockholders and informal protests have been made against the continuance of the policy.

From the point of view of the people of New York City the Rapid Transit Commission's two bills were the most important measures enacted during the session of the Legislature which adjourned on Friday. Under the provisions of one of these bills an expenditure for the extension of the subway system is permitted in excess of the present limit of $50,000,000.

The Fifth Avenue real estate holdings of the late George Kemp, valued at several millions of dollars, are to be sold at auction on May 17. The sale, to be conducted by Auctioneer Herbert A. Sherman, will be held in pursuance of a Supreme Court partition decree, under the direction of Peter B. Olney, as referee.

Application was made yesterday morning to Magistrate Whitman in Jefferson Market Court by J. Campbell Thompson, a lawyer, of 63 Wall Street, for a warrant for the arrest of Cecil Campbell Higgins, also a lawyer of the same address, for alleged grand larceny. It was alleged that Higgins had hypothecated fourteen thousand-dollar bonds of the Tintern Manor Water Company of Long Branch, N.J.

PITTSBURG, April 16. -- As she was walking along Airbrake Avenue in Wilmerding this evening Mrs. Laura Rebrach, aged thirty-two years, of Pitcairn, was shot and killed by Mrs. Hugh Beninger, with whose husband Mrs. Rebrach was strolling.
WASHINGTON, April 16.--The Japanese Legation to-night received a cablegram dated Tokio, April 16. It said:

PERHAPS the wildest horses in North America are the "broomtails," as the nondescript little ponies ranging the four corners of Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, and Utah are called. This section is known as the Yellowjacket Breaks and consists for the most part of a high, rolling mesa, intersected by a network of deep box canyons.

The pleasing announcement made by Mr. CARNEGIE of his purpose to establish an endowment of $5,000,000 as a fund the income of which shall be used to relieve of immediate pecuniary suffering those who perform acts of memorable heroism, will still further attach the people of the United States to this remarkable man and establish between them and him a new and even more kindly relation than already exists.

The problem proposed to observers of the market by the events of 1902 was why prices constantly drooped, despite many excellent conditions. The problem of the moment is why prices do not decline despite much disturbing intelligence. The answers -- when that for 1904 is certainly known -- will probably contrast as strongly as the problem.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 16. -- Lakewood continues to gather in by the score visitors from upper New York, New England, and Canada, and hotel accommodations are well booked ahead for the next two weeks. During the few short days in early May Lakewood takes on the garb of Summer, and so rapidly is the change made that it is a revelation to New Englanders.

The Colorado Sheriff who stood for twenty minutes facing a mob of 500 would-be lynchers after he had announced with profane emphasis that he would shoot the first man to advance, and that the mob could not get into the jail save over his dead body, shows at once what true heroism is and how exceedingly effective it is when backed by authority and exhibited to a mob.

While no formal action has been taken on the matter the Directors of the Allis-Chalmers Company have allowed the usual time for the declaration of the quarterly dividend on the preferred stock to go by without declaring it, and the inference is drawn that it is the intention of the Directors to suspend the dividend for some time to come.

After devoting nearly three hours yesterday to hearing arguments for and against the Remsen East River Gas bill, Mayor McClellan called for briefs from all who cared to file them with him to-morrow. No action will be taken by the Mayor until the middle or latter part of the week, and in the meantime he will go over all of the points on which the friends and foes of the measure disagree.

ANGLERS who hail Pennsylvania's brooks as their Mecca are ready for casting line in the trout pools along the Big and Little Bushkill, Saw, Paradise, and Marshall's Creeks, and the Tobyhanna and Tunkhannock Rivers. Rods, reels, and lines are being overhauled and tested. The streams are full to the banks, but the snows have melted, and the surplus volume of water has almost disappeared.
