The most elaborate dinner among chess players ever given in this city, and the most pretentious banquet of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, was the fourth annual dinner of the club last evening at the Hotel Cumberland, Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street. Emanuel Lasker, the champion of the world, was a guest of honor; and champions from all over Europe and America dined as guests of the club.

The bearing of the arbitration agreement of the Building Trades Employers' Association on the trade agreements of the subordinate associations of the employers and the unions of skilled trades has created the impression in some quarters that the arbitration agreement will have to be renewed on May 1.

BERLIN, April 16. -- Count Wolff-Metternich, Ambassador to England, and Herr von Mentzingen, German Minister to Morocco, are here. Although their presence has purposely not been made known by the German press, their visit is most important.

Michael Fitzgerald, the vaudeville performer who arrived here on Friday with his wife and his sister-in-law, who are the daughters of Mrs. Catherine Bater, took good care not to meet his mother-in-law yesterday when she arrived on the steamship Campania to try to get possession of the two young women.

There has been a good deal of correspondence in our columns of late as to the compensation of stenographers, the opportunities offered in stenography for a satisfactory career and the encouragement to a young man or young woman to devote to the acquisition of shorthand and typewriting the time required to gain at least average proficiency.

ENGLISH railways are beginning to introduce large motor cars as feeders for their lines in lieu of the more expensive branch lines or tramways. The autos are used where traffic is large enough to be worth while, but is not sufficient to warrant any heavy expenditure.

At the meeting of the Democratic County Committee of Westchester County, which was held here yesterday, the report of the Investigating Committee was made. This committee was appointed to inquire into the charges of political corruption made against State Committeeman Walsh and Chairman of the County Committee Fiske.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16. -- Guilty of murder in the first degree was the verdict given against Mrs. Catharine Danz to-day by the jury that had tried her for poisoning her husband.

Ex-Assistant District Attorney Henry Hardwicke, author of "How to Try a Case." entered Judge Cowing's court in General Sessions yesterday to defend client, looked about in apparent amazement, and announced that none of his witnesses was present. The court asked him if they had been properly summoned, and he said that they had, adding:

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Attorney General Knox has handed to the President his opinion regarding the validity of the Chinese exclusion law. While the opinion has not been made public, it is known that the Attorney General holds in effect that the denunciation of the treaty by China does not nullify the existing laws, and that the Exclusion act can be enforced as rigidly hereafter as under the treaty.

THE weddings that follow Easter are bringing out beautiful frocks, not only those of the brides, but their attendants, but also of the guests, many of whom are showing some of the newest and prettiest gowns. In a bride's gown little of originality is expected, but when it is in evidence it is always admired.

LONDON, April 6. -- Long theatrical runs seem much more common in London than in New York. "A Chinese Honeymoon" has just completed its one thousandth performance at the Strand Theatre. It is said to have yielded profits amounting to u60,000. One of the plays which is touring the provinces in England has been played some 3,100 times in one company.

They do things sumptuously at the Wanamaker store. The friends and patrons of that establishment were entertained last evening at a "Post-Easter invitation concert" at which Dr. Richard Strauss and Mme. Strauss de Ahna appeared, Dr. Strauss conducting the Weltzer orchestra of 100 musicians in his own compositions.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Secretary Moody's attention to-day was called to the fact that a serious accident had occurred on the Boston while she was engaged in target practice off Panama two months ago, resulting in the death of one enlisted man. It was stated that this is the first the Secretary had heard of the accident officially or unofficially.
WHEN Daniel Sully, the "Cotton King" of a few weeks, was walking down Fifth Avenue the other afternoon he was accosted by a business acquaintance with the remark:

IMAGINE trying to keep track of and pay homage to more than 3,000 gods, to offend one of whom might bring down the direst disaster on the offender's head! This is the task the brown little people of Japan have set before them, and a busy time they must have of it.

YET in the game market are European hares, Canadian hares -- white rabbits -- and our own "cotton tail." Each well cooked, is of superior table merit. The fasting season is over and the next table for fauna will not be due until the Fall, so that hints as to the kitchen treatment of these small deer may not come amiss.

NYACK, N.Y., April 16. -- The last Democratic County Convention in New York State to elect delegates to the State Convention was held by the Democrats of Rockland County, this afternoon at New City. It was thought by many that a strong Hearst sentiment would be manifested at the convention, but this did not prove to be the case.
PARIS, April 16. -- The Russian naval disaster displaces all other topics. The view is held in Government quarters that it will have the effect of postponing peace. A leading official said to-day:

BERLIN, April 16. -- Colonial circles have been greatly concerned about the Glasenapp column since the report of the battle at Okaharui, German Southwest Africa, which was received in Berlin March 9, as a large party, probably 2,000, of the Hereros defeated at the battle of Onganjira retreated in the direction where Glasenapp was last heard of.
LESS noise, boys! Jimmy, stop that talking; Say, Fred, if you're through, get out on your district. The strike's off, and all of you will be busy to-day. Go on -- out with you, now!"

THE season is over, Can one exclaim, "Long live the season!"? It was very short and, besides the weddings, contained only a few dates of belated dancing class meetings. To-morrow evening the last of all these will take place. It is the University Cotillion for the younger fashionable set, and will be held at Sherry's. It promises to be a very enjoyable dance.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16. -- Judge Cook, in the Superior Court, to-day ordered the final distribution of the estate of the late Charles L. Fair, who, with his wife was killed in an automobile accident in France. The estate is appraised at $3,040,000, and goes to the two sisters, Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt.

The Tefft-Weller Company has decided to dispose of its interest in the C.M. Allen Company of Philadelphia. Several offers have been made by capitalists of that city, and negotiations for the disposal of the business are now under way.

SO far this year there has been such a revolution in wedding customs that nothing now seems odd or strange. At some of the weddings no best men, at others no bachelor dinners, and at others again the bride was not given away. But there still is another innovation. The professional usher seems to have lost his grip.

Joseph J. Nagle, twenty-six years old, of Boston, Mass., was found dead in his room in the Herald Square Hotel, in West Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. Death was due, according to the hotel physician, Dr. J.T. Westermann of 6 East Thirty-second Street, to some sort of a fit, apoplectic, he thought.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 16. -- A report gained wide currency here to-day that the battleship Sebastopol and another vessel at Port Arthur had been lost. This report has been officially denied.

ALTHOUGH the cockchafer is an insect long known to science, it has remained for a sect of epicures in France to decide that the brand of bug shown in this picture is a fine thing to eat. When properly prepared, they say, it is a tidbit fit for a King. The fad, if such it may be called, has not spread to New York.

NOW, to reward you for coming to see me this rainy night," she said; "I'm going to make you something in my chafing dish. I got a new receipt book for Christmas, and I'm going right through it alphabetically. I've gotten as far as 'D' already."

The reincorporation of the Corporation Trust Company of New Jersey, as a "moneyed" institution, with $100,000 capital and a Board of Directors who cannot by any manner of means come under the historic accusation of being "dummies," promises to open an interesting question or two hinging in the corporation and banking system of the State of New York.

PARS, April 16. -- Varnishing day at the Salon of the Fine Arts Society, which is one of the first great social functions of the year, has been even more brilliant than usual. Owing to the fine weather the display of toilettes was quite beautiful and all French and American smart society thronged the Grand Palais.

A philanthropist who is a student in the philosophy of clothes, perhaps because he happens to be a clothier, dropped in at the Newsboys' Home in New Chambers Street one day recently. His sartorial eye noted where the inhabitants lacked, and his philanthropic heart prompted him to supply the deficiency.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 29. -- The Count of Flanders, King Leopold's brother, has purchased the extensive forest in the neighborhood of his Chateau des Amerois. This forest is the finest boar hunting preserve in the kingdom, and will enable Belgium's future sovereign to indulge in his favorite sport to his heart's content.

BOSTON, April 16. -- A northeast snowstorm set in here before daylight to-day and continued well into the forenoon. The snow melted as it struck the city pavements, but the public squares and country districts were covered by a white mantle.

Committees representing the leading mercantile organizations of New York, the warehouse interests, and the Customs Service are now at work preparing a new schedule of charges for cartage, labor, and storage on what are known to customs officials and importers as "general order good."

THE understudies of the Presidential Cabinet -- the Assistant Secretaries of the Government departments and their equivalents, such as the Assistant Postmasters General and the Assistant Attorneys General -- have lately been claiming a good share of attention from the public, and with good reason.

As a result of the examination of the books of the Federal Bank, at 590 Broadway, the District Attorney's office yesterday afternoon asked Police Inspector McClusky to have his detectives look for the former President of the bank. David Rothschild. Up to a late hour last night Rothschild had not been found.

SOUL, Korea, April 15. -- The Emperor received in audience this evening the members of the Diplomatic Corps. The Emperor had apparently recovered from the shock caused by the burning of the palace and was calm, making inquiries as to the health of the ladles at the legations. His intimates report that he is still nervous, however.

AS FOR every other commodity, there must be a market for the child actor. The little ones with stage ambitions cannot walk up and down the Rialto in search of engagements. If they did, their nurses would have to go with them.

NO dream is dearer to the soul of microbic man, who, like skippers in an Edam cheese, infests the world and decays it with his tillage, than the dream of subverting the earth. "Give me wherewith to pry," said Archimedes when he invented the crowbar, "and I will overturn the world."

PARIS, April 17. -- According to a dispatch from the St. Petersburg correspondent of the Petit Parisien, an American engineer is on his way to Port Arthur to direct the reconstruction of the three submarine boats which were forwarded to Port Arthur in sections in March.

The coolness, as well as the bravery, of Miss Elliott, the head nurse in the female department of the Home for Incurables, at One Hundred and Eighty-third Street and Third Avenue, averted what might have been a serious panic in Ward M of that institution last night.

Yesterday's business upon the Stock Exchange reached only 100,000 shares, and of the properties contributing individually 1,000 none moved a point except the gas properties. Brooklyn Union advanced 5 and Consolidated Gas retained 1 3/4 of a larger advance. No other price changes were notable.

" If my Sunday school training counts for anything, this has Noah and the ark skinned to a hump, so to speak," said Big Sahib, the camel, as he stepped gingerly down the gangplank from the steamship Bethania to a Hoboken pier yesterday. Under the shed he surveyed his surroundings with that look of ineffable superiority in which the camel has no competitor.

IN view of the rivalry between Montreal and the Atlantic seaports of the United States -- Portland, Boston, New York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore -- the efforts of Canada to establish a fast Atlantic steamship service capable of competing with the lines o ocean greyhounds plying to New York and Boston, attract considerable attention from students of the problem of navigating successfully the North Atlantic.

TRENTON, N.J., April 16. -- The whole of the Valley of the Delaware River above Trenton has been put back a hundred years and more to the time of ferryboats, rafts, and long drives to fording places by the failure of the bridge companies to replace the dozen or so bridges which were washed away by the flood of last October between this city and the head of the stream.

A department store detective and a policeman chased an alleged woman thief for several blocks through crowds of astonished women in the Sixth Avenue shopping district yesterday afternoon, and finally arrested her after forcing the door in the women's waiting room of the down-town elevated station at Thirty-third Street.

IN the heart of the shopping district of New York there is a dressmaking establishment from which upward of 2,000 women's gowns are sent out every year, and where the cutters and fitters never see a fashion plate. The latest costly "creations" from London and Paris as displayed in the Broadway shop windows are unknown to them.

Important and far reaching are expected to be the results of the convention of the National Association of Clothiers, held last week in Philadelphia, and especially so, it is expected, will be the change in policy decided upon there in dealing with the organizations of labor.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The Post to-night received a telegram from Don M. Dickinson of Detroit saying that on receipt of a message from Chairman Campbell stating the fact of Judge Parker's position he sent a dispatch to Judge Parker. Mr. Dickinson's dispatch to Judge Parker is dated April 16 and is in part as follows:

Excepting the loss of Admiral MAKAROFF and his flagship, we do not yet accurately know what naval loss the Russians have sustained in these later engagements. But we do know that their inferiority at sea to their opponents is absolute and, within a reasonable space of time, irremediable.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 16. -- Mrs. Julius Catlin will arrive in Morristown and open her house, Fairholme, on the Whippany Road, in about a week. Mrs. Catlin, with her daughter, Miss Catlin, and Miss Summerville are expected to sail from Havre to-day. They have been abroad since early last Autumn.

IT is expected that by the middle of June cars will be running through the new East Boston tunnel under Boston Harbor, and another long step will have been taken in the solution of the rapid-transit problem in that city.

THREE weeks ago to-morrow Countess Marguerite Cassini, niece of the Russian Ambassador, decided to hold a fair or bazaar in aid of the Russian Red Cross Society -- not, as she very frankly says, to aid only the Russian soldiers, but to help all the wounded of the cruel war now disturbing her beloved country and far-away Japan.

GERMANY, it is said, has the most lightning-fingered telegraph apparatus in the world in operation between Berlin and Frankfort. The system, the invention of the late Josef Virag and Antol Pollak, requires a loop or double line of copper wire. Some of the statements of the rapidity attained by the new transmitter are quite incredible, but a conservative and not too definite claim is one hundred words in the time it takes to count ten.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 16. -- While there are not as many people at the shore as last week, the aftermath of the Easter season is such as to cause no complaint from the proprietors of the big beach-front hotels, and there is certainly no dearth in the whirl of social doings. This is especially true at the Hotel Rudolf, where a series of dances and card parties have enhanced the visit of sojourners.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., April 16. -- Tuxedo has put on her Spring appearance. During the week several of the cottagers arrived, and many are putting in readiness their cottages for occupancy early next month. To-day a large crowd came out to pass Sunday at the club. J. Henry Smith arrived to entertain a large party at Kincraig.

DEEPLY imbedded in the masculine breast are certain delusions concerning the woman shopper. The magic words "special sale" and "bargains" are an open sesame for time-honored jokes and anecdotes anent the woman who does what is termed window shopping and the bargain-struck female who neglects home, children, and kin while she haggles over last season's shirtwaist.

The question of playing baseball on Sunday, especially the proposed game to-day between the Boston and Brooklyn teams of the National League at Washington Park, Brooklyn, was brought before Police Commissioner McAdoo yesterday. The Commissioner said that he had been in consultation with William S. Hubbell, General Secretary of the New York Sabbath Committee, and Mr. Hubbell was strongly opposed to Sunday baseball.

LONDON, April 2. -- That the Liberals will win at the forthcoming general election is an article of faith equally accepted in both political camps. It has been greatly strengthened within the last few weeks by the action taken by the Government in the matter of Chinese labor in the Transvaal.

" Bulletin No. 5" of the Municipal Art Society emphasizes the lesson that has been taught by previous publications from the same quarter. The Mayor has appointed a number of respectable or eminent citizens, of whom none has given any public evidence of any intelligent interest in the project of replanning the city, to make suggestions for the replanning.

ALLEGAN, Mich., April 16. -- Thomas F. McGarry, a prominent attorney, who was convicted of bribing ex-City Attorney Lant K. Salsbury, and turning over to him the boodle fund in the Lake Michigan water deal, was to-day sentenced to four years in the State Reformatory at Ionia.

WE have already seen how, after holding its property for a century as a "church farm" and receiving from it only the income of agricultural land, Trinity Church, a hundred years ago, by a stroke of far-sighted, enterprise not only brought its land into the market, but made it the social centre of Manhattan, to the enormous profit of the corporation.

LONDON, April 16. -- The settlement this week disclosed an important change for the better in the stock market. There was a much larger volume of transactions arranged for than at any previous settlement, and as a rule prices were on a much higher level. The buoyancy continued throughout the week, a large amount of business was transacted, and the public showed an interest in the market that was very gratifying to the brokers.

Charles K. Oliver, President of the United States Cotton Duck Corporation of Baltimore, spent several days in the city last week looking after the corporation's business. Mr. Oliver says that the new legislation in Delaware in the interest of labor, making it necessary for employers to pay monthly before the 10th of the month, has greatly disarranged things.

ALBANY, April 16. -- A snowstorm, which in many places was the heaviest of the Winter, swept over upper New York last night. It began here at midnight, and this morning the ground is covered with four inches of snow. All trains are seriously delayed.

The financing of the rice crop of Louisiana and Texas has developed into a serious question, and although the rice man who are at the head of the present movement to create a rice trust in the Gulf Coast country are working hard for its success there are still several questions to be settled before the project can be put on a firm footing.

Genuine enthusiasm for the sport was exacted of racegoers at the Aqueduct track yesterday, and none but the genuine stood the test of the wintry breeze that swept the course throughout the afternoon, for the day was one that made visitors doubt the accuracy of the caldendar and wonder just how much longer they must wait for the advent of Spring.
Poor memory means an ill-nourished brain. The proper food to help and nourish the brain will thus held the memory as in the following case:

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- The State Department has been giving careful consideration to the notification of Ambassador Cassini that Russia proposes to treat as spies newspaper correspondents engaged on the high seas in collecting news of the war in the East and its transmission by wireless telegraphy, and to the protest of the De Forest Company, which is the only company engaged in the use of wireless telegraphy at the scene of active operations.

BERLIN, April 16. -- The debate in the Reichstag regarding the question of the readmission into Germany of the Jesuits has resulted in the adoption, in opposition to the Centre Party, the Poles, and the Alsatians, of a resolution designed to supply the omission from the Constitution of a limit to the period in which the Federal Council can ratify the Reichstag's action.

WASHINGTON, April 16. -- Georgetown found no trouble to-day in defeating Harvard. Clarkson was wild giving seven bases on balls and being charged with six wild pitches. Crumley held the visitors down to five hits and fielded his position in excellent style. Score by innings:

WHAT the North Pole is to the intrepid explorer seeking for fame Camille is to the actress. It is the undiscovered country, always alluring, always fascinating. No other role -- unless it be possibly that of Juliet -- holds such potent attractiveness for the ambitious woman player.

THIS is a picture of "Old Sarge," one of the most famous mascots in the United States Army. He is a mongrel Filipino-American, and is now on his way to this country with the Twenty-ninth Regiment of Infantry.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16. -- Princeton's annual handicap games were held this afternoon under unfavorable weather conditions, the day being raw, with a stiff wind. Despite this some good time was made. Taylor, Pennsylvania, won the quarter-mile in 0:51 3-5, and Tenney, Princeton, won the 120-yard hurdle in 0:18 4-5.

AMONG the veterans in the diving and wrecking headquarters scattered along West and South Streets few casualties caused such a sensation as the frightful death of William Hoar, who became hopelessly pinned in the suction of a four-foot outlet pipe, sixty-five feet under the surface of the new reservoir at Boonton, N.J., and whose almost titanic strength gave way only after twenty-two hours of what must have been excruciating mental and physical agony.

" The Relation of the Tariff Question to the Coming Campaign" was the subject chosen for discussion by the speakers at the dinner of the Reform Club, held last evening at the Hotel Manhattan, Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue. The circular announcing the dinner had stated very definitely that principles and not the question of candidates would be considered.

LONDON, April 16. -- There is no alarm in the office of The London Times on account of the Russian pronunciamento against wireless telegraphy in connection with the Far Eastern war service of The London Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES. At present there seems to be small likelihood that The Times's steamer can be overhauled by any Russian warship.

NO bride has ventured thus far to depart from the traditional white in her bridal bouquet. The modest lily of the valley is more carried than any other flower, and this without regard to the bride's preferences. Now and then, however, a girl has the originality to carry her favorite flower, no matter what the fashion of the moment may be.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 16. -- The papers here, which since the Anglo-French agreement had been distracted first by the holidays and then by the stirring events of the last few days, are now discussing it significantly and in a friendly fashion, finding therein promise of better relations with Great Britain and a new and heavy blow to German prestige, the plan for German hegemony having been already upset by the Russo-Austrian and Franco-Italian agreements.

The third annual dinner and reunion of the Chicago newspaper men who are now engaged on the New York newspapers or in connection with The Associated Press or other news associations was held last evening at the Republican Club. The occasion, like the two previous dinners, was given over to the renewal of old acquaintances and the discussion of old times in the Windy City.

TWO transactions--the trade between Henry Corn and the O.B. Potter Trust and the purchase of nearly an entire block by the New York Life Insurance Company--gave to last week's business distinguishing features, which were perhaps of more impressive owing to the rarity of such deals in the great mass of recent small trading.

Another defeat was scored against the Brooklyn team yesterday at Washington Park, the nine from the Polo Grounds making it three straight. The game was essentially a pitcher's contest, only six singles, including one hit for two bases, being the extent of the batting record. It was a disappointing setback for Hanlon's men and for the manager himself, all of whom were anxious to win and believed they would succeed.
I'VE opened this little atelier," said a pretty Japanese student "just to sell Japanese dictionaries and teach the language.''

From the Globe and Commercial Advertiser. The Russian Government has given notice that newspaper correspondents using wireless telegraphy will be treated as spies and shot. It is another indication of the almost hysterical sensitiveness which has existed at St. Petersburg since the war began.

IT is not my purpose to enter upon an essay on Ibsen, or, worse still, a defense. It is rather to suggest to some of the people who ought to know better that before they go further in treating Ibsen either as subject of joke or a cult of the long-haired they should, according to their lights and disposition to be fair, make some investigation of the object of their criticism.

The police who guide visitors in the Bronx Park are thinking of avoiding some of their troubles by making every visitor submit to a preliminary examination in forest lore and the woodsman's arts before admitting him to the park. This applies especially to adult visitors.

It was not very difficult for Senator LODGE to stem the current of opinion in the Massachusetts Republican Convention in favor of reciprocity. The very considerable number of Massachusetts business men who have been Republicans in the past and who are disgusted with the extreme and narrow tariff policy of the party are not likely to be represented in the conventions of the party.

A curious misapprehension seems to prevail as to the exact status of the women of this country. Are they citizens of the United States, or are they not? Recently a man prominent in public affairs announced in a speech that "women are not citizens, and therefore do not count." This false impression as to their citizenship seems to prevail even among persons who should know better.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The boss emeritus of the New York Republican Party, the one pathetic figure of last Tuesday's State Convention, is spending in Washington the days of his isolation, as some of the dethroned Roman Emperors spent their declining days in dignified idleness on estates or in humble labor far from the scene of their glories.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The gossip that Gen. Grosvenor's campaign biography of President Roosevelt, recently published in The Congressional Record, emanated from the President himself, has been common about the corridors of the Capitol ever since the article appeared. Representative Patterson, in the House yesterday, however, was the first to give voice to the general belief when he said it was suspected to be not a biography, but an autobiography.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Count Cassini, the Russian Ambassador, has taken a box for the society play which will be given to-morrow afternoon for the benefit of the families of the victims of the Missouri disaster.

During the last few weeks, since the immigration figures have reached the great height at which they now are, immigration officials and Secret Service agents have been hard at work looking for violations of the contract labor laws, and their investigations have taken them over many parts of the country.

Bishop Potter officiated at the services yesterday in the Church of the Holy Communion, ordained two new priests, and accepted forty-one youthful candidates for confirmation. He was assisted by the Archdeacon of the diocese, Dr. Nelson; the Rev. Dr. Mottet, rector of the church, and eight other priests.

A large Broadway Tabernacle congregation which assembled last night in Mendelssohn Hall, at 119 West Fortieth Street, heard the Rev. William R. Huntington, rector of Grace Church, speak strongly on the growth of crime.

The stock market last week was reactionary, as is generally known, but a retrospect of the week's business in the bond market discloses an unsuspected improvement. Only 65 stocks moved a point or more, showing an artificial concentration of business, but there were 44 advances among the 65.

"He's been in the vinegar vat," remarked Policeman Berkweld last night as he hung his limp prisoner over the rail in the East Fifth Street Station, and from that remark the Desk Sergeant inferred that the captive was "pickled" beyond that stage where an intelligible record of name, address, and nativity could be obtained for the record.

-----Even more notable than the declaration in favor of the "open shop" principle, adopted at the recent meeting in Philadelphia by the National Clothiers' Association, was a speech delivered at the banquet of the delegates by Judge MAYER SULZBERGER of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas.

PARIS, April 17. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch says the military General Staff discredits the story that the Russians attacked 12,000 Japanese at the moment of their landing at Yon-gam-pho and drove them back to their ships.

The announced purpose of "the Lieutenant of his Imperial Majesty in the Far East" to seize as prizes of war steamers furnished with wireless telegraph apparatus and to treat newspaper correspondents on board them as spies does not stand examination at all in the light of reason and of international law and practice.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 17. -- Mayor McLane is becoming weary of the objectors who have been delaying improvements and the work of rebuilding the vast burned business district of Baltimore. He urges that wealthy fathers give their sons a chance in the work of rehabilitation.

Nearly 100,000 persons witnessed seven baseball games in which teams of the National and American Leagues took part yesterday. The largest attendance was at the contest between the champion Pittsburgs and the St. Louis team of the National League at St. Louis, 23,250, while 17,000 saw the Clevelands play at Chicago, and nearly the same number attended the Cincinnati Chicago game at Cincinnati.

The jewelry, valued at several thousand dollars, which was lost by Mrs. Nellie Grant Sartoris, daughter of the late Gen. Grant, on Saturday afternoon, was returned to her yesterday morning at the Holland House, all except one or two small pieces of minor importance. The man who returned the gems explained that he had found them on West Twenty-third Street at about the time when Mrs. Sartoris was shopping there.
LONDON, April 18. -- The Times, in discussing editorially the Russian ban on the use of wireless telegraphy by war correspondents, says:

Speaking on the subject "One Law for All the People," the Rev. Newman Smyth of New Haven, Conn., took exception last night, before a meeting of the People's institute at Cooper Union, to the executive order by which veterans of the civil war over sixty-two years of age are given pensions.

David Rothschild, ex-President of the insolvent Federal Bank, who is accused of having converted about $200,000 of the funds of the institution to his own use by means of "dummy loans," thus in a great measure causing the failure, was arrested last night near Forty-second Street and Broadway by Detectives McConville and Clark.

The counter attraction at Washington Park lessened the attendance somewhat at the game between the Greater New York team of the American League and the Brooklyn Field Club at Ridgewood Park yesterday, yet the official figures showed that there were 6,000 persons present.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17. -- For eight innings to-day the New York National League team and the Newark nine played an even game in the presence of 10,000 enthusiastic "rooters." When the New Yorks went to the bat in the ninth inning the score stood one run each. Few hits had been made owing to effective pitching, and the fielding as a rule was excellent.

I read with considerable interest in your issue of the 12th inst. the remarks which Judge Mahlon Pitney of Hackensack, N.J., addressed to two talesmen who had been called to serve as jurors in a murder case. It appears that when they were questioned if they had any scruples touching the infliction of capital punishment, they both replied in the affirmative, and were, of course, rejected by the prosecution on that account.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 17. -- Mayor S.M. Jones, at a meeting of his employes in the Golden Rule Trust yesterday, said:

The story of the little bank in the heart of the mercantile district, with a branch on the east side, which is disclosed by the action of the State Banking Department, is a curious revelation as to the credulity of human nature.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- There is a young man in Sycamore, Ill., thirty-two years old, who does want to marry, has no fiancee in view, yet has agreed to take a wife within two years. He is E.M. Burst, nominee for State's Attorney on the Republican ticket, good looking, tall, affable, with a pair of dreamy brown eyes, an aquiline nose, and a smile that is "fetching."

Two men are in Bellevue Hospital suffering from wounds from which they are not expected to recover, and two men are locked up in the East Twenty-second Street Station charged with assault, the result of a fight which occurred last evening in the livery stable of Matthew Smith at 245 East Twentieth Street.

There was a panic on a Second Avenue elevated car last night that might have been attended with loss of life had it not been for the coolness and strength of one of the passengers. As a five-car train, leaving the First Street station, turned into Allen Street, a fuse blew out under the second car. The flash set fire to paper and waste on the track, and the blaze was soon a block long.

The absence of street signs in cities like New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, Baltimore, and the larger cities is inexcusable, for these cities have sufficient funds at their command to mark their streets and keep a system of marking in thorough repair. But they, with the smaller cities, are negligent in this regard.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 17. -- When the football Rules Committee meets next week to act on possible changes in the rules for next season it will receive suggestions from F.H. Yost, who has coached the University of Michigan with such remarkable success. Mr. Yost said to-day that his suggestions for changes in the rules were as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Representative Rice Pierce of Tennessee, the second ranking minority member of the House Committee on Appropriations, says the aggregate regular appropriations of the first session of the Fifty-eighth Congress, now about to close, will be in the neighborhood of $700,000,000.

The annual report of the State Health Commissioner of New York to the Governor makes the startling but not surprising statement that a great many cities and towns are menaced by epidemics of typhoid fever such as have prevailed within the past year or two at Ithaca, West Seneca. Watertown, and other places.

ST. LOUIS, April 17. -- Circuit Attorney Joseph W. Folk, running for Governor of Missouri on an anti-boodle ticket, carried six moro counties in primaries and conventions yesterday. Thereby he so strengthened his candidacy that his nomination as the Democratic candidate next July seems assured.

The Central Federated Union, at its meeting yesterday, rejected by one vote a resolution passed by the miscellaneous section last week, urging the formation of an anti-high rent union, and requesting the wage workers to refuse to pay any rents to landlords unless a demand for a 25 per cent. reduction was complied with.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 17. -- The body of the unknown young woman which was found a week ago near Fleetwood. L.I., will be buried to-morrow in Greenfield Cemetery. The burial expenses will be defrayed from the hundred-dollar bill sent anonymously for that purpose.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17. -- Forced to his best efforts, in spite of the aid of team work in overcoming opposition Frank Kramer, the East Orange, N.J., bicycle rider, fell just behind record time in his winning race for the half-mile handicap for professionals at the Vailsburg bicycle track, here to-day.

ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, April 17. -- I now send further details of Admiral Togo's eighth attack on Port Arthur, which I reported briefly from the actual scene of the fighting last Wednesday.

BOSTON, April 17. -- The present week marks the two hundredth anniversary of The American Press, and the bi-centennial will he commented upon generally by to-morrow's papers, the first American newspaper having been published in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The total distance from St. Petersburg to Port Arthur by the Russian Trans-Siberian Railway and the Russian lines in Manchuria is 5,913 miles, or practically twice the distance from New York to San Francisco. This is one of the numerous interesting facts about Russia and her railway and commercial systems presented in a monograph just issued by the Bureau of Statistics, entitled "Commercial Russia in 1904."

Mr. PATTERSON of Tennessee made a witty and brilliant speech against Mr. ROOSEVELT on Saturday, pointing out his inconsistencies and citing passages from his historical writings to give effect to severe criticism. But we think that the leaders of the Democratic Party are seriously in error if they imagine that they can induce a majority of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S countrymen to vote against him on the notion that he is an insincere man.

TONIO, April 17. -- The Japanese are elated over the successes they have won at Port Arthur. They are also proud of the achievements of Vice Admiral Togo, particularly of his newest strategy of countermining the enemy's harbor and decoying him across this field of mines to an equally dangerous flank attack.

CLEVELAND, April 17. -- A meeting of noodle manufacturers of the United States has been called to meet at the Lincoln Hotel, Pittsburg, Tuesday, April 19, at 10 A.M., for the purpose, it is said, of amalgamating the interests and making a uniform price.
PORT ARTHUR, April 15. -- A survivor of the Petropavlovsk has given the following account of the disaster:

Despairing of being able to meet his father's wishes by "making a man of himself,'' and discouraged by his first failure when set to shift for himself, Joseph Rosenbaum, eighteen years old, yesterday called himself.

A question has been raised in the minds of some of your readers on the "Ethics of Gov. Odell's position, in accepting the Chairmanship of the Republican State Committee while occupying the eminent position he holds as Governor." In assuming this dual role does he simply become Governor of Republican interests and director of a partisan campaign?

To relieve the congestion which has prevailed for many weeks in the wards of Bellevue Hospital, but more especially to test in a systematic manner the effect of the "open air" treatment of consumptive cases, the authorities of Bellevue and its allied hospitals have just erected on the grounds of Bellevue a new pavilion which will be devoted exclusively to the use of the tuberculosis patients in that institution.

LIAO-YANG, April 17. -- Your correspondent, believing that the Japanese would repeat the attempt to block the entrance to Port Arthur with fireships on Easter Eve, went from Liao-Yang to Port Arthur a week ago yesterday.

Sunday baseball in Greater New York, played by professional League teams, was started yesterday afternoon at Washington Park, Brooklyn, when the Brooklyns and Boston of the National League met before a crowd of 12,000 persons and played a full nine-inning game without interference from the police or interruption of any kind.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 17. -- While the city Fire Department, reinforced by companies from the suburbs, was being taxed to its utmost fighting a fire in the Occidental Hotel this morning an alarm was turned in from St. Vincent's Hospital.

A catalogue of a remarkable kind is at the moment being completed in London. It is an index of the manuscripts, referring to the period of the American Revolution, which are in the archives of England, France, Holland, and Spain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Errors by Hulswitt and Titus in the ninth inning gave New York a victory in the first game of the series with Philadelphia by the score of 7 to 6. It was a hard-fought game from start to finish. Batting honors were equally divided, but New York bunched its hits in the latter part of the game and turned apparent defeat into victory.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 18. -- The first of five new submarine boats building at St. Petersburg and forty wagonloads of ammunition were dispatched to-day to the theatre of war. The submarine boat, which was sent off in sections, is elliptical in shape and fitted with an improved electrical apparatus for firing torpedoes, which it is claimed experiments have shown enormously increases the offensive power of torpedoes.

In commenting upon Mr. Carnegie's unparalled charities some people have questioned his wisdom, but few, if any, the goodness of his intentions. But I can hardly think that any critic of his generous bounty can find any fault with is latest gift of the magnificent sum of $1,000,000 to establish a fund to reward heroes and those dependent on them, who have distinguished themselves by here efforts in striving to save human life.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 18. -- The Russian outposts are now on islands of the Yalu River 100 yards from the Japanese outposts, which are preparing to retire.

DENVER, April 18. -- After conferring with Attorney General Miller, Attorney John L. Waldron, and Gen. Sherman Bell, Gov. Peabody to-day decided that he would not produce Charles H. Moyer, President of the Western Federation of Miners, before the Supreme Court on Thursday as commanded by a writ of habeas corpus issued last Friday.

It is a portentous array of memories that hover about any actress who undertakes to play "Camille," not only in the magniloquent pathos of Bernhardt and the sheer emotional simplicity of Duse, but in a petty horde of details as well, from the frills and crinolines of costume reproductions down to the emotional blowing of the Nethersole nose.
ALBANY, April 18. -- What is the meaning of Tammany's fight against instructions for Judge Parker?"

CHICAGO, April 18. -- Peter Niedermeyer, the leader of the car-barn bandits condemned to die on the gallows next Friday, made two desperate attempts at suicide to-day, and his condition is so critical that it is feared he will not survive. Should he still be alive on Friday he will be carried to the gallows and executed.

After acting queerly for several days, Andrew Donohue, forty-four years old, a tailor living at 202 West Fortieth Street, became violent in his tailoring establishment, 128 West Fortieth Street, one door from Broadway, yesterday afternoon, and created a panic among his employes and customers. Before policemen could be called to the store Donohue had destroyed about $100 worth of cloth and had chased his customers and clerks from the place.

A plan of arbitration by which all strikes and lock-outs will be avoided in future in paving or asphalting work was reached yesterday by a committee representing the Central Federated Union and representatives of the asphalt companies, subject to the approval of the unions involved. The agreement was reached after a conference lasting from 10 o'clock in the morning until 5:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

It is likely that Mme. Gadski will sign a contract with Henry W. Savage before this week is over, agreeing to sing the role of Kundry in the English "Parsifal" next Fall. Except for the fact that she would be expected to sing this exacting role four times every week for something like five months, Mme. Gadski would certainly accept Mr. Savage's offer. Mr. Tauscher, husband of the prima donna, said for her last night:

We believe it has not happened before in history that a war battle has been so fully known in all its details, from both sides, within so short a time, as the battle in which MAKAROFF and his flagship were lost was reported for the information of the readers of yesterday's TIMES. What tremendous conquests over time and space does such an achievement involve.

The Charity Organization Society appeals for $5 a month to aid an Italian woman who has three small children. The husband and father of the family is serving a sentence of ten years in prison. The society also appeals for $8 a month for an Italian family. The father lost both hands and forearms in an accident, the mother is very delicate, and there are two children.

A prominent New York broker tells the following story at the expense of a Philadelphian: Some time ago Mr. W. gave a dinner, and at it were several Wall Street operators. W. is always on the lookout for market tips. As a rule he is rather cautious in his habits, but that night he dined a bit too freely and awoke the next morning in a rather muddled condition.

Not one stock active enough to get into the 1,000-share class altered its price by so much as a point in yesterday's business upon the Exchange nor was there any reason in the day's developments why any such stocks should do so. Of price-making news there was none. The Northern Securities intervention decision did not come, and is not expected until toward the week end.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 18. -- As a result of a pitched battle Sunday night between officers and railroad men on the line of the Knoxville, Lafollette and Jellico branch of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, forty miles north of here, Sam Hardin, a negro laborer, is dead, and William Wade, a posse man, is fatally wounded.

MOUNT VERNON, April 18. -- After its night of wild alarms Mount Vernon arose this morning to cold breakfast and a census-taking. It didn't wake up, for it hadn't been asleep. Its fire engines, which had spent the hours of darkness charging about the streets, whistles blowing and gongs clanging, and its police, whose clubs had known no rest, had seen to that.

Col. John Jacob Astor and Harry Lehr, according to the assertions of Mr. Savage's press agent, backed out at the last moment from acting as judges in the beauty-and-grace contest to determine who should be the "typical New York girl" in "The Prince of Pilsen" company that soon is to sail for London.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The old Hanna faction in Ohio, now headed by Senator Dick, received another setback to-day from President Roosevelt and intends to fight Mr. Roosevelt's latest Foraker appointee to the end, and prevent his confirmation at this session of the Senate.

If we are to accept, from a survivor of the Petropaviovsk, the account of the death of VERESTOHAGIN, which comes on precisely the same authority as that of the death of MAKAROFF, the pictorial reporter of a battle may be quite as deeply engrossed in his work as the commander of it in his.
There was a scuffling sound outside the Tenderloin Station last night.

While David Rothschild, formerly President of the wrecked Federal Bank, was languishing in the Tombs yesterday afternoon with scant hope of obtaining a bondsman able to put up $25,000, it became known that among those who had been drawn into relations with the "rug financier" was Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy, ex-Secretary of the Navy, and once a candidate for Mayor of New York.
Coffee has a terrible hold on some people.
A large Newfoundland dog, which appeared to be rabid, frightened several small girls yesterday afternoon and nearly caused the death of one of the children by drowning.

John Creech, a clerk in the office of City Collector Fry of Jersey City, made provisional preparations for his own funeral and burial yesterday. Then he went to Christ Hospital and made the final arrangements for an operation to be performed on him there to-morrow for cancer of the tongue.

In a decision written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by W.F. Winschemann against the action of Collector Stranahan in assessing 20 per cent. duty on four performing bears under the clause providing for live animals.

Nothing more civilized has occurred in modern warfare than the behavior of the Japanese concerning the death of Admiral MAKAROFF. It is true that it was preceded by the announcement that the Russians had given a military funeral with all the honors to the Japanese naval officer who gave up his life in a gallant and desperate attempt to do them harm in the harbor of Port Arthur.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The House to-day passed the last of the supply bills of the Government, the general deficiency appropriation measure, after a stormy session which lasted till 8:15 in the evening. The contest was a party one over the deficiency appropriation for pensions which the Democrats tried ineffectively to amend by incorporating as a law the recent Executive age disability pension order.

ALBANY, April 18. -- One of the liveliest incidents of the convention occurred when the Committee on Credentials met this afternoon in the Kenmore Hotel to hear the contests from half a score of districts, chief among which was that in Westchester County. In Westchester contests were brought in the Second and Third Districts against the sitting delegates who are controlled by ex-Mayor Michael Walsh of Yonkers.

It became known yesterday that ex-Congressman Jefferson M. Levy had sold out his interest in the Commercial Cable Building Company to Clarence H. Mackay, leaving Mr. Mackay practically in sole control. The company owns the Commercial Cable Building at 20 Broad Street, running through to New Street, adjoining the Stock Exchange.

The persistent efforts of organized labor to create a public sentiment against the employment of prisoners in any useful productive industry, on the ground that it takes bread from the mouth of the honest workingman and his dependents, have been generally successful. What has resulted in the penal institutions thus converted into temples of idleness in very well set forth in the report of the Workhouse Board of Allegheny County, Penn.
FREEPORT, L.I., April 18. -- Instructions were received here this morning to postpone the burial of the woman whose body was found in the woods near the Greenfield Cemetery on Monday last.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 18. -- Dr. Lee De Forest, the inventor of the De Forest system of wireless telegraphy, was in this city to-day on his way to St. Louis. He was

ALBANY, April 18. -- By a vote of 301 to 149 the Democratic State Convention to elect delegates to the National Convention to-night voted down a resolution introduced by Senator Thomas F. Grady, acting as the representative of Tammany and its allies, merely indorsing Judge Parker for President, and then by a viva voce vote adopted the resolution presented by Senator McCarren, representing the majority of the committee, in favor of instructions for the Judge.

The most amusing moment in the revival of "Wang" at the Lyric Theatre last night occurred in the course of the first act, when De Wolf Hopper, as the Regent of Siam, and Nella Bergen, as Marie, introduced a duet showing the various ways of making love. To this old specialty new zest was added when Mr. Hopper, in his most guttural tones, announced "Parsifal Love."

WEI-HAI-WEI, April 18. -- Information has been conveyed to me that Russia threatens to treat correspondents using wireless telegraphy at sea as spies. As The Times is the only journal which employs this means of communication this is a direct threat upon the ship system directed by me.

Vice Chancellor Bergen, in Jersey City yesterday, dismissed the application of the Continental Securities Company for an injunction to prevent the Northern Securities Company from holding its annual meeting in Hoboken on April 21 and voting on the plan of distributing the company's holdings in Great Northern and Northern Pacific Railroad stocks and reducing the capital stock about 90 per cent.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Although the convention adjourned in the afternoon to reassemble at 7 o'clock in the evening, it was nearly 9 o'clock when Chairman Raines called it to order. The delegates and spectators had assembled at 7 o'clock and their patience was sorely tried by the long wait. Two bands did their best to keep the crowd in good humor, and they were assisted by a bagpipe player.

The Democrats of New York designate Judge ALTON B. PARKER as their candidate for President, and commend him to the Democracy of the Union. The instructions voted in the Democratic Convention at Albany last night may be considered practically as a determination in advance of the choice of the St. Louis Convention, so clearly has the acceptability of Judge PARKER been manifested, even thus early, all over the country.

Our dispatches indicate that the people of Missouri are determined to have JOSEPH W. FOLK of St. Louis as their next Governor. At the present time the wiles of the corrupt State machine seem to be baffled, and Mr. FOLK'S nomination and election by the ordinary process of party action seem to be insured.

Two victories for two-year-olds from the stable of Sydney Paget at the Aqueduct race track yesterday, following a similar double triumph by youngsters of the Paget establishment on Friday, the opening day of the New York racing season, have served to give to that stable a very unusual prominence as regards the younger horses that will carry the Paget colors through the early season racing.

WASHINGTON, ,April 18. -- Albert Clifford Barney scored another triumph this afternoon and the widow's and orphans of the seamen lately killed aboard the United States battleship Missouri gained many additional dollars by the large house which greeted the matinee performance of the "Dream of Queen Elizabeth" at Lafayette Square.

ALBANY, April 18. -- At 11 o'clock this morning a special train of eight cars arrived over the West Shore from Ulster County. It brought to the convention city 600 neighbors and friends of Judge Alton B. Parker, without respect to politics.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Secretary of War Taft removed one of the prime causes of friction between Congress and the executive department. He wrote to the Senate Military Affairs Committee withdrawing his support of the opposition made by Lieut. Gen. Chaffee to the military camp sites chosen by the House. In his letter he says:

LONDON, April 18. -- The St. James's Gazette, referring to the Russian ban on wireless telegraphy, says: "By this course it is evident that the Russians in sudden panic have rushed at the bull without much premeditation, but have not really succeeded in catching it by the horns. Success in a duel with specials will be as dubious as was the advantage they gained in ejecting The Times's correspondent from St. Petersburg a year ago.

Mayor McClellan received three delegations yesterday. The first presented to him a photograph of the ballot which bore the name and likeness of Gen. McClellan and the Democratic Electors of 1864. Edward Scheu, whose father was one of the Electors named on the ballot, acted as Chairman of the visiting delegation.

ALBANY, April 18. -- There was something pathetic as well as ridiculous in the collapse of the Hearst boom. The small results which were achieved, notwithstanding the evidently lavish expenditure of money by Mr. Hearst's boomers, excited sympathetic comments even from the Tammany men.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Minister Powell's energetic attitude in behalf of the United States claimants against Santo Domingo meets the cordial approval of the officials of the Administration here.

ALBANY, April 18. -- The early feature of the day was naturally the meeting of the Committee on Resolutions in the afternoon, presided over by Senator P.H. McCarren as Chairman. It developed into a heated controversy over the proposed adoption of a plank in the platform instructing the delegation to vote for Judge Parker as the nominee for President.

ALBANY, April 18. -- In the crush to get into Harmanus Bleecker Hall for the afternoon session of the convention, coats were torn, hats were broken, faces scratched, feet trampled, and tempers badly ruffled. The seating capacity of the hall was totally inadequate to accommodate those who wanted to get in or even those who held tickets, and the police arrangements were execrable.

Isaac H. Clothier of Philadelphia has bought from Louis and Samuel Sachs, through Brokers Charles E. Schuyler Co. and H.J. Sachs, the Jefferson Building, a twelve-story office and loft structure at 119 and 121 West Twenty-third Street, running through to 112 and 114 West Twenty-fourth Street, on a plot 50 by 197.6.

The third annual meeting of the United States Steel Corporation was held yesterday in the Hoboken office of the company. The meeting was attended by about 100 persons, most of whom were individual stockholders, representatives of the company, clerks, or reporters. The company was represented by E.H. Gary, Chairman of the board; Francis Lynde Stetson, general counsel; Richard Trimble, Secretary and Treasurer, and W.J. Filbert, Controller of the corporation.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 18. -- The Russ cordially welcomes the Anglo-French agreement and is ready to believe an agreement of a similar nature between Great Britain and Russia is not beyond the bounds of possibility. The newspaper even makes an attempt to sketch the lines such an agreement would follow:

Alexander Winton made his formal entry yesterday to the Automobile Club of American of his fast car, known as Bullet No. 2, for the international Gordon Bennett race, to be held in Germany in June. This is the same machine that Mr. Winton entered for the contest last year, when it was driven by Percy Owen in Ireland.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- There was a jolly time at the White House this morning when the Harvard baseball nine called to pay their respects as they were passing through the city.

ALBANY, April 18. -- The first political event of the day was the meeting of the State Committee at 10 o'clock. W.F. Balkam of Rochester presented the name of George Raines of that city as the candidate for temporary Chairman and it was unanimously adopted.
The West Forty-seventh Street police started out last night to stop a fight, and ran into a riot of unusual proportions, with what the police say is "the Smoky Row gang."

Your recent eulogistic estimate of the artist Verestchagin, reported to have gone down with the ill-fated Petropaviovsk at Port Arthur, does not mention his greatest service to mankind, which future generations with higher notions of civilization likely will recognize and honor.
ALBANY, April 18.--The platform adopted by the Democratic State Convention to-night is as follows:

NEWPORT, R.I., April 18. -- Miss Bishop, daughter of Mrs. Heber R. Bishop, is here looking for a cottage for the Summer. The Bishops last Summer occupied the John W. Ellis, Villa Stonaire, which has been sold to Edward R. Thomas.

ALBANY, April 18. -- The first political event of the day was the meeting of the State Committee at 10 o'clock. W.F. Balkam of Rochester presented the name of George Raines of that city as the candidate for temporary Chairman and it was unanimously adopted.
The West Forty-seventh Street police started out last night to stop a fight, and ran into a riot of unusual proportions, with what the police say is "the Smoky Row gang."

Your recent eulogistic estimate of the artist Verestchagin, reported to have gone down with the ill-fated Petropaviovsk at Port Arthur, does not mention his greatest service to mankind, which future generations with higher notions of civilization likely will recognize and honor.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- Charles L. Strobel, an ex-general agent of the Carnegie Company of Pittsburg, has commenced suit against Henry Phipps, Jr., of New York, an ex-partner in the Carnegie Company, asking that Phipps be compelled to account for and divide the proceeds of real estate deals in Chicago which the men have managed at various times during the last ten years.

A false tooth saved the life of Dr. Orville Westall of 359 Eighth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. But for the almost human intelligence displayed by the porcelain incisor in breaking off and dropping down his throat just at the right moment the doctor would, he believes, have been asphyxiated by gas.
TORONTO, Ontario, April 19. -- Fire swept through a section of Toronto's wholesale business district to-night, causing a loss which at midnight was estimated at $10,000,000.

" Monk" Eastman, the leader of the band of roughs which has terrorized the east side, and George Coan, the leader of a west side "gang," were sentenced by Recorder Goff, in General Sessions Court, yesterday, to ten years' imprisonment each in State prison -- the maximum punishment. Eastman and Coan both were convicted of assault in the first degree.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 19. -- A tidy tramp is being sought by the local vidocqs, and if he is found he will be locked up. Whether he will be accused of burglary or whether he will be detained merely to have his sanity determined has not been decided. For he stole a cake of soap and a dishpan, went to a nearby patch of woods, and performed his toilette.
WASHINGTON, April 19. -- A strange thing occurred in the House of Representatives to-day. Representative William R. Hearst came in.

Wall Street was concerned yesterday afternoon by circumstantial reports about a serious illness of J. Pierpont Morgan, who is now in England. The reports seemed to start up in various quarters at the same time, and they spread rapidly to other Exchanges, for inquiries came from Boston and Philadelphia about Mr. Morgan's health.

LONDON, April 19. -- The steam yacht which Sir William Armstrong Co. have built at Tynside for the Sultan of Turkey is now ready to sail for Constantinople. It is a harmonious and practical combination of Western utility and Eastern magnificence. The same firm has built other yachts for European royalty, but in none have the decorative features been so rich as in this yacht for the Sultan, which is yet to be named.

NEWARK, N.J., April 19. -- Miss Mary Philbrook, the Essex County probation officer, who weighs scarcel 100 pounds, made a prisoner of Philip Schnitzer, a six footer, who was wanted for violating his parole, on Market Street this afternoon.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 19. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day Judges Sanborn, Thayer, Van Devanter, and Hook unanimously denied the application of E.H. Harriman and W.S. Pierce and the Oregon Short Line Railroad Company for leave to intervene in the case of the United States against the Northern Securities Company on the following grounds:

ALBANY, April 19. -- Apprehension is being expressed by some of the Republican leaders that the Republican organization may be deprived of the fat patronage of the Elsberg Supreme Court Commissioners bill.

A sharp upward movement occurred yesterday in the foreign exchange market accompanied by reports that the Panama payment would be made much sooner than had been expected, and might be completed by the first of the coming month. Demand exchange which on Monday ruled at 4.8740 closed last night at about 4.8760.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 19. -- Viceroy Alexieff has applied by telegraph to the Emperor to be relieved of his position of Viceroy in the Far East.

Results were mixed somewhat at the Aqueduct race track yesterday, and though post favorites were successful in two of the six events, the general public fared ill, as private rather than public form established at least one of the winning favorites as post choices.
BARTON, S.C., April 19 -- Information of a race tragedy in which three lives were lost has been received here from Barnwell County.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, daughter of the President, will be one of the bridesmaids at the wedding of Miss Elsie Whelen and Robert Goelet, which will take place Saturday, June 11, in St. David's Protestant Episcopal Church at Devon. Miss Whelen and Miss Roosevelt were close friends at Newport last Summer and were often seen there together.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- In the hope that one of the eighteen of the George William Millers named in the Chicago City Directory may turn out to be the missing son of the late Charles Miller of Brooklyn, who left an estate of $500,000, Chief O'Neill of the Chicago police to-day detailed men to investigate.

Joseph Marks, seventy years old, the Colchester (Conn.) farmer who is charged with having murdered John Pavil, his farm hand, and who disappeared on April 9, was found yesterday at 190 Broome Street. He was living there under an assumed name and had disguised himself. He was arrested by Policemen Brown and Halpin of the Delancey Street Station, and locked up at Police Headquarters on a charge of homicide.

SYRACUSE. N.Y., April 19. -- Another blizzard struck Syracuse and Central New York to-night. The wind is blowing gale and the snow is drifting badly. Several inches of snow have fallen, and if the cold weather continues to-morrow there will be good sleighing.

The Columbia University Council, at a meeting held yesterday, made award of the various fellowships of the institution. The first fellowship ever granted by Columbia to a Chinaman was awarded to Chin Yung Yen of Tien-Tsin. Mr. Yen's specialty is constitutional law. He was a student at the Imperial Tien-tsin University from 1893-1901, and received a bachelor's degree from the Government in 1901.

One of the greatest errors ever made by the people of this State was the abandonment of the lateral canals which in connection with the Pennsylvania waterways led to the coal mines, oil fields, and salt deposits of this and the Keystone State; but their destruction was engineered by the railroad canal enemy to destroy these low transportation protecters between producers and consumers.

The Evening Post promptly recognizes that the declaration of principles by the Democratic Convention at Albany is the basis for the creation of a real and effective opposition. That is a consummation for which sensible and patriotic men have been devoutly wishing for a long while.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 19. -- The Democratic State Convention, held here today, refused to instruct the National delegates from Pennsylvania to vote for the nomination of Judge Alton B. Parker of New York for President. The delegates will go to St. Louis uninstructed, and will be bound by the unit rule.

PARIS, April 19. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch says that Prince Khilkoff, Minister of Ways and Communication, who departed yesterday for the seat of war, will cross Lake Baikal and proceed to Vladivostok as far as possible by water in order to ascertain to what extent waterways can be used.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 19. -- It was claimed by the General Staff to-day that Gen. Kuropatkin now has 300,000 men at the theatre of war, sufficient for present requirements. A prominent officer of the staff informed the correspondent of The Associated Press that the dispatch of troops to the Far East had been suspended for the present.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., April 19. -- A log driver named Kelly was murdered at St. Alexandre, Canada, and Joseph Lambert, who committed the crime, is thought to have ended his life by burning his house down and perishing in the flames.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- The clean-cut declaration of principles by the New York Democratic Convention received enthusiastic approval to-day from the Democratic Senators. The instructions to the New York delegates stirred the enthusiasm of most of those who discussed the results of the convention.
ROME, April 19. -- Signor Giacomo Boni, the famous archaeologist, who is directing the excavations of the Roman Forum, made to-day what is considered the greatest discovery of many years.

CHICAGO, April 19. -- May corn had a savage break of 2 1/4c on 'Change to-day, with Armour an open seller. The general impression was that the big line held by that house had been quietly liquidated during the last two weeks and that the deal was practically over.

LONDON, April 19. -- Elba won the Great Metropolitan Stakes (handicap, of 1,000 sovereigns, for three-year-olds and upward, about two miles and a quarter,) at the Epsom Spring meeting to-day. Mark Time was second, and Lovat came in third. Thirteen horses ran.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 19. -- The petition of the heirs of the late Henry B. Plant, asking that the balance of his estate, amounting to over $16,500,000, be transferred from Connecticut to the jurisdiction of New York courts, was to-day granted by Judge Cleaveland of the Probate Court.

BOSTON, April 19. -- Michael Spring of the Pastime Athletic Club of New York won the Marathon road race of twenty-five miles to-day, covering the distance in 2:38:04 2-5, the second fastest time since the race was inaugurated, and 9 minutes behind the record, which was made in 1901 by J.J. Caffrey of Hamilton, Ont. T.J. Hicks of Cambridge was second, his time being 2:39:341-5, and E.F. Cook of South Boston, third, in 2:42:35.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- At the meeting of the Cabinet to-day the control by the Government of wireless telegraphy was discussed. The subject was broached by Secretary Hay, in connection with the communication received by this Government from Russia through Count Cassini, the Russian Ambassador.

It was proved to the satisfaction of a large crowd at the corner of Forty-second Street and Broadway last night that an automobile will balk and behave as sulkily as any mule that has gone out "with its hands in its pockets," as Kipling says.

Advertisements are published to-day in the City Record and elsewhere calling for bids for the largest single issue of municipal bonds ever put out by the City of New York. The total amount of bonds for all purposes aggregates $37,000,000, and the record to the present time for any single issue is $16,000,000, which amount was put out during the Controllership of Ashbel P. Fitch.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 19. -- E.H. Harriman is in the Southwest on a tour of inspection. He is believed to have passed through Arizona last night, and is expected to arrive at Los Angeles some time to-day.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., April 19. -- Two young men in charge of the interlocking switch tower on the Lackawanna Railroad between Millburn and Wyoming were badly frightened last night, and a squad of policemen from South Orange were rushed to the tower in a special engine to avert a threatened hold-up.
The purchase of the dwelling 22 East Fifty-third Street by Mrs. Lewis Nixon is referred to in more detail in another column.

The protest against the increase of rent which took its inception in the east side found voice in Harlem last night at a mass meeting held at 210 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, under the auspices of the New York Rent Payers' Protective Association and the East Side Rent Payers' Association.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 19. -- Vice Admiral Skrydloff, who arrived here to-day on his way to the Far East, got an enthusiastic reception from the people who thronged the streets.

In denying the Harriman-Pierce application for leave to intervene in the settlement of the affairs of the Northern Securities Company the United States Circuit Court goes to the unexpected length of saying that if the court is satisfied with the execution of its own decree it is not open to private petitioners to interfere on any grounds.

Creditors of the wrecked Federal Bank, whose former President, David Rothschild, is a prisoner in the Tombs charged with having misappropriated $200,000 of its funds, got together yesterday and started a movement to find out what became of this money, and also of the $700,000 that marks the deficit of Rothschild's Globe Securities Company, which passed into a receiver's hands on Monday.

LONDON, April 19. -- Lady Constance Mackenzie, niece of the Duke of Sutherland, and well known in the United States, was married to Sir Edward Austin Richardson, Bart.; at Pitfour, Perthshire, this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- One of the greatest baseball games ever witnessed in this city took place between the Philadelphia and New York National League teams here this afternoon. Almost blinded by the clouds of dust that blew across the field and shivering from the chilly wind, players, umpires, and spectators were thankful when darkness made it imperative that play cease, after fifteen sharp, nerve-racking, and often brilliant innings had been completed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19. -- Edward S. Armstrong, a produce commission merchant, with offices at 18 Spruce Street, this city, to-day faced charges of robbery preferred by J.B. Coover McKee, who said he was a professional gambler in New York. According to the prosecutor, McKee was robbed of $1,200 and jewelry valued at $5,000 in Armstrong's place of business by hired ruffians, who worked at the latter's suggestion, and even threatened death if resistance were offered.

The accounts which come to us from Ohio of the relations between Senator DICK and the Administration are not pleasant reading. We do not pretend to any special sympathy with either party to the squabble that is going on in that State. The late Senator HANNA and his successor on the one side and Senator FORAKER on the other have never appealed to us.

It appears that the Commissioner of Pensions knew perfectly what he was about when he grossly usurped the functions of the Legislature by assuming to bestow service pensions by executive order. He rightly relied upon the cowardice of Congress not to resent such a usurpation, when the usurpation was made in the interest of the veterans.

Under the most unpleasant' weather conditions of the season, wlth-a cold, penetrating wind blowing across the ga'ounds and the thermometer verging on to the freezing point, the Greater New York baseball team was enabled to turn the tables on "Connie" lack's Philadelphia players, the score being 5 to'4.

PARIS, April 20. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of the Echo de Paris, who is an old acquaintance of Vice Admiral Skrydloff, was present at a small dinner given the Admiral by a Director of the Nevsky Yards, and succeeded in gaining his confidences. He reports the Admiral as saying to him:

Mr. George Wharton Edwards, relieved of the drudgery as art director of Collier's Weekly, hied him to one of the little fishing villages of Maine instead of to Holland, where he usually disports himself in Summer, and proceeded to do up Mannana in water colors with a thoroughness that leaves nothing to be desired.
BOSTON, April 19. -- To guard against a possible attempt by Hearst men to rush the convention Thursday the Democratic State Committee has taken extraordinary precautions.

In the arrest yesterday of a young man who called himself John Truell the police and owners of a big Sixth Avenue department store believe that they have stopped the theft of valuable goods from their silk department which, it is asserted, has been going on for nearly a month, during which time thousands of dollars' worth of goods have been taken.

ST. LOUIS, April 19. -- Thomas A. Shanahan, a private watchman, who to-night risked his life to help several persons escape from a burning house, is the first man to be proposed as a candidate for one of Andrew Carnegie's heroism medals.

LONDON, April 19. -- The widespread interest in the presentation of the budget today was evidenced by the crowded state of the House of Commons. Long before the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Austen Chamberlain, rose to make his statement, every part of the House was filled.

Whereas Miss Margaret Anglin, at the Hudson Theatre, has deprived Camille oil her cough, Miss Virginia Harned, at the Harlem Opera House, has deprived her of her bedstead to boot. Nothing more terrible has happened to a lady visiting the metropolis since the anecdotal auntie from the hinterland lost her God at a Bob Ingersoll lecture one evening.

An announcement is made which, if true, is an interesting illustration of the minor differentiation of the characteristics due to environmental conditions, so to speak. We are told that the telephone is giving us a race of left-eared people -that is, of people who hear better with the left than with the right ear.
PARIS, April 19. -- The Catholic periodical les Paroles Francaises says:

TRENTON, N.J., April 19. -- Gov. Murphy will sail for Europe next Saturday. The Governor has been in poor health since the death of his wife, and his physician suggested a sea voyage and absolute change and rest as the best means of restoring him to health.
NEW ORLEANS, April 19. -- The quadrennial State election in Louisiana to-day resulted in a tragedy at Gonzales, in Ascension Parish, where the "Lily Whites" and Democrats are closely divided.

In decision written by General Appraiser Marion De Vries, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained protests by W. J. Sloane and Leon Rheims of New York against the assessment of duty at $1.50 a pound as pile fabrics on upholstering fabrics of silk and cotton, silk chief value, with a pile stripe running through them.

Polo championships will be plentiful during the coming year, for besides the regular club and junior events held by the Polo Association, the delegates at the annual meeting last night at the Metropolitan Club voted to hold this year an open championship. In this event, teams may enter without the necessity of being indorsed by established clubs.

Yesterday's trading on the Stock Exchange drifted along very much as it had the previous day up till 1 o'clock, when there was a sudden increase in activity, accompanied by a rather sharp decline, which included most of the active issues.
