Owing to the increase of trading during the afternoon, the total for the day was considerably larger than that of Monday, amounting all told to about 425,000 shares.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 19. -- The Hearst organization and supporters in Texas, led by ex-Gov. J.S. Hogg, have lost the fight which they made to have the State Democratic Executive Committee fix an early date for holding the State Convention to elect delegates to the National Convention.

BERLIN, April 19. -- The questions of improving the German Consular Service through the addition of expert commercial advisers and the promotion and organization of German Chambers of Commerce abroad came up in the Reichstag to-day.

The Stock Exchange yesterday had two Northern Securities decisions to think over, and it liked them not a little bit, as is usually the way of speculators with lawsuits. They give surprises, even when they are precisely according to expectation, and there never is any finality about them.

WASHINGTON, April 19. -- Corporation Commissioner James R. Garfield, just returned from an inspection of the Chicago packing houses, is preparing schedules of questions to he sent to the trusts, under the law creating the bureau. The Beef Trust is to come under the searchlight first, for the season that the House of Representatives adopted a resolution, offered by Mr. Martin of South Dakota, requesting the Department of Commerce to investigate this corporation.

Massachusetts has not chosen Democratic Presidential Electors within the memory of man. We do not concur, therefore, in the opinion of our neighbor The World that it was a mistake to omit the Kansas City protest against the acquisition of the Philippines from the platform adopted by the Democrats at Albany on Monday.
RALEIGH, N.C., April 20. -- Snow has been falling in Asheville, N.C., all day, and the ground is covered to a depth of two inches.

TOKIO, April 20. -- The Marquis Ito, in presenting 1,500 yen ($750) to the Perry Memorial Relief Fund, expresses warm sympathy with the work, which, he says, will not only perpetuate the name of the great Commodore, but will carry home to every Japanese the traditional friendship of America toward Japan.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The chief paper read before the National Academy of Sciences to-day was a description of a series of experiments recently conducted by the Sheffield Scientific School of Yale to determine if the average human being is not eating too much.

PARIS, April 20. -- A Paris morning paper plays the role of introducer of the new Ambassador of the still nebulous State of Counany, which is endeavoring to attain a separate and independent existence among the South American republics.
CHARLESTON, West Va., April 20. -- The largest and stormiest Democratic Convention ever known in this State was held here to-day. Many Democrats took advantage of the occasion to vent their spleen.

Another very striking instancp of the steady increase in real estate vp. lues in the neighborhood of Times Square has been afforded by he advancing of the asking price on the lossrnore Hotel property to $1,250,000.

Only the stoutest hearted can refrain from sympathizing with Mr. Venner. So far as the public is aware he never made a good investment in his life, and he has advertised liberally his misadventures with Houston and Texas Central, Rock Island, Steel, Northern Securities, and doubtless others.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Brigham H. Roberts, the Mormon who was elected a Representative in Congress by the Democrats in 1898, but as the result of a protest from one end of the country to the Other was not allowed to take his seat, was to-day a witness before the Senate Committee on Elections on the Smoot inquiry.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce to-day took up the Senate's carefully prepared scheme of government for the Panama Canal zone, struck out all after the enacting clause, and substituted for it a measure which makes the President the sole ruler of the new territory, practically with the power of life and death.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 20. -- The will of A. Cass Canfield of Roslyn, who died in Aiken, S.C., last month, was offered for probate in Surrogate Seabury's court today. The estate is supposed to be worth $20,000,000, but the value is not mentioned in the documents filed.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 20. -- Gen. Kuropatkin has sent the following telegram to the Emperor:

Baseball postponements on account of the weather other than rain are of an unusual occurrence, especially in this city; in fact, men who have been identified with the game for years could not recall an instance when a contest was postponed in New York because of freezing weather and a gale of wind, such as prevailed yesterday.

Mayor McClellan, as the guest of honor and principal speaker at the annual banquet of the Brooklyn League, held last night in the Assembly Building, on Pierrepont Street, rendered an accounting to the citizens across the bridge and stated his policies on matters particularly pertaining to their welfare.

PARIS, April 20. -- It would seem that the stringent measures which the Russian authorities contemplate with regard to wireless telegraphy are merely one of the consequences of a general decision to conceal as far as possible particulars of all unfavorable events.

William Barclay Parsons of the Panama Canal Commission arrived yesterday from Colon on the Panama Line steamship Alliance, after an inspection of the work already done on the Isthmus and a preliminary study of the work that is to he done there. After the members of the commission were presented to the President of the new Republic they began their work, traveling in boats through such portions of the canal as were navigable.
WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Census Bureau to-day issued the final detailed report on cotton ginning in the United States for the crop of 1903.

TORONTO, Ont., April 20. -- The fire that raged throughout the night and up to an early hour to-day in Toronto's wholesale and retail business district was the most disastrous in the history of the city.

Following the selling movement which depressed the stock market Tuesday afternoon, traders yesterday attempted to force prices still lower, but except in a limited number of issues the day's movement seemed to indicate that it was a relatively easy matter to hold prices even in the face of professional selling.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20. -- The Yale football schedule of eleven games for next season was made public to-night by Manager Spaulding. Yale will play all but three of the games at Yale Field, the three exceptions being the games with West Point, Columbia, and Princeton. The Princeton game will, as usual, precede that with Harvard by only one week.

Two slight and unimportant accidents were included in one day's news budget this week, which had interest and value as showing how foolish are the panics which follow any unusual display of electrical phenomena in or under public vehicles.

Shortly before noon yesterday "Jake" Wunderlich smelled gas issuing from the basement of his saloon at 464 Sixth Avenue. He went down to find the leak, tripped on the last stair, and presently found himself literally swimming in a pool of frothy liquid.
CHICAGO, April 20. -- General desire to close up all deals in May wheat caused a drop of 2 1/2 cents to-day in the price of that option.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- Representative Stanley of Kentucky and Representative Pou of North Carolina look so much alike that they are continually being mistaken for each other. Mr. Stanley is now thinking about writing a sequel to Edward Everett Hale's "My Double, and How He Undid Me."

ITHACA, N.Y., April 20. -- The Cornell Varsity crew men have gone on strike and will do no more hard training until better food is provided for them. Last night sixteen members of the Varsity squad left the training table, protesting that they could not row twelve miles and live on the knicknacks that were provided them in the place of good substantial food.

Latest advices from Australia are to the effect that three prominent amateur athletes who participated in the Australasian championships will very soon become students at the University of Pennsylvania. They are H.H. Hunter of Victoria, the 100-yard champion; L.M. Macpherson of Victoria, hurdler and jumper, and A. St. C. Dawson of Queensland, sprinter.

Bernard Smyth Sons have sold for Charles T. Barney the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, 90.11 by 100. This property was to have been sold at auction yesterday.
GYANG-TSE, April 20. -- The fort was finally emptied and partially blown up to-day.

The Presidential prerogative is to be exercised over the canal strip, after all. Mr. ROOSEVELT, it appears, will brook no Congressional interference with the Executive purpose to govern that part of the Isthmus transferred to our care by the Panama treaty.

The Russian commanders in the Far East seem to labor under some fatal necessity of saying foolish things as soon as they attain the very unenviable eminence of becoming responsible for the military or naval operations of their country against the Japanese. That fine old Russian gentleman the late Admiral ALEXIEFF talked after his kind before and at the outbreak of hostilities.

BOSTON, April 20. -- A spirit of concession to the supporters of William R. Hearst was manifest at to-night's meeting of the Democratic State Committee called to perfect arrangements for to-morrow's State Convention at which four delegates at large and four alternates to the National Convention will be chosen.

Leader Charles F. Murphy has passed the word along to the delegates selected by the Tammany organization to go to the St. Louis Convention that they must be close-mouthed as to Tammany's intentions. Leader Murphy did not go to the Wigwam yesterday, but the information as to his establishment of the ban of talking was obtained from several of the Tammany delegates who were approached.

That the operations of David Rothschild, late President of the wrecked Federal Bank and backer of the Globe Security Company, should have been carried on for so long a time without moving some one in authority to exercise that authority in the neighborhood of the "financier," has become a topic much discussed in Wall Street in view of knowledge that prominent bank officials have had of what was going on for nearly two years past.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 20. -- Despite cold weather Columbia and Wesleyan played a good game of ball here this afternoon, the former winning by the score of 4 to 3. The fielding of both teams was good and the work of the two pitchers was also creditable. Score by innings:

OMAHA, Neb., April 20. -- The Loyal League, composed of most prominent Bryan Democrats of the State, to-day issued a warning to the "faithful" in Nebraska, calling attention to the strong fight Which the reorganizers are putting up, and urging them to stand up for true Democracy.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., April 20. -- Postmaster Cowperthwait of the local Post Office, under instructions from the Post Office Department at Washington, D.C., this morning, discharged Miss Maud Robertson, who has been mailing clerk in the Post Office here for eight years.

FORT MONROE, Va., April 20. -- This was a red-letter day at Hampton Institute, Virginia's famous school for the negro, which was the first stopping place of Robert C. Ogden's party of educators, who are touring the South. It was the thirty-sixth anniversary of the institute, which also celebrated Virginia Day to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 20. -- The Republicans were caught napping to-day, and the Democrats seized the opportunity to land two solar plexus blows. There were only three Republicans present at the meeting of the House Judiciary Committee, and the Democrats ran things and reported out two of Leader Williams's resolutions on the trust question.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 20. -- William J. Bryan announces that he will deliver a political address at the Princess Rink, in Chicago. Saturday night on ';The New York Platform," the platform referred to being the one ado. pted by the New York Democratic State Convention Monday last. There will be reserved seats for ministers and newspaper men, otherwise seats will be free.
CATANIA, Sicily, April 20. -- Driving amid the greatest enthusiasm and the throwing of flowers on the part of the populace, Emperor William to-day made the ascent of Mount Etna.
PORT ARTHUR, April 20. -- An instantaneous photograph which was taken of the Petropavlovsk disaster may subsequently prove to be valuable in determining the controverted questions concerning it.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 20. -- The Republicans of Vermont, through their State Convention held in this city to-day, elected four delegates to the National Convention at Chicago and instructed them to vote for the nomination of President Roosevelt. The National delegates are United States Senator W.P. Dillingham, Dr. W. Seward Webb of Shelburne, H.N. Turner of St. Johnsbury, and H.S. Bingham of Bennington.

A general shut-down of the silk mills in Paterson and other parts of New Jersey and in Pennsylvania is threatened, as a result of the paucity of orders for the Fall trade. The manufacturers talk of closing their mills next month and not resuming operations until September unless business revives, a contingency which they now scarcely expect.

If the weather is as cold to-day as it was yesterday the opening championship game on the Polo Grounds between the New York and Philadelphia teams will be postponed. This was what President Brush of the New York Club said yesterday in reply to an inquiry regarding the matter. Only freezing weather or rain, however, will stop the teams in engaging in a contest for which elaborate preparations have been made.

I read with exceeding interest the letter in to-day's issue of THE TIMES from Capt. W.C. Clark on the plea for more canals. The thoughtful mind will discover that invention, like reasoning, goes in circles. This is the case with the water wheel, most ancient means of power. To-day it reappears in the turbine engine.

James C. Kennedy, the well-known sporting man and manager of the six-day bicycle events in Madison Square Garden, died suddenly last night at about 9 o'clock in a Brighton Beach train. When between Grand and Franklin Avenues the guard noticed that one of the passengers had lurched forward in his seat, and upon investigating he discovered that the man was dead.

-- There is something queer about the word "aleatory." While not exactly in common usage, its employment is far from rare, and even when one comes across the word the first time its meaning is instantly evident if one has any knowledge at all of Latin. Yet, whenever "aleatory" appears in our columns, as it does once a year or so, a most remarkable amount of excitement is always created.

There was again a comparatively languid public interest manifested yesterday in the cycle of the "Nibelung" trilogy, with which Mr. Conried is closing his season at the Metropolitan Opera House. "Die Walkure" was presented before an audience not much larger than that which heard "Das Rheingold" last Monday; yet "Die Walkure" passes for the most widely popular drama of the trilogy.

Several of the physicians of Bellevue Hospital are ill and incapacitated as a result of overwork and strain attendant on the recent crowded condition of the hospital, and Dr. Robert S. Macdonald, the house surgeon, is so critically ill in the Townsend Cottage at the institution that there is small hope expressed for his recovery.

There was again a comparatively languid public interest manifested yesterday in the cycle of the "Nibelung" trilogy, with which Mr. Conried is closing his season at the Metropolitan Opera House. "Die Walkure" was presented before an audience not much larger than that which heard "Das Rheingold" last Monday; yet "Die Walkure" passes for the most widely popular drama of the trilogy.

From the appearance of the city yesterday when snowflakes filled the air and the thermometer was down below the freezing point, it seemed that December had slipped a cog. Summer is due on the afternoon of June 21, at 3:47 o'clock, but judging from the present outlook it will be somewhat behind time.

William Halpin, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Republican County Committee, made the discovery yesterday that New York County will be entitled to two less Supreme Court Trial Commissioners under the Elsberg bill than had been figured on by the organization.

There will be no polo game this Spring at Van Cortlandt Park between the West Point cadets and Squadron A. Col. Treat of the Military Academy, who has charge of all the polo activity there, sent word to Capt. Herbert Barry, Chairman of the squadron polo committee, last week that it would be impossible to get a team together this Spring at West Point.

Despite the protest of Attorney George F. Elliott, who appeared for the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Justices of the Court of Special Sessions imposed fines of $10 each on twenty-nine of the thirty-three men who were arrested early in the morning of Sunday, April 10, and charged with engaging in a cockfight in the private stable of Robert Pinkerton, head of the Pinkerton Detective Agency, at 782 Union Street, Brooklyn.

BUDAPEST, April 20. -- The strike of railwaymen which began yesterday on the Hungarian Western Railway has become general, and on all the Hungarian State railways to-day traffic is at a complete standstill. The Southern Railway, which is not owned by the Government, alone managed to start trains out of Budapest.
LONDON, April 21. -- The Times's military correspondent says

Only "regulars" attended the races at the Aqueduct track yesterday, but they were 5,000 strong, and in spite of Winter weather rose to the occasion when three post favorites managed to get to the winning post first. In the course of the afternoon, and especially after the 40-to-1 chance, Burning Glass, beat the only odds-on favorite of the day.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 20. -- The racing schooner yacht Ingomar, designed by Capt. Nat Herreshoff, and owned by Commodore Morton F. Plant of the Larchmont Yacht Club, sailed to-day for Southampton, where she will be put in shape for a trial of speed in various regattas against the fastest British and German yachts.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Angus Cannon, seventy years old, patriarch in the Mormon Church and President of Salt Lake "stake" for twenty-eight years, gave sensational testimony in the Smoot case today. Mr. Cannon confessed that he had six wives, all living, and had gone to prison rather than give them up.

Both New York clubs lost in the National and American League championship contests yesterday, the Nationals by 12 to 1 at the hands of the Philadelphia team and the Americans by one run after an exciting game of twelve innings with "Connie" Mack's ex-champions of the American League.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- As a means of evading the anti-rebate law and of becoming further independent of the railroads, the Standard Oil Company has planned to lay a pipe line from Texas to New York, with branch lines radiating to the various oil fields. In this way the entire crude oil production of the United States is to be handled.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- At the meeting of the National Academy of Sciences to-day a description was given of researches made by exploring parties sent out by the American Museum of New York as a result of a gift of $15,000 made by the late William C. Whitney for the purpose of learning the prehistoric story of the horse on the American Continents.

Surrogate Church handed down a decision yesterday setting aside the will of a woman in spite of the fact that her husband, who was cut off from participation in the estate, did not object to the probate. Under the decision the husband will have a large portion of the estate, which amounts to $30,000, although he has manifested no desire to do so.

When the rival Metropolitan and Belmont interests come to bid for the next rapid transit subway contract, which will be let in June, they will bid for the construction of what is substantially the east side route submitted by the Metropolitan several weeks ago. This was practically decided yesterday at the meeting of the Plan and Scope Committee of the Rapid Transit Commission.
NIU-CHWANG, April 21. -- A messenger from the Yalu reports Japanese outposts near the Russian intrenchments, with large bodies five miles distant.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- The main franchise of the Chicago Passenger Railway expired to-night at midnight. There are outstanding $1,306,000 of its bonds, drawing 5 per cent., secured on the property and franchise of the road.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- After a debate in which the service pension order was defended by Messrs. McCumber and Scott, the Senate to-day passed the Pension bill, carrying an appropriation of $137,000,000,

BOSTON, Mass., April 21. -- Although the cold weather kept the attendance at the Boston-Brooklyn game to-day down to less than 2,000 persons, the contest abounded in many interesting plays. It was a match between Pitchers Pittenger and Poole, however, only four hits apiece being the battery record, with Lumley making the only extra hit a two-baser. Brooklyn scored in the first inning by Sheckard reaching first on called balls.
CHICAGO, April 21. -- A distracted father will leave to-morrow for New York to recover his eleven-year-old daughter, declared to have been carried away last Wednesday by her aunt, Mrs. Leon Pltzele.

James N. Abeel, who became engaged to be married to Miss Eleanor Anderson, a telegraph operator in the Grand Hotel, while posing as "J. Ogden Goelet," was found guilty of forgery in the third degree by a jury before Recorder Goff in Part III., General Sessions. Abeel was charged with forging a letter of introduction with the siguature of Vice President John G. Van Every of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 22. -- All doubt as to the cause of the destruction of the battleship Petropavlovsk and the damage to the battleship Pobieda at Port Arthur is dissipated by a report submitted by telegraph to the Emperor yesterday. In it Viceroy Alexieff states in a way that leaves the matter no longer an open question that mines were responsible for the disaster.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- Most of today's session of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution was devoted to reports from the State organizations. Some discussion was had regarding the movement to bring the body of John Paul Jones, the naval hero of the Revolution, from France to this country. Finally, a committee was appointed to urge upon Congress the passage of the resolution for bringing the body back.

QUINCY, Mass., April 21. -- An unsuccessful effort was made to-day to settle the strike of 3,000 men at the Fore River Ship and Engine Company's yards. The State Board of Arbitration heard both sides to the controversy, but nothing definite was accomplished.

Owners of coastwise vessels and brokers acting for them have formed an association to regulate some practices associated with the coal-carrying trade. The organization has been perfected in the last two or three weeks, and only within a few days has its existence become known to the coal shippers.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 21. -- All information in possession of the General Staff indicates that the Japanese are preparing to make a landing near Taku-shan.
Three days beyond Jerusalem by the camel route over the sun-baked desert is the village of Zimorin, which was the home of Cecnia Miller until she reached New York last week.

BALTIMORE, April 21. -- Joe Gans of this city, the light-weight champion, was given the decision over Sam Bolen of Philadelphia to-night before the Eureka Athletic Club in their fifteen-round bout. The men fought at catch-weights and Bolen was much heavier than the Baltimorean.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 21. -- Mrs. W. Storrs Wells and Miss Nathalie Wells arrived to-day at their villa, Chetwold, on Bellevue Avenue, for the season.

It is just as well that Russia has reconsidered its order that correspondents sending war news from Oriental waters by wireless telegraph will be treated as spies and shot, at least in so far as to announce that it is not to be enforced at once. In fact, it is astonishing that the pronunciamento was ever issued, for there are many reasons why it never would be carried out.

Business upon the Stock Exchange was more cheerful yesterday. Consolidated Gas is the chief and almost the sole exception to the rule of better prices among active properties. As this highly flavored specialty was unable to communicate its own strength to a market otherwise weak, so yesterday it was unable to communicate its weakness to a market resolved to improve.

Mrs. Elizabeth Morton, the widow of Dr. W.T.G. Morton, discoverer of anesthesia, died yesterday noon at the Hotel Martha Washington of pneumonia, following an illness of more than a year. Mrs. Morton's maiden name was Elizabeth Whitman. She was a daughter of Edward Whitman and Almira Olmstead, and was born in 1826 in Farmington, Conn.

The paper read by Prof. CRITTENDEN of Yale before the National Academy of Sciences at Washington was an effort to establish by clinical records, or their equivalent, the thesis that the average human being eats too much. The professor's conclusion appears to have been that the average healthy man eats from two to three times as much food as he needs to keep him in perfect mental health and vigor.
" I've gone out of season with the oyster," was the announcement made by Police Commissioner McAdoo yesterday afternoon.

The special meeting of the Northern Securities Company's stockholders to vote on the method of distributing the Northern Pacific and Great Northern stock against which Northern Securities stock had been issued was held at the offices of the company, in Hoboken, yesterday morning.

LONDON, April 21. -- The British Government is giving careful consideration to the Russian edict in reference to the use of wireless telegraphy by war correspondents in the Far East. Whether it has made any representations to Russia in the nature of a protest against her line of action it is impossible to state at this moment, but if such representations have not yet been made, it is quite likely that they will be made.
LONDON, April 21. -- Supplies of money in the market to-day were plethoric, notwithstanding the fact that repayments to the Bank of England reduced the supplies. Discounts were weak.

CINCINNATI, April 21. -- Kate Claxton received word of her son's suicide just as she was to go on in her role in "The Two Orphans" at the matinee at Robinson's Opera House this afternoon. She immediately collapsed. Mary Stewart Cone, wife of Spencer H. Cone, a brother of Miss Claxton, and her manager, hastily assumed the part. The audience was not informed until the close of the play of Miss Claxton's bereavement.

About 11 o'clock last night a young man who is said to be a clerk employed by counsel for Banker David Rothschild, entered the Rothschild apartments in the Ansonia, with keys that he had in his possession. Shortly after, he reappeared with a large bundle of letters and papers which are thought to be documents of importance in the bank case.

WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The resolution by Representative Goldfogle of New York to secure the recognition of United States passports when presented by American citizens in Russia without regard to their religious faith was adopted by the House to-day without dissent, having been unanimously recommended by the Foreign Affairs Committee.

Though the net results of a fire at 67 Bowery yesterday were confined to fifty narrow escapes and damages aggregating $15,000, the blaze caused inconvenience to thousands of people scattered along the east side from the City Hall to Harlem, and the immediate neighborhood was thrown into a state of wild excitement.

The rushing and tackling at the bargain counters in the Brooklyn department stores was tame and gentle yesterday afternoon, many of the most expert tackles and rushers being absent. They were at the Bedford Avenue Municipal Court, where Justice Van Wart was getting kinks in his thinking apparatus trying to settle a case of "far-reaching importance" in the bargain-hunting world.
Honey on call loaned at 1 1/4 per cent. Time money rates, 2 1/2 per cent. for sixty to ninety days, 3@3 1/4 per cent. for four months, 3 1/2@4 per cent. for five to six months.

PALMA, Majorca, April 21. -- An unpleasant incident occurred here to-day. Vice Admiral Lord Charles Beresford, commanding the Channel Squadron, with a number of British officers, landed for the purpose of accompanying King Alfonso, but they were unable to find seats with the royal suite.
LOS ANGELES. April 21. -- E.H. Harriman to-day refused to discuss in any way the distribution of the Northern Securities Company's stock.
" I don't intend to express a preference for any candidate," says Mr. BRYAN. "I have not in the past declared for any, and I shall not on Saturday night."
FORTRESS MONROE, Va., April 21. -- Gov. Odell, chatting this morning at the Hotel Chamberlin, said that he would return to Albany Tuesday and consider the so-called "grab" bills.

-- We notice with an amusement which, while it is entirely sincere, is yet just a little haggard and wan, that one of our young men, in recording the arrival in this country of his Grace the Duke of Newcastle, was moved to mark him for identification, as it were, by describing him as "brother of Lord FRANCIS HOPE, MAY YOHE'S ex-husband."

The east side in the vicinity of Avenue C and Second Street was flooded for several hours yesterday afternoon by thousands of gallons of water which issued from a break in the great ten-inch water main at the crossing of those streets. The asphalt sidewalk for many yards about the break was undermined, and adjacent cellars were flooded.

The marital troubles of Mme. Lillian Nordica, the prima donna, and her ex-husband, Zoltan Doehme, were aired in court yesterday morning, when argument was had before Justice MacLean on Mr. Doehme's motion to have the interlocutory decree of divorce recently awarded to Mme. Nordica set aside.
Secretary of War Taft was the guest of honor of the Chamber of Commerce at its monthly meeting yesterday and delivered an address on conditions in the Philippine Islands.

BOSTON, April 21. -- By an overwhelming vote the Massachusetts Democratic Convention at Tremont Temple to-day elected and instructed four delegates at large and the twenty-eight delegates from the various Congressional districts of the State to support Richard Olney of this city for the Presidential nomination at the Democratic Convention in St. Louis next July.
The Republicans in the anti-canal counties of the State are preparing to oppose the candidacy of Mayor Erastus C. Knight of Buffalo for the Republican nomination for Governor.

MAN kGUA. Nicaragua. AIrll 21. -- The fishing schooners captured recently while in Nicaraguan waters and taken to Blueields had hoisted the British flag on one of the small islands off Cape Gracias-a-Dios. Nicaragua.

One has to compliment the Mormon witnesses in the case of REED SMOOT, including that candidate himself, upon their apparent truthfulness and candor. They appear to be men of too much intelligence not to know the meaning and effect of the admissions they make about the connection of a theocratic oligarchy with the State of Utah.

HAMPTON, Va., April 21. -- The educators from various States who make up the company traveling through the South in Robert C. Ogden's special train were presented today to the class that will be graduated in June from Hampton Institute.

DENVER, April 21. -- President Charles H. Moyer of the Western Federation of Miners, who arrived in Denver to-day in custody of State troops after several week's incarceration at Telluride, where martial law is in force in consequence of labor troubles, was taken before the State Supreme Court this afternoon under the writ of habeas corpus which had been issued in his case.

Your story of a day's experience with one of the Building Inspectors, which appeared in to-day's issue of THE TIMES, is most interesting, particularly as it deals frankly with the situation in the Bureau of Buildings from the standpoint of the rank and file employed therein.
LONDON, April 22. -- According to reports in the Russian press, say The Times's Russian correspondents, Gen. Linevitch is keeping a strict watch on the behavior of the Chinese troops.

The meeting in London to discuss an international agreement as to the export price of steel either means a great deal more than appears upon the surface or it is practically without significance. It is said to be a secret conference of the steelmakers of the world, to arrange for the reservation of home markets, the fixing of uniform export prices, and the prevention of what is known as "dumping."

ST. PETERSBURG, April 21. -- The last document left by Baron Toll, the arctic explorer, from whom nothing has been heard directly since he left the yacht Zaria in 1902 and started for Bennett Island, and who is reported to have perlished in the Arctic Ocean, has been found by Lieut. Kolchak. It is dated at Paul Keppan Bay, Bennett Island, Nov. 11, 1902, and is as follows:

WALTHAM, Mass., April 21. -- Charles L. Tucker, accused of the murder of Mabel Page at Weston on March 31, was brought here from Cambridge to-day for an adjourned hearing in the Police Court. When the doors were opened the room in which the proceedings were to be held and all approaches were choked by the assembled throng.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 21. -- The season of open golf tournaments in the metropolitan district formally opened to-day with the Spring tournament of the Country Club of Lakewood. The representative golfers of the East met here, and eighty-four players drove off from the first tee. Pleasant, sunny weather favored the players and a large gallery of visitors followed the contestants.

Following the announcement that two Bellevue Hospital doctors had contracted tuberculosis as a result of their work in the institution, it became known last night that no less than twenty internes at the same hospital had fallen victims to the disease in the past. In no case, it appears, was the public allowed to become alarmed by hearing of the state of affairs.
WASHINGTON, April 21. -- The House today passed the bill providing a temporary government for the Panama Canal zone after it had been criticised roundly for the power it gives the President.

The bill relating to Chinese exclusion adopted by the House last Monday as a portion of the General Deficiency Appropriation act, without consideration even by any committee, marks the uttermost limits to which demagogic legislation can be carried. Under cover of merely continuing existing law radical changes in the law have been made.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 21, -- The British cruiser Retribution, which, under instructions from the Imperial Government, sailed from Kingston April 11 for a Nicaraguan port in connection with the seizure of six Cayman turtle schooners and the arrest of their crews by Nicaraguan officials, returned to Port Royal from the Nicaraguan coast to-day, after ascertaining that the vessels and crews had been sent to Bluefields.

CHICAGO, April 21. -- For several hours to-day Chief Sanitary Inspector Charles B. Hall defied the Health Commissioner of Chicago and Judge Elbridge Hanecy of the Superior Court. Only when Judge Hanecy was on the point of taking summary action for contempt did the disposed official obey the court and surrender office.

CUMBERLAND, Md., April 21. -- A sensation was caused here this evening by the announcement that the Grand Jury had indicted Mayor Warren C. White for malfeasance. The indictment grows out of an investigation urged by Judge Boyd.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 21. -- In a telegram to the Emperor, Gen. Kuropatkin says:

I am a subscriber to your paper, and as a resident for many years of New York City, I feel I am entitled to a "fair play" notice in your columns. I have read many spiteful and unfair statements made in regard to the President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and I can not refrain from making this statement.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 22. -- Through the influence of President Palma of Cuba, Sir William Van Horne, head of the Canadian Pacific and President of the Havana and Santiago Railroad, is about to close a deal for the purchase of the old Viebac Penitentiary, located opposite Morro Castle, at the entrance of Havana Harbor, for the erection of a hotel that will cost $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Judge O.W. Powers, formerly an Associate Justice of the Utah Supreme Court, was the only witness in the Smoot hearing to-day, and he proved a brilliant and impressive one. He was asked to relate from his own knowledge and observation what he knew of the action of the Mormon Church in politics in the last twenty years.

Charles M. Skinner, author of "Myths and Legends of Our Own Land," , in his new book, "Little Gardens," treats of the garden from the point of view of the man who must confine his ambitions to a city yard or other small space. He writes in his brief preface:
LONDON, April 22. -- They say that the late Dr. Samuel Smiles, renowned as the author of "Self Help," left his "Reminiscences" in manuscript, and that the book will soon be published.

There was a good bit of talk among Stock Exchange members yesterday about the stories current that the handbook gentry who have been operating in the put-and-call market in New Street and on the Broad Street curb, had extended their activities within the sacred portals of the Exchange Building itself.

It is interesting to compare Mr. Wagner's suggestions for the exaltation of family life with Mrs. Gilman's racy arraignment of the home as it is and her ideas for its betterment. According to Mrs. Gilman the ideal home is by way of being attained through entirely new domestic machinery. She would dispense with the family kitchen, and even, if our memory serves us, with the dining room.

Prof. Curtis Hidden Page and Adolphe Cohn, both of Columbia University, are to edit for G.P. Putnam's Sons a series of French translations called "French Classics for English Readers." The first group of six volumes will be from Rabelais, Montaigne, Moliere, (two volumes) Beaumarchais, and George Sand.

ROCKHILL, S.C., April 22. -- After two days at Hampton the Robert C. Ogden party, bound for the Southern Educational Conference, to be held at Birmingham, stopped here this morning to visit the Winthrop Normal and Industrial College of South Carolina.

BALTIMORE, April 22. -- In a runaway and collision of vehicles in Druid Hill Park this evening Dr. Hiram Woods, a well-known oculist, was seriously injured; his brother, the Rev. F.C. Woods of Morristown, N.J., was cut about the head and bruised, and Miss Minnie Brooks, prominent in society and an expert horsewoman and cross country rider, was also hurt, her head and face being lacerated.

A year ago to-day, upon the morrow of the dedication of the new Stock Exchange, there was a volume of a half million shares, but within a very short space it was a stock jest that the gorgeous building, with its small dealings, resembled a handsome table with a scant menu.

If one could only sit down with Elizabeth in her German Garden and have a laugh over the seriousness with which she has been taken by some of the correspondents of THE TIMES BOOK REVIEW! We dearly love a laugh, and it is so amusing that Elizabeth should be taken to task, ethically, for her fun. And may we ask what sort of guest was the one she teased a little?

The Stateman's Year-Book for 1904 is now ready at the Macmillan Company's. Besides bringing the statistics down to 1904, the editors have taken that section devoted to the See and Church of Rome from under Italy and put it into a place by itself, while, instead of a brief resume of the late Pontiff's career is that of Pope Pius X., who was Giuseppe Sarto.

A two-alarm fire, which caused damage estimated at $20,000, occurred at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the brick five-story double tenement 1,716 and 1,718 Second Avenue, and was subdued after an hour and a half of good work by firemen under Acting Battalion Chief Martin, during which the members of Truck 13 effected several rescues.

LAKEWOOD, April 22. -- John D. Rockefeller has introduced a novelty in the way of caddies -- not collie dogs, such as they use down in Philadelphia, but little girls. Mr. Rockefeller always has a plenty of caddies, and for a time after his return from the South he employed four boys, two to carry his large assortment of clubs and two to chase the balls.

ITHACA, April 22. -- In the memory of undergraduates Cornell crew affairs have never been so mixed up before as they are now. The trouble is the talk of the campus. The first misunderstanding came last Winter when Courtney refused to appear at the crew room. Insisting that he should be given full power to choose his assistant.
PARIS, April 22. -- The United States Embassy is making urgent representations to secure the release of Henry Iselin, a prominent American living here and highly connected in New York.

Bidders on the next rapid transit subway, which is now under consideration by the Rapid Transit Commission as to route, will be compelled by the board to bid for the work in sections, so that the Metropolitan and the Belmont interests may be able to show by their bids the advantages they can offer by having their own ideas carried out by the city.

Leopold Weil has sold for Boehm Coon 51 and 53 Maiden Lane, a twelve-story office building, on a plot of about 7,000 square feet, to Edward A. Schmidt of Philadelphia. In part payment Boehm Coon take the Carnegie Hill Hotel, at the northeast corner of Ninety-second Street and Madison Avenue.

SEOUL, April 19, (Via Shanghai, April 22.) -- The belief is general here that no attempt will be made to cross the Yalu River before the end of this week, by which time the arrangements for a concerted Japanese movement, a simultaneous rush toward the river from three points, will have been perfected.

The often repeated and as oft denied reports that "Joe" Weber and "Lew" Fields, who have for several years been partners in their Broadway Dutch dialect theatre, were to part company at the close of the present season were confirmed last evening by the announcement that a new theatre was to be built for Fields at Broadway and Forty-third Street.

Assistant District Attorney Kresel said yesterday that another important arrest in connection with the wrecking of the Federal Bank and the Globe Securities Company might be looked for to-day. David Rothschild, the former President of the bank and the promoter of the Globe Company, is now in the Tombs on a charge of having stolen $200,000 of the funds of the Federal Bank.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The determination of the House Judiciary Committee to learn whether or not Representative William R. Hearst can make a speech resulted in that statesman's appearance before it to-day. Wednesday the committee sent Mr. Hearst a written invitation to appear to-day and explain his resolution calling on the Department of Justice to produce within five days the evidence submitted by Mr. Hearst against the coal-carrying roads.

In a decision written by Judge Byron S. Walte, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Aitken, Son Co. of New York against the inclusion of an item of commission in the dutiable value of goods. The merchandise was invoiced by Gillette Co. of Paris, who are described as agents of the purchasers.

Mr. O'Connor's article in review of the Autobiography of Herbert Spencer, which we publish this week, points out clearly its inevitable defects (from the literary point of view,) as well its many merits. It is not, as the reviewer expresses it, "good literature"; in all its pages "no person or event is quickened into a reality." As a revelation of self, even, the work is "vague and abstract."

IT is not strange that the author of the article entitled "A Limited Philosopher" should condemn Spencer's judgments on poetry and art. Influenced by distinctly literary ideas, as Spencer is by those distinctively scientific, his critic is naturally precluded from comprehending sympathetically, or even tolerantly, the "anfractuosities" of the philosopher's intellect.

CHICAO, April 22. -- Each wearing a red rose, Chicago's three car-barn bandits were hanged this morning. Peter Niedermeyer, the leader of the gang, who had boasted that he would cheat the gallows, and nearly succeeded in doing so, was the first to die, at 10:35 o'clock. He was in a state of collapse, and had to be carried to the scaffold.
WASHINGTON, April 22. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of William Miller Collier of New York to be Solicitor for the Department of Commerce and Labor.

LONDON, April 23. -- The Times publishes an article by Edouard Naville and H.R. Hall, in which they announce the discovery, through the excavations on behalf of the Egypt Exploration Fund, of the most ancient shrine yet uncovered at Thebes.

G P. PUTNAM'S SONS will publish anonymously the first week in May the "Jessica Letters," which have appeared serially in The Critic. This is the correspondence between a Northern editor and a Southern woman.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 22. -- The Emperor has received the following telegram from Viceroy Alexieff, bearing to-day's date:

There is in course of publication, If the publication be not already completed, a "Library of Literary Criticism in English." Certainly there are extant of it four stout volumes, bringing it down to 1824 only. At this, necessarily, "humanity shudders," and that merely from a view of the backs of the volumes, and without any reference to the manner in which the work is done.

After nearly a month of negotiation the trouble between the Elevator Constructors' Union and the Elevator Manufacturers' Association, which caused a general strike about a month ago for an advance in wages, was settled yesterday evening by arbitration at the Building Trades Club.

Again yesterday prices, in the stock market advanced while transactions decreased. A good deal was made of the manner in whlch many issues rose despite the weakness in Steel preferred, but it was evident that although prices went up easily the advance did not bring in new buyers. The market in gdining in strength lost in activity.

Police Commissioner McAdoo yesterday afternoon issued a statement in regard to his position with respect to match baseball games on Sunday. The Commissioner will allow games to be played in isolated neighborhoods, but will not permit ball games at either of the league grounds in Manhattan. He explains his decision against Sunday baseball as follows:

Whether there is any connection between the popularity of Josephine Daskam's "Memoirs of a Baby" and a new baby book about to be published by Messrs. Harper Brothers is a question which may be left to the wise. The point is that the new baby book entitled "Bruver Jim's Baby," is by a man.

WE are enabled this week, in chronicling some recent achievements in the way of humorous writing, to contrast the imaginative English small boy of Kenneth Grahame's delightful "Golden Age" with the unimaginative small boy of J.J. Bell's sketches of Glasgow domestic life.

Sir Robert Ciffen, K.C.B., author of "Essays in Finance," "The Case Against Bimetallism," , has collected a number of essays, most of them "written at intervals during a period of more than thirty years," into two volumes, which the Macmillan Company bring out in this country under the title, "Economic Inquiries and Studies."

The English political system is often praised as the most rational provision for the expression of the popular will known to the world, but it is full of extraordinary anomalies that would drive the logical mind to despair.

Regarding the statements in your last two issues suggesting neglect by the State Banking Department in respect of the Federal Rank, I was interested less than a year go in a much more flagrant instance of neglect by the same department, (if such a mild word as neglect describes it,) prominently brought to public notice by the failure of the New York Building Loan Banking Company.

I have followed with much interest the letters in THE BOOK REVIEW about "Elizabeth and Her German Garden " -- her husband, her babies, her neighbors, and -- above all -- her visitors. It seems to me that one point has been overlooked in all the letters, viz., the behavior of the visitor most often mentioned -- Medora -- and that of the unwelcome companion in the car seat.
If the titling of your leading editorial in the issue of April 16 applies to Spencer and is created from the arguments set forth in the same, may I make a few notes on it?
ST. PETERSBURG, April 22. -- The following telegram from Viceroy Aliexeff has been received by the Emperor:

MR. R. LOGAN JACK'S somewhat original title. "The Back Blocks of China," has little to do with the obstructions which might have been put in his way, but has reference to remote portions of China, through which the traveler rarely passes, though some portions of them are mentioned by that wonderful man, Marco Polo Mr. Jack's original business in China was that of a mining engineer.

The election of Senor MARISCAL of Mexico to the newly created office of Vice President of the Republic is an answer to the question constantly asked by foreigners as well as Mexicans, Who will succeed PORFIRIO DIAZ if he should resign or die? Old Gen. REYES, now Governor of Nuevo Leon, who at one time had supporters in the Mexican press gifted with more audacity than tact, may be regarded as excluded from the succession.

For the next ten years, if the plans of the architects are approved, the City of New York will be building in installments the greatest hospital in the world. The cost of the enormous structure, containing twelve pavilions and embodying all the appropriate improvements of modern science, will be $11,000,000 -- something less than one-third the price paid for the underground railroad from the City Hall to the Bronx.

Following the news, made public yesterday, that Capt. John J. Healey, until recently the President of the Central Alaska Exploration Company, had been arrested in Chicago charged with stealing $8,000 of the company's funds, a receiver in supplementary proceedings was appointed for Samuel E. Adair, Secretary and Treasurer of the company.

Mrs. Margaret E. Sangster contributes the introduction to "Presiding Ladies the White House," by Lila G.A. Woohall, (large square octavo; heavy glazed paper; pp. 137; illustrated and decorated. Washington, D.C.: Bureau of National Literature and Art.) The volume contains biographical appreciations of the twenty-five ladies who have presided at the White House, from Martha Washington down to Mrs. Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Senator Depew and Mrs. Depew entertained this evening at a dinner party and reception in honor of the Senator's seventieth birthday, which finds him as well and strong as most men twenty years his junior.

In view of the near approach of the Exposition at St. Louis distinctly commemorating the acquisition of the French claims in the Mississippi Valley the "State Papers and Correspondence Bearing Upon the Purchase of the Territory of Louisiana," published by Congress, will be of general interest.

WALTHAM, Mass., April 22. -- Charles L. Tucker, charged with the murder of Mabel Page at Weston on the last day of March, was to-day held for the Grand Jury by Judge Enos T. Luce of the Waltham District Court. He was remanded to the East Cambridge Jail pending the sitting of the Grand Jury, which is scheduled to convene the second Monday in June.

Senator SCOTT at present holds the unquestioned record as a pension boomer. His remark, in the Senate on Thursday, was that if he had his way he "would pay a pension of $25 a month to every soldier, whatever his term of service, and whether he was rich or poor." We had no notion that the G.A.R. was so important a factor in the politics of West Virginia.

Herbert L. Osgood, Ph. D., Professor of History in Columbia University, has in press at the Macmillan Company a work on "The American Colonies in the Seventeenth Century." Volumes I. and II., the first installments of the work, will very shortly appear under the sub-title "The Chartered Colonies: Beginnings of Self-Government."

Is not the ghostly "Pot of Tulips" mentioned by W.P. Colegate in your issue of this date among the stories by Fitz James O' Brien originally printed to Harper's Magazine and publishes in book form under the title of "The Diamond Lens"?

William O. McDowell, in his office 51 Liberty Street, has within the week called into being new order -- an order destined soon to number, if Mr. McDowell's hopes are realized, 25,000 members, who will constitute "the strongest body of people intellectually, taking them all in all, that the world has ever known."

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Griffith's New York American League baseball team defeated the Washingtons this afternoon in a game full of excellent fielding, and which was notable for the magnificent pitching of Chesbro. In the first inning Selbach drove a single past Ganzel, but after that not a Senator could reach first base, except McCormick, who got his base twice, getting to third the first time and out at first the other.

An attempt is being made by those interested in the Irish literary movement to bring before the public a volume in which the reading public will get some idea of what has been written in Ireland for Ireland. The book will be entitled "Irish Voices: A Miscellany by Living Writers," and will be edited, with an introduction and biographical notes, by D.J. O'Donoghue, author of "Life of Mangan," "The Poets of Ireland,"

BOSTON, April 22. -- The Brooklyns played real championship ball to-day and scored six runs to two for Boston. Besides being hit hard and often Fisher was quite wild, giving five men bases on called balls. Jones pitched steadily and kept the Boston hits well scattered. Sheckard gave an excellent exhibition of fielding, a, difficult running catch being a feature of the game.

But for the effect upon the miners in other localities and the encouragement it gives to lawlessness generally in connection with the plans and purposes of organized labor, the disturbance at Garrett, Somerset County, Penn., would be of very little consequence. The mines affected are relatively small and the trouble is local.

The dominant impression left by this remarkable novel is that of the essential oneness of humanity. Change the names and the externals of the characters, and their passions, their emotions, their ambitions, are all those of our Western world. The great apostle was literally a seer when he declared that God "hath made of one blood all nations of men."

The biographies of Abraham Lincoln, by Dr. Ellis P. Oberholtzer, and Thomas H. Benton, by Joseph M. Rogers, the well-known writer on historical subjects, to appear this Fall, will be the first to be issued in the American Crisis Series of Biographies. They will be followed by twenty-three others and all together will give a history of the civil war and the causes that led up to it.

Right you are in saying in "Topics of the Times" in yesterday's issue of your paper that the explanation of the world "aleatory," as given by The Brooklyn Eagle, has "an especial flavor" about it -- yes, its flavor grows out of its very in voluteness -- it is of the earth earthy, clear as mud.

Two points were brought out very clearly by Secretary TAFT in his admirable address to the Chamber of Commerce upon the Philippines. One was the fidelity with which the policy of the Government has been directed to the advancement of the Filipinos and the other was the present condition and the promise for the future of the industry and trade of the islands.

The fifth and last volume of the Rev. Dr. J. Franck Bright's "History of England," dealing with "Imperial Reaction: Victoria, 1880-1901," Is published by Longmans, Green Co. The author tells in his preface why he has written this volume, treating us it does of events of such recent date:

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- An unusual incident took place in the Senate to-day. The usages and "courtesies" of the Senate are regarded with as great reverence as the Constitution, and infraction of either creates a sensation. To-day both were violated.
WASHINGTON, April 22. --President Roosevelt was assailed bitterly in the House to-day by Claude Kitchin of North Carolina, who included in his castigation Gen. Grosvenor.
Charles Scribner's Sons have sent to press for the second time Robert Louis Stevenson's "Prayers Written at Vailima."

There is no reason why one should not become familiar with the works of the old masters these days. Cheap prints of well-known masterpieces are to be had at prices within the reach of every one. Especially good is the series being issued by A.W. Elson Co. of Boston. There are thirty reproductions in all of Renaissance paintings of Italy, classified and inclosed in three separate portfollos.
In "The Wood-Carver of 'Lympus" things happen as they used to do in the good old story-book land, when authors were given to painting life as we should like to have it, rather than as it is.

MR. BENSON'S contribution to the English Men of Letters Series is a sound and discriminating, thoroughly sympathetic account of one of the most remarkable men in the range of Victorian literature and art.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- At one of the stormiest sessions in its history the thirteenth annual congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution to-day adopted a report which vindicates Miss Harriet Baird Huey. The case is the famous controversy between Miss Huey and Mrs. Thomas Roberts, both of Philadelphia.

A gentleman who proclaims himself a retail bookseller, (and an old one, at that,) writes to us complaining of a certain deficiency in current criticism of contemporary fiction, to wit, a lack of commercial prescience. A merchant, he argues, "should know the quality of his goods in order to inform his customers to their satisfaction regarding them."

PARIS, April 22. -- I find on inquiry in different quarters that there is no reason to apprehend that China intends to abandon the neutral attitude she has observed since the commencement of the war. It is difficult to say what has given rise to the disquieting rumors to that effect.
A Chinaman of the real chop suey variety went into the drug store at the corner of Thirtieth Street and Broadway yesterday afternoon.

With the announcement yesterday afternoon that he had approved the Remsen East River Gas bill, Mayor McClellan filed a memorandum in which he explained his reasons for approving the measure, after showing unmistakable signs of hostility to it a week before when it came into his hands.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 22. -- In the steeplechase at Cumberland Park to-day, Pierce, who was riding Snow Drift, was unseated and thrown at the second jump. He has not yet regained consciousness, and the physicians state that his chances for recovery are slight, as former injuries to his ribs were renewed by the fall, and it is believed the broken bones are pressing on his heart.

Allegations that many pieces of mail addressed to her, which contained either checks, money orders, or express receipts, had never been received, and that several pieces containing checks which had been sent out by her had never reached their desination, were made yesterday by Miss M. Helen E. Montfort of 307 Lenox Avenue.

This book is a biographical and autobiographical appreciation, the tribute of admiration and affection of one sanguine, zealous, active man for another whom the author describes with all the frank devotion of the hero worshipper for qualities that are common to both men, with almost identical ideals, with like conceptions of public responsibility and duty, and with similar convictions about the importance of promptly "doing things" that ought, in their judgment, to be done.

NO one bears the slightest ill-will to Mr. Austin Dobson, and every one wishes him well. But when Mr. Balfour out of the small sum of 12,000, which is the fund from which civil service pensions are allotted to needy authors, gives Mr. Dobson a pension of 80 a year, there is a general feeling that such a pension is out of proportion to the necessities of the case.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- "Going to resign are you?" said Assistant Postmaster General Wynne to an indignant person who had been pouring his grief into his ears. "Can't stand it another minute, eh? Put up with it as long as you could, and now you're going to throw up your job and tell your chief what you think of him? Yes, I know. Last straw and all that sort of thing? Uh-huh.

I am one of the many lovers of Herbert Spencer's writings, and consider him among the foremost philosophers of all time. Even when my deepest instincts impel me to reject some of his speculations and many of his deductions, there is a power in his intellectual grasp and a charm in the lucidity of his statements, which are to me the finest of mental tonics and delights.
PARIS, April 22. -- The Associated Press is authoriized to announce that the contract by which the ownership of the Panama Canal passes to the United States is signed, sealed, delivered and complete.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 22. -- A tragedy, the far-reaching consequences of which cannot now easily be determined, was brought to light to-day by the following advertisement which appeared in a local paper:

I am sorry to see that you persist in countenancing our Government's un-American and Un-Christian policy in the Philippine. How you can reconcile your imperialistic ideas with the confidence you seem to feel in Judge Parker's election, should he be nominated, is more than I can comprehend.

THERE never was a historic incident more momentous than the discomfiture of the Spanish Armada. The decline of Spain dates from that eventful year, 1588. What Mr. Beckles Willson, the author of "Ledger and Sword," calls the "Elizabethan prologue" to the conquest of India now took place, and in a most original and unexpected manner.

A problem in plagiarism and the duty of folk in love is the appropriate theme of this novel of Harvard life. The plagiarist, who is an assistant professor of Scottish descent, is described by a picturesque Cambridge spinster as "a judicious mixture of Phoebus Apollo and Ralph Waldo Emerson."

A novel point in customs law has just been raised by Albert Comstock, counsel for Albert Lorsch Co., in a protest now under consideration by Gen. T.S. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers against the assessment of 60 per cent. duty on certain imitation precious stones as decorated glass.

MILWAUKEE, April 23. -- No changes will be made in the music of American Catholic churches for the present. This may be stated as the conclusion reached at a meeting of the Archbishops of the country at Washington this week upon the authority of Archbishop Messmer of Milwaukee, who returned from the council to-day.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 23. -- The first of the bicentenary celebration of the Church of St. George of Hempstead was held here to-day. The celebration was one of the most important events in the history of the Long Island Episcopal diocese.

The starting point of railroad construction in Russia was about 1843, but the building of the trunk lines dates back to the decade between 1860 and 1870. During this period lines were built connecting each of the more important southern seaports with the agricultural provinces. At this point the Russo-Turkish war of 1878-9 caused an almost entire suspension of railway building.

ABOUT the year 1869 the writer became confident that he possessed the best bird dogs in the world and the best-broken ones. Indeed, they were such as would give a seven-day clock a lesson in regularity. Their automatic rigidity in the presence of game the wonder of all beholders, so that it was resolved they must have new worlds to conquer.

LONDON, April 23. -- At Bow Street Police Court to-day Henry Slater, head of the best-known private detective agency in England, was held in heavy bail, charged with conspiring to pervert the due course of justice. With him in the dock were Albert Osborne, his lawyer, and two private detectives employed by Slater.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- William J. Bryan addressed a large audience to-night in the Armory of the Second Infantry, at the corner of Curtis Street and Washington Boulevard. The place was packed to its utmost capacity, and a large number of people were unable to get through the doors.

The fuel industry always furnishes material of interest for the very good reason that it is the basis of the prosperity of the country. Trade may be quoted dull at times, but there is always progress made in the aggregate movement, and it may surprise many people to hear that this country is now a hundred million tons ahead of Great Britain's output annually.

The wonderful performances of Ralph D. Rose, student at the University of Michigan, in putting the twelve-pound and sixteen-pound shot, has produced a general feeling in the West that the extent of the powers of the eighteen-year-old California lad has not yet been reached. It is not in this specialty alone that Rose has shown the quality that goes toward the making of a successful all-around, athlete.

TROY, Ala., April 23. -- The Robert C. Ogden party arrived in their private train at Chehaw, Ala., shortly after midnight this morning, and after breakfast the remaining six miles to Tuskegee were traveled.

BOSTON, April 23. -- The death at Rome of Richard Saltonstall Greenough, an American sculptor, was announced here to-day in a cable message received from Italy. Mr. Greenough was born in Roxbury eighty-five years ago.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- One man was killed, another fatally wounded, and a third severely injured in a fight between watchmen and thieves in the stock yards tonight. The dead man is Arthur Clemons, a watchman, who was instantly killed.

Dispatches from Paris published in Wall Street last week stated that a movement was afoot to place on the list of the Paris Bourse a number of American stocks, it being added that certain important financial interests thought the time might be propitious for the successful inauguration of such a movement. What interests were referred to does not seem very clear.

With Leo Ditrichstein as her chief supporter, Elizabeth Tyree will appear at the Savoy Theatre to-morrow night in "Tit for Tat." The play was adapted by Mr. Ditrichstein from "Heureuse," by Maurice Hennequin and Paul Bilhand. As in the case of all French plays that are translated into English, there have been many excisions for the benefit of supposed Anglo-Saxon strictures.

Van Cortlandt Park was a veritable sportsman's paradise yesterday. The golf links, which have been closed for over a month, undergoing repairs to the tees and the greens, were thrown open for play, and several hundred lovers of the old Scotch game, including both men and women, seized the opportunity to get back into practice.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 23. -- Automobiles are upsetting some of the oldest customs hedging the royal family, and the heir apparent to the throne and many members of the imperial family now dash about St. Petersburg without the slightest token to indicate their rank.

The opening of the footpath across the Williamsburg Bridge yesterday was unattended by any ceremony whatsoever. There were no city officials present, no music, and only Roundsman Dinnin and Policeman Coleman to keep the crowds in order.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23. -- Scientific methods, suggestive of those of Sherlock Holmes, are being used with great care by Dr. Henderson of the Yale Medical School in an effort to trace the mysterious person who committed a murderous assault Thursday night on Augusta Petersen, a servant employed at the Henderson residence on Prospect Hill.

A general strike of garment workers throughout the country against the open shop, involving at least 100,000 workers directly and 250,000 workers indirectly, has, at the last moment, been postponed, at least for a time. This strike had been actually ordered by the General Executive Board of the United Garment Workers and was to have gone into effect to-morrow.

PARIS, April 23. -- With only five dissenting votes the stockholders of the Panama Canal Company ratified the transfer of the canal to the United States to-day. The announcement of the vote brought out loud applause.

LONDON, April 13. -- London audiences had a chance a few days ago to pass judgment on a play which Americans have already seen and liked, and, for some reason or other, the English critics quite disagreed with the Americans. The play was "The Sword of the King," in which Henrietta Crosman was the New York star.

E.H. Sothern plays at the Montauk Theatre in Brooklyn for one week, beginning to-morrow. His play is still "The Proud Prince." After his Brooklyn engagement he begins a tour to the Pacific Coast, Mr. Sothern's season closes at Helena, Mon., July 15. Then he will take a pleasure trip through Yellowstone Park, returning to New York in time to begin rehearsals for the Shakespearian repertoire with Miss Julia Marlowe.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Ex-Judge Orlando W. Powers, a prominent Democratic leader of Utah, was the only witness to-day before the Senate committee that is investigating the Smoot case. His testimony dealt largely with the industrial side of the activity of the Mormon Church, declaring that the Church was, in fact, a trust that operated and controlled valuable industrial and commercial enterprises.

Attention is attracted to New York as a strawberry market by the announcement that the Florida crop has all been shipped. New York, it is said, consumes fully 20, 000,000 quarts of strawberries every year. They begin with Floridas which are usually here for Christmas and sell at $1 a box at wholesale.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 23. -- Willis D. Noxon, a well-known lawyer and yachtsman, was drowned shortly before 7 o'clock to-night in Echo Bay, from his schooner yacht Ellen. Mr. Noxon had spent the Winter on his yacht crusing in Porto Rican waters, and arrived here ten days ago. Since his arrival he has made his home aboard the yacht with his brother, Charles H. Noxon.
THOMAS W. LAWSON has sent out a neat card with a black border, on which it says:

The silk trade of the United States has been very much surprised by your publication of the 21st instant attributing certain statements regarding the present condition of the industry to Jacques Huber of Schwarzenbach, Huber Co., 472 Doome Street, this city. There are a number of inaccuracies in the statement attributed to Mr. Huber.

LONDON, April 23. -- The abundance of money in the market tends to keep discount rates easy, though they stiffened somewhat to-day in consequence of the Russian loan rumors. Business on the Stock Exchange is suffering from week-end slackness and the nearness of the settlement. Consols were fairly steady, though a fraction lower, owing to exchanging into the new Indian loan.

WEST POINT, April 23. -- In the baseball game to-day Harvard defeated the Cadets by the score of 12 to 3. Coburn, for the visitors, only allowed four hits throughout the game. Last year the soldiers knocked him out of the box in the fourth inning. Carter started the game for the Cadets, but was replaced by Herring in the middle of the second inning.

NEWARK, N.J., April 23. -- Two firemen were killed and seventeen others were injured at a fire that caused a loss of $73,000 at 87 and 89 Mechanic Street early this morning. At least two of the men are fatally hurt.

WASHINGTON, D.C., April 23. -- Threatening weather kept the attendance down to-day at the game between the New York Americans and Washingtons, but those in attendance saw a cleverly played contest, barring the mistakes of Stahl and Conroy. For six innings the home players acquitted themselves creditably and led by a score of 3 to 2.

Frederick W. Johnson of 2,041 Seventh Avenue has filed a petition in bankruptcy, individually and as a partner in the firm of Seymour, Johnson Co., stock brokers, formerly at 71 Broadway, who failed four years ago, with total liabilities of $435,007, of which $8,595 are individual debts, and no assets.

SOME details of the equipment of the steamer Haimun with the De Forest wireless apparatus, by means of which some remarkable dispatches have been transmitted from the Far East to The London Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES, are supplied by Dr. Lee De Forest, the inventor of the system.

Daniel Holihan was driving his hansom cab, carrying two women, up Broadway yesterday afternoon, when at Forty-first Street the girth strap of the horse parted. Up went the shafts in the air and down on its back fell the hansom. Holihan was hurled a dozen feet across the street and received a scalp wound and numerous cuts and bruises.

More than 150 Irish young men and women will arrive on the steamship Etruria from Queenstown to-day. They are part of the force which is being sent to the Irish exhibition in the World's Fair at St. Louis by the Department of Agriculture and Technical Instruction of Ireland. They are weavers of linen and poplins, workers in art metals Belleek pottery, and many other industries peculiar to Ireland.

IT HAS been asked by certain observers of the public lecture system now about to close its fourteenth season: Do these free lectures to he people educate or do they simply satisfy a transient curiosity?

CHICAGO, April 23. -- Respected and law-abiding citizens by day and expert railroad thieves at night is the life that the State is seeking to show has been led by Daniel Creider, a carpenter, and his son, Charles, who are on trial in Judge Chytraus's court. Detectives charge that stolen property has been recovered from the home of young Creider, and that the son's wife has made confessions implicating both her husband and father-in-law.

AUBURN, N.Y., April 23. -- The disclosures following the death of Albert G. Burtis of the town of Fleming, Cayuga County, a year ago, which were brought out by the contest over the probate of his alleged last will and testament are of general interest, not alone because of their peculiar nature, but on account of the important legal questions involved.

The Tenderloin has a man of mystery. He appeared yesterday morning just as he did once before about three weeks ago, under remarkable circumstances. On the first occasion he was arrested in the company of a self-style millionaire; yesterday morning he was discovered a policeman amid dense volumes of smoke under a paint shop on West Twenty-seventh Street.

Ceremonies attending the laying of the cornerstone of the new armory of the Sixty-ninth Regiment in Lexington Avenue, between Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets, were attended yesterday afternoon by Mayor McClellan, who officiated at the laying of the stone, a large number of city officials and several thousands of citizens, some of whom observed the proceedings from the roofs and windows of the houses facing on the plot where work has just been begun.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The Gridiron Club gave a dinner to-night at the Arlington Hotel which closed the club's series of entertainments for the season. It was a "Spring" dinner, and in recognition of that fact the color scheme was green. The guests numbered 125, and for a dinner so late in the season the list was notable in number and quality.

LADY CURZON has just been made the recipient of a pair of black Shan-Tung terriers, a gift from Sir Ernest Satow, British Minister at Peking. These dogs are remarkable in that they have three rows of teeth, two in the lower and one in the upper jaw. A Shan-Tung terrier invariably regards any other canine not of his own strain with supercilious contempt.

In a speedily, played five-set tennis match Wylie C. Grant and Robert Le Roy, the National indoor champions, yesterday defeated Theodore Roosevelt Pell, Jr., and Harry F. Allen on the courts of the New York Lawn Tennis Club. One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. The final score was 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 10, 7 -- 5.

EASTPORT, L.I., April 23. -- As a result of the recently passed Brown bill, which prohibits duck shooting in the Spring on Long Island, the waters skirting its southern shore now teem with all kinds of wild fowl. It is said that there have not been so many birds in twenty years in this section.

I WONDER why it is," said the tailor, with an aesthetic countenance. "that the writers of fiction pay so little attention to the costuming of their male characters. Of course nobody expects a man's clothes to be as interesting as a woman's, but they certainly deserve more space than they get in novels, particularly the novels written by women.

PORT ARTHUR, April 23. -- The Japanese failed in what is believed to have been a clever ruse of war to entice the Russian ships out of Port Arthur. Several men-of-war were sighted immediately after the battleship Petropavlovsk was blown up steaming rapidly toward Port Arthur with other ships pursuing them, demonstratively and firing at them.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23. -- John N. Thompson, who stole Princeton University examination papers in February and enticed five students into buying them, was to-day sentenced by Judge Rellstab of Trenton to a year in the State Prison. Thompson pleaded guilty.

Less than a month and a half after Andrew Carnegie's gift of $1,500,000 to the three National engineering societies, the Mechanical, the Mining, and the Electrical, and to the Engineers' Club, the conference committee chosen from the four organizations has decided on a programme of competition for the architects who are to strive to win the coveted task of planning what is expected to be the greatest central home for engineering in the world.

AMONG distinguished users of tobacco, says The United States Tobacco Journal, there are few more prominent than J. Pierpont Morgan. Mr. Morgan is a heavy cigar smoker, and he is particular about what he smokes. He has his cigars made for him especially in Havana. Each has a red band with gold lettering, and the initials "J.P.M."

While walking through the grounds of the Wyman estate, on Charles Street, a few days ago Mr. John Paul Judge, Jr., a member of the senior class at Loyola College, rescued a red-tailed hawk from the onslaught of two vicious crows and carried it to Druid Hill Park, where Superintendent Boone placed it among his collection.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 23. -- A report is current here that the Japanese have landed 20,000 troops at Kin-Chau, about thirty miles above Port Arthur and fifteen miles from Dalny.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew was "seventy years young" yesterday, as he expressed it after Oliver Wendell Holmes, and last night he was the guest of the Montauk Club of Brooklyn at a dinner in celebration of the anniversary. It was the thirteenth consecutive birthday the Senator had celebrated with the Montauks, and as usual on this yearly occasion the Park Slope Indians whooped things up in lively fashion.
