If Boston offered the fullest all-round exhibition of the works of James McNeil Whistler when the Copley Society showed paintings, water colors, pastels, and lithographs, together with etchings, it was reserved for New York to make as nearly complete an exhibit as possible of etchings and dry points.

There were developments yesterday in connection with the wrecking of the Federal Bank and the Globe Securities Company, the two concerns promoted by David Rothschild, now a prisoner in the Tombs, charged with having stolen some $200,000 of the bank's funds. Chief among these was the arrest of William M. Woods, Rothschild's successor as President of the bank, in a civil action in connection with which charges of "fraud and deceit" were made.

WITH a growth and development unparalleled probably even under the stimulus of artificial conditions or some newly discovered bonanza, and presenting in the daily life and activities of its inhabitants many phases distinct from the life of the rest of the metropolis, the Brownsville district, Brooklyn's great Jewish colony, is perhaps the most remarkable community in the world.

In articles published on March 27 and April 10 in the Financial Supplement of THE TIMES, the course of the loans by National banks of New York City and of the United States outside of New York was traced for the years 1898-1903, with the purpose of paving the way for answering the questions: Can New York City make free disposition of loanable funds in the National banks? If not, what are the controlling factors?

EVEN for the modern child who scorns Santa Claus and demands a telephone for a toy there yet remains a fairyland. The kindly magician who guides him thereto, that he may learn to revere nature, its queen, so to say, is Dr. S.P. Langley, Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution.
Henry Cohen of Henry Cohen Co., manufacturers of waists, skirts, and costumes, and of M. Cohen Brothers, furs, will sail for Europe on the Kronpriz Wilhelm on April 31.

Last week was uneventful. Of course the usual Northern Securities liquidation suit was begun, but it raised no new questions, and threw no light on old ones. And there was quite a fluttering among the specialties, Consolidated Gas especially. The Mayor signed the Remsen bill giving it fresh charter rights under cover of amending a technical defect in the old charter, and thereby gave the talent an upset.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- The most dramatic scene that has been witnessed on the floor of the House for years was enacted there to-day when Bourke Cockran delivered one of the most scathing philippics against John Dalzell ever heard in Congress, in response to a charge made by Dalzell that Cockran had made campaign speeches for McKinley for hire.

The question that is now agitating the rubber manufacturers of the United States is why there should be an increased demand and consumption of foreign-made goods. The manufacture of india rubber goods in this country has grown every year, and improvements in methods have not only resulted in making as good an article as the foreign, but in making it so cheaply that American goods are sold abroad in competitive fields in great quantities.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 23. -- The Russian capital is agog with reports of possible mediation between Russia and Japan through King Edward, as a result of his Majesty's visit to Copenhagen, though not only in official quarters, but everywhere, the Russians seem to be of one mind, that no proffer of mediation can be entertained while the empire is smarting under the sting of defeat.
DETROIT, Mich., April 23. -- D.J. Campau, Democratic National Committeeman from Michigan, is jubilant over the result of the convention at Albany.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 23. -- Concerts and musicales are dividing honors with the theatrical offerings. At the Hotel Rudolf yesterday one of the largest musicales of the season was given in the large new Japanese music room of the hotel by the Boston Ladies' Symphony Orchestra, which has been engaged for the season by the proprietor, Charles R. Myers.

Like all the rest of the worn-out bulls, you are on the point of throwing up the sponge. You expect a reaction and depression to continue further. I doubt if from this day lower prices will be seen. The public are coming, and the big men know it. The plutocrats of Wall Street, knocked down as they have been by the events of last year, are stronger than the bureaucrats of Russia.

The favorable vote of the Ontario Legislature on the bill authorizing the guarantee of the Province upon a loan of $2,000,000 in aid of the Algoma Central Railway is the last act necessary to assure the successful reorganization of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, the Philadelphia corporation which has expended more than $30,000,000 in various hydraulic, manufacturing, and railway enterprises centring about the great waterfall at Sault Ste. Marie.

BOSTON, April 23. -- The Bostons and Brooklyns played excellent baseball to-day, and for eight innings it was anybody's victory. In the ninth inning, by a pretty exhibition of hitting and running, the visitors scored a run which won the game. Babb the first batter up, was easily retired at first. Barry fumbled Doyle's hit, and McCormick sent his captain to third on a single field.

A business of about 70,000 shares and with almost no changes exceeding a fraction among properties of general interest is scarcely worth discussing in general. In detail it may be noted that Brooklyn Rapid Transit retains its strength despite much incredulity. Consolidated Gas declined three-eighths upon the Mayor's signature of the Remsen bill.

JAPAN and Korea have a most remarkable breed of chickens, such as are known nowhere else in the world. They have been brought to their present wonderful state of perfection by more than a thousand years of careful breeding and improvement.

As a result of an alarm of fire yesterday morning in the seven-story cigar factory of Hirschhorn, Mack Co., at Sixty-eighth Street and Avenue A, the 1,800 employes were thrown into a wild panic, during which one woman fractured her skull in falling from the second floor and two other persons were injured.

BIOLOGY of plants is a study that is constantly revealing new secrets of their growth to us. We know now why they grow and how they grow; but the causes which first start the seed into life are still beyond the mental grasp of the investigator. For all practical purposes gardeners to-day understand their plants so that they can raise them artificially to suit almost any fancy or need of the day.

I have read with interest the various comments on the recent statement of the United States Steel Corporation, and being one of those small stockholders who cannot get any inside information, I wish to get your opinion on some matters connected with the statement. They first show "net earnings" something over thirteen millions and then charge off certain items which I believe they are obliged to charge off, and show a "balance" of $11,263,241.

During the past two years fifteen States have enacted laws for the regulation of the labor of children, seven of them entering the field for the first time. The progress has been most marked in the South, where the change from agriculture to industry is more novel and is very rapid.

LONDON, April 23. -- At the Crystal Palace this afternoon Manchester City won the English Cup, the premier prize of British Association football, defeating the Bolton Wanderers by 1 to 0. Premier Balfour was among the spectators and Colonial Secretary Lyttleton presented the cup and medals to the winners.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Gen. and Mrs. Gillespie gave a dinner party this evening at their Rhode Island Avenue home in honor of the Secretary of War, Mr. Taft. The company included the British Ambassador and Lady Durand, Senator Frye, Senator and Mrs. Dreyden, Gen. and Mrs. Chaffee, Dr. and Mrs. Gilman, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Bradley, Mrs. Audenried, and Miss Cannon.

A curious document has been sent out by the Pennsylvania Railroad to some of its stockholders, following the distribution of its annual report about a month ago. The document in question consists of a reproduction of seven articles originally printed by a Wall Street publication, and which are favorable criticisms of the last report of the company and of the policy of its Directors.

Precisely how far the judgment of Commissioner McADOO is sustained by the provisions of the law regarding the playing of baseball on Sunday it is for the courts to say, and there is no doubt that the various organizations devoted to the protection of the "American Sabbath" will take the necessary steps to secure a legal decision in the matter.
BOSTON, April 23. -- An operation which took place yesterday at the Eye and Ear Infirmary in this city seems to indicate that the color of the human eye can be changed by the use of needles.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Under a bright sky, on a good track, and in the presence of nearly 15,000 spectators, the tenth annual relay races of the University of Pennsylvania were held on Franklin Field this afternoon. The skill, brawn, and fleetness of colleges and schools from the West, South, and East were pitted against each other.

NEW HAVEN, Penn., April 23. -- In a game that started so loosely that it promised a big score the Yale nine finally won from the University of Pennsylvania on Yale Field this afternoon by the score of 2 to 0. The game after the first inning was a closely played one, in which the Yale nine added to its lead by superior batting, and maintained the advantage by sharp fielding.

Your editorial of this morning entitled "The Old Soldiers" has the right spirit. Instead of increasing pensions, a commission should be appointed to weed out the existing pension list and eliminate the "bummers," of which class there are many. The following paragraph of the article however, does an injustice to the deserving veterans who have refused to accept pensions.

The betting quotations on the two great handicaps of the Eastern turf, the Brooklyn and Suburban Handicaps, amended up to date, have been issued by the Western bookmakers, who are laying future prices on the events in question. From one report the Future speculation has been light so far, with the betting fairly distributed among the long chances on the two races.

Mystery surrounds the death by poison of George Lessels, a traveling oil broker, 52 years old, of 377 1/2 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, who was found early yesterday morning in a room in the Castleton House, a hotel at Kent Avenue and South Eighth Street, Williamsburg. Lessels, who had been suffering for a long time from indigestion, left his home on Tuesday morning for a business trip to San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Representative William R. Hearst of New York to-day filed with Attorney General Knox a complaint alleging that a combination of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and the Central Railroad of New Jersey under a common management has stifled competition, and petitioning the Department of Justice to proceed against them under the Sherman anti-trust law.

LONDON, April 16. -- That in the Cabinet Mr. Chamberlain is what Lord Rosebery calls the predominant partner is a fact long familiar. "What view will he take on the subject of a dissolution?" is the question perturbed members put to each other. Up to the last hour of the adjournment for the Easter recess this was the topic occupying every mind, cropping up in every conversation.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 23. -- In a fast and interesting lacrosse game Lehigh defeated Stevens Institute this afternoon by 7 goals to 2. Lehigh started in with a rush and scored twice in the first five minutes of play. The playing in the second half was fast and aggressive. Lehigh scored 4 goals and Stevens 2 in this half.

LONDON, April 23. -- The Board of Trade has issued a preliminary report on cotton cultivation in the British Empire and Egypt, specially compiled by Wyndham R. Dunstan, Director of the Imperial Institute. The Imperial Institute is still continuing its investigations, and therefore no definite conclusions are given as to what extent the empire can furnish new sources of supply of raw cotton.

Without doubt Secretary HAY'S effort to preserve the neutrality, territorial integrity, and "administrative entity" of China is in the interest of all the neutral world. But it is particularly, and most of all, in the interest of China herself. That is recognized by all enlightened Chinamen -- that is to say, all Chinamen who know what is going on in the world outside of China.

The Tuxedo, a cafe and music hall in West Twenty-ninth Street, just off Broadway, was raided on a warrant late last evening by Capt. Cottrell and a score of Tenderloin detectives and plain-clothes policemen. Nine prisoners, including Joseph Frey, who is charged with being the proprietor, were arrested.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23. -- It developed this afternoon that the officials of the railroad, anticipating the strike of the boilermakers, made arrangements to bring men here to take their places. A squad of 175 strike breakers from New York were landed at the car shop pier from the steamer C.H. Northam, belonging to the railroad company, and went to the boiler shops this afternoon.

Less spectacular in many details than the more recent movements on Fifth Avenue, Thirty-fourth Street and around Times Square, the rebuilding of that section of Fifth Avenue shown in the accompanying diagram has been one of the steadiest and most consistent bits of real estate development in this city within the last ten or twelve years.

It is a pleasant illustration of the amenities of the "pleasantest club in London" that Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL should have met with nothing but sympathy, on either side of the House, in his misfortune of forgetting his "piece." There have been times, even in the House of Commons, when such a breakdown would have been met with jeers and "guying."

Through Julius Henry Cohen, Chairman of the Committee on Legislation, the Citizens' Union issued a statement yesterday concerning the Remsen bill, in which attention was called to the change of attitude on the part of John M. Bowers, counsel for the Consolidated Gas Company, concerning gas matters between 1894 and 1904.

It became known on the Cotton Exchange yesterday that the agent of Daniel J. Sully in Germany had conducted a discretionary pool in cotton futures there, taking profits of about $171,000. Heretofore it had not been known that Sully had had any connections in Germany. On the books of the Sully firm, however, appeared the name of one V. Degener-Boning of Frankfort-on-the-Main.

WHILE engaged in an official capacity investigating the claims of pensioners for Government aid, L.D. Boody of New Albany, Special Examiner for that district, ran across a greatly married woman living in Jackson County, Ind., who had been an applicant for restoration to an allowance of a widow's pension.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 23. -- H. Chandler Egan, the young Harvard student and the former amateur Western golf champion, defeated Findlay S. Douglas, the metropolitan amateur champion, to-day, in the final round of the Country Club of Lakewood's golf tournament for the chief trophy.

Racing at the Aqueduct track yesterday came to a close for the Spring season under circumstances as favorable as could have been devised by the most circumspect manager, but at that the success of three of six post favorites fell short of satisfying the general public, especially as the races throughout the programme were of a character to invite more than ordinary confidence in the matter of picking winners.

It is known to all persons who are in the habit of using books of reference that there is an excellent English manual called "Who's Who" which has swallowed up and superseded the older "Men of the Time." The handiness of such a compilation was so obvious that, a few years ago, an enterprising publisher in Chicago imitated it with a similar annual, or biennial, entitled "Who's Who in America."
BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 23. -- The strike has completely collapsed, and freight and passenger traffic will be resumed to-morrow.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., April 23. -- The cold weather of the early part of the week kept many New Yorkers in town, but to-day a large gathering came out to enjoy the bracing air and the good fishing in the Tuxedo Lake.

SHANGHAI, March 14. -- The following letter appeared recently in a Shanghai morning paper, (The Hindo-China Daily News,) and shows how the war happenings have affected the people and the markets. A Chinaman must be poor indeed when he can no longer present a "cumshaw" to any one with whom he has dealings.

A SPIRITED story is going the rounds in Washington. It appears that soon after Bourke Cockran's attack upon the lack of serious methods and the discussion of the burning questions of the hour in Congress, he met Speaker Cannon.

Twenty feet of inch garden hose was a novel feature of the paraphernalia confiscated by the police of the West Thirtieth Street Station yesterday afternoon in a raid on an alleged poolroom on the second floor of a house in West Thirty-first Street, not far from the rear of the station.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- In deciding a case of a Western turf investment concern, Assistant Attorney General Robb of the Post Office Department holds that the business of receiving bets to place on the races is a violation of the law prohibiting lotteries and games of chance.

BOSTON, Mass., April 23. -- The Boston Horse Show reached the championship stage to-day, the polo ponies and saddle horses that had won blue ribbons during the week being judged in the afternoon and the harness horses, singles and pairs, and the hunters, in the evening. The day began with several riding school classes, followed by three harness classes, in which the Jordan horses were again conspicuous.

The Distributing Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association met Friday afternoon in the Mayor's public reception room at the City Hall and decided upon the annual distribution of the funds. The collection is made in all the churches of the city on the last Sunday of every year.
CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn. April 23. -- According to the drawing to-day the players will meet in the following order in the first round of the international chess tourney on Monday:

The two Columbia Varsity crews had their first important four-mile race on the Harlem River yesterday. Followed by Coach Goodwin on the launch, the two eights rowed leisurely down the river from the boathouse at Fort George. After a few moments' rest they turned about, and a handicap of four lengths was given to the second crew.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Ten States and one Territory have to date elected 266 delegates to the Democratic National Convention. Three States and one Territory have instructed for Hearst, giving him twenty-four delegates. Massachusetts, with thirty delegates, has instructed for Olney, and New York, with seventy-eight, for Parker.

The sale of the $10,000,000 Baltimore and Ohio notes disposed of a week ago Friday in the exceedingly brief period of twenty-five minutes, offers conclusive evidence of the betterment in the demand that has recently occurred for securities og this class. Within an hour after Speyer C had sold the Baltimore and Ohio notes, they were selling at a premium over the original price, showing that the demand from investors generally was fairly keen.
The Principal of a High School in a flourishing California city says:

All three of the local clubs were successful yesterday, the New York Nationals having no trouble with the Philadelphia team, but the Brooklyns and New York Americans each won by but a single run. The Pittsburgs and Cincinnatis indulged in another sharp contest at Pittsburg, with the result that after ten innings the champions of the National League finished in the lead by a run.

LONDON, April 23. -- Mieczislas de Routkowsky, Russia's financial agent here, who has spent a long time in the United States, in an interview to-day regarding Russia's new note issue said to The Associated Press:

THAT eternal subject the weather should not be brought forward except when times are the reverse of parlous. But one must hail the new-born Spring and the sunshine which will give to a backward season the opportunities for many delightful al fresco entertainments. It is a happy idea, this arranging dinners at the different historic roadhouses and restaurants in the suburbs of New York.

Little Samuel Katz of 218 Fifth Street is dreadfully worried these days. He doesn't know when he was born exactly, and as life's a pretty uncertain thing, anyway, he would like to know where he is at.

The last Sunday in April will not be very gay, as nearly all of those who entertain on that day are either in the country or have gone abroad. James Henry Smith, Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills, Mr. and Mrs. H. McK. Twombly are among those who have people Over the week end at their country places. Yesterday there was a meet of the Meadow Brook Hunt in the afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23. -- By changes which were made yesterday in the Yale rowing crews, Weeks and Stuyvesant Fish, Jr., who have been rowing bow and 4, respectively, in the 'Varsity eight, were transferred to the second boat. Both are good oarsmen, and it is believed they will materially strengthen the second, or college, boat in the Annapolis race, while at the same time they will get the benefit of actual racing experience.

While speculative trading in the coffee market during the last week has been rather quiet as far as total sales were concerned, there appears to be a good undertone to the situation, and bull interests appear to be only waiting for a favorable opportunity to start a campaign of advancing prices.

AMERICAN agricultural machinery seems destined to revolutionize conditions of living in Palestine. Recently rich man of Damascus, Abul Rahman Pacha, ordered from an Indiana firm a modern steam thrashing machine, the second of its kind ever seen in Judea. Consul Karndal, at Beirut, states that the triumphal march of this machine through Damascus was one of the most spectacular events which has ever occurred in the White City.

In the West Side Court yesterday, William Duke admitted having received and paid over at least $200,000 within the last two years to get positions or bring about promotions for men in the Police and Fire Departments, in the Post Office, and in the Custom House. That was merely a beginning, however, as Duke explained, adding:

UPON the death of John Howard Payne in Tunis in 1852, the Vice-Consul at Goletta, a Frenchman, Mr. Gaspary, took charge of his effects, and after communication with Mr. Payne's heir, his younger brother, Thatcher T. Payne of New York, several sales of furniture and books were held to satisfy the debts which Mr. Payne had contracted previous to his death.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 24. -- Hubert A. Knight, a book agent, and for some time connected with The Magazine of Mysteries of New York, shot and killed himself in Rocky Hill yesterday in an out-of-the-way place. His body was found this noon.

NEW ROCHELLE, April 24. -- Martha Bond, who was twenty-four years old and who for over a year had been a companion to Mrs. William Carey, killed herself by swallowing carbolic acid to-day. The police believe that her act was prompted by the fact that she had been compelled to shoot her big St. Bernard dog to comply with an apartment house rule.
Your article entitled "Voracity or Veracity?" and the letter in reference thereto which appears in your columns to-day remind me of an adventure which once befell a friend of mine in Ireland.

Because of a declaration made in his recently published book entitled "Christ," an attack has been made upon the Rev. Dr. S. D. McDonnell, who succeeded the Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton as rector of All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church. Some of Dr. McConnell's statements in this book are characterized by some Episcopal theologians as much more advanced than any position assumed by his predecessor at All Souls.

BUDAPEST, April 24. -- A serious riot is reported to have taken place at the market town of Elesd, near Grosswardein, resulting from a collision between meetings of the Socialist and Independent Parties.
Merriment was turned into mourning yesterday afternoon at 405 East One Hundred and Sixth Street when death claimed one of the guests at a wedding.

SEOUL, April 23. -- Advices from the Provinces of Hamg-Yung, in Northeastern Korea, state that the country folk along the northern border of the province are selling cattle and supplies to the Russians.

BOSTON, April 24. -- John Gerken of New York, who was one of the principal exhibitors at the Horse Show which closed last night, is severe in criticising the management, which he terms "a crowd of icicles."

Free-for-all races, with mixed fields of champions at both the trotting and pacing gaits contending for the honors of the road, constituted an interesting feature of yesterday morning's sport on the Harlem River Speedway. The comparatively dry weather of the past week helped horsemen greatly in advancing the condition of their roadsters and matinee racers, and with the roadbed in excellent condition, there was every invitation for fast work by well-known animals.

Your editorial entitled "The Old Soldiers," in the issue of the 20th inst., falls to do justice, not only to the "old soldiers," but to Belisarius, history, the public, and even the writer of said article himself. He should look up the case better before presenting his brief. History tells us that Belisarius was one of the very few men of his time who rose from the ranks to the highest positions.

PARIS, April 15. -- I hear that in all probability the famous Hotel de Castille, the magnificent palace occupied for so many years by the late Queen Isabella of Spain, will be sold by auction with everything it contains. Without putting too fine a point upon it, the souvenirs which attach to it do no great credit to the Spanish Bourbon family or to the present reigning house of Spain.

Despite his announcement on Friday last that he would permit Sunday baseball playing in Brooklyn, though not in Manhattan, Police Commissioner McAdoo changed his mind yesterday, and by ordering the arrest of three players and three programme sellers at the game between the Brooklyn and Philadelphia teams, at Washington Park, proposes to put the matter up to the courts to say whether playing shall proceed on the Sabbath.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- At to-day's session of the House, held in memory of Congressmen who have recently died, Representative Littlefield of Maine delivered an address which, coming from a New England Republican, is attracting much attention among Southern men. Mr. Littlefield spoke in eulogy of the late Representative Charles W. Thompson of Alabama, but his address dealt entirely with the race question and Col. Thompson's way of meeting it.

A spirit of unrest filled the Tenderloin Station yesterday afternoon and the men on reserve lounged about the gloomy sitting room, impatient of the restraint duly prescribed and provided for in the Book of Regulations.

Mrs. Charles Schafer the wife of a grocer of Newark, N.J., called at the Church Street Station last night and said that shortly before 8 o'clock on Monday evening last her husband was assaulted on Dey Street, near Greenwich Street, and robbed of $2,004.

Assistant District Attorney Kresel said yesterday that he had gone over the papers seized by the police the other night at the apartments of Banker David Rothschild, in the Ansonia, and that they had revealed some transactions which would be brought to the attention of the Grand Jury to-day. He said that they threw some light upon the identity of the persons behind Rothschild and might lead to the indictment of other persons than Rothschild.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- This session, now drawing near its end, will soon pass into history, or such history as its do-nothing record may entitle it to, with only one characteristic outbreak by Benjamin Ryan Tillman, and that a very mild one. In this regard this do-nothing session is certainly enabled to shine with a bright historical light.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- No event of the session has so aroused the Democrats and so thoroughly excited their enthusiasm as Bourke Cockran's speech of yesterday. By that speech, and particularly by the avalanche which descended upon Dalzell at the first insinuation against the orator's integrity, he established his place among the minority.
We should hardly think that Mayor McCLELLAN would be anxious to approve an outrageous Republican gerrymander, especially when it is attended by a gross evasion, if not violation, of the Constitution.

Having eluded the police for three months, Bertram Nagelsmitt, accused of having embezzled $15.000 from the Hermann Furniture Company, came back to New York Saturday night. His return was arranged for by his wife, who alone knew his whereabouts. Mrs. Naglesmltt promised in her letters that if he would come back and talk matters over with Mrs. Dora Hermann, the head of the furniture company, he would stand a good chance of arranging a compromise.
LONDON, April 25. -- In an editorial article to-day The Times says:

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 24. -- Hudson Valley fruit growers will lose $2,000,000 as the result of the extremely cold Winter. The failure of the peach crop has been conceded since early in the Winter. The more far-reaching disaster of the freezing-out of the trees is now confronting the Hudson River Valley.

PARIS, April 24. -- W.A. Day and Charles W. Russell, the United States Assistant Attorneys General, and all the other American official who have been engaged in the Panama Canal negotiations are being congratulated on the entirely successful results of the transaction and on the overwhelming vote by which the stockholders of the Panama Canal Company yesterday approved the deed of sale which makes the transfer complete without further question.
"A. Campbell," an affable and popular passenger of the Cunarder Etruria, which arrived here yesterday from Liverpool, was Richard Canfield of New York, Providence, and Saratoga.

Surface cars in this city stopped on the far side of the street yesterday -- that is, when the motormen didn't forget that the "near-side" ordinance had been repealed. But would-be passengers, in most cases, stopped on the near side, as they have learned to do during the last three months much against their will. Many stopped there long enough to see two or three cars roll by before realizing that they were in error.

Despite the fact that an angry father had cabled to America to have his daughter, who had made a runaway match with a good-looking young Englishman, detained on her arrival at New York, the couple, Mr. and Mrs. C.C. Wray, were not hindered by the immigration or police authorities when they landed from the Cunarder Etruria yesterday morning.
The Rev. Dr. William S. Hubbell, in the First Presbyterian Church, yesterday condemned Sunday baseball, his main objection to the sport being that it was a violation of the New York State Penal Code.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 24. -- Apparently reliable information in the possession of the General Staff leads to the belief that the objective of the Japanese campaign does not involve the ambitious invasion of the interior of Manchuria with the purpose of reaching and overwhelming the main Russian army.

For many years a reader of your columns, perhaps I may be allowed to express admiration, not only for the quality of the war news you give, but also for the soundness of your editorial views upon that all-absorbing topic.

ROME, April 24. -- President Loubet, accompanied by Foreign Minister Delcasse and a distinguished party of French officials, arrived in Rome to-day to repay the visit of King Victor Emmanuel to Paris last October. They were met at the station by the King, who went in state, accompanied by the Duke of Genoa, the Count of Turin, and numerous Court dignitaries.

The novelty of actual horse racing indoors, to be introduced as a feature of the Horse Fair in Madison Square Garden tomorrow and Wednesday, has aroused keen interest among local horsemen and road drivers, and events set for the first evening's racing have attracted entries that are surprisingly numerous and high class.

MADISON, N.J., April 24. -- Sporting circles in Madison are still buzzing with excitement over the result of a wager which was made on Thursday between "Farmer John" H. Williams and a number of his friends. Counting side bets, over $6 was involved, and though the utmost secrecy was observed, the fact that real bets were made has leaked out and a scandal threatened.

After experiencing the daily discomforts of local transit and transfers I have to submit for the consideration of TIMES readers (particularly including City Fathers and transit magnates) a feasible plan for lessening the growls and improving the service.

When the wrecking of the Federal Bank was first exposed we called attention to the fact that, whether the inspection by the State Banking Department had or had not been such as the law requires and the force of the department admits, it had obviously been entirely inadequate to protect the depositors.
BERLIN, April 24. -- The situation in the Far East continues to give rise in the German press to all kinds of rumors of mediation, now or at some future stage of the conflict.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS. Penn., April 24. -- The chess masters who will begin play in the international chess tournament to-morrow morning held a meeting here this afternoon to discuss the rules and regulations which will govern the contest. All the players, with the exception of Showalter, who is due here to-morrow morning, were present.
WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The conferrees on the Post Office bill will hold to-morrow what probably will be the last meeting in regard to various important items of the measure.

The traditional concert for the benefit of the seamen's charities, which marks every voyage of every transatlantic liner, was going on swimmingly on Friday night on the Cunarder Etruria, which arrived yesterday. On the liner was the famous band known as "Ireland's Own," and the band, as the principal attraction on the programme, had rendered several selections.

NEWARK, April 24. -- Charles Frank of the Yale Bicycle Club fell and broke his collar bone in the quarter mile bicycle race, at the cycle race meet held at the Vailsburg track to-day. The accident happened when the riders had gone half the distance. Teddy Billington, Elias Sindle and Frank all went down together.

Articles of incorporation have been filed in South Dakota of the National Farmers' Exchange, a form of trust which begins business with a modest capitalization of fifty millions. Its main offices will be in Chicago, and if it is able to carry out its plans they will be found revolutionary.

At the recent convention of the National Metal Trades Association in Philadelphia Mr. J. KIRBY, Jr., of Dayton, Ohio, dispelled some prevalent illusions as to the conditions brought about in Australia and New Zealand by the trades union control of the Colonial and Local Governments.

Capt. "Bill" Clark of Fire Truck No. 2 and two of his men, assisted by half a dozen policemen, effected a rescue of a fighting and raving maniac of giant strength from a twelve-inch ledge six stories from the ground early yesterday morning. Although all three firemen were in imminent danger of falling, the firemen struggled and fought until they rolled their man inside the window.

PATERSON, N.J., April 24. -- One woman is dead and six other persons have been made seriously ill as a result of eating a poisoned dinner yesterday at noon. The dead woman is Mrs. Isabel Boyd, ninety-two years old. Those at the hospital are James Roy, fifty years old; his daughter, Pauline, aged fifteen years, and Ernest Hancock, twenty-four years old.

That the desires of William F. Sheehan and other close advisers of Judge Alton B. Parker with reference to electing a State Chairman, who would have no part in the differences of Hill and Murphy will not prevail, and that an out-and-out Hill Chairman will be selected was declared last night by a representative of some of the interests allied with Hill.

A handsome flower market will be constructed at Canal and West Streets, where the florists were wont to display their wares in the days of the old Clinton Market, if an experiment which has been undertaken by 125 of the leading flower growers about New York proves successful.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24. -- Patrolman William Nesbitt of the New York police force addressed several thousand people at the policemen's Gospel rally, held in the new Auditorium in Orange Street this afternoon.

It sometimes happens that a man with good manners can get along with a defective assortment of morals, but it is always risky for a man weak in morals to indulge in bad manners. The principle applies to political parties as well.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- Representative Cushman relates that when President Roosevelt was in the State of Washington last year he had a most enthusiastic reception. At one of the gatherings an old frontiersman confided to Mr. Cushman that Roosevelt was the greatest man he ever saw and the greatest man who ever visited the Northwest. On being asked for the reasons for his judgment the man replied:

The Central Federated Union set on foot yesterday a movement to agitate for the release of Samuel J. Parks, now serving a sentence in Sing Sing Prison for extortion, by indorsing a petition to Gov. Odell asking for the pardon of Parks. This resolution was introduced for indorsement by Delegate Smith of the Plumbers' Union. It is addressed to Gov. Odell.

WASHINGTON, April 24. -- The indications are that the last week of the present session of Congress will begin to-morrow. There are differences between the two houses to be reconciled on a few of the general appropriation bills, but these are not of so radical a character as to interfere with terminating the session the last of the week.

That the life of William Duke was threatened, and that the identity of the "man higher up" is likely to be revealed to-day were the disclosures in the city job scandal yesterday. Duke was prompted to tell of the threat upon his life by a little incident. He was walking east on Fifty-seventh Street from his home with a group of reporters.

The eleventh annual report of the President and Board of Directors of the Educational Alliance, just issued, reviews in detail the work of that institution in 1903, and treats of the efforts made to increase interest in each of the various branches of instruction, together with the results accomplished.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25. -- M. Anatole Leroy-Beaulieu of France delivered the first of his series of lectures under the auspices of the Cercle Francais of Harvard University, at Sanders Theatre this afternoon. The lecturer was introduced by President Eliot, and he spoke to a large audience. The lecture was the first of several upon the general question of "Democracy and Christianity."
Capt. Cornelius Hayes and Sergt. McCann were behind the desk in the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station yesterday afternoon when the telephone bell rang, and it was answered by Policeman Troy.

LONDON, April 25. -- Russians resident in London are greatly interested in the published report that Sir Charles Hardinge, the new British Ambassador at St. Petersburg, will be the bearer of an important letter from King Edward to the Czar concerning the question of friendly mediation between Russia and Japan.
ATHENS, April 25. -- An affray between Turkish gendarmes and Greeks has occurred at Smyrna, in which M. Delyannis, Secretary of the Greek Consulate, was slightly wounded.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Judge O.W. Powers was on the stand again at the opening of the Smoot investigation before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day, and Attorney Van Cott resumed cross-examination.

In addition to the $4,000,000 gold engaged on Saturday for export to Paris by to-day's steamer, $2,600,000 was engaged yesterday, making the total to go out by the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse to-day $6,600,000, which is one of the largest amounts that have been taken by a single steamer from this port.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 25. -- Mrs. James L. Kernochan came a nasty cropper during a run of the Meadow Brook hounds this afternoon.

VIENNA, April 25. -- The Hungarian situation is regarded here as alarming. The Socialists threaten to proclaim a general strike throughout the country, and in such an event it is stated in political circles that Count Tisza, he Hungarian Premier, will put the whole kingdom under martial law.

BOSTON, April 25. -- It was announced today that the First National Bank of this city will soon absorb the National Bank of Redemption, and that Daniel G. Wing, President of the First National, will serve as President of the merged institutions. The consolidation will represent an institution with a capital of $2,000,000, a surplus of $2,000,000, and deposits aggregating about $35,000,000.

"Barney" Smith, janitor of the New York Stock Exchange, has been sent abroad by the Governing Committee of the Exchange, so that in the milder climate of his native Ireland he may recover his health, which has not been of the best for a long time. While he is away the Exchange not only will continue his salary, but also will pay all the expenses of a first-class journey.
If Gov. Odell signs the Trial Commissioners bill, the Appellate Division Justices who will have the power of appointment will encourage an early test of the constitutionality of the measure.

There was a "killing" yesterday in the headquarters of the Helping Hand Benevolent and Athletic Association, and in consequence the President, who is also the Treasurer and Secretary, called a meeting of the Board of Directors, likewise himself, and summarily expelled Hink Siddons, ex man-o'-war's man, and now acknowledged champion "dope" of the vicinity of Thirty-second Street and Seventh Avenue.
TOPEKA, Kan., April 25. -- "Nick" Chiles, editor of The Topeka Plain Dealer, a negro paper, to-day received a letter from Cardinal Merry del Val, who wrote for Pope Pius X.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 25. -- The Associated Press is enabled to announce authoritatively that the talk of mediation in the Russo-Japanese war was founded upon the personal desire of King Edward and King Christian to avoid further bloodshed and end the conflict, but that the steps initiated have utterly failed.

The prelates of the Roman Catholic Church in this country either deny that they have advised the Pope that the carrying out of his recommendations with regard to church music is impracticable in this country or else they decline to discuss the subject. It is pretty evident, however, that in many, if not in most, cases it is impracticable.

ROME, April 25. -- President Loubet went to the Pantheon to-day to lay wreaths on the tombs of King Victor Emmanuel II. and King Humbert. He was received by veterans of the Italian Army. The function was of the most impressive nature, M. Loubet speaking to each of the veterans, some of whom wore medals gained while fighting in 1859 with the French against Austria.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., April 25. -- The Robert C. Ogden party arrived here this afternoon, having spent Sunday at Calhoun, inspecting a settlement where the Rev. Dr. Dillingham, a Miss Thorne, and a devoted band have labored for the uplifting of the negroes, teaching the men, women, and children not only to read and write but how to farm.

The Democratic situation in Westchester County has developed symptoms of grave danger to the success of the party in this State. These symptoms have been made evident by the action of Mr. Parker's friends in overruling Mr. Hill's judgment that the contesting delegations from this county should be seated in the convention last Monday.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- In addition to securing "Patsy" Donovan for manager, the Washington Club has signed "Lefty" Davis to play centre field and "Jiggs" of the Chicago Club for first baseman.
CHICAGO, April 25. -- John K. Cowen, ex-President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, died to-night, at the residence of his sister. Mrs. A.H. Seelye, in Chicago.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 25. -- Henry Simmons, alias Henry Williams, the negro who murdered Miss Lula Sandberg, an eighteen-year-old white girl, near Manor, this county, last Thursday, was captured in a barn in this city this morning. He was quickly placed in the county jail.

A young man who says he is John Woods, twenty-one years old, of 152 West One Hundred and Fifth Street, was locked up in the West Forty-seventh Street Station last night on a charge of assault made by Mrs. Alice Oliver of 715 Seventh Avenue. Mrs. Oliver says that Woods stopped her at Forty-eighth Street and Seventh Avenue, said that he was "broke," and asked for 15 cents.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 25. -- The wind and rain storm in the eastern section of Jefferson County caused the loss of four lives and much damage to property in that section. The crops in the fields in the path of the storm were severely damaged.
LONDON, April 25. -- The death is announced of the famous American Stallion Foxhall, at Lord Rosebery's stud farm.
Senator Patrick H. McCarren is to be the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee and manager of the State campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Senator Bacon to-day discussed the sale in foreign countries of American products at a less price than the same products are sold in the United States. He read a letter from Charles M. Schwab to H.C. Frick giving the cost of manufacturing steel rails, which Mr. Bacon said showed that the "trust" needed no protection against English steel manufacturers.

Yesterday's was neither an interesting nor stimulating session. Representative declines were those for Amalgamated, Sugar, the tractions, Union Pacific, and Steel preferred. Their falls of about a point were above the average, but the business in them gave the day its tone. Consolidated Gas fell 1 1/4, and has now had a greater fall on the signature than might have been expected upon a veto.

Both the New York National and American League teams were successful yesterday, the Brooklyn faring poorly at the hands of McGraw's men, while one run was Washington's portion against the Greater New Yorks. The advance of the Boston Americans was not only checked in Philadelphia, but they were not permitted to score a run.

TRENTON, N.J., April 25. -- As the result of an automobile accident last night George Holcombe, a well-known Trenton newspaper man, died to-day, and Capt. E. Yarde-Breese of the Second Regiment, N.J.N.G., is still unconscious at the Mercer Hospital. Breese, who was driving, lost control because of a break in the machinery.

Two serious accidents to contesting athletes marred the annual Spring games of the Twelfth Regiment Athletic Association held in the Armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, last night. The first mishap occurred in the two-mile handicap regimental bicycle race, when Theodore White of Company G slipped at one of the turns and was thrown against the boxes on the south side of the building.

The idea that Mr. Leo Ditrichstein wrestled with prayer and paris green in making the "Heureuse" of Maurice Hennequin and Paul Bilhaud fit for refined and pure American taste has been disseminated by the assiduous press agent, and is in fact abetted by the programme, which avers that the Parisian play has been "adapted." But this does some injustice to the new piece at the Savoy.

After calling a crowd around him near the plaza of the new Williamsburg Bridge, at South Fifth and Havemeyer Streets, Williamsburg, last night, and then calmly informing them that he was going to commit suicide, Edward Benson, a machinist, twenty-one years old, of 165 South Second Street, swallowed about two ounces of carbolic acid.

N.L. Amster, of N.L. Amster Co., consulting mining engineers of Boston, has sent out circulars to the minority stockholders of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company in which he asserts that the affairs of the company are not carried on in the interests of the stockholders.
STAMFORD, Conn., April 25. -- E.C. Benedict, the friend of ex-President Cleveland, in an interview this afternoon regarding the Democratic outlook, said:

Bertram Nagelsmitt, who is said to have left a shortage of $15,000 in his accounts as cashier of the Hermann Furniture Company when he disappeared on Dec. 19 last, was held in $1,500 bail for examination on Thursday by Magistrate Zeller, in the Tombs Court, yesterday morning, after Secretary Stamwitz of the concern had demanded a heavier bond, saying that the man's peculations had extended over a period of fourteen years.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Bourke Cockran arose in his place in the House to-day and addressed the Speaker in a portentous manner. The House had been noisy a moment before, but at the first sound of Cockran's voice a hush fell upon it. The Republican leaders leaned forward, Sereno Payne put his hand to his ear.
BOSTON, April 25. -- The Herald to-morrow will make the following announcement:

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- The conferrees on the Post Office Appropriation bill met this morning and quickly came to an agreement on the matter of Post Office sites in New York City. The compromise proposition advanced by the Merchants' Association of New York in regard to the Pennsylvania Station Post Office site was presented by the House conferrees, and an amendment framed by Representative Gardner of New Jersey, one of the conferrees, was adopted.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- New York won one of the most remarkable fielding games to-day against the Washingtons that has fallen to the lot of local spectators to witness. The visitors had the only two runs of the game scored, and Pitcher Powell was doing excellent service, in giving the Washingtons less than one hit an inning.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- There seems to be an understanding among Republican leaders of the House that the speech of Bourke Cockran on Saturday is not to be permitted to pass unanswered, and there is a report to the effect that Mr. Dalzell will put himself forward for that purpose.

It must be a source of rejoicing to many to read the concluding lines of the article in THE TIMES of the 23d, which point out that "spies are soldiers like other soldiers not a class by themselves, and pecularly mean or wicked."

ITHACA, N.Y., April 25. -- The sixteen Cornell oarsmen who have been on strike for a better training table, fixed up affairs to-night through the Athletic Council by going to a new table. It will be managed by Mrs. Atkins, who had always been in charge of the Cornell crew tables until this season. The new quarters are in the Cascadilla-building at the entrance to the university campus.

For a time yesterday afternoon the trading on the Stock Exchange ceased almost entirely. Between noon and one o'clock the transactions amounted to only a little over 13,000 shares and although the total for the day was not in keeping with the business during the smallest hour, the trading amounting to 282,418 shares, the relatively large total was due to the activity shown during the first two hours.

The most striking feature of the remarkable demonstration in the House of Representatives on Saturday was not so much the utter inability of the Republican leaders to meet the attack of Mr. COCKRAN and his associates as the ill-concealed satisfaction of the rank and file of the Republicans at the discomfiture of their nominal leaders.

While Judge Holt of the United States District Court was listening to motions over the Globe Security Company tangle yesterday morning, the representative of the creditors in this city received from Philadelphia a dispatch that made him give up hope of being able to summon Louis Rothschild and Miss Carrie Adams to testify in any court proceeding over the affairs of the Globe Company and the other Rothschild ventures.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., April 25. -- The first round of the international chess masters' tournament was played at the Hotel Rider in this city to-day, and at about 6 o'clock all the games were concluded. Showalter, who arrived after a night's traveling from Georgetown, Ky., in the morning was excused from play. He will play his game with Schlechter on Wednesday.
Hearings will be held on Thursday by the Board of United States General Appraisers on the questions of linen scrims, etamines, and feather stitch braids.
PARIS, April 25. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch reports an interview with Col. Vannovsky, formerly a military attache in Japan.
LONDON, April 25. -- A special dispatch from Shanghai says the Hai-Tien is a wreck.

Jame Tisdale, one of the few colored policemen in the department, and attached to Clermont Avenue Station in Brooklyn, was arrested late yesterday and locked up in the West Thirty-seventh Street Station on a charge of disorderly conduct. A police surgeon who examined Tisdale said he believed him to be intoxicated.

ST. LOUIS, April 25. -- It was discovered to-day that vandals had entered the French pavilion at the World's Fair and destroyed two of the most beautiful of the marble statues in the sculpture exhibit.

Gov. Odell reached New York from Washington last night and went to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where his wife and daughter, who had come straight through to New York from Old Point Comfort, were awaiting him. The Governor was accompanied from Washington by Congressman William L. Ward of Westchester.

Mrs. Paul Calvi of 312 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, reported to the police yesterday morning that jewelry worth about $4,500 had been stolen from her home Sunday night. A man she engaged as a butler two weeks ago had left the house during that night and had failed to return.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Gov. Odell arrived in Washington from Old Point Comfort this morning and drove to the White House with Representative Littauer and William C. Warren of Buffalo. There were Congressmen with the President when he arrived, but the arrival of the Governor promptly scattered them, so that the President could have as much time as he wanted with his important guest.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Senator Hale made a magnificent speech to-day when the Senate adopted the conference report on the Naval bill. His remarks were in the line of the position taken by him in his speech of March 3, when he essentially predicted the disastrous effect of an explosion such as occured on the Missouri off Key West.

Replete with shiftings of advantage for the contending horses and of sensations for the betting crowd, the race for the Excelsior Handicap, run at the Jamaica track yesterday, as the feature of the Metropolitan Jockey Club's Spring meeting, and won after a spectacular finish by Rostand, one of the light-weights and long chances of the race, made one of the most superbly satisfactory, struggles witnessed on a New York race course in recent years.

LONDON, April 25. -- Opposition to the Aliens bill, which developed during its discussion in the House of Commons today, was based largely on the belief that the measure was essentially anti-Semitic. Indeed it was alleged by some speakers that the bill actually had its origin in hatred of the Jews.
PARIS, April 25. -- A dispatch from Harbin gives a striking account of the horrible condition of the streets and the entire absence of sanitary arrangements in that town.

If a serious attempt is made to get a pardon for "Sam" Parks it will be opposed by the Building Trades Employers' Association. Charles L. Eidlitz, President of the organization, said yesterday that he did not believe Gov. Odell would pay any attention to the petition of the Central Federated Union.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 25. -- Justice Marshall to-day sentenced "Robert T. Hill," who swindled the proprietor of Young's Hotel, out of a large board bill, to six months in the Kings County Penitentiary and to pay a fine of $50.

Hayden Co. have sold for Charles Buek to James B. Sheehan, for $155,00C, the eight-story elevator apartmenthouse, known as the Westminster, at the northeast cor ner 9f St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hun dred and Forty-fifth Street, on plot 48 by 110.

The cutters and others who are threatening the clothing trade with a great National strike if the declaration of the employers in favor of the principle of the open shop is insisted upon would do well to remember that great victories are never won in the absence of great issues.

It is not in the least likely that the invitation of the Russian spider to the Japanese fly to walk into the Manchurian parlor will be accepted. If the Japanese would consent to be drawn on into the heart of Manchuria, "dragging at each remove a lengthening chain," they would incur all the disadvantages under which the Russians now labor.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 25. -- The Emperor has received the following telegrams from Gen. Kuropatkin:
TOKIO, April 25. -- The Russian Vladivostok squadron, after a long period of inactivity, suddenly appeared off Gen-san this morning and sank the Goyo Maru, a Japanese merchant steamer.

We congratulate Mayor MCCLELLAN on the veto he has put upon the two bills relating to reinstatements in the Police and Fire Departments. His action was clearly in the public interest, and, if the rumors at Albany were well founded, it may be regarded as having required some civic courage, since the bills were reported to be the outcome of a deal between representatives of the Republican and the Tammany machines.

Mme. Emma Calve's tantrum and failure to sing her second number on the programme Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House may have cost her $500. Whether Director Heinrich Conried can succeed in "docking" the erratic prima donna's pay now is doubtful, but if the will were the same as the deed, already the half-thousand cut would be made.

Work in connection with the razing of the old buildings at the northeast corner of Broadway and Beaver Street, to provide a site for the new twelve-story home of the New York Produce Exchange Bank, will be begun next Monday. It is expected that the new building will be ready for occupancy within a year.

READING, Penn., April 25. -- Four young society men of this city were smart enough to beguile the souvenir fanatics of New York into giving them nearly $2,000 for a carload of worthless slag. That was almost two years ago, but the secret never leaked out until this week.

PRYOR CREEK, Indian Territory, April 25. -- Six persons were killed by a tornado which swept through the country about four miles south of here last night. The dead include John Abbott, his wife, and two children; Albert Dealy, aged six years, and Lucy Bitting, aged eight years. Albert Dealy was probably fatally hurt, and Leopold Bitting had both legs broken.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 25. -- Chicago completely outplayed Cleveland to-day and won by a score of 7 to 4. It was Joss's first game this year, and he was touched up lively at opportune moments. Cleveland could not hit Owen with men on bases. The team work of Chicago and Sullivan's catching were features. Score by innings:

The verses written by John J. O'Conner, a boy of fifteen, on the death of his father, published in to-day's issue of your paper, have recalled some verses written by the late George D. Prentice of Louisville, Ky., at the age of fourteen, entitled "Written at My Mother's Grave."

Considerable doubt as to the magnitude of the police job swindle in which William Duke was concerned was cleared away yesterday by the admission of District Attorney Jerome that he had receipts worth at least $100,000 given by Duke and Sonner to men whom they claimed to have aided. Those are merely the receipts the District Attorney has procured.
PARIS, April 25. -- Marcel Prevost's play "Le Plus Faible" was produced here to-night at the Theatre Francais with fair success.

The John Kress Brewing Company of 207 to 221 East Fifty-fourth Street is unable to meet maturing obligations, and application was made to the Supreme Court yesterday for the appointment of a receiver and for the dissolution of the corporation by Henry M. Harr, Martin H. Hartmann, and William Forster, directors, Judge MacLean appointed W.H. Klenke as temporary receiver, with a bond of $25,000.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- With the approach of adjournment the campaign partisan feeling is beginning to run high and tempers are beginning to be worn. There were several spats in the House to-day, and the gossips predict lively scenes before adjournment comes.

BALTIMORE, April 26. -- The seventh annual meeting of the Woman's Whist League of the United States began here to-day, there being present a large number of noted whist players from various parts of the country. The delegates were welcomed by Miss Ellen Lloyd Goldsborough, President of the league.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 26. -- In a rear-end collision, which occurred a short distance west of the Pennsylvania Railroad station here this afternoon, when the Long Branch Express, heavily laden, ran into the rear of the Florida Special, one man was killed and twenty-seven persons were injured.

Nominations to the early closing races for the Grand Circuit meeting to be held at Charter Oak Park, Hartford, Conn., Sept. 5 to 9, will close to-morrow. The events are the Charter Oak, for 2:09 trotters, $10,000; the Capital City, for 2:20 trotters, $2,500, and the Connecticut, for 2:20 pacers, $2,500.

The Grand Jury yesterday took up first two grand larceny charges brought against David Rothschild in connection with the failure of the Federal Bank, of which he was President until the beginning of last March. Several witnesses were examined, but the taking of testimony will not be completed until to-day.

The New York Juvenile Asylum has sold to the State Realty and Mortgage Company the entire block bounded by St. Nicholas and Wadsworth Avenues, One Hundred and Seventy-seventh and One Hundred and Seventy-eighth Streets, and the southerly half of the block bounded by Broadway and Wadsworth Avenue, One Hundred and Seventy-seventh and One Hundred and Seventy-eighth Streets.

Dr. F.S. Earle, Assistant Curator of the New York Botanical Garden for the past two years, resigned his position in the garden last week to accept the office of Director of the new agricultural station in Cuba. He was requested by the Cuban Government to aid in the establishment of the station and was granted a leave of absence from the garden for the purpose on April 1.

About twenty-five German manufacturers and merchants arrived in New York yesterday on the Kronprinz Wilhelm, and during the next five weeks will study methods in vogue in American factories and stores, visiting for that purpose besides New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, St. Louis, and one or two other cities. A week or more will be devoted to the St. Louis Exposition.

Of the eight games scheduled in the National and American Leagues yesterday, rain or wet grounds stopped all but four, two in each league. The Greater New Yorks were unable to play their last contest with Washington, but at the Polo Grounds McGraw's men failed to keep up their recent powerful hitting, and had to succumb to the Brooklyns.

I have been interested in the letters occasionally appearing in your paper regarding religious conditions in New York City. I am a frequent visitor to your city, and have dropped into various churches, as I happened to be near them. I have heard many sermons in these churches, good, bad, and indifferent.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Eugene G. Hay the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday reversed itself and sustained a protest by Henry Pfaltz of New York against the assessment of a duty of 15 cents a pound and 20 per cent., as gelatin, on merchandise known as gelatin sheets. The importer claimed that it was dutiable at 35 per cent. as a manufacture of gelatin.

It was Miss Jennie A. Rogers of Brooklyn who brought about the nearest approach to discord in the third convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, which was held yesterday in the Clinton Avenue Congregational Church, Brooklyn. Miss Rogers is a gentle-looking little woman, but she was determined that the Federation should go on record against the Remsen Gas bill, and she made her point, despite all opposition.

Citizens of King's Bridge to the numberf of thirty-one, of whom nine were women, held a "mass" meeting in the Marble Hill Hose Company's hall last evening and drafted a petition that is to be submitted to Gov. Odell asking him to veto Senator Plunkitt's Spuyten Duyvil bill.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 26. -- As a sequel to the burning of the Van Alen country place at New Hamburg in February, 1903, Ellis B. Southworth, a New York lawyer of 68 William Street, was arrested by Deputy Sheriff Baumbush at his office this afternoon on a bench warrant charging him with arson in the first degree.

A Tammany Alderman returning from travels in the West reports that Judge PARKER "will not get a solid delegation from Indiana." It appears that the Judge has "lost ground there on account of the action of the Democratic State Convention of this State." It is "the conduct of DAVID B. HILL" that offends the Tammany Democrats.
PARIS, April 26. -- An important meeting of Colombian bondholders, convened by the Foreign Bondholders' Committee, is to be held in London to-morrow, according to private information received here.

BOSTON, April 26. -- As a result of an alleged indignity to Mrs. Montaigue and her sister of Washington, intimate friends of President Roosevelt and Secretary Shaw, by Special Employe Martin of this port, Martin has been arraigned by Collector Lyman, who is preparing an account of the treatment of Mrs. Montaigue for Washington officials.

Conditions widely different from those of the opening day confronted the race-going crowd at the Jamaica track yesterday, the attendance falling off to about one-half of what it was on Monday, and the races being run on a wet and heavy course, while a chilling breeze from the ocean searched through every nook and corner of grand and field stands.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 26. -- The Indiana Republican Convention organized to-day, and will complete its work to-morrow after having nominated a State ticket and adopted a platform.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 26. -- While King Edward's move to restore peace between Russia and Japan has failed, it is nevertheless regarded as highly significant in diplomatic circles. It is the first tangible evidence of a change in the relations between Russia and Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Senate to-day passed the Military Appropriation bill, the last of the supply measures. The amendments suggested by the Committee on Military Affairs for a reorganization of the Medical and Ordnance Departments of the army and for the establishment of a number of camp sites were thrown out on points of order.

The Republicans did not dare to press the ship subsidy scheme to a vote at the present session of Congress. Probably it would have been defeated by the votes of the Northwest, where neither the farmers nor the manufacturers are enamored of the idea of paying money from taxation to hire American vessels to carry freight as cheaply as it is now carried in open competition for all the world.
LIAO-YANG, April 26. -- Between last night and this morning the Japanese forced a passage of the Yalu, two companies crossing between Tchangjiou and Siaopoussikhe.
MADRID, April 26. -- Premier Maura, who arrived here this morning, was shot at, but was not wounded, while on his way here from the Balearic Islands.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The new Board of Regents of the University to-day elected Whitelaw Reid Chancellor and St. Clair McKelway Vice Chancellor of the University. The board confirmed appointments by Commissioner of Education Draper as follows:

Startled by the death cry of her little son Theodore, two and a half years old, Mrs. Joseph Ginsberg, looking from window of her home at 181 Christopher Street, East New York, saw the little fellow knocked down by a team of horses and the wheels of a heavily laden lime truck pass over his body.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Admiral Dewey placed himself on record in favor of the general board plan of Secretary Moody before the House Committee on Naval Affairs to-day. The present Naval Board, the Admiral said, was too large. Its sessions were like "town meetings."

Knowing you to be on the side of honesty and fair play, may I call your attention to the number of "skin game" agencies in this city. I mean those for the class of workers other than domestics. The unfortunate girl or woman in the vain hunt for work sees the tempting advertisements of these places in the "help wanted" columns of the newspapers.

Death laid a sudden hand on Charles Kelly, engineer of the East River ferryboat America, as she was crossing the crowded stream from Grand Street, Manhattan, to Broadway, Williamsburg, at 7 o'clock last evening, bearing more than 300 passengers, and many horses and wagons. No one was near Kelly, and none suspected that anything was wrong until the pilot gave the customary two bells to slow as the old sidewheeler forged toward her Brooklyn slip.

David B. Hill came down from Albany yesterday, and during the course of the afternoon he conferred with August Belmont and William F. Sheehan at their down-town offices, had a curbstone confab with James J. Martin, the Tammany leader of the Twenty-seventh District, and was closeted for over an hour with Senator Patrick H. McCarren at the Hoffman House. He had a second conference last night with Mr. Sheehan at Mr. Sheehan's residence.

Lord CHOMER in Egypt has had troubles such as our own officers in the Philippines have encountered through the inability of the native mind to grasp the ideas and methods of the Western mind. This is shown in the tendency to observe minutely the letter of orders and regulations, no matter what the circumstances may require.

The main significance of the Russian attack upon Gen-san is in the fact that the Russian Vladivostok squadron is "out" and must henceforth be reckoned with by the Japanese as part of the Russian effective. It has broken out once before, and done rather more damage than it did on this later occasion.

The Executive Committee of the Trust Company Section of the American Bankers' Association met yesterday afternoon in the offices of the United States Mortgage and Trust Company preparatory to the meeting of the Executive Council of the association to-day and to-morrow. Several questions came before the committee for discussion, upon which report will be made when the annual meeting of the section is held in connection with that of the American Bankers' Association next Fall.

Contrary to the expectations of the cynics that the National Arts Theatre Society's year of existence had ended with mere theories, as it began, there came to light at its annual dinner last night the fact that at least one very rich man was ready to put down $50,000 toward the scheme for building a temple of dramatic art in this city.

My interest has been aroused by the publication of the latest ideas of Prof. Patten of the University of Pennsylvania upon the solution of the labor questions. He gives us to understand that a solution of these questions will be produced if the wives of men who earn less than $20 per week will also become wageworkers.

We have had quite enough about the revolting effects of Mermonism upon the tastes and habits of the Mormons, in the testimony of the witness CANNON, who deposed that he married two sisters on the same day, and in the testimony of other witnesses. We have also had ample evidence of the extent to which the Mormon Church interests itself in politics, insomuch that the State of Utah is only another name for it.

The discussion in the United States Senate on Monday, started by Senator HALE in his comments on the conference report on the Naval Appropriations bill, was extremely significant. It warranted the conclusion that if the matter of the appropriation for new battleships had not been agreed to by both houses and thus placed beyond the jurisdiction of the conference committee its recommendation would be to strike out the provision for battleships.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Senator Quarles to-day bade the President good-bye preparatory to an immediate return to Wisconsin to "fix his fences," as he expressed it. Next January the Wisconsin Legislature will choose a successor to Senator Quarles, whose term expires in March, 1905.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The climax to the Cockran-Dalzell affair came in the House to-day, and but for the Speaker's personal participation in the proceedings, in violation of all custom, Cockran might have stampeded the whole body, Republicans as well as Democrats.

HUDSON, N.Y., April 26. -- After an entire day spent at Bell Place investigating the depredations of the vandals who disturbed the old Gen. Livingston tomb, Chief of Police Lane of this city and Deputy Sheriff Drumm of Columbia County declare to-night that robbery of jewels believed to have been buried with "Widow Mary" Livingston was the real motive for the crime.

Four alarms were turned in for a fire in the big plant of the John Stanley Soap Works, at the foot of West Thirtieth Street about 1:30 o'clock this morning. The building has a frontage of 100 feet on West Thirtieth Street. In the rear on Twenty-ninth Street, is the plant of the Dunbar Lumber Company, and to the East is the Philadelphia Schuylkill Coal Company.

The officials of the Philadelphia National League Club, alarmed at the many reverses sustained by the team since the championship season began, closed two deals yesterday which will materially strengthen the nine. First Baseman Jack Doyle has been secured from the Brooklyn Club, and the New Yorks have released "Billy" Lauder, last year's third baseman.

Further contraction in business accompanied a slight advance in a number of stocks in yesterday's market, but the improvement in prices as a favorable factor was offset by the smaller volume of business. United States Steel was again the most active stock, supplying about 40,000 shares out of the total of 197,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The last Cabinet dinner of the season took place this evening, when the Secretary of Commerce and Labor and Mrs. Cortelyou were the hosts of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt and all the Cabinet officers now in the city.

That Edward Theodore Chalmes is blessed with the "cool cheek" that women are prone to admire is evident from the picturesque tale of love and deception which came out in Jefferson Market Court yesterday when Chalmes, who is a valet, was arraigned on a charge of grand larceny. His pretty wife, who is known on the stage as Hazel Hughes, is the tearful heroine of what appears to be a tragic comedy.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- When the Smoot investigation before the Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections was opened to-day. Moses Thatcher was again called to the stand, and Lawyer Van Cott interrogated Mr. Thatcher in regard to his views on Church interference in politics.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 26. -- It is officially admitted here that the Japanese are crossing the Yalu River.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Notwithstanding inauspicious weather, the Countess Cassini held her fair for the Russian Red Cross this afternoon in the grounds of Belmont, the home of Mr. and Mrs. A.L. Barber, at Fourteenth and Clifton Streets, where a semi-circle of booths and a huge vaudeville tent, which later served as a dining hall, afforded shelter from the frequent showers.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 26. -- Members of the Conference for Education in the South poured into this city to-day in large numbers. The Robert C. Ogden party arrived early this afternoon. The hospitable people of the city took to their homes many of Mr. Ogden's guests. The others were quartered at the Hotel Hillman.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 26. -- The Court of Appeals to-day sustained District Attorney Jerome in the method used to secure evidence in the prosecution of Lawyer George E. Mills and Dr. Richard C. Flower. The court's decision denies the appeal of Mills from a judgment of conviction of grand larceny in the second degree, and of an attempt to unlawfully remove from the custody of the courts certain indictments.

When the volume of human pathos is finally published, a page will be filled by the story of the life and love of Bila Szabo, a disinherited son of Count Bila Szabo, physician to the Austrian Emperor Franz Josef, and of his wife, Rosa, for whom he threw away wealth and title, and in whose arms he died on Monday, at their home, 260 West Forty-third Street.

The small boys of the west side, in view of the growing scarcity of buffaloes, think it great sport lassoing dogs. Whenever the automobile of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals appears the official dog hunters are reinforced by an army of youthful rangers, who help to lasso the stray animals and yank them to the wagon.

The work and the vigilance of the Board of Health Department are evidence of great progress made in civil government and the results are eminently gratifying. From time to time its responsibilities are increased by the detection of things constituting a menace to the health of the public.

Some 300 depositors in the Grand Street branch of the wrecked Federal Bank held a meeting last night at Odd Fellows' Hall, in Forsyth Street, to denounce ex-Alderman Minsky, who, as a solicitor for the bank, had induced many of them to part with their money. They accomplished their purpose in the most thorough manner, and altogether the meeting was one of the stormiest the east side has seen in many a day.

After the poolroom matter had been disposed of at the City Club's annual meeting several of the Citizens' Union men in the club gave President Peckham an unpleasant ten minutes over the Remsen Gas bill, which last week was approved by Mayor McClellan and now is before Gov. Odell for action.

LOUISVILLE, April 27. -- The Smith family, not specifically but generally, will assemble in Louisville this Fall, if the plan of John Cabell Smith, a wealthy Kentuckian, is concurred in by the Smiths at large.

In future women teachers may marry without opposition from the Board of Education. Yesterday afternoon the board not only canceled its by-law prohibiting such marriages, but also reinstated Mrs. Vandewater, the only one who has been dismissed on this ground, all other offenders having resigned as soon as charges had been preferred against them.

A gang of eight desperate burglars armed with the most modern housebreaking tools was arrested yesterday afternoon at 145 and 147 Eldridge Street, and with their booty, $7,000 worth of tailor's supplies, were locked up in the Eldridge Street Station. The prisoners, say the police, broke into the store of Bauer Doctor, tailors at 247 Bowery, on the corner of Stanton Street, early yesterday morning and carried away everything valuable in the place.

Polo and saddle races under saddle were the big features that aroused the enthusiasm of the crowd last night in Madison Square Garden.
