It was the closing night of the horse fair, which, while a novelty in many respects, has been more successful for its initial attempt than the promoters of the enterprise had looked for.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Prof. Wrightson of the University of West Virginia had some friends, mostly musicians, at the new Willard on Monday night to meet Richard Strauss, the composer. The party was jolly and informal, and as the story telling moment arrived Strauss, under the influence of the cozy and comfortable atmosphere of the occasion, removed his coat and hung it on the back of his chair.

The precipitate ending of the strike of the employes of the State railroads in Hungary is instructive. It was effected by the simple and perfectly natural expedient of the Government in ordering all the employee of the roads who are members of the reserve or liable to military duty to join their respective regiments.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Attorney General Knox to-day transmitted to the House replies to the two resolutions of inquiry introduced by Mr. Williams (Miss.) relative to trusts.

In a decision written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday dismissed a protest by the Central Vermont Railway Company, consignees for R.F. Downing Co., against the action of the Collector at Burlington, Vt., on the ground that it had no jurisdiction.

Brokers on the floor of the Stock Exchange yesterday did not have much to occupy their attention, and to while away a dull hour an automobile was "raffled off." The machine was said to be a $5,000. sixteen-horse power machine, the property of some one in Philadelphia. The chances ran from 1 cent to $10 apiece.

In some respects the twenty-sixth has been one of the most successful of the exhibitions held by the Society of American Artists. This is the last week, the time when the doubters and waverers among buyers are apt to decide to purchase. So far the sales have passed the $5,000 mark, and by Sunday they are likely to reach $7000.

WADING RIVER, L.I., April 27. -- In the possession of Isaac Valentine, notary public, is a packet which every inhabitant with a bump of curiosity would like to see opened. The little bundle is loaded down with seals, which will not be broken except in the presence of several parties having more than a curious interest in the contents.

Placing the blame for the maintenance of poolrooms at the door of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Capt. F. Norton Goddard, as Chairman of a sub-committee of the City Club, read a report at the club meeting last evening in which he detailed arrangements made by three men working in his interests to get information as to how officials of the telegraph company work with supposed poolroom men.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 27. -- Mrs. Vanderbilt arrived here this afternoon and is the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt at Sandy Point Farm.

TORONTO, April 27. -- A dispatch to The Globe from St. Johns, N.F., says a bill has passed the Legislative Assembly of the island providing for the granting of assistance to a United States company, which proposes to go into the cold-storage business on a large scale.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 27. -- It became public to-day that the Faculty has made an important change in Princeton eligibility rules. Hereafter a student having one condition will be allowed to compete in athletics provided he has not had two chances to remove it, otherwise he will be debarred.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- William Preston Harrison wants $750,000 from William Randolph Hearst, his employes, and his newspapers. He filed five suits to-day, in which the damages are placed at $150,000 each. The cause of action is libel, based on recent publications in the Hearst newspapers.

Horace S. Ely, President of the corporation of Horace S. Ely Co., and one of the best-known real estate men in the city, died yesterday morning at his residence, 19 East Fifty-fifth Street. Mr. Ely's death, resulting from heart disease, was very sudden. He had been at his office as recently as last Saturday, and his indisposition during the last two or three days had been looked upon as only temporary.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 27. -- The British steamship Craigneuk, sugar laden, from Matanzas for Sandy Hook, thence to Philadelphia, is ashore three miles below the South Brigantine Life Saving Station. Capt. Calvin of the stranded steamship says that his vessel went ashore early to-day during the severe northeast storm.

Additional gold to the amount of $2,000,000 was engaged for export yesterday, making the total to go by to-day's steamer $2,500,000, and the total for the week thus far $9,100,000. Besides the $500,000 being shipped by Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., Lazard Freres are shipping $1,500,000, and Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co. $500,000.

Immediately after calling the case of William Duke, who is charged with complicity in the $200,000 conspiracy to secure places in the city service, Magistrate Ommen, sitting in the West Side Court, made and immediately withdrew yesterday morning the following statement:

CHICAGO, April 27. -- The tenth annual meeting of the National Municipal League began in this city to-day, with delegates present from every large city in the United States. President Charles J. Bonaparte of Baltimore called the assemblage to order. Clinton Rogers Woodruff of Philadelphia spoke on "A Year's Disclosure and Development."

ALBANY, April 27. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed nearly 100 bills. One of them is the New York Home Rule bill, which confers upon the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the power to provide for a municipal ferry service, to establish a telegraph service in connection with the Police and Fire Departments, and provide for the extension of any public building.

NEW ORLEANS, April 27. -- Wildly cheering every reference to the recent overwhelming defeat of the Lily White ticket in the State election, the regular Republicans met here to-day, strongly indorsing President Roosevelt and his Administration, and sent a mixed delegation -- two negroes and two whites -- to the National Convention.

DETROIT, Mich., April 27. -- Robinson put the game out of doubt in the eighth inning when, with the score tied, his three-base hit sent in two runs and won for Detroit. Robinson also starred in the field, and worked in a great double play with Carr to relay the ball. Woods threw splendidly. Donovan pitched well, and Flaherty was hit harder than the score shows. Score by innings:

"The worst ever," was the regular's classification of the weather at the Jamaica race track yesterday, but miserable and saddening as were the conditions under which the racing started, there was cheer for the faithful in the afternoon's results, as three post favorites and one of two equal choices in the opening race were returned winners.

WARSAW, April 27. -- XVhile several DO-i Dee offieer were attempting to enter a l house in the Dvorsky thoroughfare tO-day ! they were attacked by a band of men , armed with ,evolvers and kniYes,' I Two ot the officers, a deputy ehteu of I the secret police and a Deputy CommisI sar v, were killed and two ohers were J wounded.

Summer had been far too long in coming to suit twelve-year-old Carl Christoffer and his sister Lena, two years younger, who live in the tenement 309 East Ninety-seventh Street. So they decided to go and look for it at Katonah, N.Y.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Capt. Dannhauer, the Lokal Anzieger's correspondent with Major von Glasenapp's column in Southwest Africa, has sent a dispatch by heliograph via Windhoek, announcing that the losses of the column through deaths, wounds, and sickness since March 13 have been, officers 63 per cent., and privates, 35 per cent Forty-four men are now sick with typhus, besides those sent to Windhoek.

Dullness and strength characterized yesterday's market, and of the two characteristics the dullness was the more significant. A market which loses activity when prices are bid up does not encourage further operations of the same sort. It looks too much as though buyers were "landed" with the stock which they would be unable to pass along to other buyers.

John E. McDonald of 216 West Seventy-seventh Street has brought suit in the Supreme Court, through Bowers Sands, against Charles W. Morse, ex-President of the American Ice Company, to recover $2000,000, out of which he says Mr. Morse defrauded him in 1900 on a deal in the stock of the company.

James H. Ottley has bought from the various owners 232, 236, 238, 240, 242, and 246 West Thirty-seventh Street and 241 and 243 West Thirty-sixth Street. Mr. Ottley is President of the McCall Company, publishers of McCall's Magazine and Patterns, and will begin at once the erection of an eight-story building on this plot, which he will lease to the McCall Company for a term of years.

Collector Jessup, winner of the Columbus Stakes Selling, at the Jamaica track yesterday, was bid up after the race by J.L. Maginnis, owner of Monet, the second horse, who bought him for $3,200. As Collector Jessup was entered to sell for $1,600, Maginnis, who was entitled to half of the surplus over the entered price, secured the horse for an actual cost of $2,400.

Through the "Returns of Trade for 1903," published by the Maritime Customs Department of China, and just received in this country, it is possible to trace distinctly the relative shares of the foreign trade of China belonging to Russia and Japan, now engaged in war on Chinese territory, and to Great Britain and the United States, the two nations most directly and largely interested.

ST. LOUIS, April 27. -- Cass Gilbert of New York, one of the architects of the World's Fair buildings, has resigned his position and brought suit in the United States Circuit Court against the Exposition Company for $47,113.96 salary alleged to be due him.

President ROOSEVELT is a very determined man. Opposition seems only to increase the tenacity with which he sticks to his purposes. More than a year ago he sent to the Senate the name of WILLIAM D. CRUM, a negro, to be Collector of Customs at Charleston, S.C. The Senate had not confirmed the nomination when the day of adjournment was reached.

ALBANY, April 27. -- In arguing before Gov. Odell to-day for the veto of the J.T. Smith Dutchess County Water bill, representatives of the McClellan administration and of the Merchants' Association informed the Governor that in affixing his signature to the bill he would leave the City of New York no alternative but to go to the Ramapo Water Company for its needed supply or face a water famine.
In order to show the plan drawings for its new clubhouse, the Woman's Club of New York, gave a reception at its present home, 9 East Forty-sixth Street, yesterday, from 4 to 10 o'clock.

"It is a case of persecution, pure and simple," said Frederick A. Southworth yesterday, referring to the arrest of his brother, Ellis B. Southworth, a lawyer of this city, on the charge of arson in connection with the burning of the Van Alen homestead at New Hamburg in February, 1903. Both the Southworths have their law office at 68 William Street. Ellis B. was arrested in Poughkeepsie on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The conferrees on the Panama Canal bill to-night averted the prolongation of the session, which seemed likely, by reaching an agreement on the government of the Panama Canal zone. The first section of the Senate bill providing for the payment of $10,000,000 to Panama, and the House provision placing the canal zone under the control of the President, are accepted.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 28. -- Disappointment prevails in St. Petersburg that no official dispatches giving details of the operations on the Yalu River have yet been made public.

Heinrich Conried, impresario, sat at his desk shortly after the noon hour yesterday ruminating upon the successes and the failures of his grand opera season. He was feeling drowsy, as people do after luncheon, and happy -- for was not the last of the operas sung last Monday?

PARIS, April 27. -- The wedding of Capt. Algernon Sartoris, grandson of the late Gen. Grant, and Mlle. Germaine Cecile Noufflard, a niece of Charles E. Halle, Director of the New Gallery, London, occurred this afternoon at the Church of St. Honore d'Eylau.

-- Practically everything that can be said in defense of menageries, public or private, was presented, and well presented, in the letter from "H.A.C." printed on this page yesterday. We have considered our correspondent's arguments carefully, and recognize the weight of some of them, but they leave us unconvinced that menageries are useful enough to justify the amount of suffering and cruelty their maintenance involves.

PATERSON, N.J., April 27. -- A fast train on the New York, Susquehanna and Westtern at 8:30 o'clock to-night struck a trolley car at the Vreeland Avenue crossing. The trolley car was lifted from the rails and hurled into the ditch, beside the tracks of the railroad. The collision threw the pony trucks of the locomotive from the rails.

LONDON, April 28. -- Discussing the reported resignation of Viceroy Alexieff, The Times's military correspondent says it is probable that the Viceroy offered to resign, but failed to receive the imperial permission to do so. The correspondent goes on to say:

Eleven members of the Panama Canal Commission arrived here yesterday on the steamship Yucatan. They were preceded by Commission William Barclay Parsons, who came here a week ago. Rear Admiral Walker, the President, had prepared a written statement about the work done on the week's tours along the canal, but after landing he suddenly remembered that he had locked it in his trunk, which already had started on its way to Washington.

LIAO-YANG, April 27. -- The Japanese troops which crossed the Yalu north of Euit-ju (Cheng-ju) charged, during the night of April 26-27, the Russian position near Lizavena, a village on the Manchurian bank of the Yalu.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The beginning of the end of the House session, a day which began two hours before the usual hour for opening and continued until late at night, was a stirring one.

From the fact that during the noon hour of yesterday's session of the stock market the trading amounted to only 10,000 shares can be judged the size of the day's market. The conditions which prevailed are perhaps still more clearly shown by the amusing diversions to which the brokers on the floor gave a considerable part of the day.

Robert Grau, who brought Mme. Patti to this country for her late disastrous tour, was up in supplementary proceedings in the City Court yesterday in connection with the judgment for $95.72, secured against him some weeks ago. The cause was a printing bill contracted while he was managing one of Loie Fuller's American tours.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- Owen Wister, the novelist, is in the Pennsylvania Hospital here in a serious condition, after an operation for appendicitis.
WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Representative Morgan C. Fitzpatrick of Tennessee was taken ill to-night in the House.

NEWARK, N.J., April 27. -- Vice Chancellor Stevens to-day granted an injunction restraining David Greenhill Bruce Gardyne of London, England, and Lafayette Hoyt De Friese and Benoni Lockwood, Jr., of New York, as trustees, from declaring dividends upon or from voting or disposing of in any way 6,640 shares of stock of the Guayaquil and Quito Railway Company, pending final hearing in the case.

Col. MARCHAND of Fashoda fame -- or obloquy -- has resigned his commission in the French Army. His resignation has been "reluctantly" accepted. He retires, he says, for "motives of a diplomatic and military order." He does not specify. Neither does Gen. ANDRE. The word "reluctantly" may stand for an eloquent, anguishing sense of loss or it may not. No one knows.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Company yesterday Heinrich Conried reported that the total receipts for the entire grand opera season, including the tour, amounted to $1,500,000. In addition to the regular dividend of 6 per cent. an extra dividend was declared on the capital stock of the corporation.
PARIS, April 28. -- A dispatch published in Paris to-day says Viceroy Alexieff's report to the Czar on the affair at Gen-san contained details which were not made public.

NEWARK, N.J., April 28. -- The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey proposes within the next four weeks to sell tickets from Jersey City to Philadelphia. The route will be from Jersey City to Newark, thence to Elizabeth, Cranford, Westfield, Plainfield, Dunellen, Bound Brook, New Brunswick, and Trenton.

ALPENA, Mich., April 28. -- H. Irving Andrews, alias E.H. Witherout, was arrested this afternoon on an indictment found against him by a Grand Jury in Brooklyn. N.Y., for grand larceny in the first degree, the specific charge being raising drafts and thereby fraudulently recovering nearly $19, 000 on Dec. 31.

Quotations from "Mary's Little Lamb," other statements equally non-committal in their tendency, and complete silence were forthcoming yesterday from officials and Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company when they were asked about the charges made by Capt. F. Norton Goddard to the City Club on Wednesday night. The Captain accused the company of deliberately aiding and abetting poolrooms of this city in violating the criminal laws of the State.

Louis Minsky, ex-Alderman and President of the Minsky Realty Company, Bowery and Grand Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a charge of grand larceny in connection with the Federal Bank case. The arrest was made by Detective Sergeant Clark at Minsky's real estate offices. He will be arraigned to-day before Justice Wyatt in Special Sessions.
The racing stable of John E. Madden and the horses trained by W.P. Burch arrived from Washington yesterday and went into quarters at the Morris Park course.

Until Sunday inclusive a very fetching little exhibition of paintings by two Japanese artists will be visible in the gallery of the Century Club, West Forty-third Street. The artists are Messrs. Taikan Yokoyama and Shiunzo Hishida, members of an art movement in Japan led by Mr. Kakuzo Okakura, who belong to an art league called the Bijitsuin, or Hall of Fine Arts.

Not even the unseasonable weather of yesterday could mar the success of the twelfth annual horse show of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn, which opened last night at the clubhouse on the Park Plaza, Brooklyn, in the presence of the usual fashionable assemblage.

Mr. WILLIAM ENGLISH WALLING, in an instructive article in The World's Work, thus briefly summarizes the results of the movement to defend the industries of this country against the efforts of the trades unions to dominate them:

BOSTON, April 28. -- It was announced on the Boston Stock Exchange this afternoon that Thomas W. Lawson had severed his connection with the firm of Lawson, Arnold Co., bankers and brokers. The firm holds membership in both the Boston and New York Stock Exchanges.
Gen. T.S. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers and C.D. Lawrence, Assistant Counsel to the Government, will go to Philadelphia to-day to hear a docket of 300 customs cases.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- Representative Timothy D. Sullivan of New York and Ollie James of Kentucky are close friends. To-day Mr. James received the following characteristic telegram from Mr. Sullivan, who is in New York:

On the disputed claim for Lou Dillon, last season's champion trotter, to a record to the old-fashioned high-wheel sulky, surpassing the mark established by Maud S., which stood for years, new light has been thrown by the discovery that William W. Bair, who was trainer and driver of Maud S., is living in Philadelphia.

Mayor McClellan yesterday afternoon gave a hearing on the Municipal Court bill, This measure, which was introduced in the Legislature by Senator Elsberg, provides for an increase of eight in the number of Municipal Court Justices in Greater New York -- three of the new Justices to go to Brooklyn, two to Manhattan, and one each to Bronx, Queens, and Richmond.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., April 28. -- The results in the third round of the international chess masters' tourney, played to-day, were mostly in accordance with expectations. The results in detail follow:

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Free firecrackers and torpedoes will be given in unlimited quantities to every child in the city on the Fourth of July by the Chicago Amusement Association, provided the children will assemble in the public parks and playgrounds and explode them under the supervision of a fireman, a physician, a policeman, and a member of the association.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 28. -- William Cly of Mount Tabor, aged twenty-six, is in the hospital here with a bad gunshot wound in his left foot, which may have to be amputated. His misfortune is due to an attempt to play a good joke on some of the muskrats that infest his barn.

LONDON, April 20. -- During the week two openings in London have introduced plays which are more or less American. The patriotic American will be pleased to know that both have met the favor of the London critic, who is not always easy to satisfy.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The Pennsylvania Senators stretched the rule of Senatorial courtesy to the limit to-day in defeating the confirmation of Charles F. McKenna to be United States District Judge for Porto Rico. Mr. McKenna is a leading member of the Pittsburg bar and a veteran of the civil war.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The great increase in National expenditures within recent years was the subject of debate in the closing hours of the Senate to-day. The debate came after Senator Allison's statement as Chairman of the Committee on Appropriations

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 28. -- The Conference for Southern Education, held in this city, ended its sessions this evening after two meetings held in the Jefferson Theatre, one in the morning and the other in the evening.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The adjournment of the Senate was hardly more than the ordinary termination of the usual daily session. Twice within half an hour of the time for final adjournment the Senate went into executive session to confirm nominations that were sent in to-day. This made it necessary for the crowds in the galleries to retire.

All ferryboats navigating the harbor hereafter will have two men in the engine room, as well as in the pilot house, as a result of this letter, issued yesterday by the local Government Inspectors of steam vessels:

The impression left upon the mind of the country by the session of Congress, just ended, is one of Republican discomfiture and Democratic triumph. The session with which a Presidential year opens is always availed of for partisan manoeuvres, especially in the House. Each side seeks to put the other in a position of disadvantage.

Philip Hamburger, City Marshal, went over into East New York last night to seize the goods in the dry goods store of Kivowits Brothers, at 193 Watkins Street. Now he is sorry he went. The brothers, Max and David, are just as sorry he came.

Favoring the general route proposed by the Metropolitan interests for the next rapid transit subway, with the exception of advocating the use of Seventh instead of Eighth Avenue up to Forty-third Street, the Committee on Plan and Scope of the Rapid Transit Commission submitted its report and recommendations to the meeting of the board yesterday.

In the Essex Market Court yesterday afternoon a young man applied to Magistrate Mayo for a warrant for an official of the Jarmulowsky Bank, at 165 East Broadway. The young man said that he had a deposit of $80 in the bank; that in the morning he drew $15, and in the afternoon wanted to draw $50 more. He was refused, he said, and told he must give ninety days' notice.

LIAO-YANG, April 28. -- Major Togo Tatzozero, a member of the general staff of the Japanese Army, who is a prisoner here, having been captured at Wi-ju, where he had lived since last January, said to The Associated Press to-day:

Your correspondent of the 27th, "H.A.C.," expresses the conviction of many of New York's citizens and taxpayers as to the value of the New York Zoological Park. Apart from scientific and sentimental considerations relating to the beasts themselves is a consideration of importance, ignored by the editorial writer of Sunday and by your correspondent of to-day as well.
The platform adopted by the Democrats of New Hampshire at their State Convention contains this declaration:

I trust you will allow me to say a few words in reply to your editorial of April 26 on the subject of the open shop in the clothing trade. As a perfectly independent witness, who is neither an employer nor an employe in the trade. I have for five years given a special study to this question by a close intercourse with the two parties in the dispute.

In the discussion of the advantages to result to property owners, in lower insurance rates, from the high-pressure salt and fresh water service which is to be provided for the business districts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, the experience of Philadelphia may profitably be considered.

If there is any one factor which more than any other is exerting an unfavorable influence on the financial markets at this time it is the neverending announcements of loans secured by some railroad or other company for the purpose of "pressing improvements," "new construction," or general necessity.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- President Roosevelt has appointed Thomas C. Dawson of Iowa, at present Secretary of the United States Legation at Rio Janeiro, as United States Minister to Santo Domingo.

NEW ORLEANS, La., April 28. -- The Democrats of Mississippi who favor Judge Alton B. Parker as the Democratic nominee for President are growing impatient over his silence, and unless he declares himself on important National issues before the State Convention is held, May 15, the chances of the New York jurist for capturing the State delegation are uncertain.

DETROIT, Mich., April 28. -- Pitcher Killian came very near shutting out Chicago to-day. He had excellent control of the ball and allowed only three hits, two of which were scratches. The Detroit players drove White from the box in the third inning and then gave Patterson, his successor, a warm welcome in the fourth inning. Score by innings:

The Democrats in the House of Representatives are greatly to be congratulated, as we have just now and often before had occasion to say, upon having got a leader. For the first time in many years they shine in contrast with the Republicans in this respect. No better illustration of the advantages of party discipline has been afforded at this session than the defeat in the House of the "leave to print."

HARTFORD, Conn., April 28. -- President Charles S. Mellen of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad addressed the Workingmen's Free Reading Room Association to-night, in fulfillment of a promise made some months ago, and upon a topic relating to the present condition o workingmen.

Motorcyclists from all parts of the country are expected to compete in the annual endurance run, which will be conducted this year by the Federation of American Motorcyclists from July 2 to 9. The test has heretofore been run by the New York Motorcycle Club, but the local organization tendered it to the Federation of American Motorcyclists, the National body.

A quarrel between young men riding to work on a Ridgewood elevated train in Brooklyn yesterday morning led to a stabbing, followed by an exciting chase after the man said to have used the knife. Henry Boeckman of 341 Central Avenue and his brother and a third man were in the fracas at the start.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 28. -- Russian torpedo boats belonging to the Vladivostok squadron sank a Japanese military transport, the Kinshiu Maru, of 4,000 tons, on the night of April 26, with all on board with the exception of 17 officers, 20 soldiers, 65 of the crew, and 85 coolie carriers.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 28. -- Judge Acheson of the United States Court handed down a decision to-day in the habeas corpus proceedings in the case of Lieut. R.W. Drury and Private John Dowd, United States Army, for the shooting of William Crowley at the Arsenal last September. The Judge dismissed the writ and the defendants were remanded to the county authorities.

ALBANY, April 28. -- There is one point on which I would like you to give me information," said Gov. Odell to Fred Corey at the hearing to-day on the Niagara Power bill, extending the life and power of the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company. "What do you think of the policy of the State continuing to give away its property?"

Brody, Adler Koch have bought from the State Realty and Mortgage Company, through Pocher Co., the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Eighth Street, 200 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue, 100 by 100.11.

The Cambridge Springs chess tournament prompts me to call attention to the fact that the United States won the international yaching and chess championships about a half century ago. The old America's Cup is still here, and I think most of us are always pleased to hear of another win for Columbia or Reliance -- even those who don't care for yachting, (or, like the writer, can't afford it.)

PARIS, April 28. -- A telegram from Mukden says that, paradoxical as it may appear, it is necessary to accustom one's self to the idea that military operations on a large scale will not begin before September, of course unless the Japanese invade Manchurian territory, which henceforth will be a very risky proceeding.

DUBLIN, April 28. -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra had a great popular ovation in the streets of Dublin this afternoon while on their way to lay the foundation stone of the Royal College of Science. Troops lined the route, which was crowded for hours before the royal cortege arrived.
BERLIN, April 28. -- The Vossische Zeltung says Emperor William has expressed open dissatisfaction with the management of affairs in Southwest Africa.

A motion for the appointment of a referee was made yesterday before Supreme Court Justice MacLean, in the case which appears on the calendar as De Peyster Field against De Peyster Field. The papers were handed to the Judge. Man Man of 56 Wall Street represent the plaintiff, and Emmet Robinson of 52 Wall Street are counsel for the defendant.

Alfred John Lincoln Perrin, a lion tamer, who lives in the house of Mrs. Emma Smith at 118 Lynch Street, Williamsburg, had his neighbors in Lynch Street, between Lee and Marcy Avenues, in a state of great excitement early yesterday morning by his strange actions on the roof of many dwellings.

Twenty-five families were driven from their homes and damage aggregating thousands of dollars was caused last night in St. Raymond's Park, a residence section between Unionport and Westchester, in Bronx Borough, by the overflowing of the waters of Cebric Creek, in an arm of the larger Westchester Creek running in from Long Island Sound.

The death of Col. Burton N. Harrison, who was private secretary to President Jefferson Davis, removes a prominent figure in the retreat and capture of Mr. Davis. As I have before stated in these letters, the fate of the Confederacy was settled in a full Cabinet meeting held in Charlotte, N.C. Thereafter plans were discussed and means used to secure the safe conveyance of Mr. Davis and his family beyond the reach of Federal authority.

In a decision written by Gen. T.S. Sharretts, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by Albert Lorsch Co. of New York against the assessment of 45 per cent. duty as manufacturers of glass or haste on certain imitation precious stones. Gen. Sharretts's decision involves a consideration of the intention of Congress and the grammatical education of the writer of the tariff law.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The last session of the House was not up to some prior adjournments from a spectacular standpoint, but it stood all by itself in the love-feast which marked its close.

Doubtless it is of rather evil augury for the Louisiana Purchase Exposition that, just as it is throwing wide its doors, and inviting the world to come in, it should be disturbed by a suit by one of the architects who have helped to make it. The architect, as our readers know, is Mr. CASS GILBERT.

Kissing a rude picture of Admiral Togo until he had worn the ink off the paper and transferred to his bronzed features the red headlines of the Kobe newspaper which contained the outline of the war hero's features, Mobdodi, the Japanese carpenter of the British steamship McDuff, yesterday gave vent all at once to an amount of enthusiasm that should have been distributed over the whole course of the present war.
BALTIMORE, April 28. -- The winners of the four principal trophies at the Women's Whist Convention were announced to-day as follows:

ST. LOUIS, April 28. -- The feature of the meeting of the Committee on Arrangements for the convention of the Democratic National Committee to-day was the decision to introduce an innovation in the form of telephonic communication between the platform and each of the State delegations at the National Convention in July.

WASHINGTON, April 28. -- The second session of the Fifty-eighth Congress, which terminated at 2 o'clock this afternoon, has the distinction of having been the shortest "long" session of Congress since 1860 and of having spent more money in that time than any previous session, barring war times.

Dr. John Kells Ingram, the well-known English author of "Outlines of the History of Religion," "Sonnets and Other Poems," "Passages from the Letters of Auguste Comte," "Human Nature and Morals According to Auguste Comte," , is publishing in this country through the Macmillan Company "Practical Morals: A Treatise on Universal Education."

THE BOOK OF THE NEW YORK TIMES, with its "Queries," always interests me. In regard to "C.L.N." Fayetteville, N.Y., who makes an author of the memorable words. "Millions for defense, but not one cent for tribute," and your reply in your issue of April 23:

MRS. CRAIGIE complains that the system by which the payment of authors is made dependent on the number of thousand words written by them is a very bad one. She insists that it induces authors to pad their books and thus is ruinous to good literature.

The City Club has rendered a service to the gentlemen composing the Directorate of the Western Union Telegraph Company in making them aware of the expedients adopted by the subordinate officers of that corporation in co-operating with the poolrooms. Speculation as to the action of the board in view of the facts before them is undesirable.
PARIS, April 29. -- Emperor William's speech has caused a profound sensation here.

ORANGE, N.J., April 29. -- A second-story burglar, whose work bore many of the characteristics of that done by the man who stole jewelry valued at from $7,000 to $8,000 from the home of James B. Dill, in East Orange, visited the residence of William A. Shaw, on Reynolds Terrace, Orange, last night, and secured property valued at $2,500.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 29. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the bill of the Senate Committee on Judiciary providing for the removal from the enrollment lists in New York City of names of members of political parties who are proved to be out of sympathy with the party. The proceedings may be instituted upon complaint of any other enrolled member of the party.

ALBANY, April 29. -- When David B. Hill and William F. Sheehan returned to the Ten Eyck Hotel late to-night after an hour's conference in Mr. Hill's office with regard to the Chairmanship of the Democratic State Committee, they announced that no decision had been reached, and none would be reached until after a conference to-morrow, in which the New York and Brooklyn leaders will participate.

Mr. Julian S. Corbett has absorbed tomes of military and diplomatic history in preparing to write his new naval book "England in the Mediterranean," which, like its predecessor, "Drake and the Tudor Navy," aims to show the rise of England as a naval power. In 1609 Spain made one of her worst blunders. She expelled the Moriscos from her dominions.

IN THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW of April 23, 1904, at the request of G. Wentworth, West New Brighton; S.I., you publish a few facts in relation to the Geneva "Breeches" Bible. Feeling quite an interest in the early editions of the, Sacred Word, I have made the following extract from the catalogue of "The Bibles at the Caxton Exhibition," held in London, 1877, compiled by Mr. Henry Stevens.

NEW ORLEANS, April 29. -- Several hundred mosquitos and larvae arrived here to-day from Havana en route to St. Louis, Mo., where the curious shipment will be used to demonstrate the Havana theory that yellow fever germs cannot be implanted in the human system except through the bite of a mosquito.

-- In a laborious disquisition on the letter Q, that wholly useless member of a family in which most of the members are cruelly overworked, one of the London papers raises anew the old question as to the origin of the common phrase, "mind your p's and q's," and rejects with a good deal of scorn most of the explanations that have been invented for it.

WINSTED, Conn., April 29. -- William, the twelve-year-old son of Bradford Crawford, went into the Bradley District School in Lee, a village in the Berkshire Hills, yesterday and commenced to pick a dynamite firecracker with a pin. Suddenly there was a loud explosion and the school was thrown into a panic. Miss Evelyn Todd, the teacher, thought somebody had shot at her and almost fainted.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 29. -- In the most categorical terms Russia has officially notified the world that she will not accept mediation to terminate the war with Japan.

A masked ball in Florence and the plot of a very wicked Duke to steal an extraordinary beauty from a nunnery by night this is the stuff Mr. Cleveland's story is made of. The historical matter about the Medicis, Emperor Charles, and King Francis is hardly important. It rather cumbers the first few pages and then sinks out of sight.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 29. -- "Should the Democratic National Convention, in accordance with the suggestion of Bourke Cockran in a recent speech, nominate you for the Presidency, what would you do?"

JUST now, when we are daily hearing from the Fax East some tidings to increase our admiration for the military activity and skill of the Japanese, it is for a moment difficult to realize as we read Mr. Rittner's little book that it is about the same nation that has so courageously and effectively given battle to the Czar and his theoretically powerful army and navy.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., April 29. -- The fourth round of the international chess masters' tournament was played to-day, and at the close of play Lasker and Marshall had taken the lead ever Janowski and Mieses. Janowski, however, had left his game against Hodges unfinished, and it will surely be won by the Parisian. Janowski is therefore really the leader, having three straight wins to his credit and an adjourned game in hand.

Mrs. John Gerken was the principal winner at the annual horse show of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn at the clubhouse on the Park Plaza, Brooklyn, last night, taking three firsts with her well-known Newsboy and Shop Girl, and obtaining the ownership of the Lawson Cup by a third consecutive victory with Newsboy in the gig class.

After years of desperate fighting and back-biting in the Ninth Assembly District between the Horatio Seymour Club, which is the regular Tammany organization, and the old Pequod Club of John C. Sheehan's forces, the Tammany club this evening will accomplish the complete obliteration of the other organization.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 29. -- When Henry Brink of East Belvidere arose to-day it was suggested to him that as it was the open season for trout and he might do well to spend a morning in replenishing the larder. So Brink, who was suffering from a severe attack of Spring fever, took up his rod and fly book and hied him to the woods.

In "The Day's Work" Kipling described the important work done by the rivets and told how they had to "sit tight and hold fast." An extremely technical book on these humble but useful adjuncts of modern engineering is "Machine Design, Part One; Fastenings," by Prof. William Ledyard Cathcart of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Columbia.

When John Wayland, the son of a Major in the Continental Army, who had retired with his wife and child to a farm in the wilderness, grasped his gun and strode to meet the messenger who came from the furthest outpost of that wilderness, he prepared for danger. But the messenger was a friend, and the message he brought was from a friend and former comrade of Major Wayland.

NAGASAKI, April 29. -- To all intents and purposes the Port Arthur action of April 13 destroyed all reasonable fear of interference with Japan's plans in the Yellow Sea by the Russian Pacific squadron and with the successful outcome of the operations now reported on the Yalu.

Hawthorne's essay, "The Old Manse," (in the Riverside Press editions, limited to 500 copies, long 16mo. 89 pages; New York and Boston: Houghton, Mifflin Co., $2 net,) formed the introduction to his collection of "Mosses from an Old Manse," inspired by the Old Manse, in which he lived for three years.

The present town of Lehighton. Carbon County, Penn., was originally the Moravian settlement of Gnadenhutten. In 1755 a number of Moravians were massacred here by the Indians, and from that time the influence of the Moravians waned until their mission was entirely abandoned. Somewhere about 1825 there appeared here a woman, it may be of royal pedigree, bearing the name of Frederika Misca.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 29. -- The fight between the town of Oyster Bay and Leonard Jacob, a wealthy resident and the owner of East Island, for possession of East Beach, the town won its first victory to-day before County Judge Seabury at the Nassau County Court House.

In quick response to the change for the better in the weather, the attendance at the Jamaica race track yesterday jumped up to holiday proportions, a crowd of about 8,000 witnessing the running of the rather modest programme and incidentally picking the winners with such precision as to round out a bad afternoon for the bookmakers.

MUCH is being said in the newspapers and literary periodicals of the day in regard to the development of interest on the part of English readers in American books. A curious fact in connection with this is found in the circumstances attending the publication of Burne-Jones's "Dollars and Democracy."
DUBLIN, April 29. -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra attended the Leopards-town races to-day, the smartest day of the Dublin race week.

In Anjou, in the days of Henri Quatre, dwelt, according to this story, a pale youth who loved, or thought he loved, a maid. The maid was capricious, and so provoked the youth by her coquetries and taunts that he set out for Paris one day with no other purpose than to cut off the mustaches of one Brignan de Brignan, of whom he had heard the maid speak with some warmth of admiration.

I have been reading with much interest the communications published in your columns about ghost stories. Being an ardent admirer of Poe, I have always read with avidity every tale of the gruesome or unnatural that was recommended. It has always been a matter of wonder to me that so few persons have read any of Eugene Field's stories in the field of the weird.

Charged with disorderly conduct in having heaved two big paving stones through the front door of the First Moravian Church, at Lexington Avenue and Thirtieth Street, James Jennings, a laborer, was locked up in the East Thirty-fifth Street Police Station last night.

Preliminary competitions in foils and sabres were held last night in the gymnasium of the New York Athletic Club for the National fencing championship. The tournament, which will be concluded this evening, is held under the auspices of the Amateur Fescers' League of America. Individual championships for the coming year will be awarded in foils, sabres, and duelling swords.

" The Old Riddle and the Newest Answer," by John Gerard, S.J., F.L.S., is an inquiry as to how far modern science has altered the aspect of the problem of the universe. The book is about to be brought out by Longmans, Green Co. The author indicates the object of the inquiry in the first paragraph of his preface:

OCCASIONALLY a voice is heard suggesting that we are having something too much of this Newman and Oxford Movement business, but the publishers and writers do not seem to be of this opinion. Just at this moment we have two separate studies of Newman freshly competing for our interest.

For a long time the professional and artificial character of the stock market has been imputed to it for a reproach. Yesterday it appeared as a virtue. It is not too much to say that if yesterday's news had caught an inflating market full of novices there would have been a les agreeable report to make of it to-day.

Mayor McClellan for more than four hours yesterday listened to the arguments for and against an approval of the Elsberg bill abolishing the office of Coroner in this city at the close of the terms of the men at present holding the places. The bill proposes that the Board of Health shall appoint a Chief Medical Examiner and a Bureau of Medical Examination in the Health Department as a substitute for the Board of Coroners.

Thomas J. Majors, the New Orleans cotton operator, was yesterday elected a member of the New York Cotton Exchange at a meeting of the Board of Managers of that organization. this election settles what may be termed an interexchange dispute, in which the New York and the New Orleans Cotton Exchanges were interested.

MR. COLQUHOUN uses the word "America" as the National designation of the country called by irritatingly stupid Englishmen "The States," and he describes this country as a "federal empire." "Broadly speaking," he says, "the American empire is composed of States, Territories, dependencies, and protectorates," a sentence which shows sufficiently that he considers the United States Government not as it is by theory, but as in fact he finds it.

I can especially recommend to "Librarian" "The Knocker," "Rather Ghostly," (this is a series of short stories, all good,) "The Miser's Curse," "The Doppelganger," "What Did Mrs. Darrington See?" "Wed in the Morning; Dead at Night," and "The Dumberdene," this last was published in Harper's Weekly in early Summer of the year 1873, and is one of the best ghost stories I ever read.

At a time when Japan is proving conclusively her adoption of Western methods and her consummate cleverness with Western weapons, it is singularly appropriate that Lafcadio Hearn, who has always been enamored of old Japan -- Japan unvisited by missionaries or merchants and unspoiled by modern ways -- should remind the public, with his little volume of "Kwaidan," or "Weird Tales," of interesting and delightful characteristics that are fast disappearing from the Island Empire.

Messrs. Harper Brothers announce for publication on May 5 "The Gates of Chance," by Van Tassel Sutphen, author of "The Cardinal's Rose." The new story is officially described as one of "excitement, mystery, and rushing incident," relating as it does the adventures of two young men in search of thrills in real life.
ST. LOUIS, April 29. -- Miss Julia Ten Eyck McBlair of Washington, D.C., hostess of the Woman's Board, was badly injured to-day at the World's Fair by being run over.

Back of all the intricate details of the statements as to the spending authorized by the late session of Congress lies the unquestionable fact that the cost of the Government is steadily increasing, not only in the gross amount each year, but in the amount per capita. The simple comparison made by Mr. CULBERSON, who is a candid and a careful man, emphasizes this fact, which is well known to all students of public affairs.

There is something decidedly fresh and joyous in Anne Warner's story of "A Woman's Will." You see, this woman was an American, and she was very willful, which does not by any means mean that she was strong-willed, but neither was she really weak. She was a distinctly feminine young person, and, added to the dangers of her femininity, she was a widow.

TACOMA, Washington, April 29. -- "Bob" Taylor, a criminal with police records in Indiana, Colorado, and California, killed two men yesterday and to-day wounded Sheriff Denholm before allowing himself to be taken prisoner. The Sheriff is in hospital here.

The annual report of the Directors of the General Electric Company to the stockholders for the year ended Jan. 31 last shows net profits of $7,865,376, including royalties and profit from securities sold and after allowing for depreciation. From this amount was deducted $76,007 for interest on debentures and $1,470,098 representing the amount written off from the patents and other accounts of the Stanley Electric Company, leaving a balance of $6,319,270.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. George L. Rives and Miss Natica Rives have arrived at their villa, Swanhurst, for the season.

DALLAS, Texas, April 29. -- The trial to-day of Henry Simmons, the negro murderer of Lula Sandberg at Austin, consumed less than one hour's time. He pleaded guilty, but in order to make the trial legal the State had to observe the forms of law in taking other testimony. The jury convicted him, and he was sentenced to death.

A dividend of 1 1/2 per cent. and an extra dividend of one-quarter of 1 per cent. were declared by the Directors of the Northern Pacific Railway Company yesterday, payable May 2 to these who may be legally entitled to receive them. The official announcement was in this form instead of in the usual form, stating that the dividend would be paid to stockholders of record of a certain date.

PARIS, April 29. -- The Chinese Minister in Paris, Sueng-Pao-Ki, has made an interesting statement, which, if it proves nothing else, furnishes evidence that official China is anxious to refuse in advance the responsibility for any collision that may eventually occur between Chinese and Russian troops. He says:

ST. LOUIS, April 29. -- Great crowds are pouring into St. Louis for the opening of the World's Fair to-morrow, every excursion and other train that arrives at the Union Station bringing a full contingent to help swell the army of sightseers that throng the down-town streets and besiege the hotels and boarding houses.

WHEELING, West Va., April 29. -- For the second time within ninety days Sister Alma of the local Catholic diocese was to-day the victim of an attack. This time she may lose her sight and be disfigured for life.

Mr Tolman's contributions to the vast mass of Shakespearean commentary and criticism are marked by good sense, fine taste, insight, and a wide and intimate acquaintance with the literature of the subject. Besides essays on various problems and difficulties in Shakespeare that are worrying and long have worried the students, he has given in this volume various other literary and philological discussions that will interest the lay reader with liking for such matters.

The telephone in the office of United States Marshal Henkel kept a-buzzing for two hours yesterday morning, for he had advertised the sale of a quantity of dainty raiment which had been seized on Feb. 14. The goods seized included beautiful gowns from Paris, embroidered silk underwear, toilet articles, and exquisite baby clothes.

PROBABLY no subject has a wider range of contemporaneous interest than that of industrial peace. That we are now in a state of industrial war, in which the disasters of conflict are but emphasized by occasional and uncertain periods of truce, is a fact of which the most optimistic cannot fail to be conscious. A modus vivendi at least is greatly to be desired.

RUTLAND, Mass., April 29. -- The first batch of prisoners for the temporary industrial camp which was formally opened Saturday by proclamation of the Governor, arrived here to-day. The prisoners were chained in two gangs of eight each and were in charge of Frederick C. Pettigrove, Chairman of Prison Commissioners.

Roman Catholic Archbishop John J. Williams of Boston, Mass., quietly celebrated on Wednesday last the eighty-second anniversary of his birth. He is in good health, and discharges all his official duties with promptness and regularity.

Timothy P. Sullivan, Alderman and Vice Chairman of the board, gave an automobile imitation of Phil Sheridan's ride yesterday when, in response to an urgent call from the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, he shattered time records and speed limits to smithereens and covered the distance from the Dewey Theatre, in Fourteenth Street, to the City Hall in seven minutes.

Remembering how it was when about a year ago I asked for information regarding Rose Terry Cooke's poem, "The Two Villages," that replies came from all over the country by dozens, and at the end of six months they were still coming once every week, I have no doubt that readers will be able to help the Albany Institute to discover a few of the portraits of Albany's Mayors.

The United States Realty and Construction Company has bought, through John N. Golding, the property at 98 Cedar Street, corner of Temple Street, 104 Cedar Street, and 99 Trinity Place. With the exception of the property at 100 Cedar Street, owned by the city and used as a fire engine house, the United States Realty and Construction Company now owns all of the small block at the rear of the Boreel Building.

" Feisengarten," the Garden of Rocks, is the "mountain garden" which Mrs. Theodore Thomas, wife of the well-known musician, describes in her book, "Our Mountain Garden." It is "strictly a 'homemade'" garden, standing on the southern slope of a New Hampshire mountain.

We certainly cannot approve of much of the attack of Mr. CLAUDE KITCHIN upon Mr. ROOSEVELT. Many of his statements were extravagant, some of them were inspired by party feeling not easily distinguished from malice. We do not believe that such treatment of a political opponent is any more expedient than it is fair or courteous.

The wonderful fund of information that is brought out through the "Query" department of THE BOOK REVIEW is the excuse for this request for proof of the race that is entitled to the credit of producing Pierre Dominique Toussaint I'Ouverture. Can any reader affirm his pedigree to contain a predominating percentage of negro blood?

If Commissioner McAdoo has been correctly reported, he holds an original opinion about Sunday baseball playing; it is not right in densely settled portions of the city, but is right in sparsely settled portions. It is certainly a very interesting and important question, about equal to the ancient one of how many righteous men were necessary to save a city.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 29. -- A tremendous outburst of popular enthusiasm was witnessed this morning on the arrival here of the survivors of the Variag and the Korietz.

Readers of "The Dominant Strain" will remember it as a story of unusual cleverness and strength, one which came near to having a "staying power" rare in the novel of the hour -- or minute. "By the Good Sainte Anne" is of much lighter quality. It is a typical "Summer novel" -- which means the most diaphanous of literary productions.

Charles Lewis Hind, author of "The Enchanted Stone" and "Life's Little Things," has written a new volume entitled "Adventures Among Pictures." This is, he points out in his introductory chapter, "a book of appreciations." And he continues:

W. Cooper Hewitt announced yesterday that his entry for the Gordon Bennett international automobile race had been withdrawn through inability to complete his car in time for the technical inspection by the committee of the Automobile Club of America. This leaves only two entries for the big race, the Winton racer known as Bullet No. 2, and the car designed by L.P. Mooers.

LUMBERTON, N.C., April 29. -- The entire membership of the Robeson County bar, comprising thirty-five of the most prominent citizens, threatened with fines and imprisonment for contempt of court is the extraordinary situation in this county. The lawyers over whom this menace hangs are making threats on their own account. They say they will begin impeachment proceedings against Judge Robert B. Peebles of the Supreme Court, who has stirred up the row.

Dodd, Mead Co. are to publish a series of biographies of "The American Jurists," which will be under the editorship of Harry Alonzo Cushing, LL. B., Ph. D., whose three-volume work on "The Writings of Samuel Adams," in the Fathers of the Republic Series, G.P. Putnam's Sons, are rushing through the press, owing to the author's departure for Europe in a week or so.

LONDON, April 29. -- Prof. Campbell Fraser's "Biographia Philosophica," to be published next week by Messrs. Blackwood, contains narratives of the lives of Benjamin Jowett, Thomas Carlyle, J.S. Mill, Matthew Arnold, Herbert Spencer, and other celebrities.

The Macmillan Company is publishing this week "Pioneer History Stories," by Dr. Charles A. McMurry, in three volumes -- ''Pioneers on Land and Sea," "Pioneers of the Mississippi Valley," and "Pioneers of the Rocky Mountains and the West" "The Singular Miss Smith," by Mrs. Florence Morse Kingsley; "The Statesman's Year Book.

Mr. THOMAS W. LAWSON has made good the promise of his statement following the Bay State Gas litigation, and if he accomplishes nothing of benefit to the public or of injury to certain financiers who are said to have profited largely by the credulity of speculative investors he will at least have done what he could to "lift the lid."

The question why Charles Reade should have become and continued what Rudyard Kipling calls him, "a shamefully neglected author," seems to be in the way of being answered by disappearing. At any rate, a "standard edition" of Reade is announced from London. The people who continue to read Reade will agree that it is much needed.

Mr. J.J. Bell's newest chapter in the veracious history of "Wee Macgreegor," contributed to The Metropolitan Magazine, is not the less interesting because young Robinson's experience in relation to a "wee dog" and a "wee brither" is so strikingly like the experience of Miss Daskam's infant hero in the recently published "Memoirs of a Baby," wherein a goat (a purely imaginary but much-longed-for playmate) filled the role of Macgreegor's unobtainable dog who "answers to Joseph."

The many letters regarding the unfortunate "Elizabeth and Her German Garden" which have appeared from time to time in your paper have filled me with wonder that there should, be people so unappreciative at they are eager to attack with tooth and claw this most engaging of heroines.

Count Arthur Cassini, the Russian Ambassador at Washington, in the forthcoming May issue of The North American Review, under the caption "Russia in the Far East," discusses Russia's position in the conflict in the Far East between that country and Japan. In furnishing the article Count Cassini remarks that he is actuated by the hope that it will be of equal benefit to Russia and the readers of the magazine.

Purchases by the United States Realty and Construction Company in the block bounded by Thames, Cedar, and Temple Streets and Trinity Place, at the rear of the Boreel Building, are referred to in more detail in another column.

Men of genius have no more infirmities than other men, Maiden to the contrary notwithstanding. Instance Voltaire, Shakespeare, Wordsworth, Browning, Longfellow, and many others. There may be a popular idea among the vulgar and illiterate that a man able to manipulate a language in all its possible varieties of form must be an irresponsible eccentric, but it is a wrong idea, and a very absurd idea.

Nothing that you have printed since THE BOOK REVIEW started will attract so much individual notice and comment, I am sure, as your discussion of ghost stories. I fankly confess to a boyhood and enduring interest in the subject, not because I am a believer, but for the thrilling hold a good one still has upon me.

For two weeks the main galleries of the American Art Association, 6 East Twenty-third Street, will show the water-colors and pastels which form the thirty-seventh exhibition of the American Water Color Society. Only 345 pictures have been hung, and as wall space is abundant, everybody is debarred the luxury of grumbling over skied or crowded work.

BERLIN, April 29. -- The speech delivered by the Emperor at Karlsruhe yesterday in reply to an address from the Magistrates of the city is not regarded as shedding much light on those questions of foreign affairs which, from the German point of view, present to many critics the aspect of a tangled web.

Mr. Charles T. Copeland, lecturer on English literature at Harvard University, has come first in the field in Hawthorne Centennial year with an address on the Great New England romancer. He delivered it at Bowdoin College, Brunswick, Me., April 20. He gave particular attention to Hawthorne's relation to the English and the effect upon the people of the "Old Home," of Hawthorne's famous statement that "every extraordinary Englishman is a sick Englishman."

SHANGHAI, April 29. -- Viceroy Chang-Chi-Tung met his colleague, Wei-Wang-Tao to-day, the principal object of the meeting being to discuss military reorganization in the Yang-Tse valley and the removal of the Kiang-Nan arsenal, which Chang-Chi-Tung is anxious to expedite.

To read Stephen Gwynn's "Fishing Holidays" and not to experience an angling craving is hardly possible. Certainly what the author calls the "piscatory illusion" exists. As he explains it, savage man would take his fish in any way, with a pitchfork did he possess one, but cultured man will not indulge in any of these brutal ways.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The effort to bring about an understanding with Russia by which the passports of United States citizens of the Hebrew faith may be honored throughout the Czar's domains has little prospect of success at this time.
A customer of Anness Newman, a Broad Street curb house, gave an order to that firm yesterday to buy one share of American Can common.

" Through the Lands of the Serb" is the title of a volume of travel by Mary E. Durham. It is the account of a visit to Montenegro and Servia. The first part of the book, "Montenegro and the Way There," contains references and brief descriptions of Cattaro, Njegushi, Cetinje, Podgoritza, Rijeka, Ostrog, Nikshitje, Dukle, Antivari, the North Albanian, Skodora, and Dulcigno.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- During the discussion yesterday in the House on the bill to restore to the Naval Academy two midshipmen who were dismissed for hazing, Mr. Adams of Pennsylvania made an effective speech against the bill, in the course of which he was interrupted by Mr. Lacey of Iowa, the sponsor for the measure, who desired to ask a question.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29. -- Twenty-six counties will select delegates to the Democratic State Convention to-morrow, and one county Monday next, which will conclude the list.

LIBRARIAN" should not miss Farjeon while in search of creepy stories. One of his short tales concerning the gradual possession of a minister by a devil in apelike form seems particularly effective in its kind. You have here the sense of evil suggestion and evil control which so marks "The Turn of the Screw," without the duplication of intermittently visible tempters, which seems a defect.

Oriental rugs have become permanent factors in house furnishing everywhere. The reasons are many. These rugs are pleasing to the eye, they are wonderfully durable, and, besides, they have sanitary advantages in being easily cleaned and dusted. Mrs. Mary Beach Langton's handsome volume, with its many-colored illustrations, entitled "How to Know Oriental Rugs," gives all the necessary data concerning the products of the Oriental looms.

Stony Lonesome is not a man, it's not even a boy; it's just an inanimate village. In Stony Lonesome, to be sure, lived men; but, with the exception of Uncle Ellery, they were of small importance. The really important people were the boys. There was "the Gang." It included many boys. Usually, however, they "hunted in pairs."

Whatever Mrs. Charles T. Stout may see fit to write about golf is certain to occasion interest, not because her advice may be one whit better than many golf talks previously embodied in print, but because of her success in American championship tournaments. Better known as Miss Genevieve Hecker, she held for two successive years both the National and metropolitan women's championships.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- "When the forgings of the guns were being machined at the gun factory defects developed, the defects being described as numerous small 'breaks' in the continuity of the metal, and also minute 'sand and slag spots.' The forgings thereupon were rejected by the factory."

In his address to the Workingmen's Club of Hartford President MELLEN of the New Haven Railroad said some very wise things which may be pondered with profit by employers and workingmen alike. The tone of his address was in happy contrast with that affected by many who are leading the movement in opposition to the whole principle of trades unionism.
The verses quoted by your correspondent H.H. Ballard, beginning

My, my, what is the matter with folks? Have they all lost their sense of humor? To my mind, the "Elizabeth" books, "The German Garden" and the "Solitary Summer,'' are a perennial source of delight. Think of an English girl transplanted from the flowers and fragrance of England to the barren soil of a Baltic Sea province!

BALTIMORE, April 29. -- By the sale of the Vera Cruz and Pacific Railroad to the Mexican Government, the Maryland, Trust Company will be enabled not only to pay its debts dollar for dollar, but will have a surplus to divide among its stockholders. Announcement to this effect was made by Receiver Allen MacLane to-day.

THE literary guide book, although useful and even valuable, is not the source to which one looks for original information in regard to literary matters or literary men, but Mr. Samuel T. Pickard has enriched his "Whittier Land," to be issued Saturday by Messrs. Houghton, Mifflin Co., with details not to be found in his own "Life and Letters" of Whittier or in Mr. Carpenter's "Life" in the "American Men of Letters" Series.

No faintest echo of the noise of great steel ships and guns busy with the Russians disturbs the garden-close, smelling of cherry blossoms, where Mrs. Babcock has set her newest story of the Japan of sentiment. Of the flowerlike Princess Sado-ko (Royal Purity) a Japanese Kipling might sing "Thy face is far from this our war," and be not less truthful for being, an imperial poet.

ANOTHER novel dealing with the Ku-Klux Klan, which forms the subject of Thomas Dixon's "The Clansmen," announced a fortnight ago in these columns, is being completed by Thomas Nelson Page, whose volume of short stories, "Bred in the Bone," will be published in May by Charles Scribner's Sons. Mr. Page has been engaged on the new book for some time.

HOW we have changed methods of teaching in two centuries! In "Old-Time Schools and School Books," Mr. Clifton Johnson tells the method of instruction in use in the colonies and the United States a century or more ago.

WHAT title has Caroline, the Queen Consort of George II., to be called "illustrious"? Caroline was imbued with a wonderful patience. She had for husband a singularly disagreeable man. He was petulant, false and possessed of but a scanty stock of brains.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 29. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed three important bills of Senator Brackett affecting the business of fiduciary corporations. Two of them are designed to curtail the business of corporations whose titles are held to be misleading owing to the presence therein of the words "Trust," "Banking," "Guarantee," "Investment," and the like.

Police Commissioner McAdoo expressed himself yesterday as agreeing with District Attorney Jerome and Capt. Goddard in their view that the Western Union Telegraph Company could close up the poolrooms in the city if they refused to allow their wires to be used to supply information.

Of the numerous structures that are building throughout the city none, perhaps, excite more interest than those between Twenty-third and Fifty-ninth Streets, in Fifth Avenue. Of these the most remarkable, without doubt, are the Knickerbocker Trust, the new Tiffany building, and the Public Library, at Forty-second Street.

The Catholic Irish, encouraged by the example of the Boers, form a secret league, and resolve upon a concerted action which shall in a single night wrest Ireland from her rulers, and establish her as a republic. The success of the uprising, the collapse of the republic, are the subjects of Mr. Bullock's picturesque and exciting tale.

It is not very clear why the German Emperor at this moment should tack on to an expression of hope that the peace of the world will be preserved the statement that the events now occurring will steel German courage and that his people would be found united if it became necessary for Germany to intervene in world policy.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The Japanese Legation to-day received the following official report from Tokio on the sinking of the transport Kinshiu Maru:

I am a holder of the common stock of the International Paper Company, and have been much interested in the articles which have appeared in your columns recently concerning that company. I heartily approve of the suggestion of a correspondent of yours that the stockholders should organize and take concerted action to protect their interests.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30. -- Edmund McLaughlin of Brooklyn was arrested here to-day, and is detained at Police Headquarters, as it is believed the Brooklyn police want him. McLaughlin is the man who was shot at by his wife in Brooklyn yesterday while she was defending herself against an expected attack which her husband is said to have threatened.

ONE of the biggest hits scored in "Madame Butterfly" was that by Miss Valerie Bergere, who played the title role. Since her advent into vaudeville, Miss Bergere has been trying to find a sketch that would give her an opportunity to assume a Japanese character, and she thinks she has at last been successful in "His Japanese Wife."

The continued decline in the quotations for the issues of the International Mercantile Marine Company have again revived the discussion of the present values of the issues of this combine and the excellent showing of its rivals, the Hamburg-American and the North German Lloyd Steamship lines.

The safes of the defunct Globe Security Company were opened yesterday by Receiver James McKeen, and all were found empty. The books of the company, which the receiver hoped to find within the safes, were not there, and he does not know where to locate them.

Marcus Sergey Friede, an exporter of raw material from Manchuria, who formerly had an office at 71 Broadway, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday through his attorneys, Hays Hershfield, in the United States District Court, with liabilities of $60,000. Besides being an exporter of raw material from Manchuria, Mr. Friede was also an exporter from America of machinery and supplies, and a railway and steamship contractor.

AMULETS are much in favor at the present moment, and the wearers of them are by no means only of the feminine community. They are worn in all manner of quaint designs. Each precious stone is supposed to contain some property peculiar to itself, and it is needless to say that one of the most sought after is that which is said to ward off appendicitis.

The quantity of the Winter wheat crop and the corn and Spring wheat crops which are to follow it is one of the questions about which Wall Street busies itself much of the year, and to which just at present it is giving as much attention as can be claimed by any subject in a market as dull and profitless as the present.

FILE coaching season, now well under way, is bringing out some picturesque costuming among those addicted to that sport, and the departure and arrival of the coach Pioneer from and at the Holland House is watched with interest by both men and women, the latter, of course, being chiefly interested in the women of the coaching parties and their gowns.

The bank statement again made new high records in loans, cash, and deposits. The average system covered up completely the week's gold exports. Evidently the preceding statement did not disclose the entire gains in cash for the week ending April 23, and the rising averages for the early part of last week offset the loss of gold in the latter part of the week.

For the first time in years May opens in this city with no big building strike in progress. The employers say that no matter what unexpected things may happen in the future there is to be no general shut-down in building this year like the general lock-out of last year.

A wireless telegraph service has been opened to public use between this city and Buffalo. The distance of nearly 200 miles is the longest, assert the manager's of the service, over which practical service has been installed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1. -- The entire Fire Department of this city is engaged this morning in fighting a fierce fire in a six story building extending from Weybosset Street to Chapel Street. Aid has been asked from Pawtucket and other nearby places, as the flames are beyond control, and it is feared they will spread to other buildings in the business district.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Whether there is in existence such a harp as that described in Moore's poem "The Harp That Once Through Tara's Halls" seems to be in doubt. At all event, efforts to find the harp have failed thus far.

A 70,000-share market, with changes ruling fractional, and larger changes without significance, does not bear discussing. The bank statement, however, makes amend. Loans, deposits, and cash are all new records, just as they have been in many previous weeks. The repetition is even less remarkable than the fact that gold exports surpassing every record failed to break the series, of which any one would have been by itself unusual.

WHITE PLAINS, April 30. -- With every indication that the result of the election in New York State this year will be close and that possession of its thirty-nine Presidential electors by either party will very likely mean the capture of the Presidency, a situation is presented whereby a single large county with a powerful independent vote may turn the scale in this State and with it the Presidency and more than likely the Governorship.

The money for a payroll of $644 for the factory hands of the E.B. Meyrowitz Optical Manufacturing Company at 636 First Avenue, was the temptation which led a robber to assault Herman Ferschin, eighteen years old, of 712 East One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, in the dark hallway of the factory yesterday afternoon.

A WRITER in the Paris Revue des Deux Mondes, M. Gaston Cadoux, has drawn a fancy picture of that happy time when London, Paris, and Berlin will be lighted and warmed by electric energy derived from the sea. In those economic days sea-mills will skirt the shore, they will convert the rise and fall of the tides into electricity, which wires will conduct to the capital cities to do work, to illuminate, and to warm.

ALMOST simultaneously with recent dispatches announcing the projection of John W. Gates's Rice Trust came Austin dispatches outlining steps taken by the State of Texas to fight the unlawful combination; whereby hangs an interesting tale of a newly developed American product which bids fair to outrival our cotton and our wheat and corn crops, and which will eventually convert 80,000,000 acres of hitherto worthless land into veritable gold mines.

BERLIN, April 30. -- The Kaiser's speech at Karlsruhe on Thursday, the full import of which only dawned upon Berlin to-day, was directed, I have reason to know, at the growing diplomatic prowess of France as exemplified by the increased sphere of interest she has gained in the Mediterranean through the entente with Great Britain.

KIMMSWICK, Mo., April 30. -- A misunderstanding of orders by the engineer of Train No. 18, running as a World's Fair special, on the St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern Railroad, resulted in a serious wreck to-day at Wickes Siding, about a mile and a half north of here, in which nine were killed and seventeen injured, some of them mortally.

LONDON, April 30. -- In the market to-day rates for money and discounts were firm. On the Stock Exchange the attendance was small and operators were indisposed to trade, in view of the annual closing Monday. Prices were quietly firm. Consols and Home Rails were firmly supported.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 30. -- The Halifax schooner Onoro, of 137 tons, was wrecked early to-day on a reef off Duncan's Cove, about twenty miles west of Halifax, and Capt. Atkinson and crew of four men were lost. Two bodies which have not yet been identified were washed ashore within a few hours after the wreck occurred, and a ship's boat, badly smashed, was found on a ledge.

Transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of April aggregated 8,163,544 shares, as against 11,418,972 shares in March, 8,571,484 in February, 12,275,741 in January, 15,176,178 in December, 10,744,781 in November, 12,671,051 in October, 10,713,440 in September, 14,464,876 in August, 14,780,116 in July, 15,565,904 in June, and 12,464,587 in May of last year.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 30. -- All news from the front indicates that the armies of Gen. Kuroki and Gen. Oki, comprising about 100,000 men, are being rapidly pushed forward and will be thrown across the Yalu as speedily as possible. Japanese transports have also appeared at the mouth of the river, and, supported by a few warships, will assist in the operations.

Can nothing be done to prevent the threatened destruction of the Weberfield temple of low comedy? For years now Meyer and Mike and their dialectical antics have been one of the far famed and justly famed features of a metropolis all too barren of institutions devoted to the muses.
ALBANY, April 30. -- With a show of surface harmony the Democratic State Committee in executive session to-day chose the following officers:

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Capt. Charles Young of the Ninth Cavalry has been selected for Military Attache to Haiti and Santo Domingo. Capt. Young, who is on duty in California, is one of three colored men who were graduated from the Military Academy at West Point.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- The ceremony of pressing the gold key which started the World's Fair machinery in St. Louis took place in the East Room of the White House precisely at 1:14 1/2 o'clock, Eastern standard time, in the presence of the foreign Ambassadors, and a distinguished throng representative of American official life.

LONDON, April 30. -- The tone of the stock market was quite satisfactory this week. Gilt-edged securities seemed to be in a better position than for months past; consols advanced a full point, and about all other home and colonial securities were materially strengthened.
