ST. PETERSBURG, May 1, (4:38 A.M.) -- In a telegram to the Emperor, dated April 30, Viceroy Alexieff says of the appearance of a Japanese squadron off Vladivostok:

TO be Captain of the most important precinct in New York City and probably in the United States is no mean position, no sinecure, and something that any man might be proud to acknowledge. That position is held by John W. Cottrell, the youngest Captain in years, if not in experience, in the Metropolitan Police Department.

LONDON, April 23. -- The almost hysterical condition of nervousness in which the House of Commons lives through its slow days was sharply illustrated the other day. A frantic summons from the Whip urged faithful Ministerialists to be in their places prepared to resist the manoeuvres of a perfidious Opposition.

On the sixth anniversary of its departure for the Spanish war, and amid cries of "San Juan" and "Santiago" to recall red-letter days in its history, the Seventy-first Regiment yesterday laid the cornerstone of its new armory, which is to rise on the ruins of the one destroyed by fire at the corner of Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 30. -- Illegal collection of alleged extortionate fees and expenses is charged by the Prudential Insurance Company of America against State Insurance Commissioner Zeno N. Host.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, April 30. -- After seventeen days of hard work the special Grand Jury called to investigate the lynching of the negro who murdered Bailiff Charles Colliss, and the burning of part of the levee district, made its final report this afternoon.

In the money market things are happening fast enough and important enough to please a glutton for records. Money is even plentier than cheap. Probably it never will or can be cheaper, for at less than present prices it does not pay to handle loans. This is the natural result of a series of new maximum records in the reserve column, and, aye! there's the rub -- in the loan column.

WITH the prospect of the installation of the York Athletic Club for women in a permanent home in a fashionable quarter of town, and with talk of a conglomerate woman's club in the future the following description from The Pall Mall. Gazette about the management of Women's Clubs in London has a very timely interest.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 30. -- With propitious weather it is expected that a large crowd of enthusiasts will be at the Golf Club to-day for the opening of the season. No regular schedule has been set for May, but impromptu matches will be the order of the day for the first weeks until the Greens Committee has prepared a schedule for the Summer.

Regarding the proposed increased of $8,000,000 in the authorized preferred capital stock of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Company and the sale of $6,000,000 of this increase, the Board of Directors sent out a circular to stockholders stating that proxies for a large amount of each class of the stock, and in about equal proportions, had already been received.

CHINATOWN has been celebrating its Saints' Memorial Week, and during the ceremonies a meek-eyed but holy Lama from Lhassa has been entertained by the members of the colony, and it seems has been a means of grace for all good Buddhists.

PARIS, April 16. -- The veteran Patti is in town, and was at the opera on Monday evening when Alice Verlet made her successful debut as Gilda in "Rigoletto." It seemed as if her American tour had aged her tremendously, even if it did put money in her bank account. When she passed through Paris at the time of her last marriage she looked wonderfully young and girlish.

As is usually the case in matters relating to great public undertakings, the judgment best entitled to consideration is not that which first finds expression in the hasty and not inerrant generalization of editorial discussion. The plans for remodeling Bellevue Hospital at a cost variously estimated from eleven to fifteen millions were unqualifiedly approved or unqualifiedly condemned, according to the point of view of those who felt called upon to discuss them.

The sensational charge is officially made that deliberate incendiarism was the cause of no small number of the forest fires that in 1903 devastated enormous tracts of timber lands in the Adirondacks. The charge is made in the report on the "Forest Fires in the Adirondacks in 1903," just issued by the Bureau of Forestry of the Department of Agriculture.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30. -- Princeton interscholastic track games, held here this afternoon, were won by Lewis Institute of Chicago, with 28 1/2 points. Mercersburg Academy was second, with 19 1/2 points. The track was fact, five records going by the boards. William Hoganson took the 100-yard in 0:10, breaking the former Princeton interscholastic record.

To the inspiring rat-a-pat of the drums, the shrill fife and bugle, and the enlivening strains of martial, music, soldiers representing every branch of the service will participate to-morrow night in the opening review of the eighth annual military and athletic tournament in the Madison Square Garden.

As the twilight darkens and fades away no study is more ennobling and elevating than that of the starlit heavens, with its myriad hosts of suns peopling its fathomless depths. The month of May, itself the latest and loveliest of the Spring months, brings to us the delights of fragrant breezes, bursting buds, and exhilarating atmosphere, with evenings so soft and serene that they most temptingly invite us to open-air life.

Notwithstanding the rain yesterday crowds thronged the doorways of New York's newest department store, at Fourteenth Street and Sixth Avenue, and the place was crowded from 9 o'clock in the morning until 6 at night. Policemen were stationed both at the big entrances and at the elevators to keep the continuous procession moving.

HER little craft had skirted the coasts of Bohemia for many an "art student" year, and the rocks and rapids of a big city's high-tide life had given her more than her share, perhaps, of the ups and downs of breadwinning. But she kept a sunny sweetness through it all, and an appetite for the verities that the quibbles and vagaries of amazingly many-sided metropolitan standards seemed in nowise to impair.

ONE of the curiosities of the Connecticut River is the old-fashioned ferryboat that still plies between South Glastonbury and Rocky Hill, small settlements on opposite sides of the broad river about ten miles below Hartford. The ferry is the first on the river after leaving the capital of the State, and the boat has been in commission for so many years that the memory of the oldest inhabitant goeth not to the contrary.
George Semmler of George Borgfeld Co. sailed for Europe on Tuesday on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse. He will be gone three months.

The changed relations of landlord and tenant which have grown out of the multiple apartment dwelling have given rise to some questions which it would be very interesting and profitable to have discussed in your columns. The body of the law dealing with negligence does not seem to furnish precedents for the determination of certain questions of responsibility which are of exceeding and even acute interest to apartment dwellers.

ST. LOUIS, April 30. -- A golden button, headed by President Roosevelt at Washington this afternoon, set in motion the ninery of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, and the great fair was pronounced ally opened.

WHAT do men talk about just among men?" is a question that has puzzled many a woman. One of them has found an answer. She surprised the head of the family the other night by telling him that she knew all about it.
William F. King of Calhoun, Robbins Co., speaking of the present dullness in the dry goods trade, yesterday said:

PARIS, April 30. -- The case of the Abbe Loisy, member of the Faculty of France and recognized as one of the ablest scientists and theologians of the French Church, some of whose books have been condemned by the College of the Propaganda at Rome, is causing an agitation here similar to that which followed the publication of Father Hecker's book in the United States.

FOR the first time since I began to wear a wooden leg I have become reconciled to its inflexible curves," said the man at the end of the table. "I have just realized its possibilities. With a wooden leg I stand some show of winning fame, or at lease notoriety; without it I should be doomed to obscurity.

Next July will witness the one hundredth anniversary of the death of Alexander Hamilton -- the foremost constructive statesman this hemisphere has produced, and the General, patriot, and man of highest eminence.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Representative John Sharp Williams of Mississippi, the Democratic leader of the House, in an authorized statement to-day, says he believes that the nomination of Judge Parker at the St. Louis Convention is assured.

ZOLTAN DOEHME, until further notice Mme. Nordica's husband, has an amusing way of putting things. On one occasion he was speaking of the vocalization of the well-known singer Van Dyck, and professional leniency vanished in critical sarcasm:

THIS has been a hard season on the average actor, and it is only the lucky few who have done "stunts." One evening, not long ago, a young actor who had just come in from the road had rather an amusing -- also "tough luck" -- experience with his only remaining three dollars. Making the rounds of the several theatrical agencies, he met a friend who was in immediate need of just $3.

NORTH RIVER shad came near to glutting the local fish market at the beginning of last week, and were sold cheap, while prices for Delaware and Jersey shad went down with a rush. The northeast storm and the fall in temperature checked the fish on their journey from the Atlantic to Albany, and the cost of them almost doubled in forty-eight hours, roes selling at $1.25 each.

An immense growth in the foriegn business in American electrical supplies and novelties is reported by the officers of the American Electrical and Novelty Company who have just returned from trips abroad. F.J. Alvin, President and general manager of the company, has just returned from a six weeks' trip in which he visited Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal, and Quebec, as well as Buffalo, Boston, and several other points in New England.

Action was taken at the recent meeting in Springfield of the Department of Illinois, Grand Army of the Republic, looking to the erection of a monument in honor of President Abraham Lincoln in Washington in 1909, the centenary of his birth. It is intended to dedicate it on his anniversary. The President of the United States and the Loyal Legion are asked to co-operate in the movement.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30. -- The Philadelphia Athletics bunched their hits and won from the New York team to-day by a score of 6 to 2. It was a contest for second place in the American League championship race, and the home team deserved the victory by reason of its clean hitting, five of the six runs being earned.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 30. -- Cleveland was outplayed at all points to-day, St. Louis batting Bernhard hard in the third inning, when they secured five runs on four singles, Bernhard's error, and Jones's triple. Howell pitched a strong game, holding Cleveland down to six hits and striking Lajoie out twice with men on bases. Padden's fielding was a feature. Score by innings:

Tuxedo and Long Island shared the honors for house parties yesterday. There was polo at Van Cortlandt Park, and the coach Squadron took up passengers for the games. With the month of May cease the formal entertainments. On Tuesday there will take place the parade of the Ladies' Four-in-Hand Club.

NAPLES, April 30. -- King Victor Emmanuel visited Rear Admiral Evans on the United States battleship Kentucky this morning, remaining half an hour, expressing his pleasure at having an American warship present at the naval review yesterday, and saying many gracious things of his American friends.

It is good news that the collection of armor made by the DUC DE DINO is coming to New York, having been bought for the Metropolitan Museum with the proceeds of the Rogers bequest. London was to have had a sensational auction of this collection, but the owner prefers $400,000 down -- to a possible half million at a well-advertised sale.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 30. -- While the Russian plans never contemplated a strong resistance to the Japanese on the Yalu it is evident that the latter expected a show of defense of the river, and some surprise is manifested even here that practically no attempt was made to impede the enemy's forces.

IT used the possible for a stamp collector to pick up a nice bargain every now and then," said dealer, "but these chances are few and far between nowadays. as the majority of people are aware that old stamps have a certain increased value, and they therefore hold on to them whenever they come into their possession, determined to get it for themselves, whatever it may be.
TO PROTECT that part of Fifth Avenue in the immediate vicinity of their residences from undesirable forms of structures has already cost various members of the Vanderbilt family nearly $4,000,000.

THERE is being organized in New York a pack of dogs for the most remarkable hunt ever planned by at sportsman. They are hunters that possess the desirable attributes -- a keen nose, swiftness of foot, courage, strength, and fidelity -- and they are being gathered together from every quarter, at whatever cost, and blended with exceeding care.

FROM Canarsie around to the northern limits of Gravesend Bay, in the north and east Long Island and Connecticut coast bays and inlets, in the Dutch Kills, on the shores of Staten Island Sound, and up the Hudson and both branches of the Shrewsbury River, the water gypsies are house cleaning.

Preparations are about completed for the annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men which will be held in this city on June 15, 16, and 17 at the Savoy Hotel. It is expected that about 400 delegates will attend the convention, representing the thirty-four local associations of credit men throughout the United States, and representing about every branch of the commercial world.

AGAIN has there broken out in New York a great deal of gossip concerning bridge. All sorts of stories are being told of extraordinary scenes at bridge afternoons. The prizes are all handsome, and many of them in silver. It is also customary at bridge afternoons, where there is a large assemblage, to devote a special room to seven or eight handed euchre for the benefit of those who do not care for bridge.

Not only has the general run of dealing in small properties during the last week covered a wider range, but there has also been a noteworthy increase in the amount of vacant property buying. Business of the latter sort reached very considerable proportions in spite of an unfavorable mortgage market and some apprehension that the first of May will not pass without some labor disturbances.

The block shown in the accompanying diagram is the one which has frequently been sold to the Pennsylvania Railroad -by persons who enjoy guessing. When that corporation first became identified with the buying west of Seventh Avenue, it was looked upon as a matter of course that Broadway at Thirty-third Street -- Greeley Square -- was its objective point.
LONDON, April 23. -- Charles Frohman called attention the other day to one point in which London gets ahead of New York.

PARIS, April 30. -- The private view of the Salon of the Society of French Artists occurred at the Grand Palais to-day. This is the traditional Salon, whereas that opened recently represents the younger, or independent, element.
THE trolley habit? Oh, yes, I have a bad case of it. But then we all have our pet vices, and I'm glad mine isn't cigarettes or theatres -- just the innocuous five-cent trolley habit."

NEWPORT NEWS, April 30. -- E.P. Goodwyn of Petersburg, the broker who lost $28,000 as a result of the failure of W.E. Woodend Co., arrived here to-day, where one of his branch offices is located. Mr. Goodwyn has offered a reward of $1,000 for the arrest of Woodend, and says he to-day received a long-distance telephone message indicating that detectives were on the trail of the fugitive, and probably would capture him to-morrow.

The new twin screw steam yacht Vixen II., for John D. Archbold, a member of the New York Yacht Club, was launched at the works of her builders, the Gas Engine and Power Company and C.L. Seabury Company, Morris Heights, yesterday morning. The launching of the vessel was entirely successful, and the event was witnessed by the owner and a party of friends.

Sometimes it is both interesting and instructive to compare self-estimates with performances. In the case of the State Banking Department and the Federal bank, as well as that of the department in its relations to one or more other institutions whose ending has been peculiarly outrageous, such comparison is specially suggestive.

WITHIN a few days a plan is to be brought into an experimental stage, says The Pittsburg Post, which is expected effectually to overcome the ore dust nuisance in blast furnaces operated under conditions similar to that of the Eliza group of the Jones Laughlin Steel Company.

Many gentlemen riders and hunters took part yesterday in the annual spring steeple-chase and pony races, held under the auspices of the Rockaway Hunting Club, at Cedarhurst, L.I. The course was new to many of the riders and in the steeple-chase several of them fell, but were not badly injured.

The Louisiana Purchase Exposition opened yesterday, apparently fulfilling the promise of its projectors of being more complete at the opening than any previous world's fair. All the auspices seem to be favorable. Every citizen of the United States must heartily wish the exposition well.

Robert Johnson, alias Bob Brooks, who says he is a broker, and John Carey, known as "Philadelphia Jack," were arrested at Broadway and Forty-first Street yesterday afternoon on the complaint of Adolph Stein, a tailor of 237 East Houston Street, who alleged that they, with three other men, defrauded him out of $1,200 by means of the ancient wire-tapping game.

Lakewood's horse show will be the big feature of interest at that resort this week. The second annual show held under the auspices of the Country Club of Lakewood will open on Friday and continue through Saturday. Several new classes have been added this season and an unusually attractive list of prizes has been offered.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Prices of nearly all the great classes of domestic production have materially fallen during the past year, the chief exceptions being cotton, wool, wheat, corn, oats, and refined petroleum. On the other hand, prices of imported articles for use in manufacturing have advanced during the same period.

Sensations were showered on racegoers at Jamaica yesterday in almost the same profusion as were the raindrops that kept the crowd under shelter the greater part of the afternoon, for unexpected things happened persistently, beginning with a lightning change in the condition of the course, which a sudden shower reduced to soft mud just as dust was beginning to fly after the drying out of a day.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 30. -- Supreme Court Justice Keogh, at his chambers here to-day, listened to the examination of Gustav Ubrecht, private secretary to the late Henry Villard, in the suit brought by Mrs. Helen Villard Bell against her brother, Oswald Villard, to learn what disposition has been made of $200,000 worth of securities which she says her father left her and which, she asserts, she never received.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30. -- Yale undergraduates are highly interested in the story of a fistic encounter said to have been "pulled off" this afternoon on the top of East Rock, between Samuel A. Alderman and William Leavenworth, two Yale athletes, in the course of which there is reported to have been much hard hitting.

WHOEVER before heard of an actor who refused to get into the limelight of publicity? Julian Mitchell says he has discovered him, in Stephen Maley, who plays the high-voiced old villain, Sir Wiley Gile, in "The Wizard of Oz." But Mr. Maley's aversion to the centre of the stage is not the result of mere modesty, as one might suppose; it is based on scientific deductions.

MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, April 30. -- To-day's convention of Marshall County Democrats was the most turbulent in many years. Gag rule, which summarily squelched all opposition, dominated the convention. Anthony C. Dayly not only presided, but absolutely ruled the meeting. He assailed Cleveland, extolled Bryan, and read all sound-money Germans out of the Democratic Party.

New Jersey's progress as a woolen manufacturing State is surprising some persons who have been studying the figures issued by the State's Bureau of Statistics. A statement recently credited to W.C. Garrison, Chief of the Bureau, that the State now ranks first in the industry, was a gross exaggeration which he promptly repudiated, although he emphasized the fact that rapid strides are being made.

Robert C. Ogden and the guests he took with him through the South, where they visited many industrial educational institutions in Virgana, South Carolina, and Alabama, before attending the seventh annual conference for education in the South at Birmingham, Ala., returned to New York yesterday morning all enthusiastic over the experiences of their trip.
ARE there matinee girls in England?" Templar Saxe, the young Englishman who plays Lord Piffle in "Piff, Paff, Pouf," adjusted his monocle and seemed at a loss for an answer.

ANNAPOLIS, April 30. -- The University of Pennsylvania 'Varsity crew defeated the eight of Annapolis this afternoon by three lengths in a two-mile race which began the college boating season for the year. The time was 10:37 1/2. Annapolis was timed in 10:49. The Annapolis second crew and the Pennsylvania freshman crew also started with the older men, and the navy juniors finished a half length behind their 'varsity in 10:51.

Florida, during the height of the Winter season, will be shown on the stage of the Majestic Theatre to-morrow night, when "The Man from China" makes its first New York appearance. One of the principal comedians in the play goes under the name of Reggie Van Pelt. According to the press agent, he is intended to be a "burlesque paraphrase of Mr. Harry Lehr."

I have read with interest and not without admiration your editorials on the New York Zoological Park and menageries in general and the reply of "H.A.C." Some of my admiration has been for your own impartiality in promptly printing what seemed to me an effective reply to your own editorial.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 1. -- The following telegram from Viceroy Alexieff, under date of April 30, has been received by the Emperor:

At the dinner which was given in honor of Melville E. Stone, General Manager of The Associated Press, last night at Delmonico's, Mr. Stone spoke of a short dispatch which he said had precipitated hostilities between Russia and Japan.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 30. -- With the closing of the Lakewood Hotel this week the knell of the Lakewood season was sounded. Several of the smaller hotels have closed and there has been a general exodus of visitors during the week.

It's a common joke to say "He eats so much it makes him poor to carry it around" when speaking of some thin, scrawny fellow who eats as much as a horse, but it is frequently true if the food is not the kind the body calls for.

Controller Grout yesterday afternoon made public the report of Mrs. Mathilde Coffin Ford, his investigator into the subject of the conduct of the recreation centres by the Board of Education, coupling it with a brief statement to the effect that it had not been his intention to give out any special reports on school matters until all investigations had been completed.

IN BROOKLYN, quite near a certain ferry, dwells a whole colony of Syrians, made up not of the Mohammedans, but of those who long ago were converted to Christianity. They interchange visits, go to the same church, lead a life as near as possible to that they left in their beautiful semi-tropical Syria.

WASHINGTON, April 30. -- Prof. Alexander Graham Bell to-day gave at Columbia Station, a Virginia suburb of Washington, an exhibition of the tetrahedral kite, which he believes has solved the secret of aerial navigation. The demonstration was made to the members of the National Geographic Society, of which Prof. Bell was formerly the President.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 30. -- Ideal weather, close and exciting finishes, and 20,000 spectators marked the beginning of the race season to-day by the Kansas City Jockey Club at 'EIm Ridge. The feature was the Kansas City Derby, $5,000 added, at a mile and a quarter.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 1. -- The Chicago American League team defeated St. Louis to-day by a score of 13 to 0. The visitors found Sievers, and Morgan, who relieved him in the second inning, almost at will, and hit safely when men were on bases. Score by innings:
WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The following telegram, dated May 1, has been received at the Japanese Legation from Tokio:

BOSTON, May 1. -- With the exception of the strike of more than 1,500 bakers in this city, Cambridge, Chelsea, Lynn, Salem, and Brockton, the first day of May this year passed without any serious labor disturbances at any points in New England.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 1. -- While F.D. Carrig, night operator of the Central Railroad at Westfield, was getting a lunch at a restaurant near the station at 1 o'clock this morning, thieves broke into the station and robbed the ticket office of $1,200 in cash, which had been taken in yesterday and last night for May commutation tickets.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 30. -- According to official advices there has been serious fighting in the Sassun district of Asia Minor between troops and Armenian insurgents, the latter numbering 2,000. The troops lost 20 killed and 23 wounded.

ST. LOUIS, May 1. -- St. Louis secured an even break in the Cincinnati series by winning to-day, 4 to 3. The game was close all the way through. With the score tied in the ninth, Barclay singled and went to third on a fumble by Odwell, where he scored on Byers's fly to Odwell. Both Nichols and Ewing pitched good ball. Score by innings:

The General Manager of a big Ann Street establishment late Saturday afternoon looked around the deserted office, carefully inspected the inside of his hat before pulling it on called for the porter to make doors and shutters secure, and, accompanied by a belated customer, started for Park Row.

A few words in answer to "R.S.V.P." First-class bookkeepers earn higher salaries than first-class stenographers, and in that respect bookkeeping is the more desirable occupation. But one may have mental qualities which will enable him to become a first-class amanuensis and earn a high salary, and yet have no "head for figures."
President Percy Thomas of the Commercial Telegraphers' Union was allowed the privilege of the floor at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union to talk about the telegraphers.
Both St. Petersburg and Tokio dispatches agree that the Japanese have won a substantial victory on the land and that the first important movement that has seriously been opposed has been successful.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- An important political conference was held by President Roosevelt at the White House to-night with prominent members of both houses of Congress. They included Senators Aldrich, Spooner, Hale, Platt of Connecticut, Lodge, and Allison, Speaker Cannon, and Chairman Hemenway of the Appropriations Committee.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 1. -- A terrific hailstorm visited this region last night in the Fiskville neighborhood. Huge chunks of ice, some of which measured ten inches in circumference, fell. Holes were torn in the roofs of houses and much damage was done to the fruit and corn crops.

During the first quarter of 1904 there were reported to the Health Department of New York 200 cases of typhoid fever occurring in the Borough of Manhattan. Investigation as careful as the circumstances permitted warrants the belief that 17 of these were contracted out of the city and merely developed here. In 28 cases exposure to the disease was established, and in all probability they may be classed as cases of secondary infection.

Differences between coal shippers and owners of vessels engaged in the coastwise traffic, originating in the efforts of the owners to advance prices and enforce restrictions upon the time of loading and discharging, are not yet adjusted. The shippers concede that for the moment, owing to the large demand for vessels to deliver anthracite in the period of the heaviest discounts, the owners have the whip hand.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 2. -- The Russians believe that it will require another week to get Gen. Kuroki's army completely across and ready to advance on the Peking Road.

So far as the effect of the payment for the Panama Canal upon business and financial interests is concerned, those most competent to judge are agreed that it will be very slight and easily met. It is true that it comes at a time when the rate of exchange favors gold exports, and these have attained an unusual level for the season.

Columbia's football candidates will meet to-day for annual Spring practice. Capt. R.S. Stangland has requested all the men of last year's squad now in college to report for work, and several other good players who for various reasons were ineligible last year will also be out. Capt. Stangland and former Captain Richard S. Smith will speak to the candidates before practice begins.

It was a tired lot of troopers and artillerymen who heard the bugles sound the welcome "taps" last night in Madison Square Garden. Many of them were already rolled in their blankets, while the others had been preparing their kits for the eighth annual tournament of the Military Athletic League, which begins to-night in Madison Square Garden.

The new building of the African Methodist Episcopal Church of Zion, on Eighty-ninth Street, near Columbus Avenue, was dedicated yesterday morning. Bishop J.W. Hood delivered the dedicatory sermon, and Bishop Alexander Waters of the New Jersey Conference, Dr. Franklin, Presiding Elder of the New York Conference, and W.C. Eato, the Secretary of the Building Committee, made addresses.

Joseph Tutlisi, ten years old, of 409 East Twenty-ninth Street, was playing ball with several boys about his own age at the foot of East Twenty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon, when the ball fell into the river, and in trying to fish it out Joseph fell in
Inspector McClusky's men have not yet found Dr. William E. Woodend, the missing broker, but there were indications yesterday that developments were impending in the case of his tangled finances.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 1. -- John Felker, a labor leader of prominence, who for three years and a half was employed in the State Board of Labor, is responsible for the statement that William R. Hearst has offered $10,000 to get an independent labor ticket into the field.

ORANGE, N.J., May 1. -- The last naval battle of Ginny Lake was fought this afternoon, and to-morrow morning the flat-bottomed protected cruiser Novick and the clinker-built battleship Shikishma must be carried away by their respective crews or workmen, acting under orders of the Board of Health, probably will cover them with earth.

Joseph Dejanaro, eight years old, of 843 Tenth Avenue, was kicked by a strange man yesterday afternoon, and the boy's leg was broken. He was playing in front of his home when, according to the boy's story, a heavy-set man about forty-five years old, wearing a black mustache, stopped and began to jump him up and down.

Representatives from the 763 Masonic lodges in this State will assemble to-morrow afternoon for the one hundred and twenty-third annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons in the State of New York, which will be held in the Grand Lodge room at Masonic Hall, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

Between 5,000 and 6,000 carriage and wagon workers belonging to the Carriage and Wagon Workers' Union have decided to strike to-day in New York and vicinity unless a new contract submitted to the employers last week, embracing the new wage scale in recognition of the union, is signed this morning.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 1. -- Paul Simulsick, a Hungarian living near Hibernia, a town fourteen miles from this place, while a guest at a christening in the family of Josef Dinkis, also a Hungarian, this afternoon shot four holes in Joseph Jones's head. Jones is an Englishman. Then he barricaded himself in his little home and defied the authorities to arrest him.

The following extract from a letter recently received from a friend in Japan throws light upon the situation there. The writer is the son of a Samurai distinguished for his patriotism, and is himself a member of the present Parliament. Moreover, he is thoroughly acquainted with the spirit of his own people and with the views and feelings of foreign nations, having traveled much in America, Europe, and India. He writes:

Why should people be forced out of Prospect Park before 9 P.M.? Not only that, but the policemen in this park act in a rude and entirely unnecessary manner when asking the people, generally young couples, to "get out." I was the witness of an incident which prompts me to inquire whether the police or the public own the park.

PARIS, April 20. -- It is a traditional criticism that the Salon is up to the usual average. It might also be said that the Salon remains at a dead level of average which is beginning to be a trifle monotonous. For some three years past there has been a lull between the storms of the Academic and impressionist doctrines.

It is unkind and unreasonable to accuse Mr. T.C. PLATT, Senator from the Empire State, of not possessing and exercising influence in the dignified body of which he is a member in connection with public business of National importance. Witness the following passage in The Congressional Record for the last day but one of the late session:

One swallow does not make a Summer, but three weeks almost makes a market. For the third successive week now there has been a significant and gratifying comparison between the bond and share markets. The stock movement has been negligible, interesting only owners or operators of special properties. Of any generally interesting tendency the trace has been so slight as to inspire doubts of the accuracy of any inference, good or bad.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 1. -- The General Staff's account of the operations on the Yalu River to-day is as follows:

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 1. -- The report that Howard McVey, a young man, twenty years of age, well known in Elizabeth, had jumped into the Elizabeth reservoir last night and had been drowned caused considerable excitement here to-day. The water company commenced immediately to drain the reservior of its millions of gallons of water, but up to a late hour this evening the body had not been found.

MAINZ, Hesse, May 1. -- Emperor William, in opening the railway bridge across the Rhine to-day, congratulated the Minister of Public Works upon the completion of this German engineering triumph, which, said the Kaiser, had long been recognized as a strategical necessity. His Majesty added:

Mrs. Mary Lambertson of 310 West Forty-ninth Street was passing Forty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue yesterday when she noticed a crowd of men laughing at a small boy, who was lying face down on the sidewalk in front of James Murphy's saloon. She picked the boy up and found that he was unconscious. She also recognized him as Thomas Rafferty, who lives in the same house that she does.

Hastily summoned to attend John J. Kelly, sixty-four years old, who lived in a furnished room on the first floor of 415 East Seventeenth Street, and who had been taken suddenly ill, the Rev. Father William Twomey of the Immaculate Conception Church, in East Fourteenth Street, arrived at the house just as the sick man was geing taken away in an ambulance to Bellevue Hospital.

At an indignation meeting held last night in the Mercy Seat Baptist Church, 46 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, colored residents of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth and One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Streets, between Lenox and Madison Avenues, declared that a systematic campaign had been started by their landlords to force them from the neighborhood.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Acquilla H. Dulaney, who, the police say, is wanted in St. Louis, New York, Washington, and particularly by the authorities of Baltimore, who charge him with forgery, was arrested at the Hotel Hanover early to-day after a sensational struggle with two detectives who owe their lives to their presence of mind.
SEBASTOPOL, May 1. -- Vice Admiral Skrydloff is hastening his departure. He will leave for the Far East May 5 instead of May 8, as he had intended.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 1. -- Charles A. Daily, thirty years of age, son of Howard M. Daily, a New York real estate dealer living in this city, committed suicide this afternoon in a lot not far from his home, 123 East Lincoln Avenue. He had been ill for some time, and this afternoon was apparently delirious.

SAYVILLE, N.Y., May 1. -- Commodore Frederick G. Bourne of the New York Yacht Club entertained at his Oakdale country home, over Saturday and Sunday, Purser Russell of the White Star liner Oceanic, T. Wells, and two other yachting friends from Manhattan. They came by automobile.

Polo practice will begin in earnest during the present week. The poor condition of the fields at many of the local clubs as well as at the public fields at Van Cortlandt Park, where Squadron A plays, has retarded the active opening of the polo year somewhat this season, but at Lakewood, Rockaway, Meadow Brook, and Westchester plans have been perfected for regular practice games during the next few days.

BALTIMORE, May 1. -- Acquilla H. Dulaney, with various aliases, captured in Philadelphia to-day by Detective Thomas of this city, is wanted in Baltimore for passing a counterfeit check on Hammond Co., grocers, and for attempting to get money under false pretenses from other business men. The prisoner made a full confession to-night to the detectives, admitting that he has been guilty of similar offenses in New York, Richmond, St. Louis, Chicago, and Denver.

A crowd estimated at about 100,000 visited Coney Island yesterday. The day was ideal, and the visitors were orderly. Not a single pickpocket was arrested in the course of the day, while only a very few of those who journeyed to the resort imbibed sufficiently to justify their detention by the police.
PORT ARTHUR, May 1. -- Details of the demonstration off Port Arthur on April 27 disclose the desperate ingenuity of the Japanese.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Five hundred dollars was the price paid for a single coin at the auction sale of the coin collection of John G. Mills of Albany, N.Y., held by S. H. Chapman, which came to a close in this city yesterday.

There were renewed reports yesterday of progress in effecting a secret organization among the employes of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. While Rezin Ore, General Secretary-Treasurer of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway Employes, who came on from Detroit to New York last week, denies that he came here to try and organize the men, he says that he will be here for an indefinite time.

LONDON, May 2. -- The Times's military correspondent does not doubt that Japanese naval predominance is for the time irresistible, and assents to the statement in the Nagasaki dispatch, published in The Times last Saturday, that the action of April 13 destroyed all reasonable fear of interference with the Japanese plans in the Yellow Sea.

The point at which the battle between the Russians and Japanese was fought yesterday is on the Yalu River about ten miles above An-tung, shown on the map. The Japanese now command the road to Feng-wang-Cheng, where the Russians say they will offer stubborn resistance.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1. -- Frank L. Kramer of East Orange was the star performer in the bicycle races held at the Vailsburg track to-day. Kramer won both of the professional handicap contests without much trouble. Root and Menus Bedell were both forced out of the five-mile event with punctured tires. John Bedell finished first in the non-prize winner's race, defeating Edward Armbruster by a yard.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- When Congress adjourned last Thursday it had not redeemed itself from the reproach of having held a do-nothing session, but it had in a measure redeemed itself from the charge of having held a session as interesting as the dictionary and as sparkling as ditch water.

ALBANY, May 1. -- Hiram Cronk, said to be the sole survivor of the war of 1812, is failing gradually at his home in Dunn Brook, Oneida County. Friday he passed his one hundred and fourth birthday. For a year he has not left his bed, and his faculties have become impaired.

State Chairman Cord Meyer was not prepared to discuss his plans at any length when seen at his residence, 137 West Eighty-sixth Street, last evening, for the reason that he had not been head of the committee for more than twenty-four hours, and had had no opportunity to get in touch with its members.

Of course Count CASSINI'S article, in the current number of The North American, is an appeal for the sympathy of the American people in behalf of Russia in her war with Japan. It is an appeal which the Russian Ambassador has a perfect right to make, a right as complete as that of the Japanese Minister to represent his country's cause on public occasions.

BERLIN, May 2. -- Too much importance need not be attached to the martial references in the Kaiser's speech at Mainz or to the imperial suggestion at Karlsruhe that Germany might again have to intervene in weltpolitik.

The great influence of organized labor in English politics is shown by the willingness of the House of Commons to consider the bill introduced by Mr. PAULTON, member for Durham, designed to undo what was accomplished by the Taff Vale and other legal decisions holding the trades unions accountable in pecuniary damages for injuries inflicted upon others in furtherance of their plans.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 2. -- Chancellor Allison handed down a decision here today ordering that the Cumberland Telephone and Telegraph Company, a Kentucky corporation, be ousted from the State. An appeal to the Tennessee Supreme Court was taken.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- Angus M. Cannon, Jr., son of Angus At. Cannon, ex-President of the Salt Lake Stake of Mormons in Utah, came all the way from Salt Lake to Washington to tell the Smoot investigating committee that he had told an untruth when he stated to E.W. Wilson of Salt Lake City that he had seen President Smith of the Mormon Church perform a polygamous marriage since the Woodruff manifesto.

In decision written by Judge Byron S. Waite, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Y. Takahura Sozaki of Honolulu against the classification as confectionery at 4 cents a pound and 15 per cent. of an article known as midzu ame. The importers asserted that it was dutiable as a non-enumerated manufactured article at 20 per cent.

LONDON, May 2. -- Baron Hayashi, the Japanese Minister here, who has been the recipient of numerous telegrams of congratulation on the Japanese successes on the Yalu, and especially on the result of the first serious land fighting, said to The Associated Press to-day:

About twoscore of persons, mostly women interested in forming a new society to supplement the work of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, met last night in the ballroom of the Nevada apartment house, at Broadway and Seventieth Street. This was the first general meeting, and there was no lack of animation on the part of those present.
" Ladies and Gentlemen, walk right up and buy your tickets. The big show is just about to begin."

TOKIO, May 2. -- Details of the operations on the Yalu show that the main attack was made by the Japanese right wing, consisting of the Twelfth Division, which crossed the Yalu thirteen miles above Wiju, at Suku-chin, the same point at which a passage was effected by the Japanese army in 1894.

It was stated last night on the authority of one of their leaders that a strike of the motormen and conductors of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad was averted yesterday morning through the efforts of President John J. Durgin of the local union of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railroad Employes.

DETROIT, Mich., May 2. -- Detroit won the opening game of the Cleveland series in the first inning to-day, two hits and errors letting in four runs. Donovan was hit harder than Donahue, but scattered the safe ones and fielded finely. McIntyre's running catch of Donahue's fly in the second inning was the fielding feature.

Henry S. Kearny, who was Commissioner of Public Buildings, Lighting and Supplies during the four years of Mayor Van Wyck's administration, took pains last night to explain that his official connections with the Telephone, Telegraph and Cable Company of America and the Knickerbocker Telephone and Telegraph Company were formed three years after he had, in his official capacity, granted a valuable permit to the Knickerbocker Company without compensation.

I would gladly second the suggestion made by "Observer" in the letter published in THE TIMES of April 30 with regard to the eminent suitability of making one feature of the celebration of the coming Hawthorne centennial a fitting recognition of the work which is being done for incurable cancer patients by Hawthorne's daughter, Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The April debt statement issued to-day shows a decrease in the Treasury's available cash balance since the first of the month of $3,780,807, that balance now standing at $220,919,188. The money held by depository banks for security of public deposits is included in these figures.
LONDON, May 3. -- The Times's military correspondent says:

BOSTON, Mass., May 2. -- It was cold in more senses than one at the National League grounds today. The Boston team was beaten 2 to 0 by the New Yorks, through a collapse in the second inning. After that there was nothing doing for the visitors, and the game was sharp and clean.

Acting upon information received from various sources to the effect that certain policemen of the Tenderloin Station have been employing "shake-down" methods in the arrest of women and "graft" methods in the handling of raids on "crap" games, District Attorney Jerome for the last two weeks has had an agent gathering evidence.

The fact that the Greater New York team was scheduled to meet the Washingtons, the tail enders in the American League, at American League Park yesterday, was in itself sufficient cause to keep down the attendance, but another reason for the small crowd can be ascribed to the cold wind which blew nearly all day.

Judge Holt of the United States District Court made permanent yesterday the stay in the bankruptcy proceedings against the Globe Security Company in this State. In announcing his decision he said that the case would be taken off the calendar and would not be reopened here unless Judge Kirkpatrick of New Jersey should decide that the bankruptcy of the company could be administered best in New York for the benefit of the creditors.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The Republican National Chairmanship has been the subject of a good deal of anxious consideration in the last few days, and it is believed that a decision will be reached before long. It is a little unusual to settle such a thing so long in advance of the convention, but the President wishes to have everything arranged as early as possible.

The books and papers of W.E. Woodend Co., which have been in possession of the missing broker's attorneys, Warner, Johnstone Galston, were voluntarily surrendered yesterday to the receiver, Abraham Gruber. Woodend's lawyers also communicated to Mr. Gruber the combinations of the three safes in the Broad Street office.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 3 -- 1 A.M. -- The interest of the public in the news of the fighting on the Yalu is at fever heat, especially since the last official report, which announced the fighting at Chin-Gow, was given out.

Gold engagements announced yesterday bring the total to go out by, to-day's steamer up to $3,000,000. In addition to the $3,000,000 shipped by them on Saturday and the $750,000 engaged on Saturday for to-day's steamer, J.P. Morgan Co. took $750,000 in gold coin at the Sub-Treasury, making $1,500,000.

Hall J. How Co. have resold for the State Realty and Mortgage Company to Charles Leasenfeld the four lots on the south side of One Hundred and Seventy-eighth Street, 100 feet west of St. Nicholas Avenue. This plot is part of the property purchased recently by the sellers from the New York Juvenile Asylum.

Justice MacLean of the Supreme Court has appointed Joseph Silverstone receiver for the assets of the firm of Rose Co., women's tailors and shirtwaist manufacturers of 434 Fifth Avenue and 2 and 4 West Thirty-ninth Street, in a suit brought by Isadore W. Brill, one of the partners, against Martin A. Rose, the other partner, for a dissolution of the partnership on account of a disagreement between them.
Two large gifts to Columbia University were announced by President Butler at the meeting of the Tustees yesterday afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2. -- Dr. Greth today started to make a trip of fifty miles to San Jose in his airship, but, after traveling about five miles, a slight disarrangement of the machinery was discovered, and the aerial voyager landed safely. Dr. Greth was accompanied by an engineer named Frederick Belcher, and was satisfied with the results of the experimental flight.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- As a result of the disastrous explosion in the after turret of the battleship Missouri on April 13, a change in the form in which smokeless powder is now made in the navy has been determined on and that hereafter it will be produced in sticks with a hole down the centre.

Good horses and bad horses in their several races at the Jamaica track yesterday mixed up results in six of the most thrilling finishes that ever excited betting patrons of the turf in a single afternoon. Not a race of the programme was won otherwise than with whips out and spurs at work, heads and necks separating the contending horses at the winning post.

Only one theatre was under the ban when the day's work ended at Police Headquarters yesterday and the opportunity of getting a license for the full year had been lost. This was the Olympic, at 2394 Third Avenue, from which the license had been withheld because the Fire Department had not turned in a report regarding it.

ST. PAUL, May 2. -- Judge Bunn of the Ramsey County District Court to-day decided that the clause in the will of the late Mrs. Fanny S. Wilder, widow of Amherst H. Wilder, creating a two-milliondollar trust fund "for the worthy poor" in this city, is valid.

TOKIO, May 2. -- After the Japanese carried the line of hills extending from Chiu-tien-Cheng to Yoshoka, on the right bank of the Iho River, yesterday, the Russians made a second stand on a hill northwest of Chiu-tien-Cheng, but they began retreating at ten minutes before 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 2. -- In South Carolina to-day the county conventions were held to elect delegates to the Democratic State Convention on May 17. So far as known the sentiment of delegates elected is strongly for Parker.
I would ask you to allow me to say a few words on the rapid transit new route, as expounded on Thursday by the Plan and Scope Committee of the Rapid Transit Commission.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 2. -- Charged with having stolen a chamois bag containing gems worth $3,000 belonging to Mrs. W.H. Henshaw of New York, a guest at the Hotel Brighton, Kate McGann was arrested to-day. The police say the prisoner has a record. The bag was stolen from beneath the cushion of a rolling chair. In which Mrs. Henshaw had been riding on the boardwalk, while she stepped into a shop.

WASHINGTON, May 2. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the opinion of the Federal Circuit Court for the District of Indiana in the case of United States Marshal Pettit vs. Thomas Walshe, alias Lynchehaun.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2. -- The enforced lay-off did not sharpen the batting eyes of the Philadelphia Nationals to-day, and they fell easy victims to Brooklyn, being beaten 3 to 0. Pitcher Cronin was mainly responsible for the local team's downfall, allowing but five scattered hits off his delivery.

Every branch of the army and navy was, represented at the opening exercises of the eighth annual military and athletic tournament list night in Madison Square Garden. Never before has the big amphitheatre been decked out so handsomely in bunting, flags, and streamers of red, white, and blue.
CINCINNATI, May 22 -- Clean hitting by both teams marked today's game. Considering the number of runs scored the game was played in fast time. Attendance, 2,500. The score by innings:
Dr. L.O. HOWARD, Chief Entomologist of the Department of Agriculture, is quoted as saying during his visit to New Orleans a few days ago:

BERLIN, May 2. -- The first success of the Japanese land forces is received in comparative silence by the press, but it nevertheless excites widespread admiration. In some quarters attempts are made to minimize the significance of the achievement by pointing out that the elite of the Japanese Army was opposed merely by the vanguard of the Russians, which consisted principally of Cossack regiments.
" Russia has never ceased to wonder why the idea that she was willing and anxious to make war with Japan became so generally prevalent in the United States."

PARIS, May 2. -- Another speech from the German Emperor and another pointedly unfriendly if indirect reference to France are scarcely calculated to promote that cause of peace which the Emperor professes to have at heart.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 2. -- Ex-President Cleveland delivered the Stafford Little lecture this evening in Alexander Hall. Mr. Cleveland, who in accordance with the request of the late Mr. Little, has been the holder of this lectureship since its foundation, has been unable to fill the appointments for the last two years.

Will you allow me to call attention to English "as she is spoke" by the President of the United States. After touching the button which was to open the Louisiana Purchase Exposition yesterday Mr. Roosevelt made "a graceful speech," for which I beg to reproduce the following graceful (?) passage:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 2. -- Surrogate Silkman to-day signed a decree and order in the transfer tax proceedings on the estate of the late William Allen Butler, who for years was President of the New York Bar Association.

Hundreds of poor people, in the lower east side expected to be dispossessed yesterday, but they were agreeably surprised when they found that the Justices in the Municipl Courts had adopted a policy of leniency. Instead of warrants eviction, there were permits in many cases to remain in their dwellings until the latter part of this week.

With few exceptions the stocks traded in yesterday declined rather sharply, a number of the net losses reported at the end of the day amounting to as much as a point. This weakness was accompanied by a considerable increase in transactions which could hardly be looked upon as a favorable indication.

-- All the large skill of the "Christian Scientists" in evading responsibility for their failures and their crimes will be exercised in vain in the case of GEORGE C. RITTER, the "First Reader" in Oneonta, who, having come to a belated realization of the truth that disease cannot always be cured by denying its existence, escaped a public confession of his mistake by suicide.

Through the efforts of William F. King and S. Christy Meade of the Merchants' Association a settlement has been arrived at between W. Wickham Smith and the Government as to Mr. Smith's fee for the prosecution of the silk fraud cases.

Prices receded generally nearly a point yesterday. This is the worst that can be said of the market and also the best. Of good news there was substantially none; certainly the balance of good and bad intelligence was adverse, and yet the recession of prices was slow, orderly, and moderate.

To careful observers the most surprising fact about the battle on the Yalu is the clear superiority of the Japanese artillery. It has been expected by military critics that, when the conflict came, the Japanese infantry would show itself equal to the Russian in steadiness and endurance, and superior in initiative and dash.

The upper gallery of the Knoedler establishment, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, has a full-length painting of Mme. Emma Eames, the singer, by her husband, Julian Storey, which represents as high a level in his art as he has reached. It is a portrait full of dignity and capitally wrought in its details, such as the arm under the light covering, the fur cloak, the big fur muff.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Present agitation for the erection in this city of a monument to Abraham Lincoln has called attention to the fact that nearly forty years ago a similar movement was authorized by Congress, and has caused inquiry as to what has become of the sum, estimated at $100,000, which was raised by popular subscription but never expended to build the monument.

The one hundred and twenty-third annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons in the State of New York convened yesterday afternoon in the Grand Lodge Room at Masonic Hall, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. In the absence of Grand Master Elbert Crandall, who is ill, Deputy Grand Master Frank H. Robinson of Hornellsville presided and conducted the opening ceremonies.

Seldom have so many stars appeared together as will take part in a monster benefit to be given at the Broadway Theatre a week from next Monday for the New York Home for Destitute Crippled Children. Mrs. A.L. Erlanger is the President of the Committee of Arrangements, and she and Manager Joseph Brooks have charge of the bill.

ALBANY, May 3. -- For five hours to-day Gov. Odell listened to arguments for and against the Remsen East River Gas bill. Nothing the Governor said at the hearing gave any indication of how the arguments impressed him.

GYANG-TSE, Tibet, May 3. -- A report just brought by a mounted infantry dispatch rider says that the further side of the Karo Pass, on the direct road to Lhasa, is strongly held by the Tibetans, some of whom were drawn from the late garrison of Gyang-tse fort.

BOSTON, May 3. -- Philadelphia outbatted Boston to-day, but lost through a fielding slump and careless base running. Parent, Dougherty, and L. Cross contributed the most striking individual plays. Attendance, 5,156. The score by innings:

NEWARK, N.J., May 3. -- Andrew Kirkpatrick, Judge of the United States District Court in New Jersey, died suddenly this afternoon at his home, 91 Lincoln Park. Heart disease, following attacks of acute indigestion, which he had suffered since last Fall, caused his death.

For the first time in eight years there is a prospect that the American people can go into a Presidential campaign on an issue as to which honest and patriotic and intelligent citizens can fairly differ. We do not, of course, mean to assert that there were not many such citizens who voted for Mr. BRYAN in 1896 and again in larger numbers in 1900.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- The Phillies made an inglorious attempt to-day to raise the embargo of consecutive defeats, but, the baseball Nemesis is still pursuing them Brooklyn won the second game of the series by the score of 6 to 3. The principal factor in the Quakers' downfall was the indifferent work of McPherson.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 3. -- The Tax Assessors of Newport have completed their assessment for 1904. Their valuation is as follows: Real estate, $35,158,900; personal property, $7,866,000; total, $43,024,900. The increase over 1903 is as follows: Real, $490,700; personal $501,900; total, $992,600.
To-day's TIMES is unusually interesting and instructive in many respects. The letter on the editorial page signed "Tenant" ought to arrest the attention of landlords as well as tenants.
BERLIN, May 3. -- The weekly statement of the Imperial Bank of Germany shows the following changes:
LONDON, May 3. -- The release of dividends increased the supply of money in the market to-day.
SEOUL, May 3. -- It has been learned here that after the fighting of Sunday on the Yalu the Japanese yesterday (Monday) morning started to pursue the enemy through the mountains.

James F. Dolan, once a wealthy contractor, slept last night a prisoner in the new Tombs, which was built partly under his direction. He was convicted yesterday by a jury before Judge Foster, in General Sessions, on an indictment charging him with forging a note for $2,000 bearing the signature of Thomas Cockrell Son, dated Oct. 13, 1897.

While every Armenian felt a relief and cannot but thank your paper for the lines in favor of the persecuted Christian nation in your to-day's issue, we would at the same time warn our friends in America and Europe against horrors similar to those perpetrated in 1895.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- A plan for the general reorganization of the Red Cross to-day was submitted by Senator Proctor to representatives of the parties to the controversy in that organization which, if accepted, will reconcile the differences that now exist in the organization and will put it on a permanent basis of effectiveness.
TOKIO, May 3. -- A supplemental report was received here to-day from Gen. Kuroki. It is dated to-day and says:

In volume yesterday's stock market was almost identical with that of the previous day, but there was a marked difference in the character of the trading. It was not that the upward movement that followed Monday's decline was a very decided one, but the market developed two sides, and while the fluctuations were irregular they were, generally speaking, toward a higher level.

MOSCOW, May 3. -- Commercial circles remain depressed in spite of the optimism of the military element and the press. The head of a commercial concern of high standing in one of the largest Russian trading centres has just given expression to what I believe is the feeling of not a few of his class in Russia. He said:

CHICAGO, May 3. -- While his fiancee and another young woman vainly tried to lift the heavy vehicle, H.S. Ringi of Chicago Heights to-day lay crushed to death beneath his overturned automobile. The accident occurred in the North Chicago Road, nearly a mile from the village of Chicago Heights.

Caught on the post in the very last jump, Lady Amelia just failed to win the Williamsburg Handicap at the Jamaica track yesterday by sharing honors with Jacquin in the first dead heat of the season, and then in the run-off was beaten in pronounced style by the colt, to whom she attemptep to concede eleven pounds under the scale.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- Lieut. Col. William L. Pitcher, United States Army, is to be called upon by the department to explain why he failed to carry out a marriage engagement with Miss Carolina L. Harrold of this city.

" The newness of it all" -- the all in this instance meaning American civilization -- is very strikingly illustrated by a conflict between the State Board of Health of Massachusetts and the Assonompsett tribe of Indians, living along the shores of a chain of ponds bearing the tribal name which are the sources of water supply for Taunton and other cities and towns of Southeastern Massachusetts.

In The Independent of May 5 will be published letters, not made public before, written by Herbert Spencer to James A. Skilton and Dr. Lewis G. Janes, both of Brooklyn. The letters are copyrighted in the United States and England. Some of the letters are:
ST. PETERSBURG, May 3. -- In a report received by the Emperor from Gen. Kuropatkin, under to-day's date, it is stated that at least from 3,000 to 4,000 men were killed in the Yalu River battle.

Dr. William Edwin Woodend, owner of the collapsed brokerage concern of W.E. Woodend Co., for whom the police had been searching since Thursday last, was arrested in his home, 58 West Seventy-first Street, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon by Detective Sergeant McNaught of the District Attorney's staff.

BOSTON, Mass., May 3. -- The Boston players seemed to find quite a deal of satisfaction in the defeat of the New York National League baseball team to-day, and the satisfaction was even more pronounced when the score, 4 to 0, is considered.

Daniel Gratten, who says that he is a fireman and lives "most any old place, mostly College Point," last evening wandered into the Beacon Light Mission in Third Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-eighth and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Streets. A service of prayer and testimony was going on at the time, and Gratten was warmly welcomed as a repentant sinner.

As the result of an autopsy performed yesterday by Coroners' Physician Schultz on the body of Abraham Wendorff, who died Sunday at the Manhattan State Hospital, District Attorney Jerome will conduct an investigation to discover who was responsible for the many bruises found on the man's sides, shoulders, head, and limbs.

Justice Gaynor's remarks in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, when the National Lague baseball players who were arrested at Washington Park for playing on Sunday in violation of the law were brought before him on a writ of habeas corpus, have imbued the "rooters" on this side of the East River with the idea that the game will soon be played at the Polo Grounds on the first day of the week.

In a decision written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville, with concurring opinions by Judge Byron S. Waite and General Appraiser Eugene G. Hay, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday declared that the "favored natioin" clause in the treaty of July 8, 1815, with Great Britain does not carry with it the benefits for British goods of the reciprocity agreements with other countries.

FREEHOLD, N.J., May 3. -- Justice J. Franklin Fort denied to-day the motion for a new trial for A.C. Twining, ex-President, and D.C. Cornell, ex-Treasurer of the defunct Monmouth Trust Company of Asbury Park, and sentence was pronounced, Twining got six years and Cornell four years in the State prison at hard labor. An appeal will be taken, and the men are under $5,000 bail each.

LONDON, May 3. -- In the House of Commons to-day, during the discussion of the budget resolution increasing the duties on tobacco and cigars, Reginald McKenna (Liberal) insinuated that the Chancellor of the Exchequer had been influenced by Joseph Chamberlain's Tariff Commission and a certain tobacco merchant, who would reap direct benefit from an increased duty on stripped tobacco.

ALBANY, May 3. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the two rapid transit bills affecting New York City only. One of them removes the fifty-million-dollar limitation upon subway bond issues and substitutes therefor such amount as may be prescribed by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 3. -- "Iowa for Hearst for President," is displayed on the badges worn by what looks like a majority of the delegates who have arrived to attend the Democratic State Convention tomorrow.

Angered because another boarder received the choicest prunes and the most appetizing portions of hash, Frederick J. Wyle, who lives in the boarding house at 258 West Twenty-first Street, rebelled last night, and he is now in the West Twentieth Street Station on a charge of felonious assault.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- That Nance O'Neil and McKee Rankin, her manager, failed to carry out a contract to appear at the New Cleveland Theatre and thereby damaged the reputation of that playhouse is alleged in a declaration filed here in a $100,000 suit of W.S. Cleveland.

CHICAGO May 3. -- Chicago's ability to hit the ball proved the undoing of Pittsburg to-day, and the local team had an even dozen runs to spare at the end. Pitcher Scanlan was relieved by Lee in the fourth inning, but the change did not help matters any. Attendance, 3,500. Score by innings:

PARIS, May 3. -- Having wound up the details of the big financial transaction connected with the Panama transfer, J. Pierpont Morgan left Paris at 2 o'clock this afternoon for Aix-les-Bains. Before his departure he gave the main points of the final agreement, as follows:

Racegoers were "up in the air" after the dead heat for the stake race at Jamaica yesterday, and even seasoned veterans had to confess ignorance of what might happen when immediately following the decision of a dead heat between Lady Amelia and Jacquin, the red board, which signifies "weights correct" and an official decision of a race, was hoisted under the numbers of the dead-heaters and the third horse.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- "Even at the risk of being accused of declining that which I probably could not get, if I desired it, I answer most unequivocally that if the nomination were tendered to me I would not accept it under any circumstances whatever."

There was a little less business and a little better tone in yesterday's market. The foreign markets set the example, being less disturbed by the Russian defeat than had been feared. The domestic news was better in several directions. Louisville and Nashville, Mexican Central, and especially Southern were among roads making good reports of earnings.

ALBANY, May 3. -- The most important labor law passed by the last Legislature has been signed by Gov. Odell. It amends the labor law, transferring from the Factory Inspector to the Commissioner of Labor jurisdiction over tenement-house factories. It provides that no license for such factories may be issued while there exists in the tenement in question any communicable disease, or any violation of the local health ordinances indicating any unsanitary condition.

CHICAGO, May 3. -- The Board of Appeals of the American Trotting Association at a meeting to-day refused to recognize the record of 1:59 3/4 alleged to have been made by Cresceus on the grounds of the Wichita Fair Association at Wichita, Kan., last Fall. The decision of the association is:

The account which ex-President CLEVELAND gave at Princeton on Monday of the events connected with the riots in Chicago and throughout the West in 1894 was simple, businesslike, and very interesting. Reviewed after ten years, his own conduct with that of the Cabinet is fully justified, and their interpretation of their authority as well as their obligation under the Constitution and the laws has stood the test of time.
The members of the Ladies' Four-in-Hand Driving Club held their annual parade yesterday morning in Central Park.

Commercial failures in the United States during the month of April were 1,013 in number and $13,136,688 in amount of liabilities, against 730 in the corresponding month last year, when the amount of defaulted indebtedness was $11,811,967. In the various branches of manufacturing, 264 concerns suspended, owing $5,222,923, which compares with 212 failures a year ago, involving $6,396,295.

WASHINGTON, May 3. -- The platform to be adopted by the Republican National Convention has beer anxiously discussed at conferences which have taken place recently at the White House, in committee rooms at the Capitol, and at different residences where a number of Republicans have assembled.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3. -- The arbitrage stocks were to-day more active, and there was a.slightly larger trading in several 9f the purely lod(1 Stocks, like Philadelphia Electric, which was also weak. General Asphalt common was lower, but the preferred gained %. The coal stocks, like Reading, Lehigh Valley, and Lehigh Navigation, strengthened o/ the rumor that the Inter - State Commerce Commissioners would not be able to report the existence of an anthracite coal trust.
Since an engineer recently dropped dead on post on a Broadway Ferry boat the newspapers are a unit in demanding two men at the lever in the engine room of all ferryboats.

The elaborate statement put forth by the Russian General Staff naturally has for its object to minimize the Japanese victory upon the Yalu. According to this statement the Japanese forces engaged numbered 100,000. This seems to be quite absurd, in view of the official report of Gen. KUROKI, which names the troops, all comprised within his own command, the First Army Corps.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 3. -- Vice Admiral Togo made another desperate attempt to block the entrance of Port Arthur last night, but failed. The Russians sank eight fireships and, it is reported, two Japanese torpedo boats. The channel is still clear.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 3. -- Joseph Wharton of Philadelphia yesterday acquired possession of all the property of the New Jersey Iron Mining Company. Mr. Wharton is the owner of the Wharton mines at Port Oram, and also owns much other mining property in various parts of the United States.
LONDON, May 4. -- The Che-Foo correspondent of The Daily Chronicle cables the following under yesterday's (Tuesday's) date:
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Ranald H. Macdonald the five-story American basement dwelling 323 West Eighty-ninth Street, 22 by 60 by 100.

WESTWOOD, N.J., May 3. -- The Rawson twins, Bert and Ned, who in their youthful days were noted on account of their various escapades, appeared in new roles last night, one as a principal in a ring fight and the other as the raider of the fight. The twins now constitute the Police Department of the town, Bert being Chief and Ned the "force."

The Two Little Sailor Boys at the Academy of Music, are something new in the way of English melodrama, and are adding hugely to the gayety of Fourteenth Street, to say nothing of their even more welcome contributions to its moral uplifting and its tears.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was very quiet, and what trading there was was confined to a few issues. The four stocks in which the total exceeded 10,000 shares supplied over 100,000 shares, or about half of the transactions in the entire list. Prices were again irregular, but at the close a majority showed net gains, Steel preferred, as on Tuesday, being a conspicuous exception.

At yesterday's session of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons in the State of New York, which is holding its one hundred and twenty-third annual communication at Masonic Hall, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, the following officers were elected:

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- It was announced to-night that the details of the reorganizing of the Consolidated Lake Superior Company are in such shape that the plan of reorganization will be declared operative probably to-morrow or Friday.

BOSTON, Mass., May 4. -- McGraw's men took the measure of Pitcher Willis in two innings to-day, and then sent him from the game permanently. They secured 6 runs before Fisher went in to relieve him, and the game was then irretrievably lost. McGinnity kept the Bostons' hits well scattered, and the game never was in doubt after the first two innings.

For the second day's session of the American Bible League Convention there gathered in the Marble Collegiate Church yesterday an audience which filled the building to the doors. Again the speakers attacked "higher criticism," and ministers of various Protestant denominations followed one another in impassioned appeals for continuance of faith in the Old and New Testaments as the Word of God and not as a series of myths.

BERLIN, May 4. -- The Schichau Shipbuilding Company at Danzig recently denied a report that it had sold to Russia eight torpedo boats which it was building for the German Navy, but which the German Government had opportunely declined to take over.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- Brooklyn tied the score in the ninth innings to-day and won in the tenth, although the locals appeared to have the game well in hand. A two-base wild throw by Doyle, a base on balls, one man hit, and a single formed the combination which defeated Philadelphia. Attendance, 2,362. Score by innings:
The late Democratic Convention in New York struck the wrong chord on every topic it touched. Democrats are disgusted and Republicans are amused.

LONDON, May 5. -- The opinion gains ground here that the Japanese have at last effectually blocked Port Arthur. No official Japanese report on the subject has yet been received, but the Tokio correspondents are very positive regarding the matter, and describe the determination with which the enterprise was undertaken.

Depositors in the Grand Street branch of the wrecked Federal Bank, with a long list of grievances against ex-Alderman Minsky, who acted as a solicitor for deposits and sold the bank's stock on the east side, held another meeting last night at the Odd Fellows' Hall, 98 Forsyth Street. More than 400 depositors, whose losses range from $3 up, were in attendance.

After refusing for several days to be interviewed about Capt. F. Norton Goddard's charges that the Western Union Telegraph Company aided New York's poolrooms by furnishing their racetrack wires, Col. Robert C. Clowry, the company's President, talked yesterday.

President John P. Haines of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, acting upon numerous complaints received relative to the condition of the horses which pull the United States mail wagons in New York, paid a visit last night to the Post Office.

Tammany Leader Charles F. Murphy is said in Tammany circles to be preparing a statement on the National situation in which he will fully define his attitude and seek to justify his course in opposing the sending of an instructed delegation to St. Louis favoring the nomination of Judge Parker.

CHICAGO, May 4. -- As a result of the lockout of the members of the Stone, Lime, and Cement Teamsters' Union, W.E. Phillips, President of the Employers' Association, declared to-day that over 70,000 men may be out of work within the next thirty-six hours.
Sergt. Boettler of the Thirtieth Street Station got up from his desk to answer the telephone yesterday.

A special meeting of the Directors of the Ontario and Western Railway Company was held yesterday afternoon to consider a petition on behalf of 186,000 shares of stock, requesting that steps be taken to dissolve the voting trust now in control of the road. This voting trust has been in existence for twenty-four years. Several times there }lave been movements to dissolve- it, but they never succeeded.

Count CASSINI permits himself to be surprised at American ignorance of the causes of the war between his country and Japan. To enlighten it he puts forward what he regards as the Russian view. But there is another Russian view which he does not venture to put forward. It has been put forward by some Russian rioters in Bessarabia as a pretext for the formation of an anti-Jewish mob in the village of Bender.

While Dr. W.E. Woodend was recuperating in quiet at his residence the hearing in the involuntary bankruptcy proceedings against him was held before Special Commissioner Hitchcock in the Federal Building yesterday morning.
