Abraham Gruber, the receiver, endeavored to elicit testimony to show that the doctor had conducted a bucket shop, but the witness held that such was not the fact.

CLEVELAND, May 4. -- Judge Tilden of the Common Pleas Court rendered a decision to-day to the effect that an alimony order of the Common Pleas Court is not subject to discharge under the Federal bankruptcy laws.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- When Richard Strauss, the composer, was here, he was the recipient of many attentions, some of which, taking the form of dinners and late hours, disordered his stomach. His unfamiliarity with the English language created some difficulty when he tried to explain the results of American hospitality.

Expectation of seeing an escort of the West Point cadets to Col. Albert L. Mills, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, drew an immense crowd to the military show last night at Madison Square Garden. Col. Mills, resplendent in gold lace, acted as reviewing officer, and arrived with his staff just as the atheltic events were closing.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- J.P. Morgan $ Co. of New York were designated to-day as the disbursing agents of the United States for the Panama Canal fund, and $40,000,000 will be turned over to that firm for disbursement on account of the canal when a deposit of bonds has been made to secure the Government, which will probably be in a day or two.
EPPING, N.H., May 4. -- Miss Lydia W. Ladd, a recluse and eccentric resident of this town, who died recently, left $150,000 to be used for the establishment of an academy here.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- Ex-President Cleveland has written for The Saturday Evening Post a history of the bond issues by the Government in 1894, 1895, and 1896, which were made the basis for attacks on his Administration.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 4. -- Gov. Odell today signed the Jumel Mansion bill of Assemblyman Newcomb.

BAYONNE, N.J., May 4. -- While in an office near Newark this afternoon William A. Eddy of this city detected a decided earth tremor at 3:37, and called attention to it. On reaching home this evening he found that both his seismographs had recorded the tremor.

PITTSBURG, May 4. -- A strike which is expected to extend to an international movement against the American Bridge Company was ordered to-day by the local union of structural iron workers and bridge-men, and over 600 men in this district will go out to-morrow.
PITTSBURG, May 4. -- The Pittsburg Orchestra last season had a deficiency of $30,922.72, a liability on each of the guarantors of $448.15.

The first signpost of the Metropolitan racing season will be passed this afternoon, when on the Morris Park race course the Metropolitan Handicap, most valuable of the series of Spring handicaps prior to the decision of the Brooklyn, will be run, and in the running will make the first real turf holiday of the New York racing year.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 4. -- The Emperor to-day received the following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin:

BUFFALO, May 4. -- The bodies of John Van Gorder and his half sister, Miss Anna Farnham, brother and half sister of ex-State Senator Van Gorder of Buffalo, were found in the sitting room of their home on a farm in West Almond, this morning. They had been murdered in the night.

The improved tone which the market developed on Tuesday lasted through yesterday's session, although there was a perceptible deterioration in the character of the day's news. The foreign markets showed more reflection of the war's disturbance than on Tuesday, and the day's domestic news was less favorable.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- An informal conference between leading Republicans in the Senate and President Roosevelt was held at the Executive Offices to-day. Senators Allison, Cullom, and Spooner were with the President a considerable time.

BOSTON, May 4. -- In his annual address to-day Bishop Lawrence referred to the defalcation of Wallace H. Ham of this city, local manager of the American Surety Company and Treasurer of St. Luke's Home for Convalescents, saying:
OMAHA, May 4. -- Members of the Democratic Success League, recently organized here, say they are convinced it is W.J. Bryan's purpose to bolt the National Convention if he cannot have what he wants.

There is a genuine bargain in brushes in one of the shops. Every one may not be interested unless they are used for complexion brushes. They are the kind that is dedicated to the man with the bald head. They are delightful, regular brush size, with the handle, but the bristles of the softest kind, like those used for infants.

Every elevated line of the Manhattan Railway was blocked from ten to twenty-six minutes during the beginning of the rush hour last night, owing to the "short-circuiting" of one of the big "feeder" cables in the main power house of the company at Seventy-fourth Street and the East River.

There will be no strike on the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad. This was made certain after a meeting held by the men in a hall at Ninth Street and Third Avenue last night. Early in the morning President John L. Heins met a committee of the men and conceded several things demanded. President Heins talked peace for fully three hours and finally won over the men.

District Attorney John F. Clarke of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he would carry the matter of Sunday baseball playing before the Appellate Division, in order that Justice Gaynor's decision in the case may be reviewed by the Appellate Courts.

Luddow Street Jail stands accused of having harbored a romance, and the distant towers of the Tombs, the head of the local branch of the family, seem to frown in deprecation of the indiscretion. Sordid old Ludlow, it is charged in a moment or mellow forgetfulness, opened its doors and allowed the sunshine of a love affair to brighten up its debt-begrimed soul.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 4. -- W.R. Hearst to-day carried the Iowa Democratic Convention by a majority of more than 150 votes. Hearst resolutions were adopted, Hearst delegations from the contesting counties were seated, and Hearst delegates were selected. The delegates were instructed to vote as a unit.

LONDON, May 5. -- It is reported that after the defeat of the Russians in Sunday's great battle the Japanese advanced to within eighteen miles of Feng-Wang-Cheng, and that another engagement is expected almost immediately.

The New York Nationals, the New York Americans, and the Brooklyns were again successful yesterday, the victory of the Greater New Yorks placing them a clear second in the race for the American League championship. The Pittsburgs met with another reverse at the hands of Selee's Chicago team, and the fact is more apparent than ever that the champions of the National League are lamentably weak in the pitching department.

An air of depression hung over everybody and everything in the First District Court yesterday, for it was freely admitted by all, from Justice Daniel Finn down to the court officer, that there was altogether too much "dope" in the place.

Wall Street was surprised yesterday by news from Cleveland, Ohio, to the effect that the Ore Association, at a meeting held in that city, had been abandoned because of failure to agree on the allotment of tonnage. The Iron Age, speaking of this matter, says in its issue of to-day:

ROME, May 4. -- The Osservatore Romano, the Vatican organ, publishes an official note saying that the Holy See considers President Loubet's visit to Rome as the gravest offense against its dignity and rights.
TOKIO, May 4. -- The Japanese consider that Russian strategy in the battle of the Yalu showed the same defect as was displayed by Chinese strategy in 1894, namely, want of offensive initiative.

PANAMA, May 4. -- The proposal before the Assembly that Panama should adopt the United States gold standard was rejected after excited discussion yesterday by 16 votes to 13. The Government and the opposition parties did not act as units.

The action of Mayor McCLELLAN in vetoing the bill abolishing the office of Coroner will disappoint a great many hopes of practical reform in the administration of this department of the criminal law. The most his action can accomplish is to give these useless and obstructive functionaries a respite.

Allow me to express my thanks to "A Subscriber" for the very much needed remarks on "The Cleansing of Dentists' Tools." Public interest should be aroused against this flagrant violation of nature's most necessary law, that of cleanliness. I wish to state my experience.

All the Justices of the Supreme Court in the First Department, except those assigned to sit in the Appellate Division and Justice Charles F. MacLean, have addressed a communication to Gov. Odell expressing their disapproval of the Supreme Court Trial Commissioners bill. The Appellate Justices are Edward Patterson, Charles H. Van Brunt, George L. Ingraham, and Morgan J. O'Brien.

After having worked for eight days at the pumps on their badly strained vessel, in a sea running mountain high, and after passing four days in this way without sleep or a morsel of food except a few sea-soaked hardtack, the Captain and eight men of the Austrian brigantine Marie were rescued last Sunday by the crew of the German steamship Prinzess Irene, which arrived here yesterday.

The City Real Property investing Company is reported to have sold the plot at the southeast corner of Broadway and Sixty-third Street, 115.10 by 89.11 by 100.5 by 148.4. At the offices of the company no more definite information could be had than that negotiations for the sale of the property have been pending for some time.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 5, (3:47 A.M.) -- The magnitude of the Russian losses in the defeat at Kiu-Lien-Chen, which in a graphic report of the battle by Major Gen. Kashtalinsky, received yesterday by the Emperor, are given as 2,000 men and forty officers, had an almost stunning effect on the authorities and aroused general grief, mitigated only by satisfaction at the bravery displayed by the Russian troops.

The gallery numbered IV. according to the new arrangement of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been set aside for the collection of jadeites, nephrites, and other hard semi-precious stones bequeathed by the late Heber R. Bishop. It is at the north end of the Fifth Avenue wing on the upper floor, where one of the two galleries has been decorated in Louis XV. fashion and provided with openwork, wrought-iron gates for its two portals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 4. -- M. Anatole Leroy-Beaulieu of France delivered the fifth lecture in his series upon Christianity and Democracy at Harvard University this afternoon. The subject of the lecture was "M. de Mun et le Christianisme Social."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 4. -- The body of Archibald Harding, a patient at the Middletown State Homeopathic Hospital for the Insane, was found by two boys in an old barn at the top of the Shawangunk Mountain near Winterton, Sullivan County, Tuesday.

LIMA, Peru, May 4. -- In an interview had with him to-day by The Associated Press regarding the existing troubles between Brazil and Peru, Foreign Minister Pardo stated that his Government was preparing to resist the "unjust aggression" of Brazil.

It is only in the comparative sense that the price obtained for the thirty-seven millions of 3 1/2 per cent. bonds of the City of New York can be called "satisfactory." Of course it is not satisfactory at all, it is highly unsatisfactory, for the city to be forced to accept an average of 100.94 for its bonds in 1904, when in 1902 it got as high as 107.51.

Transportation companies had been active for some time in getting ready for last night's opening of the canals. At the canal-boat docks, on the East River, a large fleet was being loaded all day with merchandise consigned to the West. It was said that the opening business was such as to indicate a continuance of the boat shortage of the last three or four years.

NAPER, Neb., May 4. -- The three Kerring brothers, leaders, it is Believed, of an organized band of bank robbers and desperadoes, were captured last night by the Sheriffs of four Northern Nebraska counties and a posse of citizens. The capture was not effected until the posse had battled with the outlaws all day, and two of the Kerrings and a Deputy Sheriff had been seriously wounded.

With great interest I have read in your paper the letter of Mr. James J. McDonald on the rapid transit problem. Working as I did with him years ago in the Western States, I know the value of his opinion. He has condensed the whole matter into a nutshell.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 4. -- The Chinese Minister, who, in consequence of rumors of the possibility that China might not remain neutral, applied to Peking for information, has received a cablegram from the Peking Government and Viceroy Yuan Shi Kai, which reads as follows:

The death in prison of the convict SAMUEL J. PARKS might very well be passed in silence, if all that suggested itself to be said concerning it had relation to the unfortunate man who has gone to his own place. What sympathy the news of his death excites belongs wholly to those of his immediate family, who are disgraced by his career, without responsibility for it.

After the first few minutes of trading the stock market yesterday became very dull, and toward midday business on the Exchange was practically suspended. In its net results the day was unfavorable, inasmuch as most of the active stocks declined, while most of those that showed net gains were among the issues classed as specialties, and as such not characteristic of the actual tendency of the market.

LONDON, May 5. -- Further inquiries show that a Japanese loan of $30,000,000 will be issued next week. It will take the form of seven-year 6 per cent. bond, and the issue price probably will be 93 1/2, the security being a first charge on the Japanese customs.

Gen. T.S. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers held a final hearing yesterday on the reappraisement of large quantities of cheap chinaware imported from Holland by George Borgfeldt Co. It had been advanced 10 per cent. on representations made by the domestic pottery manufacturers.

George Miller, missing heir of the Miller estate in Brooklyn, who disappeared in a mysterious manner about four years ago, was located in California yesterday. He is in the Sacramento County Hospital, and is just recovering from an attack of typhoid fever.

Time alone withstood the assault of the Metropolitan Handicap in its thirteenth running at the big Morris Park race course yesterday when Irish Lad, popular favorite and top weight in the event, went out to the front at the start and before the largest crowd that ever gathered on the course won from end to end after making his own pace from the first jump to the last.
Your article on Westchester County politics, as shown by statements and figures given, is not only uncontrovertible, but calculated to command attention.

In the course of his decision upholding the legality of public ball games on Sunday Mr. Justice GAYNOR gave utterance to what the thoughtful reader will be likely to consider a very remarkable obiter dictum on the general relation between the duty of the police to enforce the law and the desire of the public to have it enforced.

Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was in the city yesterday to confer with bankers about the details of the payment for the Panama Canal. He spent most of his time at the Sub-Treasury with Hamilton Fish, the Assistant Treasurer; George F. Baker, President of the First National Bank; James Stillman, President of the National City Bank; George W. Perkins of J.P. Morgan Co., and others.

No move was made yesterday to arrange a conference between the New York authorities and President Clowry of the Western Union Telegraph Company with a view to closing the poolrooms. It is improbable that any such conference will be held.

DOVER, Del., May 5. -- Mrs. Mary A. Powell, the confessed slayer of her adopted daughter, Estella Albin, broke down to-day in the witness chair and told in detail how she had killed the girl, as she claimed, in self-defense, and not because of the jealousy she felt because she thought her husband loved the girl more than he did her.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 6, 3:30 A.M. -- With Vice Admiral Togo hovering in the immediate vicinity of Port Arthur, and transports loaded with troops lying at Pitsewo, northeast of that stronghold, Russia has braced herself for impending conflicts with the foe when she will again play a defensive role, this time, it is hoped, with better success and with less sacrifice of life than in the engagements on the Yalu.

SHERMAN, Texas, May 5. -- John Stevenson, proprietor of the Frisco Club, which was a saloon prior to the establishment of prohibition in Grayson County, and M.R. White, who worked for Stevenson, were killed at the club room in a fight with Deputy Sheriff Burris, Assistant Jailer Kirk, and Policeman Parsons.

The Board of Governors of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange has decided to rid that body of all members against whom questionable methods in the transaction of business or direct connection with bucket shops can be proved to the satisfaction of the board.

William Schmidt, better known as "The Only William," has at last achieved his masterpiece -- the grand cocktail! For years he has been dreaming about it, but up to a few days ago the elixir of life was still in the realm of the undiscovered. "The Only William" closed up his joy factory the other evening and made for home.

Members of the Chamber of Commerce attended their one hundred and thirty-sixth annual meeting at the hall in Liberty Street yesterday afternoon, when President Jesup reported that the Chamber was in most excellent condition, and that its work during the year had not only added to its local fame, but had produced results throughout the country.

The Montclair golf course is in excellent condltion and the members who have been playing lately have been surprised at the excellence of the greens. Within another week the course will be much better and several neighboring clubs have been invited to meet the Montclair golf team on the latter's links.

It seems that the "Board of Lady Managers" of the St. Louis World's Fair is laying up grievous trouble for itself. Events have brought about a partial reconstruction of that body. To the former management it appealed as a bright idea to make a collection of the photographic portraits of, by a coincidence, "four hundred" American women "of beauty or social prominence, or both."
ROME, May 5. -- There was a great sensation in the Chamber of Deputies to-day at the conclusion of the Parliamentary inquiry into the administration of Signor Nasi, ex-Minister of Public Instruction.

The walking delegate of the Machinists' Union of Hoboken is just recovering from a surprise administered to him by the James Reilly Supply and Repair Company of Jersey City. In order to prevent the delegate from calling some of their employes out on strike, the firm sent away in the dark of night the steamship Admiral Sampson, on which the endangered men were at work, to an unknown port.

Justice Gaynor tells us that because some boys and youth would feel driven to bad places after attending church unless they can play ball, and violate the State law, therefore "the question is, whether playing a game of baseball is a crime only when it interrupts the repose and religious liberty of the community."

Senator Platt returned to New York from Washington last night, and when seen at the Fifth Avenue Hotel talked freely on all matters which are now agitating the minds of the Republican politicians in the Nation and State. The Senator expects to remain in the city until he starts for Chicago on June 18.

DETROIT, Mich., May 5. -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Michigan Central Railroad to-day the Board of Directors was increased from nine to thirteen members. The four new members are William H. Newman, William Rockefeller, James Stillman and Frederick S. Winston.

We should think Capt. NORTON GODDARD would hasten to avail himself of President CLOWRY'S offer to withdraw the Western Union Company's wires from any place declared to be unlawfully occupied as a poolroom. The Captain's chief interest in this matter, we take it, is to close the poolrooms.

Burglars and sneak thieves in Brooklyn have been entering the buildings of various institutions and getting away with money designed for the maintenance of the sick and poor. In only a few instances have the police been requested to search for the thieves, for the reason that in the majority of cases the institutions robbed are conducted by religious societies which do not care to have public attention called to their affairs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 5. -- The New Haven Polo Club, an organization made up of Yale men, most of whom are undergraduates, is having daily practice at its field on Whalley Avenue, in preparation for a tournament of various clubs to be held in New Haven the week of Way 29.
MUNICH, May 5. -- Franz von Lenbach, the famous historical and portrait painter and President of the Munich Artists' Association, is dead.

-- President HAINES of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will certainly have no adverse criticism to endure because of his raid on the mail wagon horses -- except, perhaps, because he didn't act more quickly than he did, and ordered out of service only two of the horses instead of a dozen or twenty.

LIVINGSTON, Montana, May 5. -- A party of Eastern tourists, traveling through Yellowstone Park, had a narrow escape from being dashed to death in a chasm along the Golden Gate road. A coach containing five passengers slipped over the side of a precipice. It was caught by brush and its descent stayed for an instant, during which the passengers managed to extricate themselves and escape.

Yesterday was Wall Street's day for its chill, and it arrived as per schedule without any other especial excuse or reason. How little importance attaches to the general fractional decline appears from the fact that not one representative property moved a point. Among the specialties were several wider movements, none of which is associated with developments of general interest.

Three persons were painfully injured and many more received shocks and minor injuries last night just before midnight, when a trolley car crashed into a West End line motor train bound for Coney Island, which had broken down near Ulmer Park about a quarter of a mile from the Island.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Ex-Gov. Frank S. Black of New York will place President Roosevelt in nomination at the Chicago Convention. Announcement to this effect was made at the White House to-day. Mr. Black will be followed by several delegates with seconding speeches, one of which will be delivered by Harry Stillwell Edwards, the well-known author and writer of Macon, Ga.
PORT ARTHUR, May 5. -- The Japanese displayed desperate courage in their fire-ship attack on the night of Tuesday.

Harry Hall, a North Carolina negro, who was the constant companion of Consul, the chimpanzee that died six weeks ago in Europe, arrived here yesterday on the Teutonic. The boy and the animal were raised together, and they came to know each other so well that they played together as two boys would.
"All aboard!" shouted Prof. Bailey, as the Blackwell's Island Ferryboat moved out from the foot of East Twenty-sixth Street. "All aboard for Blackwell's Island, the prison, and the hospital!"

BOSTON, Mass., May 5. -- When the New York team hit Ptttenger badly in the ninth inning to-day, sending ten men to bat, six of whom hit safely, five runs were made and Boston's chances of earning a victory were forever lost. Up to that time the home team had held Its own. Boston scored three runs in the first on hits and errors, and got another by consecutive hitting in the sixth.

We have frequently called attention to the way in which the United States Senate has resisted wholesome legislation on the silver question, and the extent to which it is the last refuge of the miserable policy, conceived in cowardice and brought forth in trickery, of "doing something for silver."

TOKIO, May 5. -- Surprise is expressed in Japan at the failure of the Russians, first, to oppose the crossing of the Japanese troops at Suku-chin, where the right bank of the Yalu commands the left bank; secondly, to check the advance of the Twelfth Division through the hilly district between the Ai and the Yalu, and, thirdly, to make a stouter defense on the intrenched heights on the Ai River.

MILWAUKEE, May 5. -- After an ovation expressed in eleven curtain calls, Otis Skinner was forced to come before the curtain at the end of the third act in his new play, "The Harvester," which enjoyed an uncommonly successful premiere at the Davidson Theatre to-night, and make a speech to a fashionable audience.

BUFFALO, May 4. -- Four Italians were arrested here to-night on suspicion of having been connected with the murder of John Van Gorder and his half-sister, Miss Anna Farnham, at their home, four miles northeast of Angelica, on Tuesday night. The arrests were made on descriptions received from the Sheriff of Allegany County.

Ten persons were injured and seventy were panic stricken last evening at Bear Swamp and West Farms Road, Westchester, when a controller box on the rear platform of an open trolley car returning from the Morris Park races exploded. As a result of the accident the cars were blocked for about fifteen minutes.

For the first time since its opening last December, the new Williamsburg Bridge yesterday was the scene of a suicidal leap into the East River. About daybreak a woman, now thought to be Mrs. Frederick Schmidt of 398 Lexington Avenue, Brooklyn, plunged from the new structure, though two policemen made an attempt to prevent her.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 5. -- No further official news has been received regarding the Russian losses in Sunday's battles, but Gen. Kashtalinsky's estimate, 2,000 men, is accepted as representing practically their full extent.
In an editorial on Monday last THE TIMES makes the following statement:

LONDON, May 5. -- The fall of the curtain on Arthur Law's new comedy, "The Bride and Bridegroom," at the New Theatre to-night was the signal for the noisiest scene witnessed in a London theatre for many years.

Lowenfeld Prager have bought from the Green-Baer syndicate the plot of eighteen lots running through from One Hundred and Fifty-third to One Hundred and Fifty-fourth Street, 100 feet east of Eighth Avenue -- nine lots on each street.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 5. -- The effect of the disaster to Russian arms on the Yalu upon the Chinese is being watched with keen interest and considerable apprehension. The Russian Government appears to be satisfied with the situation for the moment. Paul Lessar, the Russian Minister at Peking, is making daily reports to the Foreign Office.
CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 5. -There were many surprises in the international chess masters' tournament to-day. The results in detail follow:

Though you bray a Bostonian anti-imperialist in a mortar, yet will not his Bestonianism depart from him. It has just been tried. Before he went to the Philippines, Secretary TAFT was a convinced anti-imperialist and believer in letting the Filipinos work out their own salvation.

By the accident of an unhappy misunderstanding THE TIMES yesterday accused the Mayor of doing something that he had not done or thought of doing; in fact, he had done just the opposite. We criticised him for approving the bill reconstituting the municipal courts, and gave reasons which we thought valid and sufficient why the measure should have been vetoed.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 5. -- It seems rather doubtful if there will be any Cleveland automobiles to represent America in the Gordon Bennett cup race in Germany. The tests of the two Cleveland cars, Winton and Peerless, were made to-day in this city, and as both broke down when going at great speed, it looks as if each would be barred.
Bradstreet's, in its issue of May 7, will say on the subject of bank clearings for the past month:

Police of the High Bridge Station captured last night after a hot chase a burglar who is believed to have looted several mansions in that neighborhood. The man was discovered in the home of Robert Lecouver, President of the Lecouver Press Company of 41 Broad Street, shortly after nightfall by Mrs. Dalley, a sister of Mrs. Lecouver.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- Elliot Danforth of New York City, one of the closest political advisers of David B. Hill and an intimate friend of Judge Parker, gave to THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day an interview which evidently is designed to put before the country Judge Parker's views on the issues between the parties.

Judge O'Gorman of the Supreme Court has appointed Jacob Gordon receiver of the assets of the partnership composed of Joseph Silverstone, William S. Harris, and Ella M. Peters, who did business as the National Photo Company at 61 Bond Street, in a suit brought by Mr. Silverstone against the other two partners for a dissolution of the partnership on account of a disagreement between them.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 5. -- The negro question was raised in the Methodist General Conference to-day when Dr. George Elliott of Detroit presented a memorial to the effect that the Committee on Episcopacy should consider the advisability of the election of a colored Bishop. He said that he believed that the Methodist Episcopal Church had reached a crisis in its relations with the colored race.

WASHINGTON, May 5. -- The final chapter of the Red Cross bazaar a regards the Washington public, took place this afternoon, when the Russian Embassy was crowded from 2 until 7 o'clock with the friends and well-wishers of the Countess Cassini, to whose personal popularity and courageous efforts the success of the bazaar is due.

LONDON, May 6. -- Viceroy Aliexeff's departure from Port Arthur is interpreted here to mean that the place is in imminent danger of isolation, and the Japanese preparations for landing are considered as confirming the belief that Port Arthur has been sealed up, probably by two of the sunken ships which Russia "failed to locate."

WINSTED, Conn., May 5. -- Calvin E. Barnes, who has been Postmaster at Clayton, Mass., a small village twenty miles north of here, for the past thirty-one years, has resigned and moved to Winsted. Uncle Sam has posted a notice in his county stamp shop that the patrons of the office must suggest to the Post Office Department some competent person to fill the vacancy within fifteen days, or the office will be discontinued.

In the galleries of the National Arts Club the old Dutch and Italian paintings lent by Messrs. Durand-Ruel have given place to an exhibition that will interest very particularly American artists and art students. It consists of a few oil paintings and many water colors and drawings, by John La Farge, President of the Society of American Artists and of the Society of Mural Painters, one of the Governors of the club.

John H. Fechtmoller, five years old, of 125 Leonard Street, Jersey City, died in convulsions yesterday, and Dr. Gilman, who attended him, attributes his death to a poisonous confection known as "two candies on the stick."

Volume II, of the two-volume work by A. Campbell Holms on "Practical Shipbuilding: Treatise on the Structural Design and Building of Modern Steel Vessels," is devoted to diagrams and illustrations of the different parts of a ship, while the first volume contains only the text. The author describes the work of construction, from the making of the raw material to the equipped vessel, including subsequent up-keep and repairs.

LAKEWOOD, May 6. -- It was a red letter day for Mrs. John Gerken, although caused by a multitude of blue ribbons, at the opening of the second annual Horse Show to-day on the grounds of the Country Club of Lakewood. She won six first prizes, all handsome silver cups, including one given by Mrs. George J. Gould, and another presented by Frank J. Gould.

" I speak of William," writes Col. Joyce, (for thus he calls the man who is reported to have played the Ghost in his own "Hamlet,") "as I knew him, child, boy, and man, from a spiritual standpoint, living with him in soul-lit love for three hundred and forty years." Col. Joyce adds that he comes of "the race of Strulbugs, who live forever."
That Solemn League and Covenant, to which the greater part of Scotland had pinned its faith, what was it?

In his "American Natural History," which Charles Scribner's Sons are publishing, William T. Hornaday has tried to accomplish two ends: First, to make clear each animal's place in the great system of nature, and, second, to introduce the animal in such a manner as to enable the reader to become personally acquainted with it.

Under circumstances which might readily have precipitated a dangerous panic, an audience which filled Proctor's One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Theatre from orchestra to topmost gallery last night was marshalled to the street in such perfect order that not a single one of them received as much as a scratch, though a fire for which three alarms had been sent in was burning overhead.

" Why is American Literature Bourgeois?" is a little riddle proposed by Gertrude Atherton in the latest number of The North American Review -- proposed, not answered. And not only is the riddle left unanswered, but it is not clear what the gifted critic wishes us to understand by the French term she has adopted.

AS a geologist Sir Archibald Geikie's fame is world wide When you read his "Scottish Reminiscences" you will acknowledge his singular ability as a raconteur. He tells us how for sixty years he has mingled with all classes of Scotland's inhabitants, and that "he has been ever on the outlook for illustrations of native humor."

Under this title E.P. Dutton Co. will bring out here a new book by Edwin A. Pratt, author of "American Railways," The volume treats of railways and their relation to agriculture, and the agricultural organization in Denmark, Germany, France, Great Britain, Siberia, the United States, Canada, Italy, Holland, Austria, Poland, Australasia, and other countries.

The subject of the "Breeches Bible." recently exploited in the columns of THE BOOK REVIEW, is suggestive of other curious misprints and the carelessness of scholars in editing the sacred book. A folio of 1717 is known as the "Vinegar Bible" from the fact that in the heading of the parable of the vineyard the word "vinegar" appears.

Hundreds of persons yesterday watched breathlessly the desperate effort which Franklin Taylor, the driver of Engine No. 133, located in Hull Street, Brooklyn, made to save the life of a child at the peril of his own and the lives of two other members of the engine crew. The company was called out to a fire in the apartments of Lester Pecan, at 68 Cooper Street.

I think there is a perfectly rational explanation of the proverb. "The exception proves the rule." Proverbs are frequently so condensed and elliptical that, to get at their original form, and, consequently, their meaning, it becomes necessary to supply one or more words or phrases which have dropped out.

ST. PETERSBURG, Saturday, May 7, (2:20 A.M.) -- Port Arthur is now cut off from all communication either by land or sea, the Japanese having disembarked in rear of the "Gibraltar of the Far East," seized the railway, and cut the telegraph.
PARIS, May 6.--An authoritative statement was given to The Associated Press to-day from the highest governmental source concerning the details and circumstances of the new Russian loan, as follows:

When the Englishmen came to settle Virginia they brought their doctors with them, and the Jamestown of 1607 had three members of the faculty. Quacks found this a profitable field, too, then as now. Those early Virginia doctors made a beginning of one good work, not even yet completed -- they stirred up the Assembly to pass laws regulating military practice.

There is something quite logical in the nomination of Mr. DEBS as President by the "National Socialist Convention." He stands and has from his first appearance in public agitation stood for the Socialist phase of trades unionism, though he has not always professed Socialism, and the kind that he does profess and tries to put in practice would be repudiated by many Socialists.
TOKIO, May 6. -- The report of Admiral Hosoya, received to-day, gives details of the landing of Japanese troops on the Liao-Tung Peninsula, suppressing the location of the landing place. He says:

The series in which these little books are the first to appear gives another indication of the growing demand for popular discussions of musical subjects. Biography is, of course, here, as in other branches, a direction in which such a demand is most potently felt; and biography is supplied here in its most condensed form.

ST. LOUIS, May 6. -- One of the most notable functions that has taken place at the World's Fair was the dedication of the Chinese pavilion to-day. It was made especially interesting by the presence of Prince Pu Lun, Imperial Chinese Commissioner.

The idea that an amphora of falernian laid down by Quintus Horatius Flaccus in 736 A.U.C. should have become so powerful by age in this twentieth century that a single drink of it has the same effect as a lifetime of prolonged inebriety, would hardly seem a hopeful one for a novelist, except a writer of farce like Mr. Anstey.

A self-appointed exile of over a year in Mexico, Elizabeth Visere McGary returned to her Texas home to write the usual book of impressions, styling it "An American Girl in Mexico." The book is light and anecdotal, containing, however, one or two stories whose age should have made them ineligible.

" A Little Union Scout" emphasizes the already well-established fact that Mr. Joel Chandler Harris easily stands among the very best of the story tellers and is at the same time in full possession of the old-fashioned disposition to exercise his story-telling abilities in making his readers acquainted with one company after another of the delightful characters of which his imagination seems to hold an unlimited supply.

ALEXANDER TEIXEIRA DE Mattos, the translator of "The Double Garden," the new Maeterlinck volume which Dodd, Mead Co. are to publish this month, is of Dutch parentage and birth, but has resided for the past thirty years in England.

Daniel J. Sully, the former cotton king, furnished some sensations yesterday when he testified under oath in his examination as a bankrupt that Edwin Hawley had been his partner, and that he believed Frank H. Ray, who had been one of his backers, had sold him out in the market as soon as he learned that he (Sully) was in trouble for lack of quick assets.

SOUTHAMPTON, May 6. -- The American schooner yacht Ingomar, Capt. Charles Barr, from Bristol, R.I., April 20, arrived here to-day. She reports meeting with strong winds and heavy seas, but sustained no damage.

IN THE BOOK REVIEW Of April 16 was an article headed "A Limited Philosopher." Your reviewer differs from Spencer on the respective excellences of Homer, Raphael, Ruskin, and Carlyle. He asserts that Homer and Raphael are acknowledged to be supreme in their respective arts.

Replying to the inquiry of "H." in regard to snakes, the writer, who has traveled afoot over each of the country mentioned, would settle that the probability of meeting these interesting animals, either poisonous or otherwise, is very small. This, of course, provided he sticks to untrodden ground, as he claims he does, and keeps aloof from ye cross-roads tavern.

E.P. Dutton Co. will bring out in this country the writings of Miss Manning, author of "Mary Powell," "Cherry and Violet,'' "The Old Chelsea Bun Shop," "To Colloquies of Edward Osborn," and "The Household of Sir Thomas More," in a cheaper edition than that issued a few years ago by Charles Scribner's Sons.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The terms of the declaration of neutrality which has been the subject of negotiations between Norway and Sweden and Denmark since the outbreak of the war in the Far East have now been made known.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday handed down a decision in the case of Mosle vs. Bidwell, which reverses the decision of Judge Wallace in the Circuit Court as to the assessment of duty upon goods withdrawn from a bonded warehouse for consumption.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- In official circles here apprehension is felt as to the outcome of the sharp clash between Brazil and Peru, growing out of the dispute over the territories in the Valleys of the Alto Jurua and Alto Purus, otherwise known as the Acre region.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 6. -- News of very heavy fighting near Feng-Wang-Cheng is expected within thirty-six hours. Large reinforcements have reached the Russian position.
ALBANY, N.Y., May 6. -The annual report of Superintendent Francis Hendrieks of the State Insurance Department on life, c-sualty, credit, and mortgage guarantee insurance was issued to-day.

It was just breaking day yesterday when two belated persons from the Metropolitan Handicap rolled into the Putnam Avenue car at the bride. One of them pulled out a handful of change, selected a quarter, gave it to the conductor, told him to "drink up the change" to Irish Lad, and then they went to sleep.

There is a new Democratic candidate for Governor in the field, and William J. Conners of Buffalo is his sponsor. Conners until the March primaries was the Democratic leader in Erie County, and now he is trying to regain control of the party organization. To aid in accomplishing this he has brought forward Charles W. Goodyear of Buffalo as a candidate for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

" In Old Egypt," a book for boys and girls, (square 12mo. Pages 229, illustrated, cloth. New York: Frederick A. Stokes Company,) by H. Pereira Mendes, is, as the sub-title indicates, "a story about the Bible, but not in the Bible." The characters and incidents are Biblical; all the Hebrew slaves and most of the Egyptians mentioned, Mr. Mendes points out, were real persons.

McClure, Phillips Co. announce a third edition of Edgar Jepson's "Admirable Tinker," a fifth edition of the "Letters from a Chinese Official," a second edition of Joseph Conrad's "Romance," and a third edition of Auguste Sabatier's "Religions of Authority."

In these two volumes the Master of Balliol College presents his view of the theological evolution of the most representative Greek philosophy. Dr. Caird confines himself mainly to Plato and Aristotle, to the chief exponents of the Stoie Philosophy, and to Philo and Plotinus among the Neo-Platonists.

The "ice free" port which Russia, thanks to the co-operation of France and Germany, took away from Japan, after Japan had taken it away from China, has become a source of weakness and of danger to her. She has made very costly and extensive improvements, both of the harbor and of the fortifications.

" Men are sermons and women rituals," says the man of words in Mr. Colton's new story now before us. Wisely he says that privately to a serious-minded young woman. He doesn't project it from the pulpit. For this man of words is a free-lance pulpiteer, one of the kind that tackles municipal problems and decries and blackguards the local boss.

The book of personal reminiscence and authentic anecdote grows in popularity from year to year, and bids fair to rival the novel in time, unless the writers of fiction get new inspiration. Sir Archibald Geikie's "Scottish Reminiscences," which we review this week, is an excellent example of its class, and represents the pastime of a geologist.

The case of James O'Gara, the groom who is suing Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg for $15,000 damages for injuries received from a kick of a horse owned by the banker's widow will go to the jury on Monday. When the trial was resumed yesterday the courtroom was crowded by well-dressed men and women interested in saddle horses and hunters.

This is a collection of fourteen short stories -- Chinese, French, Italian, American -- the initial title supplying the title. They are of merit as diverse as their nationalities, many containing a regrettable note of unreality, and a few partaking decidedly of the nature of padding.

I should like to bring to the notice of your readers "The Winding Road." by Elizabeth Godfrey, as a novel much above the dreary waste of mediocrity in which we are now wandering. The novels of the day, with very few exceptions, are so badly written and so uninteresting that the lover of a good story written in pure English is almost in despair.

The latest volume in The American Sportsman's Library, edited by Caspar Whitney, is on "American Yachting," by W.P. Stephens. The book is a history of yachting during the past century, its origin, its growth, and its recent development. Mr. Stephens has much to say about the America's Cup and the long struggle for its pos session.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 6.--Bishop Stephen N. Merrill of Chicago, senior member of the Board of Bishops, to-day presented a petition to the Methodist General Conference asking that he be retired from active service. Bishop Merrill's petition said that he was in the seventy-ninth year of his life and the fifty-ninth year of his ministry.

TOKIO, May 6. -- Gen. Kuroki in a report yesterday tells of a murderous encounter during the Russian retreat on Sunday last when a large force of Russians mistook a small body of their own men for Japanese, killing and wounding 180 of them.

Bernard Smyth Sons have sold for Frederic B. Jennings to I.A. Von Bomel the plot of over four lots at the southwest corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, 125 by 99.11 and irregular.

Business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday aggregated only about 130,000 shares, and was even less interesting than that implies, there being a minimum of news and only a fractional movement except for specialties. The majority of changes, however, was advances, and this was especially true of the few cases in which the alteration was as much as a point.

Charlotte Perkins Gilman's new book, "Human Work," will be brought out by McClure, Phillips Co. the middle of this month. This is a consideration of man and his position in the universe as a laborer, Mrs. Gilman says in her first chapter:
DENVER, Col., May 6.--The following letter was received by Gen. Sherman Bell from Miss Helen Gould the day after the Colorado reception at St. Louis:

Only one of the local clubs, the Greater New Yorks of the American League, were scheduled to play yesterday, and they were defeated at Boston by a score of five to two. Each team made the same number of base hits, but Stahl's terrible drive for a home run, with two men on bases, spoiled all the chance the New Yorks had of winning.

As generally expected, the National Baseball Commission decided yesterday that Frank Dillon, the first baseman, belongs to the Brooklyn Club on claims prior to those of the Los Angeles (Cal.) Club. The commission also gave O.H. Faulkner to the Detroit Club against the contention of the Rochesters of the Eastern League.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6. -- Continuing the discussion of his general topic, "Christianity and Democracy," M. Anatole Leroy-Beaulieu of France delivered at Harvard University this afternoon his sixth lecture in the series, his subject being "Les Democrates Chretiens et l'Antismitisme."

In your notice of Clifton Johnson's "Old Time Schools and School Books," a single line particularly interested me. I do not know whether it is the author or his reviewer's statement, but the sentence is: "The semi-exclusion of girls lasted until 1822. When the sampler period began we do not know."

" The Lighting of Schoolrooms," a manual for school boards, architects, Superintendents, and teachers, which Longmans, Green Co. are publishing, is by Stuart H. Rowe, Ph.D., Supervising Principal of the Lovell School District, New Haven, and Lecturer on Pedagogy in Yale University; also author of "The Physical Nature of the Child and How to Study It."

ITHACA, N.Y., May 6. -- Cornell will not send a crew to the American Henley at Philadelphia on May 30. That decision was reached to-night by the Rowing Committee. An unfavorable report will be returned to the Athletic Council to-morrow night, stating that the rowing situation does not warrant the sending of a crew to the regatta.

To present the largest possible amount of illustrative material for classes in rhetoric and English composition, George Rice Carpenter and William Tenny Brewster, professors in Columbia University, have selected and edited a book entitled, "Modern English Prose." There are but few available books of this sort.

Line drawings filled in with primary colors either by stencil or with free hand have long been employed for cartoons of hunting scenes. In this respect Cecil Aldin's "A Sporting Garland" is, from a general point of view, like many similar productions. Aside, however, from the method employed we have the individuality of the artist.

Born in Nantes, France, in 1807, a Jesuit at twenty-eight, the Rev. Augustus J. Thebaud came over here in 1839 to teach chemistry at St. Mary's College, Kentucky. He died at Fordham College, near New York, in 1885, after having been teacher, rector, and Superior there most of the time for forty years.

At the time of his death in 1894 William Edward Hall had completed the fourth edition of his "Treatise on International Law" for the press. The correction of the proof was done by J.B. Atlay, who prepared a fifth edition of the book, which is now being issued by Henry Frowde at the Clarendon Press.

This volume is divided into three parts: First, a sketch of Zenger and an account of his famous trial, prepared by Mr. Rutherfurd; second, a bibliography of the issues of the Zenger Press; third, a literal reprint of the trial made from the first edition printed by Zenger himself. The book is illustrated with photogravure portraits, fac similes of rare title pages, broadsides, documents, manuscripts, , and contains a copious index.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The Reichstag to-day adopted a resolution asking the Government to introduce a bill revising the military penal code so as to reduce the minimum punishment in cases where privates resort to violence against their superiors. The two conservative parties voted against the resolution.
Prof. Alfred G. Reeves of the New York Law School has published as a text book his class lectures with the following title:

The exposure and flight of the former Minister of Public Instruction of Italy, Signor NASI, must awaken deep humiliation in the Italian people and be received at once with regret and sympathy by all friends of Italy in other lands. It appears to have been a very scandalous career that this once popular and powerful politician has run.

" O'Gorman's Motor Pocket Book," by Mervyn O'Gorman, M.I.E.E., Assoc. M.I.M.E., is a vade mecum for the motorist. It is a "handbook of advice, instructions, tables, and 'tips'," by aid of which the current of motor literature can be appreciated with very little discomfort, without the trouble of making a "pearl-seeker's plunge" into its innermost workings and past history.

NEWARK, N.J., May 6. -- The members of Annex Hose Company No. 3 of the Kearny Fire Department of Arlington objected to having the hose turned on them at a fire in Stewart Avenue, Arlington, last night, and in consequence the company was disbanded. This company was an auxiliary of Hose Company No. 3, and was under the direction of Assistant Chief E. H. King.

Records in athletic events were again sent tumbling last night in the competitions at the Military Athletic Tournament, in Madison Square Garden. Harry L. Hillman, Jr., Thirteenth Regiment, added another championship to his former victories by taking the 220-yard hurdle event. His time was 0:26 4-5, while the former figures, made by P.J. Walsh, were 0:27 4-5.
LONDON, May 6. -- It is understood that William Dean Howells intends to write a novel with the scene laid in England, and will accumulate material during his present sojourn in this country.

As a sequel to his "Writing Latin -- Book One," John Edmund Barss, Latin master in the Hotchkiss School, has now edited Writing Latin -- Book Two." The present volume, while it has been prepared to follow the first book, is so complete that it can be used with pupils who have not studied the introductory work.
Mr. Angus Hamilton in his book on "Korea" records the following experience:

It was Ruskin who said "Peace and the vices of civil life only flourish together," and upon this Anna A. Rogers has founded a rather strong story, bearing in its kernel a moral and touching upon the heredity of vice -- especially the curse of drunkenness. "Nice enough world to live in, doctor," says the Admiral, speaking of Lieut. Fellowes, just court-martialed for drunkenness, "if there was no continuity between generations, eh?

The cleaning-up process which has been undertaken by the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange is about to be followed on the New York Stock Exchange. A committee of the Board of Governors of the latter has had under investigation the connection of two firms with the affairs of Dr. Woodend.

In the current number of The Critic Adeline Knapp points out a strange but unmistakable resemblance between Walt Whitman's poem, "To the Man of War Bird," and a passage relating to the frigate bird in a book by Jules Michelet called "The Bird." In a translation of a chapter in that book called "The Triumph of Wings," the following phrases appear:

THE title of the new story by Mr. Robert Hichens, "The Woman With the Fan," (published here by the Frederick A. Stokes Company,) refers to a marble statue of a lady quite ungarmented who holds aloft a fan. It is remarked by one of the characters in the book that the fan makes this work of art objectionable.

THE CENTURY MAGAZINE will present as a serial this Summer a number of corelated stories by Miriam Michelson, author of "The Bishop's Carriage." They will be called "The Madragans," and deal with the romps, adventures, and tribulations of an interesting colony of boys, girls, and infants.

SOME one forestalled me in suggesting "The Monkey's Paw" to your ghost-loving readers, but I think this story deserves more than passing mention, and is quite remarkable. There is no incident in it that might not actually have happened and be attributed to coincidence, yet it can hardly be equaled for giving you a thrill and a chill.

Principal Edward H. Boyer of Public School No. 87, situated at Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, appeared yesterday at the hall of the Board of Education to tell of 150 cases of assault and robbery perpetrated upon the pupils of his school by a band of other pupils, Mr. Boyer said:

Doubleday, Page Co. will publish the new book by Booker T. Washington, author of "Up from Slavery" and "Character Building," May 11. "Working With the Hands" is a sequel to Mr. Washington's autobiography, and covers the author's experiences in industrial training at Tuskegee. The two facts that are emphasized in the book are:

The late Dr. Henry Whitney Bellows at some distressful moment of the civil war was asked what outlet he found for his feelings, and he said: "I read the imprectory Psalms." It is evident from these pages that these Psalms have served a similar purpose in many instances, which are not the least interesting of those that Mr. Prothero records.

In 1507 there was published at St. Die a treatise called "Cosmographiae introductio" by an obscure geographer named Martin Waldseemuller. In this book, now extremely rare, occurs the passage: "And the fourth part of the world having been discovered by Americus, it may be called Amerige; that is, the land of Americus, or America."

The fierce light that beats upon a whole galaxy of thrones illumines a volume by Helene Vacaresco, which has already been mentioned in THE BOOK REVIEW, and which Messrs. Harper Brothers will publish on May 12. Mlle. Vacaresco is lady-in-waiting to her Majesty Carmen Sylva, Queen of Roumania, and has already been joined with her royal mistress in the making of a book of poems.

NEWARK, N.J., May 6. -- F.A. Croselmire of the Croselmire Ackor Company, gold refiners, was driving on Washington Avenue in an automobile with his wife and child and a Mrs. Kelly, a guest, last night, when the machine collided with a truck drawn by two horses. The auto was wrecked.

" Sociology," remarked Prof. Bailey parenthetically, as he tapped with his silver-topped cane at the doors of the University Settlement yesterday morning, "sociology demands the study of not only the Defunct, the Delinquent, the Defective, and the Dependent, but also of the Regeneration, the Rehabilitation, and the Rejuvenation of society.
LONDON, May 7. -- The Times's military correspondent says:

Only another weaving of the old material of the Southern novelist. The time after the war, the old planter stock finding its legs again, the low-bred money lender, the foolish negro, the idle "po' white trash" -- and yet Mr. McCants's story is not the average story of its kind. It is better than most, cheerfuller than most, seems to have laid hold of points of common sense which others have missed.

THE canvas which Sir Spencer Walpole covers in his "History of Twenty-five Years" is most extended. During the period included within the two volumes there were brought about the independence of Italy, the discomfiture of Austria, the supremacy of Germany, and the downfall of the French Emperor, with the consequent misfortunes of France.

In 1843 the first edition of Mlle. Alexandrine Etiennette Marie Charlotte des Echerolles's memoirs were published, and since then they have been reissued several times until in 1900 they appeared under the title of "Side Lights on the Reign of Terror." But a book of this kind, dealing intimately with the horrors of that period, has always its readers at hand.

It may be true, as one of your correspondents asserts, that nothing you have printed in the BOOK REVIEW will attract so much individual notice and comment as the discussion of the ghost stories. But I for due would like to ask what possible good can come from a discussion of these weird, uncanny, and horror-producing tales of the past?

After five alarms had been turned in the Universal Storage Warehouse, a five-story brick building, at 202 to 208 East Eighty-eighth Street, was destroyed by fire last night, and several tenement houses opposite the warehouse and adjoining it more or less damaged. An extraordinary number of hose burstings and great difficulty arising from lack of water greatly impeded the work of the firemen.

There are eighty-four illustrations in Mr. Sturgis's new book, which is a companion volume to H.R. Poore's "Pictorial Composition and the Critical Judgment of Pictures." The influences which have brought about the various styles of buildings are shown through these pictures, beginning with views from the early Grecian temples and passing through the great cathedrals to the modern business blocks.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 6. -- In one of the stormiest gatherings the party ever held in Connecticut the Democratic State Convention this afternoon chose fourteen delegates to the St. Louis Convention and instructed them to vote as a unit and for Alton B. Parker of New York as the Presidential nominee.

We are likely to witness during the coming six months a series of important strikes called to resist the movement among manufacturers and other employers of labor in the direction of the open shop. That now maintained by the Boiler Makers' Union is a case in point. In New York and its immediate vicinity, some seven thousand men from the boiler shops and ship yards were idle yesterday.

The latest addition to Newnes's Art Library is devoted to Diego Rodriguez de Silva Velasquez, the celebrated Spanish painter. Like its predecessors, there is, besides the sixty-five reproductions from the artist's paintings, a sketch of his life and work by A.L. Baldry, and a list of Velasquez's principal works and the collections in which they are included.

Justice Bischoff of the Supreme Court has appointed the Morton Trust Company special guardian for Dorothy Whitney, daughter of the late William C. Whitney, in proceedings brought by Harry Payne Whitney, who seeks to get the authority of the court for the sale of the Whitney residence at 871 Fifth Avenue.

The close of yesterday's stock market and the numerous net gains, small as they were, more than met the expectations of the earlier part of the day, which promised little for either bull or bear. Most of the session the trading was duller than on any day of the week, and was not a poor second to the conditions prevailing early in March, when the transactions fell to the lowest point in many years.

As a statement of Democratic principles of government Mr. ELLIOT DANFORTH'S allocution is sound and acceptable. As an ostensible exposition of the views of ALTON B. PARKER it has all the interest and value of a volume of impressions of the United States Constitution by a Mississippi River roustabout or a summary of the Politics of ARISTOTLE by a Shinnecock Indian.

The President of the Western Union Telegraph Company renews his offer to withdraw the wires of his company from any place occupied as a poolroom on receiving notice from the police that it is so occupied, and that they have an intention to proceed against it. It seems to us that this offers a first-rate opportunity to close up substantially all the poolrooms in this city.

Mr. Ward's little book consists of an excellent series of plates showing the microscopic structure of some plants and very small animals, the plates accompanied by a running commentary of text, very lucid and untechnical. Most people not botanists or microscopists of some sort will find in the book things they did not know before, and these things not without interest and value.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The first day of the Chevy Chase horse show drew a fashionable gathering this afternoon when nearly 1,000 visitors made their way to the suburban club to watch the judging of many high class horses. The new rule prohibiting automobiles from entering the grounds sent hundreds of patrons to the grand stand erected to the north of the ring, while two-thirds of the remaining space was roped off for carriages.

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 6. -- At a political meeting to-night Jean Chandler was mortally shot by William Leachman. The meeting was held at the Patrich schoolhouse preliminary to the Republican primaries to-morrow.

THERE does not seem to be any diminution in the number of new books that are published this season, compared with previous seasons, but nevertheless the publishers complain bitterly, and there must be some truth in the complaint, that the war in the East, the tariff controversy, and the approaching general election are exercising a baleful influence on the publishing trade.

Thirty-six minutes after filing her petition a woman was granted a divorce in a Chicago court on Wednesday last. The husband waived service and the wife testified that she had been beaten many times, and "pinched until covered with discolorations." The custody of their daughter of eight years was given to the wife.

Alexander Nelson Hood, the well-known English writer on Italian subjects, is to bring out in this country through E.P. Dutton Co. a romance, entitled "Adria: A Tale of Venice." The tale, he points out in his foreword, "aims rather to be a romantic narrative than a novel in the common acceptance of the word.
The following facts, while not answering directly the questions of "H." in this morning's TIMES, may prove suggestive.

The semi-annual meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Civil Federation was held yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The principal business proposed, it was understood, was to be the election of a successor to the late Senator Hanna as President of the Civic Federation.

By his long observing acquaintance with Ruskin and by the evidence presented in his life of the art critic and his editing of this critic's verses, W.G. Collingwood has performed a great service for all those who desire to know what influences contributed to develop the genius of the man. Collingwood's work has been objective rather than subjective.

NEWPORT, May 6. -- The docket of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, which convenes next Monday, contains the petitions for divorce of Sybil K.W. Hoffman vs. John Ellis Hoffman, and of Charles L. Robert vs. Katherine H. Robert. The ground on which both actions are based is desertion. Neither suit is contested.

The new biography of Constable, by Lord Windsor, in The Makers of British Art Series, which includes "lives" of Wilkie, Romney, Turner, Reynolds, and Landseer, is an attempt to do what C.R. Leslie did in his "Memoirs of Constable," published in 1843, which is now, according to Lord Windsor, only to be had in second-hand book stores.

As a culmination of a series of misfortunes that have come to him within the period of a year, Charles H. Finch, a wealthy Brooklyn lumber dealer, lies dying in the Seney Hospital with a compound fracture of the base of his skull and a broken jawbone, resulting from a kick from a horse.

Famous legends as retold by Emeline G. Crommelin in a manner simple and attractive to children is just published by the Century Company, and should be welcomed by young readers eager to learn those famous stories which form the foundation of most of our romantic literature.

Work on the anchorages and superstructure of the new Manhattan Bridge will be begun by July 1, according to the present plans of the Department of Bridges. The needed appropriation of $10,000,000 was granted at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, and Chief Engineer Nichols is now at work preparing the plans and specifications for the advertising of the contract.

Handy in this case means a reference atlas that can be consulted with one hand while using the other to hold a book or magazine or newspaper. Bartholomew, the great English mapmaker, has revised his "Handy Reference Atlas of the World" for the seventh time. It consists of 76 sheets bound as inserts, besides 50 pages of geographical statistics and 168 columns of index, containing over 15,000 names.

In a review of "The Irish Revolutionists," by Shan F. Bullock, you say: "The author excels in portraying the Celt, that dreamer of dreams and seer of visions; enthusiastic, passionate, quick and hot as a leaping flame, but lacking in cool judgment as in 'staying power,' destructive, not constructive, unable to garner the fruits of victory, and sure to succumb in the end to the patient and wily Saxon."

THE appearance of this the last volume of Mr. Thacher's great work marks an epoch in Columbian literature; for so great has been the author's diligence in the collection of materials that years must of necessity pass before sufficient information for another Life can be found, and we may wait long before a writer will arise who will bring to the task an equal ability of intelligent criticism.
PARIS, May 6. -- Mgr. Lacroix, Bishop of Tarentaise, in a letter to the clergy of his diocese, has given an account of an audience granted to him by the Pope on April 17.

BOSTON, May 6. -- The lines on which the great conflict between Thomas W. Lawson of Boston and the aggregation of corporate and individual financial power known as the "Standard Oil" is to be conducted when the battle is fairly on in the field furnished by the history of the Amalgamated Copper Company, became more clearly defined to-day.

MUKDEN, May 6. -- Still no foreign newspaper correspondents are allowed at Liao-Yang, where all the foreign Attaches are detained. Capt. William V. Judson of the Engineer Corps, United States Army, who is to accompany the Russian Army during hostilities, and Lieut. Newton A. McCully, the United States Naval Attache, and others have been provided with quarters there.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 7. -- President F. De Haas Robison, M. Stanley Robison, Secretary and Treasurer, and Charles Nichols, manager of the St. Louis National League Baseball Club, at the close of to-day's game between the St. Louis and New York teams filed a protest, claiming that a decision by Umpire Johnstone had cost their club the game.

Advocates of greater diversity than now exists in the production of the silk mills express pleasure in the increased favor which the public is showing toward fancy designs, which in a measure are displacing the staple fabrics. It is declared that the manufacturers now have an unusual incentive for developing ingenuity and originality.
Columbia's track team earned a hard-fought victory over the athletes of the University of Pennsylvania on South Field yesterday afternoon by a score of 54 1/2 points to 49 1/2.

FASHIONS in drinks which the up-to-date "barkeeps" serve over the polished mahogany in any of the cafes or hotel in this city change Just as do the fashions in the clothes worn by the fastidious customers of the same "absorbatories."

Louis Johnson, a colored man, drives a truck for Schleicher Co., piano dealers, at 9 West Fourteenth Street. He had a piano to deliver in Harlem last evening and drove up Fifth Avenue. At the corner of Ninety-seventh Street there is a watering trough, where Johnson stopped to let his horses drink.

YESTERDAY morning a middle-aged gentleman wearing a silk hat, gold spectacles, and other articles of apparel suitable to one of his age and professional dignity, turned out of Broadway at the lower end of TIMES Square, and strolled in a leisurely way down Seventh Avenue.

WABASH, Ind., May 7. -- Unknown persons last night entered the Union "Holiness" Tabernacle in the northern part of this city, where a "holiness" service was in progress, and dashed a large quantity of chloroform over the worshippers of whom there were many.

WHEN CAPT. LIONEL JAMES and Dr. Lee De Forest booked their passage on the same steamer from Liverpool last December, although each was unconscious of the other, it was the first of a series of events which have added greatly to the fame of them both. Capt. James, as correspondent of The London Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES, was just starting for the Orient in anticipation of the present war.

PARIS, April 28. -- The first shot has been fired in the battle royal which is to take place between Mlle. Sylviac, the clever little actress of the Varietes, and the Paris Telephone Department. The case is of considerable interest, inasmuch as Mlle. Sylviac is the champion of the long-suffering public, and although it is improbable that she will win her case, her Joan of Arc attitude excites general sympathy and admiration.

The new Trinity Building now in course of construction at 111 Broadway is to be the first of the big office buildings down town to be fitted with plunger elevators. There are to be eleven of these cars, each one with a cylinder going down through solid rock 298 feet below the foundations of the structure -- with one exception the longest elevator tubes in the world.

When Supreme Court Justice William J. Kelly appeared at the Court House in Brooklyn yesterday morning he was wearing a smile born of an experience he had just had with the local Coroners' office. The Justice had been called to act as a juror in an inquest. He went to the Coroners' office and modestly told the clerk in charge that he thought he should be excused from jury duty.

SEOUL, Thursday, May 5. -- Yi Yungtae, the new Minister of the Home Department, has reopened the sale of public offices, which had been discontinued for some time through fear of Japanese intervention. Regaining confidence from the fact that no drastic reforms have followed the signing of the protocol during the Marquis Ito's recent diplomatic visit to the Emperor, the palace harpies have recommenced their grafting.

WE first came in contact with a paternal Government when Lazarette informed us that she could no longer bring us Our allotment of two green earthenware pitchers of sea water for our morning sponge. We took it for a hint that earthenware pitchers are heavy, especially when filled with sea water, and we gave Lazarette a conciliatory franc, which she pocketed.

HOW are the mighty fallen! This is the first thought that comes to him who crosses the threshold of the gloomy old "property shop" in Twenty-ninth Street, where the trappings of past theatrical kingdoms and make-believe monarchies lie moldy and unnoticed, stripped of all their former glory.
TOKIO, May 7. -- Vice Admiral Togo's official recital of the latest engagement off Port Arthur, which was received here to-day, shows that the Japanese have blocked the entrance to the harbor.

The doom of the peroxide blonde has been sealed. Throughout the past theatrical season it has been evident that the brunette has been regaining her place in the choruses of Broadway; and now one of the leading purveyors of musical comedy has made it his settled policy to permit no false blonde to appear in his shows.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 8. (Sunday.) --There is no doubt that Gen. Kuropatkin has abandoned the intrenched position at Feng-Wang-Cheng, fifty miles west of the Yalu River, where the Russian Army was expected to make a stubborn stand against Gen. Kuroki's forces. The Japanese pressed the retreating troops with few losses to either side, and occupied Feng-Wang-Cheng.

Without a drop of city water for firefighting purposes or domestic or business use, a big section of South Brooklyn found itself in a distressing and dangerous situation yesterday afternoon and last night, with a prospect that it would continue until about noon to-day. The famine was due to the shutting off of the supply by the Water Department in order that some greatly needed repairs might be made.

BACHELOR girls, in common with most women, have both nerves and sympathies, and both have frequently been racked, when sitting in skyscraper offices, by the spectacle of men cleaning windows with nothing between them and eternity except twenty stories of air. It is estimated that a window cleaner falls and breaks his neck about every week, the year through.

One of the latest and most useful results of scientific progress along the lines of synthetical chemistry is announced in the synthetical production of camphor on a commercial scale. The process, as described by The New York Medical Journal, is very simple. Oil of turpentine is heated with oxalic acid, forming an oxalate with pinene.

THE sculptors have been busy during the past year with the decoration of the St. Louis Fair, which has taken so much of their energies that one might suppose no other work could be accomplished. But the nine pieces grouped on this page representing seven separate monuments were not prepared for the fleeting show on the banks of the Mississippi, although many of them will he there in plaster casts.

The Cathedral League of the Diocese of New York, organized to promote the erection and endowment of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral House on Morningside Heights, near the place where the new basilica is being erected.

TACOMA, Washington, May 7. -- It has just become known that four head chiefs of the Sitkas, a rival Indian tribe, were allowed to choose a new chief for the Chilkat Indians in March, following the death of Donowak, chief of the Chilcats. Following this unhappy event, his friends at once urged the claims of George Shortridge, the biggest man of Klukwan, both in stature and influence.

IT MAY well be that Dr. Antonin Dvorak, who died a week ago to-day, will not be numbered among the immortals, with the company of great composers of whom Brahms was the last representative. But few will question that he was the greatest of these latest days.

The funeral of Samuel J. Parks, former walking delegate of the Housesmiths and Bridgemen's Union, who died in Sing Sing prison, took place yesterday from the residence of his widow at 211 East Eighty-seventh Street. It was attended by about 1,500 workmen, 1,000 of whom were iron workers.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The talk about Speaker Cannon for the Vice Presidential nomination has reached such a point that the Speaker is seriously perturbed, and is enlisting his friends in a campaign against himself. He has asked a number of them to do everything they can to kill off his boom.

SOFT-SHELL crabs were dear last week, $2.50 a dozen for the best, but the vernal spell has come to stay, and there will this week be a full supply at a reasonable rate. What have been in the market have been good as to quality and size. While yet a luxury -- and they are rarely cheap -- they can be served as extras.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The President to-day made the following appointments at large to West Point:

While the week's end brought a respite in the official investigations by the New York and Consolidated Stock Exchanges into the various kinds of prescribed stock dealings turned up by the events following the Woodend failure, considerable interesting material was brought to light unofficially bearing on the conditions that have prevailed.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The final rounds in the golf tournament of the Chevy Chase Club to-day resulted as follows:

Five boxes containing sticks of dynamite were left in Washington Street, West New York, N.J., on Thursday evening by a careless employe of a firm that is supplying the explosive to the contractors who are building the main lateral sewer running through Washington Street to the Hudson Boulevard.

A bill seeking to amend a section of the Greater New York charter has passed the Legislature and had a hearing before the Mayor, apparently without undergoing the usual wholesome investigation at the hands of the press and those associations which are vigilant in guarding the city's best interests. At present the Chief of the Fire Department has the sole power of transfer and assignment.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Representative Adams of Pennsylvania conferred to-day with the President on the subject of immigration, to which he has given special attention. A bill was introduced by him which is now before the House Foreign Committee limiting immigration from any one country to 80,000 persons per annum.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The issue which the Democrats so industriously labored to create at the last session for use in the Northwest -- Canadian reciprocity -- seriously worried the Republican leaders a while ago because of the strength of the sentiment on that subject in those States. They adopted a non-committal attitude on the subject in Congress.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 7. -- The Methodist General Conference to-day paid eloquent tribute to the memory of President William McKinley. A resolution presented by the Rev. J.W.E. Bowen, colored, candidate for Bishop of Chattanooga, Tenn., struck a responsive chord, and the conference adopted it by a standing vote, the entire audience singing "Nearer, My God, to Thee," President McKinley's favorite hymn.
The Secretary of the Treasury has been waiting for the Attorney General to approve the title to the Panama Canal.

The project of organizing a National Importers' Association, which has been hanging fire for several months, has been revived, and it is expected that an organization will be perfected within a few weeks. A call will be sent out in a few days for a meeting of those interested, and an organization will be launched.
