It is a rather ambitious undertaking to attempt the revision of the entire standard of drug action, involving the re-proving by the finest scientific tests of almost the whole pharmacopeia, but this is what the New York Homeopathic College has planned, and, with the assistance of similar institutions throughout the United States and prominent homeopaths of this city, it believes it will successfully accomplish.

THERE was no doubt whatever in the mind of the man who laid the foundation for the first free public library in New York, away back in 1711, as to the sort of person he wanted for librarian. He put his ideas in writing. His original manuscript is in the library of Lambeth Palace, London.

SARATOGA, N.Y., May 7. -- Mme. Janauschek will hereafter live at the Actors' Fund Home, at West New Brighton, S.L., for which place she left to-day, accompanied by her companion, Mrs. Lillian Roach. She thus accepts the invitation of A.M. Palmer, the Chairman of the Executive Board of the home, who in a recent letter extended the hospitality of the institution.

LANCASTER, N.H., May 7. -- The capture of three prisoners who attempted to escape from the Coos County jail to-day is due to the plucky battle given them by the wife of the jailer, Mrs. W.E. Flanders. The jailer was locked inside the inner corridor of his jail by the escaping men.

A CLEVER idea in trimming was exemplified on a blue sailor hat worn on Fifth Avenue with a short dark-blue cloth walking gown. The hat had a medium-width brim, and while the top was plain blue the under brim was formed of alternate braids of blue and white straw.

TACOMA, Washington, May 7. -- Roy Smout. temporary carrier on the Getchell rural delivery route, running from Everett, went out this week on a bicycle to inspect the country through which he will be compelled to travel. His wheel broke down near Marysville, but Smout says he went faster after he got off the wheel than he did before.

Westchester County is making a strong bid for the overflow population from Manhattan Island. Now that the subway is so near completion, property owners all the way from the Harlem River to Yonkers, and from the Hudson across to Long Island Sound, want New Yorkers to come up there and buy homes, instead of crossing the East River to Long Island, or the North River to New Jersey.

The possibilities of Seventh Avenue, and more particularly of that part of it shown in the accompanying diagram, were favorite topics of discussion among real estate men when its location and its position relative to other thoroughfares were its only claims to future distinction, and long before the important transit developments of the last few years had made its ultimate prominence almost a certainty.
OF the production of Mme. Sarah Bernhard's new historical drama, "Varennes," in six tableaus, by Messrs. Lavedon and Lenotre, the dramatic critic of The London Times says:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7. -- Yale won the annual Spring track games with Princeton on Yale Field in a meet as successful in point of interest for the spectators and in point of records as any held here for many years. The star performance was the world's best pole vault made by W. McLanahan, 1905, Sheffield, of the Yale track team, who vaulted a clean 12 feet in exhibition.

Women of wealth and social prominence all over the country are to-day lost in wonder at the supposed doings of the Board of Lady Managers of the World's Fair. Every woman who responded to the recent invitation to send her portrait to the Woman's Building is asking herself why she should pay $100 to have the same picture published in a book when it was denied a place on the walls of the grand salon.

ATLANTIC CITY N.J., May 7. -- The Hotel Rudolf is now making arrangements for the entertainment of the delegates to the National Piano Manufacturers' Convention, which meets in this city in two weeks. A large number of delegates from all parts of the United States wilt be in attendance. It is likely that the big May ball, which is a feature each season at the Hotel Rudolf, will be given in honor of this convention.

Tops sounded the closing of the eighth annual tournament of the Military Athletic League last night at the Madison Square Garden. The strictly military features of the show went through with more snap and precision than on any other night. Lieut. Col. W.C. McDonald, Forty-eighth Highlanders, and Lieut. Col. H.M. Pellatt, Forty-third Queen's Own Rifles, had the honor of occupying the reviewing box.

In the Home for the Aged, conducted by the Little Sisters of the Poor in Brooklyn, there are more than 100 men between the ages of sixty and ninety-five years who would not be happy if they were deprived of the pleasure of pipe smoking. The pipes are of all sizes and shapes, and are made of various sorts of material.

IF lack of time or means will prevent you from going to St. Louis this Summer to see the big World's Fair, don't worry. There are others. Upward of $5,000,000 has been spent to establish a world's fair of New York's very own right on Coney Island, which you can visit time and again at small cost, and without the wearisome fatigue of a long railroad journey.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 7. -- The campaign now being carried on in Texas by the so-called Hearst boomers is really a contest for revenge. The Texas managers of the New York man are making a play to get even with certain politicians who are arrayed on Judge Parker's side.

The Borough of Brooklyn for many years been the wonder of all those who have come to the metropolis with a consideration of relative land values in mind. Despite its great natural advantages, Brooklyn has long been regarded in real estate circles as backward in growth, with the price of real property far below the figures its population warranted.

JACKSON, Miss., May 7. -- The most serious phase of the race problem that now presents itself in Mississippi is the alarming spread of the murder mania among the negro population, and it almost seems that the colored race is determined to solve the troublesome question by a species of self-extermination.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- Secretary Shaw this afternoon signed a Treasury warrant for $40,000,000, which will be delivered next Monday to J.P. Morgan Co. of New York, as disbursing agents of this Government, on account, of the Panama Canal purchase. The warrant, which is dated May 9, will be delivered by Secretary Shaw personally.

Textile manufacturers will await with more than ordinary interest the result of revived efforts to turn into linen yarn and cloth the American flax which, after the seed is stripped for meal or oil, goes to the paper mill or is burned as useless. For years this has been the golden object at which many inventors and promoters have aimed.

IT IS a matter of regret that none of our active young leaders of mounted troops should have taken the trouble to study on the spot the most interesting race of horsemen in the world, the far-famed, legendary Cossacks, writes the military expert of The London Times. Much can be learned about them from books, but none of them, alas! are in the English language.

Justice Olmsted and Justice Wyatt, in the Children's Court, yesterday made answer to Principal Edward H. Boyer of Public School No. 87, at Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, who on Friday asserted that the court was unduly lenient in dealing with juvenile prisoners, saying that "the Magistrates are a lot of old mollies."

DOVER, Del., May 7. -- Mrs. Mary A. Powell was to-night convicted of the murder of Estelle Albin, the jury fixing the punishment at imprisonment for life. The trial was in progress one week and the jury deliberated two hours.

JUST now, after the gayeties of a very busy week, comes the lull and the making of plans for the Summer. With the ladies' coaching parade, the Morris Park races, the Horse Show at Lakewood, and the coaching parade yesterday, there has been a succession of notable Spring events.
Louis L. Drake of the Boston Barytes Company and Secretary of the National Paint, Oil, and Varnish Association, returned yesterday from a business trip to Cleveland and Pittsburg.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- A signal proof of the flimsiness of the Russian newspaper assertions that this country unduly favors Japan is found in the endeavor of the United States to keep China neutral. This the United States did at the request of Russia.

How the battle against infectious and contagious diseases is being waged in this city by the Board of Health and with what result is interestingly and graphically shown in a collection of exhibits, illustrative of its work, which the department is now preparing for the St. Louis Exposition.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 7. -- The Russian Capital has now been without news from Port Arthur for almost twenty-four hours. The last telegram received was filed at 6 o'clock last night. It is believed that the spot where the Japanese out the railroad and telegraph line is near Port Adams, opposite Pitsewo.

For the first time in several months it becomes necessary to refer to a noticeable decline in the volume of business, and it appears that an answer is now being given to the frequent inquiry as to when the remarkable movement in tenement properties would run its course.

Notwithstanding the fact that there is one more automobile to be tested as the American representative in the Gordon Bennett international race, local automobilists yesterday took a very gloomy view of the situation. The general impression is that no American car will be sent to Germany for the big race in June. Said a prominent member of the Automobile Club of America:

Col. William Jay, the President of the Coaching Club, had good reason to be proud yesterday at the success of the annual parade, which was one of the largest and most brilliant held in many years. There were eighteen coaches in line, and the owners and their guests were representative of fashionable society in New York and its environs, and of Philadelphia and other cities.

AN-TUNG, Manchuria, Monday, May 2, via Seoul, Korea, May 7, 7 A.M. -- A Japanese force to-day charged a thousand men of the Russian rear guard, consisting of a battalion of infantry and two batteries of artillery, near Hamatan, (West of Kiu-Lien-Cheng.)

The height that Spring travel will reach this year could be estimated yesterday when several of the big transatlantic liners sailed from this port. The Lucania of the Cunard Line had every cabin taken, and many who wished to sail on her had to be turned away. The French Line, which has Thursday for a sailing day, sent out La Gascogne, and she had very few berths unoccupied.
A number of fine combination horses thoroughly broken for both riding and driving, and thoroughly acclimated, are being shown by Harry Brenchley at Durland's Riding Academy.

PANAMA, May 7. -- Jose Eusebio Morales and Ricardo Arias have been appointed by President Amador a special commission to receive the $6,000,000 which the Government of Panama is to invest in American securities. Messrs. Morales and Arias will sail for New York on Wednesday next.

DOVER, N.J., May 7. -- For the second time in a week thieves entered the Memorial Presbyterian Church in this town and stole a part of the communion service. A week ago eight cups and six silver plates, all solid silver, were carried off. These constituted the old service, which had belonged to the church since it was founded some sixty years ago.
LONDON, May 7. -- Jacob Schiff, who, on behalf of Kuhn, Loeb Co., arranged to take half the Japanese loan, had a private audience with King Edward yesterday evening.

William R. Hearst called to see Senator Gorman at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Senator Gorman said last night that he was out when Mr. Hearst called and that he had no appointment with the Representative. Senator Gorman also said that he had not seen Charles F. Murphy, and had no appointment with him.

WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The State Department was officially informed of the death of President Candamo by a cablegram from United States Consul Gottschalk, at Callao. Secretary Hay notified the President, and later sent this message to United States Minister Dudley, at Lima:

After a long delay and an enormous amount of patient investigation, the special committee of the Automobile Club of America appointed some time ago to make arrangements for a country club, will make a report this week to the Board of Governors. Thomas M. Hilliard is Chairman of the committee and he with Emerson Brooks and other members have visited a number of country clubs within fifty miles of the city.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 7. -- From the activity displayed at the Whippany River Club it is evident that that organization means to succeed and progress this year. Already many men and women may be seen on the club grounds afternoons and Sundays playing tennis and squash or cantering over the track and fields on their ponies.

Policeman John Foley of the Mulberry Street Station was greatly astonished at Spring and Mott Streets at 2 o'clock yesterday morning when he saw the bony steeds attached to an eastbound owl car approaching at a gallop. He ran into the street as the driver screwed on the brake, stopping the clamor of the cow bells.

LONDON, April 27. -- Bernard Shaw's "Candida," which has been playing in New York this season, came out for a run of six matinees at the Court Theatre recently. The play did not meet with the success it received in America. One of the papers dubs Mr. Shaw "the most brilliantly perverse writer of his time."

AFTER much study, the British War Office has appointed eight dental surgeons who are to aid in "maintaining the courage and the temper of the army." Interesting as is the announcement, England is considerably behind the United States in learning the importance of caring for soldiers' teeth.
IN the death of Warren C. Coleman last month at Concord, N.C., the South lost the moving spirit in one of its most interesting experiments -- a cotton mill owned and operated entirely by negroes.

When MATTHEW ARNOLD wrote his "Literature and Dogma" he avowed his purpose to be to help preserve the use of the Bible as a means of grace and a help to right living, no matter what disclosures might come which should invalidate the theories concerning it which had been adopted by the "popular religion" of the British Islands.

BOSTON, Mass., May 7. -- Six to three was the score by which the Greater New Yorks beat the Boston team in the presence of a great crowd this afternoon. Chesbro received the assistance of 200 "fans" from North Adams, his native town, to cheer him on to victory, and he pitched a masterly game, mowing down the local nine in a fashion to which they are not accustomed.

The war in the East is to be confined to the main combatants -- so all the Chancelleries of Europe say. All the more reason that responsible heads of countries which carry the burden of standing armies and costly navies should refrain from statements that suggest the possibility that war may break loose in Europe.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 7. -- With the arrival of the horse show dates on Friday and Saturday of this week the hotels have increased their house count a bit, and the people coming here have arrived at a favorable time. The rapid growth of the leaves and shrubbery brings nearer the approach of Summer.

THE wonderful and mysterious properties of radium have furnished beautiful themes for the pseudo-scientist to awe the lay mind with during the past two or three years, but, like the perpetual motion of long ago, this latest idol has fallen to earth and its real character is at last revealed.

Famous harness horses, many of New York's well-known amateur road drivers and a number of professional reinsmen who have distinguished themselves on the turf will be conspicuous features of the fifth annual Speedway parade and brushes of the Road Drivers Association, which will be held over a course from One Hundred and Tenth Street and Seventh Avenue to the Speedway on next Saturday.

The ridiculously small total of less than 12,000 shares in the first hour of trading yesterday promised to make the day eclipse all records for dullness for many years back, but during the second hour there was sufficient trading to bring the total up to 40,532 shares. This is the smallest Saturday's business in several years, but on Feb. 11, 1888, the business transacted amounted to only 28, 135 shares.

A member of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment is quoted as saying at the meeting on Friday: "Let's vote on this bond issue and let other things go. What's the use of wasting so much time over a trifle of $10,000,000?"

THE Summer in New York clubs begins literally on May 1. Last week Alfred Vanderbilt appeared tooling the Pioneer, wearing a gray top hat. Few of the amateur coachmen in this city have the temerity to use what is really the proper headgear for coaching.

THE Ladies' Four-in-Hand Driving Club, that had its parade on Tuesday in Central Park, has hitherto had little written about it, as its members tool coaches for fun and not for fame. Nearly every day one or more of the members of the club are driving the big coach that belongs to the club, with its four white-faced chestnuts, somewhere in the Park.

PARIS, April 27. -- Some beautiful specimens of modern French lace are being exhibited this week in the Galliera Museum, with the object of arousing the interest of the women of France in this exquisite but, alas, decaying art.

Berlin, April 22, 1904. THE Kaiser is an early riser, and never gets up later than 6 o'clock. His bath is always followed by a cold douche. His breakfast is in the English fashion, and consists of tea, bread and butter, meat, or fish. He greatly loves fish. When his Majesty reaches his study he finds his mail ready on his desk.
BOSTON, May 7. -- Whatever are Thomas Lawson's plans against Amalgamated, the execution of them is still longer delayed.
PARIS, May 7. -- The critical situation of Russia's land and sea forces excites feverish interest, Russian reverses causing almost as much depression here as at St. Petersburg.

PORT ARTHUR, Friday, May 6. -- A parade of the garrison here was held to-day in honor of the Empress's name day. Lieut. Gen. Stoessel in speech to the troops alluded to the latest phase of the war by which Port Arthur is threatened on the land side, and expressed his firm confidence in the endurance of the defenders of the Kwang-Tung Peninsula.

CINCINNATI, May 7. -- In a game perfectly played in the field the Brooklyn team was defeated by the Cincinnatis to-day by a score of 6 to 4. The home team batted the oftener, the harder, and the more timely, thereby accounting for its victory. For six innings it was a close contest, with Suthoff and Poole bearing the brunt of the battle.

The Canton Society of New York had a dinner at the Hotel Manhattan last night at which Justice William R. Day of the United States Supreme Court was the guest of honor. Justice Day, who was an inti-male friend of the late President McKinley, and Secretary of State during his first administration; Senator Fairbanks and other speakers paid warm tributes to McKinley's memory.

LENOX, May 7. -- The annual Spring cleaning up of the Berkshire resorts is now under way, and the town authorities and the caretakers of the various country estates are busy putting roads and lawns in shape for the opening of the season. Which is not ten days away. By May 15 eight of the large cottages will be open.

The Executive Committee of the National Civic Federation met yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel for the purpose of forming a joint trade agreement department intended to promote trade agreements between organizations of employers and employes. This was a department the establishment of which was favored by the late Senator Hanna.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 7. -- Mrs. Mary Weil, thirty-seven years old, committed suicide here to-day by taking carbolic acid. Her husband is a driver for a contracting firm.

Whether the wires of the Western Union Telegraph Company are led into an illicit poolroom with the loud emblazonment of installators projecting like gargoyles from the lintel of the front door, or whether they are introduced surreptitiously and ashamed, through the midnight darkness of the chimney, involves, we presume, no difference or distinction of which the law will take account.

Yesterday was the dullest day that Wall Street has known in many a year. On the Stock Exchange only 40,532 shares were dealt in, and on the other Exchanges business was at a standstill. When the hammer of the Chairman of the big Exchange fell at 10 o'clock only some fifty members were on the floor.

Of late years handball has become a popular indoor sport among the members of the Harlem River rowing clubs on account of the opportunity which the game gives to keep in good physical condition during the Winter months, and the fact that all the boat clubs have large meeting rooms on the upper floors of their clubhouses which give good opportunity for playing the game.

A collection of actors now under the management of Charles Frohman will take part in a performance of "Yvette" next Friday afternoon at the Knickerbocker Theatre. The play is in three acts. It is an adaptation by Cosmo Gordon Lennox from the French of M. Berton, author of "Zaza." Special scenery has been painted by Ernst Gros.
LONDON, May 7. -- The general tendency of the market this week was good, but there was a slight diminution in the volume of business as compared with the two preceding weeks.

AT this season of the year, when so many people are traveling to Italy for sunshine, and mostly with their eyes open for bargains in antiques, it may be well to indicate the fallacy of any such hope, writes William Le Queux, the author and art critic in the London Rail.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 7. -- Reports reaching local produce houses from Mississippi, Arkansas, and Louisiana are to the effect that many farmers - have abandoned the planting of cotton for the raising of spinach, the earliest of all green vegetables.
Yesterday's was the dullest day's business of this dull year. Two unimportant properties moved a point; all other changes were fractional and irregular. No further comment is warranted.
WASHINGTON, May 7. -- The following cablegram, dated Tokio, May 7, was received at the Japanese Legation to-day:

CLEVELAND, May 7. -- The conference between the Lake Carriers and the Masters' and Pilots' Association was abruptly terminated this afternoon and the announcement made that no agreement had been reached and that a settlement was as far away apparently as at any time since the opening of negotiations.

In your editorial of yesterday on the proposed extension of the Capitol, you referred to Mr. Walter as the designer of the wings of the Capitol. This is the popular impression, but the fact is, the credit belongs to Mr. Charles Frederick Anderson.
PARIS, April 27. -- A great deal has been said and written about the attempt on the part of two theatre managers and a capitalist to form a so-called trust in theatres.

WHEN a man can take luncheon two or three miles from his place of feet on the pavement, and when a woman can go shopping on a rainy day without taking an umbrella or a cab, modern methods of transit, it would seem, will have reached the top notch of perfection.

The interesting figures presented to the State Railroad Commission at its meeting on Thursday make plain the fact that the greatest of American transportation problems are those with which New York City is called upon to deal. During the twelve months ended with February last the railroads of New York City, of all kinds in all boroughs, carried 1,036,834,773 passengers.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 7. -- Animation once more reigns in the Tuxedo colony. Nearly every cottage is either occupied or leased for the coming season, and rooms at the clubhouses are in great demand for the future. The weather, which has been perfect for the week, proved a great attraction for many who took advantage of the fishing for trout in the Tuxedo Lake, which proved the best in years.

LOUISVILLE, May 7. -- Ten thousand people saw the running of the 6,000 Nursery Stakes for two-year-olds this afternoon. Oiseau, winner of the Ardell Stakes, at Nashville, was a prohibitive favorite, but was knocked to his knee at the start, and when he got up was absolutely last, and never had a chance to win.

Following an investigation of the forgery charge made against Miss Olive M. Garrett, a clerk in the employ of the Aetna Security Company, Joseph Martin, a lawyer of 222 Broadway, was arrested yesterday charged with grand larceny. He is alleged to have sold illegally property valued at $16,000 belonging to Walter H. Stearns, an automobile dealer of 31 Tenth Avenue.

New records for loans and deposits were made in the bank statement. The loss of cash was greater than the reported movements of currency indicated, and the increase in reserve required, added to the decrease in cash, diminished the surplus by $10,420,050.

Russian confidence in the impregnability of Port Arthur seems to be great. It is even greater in St. Petersburg, where the place is simply pronounced impregnable, than in Port Arthur itself, where the most that the commander ventures upon is a declaration of his confidence that the garrison can hold out until the arrival of the relieving army.

There seems to be hardly any limit to the marvels of radium. A French person of science foresees its immense influence on mankind when it shall be procured at a less frantic cost. He affirms that its heat rays are capable of melting down stones and massive iron and steel structures and that its qualities must interdict all war.

LONDON, April 30. -- The trend of recent proceedings in the House of Commons has been distinctly favorable to Mr. Balfour's reconstructed Ministry. Neither the budget nor the Licensing bill evoked a feeling of enthusiasm. But in respect of both it is felt that shard corners have been skillfully turned and that now the Ministerial coach may be expected to bowl safely along the straight avenue leading to an uneventful end of the session.
PARIS, May 7. -- The readiness with which the Russian loan was placed in Paris is a further evidence of French sympathy and a belief in the certainty of Russia's eventual success.

" Religion and Beliefs About the Bible" was the subject of the sermon preached by the Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage yesterday morning at the Church of the Messiah, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. He said in part:

SHAN-HAI-KWAN, May 9. -- The Russian troops are retreating from Fengwang-Cheng toward Hai-Cheng, (thirty-two miles east by north of Niu-Chwang,) and are evacuating the western side of the Liao-Tung Peninsula.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The foreign trade of the Chinese Empire in 1903 surpassed all previous records; the total was 541,000,000 haikwan taels, or $346,000,000. The annual report of the Inspector General of Customs for the Chinese Empire, which has just been received by the Bureau of Statistics, shows that the imports in 1903 were valued at 326,739,000 haikwan taels, and exports at 214,352,000 haikwan taels.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 8. -- A motor launch for which great speed is expected is under construction at the Woodyard, this place. The craft is for Albert C. Bostwick of the New York Yacht Club, and is from designs of Tams, Lemoine Crane. She is 50 feet over all, 5 feet 6 inches draft, equipped with twin screws, driven by two ninety-horse power automobile engines.
TOKIO, May 8. -- The celerity and organization of the recent Japanese movements were remarkable.

St. Stephen's College, the Episcopal boys' school at Annandale, Dutchess County, N.Y., of which Bishop Henry C. Potter is Chairman of the Board of Trustees, has been made the defendant in a civil suit for damages on account of a hazing said to have been perpetrated by eight students of the college on Archer Bedell, the eighteen-year-old son of Edwin Bedell of 1,817 Clinton Avenue, the Bronx. The amount asked is $10,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 5. -- Five-year-old Frederick E. Coggsill, who traveled from Philadelphia to San Francisco, tagged, but unaccompanied by parent or friend, reached his journey's end last night. Asked how he liked the trip, the little boy's face lit up with laughter.
The rage of the Republicans in the House when Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN made his speech on April 23 is explained and even justified by the full report which appears in The Congressional Record.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- Not in many a Presidential year has The Congressional Record been so decorous and self-restrained as it is this year. It is enough to make old Congressmen rub their eyes and pinch themselves.

There is something new in hats and caps for outing for the woman who wishes exclusive things. They are made up on original lines, from individual study, and the result is not only something that is chic in appearance, but delightfully light and cool to wear. One of the hats seems to have at first sight one of the long oval crowns which have been seen in hats before, but there is a difference.

NIU-CHWANG, May 7. -- 9 P.M. -- There is every indication that the Russians have decided to evacuate Niu-Chwang. Troops have been leaving here all day long. Forts have been dismantled and all artillery has been placed on board trains. All the local transportation has been commandeered by the Russian authorities.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- The Chicago Typographical Union accepted the challenge of the employers, who are agitating for the "open shop." By a resolution notice was served on the proprietors of the printing plants of the city that an attempt to do away with the exclusive agreements with organizations in the printing trades would precipitate a labor war.

Thrilling finishes were numerous on the Speedway yesterday morning when several persistent rivals, with old scores to settle, met in a series of brushes that furnished the crowd of spectators with some of the best sport seen on the road this Spring. Notable among the new arrivals was James Murphy, the Chicago horseman, who drove Don Derby, 2:04 1/4, the winner of the 1903 Speedway Pacing Championship.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 8. -- Grand Duke Cyril, eldest son of Grand Duke Vladimir and a cousin of the Czar, has returned to St. Petersburg from the Far East. He arrived unostentatiously, and only his family and a few friends were at the railroad station to greet him.

More than 70,000 persons were carried to Coney Island on the railroads yesterday. Although none of the newly erected amusement places was ready to do business they attracted crowds of sightseers, who were permitted to go in and look around. Most of Coney's visitors, however, found pleasure in spending their nickels and dimes in the old way, much to the satisfaction of the frankfurter men and cane ringers.

KARO PASS, Tibet, May 6, (via Kalatso, May 8.) -- Col. Brander with 300 Rifles, about two-thirds of the Gyang-Tse garrison, reached here yesterday after three days' marching, the purpose of the journey being to disperse a body of Tibetans who were station here to oppose the progress of Col. Younghusband's mission.

Clara Morris has made a great discovery. She announced yesterday afternoon at the Actors' Home, in West New Brighton, S.I., that old age was a blessing to woman and that woman ought to look forward to it as the supreme happiness of life.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached a sermon yesterday morning, at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. which was suggested by the proceedings at the Bible League convention, which was held at the Marble Collegiate Church last weak The discourse was devoted in large part to the "higher criticism."

Arthur Mallon, a policeman attached to the West Sixty-eighth Street Station, is a prisoner on parole charged with having shot Robert Brennan of 174 Forsyth Street, who is now in a critical condition at Gouverneur Hospital. The shooting occurred at 6 o'clock yesterday morning on the Bowery, near Chatham Square.

Henry Minster, thirteen years of age, of 338 East Ninety-fourth Street, was shot in the right shoulder yesterday afternoon while climbing a fence separating two lots on the north side of Ninety-fourth Street, opposite his home.

The question has been repeatedly asked why certain bonds traded in in the curb market are selling at such a low figure that purchasers at present prices would receive a return of from 10 to 12 per cent. on their investment.

There wandered into the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon, his pockets bulging with fat rolls of bills, the man who until Saturday night had the well-earned reputation of being the unluckiest of humankind. After a series of catastrophes -- beginning, according to his own statements, at the time of his birth -- Mr. Watkins of Atlanta had seen his star of ill-fortune fade and vanish within the short space of twenty-four hours.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 9. -- There is no confirmation up to the present of the report that the Russians are preparing to evacuate Niu-Chwang, but few would be surprised should it turn out to be correct.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- One of the most picturesque figures in Congress is a man who in a Maryland district has built up an organization that makes Tammany look like a mass meeting. It is a strictly personal organization, but it has all the star Tammany features, with a contemporaneous human interest that Tammany sometimes lacks.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- In view of the statement made by the Brazilian Legation, defining Brazil's position in the boundary dispute with Peru, the Peruvian Legation to-day made a counter-statement to the following effect:

BERLIN, May 8. -- In spite of Count Lamsdorff's declaration against foreign intervention, here are some German journals which still anticipate that the interests of the various powers will ultimately set European diplomacy in motion, especially if a series of Japanese victories should humiliate Russia to a degree which will make it difficult for her to conclude peace terms consistent with the safety of the Russian autocracy.

Detectives Melville S. Dockstader and Stinson McIvor of the Tenderloin Police Station, succeeded Saturday night after a desperate struggle in the apartment house 252 Fifth Avenue, in placing under arrest a woman and two men, charged with conducting a thieves' den there.

OYSTER BAY, May 8. -- The grist mill, now run by Jesse Mollineaux, which stands on the West Shore Road and is one of the oldest buildings on rural Long Island, is to be destroyed. Its lower part is said to be more than 220 years old, and the entire building stood on its present site during the Revolution.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8. -- Lying face downward at a point in the mountains which has been passed and repassed perhaps a thousand times in the search for him, the body of E.L. Wentz, the young mine owner of Philadelphia, was found near Big Stone Gap this afternoon.

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 8. -- More complete returns from the Republican primaries in Kanawha County, which were characterized yesterday with so much violence, indicate that W.M.O. Dawson will have the forty-eight votes of Kanawha County for the Gubernatorial nomination at the State Convention in Wheeling July 12. The rural districts were carried by Charles F. Teter, but the large Dawson vote in this city overcame the vote in other parts of the county.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, May 8. -- Utah's political destiny is just now hinging on the fate of Apostle Reed Smoot. Should he be thrown out of his seat in the United States Senate, and should it be made to appear to the Mormon people here in Utah that this action was due to the influence of the Republican administration in Washington, a startling revolution would follow in the politics of this State.

CANASTOTA, N.Y., May 8 -- Whether Sunday baseball playing can be prevented by an action in equity is involved in the case of Thomas T. Dunham and others vs. Binghamton and Testershire Baseball Association, which has just been submitted to Supreme Court Justice Gerrit A. Forbes of this village.

ROME, April 21. -- Count Eugene Zichy, the famous Hungarian explorer, known particularly for his researches in Asia in quest of the original home of the Magyars, gives a graphic and detailed account of the Chun-chus from his personal experiences in Manchuria.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 8. -- The Carnegie Hero Fund is not looked upon kindly by many Pittsburgers. Ex-Gov. William A. Stone, in addressing the veterans of the Lieut. James Lystle Post 12, G.A.R., attacked the philanthropy of the act.

I was very much interested in your article on the Zoological Gardens appropriation, and I thought I would write you of a little experience myself and family had on a visit to the Gardens one afternoon last Fall.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 9, (Sunday, 3:30 A.M.) -- Two official dispatches calculated to increase the depression existing among all circles in Russia were given out last night. From the point of view of the progress of the campaign the most important is a dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin reporting the capture by the Japanese without opposition of Feng-Wang-Cheng on May 6.

The death of LENBACH is felt throughout Germany all the more keenly because just at present there is no portrait painter of equal talent to take his place. He is endeared to Germans because he pictured the leaders in the glorious epoch of union -- BISMARCK, MOLTKE, WILHELM I., and others -- and also because of his downright, somewhat violent speech and a character that is usually termed "full of temperament."
ST. LOUIS, May 8. -- "Prince Pu Lun Triumphal March" is the title of a composition which Prof. Charles Kunkel, the St. Louis composer, dedicated to the Prince.

That Africander, rival of Irish Lad for first place among the three-year-olds last season, and one of the top weights in all the great handicaps of the Eastern turf, will race soon, was demonstrated at the Gravesend race course yesterday, when in the most impressive move of the day the colt galloped a mile in 1:43 and finished out a mile and a furlong in 1:58.

Our Republican friends are extremely disturbed at the possibility that the Democrats will start an "anti-Federalist" campaign and try to win over the people of the United States to the dangerous Separatist and States' Right doctrines of THOMAS JEFFERSON. They may set their hearts at rest. The shibboleths of a hundred years ago no longer are a working test of the political tribe to which those who use them belong.

A second strike throughout the city is threatened by the Asphalt Workers' Union unless they are recognized in the way they assert they were to be recognized under the agreement entered into between the representatives of the asphalt companies and the arbitration committee of three appointed by the Central Federated Union.

MUKDEN, May 8. -- The Associated Press correspondent finally received permission to proceed from Niu-Chwang to Mukden by way of Liao-Yang. A special car was provided for him on the main line after leaving Niu-Chwang, and he received official courtesies on the journey.

CINCINNATI, May 8. -- Brooklyn received several chances to score runs to-day, but could do no better than tally once against Cincinnati. The home players used their bats effectively at those points where hits were needed, and so scored enough runs to quadruple their opponents' slim figure. Although Elliott was very wild, the visitors could not hit him, and his backing up in the field was snappy and at times brilliant.
MIDDLETOWN, May 8. -- Delaware County claims to be the banner county in the matter of producing the oldest schoolmasters in point of service in New York State.

The desire on the part of certain Republicans to nominate Elihu Root for Governor is fast rounding into a determination to fight for that end. They believe that Gov. Odell has no desire to have the ex-Secretary of War nominated, but would prefer Erastus C. Knight of Buffalo.

LUSHTON, Neb., May 8. -- The Nebraska anti-merger railroad laws are to be enforced against the Burlington and the Kansas City and Omaha Railroads, the object being to annul the absorption of the latter by the Burlington.
WINSTED, Conn., May 8. -- There was a tragic ending of a house party of Torrington and Winsted people at this place today, when Miss Lena Blackman of Torrington was drowned in Highland Lake, here.

NEWARK, N.J., May 8. -- Bicycle riders with long marks, both amateurs and professionals, won everything on the card today in the handicap events at the Vailsburg track. Kramer and Fenn, who were on scratch in the professional races, and Billington, Lee, Quille, and Goerke, the amateurs, never had a chance.

There could have been no complaint of the news last week, at least in quantity. Russia, Japan, and New York City floated a quarter billion of securities, and partially as a result of the cisatlantic portion New York bank loans made a new high record. The Panama business was completed, and gold exports instead of slackening gave signs of continuance upon other accounts than Panama payments.

The announcement that ex-GOV. FRANK S. BLACK is going to make the nominating speech for President ROOSEVELT will excite some special wonder. The news was given out at the White House. That was very frank, open, and above-board, to be sure. It shows that the President is running his own campaign and makes no bones about letting the people know it.

The discovery by the Health Department that there has been an extensive traffic in worthless certificates of sufficient vaccination by east side physicians invites very drastic measures for the suppression of this petty swindle on the poor, ignorant, and credulous. The local medical societies should take the matter up for the protection of the good name of the profession.

American friendship for China is an example of the striking effect of background. Unquestionably the intelligent Chinese regard us as friendly when they contrast our treatment Of China with that received from other Powers. That is the explanation of the special request from Russia to our Government to use its influence in persuading China to remain effectively neutral in the present war.

AN-TUNG, May 8. -- The defeat of the Russians at the Yalu must be compared to the disaster at Port Arthur. It was due primarily to their perfunctory, old-fashioned methods, while the success of the Japanese must be attributed to perfect acquaintance with modern conditions, admirable intelligence, skillful utilization of military factors, and concentration at the psychological moment upon the weak point of the Russian line.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Japanese have developed a trade in a new commodity which has been decided by the General Board of Customs Appraisers to be hitherto unheard of and not enumerated in the Dingley act.

BOSTON, May 8. -- Thomas W. Lawson is out with another statement to-night. After discussing the recent hearing in the gas suit he takes up again the affairs of the Amalgamated Copper Company and says:
TOKIO, May 8. -- Last Friday, after sharp cavalry skirmishes at Erhtaitsu, Santaisu, and other places, a detachment of infantry belonging to Gen. Kuroki's army took Feng-Wang-Chang.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 8. -- A great demonstration in honor of the Right Rev. William Stang, first Bishop of the new Roman Catholic Diocese of Fall River, was made here to-day following the celebration by the Bishop of his first pontifical mass.

At its recent meeting in this city the Executive Committee of the National Civic Federation took steps to form a department the especial function of which shall be to promote trade agreements between organizations of employers and employes. A considerable committee was formed, representing both classes, and it is announced that the work will be carefully and steadily pressed.

NYACK, N.Y., May 9. -- The body of a man who is believed to have been murdered and thrown off the highest point of Hook Mountain was found hanging over a tree below a cliff that rises 700 feet above the Hudson River early last evening by three young men who were returning from a stroll over the mountains.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 10 -- 3:40 A.M. -- The War Commission adjourned at a late hour this morning, but did not make public any dispatches from the Far East. This is accepted as an indication that no fresh collisions have occurred. The Cossacks in touch with the Japanese are simply small detachments which are observing the movements of the enemy, in order to keep Gen. Kuropatkin properly informed.

As the result of Alfred R. Goslin's corner in Light, Fuel, and Power, the big Consolidated Exchange house of Floyd, Crawford Co. of 25 Broad Street, one of the largest wirehouses in the country, with offices in sixty cities, was suspended by the Governors of that board yesterday afternoon pending investigation of charges of "obvious fraud and false pretense."

The sermon was over in the Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue on Sunday evening, and the collection plates were just about to be passed around when Dr. Charles Godell, the pastor, said:
The farce began with the following "personal" in a newspaper last Saturday:

Your recent interview with Mr. William Carr regarding the making of porcelain equal to the French seems to be not complete without reference to the fact the there is now made in a number of potteries in this country a porcelain that is "hard" like the French and in use by nearly all the restaurants and hotels in this good land.

Several changes have been made in the cast of "The Man from China" at the Majestic Theatre. This week William Phillips will resume the role of Count Louis, the cook, replacing Eugene Redding; Harry Welch will take William Taylor's role of Tommy Dodd. Paul West is rewriting part of the libretto.

Is it personal and party loyalty, or a sort of hypnotism that constrains the President's official family to stand by him and stand up for him in everything he does? Mr. ROOSEVELT did not consult all the members of his Cabinet about initiating the proceedings to enforce the Anti-Trust act.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- Powers of the widest scope are conferred upon the Panama Canal Commission, and upon the Governor of the American zone on the Isthmus, under an order promulgated by President Roosevelt yesterday.

BERLIN, May 9. -- During the discussion following the third reading of the Budget bill in the Reichstag to-day Herr Bebel; the Socialist leader, referred to Emperor William's speeches at Carlsruhe and Mayence, remarking that the pointed allusions to France had caused great surprise, coming so soon after the Emperor's return from Italy, where President Loubet had been received with hearty ovations.

PITTSBURG, May 9. -- The grievance between the International Bridge and Structural Iron Workers and the American Bridge Company, has been adjusted. At a conference to-day the company agreed to remove the thirty-five non-union men employed at Corrall, Penn., where the company is erecting a bridge for the Pennsylvania Railroad.

The Door of Hope solicits the sympathy and co-operation, financially as well as otherwise, of the public at large, to further their efforts in the preventive and rescue work among unprotected girls during the St. Louis World's Fair. The organization, dedicated to the salvation of the girls on the street, later led to the founding of the first Door of Hope Oct. 25, 1890, and since known as the Mother Home.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- The old war between the music union and the non-union musicians, which has for years made the Marine Band the target of attack, has broken out in the Washington theatres. The three leading musicians of the Lafayette resigned from the union to-day and a new orchestra was organized.

Police Commissioner McAdoo issued yesterday afternoon a statement backing up all the charges of Capt. F. Norton Goddard against the Western Union Telegraph Company as an abettor of the poolroom business in this city.
The New Rochelle Yacht Club will hold its annual regatta on Saturday, May 28.

SARDIS, Miss., May 9. -- At Balleatine, a small station southwest of here, Rufus Bobo has been shot and killed by negro citizens, who were attempting to arrest him on a charge of murdering a negro woman. His brother, Mack Bobo, on being arrested on the same charge, was threatened by a mob of 400 negroes.

At the annual meeting of the Middle States Regatta Association held at the Pabst, on West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, last night, it was decided to hold the annual regatta of the organization on the Harlem River on Labor Day. The list of events will be selected by the Regatta Committee. The present officers of the association were all unanimously re-elected as follows:

On May 5 there appeared on the first page of THE TIMES an article headed "Haines Saves Mail Horses," to the effect that Mr. Haines, acting upon numerous complaints relative to the condition of the New York mail horses, had paid a visit to the Post Office, seen some of the horses, and "warned" two drivers and the starter that they must not take out such horses again.

Local automobilists are awaiting with considerable interest the result of the test to be made of the Christie machine, the only car now left of the three that entered for the Gordon Bennett international race that has yet to be passed upon by the committee from the Automobile Club of America. Mr. Christie's machine is in this city, and its mechanical features have been inspected by the club committee.

This is a continued story of exclusive things in new goods, and, of course, new styles. How does "homomen" cloth sound? If it appeals to the ear as it does to the eye it is certainly worth while. It is a pretty, silky stuff, with little tufts of silk fuzz covering it. It is one of the new Summer materials, and a suit, in a warm chestnut brown, made of it is most attractive.

The first walkover of the year made a tame beginning for the racing at Morris Park yesterday afternoon, but matters shaped themselves speedily and the day was productive of quite as much excitement and uncertainty as was the fair allotment of a day, before the programme, which included an extra race because of the walkover, was finished.

In a rear-end collision between trains of the Third Avenue Elevated Road, just south of Fifty-sixth Street, yesterday afternoon, one man, a motorman, was killed and three passengers were injured. William Cornell, the motorman of the second train, while sticking to his post, where he met his death, yet managed to make the passengers in his car understand their peril in time to save their lives.

George W. Morgan, State Superintendent of Elections, acting under instructions from Albany, will lend Deputy United States District Attorney Joel N. Marx his assistance in running down naturalization frauds in the Police Department. While regretful because the knowledge that he was investigating police naturalizations had become public, Mr. Marx said yesterday that he was glad he would have the benefit of Superintendent Morgan's full force in gathering evidence, and that he expected surprising results.

Lawrence Delmour went to Police Headquarters yesterday morning and told Inspector McCluskey of the Detective Bureau that a pickpocket had stolen a valuable watch out of his pocket on Saturday at Morris Park. He said the watch was presented to him seven years ago by a number of his Tammany Hall colleagues.

A packed audience in Proctor's One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Theatre, composed mostly of women and children, was thrown into a panic yesterday afternoon because a workman stuck his foot through the plastering over the orchestra circle and kicked down some fragments on the heads of the spectators.

The anniversary of the Northern Pacific corner was not marked by anything so apposite as the hearing in the Northern Securities case, but few failed to contrast the day's dullness with the cause whose sequel is still incomplete. The incident of the day was the completion of the Panama payment, without any marked effect.

Interest in yesterday's stock market was confined almost entirely to the day's special movements, the general movement of the list being too limited, in common with the transactions, to attract attention or arouse interest. The pace set on Saturday was scarcely exceeded, and at times during the session the market was about as dull as it could be without ceasing altogether.

ALBANY, May 9. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the Troy Municipal Commission bill, which adds the Mayor and Corporation Counsel of Troy to the Local Improvement Commission, and thus gives Mayor Hogan control of the commission.

An association has been formed in Butler, Penn., to bring actions for damages against the water company, the damage having been caused by the typhoid epidemic which lately ravaged that town, and the allegation of the complainants being that it was the result of negligence on the part of the water company in failing to protect the sources of its water supply and to maintain the purity and potability of the water it distributed.
LONDON, May 10. -- Sir Henry M. Stanley, the African explorer, is dead.

As an outgrowth of the meeting called by the Merchants' Association yesterday to take up the rumors of bribery in the Board of Aldermen over the Port Chester Railroad application it was asserted last night that on two different occasions the New York and Port Chester Company had endeavored to effect a combination of interests with the New York, Westchester and Boston Road.

NORFOLK, Va., May 9. -- Rather than see her two-year-old boy drown, Mrs. Kate Dorman sacrificed her life to-day. Mrs. Dorman, with her sisters, Mrs. Kuhn and Mrs. Landweher and Earl Dorman, two years old, were driving over Lynn Haven River in a carriage drawn by a mule. While on the bridge the animal became unmanageable and backed the vehicle and its occupants into the river.
CHE-FOO, May 10. (Tuesday.) -- Passengers arriving to-day from Niu-Chwang say that the Russian force probably evacuated that place during the night.

In almost every war there is occasion for a "forlorn hope," that is to say, for the attainment of a desirable military object by means which are so extra-hazardous that even soldiers, whose business is to die, cannot fairly be ordered to carry it out, that is carried out by means of a call for volunteers.

To any one interested in the work accomplished by the city hospitals in the Borough of Brooklyn your editorial on "The Bellevue Plans" cannot fail to excite the keenest interest. As one who is thoroughly familiar with the needs of the Brooklyn hospitals it is impossible for me to remain mute at this time.

I was for nearly five years, a special officer of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, both before and after the annexation of this place to New York City. I resigned for several reasons, one of which was, I think, an explanatory relation to the question of the efficiency of the society which has lately been discussed in your columns.

Recent reports of the high rate of mortality among our street cleaners should give us pause. For so much, or less, they sweep it up -- microbes of sputum, germs of dropped disease, dust of decay -- sweep it up, breathe it in, live by it, and, in five years, die by it. Five years! So long!

Harry Vogt, thirty-three years old, a salesman of 115 Skillman Avenue, Williamsburg, appeared in the Lee Avenue Court yesterday with his head swathed in bandages. He said he had been clubbed by Detective Germershausen of the Bedford Avenue Station early Sunday morning without the slightest provocation.

The will of Solomon Loeb, a member of the banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's office. Mr. Loeb died on Dec. 12 last. The personal property is stated to be "as much as $100,000" and the real estate "as much as $100,000." He left more than $100,000 to charity.

Baltimore dispatches bring the news that Senator GORMAN is sore perplexed by doubts in making choice of delegates at large from Maryland to the St. Louis Convention; particularly in selecting the delegate who is to make the speech nominating him for the Presidency. Some of his friends tell him that Senator-elect ISIDOR RAYNER is the best man to nominate him.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 9. -- The fifty-thousand-dollar breach of promise suit brought by Helen Karcher Miller, divorced wife of S.D. Miller, son of former United States Attorney General William H.H. Miller, against Howard Cooke of Strawberry Hill, this city, son of the late Rev. Dr. Samuel Cooke, has been withdrawn by the plaintiff.

Charles D. Grasty, proprietor of The Baltimore News, who was in this city yesterday, speaking of the rehabilitation of Baltimore since the fire, said that while it had not been so great insome of its phases as it might have been, it had been satisfactory.

LONDON, May 10. -- The Times's correspondents in Russia say that the spectre haunts the minds of Russians that at some critical moment China will suddenly declare herself openly on the side of Japan. This dread naturally is increased by the news of the Japanese victory on the Yalu, and the Novoe Vremya in a recent leading article only thinly disguises this anxiety by adopting a violently minatory tone.

Fasters have gone without food for many days at a time, but no one can go without sleep. "For a long time I have not been sleeping well, often lying awake for two or three hours during the night up to three weeks ago, but now I sleep sound every night and wake up refreshed and vigorous," says a California woman.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 9. -- After nine rounds of the international chess masters' tournament, Janowski and Marshall are tied for first place, while Lasker comes next, two points behind. Teichmann comes fourth, leading Showalter and Mieses. The principal features of to-day's round were Janowski's brilliant play against Napier, and Hodge's downfall before Marshall.

BRISTOL, Va., May 9. -- The body of E. L. Wentz, discovered in the mountains near Kelleyview, Wise County, Va., Sunday afternoon by Dave Raleigh, a miner, lies tonight identically as it was first seen, and is guarded by twenty-five men under the command of Superintendent Arthur Foster of the Osaka plant of the Virginia Coal and Iron Company.
I respectfully solicit the influence of your paper to suppress the disease-spreading device used on the Third Avenue and other surface cars -- under the disguise of a protection from accidents.

Dr. W.E. Woodend, despite his oft-repeated assertion that he and Mrs. Woodend would be on hand whenever their presence was desired in the hearing of the involuntary bankruptcy proceedings instituted against him, was absent yesterday morning when the taking of testimony was resumed before Special Commissioner Hitchcock in the Federal Building.
Money on call loaned at 1@1 1/4 per cent., with the last loan at l 1/4 per cent. Most of the day's business was at 1 1/4 per cent.

Three men were injured, one of them so seriously that he may die, at a fire yesterday afternoon in the pattern shop of the Fletcher Machine Works, at the foot of Thirteenth Street, Hoboken. Charles Hendrickson of Paterson Plank Road, West Hoboken, was injured internally, and will probably die.

A straight line across the base of the Liau-Tung Peninsula runs from the Liau-Ho to the River Yalu, from Niu-Chwang to An-tung. The abandonment of the line of the Yalu has been forced by the operations of the Japanese. The abandonment of Niu-Chwang was a necessary sequel to this, as well as the abandonment of Port Arthur at the extremity of the peninsula.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 9. -- A sensation was created in the Criminal Court to-day when County Prosecutor Keeler announced that a bold attempt had been made to bribe the jurors in the case of Guyaticano Piesciotta, an Italian, charged with the murder of Policeman Weik.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 10 -- 3:40 A.M. -- The strict censorship prevented the St. Petersburg newspapers receiving dispatches yesterday, and the lack of information gave rise to a fresh crop of rumors, including one that the armored cruiser Rurik had been destroyed.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. Hollis H. Hunnewell are guests of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald C. Vanderbilt at Sandy Point Farm. This is Mr. and Mrs. Hunnewell's first visit to Newport since their marriage here last November.

The Rev. Charles Augustus Briggs delivered an address yesterday afternoon on the subject of "The Higher Theological Education" at the Union Theological Seminary, 700 Park Avenue. The speech was part of the three days' exercises in celebration of the sixty-eighth anniversary of the seminary and the graduation of the seminarians.

Referring to a note in THE TIMES of the 4th inst., re "Mirage of Light's Flash" from the Nantucket Light House having been seen from the steamship Perugia a distance of sixty miles, reminds me of a similar effect observed by me in 1888.
LONDON, May 9. -- Baron Hayashi, the Japanese Minister here, looks for the next engagement of the war to take place at Liao-Yang. He said to-day:
Slawson Hobbs have sold for the estate of G.S. Slawson the plot, 183.2 by 100.11, on the south side of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 85 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.

LONDON, May 9. -- There were upward of eighty contestants in the stroke competition to-day, preparatory to the opening of the ladies' golf championship meeting at Troon, Scotland, to-morrow. The contest was interesting because for the past five years the winner of the stroke competition has eventually won the championship. Miss Glover, the Scottish lady champion, went the eighteen-hole round in magnificent form, finishing in 81 strokes, easily the top score.
Perhaps the fact that I have been a reader of the daily TIMES most of the time for the past twenty-five years may justify my trespassing upon your valuable space.

WASHINGTON, May 9. -- At the opening to-day of the Tyner and Barrett trial on charges of conspiracy in the Post Office Department George W. Morgan, formerly President of the Continental Security Redemption Company of Birmingham, Ala, testified that he came here with his lawyer, after receiving the Barrett opinion on bond investment companies, to ascertain whether the contract of his company was in accordance with law.

Referring to a note in THE TIMES of the 4th inst., re "Mirage of Light's Flash" from the Nantucket Light House having been seen from the steamship Perugia a distance of sixty miles, reminds me of a similar effect observed by me in 1888.

The Title Guarantee and Trust Company, the Colonial Trust Company, and the Washington Trust Company yesterday announced that they would no longer clear through members of the Clearing House Association.

Suarez's pitching was too difficult for the South Orange High School boys to master yesterday on the latter's grounds, and the De La Salle Institute team scored an easy victory. Suarez struck out eighteen batters and allowed only two hits. Score by innings:

William Frear, Chairman of the committee appointed by Secretary of Agriculture Wilson, under the authority of the act of May 3, 1903, to fix standards of purity for foods, announced that the committee will meet next Wednesday morning in the Hotel Wolcott, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-first Street, to take testimony and hear suggestions which will enable it to perform its duty.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9. -- Anatole Leroy-Beaulieu of France, at Harvard University this afternoon delivered the seventh lecture in his series upon "Christianity and Democracy." The subject was "Les Protestants et l'Anti-Protestantisme."

Two opposing investigations of the charges of "hold up" and bribery in the Board of Aldermen in connection with the refused Port Chester Railroad grant will be under way before the close of the week. One will be conducted by an Aldermanic committee named yesterday. The other will be started by the special committee organized by the Merchants' Association.

Frank admission by H.K. Pomeroy, the newly elected President of the New York Stock Exchange, in his inaugural address yesterday, that there were some "black sheep" in the board's membership, was taken as strong evidence in Wall Street that the Exchange has decided upon drastic measures in the cases of members against whom irregular practices had been proved in the recent investigation.

The outlook for the complete suppression of the disreputable poolroom business was never so good as it is at the present moment. Out of the exposure of the Western Union Telegraph Company's relation to the poolrooms two or three vital facts emerge into plain view. One is that a poolroom cannot be operated without telegraph or telephone connection.

Most of the Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company were unwilling to state yesterday their position in relation to the charge of collusion with poolrooms made against the company by F. Norton Goddard and Police Commissioner McAdoo. Senator Depew was a notable exception. He said:

LONDON, May 11. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Morning Post, under date of May 10, says that the Japanese Army is advancing in three divisions -- the first from Feng-Wang-Cheng toward Liao-Yang, the second from Polandien and Chuchon to Yung-Yao-Cheng, and the third from Sulien-Cheng to occupy Kulien-sin, with the object of severing communications with the rear of Liao-Yang, where only small preparations for defense have been made.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10. -- After the Republican State Convention, held here to-day, had selected delegates at large to the National Convention, adopted a platform, and indorsed the present Administration, it adjourned speedily. The only unexpected incident of the meeting occurred when William Howland of North Plainfield objected to the unanimous election of the four delegates at large.

GYANG-TSE, Tibet, May 8. -- After the dispatch of my telegram on May 6 the mounted infantry returned to camp on the Karola and reported that they had killed 250 Tibetans during the pursuit after the force that opposed the advance of Col. Younghusband's mission.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Rear Admiral Walker, President of the Panama Canal Commission, received a telegram to-day from John Findley Wallace of Chicago, General Manager of the Illinois Central Railroad, accepting the appointment of chief engineer in charge of the construction of the canal. Mr. Wallace will receive a salary of $25,000 a year.

The details of the lease of that portion of the Brookdale Farm at Red Bank, N.J., equipped for the breeding of thoroughbred horses, by Harry Payne Whitney from the estate of Col. W.P. Thompson, was completed yesterday, and under the terms of the contract Mr. Whitney is to take possession of the portion needed for breeding farm in September.

BOSTON, May 10. -- The stockholders of the Boston and Northern and Old Colony Street Railway Companies at special meetings to-day authorized general mortgages covering the properties of both companies, and in addition ordered the execution and issue of $25,000,000 4 per cent. fifty-year bonds.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 10. -- In the Park Hill Reformed Church this evening Miss Pearl Meredith, the oldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Leonard of Caryl, was married to the Rev. Orville Lincoln Sigafoos, pastor of the Reformed Church of Pompton Plains, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William P. Bruce, pastor of the church.

HENRY M. STANLEY was the very type of the "gentlemen adventurers" of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, who were actuated mainly by mere love of change and excitement, but whose adventurous dispositions did so much for their respective countries and so inestimably promoted the spread of civilization.

Sweetser, Pembrook Co.'s dry goods jobbing business at 376 Broadway is to be liquidated, according to an announcement issued yesterday by the corporation. It is said that the assets will be ample to meet all the debts, and probably will leave a surplus to be divided among the holders of preferred stock, which amounts to $750,000.

LONDON, May 10. -- Sir Henry M. Stanley, the African explorer, whose death was announced in these dispatches early this morning, passed away peacefully shortly after 6 o'clock. He was quite conscious to the last and able to recognize his wife.

The report that Richard Canfield has been closing out his various interests in this city, Newport, and Saratoga, preparatory to living abroad, was followed yesterday by the announcement that the houses at 6 and 8 West Forty-seventh Street had been sold by David Bucklin to Alfred M. Rau of the Municipal Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The President has in the last few days directed that a special hearing be given by the Commissioner of Patents to Thomas A. Edison, in connection with an interference brought by a rival inventor against a device pertaining to Mr. Edison's storage battery.
KINGSTON, N.Y., May 10. -- An unknown woman, who is believed to be a crank, called to-day at the Ulster County Surrogate's Court and made excited inquiries for "President Parker."

You have a lively interest in both the welfare and attractive appearance of this city. Can you tell me why whenever a procession takes place here Broadway is made a dumping place of almost cartloads of ticker tape thrown out I presume chiefly from brokers' offices by the energetic small boy?
Snugly berthed near Fulton Market is the Gloucester fishing schooner Arbutus, the first of the great mackerel fleet to reach port, and the winner of the annual race from the fishing grounds.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 10. -- Manager Hanlon made the mistake of sending in the wrong pitcher to-day, and the Cincinnatis are a game ahead on the error. Poole thought he could beat his old team to-day, and the game was far out of reach before Hanlon could call Poole in out of the shower of hits that whistled around him.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10. -- The real estate in this city owned by Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, with the exception of her Fairmount home property, the water-front lots on North Beach, and land at Holly Park, has been purchased, says a local paper, by a syndicate composed of Robert Spreckels, James D. Phelan, Will A. Magee, Thomas Magee, Jr., Frederick Magee, and Gustav Sutro. The price to be paid for these properties is $2,600,000.

Cord Meyer, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, announced last night the appointment of a committee of three to investigate the eligibility of National bank Directors to act as Presidential electors. The committee consists of William B. Hornblower, Adrian H. Joline, and De Lancey Nicoll, all lawyers.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- President Roosevelt will receive in a day or two the final report on the investigation of the New York Post Office. The report disposes of a number of questions left unsettled in the investigation of affairs there by the Inspectors heretofore. Mr. Robb went to New York last week, and with an Inspector and a stenographer conducted an examination, which closed the final points in the protracted investigation there.
ALBANY, May 10. -- Gov. Odell has signed the so-called Remsen 6 Per Cent. bill, a stringent measure designed to prevent abuses in the matter of usurious interest on chattel loans.

NIU-CHWANG, May 9 -- (Delayed.) -- The United States Consul, Mr. Miller, was prevented for a time from telegraphing to Minister Conger a statement of the situation here. Mr. Miller's message was released after he had made a strong protest on the subject.

General Appraiser Howell yesterday overruled an appeal by the Collector from the action of Appraiser Whitehead in sustaining the invoice values on a large importation of silk and cotton hatbands from Muller Eyketskamp of Barmen.

The expectation that the crop estimates of the Bureau of Agriculture, published to-day as of May 1, would be "bullish," as favoring the plans of those manipulating the market for speculative advances, is not disappointed. The document is distinctly pessimistic in general tone and might cause some disquietude if those most in interest were disposed to take it quite seriously.

MOUNT VERNON, May 10. -- Mrs. George D. Atwell, wife of Detective Atwell of the Mount Vernon Police Department, is ill at her home in South Fourth Avenue to-night as the result of a severe shock caused by a nurse from the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane mistaking her for a lunatic and attempting to drag her off to the asylum.

Giving vent to one's indignation in the public press has seldom more effect than administering a soothing syrup to the writer's feelings. Perhaps, however, you or many of your readers may be the advance guard of an aroused public sentiment for the better protection of the traveling public.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 10. -- Viceroy Allexeff has telegraphed to the Emperor as follows:

Not in years has the Tenderloin been so quiet as it was last night. There was absolutely no gambling going on, according to all in a position to know, and all the best known houses, which have done more or less business during various periods of excitement, were dark from garret to cellar.

New Body Will Not Conflict with Major Associations, but Proposes to Punish Offenders. The Stewards of the Grand Trotting Circuit, who for over thirty years have been operating in name only, have at last organized themselves into a distinctive body for the purpose, it is claimed, of placing harness racing on the highest possible plane; to prevent and detect fraud, and to work in harmony with the National and American Trotting Associations.
TOKIO, May 10. -- The sole object of the Japanese foreign loan is to secure the gold currency system and maintain, the convertibility of notes.

The Green-Baer syndicate has sold to Gottlieb M. Karpas four and a half lots at the southwest corner of Macomb's Dam Road and One Hundred and Fifty-first Street. Mr. Karpas will improve the property. The adjoining lots sold by the syndicate a few weeks ago are now being improved with six-story apartment houses.
In the article in this morning's TIMES with reference to the so-called Jerome bill I am referred to as follows:

Stocks gained somewhat in activity and lost much in tone yesterday. Advances were few and fractional. Declines were numerous and larger. The decline in Corn Products preferred is surprising. As anybody who reads its last report perceives it has discovered how to do business without expenses, which is about as near possessing the philosopher's stone as modern mortals may come.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 10. -- In regard to the labor troubles on the New Haven Road President Mellen said to-day:

Herr BEBEL continues to fulfill, in an entertaining manner, his destiny as the "awful child" of the Reichstag, who insists upon blurting out whatever the Government most wishes not to be blurted. Doubtless the Kaiser's telegram of condolence to the Czar upon the sinking of the Petropavlovsk was needlessly effusive.

Our attention has been drawn to a leading article in your issue of March 25, headed "Scotch Highball," which generalizes on the subject of Scotch whisky, and has for its foundation an article in The London Times by a revenue official and subsequent correspondence, which took place some time ago.

Mrs. Jennie Louise Woodend testified yesterday in the involuntary bankruptcy hearing against her husband, Dr. W.E. Woodend. Beautifully gowned, entirely self-possessed, and answering the questions propounded by Receiver Gruber with thorough frankness, she made a favorable impression upon the somewhat eager crowd of spectators gathered for the occasion.

The police of this city, of Albany, Buffalo, and St. Louis have been asked to look for Aloysius MeGrath, th9 ten-year-old son of John MeGrath, the proprietor of several blacksmith's shops in the city, who lives at 217 West One Hundred and Twentyfourth Street.

The stock market yesterday was extremely dull until 2 o'clock, and then, without specific reason, the list developed considerable activity. The trading up to 2 o'clock amounted to only 70,000 shares, but in the last hour more business was done than all the rest of the day, so that the total was brought up to 153,279 shares.

I believe the entire community should feel deeply grateful to Mr. Edwin Bedell of 1,817 Clinton Avenue, city, for the course he has taken in the matter of the brutal hazing of his son by the rowdies of St. Stephen's College. It is time that something be done to effectively abolish this foul, degrading, brutal, and brutalizing, morally and physically injurious practice of hazing.
PARIS, May 10. -- A dispatch from St. Petersburg says:

TOKIO, May 10. -- It appears that the capture of Feng-Wang-Cheng was effected not by the troops which fought at the Yalu, but by a mixed brigade under Major Gen. Sasaki, which, marching eastward on April 30, crossed the Yalu at Chang-Seng and moved on Feng-Wang-Cheng by a mountain road.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 10. -- Addresses from fraternal delegates was the order today at the Methodist General Conference. Bishop J.H. Vincent of Zurich, Switzerland, presided. The addresses were made by the Rev. Waddy Moss, D.D., of Didsbury College, Manchester, England; the Rev. William Didson, D.D., Canada; the Rev. Charles H. Crookshanks, M.A., Ireland; the Rev. J.C. Kilgo, D.D., Methodist Episcopal Church, South, President of Durham College.
The Charity Organization Society appeals for assistance in the following cases of need;

The lacrosse team of the Crescent Athletic Club defeated the Hobart College twelve by the score of 9 to 4 at the Crescent grounds at Bay Ridge yesterday afternoon. The first goal was scored by Hardy for the Crescents less than a minute after play began, and was quickly followed by a point for Hobart, scored by Giltrap, which tied the score.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 10. -- Lieut. Gen. Sakharoff, commander of the First Siberian Army Corps, in a telegram to the General Staff dated May 8, says that the Japanese having occupied Feng-Wang-Chang, are remaining there and are making reconnoissances of the main road to Liao-Yang and both flanks of the road.

Under the order issued by the President on Monday the Isthmian Canal Commission has power: 1. To make laws for the government of the canal strip, and to alter or annul the present laws in force within that territory. 2. To enforce the laws it enacts. 3. To appoint Judges.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Returns to the chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture made up to May 1 show the area under Winter wheat in cultivation on that date to have been about 27,083,500 acres. This is 4,932,700 acres, or 15.4 per cent., less than the area sown last fall, and 5,427,000 acres, or 16.7 per cent. less than the area of Winter wheat harvested last year.
PARIS, May 10. -- Some comments by Lieut. Col. Rousset indicate the difficulty experienced by the devoted French admirers of Russia in appreciating the strategy of Kuropatkin.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 10. --There was much rejoicing at the Hotel Rider this evening because the American player, Marshall, was leading in the international chess masters' tournament at the conclusion of the tenth round played to-day.

Tenpenny nails and dogs that bark are very much in demand in Elmhurst, L.I. An enterprising burglar or burglars, who lacked insight into the value of things, entered seven houses or more on Monday night and secured a small amount of booty. The police seem to think that the burglar is one of the handy men of the place, but those who were robbed are of the impression that the housebreaker wears petticoats.
