Both of the leaders in the National and American Leagues were beaten yesterday, the New York Nationals by 14 to 1 at St. Louis, and the Boston Americans by 2 to 1 at the hands of the Greater New Yorks. It was the worst defeat of the season for McGraw's men, and the second time that Mathewson was compelled to retire from the game.
With the prestige of a private interview with the Czar fresh upon him, Mr. HENRY NORMAN writes to The London Times:

BERLIN, May 10. -- Die Post publishes a news agency dispatch from St. Petersburg which says that Gen. Schwedoff lost over $500,000 through speculation in stocks, and took the money from the Red Cross Treasury.

The wreck of the Washington fast freight train at Port Chester early yesterday morning is a puzzle that the officials of the New York. New Haven and Hartford Railroad are unable to solve. The train was running at the rate of sixty miles an hour when it took the switch at the stone bridge spanning the little stream called the Bynam River, and plunged over an embankment seventy feet to a swamp below.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 10. -- After sustaining two defeats at the hands of the New Yorks, few of the spectators at the last game of the series between the two teams to-day expected such a result as was recorded. Even with Mathewson as pitcher, St. Louis was the only team in the game from star to finish, and when play stopped the score was 14 to 1 in favor of the local players.

The operating officials of the Manhattan Division of the Interborough Railway Company were examined by the State Railroad Commission yesterday as to the causes that led to the fatal collision on the Third Avenue line at Fifty-sixth Street Monday afternoon. The full commission, consisting of Col. George W. Dunn, Capt. James M. Dickey, and Frank M. Baker, were present at the hearing in the Whitehall Building.

ALBANY, May 10 -- Republican legislators who have been in conference with Gov. Odell on the appropriation bills are displeased over the manner in which the Governor has used the pruning knife on the Supply bill. They say that the items cut out will aggregate over $2,000,000, the largest sums being $345,000 from the appropriation for Fiscal Supervisor Bender and $235,000 from that for Excise Commissioner Cullinan, the greatest sum being for excise rebates.

In a drizzling shower and under mechanical difficulties that would have discouraged a less enthusiastic automobilist, Walter Christie made a road trial of his machine yesterday that he has entered for the Gordon Bennett international race. The test was made over a five-mile straight-away on the old Merrick Road between Merrick and Westbury, and the only member of the Racing Committee of the Automobile Club of America present was George Isham Scott.

ST. LOUIS, May 10. -- Since her arrival in St. Louis Miss Helen Gould has been constantly attended by a strong hired bodyguard, whose duty is to protect her from annoyance, principally photographic snapshots and promoters' propositions.
Nearly 100 members of the National Association of Stove Manufacturers met yesterday in their annual convention in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mrs. Rosa Czabo of 260 West Forty-third Street desires to know if her late husband, Bila Czabo, who was a son of Count Czabo, the physician of Emperor Franz Josef of Austria, left money in any of the city's banks.
MANILA, May 11. -- Lieut. Winfield Harper and thirty-nine men of Company F of the Seventeenth United States Infantry were caught on May 8 in an ambush by several hundred Moros.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The President's Summer plans have been decided upon and were announced from the White House today. He will remain in Washington until about July 1, when he will go to Oyster Bay and remain there to receive official notification of his nomination as the Republican candidate for President.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- The eighth annual convention of the National Cotton Manufacturers' Association opened here today. President Heath's annual address was a discussion of the market and the prospect for the cotton industry for the coming year. Mr. Heath said that the convention met at a time when there was essentially a crisis in cotton manufacturing because of the unprecedented high price of the raw material.
SHERMAN, Texas, May 11. -- A jury here to-day gave Louis James, the actor, a judgment for $10,000 against the Oriental Hotel Association of Dallas, Texas, for libel.

"Jimmie" Mara, Jr., weight seventy pounds, represented the Mara family in the absence of his father, the steeplechase jockey, who is laid up with a broken collar bone, and rode in the fourth race at Morris Park yesterday. The junior Mara was on the last chance outsider in the race, but he refused to be last and rode out his mount. Communicant, in order to beat two other horses.

It seems that the report of the Japanese landing on the western coast of the Liao-Tung Peninsula was at least premature. It is likely also that the number landed at Pitsewo, on the east coast, was much exaggerated in the reports. It would have been quite safe for even a small Japanese party to effect this latter landing after the Russian army had abandoned the line of the Yalu for that of the railroad.

The occurrence on the thirteenth day of the month of two dire calamities -- one to the Russian battleship Petropavlovsk and the other to our own Missouri -- revives memories of other superstitions among sailors. Prominent among these is the belief that misfortune to a vessel is sure to be followed by ill-luck to all other vessels bearing the same name.

PARIS, May 11. -- I hear from a trustworthy source that the conditions of the new Russian loan of $160,000,000 were signed yesterday at St. Petersburg by the Russian Government and the delegates of the Parisian banks. The price at which the Russian Treasury bills securing the loan are to be issued to these banks is, I am told, definitely fixed at 94 1/2.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 11. -- Practically no business was transacted by the Methodist General Conference to-day, though there were many sharp passages at arms between the parliamentary experts which somewhat enlivened an otherwise dull and featureless session.

After reading many compliments to your paper, I always remember what respect I and my college friends had to that paper yet in Russia. As my parents emigrated here when I was in 6th class of college, they left me in Russia for three years. I graduated last Spring and came here in order to continue my education as an engineer.
The inclosed letter is in the nature of a volunteer reporter's interview with a Central Park policeman. Will you publish it?

When the steamship Rotterdam arrived at her pier in Hoboken yesterday there was a great scurrying about the ship by all of the stewards and the crew to find the sixty-four midgets that were aboard. They were bound for Coney Island, where they will take part in one of the shows to be presented this Summer.

Schneider Herter have purchased through Francis B. Robert the plot, 70 by 104, on the south side of Seventy-ninth Street, 100 feet west of West End Avenue, upon which they will erect immediately a seven-story apartment house.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 11. -- Lieut. Gen. Sakharoff sent a dispatch to the General Staff to-day communicating a report of Lieut. Gen. Zassalitch, who had been reported killed, dated May 11, as follows:

BOSTON, May 11. -- Justice Gaynor of Brooklyn, in an address on "Trusts," delivered before the Jurisprudence Section of the American Social Science Association, this evening, declared that favoritism in freight rater on the public highways was "the greatest crime of our day."
ST. PETERSBURG, May 11. -- Gen. Kuropatkin has telegraphed to the Emperor that a train loaded with war material from Liao-Yang has arrived at Port Arthur.

Transactions in the stock market yesterday were nearly double those of the previous day, the increase being due very largely to the greater activity of Steel preferred and one or two other issues, including Amalgamated Copper. The day's movements in prices were irregular both in their course during the session and in the final results.

Vincenzo Candido, who is being tried for the murder of Giuseppe Bivacque last March, came into the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning pale and trembling with fear because he had understood his counsel, Stephen J. O'Hare, to say that he must die in the electric chair. Lawyer O'Hare had said just before the adjournment of the court on the previous day:
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 11. -- Elliot Danforth authorized this statement to-day:

WHITE PLAINS, May 11. -- John Donnelly, a locomotive engineer of Philadelphia, was found dead in a brook in the northern part of Westchester County to-day. There was a deep cut over the right eye and a bruise on the face.

LIAO-YANG, May 11. -- Among the wounded from the battle of the Yalu who arrived here to-day was Father Stephen Takerbackoffsky, the priest who led the charge of the Eleventh Regiment at the battle of Kiu-Lien-Cheng.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 11. -- The New York Central Railroad's big reduction of men in its maintenance of way and motive power departments is thus explained by Assistant Superintendent Smith:

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 11. -- No regular round in the International Chess Masters' Tournament was played to-day, but only games left unfinished from previous rounds were disposed of. There were five such games.

As an immediate political effect of Commissioner Oakley's removal of Thomas F. Byrnes, Deputy Commissioner of Water Supply for Brooklyn, there was a decided growth yesterday in the boom of Controller Edward M. Grout for Governor.

-- A curious question as to the proper allotment of honors due to a nationality has been raised in London by a claim made in print there by the Agent General of New Brunswick for recognition of "the gallant rescue by British seamen" belonging to the steamship Cairnisla of the crew of the Mary A. Troop.

BRISTOL, Tenn., May 11. -- "He came to his death by the accidental discharge of his own pistol" is the verdict of the Coroner's jury, which for nearly two days has been investigating the circumstances surrounding the death of Edward L. Wentz, the young mine owner, whose body was discovered on a spur of Black Mountain last Sunday.

According to Dr. Walter Bensel, Sanitary Superintendent of this borough, a case of smallpox developed Monday among the chorus of "Wang" at the Lyric Theatre. The man who was taken ill is named Wahle, and he is now in the Kingston Avenue Hospital, in Brooklyn All the "Wang" company have been vaccinated, and the Lyric Theatre has been thoroughly fumigated.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- German measles and a bull have retarded the advance of the Great Omaha day school as a seat of learning. The school is in Northern Kansas and its pupils are Indian boys and girls of the Kickapoo tribe. There was a time when the school had a large attendance and was very prosperous.

The examination to ascertain the cause of the fatal accident on the Third Avenue elevated Monday was resumed before the Railroad Commission yesterday afternoon. Col. Dunn, the Chairman, was not present. Charles A. Gardiner appeared for the railroad.

GYANG-TSE, May 9. -- All yesterday morning there was firing from Jong, but without result except that one mission follower had his hipbone smashed by a jingal bullet and died at night. Our mounted infantry went out and drove in the Tibetan horsemen, inflicting a small loss.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 11. -- A broad, well-paved highway across the continent is foreseen by Augustus Post of New York, President of the American Automobile Association. At a luncheon given in his honor to-day by John Farson at the Chicago Automobile Club he said: "The automobile will do what the bicycle failed to accomplish.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 11. -- Dr. Wolfgang Goetz of Hoboken, who says he has the United States copyright of the famous Passion Play of Oberammergau, has applied to the Asbury Park Board of Trade, through Albert Robbins of this city, for a permit to give the play for one year, three performances a week, in Asbury Park. This programme, the doctor said, would result in a profit of $3,130,000 to the stockholders.

LONDON, May 11. -- A sensational libel suit brought by the well-known racehorse owner, R.S. Sievier, against Sir James Duke, also well known on the turf, was concluded to-day with a verdict for Sir James. Sievier charged the latter with calling him a thief, a card sharper, and a murderer, and with stating that Sievier caused his famous mare Sceptre to be pulled in the Derby.

The adoption by the Reichstag at Berlin of a resolution asking the Government to introduce a bill revising the military penal code so as to reduce to a minimum the punishment to which enlisted men who are convicted of violence toward their superiors in rank are liable is an attempt to reform "wrong end foremost" the abuses of the military system in Germany.

Should you wish to strengthen your case as to the authenticity of the bust of Shakespeare, and the unreliability of the recently discovered Dugdale print of it, by a striking proof of the reckless inaccuracy of English engravers, you will find all the proof in my study of the picture of Fingal's Cave.
LONDON, May 11. -- The Times's military correspondent writes:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11. -- M. Anatole Leroy-Beaulieu of Paris delivered today at Sanders Theatre the eighth lecture in his series upon Christianity and Democracy. The subject was "Le Christianisme et le Socialisme." M. Beaulieu asked:
I have read with great interest your editorials on the "open shop"; also President Mellen's remarks to his men advising them to join the unions to give an element of conservatism.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 12, (3:35 A.M.) -- Impending events of great importance to the military situation in Manchuria are foreshadowed in official dispatches given out late to-night by the War Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 11. -- Dr. W.H. Richardson performed an operation to-day on Secretary Taft for the removal of a growth resulting from tonsilitis. The knife was used on the Secretary's nose, and the pain was acute, resulting in violent inflammation.
I have been a member of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals for years, and am very proud of it and its accomplishments.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 11. -- There were scenes of martial splendor on the Champ de Mars to-day when Emperor Nicholas held his annual review of the detachment of all troops in the military district of St. Petersburg, numbering 40,000 men.

The big North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm II. arrived here yesterday from Bremen, twenty-four hours behind her running time after a voyage in which the elements exhausted their repertoire. There were days when not a ripple disturbed the surface of the sea, and there were others which the steamship spent scaling great rolling seas.

DANBURY, Conn., May 11. -- There are forty people in Danbury who would like exceedingly well to know who D. Preston Atwood of Bridgeport is. Atwood is the most-talked-of man in Danbury to-day, as he has floated a get-rich-quick scheme that appears to go all the rest of the ventures of that sort several better, and the forty Danbury men are the victims.

That wheat markets should weaken upon the worst crop news at this season in many years is what ought to have been expected, but was not by many. The simple-minded view is that the smaller the supply the higher the price. But the sophisticated trade rushed to sell in such force to take their profits upon the news which they had foreseen that the liquidation surpassed the buying and prices yielded.

NYACK, N.Y., May 11. -- Thomas Abrams, who came to Nyack to-day for Hugh Baxter to ascertain whether the body of the man found at the foot of Hook Mountain Sunday evening was that of Henry Baxter Kingsley, a wealthy resident of Rutland, Vt., who disappeared from Westchester County last November, went away convinced that the dead man was not the one whom he was seeking.

CHICAGO, May 11. -- Sentiment collected by The Tribune by wire to-night from Republicans in over thirty States regarding the availability of Representative Hitt for second place on the Nation ticket this year appears to be quite favorable to the Congressman.

Another trial test will be made of the three American automobiles entered for the Gordon Bennett international race. This was decided upon yesterday at the Automobile Club of America after the Board of Governors had received the report of the Racing Committee regarding the previous trials of the Winton Bullet, the Mooers, and the Christie cars.

First of the two-year-olds of the present season to make claim to merit out of the ordinary with the convincing argument of winning. Song and Wine, at the Morris Park race course yesterday verified the J result of the Juvenile Stakes, run a week a ago, by winning the Laureate Stakes in a style that left no chance for dispute as to his superiority.
Chapter IX of the Penal Code relates to gaming. Section 342 of the Code, which is contained in this chapter, as amended by the Dowling act just signed by the Governor, reads as follows:

PARS, May 11. -- United States Consul General Gowdy recently received a letter from an American girl saying that she was locked up in a provincial jail without any charge having been made against her. The Consul General sent a representative to the jail and secured the girl's release and return to Paris. He then cabled to her parents, residing at Decatur, Ga., requesting funds for her return to America.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, May 11. -- The Chilean cruisers Esmeralda and Chacabuco have been definitely sold to Charles R. Flint of New York. The contract price is $5,150,000. Congress will assemble to approve the sale.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 11. -- Mrs. Elmina Springer of Chicago formally was "launched" this afternoon as a candidate for Trustee of the University of Illinois. It required two nominating speeches and twenty-three seconding speeches, but she now is proudly sailing along as "the only indorsed candidate" for an office open to women.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 11. -- The action of the new Republican State Central Committee this afternoon in electing Speaker Michael Kenealy to be Chairman means that Samuel Fessenden, after twenty years of persistent dogged fighting, is in control of the State machine, and will conduct the campaign this Fall.

All the Western clubs in the National and American Leagues, with the exception of St. Louis of the National League, were beaten yesterday by Eastern teams. McGraw's men scored a well-earned victory in their first meeting with the Cincinnati team. Brooklyn defeated the champions at Pittsburg, Philadelphia made the only run in the game with Chicago, while at St. Louis the Boston team scored one run less than the local nine.

Will the open shop destroy the trades union? That it will is the opinion of most organs of the trades unionists that have expressed themselves. In the current number of The Independent WILLIAM ENGLISH WALLING makes the following emphatic statement:

One Western Union Director declared yesterday with outspoken frankness and all the emphasis of a firm conviction that he knew of the relations between the company and the poolrooms, and that he was in thorough accord with the policy at present pursued by the company. He concluded, however, by asking that his name be kept out of print.

A topographical map of the levee system of Louisiana is a feature of the State of Louisiana's exhibit in the Palace of Liberal Arts. It shows accurately the levees along the Mississippi River from Arkansas to the river's mouth. The map was modeled by Miss Jenny Wilde of New Orleans. From 1865 to date $25,000,000 has been expended on this system. The map is 25 feet long.

It is by no means certain that the bill for the regulation of alien immigration into England which has on the whole been favorably treated in the House of Commons will become law without amendment. The feature which will undoubtedly give rise to the greatest opposition is the authority given to the Home Secretary to expel aliens under certain conditions, of which the Home Office is practically the judge.

Prof. G.E. DAWSON of the Hartford School of Religious Pedagogy has some good ideas as to what a man should know to qualify him to preach acceptably and arrest the tendency to organic and psychic degeneration in men and women who attend church. He says:

NEWARK, N.J., May 11. -- Dr. J.A. Boice of St. Agnes's Hospital, Baltimore, is in St. Michael's Hospital, where he was taken this afternoon suffering from what the physicians say is poison. He was found unconscious on a Pennsylvania Railroad train due here from Jersey City at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

Mayor McClellan attempted yesterday for a second time at a public hearing to get rid of the legislative bill providing for the restoration of the salaries of fifty or more veterans in the city's service, but instead of getting it off his hands, he found new complications.

The Port Morris Land and Improvement Company has sold, through Douglas Robinson, Charles S. Brown Co., to the Central Union Gas Company the block bounded by Locust and Walnut Avenues. One Hundred and Thirty-sixth and One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Streets, 203 by 350, containing about twenty-eight lots.

George C. Clausen, ex-Commissioner of Parks, has not yet entirely recovered from the shock he experienced last Monday when he saw the coach Pioneer, which he had engaged to carry a party of friends to Ardsley, disappearing up Fifth Avenue with Reginald W. Rives on the box where he had planned to sit.
LONDON, May 12. -- Rates for money temporarily hardened in the market to-day, owing to the large oversubscribing of the Japanese loan and Stock Exchange pay day.

The Philadelphia News Bureau sends out a circular of "information" as to the position of the United States Steel Corporation in view of the dissolution of the ore pool, which begins with the following startling statements:

DALLAS, Texas, May 12. -- There was a sensational shooting affray on the eastbound Texas and Pacific train near Texarkana to-day between the Rev. J.B. Cranfill and the Rev. S.A. Hayden, both of Dallas.

Purity of foods was the subject of discussion at a meeting held yesterday in the Hotel Wolcott by the Committee on Food Standards, which was appointed by the Secretary of Agriculture. There were present Prof. William Frear, Chairman; Dr. H.W. Wiley, Dr. E.H. Jenkins, Dr. M.A. Scovell, and Prof. H.A. Weber.

BOONTON, N.J., May 12. -- Common Council meetings in this city may enter into serious competition with traveling vaudeville troupes if the Jefferson-Lincoln Party seats its candidates, whose election is claimed by William T. Gardner, leader of the movement.

Broadway, in the vicinity of Tenth Street, was full of excitement during the early hours of yesterday morning, when, as a rule, the thoroughfare is deserted save for an occasional watchman or a blazing trolley car that whizzes through the circumambient darkness of the canon beginning at Grace Church.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 12. -- The most interesting Democratic State Convention since 1892, when Cleveland and Isaac P. Gray contested for the control of the Indiana delegation to the National Convention, was held to-day.

Western baseball teams of the National and American Leagues fared better in games with the Eastern nines yesterday than on the previous day, for, instead of having only one victory out of eight chances, they were triumphant throughout the National League circuit, and won twice in the American League.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The long-drawn-out case against Postmaster Van Cott of the New York Post Office has at last been settled. The President to-day announced from the White House the final action. Richard Van Cott, the son of the Postmaster, is to be removed at once. Postmaster Van Cott will be allowed to serve out his term.

The ensuing party conventions should insert in their platforms one plank in favor of just and equal taxation. Another plank should be inserted in favor of equal protection to all industries. A few are not protected at present. Among them are ministers, doctors, lawyers, masons, carpenters, country blacksmiths, house painters, glaziers, stevedores, clerks and salesmen, farmers and servant girls, nurses and cotton planters, and consumers who constitute the population.

Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould have begun a thirty-thousand-dollar breach of contract suit against Abner J. Haydel, the architect of their magnificent Long Island home. Castlegould, one of the famous private residences of America. The troubles incidental to the suit are said to be many, and in the countersuit Mr. Haydel is expected to institute unusual developments are looked for.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 13. -- Further progress of the Japanese in Southern Manchuria is reported in the official dispatches given out last night. The position of the division which is following the direct road to Hai-Cheng has not yet been disclosed.

LIAO-YANG, May 12. -- The first distribution was made to-day of Crosses of the Order of St. George to the men of the Eleventh and Twelfth Regiments for bravery displayed at the battle of Kiu-Lien-Cheng. The following order of the day was read to the soldiers:
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 12. -- With the Yates-Lowden men in control of the temporary organization, the Republican State Convention met here to-day.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Society experienced a new sensation to-day when it heard that Harry M. Higginbotham, the son of H.N. Higginbotham, had gone to Aurora with Miss Natalie Blair, daughter of Henry A. Blair, and that the couple had been married there and returned for the parental blessing.

LONDON, May 12. -- The eliminating tests on the Isle of Man to decide which cars will represent Great Britain in the James Gordon Bennett International Automobile Cup race ended to-day with a serious accident. During the final speed trials a car driven by Clifford Earp, one of the prominent competitors, ran into a wall and was completely smashed.

SEOUL, May 12. -- An American miner who left An-ju on May 8 has arrived here and reports that a force of 2,900 Russians recently spent the night at Unsan. He says also that large bodies of Russian troops were reported to be in that vicinity. Reports of fighting were received here today, but they lack confirmation.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 12. -- A telegram received by the General Staff from Gen. Karkevitch says:
LONDON, May 12. -- The Times publishes the following letter from Israel Zangwill to the editor:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 12. -- Capt. Cannon of the Detective Department has gone to New York to identify the negro arrested there. The burglaries in the East Side of Providence were supposed to be the work of two negroes. At least four houses were entered. One hundred or more pieces of jewelry were taken.

The body of little Josie McCahill, the missing girl who was believed to have been kidnapped, was found last night tightly wedged in a chimney of a house adjoining her home at 1,839 Third Avenue. Her relatives believe that she was murdered. The police are satisfied that her death was due to an accident.

Nothing has as yet so strongly attested the Russian sense of the desperation of the Russian position at Port Arthur as the Russia destruction of Dalny. That "fiat city" is the "business end" of the great enterprise of which Port Arthur is the military end. Dalny is, for commercial purposes, the "ice-free port" which Russia has so long been seeking on the Pacific.

Quick work by Detective Sergeants Boyle and Charlton of Police Headquarters enabled them yesterday afternoon to arrest a negro who is believed to be "the masked burglar of Providence." That hitherto mysterious robber has stolen property worth thousands of dollars from the wealthy homes of the Rhode Island city.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Mayor Harrison has given up his fight for a place on the Democratic National Committee. He announced to-day that Hearst and Hopkins could have the State Convention to themselves and that he would not even attend the gathering. The Mayor will be satisfied with a free hand in the County Convention.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 12. -- The Cincinnati team won the second game of the series to-day by 13 to 7. It was a poorly played contest. The New Yorkers fielded poorly, but not any worse than their opponents, and the game was lost simply because Mathewson could not keep the home men from hitting the ball.

-- A notable incident of an otherwise uninteresting murder trial now going on in this city followed an attempt on Wednesday by the prosecuting attorney to utilize a means of communication that is considered, outside of courtrooms, perfectly satisfactory for almost every purpose, including many of the greatest importance.

A dozen oil paintings by Mr. Frank De Haven will be shown until May 17 at the Kraushaar Galleries, 260 Fifth Avenue. His pictures are familiar to those who visit the exhibitions of the Academy and Society; they are noted generally for a rich coloration and a thick impasto, with a tendency to low-toned, shadowy land and woodscapes.

Charles Hawtrey is to enter vaudeville. He signed a contract yesterday to appear at two of the Proctor houses next week in a one-act comedy by Mrs. Hugh Bell, entitled "Time Is Money." The sketch requires a cast of only three players and lasts only thirty minutes.

I wish to second the motion of your correspondent, "Publico," who suggests that the street-car lines be watered by the companies controlling them. A woman can travel to the Gulf of Mexico by rail with less annoyance from dust than she experiences in going about in the New York City street cars a few hours.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 12. -- The Directors of the National Bank of North America of this city voted to-day to recommend to the stockholders that the institution be placed in liquidation. It is understood that two of the Directors will have places upon the Directorate of the Union Trust Company and that the latter bank will conduct the liquidation.
DENVER, Col., May 12. -- Justice Hynd to-day discharged William D. Haywood, Secretary of the Western Federation of Miners, charged with desecration of the flag.

Both a fire engine and its tender ran over Dr. Bernard Mackay, a wealthy retired physician, at Twenty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue last night, killing him almost instantly. Many men and women, who were sitting on stoops or walking near by, saw the accident. Dr. Mackay's wife and daughter, both of whom returned from Palm Beach on Wednesday, were at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 12. -- Pittsburg shut out Brooklyn to-day in a game marked by heavy batting, and yet it was not so strong when it is considered that but two hits netted runs. Beaumont's home run and Phelps's single, the latter aided by Sheckard's error, netted three runs for Pittsburg, Phillippe, for Pittsburg, struck out nine men, said to be the season's record, and he did not give a base on balls.

Unlike the first meeting on Wednesday, which was one of the most interesting baseball contests played on any local diamond this season, the game between the Greater New York and Cleveland team at American League Park yesterday soon resolved itself into a one-sided contest, with all the advantage in favor of Cleveland.

It was reported yesterday that Mrs. Hetty Green had given away $550,000. It was said that $500,000 had been given to the Nurses' Home, opposite the Presbyterian Hospital, and $50,000 had been set apart for the establishment on the east side of a nurses' settlement.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., May 12. -- Jacob A. Riis, author and friend of President Roosevelt, was surprised last night after his lecture to be told by Alderman John Pfeiffer that if he would present his bill he would be paid for two days' work which he claimed to have performed thirty-five years ago while employed here in a clay bank.

ALBANY, May 12. -- Gov. Odell has vetoed the Law's Delays bill providing for Supreme Court trial Commissioners. He bases his decision upon a strong opinion by Attorney General Cunneen, declaring the bill absolutely unconstitutional.

PARIS, May 12. -- It is announced here that Cardinal Satolli is going to the United States on a special mission. The ostensible object of the voyage is to visit the St. Louis Exposition, but it is said that Satolli will institute an inquiry into the present condition of Roman Catholicism in the United States, as serious difficulties have arisen between Apostolic Delegate Falconio and a majority of the American Bishops.

Jesse Lewisohn was served with a subpoena yesterday at the Morris Park Race track. The paper directed him to appear on Monday before Justice Wyatt of the Court of Special Sessions in a "John Doe" proceeding. When the server found him he was with Miss Lillian Russell.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 12. -- Viceroy Alexieff has telegraphed to the Czar announcing that the Russians have blown up the docks and piers at Port Dalny, Liao-Tung Peninsula, presumably to render more difficult a Japanese landing at that point.

I think THE TIMES takes a very foolish stand in asking Judge Parker to resign his position of Chief Justice so that he may state his views on current political questions. I hope the Judge will not do anything of the kind. If it is really necessary he can write a letter to some friend or give an authorized interview, expressing his opinions on the principal issues of the day.

Horses engaged to run for the Withers Stakes, at one mile, on Saturday at the Morris Park meeting, had their final trials for the big event yesterday. From the gallops made, it looks now as if not more than half a dozen horses will start, though it is possible that owners of horses may take chances and increase the size of the field.

CHICAGO, May 12. -- Influenced by an elo quent sermon, Frederick Beach, once a wellknown society man of this elty has been led to a confession of embezzlement and is now under arrest awaiting trial. In addition to embezzlement charges he may also be tried on a charge of bigamy. Beach formerly held a position of confidence In a Chicago mercantile house.

ALBANY, May 12. -- Gov. Odell to-day vetoed the Reason East River Gas Company bill, filing with his veto a memorandum characterized by vigorous denunciation of the bill itself and sharp criticism of Mayor McClellan, who approved it. Of the Mayor's action he says:

As an offset to the proposition of the Metropolitan interests to give free transfers between their surface lines and the next rapid transit subway, if built by the Metropolitan, the Interborough Rapid Transit Company has formed a combination with the Schmidt Gallatin moving platform syndicate to interchange transfers from the elevated or subway lines to a platform subway under Thirty-fourth Street.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 12. -- Emperor Nicholas II, is arranging to go to Kharkoff on May 23 to bid farewell to the Tenth Army Corps upon its departure for the Far East.

GYANG-TSE, May 12. -- British troops made a reconnoissance in force yesterday, Col. Brander taking the larger part of the garrison to flank the hills behind and to the east. The Jong Monastery on the mountain side was visited because it had harbored the enemy's horsemen two days ago, but was found to be merely inhabited by aged monks from Gompa, and therefore left unharmed.

I read with a good deal of interest your clever and thoughtful editorial entitled "The Joy of Work." All labor which tends to call forth the best faculties a man possesses, mental and physical, while it exercises his skill and judgment, ought to be joyful, if not prolonged to the verge of exhaustion.

It was, announced after the meeting of the Governors of the Consolidated Exchange yesterday that the Board had voted a reduction in the membership from 1,460 to about 1,400. To that end the Governors have adopted a plan whereby the Exchange may buy in such seats as it sees fit.

THE TIMES loses no opportunity of furnishing an estimate of the losses of labor in strikes, but I have not seen any estimate of the losses incurred by labor from inflated securities, the padded payroll, corrupt legislation, extortion, habitual violations of law practiced by captains of industry and knights of the railroad. Labor has to pay all, as well its own shortcomings as the crimes of others.
The Directors of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway, at a meeting held here yesterday, re-elected all the old officers, after hearing the report for the last year.

At a meeting yesterday of stockholders of the New York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company, held in the Mills Building, resolutions protesting against the continuation of the stock voting trust were passed.

President Wilson of Princeton, as the principal speaker at the third annaul banquet of the New York Chapter, American Institute of Bank Clerks, held last night at the Hotel St. Denis, responded to the toast, "Business and Politics," with an urgent plea for statesmanship in banking and business and a college education as a necessary preparation for the banker and business man of the future.
BIRMINGHAM, May 12. -- Joseph Chamberlain made his first speech since his return to England at a meeting of the Liberal Unionist Association here to-night and got a magnificent reception.

It seems that a serious question has arisen in connection with the arising to the height of eighteen stories of the St. Regis Hotel, in a part of Fifth Avenue which has heretofore been regarded as safely reserved for residential uses, at the corner of Fifty-fifth Street, that is to say. The new hotel is conceived and executed on a scale of sumptuosity quite without precedent.

LONDON, May 12. -- Subscriptions to the half of the Japanese loan of $50,000,000 allotted to England closed at 4 P.M. to-day. It was estimated that the loan was oversubscribed twenty times. There was a great rush to subscribe and an enormous number of applications for small amounts.

Though withdrawals cut deep into the programme offered at the Morris Park race course yesterday afternoon, the sport provided in the six races was of a high character, and a crowd of 10,000 visitors departed from the big Westchester course satiated with excitement, in spite of the fact that post favorites and popular choices were beaten in five races.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 12. -- The following statement has been officially communicated to the press:

GOV. ODELL'S veto of the Remsen Gas bill, following Mayor MCCLELLAN'S approval of it, creates an unusual and anomalous condition. The veto privilege of the Chief Executive of the State was in no wise abridged by the charter provision giving the Mayors of cities the right to approve or disapprove of local measures.

The Rev. Mother Mary Baker Eddy has issued an edict against the segregation of the sexes in clubs. Recently there came word from her at Concord, N.H., that her chosen lambs must choose between membership in her flock and identification with any club or association from which either sex was excluded.

WASHINGTON, May 12. -- The convention of Cotton Manufacturers terminated its business to-day and adjourned. At the morning session the time was devoted to speeches. Theodore Price of New York was the principal speaker, his subject being "The Effect of Speculation Through the Exchanges of the World upon Cotton Manufacture."

Organized labor used all its powers of persuasion and appeal during the last session to induce Congress to pass two bills drawn in its interest. It was unsuccessful. The Gompers-Mitchell Anti-Injunction bill never got out of the House Judiciary Committee. Hearings extending over five days were held, and about fifty witnesses were heard.

Over 400 schoolboys will compete in the first championship track and field meeting of the Public Schools Athletic League at the Columbia Oval, William's Bridge, today, and the sports will begin at 10 o'clock in the morning and last all day, except for an intermission between 1 and 2 o'clock. In the forenoon the high school novice events, for which there are 150 entries, will be decided, the order of events being as follows:

Joseph Conrad has already so firmly established himself in the esteem of the discerning that the announcement of a new novel from his pen is the cause of an immense amount of pleasurable expectation -- the more pleasurable because in all his past work there has been such a delightful lack of sameness that one can give no guess beforehand as to just what sort of entertainment the latest will afford.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 13. -- Wonderful pitching by Eddie Poole, formerly cast adrift by Pittsburg, won to-day's game from Pittsburg. The champions were not only shut out, but not one of them reached second base during the game. In the ninth inning blunders by Clark, Leach, and Wagner, allowed Sheckard to score when he might have been thrown out at the plate by fair ball playing, and this lost the game.

PARIS, May 13. -- An official dispatch to the Foreign Office from Constantinople confirms the reports that Turkish troops have burned villages throughout the Sassoun district of Armenia, killing the inhabitants.

It must be owned that the story of Col. YOUNGHUSBAND'S expedition, not at any time glorious, has become very melancholy. There may be one Briton in a million who is able to give some intelligible explanation of what the expedition is about, and some justification for the dispatch of it. But such a Briton has not, that we have been able to find out, made such an explanation either in Parliament or in the press.

BERLIN, May 13. -- By order of the Kaiser, Crown Prince Frederick William has been confined to his quarters for three days for participating in the recent dangerous riding competition on the Berlin race track, when, mounted on an Arabian horse, he outdistanced a dozen brother officers and tied with Capt. von Holzing of the First Uhlans of the Guard, for the Kaiser's Cup, but gallantly renounced all claim to the prize.

THE result of the forty centuries of human experience with ink seems to be the rather disheartening one that dissatisfaction still exists, as always has, as to the constitution of the fluid. Mr. Carvalho's entertaining book contains a vast amount of historical and anecdotical lore about ink, its manufacture and use; from which this lesson always seems to be visible.

E.P. Dutton Co. are about to add to their series of Little Biographies Arthur Christopher Benson's life of "Alfred Tennyson.'' The little volume, Mr. Benson says in his short preface, "is based on admiration and reverent love, and the desire to share with others an inheritance of pure and deep delight." Its object is threefold.

In his book on "James Lawrence, Captain United States Navy," Lieut. Albert Gleaves writes about Lawrence's birth and ancestry, his early years, and his first services. Then comes the account of his services in the war with Tripoli, his service under Preble, and his return to the United States. The following chapters deal with his marriage, and his command of the Wasp, the Argus, and the Hornet.

E.P. Dutton Co. have secured for American publication "An Autumn Tour in Western Persia," by Lady Durand, wife of Sir Mortimer Durand, the British Ambassador at Washington. This is the account of a tour which "greatly" interested Lady Durand and led to her describing it. The journey was taken while Sir Mortimer was British Minister to Persia. The objects of the tour, writes the author, were several:

HOW long may an error of the press remain probably unnoted and certainly unmentioned? In the interesting "Bibliography" contributed by Mr. George B. Ives to the Riverside Press edition of "The Essays of Montaigne," and printed in the third volume, issued this week, is reproduced a title page printed in 1598, but dated MDXCXVIII., that is to say, 1608.

James G. Blaine, son of the late United States Senator Blaine, recovered $3,337.25 in the Supreme Court yesterday in an action which he brought against Thomas Post, stock brokers, alleging that they sold 1,000 shares of Pennsylvania Railroad stock which they had been carrying for him without notifying him or giving him a chance to put up additional margin.

WASHINGTON, May 13. -- Regarding the report that Cardinal Satolli is coming to The United States in connection with a supposed contention between the Vatican and the Roman Catholic Heirarchy of the United States the following statement was made officially to-day from the Apostolic Delegation in this city, of which Mgr. Falconio is the head:

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 13. -- Mayor Allan A. Moss, who is a candidate for re-election; William T. Moss, a prominent attorney and brother of the Mayor, and Robert W. Perkins, one of the managers of the campaign for Samuel R. Buxton, the Mayor's opponent, were arrested this afternoon by Chief of Police Thomas M. Johnson and Sergt. Bryan O'Hara for fighting in the street. They were bailed to appear in police court to-morrow.

" Great Golfers," by George W. Beldam, which is being published by the Macmillan Company, gives through pictures the methods of Harold Hilton, J.H. Taylor, James Braid, Alexander Herd, and Harry Vardon and a number of amateur champions. There are 268 illustrations in all, from photographs taken at one-one-thousandth part of a second, while the players were taking strokes.
BRISTOL, Va., May 13. -- It appears tonight that E.L. Wentz left a will executed only a few days previous to his death.

It was the purchase of a six-dollar hat at a Fifth Avenue store and the tender of a check for that amount which was later marked "N.G." by the cashier of the Second National Bank that proved the undoing of a prepossessing young woman who gave her name to the police as Miss May Rawlins of New Rochelle.

At Tammany Hall yesterday it was said that the anti-McCarronites in Brooklyn now had ten of the twenty-one district leaders with them, and that as soon as they secured the additional member necessary to give them a majority, a meeting of the eleven would be called an action taken which would demonstrate that McCarren's leadership was discredited, so far as the district leaders are concerned.

The fact that no general strike of the truck drivers has yet been declared apparently is not a safeguard to any non-union drivers, judging from the experience yesterday of John Irving, a driver for Jackson Brothers, 168 Third-Street, members of the Truck Owners' Association.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 13. -- "Gone for the day" is the sign which has been hanging for two weeks in the window of Leopold Bauer's large wholesale wine, liquor, tea, and coffee store, which covers nearly half a block at West Lincoln and South Twelfth Avenues, in this city. The creditors of the concern are coming to Mount Vernon in droves, and Chief Foley has been asked to make an investigation in their behalf.

The Fleming H. Revell Company has acquired the American rights to the new book by Sir Robert Anderson, K.C.B., LL. D., author of "The Bible and Modern Criticism," "Daniel in the Critics' Den," "The Silence of God," , entitled "Pseudo-Criticism; or, the Higher Criticism and Its Counterfeit."

WE are accustomed to speak of the nineteenth century as following, not as forming, a great letter-writing period, but when we think at random of George Eliot, the Brownings, the Carlyles, John Addington Symonds. Robert Louis Stevenson, J.R Green, Edward Fitz Gerald, we cannot say that the charming talent had become extinct before the rise of the present generation.

Only one game was played in the National League yesterday, Brooklyn shutting out Pittsburg by a score of two to nothing. The schedule evidently was so arranged as to give an opportunity to the Eastern clubs to play on Sunday in the West. All the American League Clubs were engaged and Chicago was the only Western Club to win.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 13. -- Emperor Nicholas has received the following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin:

KATHARINE HOLLAND BROWN is preparing for Doubleday, Page Co. her romance of the Icarian settlement on the Mississippi, entitled "Diane." This is the story of Pere Cabet, the stern, visionary old Frenchman, and his colony of Icaria at the abandoned Mormon settlement near Nauvoo.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 13. -- After balloting and battling ineffectually from early morning, the Republican State Convention was forced to take a recess to-night without nominating a candidate for Governor. Rioting and bitterness characterized the entire day's proceedings, and there is no sign of a break in the dead-lock.

The second rear-end collision within a week occurred on the Third Avenue elevated railway yesterday at the Ninety-ninth Street station, when two north-bound trains came together with a crash, injuring eight passengers and badly wrecking two cars.

Two high themes there are of the tragedy of sinning lovers. In the one the outraged husband slays both the sinners, sternly for honor's sake, yet looks kindly on the dead; in the other, death comes to the doomed two otherwise, by the hand of fate, when the due avenger, knowing the power of the love passion over youth, knowing himself no longer young, pities and would have forgiven.

THE last of the seventeen volumes of the "New International Encyclopaedia" has been issued by Messrs. Dodd, Mead Co. Begun only eighteen months or so ago, the set has been published at the rate of a volume a month almost as regularly as a magazine.

With the return yesterday of Charles M. Schwab, former President of the United States Steel Corporation, from six weeks5 trip to the Pacific Coast, it was announced that his recent resignation from the Finance Committee of the United States Steel Corporation was given that he might devote himself entirely to the rehabilitation of the United States Shipbuilding Company, and to the affairs of the Pneumatic Tool Company, which he practically controls.

I was much amused at the suggestion of your correspondent, "H.F.L.," that ghost stories should be read in the basement dining room of a four-story house. How could any one feel the proper creepy thrill in such commonplace, prosaic surroundings? Reading, no doubt, by gas light, and sitting beside a radiator or furnace heater! No.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 13. - With a view to introducing this place to the Eastern public, D.W. Cooke, General Passenger Agent of the Erie Railroad, brought a party of forty-six, consisting of newspaper men and their wives, down here last night.

There is something important in the matter of your editorial to-day. Few can see it now. Yet a time will be when the present American literature will be a joke, not because of its ignorance, but because of the classical solemnity with which such ignorance advertises itself.

It was announced yesterday that Gen. T.S. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers, had sustained the invoice values on about seventy-five invoices of the cheaper grades of chinaware from the Maestrick district in Holland, and imported by George Borgfeldt Co. Gen. Sharretts's action is a defeat to the domestic pottery interests, which have been making a bitter fight to prevent the importation of these goods.

MR. OSMUND AIRY'S monograph on "Charles H." (now appearing in a new edition) is designed to explain Charles, not to praise him or to blame him. On the whole, he inclines to a charitable attitude toward the royal sinner. He feels obviously the fascination of the man as the world has felt it.

Apropos of the inquiry of your correspondent as to the good policy of retiring savings bank tellers who have reached a certain age, by way of obviating the haughty impudence daily inflicted by them on depositors whose investments with or drafts on the bank is the sum of their offending, I beg to point out to your correspondent that advanced age of the tellers is not the cause of their bad manners.

The bankruptcy of a Brooklyn boarding house keeper with liabilities footing up something over $15,000 and assets consisting of 30 cents cash in hand, jewelry worth $3, and two dresses, is an occurrence of more importance to her creditors than to the public at large, but there are some features of it not without a more general interest, and in which an instructive moral may perhaps be found to reside.

Greater New York's largest open air gymnasium and public athletic grounds will be opened in Pelham Bay Park on Saturday, July 16. Mayor McClellan will officiate and about 5,000 athletes of the United German Societies, the Amateur Athletic Union, the Irish Athletic Association, and other organizations will participate.

The first two chapters in the "personal memoir," by Charles J. Cornish, author of "The Naturalist on the Thames," "Wild England," , of "Sir William Henry Flower, K.C.B., F.R.S., LL.D., D.C.L.," are by Victor A. Flower, who also collected and classified most of the material available in the form of early letters and general memoranda during a visit to England, before returning to professional work at Singapore.

Miss Regina Herbert of 112 Avenue C was riding on a north-bound Lexington Avenue car last evening, and just as it turned into Lexington Avenue from Twenty-third Street two boys jumped on the car. One of them grabbed Miss Herbert's chatelaine bag, and both boys sprang from the car and ran north on Lexington Avenue. In the middle of the block they were joined by a third boy.

Hamburg Belle, winner of the Futurity Stakes last year and the most talked of filly of the season, yesterday was reported to have broken down in an exercise gallop at the Sheepshead Bay race course, where she is stabled in the big establishment trained by A.J. Joyner for J.B. Haggin. Hamburg Belle raced last year in the name of Sydney Paget, in whose name a large number of horses of Mr. Haggin's breeding have run.

President Clowry's statement that the Western Union Telegraph Company would take action in the matter of poolrooms if the police pointed the places out as such was indorsed in a resolution passed yesterday by the Executive Committee of the company. Commissioner McAdoo and District Attorney Jerome said the resolution was insincere and showed no desire on the part of the Directorate of the company to aid in weeding out the poolrooms.

PARIS, May 13. -- According to a communique published this evening, it was announced at to-day's sitting of the Council of Ministers that Russia approves the publication of the Khedivial decree annexed to the Franco-English declaration respecting Egypt and Morocco.

LIAO-YANG, May 13. -- Nemirovich Danchenko, a Russian newspaper correspondent in the service of The Associated Press, has just arrived here from Port Arthur and furnishes the following chronicle of the events of the first week of the investment of that fortress. Danchenko escaped from the beleaguered city by the last train.

Most of the essays in this volume relate to phases of ecclesiastical history and antiquarian research in England. The first, devoted to reminiscences of Ruskin in Oxford, is of a much wider interest; for it is an examination of the personal experiences and impressions left by Ruskin in his Oxford days, as an undergraduate and as Professor of Fine Arts.

-- Something over a year ago we printed a little tale to this effect: An urban guest at a suburban reception was asked by his hostess why his brother had not also put in an appearance. The guest replied that, as both could not get away from business at the same time, they had tossed a coin to see which should attend the function. "And you won?" inquired the hostess.

By a communication from Mr. Faneuil D.S. Bethune, dated May 7, 1904, published in your issue of May 10, my attention has been again called to an article published in your paper of May 5, 1904, relating to an alleged inspection by President Haines of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals of the horses used on night duty from the New York Post Office in the transportation of the United States mails.

Edward W. Weir of 216 West One Hundred and Third Street is wanted on a charge of having embezzled about $1,700 of the funds of the Actors' Society of America, whose headquarters are at 114 West Fortieth Street.

Holdridge, Dennis Preston have sold the property at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, 61 by 125, for the United States Realty and Construction Company to Charles F. Hoffman and William M.V. Hoffman. The consideration was $800,000, all cash. The sale involves only the land, the building having been put up by Henry Siebrecht after he had secured the site under a twenty-one years' lease from the United States Realty Company.

PRIMROSE DAY, which was duly celebrated by the admirers of Lord Beaconsfield, reminds one of the fact that there seems to be a revival of interest in Disraeli's novels. Doubtless they were very eleven novels, for such the world has agreed to call them, but do not some of us find them just a little dull?

PHILADELPHIA, May 13. -- Officials at the Detective Bureau at City Hall say they know nothing about the woman calling herself Mrs. E.D. Rollins of Philadelphia, who is under arrest in New York charged with passing forged checks.
From now on the fight to be made by District Attorney Jerome on Richard A. Canfield will be a direct attack. The day of the "John Doe" proceedings in this case is over.

Admiral George Dewey, Lieut. Gen. Nelson A. Miles, and Robert B. Roosevelt, the Democratic uncle of the President, expounded patriotism last night on the occasion of the eighth annual banquet of the New York Society of the Order of the Founders and Patriots of America, held at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Roosevelt attacked arbitration as significant of degeneracy.

TO MANY who have not the leisure to study, the library space to stow away, or the money to buy, Mrs. Paget Toynbee's new, authentic, admirable, and presumably definitive edition of the Letters of Horace Walpole, a modest new edition of these matchless letters (or some of them) in pocket volume, bound in flexible leather covers, well printed on opaque paper, will seem a treasure.

Some months since The Saturday Review of London offered a year's subscription -- no undesirable prize -- to the reader who should suggest the worst three "tags." We have noted from time to time the progress of the competition so far as the suggestions were published, and we now give those that won, with the comments of the competitor:

TOKIO, May 13.--Speaking at the Japan Society dinner yesterday, Sir Claude Macdonald, the British Minister, said the Courage of the Japanese in battle, their kindness to their wounded enemies, their moderation in the hour of victory, and their fair and conciliatory spirit in international dealings had made England prouder of and more pleased than ever with her ally.
CLEVELAND, May 13. -- A statement signed by W. Livingstone, President of the Lake Carriers Association, was issued to-night just before Mr. Livingstone's departure for Detroit.

The author of "Eighty years' Reminiscences" was born at Charleton, Scotland, in 1818. When he was a very little fellow some one gave him a black pony called Pinkie. Col. Anstruther Thomson remembers how he "was put upon him without stirrups," and how he "clung to his pony by his heels."

TOKIO, May 13. -- The Japanese torpedo boat No. 48 was destroyed while removing mines from Kerr Bay, north of Talien-wan, (Port Dalny,) yesterday. Seven men were killed and seven were wounded. This is the first warship Japan has lost in the war.

Yesterday was "Jamestown Day," an occasion dear to all people in whose veins flows the blood of the Old Dominion, and "The Virginians" resident in New York, as has been their custom for years past, celebrated the anniversary with a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria. The dinner was conspicuous in that very little politics was discussed.

Prof. Charles Sprague Smith's dream of a People's Palace took an important step toward realization last night in Ben Greet's sceneless production of "The Merchant of Venice" at Cooper Union. The prices of seats ranged from 50 cents down to 15 cents, and an audience of about 1,500 assembled, it being noteworthy that the more expensive seats were filled, while the few vacancies were among the fifteen-cent seats.

The voyage of the White Star liner Cedric, which ended on that vessel's arrival at New York yesterday morning, was saddened by two deaths, one in the saloon and the other in the forecastle. The saloon passenger was Mrs. Margaret S. O'Halloran of 137 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, who died of paralysis on Wednesday.

THE late Lord Acton's Letters to Mary Gladstone (Mrs. Harry Drew) make one of the most welcome books of the Spring. Miss Cary, in her admirable review of this volume, well says that a "history of thought is modern England, of no mean range and substance," might be made up of the discussions of public affairs and literature in these letters, "filled out and connected."

Mr. Quick has discovered an unhackneyed subject and he has developed it with a skill and humor that can but make his book appeal to any one who enjoys reading a delightfully realistic presentment of phases of life with which we are all familiar enough, but of which not all of us, without the assistance of some such wizard as Mr. Quick, can recognize the dramatic possibilities.

Gen. Rush C. Hawkins, M.A., LL. D., has compiled a volume of his own writings descriptive of "Our Political Degradation," being several short essays setting forth "certain facts which every thoughtful citizen of the United States should know." The papers, the author points out in his preliminary chapter, were written from a personal point of view, and treat of governmental affairs, formation, administration, and execution, and are heterodox to an extent bordering upon unpatriotic depravity.
In one of your recent editorials you speak of Boston as "provincial." I doubt if that does full justice to Boston. Had you said "parochial" it might have come nearer.

One of the latest and most curious contributions to folk-lore is Mr. Franz Boas's "Tsimshian Texts," recently published by the Smithsonian Institution. Here are stories collected at the mouth of the Nass River and Nisqa-e, translated from the Nisqa-e dialect. They were told to Mr. Boas by the more intelligent of the Indians.

LONDON, May 13. -- Early in June the Graeco-Roman Branch of the Egypt Exploration Fund will issue the fourth part of the Oxyrhyncus Papyri, the chief contents of which are the "New Sayings of Jesus" and the fragment of a "Lost Gospel," mention of which was made last Autumn.

Prof. Robert Wallace of the University of Edinburgh has compiled a volume containing the autobiography and correspondence of the well-known English economic entomologist, Miss Eleanor M. Ormerod, who died in July, 1901. The volume will be brought out here by E.P. Dufton Co. It wilt include a number of portraits and other illustrations, including drawings of trisects made by Miss Ormerod, her sister Georgiana, and others.

HOUGHTON, MIFFLIN CO. announce that the life of Walt Whitman in their American Men of Letters Series will be written by Bliss Perry, editor of The Atlantic Monthly. The life of Holmes will be by Samuel M. Crothers, author of "The Gentle Reader," and that of Lowell by Ferris Greenslet, associate editor of The Atlantic.

" Fountains Abbey" is the title of "the story of a mediaeval monastery," by George Hodges, D.D., Dean of the Episcopal Theological School, Cambridge, Mass., which E.P. Dutton Co. will publish here in June. The Abbey was founded by thirteen Benedictine monks who were dissatisfied with the worldliness of the Abbey of St. Mary of York, after having heard of the simple life of the Cistercian monks, who lived at Rievaulx.
