This book is intended to strengthen the visualizing powers of teachers. It is not designed to serve as a manual of practice. The author has recognized the fact of the common drudgery of teaching, shuffled off and on as a temporary measure of expediency, but inasmuch as he has himself adopted it as his lifework, he is not content to rest here.
NIU-CHWANG, May 13. -- Chinese bandits are committing depredations in the vicinity of Yin-Kow. Several rich natives who were kidnapped by them from Niu-Chwang have been ransomed.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 13. -- The charges of heresy made by Dr. Munhall and others against the Garrett Biblical Institute and the Boston School of Theology continue to occupy the attention of the members of the Committee on Education and to be the absorbing topic among the Methodist General Conference delegates.

" Belgian Life in Town and Country" will be the next volume in Our European Neighbors Series, brought out by G.P. Putnam's Sons. Among the many topics discussed are the types of women in Belgium. No one, the author writes, can reside any time in Belgium without forming a very high opinion of the thrift, cleanliness, and capacity for work of the Belgian women.

Amid a terrible war of words, and while the volume of statements and counterstatements is augmented every day, the proprietors of the poolrooms are carrying on their unlawful business free from all molestation. The Western Union Telegraph Company has made it evident that it does not intend to give up its poolroom business.

An infuriated German, with a Kaiser Wilhelm mustache and indignation written in every line of his countenance, strode into the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station last night, dragging by the ear a weeping small boy. Behind this pair was a crowd, which jeered the German and demanded that he let the boy go.

BOSTON, Mass., May 13. -- A petition in bankruptcy was filed to-day by William E. Stowe of Belmont and George H. Pousland of Salem, doing business as commission merchants at 147 Milk Street under the name of Whitney, Pousland Co., the liabilities being given as $111,908.31 and the assets as $413.25. Of this amount $100 is on the ledger account and $813.25 is deposited in the New England National Bank.

WHITE PLAINS, May 13. -- The Republican Committee of Westchester County is investigating the identity of a person who has sent out a circular appeal to Gov. Odell urging him to appoint a special legislative committee to investigate the connection of Justice Warren B. Hooker with the recent Post Office scandals. The writer signs himself Royce S.B. Johnson, Secretary of the McKinley Republican Union of Yonkers.

Generations of English schoolboys yet unborn will rise up and call blessed Edwin Johnson, if the contentions of his posthumous book just published here by the Putnams are successfully established. "The Rise of English Culture," which appears three years after the author's death, undertakes to abolish all English history before the end of the fifteenth century.

The suit brought by Fritz Lindinger, President of the Retail Liquor Dealers' Association, against Charles E. Warth, President of the Richmond Title and Realty Company, 140 Broadway, and which involved the sum of $2.05, the price of one pair of ducks, was settled yesterday before Justice Herman Bolte in the Second District Municipal Court.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 13. -- The battleship Missouri returned to Hampton Roads this afternoon after successful trial run to sea, and the Trial Board, which had been aboard for the past twenty-four hours, returned to Washington to-night.

It was beyond the "Land of Little Sticks," where Casper Whitney found his first musk ox. For three days and nights the hunter had only tea and tobacco with which to sustain life. Even the Indians were out of temper. To keep heart in them Mr. Whitney sang. He had traveled 1,200 miles on snow shoes to get a shot at a musk ox, and was not to be disappointed.

IT IS not from to-day to-morrow that a country makes a marked change. Evolution goes on slowly. It was an accident that brought Commodore Perry's ships into Japanese waters. It is true that a revolution followed, but, as the author of "Japan" expresses it, the revolution was "the culminating growth of years of fostering.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 13. -- A man believed to have been a New York stock broker named Snell jumped from a Cleveland and Buffalo steamer when the vessel was about three hours out from Cleveland last evening.

LIAO-YANG, May 13. -- The advance guard of the first Japanese army has appeared six miles below Lien-Chen-Kuan, (forty miles northwest of Feng-wang-Cheng and forty-five miles from Liao-Yang.) It is not making any further advance, but is erecting strong fortifications. The Japanese movements were made with the greatest care.

Dodd, Mead Co. have in active prepararation the "Original Journals of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, 1804-1806," edited, with introduction, notes, and index, by Reuben Gold Thwaites, editor of "The Jesuit Relations and Allied Documents," "Early Western Travels," The account of the expedition will now be published in full for the first time.

New plans have been formulated by the officers of the United States Realty and Construction Company for the improvement of their large holdings on Lower Broadway, which now include the site of the Trinity Building, the Boreel Building, and the small block at the rear of the latter structure, with the exception of the fire engine house site at 100 Cedar Street.

The Museum of Natural History has received during the past season a number of gifts which belong in the department of American antiquities, whose head is Marshall Savile. When the Congress of Americanists met here in 1902, one of the representatives of Mexico was Senor Alfredo Chavero, a noted archaeologist of Mexico City.

WASHINGTON, May 14. --Minister Conger reports by cable to the State Department from Peking that the Chinese Government has reiterated its determination to observe the strictest neutrality and has asserted its ability to do so.

ALBANY, May 4. -- The Lewis bill, to establish a permanent commission for the regulation of the flow of water courses, was signed to-day by Gov. Odell. The commission is to consist of the State Engineer and Surveyor, the Attorney General, the Superintend of Public Works, the Forest, Fish and Game Commissioner, and a Civil Engineer to be appointed by the Governor.
THEY were talking of the sagacity of dogs.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Vernam, with the Misses Vernam and Mr. A. Harold Vernam, are now occupying their house, on Madison Avenue. They will be here only three weeks longer, however, as they have booked passage on the Hamburg-American liner Moltke, sailing Thursday, June 2.

While the firemen were marching up Broadway yesterday to the strains of martial music, a frantic shriek from the four-story tenement house at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Tenth Street gave first warning of a fire which became the scene of many thrilling rescues and brought "One-eyed Mike" O'Brien prominently to the front as a hero.

Stevens Institute students have met the "Little German Band," and after a week's engagement have vanquished it. The students concede that the German band is a most welcome accompaniment to a college boy's lark in Hoboken, but they are not larking now -- they are "cramming" for the June examinations, and the German Band has degenerated into a disturber and a nuisance.
WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The Times says:

A convention of unusual interest to the dry goods trade of the whole country will be held in the Waldorf-Astoria next Wednesday by the Wholesale Dry Goods Association, or, as it is better known in the East, the Western Jobbers' Association.
CLEVELAND, May 14. -- While hundreds pounded on the doors and clamored for admission the Republicans of Cuyahoga County held a mass convention to-day and named delegates to the State Convention.

Between 500 and 600 delegates will attend the ninth annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, which will meet at Carnegie Hall, Pittsburg, next Tuesday, and will last three days. Including those who usually attend such meetings at least 1,000 persons are expected. In the character of the subjects to be discussed and the nature of the business likely to be brought up, this convention will be the most important ever held.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 14. -- The Cincinnatis were shut out to-day in a decisive manner by McGinnity, who pitched a flawless game. It early became evident that the local players would not be able to bat in any runs, and their only chance rested on possible errors by the visitors. No difficult chances came to the New Yorkers, but what did develop was cleanly handled, and so a shut-out was the inevitable outcome.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The incidental mention of Representative Hitt of Illinois as a desirable candidate for Vice President on the Republican ticket by Secretary Shaw a short time ago has been taken up so earnestly and with such general approval by Republicans that his nomination at Chicago may be regarded as probable.

BERLIN, May 5. -- The Swiss Government has sent out invitations to the powers asking them to send delegates to a second international workmen's conference. All the Governments of the world have accepted.
LONDON, May 7. -- The military correspondent of The London Times, describing the battle on the Yalu, writes as follows:

A prominent feature of last week was new capital issues St. Louis and San Francisco issued $16.000,000 five-year 4 1/2s to refund St. Louis, Memphis and Southeastern 4s, and $5,000,000 notes, the proceeds to be used in reimbursing the main company for advances to affiliated companies now brought into more symmetrical relations of traffic and obligations.

The Democratic conventions held thus far show Judge Parker and William R. Hearst as the leading candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination. In fact, they may be said to be the only candidates who, on the basis of instructions so far given do not practically come in the "favorite son" class.
" Is a duck a fowl or a bird?" is a question which is being debated by the Henry Clay Oratorical Society, connected with Public School No. 5, Queens.

In somewhat diminished volume the week's dealings have followed thoroughly established lines and, aside from the purchase of the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street by Hoffman Brothers, have shown no individual items of great importance.
Raw wool merchants say that there is not more than a slack demand for clothing wools, the prices of which have softened in the last week or two.

ONE sultry afternoon in June last year a New York firm's foreign buyer. Mr. Parrott, an American journalist, a Japanese gentleman, and myself lolled and perspired in the coolest corner of my little villa at Nagoya, nearly all of whose garrison of 20,000 soldiers are now trying, with others of their kind, to drive the Russian bear back to his own den.

FOUR hundred thousand dollars is a large sum to expend for a collection of antique weapons and war accoutrements. It is justifiable only when the specimens thus obtained represent a permanent value, historical, artistic, or educational.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 14. -- Cornell defeated the University of Pennsylvania in today's dual track meet, 76 to 41. Pennsylvania excelled in the dashes, in which Cartwell, Dear, and Hyman had things very much their own way, but in the field events and in the long-distance runs the Ithacans easily defeated their opponents.

THERE is a universally felt confidence in the almost omnipotence of modern science; it is generally believed that the oceans are as well explored and charted as the lands, and that outside of the two poles there is little else of practical benefit to be learned. As a matter of fact, while the twentieth century finds the world's workers far advanced in every field, the opinion as a general proposition is erroneous.

Dr. EMIL REICH, the Hungarian writer on subjects social and economic, contributes to The National Review some criticisms of America and the Americans which are interesting because presenting our country and ourselves in a new light. Primarily, Dr. REICH corrects the impression, which is shared to some extent by our own people, that this continent is favored of nature in the matter of soil, climate, and natural resources.

THERE goes another one," remarked the patent lawyer, as the door closed behind a long-haired, seedy-looking individual, who had been quietly edged out of the office by one of the clerks, with the assurance that the "Chief" was too busy to-day, and the advice, "Call again some other day."

ALBANY, May 14. -- With the exception of the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company will the fate of which will not be authoritatively known before to-morrow night Gov. Odell to night completed his work on the pending thirty-day bills, gave out a list of those which he would approve, and his "omnibus veto" disposing of all remaining bills.

Princeton University played its first game of polo in the metropolitan locality yesterday, and, although beaten by Squadron A by the high score of 13 goals to 1 3/4, gave a most creditable exhibition and afforded several thousand spectators at Van Cortlandt Park two hours of solid enjoyment and excitement.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 14. -- Detective George Atwell, whose wife barely escaped being dragged off to the Hudson River State Hospital for the Insane this week by a woman nurse, who made a mistake in the commitment papers, received a letter to-day from a woman in that institution, who says that she is a victim of the same mistake.

UNTIL recently the American Girls' Club of Paris has been the only women's organization fortunate enough to possess a clubhouse in which its members may rent living rooms, as well as enjoy the advantages of the usual club life. A few months-ago, however, a club modeled on similar lines was founded in New York, but so quietly was it started that few except those personally interested in the undertaking have known of its existence.

PARIS, May 14. -- The Foreign Office here is without additional details of the widespread devastation wrought by Turkish troops in the Sassoun district of Armenia. The French press advices giving the number of killed as 100 on each side is considered to be far short of showing the magnitude of the affair.

The Crescent Athletic Club lacrosse team defeated a team representing Harvard University by the score of 8 goals to 6 yesterday at Bay Ridge. The game was the cleverest game played at Bay Ridge this season. The teams played rather warily in the first half, and the Crescent scored twice. Jewell and Hardy each shooting a goal.

The fifth annual parade of the Road Drivers' Association of New York was held yesterday afternoon under highly favorable auspices. Between 300 and 400 turnouts participated in the event, which was by far the largest and most brilliant of its kind ever seen in this city. Assembling at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Seventh Avenue, the drivers marshaled in six divisions, led by Grand Marshal Alexander Newburger and a platoon of police.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 14. -- The Tokio dispatch recording Admiral Kataoka's operations and the loss of the Japanese torpedo boat in Kerr Bay, near Port Dalny, was considered by the Admiralty to indicate that determined operations will be undertaken against the fortress.

IT was an artist who conceived the idea of a street car dwelling. From that idea has developed a town in which the houses are cast-off street cars. This is Cartown, a collection of the queerest-looking houses that civilized human beings ever occupied for Summer homes, situated on a sandy beach on the Pacific Ocean, not far from San Francisco.
LONDON, May 14. -- A marked feature of the stock market this week was the strength of domestic gilt-edged securities and the demand for scrip of the recent new issues of the same character.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 14. -- Miss Welchman, sister-in-law of Frederick Ritter, a New York broker, was walking along Main Street, in Greenwich, to-day, leading a Skye terrier, neatly combed and washed, when George Gaines, a colored man, of Cassidy Park touched her on the elbow and said:

There will be a benefit at the Broadway Theatre to-morrow afternoon for the New York Home for Destitute Crippled Children. It was arranged by Mrs. A.L. Erlanger, President of the Home, and Joseph Brooks. The performance will begin promptly at 1:30 o'clock. The entertainment will open with the sixth tableau from "The Two Orphans," presented by Clara Morris, E.M. Holland, Frank Roberts, Basil West, Margaret Illington, Clara Blandick, and others.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 14. -- Valuable papers representing the work of months and almost impossible to duplicate, have been stolen from Post Office Inspector G.W. Crawford of Indianapolis, who was waiting for a train in Union Station here.

In connection with the recent calls by the Secretary of the Treasury for a percentage of the Government funds held by the National banks, an interesting difference of opinion has arisen between the officers of some banks and one or more of the large bond houses, whose specialty is dealing in United States Government bonds.

Yesterday's market was not of the usual Saturday sort. Four times as much business was done as on the previous half holiday. The tone was not good, the advances being much less convincing than the declines, which were of a sort adapted to continue with leisure for consideration of the bank statement.
THIS was told as a new story in the smoking room of an up-town apartment house a few nights ago:
A REMARKABLE life came to a close a short time ago in Utah when death claimed the nearly century-old Sarah C. Bigler, the famous "Saint Sarah" of the Mormons.

THE initial day of the Morris Park races was notable from a sartorial as well as an equine and sporting point of view. Many and gorgeous were the costumes worn by the social "elect" and others "among those present" on the opening day. As the day was a warm one, many a belated Spring frock made its first appearance of the season.

NEWARK, N.J., .May 14. -- Park Guard Henry Wacker was dismissed from service by the Essex County Park Commissioners yesterday because he declined to make a hero of himself. The action was taken on the complaint of Henry Doremus of Mt. Prospect Avenue, whose seven-year-old son was drowned in Branch Brook Park Lake ten days ago.

PATERSON, N.J., May 14. -- Word has been received here of the arrest in Charlestown, Mass., last evening of Domenico De Feo, who is accused of having murdered Henry English in this city on May 2. The man was captured on board a steamship which sailed to-day for Italy. He was found hidden in the forecastle, and is said to have been smuggled on board by friends among the crew.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- The retirement of Miss Clara Barton from the head of the Red Cross Society to-day terminates an acrimonious contention that has been in progress for a long time, and which threatened the efficiency and usefulness of the organization.
Joseph Kaiser reports sales of several good horses.
LONDON, May 4. -- "Have you anything like that in America?" the newsdealer demanded, putting his finger on a line on his billhead which read, "Times to lend for hire."
RICHMOND, Va., May 14. -- Miss Caroline James of New York, who was thrown from a horse yesterday afternoon, died shortly before 11 o'clock to-day in the home of her host, W.S. Forbes.

LOS ANGELES, May 14. -- The Methodist General Conference to-day retired from all active participation in Church work five of its venerable Bishops. They are Bishop Edward G. Andrews of New York, Bishop John M. Walden of Cincinnati, Bishop John H. Vincent of Zurich, Switzerland; Bishop Willard F. Mallalieu of Boston, and Bishop Cyrus D. Foss of Philadelphia.

JACOB H. SCHIFF, the banker, will return from his European trip on Tuesday next, having sailed from England last week. When Mr. Schiff departed for the other side some months ago it was stated that he was not going on business, but that if anything should happen to come along he would not consider himself sufficiently on a vacation to refuse to pick it up.

Significant indication of the course of National bank deposits by individuals, in coast cities, interior centres, and on the Pacific slope, may be drawn from the chart printed below, which shows the percentages of increase in nine leading cities, and in the country at large, from 1890 to 1903.
CHICAGO, May 14. -- The Chicago Great Western Railway Company has adopted a novel plan for protecting its right of way from drifting snows, which so frequently impede train operation.

Of the three games played in the American League yesterday all were won by Eastern teams. The Greater New Yorks outplayed the Clevelands and won by the score of 10 to 1, but the Philadelphia and Chicago and the Boston and Detroit games were closely contested. Rain stopped the contest at Washington between the Washington and St. Louis teams.

Oarsmen of this city and vicinity will celebrate the formal opening of the local rowing season to-day with a parade on the Harlem River, in which it is expected that two hundred boats, from single scull shells to ten-oared barges, and over a thousand oarsmen will compete. There will be four grand divisions of the parade, each in charge of a prominent rowing official as Commodore.

Work of the past season by the pupils of the free art schools of the National Academy of Design is now to be seen in the classrooms on West End Avenue, corner of One Hundred and Ninth Street. The best paintings and crayons from the life classes adorn the walls with an iteration that is somewhat hard on the picture lover, but fills the breasts of proud parents and instructors with joy.

THE question of Sunday games and recreational camps now being discussed by the clergy probably affects the boys' clubs and associations more than any other bodies in the greater city. Hundreds of these leagues have been established in different quarters by educators and philanthropists.

THE great explorer who has just died has often been called Stanley Africanus. Outside the domestic life of his later years Africa was his absorbing thought. He was always ready to talk about Africa. He welcomed to his town house or his country home all who knew the work in Africa in its magnitude and its influences.

WASHINGTON, May 14. -- William Randolph Hearst will support the nominee of the St. Louis Democratic Convention, whoever he may be. He to-day authorized The Washington Post to make this statement unequivocally, ridiculing a story sent from Albany that he and Mr. Bryan, Arthur Brisbane, Mr. Weaver of Iowa, and others were planning a huge bolt and the formation of a new party.

" Fair Play" writes in defense of Mr. John Peter Haines, the President of a society organized to prevent cruelty to animals, and stigmatizes as "spiteful" numerous letters which have appeared in the daily press in criticism of the management.
PARIS, May 3. -- Marie Antoinette's necklace, belonging to Don Jaime de Bourbon, and the late Duchesse d' Albe's jewels, have supplied sensational matter for the police courts.

LIAO-YANG, May 14. -- Nemirovich Danchenko, the Russian war correspondent in the serivce of The Associated Press, concludes his personal narrative of his escape from Port Arthur, the first part of which was cabled to The Associated Press yesterday, as follows:

IT was a harpsichord maker, Cristofori, in the employ of the Duke of Tuscany, who in 1711 made the first successful piano. As curator of Ferdinand de Medici he had a splendid collection of Belgian, French, and Italian Instruments to look after, and this undoubtedly aided him, though the model was so crude that the inventor could never have dreamed a monument would ever be erected in his memory.
ALBANY, May 14. -- Gov. Odell has signed the Smith bill prohibiting New York City from taking water from the Wappinger and Fishkill Creeks, in Dutchess County.
" Facts are facts and stubborn things, indeed," says a Michigan clergyman who had a memorable food experience.

It is one thing to trephine the skull of a man and quite another thing to-remove section four inches square from the skull of a thoroughbred race horse. The man can be put under chloroform and kept quiet during the operation. Experience has demonstrated that horses and other animals do not recover from the influence of powerful an-aesthetics, and owners of thoroughbreds take no chances.

The principal topic for discussion in the wholesale grocery trade during the last week has been the dullness of business. The stagnation has not been confined to any one line, but complaint has been general. Orders for large lines of goods have been the exception rather than the rule, the consuming trade buying only in a hand-to-mouth way.

A charming companion said to me this morning at the Warren Street elevated station. "I think some one should write to the papers," and in this way did I learn that the fine old British remedy for grievances, real or imaginary, found favor in the "home of the brave and the land of the free."
CHICAGO, May 14. -- A special from Che-Foo to The Daily News says:

BABYLON, L.I., May 14. -- Della Fox, the actress, is a patient at the Brunswick Home, north of this village. It is understood that she came here several days ago, and an effort has been made to keep her arrival a secret.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 14. -- The beautiful Spring weather has attracted it large gathering of well-known Now York society people to Tuxedo for over Sunday. The clubhouses are filled to-day, and many of the early Summer arrivals at the cottages are also entertaining over Sunday.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 14. -- Major Gen. Pflug, telegraphing under date of May 13, says:

BERLIN, May 14. -- The German newspapers are filled with attacks on American Consuls, led by an article in the Koelnische Zeitung. According to this representative journal, German Chambers of Commerce have repeatedly declined to answer the questions of American Consuls, as German industry would thereby be injured.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 14. -- Disquieting news regarding the attitude of the Chinese is contained in dispatches from officers at the front issued by the General Staff to-night.

SOUTH ORANGE, May 14. -- W.A. Manda, head of a firm of landscape gardeners and florists, has engaged the law firm of Cowles Carey of 15 Exchange Place, Jersey City, to contest the legality of a fine of $1,000 imposed by the United States Government for violation of the alien labor law.
BOSTON, May 14. -- The extension of education to adults was the general topic considered to-day at the closing session of the convention of the American Social Science Association.
A dispatch from St. Petersburg, reflecting the purpose of the Czar with what is probably as near an approximation to truth as is possible, says:

LOUUSVILLE, Ky., May 14. -- Carefully wraped in bandages and laboring under the delusion that she has undergone a dangerous operation for a tumor in the stomach, a New Albany, Ind. woman lies at the Kentucky University on Broadway, while her physicians are carefully watching her in the hope that their unique deception may permanently cure the hysteria with which she has been afflicted for several months.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 14. -- After another day of fruitless balloting the most remarkable Republican Convention in the history of Illinois took an adjournment tonight until 2 o'clock Monday afternoon without having broken the Gubernatorial dead-lock.

Owing to the condition of the index books In the Richmond County Clerk's office, Borough President George Cromwell, backed by the entire Richmond County bar, has started a fight to get the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to grant a $5,000 issue of revenue bonds for the establishment of a modern system.
BETTER have your hair touched up." "What for?" "Lose your job!"
NEWPORT, R.I., May 14. -- The Rev. and Mrs. Roderick Terry arrived this evening and are at the Muenchinger-King cottage.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 14. -- The Lakewood horse show of last week was the final important event of the Spring season. Since that date there has been a considerable departure of guests, and the Laurel-in-the-Pines has already reached its advertised closing day. The Laurel House remains open until June 1, and is filled with many Lakewood patrons who remain here until the last.

LONG BRANCH, May 14. -- Everything is getting in readiness at this resort, as well as other resorts along the North Jersey coast, for the opening of the 1904 Summer season. A number of cottagers have already arrived and taken possession of their Summer homes. There will be fewer changes this season, as the building of handsome new cottages along the coast has not been so great during the past Winter as in other Winters.

THE building of railroads in China is responsible, in a general sense, for the war between Russia and Japan. The construction of the few lines that exist in China have brought practically all of her international troubles upon that country. Her permission to Russia to build the Siberian line across the Gobi desert, enabling Russia to hold Manchuria, really brought on the strained relations between Russia and Japan.

Capt. Norton Goddard explained yesterday that there was a precedent for the Western Union Telegraph Company to follow if it wished to close the poolrooms in this city. This precedent, he said, was referred to by the Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Slicer when he suggested to the City Club the power the company would have if it chose to aid the police.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14. -- "Jack" O'Brien and "Kid" McCoy boxed six rounds at the Second Regiment Armory tonight, and at the finish the best that either man could expect was a draw. It was a sensational contest. In the first four rounds the crowd, which more than half filled the huge armory, was treated to twelve minutes of the fastest work ever witnessed between middleweights.

Col., William C. Gorgas of the United States Army, who is to have charge of the medical force in connection with the construction of the Panama Canal, is back from the Isthmus and is now busy perfecting his plans for the purification of the strip of territory through which the canal will run.

Sweetser, Pembrook Co.'s stock of dry goods will be sold at auction in the week beginning Monday, May 23, and thus will go out of existence one of New York's oldest dry goods jobbing houses. The committee of creditors which is now in charge of the business estimate that the stock is fairly worth $1,250,000.

They took the lid off Coney Island last night, and a quarter of a million men and women got a glimpse of a swaying, rocking, glittering magic city by the sea. It was Coney Island's opening day, but Coney Island never before experienced such a bewildering opening. First of all, there were more people there than had ever been at Coney Island at one time before.

Over 400 schoolboys, representing almost evry public school in the Boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn, and Queens, competed in the first annual outdoor meet of the Public Schools Athletic League, at the Columbia Oval, William's Budge, yesterday afternoon, in the presence of a large crowd of admiring relatives and fellow-pupils.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has affirmed the judgment for $6,000 in favor of Louis Ettinger against Jonas Weil and others in an action growing out of alleged misrepresentations as to the rents of a building sold to the plaintiff by the defendants.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 14. -- Robert M. McLane, Mayor of Baltimore, surprised his official associates and friends to-day by slipping over to Washington and getting married. The bride, formerly Miss Lusby, and the widow of Dr. John Van Bibber, is one of the most beautiful women in Baltimore.

WANDER into the New Amsterdam Theatre any morning about 11 o'clock and you can get a new perspective on things theatrical. Past the pictured likenesses of the All-Star cast alluringly exhibited in the lobby, through the gloomy auditorium to a position near the stage, there comes into view a company of actors actively engaged in the tedious preparation of a stage play.

ST. JOHANN, Saarbrucken, Prussia, May 14. -- Emperor William, replying to the Burgomaster's address of welcome upon the arrival of his Majesty there to-day, recalled the year 1870, when Emperor William I. passed through Saarbrucken on his way to the battlefield of Spichern. The Emperor said:

A CREATION of the architect and builder in this city which is certain to attract widespread attention is the new palatial residence of Charles M. Schwab, on Riverside Drive. In architectural design, richness of decoration, and completeness of details this structure is calculated to surpass in luxury and magnificence any city home in America, if not in the entire world.

IT WOULD seem as if society was a blank, and would continue so to be for the next month. If one puts aside the coaching parties, the trips to Morris Park, and here and there a few weddings -- May not being favorable to these -- there is positively nothing doing. The merry month of May applies more to the country and the suburbs than to New York.

ATLANTIC, CITY, N.J., May 14. -- The season here is being rushed. With weather more suggestive of June than the middle of May the crowd has been surging shoreward. It is great weather for yachting and automobiling and the Inlet is full of white-winged and puffing craft.

ONE of the many Russian physicians who were sent to the front has written a letter describing his experiences en route, which was recently published in the Goniec, a daily newspaper of Warsaw, and of which this is a translation:

SAYVILLE, L.I., May 14. -- The anticipated visit of President Roosevelt to this resort this Summer has induced Robert B. Roosevelt to prepare the large South Bay houseboat Water Lily for the accommodation of his guest and sons.

BERLIN, May 5. -- The German Reichstag has adopted a law prohibiting betting on horse races. Henceforth betting is allowed only to such societies as guarantee that the money thus obtained will be used for the encouragement and support of the horse-breeding industry of the country. The advertising of public races is no longer allowed. A fine of 1,500 marks, or six months imprisonment, is imposed on those who indulge in bookmaking without legal permission.

Thomas W. Lawson's most recent manifecsto calling attention to the New Jersey statute passed at last year's session of the Legislature, which, he claims, was intended to provide a way of escape for the promoters, Directors, and officers of the Amalgamated Copper Company from suit to recover the millions claimed to have been made in that promotion, comes under the general head "interesting if true."

EVERY now and then, at intervals of ten, twenty, or thirty miles, the traveler in desert Arizona catches a glimpse of snowy white against the blue of a canon pass, where some consumptive Easterner has pitched his tent in the vast loneliness where nature is so beneficent that man has only to wait in submissive patience for the healing that lurks in every breath of the dry, rare atmosphere.

While the schoolboys of the other four boroughs of the city were competing at the Columbia Oval yesterday, the athletes of the Richmond Borough public schools were holding a similar competition of their own at the Cove track, West Brighton, under the direction of the Athletic Association of the Public Schools of Staten Island District.
I write this in reference to the lawn tennis grounds of Central Park. The lawn is open all week except on Sunday.

I have read with much interest your editorials on the wage problem. You seem to regard the contest as between the members of labor unions on the one hand and non-union workers and their employers on the other.

LONDON, April 30. -- Mr. Chamberlain's declaration that there will be no dissolution until next year strengthens the feeling in the House of Commons noted last week that all is well, at least for this session. The relief is considerable in its personal bearing and is conducive to the progress of public business.

LONDON, May 4. -- Last night celebrated the return of W.S. Gilbert as a playwright. His new play, "The Fairy's Dilemma,'' was produced at the Garrick Theatre by Arthur Bourchier, and met with distinct success. It is brilliantly nonsensical, and the cast introduces fairies, demons, and imps, as well as a number of human beings who are billed on the programme as "unnaturals" in contrast to the supernaturals.

THERE is only one important club meeting this month. The Union always has its general meeting the fourth Wednesday in May. There will be an election for the governors whose terms expire at that time. These are Edward Cooper, the President of the club; Henry W. De Forest, Richard N. Young, Charles D. Dickey, Joseph Agostini, George C. Clark, George G. De Witt, and John M. Bowers.

A curious story comes by way of London from Peking. It is that M. PAVLOFF, lately Russian Minister at Soul, is aiding M. LESSAR, now and for a long time Russian Minister at Peking, to induce China to take over Niu-Chwang. Russia has no more zealous servant than these two diplomatists.

New York yesterday honored her firemen on the occasion of the annual parade of the department. Along the line of march from the Battery to the reviewing stand at the Worth Monument the people extended an enthusiastic greeting to the men whose trade it is to face death.

WASHINGTON, May 15. -- The efforts being put forward by the Hearst leaders in Kentucky are causing considerable anxiety to the old-timers in the State, and fear has been expressed that Hearst will control the convention which meets on June 12. Chairman Young of the State Central Committee and a number of politicians and newspapers have come out for Hearst.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15. -- "Never before among the corporations of this country has a clear-cut issue been made between God and mammon," said the Rev. Newman Smyth to-day in a sermon delivered in the Centre Congregational Church in relation to the connection of the Western Union Telegraph Company with a gambling syndicate.

The American team composed of fifteen members of the Manhattan Rifle and Revolver Club finished its match on Saturday against a team belonging to the Cercle des Carabinieres de Paris. Each man on the team fired forty consecutive shots with the revolver and forty shots with the rifle in a series of ten shots on a target.

John Dolan of 50 1/2 Pequod Avenue, New London, Conn., who runs an express business, asked the police of the West Thirtieth Street Station last night to aid him in searching for his thirteen-year-old daughter, Katherine, who ran away from her home on Tuesday last. According to her father, she broke into a savings bank before she left, and took quite a sum of money.

Having read with great interest the various newspaper comments on the moral -- if not criminal -- guilt of the Directors of the Western Union Telegraph Company in aiding and abetting the maintenance of poolrooms in our city, and noticed the apparent unanimity of opinion that the solution of the poolroom problem lies in the Western Union's refusal to supply racing information to such places.

It is not in the least surprising that the offer of $25,000,000 of Japanese bonds upon the New York market should have elicited subscriptions to seven times that amount. In the first place, the bonds are a fine investment. They pay 6 per cent interest, and were offered to American subscribers at 93 1/2.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 15. -- Lieut. Gen. Sakharoff has sent the following report to the General Staff, dated Liao-Yang, May 14:

Dignitaries of the Episcopal Church will participate on Thursday in the dedication of the Monastery of the Order of the Holy Cross, at West Park, a little hamlet on the west bank of the Hudson River, about ten miles above Poughkeepsie. Prelates of the Church from all parts of the country will take part in the ceremonies, which will consume the entire day.

Just to see whether the promises about the rejuvenated, rehabilitated Coney Island have been fulfilled, at least 100,000 men, women, and children visited the resort yesterday. The day dawned threateningly for the men who have recently expended millions to give the crowds something more dazzling than they had ever seen before.

Can nothing be done to compel the surface-car company of this city to treat its passengers with a trifle more of consideration than is its habit? While some of its employes are good and faithful men, more of them are the reverse. A spirit of hoodlumism prevails among a great number of them.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- A phase of the Russo-Japanese war which may not be as interesting as some others to Gen. Kuropatkin and Admiral Togo, but should be of keen interest to the average American citizen, is the way in which Secretary of State John Hay is maintaining his chieftainship among the nations of the world.

Recent mail advices from England confirm the general fact that during the past few weeks there has been something like a trade revival throughout Great Britain. It is scarcely to be expected that this will be reflected very promptly or in a pronounced degree by this country during the next few months.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., May 15. -- To-day was a red-letter day at the home of Mrs. Josiah B. Bennett of 12 Grove Place, for it marked the close of twenty-five years' service in her family by Mrs. Lizzie Knox Baker, who has been a servant in the Bennett family all that time.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, preaching yesterday morning in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, declared that the morals of the race were not keeping pace with its intellectuality, and that the Nation would do well to give up half its wisdom for some advance in moral literacy.

AT SEA ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMER HAIMUN, May 15. -- I am now again in communication with you from the approximate theatre of operations, and it behooves me to give to the readers of The Times the reason for the prolonged suspension of this wireless service telegrams.

MOSCOW, May 15. -- The Emperor will pass through Moscow to-morrow on a flying tour of nine or ten cities in the Provinces of Moscow and Kharkoff, where he will personally bid farewell to the various brigades and divisions of the Seventeenth Army Corps, which have been mobilized at these points, and which are ready to start for the front.

I notice in your paper this morning a letter from "Humorist" in relation to the inadequacy of the means of access to the platform of the Third Avenue Elevated Railroad at Hanover Square. It is a grievance which has long dwelt in my mind, but it never before occurred to me to ventilate it.

A committee of three was appointed at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union, at the request of D.L. Russell, President of the Commercial Telegraphers' Union, to take steps to bring about the annulment of the charter of the Western Union Telegraph Company for furnishing the wires to the poolrooms in this city. President Russell prefaced his remarks by a statement in which he said:

CHE-FOO, May 15. -- The United States cruiser New Orleans, with Rear Admiral Stirling on board, arrived to-day from Shanghai. Her orders were simply to come to Che-Foo. Rear Admiral Stirling said the reason for his coming and his future movements were unknown to him.

LIAO-YANG, May 14 -- (Delayed.) -- The Russian fleet scored its first distinct naval success of the war on May 10 by torpedoing and crippling, though not sinking, an armored Japanese cruiser in Talienwan Bay.

-- A New Jersey Judge puts the money value to parents of a boy at twice that of a girl. At any rate, he refused to reduce the verdict for $6,000 obtained by a father for a little son killed in the Clifton Avenue crossing accident, but did reduce from $5,000 to $3,000 the damages awarded to another father for a daughter who met the same fate.

Rice interests throughout the country appear to look with much favor on the Rice Exchange which has recently been organized at Crowley, La. Daily sales of both rough and clean rice will be made by sample under the rules and regulations of trading, and it is generally believed that the Exchange will greatly aid the farmers in the rice belt in marketing their crop.

Although it is somewhat early to estimate the merits of proposed contenders for the championships of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association, which are to be held at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, on May 27 and 28, a pretty good idea can be formed as to their capabilities after the dual meet between Harvard and Yale next Saturday.

While the Board of Aldermen will begin to-day an inquiry into the charge of bribery brought against themselves in connection with the "holding up" of the New York and Port Chester Railroad franchise, the inquiry will be otherwise assisted by District Attorney Jerome, who, it is announced, will conduct an investigation of his own into the matter.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company has made public announcement that all the motor cars in use in its subway division are to be equipped with automatic controllers, so that when the conscious effort of the motorman to keep the circuit open is relaxed and his hand is withdrawn, the current is cut off and the brake applied. In the statement referred to it is described as follows:

VANCOUVER, B.C., May 15. -- Vancouver Harbor is to be fortified upon the recommendation of Lord Dundonald, general officer commanding the Canadian military, who inspected the port a few months ago and was struck with its lack of protection in case of war. The necessary guns have been ordered in England and will be delivered in Vancouver this Summer.

ALBANY, May 15. -- Gov. Odell to-night announced his disapproval of the bill of Assemblyman Thompson, extending the time for beginning work by, and also enlarging the scope and powers of, the Niagara, Lockport and Ontario Power Company. The veto was fully expected as announced last night, and was accompanied by a memorandum explaining it.

Three important events in golf are scheduled for this week. First will be the annual interscholastic championship, which will begin to-day on the links of the Nassau Country Club, at Glen Cove, L.I., and continue to-morrow and Wednesday. The Lawrenceville School holds the team championship, and a strong team will be entered to defend the title.

The well-known "prisoner of Barcelona," who has helped to make famous the game in which the prisoner needs help in rescuing his trunk from some French railway station, has arrived again, contemporaneous with the opening of Coney Island -- although that is probably only a coincidence.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 15. -- The largest crowd of the season on the local grounds was on hand to-day when the Cincinnatis batted out a victory over the New Yorks. The official attendance was given as 21,683. Luther Taylor was helpless before the home batsmen, and before two innings were over McGraw saw the need of a change, and ordered Milligan to the front.

PEKING, May 15. -- I have been investigating the report industriously circulated in Europe that China is contemplating a breach of neutrality and find no justification for it. On the contrary, in the face of great provocation, nothing could be better or more reasonable than the attitude of China, and there is no reason to fear that any departure from this attitude is contemplated.

AN-TUNG, May 6. -- The capture of the Russian position at Kiu-Lien-Cheng revealed that the Russians had been unable to remove eight of their guns, owing, it is believed, to lack of horses, which shows the deadliness of the fire of the Japanese directed against the Russian picketing lines the previous day.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- The mosquito, which is just now beginning to make itself felt throughout New Jersey, is the subject of considerable discussion in the annual report of State Geologist Kummel, which has just been issued. Authorities such as ex-State Geologist Smock and C.C. Vermoule have contributed to the recommendations as to the best means to exterminate the plague, and agree with the majority that reclamation of the meadows is the proper remedy.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 15. -- The Directors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad have given instructions to President Mellen to proceed with the work of four-tracking and widening the cut at this city. For years this cut has been inadequate, on account of the growing business of the road, as it has but two tracks. It is estimated that the work will cost upward of $1,000,000.

GOSHEN, N.Y., May 15. -- The case of John J. Huyler, Jr., against the executors of the estate of Clarissa J. Huyler, the Spiritualistic medium who was connected with the Marsh case, came up in Special Term yesterday, when Justice W.J. Gaynor directed that counsel must produce letters that passed between Mr. and Mrs. Huyler after 1898, and all wills made by them.

VIENNA, May 15. -- The enormous budget demands for the army and navy (carrying a total of over $51,791,200) have caused the utmost bewilderment among all parties in both halves of the monarchy, more especially since the rumors of such forthcoming demands were persistently denied in official quarters.

Contracts have just been awarded by the Board of Education for the general construction and for the plumbing and drainage of the new Commercial High School to be on Albany Avenue and Bergen and Dean Streets, Brooklyn. The contract for the general construction was awarded to the Remington Construction Company, whose bid, $453,000, was the lowest received, and the plumbing and drainage contract went to John Thatcher Son for $2,600.

PATERSON, N.J., May 15. -- The question whether circus parades should be allowed in the streets of New Jersey cities and towns may be a matter for discussion at the next session of the Legislature. Many business men and some school Principals do not look with favor on these displays. Paterson is said to be one of the best towns in the State for circuses.

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Jocko, the pet monkey of the cruiser Dixie, and Mickey, the goat mascot of the Columbia, mixed it up at the League Island Navy Yard to-day. The result was that three persons were knocked overboard.

A crowd of men and women who had been attending a church meeting up town were assembled in a hall adjoining the church talking on various topics when the subject turned to flowers and plants. One of the women, addressing her husband, said:

PHILADELPHIA, May 15. -- Miss Roosevelt, as the guest to-day of Gen. and Mrs. Edward De V. Morrell, passed a socially active day. Mrs. Roosevelt, also visitor here, observed Sunday quietly. In the morning the first lady of the land attended church, and in the afternoon drove unobtrusively along the river.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 15. -- The Pacific Steel Company, which was recently organized for the purpose of establishing large steel plants at San Diego, Cal., and at the mouth of the Balsas River, on the Pacific Coast of Mexico, is rapidly acquiring all of the valuable iron ore property in Mexico.

Two boys, thirteen and fourteen years old, who had tried to get a free ride on a New York Central train coming into this city late Saturday night, were found on top of a tall refrigerator car early yesterday morning, both seriously hurt and one dying. They had struck a low bridge while seated on top of the car.
GALVESTON, Texas, May 15. -- Paul Clarkson, who poses as a prize fighter, was operated on in the jail this morning, and a diamond, valued at $250, was taken from his stomach.

Business in fine cloaks and suits, which has been very poor throughout the Spring, has shown a decided improvement during the last week, and the retailers have begun to place substantial orders for lightweight garments for Summer wear.

BOSTON, May 15. -- Lilian Whiting, who wrote "World Beautiful," "The Spiritual Significance," "The Life Radiant," and other well-known works, has been charged in an affidavit filed in Greeley Colo., with conspiring with Ralph C. Meeker, a New York newspaper man, to defraud his sister, Rose E. Meeker.
BUDAPEST, May 15. -- In a speech at the receptionof the delegations to-day Emperor Francis Joseph said:

On account of the rain and fog of the early morning, which made it difficult and dangerous for the crews from the Hudson River and Long Island rowing clubs to get around to the Harlem, the oarsmen's opening day parade, whch was to take place on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, was postponed until next Sunday afternoon, when it will be held if the weather is favorable.

NEWARK, N.J., May 15. -- It is not often that Frank Kramer, the National champion cycle racer, is caught in a spill on the track, but the unexpected happened to-day at the weekly cycling meet at the Vailsburg track, and both Kramerer and his team mate, Fenn, were put out of the five-mile professional handicap in consequence of the mishap.
JACKSON, Ky., May 15. -- News reached here to-night of the assassination of Riley Coldiron, in Perry County.

It is to be regretted that the encouraging predictions of an abatement in the typhoid death rate of Philadelphia have not been vindicated by official statistics. During last week 297 new cases were reported and 38 deaths. Until quite recently the occurrence of the disease was largely confined to West Philadelphia.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 15. -- As the result of rash daring, Midshipman Philip Brittingham, the nineteen-year-old son of the Rev. Joseph Brittingham of Wheeling, W.Va., was drowned two miles off the Naval Academy this afternoon. Brittingham sank only after several heroic attempts to rescue him had been made by his classmates.

Anatole Leroy Beaulieu, author of "Israel Among the Nations," who has recently completed a course of lectures at Harvard University, was entertained at a reception given in his honor by the Judeans last night at the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The gathering comprised the leaders of numerous Jewish organizations in this city, as well as a large number of New Yorkers interested in educational work.

Ten weeks ago Judge Fitzsimons of the City Court died, and up to the present time no appointment to fill the vacancy has been made. Why Gov. Odell (the Governor-Chairman) has not made the appointment no one knows.
AN-TUNG, May 5. -- Operations which resulted in the crossing of the Yalu by the Japanese culminated on May 1 in the occupation of Kiu-lien-Cheng, on the north bank of the river, opposite Wi-Ju.

In the poolroom controversy both sides are "sparring for points." No poolrooms will be closed until the Western Union Telegraph Company exhibits a higher degree of morality or the District Attorney and the Commissioner of Police more sense and judgment.

How Sir Thomas Lipton's attempts to obtain from the New York Yacht Club a statement as to whether that organization would consider a challenge for the America's Cup under its new measurement rules, were baffled by the refusal of the New York Yacht Club to commit itself in the matter, was told for the first time by the publication yesterday of the correspondence between the Irish yachtsman and the local club on the subject.

A petition in bankruptcy has been filed against T. Hill Leary and James A. May, who compose the firm of T.H. Leary Co., stock brokers, at 41 and 43 Wall Street, with branches at Kingston, Rondout, and Poughkeepsie. They were expelled from the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange on May 5.

LONDON, May 17. -- "Cynthia," in which Ethel Barrymore appeared at Wyndham's Theatre last night, is regarded by the critics as inferior to the previous efforts of Henry Hubert Davies, and as hardly giving Miss Barrymore a good chance.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 16. -- Sir Charles Hardinge, the new British Ambassador to Russia, arrived in St. Petersburg this afternoon. As soon as the Emperor returns to St. Petersburg Sir Charles will present his credentials, and at the same time deliver a speech which it is expected will reveal, guardedly of course, the object of his mission, which is generally known to be the establishment of better relations between Russia and Great Britain.

Eighty families in the line of five-story brick tenements at 203, 205, 207, and 209 East One Hundredth Street are on strike against what they declare to be an unjustifiable and unreasonable advance in their rents. The women by day and the men by night are picketing the houses and, mounting guard on the stoops, are warning away possible renters.

Ex-Senator David B. Hill came to Manhattan from Albany yesterday afternoon. His presence was explained by some of his friends thus: "Law business." Nevertheless, Senator McCarren, Controller Grout, and exLieut. Gov. Sheehan conferred with him about dinner time, and as a result there was a general understanding last night that Mr. Hill stood committed to the candidacy of Edward M. Grout of Kings for the Democratic nomination for Governor this year.

Signalizing her last appearance as an independent star, before her happy conjunction next season with E.H. Sothern in a Shakespearean repertory, Miss Julia Marlowe appeared last night at the Empire in Frederick Halm's impossibly romantic, deliciously sentimental piece of old- fashioned theatrics, "Ingomar," the play in which she made her first prominent appeal to recognition some years ago.

M. Anatole Leroy-Beaulied was the guest of honor at a dinner held last night at Delmonico's, where a silver loving cup was presented to him on behalf of his friends in New York. Oscar S. Straus, as Chairman of the Dinner Committee, delivered the address of welcome and Nathan Bijur the remarks incident to the presentation of the cup.

MUKDEN, May 15. -- (Delayed.) -Lieut. Col. Schuyler, United States Army, military observer with the Russian Army, arrived here to-day, and after an interview with Viceroy Alexieff left for Liao-Yang in the afternoon.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 16. -- The Chinese Minister here has given Foreign Minister Lamsdorff fresh assurances of the purpose of his Government not to violate its neutrality and to preserve tranquillity throughout the empire.

Within a short period the public have been shocked by the death of a little girl while at play on the roof of her house. The slaughter of a boy by an automobile while engaged in a game of ball on the streets was chronicled by the press only a few weeks earlier. It is full time that such tragedies should receive the attention of other officials of the city than the Coroners.

Jesse Lewisohn, reputed possessor of certain secrets about Canfield's gambling house, which the District Attorney seeks to hear, twice refused yesterday to answer questions propounded him by Mr. Jerome, and was saved from prison only by a stay of proceedings granted on application of his lawyer, Alfred Lauterbach, by Justice Dugro of the Supreme Court.

CHAMBERLAIN, S.D., May 16. -- The notorious desperado Jack Sully, who for many years has been the terror of the Rosebud country, was killed in a running fight with officers on the Rosebud Reservation this morning.

Shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a diminutive messenger boy, carrying big suit case, discovered that the cover of the fire hydrant at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street was open. The wrench with which to turn the faucet inside was lying on the sidewalk, where a street clearer had left it.
New styles in carpets were shown and new prices announced for the Fall season yesterday. The carpet opening occurs every six months, and is an event in the trade.

It is more agreeable to dwell upon yesterday's later prices than those made earlier and reflecting appreciation of the bank statement and gold engagements, reinforced by failures in the South and worse crop reports. Probably neither of the two latter factors should count for very much.

TOKIO, May 16. -- The Japanese dispatch boat Miyako has been destroyed by striking a submerged mine while assisting in the operations of clearing the Russian mines from Kerr Bay, northeast of Talienwan Bay, on which Port Dalny is situated. There were twenty-four casualties.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 16. -- The Japanese evidently are determined that there shall not be any further rail communication between Gen. Kuropatkin and Port Arthur. Official advices received to-day by the General Staff say the Japanese have destroyed fifty miles of the railroad north of KinChow.
ON THE YALU, May 8. -- To-day I examined the trophies captured from the Russians. The field guns number 21. All are of the latest patterns, dated 1901 and 1902.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 16. -- Through a balk called on Mathewson in the fifth inning to-day when two men were out and New York five runs ahead, Pittsburg was enabled to get a foothold in the first game of the series here. In the next inning Mathewson was batted almost off the rubber by the Pittsburgs, who managed to get six runs all told.

There is reason to believe that Edward K. Sills, fifty-six years old, of 146 West Eighty-seventh Street, a retired member of the wholesale grocery firm of Sills Co., at 750 Eighth Avenue, was the man who leaped into Lake Erie from the steamboat City of Erie last Thursday night, when the vessel was about three hours out from Cleveland.

PITTSBURG, May 16. -- The Bostonians produced "The Queen of Laughter" at the Nixon Theatre tonight. Henry Clay Barnabee is not in the piece, and W.H. McDonald is the star with Gertrude Zimmer. The latter received eight curtain calls in the first act.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The range of gossip about the prospective Chairman of the Republican National Committee has reached Secretary Cortelyou and he has been slated in current conjecture for the place.

SANTA CRUZ, Cal., May 16. -- At the opening to-day of the California Democratic Convention to choose delegates to the National Convention, William R. Hearst failed to gain control of the assemblage, by a vote of 367 to 345.

The English yachting season has just opened and news is awaited on this side with considerable interest of the schooner Ingomar's first showing in those waters. The Ingomar arrived abroad about a week ago and went at once into dock to be overhauled and fitted with her racing spars, so she ought to be, if she is not already, in commission during the current week.
SAYVILLE, L.I., May 16. -- Robert B. Roosevelt, the venerable, but still youthful, uncle of the President, has arrived at his country home, Lotos Lake, for the Summer season.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- In an opinion written by Chief Justice Fuller, the United States Supreme Court to-day sustained the action of the immigration authorities at the Port of New York in ordering the deportation of the Englishman Turner, alleged to be an Anarchist.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F. May 16. -- The sealing steamer Aurora, which has been landing machinery for the whale factory at Cape Charles, Labrador, returned to Wesleyville, 100 miles north of here, this morning, bringing the body of Leonidas Hubbard, Jr., assistant editor of Outing, who perished in the interior of Labrador last October while on an exploring expedition.

Much remains to be explained concerning the manner in which Letitia O'Neil, the sixteen-year-old nurse girl employed by William Smylie, the wealthy licorice manufacturer of Brooklyn, received the bullet wound from which she died on Saturday night. Her mother, Mrs. O'Neil Kerrigan, of 349 Herkimer street, is firm in her belief that her daughter was murdered.

WASHINGTON, May 16. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day dismissed for want of jurisdiction the case of Ferdinand Holzendorf, an action to compel Secretary Hay to "prosecute with great vigor" a claim for $500,000 against the Emperor of Germany.

After four straight defeats at Boston the Dtroit team came to town yesterday to play four games with the Greater New York. With the prestige of thre victories over the powerful batting aggregation from Cleveland, went into the contest decided favorites, but after the fourth inning the visitors had everything their own way, and won by a score of 11 to 6.

CHICAGO, May 16. -- When Pitcher Weimet was not giving the Brooklyn players bases on balls to-day he was either striking them out or preventing them from hitting safely. The Chicagos scored ten singles to Brooklyn's five, but this advantage would not have operated against the visitors but for their poor fielding. At that the finish was close, the Brooklyns coming within a run of tying the game in the ninth inning.

Where novelty was lacking at Morris Park yesterday the returns from strict adherence to public form made ample recompense to the betting crowd, and when Oarsman, with one pound off, beat Major Daingerfield, with three pounds on, as against the last meeting of the two, when positions were reversed, the "regulars," who made up the greater part of the attendance became as warmly enthusiastic as their kind can become.
One of the common symptoms of coffee poisoning is the bad dreams that spoil what should be restful sleep. A man who found the reason says:

Clarence Whitman, the President of the Merchants' Association, wrote to Mayor McClellan yesterday making further charges against the Aqueduct Commission, and informing the Mayor that the association had laid the matter before the District Attorney.

Bernard Smyth Sons have sold for the New York County Realty Company to Lowenfeld Prager 738 and 740 Ninth Avenue, southeast corner of Fiftieth Street, a plot 44 by 80, now covered by a frame building with stores.

The exercises in connection with the annual commencement of the General Theological Seminary were begun with the delivery of the baccalaureate sermon by Bishop Doane of Albany yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd, in Chelsea Square. Not all of the class of 1904 will receive degrees, but those to whom will be granted degrees or diplomas, including some not able to be present, will number between thirty and forty.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 16. -- Hair was pulled and more serious trouble was narrowly averted between prominent State politicians this morning in the lobby of the Tulane Hotel. Ex-Gov. McMillin and W.R. Romaine, the latter editor of The Pulaski Citizen, met for the first time since editorial comments on Gov. McMillin's position on the whisky interests of Tennessee appeared in The Citizen.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- The Moros who attacked the American troops on May 8 and killed two officers and a number of men may be severely punished, by Major Gen. Leonard Wood, who is marching on the band with a force of 450 officers and men. Major Gen. Ainsworth, military secretary, to-day received a cablegram from Gen. Wade in reply to a message asking particulars concerning the movement against the Moros in Mindanao.

ATHENS, May 16. -- In view of the manifestations of Greek sympathy for Russia, the Russian Legation here, by the express desire of the Czar, issues daily reports of the progress of the war in the Far East.
Controller Grout and Alderman McCall, Chairman of the Finance Committee in the board, had another clash in the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday over the Staten Island Ferry matter.

Serious embarrassment to the City Government has been caused through the action of Gov. Odell in vetoing the bill increasing from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000 the limit to which the city may go in authorizing issues of special revenue bonds. Owing to this veto, Mayor McClellan was compelled yesterday to call a special meeting of the Board of Estimate for to-morrow at 10:30 o'clock.

As the steamship Minneapolis, from London, steamed up the bay yesterday morning, six lean, sad-looking men were seen huddled together alongside the rail well forward, looking with longing eyes toward the city before them. All of them were good types of the coster boy of the London music hall. One very short fellow, whose face was almost as red as a grenadier's coat, turned to his companions and said in a weepy voice:
Will you please tell me where to make a complaint for carelessness in the inspection or repairs of elevators?

In a notice addressed to owners and trainers of horses at Morris Park, the Stewards of the Westchester Racing Association made announcement of action that is a trifle unusual, in an order that withdraws from the programme three overnight races for the latter part of the week, for which other races will be substituted later.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission will begin a hearing on the question of the differentials in freight rates between New York and Atlantic Coast seaports and interior points on Wednesday at the United States Court Room in the Post Office Building. A large number of the commercial organizations of the city will be represented at the hearing, of which the Produce Exchange and the Merchants' Association have taken the most active part in the present movement.

The extremely interesting war news which we printed yesterday makes it fairly clear that the immediate objective of the Japanese is the capture of Port Arthur. But we say "immediate" advisedly. The capture of the place would be a great moral victory for the Japanese and a great moral defeat for the Russians.

PARIS, May 17. -- The Matin is publishing the history of an alleged treasonable incident of a seasational nature. It declares its London correspondent obtained from one "Fragola Pietro," a London hotel employe, nearly 100 plans of the French naval defenses.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 16. -Attempts to use Federal influence to break the dead-lock in the Illinois Republican State Convention gave a new turn to the bitter political fight today. After the twenty-ninth ballot the convention took a recess until tomorrow, and to-night conferences are being held to prevent the operation of such an interference.

LONDON, May 16. -- Notwithstanding the highly flattering reception of "The Prince of Pilsen" Saturday by the firstnight audience, the London papers, from The Times downward, are practically unanimous in condemnation of the production.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 16. -- An insurance policy, on which the premiums amount to $75,000, for the protection of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition from claims on account of accidents on the Fair Grounds at St. Louis resulting from its own acts or those of employes has been issued by the Maryland Casualty Company.

For one week only Mr. Charles Hawtrey is in vaudeville at Proctor's. His vehicle is "Time is Money," a "comedietta" by Mrs. Hugh Bell and Mr. Arthur Cecil, in which, as the programme avers, Mr. Hawtrey has appeared in London "with marked success."

NEW ORLEANS, May 16. -- J.H. Maury, a noted cotton bull leader and member of the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, and George Courtenay, a liveryman of Pass Christian, Miss., had a shotgun duel yesterday over a horse deal.

MUKDEN, May 17. -- It was announced here to-day that the main body of the Japanese forces is advancing on HaiCheng (about ten miles southeast of Niu-Chwang) and Kai-Ping, (about thirty-five miles south of Niu-Chwang.) and that a smaller force is marching in the direction of Liao-Yang.

Messrs. Hornblower, Nicoll, and Joline, the committee of three appointed by Chairman Cord Meyer of the Democratic State Committee to investigate the eligibility of James T. Woodward, Harry Payne Whitney, and Isidor Straus, National Bank Directors, as candidates for Electors on the Democratic National ticket, have finished their report.

After a long and tedious row in the Board of Aldermen over the Port Chester Railroad franchise again yesterday, and after the majority of the board repeatedly had voted adversely on all attempts to compel action on the railroad application, Chairman Haggerty of the Railroad Committee announced that a public hearing would be held on the entire Port Chester matter on Monday afternoon next at 3 o'clock.

Being an ardent admirer and reader of your invaluable paper, I must yet disagree with your attitude on labor matters, which is entirely too theoretical and ignores the element of human nature, which is so uncertain in calculating results such as one would expect from individual action, thus making necessary unionism.
LONDON, May 18. -- The Daily Telegraph's Niu-Chwang correspondent, cabling under date of May 17, says:

The letter of President VREELAND of the Metropolitan system to the President of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, suggesting certain changes in the plans for subway extension, is in the main wise and well-considered. The most important of these is that a cross-town loop under Chambers Street be provided, to furnish a connection between the east and west side lines.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- The full story of the killing of the American missionary, Dr. Labaree, near Mount Ararat, as a re-result of a bitter religious hatred, is told in a report just received at the State Department from Richmond Pearson, United States Minister to Persia, under date of Teheran, April 18, 1904.

Gen. Samuel Pearson of Scranton. Penn., who served in the Boer war, and Cornelius W. Van Der Hoogt, a foreign correspondent, of Baltimore and Washington, who are stopping at the Everett House, were arrested yesterday on the complaint of ex-Assistant Secretary of the Interior Webster Davis, who served under the McKinley Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 17. -- Ex-Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith testified to-day, in the Tyner-Barrett postal conspiracy case, as to the custom in the department in relation to the issuance of fraud orders.

It's a fight to the finish between the union musicians of New York and the theatrical managers, and each side is prepared to stick to its demands to the last ditch. Heinrich Conried, who left for Europe yesterday, has been most active in urging drastic action against the Musical Mutual Protective Union, but he has behind him all the members of the Association of Theatrical Managers.

QUINCY, Mass., May 17.--The battleship Rhode Island was launched to-day after a delay of more than two weeks caused by a strike of the mechanics at the works because of trouble over the hours of labor. No announcement was made in advance of the day on which the launching was to take place.

CHICAGO, May 17. -- Although the Brooklyns outplayed the local National League team to-day both in batting and fielding. Selee's men were enabled to win by a lucky streak of batting in the first and sixth innings. In the first inning Wicker's base on balls and Kling's hit to the clubhouse, which resulted in the first home run of the season on the home grounds, netted two runs.

TRENTON, N.J., May 17. -- Argument was begun to-day before Vice Chancellor Stevenson in the suit brought by Alfred F. Stevens to compel the United States Steel Corporation to pay dividends on its common stock. The case was before the court on a demurrer filed by the corporation.

It is extremely unfortunate that the Governor has vetoed the bill authorizing the city to issue $2,000,000 of revenue bonds in each year in place of $1,000,000 as allowed by the law at present. The special purposes for which the bonds were needed were the maintenance of the night schools, the Summer schools, the recreation grounds of the Board of Education, and the removal of ashes from the big buildings by the Street Cleaning Department.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 17. -- The following telegram from Gen. Kuropatkin to the Emperor, under date of May 16, has been given out here:

William Nelson Cromwell, counsel for the Panama Canal Company, with Charles W. Russell and William A. Day, who represented the United States Government at the transfer of the property and papers of the company in Paris, returned to this country yesterday on the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse.
DENVER, Col., May 17. -- At 9:30 P.M. Chairman Hodges of the Republican City Committee claims the election of Springer, Republican, for Mayor by 7,500 to 10,000 plurality over Speer, (Dem.)

While crossing Broadway at Sixty-second Street shortly after 6 o'clock last night the four-horse coach "Good Times," which had taken a party from the Morris Park races to the Waldorf-Astoria, collided with a south-bound Broadway car, which was crowded with passengers. There were no passengers in the coach, which was on its way to the Mineola stables with the driver and grooms.

I notice that Mother Eddy, in her order forbidding Christian Scientists to join single sex societies, makes an exception of the Masons. It was not necessary to make this exception. For the Eddyites cannot join the Masons, nor remain members of the Knights Templars in good standing. Freemasonry is founded upon the Scriptural truth of a living, personal God, and the Knights Templars base their existence and work upon the Apostles' and Nicene creeds.

CONCORD, N.H., May 17. -- Without friction or delay in the Republican State Convention, which met here to-day, delegates at large and alternates at large to the Chicago National Convention were elected.

-- On the staff of the Japanese Army that crossed the Yalu, it is reported, there are two Professors of International Law from the University of Tokio. A statement so delightful simply must be accepted as true, and we would not for the world suggest that perhaps the professors are with the army not as professors, but as patriotic Japanese, like the rest of the staff.

The dispute over the estate of Arthur Beckwith, the artist, who was not heard of after his escape from a Flushing insane asylum, was settled yesterday by Surrogate Thomas's acceptance of Referee James Yerrance's report that Beckwith died on April 24, 1901. The creditors of the artist's brother, Leonard, will be prevented from claiming any portion of the estate, but Leonard's children will get about $250,000.

Your editorial about the officer and soldier in Germany in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 12 has not surprised me. It only shows again your well-known and often-before manifested animosity toward everything German, and especially toward the German army officer.

According to a too familiar formula the market has recently shown activity only at the expense of values. Yesterday's market reversed this experience, prices improving at the expense of activity. In other words, the market was firmer but duller. This is not mere phrasemaking; it corresponds to significance in the observed phenomena.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 17. -- With the dead-lock still unbroken, although nine more ballots were taken to-day, the Republican State Convention took a recess to-night until to-morrow morning.

In the midst of the excitement caused by yesterday's announcement that the President of the Western Union Telegraph Company had cut off all racing information from the poolrooms, Police Commissioner McAdoo sent Inspector McLaughlin and twenty detectives to raid what they called a "poolroom exchange" in East Forty-second Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 17. -- In one of the most exciting ball games played in Syracuse this Spring Manhattan defeated Syracuse University by a score of 8 to 4. After the visitors had been held down for six innings to one hit, the bombardment began in the seventh, when Capt. Duffy sent out a three-bagger and tied the score.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Howell, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained protests against the assessments of $3 a pound on certain fabrics imported by the American Whalebone Company. They are described as "woven fabrics in the piece, of silk and cotton, weighing between 1 1-3 and S ounces a square yard, yarn dyed, colors, silk under 30 per-cent."
