WASHINGTON, May 17. -- There is as little known to-night as there was twenty-four hours ago in regard to the accession of Secretary Cortelyou to the National Chairmanship of the Republican Campaign Committee. The general view of the matter is that the suggestion has been made in a tentative way to see how it would strike the party and the country.

The National commission charged with the duty of erecting a monument to the memory of WILLIAM McKINLEY held a meeting in this city last week. It is announced that there will be a second competition for designs. The monument will be erected at Canton, Ohio, at a cost of $400,000.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 17, (World's Fair Grounds.) -- When the second day's session of the National Editorial Association was called to order Col. John Lyman of Louisiana read a paper by Joseph Pulitzer of New York entitled "Institute of Journalists." This was followed by a brief address from Sir Hugh Gilzean-Reid of London, President of the World's Press Parliament, chief founder and ex-President of the British Institute of Journalists.

PARIS, May 17. -- A dispatch to the Temps from Vienna says information received there shows that the conflict between Viceroy Alexieff and Gen. Kuropatkin is acute. The latter attributes the Russian defeat on the Yalu River to Viceroy Alexieff's orders countermanding his previously given instructions.

The discontinuance of horse-race reports to "subscribers" is not the same thing as depriving the poolrooms of the news they need. We presume President CLOWRY of the Western Union is well aware of that fact. The public, which upon the first reading of President CLOWRY'S order, jumped to the conclusion that the Western Union Company had cut off the poolroom service became aware of it a little later.

Ex-Senator David B. Hill spent the greater part of yesterday down town. Several of his friends met him in the financial district, but to all of them he would give no inkling as to his status in the McCarren-Murphy fight.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 17. -- This morning Janowski and Marshall continued play in their adjourned game from the eleventh round of the international chessmasters' tournament. Twelve moves were made, bringing the total number to 76, when Janowski resigned. Marshall now leads the Parisian with 1 1/2 points and Lasker with 2 1/2 points.

The examination of Daniel J. Sully in the proceedings in bankruptcy against Daniel J. Sully Co. was continued yesterday before Macgrane Coxe, the referee in bankruptcy. Mr. Sully was questioned about the account of Frederick Zerega Co. of Liverpool, which appears in the Sully Co. books.

Arrangements for the annual Irvington-Millburn bicycle road race on Memorial Day are being completed by the Bay View Wheelmen of Newark, and at a recent meeting of the committees in charge of the historic event it was stated that there will probably be over fifty place prizes in addition to the team and time prizes.
The United States Steel Corporation has made application to the Stock Exchange to list $17,098,000 of its 5 per cent. bonds, the remainder of the $170,000,000 outstanding.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 17. -- A local ordinance forbids the maintenance of poolrooms in San Francisco. Harry Corbett's and other sporting exchanges receive no race reports. The result is that poolrooms are run in San Salito, just across the Bay. The Western Union is serving these poolrooms with Morris Park results as usual to-day, having received no orders to cut them off.

The old adage that all whisky is good, but some is better, was attacked yesterday before the Food Standards Committee at the Hotel Wolcott by Col. W.M. Thomas of Kentucky, who declared that much of the whisky sold in the United States was unfit for human consumption.

Crazed by liquor; William Hederman, an Anarchist, who claimed that he had been delegated by his comrades to assassinate President Roosevelt, shot his mother yesterday afternoon and would have attempted the life of his sister had it not been for prompt action on the part of the police of the Wakefield Station.

With the exception of the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, the holdings of the George Kemp estate, which were sold at auction yesterday, were bought by John Larkin, who, it is understood, acted for the George Kemp Real Estate Company, to be incorporated in the near future, with an allotment of shares to the various Kemp heirs in proportion to their respective interests in the estate.

We should like to know how Mayor McCLELLAN and Controller GROUT reconcile with a decent standard of public service the methods employed in the fight between Mr. MURPHY on the one hand and Mr. McCARREN on the other.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 17. -- New York was well represented at the Fasig-Tipton blue ribbon sale in Glenville to-day. Prices were very low, only three horses bringing over $1,000. The highest price paid was $2,000, which C.K.G. Billings gave for the pacer Prince Direct, 2:07. Baron De Shay, 2:08 1/2, consigned by M.E. Sturgis of New York, was purchased for $1,300 by Joseph Hubinger of Hartford, Conn.

NIU-CHWANG, May 16, (delayed.) -- The Russian evacuation of this city has been completed. Nothing remains but the destruction of the gunboat Sivouch, which it is expected will take place early in the morning.

" Regulars" had a day of their own at the Morris Park race course yesterday, and for practically the first time this season went about racing as a business undisturbed by the jostling of a large crowd, though quite a number was on hand for all that.

There is a distinctly Hibernian flavor about the story of the "Tenants' Protective Association of Harlem." It is true that, some three-quarters of a century ago, certain inhabitants of the State of New York organized such an association, the basic principle of which was not only that they would not stand a raise, but that they would pay no rent at all; and these were all or mostly of "Saxon" descent.

Apparently, for no better reason than that prices had been going down for a number of days, the stock market yesterday showed a more or less rally in prices confined for the most part, however, to fractions. The advance was most marked during the early trading, the closing prices being at some concession from the best figures of the session.

By order of President Robert C. Clowry, the direct racing service of the Western Union Telegraph Company to subscribers in New York City was discontinued yesterday. Not only did Col. Clowry stop the service to poolrooms, but he also withheld racing news from the concerns which had been distributing it by ticker. And yet the poolrooms continued to do business, with scarcely noticeable interruption.

When the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse arrived here yesterday the death at sea was announced of a man whose name was on the passenger list as "Herr Harrison," but whose real name was Thomas Patrick Burns. He was a resident of Doncaster Lodge, Kensington Road, London, and he died on Sunday night at 7 o'clock.

It is, indeed, encouraging to find a mail contractor with sufficient regard for public opinion to speak out in response to criticism, as Mr. Travis did in your columns the other day. And, in justice to him, it should be stated that there has been a marked improvement in the quality of horses employed since he took charge of the work.

BOSTON, May 17. -- A batting rally in the eighth inning gave Cleveland another victory over Boston to-day. Parent wrenched his leg through a collision with Lush at second base, and was forced to retire. He was succeeded by O'Neill. Turner played a brilliant fielding game for Cleveland. Attendance, 5,474.

After yesterday's adjournment of the bankruptcy proceedings against his brokerage firm for one week, in which time he believes that he can make a satisfactory settlement with his creditors, Dr. W.E. Woodend said he expected to resume business before a great while. Nothing further was done in the way of forcing him to disclose the names of the New York Stock Exchange firms with whom he had arrangements to place orders.

Owing to the absence from the city of Mayor McClellan yesterday, no action was taker toward calling on Gov. Odell for a special session of the Legislature to grant relief in water supply matters. Some time to-day, however, the Mayor will communicate with Prof. William H. Burr, the Chairman of Mayor Low's Burr-Hering-Freeman commission, and then some definite plan will be decided on.

Brooklynites swarming up Park Row past the Post Office at the height of the rush yesterday afternoon paused to watch the antics of a tall, well built Swede, who charged furiously upon trolley cars as they passed, grabbing at the handrails and cursing them with strange oaths. No policeman interfered, although his performances continued for nearly an hour, according to John Jones of 163 Luquer Street, Brooklyn.

Mayor McClellan and Mrs. McClellan went house hunting in Seabright, N.J., yesterday. They found everything they wanted except a luncheon, which, however, they happened to need very badly. As it was, the butler in the McClellan home in Washington Square was obliged to display unusual activity when the Mayor and his wife returned to dinner last night.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 17. -- At the afternoon session of the Methodist General Conference to-day the Episcopacy Committee recommended the election of eight new Bishops, this recommendation being adopted by the General Conference. The election will be held to-morrow morning.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 17. -- Two little singles were all pitcher McGinnity gave the Pittsburg champions in nine full innings to-day. Only one home player reached third base, and but two reached second in the game. In the meantime McGraw's men took kindly to the pitching of Phillippe at times and scored seven runs.

Nearly 2,000 residents of the Bronx crowded into the temporary armory of the Second Battery, N.G.N.Y., at Bathgate Avenue, near One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street, last night at a reception given by the Protestant Episcopal churches and missions in the Bronx to Bishop Potter and Bishop Coadjutor Greer.

A fire which was discovered in the forward hold of the British steamship Swazi, lying at Forty-first Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, caused damage to the ship and cargo amounting to about $40,000.

After a day of unusual secrecy on the part of all who knew her identity, it became known last evening that the woman for whom a general alarm had been out under the name of "Martha Cutting" was Mrs. H. Leroy Jones of 6 East Twelfth Street. Mrs. Jones is connected with some of the oldest and most distinguished families of the Knickerbocker set. Here whereabouts are as much of a mystery as ever.

BOSTON, May 17. -- Judge Barker of the Supreme Court to-day announced a decision adverse to Receiver George W. Pepper of the Bay State Gas Company of Delaware, in his action for the nullification of the sale of the Boston Gas Companies in connection with a plan to merge them into a new combination.

A.J. Ely, a Williams College graduate, won the University Club golf tournament yesterday in the thirty-six hole handicap tournament, held as usual on the links of the St. Andrews Golf Club, near Chauncey, Westchester. His net score was 157 from 32 handicap. W.R. Thurston, of Williams, made the best gross score of the day -- 170 strokes.

Shipments of gold by to-day's steamer amount to $4,882,687, of which $2,500,000 is being shipped by J.P. Morgan Co. in coin taken from the Sub-Treasury and the balance by Lazard Freres in gold bars. The engagement of $500,000 by the National City Bank was canceled, but this lot was immediately re-engaged by Lazard Freres to be shipped next Saturday, together with other bars, making in all $1,200,000.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May I8. -- Iowa's long fight between "stand pat" Republicans and the liberals upon the issue of tariff revision and reciprocity ended in complete victory for the former in to-day's State Convention for selecting delegates to the National Convention.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 18. -- Commodore Trenor L. Park of the American Yacht Club, through his attorney, F.W. Sherman, has taken an appeal from the fine of $25 imposed upon him by Justices of the Peace Kane and Wilcox of Port Chester for speeding his automobile on the Boston postroad in the town of Rye on April 27.

There are in all our large cities many poor prisoners imprisoned for life for no offense; no crime or misdemeanor even being charged to them. On Saturday one of them, a lioness, gave birth to young ones, and killed them.

LOS ANGELES, May 18. -- The Methodist General Conference to-day voted for eight Bishops, but elected only one -- Joseph F. Berry, editor of The Epworth Herald -- who received more than two-thirds of the entire vote cast on the first ballot. One other ballot was taken, but the result of this will not be known until to-morrow.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 18. -- The Admiralty received to-day an official dispatch from Rear Admiral Wittsoeft, believed to have been dated from Port Arthur May 14, reporting that there had been no fighting afloat since the telegraph line was cut, the Japanese ships not having attacked. Everything was well with the Russian squadron.

CHE-FOO, May 18. -- As a result of the engagement which the Japanese had on Monday with the Russian garrison at Kai-Chou, on the west coast of the Liao-Tung peninsula, twenty-three miles directly south of Yin-Kow, the port of Niu-Chwang, the Russians were driven out of Kai-Chou, the nearest point to Niu-Chwang, with the exception of the Liao River, where there is sufficient water to allow of landing the troops.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 18. -- Having followed a clue along the trolley line from South River to this place, the police are looking for the Rev. J.F. Cordova, pastor of the Methodist Church in South River, and Julia Bowne, an eighteen-year-old girl who was a member of the church choir.
BOSTON, May 18. -- The report of the Directors of the American Peace Society, read to-day at the seventy-sixth annual meeting of the organization, contained the following:

President Robert C. Clowry of the Western Union Telegraph Company took the bull by the horns yesterday and abolished absolutely the racing news bureau which that corporation had conducted for years. With a stroke of his pen he blotted out the far-reaching system of gathering and distributing the news of the race tracks -- a system which it had taken more than two decades to perfect, until it yielded receipts estimated at $5,000,000 annually.
A group of veterans were telling stories at the Allyn House last evening, and one of the number related one about when his regiment was down in Northern Virginia. He said:

I have read with considerable interest and some amusement your correspondent's criticisms of the uncivil bank officials. So far as savings bank tellers are concerned I think they have ample reason to feel a little cross-grained oftentimes. A large percentage of the depositors in these institutions are exceedingly dull, ignorant people, and the patience of the tellers is sorely tried in dealing with them.

Further bitterness in the warfare between Tammany Hall and the McCarren organization was engendered yesterday by moves made on both sides. Controller Grout fired a broadside into the Murphy camp by issuing a statement defining his position.

LONDON, May 18. -- The Stewards of The Jockey Club, as an outcome of the sensational libel suit brought by the well-known racehorse owner, R.S. Sievier against Sir James Duke, also well known on the turf, which was decided in favor of the latter, have warned Mr. Sievier off the turf.

The "City Employe," who acts as if he were hurt by my "attempted" arraignment of Mr. Justice Seabury for his curious decision on the garnishee law, alleges that I have resorted to vituperation and slander in order to have a hit at city employes. Possibly, the gentleman's letter, if laid alongside of mine, would show who had resorted to vituperation.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 18. -- The Republican State Convention at Greensborough to-night nominated for Governor Charles J. Harris of Jackson County, and for Lieutenant Governor Isaac M. Meekins of Pasquotank.

Mrs. Constance Classon, wife of Hans Classon of Boyd Hill, Staten Island, died of carbolic acid poisoning yesterday, and there is much mystery surrounding her death as a result of clash between the police, the attending physician, and Coroner Schaeffer. It was not until Capt. Naughton threatened to place uniformed men on guard at the house that any information as to the facts in the case were forthcoming.
ST. LOUIS, May 18. -- Rain put an end to the game between St. Louis and Philadelphia in the second half of the fifth inning with St. Louis leading 3 to 2. Attendance, 2,300. Score by innings:

In his address incidental to the conferring of diplomas on twenty-six graduates at yesterday's commencement exercises of the General Theological Seminary, Bishop Henry C. Potter referred to the late poolroom service of the Western Union Telegraph Company as indicating that the ministry was a promising field for young Americans.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 18. -- The Republican State Convention reconvened to-day with a small attendance outside the 951 delegates. There were contests for only two minor places on the ticket.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Smoot inquiry has been dropped until after the November elections. It was the intention of the committee to go to Utah this Summer and examine witnesses who could not be brought to Washington. It is now learned that the committee has abandoned all preparations for the Westward trip, and will not take up the matter in any form until late in the recess.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 18.--Miss Helen Gould is said to be contemplating the expenditure of several million dollars in the establishment of a building in some city of the Middle West devoted exclusively to the interests of clubwomen of America represented in the National organization now meeting in St. Louis.

Dr. Adolph Stern of West Sixty-eighth Street was robbed of $1,200 in a West Thirty-eighth Street poolroom on April 29, and yesterday appeared in Jefferson Market Court to press a charge against the men said by the police to be the guilty men. They described themselves as Robert Johnson, John Cary, Albert Rose, and Timothy Bailey.

-- Mr. F.C. THEO. KRUGER thinks that one of our recent editorial articles illustrated anew our "well-known and often- before manifested animosity toward everything German, and especially toward the German army officer." Also, Mr. F.C. THEO. KRUGER asks: "Why are yon hostile against these gentlemen and what is the cause of your wrath against them?"

BRESLAU, Prussia, May 18. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of the Breslau Zeitung reports that the authorities detected and thwarted a plot to attack the Emperor with a bomb during the Spring parade in St. Petersburg, May 10.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The Tyner-Barrett trial was to-day rather ramatic. Gen. Tyner himself gave his testimony sitting in his wheel chair near the witness stand. His speech was exceedingly feeble, and his attorney had to utter his questions close to the aged defendant's ear.

It is perhaps to be expected that personal interest and local sentiment will to a certain extent prejudice and influence one's views and sentiments, but it does seem that the press of New York might give a more just and fair consideration of the question of the city water supply as it relates to the streams of Dutchess County.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 19 -- 3:10 A.M. -- Official dispatches regarding the present disposition of the Japanese forces add little real interest to the situation, the most important statement being that there is a force of 5,000 at Khabalen, eleven miles southwest of Feng-Wang-Cheng, and the fact that the Japanese are entrenching around Feng-Wang-Cheng.

Probably the stock market yesterday is best described by saying that it was at a standstill. Only three stocks -- Pennsylvania, Union Pacific, and Steel preferred -- where sufficiently traded in to be entitled to be called active, and in these three the average net change was nothing. An advance of an eighth of a point in Union Pacific was offset by an equal decline in Steel, and Pennsylvania closed unchanged.
ROME, May 18. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Foreign Minister Tittoni made a most optimistic statement of Italy's foreign policy.

Wall Street enjoyed itself yesterday at the expense of a well-known member of the Stock Exchange. The man about whom the story was spread had lost money and temper in the Street and at the race track.

PORT CHESTER, May 18. -- John W. Lounsbury, a wealthy banker and an intimate friend of John D. and William Rockefeller, dropped dead of apoplexy this afternoon at his home in Port Chester, just after returning from a drive.
" Who make the best soldiers?" inquired a Hartford man of Gen. Joseph R. Hawley when Senator Hawley was stopping at the Hartford Club.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission yesterday began its hearings in this city in the investigation of the differential freight-rate situation. The hearing was attended by representatives of almost every prominent trunk line reaching tidewater on the Atlantic Coast as well as by representatives of various commercial bodies of this city, Philadelphia, Boston, and Baltimore.
Congressman Timothy D. Sullivan was a visitor to the races at Morris Park yesterday.
TOKIO, May 18. -- The official report of the landing of the Second Japanese Army, commanded by Gen. Oku, has been received here. It is as follows:

Herman D. Nessler of 77 East Eighty-ninth Street, who is the complainant against David Rothschild, head of the defunct Federal Bank, was the first witness called yesterday in the trial of Rothschild. He told of the ten-thousand-dollar note transaction on which is based the indictment for grand larceny against Rothschild.

Routes by which the great Japanese armies in Manchuria are enveloping the position occupied by the Russians under Gen. Kuropatkin are shown in the above map. The strategy of the Tokio General Staff has been designed to crush the Russians after surrounding them.

Millard Veit has sold for Arthur E. Silverman to Harry Goodstein 245 and 247 West One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, a six-story elevator apartment house, on plot 50 by 100.11. In part payment Mr. Silverman takes the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street, 75 feet east of Lenox Avenue, 60 by 100, and will erect thereon a six-story apartment house.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Ex-Gov. Black of New York, who had a conference to-day with the President regarding the speech to be made by the former in placing Mr. Roosevelt in nomination at Chicago, was asked to-day as to the crusade of District Attorney Jerome against the poolrooms and other alleged evils of the metropolis.

The preservation of Fraunces's Tavern as a historical landmark was assured yesterday by the anouncement of the Society of the Sons of the Revolution that it had purchased outright this building, made famous by Revolutionary memories. The price paid for it was withheld.

Meadow Brook defeated the first team of the Rockaway Hunt Club yesterday in the closest game of polo played this season on the field of the Meadow Brook Club, near Westbury, L.I. The home team won by the narrow margin of one-quarter of a goal, scoring 7 1/4 goals to 7.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 18. -- It is officially denied that Viceroy Aliexeff has gone to Liao-Yang to assume command of 20,000 troops there, and that Gen. Kuropatkin has left Liao-Yang for Harbin. It is said that Kuropatkin is either at Liao-Yang or in its vicinity.

The whereabouts of Mrs. H. Leroy Jones, who mysteriously disappeared from the Morris Park race track on Monday, remain a mystery. A general alarm has been sent out by the police, but so far it has been unproductive of results, and it was said at Police Headquarters late last night that no clue as to Mrs. Jones's whereabouts or concerning her movements since Monday was in the possession of the department.

Old Trinity had just tolled 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a woman frantically waved a handkerchief from one of the upper windows of the Lord's Court Building in William Street. Coincident with the waving of the handkerchief, a man on the street ecstatically cried: "There she is! There she is!" and pointed up to the window.

Creditors representing 51 per cent. of the total amount of claims against the suspended brokerage firm of Floyd, Crawford Co. have agreed to an offer made by James C. Lenney, attorney for the partners, on the basis of 10 per cent in cash and the remainder in notes running from one to twenty-eight months.

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- Lieut. de Faramond of the French Embassy went to New York to-day to meet his uncle and aunt, the Marquis and Marquise de Feizen, who arrive to-morrow from France to attend the marriage of their nephew and Miss Ivy Langham next Tuesday. Mile. Yvonne de Feizen, who accompanies her parents, will act as a bridesmaid at the wedding.

CHICAGO, May 18. -- Brooklyn lost again to Chicago to-day in a closely contested game, Chance scoring the winning run in the eighth inning by sending the ball over the right field fence. The batting as a rule was light, and the mistakes of both teams were costly. Chicago scored two runs in the fourth inning. After Moriarty struck out, Casey reached first on called balls and stole second.

PARIS, May 18. -- The Papal protest against President Loubet's recent visit to Rome will be the subject of questions in the Chamber of Deputies, and the reply which Prime Minister Combes purposes to make is likely to cause a widespread sensation.
LONDON, May 18. -- By a majority of 55 Premier Balfour to-night successfully defeated an attempt to upset the Government upon the fiscal question.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 18. -- Undaunted by the sight of a revolver and a threat that their heads would be blown off, Capt. Joe Gale and Raymond Bailey, two young inlet skippers, boarded the boat of William Mannery, a thoroughfare oystermaan, and rescued his wife and daughter. Mannery had demanded that his daughter give him some money in her possession.

Mr. ROOSEVELT can hardly look on the situation in Iowa with complete satisfaction. It must suggest to him the serious sacrifice he has been forced to make in order to keep the personal leadership which he regards as so entirely necessary to the progress of his party and his country.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 18. -- Gov. Odell returned from Newburg to-night and at once turned his attention to reports that the fiscal officers of New York City were disturbed over his veto, especially of the Hornidge bill, which raised from $1,000,000 to $2,000,000, the limit of special revenue bonds to be issued by a three-fourths vote of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 18. -- The only contest in the State Republican Convention held here to-day developed on the question of primary reform involving the nomination of candidates for State offices, the Legislature and Congress by direct vote of the people. The anti-primary reform element scored a decisive victory.
BRUSSELS, May 18. -- The Russian Government has made large purchases of carrier pigeons in Belgium for service in the Far East.

ORANGE, N.J., May 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Otto Sperber, who represent various French and German press associations, and who are very fond of walking, have arrived in town and are stopping for a few days with Mr. and Mrs. Henry Preusse, at 401 Scotland Street. They traveled from Buenos Ayres through South America and the Isthmus for the purpose of ascertaining South American commercial possibilities.
BERLIN, May 18. -- Business on the Boerse to-day was extremely dull.

This community is enjoying a rich foretaste of the blessings of municipal ownership through disclosures made in the discussion of the Staten Island Ferry purchase at the meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners on Monday.

District Attorney Jerome expressed some strong views on reform in public office, virtue, and respect for the law, citing the Western Union's action in discontinuing its poolroom service as an example of what might be done to correct existing conditions, at the annual dinner of the New York Civil Service Reform Association last light at the Hotel Manhattan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18. -- A drizzling rain fell during the greater part of to-day's game, but despite the weather the fielding of both teams was good. The locals won from St. Louis by superior work at the bat. Morgan and Pelty were both batted hard. Attendance, 1,441. Score by innings:

About one hundred representatives of dry goods jobbing houses, chiefly from the West, gathered yesterday at the Hotel Majestic to attend the convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Association, which was organized about a year ago, and the membership of which is confined to the Western cities.

On the 12th inst., in an article referring to the gallant rescue made by the British steamer Cairnisla, by members of the crew, who were undoubtedly Scandinavians, (i.e., Norwegians, Danes, Swedes, or Finns,) you allude to them as "Dutchmen." The Scandinavians are, as has been shown by ethnologists and anthropologists, a very mixed race, the earliest inhabitants of Scandinavia and Finland being probably the Goths and Laplanders.

The Western Union Telegraph Company has at last withdrawn from the position which it ought in the first place to have seen it could not continue to occupy. It has gone out of the business of collecting racing news, which was after all the essence of its collusion with the poolroom offenders.

Augustus Post, Chairman of the Touring Committee of the American Automobile Association, has been in Chicago and St. Louis for the purpose of making final arrangements for the big automobile tour to be made this Summer under the auspices of the American Automobile Association.

BERLIN, May 18. -- In columns upon columns of correspondence from Paris to the German journals, particularly the Cologne Gazette, efforts are made to exhibit more or less intelligent appreciation of events before they occur by canvassing the line of policy which will be adopted by France and other powers at the conclusion of the war between Russia and Japan.

Mr. and Mrs. John Gaffney and their daughter, Miss Humphreys, arrived in New York yesterday on the German Lloyd steamship Koenig Albert. Mr. Gaffney said it had been his intention to return to America by way of the Trans-Siberian Railway, but that the Russo-Japanese war made this impracticable.

Chairman Cord Meyer of the Democratic State Committee announced yesterday afternoon that he had received the resignations of Isidor Straus, James T. Woodward, and Harry Payne Whitney as candidates for National Electors. Chairman Meyer said that these men believed that loyalty to the interests of the party demanded that they leave the ticket, inasmuch as doubt had been expressed as to their eligibility.

In the exercise 6f executive prerogative to approve or veto legislative enactments, Gov. Odell does not shine brilliantly by comparison with Mayor McClellan. He is altogether too anxious for partisan advantage, and too quick to ascribe directly or indirectly improper motives to his political opponents.

Wednesday's stock market was like Tuesday's, only more so. That is to say, there was further loss of volume, with dullness in the strong moments and activity whenever prices softened. In the earlier trading business was in small lots, and the tone was moderately good. In the later business lots were larger, and prices were softer.

The Board of Aldermen is considering a resolution providing, among other things, that every train on the elevated railroad shall have two motormen. The preamble to Alderman DOWLING'S resolution sets forth that --

WASHINGTON, May 18. -- The terrific effects on shipboard of modern heavy gun fire are described in a report received today by Surgeon General Rixey of the Navy Department from Dr. H.D. Wilson of the Vicksburg, who aided the wounded on the ill-fated Russian cruiser Variag after her return to Che-mul-pho from her fight with a Japanese squadron.

Racing at the Morris Park track yesterday was rescued from the commonplace by the truly remarkable achievement of the Oneck stable, one of the least conspicuous establishments of the Eastern turf, which made a record for itself and tied the record of the H.B. Duryea stable on Metropolitan Handicap day, by winning one-half the programme, or three races in all.

Unable to obtain bail, Gen. Samuel Pearson of Scranton, Penn., who served in the Boer war, and Cornelius W. Van Per Hoogt, a foreign correspondent from Washington, who were arrested the other day on a blackmail charge preferred by ex-Assistant Secretary of the Interior Webster Davis, remained in the Jefferson Market Court prison yesterday.

After a three-year fight against the Theatrical Syndicate, the Independent Booking Agency is to be dissolved. James K. Hackett has announced that he is about to sever his connection with this organization, which action will leave Harrison Grey Fiske the only member, and will break up the co-partnership which had existed between the managers who sought to conduct their business untrammeled by the syndicate.

At the session of the Aldermanic Investigation Committee yesterday President William C. Gotshall of the New York and Port Chester Railroad was sworn as a witness, but after saying that his information as to the bribery stories came from a Mr. Mills, he was excused until to-morrow at 3 o'clock.
MADISON, Wis., May 18. -- The Republican State Convention broke up in a row night at 6 o'clock and every delegate in convention who was opposed to the renomination of Gov. La Follette walked out.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The British Ambassador and Lady Durand have selected Lenox as their Summer home, and to-day completed arrangements for two cottages there for their family and staff. Arthur Raikes, the First Secretary, will sail next week for Europe to be gone three months, while Mr. Waterlow, the Third Secretary, and Mrs. Waterlow sailed to-day for a Summer's absence.

CAMBRIDGE SPRINGS, Penn., May 19. -- The international chess tournament, which was begun at the Hotel Rider in this city April 19, was concluded to-day. Marshall won the contest, Lasker and Janowski being second and third, Marco fourth, Showalter fifth, while Schlechter and Tschigorin were placed in sixth and seventh places.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- China has been informed that the Washington Government claims the right to dispatch warships not only to those Chinese ports declared by treaty to be open to the world, but also upon the inland waters of China "wherever Americans may be and where by treaty with China they are authorized to engage in business or reside, for the purpose of spreading the Gospel."

A fast trial by the Hampton Stable's Africander, at a mile and a quarter over the Gravesend track yesterday, backed by reports of the perfect condition of H.B. Duryea's Irish Lad, winner of the Metropolitan Handicap, set horsemen at the Morris Park race course yesterday talking of the prospects for the Brooklyn Handicap as though the race had settled down to a contest between the two.
The position taken by the Central Federated Union would seem to admit of statement in two brief propositions:

Over twenty members of the Produce Exchange Golf Club wended their way in the rain yesterday afternoon to the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains, to compete in the annual club handicap. T.R. Van Boskerck won the event with a net score of 77 strokes from 7 handicap. The lowest gross score was 75 strokes, made by Francis M. Wilson, who received the excessively high handicap of plus 8. His card is:
LONDON, May 20. -- Special dispatches from Shanghai to the London morning papers report that the Shikishima was sunk while the Fuji and the Asama had to be towed away badly damaged.
WASHINGTON, May 19. -- In front of the Capitol at an early hour this morning there was a performance which surprised the many persons who witnessed it.

-- Practitioners of the pleasant art of equestrianism are discontented, and for cause, with the opportunities for the enjoyment of their favored amusement that exist in the parks and suburbs of New York, and some 600 of them have signed and sent to the Mayor a petition for increased facilities -- more soft roads, that is -within the city limits.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19. -- Prominent Indiana Democrats who were leaders in the Gold Democratic organization in 1896, and who opposed Bryan in 1900, have taken up eagerly the renewed suggestion that ex-President Grover Cleveland might be willing to become the Democratic nominee this year.
MADISON, Wis., May 19. -- Rival Republican State conventions were held to-day at which two complete State tickets were nominated, intense bitterness prevailing on both sides.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 20. -- The loss of at least two Japanese warships is officially confirmed. A message dated at Port Arthur, received by carrier pigeon at Mukden, was transmitted to the Emperor early yesterday morning, saying that two Japanese warships had been lost off that port. This message followed the Emperor to Koursk and no one here knew its contents until late last night, when foreign telegrame brought full details of the Japanese loss.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 19. -- The Russians now say that the fates are against the Japanese. The latest Japanese movements reported to the General Staff tend nevertheless decidedly to befog the authorities to the real intention of the enemy. Why Gen. Kuroki should suddenly stop his advance on Hai-Cheng and Liao-Yang, when Gen. Kuropatkin was known to be preparing to withdraw, is a question partially answered by the condition of the roads.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- For the fourth successive time the Chicago team of the National League defeated the Brooklyns to-day, and but for two errors in the ninth inning Hanlon's men would have been shut out. Wicker pitched a magnificent game, but his support was rather poor. Chance gave another fine exhibition of batting, hitting the ball safely every time he went to the bat.

Among the many more or less important results to follow the evacuation by the German and the reoccupation by the American Eagle of Fraunces's Tavern, due to its purchase by the Society of the Sons of the Revolution, and the future removal of proprietors Glintenkamp Precht, is the making homeless of thirty-eight longshoremen and Col. Ass Bird Gardiner, ex-District Attorney.
We reprint an extract from the report of an interesting interview with Mr. JACOB H. SCHIFF, which we printed on Wednesday:

TANGIER, Morocco, May 19. -- Mr. Perdicaris, a wealthy American resident of Tangier, and Mr. Varley, his step-son, a British subject, were carried off last night by Raisuli, the brigand, and his band of 150 armed men. The villa inhabited by Mr. Perdicaris, situated three miles outside Tangier, was surrounded, the servants were beaten, and Mr. Perdicaris and his family attacked inside the house.

Dedication ceremonies were held yesterday at the new Protestant Episcopal monastery of the Order of the Holy Cross located on the Hudson River at West Park, ten miles north of Poughkeepsie. Nearly 100 leading clergymen attended the exercises, and delegations were present from many of the other orders, including the nuns of the Episcopal sisterhoods.

PARIS, May 19. -- The automobile trials for the purpose of selecting the French team for the James Gordon Bennett international contest will occur at Ardennes to-morrow. There are twenty-nine entries. The start will take place at 4 o'clock in the morning, and every two minutes thereafter other automobiles will be sent away.

To those who gather daily at the Real Estate Salesroom, 161 Broadway, in search of houses and lots at tempting figures it will be glad news that the place also affords great bargains in securities. On Tuesday J. Clarence Davies a real estate broker, picked up there stocks worth more than $21,000 for a total outlay of $815.

Ravitch Brothers have sold to Clara and Della Max the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, a five-story flat, 33 by 108. In part payment for this property the buyers give the plot on the south side of Ninety-ninth Street, 150 feet east of Madison Avenue, 150 by 100.11, with an abutting plot on Ninety-eighth Street, 50 by 100.11.
PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- Although the home team outbatted St. Louis to-day the visitors won through poor fielding of the locals. The attendance was 4,382. Score by innings:

It was announced yesterday by members of the Creditors' Committee in charge of the affairs of Sweetser, Pembroke Co. that no statement of assets and liabilities would be made until after next week's auction sale of the firm's stock. In the meantime a force of experts will be put at work on the books.

Echoes of the famous "Cincinnati wheat deal" of nearly twenty years ago are awakened by a judgment for $180,745.65 which was entered yesterday against Edward L. Harper, the head of that disastrous speculation and President of the Fidelity Bank of Chicago, which went down to ruin in the general crash.

Members of the Rapid Transit Commission are looking with decided favor on the proposition made by the Schmidt Gallatin syndicate, in connection with the Belmont interests in the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, to install a system of moving platform subways in the cross-town streets so as to provide an interchangeable transfer system between these subways and the Interborough subways and elevated lines.
TOKIO, May 19. -- Vice Admiral Togo has reported as follows:
LONDON, May 20. -- The correspondent of The Daily News cables from Tien-Tsin as follows, under date of May 19:
CHICAGO, Ill., May 19. -- A special to The Daily News from Che-Foo says:

Reaction again set in in the stock market yesterday, but it was confined, as the previous day's upward movement had been, to small fractions. The trading was on a slightly larger scale in keeping with recent experience, in that the tendency on declining prices has been toward larger dealings, while recovery has more often than not been attended by decreasing business.

I am an Englishman and have always heard that the freedom obtained here was far in excess of any benefits conferred upon other nations' citizens. I have been closely watching your poolroom farce, enacted with Jerome in the leading role, supported by McAdoo and other lights of the legal profession, with many villains represented by "Western Union Directors."

NIU-CHWANG, May 19. -- A courier who arrived here shortly before midnight reports that the Japanese fleet was sighted from Tower Hill, ten miles north of Kai-Chow, on Monday. The bombardment of the coast was extensive, covering a distance of twenty-five miles. Only Japanese marines, it was reported, were landed.
CHICAGO, May 19. -- A scramble by short sellers to get out of the market to-day sent the price of May wheat to the dollar mark, an advance of 3 1/4c. The closing price for May was 99.

A dapper young man, smooth shaven and wearing a light hat and a brown suit, walked into Lindo Brothers' jewelry establishment, at Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon, and, after looking over women's watches, selected one and said he would take it. Then he began to feel about his pockets.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 19. -- The poolrooms received telegraphic service from the race tracks as heretofore to-day. Tickers in the different poolrooms told off the events, the odds, and the winners, as though nothing unusual had happened. The proprietors of the rooms do not anticipate any further interruption.
ST. LOUIS, May 19. -- Secretary of State Hay made an address to-night at the opening of the Press Parliament of the World at the Louisiana Exposition. Mr. Hay said in part:

ALBANY, May 19. -- The announcement that Secretary Cortelyou is to be Chairman of the Republican National Committee brought out the story at Gloversville that his successor as head of the Department of Commerce may be Congressman Lucius N. Littauer.

CHICAGO, May 19. -- There is a rumor around the poolrooms to-night that the Chicago gambling combination is to disseminate race track news throughout the country, in the place of the Western Union service. It is said it has made connections with gamblers in all the large cities and that the arrangement assumes the proportions of a National gamblers' trust.

Gathering their racing news from various unknown sources, the majority of the poolrooms in New York City opened for business yesterday afternoon at the regular hour and accepted bets just as if the Western Union Telegraph Company was furnishing them the service direct from the tracks.

CHE-FOO, May 19. -- A party of thirteen Russians arriving from Dalny this morning by junk are authority for the statement that during a bombardment of Port Arthur by the Japanese Monday afternoon the Japanese battleship Shikishima and the cruiser Asama struck mines and sank.

NEWPORT, May 19. -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to-day granted a new trial in behalf of the defendants in the trespass and ejectment suit of Sidney Webster vs. Alfred M. Coats, and Charles Astor Bristed. All the parties to the suit own land on Brenton Road in this city, and the plaintiff claims that the defendants had no right to use water, telephone, and electric light connections which he had made.

BUFFALO, May 19. -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States was this afternoon stampeded for the Rev. J. Addison Henry, D.D., of Philadelphia, for Moderator. Dr. Henry was elected unanimously almost before the other leading candidates for the position knew what was going on.

NEWARK, May 19. -- An explosion of soluble cotton, which is something like guncotton, and which is used in the manufacture of lacquers, completely wrecked the one-story frame building occupied by the Petrifoid Company at 232-236 Thomas Street, this morning, seriously injuring several persons.

MOSCOW, May 19. -- After exhaustive inquiry I find there is no need to take seriously the Russian threat to dispatch a naval reinforcement of transcendent strength from the Baltic to the Far East in July.

We have read with expectant interest a personal sketch of WILLIAM R. HEARST from the pen of Mr. CHARLES E. RUSSELL of Mr. HEARST'S Chicago American, published in Harper's Weekly of May 21. The sketch "was written," says Harper's Weekly, "by one of the very brightest young men in Mr. HEARST'S employ, and naturally presents his best side."

Two official acquisitions were claimed by the Tammany men yesterday in their fight against the McCarren organization in Kings County. They declared that Gottfried Westernacher, Deputy Bridge Commissioner, and an old-tme McCarren man, had gone into the Murphy camp, and probably would be found fighting against Conrad Hasenflug, McCarren's leader in the Nineteenth Kings County District, when the Fall primaries draw near.
PANAMA, May 19. -- Gov. Davis to-day issued a proclamation from "The Office of the Governor of the Isthmian Canal Zone, Culebra, May 19," and addressed "to the inhabitants of the Canal Zone."

The automobile trials to select a team to represent this country in the coming race for the Gordon Bennett international race to be decided in Germany next June were held at the Empire City track, Yonkers, yesterday, and resulted in a complete fiasco.

" It's like being in a poolroom," complained a nervous bettor at the Morris Park race track yesterday, when the horses at the post for the first race disappeared in a fog bank immediately after the start was made, following a send-off that was so obscured by rain and mist that even the most anxious backer could not say whether his choice was first or last.

ST. LOUIS, May 19. -- St. Louis won the second and final game from Philadelphia to-day, 9 to 2. Taylor held the visitors safe all the way, the latter not scoring until the seventh inning. St. Louis hit Duggleby hard. A home run by Titus was a feature. The attendance was 2,800. Score by innings:

Incoming steamers and sailing vessels from our Southern and West Indian ports say that they have been greatly accelerated on their northern journey by an apparently abnormal increase in the velocity of the Gulf Stream. The average time of steamer voyages has thus been shortened seven hours from Havana, twenty-two hours from Trinidad, and many incoming vessels report proportional reductions in the duration of their trips.

WASHINGTON, May 19. -- The conferences at the White House in regard to the details of the Chicago Convention have been concluded. This morning ex-Gov. Black made a brief call and then, accompanied by ex-Secretary Root, took the 10 o'clock train for New York.

There are interesting rumors about Mr. BRYAN. Some of his friends say that he has already made his plans for St. Louis. He will try to stampede the Convention. There will be apparently no delegates instructed for BRYAN, and those instructed for Mr. HEARST will not be sufficiently numerous even for obstruction.

That the Jesse Lewisohn contempt case again will be taken on the protracted round of the higher courts before District Attorney Jerome will be in a position to make him yield up the secrets affecting Richard A. Canfield was intimated plainly when the young banker appeared before Supreme Court Justice Dugro yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus.

A meeting of the stockholders of the Empire Trust Company was held yesterday, and the following permanent Directors were elected to replace the temporary board installed when the Empire Trust Company was merged recently with the McVickar Realty Trust Company. The following Directors were chosen:

LOS ANGELES, May 19. -- Three additional Bishops were elected to-day at the Methodist General Conference, Dr. W.F. McDowell of New York and Dr. Henry Spellmeyer of Newark on the second ballot, which was announced at the morning session, and Dr. J.W. Bashford of Delaware, Ohio, chosen on the fourth ballot late this afternoon.

While a little girl about eighteen months old, the only daughter of a young Sutherlandshire crofter, living about a mile from Invershin Station, on the Highland Railway, was playing at her father's cottage door on Saturday evening, an eagle swooped down, gripped her in its claws, and carried her off to the mountains, where some hours later her dead and mutilated body was found by a gamekeeper.

LONDON, May 19. -- A deputation from the Jewish Board of Deputies visited the home office to-day for the purpose of offering objection to some of the clauses of the Alien Immigration bill, which many Jews believe had its origin in Anti-Semitism.

The disposition now announced to have been made of Fraunces's Tavern is the best that could possibly have been made. It is always a more affecting proof of interest in a public project if those who advocate it put their hands into their own pockets to promote it than if they try to insert them into the Public Treasury for that purpose.

PITTSBURG, May 19. -- Roscoe Miller, the pitcher who was cast adrift last season by Manager McGraw of the New York Club, to-day materially assisted in beating his old team mates by the close score of 2 to 1. The New Yorks made a ninth-inning rally, however, which scared the crowd and made the Pittsburg players look anxious.

The Governors of the Consolidated Exchange held another long meeting yesterday, and expelled Andress S. Floyd and Frank B. Crawford, the partners in the suspended firm of Floyd, Crawford Co., from membership. This, it was stated officially, was the only business done, and it followed upon the continued refusal of Messrs. Floyd and Crawford to appear before the Governors to make answer to charges.

A ruling which was made yesterday by Judge Holt of the United States District Court, when he directed a bankrupt member of the Stock Exchange to sell his seat for the benefit of his creditors, upsets all the precedents of the Exchange. The Exchange has never recognized any judicial order for the sale of a seat.
WELDON, N.C., May 19. -- A negro tramp was lynched at Seaboard N.C., last night by a crowd of his own race for an assault upon a seven-year-old negro child.

Some one in Pittsburg yesterday, discovering that John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and Henry Frick, with some friends, had arrived in that city in the private car of President Cassatt of the Pennsylvania, evolved a report that there was a big scheme on hand to settle the "Pennsylvania-Gould fight" by turning over the Eastern Gould properties to the Pennsylvania.

GYANG-TSE, May 19. -- A British force made a sortie this morning in order to clear a house 600 yards from the compounds, which the Tibetans had occupied with sixty men. Everything was carried out successfully just before dawn. Our casualties were insignificant. The enemy resisted a quarter of an hour, and it was necessary to blow in the main doors.

CAPE HAITIEN, Haiti, May 19. -- Dominican Government troops, commanded by Gen. Raoul Cabrera, and Dominican revolutionary troops, led by Gen. Pelico Lasala and other Generals, met recently at Guayacanes, (Santo Domingo,) midway between Santiago de los Caballeros and Monte Cristi.

There were a few more shares sold yesterday than on Wednesday, but not enough to enable the market chronicler to describe it as active. And while advances and declines were a trifle more evenly divided, there were not enough of either to give any special tone to the day's business.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 19. -- There were several additions to-day to the list of Summer residents who are occupying their Newport homes, and several additional rentals were announced to-day.

A fire which resulted in but little damage, but which caused great excitement in the busy district, occurred yesterday afternoon in the Brooklyn Borough Hall. The blaze started among some papers in a desk in the private chambers of Justice Almet F. Jenks of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, on the third floor of the building.

Sir William Lee-Warner's life of the Marquis of Dalhousie is in two large octavo volumes, Vol. I. includes the period from Dalhousie's birth in 1812 to the year 1852, the second volume continuing his career to the day of his death in December, 1860. There are several illustrations and one or two maps.

BALTIMORE, May 20. -- Col. Robert Girard Mitchell, a Marylander and the uncle of the late Edwin Booth, the actor, died in Atlantic City Wednesday, and the remains were buried in the Booth family lot in Greenmount Cemetery here to-day.

CINCINNATI, May 20. -- Roth's single in the ninth inning alone saved Philadelphia from being shut out without a hit in the game with the Cincinnatis to-day. Lush was retired after the first inning. Brackenridge, who succeeded him, was just as easy.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- An advance of 2 1/2 cents in the price of May wheat was followed by a sharp break of 4 3/8 cents to-day. The erratic actions of the May option resulted from speculative manoeuvres attending the scarcity of wheat for present use. Closing figures on May were unchanged from yesterday's final quotations.

Why Mrs. H. Le Roy Jones left home as yet remains a dark secret, but if she did it, as first suggested by her husband's lawyer, in order "to work out her own destiny" in the glare of the footlights, the latest story circulated in connection with her disappearance and vouched for by the legal representative of the family, should do her a whole lot of good when the theatrical season opens.

The Macmillan Company announces second printings of the new paper-covered editions of James Lane Allen's "Choir Invisible" about to be published, and Merwin and Webster's "Calumet K," and that Dr. Streeter's "Fat of the Land" is already in its fourth edition.

READING the autobiography of Herbert Spencer and the latest volume of Carlyle's letters, one is forcibly reminded of the importance and prominence of the human stomach. Both books contain constant references to the stomachs of their authors, and it is evident to the reader, however important philosophy may have been to Spencer and however great "eternities" may have seemed to Carlyle, the respective stomachs of the two men were really their chief concern.

BUFFALO, May 20. -- Action looking to the union of the Northern and Southern Presbyterians was taken by the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States to-day. On motion of Dr. Tunis Hamlin of Washington, this resolution was adopted, with only one dissenting vote:

BOSTON, Mass., May 20. -- The Financial News says: "We are informed that Henry M. Rogers has turned over to Benjamin F. Thayer the entire management of the Amalgamated Copper Company. Mr. Thayer is to be supreme in all that concerns the company, and will dictate its policy both as regards its actual business management and its policy with respect to the Montana situation.

In the various letters approving or criticising Mrs. Atherton's expressions concerning bourgeois, none of the writers clearly defines the meaning of the word, which is transplanted from the French language. The real meaning is the resident of a bourg or small town, with the tastes, habits, and appearance of such differing widely from a Parisian. In France one sees signs with "Cuisine Bourgeois."

The translation by Col. W.H.H. Waters, R.A., C.V.O., late Military Attache of the British Embassy at Berlin, of the official German scientific work on "The War in South Africa" is interesting because the views expressed are the reverse of those in the German press and the men in the field.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 20. -- The views prevailing in high official naval circles relative to the disaster to the Japanese warships Hatsuse and Yoshino were set forth in the following statement to-day to the correspondent of The Associated Press:

This volume appears upon the hundredth anniversary of the event which it commemorates. It is a reprint of a book, now rare, prepared by William Coleman, the first editor of The Evening Post, in which he preserves a record of the impression made by this most famous duel in our political annals -- an impression which has scarcely been surpassed by the assassinations of Lincoln, Garfield, and McKinley.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Mr. Perdicaris, the wealthy American resident of Tangier, Morocco and his stepson, a British subject, who were captured by brigands, have been carried into the mountains, where pursuit is almost impossible. Consul General Gummere, who sends this information, reports that no terms have been received from the brigand chief.

Upward of $1,000,000 was appropriated by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday for the construction of new public baths. Of this sum, $633,000 is for four baths in Manhattan, $345,000 for three in Brooklyn, and $75,000 for one in the Bronx.

The games yesterday in the major leagues resulted in several notable changes in the standing of the teams, the most conspicuous being the dropping of the New York team from first to third place in the National League. Chicago's victory over McGraw's team placed the Western nine in the lead, while Cincinnati took second place by its easy defeat of Philadelphia.

E.G. Bruckman of 32 Broadway, a stockholder in the Commonwealth Trust Company, successor to the Trust Company of the Republic, has addressed a letter to the stockholders of the institution asking them to join him in action to recover any assets that may have been dissipated through the connection of the company with the United States Shipbuilding flotation.
TOKIO, May 20. -- Vice Admiral Togo's full report of the loss of the battleship Hatsuse and cruiser Yoshino is as follows:

William Butler Yeats has been taken to task by Clement Shorter for calling Lady Gregory's "Cuchulain of Muirthemne" the best book that has come out of Ireland in his time. Mr. Yeats, writing to The London Daily News about Mr. Shorter's objection, says:
Having been a constant reader of your very fine paper, I was very much astonished at the course you have taken regarding the Western Union Telegraph Company versus poolrooms.

Mr. M.L. Johnson's suggestion is better than mine, of course, but we cannot each buy a lonely estate for the express purpose of reading ghost stories there. I, too, had an uncle with a country house and a library when I was younger -- but have not now.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 20. -- Because he felt that he had been snubbed when Miss Ruth Wetmore was chosen to be sponsor for the battleship Rhode Island, Gov. Lucius F.C. Garvin, two days before the launching, on April 25, wrote a letter of inquiry to President Roosevelt, inquiring why he was not consulted about it.

The scope of the new book by Prof. William Harrison Woodward, author of "Vittorino da da Feltre," is indicated by its title, "Desiderius Erasmus Concerning the Aim and Method of Education." In studying Erasmus, the author points out in his preface, he has repeatedly read treatises, prefaces, and letters pertinent to the subject.
May I call to your attention several apparently unintentional errors in a criticism appearing in your columns on Monday, under the title "Performance of 'Hamlet' by High School Boys"?

Word was received from Albany yesterday that a certificate of consolidation had been filed with the Secretary of State of five electric railway lines to form the Bronx Traction Company. The total capitalization of the new company is $585,000, and it will be run as part of the Union Railway Company, Edward A. Maher being President of the five companies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20. -- Unusual interest attaches to the annual track meet between Harvard and Yale, to be held in the stadium on Soldiers' Field to-morrow. Seven first places are conceded to Yale, but it has been several years since so many events promised close contests.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Many Republicans look upon the split in the party in Wisconsin as likely to cause serious trouble in the campaign. They fear that, no matter how the National Convention may decide between the two sets of delegates, the State will be lost, a Democratic Governor and State officials be elected, and not impossibly the Electoral vote given to the Democratic candidate for President.

PROF. SHALER'S latest proof of his surprising literary productiveness and versatility is a book written with the same ease of manner that was so eminently characteristic of the author's former books, "The Individual" and "The Citizen."

In "The Deliverance" Miss Glasgow has spoken clearly and fearlessly of the depths in life and living whither she has penetrated to see the true significance of things, as another woman, greatest of novelists, saw them a generation ago. I hear criticisms and faultfindings echo around me. Victor Hugo trifled with realism, I am told, and Miss Glasgow has likewise offended in giving rein to imagination.
We suppose one may be forgiven for groaning in spirit over a novel beginning "Early in the year 1400," even though it opens with a wedding feast in the sumptuous days of Charles VI. of France.

Dr. T. Clifford Allbutt has compiled a little volume for his "own" students containing "Notes on the Composition of Scientific Papers," He was inspired to write it by the many mistakes he saw when reading the compositions of students studying for the degrees of M.B. and M.D. There are two chapters in all.

WASHINGTON, May 20. -- Col. Thomas W. Symons, United States Army, entertained a dinner company this evening at his home on Lafayette Square, complimentary to Rear Admiral Walker and the other members of the Isthmian Canal Commission now in the city, Mr. Burr, Mr. Hatrod, and Mr. Grouski.

Although of pocket size, Phillip's "Handy Volume Atlas of the World," by E.G. Ravenstein, will render more efficient service than many a volume of greater bulk and higher pretensions. In a sense this atlas may be looked upon as a new edition of the Handy-Volume Atlas, first published some years ago by Philip Son of London.

David Rothschild, President of the defunct Federal Bank and head of the Globe Security Company, was convicted yesterday by a jury before Recorder Goff in General Sessions of grand larceny in the first degree, the charge being that he had stolen a promissory note valued at $10,000 from Herman D. Nessler, an old acquaintance.

It was a happy home-coming crowd that landed from the Astoria ferryboat at the foot of East Ninety-second Street in the rush hour late yesterday afternoon, and it is interesting to note that no one saw the little black dog that had his tail squeezed in the ferry gate until the pup took pains to make his presence known.

This is a breezy and unconventional account of a breezy and unconventional man; not a biography in the usual sense, nor pretending to be, still less a criticism, yet giving a clear view of the life of the novelist and playwright, especially as it was brought into contact with the stage and with theatrical people.

Several of the Presidents of trust companies in this State have called a meeting of such officials, to be held in this city on May 27, at 3 P.M., in the Trustees' room of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, for the purpose of forming a Trust Company Association of the State of New York. The call is signed by the following men:

In your issues of the 7th and 14th inst. correspondents describe some "early samplers." Never having investigated the subject, I do not know what a real early sampler is, but I have one considerably older than those mentioned. It was made by my great-grandmother, whose home was in Dedham, Mass.

The Sub-Treasury yesterday paid the balance of the money due to the Republic of Panama in connection with the purchase of the Panama Canal by the United States Government. A first payment of $1,000,000 was made some time ago, and yesterday the second payment of $9,000,000 was made. The warrant on which the cash was paid out was drawn to the order of the "Republic of Panama, J.P. Morgan Co., fiscal agents."

Miss Jessie Gleason, daughter of the late Mayor Patrick J. Gleason, attended a mass said in memory of her father in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Long Island City yesterday morning, and on leaving the church was served with a summons to appear before Surrogate Noble in connection with the former Mayor's estate.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 20. -- The sensational results of raids by the Albany police last night and to-day upon a resort in South Lansing Street, intended to break up a "growler gang." were believed until to-night to afford a sequel to the recent mysterious plundering of the family tomb on the old Livingston estate below Hudson.

A general extension of the strike of the freight handlers employed by the Marine Department of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, which will affect all the freight traffic between New York and the New England States, is now threatened as a result of the strike at Pier 19 of the Fall River Line, which started on Wednesday.

The first of a two-volume work by Walter Lowrie, author of "The Doctrine of St. John," , on "The Church and Its Organization in Primitive and Catholic Times" will shortly be brought out by Longmans, Green Co. It deals with the primitive age. The second volume will treat of the characteristic developments of Catholicism.

ST. LOUIS, May 20. -- At the second session of the World's Press Parliament, while John Ferguson of Colombo, Ceylon, was speaking, the erection of the great pipe organ in Festival Hall interfered with the convention and a request was made that the work on the organ be suspended until the session was over.
NIU-CHWANG, May 20. -- The reports of the Japanese retreat to Feng-Wang-Cheng are officially confirmed.

"I won't go into particulars. It wouldn't mean anything for me to tell you that she (Cynthia) has gold bronze hair and Russian-violet eyes, that she is tall and graceful, and strong and supple, and tender and direct, and subtle and frank, and incomprehensible and melting, and distant and gay and grave, and logical and whimsical, and ineffably dear and delectable in all of these."

GYANG-TSE, May 20. -- A party of mounted infantry with mailbags was ambushed yesterday two miles from here. The eighteen soldiers composing the escort fought gallantly, but lost one man killed, two men wounded, and seven horses killed and wounded.

A telegram sent direct from President T. Estrada Palma, in his palace in Havana, and a letter from President Roosevelt, were features of the celebration of the second anniversary of Cuban liberty at a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening. Former Secretary of War Elihu Root presided.

No such pink-toed, round-eyed, delightfully babylike baby as Josephine Daskam's Martin Brinkershoff -- familiarly known to his loving friends as Binks -- is the stray bit of humanity that wanders into the camp of Borealis and changes the lives of the rough men who had almost forgotten the sound of a baby's voice.

Jesse Lewisohn, the banker, who will not tell District Attorney Jerome what he knows about Richard Canfield's house in East Forty-fourth Street, won a victory yesterday in Part II, of the Supreme Court, where Justice Dugro granted his application for a writ of certiorari to have the Appelate Division of the Supreme Court review the proceedings before Judge McMahon and the Grand Jury which resulted in Judge McMahon committing him for contempt.

Nature books and stories of country living may be a little overdone in the present day, but they are hopeful signs of a reaction from the mad chase along stony-hearted streets of the almighty and fugacious dollar. Especially do we welcome the books that tell of homes made in the country by those who bring with them the best the city has to give.

The biennial Conference of Jewish Charities, to be held in this city within a few days, is an event of interest and importance. The magnitude and the very practical character of the work carried on by the societies and foundations to be represented cannot fail to command the respect and admiration of all who are interested in schemes of benevolence.

The promise of graduation from the ranks of the writers of interesting short stories to those of the successful novelists contained in Mr. Carryl's novelette, "The Lieutenant Governor," is continued but not quite fulfilled in "The Transgression of Andrew Vane," a much longer and more ambitious attempt.
CHARLESTON, S.C., May 20. -- George W. Murray, colored, formerly Congressman from the Third District, this evening was convicted of forgery at Sumter. The trial consumed nearly two days.

CHICAGO, May 20. -- The New York baseball team came on the home grounds leader of the National League. Two hours and a half later this same team left the field defeated by a score of 3 to 2, and consequently displaced from its high position by the local nine.

An autobiography this is said to be -- the record of a man who was much given to self-analysis, a man who lived simply, and learned thoroughly the "technique of rest." From his earliest infancy this man was one who "loved things more than people." He was not a strong child, which may have and probably did account for many of his retiring ways and habits.

When the experienced reader observes the paragraphs pullulating about some writer whom the world has agreed to forget, his suspicions are aroused and he apprehends at least a new edition. That has been the result, if not the cause, of a good deal of writing about Charles Reade which had no very evident provocation.

NORTH SYDNEY, N.S., May 20. -- The worst marine disaster in the history of the St. Lawrence River coal trade occurred today off Cape North, the northernmost point of Cape Breton, when the British steamer Turret Bay, laden with coal, and bound from Sydney to Montreal, Struck on the rocks off St. Paul's Island, and sank in deep water twenty minutes later.

This is a most comprehensive, interesting, and instructive account, told by a man of unquestionable vigor and earnestness, of conditions past and present in the Philippines, as found in history and by the personal observation of a zealous, broad-minded, and intensely practical missionary of the Methodist Church, a man who went to the Philippines with six years of experience in India to prepare him for another part of the field in Asia.

Yesterday's business was the smallest and dullest of this dull and idle week, and the movement of prices was worthy of the stolidity of tone. Among fifty active stocks there was just one alteration of a point, and that an advance. Among the fractional changes advances ruled, so that such tone as there was was firmer.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 20. -- The Brooklyns were beaten to-day in the first game of a series of four by St. Louis, by a score of 4 to 0. It was a pitchers' contest for six innings, neither team scoring a run, but in the seventh and eighth innings, aided by fielding errors, the local nine scored four runs.

Mr. Edgar Stanton Maclay calls attention to one of our naval officers during the Revolutionary period whose claims for undaunted courage and devotion have in large measure been overlooked. As commander of the Merrimac, in the first years of the nineteenth century, Brown is best known. It is this gallant man's early adventures which the author gives in detail.

In this elaborate examination of the period in which the authority of the Church was first seriously questioned, and in which the influence of the new classical learning began to make itself felt, a Catholic historian has presented the Catholic view. The Catholic Church, says Mr. Stone, made friends with the Renaissance of letters, out of her broad sympathies.

There is nothing poetic about a "cold in the head," and yet Dr. A.R. Baker starts his lecture on "Coughs, Colds, and Catarrh, How to Avoid," (Cleveland, Ohio: The Arthur A. Clark Company,) with a poem singing of the horrors of that very trouble. After this amiable preamble he plunges into a serious yet untechnical discussion of the sensible and rational manner to go about avoiding "colds."

For the information of your correspondent who inquires for a geography and map in use when he was a schoolboy in the forties, I will state that my schooldays were mostly in the thirties, and I studied from Olney's Geography and Atlas. I do not remember that the "Louisiana Purchase" was a marked feature on the map, but the district now covered by many States was designated the "Great American Desert."

It is refreshing to find a lawyer, and one of high standing and long experience, ready to own that the criminal law, as it is now interpreted and applied, follows certain traditions which practically "exist for the manumission of murderers and the security of the swindling world in general."

MISS ELEANOR HOYT is preparing for the press a new volume of short stories, entitled "Nancy's Country Christmas," after the first tale. The book is to be illustrated in color, and will be published in the Fall by Doubleday, Page Co.

AN Occidental world stands amazed to-day when compelled to acknowledge the wonderful force Japan shows in that deadly strife between herself and Russia. Brutal physical strength is, in the present century, of secondary importance.

There has been a good deal of vague discussion as to the value of college training for business men. Dr. Thwing, President of Western Reserve University and Adelbert College, has had the happy idea of consulting business men in several important branches, combining their views with others publicly expressed, and commenting on them from his own point of view.

Senator McCarren received a severe blow in the fight being made by Tammany on his reorganization when yesterday afternoon William Brennan informed the Senator that he (Brennan) had decided to cast his political fortunes with the anti-McCarren forces. Brennan is the Deputy Tenement House Commissioner for Brooklyn, and is the Democratic leader in the Thirteenth Assembly District.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 20. -- High Admiral Grand Duke Alexis has received the following dispatch, bearing to-day's date, from Viceroy Alexieff:

One of the most important cases on the classification of wool which has come before the Board of General Appraisers for a long time was heard yesterday by Sub-Board No. 3, consisting of Judges Waite, Somerville, and Eugene G. Hay. It involved the duty on 72,930 okes of Syrian wool at the rate of either 7 or 4 cents a pound.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 20. -- Information has been received here that Boundless, winner of the $50,000 American Derby of 1893, has fallen and broken his neck on a farm eight miles from here. Boundless was by Harry O'Fallon-Endless, and it is said made a fortune for his owner, J.E. Cushing of Minneapolis, when he won the American Derby. He had not raced since the Chicago World's Fair.

Frank Wolf, who has won local fame as the "worst boy in Jersey City," was arraigned before Judge Blair, in the Quarter Sessions Court yesterday, on a charge of grand larceny. His head reached only a little above the table in front of the Judge's desk and Assistant Prosecutor Vickers was obliged to move him to a place where the Judge could see him.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision reversing an order of the Special Term and ordering the release of Joseph A. Farley, who was recently committed for the action of the Grand Jury by Magistrate Leroy B. Crane on the charge of grand larceny.

BOSTON, May 20. -- The suicide of Miss Kate Greene in New York to-day was due, so her relatives here say, to grief over the death of her sister Fannie several months ago. When Robert B. Greene, a retired New Bedford oil merchant, died, he left his large estate, including the house at 345 Beacon Street, to two of his three daughters. The third daughter, Mary, lives abroad.

WAS it a pessimist who wrote that the Balkan States were "a heap of refuse, always subject to spontaneous combustion"? There are some persons who, very deep in the politics of the fag-end of Europe, insist that the Balkan States really are quite innocent of all the charges brought against them, and that the constant strife is entirely due to the machinations of Russia mad Austria.

The almost limitless Northland of Canada is the subject of Mr. David T. Hanbury's volume, and the country is almost a terra incognita. To the sportsman, the naturalist, and the ethnologist, there may be found in these arctic wilds much that is interesting. The explorer, however, must be willing to face the rigors of the climate and the privations of hunger.

IN a thousand pages, with innumerable photographs to illumine the text, Capt. Otto Sverdrup has set down a very detailed and homely narrative of his expedition into the north of Greenland begun on St. Hans's day, June 24, 1898, and concluded Sept. 19, 1902.

A GHOST STORY fit to rank with the best of those recently recalled by the readers of THE BOOK REVIEW is "The Lady's Maid's Bell," one of nine admirable tales in Edith Wharton's newly published volume of collected short stories called "The Descent of Man," and the only one of them that deals with the supernatural. In truth, Mrs. Wharton's short stories are generally concerned with the very practical affairs of contemporary social life.

Police Commissioner McAdoo dealt yesterday afternoon what he hopes will prove a deathblow to the poolrooms of New York. At his direction and under his supervision simultaneous raids were made at 4 o'clock upon 7 poolroom exchanges and 15 poolrooms, 70 prisoners being taken and 152 telephone and 15 telegraph instruments confiscated.
