It is obviously a serious situation which compels so loyal a Republican and so strenuous a partisan as Senator SPOONER to head a bolting delegation from his State to the National Convention. We do not mean to say that Mr. SPOONER has the narrow mind and the indifferent conscience which ordinarily go with partisanship.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 20. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin to the Emperor, dated at Liao-Yang May 19, has been received here:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 20. -- At to-day's session of the seventh biennial convention of the General Federation of Woman's Clubs a storm of objection was raised when, after the presentation of a resolution providing for the use of ballot boxes at federation elections, a substitute was offered which provided for an oral vote by States, the ballot of each delegation being announced from the floor by the State Federation Presidents.

Gov. Odell, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, is to sail for Europe Tuesday morning, in company with his son Herbert, on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse. He will return to America in time to be present at the Republican National Convention, to be held in Chicago June 21.

There are eight stories included in this volume. Undoubtedly they are good stories of their kind, the kind with which the author has familiarized us in "The Call of the Wild." They are all about the Klondike, and that fact involves monotony. There is not much to be said in favor of that country as a field for fiction, except that it is a field which has not been worked.

Those godfathers and godmothers who gave to Anna's sister the name of Annabel made almost as much trouble for the heroine of Mr. Oppenheim's latest novel as did Annabel herself -- and that was not a little. For the sisters so closely resembled one another in looks that the similarity of names simply made confusion worse confounded.

RUPERT HUGHES has written a novel entitled "The Real New York," in which he describes the different sections of our city. A group of persons from various parts of the country -- Chicago, Terre Haute, San Francisco, and other cities -meet on a railway train entering New York.

In connection with two important and necessarily costly public improvements now in hand or about to be undertaken, Mayor McCLELLAN has at once an opportunity and a responsibility which he should not permit himself to forget. He may add to the credit of his administration the initiation of pipe galleries in New York or he may win the "reversed prestige" of failure to see what was obvious to every intelligent student of municipal development.

Another story by Mr. S.R. Crockett dealing with love, adventure, intrigue, and final reward and retribution is that of the career of "Strong Mac," a comely youth, bold and handsome, much in love with Adora Gracie, the daughter of the village dominie. And no wonder, for Adora was certainly adorable, and smart and self-reliant as well.

One purpose of "The Religion of the Universe," the new book by J. Allanson Picton, M.A., author of "New Theories and the Old Faith," "The Mystery of Matter," "The Religion of Jesus," , is to show that the issues between religion and science have no definite finality, as set forth by Herbert Spencer in his "First Principles."

LONDON, May 20. -- A new and cheaper edition of Herbert Spencer's works will be issued by Messrs. Williams Norgate. The first volume will be "The First Principles" and will sell for about $1.87, or less than half the cost of the present edition.

ELIZABETH ROBINS is certainly a woman of some extraordinary gifts. Perhaps if she had never been an actress she might have gained larger and more enduring fame as a writer. The chief quality of the best of her histrionic efforts has been intelligence -- which often counts for less in the actor's art than some other qualities.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 20. -- In the United States District Court to-day George W. Rumble was convicted of using the mail for fraudulent purposes. The case will be appealed and Rumble will be given his liberty on a bond of $10,000.

LAST Saturday, a fortnight before the date of publication, it was necessary to send a new large edition of "A Texas Matchmaker" to press, and this before the news companies have begun to send in their orders. Careful study of the advance sheets leaves one chiefly impressed by the absence of extravagance in the behavior of the cattlemen.

An agreeable change in the weather, a fast track, and an interesting programme were circumstances that added much to the enjoyment of about 10,000 visitors to the Morris Park race course yesterday, but more than these things, the fact that four post favorites passed the winning poet first, while well-backed horses won in the two remaining events, filled the crowd with satisfaction and left little to be desired.

Though yesterday's total in the stock market was the smallest of the week the tone of the market was somewhat improved, and with very few exceptions the closing prices were at advances over those of the previous day. The early recovery in Union Pacific from 82 to 83 1/2 helped sentiment a good deal, and traders became more willing to work for an advance.

Two new volumes have been added to "The Builder" Student's Series, which is issued in this country by the Macmillan Company. They are "Roads; Their Construction and Maintenance, with Special Reference to Road Materials," by Allan Greenwell and J.V. Elsden; and "Stresses and Strains; Their Calculation and that of Their Resistances, by Formulae and Graphic Methods," by Frederic Richard Farrow.

While mentally unbalanced as the result of acute nervous prostration, Miss Kate Greene, forty years old, of 345 Beacon Street, Boston, dropped from a sixth story window of the Hotel Endicott, at Columbus Avenue and Eighty-first Street, yesterday morning, receiving injuries from which she died shortly afterward in the Roosevelt Hospital.

Just now, when the building of a new home is being considered, the special issue of The Architectural Review will be of interest to architects and owners. The number contains articles on American country and suburban houses. The opening article, by Robert D. Andrews, deals with "The Changing Styles of Country Houses."

Hyben -- a name not found in encyclopedia or atlas -- is "a straggling green island" on the Hampshire coast. The "tyrants" of its northern end are two blacksmiths, not dependent upon the forge for a livelihood, men of landed property, who work at the smithy simply because their trade has come to them as an inheritance.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 21. -- The Brooklyns fared no better to-day against the local team than they did yesterday, and in a close finish were beaten by a score of three to two. The St. Louis men played a perfect fielding game and outbatted the visitors, but with the exception of the sixth inning, Jones kept the hits well apart.

The long contemplated combine of the broom manufacturers of the country now appears to stand a fair chance of becoming a reality. Representatives of many of the largest factories are now in Chicago to talk over the situation and come to some definite understanding with the Western and New York capitalists who have agreed to put up the money.

WHILE Guilford clams are not in the market because the Connecticut beds were almost ruined by the severe Winter, there is an ample supply of the delicacy from Lone Island. The bivalves are not as large as Guilfords -- the diameter of the golden belly about that of a silver dollar, but plump and succulent.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 21. -- A colored man who gave his name as Samuel Blackson was arrested by the police of the Grand Avenue Station shortly before midnight to-night. He was found on Orange Street, in the neighborhood of Humphrey Street, where last Thursday evening the daughter of a Yale professor, whose name the detective department has refused to divulge, was beaten and robbed.

OWING to a mistake in "feeding" sheets into a printing press there appeared in South Africa one sheet of five-shilling stamps on which King Edward's head is reversed. Some of the stamps got into circulation before the error was discovered, and collectors are now willing to pay about 500 times the face value of the bit of paper to secure specimens.

For the purpose of determining just how he stands in the Democratic fight in Brooklyn, Senator McCarren last night arranged to meet a score of district leaders and other influential men in the local organization in private conference this evening.

Several persons were injured, one seriously, when one Third Avenue car, crowded with people, crashed into another at Park Row and Roosevelt Street early this morning. Both were open cars. The one in charge of Motorman "Abe" Bishop was standing in front of 184 Park Row discharging some passengers when Car 1,579 of the same line, in charge of Motorman George Edwards, crashed into the rear of it.

The flurry of bucket-shop exposures through which Wall Street has been passing during the fortnight past, while not so acute as that attending the denouement of the E.S. Dean swindle, because unaccompanied by police raids, appears to be more far-reaching in its consequences, and therefore likely to produce a more lasting effect for good.

Two very angry and excited women, who said they were Mrs. Hamilton Devanney of 246 East One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street and Mrs. Daniel O'Connell of 2,403 Second Avenue, rushed into the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station last night, and Mrs. Devanney told Sergt. Jones that she was holding Mr. O'Connell's baby as security pending the return of $85 alleged to have been stolen by the other woman's husband.
COPENHAGEN, May 21. -- The Danish scientific expedition to Greenland under the leadership of Ericksen has arrived at the Danish colony of West Greenland after much hardship and suffering.

DID not Charles Lamb confess to an "almost feminine partiality to old china "? Surely with his domestic tastes, Thackeray had a liking for teapots. In one of those delightful letters of his of 1857, addressed to an American family and published in The Century of March of this year, the great romance writer of the Victorian era wrote:

MOSCOW, May 21. -- The Emperor's 2,000-mile journey through Southern Russia ended here this afternoon with a review of several sapper and engineer battalions in the courtyard of the Nicholas Station and a hurried visit to the shrine of the Iberian Virgin and the church in the Kremlin, where the Emperor was crowned.

The dinner of the Arctic Club, that is given about this time each year in honor of the "Field Workers," and which was held in the Aldine Association at 111 Fifth Avenue last evening, was made notable by the announcing of a startling theory as to the best and quickest way to discover that mysterious point of land that is situated somewhere beyond Franz Josef Land and is known as the north pole.
TIFFIN, Ohio, May 21. -- Daniel Crum, a wealthy farmer, and his hired man, Albert Rice, were shot and fatally wounded to-day by Adam Reinman, a neighbor, while at work plowing in a field.

It was announced last week at the Appraisers' Stores that the Finance Committee of the Senate had appointed a sub-committee to investigate the alleged necessity of changes in the Customs Administrative act, which formed the basis of the Payne bill introduced at the last session of Congress.

Play was continued yesterday in the championship lawn tennis tournament of the New York Lawn Tennis Club. Two matches in the doubles and one in the singles were decided, and were productive of excellent sport and drew a numerous gallery of spectators to the courts at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

The threat of Thomas Healey, walking delegate of the freight handlers' organization, to call out the freight handlers of the New York, New Haven and Hartford system along the east side river front was carried out yesterday. The orders were given early in the day, though Healey went to Fall River in the morning to extend the strike to the other piers.

The New York branch of the Army Relief Society is to give a garden party at Governors Island on Thursday, June 2, to raise emergency funds for dependent widows and orphans of officers and enlisted men of the regular army. A long programme has been prepared as follows:

After much talk and many meetings by persons and societies who recognized the need of acquiring for the public of New York an ocean park, something businesslike has at last been done by several civic and philanthropic bodies on the east side. The action taken is the selection of a committee to advocate one particular site.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 21. -- The past week was a gay one at the Hotel Rudolf, and the amusements included the season's third german, led by Miss Lotta Cummings of New York City. She had as her partner S. Freeman Kirkland of Baltimore.

NEW YORK is soon to have three more free public baths, one of which will be opened this month and the others somewhat later in the season. The first to be completed is at 347 and 349 West Forty-first Street.

The announcement last week that the entire stock of Sweetser, Pembrook Co. would be sold at auction this week and that the firm, which is one of the oldest in its line in the city, would finally go out of business, marked another step in what many believe to be the gradual extinction of the jobbing trade in this city.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 21. -- Dr. J.R. Day, the Chancellor of Syracuse University, was to-day chosen to be Bishop of the Methodist Church. He was the eighth choice of the General Conference, and was elected on the fourteenth ballot, completing the list of Bishops.

Hildebrandt, leader of the curbstone band playing in front of Alderman Haggerty's Avenue C saloon yesterday, delivered a few strains of "Meet Me at St. Louis," and then turned into the saloon, motioning for the others to follow.

Among the hundreds of young women who are studying law, at the University of New York or elsewhere, and who seem absolutely at sea as to what they intend to do with their legal lore when acquired, it is interesting to find one who has made intelligent and lucrative use of her fund of special information.

The order of Judge Holt directing Edward S. Hatch of the suspended Stock Exchange firm of Hatch Hurlburt to "execute a request" upon the Exchange to sell his seat, transfers the controversy over the disposition of that highly valuable asset of the respondent from between Mr. Hatch and his creditors into the hands of the Stock Exchange and the United States Court.

THIS war between Russia and Japan means that we shall have to throw away all our old plates of the interior of Manchuria, Korea, and Eastern Russia, and make new ones," said the New York agent of the largest map-making concern in the United States.

Poor Master Hewitt of Jersey City reports an unprecedented flight of tramps from this part of the country to St. Louis. He says that his office is besieged, as never before, by nomads seeking passes on the railroads to points in that direction.

The usual Saturday surprise was of an agreeable nature for a novelty. The market opened as it closed, stolid rather than strong, and immovable above all. But this changed in the twinkling of an eye upon the appearance of the bank statement. The reduction of cash was somewhat larger than had been expected, but there was an unexpected and large reduction of loans.

AN INTERESTING feature of the recent celebration of the ninetieth birthday of the Baroness Burdett-Coutts, in England, one which shows the esteem in which she is held by all ages and classes of people, was a gift from the little Baroness Clifton. It was a basket of La France roses with a card bearing the words: "From the youngest Baroness to the oldest Baroness."

PARIS, May 21. -- The formal announcement of the recall of M. Nisard, the French Ambassador to the Holy See, was given out this evening, and the following official statement was communicated to the press:

THE question as to the earliest usage of tobacco yet awaits solution. Chinese and Japanese annals will have to be considered. Once more the question arises, Did tobacco originate in the East or in the West, and was smoking transmitted from one continent to the other?

The scheme of the United States Realty and Construction Company for erecting gigantic twin skyscrapers, covering the old sites of the Trinity and Boreel Buildings and the small block at the rear of the latter structure, promises to be the most noteworthy building operation ever undertaken in this city.
BERLIN, May 21. -- I am informed from an excellent source that the oft-repeated rumors that the days of Count von Buelow as Chancellor are numbered are about to be confirmed.

Senator Elsberg of the Fifteenth Senate District, which comprises the Twenty-fifth, Twenty-seventh, and Twenty-ninth Assembly Districts, will have a difficult fight for renomination, if the combination just effected between the Twenty-fifth District organization, of which ex-Alderman Herbert Parsons is the head, and the Partridge- Morris-Ware-Schwartzler followers in the Twenty-ninth District, succeeds in putting the blocks in his path it is expected to.

With their hats tilted and loose strands of hair blowing over their faces, two young women alighted from a trolley car at the foot of East Thirty-fourth Street and made their way to one of the ferryboats of the Long Island Railroad.

DEAR to the heart of the old-time Southerner was the faithful "mammy" nurse, with her scarlet bandanna, snowy apron, and weird collection of ghost stories and "spook" songs. The children loved her and their parents prized her above all the servants on the plantation. Benignant and patient to a fault, the old nurse never wearied of following her restless charges through the gardens and orchards.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Naval officers here are talking about the recent heavy losses of naval vessels through the explosion of mines near Port Arthur, and it is suggested that the subject of regulating the use of such mines by international agreement will come up at the next meeting of the Naval General Board for consideration.

Awards of fifty-six scholarships for the academic year 1904-5 have just been announced by the University Council of Columbia University. One of those to receive a scholarship is Samuel Lucas Joshi, a high caste Brahmin of Madras, India. He was graduated from the University of Madras in 1896, and is now pursuing studies in political economy and finance at Columbia.

Kings and Queens of cannibal or even suspected islands are frequently exposed in song and fanciful literature in situations prejudicial to dignity, and the ex-royal LILIUOKALANI wedged in a Washington dining-room door too narrow for her bulk and unable to go either way is not the first of her kind to be exhibited in a disadvantageous and even ridiculous position.

FROM present indications the Spring floods this year will be unusually severe. To the average reader the report in a newspaper of a great flood comes as first news, yet to hundreds of thousands of people the coming of the catastrophe has been known for days, sometimes weeks, in advance.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., May 2. -- Ideal Spring weather favored the colonists at Tuxedo during the week's end, and in consequence a large gathering assembled at the clubhouses and among the cottagers. Nearly all the season's arrivals are now here, and each cottager is entertaining guests over Sunday.

CLEVELAND, May 21. -- The Twenty-first district Democrat convention to-day nominated Edmund G. Vail for Congress. Mayor Tom L. Johnson and John H. Clarke were selected as delegates to the National Convention. They were not instructed.
The Atlanta-Birmingham Fire Insurance Company has been licensed to do business in the State of Minnesota.

Conventions for the election of delegates to the Democratic National Convention were held in the week just ended in Wisconsin, Montana, California, South Carolina, Ohio, and Minnesota. In the two latter only district conventions were held.

The United States Government is making investigations and has already issued a bulletin upon the subject of rubber gathering in the Philippines. It is known that in some of the southern islands the Hevea or Para rubber tree grows as perfectly as it does upon the Amazon and its tributaries, and in all of the islands the Castilloa or Mexican rubber tree can be made to grow.

An investigation is being made by the domestic manufacturers of underwear as to the exceedingly low price at which much foreign underwear is being sold in this market. Special complaint has been made about certain lines of Swiss ribbed goods, and it is said that certain firms of importers are able to sell the goods here at less than it costs other importers to land them in this country.

WHILE Uncle Sam and the Insular Government officials of Porto Rico have been worrying a great deal over the ravages of the disease known as tropical anemia, or blood impoverishment, which is prevalent throughout the island, they have not reckoned at all apparently on the havoc caused by that other great foe to health and happiness -- nostalgia.

A NEW BOOK PLATE has just been designed for the Mayflower Society of this State to use in the books now being secured for its library. It is the first bookplate issued by any of the purely patriotic societies, and was designed by a direct descendant of the little band of men and women who made themselves and their ship famous years ago.

The contracts for the construction of the two mammoth turbine transatlantic liners that the Cunard Company is going to operate between Liverpool and New York have been signed. These great ships, which the Cunards insist must be the fastest vessels that ever plied the Atlantic, will be built by John Brown Co. and Swan, Hunter Wigham, Richardson.

Chicago's leadership in the National League was of short duration, for with McGinnity pitching, the New Yorks turned the tables on their conquerors of the previous day and did not allow them to score a run. Twenty thousand persons witnessed the contest, which was an unusually large crowd for a week day at Chicago.

Bridge Commissioner Best met representatives of the New York City Railway, the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, and the Coney Island and Brooklyn yesterday, and the contract providing for the running of cars over the Williamsburg Bridge was signed. The contract itself literally is between the Bridge Company and the city, the Bridge Company being owned by the three street railroad systems.

CURIOSITY as to the personality of Tom Browne, the English artist, has been aroused among our readers by his remarkable series of impressions, drawn expressly for THE NEW YORK TIMES, and now in course of publication. Perhaps this curiosity can best be satisfied by this sympathetic sketch written by Mr. Mark Sullivan of Boston, and published last week in The Transcript of that city, just after Mr. Brown sailed for Europe.

ORANGE, N.J., May 21. -- Six Newark school teachers -- Miss Lou K. Beardsley, Miss Jane Schaeffer, Miss Elsie Johnson, Miss S. Mailison, Miss Mary North, and Miss E.N. Davis -- journeyed to the South Mountain Park this afternoon on a botanizing expedition. Botanizing is not allowed in the park, and Policeman O'Brien says he told the visitors they must not do it.

The American liner St. Louis came up the bay yesterday afternoon on her arrival from Southampton with her flags at half-mast for Joseph Humphreys, Charles Frohman's general stage director, who died on board at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning shortly after the vessel had passed Nantucket.

LONDON, May 21. -- The approach of the Whitsuntide holidays had the usual effect of restricting business on the Stock Exchange this week, dealings being influenced by a desire on the part of the brokers to leave their affairs as snug as possible on Friday night, when the house closed for three days.

THE Fourth of July is not a distinctly American institution. To be sure, it happens to be Independence Day for the United States, and more than a century and a quarter of observances of that great event have brought it about that the signing of the charter of American liberties in the old State House in Philadelphia on that date overshadows all else when the holiday arrives.

NEARLY all of the gowns and the blouses made in Paris are collarless. Sometimes they are merely rounded out at the neck, and then again they are cut pointed in both the back and the front, or at the front only. In the tailored costumes, with coat and skirt, of course stocks are worn.

With the general improvement shown in bonds within the past month or two the gains made in the Jersey issues traded in on the curb have attracted as much attention as any. Some of the issues in question are regularly quoted, but very seldom have transactions in them been reported up to the beginning of April.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The young men who have been eating poisons under the direction of the Agricultural Department and the immediate administration of Prof. Wiley, since January last, have been graduated, so to speak, and to-day resumed the diet of the ordinary person.

LONG BRANCH, May 21. -- The cottages here are rapidly filling up for the season, and the activity of Long Branch has begun. The town is now governed by the Coult Charter act, which was adopted last Tuesday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 21. -- The many reasons that combine to make Lakewood an ideal Spring resort have induced several of the cottagers to plan to linger here through June. The Laurel House has a good patronage, and the Rhinelanders, de Peysters, and other well-known New Yorkers who have season apartments at that hotel will remain until the close.

That the man chiefly responsible for the looting of the Federal Bank should be convicted of the vulgar crime of grand larceny is in a way satisfactory. It stamps him with the infamy he justly earned in the transaction for which he was tried and puts him personally a little below the level of the footpad who faces the risk of being resisted and hurt in his operations.
NEW ORLEANS, May 21. -- A verdict for $28,390 was given in favor of the Sewerage and Water Board of New Orleans against the National Contracting Company in the United States District Court to-day.

NEWARK, May 21. -- Argument on the application of E.H. Harriman to restrain the Northern Securities Company and the Equitable Trust Company from distributing the Northern Pacific stock on the proposed plan was continued here to-day. Former Secretary of War Elihu Root, for the defendants, resumed his argument. Mr. Root contended that the differences in the price of the Northern Pacific stock prompted the present suit.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 21. -- The Government to-day received news confirmatory of the rumors in circulation here that Gen. Stoessel has made a successful sortie from Port Arthur, resulting in the defeat of the Japanese, with the loss of over 1,000 killed or wounded. The Russian losses were 116 killed or wounded.

ROME, May 21. -- France has practically broken off diplomatic relations with the Holy See. M. Nisard, her Ambassador to the Vatican, acting under instructions from Paris, left Rome to-night on an unlimited vacation.

A TINY mite of five years attracted more attention and more applause at the recent military tournament on the afternoon of his appearance than any one or anything else. He was drum major of a drum corps formed of nineteen other midgets, none over six, but none of whom, however, was quite as diminutive as himself.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 21. -- John Newcomb of Dover, a shoemaker at Sussex and Clinton Streets, occasionally sends Nero, his big Newfoundland dog, to fetch his luncheon from home.

H.C. Schradeick of the Brooklyn Boys' High School, in the dual athletic meet held between Polytechnic Preparatory School and the Brooklyn Boys' High School yesterday, at Grand Street Park, Brooklyn, won the half-mile and one-mile runs.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 21. -- In their last boat race of the season here this afternoon the midshipmen defeated both the first and second crews from Georgetown University in record-breaking time.

Engagements for next week's shipments make the total exports of gold $60,000,000. No larger sum was ever sent in the same period, nor under such remarkable circumstances. On the movement of merchandise foreign buyers owe us $26,000,000 for last month's balance, and $449,000,000 for ten months.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Cauldwell will leave Morristown about June 15 and go to the Adirondacks, where they will spend the Summer. Their house on Elm Street will not be closed, as it has been leased to New York parties for three months.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- Rumors are current in railroad circles that a new deal between Hill and Harriman is contemplated whereby the Northern Pacific will practically become a part of the Harriman system.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 21. -- Details of Rear Admiral Wittsoeft's mail dispatch to Viceroy Alexieff, (transmitted by telegraph yesterday to High Admiral Grand Duke Alexis,) which were not made public, establish the fact that mines planted by the Russian torpedo boats were responsible for the destruction of the Hatsuse and the damage sustained by another battleship of the Fuji type off Port Arthur.

Despite much early doubt in Wall Street about the possibility of successfully floating a foreign loan in this market, the principal difficulty encountered by the syndicate that had charge of floating half of the $50,000,000 Japanese loan in New York was in giving banking houses enough share in the syndicate to satisfy them.

As a resident of nearly ten years in Tangier, Morocco, and as possibly the most intimate friend in America of Messrs. Perdicaris and Varley, the victims of the outrageous act of brigandage reported in THE TIMES, it has seemed to the writer wise to address the public, giving facts regarding the present conditions and those leading up to the abduction by brigands of these unfortunate gentlemen.
THE eighteenth century beau was accustomed to view life through a monocle mounted on a long handle of gold or pinchbeck.

When Venice comes to New York and puts up at the Madison Square Garden Summer is indeed at hand. Once again Conductor Duss will give nightly concerts in the large building, and the gondolas will make their leisurely way around the Grand Canal. To-night Venice's New York season opens with a flourish.

ALBANY, May 21. -- Oneida County, comprising the Thirty-fourth Senatorial District, promises to be again this Fall the arena of a lively political fight. It has been the field of many a battle royal from before the times of Horatio Seymour and Roscoe Conkling.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 21. -- Mrs. Cordova, wife of the Rev. J.R. Cordova, pastor of the South River Methodist Church, who disappeared after conducting a prayer meeting with his pretty choir singer, Miss Julia Bowne, has sworn out a warrant for the arrest of her husband on a charge of desertion.

Although there is no precedent for the action of President ROOSEVELT in confiscating the films for a representation by kinematograph of a scene on the Capitol grounds in Washington, one cannot but sympathize with his desire to stop the burlesque. Strictly speaking, it was a high-handed proceeding which might establish a precedent.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 21. -- The announcement is made that the California. Fruit Agency, the big merger company in control of the packing and shipping of a large part of the orange crop of Southern California, will go out of business next September.

Staten Island formally acknowledged, declared, and gloried yesterday afternoon that she was an integral part of the Greater New York on the occasion of the laying of the cornerstone of the Richmond Borough Hall at St. George. The ceremonies attendant on the laying of the cornerstone were elaborate.

LENOX, May 21. -- Lady Henry Mortimer Durand, wife of the British Ambassador, has selected the Judge Bishop cottage, on Court House Hill, as the Summer residence of the British Embassy. Sir Henry and Lady Durand will arrive the first week in June, and will remain in Lenox until late in September.

Not since Richard Croker issued his famous closing order to all the poolrooms in New York and that order was carried out to the letter by Superintendent of Police Thomas Byrnes has that particular branch of industry suffered such a serious setback in this city as it did yesterday, following the wholesale raids by Police Commissioner McAdoo's men.

BY watching the Columbia University crews in practice on the Harlem these early Spring afternoons, it is easy to note the vim put into the men by Edwin Gould's ten-thousand-dollar gift for the endowment of a Professor of Rowing. Nor is the new enthusiasm confined to the men in the boats.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- The police to-day raided the office of the Baldwin Cotton Company and arrested two men who gave their names as A.J. Emerest and Gerald Eberman. The prisoners are charged with operating a "get-rich-quick" scheme.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 21. -- The annual run of the New York Coaching Club this year was from New York to Blairsden, the home of C. Ledyard Blair, at Peapack, N.J. The day was perfect for coaching and every one was in fine spirits when the coach left the Metropolitan at 10 o'clock in the morning, exactly on schedule time.
ST. LOUIS, May 21. -- In her address on the education of women last evening before the National Federation of Women's Clubs President Thomas of Bryn Mawr College spoke as follows:
A Massachusetts lady who has been through the rnill with the trials of the -, usual housekeeper and mother relates an interesting incident that occurred not'
"I was mighty glad to hear of the leasing of W.L. Stow's country place down near Westbury," remarked the broker, who pays a good deal of attention to that sort of property.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, May 21. -- The cornerstone of the machine shop of the Farmers' Co-Operative Machine Company was laid this afternoon in the presence of 1,500 people. The principal addresses were made by S.H. Ellis, of the National Grange, General J. Warren Keifer and A.O. Bradfute, President of the International Livestock Association.

A Japanese doctor of medicine publishes a treatise concerning the odor of the Occidental races, sustaining the proposition that at first the Orientals do not like it. They grow used to it in time, however, and finally, with continued experience, do not notice it at all. It seems to be his opinion that each race has its peculiar fragrance, that it is partly radical, but is in a measure influenced by dietary and other conditions.

PLAINFIELD, May 21. -- New Market, the home of Mayor William Smith, the late Mrs. Charles L. Fair's brother, is to have a fire engine and a public library, gifts of the new philanthropist. The Mayor announced to-day that he would start on his trip to St. Louis on Tuesday morning, although his big racing auto has not arrived.

NEW YORKERS seem to appreciate their own town, which is at its best in the Springtime. The travel abroad has not been heavy, and already the tide is turning. Within a fortnight many of those who sailed in the Lenten time will have returned. Newport cottagers also are overhauling their houses, ready for an early and a brisk season.

Two dispatches from The London Times's correspondents in Russia, published in our columns yesterday morning, throw light on the recent experience of Russia in her attempts to promote national riches by arbitrary and violent means.

Men and women fought fiercely, at Twentieth Street and Sixth Avenue last night, in their frantic efforts to get out of a burning street car, and when they did finally succeed n getting off it was with badly torn clothing.

CHICAGO, May 21. -- English Lad, the heavily backed favorite, won the Chicago Derby at Hawthorne to-day by half a length in a fierce drive with Prince Silver Wings. Moharib, winner of the Kansas City Derby, was third. The mile and a quarter was covered in 2:06, a fraction of a second slower than English Lad took in his try-out over the same distance a few days ago.

LONDON, May 11. -- Mme. Melba made her first appearance for the season at the Covent Garden Opera House last night to a house crowded with fashionable Londoners in their most gorgeous costumes and jewels. The Queen and the Prince and Princess of Wales occupied the royal box, and in all the big opera house there was not a box or a stall vacant after 10 o'clock, and upstairs the crowd was standing two deep.

THERE was once a time when nobody could hear of a great scientific discovery without having a mental picture of a dreamy, hermitlike student who buried himself in his laboratory among nasty fluids and disagreeable gaseous odors. Such an impression no longer holds good.

BERLIN, May 14. -- Germany will send teams to St. Louis to take part in swimming, turning, lawn tennis, wrestling, and rowing contests. The last-named sport, owing to the initiation of the Kaiser, in recent years has been especially developed in Germany. This above all is true of Berlin, as is shown by the large number of fine rowing clubhouses found on the Spree.

NORFOLK, Va., May 21. -- In the United States Court to-day Mrs. Naomi K. Sheridan of New York entered suit for $15,000 against the Standard Oil Company for injuries she alleges she sustained in a recent collision between the yacht Diana, owned by Mr. Sheridan, and the yacht Petrolia, owned by the Standard Oil Company.

WILL Castlegould, the largest and most wonderful residence yet conceived by an American, ever be completed? This is a question that architects all over this land, and other persons familiar with the scope of Howard Gould's mammoth undertaking, have been trying to answer for more than three years.

The United States battleship Kentucky, which for the past three years has been the flagship of the China squadron, arrived here yesterday flying the flag of Rear Admiral Robley D. Evans. She is now at anchor off Tompkinsville, after making a warship record by her run from Hong Kong, covering the distance of 12,699 miles at an average speed of 12.7 knots, following a 9,000 mile run from the China station to Honolulu and back.

London, May 10. AT last somebody has come to the defense of that inscription in the Blackmore Memorial: "This tablet with the window above are a tribute of admiration and affection to the memory of Richard Doddridge Blackmore." The letter this new-comer has written about the inscription has given a decided turn to the controversy that has raged over it.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, May 9. -- The Americanization of Porto Rico is a thing of years. There is much to be done before the majority of the people here, uneducated and simple as they are, can be made successful American citizens. But there is no doubt that these particular descendants of the Latins and Indians have some peculiar attributes which we in our zeal to reform should neither make over nor endeavor to better.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., May 21. -- Four bodies of persons drowned during last night's floods have been recovered. A number of persons are still missing.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- Wilbur F. Wakeman has been in conference with such Republican leaders as are in Washington. Mr. Wakeman is the wheelhorse of the American Protective Tariff League, the citadel of the "stand-patters." He believes that the tariff is the principal issue at this time and that it will be the thing in the approaching campaign.
ST. LOUIS, May 21. -- The National Federation of Women's Clubs concluded the first week of its convention this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 21. -- The State Department has paid over to J.P. Morgan Co., the fiscal agents of the Panama Government the remaining $9,000,000 of the sum stipulated in the treaty as the consideration for the canal concession.

LONDON, May 14. -- It is only the sanguine-minded who look to find substantial, permanent, desirable political effect from the King's visit to Ireland. There was less deliberate aloofness displayed than was threatened. There would have been less still had there not been keenly jealous supervision.

The poolroom men may well take alarm at the sternness and sufficiency of the measures which Police Commissioner McADOO has taken to drive them out of business. He has found the weak point in their system. Poolrooms are a device for extending far beyond the limits of the race track the area within which betting on horse races is possible.

In 1870 there were 2,001,293 farms in the United States. According to the last census there were 5,739,000 in 1900. The advance in the value of farm products was from a fraction less than $2,000,000,000 in 1870 to $3,764,000,000 in 1900. In 1870 there were 5,888,987 persons engaged in farming, while in 1900 the number had grown to 10,483,000.

PARIS, May 21. -- M. Paul Doumer's election to the Chairmanship of the Budget Commission is undoubtedly a hard knock for M. Combes, though it is too soon to declare, as the anti-Ministerialist papers do, that the "bloc" is breaking up and the Cabinet has only a few days to live.

Justice MacLean in the Supreme Court yesterday decided that in the interests of the public the interlocutory decree of divorce granted to Lillian Nordica, the singer, from Zoltan Deome, in January last, must be reopened and sent to a referee for the purpose of ascertaining whether the divorce was secured by fraud and collusion.
EXCUSE me, Sir, while I go and see if I can't please that crank woman.

The annual Spring and Summer season of opera at the Orpheum Theatre will begin to-morrow night with a presentation of "The Fortune Teller." The three principal comedy characters will be portrayed by Robert Lett as Fresco, Herman Hirschberg as Boris, and Phil Bransonas as the old Count.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21. -- Yale defeated Harvard in the dual track and field meet on Soldiers' Field to-day by the score of 57 7-12 points to 46 5-12, the fractional points being due to ties in the pole vault and the high jump. There were the usual thirteen events, with five points counted for a first place, two for a second and one for a third in each.

As a finale in a deliriously exciting afternoon's racing at the Morris Park race course yesterday. Hermis, with the top weight of 128 pounds, cantered in winner in ridiculously easy style and fast time, and by his remarkable and unexpected victory leaped into a place of prominence for the Brooklyn Handicap, to be run on Thursday at the Gravesend track.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21. -- In a contest in doubt until the last event was run off, Princeton won from Cornell this afternoon in a dual track meet by the score of 59 1/2 points to 44 1/2. Princeton started off with Miller, capturing the 100-yard dash from Sears. Chapin took the mile run from Trott in the fast time of 4:29.

The managers of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, yielding to an almost unprecedented pressure of adverse public opinion, have appointed a committee to "investigate in detail the accounts and affairs of the society, with power to employ an auditing company."
There is a pretty good-sized hard coal tonnage being mined and disposed of, as one may judge from the following schedule:

MACON, Ga., May 21. -- A tragic sequel to the crash early in the week of the private bank of I.C. Plant's Sons and the First National Bank came this afternoon, when Robert H. Plant, the head of both institutions, committed suicide, thereby making available over $1,000,000 life insurance for payment on liabilities of about $800,000 of the two banking institutions.

It would have saved trouble had the Treasury Department impressed on the Ways and Means Committee the need of a specific provision in the tariff for "legs of all kinds." A perplexing and tedious case for customs officers and the department itself was that involving the rate of duty on an imported cork leg, which was finally rated as "family supplies."

TOUCH IN' on and appertainin' to this here poolroom business," said the former Chief of Police, "Big Bill" Devery, the other day, "the game of talk that these Western Union people are putting up reminds me of a feller we got once who was makin' very superior sectional jimmies.
BERLIN, May 21. -- The Vorwaerts, the Berlin Socialist organ, prints the following remarkable manifesto sent by Japanese Socialists to Russians:

Apparently the checking of the column which formed the extreme right of Gen. KUROKI'S advance is a vindication of the superior efficiency of the Russian cavalry, a superiority which has not been disputed, but had not before been manifested. According to Gen. McCLELLAN'S similitude, "cavalry are the antennae of an army."

DRS. SOLLIER AND COMAR, both Parisian specialists in the study of hysteria, state that they have discovered the existence of a new and remarkable sort of power of second sight in certain patients. Instances of the form of vision in which the seer perceives at dusk, under certain conditions, his own double are well known to the scientific investigator as well as to the romance writer.

ROME, May 22. -- The Pope said mass this morning in the presence of sixty-four Italians and foreigners, and gave up the rest of the day to the consideration of the difficulties with France, reading clippings from the newspapers on the subject.
Allow me to suggest what I think would prove very attractive if placed in the proper language and inserted in the next platform of the Democratic Party.

The lives of more than a hundred passengers on a suburban train of the New York, New Haven and Hartford were imperilled in a peculiar accident that occurred at One Hundred and Thirty-first Street and Brook Avenue yesterday afternoon. The train consisted of five passenger coaches, which were being pushed by engine No. 224, in charge of Engineer James Bynes.

A fire that did considerable damage to the telegraph and electric light wires of the Edison Company occurred in the subway at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fulton Street yesterday morning, its exact location being the same as that of the fire that paralyzed telegraphic and telephone service in the down-town district on April 6.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 22. -- Out of a party of five thrown from a carriage in a runaway accident here to-day only Mrs. Helen Herring, who is past eighty-five, and her greatniece, who is just five, escaped injury. Mrs. Henry Banta, a niece of Mrs. Herring, was the most seriously hurt. Her right leg was broken in four places and her face was cut.

The marine firemen and oilers on the lines controlled by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Company who quit work originally in sympathy with the freight handlers at the Fall River piers at the foot of Warren Street have now changed their attitude into a general demand for an increase in wages from $40 to $45 a month. According to the strikers this demand will be made on all the coastwise steamship lines.

The $35,000,000 5 per cent. bonds of the Republic of Cuba, due 1944, which recently were purchased by Speyer Co., have been privately sold to a considerable amount. The loan has a practically unique interest in that it is the first loan issued after the acceptance by the Cuban Republic of the so-called Platt amendment.

Pacers furnished the best of the Sunday morning sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday. The footing was ideal for fast work when the contests opened with a half-mile tilt between Don Derby, (2:04 1/2,) winner of the 1903 Speedway pacing championship, driven by John Kelly, and Nathan Straus, (2:05 1/4,) driven by his owner, Joseph Meyer of Newark, N.J.

AT SEA ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMER HAIMUN, May 22. -- Although the Japanese Government is still prohibiting the movement of the Haimun into the real theatre of war, yet it is possible in these waters to form a more accurate estimate of the conditions of the struggle than hitherto has been the ease.

VLADIVOSTOK, May 22. -- Vice Admiral Skydloff arrived here at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon. He was met at the Okeanski station, thirteen miles outside Vladivostok, by Major Gen. Voronetz and deputations of the military, naval, and municipal authorities, as well as by an enthusiastic crowd, and bread and salt were given him.

Definite information that it is the intention of Gen. Oku, in command of the Second Japanese Army, to attempt the capture of Port Arthur immediately by direct attack is given in a wireless dispatch from the correspondent of The London Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES on the steamer Haimun.

The United States Army transport Kilpatrick, with soldiers and civilians, and carrying in her hold the bodies of sixty-four soldiers, arrived yesterday, after a fifty-seven days' trip from Manila, and docked at the Government pier on the East River.

GOV. ODELL is going to Europe. He will return in less than a month. We presume he needs the rest and recreation of an ocean voyage and a brief sojourn in foreign lands. He has had a busy Winter. Nevertheless, it is unusual for the Governor of the State of New York, or for that matter of any other State, to go beyond the seas during his term of office.

BUFFALO, May 22. -- The proposed union of the Cumberland and the Northern Church continues to be the absorbing topic among the Commissioners to the one hundred and sixteenth General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in session here. The supportters and opponents of union are lining up for the contest next Thursday.

A mallet blow on the head which Henry D. Babcock, Jr., a Yale freshman, received in the Yale-Princeton polo match at Van Cortlandt Park on Saturday afternoon, resulted in his death at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. He was the son of Henry D. Babcock of Hollister Babcock, bankers, at 17 Broad Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 22. - A testimonial dinner was given by the local lodge of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad for Andrew P. Kelly, Chairman of their Grievance Committee, to-day.

PORTLAND, Oregon, May 22. -- Because of the revival of the controversy over the question whether it was Gen. Funston or some private soldiers who swam a river in the Philippines, Gen. Funston to-day gave out the following statement:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 22. -- Antone Martin, the wealthiest Italian in this section of New Jersey, was shot and killed by Charles Vastel, a nineteen-year-old boy, at the Vastel home, on Hunter Avenue, last night. Martin had first attempted to shoot Vastel's father, and had fired one shot when the boy wrested a revolver from his father's hand and sent three bullets into Martin's body, and Martin died soon after at the hospital.

One hundred and forty-seven boats, ranging in size from single sculls to eight-oared barges, and carrying over 700 oarsmen and passengers, among whom were many women, took part in the annual water parade of the Harlem Regatta Association on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, after having been postponed from the preceding Sunday on account of the unfavorable weather on that day.
GYANG-TSE, May 22. -- A small force from our garrison, Chung-lo, moved out yesterday under Col. Brander to clear the line to the south.

NEWARK, May 22. -- Charles E. Lyon, forty-six years old, the son of D.M. Lyon, the founder of the Lyon Sons' Brewing Company, committed suicide at his home, 1,151 Broad Street, to-day by shooting himself in the head. His act is said to be due to financial losses in steel speculation.

A decidedly healthy tone has developed during the last week in the dry goods jobbing trade due entirely to the warm and bright weather that has prevailed, and the indications now are that the Summer business will be good, and possibly better than usual. William F. King of Calhoun, Robbins Co., one of the principal jobbing houses, said yesterday:
A partnership, with H.P. Whitney, E.W. Jewett, and R.H. Russell owning equal shares in the two-year-old Bedouin, a colt of the late W.C. Whitney's breeding, has been registered with the Jockey Club.

Courtenay Robert Percy Vernon, third Baron Lyveden, and the party of Englishmen and women who come to America with him to look upon "the wonders and the beauties of this grand country," as he expresses it, spent yesterday admiring such of those wonders as exist in and about New York City. Lord Lyveden was here with

That Gov. Odell found it necessary to veto a bill that will embarrass the present city administration to continue the excellent work of vacation schools and public playgrounds is to be deplored. Of all the work undertaken to make good citizens, nothing has been so successful to carry out the purpose as the opening of public playgrounds, especially in a city like New York.

PARIS, May 23 -- The Ministry of the Interior authorizes a denial of the statement that M. de Navonne, First Secretary of the French Embassy to the Vatican, will act as Charge d'Affaires at the embassy, stating that the Government considers that his selection would attenuate the importance of the action taken in the recall of Ambassador Nisard.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- One of the questions with which the Panama Canal Commission will have to deal is whether the eight-hour law applies to the construction of the Panama Canal. The application of either the present law or the pending bill, if enacted, would extend the time of construction at least two years, and increase its cost by many millions of dollars.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22. -- The Democratic State Convention will be held here next Tuesday and Wednesday. All who are opposed to Hearst are classed as conservatives and as they have a majority of the uncontested delegates, they will no doubt decide the contests against Hearst contestants and control the convention.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 22. -- When the funeral of E.L. Dubois, a prominent Des Moines clubman, began to-day, three women advanced, each demanding recognition as his wife. One was Mary E. Dubois of Denver, another was Grace A. Dubois of New Orleans, and the third was the Mrs. Dubois with whom he has lived here.

That Senator McCarren still holds a firm grip on the leadership of the Kings County Democratic organization, despite the combined efforts of Charles F. Murphy and Willoughby Street to depose him, was demonstrated last night to the complete satisfaction of his friends, when fifteen of the Executive Committeemen, gathered together at his call, unqualifiedly pledged him their support to the end in the fight.

DUBOIS, Penn., May 22. -- Mrs. Frank Paul, wife of a well-known resident of Cardiff, a village near here, sacrificed her life for her husband's hat to-day. An Italian, with whom her husband had quarreled, shot her down in cold blood as she was trying to recover the hat.

Jerome D. Gedney, a lawyer living at East Orange, N.J., was a prisoner before Magistrate Mott in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning charged with assault. The complainant, was S. Carl Gerstle, a coffee merchant, who also lives in East Orange.

A record-breaking crowd sunned itself in Central Park yesterday, and half a dozen collisions, runaways, and other accidents marked the celebration of the finest Sunday so far this year. With the big crowd, however, there were, aside from the principals in the accidents, but two arrests all day, one of a man who was annoying the animals, and the other a suspected pickpocket.

VINELAND, N.J., May 22. -- That Alfred Morgan, an aged recluse and a relative of J. Pierpont Morgan, was murdered early this morning and the little frame house in which he lived set afire in order to hide the crime is the belief of the Vineland police. His death makes a mystery such as Vineland has never had before.

JOHANNESBURG, Transvaal Colony, South Africa, May 22. -- Persistent rumors of unrest among the native tribes have been rife for some time. "Unrest" is perhaps too strong a word to use at present. The natives have been talking a good deal and feel themselves dissatisfied, but only in a vague manner.

WASHINGTON, May 22. -- The effect of the split in the Republican Party in Wisconsin on the election of members of the next House of Representatives is arousing apprehension. There is fear that in the sharp combat between the two factions several seats may be lost by the Republicans.

Reckoning all stocks and bonds which moved a point or more, the week's market was as near a balance as possible. Ten bonds rose and ten bonds fell. Twenty-eight stocks advanced and twenty-seven stocks declined. Between Monday and Friday the average for industrials rose .07, and for rails .56.
WASHINGTON, D.C., May 22. -- Mrs. Oliver Cromwell entertained at a large luncheon at the Chevy Chase Club to-day.

Please accept my thanks for publishing my communication in regard to the County Clerk's records of Richmond County in last Sunday's issue. Mr. Cromwell is right in stating that an appropriation of $1,500 for recopying was made in 1902, but his statement is misleading, for the County Clerk could have informed him, if he did not know it, that not one cent of this appropriation was expended for this purpose.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 22. -- Every run scored in to-day's game between Cincinnati and Philadelphia was assisted across the plate by one or more errors. Kellum pitched a better game than Frazer, but the latter received better support. Attendance, 12,000. Score by innings:

If I were Mr. H. Fern, who writes in your issue of May 20, I should be a little cautious in giving information as to my nationality. Maybe there are among us some characteristics to Englishmen in general. This, as a fair-minded American, I would, and could not, permit; it would be rank injustice to our mother country.

Mrs. William C. Gotshall, wife of the President of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company, was hurt yesterday afternoon by a man who struck her on the head with a rock while she was riding in an automobile. Mrs. Gotshall was returning from the Oakley Club, on Long Island, at about 6 o'clock. She was sitting in the rear seat with her husband, the machine being in charge of a chauffeur.

TOKIO, May 22. -- A supplemental report was received here to-day covering the opposition encountered by the Japanese force which landed at Taku-Shan, about fifty miles west of the mouth of the Yalu, on May 20, (May 19?)

LONDON, May 23. -- Lord Inverclyde has a letter in The Times this morning in deply to the letter of Herr Ballin published May 16. In that letter the Director General of the Hamburg-American Line said he never knew why the Cunard Line retired from the agreement entered into between British and Continental lines, under which the latter renounced the Anglo-Scandinavian emigrant traffic.

H. Christoffers of the St. George Athletic Club won the half-mile run, which was a feature of the annual celebration of the Kerrymen's Association at Celtic Park, Long Island, yesterday. Christoffers received an eighteen-yard handicap, and by using excellent judgment won by several feet. W.G. Frank of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association, with ninety-five yards handicap, captured the one mile and a half run easily.

NEWARK, N.J., May 22. -- John S. Ward, General Manager of the carriage firm of Ward Johnson, spent a considerable part of to-day in vain striving to reach that spot between his shoulder blades where there still clung remnants of a porous plaster, stuck there by a thief who got away with Mr. Ward's two-hundred-and-fifty-dollar diamond stud, his watch and chain, and $50.

NEWARK, N.J., May 22. -- At the annual meeting of the Directors of the Northeastern Saengerbund, held here this afternoon, Major Carl Lentz of this city was re-elected President; Dr. L. Wyland of New York, vice President; A. Obste of Baltimore, Secretary; Carl Kuhl of Philadelphia, Recording Secretary, and August Goertz of Newark, Treasurer.
WASHINGTON, May 22. -- It has been said that Panama will adopt the money of the United States, and will not coin money of its own. This, according to latest information, is incorrect.

The enterprising managers of the "greatest shows on earth" at Coney Island were smiling and happy yesterday. With clear skies overhead, gentle breezes, and a temperature more suggestive of July than May, the amusement places were all thronged with people bent on seeing the new wonders of the island.

When young Mgr. Rafaele Merry del Val was in this country in 1896, trying to iron out the religious creases made in Canada's politics by the Manitoba school dispute, his first important mission, a distinguished lawyer of this city, who met the Papal Ablegate twice, said of him: "Mgr. Merry del Val is diplomacy personified and idealized."

LONDON, May 23. -- The correspondent of The Times in Russia says that the mother of one of the Jewish surgeons who were sent from Warsaw to the war recently received from her son a letter which throws a characteristic light on the results of the Russian censorship.

Theodore Burris, who was arrested on Saturday night charged with having stolen Toby, a prize French bulldog, belonging to Dr. Duff Green Maynard, Superintendent of the St. John's, Guild at 501 Fifth Avenue, was arraigned before Magistrate Mayo, in the West Side Court, yesterday.

There are now 124,062 Odd Fellows in Pennsylvania, 12,721 having been initiated into the order last year. In the last thirty-six years the lodges in the State have distributed $16,398,948 for relief and the prevention of distress and actual want. The order has four orphans' homes in the State.

Enough activity and strength were shown in the first hour of trading yesterday to give the impression that the upward movement with which the market closed on Saturday marked a radical change in the character of the market, as it certainly had marked to some extent change in market sentiment.

CHE-FOO, May 23. -- The Captain of a Russian merchantman, who left Port Arthur on May 20, and is among the recent arrivals from Dalny, says that on the 20th the Russians succeeded in sinking a small Japanese gunboat and two torpedo boats. All the damaged warships, except the Czarewitch and the Retvizan, are ready to rejoin the fleet.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23. -- A message from Hazard, Perry County, reports the reopening of the French-Eversole feud, John Eversole assassinating William Smith to-day.

Lee Ridley, winner of the selling steeplechase yesterday at Morris Park in the colors of Thomas Hitchcock, Jr., is one of four horses bought by his owner at Washington for $500. With but little schooling, the horse showed himself a really clever jumper, and was so well thought of in his race yesterday that he was backed down from 10 to 1 to a post price of 1 to 1.

LIAO-YANG, May 23. -- Gen. Ma, commander of the Chinese troops, is in constant communication with Toulisan, the chief of the Chinese bandits, who are adopting military organization under Japanese instructors.

Though the trial of Dr. Richard C. Flower, the mining company promoter, is set for to-day before Recorder Goff in General Sessions, his counsel, Howe Hummel, informed the District Attorney's office yesterday that they had no idea where he was and that they had not seen him for more than a week.

LONDON, May 24. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the war has already begun to produce a serious effect on the economic life of Russia, and a writer in the Viedomosti presents reports which go to show that commerce and industry throughout the country are passing through a severe crisis.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 23. -- It is reported that Foreign Minister Lamsdorff has received a message from the Russian Consul at Che-Foo saying that the Japanese have made a land attack on Port Arthur and that in doing so they lost 15,000 men killed or wounded.

Andress S. Floyd and Frank B. Crawford, members of the suspended Consolidated Stock Exchange firm of Floyd Crawford, confessed bankruptcy before Judge Holt in the United States District Court yesterday in order to pave the way for the settlement plan which has now been agreed to by 51 per cent. of the creditors, both in number and in amount of claim.

Owing to the sudden death of H.D. Babcock, Jr., the member of the Yale polo team who was injured in the match at Van Cortlandt Park on Saturday with the Princeton team, all the polo games scheduled to be played yesterday were postponed. Squadron A was to have played its first regular match at Van Cortlandt Park with the Yale polo team, and it had been expected that Babcock would be a competitor.

Wholesale poolroom raids were resumed yesterday by order of Commissioner McAdoo, and by the time the police had completed their afternoon's work forty-five suspected places had been entered, sixteen prisoners taken, and 124 telephone and two telegraph instruments confiscated.

Two Brooklyn Handicap horses made public demonstration of their fitness and merit as the features of a remarkably lively "off day" for racing at the Morris Park track yesterday, both of them, Savable and Hurstbourne, winning, and so adding new perplexities to the hardest problem that a Brooklyn Handicap ever has presented to turf patrons.

Notice of contest of the will of Miss Fannie H. McGavic was filed yesterday with the Surrogate by Louis Steckler, counsel for Adele Timpson, Edward L. Price, and Edmund H. Ingersoll, cousins of the deceased.

Probably the largest crowd of dry goods buyers ever assembled at one time in New York attended the opening of the sale of Sweetser, Pembrook Co.'s stock yesterday. About 1,000 persons were on the floor at one time during the afternoon, and the bidding was extremely spirited.

PATERSON, N.J., May 23. -- Ex-Attorney General John W. Griggs, who is an expert golf player, has been elected Captain of the golf team of the North Jersey Country Club, which has an excellent eighteen-hole course at this place. Mr. Griggs spends much of his leisure on the links, and is not opposed to Sunday golfing.

BERLIN, May 23. -- A correspondent of the Frankfurter Zeitung, writing from Harbin under date of April 15, says that two officers -- Lieut. Col. Korlinsky and Staff Captain Ignotowich -- are in the Harbin prison awaiting the carrying out of sentences of death imposed upon them for selling large supplies of Russian gunpowder to Chinese.
George Pfuhler of 156 East Eighty-fourth Street, a Building Inspector, has resigned from the department under charges of extortion. The complainant against him was Ralph R. Mable of New Rochelle.

Andrew Carnegie has been admitted to the honorary freedom of the Worshipful Company of Musicians. At a dinner given by the company in his honor he referred to the immense influence which music exercised in human life. With him that influence began early in life -- at his mother's knee, where he learned the songs of Scotland. Of the technique of music he knew nothing.

It was an ill-starred supper last night at the theatrical boarding house of Henry P. Fox, 44 West Twenty-fourth Street, where all the boarders are "stars." Didums Was, a diminutive fox-terrier, was the evil genius of the evening meal, and made trouble right up to the moment when the curtain fell on his troubled life.

BOSTON, May 23. -- News of the reported death by drowning of John H. Thomson of the St. John firm of William Thomson Co. was heard with great regret in Boston shipping offices. The Thomsons have done much business at this port and at New York. They were well known in shipping circles on both sides of the ocean.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 23. -- Morris Kleiman, a native of Russia but a citizen of Wisconsin, who was arrested May 14 at Cheliabinsk, has been released through the intercession of Ambassador McCormick. It appears that his arrest was partially due to representations made by the agent of a firm competing with the one represented by Kleiman.
TANGIER, May 23. -- Letters from Mr. Perdicaris state that his health is good and that he is well cared for.

The report to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the special committee on marriage and divorce promises to have a considerable effect toward allaying what members of all the Churches and of no Church have agreed to regard as an evil.

"I am an Englishman," says Mr. H. Fern in your issue under date of May 20, and then the said Englishman starts in on a tirade about American freedom, and closes with the statement that there is "more freedom and better justice in England." So, why do you come to America and remain here to make your living, Mr. Fern?
TRENTON, May 23. -- Argument in the Northern Securities case was continued here to-day. John G. Johnson opened the argument for the defendants.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 23--By a vote of 262 to 244 the General Assembly of the Pesbyterian Church of the United States in America this afternoon wiped out that part of the report of the Special Committee on Marriage and Divorce which advised Presbyterian ministers to refuse to marry any person whose marriage is forbidden by the church of which that person is a member.

In his speech to about 200 graduates of the Packard Commercial School, at Carnegie Hall last evening, the Rev. Dr. Frank Knight Sanders, Dean of the Theological Department of Yale University, on "The Twentieth Century Business Man," said that in his opinion the age now dawning would be the age of the business man, but not the business man of the past.

Again was the lie passed in the Aldermanic Chamber over the Port Chester Railroad application yesterday, this time while the Railroad Committee of the board was holding a public hearing on the New York and Port Chester application, and for a time it looked as though James W. Osborne, ex-Assistant District Attorney, and appearing for Westchester property owners, would come to blows with E.J. Lucas of Mount Vernon.

It is a pity that no arrests were made on Sunday in the case of the assault upon a lady in an automobile on the upper east side. This appears to have been an aggravated instance of the brutal lawlessness of the gangs that infest that neighborhood and could the guilty person have been brought to court, it might have been possible to pass an exemplary sentence upon him.

Policeman Brady of the West Thirtieth Street Station, and O.P. Roberts of 802 Second Avenue, helped a lot of children out of the way of a runaway horse at Fortieth Street and Broadway yesterday when a delivery wagon horse became frightened and dashed driverless through Fortieth Street.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 23. -- The Brooklyns scored a surprising victory to-day over St. Louis, the score being 7 to 4. When the visitors went to the bat in the ninth inning the score was 4 to 1 against them, and Dunleavy's pitching had been very effective Before the inning was over seven hits were recorded against the St. Louis pitcher, including two home runs, and six runs were scored.

At least seven business men are known to have received subpoenas from the District Attorney's office demanding their appearance before the Grand Jury as witnesses against Richard A. Canfield. The seven, who are said to be only a minority of those to be questioned eventually, are John W. Gates, John A. Drake, William E. Peck, James M. Waterbury, Jr., Joseph Israels, Sarsfield Lavelle; and Eberhard Faber.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 23. -- To save the lives of many passengers on the train over the Naugatuck Division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad due here at, 6 o'clock a derail switch was turned and the train was thrown off the track while running at high speed. The switch is just east of the new rolling lift bridge on the big viaduct in this city.

LONDON, May 24. -- The Morning Post's Shanghai correspondent says it is reported the Russians are removing stores and provisions to Harbin, and that 100 locomotives and 800 cars are collected at Liao-Yang in readiness to convey passengers and goods. Therefore, he says, the conclusion is that the Russians are preparing to retreat.

Since reading several articles in your paper, apropos of the Hawthorne Centennial, suggesting that a substantial offering to his daughter, Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop, in aid of her work for incurable cancer patients, would be a fitting memorial, I have waited for some practical beginning of the same, but so far in vain.

TACOMA, Washington, May 23. -- It is reported from Victoria that wreckage of the steamer Corwin, which sailed on Tuesday from Seattle for Nome with eighty-nine passengers, has been found on the west of Vancouver Island.

Yesterday's market was active and not at the expense of values, therein constituting a happy exception to the recent rule that activity meant weakness and that strength signified dullness. Naturally activity was greatest when the effect of the chief factor -- the favorable bank statement -- was greatest, that is, in the opening hour.

Semi-final tennis matches in three events brought out some high-class play yesterday in the championship tournament of the New York Lawn Tennis Club on its courts, at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Wylie C. Grant and Robert Le Roy, the holders of the National indoor championship, won their place in the final round of the championship doubles.

Setting explosives adrift in the ocean -- as the correspondent of The London Times and THE NEW YORK TIMES on board the Haimun warned the world in his wireless message on Sunday the Russians have done -- is a new phase of warfare against which the whole world will protest in no uncertain terms.

There is obvious need of an international conference to regulate the use of modern appliances of warfare not contemplated in the existing international code. That fine old Russian gentleman Admiral ALEXIEFF undertook, of his own motion, and without reference to anybody, to regulate the use of one of them, wireless telegraphy namely.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 23. -- Bishop-elect James R. Day of Syracuse, N.Y., furnished the sensation of the Methodist General Conference in session here by resigning to-day from the position he was about to be elevated to. At his request he was granted permission to absent himself from all further meetings of the conference, and will leave for his home immediately.

There is a rude suggestion of the revenges the whirligig of time brings about in the report from South Africa that the Kafirs are deeply stirred by the preaching of a gospel of "Ethiopianism," a sort of barbarian Monroe Doctrine of "Africa for the Africans," which, if it once take root in the mysterious mind of the blacks, may make a good deal of trouble.

ARRAS, France, May 23. -- President Loubet made two significant speeches to-day in connection with the holiday here. The Bishop of Arras welcomed M. Loubet as the representative of the union of Church and State. In replying M. Loubet said:

CHATHAM, N.J., May 23. -- Charles M. Schwab, ex-President of the United States Steel Corporation, contributed $11.70 to the Commonwealth of Chatham yesterday. Mr. Schwab was permitted to do this after he had proved that his automobile was able to skim over the Chatham roads at a speed greater than that allowed by the Fathers of the rural community.

WASHINGTON, D.C., May 23. -- Gen. Miles, who returned to Washington to-day, had little to say concerning politics. In a business venture, the precise nature of which does not appear, he seemed more interested.

To Prof. WILLIAM JAMES of Harvard and other good men who criticise the Philippine policy of the United States Government we commend an attentive reading of this news dispatch from Manila, which we here copy by preference from the columns of our neighbor The Evening Post:
WASHINGTON, May 23. -- Gov. Wright has cabled the Secretary of War, quoting the following from a dispatch sent by Gen. Wood:

NEWPORT, R.I., May 23. -- Two divorces were granted in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to-day, neither case being contested. The divorces will not be operative, however, until after the expiration of six months, when the final decrees will be granted.

David Rothschild, President of the defunct Federal Bank and the Globe Security Company, was sentenced yesterday by Recorder Goff in General Sessions to State prison for nine years at hard labor for grand larceny, Moses Grossman, counsel for Rothschild, then obtained a stay of sentence from Justice. Gaynor of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn.

Since the excitement regarding the selfishness of the male sex in monopolizing the seats in the elevated railroad cars has died out, it seems to be quite the custom for women to stand. There have been so many shameful instances of it lately that it is to be hoped the papers will take the matter up again.

There is a refreshing novelty in the incident of President MELLEN and other officers of the New Haven Railroad attending a dinner of a lodge of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen given to the Chairman of its "Grievance Committee," and testifying to the "pleasant relations" they had sustained with that committee.
Excessive smoking, which caused a cancerous growth on his tongue, brought about the death on Saturday evening of Ernest Henry Blinn, a prominent resident of the East New York section of Brooklyn.
At Twenty-third Street and Eighth Avenue the stout lady got aboard the cross-town car just as the thin lady attempted to get off. In the squeeze that resulted one of the two dropped a glove.

Bishop Earle and his learned colleagues, who appear to be busily engaged in dodging the responsibility for the "Exeter English" in the Blackmore Memorial inscription, might well assume a bolder front, as the following quotations sufficiently prove, grammatical canons to the contrary notwithstanding:

M. L. Hess have sold for Alexander and Sarah R. Heckert the three lots on the south side of One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street, 75 feet west of Seventh Avenue, to Joshua Silverstein, who will erect thereon two six-story four-family flats, each 37.6 feet front. This property has been held in the Heckert family over forty years.

To Europe to hunt a candidate for Governor on the Republican ticket this year is the great object, among other lesser things, of Gov. Odell's sudden trip which begins to-day with his embarkation on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, which is scheduled to leave her pier at the North German Lloyd docks in Hoboken at 10 A.M.

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., May 23. -- Herman Froelich, a farmer of this place, and all the members of his household were chloroformed by burglars last night. Froelich felt a suffocating sensation when he awoke this morning, and soon realized that he was suffering from the effects of chloroform. He aroused the other members of the family with difficulty, all having been put under the influence of the drug.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 23. -- Judge Bishop granted a temporary injunction to restrain Ernest H. Hurd, a Yale senior, from calling on Mrs. Lavinia H. Foy, a wealthy widow, ninety years old, as the result of a hearing held in the Common Pleas Court to-day. It was based on a complaint presented by "Lavinia Foy, by her best friend, George M. Harmon."

READVILLE, Mass., May 23. -- Seventy-six blooded horses, the entire complement of the famous racing stable and stockbreeding farm of the late J. Malcolm Forbes of Boston, were sold under the hammer at the trotting park here to-day. The horses brought $116,450, or an average of $1,532.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 23. -- Chancellor James R. Day's action in declining the honor of the Bishops meets with the approval of the Trustees and the Faculty of Syracuse University. They have been confident that he would not give up his work here and are gratified that the university is not to lose him.
LONDON, May 24. -- Admiral Algernon de Horsey, in a letter to the editor of The Times, says:
