ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 23. -- One reason which caused all the teachers of George W. Vanderbilt's parish school to resign was a complaint that Miss Nolan, one of the teachers, was incompetent.

The settlement of the New Haven Railroad freight handlers' strike is altogether a matter of the enforcement of law and the preservation of order. The freight handlers employed about the docks of the Sound steamboats of the New Haven line went on strike because their demand for the discharge of a nonunion foreman, a faithful man long employed by the company, was refused.

Occasionally some eccentric person writes to the newspapers denouncing as a "hog" the passenger upon a street car who takes advantage of his priority to pre-empt the end seat, and forces later comers to pass him instead of moving up to make room for them. Really, there are two sides to that question. The end seat being by hypothesis the more eligible, why should not the rule of first come first served apply to it?

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- The Methodist Protestant Conference unanimously indorsed the inter-Church movement for uniform laws on marriage and divorce to-day and appointed a committee of three to represent the denomination in this regard.

Why do not the press of the United States take advantage of the present state of public opinion, which has taken away the service of the Western Union from the poolrooms, and turn the searchlight upon the identical service bucket shops obtain from the same Western Union? A wholesome public sentiment exists against this evil, which is worse by far than the poolroom evil.

-- Once a year or so somebody gets a momentary fame in many kindly newspapers by "rediscovering the lost art of tempering copper." That is always the way of putting it -- the lost art is rediscovered, and never is the art discovered. And yet, so far as we know, copper, though often hardened sufficiently to carry a cutting edge for a short time, was never "tempered" in any true sense of that term.

Those who reckoned that the bank statement was good for a three days' rise were mistaken. A little selling by London was the ostensible cause for cutting its career short sooner than even the bears had reckoned, and thus the question is raised again whether such relapses as yesterday's do not do the market more harm than rises like Monday's do it good.

Myer S. Isaacs, for years President of the Branch de Hirsch Fund and leader in many other charitable and philanthropic movements of the Jewish people, died in the Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, yesterday afternoon from heart disease, to which he had long been subject.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 24. -- The meetings preliminary to the Democratic State Convention, which will begin to-morrow, were unusually animated to-day owing to contests from the larger conventions involving two hundred delegates and nine members of the committees that are selected by the twenty-one Congressional Districts. The State Central Committee passed on these contests.

LONDON, May 25. -- Thomas Erskine Holland, Professor of International Law and Diplomacy at Oxford, who is regarded as the greatest authority on international law in Great Britain, says in a letter to The Times:

NEW ROCHELLE, May 24. -- In St. John's Methodist Episcopal Church to-night Miss Emily Isabel Wadley, only daughter of Albert Wadley of New York and Newport, was married to Arthur Trumbull Goodenough, the only son of the Rev. Dr. Arthur H. Goodenough, pastor of the Prospect Methodist Episcopal Church at Bristol, Conn., and formerly pastor of St. John's Church, New Rochelle. The ceremony was performed at 7:30 o'clock by the Rev. Dr. Goodenough.

A.W. Houghton, of the Arnold Print Works, chairman of the Creditors' Committee which is liquidating the business of Sweetser, Pembrook Co., made light yesterday of the objection to the proceeding made by a group of the preferred stockholders, headed by John J. Schwartz, an attorney, of 100 Broadway.

In honor of the birthday of Queen Victoria Englishmen and Americans who were educated in Great Britain and who have formed the British Schools and Universities Club of New York City gathered last night at Delmonico's for their annual dinner.

Daniel J. Sully Co. yesterday filed their schedules in bankruptcy in the United States District Court. It appears from the schedules that among the largest creditors and debtors of the firm were various accounts under such names as "Artist Account," "Mrs. Sully," "No. 1," "No. 2," "No. 8," and others which were really speculative accounts for Sully himself or jointly with others.
CLEVEI-,..ND, Ohio, 5iay 24.,Irs. lars E. ragar said last nlght that she thinks her son Is emporarily deranged from overstudy.

There was great excitement in political circles in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon when it was reported that Hugh McLaughlin had given to charity all the stamps which he has been collecting for years in Willoughby Street. The news caused a sensation among politicians, from Newtown Creek to Coney's tumbling surf.

LONDON, May 25. -- The Daily Telegraph's correspondent at Niu-Chwang says the Japanese land operations against Port Arthur are meeting with little success and that Lieut. Gen. Stoessel and Major Gen. Fock continues to make well-directed but desperate sorties against the advance of the Japanese, who are fighting with a stubborn determination almost unknown in history.

Amazing things happened in every race at the Morris Park course yesterday, but the most astonishing occurrence of the day was reserved for the fourth event, the Jockey Club's weight for age race, won by Eugenia Butch, but awarded to Dolly Spanker, after the disqualification of the winner and unquestionably the best horse.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 4. -- The report, cabled to The Associated Press yesterday, that the Foreign Office had received a telegram from the Russian Consul at Che-Foo asserting that the Japanese had made a land attack on Port Arthur and had lost 15,000 men killed or wounded, and that the Russians had lost 3,000 men, is true, but as nothing confirmatory has been received from any other source the report does not receive credence.

The final workouts for the Brooklyn Handicap were responsible for the largest morning attendance of the year at both the Gravesend and Sheepshead Bay race courses yesterday. At the Gravesend course the most noted horse worked was Hermis, who established his right to consideration by winning a sensational and fast race at Morris Park on Saturday.
While there were no poolroom raids yesterday, there were at least significant developments in the poolroom situation.

" E.E.M." whose letter appears in today's issue, must be a recent arrival, and will no doubt be glad to be "set right" on the subject about which he inquires. Once the writer was standing on the platform of an elevated train and was ordered inside by the train hand, under the rule. Meantime a man in the same car was spitting vigorously.

" Outcries against the Russians are premature so long as we do not know whether they have done what they are charged with -- namely, sowing mines broadcast in the open sea. The Hatsuse may have been destroyed by a mine accidentally adrift -- perhaps by a Japanese mine."

DELPHOS, Ohio, May 24. -- The New York Limited on the Pennsylvania Railroad would have been wrecked at the Auglaize River, three miles east of here, at midnight had it not been for Charles Peltier, a boy fifteen years old.

In an address before the Illinois Manufacturers' Association Mr. WILLIAM C. BROWN, Vice President of the New York Central Railroad, ventured the conjecture that in the Northern Securities decision the Supreme Court took account of public opinion as well as of the Constitution and the law. We quote Mr. BROWN'S language:

Following a hearing yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Hitchcock, in the bankruptcy proceedings against Dr. W.E. Woodend of the firm of Woodend Co., Receiver Abraham Gruber asked the Commissioner for an order calling upon R.D. Rumley, Dr. Woodend's former cashier and manager, to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt of court for declining to answer questions while on the witness stand.

A small, sly-eyed dog, whom nature painted an aggressive yellow, who never was honored with a christening party, and who, in the absence of a permanent dinner table, is compelled to live from foot to mouth, found himself yesterday, in the course of his somewhat aimless journey through life, on the downtown track of the Third Avenue elevated line, at Houston Street.

WASHINGTON, May 24. -- Through the American Ministers abroad the Naval Attaches of the United States have been instructed to report upon the number and danger to neutral shipping of war mines floating off the Manchurian coast.

CAPE MAY, N.J., May 24. -- The First National Bank of Cape May has been closed by order of the Controller of the Currency. The bank was recently reorganized, and the present officers called Bank Examiner Buck here last evening. It is said that the depositors will be paid in full. The troubles of the bank are said to be due to the financial difficulties of its former President, Mr. Wesley R. Wales.

Lovely! There are too few policemen in New York to police properly the crowded park drives on Sundays, so that the pedestrians have to wait at the crossings until emboldened by sufficient numbers to make a dash into the lines of vehicles that speed by with haughty indifference to the rights of the public.

GROTON, Mass., May 24. -- President Roosevelt was the principal speaker at the annual prize day exercises to-day in the Groton school, where his sons, Theodore, Jr., and Kermit, are studying. He arrived here at 9:05 o'clock this morning and was driven to the school.

MONTCLAIR, May 24. -- The wheels of justice at this place got sadly clogged this morning, and finally experienced so much difficulty in their accustomed revolutions that they reversed themselves completely and ground out what appeared very like fines against the respected Recorder of the town police court and his official attorney, E.B. Goodell.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. May 24. -- The story of the murder of her stepfather, Lafayette Taylor, by her mother, Kate Taylor, on Jan. 26, 1903, was told on the stand to-day by Ida May De Kay, fifteen years old. She charged her uncle, Peter Yerkins, with being an accomplice. Mrs. Taylor, who is on trial for the second time, wept as the girl told of the crime. Miss De Kay said:

A man rushed into the Tenderloin Police Station early last evening, breathless, in a state of high excitement, and told Sergt. Boettler that he was being pursued. He said that he was a physician, living somewhere on or not far from Fifth Avenue. He appeared to be between thirty-five and forty years old.
VIENNA, May 24. -- The Pope has conferred decorations on two office holders of a Catholic student association who were deprived of their posts for refusing to accept challenges to duels.

Similar to the attack on Mrs. William C. Gotshall, who is in danger of her life through being struck by a stone on Sunday, was an assault last night on Albert B. Hilton, son of ex-Judge Henry Hilton. Mr. Hilton, who lives at 1,047 Fifth Avenue, was riding in an automobile at Washington Avenue and One Hundred and Eighty-second Street, when a boy threw a stone or club at him, striking him in the head.

The stock market yesterday showed such a complete change from the favorable conditions with which the week opened that even the traders were disappointed, not to say surprised. Transactions were smaller and prices with very few exceptions lower, the declines in many issues being sufficient to wipe out the improvement scored on Monday.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., May 24. -- The investigation of the Grievance Committee of the State Bar Association as to the connection of Supreme Court Justice Warren B. Hooker with the charges outlined by the report of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow was begun in the St. Charles Hotel in this city this afternoon.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 24. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin to the Emperor, dated May 3, was received today:

As Dr. Richard C. Flower, the mining promoter who is under five indictments for grand larceny, failed to appear in General Sessions yesterday, Recorder Goff. ordered his bail bond of $23,000 forfeited. Mrs. Belle Gray Taylor was the complainant against Flower in the specific indictment on which he was to be tried yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 24. -- Dean George F. James of the Department of Pedagogy in the State University, told the St. Paul Federation of Grade Teachers that more than 100,000 teachers would retire this year because their salaries did not afford living.

When the Merchant Marine Commission was proposed in Congress we expressed the opinion that it was intended to be simply a means of collecting material to promote the ship subsidy scheme, and that it would be very difficult to make of it a real investigation into the question of marine transportation.

All the American League clubs played yesterday, but only one National League game was scheduled, Pittsburg against Boston. The champions kept up their recent good form, and for the second consecutive time shut out the Eastern team. In the American League the results made several changes in the championship record.

George F. Baer, President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, was the principal witness at the hearing of the Inter-State Commerce Commission on the anthracite coal rate, which was resumed yesterday in the Federal Building. The hearing was a continuation of the sessions of September last, based on the complaint of W.R. Hearst against various coal-carrying railroads, charging them with violations of the Sherman act.
NEW HAVEN, May 24. -- Prof. Theodore S. Woolsey, Professor of International Law at Yale, to-day made the following statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency under the second Cleveland Administration, was at the Holland House yesterday, and in an interview, talked of his reasons for believing that the Democrats had an excellent opportunity for victory in the coming National contest.

A woman who said she was Mrs. Anna D. Smith, daughter of the late Gov. Dennison of Ohio, who Was Postmaster General in President Lincoln's Cabinet, was arrested last night and locked up in the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station, charged with defrauding the Hotel Navarre, at Seventh Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

Gunn Grant, builders, have bought from the Realty Company of America the block front, eight lots, on the east side of Broadway, between One Hundred and Sixty-first and One Hundred and Sixty-second Streets. This is one of the properites taken by the preset sellers from Isaac H. Clothier in exchange for the Euclid Hall apartment house.

Here is a translation of the note addressed by the Vatican to the Catholic powers in protest against President Loubet's visit to Rome. This is the text of the version received by the Prince of Monaco and published by M. Jaures's new Paris paper, Humanite, May 17. The version received by the French Foreign Office is said to have been modified.

TRENTON, May 24. -- The Lake Superior Corporation, with an authorized capital of $40,000,000, was incorporated here to-day. The company is empowered to construct and operate canals and to do general construction work. Incorporators: Charles E. Orvis, Edward White, and W.F. Hobbie, all of Jersey City.
NEW HAVEN, ConnT, lIiiy 24. -- President Mellen of the.qew York, .iNew I-Iaven and Hartforl. Railroad has issued a statement, in which he skys:

It is not long ago that the wise ones of the Street were discussing with a solemnity proportioned to the prevalent leisure the probable or certain effect upon the minds and the business of men of the payments in connection with the Panama Canal and the export of gold which it was feared that these would involve.

PARIS, May 25. -- In Parliamentary circles keen attention has been aroused by the news telegraphed to-day from Washington that Russia's broadcast sowing of mines in the open sea, thereby endangering international commerce, is to form the subject of official reports by American Naval Attaches.

The striking freight handlers have shown great good sense in refraining from violent attacks upon the men who have taken their places on the New Haven Railroad Company's docks. In ordering police measures which have made it easy and natural for the strikers to take this sensible view of the rights of the Community Commissioner MCADOO has shown that he knows how to do his duty.

JACKSON, Miss., May 25. -- Yazoo City, the wealthiest town in the Mississippi delta, located fifty-five miles north of this city, was swept by fire to-day, and to-night not a single business house in the town is left standing. Over 200 buildings were destroyed and the loss is estimated between two million and two and a half million dollars. The first figure will probably cover the total destruction.

The full text of the Papal protest, signed by Cardinal MERRY DEL VAL, against the visit of President LOUBET to King VICTOR EMMANUEL, which we printed yesterday, is even more offensive than we had been led to believe by the cabled reports. It is really amazing to read such a lecture as is delivered to the monarchs and chiefs of state of Europe concerning the etiquette of their intercourse with one another.

A runaway cab horse, a collision with another vehicle whose occupants were thrown out, and the spectacular seizure of the frightened animal by Policeman Day of the West Thirtieth Street Station, in Fifth Avenue between Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Streets last evening, were the features of the liveliest few minutes Madison Square has witnessed for some time.

Chief Engineer Pegram of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad appeared before the State Railroad Commissioners yesterday and submitted the proposed changes to be made by the company in the stations of the elevated lines. At the close of the conference the following statement was given out by the commissioners present, who were Commisioners Dunn, Baker, and Dickey:

LONDON, May 26. -- The Standard publishes a dispatch from a Russian correspondent in whom the paper says it places great confidence containing most sensational statements regarding the alarming condition of Russia as the outcome of the war.

Why not run cars on the subway and see what we have paid for before we spend $100,000,000 more for something we do not know will be successful? The accident on the subway yesterday calls attention to some of the dangers thereof. The subway they 0tell us, now is completed to Eighty-sixth Street.

Seven runs and as many hits, including a home run and a triple, were the net results of the batting display of the St. Louis team against Pitcher Powell in four innings at American League Park yesterday, and that work proved sufficient for the Western nine to win the game. Puttmann, the left hander, relieved Powell in the fifth inning and did surprisingly well.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 25. -- The British and American press reports of possible protests against the laying of mines in the waters of the Liao-Tung Peninsula because of the danger to international commerce evoke much interest here. It is generally remarked that there was no talk of protests while Russian ships were being blown up, it only beginning after the Japanese ships met with disaster.

After an alternation of a weak day and a strong day, it is reasonable enough to expect an irregular day. Such a day was Wednesday, in which prices at first were soft in sympathy with Tuesday's close, then became apathetic, and finally closed moderately hard, with changes in the quotation sheet as irregularly distributed between ups and downs as such shifts of trading temper naturally would produce.

" When Admiral Dewey started for his station in the Pacific Ocean prior to the Spanish war," said a railway man, "he attracted little attention. On his way West he took the Baltimore and Ohio train to Chicago. He and his secretary had a drawing room. While they were temporarily absent from it some one stole $80. This robbery soon became known, and the officials in Chicago were notified.

KEARNY, N.J., May 25. -- Two New York detectives employed by a resident of Arlington Heights to ferret out some of the mysterious burglaries committed in that section recently came to grief to-day when they were themselves arrested as suspicious characters.

CHE-FOO, May 25. -- A portion of the Japanese fleet bombarded Port Arthur at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The attack was witnessed by a Frenchman, who left Dalny on the night of the 22d, arriving here to-night. He says that eight large warships circled before the entrance of Port Arthur Harbor for one hour, firing broadsides at intervals of ten minutes.

New rules regulating automobile traffic were promulgated to the force yesterday by Police Commissioner McAdoo, to take effect Saturday. Just what they are he refuses to say. It is known that it contemplates extra police protection along the favorite routes of motorists and the guarding of the interests of all concerned, whether autoists, pedestrians, or drivers or bicyclists.

Findlay S. Douglas won the prize yesterday for the lowest score in the thirty-six-hole round, which marked the opening of the metropolitan golf championship tournament on the links of the Garden City Golf Club. His total for the double round was 165 strokes, an 84 being made in the morning and 81 in the afternoon, while George H. Brokaw came second with 168.

NEWPORT, May 25. -- The Summer residents are coming to Newport in large numbers, larger than ever before so early in the season. Every day for the last two weeks additional cottages have been opened, and the occupants have arrived for the season. To-day's arrivals numbered half a dozen.

The last monthly meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation until October was held yesterday at its rooms, 203 Broadway, and was devoted chiefly to hearing addresses by A. Barton Hepburn, and J. Noble Hayes on the work of the Law's Delays Commission.

Yesterday in the stock market honors were about evenly divided between the bulls and the bears. Early in the day the covering of shorts seemed a relatively easy matter, for the tendency of the market was still reactionary, but by the end of the first hour the movement was again upward, and for a time the market was strong.

LONDON, May 25. -- Sir John MacDonell, one of the highest authorities on international law in Great Britain, when asked by THE NEW YORK TIMES'S correspondent to-day for his views on the sowing by the Russians of mines in the open sea, said:
LONDON, May 26. -- The Times says in an editorial article to-day:
WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Secretary Taft returned here from the Adirondacks to-day, very much improved in health.
LONDON, May 26. -- The Times says:

The management of the street-car lines in Philadelphia is enforcing a very proper regulation on cars in which smoking is not permitted. Conductors are required to see to it that passengers do not carry lighted cigars, cigarettes, or pipes, or those which have been lighted and permitted to "go out."
J.N. Kelley Son have sold for Sonn Brothers to an investor the seven-story apartment house, 306 West Ninety-ninth Street, on plot 60 by 100.

WILKESBARRE, May 25. -- A telegram received at the Susquehanna Coal Company's office, in this city, this evening, states that ten miners were suffocated by gas and sulphur fumes from a small locomotive this afternoon in the workings of the Summit Branch Coal Company at Williamstown, Dauphin County.

Articles of incorporation were filed yesterday at Albany for the Kings County Lighting Company, Brooklyn, with a capital of $2,000,000. The Directors given are: Asley T. Cole and Charles T. Lark of Manhattan, William J. Bagnell, Bayonne, and W.R. Fuller, Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- At the final session of the seventh biennial of the General Federation of Women's Clubs to-night the Federation honored two ex-Presidents and ignored another member who had served in the same capacity.
Your correspondent's criticisms of the manners of bank tellers and railway ticket agents recall to my mind an amusing incident.

Did Morse himself claim to be the inventor of the telegraph? When introduced at the Austrian Court the Emperor asked: "Are you the man that invented the telegraph?" Morse touched himself on the breast and replied: "I am the telegraph."
LONDON, May 26. -- The Times's insurance correspondent says:
In boasting of the condition of preparedness for a strike if one should seem necessary to accomplish what he had in view, President GOULD of the National Brotherhood of Teamsters said yesterday:

Mr. J.J. HILL gave the Merchant Marine Commission on Tuesday a good deal of tempered common sense to reflect upon. He told them that a merchant marine built up on subsidies and bounties would not be worth much, for it would be very costly and would not last long. If we really wished for such a marine we could get it by taking off the prohibition from foreign-built ships.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 25. -- There are indications that Gen. Kuropatkin is preparing to make a very important move against the enemy. One of the reasons for this belief is the sudden increased restrictions upon the war correspondents at the front. The prevailing belief here is that Gen. Kuroki's army is in difficulties.

-- Not only does the person fortunate enough to find an empty "end seat" on an open car have, under the customs that regulate numberless things of the kind with all the force of law, as good a right to retain as to take that seat, but it is at least questionable if by so doing he does not follow exactly the course that gives the least trouble to other people.

Even if the poolrooms are supposed to be closed and handbook men are alleged to be running away from New York, four men were stabbed in a fight yesterday afternoon over what one witness says was a handbook bet in a billiard room. One of them, who is described as Eli F. Gerard, a broker of 29 West Sixty-fourth Street, was seriously stabbed and has a dislocated shoulder.

ST. LOUIS, May 25. -- J.M. Donald, a New York banker, who is attending the meeting of the Missouri Bankers' Association, in discussing President Roosevelt and the financial outlook here to-day said that President Roosevelt had assured the bankers of the country that he would abide by whatever policy they decided was best.

Fourteen entries were received yesterday by the Automobile Club of America for the Spring run to Gettysburg, which will start to-day. One week will be occupied on the journey, and the actual route for the entire trip from this city, as mapped out by the Runs and Tours Committee, includes 634 miles. The run to-day will be to Philadelphia.

LONDON, May 26. -- Dr. T.J. Lawrence, Professor of International Law at the Royal Naval College at Greenwich, read a paper at the Royal United Service Institution yesterday on "Problems of Neutrality Illustrated by the Russo-Japanese War."

Deputy Assistant United States Treasurer George W. Marlor was busy at his desk in the Sub-Treasury Building in Wall Street yesterday afternoon when he was accosted by a visitor, who was much out of breath, as if he had run up the long flight of steps leading to the Wall Street entrance of the building.

I.B. Newcombe, who was the floor member of the brokerage firm of Stewart Browne Co. before its dissolution a week ago, and at that time announced his connection with a new proposed firm of I. B. Newcombe Co., at 52 Broadway, was called before the Board of Governors of the Stock Exchange in a session yesterday that lasted from 3:30 p.m. to 9:30 p.m.
TANGIER, Morocco, May 25. -- I have received letters from Mr. Perdicaris and the brigand Raisuli.

The Brooklyn Eagle has published a spirited, and well-founded protest against what it accurately describes as an "outrage." The outrage consists in laying waste with a pavement of granite blocks the great plaza at the eastern end of the Williamsburg Bridge so as to convert that expanse into as unattractive a place as the corresponding space at the eastern end of the East River Bridge.

ROME, May 25. -- The Osservatore Romano, the Vatican organ, publishes an official statement reviewing the relations existing between Cardinal Merry del Val, the Papal Secretary of State, and M. Nisard, French Ambassador to the Vatican, immediately before the recall of the latter as the result of the Papal protest against the visit of President Loubet to Rome.

A man supposed to be W.J.F. Southmayd of Brooklyn, foreman of a "rodding gang" employed by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company on the electric lighting work, was instantly killed in the subway at Elm and Canal Streets last night by the blowing out of a cable connection in a duct house at that point.
PARIS, May 25. -- A dispatch to the Temps from St Petersburg says Gen. Kuropatkin has cut the land communications between the armies of Gens. Iurold and Oku.

BUFFALO, May 25. -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States to-day reopened the discussion on divorce and marriage, and by a two-thirds vote passed a resolution which puts the Presbyterian Church in accord with the stand taken by all other Protestant churches, but which leaves it unbound by the restrictions of the Catholic Church.

The announcement of the plan for reorganizing the finances of the United States Realty and Construction Company was made public yesterday in a circular to the company's stockholders. The circular was signed by a committee consisting of James Stillman, P.A. Valentine, Otto T. Bannard, Stephen S. Palmer, and James H. Post.

L.J. Curran of Chicago, the head freight handler, who came here from the West to help his union win its strike against the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, made no threats of strikes yesterday. And while he was denying that he had ordered a general strike along the entire system of the company, the latter's officials made it plain that they considered they had beaten the strikers to a standstill.

WASHINGTON, May 25. -- Within twenty-two minutes after the retirement of the jury in the case of James N. Tyner and Harrison J. Barrett, tried on charges of conspiracy in connection with their duties as law officers for the Post Office Department, a verdict of not guilty was returned.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 25. -- To-day's Democratic Convention was stormy and turbulent. The conservatives were in the saddle and ruled the convention. The platform leaves the formulation of National issues to the National Convention.

SEOUL, Korea, May 25. -- A telegram has been received here from Gen-san, on the east coast of Korea, saying that the Russians, after the engagement with Korean troops at Ham-Heung on May 19, burned the shrines and the royal mausoleums which were erected there by the founder of the present Korean dynasty in the year 1364, and which were regarded by the Koreans as sacred.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 25. -- All the freight handlers, with the exception of about a dozen, in the three large sheds of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad here went out to-day. About 150 men in all left work. The company has decided to fill the vacancies with non-union men.

CHICAGO, May 25. -- Francis P. McColl, yachtsman and member of prominent clubs in New York, San Francisco, and Chicago, has obtained a divorce from his wife on the ground of desertion. Mr. McColl, who is President of the American Key Can Company and Vice President of the Sardine Trust, filed his suit in the Superior Court April 19, and Judge Chettlain gave the decree May 20.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 25. -- The Democratic State Convention was held to-day. While no instructions were given, the resolutions recited that at the present time Judge Alton B. Parker is the most available and acceptable candidate for the nomination for the Presidency, and that the sentiment of the Convention is for his nomination.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26. -- Ten persons were killed, one fatally injured, and fifteen hurt by an explosion of boilers which totally demolished the towboat Fred Wilson off Riverview Park to-day.

Mrs. Herman Leroy Jones. who disappeared in a mysterious manner on Monday of last week while attending the races at Morris Park with her husband and his counsel, Robert L. Cutting, was found by her husband at 6 o'clock last night in a boarding house on West Twenty-second Street.

Who was the man who called at the office of J. Alexander Koones, in the Equitable Building, on Wednesday, and whose presence outside the door seemed to excite Lawyer David Levy very much just before Levy went into an adjoining office and committed suicide?

STAMFORD, Conn., May 26. -- Papers were served to-day by Deputy Sheriff Hendrie in a suit for divorce brought by Lottie C. M. Comstock against William W. Comstock, both of South Norwalk. Intolerable cruelty is the ground for the action, and the plaintiff asks alimony to the amount of $75,000.

QUINCY, Mass., May 26. -- The striking boilermakers of the Fore River Ship and Engine Company to-day voted to return to work under the conditions arranged by the company for the Summer months. The boilermakers, however, will demand a return to the 54-hour basis as soon as the Summer is over.

CHICAGO, May 26. -- At the office of the Freight Handlers' Union no one knew of Flannery sending a strike order to the East. He is Acting Secretary, and is not supposed to have any authority in the matter. The management of the strike, it was said, is entirely in the hands of the international officers, with Curran vested with practically absolute power.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at luncheon to-day. Their guests included the Russian Ambassador and Countess Cassini; the French Ambassador and Mme. Jusserand, and the Spanish Minister.

PARIS, May 26. -- Yvon Evans, known as Viscount d'Oyley, a son of the American dentist, Dr. John Evans, died to-day at a private sanitarium as the result of a bullet wound received under mysterious circumstances.

The three leading aspirants for the National League pennant were scheduled to play yesterday, but Chicago was unfortunate in having its game with St. Louis postponed by rain. The Cincinnati team, now on its way to the Polo Grounds to play a series of four games, beginning on next Wednesday, met the Pittsburgs yesterday and gave the champions a rather severe drubbing.

NEWPORT, May 26. -- Mrs. William R. Travers has rented the Weaver cottage, on Berkeley Avenue, for the season. Mrs. Travers, who has been the guest of her brother, Joseph Harriman, returned to New York to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- Residents of this city who have been studying the "want" advertisements and personals in The Washington Post are going around with a dazed look. The following advertisements have appeared in a single issue of that sedate journal, and have bewildered the town:

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The Methodist Protestant Conference to-night adopted a partial report of its Church Union Committee; providing a method of union of the Methodist Protestant Church, the Congregationalists, and the United Brethren. The committee suggested a revised method of bringing about the union by which the three churches might be united within a reasonable time, instead of waiting for a long period before the proposals outlined for the amalgamation could be made effective.

It may be that a globe-trotting company of Spanish players will come to New York next season and astonish the Rialto. Ysaac Puga, manager of an organization styled the Luisa Martinez Casado Spanish Dramatic Company, has signified that it is his desire to conquer this metropolis -- to show Americans what real acting is.

No doubt the pressure upon Mayor McCLELLAN to remove Commissioner WOODBURY and appoint a Tammany district leader in his place has been very much increased by the action of the Board of Aldermen in refusing to authorize an appropriation needed to enable the Department of Street Cleaning to do its work more thoroughly and with greater economy.
LONDON, May 27. -- Various dispatches from Tokio and Shanghai give circumstantial accounts of the storming and capture of Kin-Chow (32 miles north of Port Arthur) yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 26. -- William Rodenbach of the New West Side Athletic Club of New York, the middle and heavy weight champion of the Amateur Athletic Union, won a decisive victory over Samuel Berger of the Olympic Club, last night. Although a smaller man by a score of pounds, Rodenbach managed to outpoint Berger and to get the decision at the four-round limit.

A very important musical discovery has just been made in Leicester by the finding in the most unexpected manner of the long lost score of Richard Wagner's "Rule Britannia" overture. The overture, which was written at Konigsberg in 1836, was sent to the London Philharmonic Society in 1840, but it was not produced and was in some mysterious way lost.

It is "Count de" Granberry now among his intimates. That is to say that W.H. Granberry, who is Chairman of the Stock List Committee of the Stock Exchange, has been decorated by the Czar of Russia with the big four-inch star and the cross of the Royal Imperial Order of St. Stanislas in the second class, which is reserved for foreigners.
BUFFALO, May 26. -- To-day's session of the Presbyterian Assembly closed amid great excitement and with the question of union with the Cumberland Branch still unsettled.

In your issue of to-day I notice a dispatch from St. Louis quoting an interview with James M. Donald, Vice President of the Hanover National Bank of New York, in which Mr. Donald says that the prosperity of the country "depends on the prosperity of the banks." Why so, forsooth? Are banks producers? To be sure they are necessary adjuncts for the producers, but their part in world's commerce is a secondary one.

In the nave of the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Precious Blood, in Baxter Street, near Canal, last evening, Guguilo Ruggiero, thirty years old, a musician, living at 219 Mott Street, was shot by Giacomo Geroimini, forty years old, of 214 Canal Street. The men quarreled over Camilla Cavallero Ruggiero, twenty-two years old, of 214 Canal Street, whom the man who was wounded had married by a civil ceremony last Monday.

PARIS, May 26. -- I have interviewed to-day several important members of the Diplomatic Corps, and can assure you that a unanimous feeling of strong condemnation prevails among the diplomatists accredited here with respect to Russia's action in sowing mines broadcast in the Gulf of Pe-chi-Li and thus endangering neutral commerce.

The poolroom syndicate, composed of racing information bureau proprietors, sent the results of the races out yesterday from the syndicate's new headquarters in the banking district. The racing news was received from the track by telegraph, but the Western Union Telegraph Company took no part in distributing it among the poolrooms.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 26. -- The beginning of a new and more friendly era in Anglo-Russian relations is believed to have been inaugurated by the cordial manner in which the Emperor this afternoon, at the Tsarskoe-Selo Palace, received Sir Charles Hardinge, the new British Ambassador.
TACOMA, Washington, May 26. -- Miners on the Tanana River and its tributaries have resorted to steaks of horse and dog meat during the last few weeks while awaiting the arrival of supplies.

A whiff of smoke arising from the grandstand at the Polo Grounds yesterday caused a little excitement, but when it was discovered how trivial the affair was the incident wan soon forgotten. Just after the bell rang for the game between the New York and Brooklyns to begin, which was at 4 o'clock, the smoke appeared in the front of the big stand and close to the players' bench of the New Yorks.

Benjamin Van Buren of 178 Hudson Avenue and Nicholas Hoffart of 71 Waverley Avenue, Brooklyn, passengers on a car of the Bushwick Avenue line, bound for the bridge, were standing on the running board because of the crowd last evening, when, in passing a sewer opening at Flushing Avenue and Adelphi Streets, a protruding plank swept them off.

LONDON, May 27. -- The Shan-hai-Kwan correspondent of The Daily Chronicle sends a report received from Niu-Chwang that on May 23, thinking that the Japanese had retired from Feng-Wang-Cheng, 15,000 Russians from Hai-Cheng and Liao-Yang marched toward Feng-Wang-Cheng.

Mrs. Edward Petzel, who lives on the first floor of the tenement house at 554 West One Hundred and Thirty-second Street, yesterday afternoon went out to make some purchases, leaving her two boys, seven years and one year, respectively, in the apartment, the door of which she looked. The boys got to playing with matches and set fire to the bed.

The verdict of acquittal in the cases of TYNER and BARRETT has a very curious look. Was President ROOSEVELT mistaken when he declared over his official signature that TYNER was one of "the three chief offenders in the Government service" whose wrongdoing was disclosed by the Bristow report? Was he wrong when he said:
In your issue of the 24th inst., in an article entitled "Pig Iron Production to Be Cut Heavily," Mr. B. Nicholl of B. Nicholl Co. says:

More than one of your correspondents have, within the last few days, asked the Englishmen in this country a question to this effect: "If things here are not altogether to your liking, why do you not return to your own country?"

Lawrence J. Curran, who is leading the strike of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad freight handlers, announced last evening that he had sent a cipher dispatch to Chicago to Secretary Flannery of the International Freight Handlers' Union to call out all the freight handlers on the New Haven's system.

Judge Townsend, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday handed down several decisions reversing the Board of United States General Appraisers, on customs cases. Most important of them was the case of W. Nishimiya against the United States, involving the classification of sake, or Japanese rice wine.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 26. -- The General Staff is not in a position to-night so confirm or deny the Tokio report that the Japanese have occupied Kin-Chow. The latest official information regarding fighting in that vicinity was conveyed in a telegram from Gen. Kuropatkin, which said that the Japanese had lost 700 men on May 18. Gen. Kuropatkin apparently accepts the report, which was from a Chinese source.

Two thieves were detected early yesterday morning robbing the far being given by the Ladies' Auxiliary for the benefit of St. Mary's Hospital, Jamaica, L.I., in the new hospital building. The watchman made the discovery shortly after 2 o'clock. The intruders, leaping from a second-story window with a bag of loot, made targets for a dozen revolvers in a half-mile chase.

With a first-class horse race on the cards, it was not to be expected that buying and selling stocks should receive attention yesterday. And even if there had not been more important business to attend to, the approach of a triple holiday would have killed what little interest has been shown recently. The combined effect was to reduce the volume of business to nominal proportions, with no changes in prices worth discussion.

PORT JERKS, May 26. -- A passenger train left this village for Monticello during a storm last evening over a branch of the Ontario and Western Railroad, and at Hartwood ran into a thousand-foot land slide so far that it could neither go ahead nor back out. Soon after another slide occurred behind the train.

Surprises were the characteristic features of the match play rounds yesterday in the metropolitan golf championship tournament on the links of the Garden City Golf Club. Of first importance was the defeat of the title holder, Findlay S. Douglas. Arden M. Robbins of the St. Andrew's Golf Club vanquished the champion by the excellent score of 3 up and 2 to play.

E.B. Thomas, President of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, who yesterday testified before the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the coal hearing, was the first of the railroad Presidents who are also at the head of coal companies to appear entirely happy on the witness stand.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26. -- The Record will publish this to-morrow from Princeton, N.J.:

So many Wall Street habitues were away at the races yesterday that no surprise was expressed when the market in the early afternoon ceased almost entirely. Between 1 o'clock and 2 o'clock the trading amounted to only 6,000 shares, and during the closing hour the transactions fell short of 20,000 shares. Naturally, the changes in prices in market as narrow as this were not of much consequence to either bull or bear.

As a result of a riot last evening involving half a dozen Italian strike breakers employed on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad docks, who were attacked, or thought they were, by men whose places they had taken, Giuseppe Mussili, twenty-six years old, of 83 Mulberry Street, is in the Hudson Street Hospital with a wound through the left shoulder inflicted by Detective Sergeant Galvin, whom the Italian had previously shot.

All the efforts of Tammany members of the Board of Aldermen to displace Mayor John McGaw Woodbury as Commissioner of Street Cleaning have failed to align Charles F. Murphy in opposition to the Commissioner. That the Tammany leader is absolutely and firmly back of Mayor McClellan in his support of Commissioner Woodbury is asserted on high authority, and Mayor McClellan himself has been assured that Mr. Murphy agrees thoroughly with the position he has taken.
Herbert A. Sherman has sold for Charles T. Harbeck 6 West Seventeenth Street, 150 feet west of Fifth Avenue, a three-story dwelling, 25 by 92.

It is plain enough that the withdrawal of the representative of France at the Vatican was really compelled by the extraordinary behavior of Cardinal MERRY DEL VAL. Not "the most Catholic" nation, Spain itself, could put up with so arrogant a lecture upon international etiquette as the Papal Secretary bestowed upon the French Republic.

BALTIMORE, May 26. -- The failure of he Gorman machine, which absolutely controlled the Democratic State Convention to-day, to include Isidor Ryner, United States Senator-elect, in the list of the delegates at large headed by Senator Gorman, has caused much comment in political circles.
PARIS, May 27. -- Mme. Rejane has signed a contract with George C. Tyler of the theatrical firm of Liebler Co. of New York, for an American tour, beginning November next.

ALBANY, May 26. -- Reports of railroad, companies for the quarter ended March 31, 1904, made to the State Railroad Commission show that those operating in New York State had a most disastrous period from a profit-earning standpoint.

Judge Parker's weakness as a candidate for President is more apparent every day, while it is conceded that Grover Cleveland can surely carry the State of New York over Roosevelt. At this juncture, amiability, respectability, and nice deportment, lovely characteristics in themselves and admirable in a nurse, are not the kind most needed at the head of the Government.

As a relief from the inquiry as to whether the volcanic outburst of Summer is agreeable, let us for a moment change the subject and dwell briefly upon the thought of snow in its municipal aspects. The Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia has rendered a decision of unusual interest as defining the duties of citizens under municipal regulations and ordinances as to snow removal.

WASHINGTON, May 26. -- The dissatisfaction of the Republican leaders over Secretary Cortelyou's selection by the President to be Chairman of the National Committee is reported to have culminated to-day in a protest by Senator Aldrich of Rhode Island, who is said to have come here for the purpose.

AT SEA ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, May 26. -- Acting on the information which I communicated to The Times on Sunday concerning the landing of a Japanese force at kai-Chow, on the west coast of the Liao-Tung Peninsula, I left my base on Tuesday for the purpose of verification.

FALL RIVER, Mass., May 26. -- A movement in favor of a general reduction of 10 per cent. in the wages of the cotton textile operatives of this city was formally set on foot at a meeting of the Fall River Manufacturers' Association to-day. The Executive Committee was instructed to secure signatures binding the thirty-five corporations represented in the association to abide by a cut-down in the schedule.
ST. LOUIS, May 26. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt was fairly mobbed upon her arrival here to-day by an enthusiastic crowd of thousands of women.

BALTIMORE, May 26. -- The Democratic State Convention of Maryland met here to-day. Senator Gorman was a delegate from Howard County, and his entry into the convention hall was the signal for enthusiastic applause, as was every remark made by the Senator during the proceedings.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 26. -- A cow, a baby carriage, and a mischievous little girl furnished the citizens of Hancock, Delaware County, with more excitement on Wednesday than they have before experienced in several moons. Mrs. Frank Denison on that day drove her pet cow from a field to her front yard for the purpose of having it mow the lawn in its own way.
LONDON, May 27. -- In a letter to the editor of The Times, J.T. Bucknill, late Major in the Royal Engineers, says:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 26. -- Prof. William Henry Pettee, Senior Professor of Mining Engineering at the University of Michigan, with which institution he had been continuously connected since 1875, dropped dead to-night

GOSHEN, N.Y., May 26. -- A pack of English fox hounds which reached New York Tuesday has arrived at the kennels of the Orange County Hunt in this village. These hounds were imported by E.H. Harriman and John R. Townsend, and are from one of the most celebrated pack of England. They will be exhibited at the Philadelphia Horse Show next week, together with twenty hunters from the Orange County Hunt.

Drawing from their experiences in the cattle-raising country of Texas, Mrs. Grace MacGowan Cooke and Miss Alice MacGowan have collaborated in the writing of "Huldah." Huldah is the mistress of the Wagon Tire House, the only hotel in Blowout; but, more than that, she is a gentle, genial soul whose simple philosophy is that of brotherly love.

MRS. ATHERTON simply made a mistake in forgetting her milieu. Should she live in Hungary for a dozen years or so, until the place became as familiar to her as Lake Placid or Piccadilly, she could write about it without perpetrating the absurdities which we find in "Rulers of Kings."

Robert Norvell, a Lieutenant in the American Army, is sent by Colonel Clark, who has captured Vincennes, to spy out the defenses of Detroit and report on the possibility of surprising its British garrison. At Grosse Ile he meets Felice Constant and falls in love with her, while she, talking to herself after their first meeting, breathes:

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Postmaster General Payne, who will remain with the Republican National Committee as Vice Chairman at the President's request, will not, like Mr. Cortelyou, resign from the Cabinet. He will continue to preside over the Post Office Department, and will make frequent trips to New York and Chicago to give advice and take charge of details which may be assigned to him.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst sailed for Europe on the White Star liner Arabic yesterday. Dr. Parkhurst will be gone four months. He refused to discuss his recent mysterious trip of inspection among the city's saloons, but did not object to discussing Roosevelt, and just before the Arabic sailed said:
Who is the end seat hog? The end seat hog is the man who comes into the ear late and demands that I give up to him my desirable end seat which I secured by being early.

Evidences of the hilarious times enjoyed by detectives who have worked for the District Attorney's office in connection with the Dodge-Morse divorce tangle have for days been piling into the Department of Finance, and the auditing bureau of the Controller's office found yesterday that, with bills in for only two months, the appropriation of $15,000 made to bring Charles F. Dodge back here for trial for perjury is more than half expended.

Shaken down by Fort Wadsworth's heavy gun practice, which seemed to make a bigger racket than ever before, a section of the ceiling of Public School 100 on Coney Island fell with a crash yesterday afternoon. Part of it struck twelve-year-old Alfred Wharen, Jr., of 2,909 West Third Street, and fractured his skull.

Florence Morse Kingsley's "The Singular Miss Smith." which has been appearing serially in The Saturday Evening Post, is now published in book form by the Macmillan Company. The story deals with the servant question from a novel point of view.

NEW HAVEN, May 27. -- Policeman Coonan and two other officers to-night arrested William McLane, a negro, on the charge of attacking an unknown woman on Wednesday near the Evergreen Cemetery, the third of a series of brutal attacks upon young women in what is known as the Prospect Hill section of the city.

Mayor George B. McClellan's chauffeur, Martin Seller, was arrested at Forty-seventh Street and Eighth Avenue last night as he was speeding the Mayor's red automobile at a rate of over fifteen miles an hour.

Some of the lawyers for the poolroom men yesterday made demands upon the New York and New Jersey Telephone Company to replace the telephones which were ripped out of poolrooms by the police last week. The telephone company informed the lawyers that the matter would be referred to the law department of the company and the contracts examined.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 27. -- Gen. Kuropatkin, under date of May 26, telegraphs to the Emperor as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., May 27. -- Ex-Mayor Henry S. Peters of Dover, this State, started yesterday with a party of six from the Passaic River Yacht Club house, at East Newark, on a 4,300-mile trip by yacht to St. Louis, where they propose to attend the exposition. In the party are ex-Mayor Peters's mother and wife, William H. Mains, his uncle; Miss Mains, and Miss Hazel Young.

The hearing of the Inter-State Commerce Commission of the charges brought by William R. Hearst through his counsel, Clarence J. Shearn, in the Federal Court was adjourned yesterday until September, Mr. Shearn having presented his case with the exception of the examination of one witness.

With flags half-masted the steamship Silvia, from St. John's, Newfoundland, got in yesterday morning, having on board the body of Leonidas Hubbard, Jr., Outing's editor and explorer, who died of starvation in the wilds of Labrador last October. The body was in charge of A. Dillon Wallace, the New York lawyer, who went to Labrador with Mr. Hubbard.

PARIS, May 27. -- The attitude of the French officials toward the question of Russia's conduct in sowing bombs in the Gulf of Pe-chi-Li is, as I have already explained, very guarded, for, although Russia is by no means so popular in this country as might be supposed, the Government has to speak and act with the utmost discretion when affairs of its friend and ally are concerned.

It has remained for Miss Rives to put Byron into a novel. The Castaway is none other than George Gordon and the novel is a highly colored and romantic story of the English poet's life -- very much such a one as he himself suggested that his history should be: "The Loves of Lord Byron."

G.P. Putnam's Sons are publishing this week "Ferdinand the Great, and the Rise of Prussia," in the Heroes of the Nations Series, by W.F. Reddaway, M.A.; "Belgian Life in Town and Country," by Demetrius C. Boulger, in Our European Neighbors Series, and a new edition of the "Letters and Speeches of Oliver Cromwell," by Thomas Carlyle, edited by S.C. Lomas, with an introduction by C.H. Firth.

FAMILIARITY does not always breed contempt. Of so much this book of Mlle. Vacaresco is proof. "I have," says she, "met almost all the reigning sovereigns of modern Europe and their consorts, and have much to relate about them, since I soon became a keen observer of every Court I stepped into."

THE new matter in the centenary edition of Emerson's poems includes four pieces sufficiently complete to have titles, "Insight," "September," "October," and "Riches," and also some of the twenty early pieces written during the period of the poet's school teaching, study for the ministry, his illness, bereavement, travel, and return to his own land.

The writer has been deeply interested in reading a memoir of the Rev. Sydney Smith, England's famous wit, humorist, projector of The Edinburgh Review, and for over forty years one of the most distinguished and powerful contributors, and in later life prebendary of old St. Paul's, London.

Henry H. Hendricks, junior member of the firm of Hendricks Brothers of 49 Cliff Street, the oldest metal house in the United States, dropped dead in the waiting room of the Christopher Street Ferry yesterday morning.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 27. -- Yale having accepted the challenge to compete abroad with Harvard against the Oxford Cambridge athletes, her plans have been left with Capt. E.J. Clapp of the track team, and Joseph B. Thomas, Jr., '03. The meet will consist of eleven events, making it necessary for six to be won.

Editorially few New York newspapers have given the meetings of the Merchant Marine Commission consideration. There is no more reason why we should give up shipbuilding than why we should give up building locomotives, or automobiles, or wagons, or mill machinery, or anything else.

Messrs. Sheringham and Meakin call their story "a midsummer idyll compiled out of the traditions of the Irresponsible Club." The members of the club are six, and include the Ambassador, courtly, gallant, and diplomatic, as an Ambassador should be; the Scribe, humorous, kind-hearted and thoughtful; the Mime, the Poet, the Exotic, and the Man of Truth, all truly irresponsible if left to themselves.

Pushing and elbowing their way through the crowd in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, two City Marshals and a policeman dragged a prisoner before the bar. The prisoner described himself as Adolph Sachet, owner of a candy store at 134 Monroe Street.

Three men battled with a powerful python in Central Park yesterday, and after one of the men had been bitten, another badly squeezed, and all three scared almost out of their senses, the big snake was overcome and tossed, a writhing mass, into the corner of the cage.

There is something entirely new in reed furniture, and it has so distinguished an air that it may be called "smart." It is made after the style of iVfission furniture. with the straight lines, but is of reeds stained a dark wood tone {nd upholstered with Spanish leather. In one handsome set there are four pieces.

Five allegorical stories are told within the sixty-five pages of this volume. Of these, "Is He the Dearest One?" and "A Legend of the Sea" may be considered as being two more of the parables related by the Polish novelist for the purpose of perpetuating national pride among the members of his race.

In the June number of Harpers' Magazine is a story-entitled "A Little Candle." It is a child's story. This paragraph occurs in it, almost at the beginning:" 'How many fingers have you on your right hand? How many on your left? How many on both?' The teacher read the questions with labored precision from Smith's Arithmetic."

" The Gems of the East," A. Henry Savage Landor's new book of scoutings in the dim corners of those isles of the sea where the Malays dwell, is announced for publication by Messrs. Harper Brothers on June 3. Mr. Landor in the opening chapter makes delightful promises of what the book is to be:
BEAVER, Penn., May 27.--To-night the family of Senator Quay are all under one roof at the old homestead. The absent ones arrived one by one during the day.

Charles Scribner's Sons have decided to postpone the inauguration of their Library of Ancient Inscriptions until next Autumn. The series will be as already announced, under the editorship of Profs. C.F. Kent and F.K. Sanders of Yale University, and will open with "Babylonian and Assyrian Laws, Contracts, and Letters," by the Rev. C.H.W. Johns, M.A., of Columbia University.

CHICAGO, May 27. -- Dr. Thomas Darlington, Health Commissioner of New York City, inspected several branches of Chicago's Health Department to-day. He was interested in reasons why the death rate of Chicago is lower than that of New York.

PARIS, May 27. -- After an exciting debate, in which Premier Combes and Foreign Minister Delcasse set forth the action and purposes of the Government toward the Vatican, the Chamber of Deputies to-day, by an overwhelming vote, approved the course of the Government in recalling M. Nisard, Ambassador to the Vatican, and rejected all propositions of the extreme element for an immediate dissolution of the relations between Church and State.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 27. -- Cleveland and St. Louis played a postponed game to-day, Cleveland winning by bunching hits off Glade in the third and fifth innings. Donahue kept the St. Louis players' hits scattered. Bay's batting was a feature. The Chicago baseball team watched the game from the grand stand. Attendance, 4,018.

Aside from the books that are conventionally stated to be "most in demand," there are a number, particularly in the juvenile category, which because they are recommended for libraries and other special purposes, pass from one edition to another almost without notice. The Century Company say that "Lady Jane," by Mrs. C.V. Jamison, published thirteen years ago, was printed for the fourteenth time in April last.

Folsom Brothers have sold for J. and N. Cohen the six-story elevator apartment house known as the Roxburghe, at 237 and 239 West One Hundred and Eleventh Street, on plot 50 by 100.11. The price was about $100,000.

IT is the salient and the characteristic virtue of the novels of Mr. Winston Churchill that as weighty chapter succeeds weighty chapter they give one the sense of breadth and moment -- the sweep of great historical epochs.

From recent developments it seems more than likely that the Public Schools Athletic League of New York will, within a reasonable time, have a field and track upon which to hold its competitions. The committee having the welfare of the league at heart, composed of Gen. George W. Wingate, S.R. Guggenheim, Dr. Luther Halsey Gulick, James E. Sullivan, and Gustavus T. Kirby, have been engaged in making plans toward this end.

In this volume Mr. Hulbert turns from the purpose of the series to which it belongs and begins a treatment of the historic highways of America by another method. He wishes to show how these highways were evolved from Indian trails to the traveled roads of frontier civilization, and to give an idea of the part they played in that life and the development of the country.
The Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday overruled a protest by A.A. Vantine Co.

LONDON, May 27. -- An important addition to the expert judgment of the world in regard to floating mines on the high seas is contained in a statement, prepared in response to a request by THE NEW YORK TIMES'S correspondent, by Sir Frederick Pollock, Bart., one of the most learned lawyers of Great Britain and one of the highest authorities on international law.

If any one wants to start a corner in "dope," now is the time to do it. One of the firms in this city which deals in opium and essential oils has sent out letters to rich men and those who are supposed to be interested in anything that permits of a corner, explaining that the supply of opium is far below the normal.

Dr. Emil Reich, whose "Success Among Nations" will be published next week by Harper Brothers, has in the book a variety of things to say about different kinds of national success, as economic success in Egypt and in Carthage; success in imperialism represented by Macedonia, Rome, Venice, Spain, Holland, England; intellectual success, represented by Greece, by the Renaissance Italians; religious success, represented by Jews, Catholics, Calvinists.
It was in the gray dawn of yesterday morning. There were three of them, and they had been either celebrating the result of the Brooklyn Handicap or drowning their sorrow over the same.
WASHINGTON, May 27. -- The following cablegram has been received at the Japanese Legation:

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 27. -- By the decisive yea and nay vote of 441 to 188, the Methodist General Conference to-day decided not to make any change in the Church discipline in the matter of prohibited amusements.

Speaking of the term "the Great," in relation to Emperor Frederick, W.F. Reddaway says in his book in the Heroes of the Nations Series on "Frederick the Great, and the Rise of Prussia," that he deserved the title because of his home administration rather than his conquests. From the moment of his father's death, the author continues, Frederick "was master of his people and of his policy as few European potentates have ever been."

CHICAGO, May 27. -- Photographic reproductions of the spectra of the sun and the brightest stars are about to be undertaken by Prof. George E. Hale, Director of the Yerkes Observatory, on Mount Wilson, near Pasadena, Cal., a grant of $10,000 from the Carnegie Institution a few months ago having enabled Prof. Hale to build a new horizontal telescope, with which instrument he expects to conduct observations on Mount Wilson.
It is certainly incumbent on the representatives of the City of New York to take advantage of the Governor's offer of an extra session of the Legislature to consider this city's water supply problem.

By way of variety, after the sweep made by the best-backed horses on Brooklyn Handicap day, the long-chance division was prominent yesterday at the Gravesend race course, three of the six events, including the single stake race of the programme, going to outsiders, against whom odds of from 10 up to 15 to 1 were laid.

The story of "Dorothea" gives contrasting pictures of a narrow, strait-laced Dutch community, and of the brilliant, complex Continental society that converges in Paris. Of this queen city of fascinations, the portrayal is wonderful. It literally rises "like an exhalation" from the pages. Much wisdom is couched in the epigrams which sparkle through the finely casual dialogue, and every character is a creation, not a manufacture, each sustaining its individuality unfalteringly to the close.

ORANGE, N.J., May 27. -- Superintendent of Public Schools Dr. William M. Swingie of Orange has decided the standing of the shirt-waist man, or rather boy, and has announced that shirt waists don't go in the High School, even if it is hot weather.

I have been much interested in the descriptions of early samplers which have appeared in the last two issues of THE BOOK REVIEW, and feel that an old sampler worked by an ancestor of mine deserves "honorable mention."

Just inside the entrance to Central Park, at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon, nineteen-year-old Margaret Brandalon of 325 East Twenty-third Street, and her sister, Frances, who is a year her junior, were attacked, the police say, by Charles Green, a young negro, of 228 West Sixty-first Street.

Mrs. Wharton is one of the few contributors to current fiction who practically take the view that that art is a branch of literature. This circumstance so far distinguishes her from the mob of gentlewomen who write with ease and are read with difficulty or not at all by literary readers as to give such readers a special interest in what she does.

The letters are, one and all, absolutely artless and natural -- not composed with an eye to publication, as were those of Pope, Walpole, Gray, Byron, and even Coleridge himself. They were, in fact, written primarily for the writer's own pleasure, and because he was fastidious in his pleasures, and above all things detested fine writing and cleverness prepense, he sedulously resisted all temptation to premeditate.

The chief and most significant feature of a history of caricature must be the reproduction of skillfully and discriminatingly chosen specimens of what has been done by the most influential caricaturists. In this respect Messrs. Maurice and Cooper have made their book an important contribution to the subject. There are a few omissions that seem all the more singular in the copiousness of the illustrations.

Unless Corporation Counsel Delany finds legal fault with the form of the permit to the New York, Westchester and Boston Railroad to cross streets of the Bronx in the construction of an electric road, the Board of Estimate and Apportionment will, at its next meeting, finally approve the terms fixed by Controller Grout and return the matter to the Board of Aldermen.

TOKIO, May 27. -- The Japanese Army swept the Russians from Kin-Chow yesterday morning and in a desperate attack stormed the almost impregnable position of the Russians on Nanshan Hill, west of Talien-wan.

The Trust Companies' Association of the State of New York was formally launched yesterday at a meeting of representatives of fifty out of the eighty-odd trust companies in the State in the Directors' 'room of the Mutual Life Insurance Company. Articles of association were adopted and officers elected.

Barring the business in Detroit Southern yesterday's stock market was about as tame a performance as even the most violent opponent of excitement could possibly require. That the performance was entirely perfunctory was clearly enough demonstrated by the smallness of the day's transactions and the smallness of the day's net changes.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 27. -- George J. Gould, who with Miss Helen Gould has large estates in Delaware County, has just given an order for 200,000 trout fry to be placed in Dry Brook and other streams in the vicinity of Arkville and Margaretville.

READVILLE, Mass., May 27.--The five days' combination suction sale of thoroughbred horses at the Readville trotting park closed to-day. Sixty-four horses were sold to-day, bringing $17,000, or an average of $281.

The President's choice of Secretary CORTELYOU for Chairman of the Republican National Committee irresistibly compels reference to the classic anecdote of the colored gentleman to whom the object of his affections had sent a safety razor. Holding the gift at arm's length and viewing it with the eye of disapproval, he exclaimed: Miss Maria ought to know that that ain' any kind of an instrument for a gemman to carry to a pahty.''

ONE of the most noticeable contributions to the June magazines is H.G. Dwight's "Henrietta Stackpole Rediviva" in Scribner's. We note that this is classified in the publishers' announcements as a "short story," but if it is not true, it is nothing at all. So we are compelled to accept Mr. Dwight's article as a statement of absolute fact, and, thus viewed, it is both interesting and important.

MISS CLARA BARTON'S resignation of the Presidency of the Red Cross Society, a position she has held since the society was organized, more than twenty years ago, gives particular interest to her "Story of the Red Cross," which will be published some time next month by D. Appleton Co.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 27. -- The General Staff, in view of the foreign news of the capture of Kin-Chow, admitted that there was little now to hinder a Japanese advance on Port Arthur itself, and that the actual siege of the Gibraltar of the East had now begun in earnest. The Staff insisted, however, on the ability of the fortress to hold out.

Two new volumes in The Langham Series of Art Monographs are being issued by Charles Scribner's Sons. They are "The Illustrators of Montmartre," by Frank L. Emanuel, and "Auguste Rodin," by Rudolf Dircks, author of "Verisimilitudes," "The Libretto,"

ONCE, long ago, Christopher Wren entertained the idea that London might be rebuilt on a better plan. That was when the great fire of 1666 took place. Even then all he could have done would have been to rebuild the City.

For the Editor's Study of this month's Harper's, by way of introducing the opening chapters of Mrs. Humphry Ward's new novel, "The Marriage of William Ashe," Mr. Henry M. Alden has written some interesting words about the continued vogue of the serial story. He recalls the publication serially in Harper's Magazine of "Little Dorrit," "The Adventures of Philip," and "Daniel Deronda." He says:

THREE Years in the Klondike" is an essentially clever book, giving a clear and vivid account of a part of the Klondike region, with particulars as to the methods of mining. Dawson is described under various conditions. In 1898 the author left San Francisco for the Klondike.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was further hampered yesterday in its efforts to deal with the situation brought about by the striking freight handlers, when President Curran of the International Union succeeded in inducing more than 150 Italian strike breakers to quit work on the Fall River pier, at the foot of Murray Street.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- The preliminary heats in the first intercollegiate track and field championship meet ever held outside of New York took place on Franklin Field this afternoon. The number of contestants entered was so large that trials were necessary in eleven out of the thirteen events on the programme.

BUFFALO, May 27. -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, by an overwhelming viva voce vote to-day, adopted the report of the Committee on Union with the Cumberland Presbyterian Church. The question of the proposed basis of union will now go to the Presbyteries of the General Assembly.

LONDON, May 28. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the Russian Ministry of Public Instruction has issued a circular instructing the directors of secondary schools to instill in the minds of their pupils a carefully elaborated theory of the orgin and significance of the present war.

By uphill play in a fast four-set tennis match, Wylie C. Grant and Robert Le Roy won the doubles championship of the New York Lawn Tennis Club yesterdoy on the courts at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. They defeated Robert T. Bryan and Arthur T. Friedman by the score 2 -- 6. 8 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2.

The Daniel Press of Worcester House, Oxford, was made the subject of an article in The London Times of Feb. 20, 1903. This press, instituted by the Rev. C.H.O. Daniel in 1874, had, up to the time of the article, printed fifty-three books and brochures, and about a dozen fly-leaves.

WHATEVER may be thought in England of Mr. Gilbert K. Chesterton's first acknowledged work of fiction, "The Napoleon of Notting Hill," (John Lane,) it must seem a waste of much effort to an American who knows little and nothing of English politics or peculiarly English habits of thought, and cares less.

Stories of Nebraska in its early days as a Territory, "when it was toddling 'round in short pants, you might say, getting used to its own feet." The relator, a shrewd but kindly David Harum of the West, tells them with a relish for the memory of the days when he and hundreds of others went out to woo the virgin wilderness.

In A.S. Barnes Co.'s Woman's Home Library Series, edited by Mrs. Margaret E. Sangster, Mrs. Cynthia Westover Alden writes the first volume on "Women's Ways of Earning Money," (small 12mo. New York: A.S. Barnes Co.,. $1.) In twenty-five chapters she gives about that many different suggestions for the guidance of those who are suddenly thrown upon their own resources without knowing just what they should do.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- Boston won today's game by opportune hitting, scoring 3 runs to 2 for the home team. Both Willis and Frazer were in good form and the result was in doubt until the last man was out. Attendance, 730. Score by Innings:

" The Wizard's Son" and "The Beleaguered City," by Mrs. Oliphant, are very good supernatural stories. Lewis's "Tales of Horror and Wonder" ought to be good. They are published by Cassells. Blackwood's Magazine made a specialty of supernatural stories. Poe wrote a skit on them.

With a large class of novel readers there is always a keen sympathy with the men and women who blazed the trail on the frontier; those who defended their homesteads and stockades against fierce American Indians -- the most cruel, wily, and warlike foe that civilized force ever encountered.

Mrs. Aubrey Le Blond's "Adventures on the Roof of the World" is a work not intended for the climbers, but to give the general public an acquaintance with mountaineering. In the introductory chapter Mrs. Le Blond tells of the Alpine guides, and she writes, "The mountain guides of Switzerland form a class unlike any other, yet in the high standard of honor and devotion they display toward those in their charge they have no equals."

Water has found another victim among the corporations of Wall Street, according to an announcement made in the Street yesterday, when an official explanation was made of the reason why the Detroit Southern Railroad would be unable to pay the July coupons on its first mortgage bonds. In this case it was not the water in the stock, but bad water in the engines which caused the trouble.
LONDON, May 27. -- The demand for money in the market was increased today, it being payday on the Stock Exchange. Discounts were easier, owing to firmer Continental exchanges.

In a sense the Japanese victory at Kin-Chow completes the investment of Port Arthur. That is to say, it completes the investment of the small peninsula, some thirty miles in extent, which forms the extremity of the great Liao-Tung Peninsula, and of which in turn Port Arthur forms the extremity.

WASHINGTON, May 27. -- Members of the District Government are likely to ride in automobiles at the public expense if the District Attorney is not at fault in his construction of the last District Appropriation bill passed by Congress.

One word more concerning the unfortunate Elizabeth and the much-injured feelings of her devoted admirers. We who really do not love her to distraction are forced in self-defense to state that it is by no means proved that we are utterly devoid of the saving sense of humor merely because "our friends the enemy" say so.

From certain facts which developed yesterday in the Surrogate's office it was made evident that there will be a bitter contest in the courts over the estate of the late David Stevenson, the brewer, who died in 1892 and left over $3,000,000.

MME. SARAH GRAND is very much in evidence these days. She is writing a series of articles in one of the leading daily papers in which she attacks her own as well as the other sex. Men, she assures us, have lost the sense of honor that once was a male characteristic.

-- Our recent expression of profound doubt as to whether "the long-lost art of tempering copper" ever existed anywhere to be lost by anybody has elicited some real information of exactly the sort we expected to get if we got any -- the information, that is, that there is no information on the subject to be obtained except the information that there is none.

This volume ("Masters in Art: A Series of Illustrated Monographs." Quarto, pp. 504, gilt top, uncut, cloth. Boston: Bates Guild Company) is made up of monographs on George Romney, Fra Angelico, Watteau, the frescoes of Raphael, Donatello, Gerard Dou, Carpaccio, Rosa Bonheur, Guido Reni, Puvis de Chavannes, Giorgione, and Rossetti.
