Not all the pains that may be taken to give rumors of the renewed tender of our good offices to the combatants in the Far East an inspired and semi-official form will make careful observers of the progress of events believe that there is any foundation for them. We all have complete confidence in the President's benevolence and in the Secretary of State's discretion.

Volume IV, of the works of Charles and Mary Lamb, edited by E.V. Lucas, being "Dramatic Specimens and the Garrick Plays," (8vo. Gilt top. Uncut, Red silk. Green paper label. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $2.25,) contains three illustrations, the frontispiece, a photogravure portrait of Charles Lamb from the painting by William Hazlitt, the title page of the first edition of Lamb's "Specimens," and a picture of the British Museum in Lamb's day.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27. -- The closing session here of the Merchant Marine Commission was held to-day. One of the principal speakers was Edwin S. Cramp, Vice President of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, who declared himself in favor of differential duties as a means of reviving commerce.

LONDON, May 27. -- The Spring publishing season has about ended. Many books previously announced for early publication will be held until the Autumn. Even with these, the number of notable books thus far announced for the Autumn lists is not large.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 27. -- United States Senator Kean makes warm denial of the story that he has had differences with President Roosevelt over the selection of Secretary Cortelyou for the Chairmanship of the Republican National Committee. He says that he went to the White House yesterday only to recommend the appointment of Representative Lanning as Judge Kirkpatrick's successor in the United States District Court.

I cannot quite share Mr. E.A. Wilson's opinion that you "should certainly know better than to call 'conspicuous by his absence' 'a clumsy adaptation of a French phrase.' "I do not recall Lord Brougham's use of the phrase, but it is familiar to me in French current literature, where, indeed, it recurs so often as to justify classing it as a "tag."

THIS has been a belated Spring season, when, after many promises and a dreary waiting time of nipped buds and deferred hopes, leaf and flower -- suddenly unfurl with a swirl and rush that savor of the magical.

The American Economist this week devotes a large amount of space in its current number to an article by FRANCIS CURTIS, who seeks to show that the bond issues in the second Administration of Mr. CLEVELAND were made necessary by the "free trade victory" of 1892, which demoralized and frightened the business men of the country and led to the depletion of the Treasury.

ROME, May 27. -- The Vatican authorities followed closely the debate in the French Chamber of Deputies to-day, reports of which were received through special dispatches and taken to the Pope by Cardinal Merry del Val, the Papal Secretary of State.

Cincinnati's loss of a game to Pittsburg yesterday and the success of the New York and Chicago teams caused the former to drop from the lead in the National League series into third place, although the record after the games on the previous day showed the Cincinnatis to be 30 points ahead. The New York and Chicagos are now tied for the lead, with Cincinnati one point in the rear.

The explosion at Broadway and Thirty-second Street in the early morning hours of yesterday was without fatalities for no better reason than that the street at that time was practically empty. This was an explosion in an electrical subway of illuminating gas in admixture with air.

The pretty, dark-haired little girl who for the last six years has been the sunshine of the comfortable home of Valery Noisette, a well-to-do and elderly importer of 118 West Seventeenth Street, has gone from the big house where she was so gladly welcomed before she was old enough to walk alone, and she is not likely to return.

DODD, MEAD CO. announce for early Autumn publication a new novel by, Marie Corelli. It is described as "a story of pure love and faith, and is more on the lines of 'Thelma' than any book which the author has written since that book."

GREENWICH, Conn., May 28. -- President Charles Singer of the New York and Stamford Railway is to inaugurate a parlor trolley service Monday, charging double fare for seats in the parlor car of the company and running it between Port Chester and Rye Beach.

Henry W. Taft and David H. Miller, receivers for Daniel J. Sully Co., yesterday declined to make the demand for delivery to them of 190,000 bales of spot cotton, which action the Sully firm had urged against the forty firms with which Sully had outstanding contracts. The Sully demand was based on the technicality that he had not failed, but only suspended.

MEMORIAL Day marks the opening of the outing season, This is an axiom, Society has not gone abroad this Summer in any large representation, and the ships coming in from European ports are filled with returning tourists. Within a fortnight Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Mrs. Ogden Goelet, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexei, Mr. and Mrs. William B. Leeds, and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lydig will be in this country.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Marion De Vries the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Hunter Whitcombe and others of New York against the assessment at 45 per cent. as manufactures of cotton of certain curtains, tapestry goods, table covers and doylies made of cotton damask.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The fact that there has been a tentative discussion in the War and Navy Departments as to the ultimate consolidation of various Government departments using wireless telegraph system has led to a report that the Government is to take control of the wireless telegraph business of the Atlantic and Pacific seacoasis. A high authority in the Navy Department, in discussing the matter, said to-night:

NEWARK, N.J., May 28. -- Four young men were ordained to the priesthood by Bishop O'Connor in St. Patrick's Cathedral to-day. They are Paul P. Gutere, Henry A. Beale, James Reynolds and Everard A. Degnen. At the same time a number of sub-deacons were made.

Nothing happened in the market last week. The Stock Exchange was open as usual, and some stocks were sold at changes in price interesting to their owners, or mayhap to sellers who were not owners, but of anything like a general and decided price tendency, interesting to market students at large, there was no more sign than there has been for weeks together.
ST. PETERSBURG, May 28. -- The Emperor has received the following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin, dated May 27:

There have been held in Europe and recently in the City of Washington large patriotic charity fairs and functions in aid of the Russian Red Cross organization, but I have hear of no movement for the Japanese Red Cross in this or any country.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28. -- Disguised by a rough coat, an automobile cap with a long pointed brim, and huge automobile goggles Reginald C. Vanderbilt twice eluded New York detectives armed with subpoenas calling upon him to appear and testify regarding knowledge of gambling in Richard Canfield's establishment. He passed through New York twice and arrived safely in this city, where he has registered some of his finest horses for the Wissahickon horse show.
We fear it will be difficult for the most friendly of commentators to extract from the career of Senator QUAY any lesson that will be kindly to his memory and helpful to righteousness.
The idea running through your editorial of this morning, "Church and State," is that the Catholic Church receives a species of charity or gratuitous support from the French Republic.

HARRISBURG, Penn., May 28. -- Owing to the death of Senator Quay, Gov. Pennypacker has recalled the invitations for the state dinner to the Justices of the Supreme Court at the Executive Mansion on Tuesday evening. Speaking of the Senator's death, the Governor said:

Harold Wilcox won the metropolitan golf championship yesterday in the final thirty-six-hole round on the links of the Garden City Golf Club. He defeated Percy R. Pyne, Jr., of the Morris County Golf Club, Morristown, N.J., by 6 up and 4 to play. Wilcox is the youngest golfer who has ever won a prominent championship in the local territory.

A reader of THE TIMES has asked for information about the duties of bank Directors in New York and the emoluments of their service. The query is a natural one in view of a banking situation like that in the financial district of the city, especially, and to a large extent in other parts as well, in which the majority of banks are individually known as belonging to some particular group or sphere of influence.

DALLAS, Texas, May 28. -- Richard Weaver, sixteen years old, to-day avenged the death of his father, Houston Weaver, who was shot and killed without apparent cause in front of the village Post Office at Witmer, twelve miles south of here, just four months ago to-night.

SMALL HOSPITAL WARDS are the latest features among the comforts and conveniences of the shops in a big city. In some of the shops there are trained nurses always in attendance, and in others perfectly equipped doctors' offices, where all sorts and kinds of ailments are treated, minor surgical operations performed, and, in special emergency cases, future shoppers are assisted into the world amid surroundings eminently appropriate.

The New York and Chicago teams gained a point on the Cincinnatis yesterday, although all three teams won. Cincinnati had a fairly easy time with the National League champions, but the New Yorks did not secure the victory from Brooklyn until the eleventh inning, while the Chicagos, after being outbatted, beat St. Louis by a run. At Philadelphia the Bostons won again from the locals by a score of 5 to 3.

THE Housing of the Bachelor is a subject of timely interest at this period of the year, when, proverbs to the contrary, house and apartment dwellers are trying to disprove the theory that it is cheaper to move than it is to pay rent.

IN no part of the world has the woman spy been brought to the point so near perfection as in Europe, and it may be unhesitatingly said that in Russia, which fairly swarms with eyes and ears of the Czar, the dashing, beautiful woman, of high breeding and title, perhaps, has become the most necessary arm of that underground system which appears to read thoughts as well as detect designs.

THE Japanese propensity for "miniaturizing" has of late led to experiments with many plants not native to the Flowery Kingdom, and as a result there are now shown heliotropes, impatiens, cacti, , from one and a half to four inches in height, which are not merely small examples of these different families, but wizened growths, of mature habits and proportion, perfect duplicates of the plants nature planned on a scale several hundred times larger.

Whether or not the nice distinction between "trading with" bucket shops and "trading for" them will avail those members of the Stock Exchange who are under suspicion of being engaged in improper dealings, and who are said to have evoked this distinction in defense of their course, it is probable that the value of the technicality will be small in the eyes of disinterested observers.

The Russian hope that Port Arthur would prove to be another Sebastopol must be becoming very dim. The conditions which enabled the Crimean fortress to hold out for nearly a year are lacking here -- the uninterrupted communication with the "hinterland," the divided counsels and feeble action of the allies.

The Board of Governors of the Brooklyn Yacht Club announced yesterday that Sir Thomas Lipton's offer to place in the custody of the club a cup for an ocean race from Gravesend Bay to Marblehead, Mass., had been accepted. Sir Thomas, who has been on an extended yachting trip in the Mediterranean, has informed the club that he would have the cup made and forwarded upon his return to London.

For several weeks reports have been published regarding the scarcity of negro labor in the cottonfields and agricultural districts of the South, and some one has put the blame all upon the lynchings. Will you allow me to put these persons on the right track and show them the true reason? Ever since the war there has been a tendency toward raising the negro above the drudgery of the fields.
Oliver P. Malone of the Russell Erwin Manufacturing Company returned last week from a business trip to Mexico. He will sail for Europe next month.
JOPLIN, Mo., May 28. -- Miss Maude McGee, queen-elect of the Joplin Carnival to be held next week, was attacked by Mrs. B.R. Weyland at a late hour last night in the Pyramid Lodge rooms.

SEOUL, Korea, May 28. -- Edward V. Morgan, United States Consul at Port Dalny, who arrived here yesterday, is the first American official to journey from Fusan to Soul overland. The trip took ten days.

Fearing that such action on their part might precipitate trouble, the Brooklyn police will not stop the baseball game to be played this afternoon at Washington Park by the New York and Brooklyn teams. It has been decided to obtain evidence as to the circumstances under which the game is conducted and submit the question of the legality of Sunday baseball to the Supreme Court for settlement.

CARRYING the church to Sunday workers is one of the new fields of activity taken up by the City Mission Society of 38 Bleecker Street. So far only the employes on the elevated trains and stations and a few surface road employes in Manhattan are reached. As soon as more missionaries can be secured Sunday workers of every sort will receive attention.

BUFFALO, May 28. -- The Presbyterian General Assembly brought its sessions to a close this evening. It was one of the most memorable gatherings of this denomination held in recent years, marking, it is believed, the prelude to union of all branches of the Presbyterian denomination in the United States.

NOW is the time when amateur photographers by the hundred turn their thoughts toward nature photography and resolve that before the Summer is over they will be able to show their friends some really startling pictures of bird, animal, and insect life. And bird photography appeals to the majority of amateurs as the most attractive of these subjects.

The Census Bureau issues a bulletin of some interest relating to the use of the telephone in the United States. From the figures given it appears that in 1902 there were something more than five thousand millions of telephone messages exchanged in the United States. This suggests some calculations which may profitably employ the arithmeticians.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 28. -- In a race rowed under ideal conditions here to-day Cornell's Second Varsity crew defeated the Harvard Second Varsity eight by three lengths of open water, in the slow time of 11:27 2-5. The time was more than a minute slower than the record for the course.

There were no prices yesterday, the Exchanges being closed. On Monday the banks and the Exchanges will both be closed. As Saturday was not a legal holiday the banks were open, but business was nominal. Abroad the chief thing of interest was the strength of Japanese bonds and weakness of Russian on the war news.

LONDON, May 21. -- Lord Cawdor created unparalleled sensation in the House of Lords the other night by rising to address it with his hat on. Unconscious of his offense, he added to the comicality of the scene by angrily regarding noble lords who greeted him with shouts of "Order!"

PITTSBURG, May 28. -- Matthew Stanley Quay, senior Senator from Pennsylvania, slept peacefully into death at 2:48 this afternoon at Beaver, after an illness which had been more or less persistent for the past year, which took a turn for the worse ten days ago, and which the doctors diagnosed as chronic gastritis.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 28. -- Several of the largest houses were opened to-day, including Inchiquin, which Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones will occupy. Mr. and Mrs. Jones arrived to-day on the steam yacht Narada. They were accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Childs and Mrs. Charles M. Oelrichs. Mr. Oelrichs will remain over Decoration Day with his family, who are occupying their cottage on Kay Street.
It was hot and it was dusty. The horses had toiled hard all day long and, even though they did weigh three-quarters of a ton apiece, they were tired.

THE Art Museum of the Cooper Union has received a very suitable gift from Mr. George A. Hearn in the shape of a large painting by the French Court painter, C.J. Natoire. It embodies a famous old anecdote of classic times which was often taken before Natoire, and has been used since his period.

AMONG people familiar with the physical aspects of the country there can hardly be two opinions concerning tho n!ost majestic and imposing enlinence within its borders. Much as they admire thip eminence, the idea that it is entitled to be regarded as an industrial factor never has occurred to them.

In a market of the present character it seems very unlikely that there will be any well-defined line separating the busier Spring months from the less active period between June 1 and Oct. 1. Large real estate interests, both corporate and individual, are practically just where they have been for the last twelve months -- well loaded up with valuable properties.

Criticised severely by dissatisfied stockholders of the company and apologized for by the friends of the management that prepared it, the recent annual report of the Corn Products Company seems to offer a striking example of accounting methods that are directly opposed to the recognized movement of the day toward fullness and accuracy in the statements submitted by the management of corporations to stockholders.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 28. -- There is no attempt here to disguise the fact that the successful forcing of the neck of the Kwan-Tung Peninsula proper puts a practical end to resistance to the enemy until he reaches the actual fortifications around Port Arthur.

ARTICHOKES will not be cheaper this season. Those from California are 10 cents each and the French ones sell at double the price. The cheaper variety is, as a rule, insipid and lacks the nutty quality of the imported, while it is palatable when served with a rich gravy sauce or a fine Hollandaise sauce, the flesh of the vegetable, or "fond,' alone being used.

"Anti-Cleric" will never "square" anything if he does not go to the trouble of using his brains to do it. Any one with the smallest perception might see that Archbishop Mesmer's answer in regard to voting the Social Democratic ticket involved the relations between Socialism and the teachings of the Catholic Church, and consequently has nothing to do with Republican or Democratic principles, so there is really nothing to square.

LONDON, May 20. -- The success of "Cynthia," which was produced at Wyndham's Theatre on Monday, was due entirely to the personal charm and capable acting of Ethel Barrymore and not to the merit of Hubert Henry Davies's play. Almost all the London critics pronounced "Cynthia" thin and unconvincing and a disappointment after "Cousin Kate" and "Mrs. Gorringe's Necklace," Davies's two earlier plays.
Port Arthur, now cut off from all communication by land and sea, has been, during the many years of quiet preparation for war, Japan's one objective point.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- A.F. White, who is employed by the Japanese Government as mechanical engineer at the Government shipyard at Tokio, is here on his way to England, having recently left Japan for a vacation of a few weeks. He called to-day on the British Ambassador and Japanese Minister.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 28. -- A further confession was made to-day by William McLane, the colored youth who when he was arrested last night admitted that he was the author of an attack on Miss Mary E. Flanagan in Canal Street early in the week. The police now believe that McLane committed the three assaults which have occurred in the neighborhood of Whitney Avenue and Prospect Street recently.
Will you allow me space in your valuable columns to present to your readers a few considerations regarding the relations, past and present, of England and Russia toward this country?

The housewives in the flathouse at 93 Magnolia Avenue, Jersey City Heights, are eagerly seeking a ventriloquist with a box of the most tempting strawberries. He walked down the avenue yesterday with the box in his hands and shouting for customers at 5 cents per box. Mrs. Gint called him to the basement of the house to bargain with him down the dumb-waiter shaft for a lot.

No better demonstration of the self-destructive tendencies of monopolies has been shown to the financial community and to the public at large for some time than that afforded by the Denver and Southwestern Railway Company's ignominious collapse which has just resulted in the bringing out of the most radical plan for reorganization of which there is any record.

Naphtha on board the fishing sloop Joe Pickett, tied up for the night at Bay Thirty-second Street, Bath Beach, blew up just before midnight, last night, destroying the vessel, and burning and otherwise injuring seven firemen and policemen who were trying to put out a fire which had started on the vessel.

WHEN a New Yorker opens his newspapers and sees a reference to gold mines, to ore crushers, to roller and to stamp mills, his mind unconsciously reverts to Cripple Creek, to the Comstock Mines, and similar world renowned districts operated among the gigantic mountains and rolling hills of Furthest West.

The fact that The Times of London, which most Englishmen regard as a national institution and not merely as a newspaper, is to reduce its price 23 per cent. to subscribers has caused its rivals to comment upon its history of nearly 120 years. The most conspicuous tribute is evidently from the pen of Alfred Harmsworth, for it appears unsigned in his paper.

LIKE many busy fathers, George A. Beaton, President of the American Finance and Securities Company, finds his keenest pleasure in talking and playing with his eight-year-old son, Bruce. Since the Beatons have moved to their Summer home in Plainfield Bruce finds that his father's commuting sadly interferes with their daily association, Sunday being the only time they are able to spend any great amount of time together.

Surely you did wisely in violating your rule regarding anonymous communications in to-day's issue to enrich the knowledge of your readers that if in need of a third set of teeth they should have a copy of Mrs. Eddy's book sent them.

Mme. Elzini Nicholson Brown is a palmist at 425 Sixth Avenue. Yesterday morning when she woke up, however, she forgot to examine the lines of her own hand or she might have learned that it was her unlucky day.
BERLIN, May 28. -- The controversy between France and the Vatican is followed here with the greatest interest. In an interview this evening at the Foreign Office I asked:

It is understood that ex-Senator Edward Murphy of Troy, colleague of David B. Hill in the United States Senate from March 4, 1893, to March 4, 1897, when the Albany-Elmira Senator retired from the upper house at Washington, will be Chairman of the New York delegation to St. Louis in July.

A wise man once said to his heir: "My son, eschew the personal advertisement in the newspaper, especially moreover if it happens to have been inserted by a widow of eighteen who wants some philanthropist to develop her histrionic talents, but should my advice fall upon deaf ears, do not, above all things, forget the 'clubby' feeling so far as to use a fellow club member's name to further your flirtatious career."

That sterling loans should make their appearance in this market with money rates as low as they have been for many weeks past, including last week, when bankers began drawing against their credit abroad to loan the proceeds of their drafts here, was a somewhat unusual incident, and one that attracted considerable attention, especially in view of the resultant decline in foreign exchanage rates with the incidental lull in gold exports.
ONE of the things that a woman with brains never gets quite used to is the ease with which the woman without them commonly gets along.

That the will of James Phelan, who died in Paris in 1887, leaving an estate in New York of more than $1,000,000, may be upset was indicated by the decision rendered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Scott, who denied the demurrer interposed by the United States Trust Company, which, as trustee under the will, is being sued by Charles J. Phelan, the testator's son, for possession of a one-third share of the residuary estate.

BERLIN, May 28. -- The announcement this week of the appointment of Baron von Heycking to be German Minister to Servia greatly surprised diplomatic circles. How, it is asked, can a diplomat who has been Minister to Mexico and Peking go to Belgrade?

POUGHKEEPSIE, May 28. -- The annual "Senior Howl" at Vassar College was this year celebrated with more than usual gusto. This marks the conclusion of the college course for the seniors. Dinner was served at 5 o'clock in the seniors' corridor.

CLEVELAND, May 28. -- The following letter addressed to E.C. Maytham, Harbor Captain of the Masters and Pilots' Association at Buffalo, from Capt. D.P. Craine, who recently took out the big steamer Saxona from Buffalo, was made public at the local headquarters of the association in this city to-day:

PARIS, May 28. -- The French Humane Society has given a handsome prize and a gold medal to Eugene Leigh, the American trainer, for the exemption of his stables from brutality, the thoroughness of their sanitary equipment, and the special care given to the horses. This leads French turf circles to make sarcastic references to the alleged American methods of giving stimulants to race horses.

THE voiles or veilings have now been in extensive use for several years, but increase, if that be possible, in popularity, and are worn on every occasion. There are instep length costumes for the street, trailing reception gowns, and beautiful evening gowns in white and tile pastel tints trimmed with expensive laces.

PARIS, May 16. -- Efficient power in motors for river craft is more than trebled, according to the inventor, Count de Lambert, a Russian of French extraction, by a new design in boat- building which he has had carried out. His vessel consists of two flat-bottomed skiffs, 18 feet long, coupled side by side. In the middle is a motor propelling a screw at the stern.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 28. -- The Methodist General conference to-night voted by a practically unanimous vote to amend the church constitution so as to provide for the election of bishops of other than the white race.

W.S. GILBERT'S "original domestic pantomime," christened "The Fairy's Dilemma," was produced at the Garrick in London on Monday, May 2. The play is in the mildest Gilbertian vein, and has, as perhaps its greatest novelty, the appearance of Miss Violet Vanbrugh and Arthur Bourchier in a rollicking pantomime, as Columbine and Clown respectively.
WASHINGTON, May 28. -- American blue-jackets and marines may make a forced march into the interior of Morocco to effect the release of Messrs. Pericardis and Varley, captives of the bandit Raisuli.

WITHIN a few weeks the largest ship afloat will again enter this harbor. This is the White Star liner Baltic, which is due to arrive here on her maiden voyage on July 7. In succeeding to the title of Queen of the Atlantic the Baltic follows her sisters, the Oceanic, Celtic, and Cedric, which have held it successively for the past five years.

HIGH-POWER automobiles of the present day present queer shapes. Especially is this true in the automobiles built solely for racing purposes. Excess in speed requires immensely powerful motors, and when it is claimed that a gasoline machine possesses anything over twenty-five horse power the fact is apt to be apparent, even to the ordinary observer, in the large proportion of the vehicle that seems to be taken up by its mechanical necessities.

A sidelight on the reasons for the decline of the dry goods jobber was cast the other day by a conversation with the head of one of the leading auction houses on the changes in the nature of his business in the last twenty-five years.

The report that intense dissatisfaction in the Grand Army of the Republic has been created by the official announcement that the Italian clubs under Republican Leader James E March will take part in to-morrow's parade was confirmed at the complimentary dinner tendered to Grand Marshal Frederick L. Schaefer by his staff last night at the Hotel Regent.

The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Atlantic City will be celebrated June 15-18, inclusive. The occasion is going to be commemorated in grand style, and already those in charge of the affair say they are assured of the biggest crowd of visitors that this resort has ever had.

LONG BRANCH, May 28. -- Not in many years have the cottagers arrived at Long Branch so early and in such great numbers as they have this season. Heretofore there has never been much of a rush among them until the 1st or 10th of June, but this year a large number have arrived very early.

J.E. KELLY and four other members of the Atchison bunch on the Consolidated Exchange -- namely, Scoble, Scoville, Clark, and Mumford -- had a narrow escape from being squeezed in the Consolidated Gas corner which was recently engineered in the Street. They made up a pool of 100 shares each on the theory that the price was too high, and proceeded to offer it short at the Consolidated Gas post.

A number of British financial publications are viewing with not a little concern the passage of the latest addition to their companies legislation, which seeks properly to punish Directors, officers, or agents of a company who willfully circulate or concur in the circulation of false statements regarding the company's condition.

THE removal of the telegraph instruments from poolrooms in this city came as a particularly severe blow to one class of race track enthusiasts -- those who were able to read the telegraph sounder from outside the cashier's inclosure. The method pursued by these speculators was to place wagers on the strength of tips that came over the wire.

That Cooper Union has become too small for the work which is carried on in the building, and for which Peter Cooper, its founder, intended it, was one of the announcements made during the forty-fifth annual commencement, which was held in the basement auditorium of the building last evening.

CLEVELAND, May 28. -- While being pursued by Detective Wilson last night, two men, thought to be freight car robbers, jumped into the river and it is supposed were either drowned or killed by the detective.
The first warm days of May afford opportunity for an interesting study of human nature as exemplified in the tentative resumption of the straw hat habit.

ALTHOUGH columns have been written about J. Henry Smith, who to-day is the wealthiest bachelor and the possessor of one of the most magnificent residences in New York, probably few remember that the late George Smith, who was the source of all this wealth, wrote a book upon finance which for years was regarded as an authority and which has its place yet in many club libraries.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 28. -- Lakewood concludes on June 1 one of the most eventful seasons in her history. A Winter of unusual cold drove many patrons southward, yet the percentage of fall and spring business at the hotels has been so great that the Laurel House and the Laurel-in-the-Pines have made a showing which is especially gratifying.

An Eighty-sixth Street crosstown car, with its floor and sides blazing and a trail of smoke and sparks streaming behind, raced through the sunken roadway across Central Park last evening, while the twenty passengers, including two women, crowded to the doors and platforms in fright, ready to jump off at the first opportunity.

W.W. Nyles, counsel for the Automobile Club, called at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon and had a conference with Inspectors Brooks, Cortright, and Grant with regard to Commissioner McAdoo's plan to establish new routes to the ferries for automobilists so that they will not be annoyed by boys throwing stones.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The President is still busy arranging the details of the Republican National Convention. He has now made some arrangements with regard to the seating of visitors and decided upon the man who is to make the seconding speech for Mr. Roosevelt on behalf of the Northwest, and it is felt that satisfactory progress is being made.

W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr.'s 60-horse power automobile launch, which was launched at City Island on Friday, is expected to be one of the prominent competitors to-morrow in the power boat races to be held in the waters off Manhassett Bay Yacht Club under the auspices of the American Power Boat Association.

In reply to the letter of "Londoner" in your issue of May 23, permit me to say that I agree with him as to the indecency of the overcrowded condition of our cars. That it is "unnecessary" is equally true, but the responsibility in the matter does not lie altogether on the women.

The highly interesting editorial in today's TIMES on "Snow on the Sidewalks" beautifully illustrates the difficulty of putting nuisances out of the way along lines of certainly not abstract justice. Snow on the sidewalks is no doubt a nuisance, and a dangerous nuisance, but no particular class of citizens can be accused of being the cause of the nuisance.

Mr. A. HENRY SAVAGE LANDOR contributes to the current North American a most interesting article upon "The American Soldier as Seen in the Philippines." It is a vindication of the United States Army which will be particularly gratifying to that organization, which ought to be gratifying to every American citizen, and which ought correspondingly to put to shame those ill birds, Bostonian or Congressional, which take perverse pleasure in fouling their own nests.

The theory of those who advocate the establishment of a national theatre is that a great number of people in this country are prevented from witnessing good plays by the avariciousness of theatrical managers who think only of producing "popular successes." But this theory is scarcely borne out by an examination of the plays most favored by amateur actors.
According to The Associated Press dispatches, Mr. Tuesdale, President of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, in response to prodding by Mr. Shearn, is reported to have angrily retorted as follows:

The lovely June evenings are the first of the year when sitting out of doors is a wise thing to do, and they really afford an opportunity for a more intimate knowledge of the stars than any of the previous evenings of the last five months. In fact, since last October we have been housed and forced at evening to contemplate nature through a glass -- a window glass.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 28. -- Widely prevalent rumors of the possible candidacy of George J. Gould for a seat in Congress as the representative of the Third District are more generally credited than previous reports of like tenor have been.
HERE is a sample of the way in which primitive workers still till the land in the heart of Somaliland.

Judge Alton B. Parker of New York made great strides in the contest for delegates, which was continued last week, when conventions were held in Tennessee, Alabama, Ohio, Maryland, and Arizona. Counting Tennessee's twenty-four delegates, who received iron-bound instructions for Parker, and Alabama's delegates, who, though not "instructed" for him, were pledged for him by the adoption of ringing resolutions indorsing his candidacy, the jurist's total was increased from 128 to 174.

TOKIO, May 28. -- Japan paid heavily for her victories at Kin-Chow, Nanshan, and Talien-wan, losing 3,500 men in killed and wounded in the repeated assaults against these positions, but she scored a sweeping and valuable victory over the Russians, capturing seventy guns, clearing the way to Port Arthur, and inflicting losses on the enemy which in the end are expected to total 2,000 men.

One of the well-established means of judging the market situation has been the size and character of the short interest. Very frequently the principal influence governing the course of prices has been the effort of the shorts to buy back stocks of which they were short and rich harvests have at times been reaped by those who have successfully estimated the short interest and undertaken the task of driving it to cover.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 28. -- Although work is being pushed night and day to prepare the Baltic fleet for service, it is feared now that it cannot be ready to sail for the Far East before September. The delay is considered especially unfortunate in view of the situation at Port Arthur, where the arrival of the fleet before the fall of the fortress would compel the raising of the siege.
LONDON, May 28. -- The stock market this week took its usual post-holiday course, trading being quiet and on a restricted scale.
The recreation piers, which mean so much in Summer to the population of the crowded districts of the city, were opened yesterday for the season with attendant and appropriate ceremonies.
OF the large number of persons who play billiards there are probably few who know much about the cues and balls which they use.

There are profits and profits in the Cuban $35,000,000 loan. Those which have most keenly excited the curiosity of New York's financial community have been the ones to be made by the bankers who gobbled up the issue in the face of several other syndicates at a price technically but one-half of 1 per cent. removed from the lowest bid allowable, and actually, by virtue of interest arrangements, at a figure some 2 points lower.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- The study of flight in the air has a peculiar charm to one who engages in it. The problem, so simple that the smallest fledgling may in a dozen efforts master it, leads to a dream of the conquest of space and time, perhaps the greatest of which the human mind has ever taken thought.

A CURIOUS phenomenon connected with the forcing of flowers under somewhat exceptional circumstances was observed not long ago by M.J. Jolly, says The Scientific American. On Sept. 2 last a large fire broke out in the village of Chaussee-sur-Marne, and destroyed a large part of the village.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 28. -- Somers Point is inclined to regard as significant the fact that Superintendent Lovell of the West Jersey and Seashore Railroad, and Fourth Vice President Rea, of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, recently visited that place in a special train with a party of prominent officials.

PARIS, May 28. -- Premier Combes's announcement that the question of the separation of Church and State would come up in January has drawn attention to the bill already formulated by the committee on the separation of Church and State. It is a sweeping measure, the opening clauses reading as follows:

The Stanley Enterprise recounts the case of a citizen of Albermarle who received through the mail a certificate of stock in a Western mining company, conditioned alone upon the mailing of a small amount to another concern as a subscription price to a magazine that was supposed to be published by owners of majority of the stock of said mining company.

The Stanley Enterprise recounts the case of a citizen of Albermarle who received through the mail a certificate of stock in a Western mining company, conditioned alone upon the mailing of a small amount to another concern as a subscription price to a magazine that was supposed to be published by owners of majority of the stock of said mining company.
BERLIN, May 28. -- The popular chagrin here over the Anglo-French understanding found expression at the annual meeting to-day of the German Colonial Society at Stettin.

WASHINGTON, May 28. -- Reports received here from the Far East dwell at length upon the terrific power of the Japanese Shimose powder, the nature of which is an absolute secret. It is not used to propel the shot but forms the bursting charge of the army and navy explosive shell.

PARIS, May 29. -- The Prix du Jockey Club, the French equivalent of the English Derby, drew a large and fashionable crowd to the Chantilly course this afternoon. Edmond Blanc's Ajax, a hot favorite, won by half a length from M. Caillault's McDonald II.

LONDON, May 30. -- The correspondent of The Standard at Tokio telegraphs that a memorable gathering of educationalists and students representing the Imperial University and other institutions of learning on Saturday enthusiastically passed a resolution recording their gratitude to the Government of the United States for having opened Japan to a new life and a new civilization tile Perry treaty.
TOKIO, May 29. -- The details of the fighting at Kin-Chow emphasize the heroic tenacity of the Japanese in their conduct at Nan-Shan Hill.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 29. -- It was said in Mamaroneck to-day that a new clue had been discovered which may lead to the recovery of the diamonds, valued at $15,000, which were stolen from the home of Henry Falton, the New York feather importer, three months ago. The case is in the bands of a detective agency in New York, which is said to be working with Scotland Yard.
PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- The North American this morning prints a special dispatch from Princeton, N. J., on National Democratic politics in which ex-President Grover Cleveland is quoted as follows:

Joseph Davidson, thirteen years old, and his brother Harry, twelve years old, who live with their Parents at 311 West One Hundred add Forty-fifth Street, have been missing from their home since May 14. Their father says that he believes they have runaway to become jockeys.

PARIS, May 29. -- Full details of the Russian reverse having reached us yesterday, it might have been expected that a flood of comment would fill the Paris press to-day, yet to-day's papers have little to say beyond the publication of the latest telegrams from St. Petersburg and Tokio.

The Pacific Mail steamship Manchuria, the largest ship afloat under the American flag, arrived yesterday afternoon from Camden, N.J., and is now at Pier 38, North River. She will remain there on exhibition all this week, and will then sail for San Francisco, to enter the regular Oriental service.

No tendency at all was disclosed by last week's business in the listed bond market. Of descriptions which moved so much as a point twelve advanced and twelve declined. The small total which reached that moderate activity well indicates the dullness of trading, which aggregated only $6,670,000, a large decrease compared either with the previous week or earlier years.

A tall, angular man, trembling violently, walked into the reception room at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning and asked for treatment. Before he went to the alcoholic ward, to which he had been assigned, he gave his name as Balfour Toravendale, and said that he was a native of Scotland and a relative of the British Prime Minister the Rev. Hon. Arthur James Balfour.

In keeping with the announcement made on Saturday by both Deputy Police Commissioner Farrell and District Attorney Clarke of Brooklyn, which received the indorsement of the representatives of the Sabbath Observance and other organizations, the game yesterday between the New York and Brooklyn Clubs at Washington Park was played under almost the same conditions that prevail on any other day.

ORANGE, N.J., May 29. -- The Rev. Father Giovanni Quarenda, rector of an Italian Catholic church in Silver Lake, was probably fatally injured this afternoon by falling off a swiftly moving open car on the Orange and Passaic Valley Railway in Orange. He was removed to the Orange Memorial Hospital in an ambulance.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29. -- Frank L. Kramer, the National cycling champion, won the two-mile handicap event at the Vailsburg bicycle track to-day. Kramer's time for the distance was 4:00 4-5, which is one second slower than the world's record, held by himself.

PORT CHESTER, May 29. -- Five thousand Italians, who assembled at Port Chester this afternoon to witness the laying of the cornerstone of the new Church of Our Lady of Rosary, went away happy because they received from Archbishop Farley the Apostolic benediction, which was sent to them by Pope Pius X.

It is the generally accepted opinion in the navy that two of the three scout ships recently authorized by Congress will be of the turbine type. The vessels without the turbine are in themselves brand-new departures in American naval construction, and the substitution of the turbines will make them still more unique in the service.

Our recent inquiry as to whether humanity, owing, among other things, to the abundance of reading matter and the ease and cheapness of journeys short and long, was not tiring of the forms of social intercourse that once were its most important and popular devices for utilizing leisure time, is answered -- after a fashion -- by The Milwaukee Wisconsin.
CLEVELAND, May 29. -- William Livingstone, President of the Lake Carriers' Association, to-night gave out the following statement:

LONDON, May 30. -- The Standard's Tien Tsin correspondent telegraphs that M. Uchida, the Japanese Minister at Peking, has demanded an immediate reply to the inquiry previously sent to the Wai-Wu-PU (Foreign Office) as to whether China is prepared to hold and administer the territory the Japanese have conquered.

A recent editorial article in THE TIMES on "The Homeless Poor of a Great City" closes with an appreciation of Count Rumford's work in Munich which is as pertinent as it is deserved. A wrong inference might, however, be drawn from the concluding statement that "posterity has not had the good sense to even attempt to follow Count Rumford's example."

Sports on both land and water will attract thousands of pleasure seekers to-day, while those who love sport for its competitive side will be represented in large numbers in the various contests arranged for. The baseball enthusiasts will have a grand array of games both professional and amateur to attract their attention.

THOMPSONVILLE, Conn., May 29. -- Assistant District Attorney Frank P. Garvan of New York was one of a party of automobilists arrested this afternoon by Town Constables on the charge of speeding their machine beyond the limit allowed by law. With him at the time were Mr. and Mrs. Frank Black and Mrs. Nicholl, all of New York.

Nathan Straus, the bay pacing gelding with a record of 2:03 1/2 who will make an attempt to capture the world's pacing record in the Grand Circuit this season, scored a notable victory on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, when he defeated the 1903 Speedway champion Don Derby, 2:04 1/2 two heats out of three.

Another large dock fire, the fifth in four years to spread destruction on the New Jersey shore, raged yesterday afternoon and last night, making a spectacle that in grandeur was second only to the catastrophe of June, 1900, when the piers and three of the great liners of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company were destroyed.

PITTSBURG, May 29. -- Senator Quay last Friday signed his will, having previously destroyed one he wrote while at Morganza. The estate is valued at about $800,000, according to the calculation of William Montgomery, cashier of the Allegheny National Bank.
EAST ORANGE, May 29. -- Capt. Demorin Libby, known to old New Yorkers as "The Original Libby," will celebrate his ninetieth birthday on June 7, at the home of his son, in East Orange.

Your editorial about the officers and soldiers in Germany in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 12 is entirely justified. It shows again how well you are informed as to the shameful ill-treatment of the German soldier by his superiors.

LONDON, May 20. -- British naval officers generally doubt very much whether their Government will consent to be concerned in a remonstrance directed to Russia or to Russia and Japan against such use of floating mines as tends to endanger neutral shipping on the open seas.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29. -- An attempt to assassinate the Rev. Antonio Isoleri, rector of the Church of St. Mary Magdale di Pazzi, was foiled by the police to-day during a pageant in honor of the church's patron saint. A band of Anarchists rushed to the priest's carriage, the leader leveling a revolver.

Of a total attendance of 1,547,873 visitors to the New York Aquarium in 1903, the daily average for July, August, and September was 6,255 -- or about 2,000 more per diem than attended during the Winter months. It is fair to assume that the present Summer will see an increase in the number of visitors.

SEOUL, Korea, May 29. -- Continuous and conflicting reports concerning the movements of the Russians are being received from Korean sources with wild guesses as to the number of men seen, while owing to the differences existing between the Korean and Japanese pronunciation it is difficult to determine the localities mentioned.

An amendment to the New York Charter was enacted at the last session of the Legislature which will do much to relieve cases of great hardship that are common under our absurd system of taxing personal property.

Their demands for money ignored by their intended victim. Italian blackmailers in Brooklyn attempted yesterday morning to blow the victim and his home to pieces with dynamite, and almost succeeded in totally wrecking the house. A woman was slightly hurt, but the man picked out for death escaped unhurt.

CHESTER, Penn., May 29. -- The naphtha launch White Seal left here to-day for Wilmington with a party of pleasure seekers. Before going five miles the launch had rescued the crews of two sailing yachts which capsized in the Delaware River, and saved the lives of fourteen persons. One person was drowned.
"I feel like the boy who pulled the bung out of a full barrell of cider," said Alderman Michael Stapleton, yesterday. "He got more'n was comin' to him."

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, May 29. -- According to the statement of Henry B. Welschen, a well-known mining man, who has arrived here from Jiminez, Dr. R.C. Flower of New York passed through that place two days ago on his way to Parral, this State. Welschen says that he knew Dr. Flower in Arizona several years ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 29. -- Intense interest is displayed in the Japanese reports of the Kin-Chow battle. The people in the streets almost mob newsboys to secure extras containing the dispatches. Crowds stood around the official bulletin boards awaiting the Russian versions, but none arrived.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Secretary Moody has issued a general order containing certain extracts from the report of the Missouri court of inquiry regarding the conduct of the officers and men at the time of the accident on board of that vessel, April 13, and letters from the President to the Navy Department regarding the bravery of the officers and men of the Missouri.
LONDON, May 30. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the Warsaw Dnevnik has published a number of letters written from Port Arthur by Col. Agapyieff, who perished on the Petropavlovsk.

WEI-HAI-WEI, May 29. -- The following telegram is a compilation of news which has reached me from three sources. Yesterday I received a long wireless message from The Times's naval correspondent, sent from a point over 200 miles away, but owing to the great distance and a heavy thunderstorm the message arrived in a mutilated condition.

David J. Brewer, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, in an address delivered in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church last night, characterized the Bible as the greatest book in the world and the teachers of it better patriots than the soldiers who won battles. The Justice as talking to the Bible Teachers' Training School at its commencement exercises. He said in part:

Two naphtha launches, in which were two men, two women, and two children, were rescued yesterday afternoon by the police from a perilous position in Little Hell Gate, which is in the East River, between Randall's and Ward's Islands.

The story of the rich young man who passed through New York last week on his way to exhibit himself and his horses at a snow in Philadelphia, and who donned a chauffeur's livery to escape the service of a subpoena from the State, is not creditable to him and his class or agreeable for his fellow-citizens to read.

TOKIO, May 29. -- Certain Russian correspondence which has been intercepted by the Japanese at the blockade of Port Arthur gives the information that some Russian torpedo-boat destroyers have been sunk by mines outside of Port Arthur as well as details of the placing by the Russians of the mines which effected the destruction of the Japanese battleship Hatsuse on May 15.

LONDON, May 30. -- The London dailies exhaust the vocabulary of admiration for the Japanese. The achievement at Kin-Chow they regard as proving the absolute military equality of the Japanese with the best European armies, and as qualifying Japan to rank as a great power. The Dally Telegraph says editorially:

There is no theory of party loyalty or of factional advantage that will explain, much less justify, the present political attitude and behavior of Mr. CHARLES F. MURPHY, the Tammany leader. He seems to be determined to go to St. Louis with a grievance. That is the only explanation which would account for his perverse tactics.

Now that the Police Department is trying to aid automobilists by piloting them through streets where they will not be targets for bricks, patrons of the Metropolitan Street Railway's Second Avenue trolley line are wondering whether there is any chance of relief from ancient vegetables and paper balls that continually threaten the ordinary plain people who pay 5 cents for a ride through Chrystie or Forsyth Street.

The defenses of Port Arthur, it is well known, are so great in strength that military observers of the war in the East have not been willing, heretofore, to believe that the Japanese would try to carry them by assault. It has been generally regarded as probable that they would be reduced by siege operations that might -- probably would -- last until the garrison was starved out.

Two arrests were made by the Jersey City police yesterday, both of which were supposed at the time to be in connection with the murder of Dominic Sokotoski, the non-union freight handler who was beaten to death on Saturday night as he was returning from work at the Fall River Line pier.

Each one of the 5,000 pushcart peddlers on the east side hates Street C. leaning Commissioner John McGaw Woodbury with his whole heart and soul. They fear him so much, however, that whenever the Commissioner appears among them with his red automobile and warlike demeanor they say nothing, but simply stand and quake.
TANGIER, May 29. -- The statement published in the English press that Messrs. Perdicaris and Varley have gone wild boar shooting and are enjoying themselves is absolutely without foundation.

Yesterday was Whit Sunday in the Greek calendar, and a solemn requiem for the soldiers and sailors already fallen in the Far East was sung after the high service at the Russian Cathedral of St. Nicholas, Ninety-seventh Street and Madison Avenue, which was attended by Consul General Ladygensky.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 30. -- The correspondent of the Russky Invalid (the army organ) with Gen. Mistchenko's division of 5,000 Trans-Baikal Cossacks, sent to Korea to keep in touch with the enemy, gives a detailed account of a ride destined to become classic in cavalry annals.
I am sorry to see one nominally of the Anglican Church -- your correspondent calling himself "American Episcopalian" -- using your pages to abuse the Church with these words:

The four-story brick building at 29 Madison Street, of which the ground floor is occupied by Harry Polinsky's grocery and the three upper floors by furnished rooms, caught fire last night in the basement. The origin of the blaze has not been ascertained, but it spread so rapidly upward and so dense was the smoke that poured up the stairway that exit by that way was cut off.

CHICAGO, May 29. -- After pitching fine ball for seven innings Hess showed weakness in the eighth, when three bases on balls, a double, a single, and a passed ball scored all of Chicago's runs. Both teams put up a fast fielding game, Holmes carrying off the honors.

WASHINGTON, May 29. -- Exports of manufactures in the fiscal year which ends with next month seem likely to exceed those of any preceding year, according to ten months figures just presented by the Department of Commerce and Labor through its Bureau of Statistics.

TRENTON, May 30. -- Nathan Sibbett, the fourteen-year-old boy who was arrested here late last night after his mother was found dead in her home, at Jacobs Creek, was held to-day for the Coroner's inquest.

I see that many correspondents are writing to you against the proposed "end seat" ordinance. While I do not think such legislation practicable or wise, yet I am in sympathy with its spirit. I think the railroad company should put up the sign, "Passengers must take the seat farthest from the entrance."

LONDON, May 31. -- Admiral Sir Cyprian Bridge, one of the foremost officers of the British Navy, in a letter to the editor of The Times expresses views regarding the use of mines in naval warfare which harmonize perfectly with the statement concerning the attitude of the Admiralty which was cabled last night.

The following letter from Lady Hamilton, written after Nelson's death, is printed for the first time in the current number of Chambers's Journal, in an article by the Rev. R.A. Gatty on his father-in-law, Dr. Scott, who was Nelson's secretary and Chaplain:

J. Flanagan of the Greater New York Irish Athletic Association won both the sixteen and fifty-six pound weight-throwing contests in the games held at Celtic Park yesterday. Flanagan also finished second to John Sheridan in the discus-throwing event. Harry Hillman of the New York Athletic Club won the 120-yard low-hurdle race from S.C. Northridge by several yards. George Bonhag was defeated by H. Cohn in the one-and-one-half-mile invitation race.

Memorial Day was observed with more of the real spirit of the occasion yesterday than for many years. There were greater throngs in the streets to cheer the veterans and greater crowds at the centres of interest.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30. -- The New Yorks did not have the slightest trouble in defeating the Philadelphia team this morning, and up to the eighth inning in the afternoon game they were in an excellent position to score another victory. Taylor, however, weakened in that inning, and by good, hard hitting the Philadelphias put together three runs, which proved to be one more than enough to win the game.

One of the waiters at the Cafe Francis, 53 West Thirty-fifth Street, on going into the cellar yesterday evening, was confronted by a volume of smoke that quickly filled the halls, kitchen, and dining room. The kitchen servants hurried to the street, as did also a number of the guests, who were on the lower floor.

With a field of thirty-two competitors, many of them the college experts in singles, the annual tournament of the New York Lawn Tennis Club was begun yesterday on their courts at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Three of the competitions in the opening round brought out some fine tennis and held a large gallery about the grounds the entire day.

The long-mark men received most of the prizes at the annual games of the Brooklyn Athletic Club, held yesterday at Grand Street Park. B. Freedman of the Red Men's Athletic Club won the two-mile run from the 165-yard mark. William Nelson of the National Athletic Club won the 75-yard novice. Summaries:

TRENTON, May 30. -- Elmer Gilbert stood on a wharf at Saugers Creek this evening and decided that life was not worth living. The overcast sky was in accord with his gloomy spirits, and the metallic lustre of the coal oil spread on the waters of the creek to kill mosquitos reminded him that an avenue to death was at hand.
LONDON, May 30. -- Money was in good month-end demand in the market to-day. Discounts were easy, in anticipation of easier money at the month-turn.

A thunderstorm, after threatening all the afternoon, burst over the city early last evening, menacing lives and causing much inconvenience to belated holiday makers. A crowded music hall was struck by lightning, causing a panic; the thousands along the Speedway were drenched, and an eight-oared shell competing in the Harlem Regatta was swamped, and Bellevue Hospital was left in darkness by the lightning's pranks.

NEGAUNEE, Mich., May 30. -- All hope of finding Mayor Hudson alive has been abandoned. He is believed to have perished in the woods. The mines here have shut down, and since Saturday morning 1,500 men have scoured the woods, but no trace has been found of him except some papers belonging to him which were found Saturday afternoon.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- When the members of the Celtic Club of this city visited the graves of their departed members to-day the final resting place of Thomas Dunn English, for years an honorary member, was found to be neglected.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 30. -- News has reached here from Wilkesborough of the reception accorded James E. Boyd, Judge of the United States Court for the Western District of this State, on his arrival there. When Congress authorized the court at Wilkesborough Judge Boyd was bitterly hostile to the move.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- President Roosevelt and party returned to Washington from Gettysburg at 8:20 o'clock to-night. On arriving at the station the President gave a hearty handshake to the engine crew.

WASHINGTON, May 30. -- The possibility that international complications may grow out of the effort of the United States to rescue one of its citizens. Mr. Perdicaris, and his kinsman, the Englishman Varley, who have been abducted by Raisuli, the Moroccan bandit, is not taken as a matter to be seriously considered at this stage of the affair.

NUTLEY, N.J., May 30. -- The happiest man in this town to-day is Charles Keith, and the happiest woman is Mrs. Keith, for after eighteen years of married life a baby -- such a blue-eyed, handsome little girl baby -- has come to their handsome home in Chestnut Street. The baby was four days old when it arrived, on Friday.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- Frank L. Kramer, the National cycling champion, won the half-mile professional event easily at the Vailsburg track to-day. Kramer crossed the tape four feet in front of Iver Lawson, riding easily. The real contest was between Fenn and Lawson for second place, and Lawson just managed to defeat Fenn by a half a wheel for the place.

One who watched the semi-military, semi-civic Decoration Day parade yesterday, if old enough to remember the parades of the period before the war, missed something -- several things, indeed -- which he is likely to recall with a sense of regret. Primarily, he misses the uniforms which once delighted the eye and made our militia regiments gorgeous.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 30. -- The first yacht races of the season of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club to-day finished in a heavy squall. The club was formally opened for the yachting season, the new Commodore, George Lauder, Jr., being present with Vice Commodore Shearson and ex-Commodore Willis.

The Executive Board of the Atlantic Marine Firemen's Union, which has been in session for several days at the Clarendon Hotel, announced yesterday evening that it had taken action on the grievances of the firemen on the boats of the coastwise steamship companies. Secretary James Sullivan of the union then made a statement in which he said that committees would call on the managers of the coastwise lines early to-day and submit the demands.

PARIS, May 30. -- Just arrived from Morocco is Jean Hess, whose fame as an explorer is European, and whose recent work, "La Question du Maroc," is the most living exposition of Moorish affairs which has appeared in the French language.

TANGIER, May 30. -- The United States armored cruiser Brooklyn, flying the flag of Rear Admiral Chadwick, arrived here to-day. The United States cruiser Atlanta arrived later and joined the Brooklyn. Two other American warships are expected shortly.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 30. -- Nothing remarkable in the way of high speeding qualities was shown by the French locomotive built for the Pennsylvania Railroad, in its test runs over the West Jersey and Seashore system between Camden and this city to-day. The engine was tested in speed power, in endurance, and in making steady time, and the crews say to-night that she did not touch the fliers built in the Pennsylvania Railroad shops.

LONDON, May 31. -- The Times publishes a long article by an American correspondent the purpose of which is to show that there is nothing in Russia's oft-repeated assertion that the United States is vastly indebted to her for kindness and support rendered in critical periods of the Republic's history.

No changes occurred in any of the positions of the clubs in either of the major leagues yesterday, but the Boston Americans were the only players to win both of their games. Rain played havoc with the arrangements made for large crowds at Cleveland and Detroit, as no games were played at either city. At Pittsburg the National League champions managed to have a game with St. Louis in the afternoon and were overwhelmingly defeated.

LONDON, May 31. -- Gen. Kuropatkin, says The Daily Telegraph's St. Petersburg's correspondent, is fighting two enemies -- one at home, the other in Manchuria. While his military reputation is undergoing a terrible ordeal, he is also accused of failure as Minister of War to make proper preparations for war.

Manhasset Bay was alive with automobile boats yesterday, and the way they skimmed over the water in front of the clubhouse of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club was a caution to the "squareheads" who know no boats but sailing boats. There were six automobile boats entered in various classes in the first championship regatta of the American Power Boat Association.

CINCINNATI, May 30. -- The two games between the local team and the Chicagos attracted over 16,000 persons to the grounds to-day. In the morning contest the Cincinnatians bunched their hits and won. Chance had his face badly lacerated by being hit with a pitched ball, but he continued playing. In the afternoon the visitors won in the ninth inning by heavy batting. Score by innings:

Six persons were slightly burned and a panic of passengers was caused by the explosion of a motor on a Fulton Street car in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. The car was bound down town. When it was opposite Glenada Place a muffled explosion was heard, and blue flames shot from the controller box, directly in front of the motorman, William Cornelius of 2,196A Fulton Street.

More than 20,000 children from various sections of the city attended May Day parties in Central Park yesterday. They romped and played on the grassy lawns, lest themselves in the roadway tunnels, poked sticks at the lions in the menagerie, and all but the few who met with accidents enjoyed the day's outing.

Edward J. McCallum of New York, despite the fact that his number was "13," flashed past the judges the winner of the twenty-five-mile Irvington-Millburn road race, the sixteenth running of which was decided yesterday over the time-honored course. McCallum had a handicap of six minutes, and his actual time for the twenty-five miles was 1:16:29.

BALTIMORE, May 30. -- Robert M. McLane, Mayor of Baltimore, shot himself through the head at 3 o'clock this afternoon at his home, 29 West Preston Street, and died two hours later. Coroner Benjamin F. Hayden of the Central District, after making an investigation, decided that it was case of suicide, and deemed an inquest unnecessary.

ST. PETERSBURG, May 31. -- The reported defeat of Cossacks at Ai-Yang was the only news and almost the only topic of conversation in St. Petersburg last night. No official dispatches were given out last evening, but officers at military headquarters were reluctant in accepting the Japanese dispatches.

Coney Island crowds established a record for Memorial Day, and it was estimated in the afternoon that fully 225,000 persons were at the resort, causing the managers of the various transportation lines to shudder at the thought of the problems that will confront them when the weather gets really hot.

About 4,000 spectators witnessed the first annual out-door athletic games of the Inter-Settlement Athletic Association, which were held yesterday at Columbia Oval, William's Bridge, N.Y. There were 360 entries received for the nineteen events.

Seventeen of the twenty motor cyclists who started in the second annual hill-climbing contest of the New York Motor Cycle Club on Fort George hill yesterday finished. Two others finished, but were disqualified, and H. Taylorsen, who used the only French machine in the race, stopped half way up the hill. The race was won by F.W. Rogers, his time being one minute.
Gebhard Lendbolt, a retired furniture dealer, on Sunday night was talking with his two sons in the library, when he remarked:

At the recent meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers in Pittsburg President PARRY said some things which are not the less true because some leaders of organized labor will make haste to contradict them with a vehemence of denunciation which will accomplish no good purpose.

In various newspapers yesterday a "Close Friend" of Charles F. Murphy was quoted, as authority for a statement that Mr. Murphy, dropping his veil of mystery, was out openly against Parker and for McClellan, for President. The statement declared that Tammany was highly respectable and intelligent and no longer of the proletariat.

As a result of the sudden collapse of an old four-story building at 65 East Eighth Street yesterday morning a young woman is in danger of death at St. Vincent's Hospital, and three men are lying painfully injured in a neighboring ward. The collapse, according to the officials of the Building Department, was one of the most remarkable that ever occurred in the city.
ROME, May 30. -- The Chamber of Deputies was crowded to-day when the interpellation on the attitude of the Government toward the Vatican's protest against President Loubet's visit was debated.

Columbia University oarsmen scored a sweeping victory in the annual regatta of the Harlem Regatta Association, held over the Speedway course on the Harlem River yesterday, winning five of the six events in which they were entered, including the intermediate and the senior eight-oared races and all three four-oared events, in competition with the best crews of the New York Athletic Club and of the Harlem River rowing clubs.

The Agricultural Department makes an interesting announcement of the discovery by one of its experts in the province of Alta Vera Paz, Guatemala, of an ant which devotes its energies to the systematic destruction of the boll weevil. The cotton fields of the Indians of that province are not immune from invasion by the weevil, but they have been so fully protected that the plants have suffered no injury.
" Hello, Sinkers," said Sarsaparilla Reilly when he entered the little restaurant, "were you in the Decoration Day parade?"

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 30. -- The dead body of C.M. Dewey, formerly of New York, a St. Louis clothing manufacturer and jobber, who disappeared a week ago, was found to-day hidden by weeds in a vacant lot on Bircher Road, near the city limits.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30. -- The Justices of the Supreme Court of New Jersey will take advantage of the authority vested in them by the last Legislature and completely rearrange the judicial districts of the State. Five of the nine circuits already have been changed.

Vice President Loomis of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company said yesterdy that it would be impossible for several days to come to estimate the exact loss caused by the fire that on Sunday swept six piers in the Jersey City freight yards. The company, he said, had made all necessary arrangements to maintain its service unimpaired and would start the rebuilding of the burned piers immediately.

LONDON, May 30. -- The Royal Yacht Squadron has been obliged to decline the challenge of Commodore Morton F. Plant of the Larchmont Yacht Club for the Cape May Cup with his schooner-yacht Ingomar because the Britannia (which won the Cape May Cup) is too antiquated to defend it. The trophy therefore will be returned to the New York Yacht Club at the earliest possible moment.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., May 30. -- On historic Cemetery Hill, near the spot where, on Nov. 19, 1869, President Lincoln delivered his immortal address, President Roosevelt to-day spoke to an immense and eager assemblage upon the legacy of the civil war and the part that devolves upon each citizen to-day in keeping the Nation great.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 30. -- An order to show cause why he should not be held in contempt of court has been served on Josephus Daniels, editor of The News and Observer, and National Democratic Committeeman from North Carolina, by Federal Judge Purnell because of editorials and paragraphs issued in The News and Observer Sunday morning.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 30. -- News has been received here that Lucama, a little town near this city, has been in a state of ferment for the past week. On Monday a passenger train was wrecked near the station and several of the cars were destroyed by fire, among them the express car.

PARIS, May 31. -- Foreign Minister Delcasse, in consequence of a communication from the State Department at Washington, transmitted through Ambassador Porter, has telegraphed instructions to the French Minister at Tangler to use his utmost endeavors to obtain the release from the brigand Raisuli of Ion Perdicaris and Cromwell Varley.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 31. -- Mayor McLane's suicide puts the Republicans in control of the City Government under a provision for the centralization of power provided by the new city charter. The Republicans now also control the burned district commission and all improvements from this time on.

Subway work in Forty-second Street will be completed and the surface of the street will be restored to a passable condition by Monday of next week, as the result of orders issued last evening through the contractor and Commissioner Oakley of the Department of Water Supply, Gas, and Electricity.

At a public hearing held by the Committee on Elementary Schools of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon on the advisability of reintroducing corporal punishment into the schools, both the ethical and practical questions involved were thrashed out, and the preponderance of opinion seemed to be that moral suasion was a rather roundabout way of reaching the divine side of a bad boy's nature.

For the first time in more than a week Leader Charles F. Murphy of Tammany Hall was at the Fourteenth Street headquarters yesterday, having come in from Atlantic City early in the morning. He had very little to say.

Princeton's greatest doubles tennis players, Frederick B. Alexander and Raymond D. Little, the intercollegiate ex-champions, yesterday gave an excellent exhibition of speedy play in the beginning of the Manhattan Doubles Championship. The contest was a part of the annual open tournament of the New York Lawn Tennis Club on their courts at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

VINELAND, N.J., May 31. -- The greatest surprise that Vineland has had in a long time is the wedding announcement of Miss Susan P. Fowler, one of the original dress reformers, who has been photographed as a lecturer and farmer, for newspapers for years.

John R. Platt of 7 East Fifty-fourth Street, an octogenarian and a retired glass manufacturer, yesterday brought suit in the Supreme Court against Hannah Elias, the negrees who was brought into prominence at the time of the murder of Andrew H. Green, to recover $685,385, which sum, he declares in his bill of complaint, she extorted from him by blackmail between 1896 and May 21 of this year.

Of the children lost in Monday's Grand Army parade all but three have been returned to their parents. One of the three left-overs is as black as the ace of spades, another is light brown, and a third so very white that some of the policemen declare him to be an albino. All of them are in charge of the Gerry society.

The suit brought by the Continental Insurance Company against the New York and Harlem Railroad and the New York Central Railroad, alleging that the Directors of the former road, being also Directors of the latter, had made between the two railroads a contract which was conceived in fraud and was against the best interests of the stockholders of the Harlem Road, of whom the Continental Insurance Company was one, has been dismissed.

There appears to-day in the columns of your esteemed paper an article headed "Severe on German Army Methods," and signed by "One Who Knows." As to the signature, I feel tempted to just put the little word nothing at the end of it.

Higher prices from London helped the stock market at the opening of yesterday's session, but the improvement was very soon lost, and by the end of the first hour nearly all the active stocks showed some decline from Friday's closing prices. The course of the market during the balance of the day was irregular, but in the end the net losses outnumbered the advances.

LONDON, May 31. -- At the Spring meeting of the National Rife Association, held in London to-day, Lord Cheylesmore, the President, referred to the correspondence between the National Rifle Association and the American Rifle Association relative to the allegation that the America team, which won the Palma Trophy in 1903, did not use the National arm of the United States, and thereby did not conform to the conditions of the contest.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- This cablegram has been received at the Navy Department from Rear Admiral Chadwick, commanding the South Atlantic Squadron, at Tangier:

EAST ORANGE, May 31. -- It has just become generally known that the last canvas upon which the late Thomas Nast labored was burned. The picture was a portrait of Andrew Reasoner, who was Superintendent of the Morris and Essex Division of the Lackawanna Railroad, and who died in East Orange a few years ago.

Prince Pu Lun, nephew of the Emperor of China, Minister to His Imperial Presence, and with an outside chance to gain the throne of the Flowery Kingdom, arrived in New York, yesterday morning. The Prince is in America as the representative of his Emperor at the World's Fair in St. Louis.

Charles A. Taylor, theatrical manager and playwright, who gives his place of business at the New Star Theatre, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities of $12,275 anal no assets. The liabilities were contracted from 1896 to 1901 for printing, money loaned, salaries of actors and actresses, costumes, board of actors and transportation, rent,

LONDON, June 1. -- The Times expresses gratification at the action of the United States in asking France to exercise her good offices in order to obtain the release of Mr. Perdicaris.
