It says the case in hand is one of those incidents which make a special claim on France to utilize that position of exceptional influence in Morocco which the Anglo-French agreement guaranteed to her, adding:

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 31. -- During the conference here to-day between State politicians who are attempting to dethrone Gov. Beckham as the head of the State political machine a dispute arose between Allie W. Young, Chairman of the State Central and State Executive Committees, and United States Senator J.C.S. Blackburn as for whom the delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis shall be instructed.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- There is keen interest in army circles in the artillery operations which have made the battle of Nan-Shah Hill one of the greatest of modern military contests. The details of the various engagements, as reported by the wireless dispatches of THE NEW YORK TIMES, are read with consuming interest.

AT SEA ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, May 31. -- Later details from the Kwan-Tung Peninsula show that Gen. Oku undertook operations on May 25 and 26 which few Generals would have undertaken in view of the enemy's strength and the nature of the prepared works they occupied.

WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The President will leave Washington for his Summer home at Oyster Bay on Saturday, July 2. He has decided to receive his notification of the nomination at Oyster Bay, which probably will be made to him early in July.

J.B. James has sold for the Putnam estate to I.S. Korn the six-story apartment house, on plot 53 by 100, at the southwest corner of Central Park West and Eighty-third Street, and the similar adjoining property on Central Park West, on plot 42.6 by 100, the two parcels together covering the northerly half of the block front between Eighty-second and Eighty-third Streets.

CHE-FOO, May 31. -- Five hundred Chinese refugees from Dalny and Tallen-Wan arrived here to-day. After sifting their conflicting stories it appears that the Russians left Tallen-Wan on May 26 for Port Arthur, after burning everything likely to be of use to the Japanese.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 31. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Astor Bristed arrived to-day at their cottage on Wickham Road. Eugene Schieffelin arrived at the Hartshorn cottage on Harrison Avenue, and the family of Mr. George S. Scott at their cottage, Belmead, on Bellevue Avenue.

Presumably the three-day holiday benefited the members of the Exchange, but it did the market no good. Business was resumed after the recess from Friday as though no adjournment had been taken. With a volume of 137,413 shares it cannot be contended that either bulls or bears are active, and it is necessary to admit that the familiar and still continuing sagging tendency is as nearly natural as markets ever are.

NIU-CHWANG, May 31. -- Refugees who continue to arrive here from the southern part of the Liao-Tung Peninsula report daily fighting there and severe losses for both armies, but the reports are not confirmable officially. The Russians here are depending on the press bulletins for news from that vicinity.

Just as a change from the monotony of having all the favorites win, results went very near the other extreme at the Gravesend race course yesterday, and favorites were beaten with such regularity and precision that until Hurst Park galloped home for the last event of the day the followers of public form were in a state closely akin to panic.

James Johnson, a love-crazed Norwegian, who keeps a boarding house at 210 East Thirty-second Street, filled the air full of lead from a pair of revolvers at his home yesterday, first to compel a girl to marry him, then to fight off the police who were after him, when he sought refuge in a grate-covered coal bin under the sidewalk.

Acting under orders from Charles F. Murphy, after Mayor McClellan had urged the course upon the Tammany leader, the Tammany members of the Board of Aldermen backed water yesterday in their attitude toward Commissioner Woodbury of the Department of Street Cleaning, and granted the $314,200 appropriation for new plant and equipment which had been voted down at the meeting the week before.

Munn, Son Co., one of the oldest cotton firms in the city, found it advisable yesterday to announce its suspension on the Cotton Exchange. The announcement that the firm was in difficulty caused a small sensation on the local exchange, where the company has been known for years as one of the best spot cotton and brokerage houses in the city.

BEAVER, Penn., May 31. -- The funeral of Senator Matthew Stanley Quay was held to-day. At 10 o'clock brief services were held at the house. All Beaver Valley was draped in mourning and crepe hung from every business house and many residences in Beaver.

Sweetser, Pembrook Co.'s stock of domestic flannels and blankets was almost all sold yesterday, the first day of the second week of the sale. The remainder of this stock will be sold to-day, and then the stock of hosiery, underwear, and gloves will be taken up. It is expected that the sale will be finished by Friday.

Time does not ease the pain which the New York Democratic platform gave and still gives to Mr. BRYAN. Speaking to an audience assembled in the auditorium of the fair grounds at Dallas, Texas, last Friday, Mr. BRYAN belabored the Saratoga platform with all his might, pausing occasionally to give a whack to Mr. CLEVELAND and Judge PARKER.

PARIS, May 31. -- The question of explosive mines sown in neutral waters deeply interests the commercial classes here, but there is a note of timidity in the expression of opinion on the subject by leading business men which is due to fear of offending Russia.
LIAO-YANG, May 31, 5:20 P.M. -- Continuous fighting has taken place northeast of Feng-Wang-Cheng and on the railway above Kin-Chow since May 27.

In your "Topics of the Times" column to-day you have treated of a subject upon which I have indulged in considerable speculation from the point of view of a human being naturally fond of the companionship of and mingling with his fellows, but who, owing to something in his makeup, does not seem to find his yearnings reciprocated even to a slight extent.
LONDON, June 1. -- The Daily Mail's correspondent at Niu-Chwang says:

It is quite time for the Board of Health to step in and stop the nuisance of overcrowding the open street cars, as it stopped the nuisance of spitting. There is no more unwholesome condition during hot weather than to feel the heat from a perspiring body standing in front of one, and another standing at one's back on an open car.

Alleged loose business methods of the Board of Superintendents of the Department of Education in nominating teachers may compel the Commissioners of the Board of Education to pay the salaries of a number of the most recent appointments, as the two-hundred-thousand-dollar fund for this purpose has apparently been exhausted.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- Cold, damp weather lessened the attendance at the open-air horse show to-day on Wissahickon Heights, but the quality of the horses judged was of the same high order as on the previous day. Mrs. John Gerken captured four of the ten first prizes. Reginald Vanderbilt was forced to be content with two third prizes.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- In the United States Supreme Court opinions were handed down to-day in three cases involving questions pertaining to administration of criminal law in the Philippine Islands.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31. -- Four masked robbers early to-day visited the car barn of the Delaware County Electric Railway, at Clifton Heights, near here, and blew open two safes, securing in cash, but failing to get $1,000 which was in one of the safes. The cracksmen bound and gagged three employes of the company and the male passengers and terrorized two women passengers.
A well-dressed man, about twenty-three years old, walked into the West Sixty-eighth Street Station early this morning and asked Sergeant Reahan to tell him who he was.

It was just half a century, on the 31st of last March, since the first treaty between Japan and the United States was signed by Commodore PERRY. By that treaty Japan became the pupil in modern civilization of the United States. The Japanese have not forgotten the fact, and we, on our side, ought not to forget it.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 31. -- Chief Judge Alton B. Parker of the Court of Appeals supplemented his address on "The Origin and Development of the Law," delivered before the students of the Albany Law School to-day, with an interesting informal talk in which he told of his early experiences as a lawyer.
The following article, entitled "Summer Shooting," and written by Ex-President Grover Cleveland, will appear in The Independent to-morrow:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 31. -- Three through trains marooned near Quenemo, Kan., on account of the flood which had washed out portions of the Santa Fe and Missouri Pacific tracks, reached here today. A majority of the passengers were east-bound, many of them coming from the Methodist General Conference at Los Angeles and others from El Paso.
Mr. G. ELTON MAYO furnishes to The Pall Mall Gazette the following statement of the policy of the new Premier of Australia, as outlined recently by Mr. WATSON himself:

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 31. -- Alderman Charles T. Johnson, indicted for receiving a bribe in the Lake Michigan water deal, to-day appeared in the Superior Court and pleaded guilty to accepting $350. Judge on Newnham released him on bail for appearance at the call of the court for sentence. Immediately after his release he filed with the City Clerk his resignation as Alderman of the Seventh Ward.

-- Commenting on the recent report from Washington that the Post Office Department has decided to withdraw the privileges of the mails from quack doctors by issuing fraud orders against them and withholding their letters, The Medical Journal says that this is "news that seems too good to be true."

President ROOSEVELT'S message of "profound sympathy, official and personal," sent to the widow of Senator QUAY, was characteristically frank and manly. "Throughout my term as President Senator QUAY has been my stanch and loyal friend." This was undoubtedly the fact, and the proclaiming of it at the moment of Mr. QUAY'S death was due to an impulse which the President is the last man to resist.

"I thought the office of Mayor was a great character developer," said Mayor McClellan, yesterday, "but since I have become the owner of an auto car I have decided that an automobile is a greater developer of character -- the greatest I've ever known."

As we have already pointed out, Port Arthur may even now be said, and with accuracy, to be "invested." It was so when it was shut up from communication by sea or land with the outside world. That definitively happened with the taking of Kin-Chow. It means that the garrison can receive from outside no further reinforcements of men, munitions, or provisions, but must defend itself with what resources it now has until relieved.
ROME, May 31. -- Mgr. Kennedy, Rector of the American College, presented to the Pope to-day the graduating class of 1904, consisting of ten students, who have just been ordained.

CHICAGO, May 31. -- The reported deathbed confession of William Tascott, the long-sought murderer, in the heart of the Alaska wilderness recalls the Snell murder of sixteen years ago and the long hunt for the supposed slayer of the millionaire. On the night of Feb. 8, 1888, Amos J. Snell, a wealthy real estate owner of the west side, was found murdered in the private office of his home, beside his safe.
WASHINGTON, May 31. -- The factional quarrel in the Republican Party in Wisconsin has been the brought to the White House and laid before the President, who would have nothing to do with it.

It is a curious coincidence that in the opening of the twentieth century the United States should be called on to do police duty on the shores of the Mediterranean and to protect its citizens against the violence of descendants of the North African pirates whom it punished in the early years of the nineteenth century.

Awards for Indian supplies for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1905, were announced yesterday at the Indian Warehouse, 119 Wooster Street. Robert M. Fair, representing Marshall Field Co. of Chicago, carried off all the largest contracts.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 1. -- The contract between the Dominion Government and Colombier Brothers of Bordeaux, for a line of steamships between France and Canada has been canceled, and negotiations for the service are proceeding with Sir William Armstrong, the British shipbuilder.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 1. -- The report of Charles F. Lewis, who was appointed to appraise the personal estate in New York of James King Gracie, who was an uncle of President Theodore Roosevelt and who died in New York City on Nov. 23, 1903, has been filed. The will benefits the President and his family to the extent of $36,000.
LIAO-YANG, May 30. -- The Japanese lost 200 killed and a number of horses in a fight at Vagenfuchu to-day.

CHE-FOO, June 1. -- It will take some little time to make Dalny and Talien-Wan practicable as a Japanese sea base, as to south of Shan-Shantao the islands have been connected very skillfully with the mainland by mines, both observation and blockade mines zigzagging over a large field.

----- It is sufficiently discouraging -- not to say disgusting -- that at the hearing on corporal punishment given by the Board of Education's Committee on Elementary Schools, this week, only two of the Principals present, one woman and one man, spoke in opposition to the abominable demand for the re-establishment in our public schools of that ancient atrocity.

According to Prof. William H. Burr, one of the experts employed by the city to devise a plan for averting a water famine in the near future, Gov. Odell's approval of the Smith Dutchess County Water or so-called "Ramapo bill" has set back the City of New York three whole years in its struggle for an adequate water supply, unless something should happen to cause the repeal of the new law.

ATLANTA, Ga. June 1. -- A delegation composed solidly of Parker men and under the unit rule instructed to vote for the New York jurist "as long as in the opinion of a majority of the delegation there is a possibility of nominating him," is all that the Hearst managers have to submit to the New York editor as results of the systematic campaign that has been waged in his interest in Georgia.

The long contention between the Consolidated Gas Company and the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity begun by ex-Commissioner ROBERT GRIER MONROE has come to an end through the surrender of Commissioner OAKLEY, who to-morrow will recommend to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the acceptance of the bid of the Consolidated to supply 22,500 incandescent street lamps with Welsbach mantles for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx at $24.75 each.

Clarence Rudyard, twenty-one years old, of 820 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, has been missing since Sunday morning last, and it is feared that he was drowned while bathing at Navesink Highlands, N.J., where he was in camp with the Second Battalion of the Naval Militia, of which he is a member.

ALBANY, June 1. -- Justice Brewer of the United States Supreme Court called attention to the great influence of the corporations on the legislation-making lawyer in an address before the Albany Law School to-day.

MOSCOW, June 1. -- I learn from a usually well-informed source that Harbin will be fortified against the contingency of a siege without loss of time and irrespective of expense, that the heavy siege guns already dispatched by rail east from St. Petersburg are really destined for Harbin, and that a considerable number of heavy siege guns are to be removed for the same purpose from Kronstadt and other first-class fortresses.

We read that many of the friends of the late Mayor of Baltimore, who seems to have had many and warm friends, are making themselves heard in opposition to the theory of suicide adopted by the officials who have conducted the inquest. This is what one would expect, in the absence of absolutely conclusive evidence of suicide.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1. -- After one man had been killed last night and with the striking furnacemen at Hanging Rock threatening further trouble at any moment, four companies of militia were ordered to proceed to the scene to-day.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 1. -- Gen. Sakharoff has telegraphed as follows, under to-day's date, to the General Staff:
WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Secretaries Hay and Moody held a conference with the President to-day over the latest advices regarding the Perdicaris case.
LONDON, June 1. -- The race for the Derby Stakes, (of 6,500 sovereigns, about one mile and a half,) at Epsom to-day was won by St. Amant.

Prince Pu Lun had a day of sightseeing yesterday, during the course of which he added at least one experience to his list, which in all probability no scion of royalty ever before encountered in this country. Prince Pu not only saw the inside of a New York flat, but, just as any plebeian might do, he climbed three flights of stairs to enjoy the privilege.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., June 1. -- The Tenth Annual Conference on International Arbitration opened here to-day with a larger attendance than at any previous meeting of the body, nearly three hundred people being present. Judge George Gray of Delaware was chosen to preside over the conference.

PARIS, June 1. -- The request of the United States for the co-operation of France in bringing about the release of Messrs. Perdicaris and Varley has produced a very favorable impression at the Foreign Office here, where much significance is attached to the request, as embodying the first distinct international recognition of France's paramount influence in Morocco.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The Treasury statement issued to-day shows that the available cash balance is $163,287,516, a loss during the month of $57,631,672. Payments of the Panama Canal and the loan of $4,600,000 made to the St. Louis Exposition explain this large falling off in cash.

Floyd A. McFarland of San Jose, Cal., the racing cyclist who spent last Winter in Australia, where he was suspended for three years by the League of New South Wales Wheelmen, has arrived in this city and has made an explanation of the matter to the officials, of the National Cycling Association, which explains why that body has as yet received no notice of the action of the Australian cycling authorities.

Ex-Secretary of State John T. McDonough, who, following his retirement from the State service, was appointed a Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines, is understood to be due to arrive in this country very soon for the particular purpose of presenting his claims for a nomination to the Court of Appeals bench by the Republican State Convention this year.

DETROIT, Mich., June 1. -- The Greater New York baseball team began its Western trip with a victory to-day, defeating the Detroit nine and "Wild Bill" Donovan by 5 to 3. Griffith presented his new man, Collins, from the Rochester Eastern League team, and he showed quite promisingly. Chesbro pitched a good game for New York, despite the fact that he was hit quite freely.

Elm Street will be restored to its normal condition at an early date as the result of a letter forwarded yesterday by Borough President Ahearn to Secretary Burrows of the Rapid Transit Commission, the letter developing the fact that owing to an error in March the Borough President's office missed a notification from the Rapid Transit Commission to the effect that the street was in condition to deliver to the city by the commission.
A sense of justice impels me to protest against the severe and unmerited criticism contained in THE TIMES of May 30, "Undisguised."

Defying the prevailing state of liquidation as to external weather conditions by adequate provision for liquidation within, the party from the New York Stock Exchange formed to accompany the baseball team to Boston, the team itself, and six individuals who when they are not rubbing down the players will be utilized to open refreshments and to take away the "empties," departed on the Fall River boat for Boston yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, June 1. -- To further the peace programme of which he is, barring the Czar, the most illustrious exponent in Europe, Baron d'Estournelles de Constant, with whom I had a conversation to-day on behalf of THE NEW YORK TIMES, welcomes anything which can prove more clearly to men's minds the odiousness and stupidity of war.
BERLIN, June 1. -- Henryk Sienkiewiez, ] he Polish novelist, is going to lanchlt/cJl/ { in search of literary material.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1. -- Crows rising from a clump of bushes attracted the attention of Detective Berry to-day while he was walking across Tinicum Island, marshy land in the Delaware River across from Essington, where many brokers and business men of Philadelphia have Summer boathouses.
Regarding the Democrats now arrayed against Mr. Murphy, just a few facts:

I congratulate you on the article in your issue of May 25 on Christian Science. People who are not interested in or have not had to deal with Christian Science in their families are not aware of the misery, unhappiness, and unnecessary deaths that Christian Science has brought into a large number of families throughout the country.

The sharp break of sixty points in the cotton future market yesterday, which caused considerable excitement on the local Exchange, attracted particular attention because it was due largely to a woman that the market went to pieces.

Gabe Case is dead. He had long been ill with Bright's disease, but had been able to drive up the Speedway within a fortnight. The end came yesterday afternoon at McGown's Pass Tavern, which he had conducted for the last fifteen years, and where were reflected the glories of old Florence's at Jerome Avenue, whose great fame became dimmed in the lustre which Gabe Case shed upon it in his own name.

John Barrett, ex-United States Minister to the Argentine Confederation and newly appointed Minister to Panama, who arrived here last week from Buenos Ayres, talked yesterday of the recent expedition of the Scotia to the Antarctic regions. He said that the scientists had returned to Buenos Ayres loaded down with specimens of great zoological value and no less than 2,000 pounds of fish for food.
The "new backer of Schaefer," whom you quote in this morning's issue, is certainly qualified by lack of knowledge to back almost anything and win.

" The lid," that bugaboo of the police, that mysterious something upon the hinges of which nearly every local humorist has attached a story -- that dreaded "lid" the very mention of which in long-suffering society often means immediate and permanent ostracism -- has at last been found and put on the shelf for good. It is now in the Morgue.

Gilsey Brothers Co. have sold for Elizabeth A. Wilcox the Warrington, an eleven-story apartment hotel at 161 and 163 Madison Avenue, on plot 49.4 by 98.9, to Howard N. Potter. The price was $500,000. Mr. Potter gives in part payment property at New Rochelle valued at $150,000. The Warrington is one of the most successful apartment houses in this district, among its patrons being Alfred G. Vanderbilt.
CHICAGO, July 1. -- Owen was the star of today's game. He not only shut the visitors out with but two hits, but scored the winning run with a timely single. Attendance, 2,100. Score by innings:

PATERSON, N.J., June 1. -- When the name of James Richards was called in the Court of Quarter Sessions this morning to answer to all indictment charging him with assault and battery, Prosecutor's Detective Nat Shane was seen coming through the crowd at the door, leading by the hand a little fellow who hardly reached to the knee of the detective.

The prospect of a general strike of the firemen on the coastwise steamship lines seemed remote yesterday. The committees which visited the managers of the companies were listened to courteously, and there was an evident desire on the part of the companies to avoid trouble and to remedy any grievances that the committees of the firemen may be able to prove exist.

Your editorial in THE TIMES of May 28, prompted by the explosion of gas in the subway at Thirty-second Street and Broadway, and condemning the gas companies for opposing placing gas mains in pipe galleries in the subways, suggests to a looker on who has studied somewhat the subway problem, this question: Is it advisable to include gas mains and electric conduits in our subway system?
NEWPORT, R.I., June 1. -- The new Holland submarine torpedo boat Fulton had the first of its tests before the naval inspection board off Newport to-day.

Although the Carlton Stakes, which is to the Brooklyn Derby what the Withers is to the Belmont, was renewed at Gravesend yesterday, the weather was so disagreeable that the attendance was restricted almost wholly to the professional element, and even the regulars found the day not one of uninterrupted prosperity.
PARIS, June 1. -- A St. Petersburg telegram says:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1. -- Before a large crowd of friends and relatives here this evening those midshipmen who have won distinction in athletic events during the year were presented with the medals won by them. The presentation was made by Admiral George Brown, United State Navy, and took place immediately after the dress parade. Those who received rewards are:

Within a narrow range yesterday's stock market fluctuated a good deal. At the opening the selling was sufficient to put the whole list down a little, but recovery followed, and several times after these initial movements the list showed alternately firmness and heaviness, with the final count in favor of the bears. The abandonment of the market to the professionals seems as complete as it can be.

LONDON, June 1. -- Rumors of mediation in the Russo-Japanese war caused a rise of one-half per cent. in consols, and a general upward tendency on the London market this afternoon, but the rumors have found no confirmation in diplomatic quarters.

Commercial failures in the United States during the month of May, according to reports compiled by Dun's Review, were 997 in number and $9,817,998 in amount of defaulted liabilities, which compares with 943 bankruptcies involving $12,314,206 in the corresponding month last year. Manufacturing failures numbered 245, with debts of $3,509,884, against 217 a year ago for $3,403,615.

By far the most illuminating and complete statement of the needs and aspirations of the Japanese people which led them to take up arms against Russia is made by Dr. K. ASAKAWA of Dartmouth College in the current number of The Yale Review.

DETROIT, Mich., June 1. -- After months of loud claims, the spending of much money, and the forming of clubs, the Hearst boom in Michigan collapsed in the State Convention to-day, that gathering being in thorough control oF D.J. Campau, who was re-elected Michigan member of the National Committee.

" Foster Holmes," who the police say is really "Larry" Summerfield, who has been arrested a number of times for alleged wire-tapping games, was taken a prisoner to the Tenderlcin Police Station last evening. With him, also prisoner, went a man who said he was James Holden.

Business upon the Stock Exchange continues dispirited and dispiriting. Nobody is putting stocks down. They are putting themselves down upon lack of adequate reason for keeping them up. Yesterday's business seemed indicative that each of several pools was willing to let its favorites go, reckoning that it would be easy to take them back lower down and cheaper than to keep them.

LONDON, June 1. -- Walter J. Travis, the American amateur golf champion, continued his victorious career to-day in the third and fourth rounds for the championship of Great Britain, played over the links of the Sandwich Golf Club. In the third round Travis beat R. Graham Murray by 3 up and 1 to play, and in the fourth round he defeated H.E. Reade, the golf champion of Ireland, by 2 up.

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 1. -- By the terms of the will of the late John E. Van Etten, a well-known lawyer of this city, Mr. Van Etten's wife is ignored. His cook and housekeeper is provided for in a clause which reads in effect that to her shall be given all the money she needs all her life.

OMAHA, Neb., June l. -- The Nebraska Democratic State Convention to-day unanimously selected W.J. Bryan to head the delegation to the National gathering at St. Louis, and adopted a platform which reaffirms the Kansas City platform of 1900. The delegation is instructed to vote as a unit on all questions, but the unit rule may be suspended by a majority vote of the delegation.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- The War Department information bureau has been trying for two months to make ready a new map in detail of the Liao-Tung Peninsula showing the theatre of operations around Port Arthur, but has not been able to secure accurate data.
WINSTED, Conn., June 1. -- To save her husband the expense of paying the wages demanded by union carpenters, Mrs. D.J. Whitman is reshingling the family residence, two stories high.

NEW HAVEN, June 1. -- John A. McCall, President of the New York Life Insurance Company, delivered an address on "The Regulation of Life Insurance in the United States and Foreign Countries" before the Insurance Course at Yale yesterday. He said in part:

I saw the other day in your valuable paper a letter from a man bewailing the shape of hats this year. It gives me an opportunity of putting into ink a few observations of my own on this and its suggested subjects.

WASHINGTON, June 1. -- Attorney General Knox to-day announced the appointment of William M. Lanning of Trenton, N.J., to be United States District Judge for the District of New Jersey, in succession to the late Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 1. -- J. Conover Bowne of South River received a telegram to-day stating that his daughter, Julia Bowne, and the Rev. J.F. Cordova, late pastor of the South River Methodist Episcopal Church, who went away together on May 17, were staying in Toronto, Canada.
Fifteen shares of Bank of Commerce stock sold on the Stock Exchange yesterday at 209.

There were developments yesterday in the suit instituted by John R. Platt, the octogenarian, to recover $685,385 which he says he paid as blackmail to Hannah Elias, the negress, whose name was first heard when Andrew H. Green was last Fall shot down and killed by Cornelius Williams, a discarded negro admirer of the woman.

At a dinner of the American Asiatic Society given last night in Sherry's to Prince Pu Lun, nephew of the Emperor of China, it was announced on the authority of the Chinese Minister, Sir Chentung Liang-Cheng, that the Empire of China had at last become a signatory of the Geneva Convention.

LONDON, June 2 . -- A dispatch from Rome says a telegram has been received there from Tokio reporting that Gen. Kuroki has completely defeated Gen. Kuropatkin's forces near Sumentse, (probably Saimatsza or Simatsi.)

At a dinner of the American Asiatic Society given last night in Sherry's to Prince Pu Lun, nephew of the Emperor of China, it was announced on the authority of the Chinese Minister, Sir Chentung Liang-Cheng, that the Empire of China had at last become a signatory of the Geneva Convention.

The exhibition of the new steamer of the Pacific Mail Line at her wharf in this harbor was a very noteworthy event. The new ship far outclasses anything we have hitherto had afloat upon the Pacific, or, for that matter, upon the Atlantic. An American steamer which outtons the Cedric, the giant of the Atlantic liners, by some 3,000, is a subject for patriotic pride.

BALTIMORE, June 2. -- Jesse B. Baker, a bookkeeper formerly employed by the National Howard Bank of this city, was arrested at his home here to-day charged with embezzlement. He admitted that there was a shortage in his accounts of between $10,000 and $12,000.

Business on the Stock Exchange was smaller yesterday than on Wednesday, but the tendency of prices was still downward. The trading generally was characterized by the same lifelessness that has prevailed of late, but in a few stocks there were fluctuations of sufficient importance to attract to them more than usual attention.

Charles Dennison, bartender for George Boermann, who keeps a highly decorated saloon in Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot at about 1 o'clock this morning, and probably fatally wounded, by a man supposed to be Fred Thompson, who lives in Arlington Place.

Judge Townsend in the United States Circuit Court yesterday handed down several decisions in customs cases, some of which are of great importance. The case that has attracted most attention is that of Gartner Freidenheit against the United States. The question at issue was the duty to be paid on silk ribbons.
WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The Navy Department has received a report from Lieut. Commander Scribner, whose automobile killed a child in Boston on Memorial Day.

Hannah Elias, locked in the house at 236 Central Park West, which John R. Platt declares she bought with money wrung from him, yesterday successfully defied the civil order for her arrest issued by Justice Dugro of the Supreme Court.

BRYN MAWR, Penn., June 2. -- The commencement exercises of Bryn Mawr College were held this morning in Taylor Hall. The ceremonies were opened by the singing of "America," and a prayer was offered by Prof. George A. Barton.

The contention that it is no crime to swindle a bookmaker caused the postponement of the sentencing of Christopher Risley of Brooklyn in the Queens County Court yesterday. Risley had been convicted of grand larceny in cheating A.C. Thomas, a bookmaker, out of $130 at the Aqueduct track in the Fall of 1903.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 2. -- Lieut. Col. Gourka has succeeded in eluding the Japanese on the Liao-Tung Peninsula, and has arrived at the Russian Headquarters at Mukden from Port Arthur. He is attached to the staff of Gen. Fock, and was the bearer of important information regarding the fighting and Kin-Chow and the situation at Port Arthur.

One notes with satisfaction that the Commissioner of Bridges is likely to get himself into trouble by assuming as his chief object the undoing of the work of his predecessor. Spite is really not a sufficiently broad or secure basis for the operations of an important municipal department.

Coal shipments over Pennsylvania lines east of Pittsburg and Erie for the week ended May 28, it is stated, were 736,275 tons, making the total for the year to date 16,340,627 tons, against 17,105,054 tons last year.

Prince Pu Lun, the royal representative of the Emperor of China at the St. Louis Exposition, visited the banking district yesterday, had luncheon at the Chamber of Commerce, and learned all about wash sales at the Stock Exchange, where the brokers gave him a roaring reception.

The entire indebtedness of the National League, which was incurred at the time its membership was reduced from twelve to eight clubs in 1900, was wiped out yesterday when President Pulliam sent the last installment, said to amount to about $10,000, through N.E. Young, trustee, to J. Earle Wagner of Philadelphia, one of the owners of the Washington Club.
LONDON, June 2. -- Ethel Barrymore will sail for New York June 5, and' will proceed almost immediately to San Francisco, where she will open her season.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- The belief is encouraged at the State Department that the rescue of Mr. Perdicaris may be accomplished without the necessity for a land expedition. The United States is making no direct effort now, and will not do so until the result of the action by France is known.

ST. LOUIS, June 2. -- In a drizzling rain on a muddy field the handicap athletic meet preliminary to the Amateur Athletic Union championships was held here to-day on the new stadium of the World's Fair grounds. These games are the first important events held in the Olympic series of sports.

The supporters of Judge PARKER have derived solid encouragement from the action of the Georgia Democratic Convention in sending to St. Louis a delegation instructed to vote as a unit for the Judge "as long as in the opinion of the majority of the delegation there is a possibility of nominating him."
LONDON, June 3. -- Telegrams from different points seem to confirm the rumors that Gen. Kuropatkin is attempting a diversion in the direction of Port Arthur.

Bulletins from the front were eagerly scanned by the company of the faithful here, who, unable to accompany the Stock Exchange baseball team on its quest after the scalps of the Beantown Stock Exchange aggregation, were yet with it in spirit. The messages began coming so early that the mode of transmission was somewhat in doubt, but the general opinion had it that it was to wireless telephone that the Street owed its information.

DETROIT, Mich., June 2. -- Two lucky hits that dropped on the foul line too far out for the infielders, each of which came with two out and two runners on the bases, gave New York four of its five runs to-day. It was a lucky victory, Killian's pitching being of the winning kind. Griffith had much to do with the victory, stopping Detroit's scoring and starting that of his own side.

Louis Spiegel, a lawyer, who appeared before Justice Greenbaum in the Supreme Court yesterday to argue on an order directing the District Attorney to show cause why a forfeited bail bond should not be vacated and canceled, charged Assistant District Attorney Minor with sharp practice in dealing with Spiegel's client, Antonio Ferrara, a confectioner of 195 Grand Street.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 2. -- Douglas M. Smith, paying teller of the National Tradesmen's Bank of this city, was arrested to-day, charged with having embezzled $60,000 of its funds, a greater part of which he admitted he had lost in speculation.
The question whether or not a man may spend his hard-earned money as he likes, no matter how frivolous the manner of expenditure, came up in the Tenderloin Station last night.

Assisted by six physicians detailed by the Department of Health and by three of his own Medical Inspectors, Commissioner Woodbury of the Department of Street Cleaning has begun a personal investigation of the physical condition of every one of his 6,000 "white wings," including foremen and Superintendents.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 2. -- A desperate effort on the part of the leaders to break the dead-lock in the Republican State Convention failed to-day, and at 8 o'clock this evening the assemblage took a recess until 10 o'clock to-morrow morning without having nominated a candidate for Governor.
LONDON, June 2. -- Money was in fair demand in the market to-day. Discounts were firmer, owing to the general tone.

Podszus announced by advertisement to his friends that he would be at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Several of them who went there to find him were disappointed because he did not put in an appearance. Podszus, according to his own statement, is the editor of the Heirats Zeitung of Berlin, which is the "thunderer" of matrimonial newspaper. Its columns are the Sargasso of lost and strayed affinities in the Fatherland.
Bird S. Coler, who is now, owing to the retirement of Shevlin, the nominal head of the anti-McCarren organization of Kings County, appeared in Tammany Hall yesterday for the first time in months.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones returned to-day in the steam yacht Narada and at once took possession of Inchiquin, which they have rented for the season. Mr. Jones's thirty-footer Carolina will be put in commission immediately, and will be the first of its class to be ready for a sail this season.

Preparations were practically completed yesterday for the $2,000 gold cup race between the fast auto beats entered by Smith Mabley and Hollander Tangeman respectively. Challenges by the two firms were made and accepted last Winter. Each side deposited $1,000, and with this sum a magnificent gold cup has been designed, which after the race will be made a perpetual trophy, open for competition only by amateur auto boat owners.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 2. -- John W. Manning, a prisoner at the United States Barracks, was shot and killed here to-day by Private Speck, one of the sentries at the garrison. Manning was held awaiting trial for desertion, having enlisted fraudulently three times and deserted twice. While at work to-day he attempted to escape. Failing to stop at the command, he was shot through the head, dying instantly.

While public attention is concentrated on the "end-seat hog" the conditions that evolved this creature out of the meek, long-suffering New Yorker are overlooked. Who has not seen a well-behaved crowd of men, women, and children transformed into a fighting mob by the simple expedient of transferring the human contents of three car into one?

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., June 2. -- Vigorous denunciation by A.B. Farquhar of the National Association of Manufacturers, of military measures of the United States Government was the feature of the evening session of the Lake Mohonk Arbitration Conference. Mr. Farquhar condemned what he termed war preparations. Continuing, he said:
PARIS, June 3. -- The correspondent of the Echo de Paris at St. Petersburg telegraphs:

The official of the life insurance company who demanded an adjudication of his company's liability under a policy held by a man legally executed, certainly must be of the gnat and camel order. The learned Pennsylvania Judge decided that the terms of the policy were not binding, inasmuch, as under the circumstances, the payment of the face of the policy to the beneficiary would be against "public policy."

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Major Gen. Ainsworth, the military Secretary, to-day received from Gen. Wade, commanding the division of the Philippines, a cable report of the recent attack upon American troops in Mindanao. The following is an extract from the dispatch:
I, with many others, do not understand the action of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States in adopting resolutions separating the black brethren from the white.
The monthly circular of the National City Bank yesterday on Treasury finances and Government securities, in discussing the possibility of another call on the depositary banks, said:

The hearing in the case of Dr. W.E. Woodend was resumed yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Hitchcock. Charles Schumacker, Jr., a stock broker, said that he had received orders from Woodend Co., and when he executed them, received the regular stock exchange rate of one-eighth per cent. When asked if he paid the commissions back again, he said: "You bet your life I didn't."

NEWPORT, R.I., June 2. -- The submarine boat Fulton fired three torpedoes to-day with an average range of 1,700 yards, which Capt. Train, President of the Government trial board characterized as "satisfactory" and which naval experts generally recognize as far superior to all expectations.
Gottlieb M. Karpas has sold a plot of eight lots on the south side of One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street, about 125 feet west of Lenox Avenue, 200 by 99.11.

WASHINGTON, June 2. -- Judge J.C. Pritchard of the Fourth United States Circuit Court to-day granted a temporary writ of habeas corpus, ordering the release on bail of Josephus Daniels, President of the Raleigh (N.C.) News and Observer, who has been held in contempt of court by Judge Purnell of the Federal Court.

The movement now on foot to reopen, by means of a special session of the Legislature promised to be called by Gov. ODELL, the subject of a water supply for New York should focus in a demand for the unconditional repeal of the Smith bill. The party which controls the Legislature should see the wisdom of such repeal before opportunity has been given for an exposure of the whole scandal of its enactment and approval.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 2. -- Gov. Aycock took a hand in the Atlantic and North Carolina Railroad matter to-day, when he wired the Superintendent of the road at Newbern to oust the receivers appointed by Judge Purnell and if necessary to call upon the Sheriff to do so, adding:

ASBURY PARK, June 2. -- Wiggy Jones who has been a shining example here for many years, was waiting for his friend the druggist to open the shop this morning. When Wiggy, by a tremulous movement of his left eyelid, had recalled to the man of physics the number of the usual prescription, the druggist in a tone of astonishment remarked:

One game in the National League and three in the American were all that were played in the major leagues yesterday. In the East, where the Western clubs of the National League are making their first visit of the season, only the New York and Cincinnati teams succeeded in filling their engagement, the other games being stopped by rain or wet grounds.

The story of a system of robbery by which thousands of dollars worth of costly furs were stolen, stored in cellars and basements and sold at the convenience of the thieves, was told to the District Attorney's office yesterday by Samuel Filarsky, a member of the firm known as the United States Fur Company, 56 Prince Street.

Shortly after 9 o'clock last night a crowd of about twenty boys gathered about one of the Mount Vernon cars at One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street and Melrose Avenue and hurled stones at the car and its occupants.

The Edithia, the largest and most powerful gasoline yacht in the world, designed by Gardner Cox of this city for John H. Hanan of the New York and Larchmont Yacht Clubs, was launched yesterday afternoon at the yards of Samuel Ayres Sons, at Upper Nyack, N.Y., and was christened by Mrs. Hanan, after whom it is named.

PARIS, June 2. -- There is reason to believe that since the United States applied for the good offices of France in securing the release of Mr. Perdicaris efforts have been made through the French legation at Tangier and the Shereef of Malan to come to terms with the brigand chief Raisuli.

WEI-HAI-WEI, June 2. -- I have just returned from a cruise on The Times's steamer Haimun off Kin-Chow Bay, and have been able to glean some further particulars by approaching the vicinity of the engrossing operations on the Liao- Tung Peninsula.

McChesney, top weight in the earlier of the Spring handicaps, and known as the champion race horse of the West, is off for the West again, with the set purpose on the part of his owner, E.E. Smathers, of running for the World's Fair Handicap at St. Louis, the one $50,000 race of the season for mature horses.
Is there any radical difference between an assault by a brickbat and an assault by an automobile?

The statement of Mr. RUSSELL SAGE in an article contributed to The Independent, to the effect that "during the eighty-eight years of my career I have not once taken a vacation" is interesting; but, like most generalizations from personal experience, it is probably not strictly true, and if it were it would have no great value as establishing a rule of sane living for the average man.
TANGIER, June 2. -- The Italian third-class cruiser Dogali arrived here this morning.

If Gen. SPENCER'S statement of the case be accurate, it appears that the indignation of those Britons who have been reported by cable to have been so disgusted with the sharp practice of the American team which won the Palma Trophy was entirely misdirected.

Mrs. A.L. Erlanger, the wife of A.L. Erlanger, of Klaw Erlanger, theatrical managers, who is the President of the corporation recently formed for the purpose of erecting a permanent charitable institution to be known as the New York Home for Destitute Crippled Children, received at her residence yesterday afternoon, delivered by a workingman in overalls, an unsigned letter, with ten $100 bills inclosed, a contribution to the charitable purpose. The letter was as follows:

RALEIGH, N.C., June 3. -- The contempt proceedings of Federal Judge Purnell against Editor Josephus Daniels of The News and Observer, who has been in custody since Monday for refusal to pay a $2,000 fine, was ended this afternoon, Mr. Daniels being released.

English newspapers testify to the growing demand in Great Britain for American books. The prejudice against literature "made in America" is vanishing. English folks like the dainty American bindings and typography, too. American scientific and technical books sell in England as well as works of fiction and humorous writings. Some booksellers are inclined to accept the situation and make the best of it.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Georgetown Rowing Association has decided to enter a four-oared crew in the Poughkeepsie regatta. Coach Dempsey to-day moved Atkinson, last year's stroke, back to 4, and put in Shanley, a freshman, to set the pace.

James R. Keene, J.H. Bradford, F.R. Hitchcock, H.K. Knapp, and Andrew Miller, comprising a quorum of Stewards of The Jockey Club, met at the Brooklyn Jockey Club's track. Gravesend, yesterday afternoon, Mr. Keene presiding.

Housecleaning operations have now spread from the Stock and Consolidated Exchanges to the Cotton Exchange. The managers of that Exchange are undertaking to drive from the floor rumor and libelous stories about the financial standing of cotton firms.
MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., June 3. -- The conference on international arbitration, which concluded its sessions to-day, adopted a platform, in part as follows:

Houghton, Mifflin Co. have in active preparation for issue this month "Documents Relating to the Purchase and Exploration of Louisiana," a volume containing "The Limits and Bounds of Louisiana," by Thomas Jefferson, and "The Exploration of the Red, the Black, and the Washita Rivers," being the journal of William Dunbar.

I would like to suggest an appropriate environment for the reading of ghost stories, one in which I shivered and shuddered over Bulwer's "Strange Story." It was at the seashore, and the cottage where I was staying stood near the water, barely a stone's throw away. The windows of my room overlooked the ocean, and were unprovided with shades or blinds, Diaphanous muslin draperies hung within.

Little Italy is much wrought up over the kidnapping of Maria Basso, thirteen years old, who was known as the belle of the section. The child was stolen at First Avenue and One Hundred and Fourteenth Street Sunday in broad daylight, two men throwing her into a carriage after stealing her from her brother's side.

James A. Blair retired yesterday from the Board of Directors of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad. His resignation was acted upon at a meeting of the board, at which it was also voted to issue out of the treasury $1,000,000 4 per cent. refunding bonds, the proceeds to reimburse the company for certain extensions and improvements.

Pity is love's proxy, and it plays its part in this story not differently from its usual fashion in such cases. For stage, the soft emotion of such passionate kinship has here the high world of English officialdom. It may walk in couples with Dukes and Duchesses and King's Ministers and hobnob with county families and M.P.'s.

ST. LOUIS, June 3. -- The United States Circuit Court was to-day the scene of a sensational attack upon the character of the late James L. Blair by Judge McKeighan, counsel for the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York. Judge McKeighan declared that his clients demanded the cancellation of the $200,000 Blair policy on the grounds that from 1896 until the issuance of the policy he was an habitual forger.

Mr. Ogden has conspicuously succeeded in bringing out in this little biography the "playful and engagingly human aspects of Prescott's character" which Ticknor left out of his. It is not intended to supplant that stately treatise; but it doubtless will, as a readable book will supplant an unreadable one, especially when it comes so much nearer to the truth of the subject.

The story which comes to us from St. Petersburg, by way of Paris, that Gen. KUROPATKIN has been instructed to attempt the relief of Port Arthur, has as many marks of authenticity as most dispatches about the war. Moreover, it has intrinsic probability in its favor. The actual situation is galling and intolerable to Russia.

Some sort of newspaper discussion has been going on touching the alleged resemblance of a sonnet called "Opportunity" by the late Senator John J. Ingalls and an Italian poem by Dr. N. Gigliotti called "Il Fata," which it is said was published in La Sveglia of Naples and afterward in an Italian newspaper of Denver, Col., before Mr. Ingalls's sonnet was published.

Prof. Rowe deals here especially with the attempts of the Americans in Porto Rico to fuse the English and Spanish systems of law, the American and Spanish notions of government, into a new system adapted to current conditions. He acknowledged the difficulty of the task, but takes what is doing in Porto Rico as a sort of sample and prophecy of what must be done sooner or later in many other Spanish-American countries.

The "Letters from an American Farmer," by J. Hector St. John Crevecoeur, to a friend in England, describing conditions in America early in the eighteenth century, are now reprinted from the original edition by Fox, Duffield Co., with a prefatory note by Prof. W.P. Trent of Columbia University and an introduction by Ludwig Lewisohn.

The tender to Mayor TIMANUS, the successor of the late Mayor MCLANE, of the resignations of the four Commissioners appointed to supervise the rebuilding and general improvement of the burned district of Baltimore threatens to throw again into confusion and uncertainty the whole subject of rebuilding the area swept over by the great conflagration.

Seeking to define a plan of action for the anti-Parker forces in the Democratic National Convention, conferences were held at the Holland House yesterday by United States Senator Arthur Pue Gorman of Maryland, ex-Senator James Smith, Jr., of New Jersey; James M. Guffey, the National Committeeman from Pennsylvania, and United States Senator Joseph W. Bailey of Texas.

LONDON, June 3. -- Mrs. Cromwell Varley has sent her relatives in Norfolk an interesting description of the seizure of Messrs. Perdicaris and Varley. After describing the sudden attack of the bandits and the capture of the outbuildings, she continues:

LONDON, June 4. -- No further light has been thrown on the mysterious rumors concerning Gen. Kuropatkin's intentions. Dispatches to The Morning Post from Shanghai and to The Chronicle from Niu-Chwang repeat the reports of the movement of 15,000 Russians to Kai-ping. The correspondents assert that five days' fighting took place at Wafangtien and that the Russians are employing 4,000 carts to remove munitions from Liao-Yang to Kai-yuen, seventy miles north of Mukden.

After a year of quarreling with his young wife, with whom his wealthy friends of Pittsburg thought he was on the best of terms, Lawrence C. Phipps seized his two little daughters from her at the Holland House before daybreak yesterday morning.

Prof. Emerson Gifford Taylor, Instructor of Rhetoric and Doctor of Philosophy of Yale, has written a most interesting love story centring about the life of the big college. In "Dale," those who care to will probably recognize the professor's own Alma Mater -- at any rate, he writes as though he himself were well acquainted with the ins and outs of "Dale" life.

The first and second volumes in the Langham Series of Art Monographs, edited by Selwyn Brinton. M.A., deal, respectively, with "Bartolozzi and his Pupils in England," by Selwyn Brinton, and "Color Prints of Japan," by Edward F. Strange, assistant keeper in the Victoria Albert Museum. (Square 16mo. Green limp leather. Colored and other illustrations. Gilt tops. Imported by Charles Scribner's Sons., $1 each.)

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 3. -- "Gentlemen of the jury, it is a pity that a sickening flirtation between jurors and the defendant in a criminal case, has the power in this court to defeat the ends of justice."

From the time Nancy Stair, daughter of my Lord Stair of Stair Castle and aged five years, sent an imperious note to her father, whose man had been dispatched to bring the child to her ancestral home -- the text of which ran, "I'm not coming. Nancy Stair," written with determination if not with firmness -- one could expect pretty much anything thereafter.

BERLIN, June 3. -- Major General Mackel, retired, who for a number of years was Professor of Military Tactics in Japan, has received a cable message from Baron Kodame, Chief of the Japanese General Staff, announcing the victory of the Japanese at the Yalu River, "by officers whom you educated."

Havelock Ellis, author of "A Study of British Genius," "Affirmations," "The Criminal," "The New Spirit," "The Nineteenth Century: A Dialogue in Utopia," , has revised and enlarged the third edition of his "Man and Woman: A Study of Human Secondary Sexual Characters," and Charles Scribner's Sons are bringing the fourth edition out in this country.

Under command of Major O.B. Bridgman, Squadron A set out at 4:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon on its fifty-mile march to the State camp, near Peekskill. Every man in the squadron wore the new olive drab service uniform, which was issued for use on Memorial Day. These uniforms are of wool and cotton, wool predominating.

In your issue of May 21 you question Mr. Albert Bigelow Paine's assertion that Thomas Nast practically created our accepted pictorial embodiment of Santa Claus, and as Mr. Paine has since suggested that he would be glad to know the facts regarding this claim, allow me to offer the following:

WHAT is known as the "Great American Desert" is a vast stretch of country between the Rocky Mountains and the chain of peaks known is the Coast Range. Not many years ago it was almost an unknown region; to-day the mystery of it has been in a measure solved by the railroads.
Frank B. Sanborn makes the following interesting statement in the preface to his history of "New Hampshire," published by Houghton, Mifflin Co.:

The state of siege about the home of Hannah Elias, 236 Central Park West, attracted even larger crowds yesterday than on the first day of its investment by the small army of process servers unleashed by the filing of John R. Platt's $685,365 suit against the woman.

Mr. Hogarth, the author of "The Penetration of Arabia," tells us that he has not set foot in the country, but that "his sole qualification for writing the story of Arabian exploration rests on a study of the literature of Arabian travel, which the fascination of the subject has led him to pursue for many years." The Arabian peninsula is a land larger than peninsular India, containing nearly 1,250,000 square miles. The population is unknown.

Your accounts of "Early Samplers" have interested me very much, as I have one worked in 1718 by my great -- great -- grandmother, Rebekah Claypool, in the seventh year of her age. She was afterward Mrs. Henry Pratt of Philadelphia. The sampler is 9 by 16 inches, worked on a fine, close yellow linen.

TRENTON, N.J., June 3. -- Nathan Sibbett, the fourteen-year-old boy who was arrested last Sunday on the charge of being responsible for the death of his mother, whose body was found at her home at Jacobs Creek in a partly decomposed condition, was to-day formally committed on a charge of murder.

A HENRY SAVAGE LANDOR has been looking at the inhabitants of the Philippine Islands closely and with friendly eyes, giving attention to such of the tribes as are wildest and least visited, preferring heathen to Moslems, Moslems to Christians.

In "A Story of the Red Cross" Miss Clara Barton, whose resignation as President of the society was announced recently, gives a short account of the work of the Red Cross during the past twenty-five years. In her opening chapter she writes that the book was suggested to her by the question of a child who wanted to know what the Red Cross has done. Miss Barton says in her preface:

As some one recently pointed out, there is a vast difference between the blunders of carelessness and those of ignorance. If one uses such a sentence as "Who are you guarding?" it may not mean that one knows no better; but to speak -- worse still, to write -- such English as "whom she knew was going," is to proclaim a lack of information regarding the commonest law of our grammar.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- President Roosevelt, undismayed by the criticism that has beset him ever since he began to manifest a desire to give the negro political recognition, has decided that a representative colored Republican of the country shall make one of the seconding speeches at the Chicago Convention.

LISBON, June 3. -- The battleship squadron of the United States North Atlantic fleet, consisting of the Kearsarge, (flagship,) the Alabama, and the Maine, under the command of Rear Admiral Barker, arrived here on Wednesday from Cuba, by way of Fayal. The Iowa remained temporarily at Fayal on account of having a sick man on board.

WE HAVE reason to be grateful for the compression of this biography into one volume. So many ecclesiastical biographies of men of similar distinction have been enlarged to two or three; Pusey's (but he was a much more important figure) counting five.

NO ONE who pretends to follow the run of current history on the Eastern hemisphere can afford to ignore the book dealing with Russian conditions which has just come from the pen of Dr. von Schierbrand. It contains just what people are anxious to know and it presents the material in a coherent form.

" Wireless Telegraphy," by William Maver, Jr., is a text book on the theory and practice of marconigrams, expressed in non-technical language, unencumbered with mathematics. (New York: Maver Publishing Company, $2.) Begun as an appendix to the author's encyclopedia of the telegraph, the rapid progress made by the art compelled a separate book to give the subject adequate treatment.

" How to do Bead Work," by Mary White, is a companion volume to her books on basket making which have proved very popular. Beginning with a brief sketch of the Indian bead work, which was the origin of the present fad of bead work, Miss White gives some simple and clear direc tions to beginners in the work.

The author has adopted the novel expedient of writing a synopsis of her book toward the closing chapters, in case the reader should have missed the plot as he goes along. Just the thing for Summer-reading, when the attention is prone to wander. The summary is given in the form of a play. It reads:
PARIS, June 3. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch says:

Mortimer Menpes, in his book "Whistler as I Knew Him," describes the master as a man, as a painter, as an etcher, as a traveler; Whistler on house decoration, Whistler and the "one-man show," Whistler and the Royal Society of British Artists, Whistler and his followers, "Whistler the Exaggerated," and a description is given of how Whistler usually spent a day.

The leading fire insurance companies of the United States, through a committee appointed by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, have undertaken an inquiry from which great results are expected. It is proposed to employ a body of expert engineers to investigate fire hazards under as great a variety of conditions as possible, with suggestions as to the behavior of fire-resisting materials under test and of the efficiency of firefighting equipment.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- By experimenting for a year with a guinea pig and writing a thesis of 5,000 words on her studies, Miss Bessie Allen, a student at the University of Chicago, has passed the cross-examination by the Faculty of the Department of Neurology, and will next week receive her degree of Doctor of Philosophy. Her thesis on "the psychology of the guinea pig" was her final test.

We publish this week, with great pleasure, a communication from the Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., author of "The Leopard's Spots" and "The One Woman," touching the merits of the book called "The Jessica Letters" and some other things. We fancy our readers will be particularly impressed by the attitude of Mr. Dixon toward classical education. He speaks as severely of the common use of Latin as Herbert Spencerspeaks in his autobiography of Homer's Iliad.

NOW that Stanley is dead some people are beginning to ask why he never received any higher honor from the Government than a mere knighthood. Beyond any question he was the greatest explorer of the nineteenth century.

IN the current number of The Metropolitan Magazine a Mr. Francis Sullivan, painter of pictures by occupation, as it seems, after a few words in dispraise of all literary criticism, and a few half-patronizing, half-disparaging remarks about Prof. Woodberry's Life of Poe, turns himself for the time being into a literary critic of the most objectionable kind -- the kind that seeks in real life for the "originals" of a poet's fancies.
Everett P. Wheeler has a noteworthy article in the latest number of the Yale Law Journal on "Constitutional Law of the United States as Moulded by Daniel Webster." Mr. Wheeler says:

Following the announcement, that Mrs. Phoebe A. Hearst had withdrawn her financial support from organizations for the aid of students at the University of California Herbert Welsh of Philadelphia makes an open appeal for funds for the Phoebe A. Hearst College for Kindergartners at Washington, in which she was greatly interested.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 3. -- By making a combination with Charles S. Deneen, L.Y. Sherman, Howland J. Hamlin, and John H. Pierce, Gov. Yates to-day broke the dead-lock in the Republican State Convention and brought about the nomination of Charles S. Deneen for Governor. The nomination was made on the seventy-ninth ballot, which stood: Yates, 1; Lowden, 522 1/2; Deneen, 957 1/2; Warner, 21.

WASHINGTON, June 3, -- Secretary Taft to-day decided to recommend to the President against the reinstatement of John M. Shook in the army as requested by all the members of the Kansas delegation in Congress.

THE motor car or the automobile, as one pleases, will probably take the place of the horse in fiction for a little while, and the pioneer, "The Lightning Conductor," has shown that romance can drive it, as easily as "the 9:15" of Mr. Kipling, but Mr. G. Sidney Paternoster's "The Motor Pirate" is a vehicle of another sort.

THE great increase in naval activity of late years has meant a steady growth in the size of the naval reference books. The editions for 1104 of the two important English annuals, Clowse's Naval Pocket Book and Brassey's Naval Annual, are soon to appear, and will be much larger than the 1903 issues, with a proportionate increase in price.

The report prepared by Mr. LOUIS WINDMULLER for the Chamber of Commerce annual compilation shows plainly enough that, whoever may get gain from the tariff on wool and woolens, it is not the wool raiser.

Mr. Garland appears in this new book of his intent rather on the setting forth of a theory than the telling of a mere story. He outlines in the guise of fiction a programme for the upbuilding in New York of a paying taste for wholesome and homely native-grown American plays.

DENVER, June 3. -- Some six or eight months ago Lawrence C. Phipps and his wife had trouble here, following the publication of a story concerning their affairs. They separated, but later became reconciled and lived together again here.

Will you allow the writer to follow your Goshen (N.Y.) correspondent of May 18 in describing the sampler made by my father's mother in 1798? Its size is 9 1/3 by 10 inches, on homespun linen, now very brown with age. Three different styles of the alphabet, both capital and small letters, a line of numerals, and the name, "Nancy Goldsmith."

BALTIMORE, June 3. -- That the late Mayor McLane was for a long time devotedly attached to the woman whom he married only three weeks before he shot himself is shown in his will, filed for probate today.

The General Executive Board of the Atlantic Coast Marine Firemen's Union met all day yesterday at the Clarendon Hotel, and a statement was given out last night to the effect that a strike had been decided on against every coastwise steamship company which refuses or has refused to sign the proposed agreement.

This latest addition to the publications on the royal game of golf seems thoroughly warranted by its novelty. It will also prove of value to the close student of the game, who knows enough to compare the methods of different players, and who takes pleasure in doing so.

Your editorial of last week concerning the defects of the street-car service was a very just and timely utterance. It must be evident to all who, like the present writer, have passed their lives in this city, that a marked change has taken place within a few years in the personnel of the force of street-car employes.

The new and cheaper edition which has been brought out of George Cary Eggleston's "American Immortals," (large 8vo, illustrated, pp. 432, cloth. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons, $3.50,) contains all the photogravure plates that were included in the more expensive edition of the book issued two years ago.

Mr. W.L. Alden in his London letter takes a little fling at Esperanto, the so-called universal language, with which apparently he has but the most cursory acquaintance, or he would hardly describe it as "no more than a simplified and broken Italian." As well describe English as "no more than a simplified and broken German," which is in a sense quite true.

Cincinnati recovered its lead in the National League pennant race by defeating New York yesterday, and Chicago's success over Philadelphia places the team controlled by Selee dangerously near the Polo Ground representatives. The same teams are scheduled to play to-day, with the best batteries to held them. At the Pole Grounds, McGinnity will be pitted against Harper, and another stubbornly contested game may be expected.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 3. -- Emma Loomis and Dorothy Chandler, the daughters of Lawrence Cowle Phipps, who were torn from their mother in New York this morning, are at the Phipps home, on Wilkins Avenue, to-night. They arrived in a closed carriage shortly before 9 o'clock. They were accompanied by a maid, who was mistaken for their mother in the darkness.
WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Secretary of the Treasury has issued a circular of instructions to customs officials assessing a countervailing duty on wines and rectified alcohols imported from Chile.

WITH the early authorized but incomplete edition of Ruskin's works edited by Charles Eliot Norton more or less accessible through library or reading club and the many unauthorized issues of his principal writings to suit the most meagre purses, the American student of the "arts ef expression" has been able to acquire considerable knowledge concerning the famous critic.

Some of Thomas Chatterton's cleverly contrived manuscripts of a supposititious Bristol friar of the fourteenth century, yclept Rowley, together with the original copies of some of the poems Chatterton signed with his own name, were sold at auction in London the other day for about $1,470.

The dingy old Post Office yesterday became fragrant with the perfume of flowers. There was a procession of bouquet-bearers assailing the old building from all sides, the main point of assault being the office of the Superintendent of City Delivery.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 3. -- The best informed military circles attach no importance to the reports that Gen. Kuropatkin has detached a large force from his army at Liao-Yang and dispatched it southward to relieve Port Arthur, and it is distinctly denied that Emperor Nicholas personally ordered such a movement.

A notable golf triumph is the victory of WALTER J. TRAVIS in the contest for the amateur golf championship of Great Britain which ended yesterday on the Sandwich Club links. How the defeat of the great British players was accomplished, what mistake here or what error there contributed to this unlooked-for downfall of Great Britain's golfers, we may be sure will be figured out in the closest detail.

In a decision written by Judge Byron S. Waite the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday ruled that an orphan asylum is not entitled to the exemptions from duty allowed religious and educational institutions for casts of religious statuary. The goods in question were imported by Benziger Brothers of New York for the use of and by order of a Roman Catholic orphan asylum.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 3. -- The approximate amount of cash embezzled by Douglas M. Smith, teller of the National Tradesmen's Bank of New Haven, since about Dec. 15 last is slightly in excess of $50,000, according to a statement by President William T. Fields of the bank to-day, who also admitted that the shortage will exceed $65,000.

These stories illustrate the life and traits of the logdrivers on the Penobscot River, and incidentally they reveal in an uncommonly comprehensive manner why it is that the gaunt and rocky hills of Maine have always been sending out into the world masterful men who have taken the lead in many walks of life.

DETROIT, Mich., June 3. -- The Greater New Yorks made a good bid for to-day's game with Detroit, tying the score in the ninth inning and going ahead in the tenth. Powell, who pitched the first eight innings, was very effective, but things then went against him. Hughes, who replaced him, did not bother Detroit much.

Mr. Churton Collins's paper on the poetry of Gerald Massey will do good if it does but induce some people to turn to the pages of the poet's "My Lyrical Life," (2 vols., 1889.) Mr. Collins writes enthusiastically, but too much as if he had only now, for the first time, made acquaintance with the products of Mr. Massey's Muse.

Part. II. of the "Life and Letters of H. Taine," translated from the French by Mrs. R.L. Devonshire, is in active preparation at E.F. Dutton Co.'s. It includes the period from 1853 to 1870, continuing the account from 1852, with which the first part ended. Part I, was published in 1902, and recorded the period from 1828 through 1852.
PARIS, June 4. -- The Madrid correspondent of the Petit Parisian says he has obtained from a Spanish statesman the lines of a treaty which will be signed shortly between France and Spain, as follows:

A religious poem on St. John will shortly be issued here by E.P. Dutton Co. It is by the Rev. Dr. Robert Forman Morton, a well-known English clergyman and author of several prose books, including "The Dissolution of Dissent," "The Trinity," "Brief Sermons for Busy Men." "Alfred Tennyson: A Saintly Life," The poem is made up of sixty-seven quatrains, divided into twelve "chapters."
PARIS, June 3. -- Private intelligence received in Paris from different quarters gives a gloomy account of the growing feeling of depression and anxiety in Russia.

ANNAPOLIS, June 3. -- Admiral Dewey to-day laid the cornerstone of the chapel which will form part of the magnificent new naval academy at Annapolis, for which the Government has appropriated $10,000,000.

The new book by Ralph Henry Barbour, author of "Behind the Line." "Wetherby's Inning," "Captain of the Crew," "The Half Back," , entitled "The Book of School and College Sports," which D. Appleton Co. will publish in a week or two, deals with American football, baseball, track and field athletics, lacrosse, ice hockey, and lawn tennis.

Frederick B. Alexander, the Princeton intercollegiate tennis champion, yesterday reached the final round of the open singles in the tournament of the New York Lawn Tennis Club. The match was one of the most keenly contested in the tournament now nearing the end on the courts at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

GREENVILLE, Miss., June 3. -- John Sims and his manager, named Cato, were killed by negroes on the Sims Williams plantation at Trail Lake, Miss., thirty miles east of here last night. Three negroes have been killed since in consequence.

TAMAQUA, Penn., June 3. -- Unless the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company makes some concessions, it looks as though there would be a strike of the 5,000 miners in the Panther Creek Valley. The situation is becoming very serious. The Seventh District Executive Board, after an all day's session at Lansford, adjourned to-night with the understanding that a strike could not be averted unless the company agreed to reinstate the old employes.

WASHINGTON, June 3. -- The Sanitary Housing Company, a philanthropic organization formed by a number of citizens, mainly from official and scientific circles, has entered on the work of ameliorating the condition of the poor of Washington. The company has at its head Gen. Sternberg, ex-Surgeon General of the army.

Bridge Commissioner Best yesterday issued a formal statement in which he made public for the first time the exact terms and conditions of the contract which he signed on May 21 for the handling of street railway cars on the Williamsburg Bridge. The signatory parties were the Bridge Commissioner, the Brooklyn Heights Railway Company, the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railway Company, the New York City Railway Company, and the Bridge Operating Company.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- Charles S. Deneen, nominated by the Republicans for Governor of Illinois, was born at Edwardsville, Ill., in 1863. His father, Prof. S.H. Deneen, was one of the most prominent educators of the State, holding for thirty years a chair in McKendree College at Lebanon as Professor of Latin and Ancient History.

ORANGE, N.J., June 3. -- Stuart Lindsley, a contractor and member of the firm of Wright Lindsley of this town, was held up this afternoon by three Italian highwaymen, robbed of $800 and a gold watch, and then carried, with his ankles tied, and put across the rails on the Erie's tracks.

AT LAST mine enemies have written a book -- two editors who review novels! I seize it, determined at least to tousle Jessica's hair a little. The temptation is strong to quote fragmentary sentences from its lofty sentiments and make the book ridiculous by silly comments.
NYACK, June 3. -- A suit for slander, brought in the Rockland Supreme Court, has caused a sensation here, as the parties are all prominent in social circles.

AJAX, about to die, salutes" the car of the sweet sun," the "Beautiful Light," with the passionate love of a Greek for Nature in all her radiant aspects, and for a good 2,000 years since Sophocles poets annually have welcomed the return of the long, light days with their promise of fruitage-laden Summer.

F.R. Wood Co. have sold for Fanny Thorp the four-story brick and stone dwelling 42 West Ninety-second Street, 17 by 55 by 100.8; also, for Caroline de Verdi 310 West Ninetieth Street, a four-story dwelling, 20 by 100.8.

In this romance the author has once more resorted to the Bible -- the fountainhead of so much dramatic inspiration -- for his narrative of love, intrigue, and revenge. In a previous novel he told a story of Pilate's wife. The present volume deals, for the most part, with the love affairs of Jezebel, the wicked daughter of the high priest of the worshippers of Baal, who married a handsome young Jewish herdsman.

There is a word of Persian Omar (as FitzGerald makes him) about the "Master Knot of Human Fate." The author here quotes the quatrain which contains the word, and adds further quatrains of her own in the Omaric manner -- not that we aspire to cockneyism. "Great Omar," she says, "this vague tale retold contains part answer to the riddle."
