It is some time since there has appeared a contribution of unmistakable value to the literature of English history. Such a work we now undoubtedly possess in Mr. Porritt's scholarly study of the unreformed parliamentary system in Great Britain and Ireland. It will be gratifying to Americans to know that most of the author's extensive research was done during a prolonged sojourn on this side of the Atlantic.

CHICAGO, June 3. -- By a decision rendered to-day by the Appellate Court upholding the Board of Trade in the expulsion of John Dickinson for violation of rules in 1901, the board's right to enforcement of a rule forbidding members to conduct business on smaller commissions than are sanctioned by the board is established.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 3. -- Lieut. Gen. Zilinsky, Chief of Staff to Gen. Kuropatkin, transmits to the Minister of War under date of June 2 a report of Gen. Stoessel, dated Port Arthur, May 28, as follows:

SURREY, Essex, Sussex, Hampshire, are common names in the United Slates. Our ancestors of English origin brought to their new home the remembrances of their past. So when we read "Old West Surrey" the topic seems most familiar to us.

Samuel Cowan, who will be remembered as the author of "The Gowrie Conspiracy," "Mary Queen of Scots, and Who Wrote the Casket Letters," and other books dealing with Scotland and its history, has been for about forty years identified with the social and political life of Perth, the story of which, from the invasion of Agricola to the passing of the Reform bill, he gives in the two volumes entitled "The Ancient Capital of Scotland."

CLEVELAND, June 3. -- Donohue shut Boston out with but one hit up to the ninth inning, when three hits were bunched, giving Boston 1 run. With two on bases, Freeman then hit into a double play. Gibson kept Cleveland's hits scattered after the second inning. Both teams fielded sharply, and Cleveland managed to score a narrow victory of 2 runs to 1. Attendance, 5,676. The score by innings:

LONDON, June 3. -- The American golf champion, Walter J. Travis, to-day acquired the title of amateur champion of Great Britain on the links at Sandwich, where he defeated E.D. Blackwell, a representative of the Royal and Ancient Club, St. Andrew's, by four up and three to play in a 36-hole match.

BOSTON, June 3. -- The annual banquet of the American Free Trade League, held at the Hotel Vendome to-night, marked the twentieth anniversary of the formation of the league and the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Richard Cobden, the father of the free trade movement. Harvey H. Shepard presided and about 150 members of the league were present.

" Olive Latham," (Lippincotts,) the new novel by Mrs. E.L. Voynich, author of "Jack Raymond" and "The Gadfly," has many of the qualities of her former works. It is directly and vigorously written. The characterization is strong and vivid. The story frequently holds the attention absorbingly for many chapters.

BERLIN, June 3. -- The International Woman's Suffrage Conference, called by the International Woman's Suffrage Committee, with headquarters in the United States, met here to-day and organized an International League for the Promotion of Woman's Suffrage.

LONDON, June 3. -- The complate text of "St. Monica's Chronicle" will be published soon for the first time from the original manuscript. The contents are a succession of scenes from the days of persecution.

Between the commercial banks and the savings banks there is little in common, and it is natural that the two classes of banks should maintain independent associations. But the distinction between the trust companies and the commercial banks, is not so distinct throughout. Many trust companies combine commercial banking with their trustee business, though few of them discount paper to any material extent.

STAFFORD SPRINGS, Conn., June 4. -- Burglars bound and gagged Henry Mellen, the borough policeman, early to-day and left him lying unconscious in the Post Office corridor while they blew the safe in the office and got away with its contents.

More than half a million persons visited Luna Park last week, despite the cloudy and rainy weather. "Fire and Flames," the new spectacle, showing the burning of a block of houses, has proved a sensational success. The cast of this show includes 657 men, women, and children. This week sixty-two performers will take part in the Circus Maximus.
LONDON, June 4. -- Expectation of greater ease in the money market after the turn of the month was not realized. The movement this week has been rather in the direction of dearer money.

If young ruffians like JOSEPH ROSSO, when caught red-handed, are to be relieved of responsibility for crime on the false assumption that they do not know right from wrong and cannot be held guilty of offenses which, committed in riper years, would consign them to a prison cell, our courts will become the laughing stock of lawbreakers and our Criminal Code a hollow mockery.

That Lower Broad Street is attracting less attention just at present than at any time during the last two or three years is undoubtedly due to the comparatively few new office building projects which have been launched this Spring and to the general tendency toward delay among those who have such projects under consideration in the down-town district.

The German Reichstag has been debating a law which is greatly needed to protect citizens from the delays to which lawsuits are subjected and to recompense those who have been unjustly accused for their loss of time and the expenses they may have been forced to bear.

Last week at the commencement exercises at Tuskegee, Bishop CHARLES B. GALLOWAY of the Methodist Episcopal Church South made a most impressive and sagacious address to the graduating class. He pointed out to the members of the class that upon them very critical eyes would be fixed, and that as they lived and succeeded so their people would be judged. He added:

Princeton's ex-champion tennis team, Frederick B. Alexander and Raymond D. Little, won their place in the finals yesterday of the doubles for the Manhattan championship challenge bowls, the main event in the tournament of the New York Lawn Tennis Club, at One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and St. Nicholas Avenue. Their opponents are Charles F. Watson, Jr., and W.P. Blagden, the Orange Tennis Club-Harvard University pair.

The nomination of CHARLES S. DENEEN by the Republicans for Governor of Illinois shows a distinct advance in the politics of the State. It is, for one thing, and no small thing, a total defeat for what is looked upon as the "Federal machine," comprising both the United States Senators and a majority of the Representatives in Congress.

Those who spread slanderous reports attacking the credit of individuals and of firms are sometimes brought to justice, but the practice of circulating false rumors about corporations for stock jobbing purposes goes on unchecked. There is no greater stain upon the character of our financial community than that such acts are allowed to go unpunished.

The North China Herald prints a translation of the memorial submitted by Sir Robert Hart, Inspector General of Customs in China, to the throne at Peking. Even before this remarkable document, which proposes nothing less than the complete reorganization of every branch of the Government of the Middle Kingdom, was publicly known, it had been severely criticised by the Viceroys to whom it had been sent for consideration
PEORIA, Ill., June 4. -- An explosion which occurred in the eleven-story warehouse of the Coming Distillery, the second largest in the world, this afternoon, completely wrecked the building.

Quaint little old New Dorp had plenty to talk about yesterday. There was a real live elephant in town -- an elephant, which, according to the police reports, swam all the way across the bay from Coney Island for the simple and, according to the residents, the meritorious purpose of seeing exactly what kind of men and women lived in and around the town whence came the Vanderbilts.

In a statement defining his position with reference to the Democratic situation in Brooklyn, ex-Controller Bird S. Coler yesterday denied that he was aspiring to the leadership, attacked Senator McCarren, and declared that the fight against the Senator was one to sustain Mayor McClellan in effort to give the city clean and progressive government.

PARIS, June 4. -- The leading military authorities here expect the early fall of Port Arthur and view this as a most serious if not irreparable blow to Russia, the present condition of Port Arthur being compared to that of Metz and Sedan during the Franco-Prussian war.

Both Senator Arthur P. German and Col. James M. Guffey left the Holland House yesterday for their respective Maryland and Pennsylvania, homes, after having spent three days in conference with anti-Parker Democratic leaders sizing up the Presidential situation. Neither the Maryland Senator nor the Pennsylvania Democratic National Committeeman would make any statement before leaving the city.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, June 4. -- With the advent of June the cottage season is fairly inaugurated at the Pier, and within a week many of the Summer colony will be at their villas for the season. Each year the Pier has made an advance as a cottage resort, and this season the cottage colony will probably be larger than last Summer.

ST. PETERSBURG. -- Readers of Maxim Gorki will hardly require to be told the meaning of the word "bossiak." Few of us, however, have probably reflected as to how the"bossiak" came to be what he is. It is only perhaps within Gorki's lifetime that the class has become a distinct and comprehensive one in Russia.

CONGRESSMAN W. BOURKE COCKRAN amused some of his political friends at the Waldorf-Astoria a few nights ago by a story of the twelve-year-old son of a friend of his, an Englishman living in this city. The boy, like his father, was born in England, but had been going to school here for six years, and in that time had studied his American history with a due amount of American patriotism.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 4. -- The most notable military wedding which has occurred in the South in recent years was solemnized to-night, when Miss Edith Wait Mercer, daughter of Capt. Mercer, became the wife of Lieut. George Henry Gosman of Brooklyn, one of the best-known officers in the medical corps of the army.

FEW who have watched the progress of the work on the giant subterranean tank just completed in Battery Park realize that this 100,000 gallon reservoir, to contain the purest of ocean water, will practically revolutionize the New York Aquarium into the foremost exhibit of its kind on either side of the Atlantic.

THE international women's congress, which will meet in Berlin June 12, will prove more than an object lesson to the German people. The most representative women from the most distant parts of the world are expected on the shores of the Spree. The addresses of such notable American women as Susan B. Anthony, Dr. Anna Shaw, Mary Wright Scwell, and Mrs. Perkins-Gilman are likely to prove a revelation to this country.

SINCE the death of William C. Whitney in February and the distribution of his millions among his four children -- two sons and two daughters -- a new figure in the person of young Harry Payne Whitney has risen in the financial world.

Prince Pu Lun of the Celestial Empire visited Coney Island last night. It was the first time in the knowledge of the oldest inhabitant and in the memories of the press agents who do business on the island that a man of royal blood had ever come to the land of the barker and the home of the wienerwurst, except incognito.

The writer of this letter tramped German soil during the first twenty-five years of his life, and he cannot understand how anybody who pretends to have studied Germany can write such absurd statements as does Mr. P. Bloch in his letter to THE TIMES.

NEARLY eight thousand, or, to be exact seven thousand nine hundred and twelve persons in the five boroughs of this Greater City were reported to the police and health authorities during the past year to have met with accidental deaths or to be unaccountably missing. This is the astonishing revelation disclosed in the mortuary report filed a few days age with the Department of Health.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Representative Hemenway of Indiana, who saw the President to-day, believes that Senator Fairbanks will accept the Republican nomination for Vice President if it should come to him. That is the general belief of Mr. Fairbanks's Indiana friends.

Open-air amusement begins with a flourish to-morrow night when the two biggest roof attractions of the season open. One of them is Oscar Hammerstein's show, called the Paradise Roof Gardens, over the Victoria Theatre. The other is on top of the New Amsterdam in the Aerial Theatre.

Miss Ethel Hornick, who is considered one of the most beautiful women on the stage, is to be married to Dr. William Wallace Walker in Sioux City, Iowa, on June 28. Miss Hornick began her successful career in an open-air performance of "As You Like it" at Stratford-on-Avon, under the management of Augustin Duly, when Miss Ada Rehan was the Rosalind.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 4. -- Paul Bitterlich, a widower, having seven children, the oldest being sixteen years of age, was shot and almost instantly killed in an orchard on the Hollister estate, off Hollister Avenue, shortly before 2 o'clock this morning. The shooting was done by Policeman Charles McManus, who in a statement to the authorities says that he discovered Bitterlich attempting to enter the Hollister mansion.

Two trades of noteworthy proportions -- those involving the Warrington, on Madison Avenue, and the Hawthorne, on West Forty-ninth Street -- relieved to a considerable extent the monotony of small dealing last week, although there was nothing of unusual character about either of these transactions, except, possibly, that they gave additional force to the oft-repeated opinion that trades have afforded the only market for large properties this Spring.
The following food tale written by a clever young newspaper woman is a true story that came under her personal observation:
LENOX, Mass., June 4. -- Over forty of the Lenox Summer residents have arrived at their country seats, and the month opens with the usual round of small dinners and luncheons.

LONDON, June 4. -- The special dispatches reporting that an Anglo-American arbitration treaty is under way have attracted no little interest here. The Associated Press is authoritatively informed, however, that no negotiations are on foot or contemplated looking to a revival of the late Lord Pauncefote's unsuccessful efforts.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4. -- Justice Keogh, in the Supreme Court, to-day granted a writ of habeas corpus directing the production of "Al" Adams, "the policy king," before him on June 18, when he will decide on questions as to the legality of his present confinement in Sing Sing Prison, which have been raised by Lawyer Abram S. Rose, who secured the writ.

" All these complaints about transit in New York are nothing new to me. I can remember 1815, and there was just as much kicking then as now," said Charles H. Haswell to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

AMONG the new ways educated women have discovered to earn a comfortable living in New York is one that might be called the profession of "Author's Assistant." Who would have thought, a score or more years ago, that a writer of novels could develop into such a captain of industry that he could relegate to the shoulders of a corps of helpers the drudgery of delving for his materials?

ALL of our native reptiles lie in a torpid condition until the Summer sun stimulates them into renewed life, while the snails creep into holes in the walls or into the ground, there to lie foodless and to all appearances and purposes lifeless, unttil the period of leafing returns; but as we go further South, hibernation ceases.
TRENTON, June 4. -- Benjamin Reeder, 92 years old, and his wife, who was 81 years of age, were buried here to-day in the same grave. Mrs. Reeder died a month ago.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 4. -- W.S. Smith, a brother of Samuel Smith, United States Consul at Moscow, and who is in business at Port Arthur, has arrived here. Mr. Smith expresses confidence that Port Arthur will never be taken unless the Japanese sacrifice thousands of men. To The Associated Press he said:

LONDON, June 4. -- The official acceptance of the challenge sent by the Oxford University Athletic Club, on behalf of Oxford and Cambridge Universities, to Harvard and Yale for an athletic meeting in London this Summer has been received by cable.

The Hon. DAVID B. HILL is a pretty bad sort -- everybody knows that. He sits up nights thinking about politics, and spends his days putting his midnight schemes into execution. Good men would loudly rejoice if the leadership could be snatched from the hands of HILL and transferred to those white-souled and blameless reformers the Hon. ARTHUR P. GORMAN and the Hon. JAMES SMITH, Jr.

An hour after he had been locked up last night in the East Twenty-second Street Station on the charge of attempting a burglary in a boarding house at 121 East Twenty-third Street, the prisoner, who says he is Samuel Cooper, and a barber, but who refuses his address, tried to strangle himself in his cell with his suspenders and a piece of heavy cord.

The Vesuvius, famous as the ship that carried the pneumatic dynamite guns, is about to be rescued from the obscurity to which she was consigned just after the Spanish war, and will become an active part of the American navy.

Twenty-four police Sergeants were transferred yesterday by Commissioner McAdoo, and it was said at Headquarters that the shake-up was part of a plan to drive the poolroom men entirely out of business. It was understood that the Commissioner had heard the Sergeants had banded together for the purpose of co-operation and self-protection, and practically controlled the workings of various precincts despite the Captains.

George Richmond, fifty-five years old, consulting engineer and head of the sales department of the De La Vergne Refrigerating Machine Company of One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Locust Avenue, was found dead in his private office, in the Carr Building, One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, yesterday afternoon, with a gas tube in his mouth and a bottle of brandy and chloral in his hand.

LONDON, June 4. -- The Cobden centenary meeting at Alexandra Palace this evening, Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman. the Liberal leader in the House of Commons, presiding, took the form of a tremendons free-trade demonstration.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- Senator Daniel of Virginia, speaking of the probable action of the St. Louis Convention, expressed the belief that a man of the type of Parker would be nominated, and that the platform would be devoted to declarations covering present issues rather than utterances relative to the past.
LONDON, June 4. -- Money was in quiet demand in the market to-day and supplies were not overabundant. Discounts were firm, in view of repayments due to the Bank of England and local loans issues.

A QUEERLY SHAPED GONG, which occupies a position of honor in the centre of the City of Soul, Korea, is said to be one of the largest in the world, and is called "the bell with the wail of a child in its voice." When first cast the bell sounded with a harsh and cracked note, and the superstitious Emperor, fearing an ill omen, consulted with his magicians.

THE league of girls' basket ball teams that has recently closed its series of games for the season is remarkable in that it is the first league composed of girls that has ever been formed. Its members are students of the Normal College, Sachs Academy, Ethical Culture High School, and the Madison Academy.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 4. -- Alonzo Murphy who lives on a farm at Pochuck, near Sparta, has a curiosity in the shape of four chickens that were hatched and are now being raised by a woodchuck. Mr. Murphy found the strange brood when he set a trap on his farm and caught therein a woodchuck.

During several days last month a committee of food exports was in session at the Hotel Wolcott taking testimony as to the adulterations and the use of preservatives in food, and as a result of its work it is expected that the Secretary of Agriculture in a few months will be able to promulgate a set of standards which will define what is meant by purity in foods and what constitute adulterations.

CHICAGO, June 4. -- Michigan won the annual track and field meet of the Intercollegiate Conference Athletic Association on Marshall Field to-day with a total score of 32 points. Chicago was second, and Wisconsin third. In all seventeen colleges and universities had representatives on the field.

Athletes of the Boys High School of Brooklyn won the championship of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League at the eleventh annual track meet, held at Celtic Park, Laurel Hill, Long Island City, yesterday, with a score of 72 points. The Polytechnic Preparatory School was second with 36 1/2 points, and the Erasmus Hall High School was third with 33 1/2 points.
ALBANY, N.Y., June 4. -- The State Department of Health to-day issued its bulletin of statistics for the month of April. There were 13,700 deaths in the State during that period. The bulletin says:

SOME time ago Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan bought in succession three collections of ancient and mediaeval textiles which together form the completest record of the work of the loom to be found in the country. He has presented them to the Cooper Union, and they have been installed in the museum, where Miss Eleanor Hewitt has devoted her time to their cataloguing.

Shortly before noon yesterday Fannie Fiserman, nineteen years old, of 62 Amboy Street, Brooklyn, was assaulted in the hallway of 418 Broadway, where she is employed as a stenographer by Tafer Ebstein, dealers in advertising novelties, and robbed of $525 which she had just drawn from the National Butchers' and Drovers' Bank.

Frank Thomas Young, a successful bookmaker and owner of race horses, and at one time an amateur athlete, whose prowess won for him the nickname of "Caesar," was shot and killed early yesterday in a hansom cab at Franklin Street and West Broadway.

ALBANY, June 4. -- By July 1 next the State Hospital for the treatment of incipient tuberculosis at Raybrook, Essex County, will be so far completed that eighty patients may be received. The wings of the hospital are yet unfinished, but when they are ready for patients 150 more can be accommodated.

The annual convention of the National Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association will begin next Wednesday morning at the Waldorf-Astoria and will continue throughout Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. More than two hundred delegates from all over the United States are expected to be present, and about the same number will be in attendance from New York and near-by places.

The masticatory impulses of the United States Senator were formerly wont to expend themselves on Dognose plug tobacco. The furniture of the upper (as of the lower) legislative chamber was provided with reference to the custom and on a scale of liberality befitting the greatness of the country which those patriotic lawgivers served.

LONDON, May 28. -- ln a passage of a charming tribute to the memory of Lord Sailsbury offered in the House of Commens the other night Mr. Balfour rivetted attention by stating that but for the influence of the late Prime Minister he would never have entered politics. Some weeks ago, in private conversation, he made the same confidence to me with fuller particulars.
The big policeman who stands at the corner of Thirty-third Street and Sixth Avenue objected to the peanut stand, so the long-suffering Italian started to "move on."

LONDON, June 4. -- The controversy aroused here over the Palma Trophy affair has brought to a climax a long series of unpleasant incidents associated with Anglo-American sporting contests. Scarcely any of these has occurred in England without leaving bitterness on one side or the other, and Americans resident in the United Kingdom have come to dread the visit of any American team.

OMAHA, Neb., June 4. -- Mrs. Eliza Ross of Cincinnati to-day filed a suit in the United States Court in which she charges the famous Jacksonsian Club of Omaha with maintaining a poker joint in its zooms in this city.

STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, April 7. -- It was difficult to believe, as the Haimun put to sea in the most perfect weather, that a few hours' steaming would bring us to the theatre of remorseless war. Wei-hai-Wei stood washed in yellow and blue behind us. As yet this sanitarium of the Far East had not donned her mantle of Summer green, but stood out as barren and windswept as the rest of the rockbound peninsula.

CHILDREN and flowers are the sweetest things that grow!" So says one of the twelve matrons on Ellis Island, and the remaining eleven echo the sentiment. That they are authorities on the subject is conceded by every one who sees them on duty among the baby immigrants, thousands of whom spend from one day to four months on the island in the course of a year.

ST. LOUIS, June 4. -- New York athletes won a majority of the events at the championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, held in the Stadium at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition to-day.

Murray Olyphant, a Princeton student and member of the Englewood Golf Club, won the amateur golf championship of New Jersey yesterday in the final 3G hole round, played on the links of the Englewood Golf Club. He defeated his club mate, C.H. Blake, Jr., and who is a member of the Columbia University team, by 8 up and 7 to play.

WHEN it comes to whittling, the Yankee can beat the world, but there are whittlers and whittlers. The fellow who sits on the cracker box in the corner grocery and cuts the slab of firewood into shavings has been written about by the poet and novelist until he is familiar to every reader, but this country contains knife-blade artists who have performed some really wonderful exploits.

The result of the Georgia, Nebraska, Michigan, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Ninth Ohio, and Second and Fourth Districts Maine Conventions during the week just closed leaves Judge Parker of New York miles ahead of all competitors, with 210 delegates. William R. Hearst is next with 135, Olney third with 32, Wall fourth with 26, and Gorman last with 12.

The arranged visit of King EDWARD to Kaiser WILHELM at Kiel causes The London Spectator to apprehend some stroke of dynastic politics. The apprehension seems to be derided in England. And yet it seems reasonable. It is all very well for Mr. BALFOUR to declare that "no British Minister ever seriously contemplated military alliance with Germany."

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 4. -- Under the muzzles of the big twelve-inch guns of the battleship Missouri, and in the presence of a party of nearly 100 people from the State from which the ship was named, the formal presentation of the handsome silver service, the gift of the State of Missouri to the warship, took place to-day.

While the bones of the old United States Realty and Construction Company are by this time pretty dry, and the losers have probably figured their individual and particular losses so many times that the figures are not likely to slip from memory, it is none the less timely to see what the situation of the reorganized company may be as to the watery affliction that proved so fatal in the first instance.

The bank statement showed continued liquidation of loans, but in a smaller degree than during the previous two weeks. The movement, however, was quite general, only twenty-one banks having increased their loan accounts, nearly all of them by small amounts. It is interesting to note that after decreasing loans since May 14 by $42,363,400 that item in the statement is higher by $121,427,100 than on June 6, 1903.

Two out of five monkeys which escaped from the Bostock animal show at Coney Island last Sunday to the roof of Philip Jolly's Hotel, at Surf Avenue and West Eighth Street, have been working their own sweet will about the place during the entire week and are still at large.

The most peculiar orange season ever known is about closing. Practically all the Washington navels from California have been shipped and sold. The Florida oranges are done, after the distribution of a crop approximating 2,500,000 boxes. Porto Rico sent 250,000 boxes, the largest quantity ever shipped from the island, but Jamaica exports fell off, amounting to only 70,000 boxes, where they usually run up to 110,000 boxes.

OSSINING, June 4. -- Squadron A of New York City camped for the night at Ossining. The men pitched their tents in a very short time and most of the troopers did not leave their shelters. They were thoroughly tired by the long trip and were glad to rest.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., June 4. -- The annual reception at St. Christopher's Home, the home for destitute children, was held to-day. About 300 guests were present, most of there coming from New York. The exercises consisted of addresses and singing and flag and dumbbell drills by the children of the home.
TOLEDO, Ohio, June 4. -- The Hon. James M. Brown, President of the American Humane Association, sent the following protest to the Governor of Missouri by telegraph to-day:

DETROIT, Mich., June 4. -- The New Yorks took the closing game of the local series, partly through good judgment by Griffith and partly through bad work by Detroit. Chesbro was sent in to make sure of the game, though Hughes was due.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 4. -- Any one who has the foolish idea that frogs aren't able to converse will be a welcome visitor at the home of Irving Apgar of German Valley. And if the argumentative visitor doesn't go away impressed with the frog as a conversationist the chances are a thousand to one against his declining to believe that frogs don't weep with as much feeling as a hysterical actress.

ABOUT 12,000 women in the United States this year are to have brand-new bonnets for the first time in many Summers. They are women, too, who heretofore have not known what it is to have a new Easter hat, or what it is to wear a flower or a feather. Their millinery has not only this peculiarity, but each one's bonnet is as exactly like her sister's as two peas.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics of the Department of Agriculture estimates the total area planted in cotton in the United States this season at 31,730,371 acres, an increase of 2,823,016 acres, or 9.8 per cent., upon the acreage planted last year.

THERE will be no further need for the Health Board to brand the lakes and streams of Central Park as public menaces. All of these water areas nave been remodeled, cleaned, and beautified by a reconstruction committee consisting of City Entomologist Dr. E.B. Southwick of the Park Department and Dr. William N. Berkeley of the Department of Health.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 4. -- Five days of rain and chilly breezes and but two days of sun and warmth is the weather record for the week. Despite this drawback hundreds of cottagers braved the inclement weather and came to Asbury Park to open their Summer homes, for June 1 marks the beginning of the outing season here as elsewhere.

WITH the recent of suspension The Worcester Spy, one of the few newspapers in the United States that has been in continuous publication for over a century, the last publication intimately associated with the name of Isaiah Thomas,. has ceased to exist. Isaiah Thomas is scarcely remembered at the present time, although during his active years he was recognized as one of the leading printers and publishers in the country.

As the season advances the crop forecast steadily improves. The cotton estimates published yesterday by the Department of Agriculture warrant the expectation of a much larger crop than was anticipated. The area planted shows an increase of 2,823,016 acres, bringing the total under cultivation up to 31,703,371 acres.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 4. -- By turning over $20,000 in securities to Mrs. Francis D. Sullivan, Thomas H. Wyckes, Vice President of the Pullman Palace Car Company, has settled out of court the suits started by Mrs. Sullivan.

The charges of blackmail made by John R. Platt against Hannah Elias have been officially recognized by the office of the District Attorney. Last night Assistant District Attorneys Lord and Kernochan, by appointment, met Washington Brauns, counsel for the woman, at the Hotel Grenoble, and there talked over the case.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., June 4. -- Conductors and other employes of the Pennsylvania, the Central Railroad of New Jersey, and the New Jersey Southern lines running between New York and the North Jersey coast resorts, on the New York and Long Branch Road, were notified late this afternoon in a general order that beginning to-day all Sunday trains will stop at this place to receive and let off passengers.

There has risen a new financial luminary, who confesses unhesitatingly that he can make 50 per cent. interest on investments placed in his hands, provided the placers will not bother him by asking questions. His name is Sydney Flower, and he is publisher of a magazine known as New Thought.

Yesterday's stock market aggregated about 50,000 shares, and all fluctuations were fractions with three exceptions, each of which was a bargain of 100 shares. Iowa Central's fall of 4 1/2 is not properly chargeable to the day's business at all, since it merely signifies the readjustment of a stock seldom dealt in to the conditions disclosed by the Minneapolis and St. Louis's fall, with which group Iowa Central is affiliated.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The Southern tennis championship was concluded on the Bachelor courts to-day, victory in the chief event going to Harry F. Allen of New York, who defeated Frank Geoghegan in three straight sets after one of the hardest fought contests in the history of the sport in Washington. Score, 8 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 0. Summary:

Actual work in the new office of the Commissioner of Licenses will begin to-morrow when the Inspectors, whose selection was announced yesterday by Commissioner Frederick L.C. Keating, will set out on their first tour of the employment agencies.

LONDON, May 10. THERE is considerable discussion in the English press on the subject of co-education and the college system which is so common in America. Not that there is any question raised of giving English men and women university education together.

THE suburban season is in full swing. House parties, tennis, polo, and horse shows, tempered with golf and a little coaching and a few luncheons and dinners, constitute a programme which will show but slight variation until the time comes for Newport and Bar Harbor and Saratoga.

I have been trying to learn why our road-makers, after repairing or fixing up a street, spread a heavy layer of dust and dirt over the job. It is supposedly to settle in and fill spaces and crevices, and then bind the whole. The surplus, however, is never swept up and carted away; its distribution is by the convenient wind, and some is washed into sewer basins, to be laboriously spooned out.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4. -- Early this morning several young men of Hempstead began making quiet inquiries about a young couple who were recently married and who were reported to be stepping in this town. They said that they wanted to give the couple a "send-off," but had no opportunity to do so in New York, where the marriage was celebrated, as the couple had managed to elude them.

Without waiting for the decision of the Appellate Court as to Jesse Lewisohn's alleged contempt of court, District Attorney Jerome has determined to continue his efforts to get evidence on which to indict Canfield. Subpoenas have been issued for a second time for seven men to appear on Tuesday before the Grand Jury which will be impaneled to-morrow.

The situation of the moment is not that ordinarily characteristic of the stock market. It prides itself upon discounting the future, yet last week's market discounted nothing whatever, either good or bad. It simply allowed itself to be paralyzed by reflections upon past conditions and misdeeds which have traveled a long way toward their remedy.

ON THE 19th of February of next year the Department of Education of New York will celebrate its centennial. Just one hundred years have elapsed since the first free public school was established. Mr. A. Emerson Palmer, Secretary of the Board of Education, has been authorized to prepare an exhaustive history of the growth of the public school system.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 4. -- The General Staff has received the following dispatch from Gen. Sakharoff, dated May 31:
NO WOMAN with a lick of sense ever lets on that she knows more about any subject than the man she is talking with.

PEEKSKILL, June 4. -- A part of the Guardsmen who are to occupy the State Camp for the first of the five weeks' season arrived to-day by train. The remainder, Squadron A of New York and Troop C of Brooklyn, who are riding up, are due to arrive here to-morrow noon.

ALTHOUGH fringes, braids, galloons, lace bands, and other trimmings are fashionable, the finest and at the same time least conspicuous, but most expensive ornamentation, is that having the gown fabric itself as its foundation. Exquisite designs may be embroidered upon the gown or worked in curious fashion by the pulling of threads and the insertion of medallions, or laces and other ornaments may be appliqued on or inserted in the gown foundation.

WHEN the good Bishop made his famous remark about the strawberry be no doubt voiced a sentiment which finds responsive echo in the hearts, not to say stomachs, of many thousands of men. "Doubtless God might have made a better berry than the strawberry, but doubtless God never did."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 4 -- Yale captured the first game in the baseball series with Princeton this afternoon by a score of 3 to 1. Princeton got its only run in the first inning. Neither team was able to score after the third, Byram, for Princeton, and Mackay, for Yale, settling down to steady work in the pitcher's box.

WASHINGTON, June 4. -- The discussion that took place during the late session of Congress on the superannuation of clerks and employes in the executive departments here, moved the Civil Service Commission to conduct an investigation on that point, the result of which is shown in figures that will be interesting and instructive should Congress decide to consider the proposition to retire all who have reached the age of seventy.

LONDON, June 4. -- King Edward's activity in the field of international diplomacy has given rise to some uneasiness in Foreign Office and other Government circles, which finds special vent in the comment regarding the forthcoming meeting of his Majesty with Emperor William at Kiel.

Your correspondent who asks which is the greater ruffian, the one who stones an automobile or the one who runs an automobile at a reckless pace through a crowded street, hits the point of the whole automobile trouble. The so-called "ruffian" who stones automobiles is usually a half grown boy.

The skirmish by the owners and trainers of horses engaged in the Suburban Handicap to secure jockeys for that great race has resulted in engagements being made by most of the prominent riders for that event, though the race still is ten days off, the conditional contracts indicating that at least sixteen owners expect to send their entries to the post on June 16.

Only one game was scheduled in the National League yesterday, and that was played at Washington Park, Brooklyn. It was the fourth Sunday contest that the officials of the Brooklyn Club carried out to a successful issue.

The Fifth Ward of the Borough of Queens is one of the most prosperous sections of Long Island. The Board of Estimate has recognized this, and from year to year has appropriated sufficient money for the maintenance of the highways in proper condition, and in keeping with the residential character of most of the towns of which the ward is comprised.

Twenty-four "window climbers," who were arrested on Saturday at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge for crowding and climbing over guard rails into Coney Island trains, were arraigned yesterday morning before Magistrate Ommen in the Tombs Court. They were fined $2 each. Magistrate Ommen said:
BALTIMORE, June 5. -- Death and illness have inflicted heavy blows upon the Keyser family in the last few days.

Almost we are upon the threshold of the very month of weddings. It is not the happiest time of year, therefore, to write in discourse of matters relevant to doubtings in love. However, time, tide, and the gossip of the hour wait upon no mortal contingency, and it happens that the incident suggesting these lines is of note at the instant.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- Ex-Senator Warner Miller of New York lunched with the President yesterday and left for New York last night. He would say nothing about his visit to the President beyond declaring that it was without special significance. Regarding National politics Mr. Miller said there seemed little interest exhibited in the clubs and among business men over candidates for Vice President.
VIENNA, June 5. -- The American jockey, G. Stern, to-day rode Conamore, winner of the Austrian Derby. Conamore is owned by Count Louis Trauttmansdorff.

Although several new facts were brought to light yesterday in connection with the shooting of "Caesar" Young, the bookmaker, in a cab at West Broadway and Franklin Street on Saturday morning, there was little in the developments of the day tending to clear up the mystery surrounding the affair. It was intimated, however, that there would be interesting disclosures at the inquest to-day.

In THE TIMES of May 28 there appeared a letter over the signature "An English Churchwoman" which stated that the fact that "An American Episcopalian" refers to the Episcopal Church as of a Protestant denomination is proof that he is not an Episcopalian at all.

There was very little in the game yesterday at Washington Park, Brooklyn, between the Brooklyn and Pittsburg teams to commend itself to the spectators, for errors were abundant and the hits were so scattered that they were valueless, so far as run getting was concerned.
McAdoo Says Senator's Partner Was Removed as Police Commissioner Because He was Not in Sympathy with Reform.

Last week's business upon the Stock Exchange would seem to indicate the pause of the pendulum at the bottom of its beat. Buying and selling can never completely stop, but when a week's business is only 622,481 shares it certainly is near the bottom of the ebb. And when the price movement is analyzed the impression of balance is confirmed.
One of two accidents that occurred at Coney Island yesterday resulted fatally, and the other, it appeared last night, would result the same way.

Assistant District Attorneys Lord and Kernochan yesterday afternoon held a conference with Lyman E. Warren and James O'Beirne of the firm of attorneys representing John R. Platt in his suit aaginst Hannah Elias. The conference took place at the Ariston Apartment House, and was relative to possible criminal proceedings against the woman.

The Sunday baseball players in Centre Street in the vicinity of the Tombs Prison turned the tables on the police yesterday by dragging a policeman as far as the Centre Street entrance of the prison. Guards from the prison effected a timely rescue.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 5. -- Ex-Lieut. Gov. William F Sheehan is not here to offer the Vice Presidential nomination to Circuit Attorney Joseph W. Folk. He has no appointment to meet Mr. Folk or any other politicians while here, and said to-day he did not expect to hold any political conferences while in the city.

Tennis players will divide their attention between three tournaments this week in addition to finishing play in the final matches of the New York Lawn Tennis Club's successful meeting. Of the three meetings that are new, the Metropolitan Championship, on the courts of the Wrest Side Tennis Club. One Hundred and Seventeenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, ranks first in importance.

BOSTON, June 5. -- According to the counsel of Charles L. Tucker, accused of the murder of Mabel Page at Weston, a witness will come forward to testify that he saw Tucker on the day of the murder at a place and time that would make it impossible for the State to prove its theory.

The first account from any one having personal knowledge of the carrying off of the Phipps children by their father, Lawrence C. Phipps of Pittsburg, was given yesterday by W.H. Whitaker, manager of the Hotel Netherland, from which hotel the children were taken.

In an address on the subject of "Sunday Observance,' delivered by Supreme Court Justice Gaynor in All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and Seventh Street, Brooklyn, last night, the Justice spoke in terms of criticism of "meddlers and notoriety seekers."
By all means let us have flogging in the public schools! Why was it ever dropped out? How otherwise are you going to teach the little animals submission?

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 5. -- There were two Chaplains at the State Camp to-day, but only one church service was held. The Rev. Dr. Lindsay Parker, rector of St. Peter's Church of Brooklyn and Chaplain of the Twenty-third Regiment, held services at 10:30 in the old mess hall, which has been fixed up for use this year as an assembly room for the men.

Generally at this sesson the price of salt declines, but according to information from several sources there is not likely to be any material reduction, in prices this Spring. Almost every year there is a considerable quantity in the Saginaw Valley in Michigan to come forward, but this year the Spring floods destroyed practically everything that was not shipped by rail.

NEWARK, N.J., June 5. -- Frank L. Kramer, the champion racing cyclist, won the two-mile professional handicap at the Vailsburg cycle track to-day after an unusually fast and spirited race in which the pace proved too fast for several excellent riders.

GYANG-TSE, June 2. -- Col. Younghusband's letter demanding that the Amban come to Gyang-tse with qualified Tibetan representatives to settle the outstanding differences before June 25 was returned this morning from the jong, unopened and without comment.
Two fifteen-foot pythons attempted a jail delivery yesterday from the bird and animal store of Louis Ruhe, at 248 Grand Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 5. -- St. Louis defeated Washington to-day after fourteen innings of brilliant playing. After pitching eight and one-half innings, Jacobsen was replaced by Patten, who finished the game. Sudhoff pitched the complete fourteeen innings for St. Louis, and allowed Washington only ten hits. In the tenth inning of the game Coughlin was put out of the game for disputing a decision of the umpire.

LONDON, June 6. -- That the curtain is drawn again over the progress of the war probably indicates that important events are impending or afoot. The explosions heard at Port Arthur suggest that the Russians have renewed their attempts to remove obstructions in the mouth of the harbor. All kinds of rumors are current, few of which appear to have any reliable basis.

The seriousness of the present crisis in Morocco and the consequences which would follow a mistake in dealing with it may warrant a statement from the point of view of an old resident of the empire, and one very familiar with the character of the country and the temperament of the people.
CHE-FOO, June 6, (Monday.) -- But two miles separated the Japanese and Russian Armies on the Kwan-Tung Peninsula on June 2, according to Chinese who have arrived here from Dalny.

By special order of Police Commissioner McAdoo, the police Inspectors of Manhattan all were out in automobiles yesterday afternoon trying to catch some of the boys who recently have been in the habit of throwing sticks, stones, and bricks at passing automobilists.

Fanny, the elephant which swam from Coney Island to Staten Island, arriving there early on Saturday morning, was taken back to the show whence she is said to have made her escape, early this morning. She spent Saturday night in Clifton, and arrangements were completed last evening for taking her home.

DENVER, June 5. -- Lawrence C. Phipps gave out a signed statement this evening, declaring that he was the only person who had a hand in the removal of his children from the Hotel Netherland, New York, and that the children accompanied him without demurring.

In THE TIMES of May 29 I read an account of the Japanese method of dwarfing trees, which was correct as far as it went, but I think there was an important omission. It is true that the soil should not be rich; that the growing trees should not have much water, and that undesired new growth should be pinched back, but the roots need attention also.

ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., June 5. -- J.W. Titcomb, Chief of the Division of Fish Culture in the National Fisheries Bureau, has reached his home here after a nine months' stay in Argentina, where he was sent by the Government to aid the administration of that republic in the introduction and propagation of salmon and trout.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- In the presence of thousands of ex-Confederate and ex-Union soldiers and of numbers of officers of the United States Army and the Grand Army of the Republic, the first formal memorial exercises ever held over the graves in the Confederate section of Arlington Cemetery were held to-day.

The thirteenth annual regatta of the Hudson River Yacht Club was called yesterday afternoon under unusually delightful conditions. There was plenty of breeze and a great gathering to watch the racing. Handsome carriages lined the curb along the Riverside Drive, their occupants witnessing the sport with field glasses.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 5. -- The factory of the Manhattan Piano Case Company at Creskill, on the west slope of the Palisades, five miles from this town, was destroyed by fire to-night.

The Treasury statement at the opening of the present month has attracted more attention throughout the country than any like statement made in half a dozen years. This is not surprising when we consider the actual situation, compare it with that existing one short year ago, and try, from the comparison, to forecast the immediate future.

Fire was discovered at 2 o'clock this morning in the big storehouse of McKesson and Robbins, the wholesale druggists, at 77 Ann Street. The fire had been burning a long time before it was discovered. The firm's main house is at 91, 93, 95 Fulton Street, extending through to Ann Street. The store room is across Ann Street, the two buildings being connected by an iron viaduct above the street.

All were members of the Battle Row gang, and none of them was more than twelve years old. They had started from Cherry Hill after Budd Johnson, the negro boy, had made the announcement that he had twenty-nine cents, and they reached Coney Island by "snitching" rides.

The following little table is compiled from the summary by The Financial Chronicle of the report by the Bureau of Statistics of the exports of steel and iron for the month of April, in comparison with like exports for the same month and for five months of 1903:

Three bell boys who had been dismissed from the Gilsey House on Saturday night returned to the hotel last evening and created such a disturbance that they were all arrested. They said they were William Walsh of 950 Sixth Avenue, Arthur S. Hall of 349 West Twenty-seventh Street, and William Carney of 908 Sixth Avenue.
TANGIER, June 5. -- The Sultan's authorization to carry out Raisuli's demands cannot be received for another day or two.
BERLIN, June 5. -- The possibility of equipping and dispatching a Russian squadron from the Baltic to the Far East in the present year is discussed with considerable skepticism in this country.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 5. -- Lying under her bed, with bruises on her neck, shoulder, and legs, Mrs. Mattie E. Carlisle, a widow, of about sixty years of age, was found dead this morning by the police. While there are evidences of foul play there is a difference of opinion as to the cause of her death, and the affair is shrouded in mystery.

Princeton students, said to be an army officer's son and an Admiral's nephew; some other men, two bulldogs, including the Princeton mascot that went to New Haven Saturday, and House Detective Edward Shepherd of the Park Avenue Hotel were in a free fight in the hotel cafe and out on the street early yesterday morning. The detective was hurt. The dogs chewed each other, but were beaten apart.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- An interesting question has been raised by the Tax Office of this city regarding the exemption from taxation of real estate that is used by foreign legations. The rule has obtained to exempt from taxation property owned by any foreign Government that is used by its representatives as residence and office.

LONDON, May 20. -- The old Black Bull of Holborn was lowered from his perch yesterday, and his retirement from public life marked the beginning of the demolition of the famous old London inn that bore his name.

WASHINGTON, June 5. -- The foreign trade in iron and steel will show in the fiscal year, which ends with the present month, a marked contrast compared with that of last year. The imports of iron and steel in the fiscal year 1903 were the largest since 1891, and, with the exception of that single year, the largest since 1883.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 5. -- Cottagers are arriving from New York daily. Nearly every cottage here is already occupied. The Summer hotels will not open for business until later in the month.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 5. -- In an address delivered before the annual convention of the American Federation of Zionists, held here to-day. Dr. Maurice Fishberg spoke of the physical condition of the Jews in the United States.

Gov. Franklin Murphy of New Jersey, after a six weeks' sojourn in Europe, arrived home on the White Star liner Celtic yesterday morning. The Celtic was expected on Saturday, and on that day Secretary of State Dickinson and a party of New Jersey politicians journeyed to Sandy Hook on the tug Sea Gull to welcome the Governor.

The price of lower grade resins has been steadily and rapidly advancing for several months, and the present quoted price is exactly 100 per cent. higher than it was two years ago. Lower grade resins could be bought in 1902 for $1.50 a barrel, and now the price is $3 a barrel and upward.

Mr. Russell Sage's advice, it seems to me, should be adopted by all those who live to get money, but by those of us who get money to live his opinion must be studiously ignored. For what shall it profit a man, at the noble age of eighty-eight years, if his strong box be full and his mind be empty; if his only memories are those of the counting room?

Following the intense heat of midday and late afternoon, a heavy windstorm struck the city yesterday evening, sending thousands to cover, and was followed by a heavy rainfall in some parts of Manhattan. The severity of the wind, however, was greater in other boroughs, where the blow unroofed several houses and blew another one, half completed, about twenty-five feet, tore down trees, and did other damage.

The building in Cincinnati of the first concrete office building of the modern "skyscraper" type is an event of more than ordinary architectural and technical interest. It points to the almost unlimited possibilities of this material in building construction, without fully realizing those which will be found of the greatest interest and value.

Mr. JOHN SHARP WILLIAMS, upon the application of our neighbor The World, has been giving that journal at some length his opinion upon the President's letter to ex-Secretary ROOT on the second anniversary of the independence of Cuba. We regret to find in Mr. WILLIAMS'S letter rather more than a "trace" of what we are compelled to call factiousness.

As a result of a pistol battle between a gang of 150 Italian laborers employed on the Cunard piers at Gansevoort Street and Policemen Lennon and Morton of the Charles Street Station at 7 o'clock last night two of the Italians are in St. Vincent's Hospital with gunshot wounds, and a third was so badly battered by the policemen's clubs that it is feared he will die.

Two men were wounded last night in a lively shooting affray, that had for its battleground the fourth floor of a crowded five-story tenement at 614 East Sixteenth Street. William Gillen, twenty-four years old, who lives in the rear apartment at that floor, was attacked by a gang of about twenty men, who had previously attacked him in the street during the day and had stabbed him in the forehead.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 5. -- This city has completed extensive preparations for the reception and entertainment of the delegates of the largest and most important convention that ever visited the resort. It is the annual gathering of the American Medical Association. The advance guard has already made its appearance, and several hundred delegates have taken up their headquarters at the various beach front hotels.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 5. -- Enraged becaused the authorities stopped the widely advertised bullfight, which was to take place to-day and they could not get their money back, a mob of nearly 7,000 persons stormed the grand stand, demolishing every bit of furniture; tried hard to lynch the manager.

FITCHBURG, Mass., June 5. -- Suit has been instituted by Anna L. Ayer of Washington, D.C., against Edith L. Weeks of Cambridge to recover from the estate of C.L. Weeks, who committed suicide Sept. 26, 1893, and that of Mrs. Rebecca L. Weeks, his widow.

MEXICO CITY, June 5. -- Jose Y. Limantour, Minister of Finance and Commerce, has published a letter declining the Vice Presidential candidacy. He gives as his reason a conviction that his aptitude does not lie along political lines. He is willing to continue serving his country in an administrative capacity as long as his services are considered useful.
MALAGA, June 5. -- The Spanish battleships Pelayo and Numancia and the armored cruiser Cardenal Cisneros have left here for Tangier.

ELMIRA, N.J., June 5. -- There were numerous washouts and landslides on the Northern Central Railroad between Elmira and Williamsport, Penn., last night, and the whole division has been tied up for the past twenty-four hours. The washouts between Gillets and Troy, Penn., were the worst. Two of these were 10 feet deep and 40 feet long.

WHEELING, West Va., June 5. -- The strike of miners in the Fifth Sub-District of Ohio was declared off this afternoon after a conference between the miners and operators, and to-morrow morning about 8,000 men will return to work.

PARIS, June 6. -- The billiard match between Schaefer and Cure for 3,000 points, eighteen-inch balk line, two shots in, began to-night. The score was: Schaefer, 500: Cure, 407. Schaefer made two runs of 127 each.

Officers of the Treasury Department are beginning to feel some anxiety as to the security for the Government loan of $4,500,000 in aid of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, and are beginning to speculate as to whether it may not soon become necessary for the Government to step in and run the show, in a sense as a receiver, until it is recouped.

DENVER, June 6. -- The infernal machine with which the murders at Independence Station were committed consisted of a quantity of dynamite, probably 300 pounds; a loaded revolver, and a long, fine steel wire attached to the trigger. The revolver was fastened so that the pulling of the trigger would not draw it away.

Mr. Cassenove G. Lee of Washington, recognized authority on civil war statistics, has prepared an interesting table showing the enormous numerical superiority of the Northern army over that of the South during the civil war. Mr. Lee's figures show that the total enlistments in the Northern army were 2,778,304, as against 600,000 in the Confederate Army.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 6. -- The very erratic pitching of Hughes and the inability of the New Yorks to hit Bernhardt at opportune moments gave Cleveland a rather easy victory in the first game of the series to-day.

It is not surprising that the stories of suspicious feeling in Madrid as to the action of the United States in Morocco should turn out to be fictions and that the Spanish Government should be reported to be ready to co-operate heartily with our own in any measures necessary to the protection of foreigners in that country.

District Attorney Jerome plunged into the Hannah Elias case with energy when he returned to New York yesterday from Lakeville, Conn., and his activity will, it is expected, result in some action to-day in the case of the woman who is accused by John R. Platt of having got from him almost $700,000.

Trading in New York, Ontario and Western practically monopolized the stock market yesterday, and Wall Street was filled with rumors to account for the unwonted activity and strength of a stock that until very recently was even duller than the rest of the market.

LONDON, June 7. -- Fashionable London last evening made a very unusual pilgrimage to the suburb of Camden Town, where Mrs. Patrick Campbell presented in the local theatre a new play, "Warp and Woof," written by the wife of the Colonial Secretary, the Hon. Alfred Lyttelton.
In THE TIMES of May 26 last appears a communication, signed Wallace Wood, and entitled, "Did Morse Invent the Telegraph?"

Two young Italian brothers, but a short time in the country and new to American ways, who have been engaged as caretakers of the vacant house 227 East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, attacked a party of school boys yesterday afternoon, stabbing them with a sharpened file and scissors and striking them with a club.
AT SEA ON BOARD THE TIMES'S STEAMSHIP HAIMUN, June 6. -- Trustworthy news from the Port Arthur front is limited at present.

William Astor Chanler has secured control of what is generally known as the most valuable block of real estate in the Bronx -- that bounded by Third, Bergen, and Westchester Avenues and One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street -- and some important improvement of the property may be expected in the near future.

Over a month ago it was published in the daily papers that the city was to have a new system of pipes for the supply of salt water for the use of the Fire Department, and the total expense for the construction of the same was figured at about $49,000,000. That is a costly plan and a questionable one at that.
A man who had both jaws shot away had trouble eating ordinary food, but found a food-drink that supplies the nutriment needed.

Local automobilists, who have so long and earnestly sought an automobile speedway, where they could drive their machines at speed without fear of danger to other road users or of arrest for infraction of speed laws or ordinances, and where speed trials, races, and other contests could be held under renditions at least approximating those enjoyed by motorists abroad, are at last to attain their desire.

Superior team work, aided by brilliant riding and accurate hitting by Rene La Montagne, Jr., and Daniel Chauncey, Jr., gave the Rockaway polo team the victory yesterday over the Country Club of Westchester on the latter's polo field. The match was the second and last in the club tournament for the Country Club cups. Rockaway won by 10 3/4 goals to 8 1/2 for Westchester.
LIAO-YANG, June 6. -- Nemirovich-Danchenko, a war correspondent in the service of The Associated Press, has sent from the front an account of the battle of Kin-Chow, in which he says:

Had it not been for the relief in the way of activity offered by New York, Ontario and Western yesterday's stock market would have been as little entitled to a place of distinction as the market of any recent day. Of the day's total of 234,134 shares, all but about 100,000 shares represented the trading in Ontario and Western.

WASHINGTON, June 6. -- Recently Secretary Shaw sent a communication to President Francis of the St. Louis Exposition suggesting the importance of persistent exploitation of the Exposition to the end that the admission fees might be increased to the highest possible point.

That horse stealing is prevalent in Manhattan and a special menace to butchers and to grocers was brought out at a meeting of the New York Retail Butchers' Association held last night in Terrace Garden.

Following up the declaration made by Charles F. Murphy to the effect that police policy and not politics caused the break between Tammany Hall and Senator McCarren in Brooklyn, Police Commissioner McAdoo yesterday issued a statement in which he made it plain that he agreed with the Murphy statement of conditions.

BERLIN, June 6. -- Col. Gadke, telegraphing from Russian headquarters at Mukden, reports that both the Japanese and Russians are showing unmistakable signs of activity, which seem to point to important developments in the near future.
LIAO-YANG, June 6. -- Details have been received here of two smart outpost fights, one on the Liao-Tung peninsula and the other in Southern Manchuria.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 6. -- The first candidate to pass his physical examination at the Naval Academy this morning was C.W. Adair of Xenia, Ohio, a strict vegetarian. He has not eaten a particle of animal food to his knowledge for over two years.

Nan Patterson, the actress, who was arrested in connection with the mysterious shooting of "Caesar" Young, the bookmaker, while riding down West Broadway in a hansom cab on Saturday morning, remained a prisoner in the Tombs last night, despite efforts to have her released on bail.

HOUSTON, June 6. -- W.T. Eldridge, Vice President and General Manager of the Cane Belt Railroad, was shot twice this evening at Eagle Lake while entering his office quarters. One bullet pierced his breast, passing through the left lung, the other shattered a hand. The shots were fired from ambush and the would-be assassin leaped from cover and made his escape.

When the members of the Cotton Exchange came down to business yesterday morning they were surprised to hear that Frank Hayne, the New Orleans operator who had arrived in this city some weeks ago with the reported object of conducting a corner in the July option had returned to the Crescent City.

DENVER, Col., June 6. -- The State Supreme Court to-day, Justice Steele dissenting, refused the application for a writ of habeas corpus made by counsel for Charles H. Moyer, President of the Western Federation of Miners. Moyer is held as a military prisoner at Telluride by order of Gov. James H. Peabody.
WASHINGTON, June 6. -- The following cablegram was received at the State Department to-day from Consul General Gummere, dated Tangier, June 6:

It was in the third week of last August that Colorado began to be stirred by the miners' strike that since has caused unnumbered murders, riots, court controversies, and crimes of various degrees. Demanding a rise of wages and an eighthour day, the miners made complaints first against their employers and later against the State authorities, who they declared were Anarchists for establishing military rule and practically driving most of the strikers from the State.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 6. -- Frederick F. Proctor, the theatrical manager, is nursing a broken ankle in the Colonia Golf Club at Rahway as the result of an accident which he sustained while riding in his automobile with his wife. It was a disastrous end to a honeymoon trip on which Mr. and Mrs. Proctor had been since Thursday.

The Right Rev. Mgr. Michael Joseph Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the diocese, yesterday celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary, the silver jubilee, of his ordination to the priesthood.

ROSELLE, N.J., June 6. -- Joseph M. Pouch murdered three of his children, and, after wounding a fourth, killed himself this evening in his cottage near the station of the Central Railroad of New Jersey.
The unchecked spread of consumption prompts me to offer a suggestion, which, if adopted, could not but result in great benefit to the health of the community.

NEWPORT, R.L., June 6. -- The final tests in the submarine trials which have been conducted for a week past by the trial board of the Navy Department were begun to-night, when the Holland type submarine torpedo boat Fulton was taken to a point between Point Judith and Narragansett Pier and at 8:30 o'clock sunk to the bottom of the bay, where, unless plans miscarry, she will remain for twelve hours.

LONDON, June 7. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that in consequence of the transfer of all the money the Russian Government can lay its hands on to the war chest the Government will find itself compelled to stop work on the various railways now in course of construction and to postpone the starting of the new lines which had been finally decided upon.

DENVER, Col., June 6. -- A reign of terror, brought on by a dynamiting plot, followed by rioting and an assault on the militia, exists in the Cripple Creek mining region to-night. Armed men throng the streets and conflicts are of hourly occurrence. Militiamen are marching hither and thither, making arrests by wholesale.

The Russian Ministry of Public Instruction has issued a circular to the Directors of secondary schools throughout the empire giving the official Russian theory of the origin and merits of the present war, which theory is to be inculcated upon the pupils in the schools. The circular recites that the eastward expansion of Russia has been carried on with singular regard for the people whose territory has been annexed.

It is not easy for any one interested in National politics to regard seriously the apparently fierce contest waging between Senator McCARREN and Mr. MURPHY, except as a discreditable and unfortunate incident in the National campaign. It is a quarrel that cannot but have a bad effect on the prestige of the Democratic organization of the State in the National Convention.
' Jimmy" Callahan still plays second base for the Chicago Americans, but by his request has been relieved of the management of the team and the, plee given to lielder Jones.

Col. W.H. Storey, who has charge of the Custom House seizure room, was sealed at his desk yesterday afternoon when a strange-looking individual entered the office stealthily, closed the door behind him, placed his forefinger on his lips, and finally deposited himself in a chair.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 6. -- In a speech before the Roosevelt Workingmen's Club this evening Secretary Shaw said in part:

VICTOR, Col., June 6. -- Armed conflict between the union miners and the State troops has come at last in Colorado. Bitter feeling growing out of the great mining strike resulted to-day in a fight in which a squad of militiamen stormed the Miners' Union Hall at this place and wounded at least twenty men.

The project of Sir ROBERT HART for a reorganization of the Chinese Empire is received in England with an amazement bordering on stupefaction. At any time before the war between China and Japan, perhaps at any time before the Boxer uprising and its sequel in 1900, any plan emanating from the veteran Inspector General of Chinese Customs would have been received with confidence, at least until it had been examined.
The Manufacturers' Club of Philadelphia is reported, apparently by authority, to be about to enter openly on a campaign for the election of Mr. ROOSEVELT to the Presidency.

Favorites and "good things" monopolized the purses and stakes at the Gravesend race course yesterday, and results were so much in favor of backers and so strongly against the layers, that the heat in the betting ring seemed to justify the report made by a waggish "regular," that the thermometer in the betting inclosure had "busted."

PARIS, June 6. -- In consequence of differences between the Duke and Duchess of Valencay, steps have been taken to dissolve the marriage. The Duchess was Helen Morton, a daughter of Levi P. Morton of New York.

The National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers was formally organized yesterday at the Manhattan Hotel. The membership roll was signed by forty-four of the leading manufacturers in these lines from all parts of the country. The charter of tile association, under the laws of the State of New York was receiver, and the constitution and by-laws were adopted.

Punishment was meted out yesterday in the Magistrates courts to the young roughs who had the ill-judgment to pelt with missiles Police Inspector Schmittberger, Mrs. Schmittberger, Detectives Lemon and Simmerlein of his staff, and Roundsman Himmel, who toured the east side Sunday in a red auto and in regulation attire, for the express purpose of catching such persons as recently attacked Mrs. William C. Gotshall and Col. Albert Hilton.
Toodlums, before he entered the contest, was a spotlessly white lapdog. His mistress, who was also attired in spotless white, had been giving him an airing yesterday afternoon.

At the meeting of the Columbia University Trustees yesterday, President Butler announced that the Marcus Daly scholarship of $1,000 had been founded by Mrs. James W. Gerard, wife of J.W. Gerard, Class of 1890, and daughter of Marcus Daly, the Montana mine owner. The $1,000 will go to a student who has worked in the mines, or is a descendant of a Montana miner.

The New York team gave an exhibition of hard and effective batting yesterday in a game with the Pittsburgs at the Polo Grounds that is seldom witnessed in this city. Every man of the team, excepting McGann and Bowerman, hit safely for one or more bases. Home runs were made by Gilbert and Bresnahan, Mertes scored a three-baser, and two-base hits were tallied by Mertes, Gilbert, and Browne, the latter having two to his credit.

The Interclub Tennis League, composed of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Ardsley Club, the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club, the Apawamis Golf Club, the Country Club of Westchester, the Great Neck Lawn Tennis Club, and the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, has perfected its arrangements for the season and the indications point to a series of interesting competitions on the courts.
PARIS, June 6. -- The rumors current in Madrid that the European powers have exchanged notes relative to restricting American operations in Morocco are discredited by the Foreign Office.

Becoming somewhat impatient at having been left out of the Democratic councils and conferences of late, the radical wing of the party, which flocked around William Jennings Bryan in the last two Presidential campaigns, has decided to hold a State Convention of its own in order to send a protesting delegation to St. Louis against the nomination of Judge Alton B. Parker for President.

TRENTON, N.J., June 6. -- Counsel for E. H. Harriman and Winslow S. Pierce to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court a second amended bill in the suit brought by them to restrain the carrying out of the proposed pro rata plan of distribution of the assets of the Northern Securities Company.

Business upon the Stock Exchange yesterday developed nothing of general interest. There was some increase of activity, but the price movement was fractional and irregular except for two specialties. Ontario and Western was strong, and Chicago Great Western descriptions were weak upon unusually large transactions.

NEW HAVEN, June 6. -- A lecture was delivered to-day by James W. Alexander, President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, before the students of the Yale University course of insurance. Mr. Alexander's subject was "The Hazard of Inexperience."

The story of how Matthew Clune, at one time manager of John L. Sullivan, parted with his diamond stud, was told yesterday in the Supreme Court by witnesses at the trial of the action brought against Clune by Harry O'Grady, who asked $25,000 damages for false arrest. O'Grady was employed as a bellboy in the Vanderbilt Hotel, which is owned by Clune, and acted as his employer's valet.

Louis Lese has sold the plot, 200 by 99.11, on the north side of One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street 205 feet west of Fifth Avenue, to Ignatz Roth, who has resold the property to Ravitsch Brothers for improvement with six-story flats.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 7. -- Crowded galleries listened to Finance Minister Fielding's budget speech in the Commons today. The Minister spoke of the prosperity of the country, which, he said, was far more marked in Canada, where a moderate tariff existed, than in the United States, where there was a high tariff.

Now that the Supreme Court has decided that it is constitutional to exclude John Turner from this country as a theoretical Anarchist, in order to be quite logical Congress should enact a law expelling from the country native born citizens who hold Anarchistic opinions.
Ten shares of Bank of Commerce sold on the Stock Exchange yesterday at 209.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 7. -- The schoolship St. Marys, which has been anchored off New London for the past ten days, set sail to-day for her annual cruise to European ports.

VICTOR, Col., June 7. -- Fifteen deaths have resulted from the dynamite outrage at Independence, and several of the injured are in a critical condition. It is believed that the bodies of several other men were blown to atoms. Two men were killed and eight wounded in the subsequent rioting here.

After a voyage of twenty-four days from Singapore a male ourang-outang, said to be the largest of its species ever brought to America, reached here yesterday aboard the tramp steamship Hong Wan I., a vessel owned by a British company engaged in the China trade. The beast has no name, and never had one, according to Capt. J. Slaker of the steamship.

In your paper of this date I find announced with the usual news item brevity the killing of "a Japanese athlete" at Luna Park. It seems that the poor fellow, "missing his tip" or losing his balance in some other way, fell to his death. Following that is the story of the probably fatal injury of a seven-year-old girl by falling off a toboggan slide.
ALBANY, June 7. -- The Court of Appeals has under consideration the question whether college fraternity chapter houses should be exempt from taxation under Subdivision 7 of Section 4 of the tax law.

DENVER, Col., June 7. -- A local attorney has filed in the District Court a suit for divorce brought by Lawrence C. Phipps against Genevieve Chandler Phipps. The lawyer obtained an order from the court to seal the complaint in an envelope and have it placed in a vault.

The correspondent "Looker On," whose fetter appeared in your issue claims to have "studied somewhat the subway problem,'' but his study must have been to very little purpose if he finds himself in a position gravely to ask foolish questions concerning a subject of which the most superficial knowledge would have supplied the answer.

Much excitement was caused at the Pennsylvania Railroad Station in Jersey City yesterday by what was presumed to be a kidnapping case. Four well-dressed women and three men alighted from the Asbury Park train and were proceeding to the Jersey City exit when one of the women began to scream.
