WASHINGTON, June 7. -- A report, dated April 20, has been received here from United States Consul General Mason at Berlin, treating of the recent high speed steam locomotive tests in Germany following the elaborate experiments in high speed electrical traction.

NEW ROCHELLE, June 7. -- On account of the serious illness of Mrs. Young, wife of the dead bookmaker, she was unable this morning to accompany the body of her husband to Kensico Cemetery, where it was placed in a receiving vault. It is said that the remains will be taken to England for burial.
PARIS, June 7. -- W.K. Vanderbilt's Sylphe III. won the Prix St. Germain today, and his Azur came in second in the race for the Prix Chatou at the Long-champs races.

THE TIMES of Saturday commenting on the matter of food supplies for Port Arthur, places the Russian base of supply at a distance of 6,000 miles from Port Arthur! Will THE TIMES kindly locate that source? Where is it? At St. Petersburg? Why not at Kazan, a thousand miles nearer Port Arthur, or at Tobolsk, 2,000, or at Irkootsk, between 3,000 and 4,000?

The hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the first institution for higher education established in the Province of New York could not fail to be an interesting event. Columbia is not only the oldest college in New York. It is outranked in seniority throughout the Union only by Harvard, William and Mary, Yale, Pennsylvania, Princeton, and (under another name) Washington and Lee, and in that order.

LONDON, June 8. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say the Novoe Vremya publishes an editorial article in which, on the strength of a telegram from Viceroy Alexieff, it charges the Japanese with sowing mines in the open seas, and remarks that it is not improbable that the Hatsuse was destroyed by a mine set afloat by the Japanese.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., June 7. -- Apart from a few small fights in connection with the rounding up and arresting of union miners, no outbreak has occurred in this district to-day. Two local militia companies and a small army of armed deputies under Sheriff Edward Bell are in full control of the camp. Though there has been no turbulence to-day, there is an undercurrent of feeling which bodes ill.

Seven hundred members of the Hotel Men's Mutual Benefit Association gathered yesterday morning at the Hotel Manhattan for the twenty-fifth annual convention of the organization. Most of the delegates were above weight -- jolly, big fellows, who loved to tell a story and laugh at one another while they were busy saving their collars from wilting by the constant application of handkerchiefs.
DENVER, June 7. -- Nearly 500 troops are mobilized at Colorado Springs and neighboring towns and can be rushed to the Cripple Creek district on short notice.
Permit me to call your attention to a few deficiencies in the New York Public Library in the hope by giving them publicity a way will be paved for their removal.

Mrs. MARY H. HUNT, a lady whose name we recall as somewhat prominently connected with the work of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, announces a rather startling conclusion as to the disqualification of moderate drinkers to hold or express any opinions on the subject of alcoholic beverages. She is quoted by The Hudson Register as saying:

In a decision written by Judge Byron S. Waite the board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Conrow Brothers of New York against the assessment of 5 cents a pound as dressed poultry on pigeons. The birds were caught in a wild state, in nets, in Italy, shipped alive to England, and there killed and dressed and shipped in cold storage to this city.
LONDON, June 8. -- Ernest Brindle, The Daily Mail's correspondent in Manchuria, in an account of the death of Lewiz Etzel, says:

ALBANY, June 8. -- Myles McDonnell of Boston, formerly of New York, where he was well known as a gambler, was shot dead in the drill room of the Ten Eyck about 1 o'clock this morning by Richard E. Preusser of the stock brokerage firm of Preusser Co., whose place of business is at the corner of State Street and Broadway.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 7. -- The steamer General, which runs between Wickford and Newport, was run into by the ferryboat Conanicut just outside of Newport Harbor during a dense fog to-night.

Friends of the Port Chester Railroad, and all members of the Merchants' Association at that, were taken into the Sullivan-Westchester camp yesterday afternoon. These erstwhile advocates of the Port Chester franchise, H.D. Dumont and S.C. Mead, of the Merchants' Association, made the pilgrimage to City Hall to see Alderman Sullivan and to ascertain why no action had yet been taken by the Railroad Committee on their pet measure.
PARIS, June 7. -- A St. Petersburg dispatch quotes a general officer of the Russian Army as follows:

With Mrs. Fiske at its head, a permanent stock company will make its headquarters in the Manhattan Theatre next season. This organization, for which Harrison Grey Fiske has been making plans for some time will give, among other high-class plays. "Becky Sharp," in which Mrs. Fiske was seen years ago; "Monna Vanna," a revival of "Hedda Gabler," and "Rosmersholm."
ST. PETERSBURG, June 8. -- The Government, it is authoritatively said to-night, has no mere information than the public of happenings in the neighborhood of Port Arthur.

Through the action taken yesterday in the Surrogates' Court by the relatives of Mary J. Winthrop the Theological Seminary of the Presbyterian Church at Princeton, N.J., is deprived, at least for the present, of a legacy of more than $2,000,000 which Mrs. Winthrop left to the institution.

Armed with a warrant charging Hannah Elias with criminal extortion, four Detective Sergeants from Police Headquarters broke into her home at 236 Central Park West at 11:35 o'clock last night and placed her under arrest.
CHE-FOO, June 7. -- Preceding a sea attack on Port Arthur last night, the Japanese apparently made a determined effort to advance on that stronghold by land.

In the best race of his career, Major Daingerfield, champion three-year-old of 1902, was returned winner of the Standard Stakes at the Gravesend course yesterday, when, in hand at the end, he galloped home before Africander and Hermis, beating them in the most positive style at even weights.

Following the meeting of the Racing Board of the American Automobile Association at the headquarters, 753 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, it was announced that the Vanderbilt Cup race will be held on Oct. 8, and the event will be open to teams from any automobile club recognized by either the American Automobile Association or the Touring Club of France, which practically opens the race to the world.

NEWARK, June 7. -- Testimony was taken to-day by Vice Chancellor Stevens on the application made last week by Elvin W. Crane, counsel for Patrick Kelly of Summit, for an order opening a decree of foreclosure granted by the Union County Court and to permit Mr. Kelly to enter his defense to the foreclosure proceedings instituted by William R. Alling.

There was another clash yesterday between the elevated railroad company and Patrick Gallagher, the contractor who is building a public comfort station in Chatham Square, and a consequence was the appearance of Gallagher before Magistrate Ommen in the Centre Street Police Court.
LIAO-YANG, June 7. -- The Japanese have drawn in their advance guards from Vafangow. They blew up part of the railway and the telegraph station on the night of June 3. The damage was soon repaired.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- The Board of Stewards of the Western Jockey Club has restored to good standing the following persons and horses: Ralph Worthington, jockey, (suspended Louisville, May, 1903;) C.J. McIntyre, jockey, (denied privileges, St. Louis;) Alzora, property of W.F. Walter, (Turf Congress tracks:) Scorpolette, property of W.H. Plourd, (Turf Congress tracks.) Applications for the reinstatement of the horses Brown Vall, King Barleycorn, Versifier, Anglesea, and Gloria Mundi were denied.
LA CROSSE, Wis., June 7. -- Mrs. Mary Asseline, who was married five weeks ago to William Asseline of French Island, died at her home at West La Crosse to-day, a victim of a charivari party.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 7. -- The submarine torpedo boat Fulton, which was sunk to the bottom of the ocean last evening for a test, remained there over twelve hours, coming up at 11:10 A.M. to-day.
The necessity for reforms of greater evils that the proposed "end seat" ordinance is intended to effect must appeal to any person who uses the surface and elevated cars in Greater New York.

Your correspondent signing herself an "English Churchwoman" refers to the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States as the "Anglican" or "English" Church. The Episcopal Church in this country is no more the English Church than the House of Representatives sitting at Washington is the British House of Commons or a branch of that legislative body.

PARIS, June 7. -- I can state with every confidence that the approaching meeting between King Edward and Emperor William at Kiel inspires nobody here with the faintest anxiety. In official circles it comes almost as a relief to the slight feeling of concern caused by certain recent manifestations, such as the toast at Naples emphasizing the Triple Alliance and the speeches of the Kaiser on his return from Italy.

CHICAGO, June 7. -- After securing her wedding outfit by having the goods charged to many men of wealth, Rose Reifers, eighteen years old, was arrested to-day while passing herself off as a daughter of Theodore A. Kochs. She had ordered jewelry to the value of $350, charged to Mr. Kochs's account.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 7. -- All the Columbia crews were on the water to-day, and as the weather was considerably cooler than yesterday they were given a hard work-out. The sky was cloudy, but the water was smooth, and on the whole conditions were excellent for hard work.

Police reserves had to be called out from every station in the Bronx yesterday afternoon to prevent a demonstration of 300 striking freight handlers of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and their sympathizers.

ST. LOUIS, June 7. -- In a letter received by the Exposition Company to-day, Leslie M. Shaw, Secretary of the Treasury, gave formal notification that if payments on the $4,600,000 Government loan are not promptly forthcoming when due, he, as the guardian of the United States Treasury, will take charge of the receipts and collection of fair tickets.

If the workmen of the country can be persuaded to take Mr. SHAW'S assumption as true they may possibly find his conclusion true also. The assumption of the Secretary of the Treasury is that when the Republican Party in power "universal and constant employment at reasonable wages" is secure.

A judgment by default for $5,678 was entered in the United States District Court yesterday against Mrs. Nellie Bostwick Cary of 801 Fifth Avenue in favor of the Lichtenstein Millinery Company of 538 Fifth Avenue for millinery and furs sold to Mrs. Cary between Sept. 21 and Dec. 17 of last year.

Because of the absence of a policeman from his post, the delay of an ambulance in answering an emergency call, and the refusal of the ambulance driver to aid the surgeon in finding the necessary bandages, a seriously injured man suffered without relief for more than half an hour after falling two stories down an elevator shaft in the building at 1 to 5 Bond Street yesterday morning.

Chicago regained the lead in the National League yesterday by defeating Brooklyn, while New York's reverse at the hands of Pittsburg compelled McGraw's men to drop into second place, and Boston's victory over Cincinnati put the old leaders in third position. In the American League rain prevented the Greater New Turks and Clevelands from playing more than three and a half innings, but all the rest of the games scheduled were decided.

DOVER, Del., June 7. -- Contrary to the expressed wish of Judge George Gray, the Delaware Democratic State Convention by a unanimous vote to-night instructed its delegates to the St. Louis Convention to present the name of Judge Gray to the convention as the choice of the Delaware Democrats for President and to work for his nomination.

A judgment by default for $5,678 was entered in the United States District Court yesterday against Mrs. Nellie Bostwick Cary of 801 Fifth Avenue in favor of the Lichtenstein Millinery Company of 538 Fifth Avenue for millinery and furs sold to Mrs. Cary between Sept. 21 and Dec. 17 of last year.

Her premonition that something was wrong in her apartments in Le Marquis Hotel, at 12 East Thirty-first Street, while she was attending the Duss concert, in Madison Square Garden, with her husband last evening, led to the discovery by Mrs. Halsey Corwin of the theft of $50,000 worth of her diamonds and jewelry.

Monday's market was evidently a miscue. Ontario and Western was both less active and strong yesterday than in the previous day's session, but the general market increased somewhat in activity and decidedly in tone. Ontario and Western lost a half on the day's business, which was much smaller than Monday's, but the general list averaged more than that much higher, with conspicuous cases of improvement in no way related except speculatively to Ontario.

According to the early and tentative estimates of the city officials, the tax rate for this year in the various boroughs will be between ten and twelve points higher than last. Controller Grout reported to the Board of Aldermen yesterday an estimate of the miscellaneous receipts of the city during the fiscal year of 1904, and this general fund is estimated to reach $22,521,663.21.

In your issue of to-day's date you have an article impugning the fair play and sportsmanlike spirit of the Englishman. Of all people in the world the American is not only lacking in all the attributes of sportsmanlike spirit, but he possesses every qualification inimical to the enjoyment and welfare of pure sport.

Mayor McCLELLAN has courteously referred to the Board of Aldermen the question whether an extra session of the Legislature may advantageously be requested for the repeal of the Smith bill exempting Dutchess County from the operation of the general act authorizing municipalities to condemn water rights where they are found and when they are needed for the water supply of cities.

Steps will be taken to-day by the District Attorney's office to cause the indictment of Nan Patterson, the actress, who has been a prisoner in the Tombs since the mysterious shooting in a hansom cab last Saturday of "Caesar" Young, the bookmaker.

LIAO-YANG, June 8. -- An entire absence of personal feeling against the Japanese is noted here. This may be due to a feeling of superiority over the foe, for there is no doubt the Russians here are entirely confident of final victory.
ST. LOUIS Mo., June 8. -- A local newspaper this evening says:

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Friends of Bourke Cockran have to-day made use of his presence in Washington to give currency to a report that he came here to protest to the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee against the decisions of the committee not to circulate his famous speech in the last days of the recent session as a campaign document.

The announcement that 120 candidates from the United States have passed the Oxford examinations for the Rhodes scholarships is almost as surprising as it is gratifying. It is surprising in view of the fact that English classical scholarship, at least, if not much more widely diffused than American, is conducted on special lines, upon which presumably the examinations have also proceeded.

As intimately related to the subject discussed at some length in these columns in our issue of yesterday, the pushcart and peddler evil, we invite the attention of the Mayor to the conspicuous propriety and advantage of restricting by the discreet use of his veto power the self-conferred right of the Board of Aldermen to grant by resolution permits for stands within the stoop line for the sale of "fruits or soda water, or both."

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Up to midnight no request had been received by the President for Federal troops at Victor to quell the lawlessness of the miners. The President will not intervene unasked, unless the conflict should take a turn which would impede the United States mails, a contingency which it will be remembered President Cleveland had to deal with during the Chicago riots in the Gubernatorial term of the late John P. Altgeld.
NIU-CHWANG, June 8. -- The funeral of Lewis Etzel, correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph, will take place here this afternoon.

Hannah Elias, the negro woman upon whom John R. Platt declares he squandered almost $700,000, is the occupant of a cell in the second trier of the woman's department of the Tombs. The tier is known as "Coon Row," and is devoted to prisoners of her sex and color.

The "Svampa incident" is attracting much attention in Italy, and indeed all over Europe. The King of Italy happening to be in Bologna, Cardinal SVAMPA, the Archbishop, paid him an official visit, and, among other attentions, caused the "Royal March," the Italian national air, to be performed in his honor.

Both of the Western rivals of New York for the leadership in the National League were defeated yesterday, while the Polo Ground's representatives were successful over Pittsburg and again went to the front. To-day's game will wind up the series between New York and the champions, and then Chicago will play three games with the local team.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 8. -- The masterly pitching of "Jack" Powell and the bunching of hits by the New Yorks in the second inning gave the visiting team a victory to-day and broke the winning streak of Donahue, who blanked the visitors after the second inning.

Columbia celebrated her one hundred and fiftieth annual commencement yesterday in the university gymnasium. Six honorary degrees and nearly 1,000 degrees in course were granted. About 4,000 people gained admission to the building, while nearly as many more were turned away.

A single surprise was produced in the six races at the Gravesend track yesterday, and even when that unexpected happening broke through the expectations of the form followers the post favorite was so close that bookmakers shuddered in apprehension before the numbers announcing the order of the finish was displayed.

In asking for an appropriation with which to provide facilities for cheap surf bathing at Coney Island, the President of Brooklyn Borough, whether intentionally or unintentionally makes little difference, has called to what ought to be the city's deeply regretful attention one of the greatest among its many sins of omission.

Play was continued in the Metropolitan lawn tennis championship tournament yesterday on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club, One Hundred and Seventeenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In the singles L.E. Mahan and Robert Le Roy, the two Columbia University men, advanced to the competitions for the semi-final round.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 8. -- Commencement exercises at Vassar were held to-day in the new chapel in the presence of a large number of students and their friends. This was the largest class ever graduated from Vassar, numbering 176.

The number of those who were willing to give the market some credit for genuine strength and to hear predictions of higher prices without some expression of contempt were more numerous yesterday than they have been on any day of late. Some even were found who expected a ten-point advance in the whole list.

The discussion regarding corporal punishment of children now going on in your paper is especially interesting to a Russian, a "semi-barbarian," and as such I hope I will be permitted to add my mite to this pertinent subject.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Speaker Joseph G. Cannon arrived last night from Illinois and to-day gave the President an account of the proceedings of the Springfield Convention over which he presided.

The police of the King's Bridge Police Station are looking for a ghost which Hilda Semdorf, a Finnish servant girl in the employ of the Rev. Joseph M. Hodson of 520 King's Bridge Road. says robbed her of $149 Monday night. Hilda, who has been in this country only a short time, talks poor English and is very superstitious. She says the earth is infested with ghosts of various kinds and shapes.

CHEFOO, June 9, (Thursday.) -- The Chinese, both merchants and coolies, are leaving Port Arthur with the permission of the Russian authorities. Fifty junks which left Port Arthur yesterday with Chinese passengers are now arriving here.

You say in to-day's issue of your paper. "To-day's outburst had its inception in the strike of the members of the Western Federation of Miners when, more than a year ago, 4,000 men quit work to secure an eight-hour day." This is true, but not the whole truth. The facts are as follows:

Developments yesterday in the case of Nan Patterson, the actress held without bail in connection with the death of "Caesar" Young, the wealthy bookmaker and owner of race horses, indicated that the mysterious shooting in the hansom cab was approaching a solution. When the case of the Patterson girl goes before the Grand Jury, probably to-day, two witnesses whose names have not yet appeared in connection with the affair will testify before that body.
HAMMONTON, N.J., June 8. -- Three men made a daring attempt between 2 and 3 o'clock this morning to rob the local Post Office. That they did not succeed was due to Night Marshal John W. Myer.
Said (P) Shaw, Secretary of the United States moneybags, to a Roosevelt workingman's club: "May the good Lord deliver us from another period when living expenses are cheap."
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 8. -- At the commencement exercises of Union College to-day Bishop William Croswell Doane of Albany made an address, in which he said:
LONDON, June 9. -- A dispatch to Reuter's Telegram Company from St. Petersburg transmits the following from Liao-Yang:

CHICAGO, June 8. -- Chicago clubwomen to-day challenged Dr. A. Lathrone Smith of Bishop's College, Montreal, to prove his assertion made before the American Medical Association that higher education unfits girls for wifehood and motherhood.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 8. -- Nothing is know here of the various rumors to the effect that Port Arthur has fallen, but it is not considered possible at this time.

BOSTON, June 8. -- The Directors of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad have the right to change the rate of interest on $4,992,000 bonds, according to a decision by Judge Lathrop of the Supreme Court to-day.

In to-day's Issue of L'Araldo Italiano commemorating the tenth anniversary of the foundation of the Italian newspaper, Ernesto Biondi, the Italian sculptor, whose bronze group, "Saturnalia," was classed as immoral by the Trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, contributes a long article on "American Sculptors and Painters."

CINCINNATI, June 8. -- This was a bad day for favorites at Latonia and in each one of the six events public choices went down to defeat. The feature of the day was the mile and a sixteenth handicap, which was won by Handmore at odds of 8 to 1. Sir Gallant was coupled with Handmore and finished second, Ed Tierney, second choice, finished last.

One of the prettiest of the June weddings of this season took place yesterday at St. Luke's Church, Matteawan. The bride was Miss Helen Van Cortlandt Le Roy Kent, only daughter of the late James Kent, and the bridegroom was Louis Allston Gillet of this city. The church was decorated with pink and white flowers and palms.

ST. LOUIS, June 8. -- As a sequel to the dramatic incidents of Sunday, when the bullfight was prevented and the arena of the Spanish bullfighters was destroyed, Don Manuel Cervera, Captain of the matadors, was killed to-day in a fight with Carleton Bass, a native of Ireland, who has the title of "The American Matador."

VICTOR, Col., June 8. -- Adjt. Gen. Sherman M. Bell and staff arrived here early to-day and immediately promulgated military rule in Teller County by posting on the door of the armory, where a large number of union men and sympathizers are imprisoned. Acting Gov. Warren A. Haggett's proclamation of martial law.
"Do you think we ought to take the Philippines?" Mr. Hennessy asked of Mr. Dooley some four years since. "I do," was the answer, "may the Divil fly away with 'em."

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., June 8. -- One union miner was killed and fourteen were captured in a battle with troops and deputies under Adjutant Gen. Bell this afternoon in the hills about a dozen miles south of Victor.

A blonde woman and her pug dog have been having fun for four days with conductors and inspectors on the Third Avenue and Mount Vernon division of the Union Railway Company. Encouraged by her success last Saturday in taking a ride from the Harlem to Mount Vernon with her dog, in spite of company rules, the woman tried it again on Sunday.

WINSTED, Conn., June 8. -- The large floating island in Lake Garfield, at Monterey, in the Berkshire Hills, through which men fish for bullheads in the daytime, and which last Summer took its first trip across the lake in twenty-five years, made another move yesterday.
BOSTON, June 8. -- It was announced here to-day that the entire property of the New England Brick Company will be sold at auction under foreclosure proceedings on July 6, at Cambridge.

David Cohen has bought from the Bernheimer estate fourteen lots on the north side of One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues. Some of the property has already been resold for improvement.

About 400 members of the National Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association gathered yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria for the annual convention of the organization. Practically every distiller and wholesale dealer of importance was represented. J. Walter Freiberg of Cincinnati presided.

There is considerable speculation among local yachtsmen as to whether the fifty-eighth annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club, to be held on the lower bay next Thursday, will attract enough entries to allow it to be held, or will have to be abandoned for lack of starters, as was the case last year.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 9, (Thursday.) -- By a vote of nearly three to one the Kentucky Democratic State Convention early this morning declined to consider a resolution to indorse Judge Alton B. Parker of New York for the Presidency.

DENVER, Col., June 8. -- The twenty-four deported union miners from the Cripple Creek district, exiled since the serious riots in that section, have arrived at Denver on a special train over the Denver and Rio Grande. In the rear of the car stood nine guards, armed with shotguns and army rifles, who had been deputized to conduct them to Denver from the gold camp.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- Assertions were freely made here to-night that great financial interests of Pennsylvania and New York had set out to remove Attorney General Philander C. Knox from the President's Cabinet by giving to him the Senatorial seat made vacant by the death of Senator Quay.
LONDON, June 9. -- The Times's military correspondent says:

Oscar Pomeroy Howe, a retired veteran school teacher and a soldier in the civil war, is dying at Roosevelt Hospital as the result of an attempt to kill himself by stabbing himself in the left side last evening at his home, 668 Eighth Avenue. Suffering from insomnia and general debility for a year, according to his wife, drove him to the deed.

BERLIN, June 8. -- The painful impression made by the scandalous failure of the Pommeranian Mortgage Bank was heightened by the knowledge that the Empress's charitable undertakings were partly financed through that institution. The exact relations of the bank to Baron von Mirbach, the Empress's agent in charitable matters, was not disclosed, however, until the trial of the bank's Directors, which began to-day.

What is the matter with the Italians it this country anyway? Your columns daily are filled with accounts of shootings and cuttings committed by them, and Magistrate Flammer, in the Harlem Court yesterday, upon the arraignment of two Italians who had been badly handled by a crowd after stabbing several boys, made the remark that they could not expect any better treatment.

When the Rapid Transit commissioners hold their regular meeting this afternoon an attempt will be made to set a definite date for the opening of the subway, and the contractors will be called upon to make an announcement as to when trains may be running over the line.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8. -- William McAlister, flagman at the Cumberland Street crossing of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway, gave his life to-day to save three girls from death beneath a fast train.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- District Attorney Beach went before Justice Gould of the District Supreme Court this afternoon and entered a nolle prosequi in the ease of Harrison J. Barrett, nephew of Judge Tyner, ex-Assistant Attorney General for the Post Office Department.

WASHINGTON, June 8. -- The Zoo wolf or dog case was remanded back to the District Supreme Court to-day for another trial. A year ago a girl living near the National Zoological Park was bitten by some animal which rushed into her mother's yard, dashed upon her, sank its fangs into her leg, and then ran off before the victim could fairly know what it was that attacked her.

All early indications point to the fact that 1904 will be a "bumper" mosquito year. Wherever mosquitos are usually found they now abound, and where they usually abound they would already be intolerable if it were not necessary that those who cannot escape them shall tolerate them.
An action has been begun in the Supreme Court by James Hebron, owner of a cab stand, against Frank Work, the horseman, for the recovery of $7,128.77, which Hebron says is due him in a stock deal.

Mrs. Emma Pryke, who is sixty years old was working in the Pryke's apartments on the third floor of the house at 134 West Fifteenth Street just before noon yesterday when two young men called. They said they had noticed a sign for rooms to let on the door and wanted a double room.

"The Hazard of Inexperience," the title chosen by Mr. JAMES W. ALEXANDER for his lecture before the students of the Yale University course of insurance, was happy, since it enabled him to traverse a wide range of discussion in showing the great interests to which inexperience constituted a special hazard in the "business," or the "cause," of insurance.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- American marines have landed in Africa. Admiral Chadwick this afternoon cabled the Navy Department from Tangier as follows:

There was an alarm turned in shortly after 1:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon from Box 428, at the northeast corner of Seventeenth Street and Broadway, by Chief Croker of the Fire Department, with the result that notwithstanding the many Broadway cars and the heavy traffic in the way of the first engine to respond, No. 14 was there within fifty-four seconds, all hitched to a standpipe ready for work.

The more cheerful temper of the market which was apparent in Tuesday's closing business was manifest during most of yesterday's trading. Only a few specialties failed to participate, and the enthusiasm more than made this good of carrying up several leading properties, against the effect of news scarcely stimulating.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., June 8. -- The destruction of camps in the Adirondack Mountains continues in the name of the State by the Forest Commission.

NEWARK, June 8. -- Miss Lyda Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Heller of 4 Bloomfield Road, and George Arthur Soden, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Soden, were married at the Continental Hotel to-night, and will leave New York City to-morrow morning in an automobile, bound for the St. Louis Exposition, on a honeymoon trip.
WASHINGTON, June 8. -- Chairman Cowherd of the Democratic Congressional Committee to-day said:

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 8. -- The missing Mary Virginia Rhodes, a beneficiary under the will of the late Cecil Rhodes, whose whereabouts has been a mystery for several years, has turned up in Asheville. She is now Mrs. Mary Virginia Rhodes Baker and is a missionary.

A journal of St. Petersburg devotes itself, with every appearance of gravity, to a rumor which seems to have been spontaneously generated in Europe. At least I have not heard it in this country. It is that the Government of the United States is considering the cession of the Philippines to Japan.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 9. -- Gen. Kuroski has assumed the offensive eastward. He was sent an overpoweringly strong column that has driven out the Russians from their fortified position at Sai-ma-Tse, twenty miles northwest of Feng-wang-Cheng, inflicting a loss of 100 men killed or wounded.

A portion of the route to St. Louis over which the automobilists will travel in their tour to the World's Fair during the latter part of July will be a section of the famous Cumberland turnpike, the first National highway in the United States and upon which over $7,000,000 was spent between the years 1806 and 1844.
Circuit Attorney POLK is making his canvass for the Governorship of Missouri on a platform which no citizen need have difficulty in understanding. This is it:

DENVER, June 9. -- The closing of the Portland mine at Victor by order of Adjt. Gen. Sherman M. Bell will probably be the means of reaching the Federal courts with a case to test the power of Gov. Peabody to vest in the military absolute power in the district declared to be under martial law.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 9. -- Senator Depew expressed optimistic views on the so-called depression now existing in the course of an address delivered to-day before the National Millers' Association. He said:
"What is the matter with the Italians in this country, anyway?" asks "An American" in THE TIMES of to-day.

With the check of the Morton Trust Company on the National Bank of Commerce for $1,000,000 working capital safely in their possession, the stockholders of the revivified Lake Superior Corporation, once the Consolidated Lake Superior Company, met yesterday at the offices of the company, 100 Broadway, and elected a Board of Directors, which later organized formally for business.

In your editorial on the growth and expansion of Columbia University you advance the point that comparatively few people take advantage of the courses offered by that institution. The reason for this is very clear to those who have "inside information." Columbia is not a truly American university; at least, it is not a democratic institution, a place for all classes alike. It has always been, and is to-day, the college of the aristocracy.
GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 9. -- In the four-mile row over the Thames River course early this evening the Harvard 'Varsity crew knocked off thirty seconds from the time of the best previous trial.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- The following report from United States Consul General Woman, dated at Munich, Germany, April 28, has been received here:

BAR HARBOR, Me., June 9. -- Levi Z. Leiter of Chicago died of heart disease early to-day at the Vanderbilt cottage here, which the Leiters had taken for the season. Mr. Leiter had not been well for a long time, but up to yesterday he was able to take his usual drive. A weakness of the heart developed shortly after midnight, and death occurred at 3:40 A.M.

Mrs. Julia H. Egan's will, which had been locked up for safe keeping in the Surrogate's office more than a year, was filed for probate yesterday, much to the surprise of the testatrix's husband, James Egan, the distiller, whose place of business is at 367 Seventh Avenue. Mr. Egan never knew that his wife had made a will until it was filed.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9. -- Attorney General Philander C. Knox of Pittsburg was selected to-day to fill the seat in the United States Senate made vacant by the death of Matthew Stanley Quay. He will accept, and serve by appointment of Gov. Pennypacker until March 4, the date of the date of the expiration of the late Senator's term.

Lawyers and lawmakers may be admonished to bear in mind that the severest critics upon the actual condition of the administration of justice are not the ignorant but suffering laity, whose opinions "the profession" can afford to disregard, or thinks it can. They are the men practically concerned in administering that justice, or such of them as, by the nature of their tenure, are

Armed with a body attachment issued by Judge Newburger of the Court of General Sessions, detectives were scouring the city last night in an effort to trace J. Morgan Smith, brother-in-law of Nan Patterson, against whom District Attorney Jerome had asked the Grand Jury to return an indictment charging to her account the shooting of Caesar Young, bookmaker and turfman, in a hansom cab last Saturday morning.
Two alarms were sounded for a fire in the four-story brick tenement at Melrose Street and Bushwick Avenue, Williamsburg, at midnight last night. Six families lived in the building.

Max Marx has bought from Frederick Baar the seven-story apartment house known as the Rudolph at 325 Central Park West, between Ninety-second and Ninety-third Streets, on plot 50 by 125. Mr. Marx gives in exchange a plot of fourteen lots on Eleventh and Wadsworth Avenues and One Hundred and Ninety-first Street.
BERLIN, June 9. -- John Alexander Dowie, at a meeting here this evening, bitterly assailed the Lokal Anzeiger for its statement that Zion City was in the hands of a receiver.

David B. Hill came to the city most unexpectedly yesterday. He held a long conference with Senator Patrick H. McCarren at the Hoffman House, and to-day will see William F. Sheehan, Attorney General John Cuneen, De Witt C. Flanagan, who was defeated by Congressman Charles N. Fowler of New Jersey in 1902, and J.E. Lamb of Indiana, second only in importance to Thomas Taggart among Hoosier Democrats, also saw the New York leader.
Why has it not occurred to some fair-minded and intelligent people to protest against the snap-shot judgment of the press and public on the merits of this nauseating case against Hannah Elias?

CHE-FOO, June 9. -- Chinese arriving from Port Arthur say the entrance to that harbor is still blocked, and large vessels are unable to pass in or out. Gunboats and torpedo boats can only effect a passage at high tide.

Hannah Elias, who is accused by John R. Platt of having blackmailed him out of $685,385, this afternoon will be arraigned in the Tombs Court before Magistrate Ommen. Platt will be the first witness placed on the stand by the prosecution. When he has finished the woman herself will give her version of their acquaintance.
RICHMOND, Va., June 9. -- The State Democratic Convention met here to-day, but adjourned this evening until to-morrow without adopting any resolutions.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 9. -- Treatment of tuberculosis with antitoxic serum was discussed by Dr. Edward Baldwin of Saranac Lake, N.Y., before the Section of Materia Medica, Pharmacy and Therapeutics of the American Medical Association to-day.
GYANG-TSE, June 9. -- Yesterday while Col. Younghusband was at Khang-Ma on his way to Chumbi an attack was made on the post by a force of Tibetans.

The fate of Leonidas Hubbard in Labrador leads me to present briefly some of the conditions which confront the explorer who has the hardihood to break from the coast and attempt exploration in the Labrador Peninsula -- the vast Lone Land, which although seen by the Cabots in 1497, is to-day less known than any other quarter of North America.

A pathetic story comes from Brooklyn of a worthy matron, the wife of a skilled artisan of excellent character and admitted responsibility, who has given up the quest for a home in the city after being refused in eighty-seven successive instances the privilege of leasing eligible apartments within the family means.

Mayor McClellan, Controller Grout, and Corporation Counsel Delany were yesterday served with papers demanding the restoration to the "Town of New Harlem" all that part of Manhattan Island lying north and east of a line extending from Seventy-fourth Street and the East River to One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and the North River.

CRIPPLE CREEK, June 9. -- "Death to unionism in the Cripple Creek district" is the new slogan of the Citizens' Alliance, which has sent a decree broadcast that every person connected with any union here must either sever his or her connection with such organization or leave this district.

ALBANY, June 9. -- Richard E. Preusser, who shot and killed Miles McDonnell at the Hotel Ten Eyck early yesterday morning, was arraigned in the Police Court to-day, and, through his attorney, waived examination. He was held for the Grand Jury. His case will probably be presented to-morrow, as the Grand Jury is now in session.

LONDON, June 9. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir Charles Dilke, (Advanced Radical,) raised the question of the administration of the Congo Free State. He advocated an appeal to the United States to act with Great Britain in the matter, pointing out that the United States was responsible for the creation of the Congo State, and saying he believed that such co-operation would be pregnant with good results.
WASHINGTON, June 9. -- President Roosevelt had as his guests to-day at luncheon Speaker Cannon, Senator Dryden of New Jersey, and Representative Hitt of Illinois.

More than a few were disappointed by yesterday's stock market, which failed to redeem the promise of Tuesday's and Wednesday's improvement. Activity and strength faded away as inexplicably as they arrived, the news being no better nor worse, and such news as there was having the same inconsequent effect.

The principal business of the convention of the Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday was the discussion of the report of Chairman W.N. Hobart of the Protective Bureau. The object of this bureau is to combat the prohibition idea.

Permit me to set myself right on the "pier question." I made no allusion to the recreation pier in church. A reporter called on me Sunday, inquiring what I thought of the North Second Street pier. I told him, and I repeat it, it is no place for decent people.

CLEVELAND, June 9. -- Clark Griffith's New York Americans performed an exceptional feat to-day when in the ninth inning they not only saved themselves from a shut-out, but made their only runs and won the game. A greater surprise to a big crowd of Cleveland baseball "rooters" was never perpetrated. Up to the first half of the ninth inning it had been a pitchers' battle between Moore and Chesbro.

Mrs. Edward C. Underhill, wife of Edward C. Underhill, a lawyer living at 166 West Ninety-fifth Street, with offices at 82 Wall Street, had her butler arrested last night after being terrorized by him for about two weeks. During that time, she says, she was in constant fear that he would shoot or poison her.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 9. -- After a hard battle with the heavy sea running in the Sound last evening Lamont Dominick, Yale, '93, and a member of the Riding Club of New York, son of George F. Dominick, a New York banker, rescued three men from drowning off his father's estate at Field Point Park, directly opposite E.C. Benedict's mansion. A fourth man, named Michael Bibrow, was drowned.

Yesterday's "spell of weather" certainly made it interesting for the bridal party and the guests at the Low-Herrick wedding, and the wind that blew in fierce gusts through Fifty-seventh Street did its best to wreck the awning at the Church of Zion and St. Timothy. Nevertheless the church was well filled with guests.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Members of the Honorary Board of Filipino Commissioners to the Louisiana Purchase Exposition reached Washington to-day as guests of the Government. The party consists of the forty-three Commissioners named by the civil Governor of the Philippines and several ladies. The Washington visit will continue until Monday morning, when the party will start for New York and the New England States.

CHICAGO, June 9. -- Financiers who had been more or less intimately connected with Mr. Leiter agree that his estate is worth somewhere between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000. In 1897, a year before his son's disastrous wheat deal, Leiter's wealth was estimated between $18,000,000 and $20,000,000.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 9. -- The Emperor has received the following report from Gen. Kuropatkin, dated June 8:
At yesterday's meeting of the Rapid Transit Commission it was announced formally by President Orr that New York's great tunnel would be opened in September.

In your paper of this morning you make it appear that I call all American artists a set of wall builders and canvas daubers, while the fact is. I did not state anything of the kind. The article which appeared in the Araldo Italiano this morning was written by me, and your enterprising reporter failed to get the proper meaning of my words.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 9. -- The intense heat has given way to a cold rain, and Companies K and A report that their night in the woods was anything but enjoyable.
SEOUL, June 8. -- M. Hayashi, the Japanese Minister to Korea, summed up the Korean situation yesterday as follows:

LONDON, June 9. -- With a view to cutting into the Cunard Line's Liverpool to Boston traffic the North German Lloyd Line has decided to carry third-class passengers from any part of the United Kingdom to Boston for $13.37. The Hamburg-American Line also announced a ten-dollar rate from Leith to New York.

ORWELL, N.Y., June 9. -- During a heavy thunderstorm that passed over this section last night the Wesleyan Methodist Church at Pine Meadows was struck by lightning. The Rev. A.J. Wilson, pastor of the church, was struck by the bolt, which passed through his body from the right shoulder to the left foot. A hole was burned in his foot, and his clothing was torn from his body.

DENVER, Col., June 9. -- Gen. Charles L. Cooper, retired, of the United States Army, has been assigned to Colorado as adviser of the organized milita for a period of four years. Gen. Cooper comes at the request of Gov. Peabody, and will receive the full pay and allowance of his rank. He served at Fort Logan as Lieutenant Colonel of the Fifteenth Cavalry in 1901.

VICTOR, Col., June 9. -- In a bloodless assault made by 150 militiamen and deputies, led by Adjt. Gen. Sherman M. Bell, on the Portland mine to-day, the mine was indefinitely closed, to be reopened later on terms which will prevent any workmen securing work without presenting satisfactory working cards from the Mine Owners' Association.

----- An irascible correspondent, manifesting an irritation of temper that we have ourselves long felt, wants to know why, if a Police Inspector must call the man who runs his automobile for him a "chauffeur," he does not also order the man to "chauff to Harlem" or anywhere else he desires to go.

Troubles for bettors were many, and visitors were few at the Gravesend race course yesterday, when, in the most dismal racing weather of the season, a commonplace programme was run off on a track deep in mud and water. Added to the chilling breeze that swept through the stands, rain fell constantly, and kept the smallest race-going crowd of the year under cover of the stands and betting rings.

If the civil war in Colorado were merely a local disturbance, significant of nothing except as indicating a lax state of public morals and a crude and imperfect social organization, it would be serious enough; but as showing what is the inevitable outcome of class conflict when unrestrained by a well organized public opinion in favor of the supremacy of law under all conditions, it is appalling.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 9. -- Resolutions adopted by the Committee on Resolutions of the Democratic State Convention early to-day call for an uninstructed delegation to the National Convention, but the delegates are required to vote as a unit.

LONDON, June 9. -- Walter J. Travis, the American and British amateur golf champion, dropped out of the open golf championship contest at Sandwich after to-day's round, under the rule whereby players with a score of twenty behind the leader are eliminated. Travis's score to-day was 88, and yesterday 83, a total of 171.

The situation in Colorado is not so clear a case for the mine owners as might be inferred from the columns of your valued paper, and while nothing can excuse the latest outrage, it may be well to remember that so far, after nearly a year of strikes, not a single union miner has been convicted of any crime in the three counties that have been the scene of so much bloodshed and wrath.

A tall man with a look of settled melancholy lined up at a place in Park Row where they sell absurdly small ones even in hot weather, and before he had time to indicate his preference his hat was knocked off by an arm of the fan which whirled around on top of an upright in front of the bar.

Cardinal Francis Satolli, Prefect of the Congregation of Studies, arrived in this country yesterday morning on the Prinzess Irene of the North German Lloyd. Cardinal Satolli is the first prince of the Church attached to the Vatican who has ever left Rome except when sent on a special commission by the Pope.

BERLIN, June 9. -- The American delegates to the Congress of the International Woman's Suffrage Committee have come into conflict with a time-honored German custom, and the German custom has got the worst of it.

The marriage of Princess ALEXANDRA, daughter of the Duke of CUMBERLAND and BRUNSWICK, claimant of the throne of Hanover, with the Grand Duke of MECKLENBURG-SCHWERIN may well have given satisfaction to the bride's grandmother, the aged Queen of Hanover. She had lived, it is true, not quite long enough to be present at the wedding, but long enough to enjoy thwarting the Prussian family which seized her throne.

My attention has just been called to an article (if it so may be dignified) which appeared in the editorial column of your issue of May 30 under the caption "Undisguised," with respect to Mr. Reginald Claypool Vanderbilt. I say it referred to Mr. Vanderbilt, although you carefully refrained from mentioning his name.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Information of the agreement made at Philadelphia to-day to cheese Attorney General Ithe vacancy came to the President from that gentleman himself over the telephone. Mr. ]the same time informed the President that he had deeided to accept tile tender of the Senatorsilip, and that he would return to 'ashington within a few days and place his resignation in the President's hands.

Signor ERNESTO BIONDI is rash with the perfervidness of a sculptor scorned when he attacks American architecture, sculpture, and painting in one sweeping burst of disgust. His indictment of a nation must instantly react on his own lovely land and cause one to ask whether Italy is any better off.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, June 9. -- The six delegates from Utah to the Democratic National Convention will go uninstructed. Four of the six, it is understood, are against William R. Hearst, with a leaning toward Judge Parker as first choice. Two delegates probably will support Hearst.

Among the passengers who arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Prinzess Irene yesterday was Frederick Taylor, the traveler and explorer. Mr. Taylor left New York about two years ago, and since that time has visited many obscure places in the Far East. He spent seventeen days in the jungles of Bengal hunting tigers. In this district at the time the plague was raging the mortality was very high.

After Justice Kelly had awarded to Policeman Daniel Undermark the custody of his eleven-year-old son in the Supreme Court of Brooklyn yesterday the little boy clung to his foster mother, Mrs. Agnes Donnelly, with whom he had been living, and set up a series of howls that were heard throughout the Court House, disturbing court proceedings and causing a crowd to gather in the corridor.

The pediment of the new Stock Exchange is the most ambitious and elaborate effort yet made toward the decoration of public buildings in New York by means of sculpture which shall assist the architecture to tell their story, by the use of more direct and specific expression of their purposes than unassisted architecture can give.

Mrs. Russell Sage was among the "sweet girl graduates" at New York University yesterday afternoon. At the commencement exercises she received the degree of Master of Letters. As Chancellor MacCracken slipped the colored hood over her head she smiled with the delight of a child at a new toy.

Chafing under the rigid restrictions of the workhouse on Blackwell's Island is John Donnelly, a poet, who, in rhyme, sent yesterday to Magistrate Cornell, who committed him, his yearning for liberty. The poem follows:

PARIS, June 9. -- Foreign Minister Delcasse made a statement in the Chamber of Deputies to-day giving a summary of the official investigation into the atrocities in Armenia. The question came up upon the request of M. de Pressense (Socialist) that France make a naval demonstration against Turkey in order to stop the Armenian persecutions.

Little could be seen at the piers yesterday indicating that a strike of the firemen, oilers, water tenders, and coal passers on the coastwise steamships was in progress. The various companies affected were all able to get their vessels out on time, some with their regular crews, others with new firemen.

WASHINGTON, June 9. -- Official denial is given the statement made by Chairman Cowherd of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee to the effect that a force of clerks in the Department of Commerce was being employed in preparing matter for insertion in the Republican campaign books to be issued.

The contract for the building and installation of the first electro-magnetic railroad to come into existence in this or any other country has been awarded to R.S. Bishop Co. of 11 Broadway, Manhattan.

On account both of its interesting participants and of the charm of the country over which its battle ground extended the romantic possibilities of the French and Indian war in America have never been neglected by our novel writers, yet there seem still to be untouched phases of the subject.
LONDON, June ll. -- The Daily Mail says: "Two infernal machines were found on the night of June 7 concealed in tobacco boxes in the Tsarskoe Selo Palace, where the Russian Emperor is now residing.

MR. ROBERT W. CHAMBERS attacks the sentimentalists of the "nature books" as fiercely as Director Hornaday of the Zoological Gardens, whose book about animals is reviewed on another page this week. Only Mr. Chambers's weapon is humor.

We wish that estimable gentlemen engaged professionally in the instruction of the public, like Dr. MACCRACKEN, and well-meaning gentlemen with a call to reform the public morals, like Mr. COLER, could find a more exact term to express the evils they class under the vague title of "commercialism."

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- Consul General Guenther, at Frankfort, sends a report saying that Prof. Lassar recently delivered a lecture before the Medical Society of Berlin on the results of his experiments with radium as a remedy.

George J. was a witness yesterday afternoon, called by the defense in the suit brought in Part VI. of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, before Justice Spencer and a jury, by Morris Menges of Sheepshead Bay against Gen. Louis Fitzgerald for $1,000,000, asked for services alleged to have been rendered to enable Gen. Fitzgerald to obtain control of the Western Maryland Railroad, purchased by the Fuller Syndicate from the City of Baltimore.

Fifty years ago the Republican Party was organized, and this elaborate history of over 1,000 pages is a tribute to the completion of the first half century of that party's existence. The issues that gave the Republican movement life are explained, while the later issues of tariff changes, trusts, sound money, insular possessions, and the Isthmian canal, including the recognition of the Republic of Panama, are treated intelligibly.

ODESSA, June 6. -- Reports from most of the manufacturing areas of Russia state that the output is limited. Factories are struggling along on half time and hands are being discharged for want of orders.
PARIS, June 10. -- In the course of an acrimonious discussion in the Chamber of Deputies to-day between Premier Combes and M. Millerand, the Socialist ex-Minister, some one on the Right shouted.

A MOTTO found in the title page of Geoffrey Drage's "Russian Affairs" might cause some surprise. Count Modravieff writes: "I believe that Russia has a civilizing mission such as no other people in the world possesses, not only in Asia, but also in Europe * * * We Russians bear upon our shoulders the New Age; we come to relieve the 'Tired Men.'"

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 10. -- Gov. Pennypacker to-day appointed Attorney General Knox to succeed the late Senator Quay. The announcement of Mr. Knox's appointment was followed by a long statement from the Governor, giving his reasons for not calling an extra session of the Legislature for the selection of a Senator for the unexpired term of Senator Quay, which expires on March 4, 1905.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., June 10. -- Throughout the strike the women have been most aggressive in urging on their men folk. Their insults and taunts of non-union men have been of all the hardest to bear because they could not be answered with a blow. The woman's auxiliary of the miners' federation has branches in nearly every town and city in the district.

The legend that Gen. James Wolfe, while his boat was softly rowed down the St. Lawrence River, in the dark night preceding the day of his splendid victory and heroic death on the Plains of Abraham, murmured some verses of Gray's. "Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard," and praised them to his officers, has generally been accepted by students of history as gospel truth.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 10. -- The Emperor has received from Gen. Kuropatkin the following telegram, dated June 9:

GEN. BOYNTON'S review of Mr. Waddy Thompson's School History of the United States covers a field generally neglected hitherto, or treated in a perfunctory way, in the critical consideration of published books. Yet no rational American citizen will deny the importance of teaching all American children the true history of their country as free as possible from the influence of partisan bias and sectional prejudice.

The ninth annual convention of the Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association was concluded last night with a banquet and vaudeville performance at the Waldorf Astoria Officers for the coming year were elected at the morning session as follows:

The Grand Jury adjourned yesterday without returning an indictment against Nan Patterson, the actress who was in the hansom cab with "Caesar" Young, the bookmaker, when he was mysteriously shot and killed in West Broadway last Saturday morning. In the District Attorney's office, however, it was understood that some decisive action might be looked for on Monday, when the Grand Jury will meet again.
CHICAGO, June 10. -- Mayor Harrison announced to-night that no bookmaking would be allowed at Washington Park on Derby day and that no betting would be allowed during the Washington Park meeting.
Daniel B. Freedman has bought from Max Marx the five-story building 162 William Street, 24.11 by 62 by 23.2 by 64. Mr. Marx bought the property at auction yesterday for $34,455.

DENVER, Col., June 10. -- The Executive Board of the Western Federation of Miners decided to-day to appeal to President Roosevelt to investigate the condition in Colorado. Secretary W.D. Haywood was instructed to send the following telegram: The Hon. Theodore Roosevelt, Washington, D.C.:

"The German Official Account of the War in South Africa" has been translated and edited by a British officer. Col. W. H.H. Waters writes that there are other great powers who "have a fully equipped military history section," but he lays particular stress on the thorough and systematic methods of the Germans. Commenting on the effects of the African climate on Europeans, the German General Staff writes:

LONDON, June 10. -- The work entitled "The Pan-Germanic Doctrine," which Messrs. Harper Brothers announced several months ago, is published to-day. The secret of the authorship has been well kept, but it is understood that the book was written by an Englishman long resident in Germany, who has devoted great care to its preparation.
TANGIER, June 10. -- Kaid Omar Yussi, commanding the loyal forces near Fez, has been killed in action, his troops being routed and losing machine guns.
PARIS, June 10 -- In the highest Russophile circles here a very despondent feeling has been caused by the recent news from the seat of war.

EVERY now and then a short article appears in THE TIMES BOOK REVIEW on Esperanto, the language made a number of years ago by Dr. Zamenhof of Russia. The question is usually asked in its discussion whether it will ever become the international language.

Joseph Jacobs, the former pride of the District Attorney's staff of sleuths, has once more come forth from a seclusion of considerably longer duration than usual -- this time his countenance much discolored about his left eye.

The first volumes in the new edition of Prof. Arber's "An English Garner; Ingatherings from English History and Literature," which E.P. Dutton Co. are to bring out in twelve volumes, are nearly ready for publication. They are "Elizabethan Sonnets," in two volumes, edited with an introduction by Sidney Lee, author of "A Life of William Shakespeare" and "Queen Victoria: A Biography," and editor of "The Dictionary of National Biography."

One of the green policemen of the Tenderloin who evidently had never heard of Brian G. Hughes, the practical joker, went to the West Thirtieth Street Police Station yesterday with a package of papers which he said consisted of stock certificates picked up in the Rapid Transit tunnel at Twenty-eighth Street and Fourth Avenue.

ST. LOUIS, June 10. -- Ernest Carelton Bass, the bull fighter, who slew the matador Cervera here on Thursday after the bull fight fiasco and the burning of the amphitheatre, and who is now held by the St. Louis police, is said to be the son of a noted English family and the heir to a title and estates in England.

There seems to be a strong demand by school teachers to be allowed to inflict bodily punishment upon refractory pupils. If the power to use the rod is to be exercised as it once was, I fear that it will be used with discrimination, recklessly, and unjustly.

The band of process servers who have been on the trail of Howard Gould for the past two weeks have succeeded at last. Abner Haydel, the architect for the four-million-dollar Castlegould, wants Mr. Gould in court. A month ago Mr. Gould brought suit against the architect for breach of contract.

The Baron Kentaro Kaneko, the special Japanese envoy to this country, will have an article in the July Century on "The Magna Charta of Japan." He is the possessor of the degrees of LL. B. and LL. D. from Harvard University, from which he was graduated in 1878. While attending the Law School there he met Longfellow, Holmes, R.C. Winthrop, and other well-known men.

Mr. JACOB A. CANTOR, late President of the Borough of Manhattan, performed a useful public service in causing to be published as a municipal document the report of the proceedings of the International Fire Prevention Congress held in London a year ago, prepared by Prof. IRA H. WOOLSON of Columbia University, who represented New York at that gathering.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 10 -- Ambassador McCormick says the story is absurd that he has been coldly treated by Russian society because as a part of his official duties he takes care of Japanese interests or as a consequence of the supposed friendliness in the United States toward Japan.

Attaches of the Jefferson Market Court were fairly dazzled yesterday by the smile of Rosie Fried, twenty-six years old, of 117 Fourth Avenue, who was arrested as an alleged accomplice of a noted shoplifter. The young woman was handsomely gowned and of otherwise striking appearance, which was heightened when her lips parted, showing a carat and a half diamond set in one of her front teeth.

Referring to your columns of to-day, may I add to the communication of "E.A.W." that the disproportion between the enormous outlay in this country for public libraries and the amount of visible good accomplished by them seems to me appalling.

The creditor's of Daniel J. Sully Co. held a meeting yesterday at the office of MacGrane Coxe, the referee in bankruptcy, to elect a trustee for the further administration of the estate of the bankrupts. The meeting was quite a lively one, and brought out the fact that there was a division of opinion among the various classes of creditors.

WASHINGTON, June 10. -- As a rule the President does not complain of criticism of his acts, but he resents being charged with a desire to dictate what shall he done by the Chicago Convention in all the matters of detail that properly belong to the convention and its officers.

There has been no better volume included in this series of Little Biographies than Mr. Benson's life of Tennyson. He has found space in its short compass to give the narrative of Tennyson's career; to sketch his temperament, ideals, and beliefs; to indicate from his own words and writings his view of the poetical life and character, and to touch the chief characteristics of his art from a technical point of view.

The mechanical work of this book, in its make up style and front cover, was a labor performed by the writer, a job compositor, to help to pay its way. So it is written on the last page of "The Red Book." "The Red Book" piles up words on a great many subjects, borrowing from many languages. The alien words are thoughtfully assembled in an appendix, with translations.

"Wings and No Eyes" is the title of a comedy of love," by Philip Crutcher, which the Grafton Press has in preparation. John Cobbs, a book agent, buys a bookstore in Judithland, in the State of Mississippi. A few miles further out of the town lives an authoress, whom John makes up his mind to marry.

An old woman, known now as "Mrs. Brown," who has lived for years in an old hut on the abandoned pier at East Sixty-sixth Street, where the Pastime Athletic Club used to be, and who is said to be the widow of William Murray, the superintendent of the club, hurled a stone at one of a crowd of small boys who were tormenting her yesterday afternoon.

I can remember that Nast's "Santa Claus" gave me, as a New Yorker, no shock of novelty. It was not so much Dutch or German as English. The fact is, the artists who drew on wood in the fifties were more or less under the influence of Orr and Avery, the ruling wood engraving houses.

The Hon. Alexander Nelson Hood, private secretary to the Princess of Wales, and hitherto known to a few readers of polite literature as the author of certain articles on Italian life, has written a novel which he calls "Adria: A Tale of Venice." If the chief interest in the book reposed in the ability of Mr. Hood to imagine a story and impart it in an interesting manner "Adria" might be dismissed with few words.

GP. PUTNAM'S SONS have in preparation a book on the Siamese exhibit at the World's Fair in St. Louis, to be published under the auspices of Prof. James Howard Gore, the Commissioner General of the exhibit.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 10. -- William H. Oppie, Postmaster at Griggstown, ten miles from here, and his wife, were attacked and robbed early this morning in their home in the Post Office by two burglars. After they had ransacked the office they entered the living apartments and roused the Postmaster and his wife, both of whom are over seventy-five years old.

The new Cuban sixes were placed in the unlisted department of the Stock Exchange yesterday, and the first sale recorded was at 98 1/8 flat. This figured out at 94 5-16 with interest on the basis of the curb trading, as that is at the rate of $4.87 per pound sterling exchange, whereas the Stock Exchange rate is $5 per pound.

The modest paragraph on this page of THE BOOK REVIEW May 21, intimating that a controversy might arise from Mr. Albert Bigelow Paine's statement of his belief (in Pearson's) that Thomas Nast actually invented the pictorial idea of Santa Claus which has long prevailed in this country, has borne excellent fruit. The controversy is on, and our readers have been getting the benefit of it.

THIS school history, by a Southern author, is remarkable in that it is the most successful attempt of any writer from that section to make an impartial presentation of the questions which so long divided the country and finally brought on the civil war. So far as my knowledge of school histories extends, it is the first from the South for which this claim can be made.

WILLIAM H. FLEMING, A.M., the well-known lecturer, author, and editor of Shakespearean subjects and plays, is preparing for Doubleday, Page Co. the fourth series of his work on "How to study Shakespeare." This volume will contain the Plays of "Richard II.," "Cymbeline," the first and second parts of "Henry IV.," and "The Taming of the Shrew."

VICTOR, Col., June 10. -- In the investigation by the jury empaneled by Coroner Hall into the explosion at the Independence station Monday, when more than twenty men were killed or crippled, the first witness to-day was James Dooner, engineer of the train that was pulling into the station at the time of the explosion.

Dominick Mairessa, a seven-year-old Italian, who lives with his parents at 453 East One Hundred and Forty-sixth Street, was a busy lad last night. Little Dominick reads all the dime novels he can get.

A shooting affray took place yesterday at Pier 16 of the Ward Line as a result of the strike of the marine firemen, coal passers, and others. The line, in spite of the strike, has managed to get its boats off on time, and this enraged the strikers.

Mr. Sichel is known as an admirer of Lord Beaconsfield's personality and achievements, and in this short biography has treated that magical career and those wonderful gifts with a high sense of appreciation, and with that partisan spirit that is inevitable from one writing under the spell of that influence.

Bids for the new Staten Island ferryboats were opened yesterday at the office of the Dock Commissioner, Borough President Cromwell of Richmond and several prominent Staten Islanders being present. Deputy Dock Commissioner Bill opened the bids, Commissioner Featherson being absent because of the death of his father.

That Mr. Havelock Ellis's book has gone into a fourth edition in the ten years since it was published, not to speak of innumerable translations, is in itself a proof of its value. It is intended to give definite data concerning the constitutional differences between men and women -- differences that lie at the root of many social questions.

New York increased its lead in the National League by shutting out Chicago yesterday at the Polo Grounds, and Selee's team and Cincinnati are now upon an even standing. The latter was unable to play yesterday at Philadelphia, owing to wet grounds. In the American League the Greater New Yorks' defeat by Chicago put Griffith's men in fourth place, while Cleveland went ahead of the local team by its victory over Philadelphia.

The scene of this story is a village of Cornish fisher folk and the residences of the gentry round about. It begins with the horrid apparition of a witch-woman cursing a newly built fishing boat and includes a pageant in which the same boat is blessed in a solemn service by the Canon and the Bishop's chaplain.

The reviewer of "Pamela Congreve" is badly astray as to the word "corn," used generally, I admit, in this country to mean Indian corn. In Scotland the word corn usually means oats, but in Great Britain it is used to describe grain in general, as, for instance, "the corn trade." Indian corn is called maize, and not corn.

The Century Company reports that among its "books of yester year," the first of Kipling's Jungle books has recently been printed for the twentieth time, and the second for the twelfth; John Luther Long's "Madame Butterfly," now seven years old, has been reprinted twice in the present year, and Mrs. Ruth McEnery Stuart's "Sonny," issued in 1807, was printed for the fourteenth time last, February.

THE sub-title of "Early Western Travels," which reads "a series of Annotated Reprints of some of the best and rarest contemporary volumes of travel," explains the character of the work edited by Mr. Reuben Gold Thwaites.

Cardinal Francis Satolli was the guest of Archbishop Farley yesterday. A reception was held in his honor last night in the archiepiscopal residence, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street. Previous to this gathering of the prominent Catholic clergymen and laymen the Cardinal said that his visit to the United States was absolutely unofficial, and that he had come here simply as a private citizen.

"The World of Fashion and of Letters at Bath under Queen Anne and the Georges," (Une Ville d'eaux anglaise au XVIIIe Siecle,) is a study by A. Barbeau, author of "Joan of Arc," , of England's famous watering place, which, under the Georges, was regarded as almost an obligatory rendezvous for society.

The letters signed "American Episcopalian" and "K.D.L." are on the right line. The Protestant Episcopal Church is a Protestant body, and Protestant it must remain. Mcreover, it is American, not Anglican. The Anglican Church ceased to exist here upon the successful result of the American revolution. British rule and the British Church were cast off forever, and the Protestant Episcopal Church was formed for the United States of America.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 10. -- Remote as now appears the chance that the Japanese fleet will ever be in a position to venture up the Baltic and make a demonstration against the Russian capital, or that a European power will be drawn into the war, Russia evidently is taking nothing for granted.

The new Morris High School building, at One Hundred and Sixty-sixth Street and Boston Road, which has just been completed at a cost of nearly half a million dollars, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon in the presence of numerous members and ex-members of the Board of Education, members of the Board of Trade, and 2,000 of the school's pupils, with their parents and teachers.

Owing to Controller Grout's objection to Bridge Commissioner Best's desire to spend $500,000 for a temporary terminal in City Hall Park for the Brooklyn Bridge, the whole matter was held up at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. Controller Grout said his understanding had been that not more than $200,000 would be used for the temporary structure, and he was astonished at the request for two and a half times that amount.

The Summer Reading Lists of THE NEW YORK TIMES BOOK REVIEW have long been esteemed useful by both readers of books and booksellers. The Summer Reading Number is to be published next week, June 18. It will contain, as usual, two lists of meritorious or promising books published this year, or to be published within a few weeks. The first list of fifty titles will include short descriptions of each book.

George White, a wealthy merchant of Bristol. Thomas Chatterton's native city, was the purchaser at the London auction sale of the relics of the unfortunate poet mentioned last week. He has given the manuscripts and pocketbook to the Bristol Museum. Of the relics, The Pall Mall Gazette says:
Don't such remarks as were made by Secretary Shaw make you tired?

Those were stirring days when the haughty Spaniard ruled in New Orleans and the painted redskin howled by night in the wilderness on both sides of the Ohio and Mississippi. Mr. Stephens takes you in spirit back to them. You are introduced to the boys of 1803 as they sit about the fire in a log schoolhouse, plucking wild turkeys.

In your editorial of to-day's date on "Temperance and Abstention." you quote an opinion of Mrs. Mary H. Hunt as to the incapacity of moderate drinkers to hold or express any opinion of value on the subject of alcoholic beverages.
DENVER, Col., June 10. -- It may take time, but James F. Burns proposes to even up matters with the State of Colorado for the arbitrary closing of the Portland Mine, his friends declared to-day.
Will the editor allow me to call his attention to two errors which appear in the announcement in to-day's BOOK REVIEW of the forthcoming book of memoirs, "A Belie of the Fifties"?

Two Italians who are believed by the police to be the ringleaders of a gang of expert counterfeiters who have been flooding Harlem with spurious twenty-five and fifty cent coins were captured in their workshop at 218 East One Hundred and Eleventh Street yesterday afternoon after a desperate fight.

The Smithsonian Institution issues through the Government Printing Office in Washington the "Twenty-second Annual Report of the Bureau of American Ethnology" for the year 1900-01. There is a brief administrative report of less than fifty pages and two "papers" or individual reports that are the true inwardness of the volume.
A VOLUME of letters attributed to John Hus, one of the precursors of the Reformation, has been edited by Herbert B. Workman and R. Martin Pope, and published in London by Messrs. Hodder Stoughton.

NEWCASTLE, Col., June 10. -- The two survivors of the band of train robbers which dynamited an express car on the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad near Parachute have escaped from a ridge in Garfield Creek Canon, where they had apparently been surrounded by pursuers. They cannot have gone far, and it is believed they will soon be located.

The first of a series of races to be held by the Atlantic Yacht Club for a $150 cup offered by Rear Commodore Havens will be sailed this afternoon off the clubhouse at Sea Gate. The contest is open to thirty-footers and smaller boats sailing on time allowance. The most notable entries are Red Wing, J.B. O'Donohue; Vivian, S.E. Vernon; Baghera, Hendon Chubb; Bobtail, Edgar F. Luckenbach, and Eva, E.O. Rahr.

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 10. -- The Harvard crews were put through very light work to-day, not rowing at all in the morning, and going through a short row in the afternoon. From this fact it is evident that Coach Colson feels worried about some of the men. Two or three of the oarsmen are down in weight, but otherwise are fit.

Joseph E. Murray, boxing instructor for the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, appeared in the West Side Court yesterday to answer to a charge of assault made by Policeman John E. Kelleher. The policeman said that he got on an elevated train of the Sixth Avenue line about 1 o'clock on the morning of June l, and because he jostled Murray's foot in passing the latter punched him in the eye.

Tennis matches in doubles of a spectacular character, with William A. Larned, the ex-champion, as one of the competitors, provided exciting sport yesterday in the special invitation tournament on the courts of the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island. Larned was in excellent form, and with his partner, Willis, was successful in defeating George Miles, Jr., and Watkins of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club by the score of 3--6, 6--4, 6--3.
