VIENNA, June 13. -- The Polish newspaper Czas, which is usually well informed in regard to the affairs of the Russian Court, publishes to-day a communication from St. Petersburg on the state of mind of the Czar.

Plans were perfected yesterday for an amalgamation of the proposed National Association of Importers with the Foreign Trade Association, composed both of importers and exporters, at a meeting of the importers held at the Broadway Central Hotel.

The old Hoffman House -- or, strictly speaking, all of the old and larger part of the hotel -- which has been for over thirty years the informal headquarters of the National Democratic Committees and one of the greatest resorts for turfmen in the city, is about to be torn down and rebuilt.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- No one in authority here will discuss the action of the State officials in Colorado in deporting citizens of Cripple Creek into neighboring States. It is probable, however, that the matter will be taken up in some form by the Federal authorities, and it may be a subject for the consideration of the President and Cabinet to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- Representative Littauer was among those who talked today with the President. It is supposed Mr. Littauer brought messages and suggestions from New York regarding party organization and leadership in that State in the approaching Presidential campaign, but he would not admit that such matters were discussed.

Nan Patterson was indicted yesterday by the Grand Jury for murder in the first degree on a charge of shooting and killing Frank T. Young, the bookmaker, known as "Caesar" Young, on June 4 last. She will be arraigned to plead on the indictment this morning before Judge Newburger in Part I., General Sessions.

When the radical Democrats who are opposing the nomination of Judge Parker for President hold their convention in Cooper Union on the evening of June 20, William Jennings Bryan will be the chief speaker of the occasion.

In your editorial on "Commercialism" (June 11) you complain that this term is vague, and say that as trickery and greed are found in professional as well as commercial life, it is unfair to dub all wherever found "commercialism."

About 8,000 members of the National Schuetzen Bund, in attendance at the annual "schuetzenfest" of the organization at Union Hill, N.J., took part in a parade in this city yesterday morning and were reviewed by Mayor McClellan. The Mayor, after being informed that the Bund had a membership of about 25,000, remarked that they would make about an army corps, and commented favorably on the appearance of those in line.
DENVER, Col., June 17. -- Gov. Peabody to-day made the following statement:

BERLIN, June 13. -- The International Woman's Congress, called by the League of German Women's Societies in connection with the International Council of Women, opened this morning in Philharmonic Hall. There was a large attendance of women from all the Continental countries, the United States, and Australia.

Parish, Fisher, Mooney Co. have sold for Mrs. Catherine C. Giles, eighteen lots at the northwest corner of Giles and Cannon Places, King's Bridge, to M.S. Eylar. Mr. Eylar has resold the lots to John C. Martin.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 13. -- The General Staff has received the following dispatch from Major Gen. Karkevitch, dated June 12.

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 13. -- Coach Colson started off the week's work of the Harvard 'Varsity crew this morning with a change at No. 4. Soon after breakfast he took Meier and Ober out in a pair-oar for a mile, shifting Meier from starboard, where he has been rowing in the second eight, to port and putting Ober, who has been rowing on the port side in the 'Varsity boat, over to starboard.
CHICAGO, June 13. -- Speaker Joseph G. Cannon spent a few hours in the city today. He called at the Auditorium Annex and shook hands with the members of the National Committee who were around.

So great is the number of immigrants expected to arrive at New York this week that some of the authorities on Ellis Island believe that it is going to be necessary to erect tents on the island in order to accommodate the increased numbers that will be detained for investigation, owing to the new ten-dollar rate from London to New York that the International Mercantile Marine and the German lines are now offering.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 13. -- Senator Beveridge has received official notice that he is to make the first speech in the Republican National Convention, seconding the nomination of Roosevelt. He will follow ex-Gov. Black of New York, who will place the candidate in nomination.

CONCORD, N.H., June 13. -- Half a dozen newspaper photographers who came here to-day to get pictures of scenes in connection with the visit of Christian Scientists from Boston to Mrs. Mary Baker Eddy's First Church of Christ Scientist, now building here, had a rough time of it this afternoon.

Irish Lad favorite for the Suburban, and the top weight for that race, had his final trial for the big event of Thursday at Sheepshead Bay yesterday morning, and with a mile and a quarter turned in 2:08 3/4, in the most impressive manner, established himself more firmly than ever as the first choice for the $20,000 prize offered by the Coney Island Jockey Club.

The water wagon -- that is, the sprinkler cart -- came to a standstill at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street yesterday morning at four o'clock. The driver got off his seat and stood on the sidewalk scratching his head doubtfully, and staring down the alley over which he had just sprayed many gallons of water.

Under the laws of Illinois a curious "college" has been incorporated with respectable incorporators. No one under the age of sixty years is eligible to matriculation. On entering one must purchase a scholarship, and is thereafter free from financial cares. This costs $200, if the purchase is deferred to the age of eligibility.

LONDON, June 13. -- Lord Muskerry (Conservative) in the House of Lords this evening questioned the Government concerning the reservation by other countries of coastwise trade to vessels of their own nationality, and especially to the proposed application to the Philippine Islands of the coastwise laws of the United States.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 13. -- Comiskey's team defeated the New York Americans in the final game of the series at the South Side Park this afternoon, and thereby managed to secure an even break on the visit. The final count after the contest, which was speedily played, was 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 13. -- James N. Tyner, who was removed from office as Assistant Attorney General for the Post-Office Department during the investigation of the department, and who recently was fried and acquitted by a jury, has addressed the following letter to President Roosevelt:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13. -- Walter Clarkson, Captain and pitcher of the Harvard 'Varsity baseball team, was barred from further participation in college athletics by the Harvard Athletic Committee at a meeting to-night, which lasted from 7 until 11:30 o'clock.

Capt. J.M. McGregor of Detroit, President of the International Pilots Association, is at the Ashland House, whither he came from Washington to see Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, as to whether that organization will take up the fight of the Lake Carriers' Association and the pilots. President Gompers was out of town.

Several influences combined to assist the market yesterday. The close of the previous week had been with improving sentiment and prices, and over Sunday several commentators had done their best to promote a continuance of those conditions, which were further assisted by the day's news.

LONDON, June 14. -- The Times's Russian correspondents say that amid all the confusion of the war M. de Plehve, the Russian Minister of the Interior, is carrying out his chosen task of defending the autocracy against attacks at home. His favorite methods of prevention are being employed with redoubled vigor.

Entries closed yesterday with Anson B. Cole, Chairman of the Challenge Cup Committee of the American Power Boat Association for the challenge cup races to be held June 23, 24, and 25 in the Hudson River, starting from the Columbia Yacht Club, foot of West Eighty-sixth Street. The full list of entries, however, will not be announced until to-day, as any entries by mail which may arrive this morning will be included.
Gov. Odell arrived in this city from Europe last night on the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, brown as a beechnut, and in excellent physical and political spirits. His son Herbert also returned.

As a companion to the ordinance proposed by Alderman Stapleton to abolish the "end seat hog," Alderman Downing of Brooklyn introduced a proposed ordinance at yesterday's meeting of the board making it a misdemeanor, punishable by $50 fine or three months' imprisonment, to stand in an open trolley car. The resolution was sent to sleep with the Committee on Railroads.

It is hardly true that the impending immigration, stimulated by the reduction from $15 to $9.60 in the steerage rates, is sure to prove "unprecedented." We have had similar rushes before, and we are likely to have them whenever a "rate war" breaks out between the steamship companies during a period of prosperity.

That the New York Central Railroad seeks to acquire the block bounded by Lexington Avenue and Depew Place, Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, or at least the northerly half of it, was the interpretation given yesterday to several recent sales of property thereabout.

While the steamboat Chester W. Chapin, bound from this city to New London with 200 passengers, was trying to avoid collision with other marine craft off the lower end of Ward's Island early last evening, she bumped across the sharp rocks of Nigger Point, tearing a great hole in her bow, through which so much water passed that her forward compartment was filled.

Mrs. T.H. Polhemus of the Eastern Parkway Golf Club, Brooklyn, won the medal for the lowest score yesterday in, the qualifying round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association tournament. The competition was started on the links of the Apawamis Club, at Rye, and will continue throughout the week.

Herewith I take the liberty asking your permission to say a few words to "One Who Knows." I really do not believe he knows the first thing toward the feeling existing between a Prussian officer and his soldiers. If he would care to look a little deeper I think he would learn they understand each other perfectly well, and in danger will stand heart to heart.
LONDON, June 14. -- Money was in good demand in the market to-day, and the supply was more plentiful, owing to the release of the Japanese loan installment. Discounts were firm.

Horace A. Hutchins of the Standard Oil Company has sold the Euclid Building, a six-story structure, at 564 to 568 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northwest corner of Forty-sixth Street, on plot 32.8 by 100.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 14. -- After six weeks of tie-up on the great lakes that has directly involved only a couple of thousand men, but indirectly more than a hundred thousand, the strike was broken to-night by the surrender of the masters, who, with the pilots, have been holding out for a more uniform scale of wages this season than was offered by the Lake Carriers' Association.

The big Cunard Line steamship Carpathia left her dock here yesterday with an army of invasion aboard. Her passengers, the Salvation Army delegates to the congress at London, crowded to starboard as she slipped out and made the big craft list perceptibly.

TANGIER, June 14. -- Among certain classes of the foreign residents here the presence of the American ships is regarded as almost an act of aggression. America has come as a new factor in Moroccan politics, and this raises resentment in certain quarters, but the entire European population should be grateful to the United States, which supplies almost the only security for their lives and property.

Just one door north of the home of Hannah Elias, at 236 Central Park West, last evening a bay horse attached to a dump cart and owned by James Reilly of 310 West Thirty-first Street, came to a halt and refused to go further. Hugo Weissbader of 422 West Twenty-seventh Street, the driver, applied his whip, but the horse wouldn't move.

One of the commonest expectations about the result of the war is that it will promote the modernization and liberalization of Russian politics. The expectation is natural enough and would be plausible of any other European nation than Russia, with the exception of Turkey, if indeed either Russia or Turkey is entitled to be called a European State. Citizens of politically advanced countries inevitably generalize from the conditions with which they are familiar.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 14. -- A Fountain Westervelt, the broker of the Consolidated Exchange who disappeared on Saturday, was not in financial difficulties, as far as is known, and his marriage to Miss Florence W. Olmstead of this place was set for to-morrow evening. Miss Olmstead has heard no word from Mr. Westervelt, and is almost prostrated.

Samuel M. Burbank, nephew of Ambrose Beckett Burbank, who died in January, leaving, it is thought, more than a million dollars, cut his throat yesterday, shortly before noon, in the office of Eugene D. Hawkins, senior member of the law firm of Hawkins, Delafield Sturges, at 1 Nassau Street.
The third and last section of the rapid transit tunnel under the Harlem River was sunk at an early hour this morning, and it is expected that the tunnel will be completed inside of six weeks.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 14. -- The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated Lawrence B. Stringer of Lincoln for Governor, and instructed the delegates to the St. Louis Convention to vote as a unit for William R. Hearst for the Presidential nomination.

The thirty-eighth annual regatta of the Atlantic Yacht Club was sailed yesterday under ideal conditions, clear skies, brilliant sunshine, and a piping breeze from the south that crested the lower bay with whitecaps. But, unfortunately, the fleet was small -- small in boats, and small in numbers.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 15, 3:16 A.M. -- Emperor Nicholas has received the following telegram from Lieut. Gen. Baron Stakelberg, bearing yesterday's (Tuesday's) date:

In the First Criminal Court, Jersey City, yesterday, Police Justice Higgins heard testimony a second time as to whether or not a black-and-tan dog owned by Mrs. Mary Bartsch of 335 Tenth Street should be put to death on the complaint of Patrick J. Flanagan, a letter carrier, who alleged that the dog bit him on the leg while he was delivering a letter at the house.

NEW ROCHELLE, June 14. -- In order to disprove the contention that her dog, Ping Pong, which was shot and killed a week ago by young Harry Emigh of Rochelle Park, was not licensed, Miss Lillian Pike, the daughter of Fire Commissioner Pike of New Rochelle, to-day had the body of the animal exhumed.

CRIPPLE CREEK, June 14. -- Virgil King, Charles Matthews, and Patrick Mullaney were taken from the Victor "bull pen" to the county jail to-day. The military authorities say that King and Mullaney will be charged with complicity in the Independence dynamiting, and that Matthews is held as a witness.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14. -- Bright June weather graced the wedding day of Miss Elsie Whelan and Robert Goelet. The wedding party was of unusual size and distinction. Miss Alice Roosevelt was one of the bridesmaids, while the others were all well known in society.

LAMAR, Col., June 14. -- In straggling bunches of twos and threes the exiles from Cripple Creek are making their way back to the hills. A few stopped in Lamar to-day and talked freely. Hans Hansen said:

The largest sum ever awarded in a civil suit in Brooklyn is involved in the verdict of $1,112,000 handed down by a jury in Part VI. of the Kings County Supreme Court, in favor of Morris C. Menges in his suit against Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, Vice President of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad Company, and Director of many large corporations.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., June 14. -- Mistaken for a highwayman, Frank Reineck, sixteen years old, was stabbed to the heart by his father, Walter Reineck, in a dark piece of woods near their home, in East Riverside, at 10:15 o'clock last night.

Out of an offer from John D. Rockefeller to contribute toward lifting the mortgage of the Washington Heights Baptist Church, at Convent Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, there has grown a row that threatens to disrupt the organization, depopulate the hitherto well-filled pews, and perhaps oust the minister from his position.

EGG HARBOR, N.J., June 14. -- Benjamin E. Boleman of this city is under arrest, charged with attempting to murder his wife. Boleman, it is asserted, went to a drug store yesterday, and bought chloroform on the pretense that he wanted to kill his cats. His wife says that he waited until his family was asleep and then put a towel saturated with the drug over her face.

The final trials of the Suburban Handicap horses were held on the Long Island race tracks yesterday morning, when all the prominent entries except Irish Lad that worked the day before, 'and the horses that ran in the Brookdale Handicap in the afternoon at Gravesend, were out for fast gallops.

The stock market yesterday recovered from Monday's temporary depression, and in some parts of the list so much strength was shown that in market comments that made their appearance in the Street yesterday a place was again given to the long-disused word "buoyancy." In the tractions, and in Manhattan in particular, the trading was sufficiently animated to revive the belief that the market had not altogether forgotten its old ways.

WASHINGTON, June 14. -- Secretary of the Navy Moody is to succeed Mr. Knox as Attorney General. It was the intention of Mr. Moody to retire from the Navy Department at the close of President Roosevelt's term in March next and to resume the practice of his profession. The Navy Department is not entirely to his liking, and the tender of the office of Attorney General was gladly accepted by him.

BERLIN, June 14. -- The Empress to-day received at the Schloss twenty-one members of the International Council of Women. Mrs. May Wright Sewall of Indianapolis, in an interview after the reception, said that throughout the conversation, which lasted an hour and a half, the Kaiserin gave the impression that she entirely sympathized with the progressive movement of women throughout the world.
Eugene Zimmerman issued this statement at the Lotos Club last night relative to the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad:

WHITE PLAINS, June 14. -- A supplemental accounting was filed to-day by the executors of the estate of J. Jennings McComb. Mrs. Fannie McComb Herzog brought proceedings to compel the executors to render an accounting, and they filed a partial statement in March last. The supplemental accounting filed to-day covers everything up to June 1.
RICHMOND, Va., June 14. -- Carlton McCarthy, Democrat, was elected Mayor of Richmond to-day with a full Democratic Board of Aldermen and Councilmen.

PARKDALE, Col., June 14. -- The special deportation train from Victor bearing miners from the Cripple Creek district reached here this evening at 6 o'clock. At the station where the men were transferred to a Denver and Rio Grande train for the West, a great crowd had gathered. Several hundred union men in sympathy with the men being deported began to hurl epithets at the Guardsmen.
In a recent issue The Toronto Globe says:

BOSTON, June 14. -- The Transcript says that the control of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton has been purchased by a syndicate of New York capitalists, with which are several members of the Pere Marquette people, but which does not in any way represent the Pere Marquette Railroad Company.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 14. -- J.H. Harding, a resident of Philadelphia, lost a satchel containing diamonds and jewelry worth $10.000 from his automobile while on his way to his Summer home, at Monmouth Beach, with his family yesterday afternoon. To-day the valuables were returned to him intact by Mrs. Thomas Rooney of Hightstown.

VICTOR, Col., June 14. -- The Cripple Creek district has been cleaned up. So far as is known, there is not a member of the Western Federation of Miners or a sympathizer of this organization who is at large in Teller County to-day.

From the beginning to the end of the game at the Polo Grounds yesterday the New Yorks kept the St. Louisians well in check and won by a score of 6 to 1. "Jake" Beckley saved his team from a shut-out by hitting the ball to deep centre field for three bases, and on Smoot's rather long fly to Browne "Old Eagle Eye" scored.

Sweetser, Pembrook Co., the dry goods jobbing house which is in liquidation, yesterday paid a dividend of 50 per cent. to all its creditors. Much secrecy was preserved as to the total amount of the dividend and the total amount of the firm's liabilities. Howard P. Sweetser declined to tell what the firm owed.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 14. -- Secretary of War Taft, Sir Mortimer Durand, the British Ambassador: Lieut. Gen. Chaffee, Major Gen. Corbin, Col. Foster of the British Army, and Major von Etzel of the German Military Staff arrived here today, and were met at the railroad station by Brig. Gen. A.L. Mills, his military staff, and an escort of cavalry.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 14. -- The Vazvedchik, the leading service magazine, in reviewing the war, arrives at the conclusion that after three and a half months the Russians find themselves exactly where they expected to be, while the Japanese are behindhand.
That the commercial policy prescribed by Congress for the Philippines should excite foreign protest is not remarkable. What is remarkable is that the protest should not have been heard earlier.

LONDON, June 14. -- There are some indications of a possible ending of the Atlantic rate war. It is reported that terms of settlement were discussed at a conference held at Liverpool to-day. No details are given, but it is said that terms of agreement for all lines sailing from British ports were under consideration.

BRYANTSVILLE, Ind., June 14. -- Three men are dead and two wounded, one fatally, as the result of a pistol fight on the streets of this village to-day. The dead are James and Charles Rout and Milton Tow. James Tow is fatally wounded and Frank Tow is badly hurt.

The item in to-day's TIMES about the sad fate of an albino robin at Chatham, N.J., reminds me of a similar fate which was visited last Summer upon an albino crow in this neighborhood. This unfortunate bird was one of a large flock that frequented the fields and shores near Crab Meadow on the north shore near here.

A husband and father, a stranger to Philander C. Knox, called upon him in the hope that he would find counsel which might restore a shanghaied son to his home. A mother's health was at stake; reason was threatened. Mr. Knox manifested a degree of sympathy such as an old friend or relative would display.

Owing to the discontinuance of the traffic agreement between the Minneapolis and St. Louis and the Rock Island, and because of the falling off in earnings of the former road, the Directors of the Minneapolis and St. Louis yesterday decided to pass the dividend on the common stock and at the same time declared the usual semi-annual dividend of 2 1/2 per cent. on the preferred.

Reading Mrs. Ford's letter in yesterday's TIMES, in which she advocates the abolition of three branches from the elementary schools. I, as a mother of a pupil in said schools heartily indorse her opinion. I wish she would use her influence in abolishing the cooking lessons, particularly.

Chinatown last night was plunged in a gloom worse than Cimmerian, and, notwithstanding the fact that the chop suey restaurants were more crowded than usual, there was an air of silent preoccupation overhanging the habitues of Mott and Pell Streets.

Thus sang the small boy and all his chums in the lower part of old Greenwich Village yesterday. And as they sang they peered into holes and crevices in the sidewalk, into back yards, and ash cans, and locked quizzically at each other.

CHICAGO, June 14. -- Interest in the Wisconsin factional fight was created to-day by the presence in the city of Senators Spooner and Quarles, Congressman Babcock, and E.L. Phillip, the leader of the Stalwarts in the State. All of them had conferences with Chairman Payne of the National Committee, but the conferences brought no result.

You take the negroes of New York to task for their ill-advised attempt to make a race issue of the arrest and prosecution of a notorious woman. I sternly protest against your statement that we are making or seeking to make a race issue out of an episode so singularly disgusting in its published details that I am unable to understand why they are even published.

All three of the leaders in the National League were beaten yesterday, Cincinnati losing the first double-header of the season at Brooklyn. New York still leads Chicago a game and Cincinnati by two games. All the Western teams in the American League were successful, New York being the only Eastern nine to score a run.

An estimated total of a thousand dead, besides several hundred injured, is the record of the fire disaster which yesterday destroyed the big excursion steamer General Slocum, which was burned to the water's edge before her Captain succeeded in beaching her on North Brother Island.

JACKSON, Miss., June 15. -- The Democratic State Convention late this afternoon instructed the delegates from Mississippi to the National Convention to vote for Alton B. Parker so long as there warn any chance for his nomination.
DENVER, June 15. -- An evening paper says:

MOSCOW, June 15. -- The Berlin correspondent of the Novoe Vremya telegraphs that the Japanese attacking Port Arthur are doomed, adding:

Wall Street was roused out of its lethargy yesterday by the announcement, made unofficially but sufficiently authenticated to give complete credit to it, that the directors of the Southern Pacific Company had authorized the issue of $100,000,000 of 7 per cent. preferred stock, of which $40,000,000 was to be issued at once.
About three hundred delegates gathered at the Hotel Savoy yesterday to attend the annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men. Forty-one cities were represented.

The orator of the day, Henry Watterson, said in part:

The General Slocum was one of the best known vessels about New York Harbor. PRINCETON, N.J., June 15. -- The one hundred and fifty-seventh annual commencement exercises were held this morning in Alexander Hall.

TANGIER, June 15. -- I am informed that Raisuli, notified by the Sultan's deputy that all his terms have been granted and that some are already actually in execution, now makes further extensive demands, to which the Moorish authorities will probably agree. Under cumstances it is impossible to say wheth-the circumstances it is impossible to say whether the new demands will not followed by still more, of a nature impossible even to surmise.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 16. -- Not since the war began has such excitement been apparent at the War and Naval Ministries as now reigns there. With an encounter between the opposing fleets imminent and heavy fighting in progress south of Vafangow, news both from the land and sea is awaited with feverish anxiety.

Overshadowed as it was by the importance of the Suburban Handicap to be run to-day, the close of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's Spring meeting on the Gravesend track yesterday vastly exceeded expectations in the size of the crowd that it attracted and in the excellence of the sport provided.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission handed down its decision yesterday relative to the appointment of Dr. William P. Spratling, formerly Superintendent of Craig Colony for Epileptics at Sonyea in the Genesee Valley, who was recently appointed by the Trustees of Bellevue and allied hospitals as head of Bellevue.

W.E.D. Stokes and the Onward Construction Company were made defendants in a suit to recover $73,665.79 brought by George Neidlinger as assignee of the claim of the Vinton Company, and which was brought on for trial before Justice D. Cady Herrick, sitting in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon.

The greatest stroke of ill-luck that could have befallen Mr. MURPHY and the other opponents of Judge PARKER'S candidacy in this State is the adhesion of Mr. W.J. BRYAN to their cause. Naturally the opposition of Mr. BRYAN is to be set down as a piece of good fortune for Judge PARKER.

VILIA GROVE, Col., June 15. -- " Give me liberty or give me death!" The speaker was one of thirty-six union men deported from the Cripple Creek district. He was an Americanized German, and the accent still clung. He stood on the monument marking the line between Colorado and New Mexico.

Stories told by the survivors of the burning of the General Slocum give a disjointed but vivid picture of the terrible swiftness with which death swept the vessel, of the panic which raged over her decks, and of the sudden tragedy which took hundreds of the helpless. Many of those who were rescued have no very clear idea of how they escaped.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- In the easiest imaginable manner English Lad, the American Derby favorite, won the Derby Trial Special at Harlem today, making the balance of his field look cheap. Lonsdale finished second, while Elwood was a close third. The time of 2:08 2-5 for the mile and a quarter was slow, but English Lad could have covered the distance much faster had he been urged.

LONDON, June 15. -- The contributions to the fund being collected in London for the relief of the widows and families of the Japanese killed in battle in the Far East amount to over u16,000, and additional contributions are coming in every day.

TOKIO, June 15. -- Three Japanese transports, outward bound from Shimonoseki for the army bases in Korea and Manchuria, met the Russian Vladivostok squadron this morning outside the Strait of Korea. The Russians fired eighteen shots at the Japanese ships.

LONDON, June 16. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Tokio, filed yesterday afternoon, said a naval engagement was then in progress off Tsushima Island, in Korea Strait, between three Russian cruisers, which escaped from Vladivostok, and a number of Japanese ships.

The General Slocum had not finished burning before the news of the disaster had reached the offices of her owners, the Knickerbocker Steamboat Company, on the third floor of the building at 149 Broadway. Five men were at once dispatched under the direction of James K. Atkinson, the Secretary and General Passenger Agent of the company, to give what assistance they could and to get a full report of the matter for the company.

LONDON, June 16 (Thursday.) -- Dispatches from Tokio to The Daily Chronicle and The Daily Express, dated yesterday, say news has been received there, but has not yet been officiall published, of a great Japanese victory near Fu-Chow, on the railway, seventy miles north of Port Arthur.

No tale could more fully combine the elements of pity and horror than that we have to tell to-day. GYANG-TSE, June 15. -- The British have captured a Lama who has just arrived in this vicinity from Lhasa.
Manhattan and the Bronx are now threatened with a general strike of the 9,000 bricklayers in their nine unions. A practical tie-up of the entire building industry may result.

SOUTH ORANGE, June 15. -- The forty-eighth annual commencement of Seton College was held to-day in the open air on the campus. Dean Joseph M. Flynn of Morristown delivered the address to the graduates. One of the principal features of the exercises was the awarding of the Knights of Columbus Medal to former United States Senator James Smith, Jr., of New Jersey.

It is an extraordinary tragedy that changes the entire aspect of New York's swarming east side, that makes its echo heard on every street corner, that fills the streets with lamentations, and makes the tens of thousands almost forget their business, their pleasures, and even their individual troubles.

CHICAGO, June 15. -- Preliminary to more extended meeting to-morrow, when a number of contests will be heard, some of which may be brought before the National Republican Convention Tuesday, the National Committee met this afternoon in its rooms in the Coliseum.

ST. LOUIS, June 15. -- Judge Thayer of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting in Chambers, has granted a writ of habeas corpus to have Charles Moyer, President of the Western Federation of Miners brought before him on July 5.

WASHINGTON, June 15. -- The letter addressed to the President by James N. Tyner regarding the utterances of the former, in which Mr. Tyner was characterized as the "chief offender" in the Post Offices cases was the subject of a conference to-day at the White House between the President, Attorney General Knox, and the special counsel of the Government in the trial of Tyner and Barrett.

With a field of only seven horses announced to start, the race for the Suburban Handicap, oldest and most popular of the great Spring turf events for mature horses, will be run this afternoon at the Sheepshead Bay course, and will give occasion for the greatest racing holiday of the New York turf season.

TOKIO, June 15. -- 2. flotilla of torpedo boats and torpedo boat destroyers under the command of Capt. Tsuchiya, co-operating with the army, made a reconnaissance in force near Siao-Ping Island yesterday and bombarded the Russian outposts on the coast to the west of the island. (Siao-Ping Island is twelve miles to the west of Port Arthur.)
ST. PETERSBURG, June 16. -- The War Office announces that Gen. Stakelberg was forced back before greatly superior numbers and retreated northward.

That even the Southern Pacific incident could not lessen the interest of Exchange members in yesterday's race seemed pretty clearly demonstrated by the way in which the market faded away after 12 o'clock. In the first hour nearly 140,000 shares were dealt in -- between 1 o'clock and 2 less than 10,000 shares.

TANGIER, June 16. -- Raisuli's new demand is the Governorship of the four large tribes which extend from the gates of Tangier nearly to Larache and Alcazar, covering some 500 square miles. The Moorish Government concedes the demand.

In considering the reported sortie of Vice Admiral SKRYDLOFF'S squadron from Vladivostok it is difficult to form an accurate estimate of the probable result, owing to the lack of news concerning the vessels detailed by Japan to look after the Russian fleet. All the features of the escaping ships are known, but practically nothing can be learned about the vessels that have been in pursuit.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- A rigid investigation of the General Slocum disaster has been ordered by Secretary Cortelyou of the Department of Commerce and Labor. It will be conducted by the Steamboat Inspection Service under the direction of George Uhler, Supervising Inspector General. Gen. James A. Dumont and Thomas H. Barrett, constituting the local Board of Steamboat Inspectors in New York, will have active charge of the inquiry.

An unidentified elderly man, who wore good clothing, but had little money on his person, was run over early last evening at Broadway and Twenty-fifth Street by one of the huge electric omnibuses of the Automobile Observation Company, and almost instantly killed.

It is satisfactory to note that public opinion is being aroused on the subject of the wanton destruction of shade trees by the servants of telephone, telegraph, and electric light companies, who are sent out to string wires and who carry the implements with which to make short work of a tree which they deem in the way of their operations.

In connection with to-day's disaster in the General Slocum, it may interest those who ride on excursion steamers around New York to know that on some steamers the life preservers are carried under the deck, with the consent and approval of the Government Inspectors!

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 16. -- The Atlantic City Jubilee was to-day turned into a fete and to-night visitors and residents are vieing with each other to make the occasion one of lively pleasure. The brightly lighted streets and boardwalks are filled with a happy crowd. Fifty thousand people are estimated to have lined the beach and boardwalk to witness the fireworks display.

HOMBURG, Prussia, June 16. -- Emperor William and the Empress arrived here today to attend the automobile contest for the James Gordon Bennett Cup to-morrow. There was considerable excitement this morning during the weighing of the cars which are to compete for the trophy. A lighted match carelessly thrown down ignited petrol which was escaping from one of the cars and the whole street became stream of flame, causing a panic among the spectators.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 16. -- The oil war now raging in Augusta promises to cost the Standard Oil Company $2,000,000. To-night the losses of the Standard Company are estimated at $800,000 in two days' fighting.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16. -- The discovery was made to-day by the caretaker that Mrs. Julia Ward Howe's Summer residence in Portsmouth had been broken into and ransacked. Several rooms which had been locked were forced open and the contents scattered about.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, June 15. (by steamer to Manzanillo, June 16.) -- The worst storm of a decade began Friday and culminated Monday night in fourteen inches of rain, which fell in five hours, accompanied by a hurricane.

The Executive Board of the Elevator Constructors' International Union met at the Ashland House last evening and ordered an international strike against the Otis Elevator Company. Notifications were sent to all the local unions in New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, Pittsburg, Cleveland, New Orleans, Baltimore, Washington, San Francisco, St. Louis, Milwaukee, Kansas City, St. Paul, Minneapolis, Omaha, Buffalo, Rochester, Montreal, and Toronto.

WASHINGTON, June 16. -- The announcement is made that Major Gen. Henry C. Corbin, now in command of the Atlantic Division and Department of the East, is to succeed Major Gen. James F. Wade in command of the Philippines Division.

If in the platform it adopts the Democratic Convention at St. Louis altogether ignores the money question, its action will be construed as a sensible recognition of the fact that the currency is not an issue before the people. In the view of candid men that would be an ample recantation of the errors and heresies to which the party was committed under the fatal leadership of BRYAN. Partisan opponents are not candid, however.

CRIPPLE CREEK, Col., June 16. -Assitant District Attorney S.D. Crump to-day wired Sheriff Rulan, at Telluride, to hold Charles H. Moyer, President of the Western Federation of Miners, until K.C. Sterling, a secret service agent of the Mine Owners' Association, can bring him to Cripple Creek. Sterling left this afternoon for Telluride.

GUANTANAMO, Cuba, June 15 -- (Delayed in transmission.) -- The most severe storm on record has swept over Guantanamo. There were showers all Monday, and at night a steady downpour of rain began, lasting til noon Tuesday.

Five newly discovered sayings of Jesus Christ, with a fragment of a lost Gospel, have just been published by the Oxford University Press of London and New York for the Egypt Exploration Fund. These discoveries form the second chapter in the remarkable results of the excavations in the ancient Egyptian City of Oxyrhyncus by Dr. Bernard P. Grenfell and Dr. Arthur S. Hunt of Oxford.
LONDON, June 16. -- Money was plentiful in the market to-day, and there was a moderate demand.

Shipping men yesterday expressed diverse opinions concerning the action of Capt. Van Schaick of the General Slocum in beaching his vessel on North Brother Island. In every steamboat office the chart of the waters about Hell Gate was carefully gone over in considering whether or not the Captain of the vessel did all that he could have done to save the lives of his passengers.

There is, it seems to me, great danger that the moral lesson of the loss of the Slocum will be diverted to the wrong object. Much is made in most articles upon the subject of the "antiquated" character of the boat, of the facts that she was a side-wheeler, and that she had a wooden hull.

The second day's session of the annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men was held on board the steamboat Rosedale yesterday, and only lasted two hours. The remainder of the day was given up to enjoyment, the boat making the trip to West Point and returning late in the evening.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 16. -- The Yale crew rowed two miles in 10:05 this evening under unfavorable weather conditions. Despite the rough water, the men rowed down to the navy yard and raced with the freshmen homeward. The first crew pulled an even stroke and beat the freshmen easily.

After studying the United States by sightseeing, the native members of the Honorary Philippine Commission of Visitation to the United States have come to the conclusion that they like our form of government and believe it applicable to their own. They believe that it is time for an election at home, and that the sooner representatives of a native congress are elected the better for both countries.

Notwithstanding the declaration of the first mate of the General Slocum that his effort to fight the fire was made useless because the hose burst in many places, and the testimony of investigators that the canvas covers of life belts had rotted, the local officials of the United States Steamboat Inspection Service yesterday declared that the life-saving appliances were in good order.

Police Commissioner McAdoo visited the scene of the wreck yesterday and directed the work of the police on North Brother Island personally. When the Commissioner returned to Police Headquarters he expressed the opinion that the excursion boats in and about New York Harbor needed to be thoroughly inspected.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 16. -- The Alabama Daughters of the Confederacy asked the United Confederate Veterans in session here to let them revise the words of "Dixie," the greatest war tune of the South. The request was the occasion for a tremendous outburst of opposition on the part of the entire assemblage.

The fact that within a few weeks the steamer General Slocum was "inspected" by officers of the Steamboat Inspection Service and certified in good condition for the business in which she was to be employed during the excursion season calls attention to the perfunctory manner in which such inspections are made and the ease with which certificates may be obtained as to conditions which, on critical investigation, would be found to be all wrong.

CHICAGO, June 16. -- Senator Fairbanks, on his arrival here to-morrow, will have to declare whether or not he is a candidate for Vice President or practically put himself out of consideration for the nomination. This was the decision reached by members of the National Committee informally to-day.

Burns, President and manager of the Portland Mine, in a damage suit which Burns will bring against Gov. James H. Peabody, Adjt. Gen. Sherman M. Bell and the State of Colorado, for $100,000, for the closing of the Portland Mine by the military.

TOKIO, June 16. -- The Russian hope of relieving the pressure on Port Arthur by threatening the rear of Gen. Oku, the commander of the Japanese forces investing the Russian stronghold, came to an end yesterday at Telissu, a point on the railroad fifty miles north of Kin-Chow and twenty-five miles north of Vafangow, where the Russians were outmanoeuvred, enveloped, and sweepingly defeated.

There were only seven entries for the fifty-eighth annual regatta of the New York Yacht Club, sailed over the club course on New York Bay yesterday, and one of these failed to appear at the starting line, reducing the actual number of competitors to six. Of these two were schooners and four were sloops.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 16. -- Gen. Bobrikoff, Governor General of Finland, was shot and mortally wounded at 11 o'clock this morning at the entrance to the Finnish Senate at Helsingfors.
PARIS, June 16. -- I was informed to-day by a personage in very close touch with the best sources of Russian news that the next move which Japan was expected to make would be relative to Siberia.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 16. -- The Young Men's Christian Association tents, the popular civilian feature of the State camp of military instruction, were crowded last night at an entertainment and reception.

With a class of 154 new lawyers, the New York Law School held its commencement for 1904 last evening in Carnegie Hall. George Case, Dean of the Law School, presided. The Rev. Ezra Squier Tipple, D.D., offered prayer, and the address to the graduating class was delivered by Frank Sullivan Smith, member of the New York State Board of Examiners.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 16. -- There was a strong police force in the Academy of Music to-night at the commencement exercises of the Western Female High School. The public school authorities feared a disturbance by City College boys and others should an attempt be made to give Miss Leila Bangert her diploma as a graduate.

In the streets of "Little Germany," as its peaceful folk have named that section of the city stretching from First to Seventh Street, there was neither dancing nor music yesterday. The avenues and by-ways that for a score of years have been famous for their outdoor gaieties were silent. The sunshine that beat down upon the crowded pavements was greeted by an answering sob.

With every hour grows the horror of the disaster that visited the excursion party of women and children from St. Mark's German Lutheran Church, when the General Slocum, with the excursionists on board, was burned at North Brother Island on Wednesday. It seems probable that more than 900 persons lost their lives by fire or or in the river, and the list may grow larger.

The Republican Party is committed to the doctrine that it is a good thing that the cost of living should be high. The country has not forgotten President HARRISON'S extraordinary discovery that a cheap coat was usually worn by a cheap man. Now comes Secretary SHAW, with hands and eyes piously uplifted as he utters this prayer: "May the good Lord deliver us from another period when living expenses are cheap."
TOKIO, June 16. -- The Russian force at the battle of Telissu is believed to have been an army sent by Gen. Kuropatkin to hamper the Japanese operations on the Liao-Tung Peninsula.

A vote on the proposition to allow the New York and New Jersey Railroad Company to construct a trolley spur under Ninth Street from Christopher Street to Fourth Avenue could not be had yesterday by the Rapid Transit Commission, owing to the absence of Mayor McClellan and Commissioner Jesup, Commissioner Claflin, was against the project, but he announced that he would not vote.
