N.B. Thurston, who accompanied the battery on its march.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 19. -- Emperor Nicholas has received the following dispatch, dated June 19, from Vice Admiral Skrydloff:

TOKIO, June 19. -- Scouts having brought news that the Russians were massing a large army at Telissu, (Vafangow,) twenty-eight miles north of Polan-Tien, evidently with the intention of attempting to force the Pitsewo -- Polan-Tien line, which forms the northern gate of the peninsula, Gen. Oku resolved to assume the offensive.

The Democratic Party in its whole history has rarely had such an opportunity as presents itself now to insure party success, and at the same time to advance the welfare of the whole country. Seldom has there been a period when the need of larger and broader foreign markets has been so urgent and so palpable, or when the absence of such markets was working greater harm to all industrial interests.

The Slocum's nameless dead, buried Saturday, tier on tier, in a grim trench in the Lutheran Cemetery, Middle Village, Long Island, were remembered yesterday by the little children of the Trinity Evangelical Church there, who marched to the cemetery with arms full of flowers and smothered the unmarked graves beneath fragrant blossoms.
PLYMOUTH, June 20. -- The Kaiser Wilhelm II. arrived here at 1:57 o'clock this morning.

George Westinghouse has sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES a circular recently issued by the Board of Trade of Great Britain in regard to the precautions to be taken against the risk of fire and accident on underground electric railways. As the New York subway is nearing completion, the British circular will form interesting reading matter at this time.

The Electrical Review uses a silly argument when it implies that those who do not own an automobile are envious of those who do. The writer, and there are thousands like him, would not give a dollar for the finest automobile ever built.
LONDON, June 20. -- The correspondent of The Daily Mail at Tangier, under date of June 19, says that a letter was received that day from Raisuli, in which the bandit said:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 19. -- Chaunccy Hotaling, aged forty years, was placed in jail here this afternoon charged with the murder of his three-year-old blind son, whom he had always abhorred because of the child's infirmities, and the attempted murder of his wife.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- When William Loeb, Jr., secretary to President Roosevelt, left Chicago for Washington to-night he was the bearer of a message of protest on the part of the National Committee against the selection of George B. Cortelyou for National Chairman.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., June 19. -- Henry Grauman, a farmer living near this city, was driving along the Philadelphia and Atlantic City turnpike to-night just outside of this city when his carriage was hit by a large automobile said to belong to a resident of Philadelphia.

LIAO-YANG, June 18, (Delayed.) -- The Japanese continued to press the Russian forces returning from the battle of Vafangow on the night of June 16. They had remained at Vafangow all day and at night persistently pushed forward and tried to get round the Russian right wing, which had borne the brunt of such heavy fighting the previous day.

ORANGE, N.J., June 19. -- Nine of the forty-four men who went on the annual outing of the East Orange City Council yesterday reached their homes late this afternoon, having been oblized to spend the night in the town of Newfoundland, out of reach of either telephone or telegraph.

Memorial services were held yesterday in churches all over the city for those who perished in the Slocum disaster, and special prayers were said by the congregations. In the stricken district every church without respect to creed was draped in deepest mourning. In many of these and other churches the collections taken were for the swelling of the fund now being collected for the benefit of the sufferers.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Ex-Secretary Elihu Root had an hour's conference this afternoon with Senator Platt, during which Senator Platt told Mr. Root that he would like to see him nominated for Governor of New York, and Mr. Root replied that he did not want the nomination and would not accept it.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Senator Lodge arrived to-day. His coming has been anxiously awaited by those interested in the declaration of principles that will be made in the platform, which it is understood has been prepared and is in his possession.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 19. -- In what is said to be an effort to compromise the divorce proceedings of Lawrence C. Phipps against his wife, the attorneys of both sides have been in conference all of to-day and to-night.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- From all parts of the country delegates poured into Chicago to-day to attend the Republican National Convention on Tuesday. Enthusiasm and bands were conspicuously missing, the only band to arrive being one with the Pennsylvania delegates. The Pennsylvania band brings the grand total of bands that have come to two, the other being from Hawaii.

CHICAGO, June 19. -- Congressman William L. Ward of Westchester is to be the next National Committeeman from New York to succeed George R. Sheldon. This was definitely decided upon by the New York delegation to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- President Roosevelt, who with Mrs. Roosevelt spent Sunday with Attorney General Knox on his farm at Valley Forge, visited the historic campground of Washington to-day. The forenoon was taken up with a long drive over the territory, visits being made to Washington's headquarters and other places.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 19. -- Application for a new trial will be made in the case of Anna Valentina, who was convicted of the murder of Rosa Salza of Lodi, on the ground that the woman is insane and has for some time exhibited insane tendencies.

A careful revision of THE TIMES'S list of the missing in the Slocum disaster shows that the correct figure yesterday morning was 262. Allowing for deduction of bodies identified yesterday and the addition of those newly discovered missing the total is now 258. The total number of bodies recovered is 628.

The passengers on the steamship Etruria of the Cunard Line were somewhat puzzled by an addition to the ship's bulletin printed on board, which was handed to them as they went to breakfast yesterday morning while the ship was lying in Quarantine, waiting to be passed by the health officer.

In the play for the championshln in men's singles in the tournament of the East Jersey Lawn Tennis Association, a feature on Saturday at the Jersey City Golf Club was the vietory of C. C. Shaw, a promising young player of the Bergen Point Lawn Tennis Club, over A{. S.'-C'harnock of the Elizabeth Town and CoQntry Club.
CHICAGO, June 19. -- There was a conference of the Illinois delegation to-day at the Auditorium, at which it was decided to begin an aggressive campaign in favor of Representative Hitt.

Three persons were burned through a boy throwing a lighted firecracker into a One Hundred and Sixteenth Street cross-town car at Lexington Avenue last night. They are Edith Meisner, fifteen years old, of 51 East One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, slightly burned about the body; her mother, Mrs. Fanny Meisner, burned about the hand, and Jacob Lowry of 67 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, burned about the hands.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 19. -- After making several attempts in the last few weeks to rent a cottage along the North Jersey coast for the Summer, and failing to do so each time, Hannah Elias of New York has finally obtained one at Long Branch.
CHICAGO, June 19. -- The scare movement started yesterday by Gov. Odell and his associates of the New York delegation over the Vice Presidency subsided this morning.

BENNINGTON, Vt., June 19. -- Gideon C. Burton, a native of this town and proprietor of a job printing office in New York, committed suicide by shooting, at the grave of his daughter here to-day. Burton was sixty-seven years of age and came here this morning from Brooklyn with the expressed determination, it is said, of killing himself.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 19. -- The iron has entered into the soul of John Farr of Short Hills. Mr. Farr lives on Forest Drive. He is Treasurer of the Baltusrol Golf Club, a member of the Board of Education, but, much more, he is a member of the Short Hills Protective Association, which seeks to drive away from Short Hills the burglars which occasionally visit the rural community.

CHESTER, Penn., June 19. -- Four boys standing under a cherry tree on a farm near Felton, three miles from here, were killed by lightning to-day. They were Ross Smith, aged thirteen years, son of the owner of the farm; Alexander Fullerton, thirteen years old, Felton; William Davis, fourteen years old, Upland, and Samuel Clerk, fifteen years old, colored, Chester.

It is a rather sorry lot of Republican war horses that have been conferring together at Chicago and exhibiting their galls and sore spots to each other and to a not very sympathetic world. In fact, since death removed HANNA and QUAY and illness incapacitated Postmaster General PAYNE, the Republican Party has had no war horse ready to take the field at Chicago.

Miss Jessie Crosby, who lives with her father at the Marie Antoinette Hotel, at Sixty-sixth Street and Broadway, is the person whose apartment was entered some time ago and from which about $2,000 worth of jewelry was stolen. James Dunsmore and Robert Hall are the names given by two men now under arrest in Baltimore charged with the theft of the jewels, and, according to advices from that city, they admit having committed the crime.

TOKIO, June 19. -- The raid of the Vladivostok squadron has brought a great amount of criticism upon Vice Admiral Kamimura, and his failure to catch the Russians in the fog off Gen-San, Korea, when the Japanese transport Kinshiu was sunk on April 26 with a loss of about 200 men, has been recalled.

The singing of an old Finnish battle song by the Swedish Students' Chorus of the Lund University at their concert in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon provoked a demonstration the like of which has seldom been witnessed in this city. Men and women sprang from their seats with shining-eyes, handkerchiefs fluttered in the air, and a cheer was sent up that shook the hail and could be heard a block away.

As the Republican National Committee is bound by its contract with the hotel keepers of Chicago to give them a chance at the convention "guests" for at least three days, and as the work cut out for the convention need not last for more than two days, and could really be done in one day, perhaps it will take up the question of correcting the gross over-representation of the Republicans in Democratic States.

A forward heel of a big tally-ho that was returning with a party of twelve men from an outing at Ridgewood broke in Myrtle Avenue, near Navy Street, Brooklyn, late last night. The coach upset and nearly all of the twelve men were thrown out to the street.

If that spectacular set of young and old men, until Saturday known as county detectives, but who now are just simple every-day subpoena servers, accountable for their every official act to Chief Clerk Henneberry of the District Attorney's office, wish to keep their jobs, they will have to show results.

A number of our State Legislatures have recently attacked the business of life insurance indirectly through a tax imposed upon the premiums paid to the various companies as well as by an increase in already existing taxation. Such a proceeding is both unwise and unjust.

For the second consecutive week the business in the security market shows marked improvement. Fifty-four shares moved a point or more, and only twenty-one declined. Forty-one bonds made a similar movement, and only three declined. The list is so short that it is well to give it -- Buffalo Gas 5s, 3 3/8; Central of New Jersey 5s, 1; Texas Pacific 2 per cent. incomes, 9.

The astonishing immunity of the street-car companies of this and neighboring cities from legal responsibility for the manner in which the electrical equipment of their cars is in many instances installed involves a wholly unnecessary danger to those who use their vehicles. If when a fuse "blows" a car takes fire it is prima facie evidence that the car is not properly equipped and that the insulation of its electrical conductors is imperfect.

ANDOVER, Mass., June 19. -- Commencement week at Phillips-Andover Academy was opened this afternoon with the baccalaureate sermon by the Rev. H.B. Frissell, Principal of the Hampton (Va.) Normal Institute. He said in part:

Franklin Eberhard, who lives at the Park Avenue Hotel, could not be found yesterday afternoon, the clerks at the hotel saying that he had not been there in two days. Several persons were anxious to find Mr. Eberhard. Mr. Eberhard is the head of the firm bearing his name, with offices at 16 and 18 Broad Street.

William J. Bryan arrived at the Hoffman House last night in company with M.F. Dunlap, the chief manager in Illinois for William R. Hearst, and through whose efforts much was done toward giving to the New York Representative the fifty-four delegates of that State.

Ai. J, IcGarr.v. the champion cross-countrY runner of ths Mot( Haven Athletic Club, won the mile handicap from scratch at the games of the club, held at the club grounds, One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street and Lincoln Avenue, yesterday afternoon in an exciting finish with J. Oberhaus. who had a start of 65 yards. Summary:
The report of the United States Realty and Construction Company covering the eleven months' business ending May 31 was made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Although a fairly good programme was offered at Washington Park to-day, not more than 2,000 persons saw the events run off. The same conditions that governed the racing Saturday prevailed to-day, the edict of Mayor Harrison against wagering money on the results being rigidly enforced.

Harlem River oarsmen are preparing a petition to Police Commissioner McAdoo requesting efficient protection against the stone-throwing hoodlums who infest the various bridges over the Harlem River and endanger their lives and property. Hardly an evening has passed during the past few weeks without one or more oarsmen being struck while passing under Central or Madison Avenue Bridge, or the partially completed Lenox Avenue Bridge at One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- Cardinal Satolli was the guest of honor at a dinner given to-night by Secretary of War Taft at the Arlington Hotel. Covers were laid for twenty persons. Those present included representative Government officials and well-known dignitaries of the Catholic Church.

TOKIO, June 20. -- The Russian squadron proceeding south from Vladivostok on June 13 plundered and sank two small Japanese sailing craft. The crew of one of these vessels was transferred to a third sailing ship, which was also was plundered. The fate of the crew of the second is uncertain.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 20. -- Lieut. Gen. Zilinsky, Chief of Staff to Viceroy Alexieff, has sent the following telegram to the Minister of War under date of June 19:

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- The will of Levi Z. Leiter was filed to-day. It is stated Jane 1 and names the widow and Joseph Leiter as executors. These two, with Seymour Morris and the daughters Nancy Lathrop Carver Leiter and Marguerite Hyde Leiter, are trustees.

Local oarsmen are interested in a plan for the removal of the ledge of rock which projects into the Harlem River from the Bronx shore just below the boathouses in McComb's Dam Park, and which prevents the use of the easterly channel under the central bridge except for boats of very light draught.

WASHINGTON, June 20. -- It can be stated with definiteness that Representative Victor H. Metcalf of the Third California District will succeed Secretary George B. Cortelyou as the head of the Department of Commerce and Labor. It has been assumed for ten days that Mr. Metcalf probably would be invited to accept the portfolio.
Irving P. Lovejoy has resold for John D. Crimmins to a client the entire block bounded by Third and Park Avenues, One Hundred and Eighty-eighth and One Hundred and Eighty-ninth Streets.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Sergeant at Arms Stone and his first assistant, Mr. Owen of Wisconsin, held a conference of their own this afternoon. They gathered their assistants and the ushers and pages in the convention hall to instruct them in their duties.

There were eighty-two interments of victims of the Slocum disaster at the Lutheran Cemetery in Middle Village yesterday. The largest funeral was that of Mrs. Amelia Richter of 406 Sixth Street, her three daughters, and her two sons. They were buried in a plot together. In another funeral there were five hearses carrying members of the same family.

Ninety-one more bodies were recovered yesterday, and 8 additional bodies between 12:30 and 1:30 o'clock this morning, at the scene of the Slocum disaster, making the total number of bodies recovered to date 727. The number of identified dead is 626. Allowing for identifications made yesterday, the list of the missing numbers 230, which, added to the identified dead, makes the probable total dead 856.

My attention has been called to a communication in THE TIMES of June 7 headed "Vail, Father of the Telegraph," and signed Stephen Vail. While I have no desire to enter into a newspaper controversy with Mr. Vail, and while I am sure that you have no desire to encourage one, I trust in justice to my father, Samuel F.B. Morse, you will allow me a few words in reply.

An automobilist who said that he was Maurice B. Mendham, a broker, of 20 Broad Street, and lived in Yonkers, tried to fight off Bicycle Policemen Kerrigan and Donohue with his cane at Fifty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue last evening, according to the police, when they were trying to arrest his chauffeur for illegal speeding, and was finally arrested on the charge of interfering.

Eight entries, all of them fast boats, have been received for the Challenge Cup series of races to be held under the auspices of the American Power Boat Association on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday over a thirty-two-mile course, starting from the Columbia Yacht Club, foot of West Eighty-sixth Street, and running to a point sixteen miles up the Hudson, the upper mark being placed about an eighth of a mile this side of Piermont.

MUNICH, June 20. -- The Provincial Court has dismissed the appeal of Herr Conrad, a Munich writer, from the decision rendered against him in a libel suit brought by Heinrich Conried, Director of the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, because of an attack made by the writer on the Director as a result of his production of "Parsifal."
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., June 20. -- Two hundred and two Chinamen, who have been confined at the detention house at Malone for eight months, left to-night for Hongkong by way of Vancouver.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 20. -- Gen. Kuropatkin has telegraphed to the Emperor under date of June 18 as follows:

The little fifty-four-foot fishing sloop Claude of Keyport, N.J., while making her way from Hell Gate into the Sound late yesterday afternoon, was run down by a railroad float loaded heavily with cars. The bow of the sloop was stove, while the shock of the collision dismasted her and she drifted on the Long Island shore at Astoria, a helpless wreck.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Charles Warren Fairbanks of Indiana will be the Republican candidate for Vice President. All doubts as to whom the convention will nominate for President Roosevelt's running mate was dispelled to-night by the New York delegation, which decided to cast its 78 votes as a unit for the Senator from Indiana.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20. -- When Reginald C. Vanderbilt sought to return to his Newport home some rather circumstantial stories were published about the bold way in which he took a train for New York and went there to the house of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Neilson.

The New York National League team had another walkover in the fourteenth game with Brooklyn at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the score being 12 to 4. The contest was on the burlesque order, so far as the Brooklyn team was concerned, and there were probably fewer people present than at any other game played at the Polo Grounds this year.

The most interesting topic of the opening week remains the one with which last week closed, and the course of prices attests an alteration of market estimation of the Southern Pacific proposal. Union Pacific was as steady as possible yesterday, too indifferently strong to afford a basis for last week's hasty inference that the Southern Pacific preferred stock issue was designed in Union Pacific's interest rather than in the interest of its subsidiary company.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- At a meeting tonight of the New York State delegation it was decided that the delegates should vote as a unit for the nomination of Theodore Roosevelt for President and Senator Fairbanks of Indiana for Vice President.
BUFFALO, June 20. -- The Buffalo Enquirer to-day published the following from Grover Cleveland, indorsing his former law partner, Charles W. Goodyear of Buffalo, for Governor:

In your issue of to-day you print an article entitled "Instruction in Garbage," and signed "A Mother." In this article she asks: "I would like to know why we mothers are obliged to submit to such an imposition?"

The increase in the number of Slocum victims' bodies found yesterday was hardly expected. Coroner O'Gorman of the Bronx had every available man at work, and there was a small fleet of volunteer boats, manned by searchers, who scanned the waters and made for every body that appeared.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- There is evident uneasiness among the "stand patters" regarding the platform. Those who desire some conservative declaration for a readjustment of duties to meet "changed and changing conditions," as Senator Hansbrough's resolution puts it, have been active during the day, and have discovered that they have the sympathy of a considerable number of delegates.

Largely as a result of an advance in Southern Pacific which exerted favorable influence on sentiment the stock market yesterday showed general improvement, although the net gains were for the most part restricted to fractions. The market was firmest during the early part of the session, the afternoon's trading showing more irregularity than had been displayed earlier.
LONDON, June 20. -- Sarah Bernhardt appeared at His Majesty's Theatre to-night in Sardou's "La Sorciere" before a large audience.

FAIR GROUND, L.I., June 20. -- Samuel Meringola, an Italian, forty-nine years of age, to-day killed his brother, Thomas Meringola, fifty-two years of age, with an axe, shot his niece, Mrs. Carman Pietra, and then tried to kill himself by cutting his throat.

BALTIMORE, June 20. -- Mrs. J.B. Crosby and her daughter, Miss Jessie Crosby, whose jewels, valued at $2,000, were stolen from their apartments, in the Hotel Marie Antoinette, New York City, to-day, in company with officers, visited the pawnshops here to recover the stolen goods pawned by the men arrested for the robbery.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Princeton University to-day defeated the University of Chicago in the first out-door track and field dual meet ever held between representatives of the two universities. Out of a total of 14 points, only first place figuring in the count, Princeton secured 7 1/2 points, while Chicago finished with 6 1/2.
Coroner Berry and a jury of fifteen men began an investigation yesterday into the disaster which occurred to the steamboat General Slocum on Wednesday last.

The President of the Knickerbocker Company is reported as having said, in answer to the assertion that the "life preservers" were rotten, that "it will often be found that if two people get hold of the same preserver, in the mad efforts of each to get it, it would easily be torn apart. Under such circumstances a new preserver would be torn as easily as an old one."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 20. -- The scene on the river this evening was one of greater activity than at any previous time since the rowing season began. It was at the last of the flood tide when the Cornell 'Varsity appeared shortly before 6 o'clock. The crew started on the finish line and ended the trial at the start of the four-mile course.

Everything pertaining to the candidacy of Judge Alton B. Parker was bitterly assailed last night at Cooper Union by William J. Bryan. Two thousand persons crowded into the hall and sweltered for two and one-half hours, while another 1,000 had something of a cooler time outside, because of a momentary rainfall.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 20. -- According to the Novoe Vremya, the Russian oil combinations have capitulated to the Standard Oil Company, and even the Rothschilds and Nobel interests have come to terms with the American concern.

A new scheme conceived by a former druggist has found so much inspiration among others that this evil has now reached considerable proportions. "Chemical" houses have set to work to make things easy for the doctor. Here are 48 preparations covering the "entire field of medicine."

Another will of a victim of the Slocum disaster was filed yesterday in the Surrogates' office. This was the will of Mrs. Martha Moeller of 20 St. Mark's Place. In it she mentions the fact that she has money on deposit in many New York Savings banks, and she appoints Dr. Robert Kunitzer of 188 Lenox Avenue as trustee to take charge of these deposits for the benefit of her children, Edwin and Henry Moeller.

I am a very recent graduate of Columbia, and my experiences in working my way through the four years' college course lead me to believe that your correspondents "Soixante" and "Engineer" are wrong in their conclusions. I came to the university from a distant State with little money and not a single friend or acquaintance in Columbia or the city.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 20. -- The News has received a cablegram from Hector Fuller, its special staff war correspondent, who was arrested on June 13 when he rowed to Port Arthur from the Miantoe Islands, giving the following account of his release and the situation inside the besieged fortress:

CHICAGO, June 20. -- Among the Republican leaders discussion of the probable outcome of the Democratic National Convention at St. Louis seems to be one of the most interesting of topics. This is largely because of the fact that everything at this convention is cut and dried, and the Republicans plainly are showing more interest in what the Democrats are doing than in what is going on here.

There are now on exhibition before the country two great party machines, which are attracting all the attention the American people are inclined to spare from their daily vocations and interests -- and this is much less this year than it has ever before been since the collapse of the Federalist Party some four score years ago.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 20. -- Michael J. Sullivan, the man who demanded $10,000 from President Mellen of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and promised in return to reveal the plot for wrecking the special train on that road, which bore the Connecticut delegation to the Chicago Convention, was arrested at Tunkhannock to-day.

An elderly gentleman, with trim gray beard and spotless white spats, dashed through the grove in the rear of the Sheepshead Bay grandstand after the last race yesterday afternoon, with a portly gentleman of no less distinguished appearance in pursuit, shouting "Hi, hi, there; stop him!"

CHICAGO, June 20. -- In the Great Northern Hotel, where Speaker Cannon has his headquarters and a number of the State delegations are located, there are conspicuous printed notices which have excited a great deal of comment. One reads as follows:

Franklin Everhart of the firm which bore his name, at 16 and 18 Exchange Place, is still missing, and there are many who would like to interview him, including Inspectors of the Post Office Department. Incidental to the absence of Everhart is the fact that the office of the United States Cereal Company of 27 William Street has been closed for some days to anxious inquirers.

The "fish in brine case," on which the attention of the entire fish trade, both in New York and Boston, has been fixed for several months, was decided yesterday by the Board of United States General Appraisers. General Appraiser Fischer wrote the decision, which is in favor of the importers.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- The Executive Committee of the League of Republican Clubs met to-day and decided to have the next meeting of the league at Indianapolis Oct. 5 and 6. The committee heard the report of President J. Hampton Moore and other officers. The following message from President Roosevelt was read:
CHICAGO, June 20. -- The Committee on Resolutions selected by the State delegations at their caucus to-day, from reports received at a late hour to-night, is made up as follows:
WARSAW, June 20. -- One of the first consequences of the Russo-Japanese war is the serious crippling of trade in Siberia, European Russia, the Caucasus, and Poland.

We credit Senator PLATT with entire sincerity and with loyalty to his party in urging ex-Secretary ROOT to accept the Republican nomination for Governor this Fall. He wants Mr. ROOT nominated because he feels that he is the best wheel horse the party possesses, and he knows that the heavy Republican stage-coach will have some pretty steep hills to climb in New York this Fall.

LIVERPOOL, June 20. -- The Haverford College cricket team arrived here yesterday on the Cunard liner Umbria. The team enjoyed the trip across and all were in perfect health. The team is under the management of Henry Cope and comprises the following players: C.C. Morris, H.H. Morris, A.G. Priestman, R.L. Pearson, H. Pleasants, Jr., R.P. Lowry, A.T. Lowry, W.P. Bonbright, F.D. Godley, A.H. Hopkins, E. Ritts, J.D. Phillips, H.W. Daughton, and E.E. Peirce.

Onatas, one of the high-priced horses bought by E.R. Thomas when the Thomas stable was formed last season, pulled up lame after the finish of the first race yesterday, and he probably will have to be retired permanently.

Philip Krantz jumped from the middle span of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday afternoon, and as a result, if he lives -- and the chances are that he will -- he must hereafter turn his left ear to those who want to communicate with him. He is in the Hudson Street Hospital, suffering from either a ruptured tympanum or fracture of the skull, the doctors do not know which yet.
PITTSBURG, June 20. -- A local newspaper to-morrow will say:

We read that there is great dissatisfaction in Japan with the action and inaction of Admiral KAMIMURA. It is strongly intimated to him that it is high time he should retire from the navy by resignation or from Life in the high Japanese fashion of hari-kari.

When an era of good feeling occurs in the press and controversies are carried on with a sweetness of courtesy which deprives them of much of their cogency and of all their hilariousness, the experienced observer knows that this is too sweet to last. He foresees that tempers must at last give way under the strain of the daily polemic, and awaits the reaction toward those refreshing personalities which show that editors are human.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- There is one woman delegate to the convention. She is Mrs. J.B. West of Lewiston, Idaho. It is by no means the first experience she has had at National Conventions, she having served as an alternate at the Philadelphia Convention four years ago.

It seems as if life preservers were purchased by the steamboat companies on the principle which prompted the old woman to select a straw bonnet when offered a choice between that and one of more substantial material, on the ground that when she was through with it "it would make a mouthful for the coo."

PARIS, June 20. -- The impression in the lobbies of the Chamber and in political circles generally is that evidence given to-day by M. Michel Lagrave, the French Commissioner General to the St. Louis Exposition in the matter of the Chartreux millions constitutes a terrible blow to the Combes Ministry, which it will with difficulty survive.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- When Gov. Odell was questioned to-night about the persistence of the Platt men in advocating the nomination of Elihu Root for Governor, despite the fact that Mr. Root told Senator Platt yesterday that he did not want the nomination and hoped discussion of his candidacy would stop, the only comment which the Governor would make ways: "We do not nominate a Governor of New York at a National Convention."

PLYMOUTH, England, June 20. -- The average speed of the North German Lloyd Line steamer Kaiser Wilhelm II., which arrived here at 1:57 this morning, for the 3,112 miles from Sandy Hook Lightship to Eddystone Lighthouse was 23.58 knots per hour, as compared with the 23.51 knots of the Deutschland of the Hamburg-American Line.

CHICAGO, June 20. -- When Gov. Odell was questioned to-night about the persistence of the Platt men in advocating the nomination of Elihu Root for Governor, despite the fact that Mr. Root told Senator Platt yesterday that he did not want the nomination and hoped discussion of his candidacy would stop, the only comment which the Governor would make ways: "We do not nominate a Governor of New York at a National Convention."

CHICAGO, June 21. -- A unanimous nomination for Fairbanks as well as Roosevelt is what is now being striven for, and the indications favor the attainment of that result. Many of the delegates, however, are exasperated with the conduct of Mr. Fairbanks in declining to make a straightforward statement regarding his desire for the nomination, and they would be pleased to see a vigorous opposition maintained to the last.

-- A Swedish paper prints what it says -- and the statement seems entirely credible -- is a copy of a letter addressed to the Czar and written by EUGENE SCHAUMANN just before he assassinated Gen. BOBRIKOFF. The original was in his pocket when he committed suicide, but, feeling sure that it would not be permitted to reach the Czar's eyes, he sent the copy to a friend outside of Finland for publication.

The circular issued by authority of the British Board of Trade relative to the construction and equipment of subways in London and other English cities, sent us by Mr. GEORGE WESTINGHOUSE and printed in THE TIMES of Monday, has rather more of technical than of popular interest.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 21. -- Mrs. Ogden Goelet arrived to-night and opened her villa, Ochre Court, for the season.

MOMBASA, British East Africa Protectorate, June 21. -- Sir Charles N.E. Eliot, British Commissioner and Commander in Chief for the East Africa Protectorate, has resigned the Commissionership because he is opposed to the proposed Jewish settlement in the protectorate.

VLADIVOSTOK, June 21. -- Lying in the harbor are the three Russian cruisers which have just returned from their successful raid in the Japanese Sea and Strait of Korea. Vice Admiral Bezobrazoff took the squadron out on June 12.

The New York Contracting and Trucking Company of 506 East Twentieth Street has been awarded the contract for excavating the site of the Pennsylvania Railroad terminal, bounded by Seventh and Ninth Avenues and Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets, by the Directors of the Pennsylvania, New York and Long Island Railroad Company.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- A commission, consisting of Lawrence O. Murray, Assistant Secretary of Commerce and Labor; Major General John M. Wilson, U.S.A., retired; Commander Cameron McR. Winslow, U.S.N.; Herbert Knox Smith, Deputy Commissioner of Corporations in the Department of Commerce and Labor, and George Uhler, Supervising Inspector General of the Steamboat Inspection Service, has been appointed to investigate the disaster to the General Slocum.
CHICAGO, June 21. -- Ex-Secretary Root's address as temporary Chairman of the convention was in part as follows:
PITTSBURG, June 21. -- The attempt to compromise the quarrel between Lawrence C. Phipps and his wife has failed.

Of the Slocum's dead 121 more bodies were found yesterday, according to the count made by the Coroner in charge at North Brother Island at 11 o'clock last night. To the list of identified dead 90 were added yesterday, taking 62 from THE TIMES'S list of missing. Allowing for newly reported missing, due to the police house-to-house canvass, THE TIMES'S list of missing now numbers 195.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- A tariff plank declaring emphatically for protection, but promising revision "when necessary," with the recommendation that such revision should be made by Republicans, was agreed upon late to-night by a subcommittee of the Committee on Resolutions, according to a member.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., (State Camp,) June 21. -- The Eighth Regiment had early morning drill, followed by forenoon drill, in which the Second Battalion had battle formation along the bluff and through the woods. The First Battalion had advanced guard. Guard mount at 8:30 A.M. and evening parade at 6:15 completed the military programme of the infantrymen.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Three errors gave New York a victory over the local team in a game that would have gone beyond nine innings with perfect fielding. Chesbro and Patten, the star pitchers of each team, were getting rid of the batters without serious damage to them for six innings, but in the next overanxiety by Moran sent the game sky-high so far as the locals chances were concerned.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- If the wise philosopher who made the observation that the pleasure of anticipation is greater than that of realization had been in the Chicago Coliseum when the Republican National Convention held its first session to-day, doubtless it would have occurred to him also that verily those who have a good thing are not half so enthusiastic as those who are looking for one.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- There .will be no more horse racing at Washington Park this year, and a report was in circulation tonight that the track where so many American Derbys have been decided will be abandoned.

The first general strike of tailors in six years, and the first strike of any magnitude against the open shop, began yesterday by 1,200 clothing cutters quitting work. This will be followed to-day by a general strike of all branches of the ready-made tailoring industry, which, though it is directed against the New York Clothing Manufacturers' Association, will involve the union men in non-association shops where the work is done through contractors.

Daniel J. Sully, one time cotton king, now bankrupt, was examined yesterday at a meeting of his creditors regarding his personal property, and especially the purchase of the house in which he lived, and the fine bronzes and silverware which were bought to equip it, and the expensive jewelry which he selected at Tiffany's to present to his wife, but for which he never paid.

ST. LOUIS, June 21. -- As a result of a shooting affray in which three men were shot on "The Pike" at the World's Fair ground, Saturday night, "Zach" Mulhall, live-stock agent of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad, was to-day, by order of the World's Fair officials, excluded from further appearance in the show where the trouble took place.

INDIANA, Penn., June 21. -- During a game of baseball to-day between the Johnstown amateurs and the Indiana Normals, George Thomas, catcher for the Johnstowns, was almost instantly killed by being hit over the heart by a foul tip.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- The La Follette faction of the Wisconsin Republicans declined to make a contest before the Credentials Committee this afternoon, declaring that it refused to do so on the ground that the committee was not an unprejudiced body, and making the flat statement that they understood that some members of the committee had been "approached."

The Glen Cove Cups, raced for yesterday by yachts of the New York Yacht Club, were won by the schooner Katrina and the sloop Isolde. The latter won by the narrow margin of 14 seconds. The race was a disappointment, so far as regards the number of boats included, for, although there were seven entries, the starters numbered only five.

WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Assistant Secretary of State Loomis has been notified by the officials of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company that his brother, Kent Loomis, who was en route to Europe, had disappeared from the Kaiser Wilhelm II. Mr. Loomis is confident that his brother has not come to harm.

The National Importers' Association completed its organization at the Broadway Central Hotel yesterday by the adoption of a declaration of principles and the election of a full Board of Directors and officers. It was announced that 190 firms had signed the membership roll, and that several hundred more had signified their intention of coming in as soon as the organization was formally launched.

The Randolph-Backer Company has resold the plot, 77.6 by 98.9, on the north side of Thirty-third Street, about 250 feet east of Third Avenue, for Hyman Oppenheim, to a builder, who will erect thereon two six-story flats.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- There was quite a flutter in the Committee on Rules and Order of Business, which met after the convention adjourned, when objection was made by some of the Middle Western and Eastern States to the proposed increase of representation of Alaska in the next National Convention.

Wall Street is beginning to hear estimates regarding the earnings of the United States Steel Corporation for the quarter ending June 30, next. According to a trustworthy source, the net earnings will be from $18,000,000 to $20,000,000, or considerably less than the net earnings of the other corresponding quarters in the history of the company.

CHICAGO, June 21. -- To-day's game was a pitchers' battle, in which the locals won out in the ninth inning, a base on balls, followed by two singles, scoring the winning run. Cleveland scored their only run in the third inning by bunching three singles. Attendance, 7,550. Score by innings:

RUGBY, England, June 21. -- The first game of the tour of the Haverford College cricket team was played here to-day. Opposed to the young Americans was the eleven of Rugby School, and a grand contest was the result of the meeting.

" Little Japan," a complete Japanese village, with a theatre, bazaars, tea houses, and geisha girls, will probably be the main attraction this year at Glen Island, which opens to-morrow. The whole village and all therein, even to whole generations of one Japanese family, have been imported across the Pacific.

Acting Capt. Wilson of the Bronx Park Police Station last night asked the Superintendent of the Zoological Gardens to try to take into custody a big brown owl which for the past three weeks has been scaring the policemen who were assigned to Post 16, which is one of the most lonely posts in the gloomy old Bronx Precinct.

I have read with great interest the various suggestions offered in your issue of to-day relative to preventing a repetition of the General Slocum disaster. Permit me to add one more and to my mind a vital one.
The 380 votes claimed by THE TIMES for Judge PARKER on the first ballot are only 38 per cent. of the St. Louis Convention -- less than GRANT had in 1880, when he was defeated.

CUXHAVEN, Germany, June 21. -- At a banquet on board the Hamburg-American Line steamer Deutschland to-night on the occasion of the distribution of the regatta prizes, which was attended by Emperor William, the Emperor thanked those present for the opportunity of spending a few hours among them as a comrade and fellow-yachtsman.

Miss Bertha Galland has decided not to disturb the internal electrical organism of steamships in midocean any more. Last time she tried it -- and it was the first time, too -- she succeeded in so disturbing the religion of the wireless telegraph operator on the Campania that he quoted more words from the dictionary of his Satanic Majesty than even the wireless operator in "The Dictator."

Three races out of the Futurity chute and two of these the stake features of the Sheepshead Bay programme yesterday gave meagre satisfaction to the visitors who filled the grand and field stands and sweltered in the heat of the most oppressive afternoon that racegoers have experienced this season.

In his speech at the Bryan Cooper Union meeting Mr. F.W. HINRICHS of Brooklyn declared that if Judge PARKER were elected President he might have the naming of a Judge of the Supreme Court, and would thus have it in his power to overturn the Northern Securities merger decision.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 21. -- The battle of the Yalu was fought over in miniature again on the banks of the Speedwell River this morning, when half a dozen inmates of the insane asylum at Morris Plains escaped and intrenched themselves on the north bank, defying the hospital authorities for several hours.

No other National celebration is followed by so many disastrous accidents and fatalities as is our great National Independence Day. Thousands of boys are disfigured, crippled and fatally wounded as a direct result of this celebration.

Charles W. Goodyear of Buffalo, who received the indorsement of Grover Cleveland for the nomination for Governor on the Democratic ticket, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Kronprinz Wilhelm with Mrs. Goodyear. When Mr. Goodyear read the ex-President's letter of indorsement, published in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES, he smiled and said:
LONDON, June 22. -- The Times's insurance correspondent says:

Mr. BRYAN plays the part of the Devil's Advocate with astonishing fidelity and earnestness. Formal advocacy of the nomination of Judge PARKER would not be half as effective as his opposition. Indeed, the friends of Judge PARKER will readily condone Mr. BRYAN'S impudence in meddling in New York politics out of gratitude for the service he has rendered to their cause.
WASHINGTON, June 21. -- Secretary Cortelyou of the Department of Commerce and Labor left here this afternoon for Chicago to attend the National Republican Convention.

Leo J. Gallagher, the ten-year-old son of John Gallagher, caretaker for Dr. Theron W. Kilmer at his residence, 165 West Eighty-fifth Street, was run over and killed by a south-bound surface car at Eighty-fifth Street and Amsterdam Avenue last night.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 21. -- The News to-day received from its special war correspondent, Hector Fuller, who effected an entrance into Port Arthur, where he was imprisoned five days, a cablegram dated Che-Foo, June 21, in which Fuller gives his experiences as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., June 21. -- The New York National League team, with McGinnity as pitcher, had little difficulty in winning to-day's game from the Boston nine, The latter hit the "Iron Man" as hard as New York hit Willis, but the latter was indifferently supported, while the former was always master of the situation.

Play was continued in the invitation round robin tennis doubles yesterday on the grass courts of the Crescent Athletic Club, at Bay Ridge. The draw of the tournament, which had assumed a perplexing problem because of absentees on the opening day, had been re-arranged by the Chairman of the committee, R.H. Starr, and excellent progress coupled with exciting competitions was made.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 21. -- Samuel Hoffman caused the people living in his vicinity a bad scare early this morning when, because of some disagreement with his wife over the way breakfast should be prepared, he became exceedingly angry, knocked her down with his fist, and then departed in search of an axe.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 21. -- College crew practice was more active to-day than at any time since the beginning of preliminary work here this season. Altogether thirteen crews were on the water to-day, and engaged in the stiffest sort of work despite the heat.

ST. LOUIS, June 2l. -- Accompanied by trainer Will Shields, a force of stable hands, a chestnut pony, and a black bulldog, Hermis, winner of the Suburban Handicap last week, reached the Fair Grounds this evening. Arthur Redfern, who is to bestride the Shields' horse in the $50,000 World's Fair Handicap next Saturday afternoon, reached the city to-night and will remain here until after the race.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 21. -- The first day's programme of the Grand American Handicap week included ten competitions at twenty targets each. Two hundred and forty shooters completed nine of the events. The day was again an ideal one for shooting, but the field proved a trifle unwieldy.

The testimony thus far brought out in the Slocum inquest makes a very bad showing for the equipment of that boat, but even a worse showing for the moral standards of the management of the company through a comparison between the testimony called out on examination and that embodied in the sworn statements made several days ago by officers and crew.
CHICAGO, June 21. -- Secretary of the Treasury Shaw and Representative J. Adam Bede of Minnesota to-night addressed an immense mass meeting in the Auditorium. Frank O. Lowden presided.
Cannon were used yesterday to hasten the recovery of the Slocum's dead, after the thunderstorm of Monday night had brought up many bodies, and many more were recovered.

Watchmen and basin keepers along the South Brooklyn shore at about midnight last night, while watching an auxiliary sloop which was about half a mile off shore, and which seemed to them to be moving slowly up the bay toward Manhattan, suddenly saw the boat light up with flames. A few seconds later there was an explosion aboard and a loud roar came across the water.

The Republican Convention could have chosen no better eulogist and defender of the Roosevelt Administration than ELIHU ROOT. But exception will be taken at once and in his own party to one of the declarations made by Mr. ROOT in his speech as temporary Chairman of the convention yesterday.

The battle of Vafangow as evidently the bloodiest that has yet been fought. The Russian admission of a casualty list exceeding 6,000 makes that plain. But in apparent strategic importance and decisiveness it seems far less noteworthy than the fight on the Yalu, which cleared Korea of the Russians and gave the control of it, and with that control one of the primary objects of the war, to the Japanese.

The securities of the American Steel Foundries Company, which were stricken from the Stock Exchange list last February on account of a misstatement of $500,000 in the "working-capital" account on a statement of condition made to the Exchange when the stock was listed, were put back on the list by the Governors at their meeting yesterday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 22. -- Fifteen members of the graduating class of 1904 of the Mount Vernon High School were kidnapped last night after the commencement exercises by a band of hazers composed of graduates and taken to the woods in Pelham, where they were tied to trees and immersed in a pond. Some of the graduates did not get back to Mount Vernon until daylight.

In one of his almost unfailingly entertaining and suggestive speeches, that made at the distribution of the regatta prizes at Cuxhaven, the German Emperor, we are told, "spoke enthusiastically upon the usefulness of international sport in bettering relations between the countries participating."

In response to the special plea by an Italian for his country in THE TIMES, I am prompted to ask. Are not most of the attempts and acts of assassination the work of Italians? Are they not to-day the mercenaries whose votes are for hire to the corrupt politician on election day, and therefore the most dangerous element in our local politics?

Over 500 dogs, many of them already familiar to dog fanciers by former exhibits in the Madison Square Garden, were shown yesterday under most enjoyable and picturesque conditions at Mineola, L.I. The canines were benched in two of the exhibition buildings in the Mineola Fair Grounds, while the judging was done in five rings under the big and shady pine trees between the halls.
BOSTON, June 22. -- Wiltse led the New Yorks to another victory to-day, allowing the local players but four hits, while Fisher, who was in the box for Boston, was batted for no less than fourteen.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- The convention has disposed of all preliminaries and to-morrow the main purpose for which it convened will be carried out in the nomination of candidates for President and Vice President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- The experiment which has been conducted for nearly two years by Dr. Wiley, Chief Chemist of the Department of Agriculture, to determine the effect of the staple preserved foods on human health has been brought to a conclusion. The formal report has not been made public, but the conclusions were given out to-day.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Speaker Cannon, Chairman of the convention, had carefully prepared a speech of about 2,500 words, which had been duly printed for the benefit of the convention and in readiness for publication in the newspapers.

Up to 2 o'clock yesterday none of the active stocks had fluctuated as much as half a point, and the majority had not moved more than a quarter of a point. This shows as conclusively as anything could show that the market was without impetus, and that the fact that at the close the larger part of the changes were advances was a matter of accident rather than otherwise.

In order to obtain an accurate list of all the passengers on the General Slocum at the time of the disaster and to learn how many of them lost their lives or were saved, or are still missing, the police set out yesterday to investigate the matter thoroughly. The investigation was begun under the general direction of Inspector Schmittberger.
Ex-Mayor Seth Low arrived here yesterday on the steamship Oceanic of the White Star Line after his five months' tour of Italy, France, and England. He was accompanied by Mrs. Low.

Police Commissioner McAdoo yesterday received and made public reports from thirty-six precinct commanders as to the general provisions for the safe handling of excursion crowds at the piers in as many precincts.
PEKING, June 22. -- An imperial edict has just been issued which pardons all who were connected with the reform movement in 1898, with the exception of Kang-Yu-Wei, Liang-Che-Chau, and Sun-Wen.
CHICAGO, June 22. -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew amused a big crowd in the corridor of the Auditorium Hotel to-night with a speech which he made from the main stairway. He said:

According to Montreal dispatches, Canadian capitalists have formed the Rio de Janeiro Tramway, Light and Power Company. Limited, with a capital of $50,000,000, to operate all tramways and lighting companies at Rio do Janeiro, Brazil.
TOKIO, June 22. -- Accounts received from Chinese sources indicate that success has hitherto not attended the Russians' strenuous attempts to free the entrance of Port Arthur.

SAN ANTONIO, June 22. -- The Democratic State Convention finished its business to-day and instructed its delegation to the National Convention to vote for Judge Parker and to vote as a unit on all questions. A feeling of party unanimity and earnestness ruled throughout.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 22. -- Henry Watterson, in The Courier-Journal to-morrow, will assail W.J. Bryan for his New York speech. Referring 1/8 to the meeting at Cooper Institute, Col. Watterson will say:

Clinton W. Stevens, the proprietor of the bath houses at Classon Point, saw a spar floating out in front of his house yesterday afternoon, and thinking it might be wreckage from the Slocum, rowed out and brought it ashore.

The burial of the second group of the General Slocum's nameless dead will take place this morning from the Morgue. On Saturday last twenty-nine bodies which were beyond all hope of identification were buried in one trench in the Lutheran Cemetery. Middle Village, L.I. The coffins were piled tier on tier, and the trench was not more than one-quarter filled.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- The apprehension that there would be a contest in the convention over certain features of the platform was allayed by a unanimous agreement of the subcommittee reached at an early hour this morning.

In connection with the difficulty of locating the bodies of the victims of the Slocum disaster still remaining in the water, it has occurred to me that this is a good time to call the attention of the authorities and the public in general to something I have never heard mentioned or seen advocated as a means of saving life or of locating the bodies of drowned or drowning persons at once.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- This was "Uncle Joe" Cannon's day at the Republican National Convention. From the minute the quaint Speaker of the House took the gavel from Elihu Root at to-day's session and became the permanent Chairman, the body took on an air more nearly resembling life than at any other time.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 22. -- As the result of the severe hailstorm which has visited the neighboring section cotton, corn, wheat, and all the other growing crops have been completely demolished and the country for miles around entirely devastated.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Further to stimulate party enthusiasm a political mass meeting was held in the Auditorium to-night which was addressed by Senator Depew and other well-known Republican orators, who sounded the keynote of the coming campaign.

Over five hundred young women received their diplomas at Carnegie Hall last night as graduates of the Normal College. The large auditorium was filled to the highest gallery with the friends and relatives of the graduates, and they applauded vigorously when the numerous prizes were awarded and the diplomas were distributed.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Mrs. Annie Brzobohata, a widow, seventy years old, has been robbed of $1,700 which she had been accumulating during sixteen years, to be used as part recompense for a murder committed by her husband. The money was kept beneath a cupboard in the house.

KAI-CHOW, June 22. -- Japanese scouts have appeared two miles from Seu-Chen, (Siung-Yue-Cheng?) The main columns of the enemy are three miles in the rear. Gen. Samsonoff, with the Russian rearguard, is falling back as the Japanese advance.

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Washington Park's racing events will be continued at the Hawthorne track, beginning Friday. This decision was reached at a turf conference held this afternoon in the offices of the Western Jockey Club at 59 Clark Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22.1/4 The United States championship lawn tennis tournament in ladies' singles and doubles and mixed doubles was continued to-day at Wissahickon Heights. Miss May Sutton, the seventeen-year-old California girl, was the centre of interest, and she easily defeated Miss F. Stotesbury, allowing her opponent only one game in the two sets, thirteen games being played.

-- Rear Admiral GEORGE W. MELVILLE, now retired and practicing his profession of naval architect and engineer in Philadelphia, has been interviewed by The Inquirer of that city in regard to a report on the laws governing steamboat inspection and their enforcement, made four years ago by a Government board of which he was a member.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- Washington got a good start on New York in the first inning to-day, and the game had the appearance of an ultimate victory for the tail-enders until the opening of the fourth inning, when Dougherty started the biggest batting rally of the season in this section. Eight safe drives for a total of fifteen bases, scoring seven runs, was the result of the cannonading of the Washington pitcher.

It is odd that a village founded by the French in what is now known by the Latinized name of New Scotland should be the first place on the Atlantic Coast of North America to be celebrating the three hundredth year of its birth. The name of Annapolis is at least a century younger than the place.
LONDON, June 23. -- The Times's Kronstadt correspondent, in a letter dated June 17, says:

CHICAGO, June 22. -- Secretary Cortelyou arrived this afternoon, and is stopping at the Chicago Club, where he was called upon to-night by many of the Republican leaders, including several members of the National Committee. The opposition to Mr. Cortelyou's selection has been withdrawn, but there is still a decided feeling against the wisdom of his selection on the part of a number of the members of the National Committee.

CHE-FOO, June 22. -- A well-informed Chinaman of Che-Foo, who has interviewed many of his countrymen who have arrived here from Port Arthur during the last three weeks, gathers that the conditions at the Russian fortress are far worse than heretofore reported.
LONDON, June 22. -- A dispatch from Niu-Chwang to The Daily Mail under date of June 21 says:

CHICAGO, June 22. -- With only one session of the convention each day, and little to do at that, the delegates have plenty of time for sightseeing and visiting, and the whole gathering has partaken of the nature of a holiday outing more than of a political business meeting. This morning there were a number of breakfast parties at the clubs and hotels.

It was learned yesterday that the vessel which blew up at the foot of Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, shortly after midnight yesterday morning was the sloop Theo L., and that she had two men aboard. These men were the owner, Albert Euckele of 4,516 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, and a friend, Charles Johnson of 482 West Twenty-fourth Street, Manhattan, who was employed with Johnson on the Anchor Line pier, Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- An informal meeting of the commission appointed by Secretary Cortelyou to investigate the General Slocum disaster was held to-day at the Department of Commerce and Labor. The members of the commission, Assistant Secretary Lawrence O. Murray, Major Gen. John H. Wilson, Commander Cameron McR. Winslow, and Herbert Knox Smith, Deputy Commissioner of Corporations, were present, the only absentee being George Uhler, the Supervising Inspector General of the Steamship Inspection Service.

Michael J. Sullivan, who was arrested on Monday at Tunkhannock, Penn., after writing a letter to President Mellen of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad promising to reveal, for $10,000, a plot to wreck a special train carrying Connecticut delegates to the Chicago Convention, was arraigned yesterday in the Tombs Police Court and remanded to Police Headquarters for forty-eight hours to await the action of the Connecticut authorities.

David B. Hill's campaign to become Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions at the Democratic National Convention in St. Louis was carried a degree further last night when he held a long conference with National Committeeman James M. Head of Tennessee with a view to obtaining the support of the Tennessee member for his candidacy for the Chairmanship.
LIAO-YANG, June 21. -- The Japanese army base at Siu-Yen is evidently strongly established along a line from Kai-Chow to Yen-Tai.

She appeared to be badly frightened when she entered the Surrogates' office yesterday morning, and she kept glancing about as if she feared some one would throw something at her. Approaching the Administration Bureau she stopped at Clerk Wolf's desk and said:

The New York National League team won the second game of the series with Boston quite handily yesterday, and increased its advantage over the Cincinnatis, who narrowly escaped a shut-out at the hands of the Chicago players. The tail-enders, Brooklyn and Philadelphia, contested for thirteen innings at Washington Park, the visitors scoring the only run.
CHICAGO, June 22. -- Mr. Paul Morton started for Washington to-day, and it is said that he went at the urgent request of President Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22. -- The body of a well-dressed young woman about thirty years of age, was found by two boys to-day lying on a shoal in Big Crum Creek, near Liebersville, about fifteen miles outside this city.

TANGIER, June 22. -- A spot has been selected for the delivery of the Moorish prisoners to Rais Uli and the payment to him of $20,000 of the ransom. Rais Uli undertakes to hand over his captives on that understanding, the other terms having been already fulfilled.
We are in great danger of two serious errors in connection with the appalling disaster which has befallen this city and Nation in the burning of the steamer General Slocum.

Great indignation was expressed last night by a trainload of passengers on a Brooklyn Rapid Transit train bound for Coney Island when, after one of the passengers had been badly injured, the conductor refused to await the arrival of an ambulance and continued the trip to Coney Island.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 22. -- The three Harvard eights rowed two miles down the river to-night, the 'Varsity finishing about three and a half lengths ahead of the freshmen, who beat the second crew a few feet. Under perfect weather conditions the 'Varsity pulled a steady, strong stroke, and made the two miles in 10:03.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., (State Camp.) June 22. -- The officers of the Twenty-second Regiment, who rode up from New York with the First Battery last week, to-day presented Capt. Louis Wendel of the battery with a wrist watch made by Tiffany.

In the present market dullness does not mean weakness, nor does strength mean activity. The volume of business remains nearly constant, and prices show daily improvement, generally in tone and often in figures. All the Pacifics were strong together yesterday, and the market was strong with them.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 22. -- The Prudential Trust Company, located in the East End, and capitalized at $200,000, made a voluntary assignment to-day, the result of a judgment entered yesterday for $29,725 by Machin Brown, Philadelphia contractors.

Ranald H. Macdonald Co. have sold for Francis K. Pendleton to the North River Savings Bank 29 and 31 West Thirty-fourth Street, two four-story dwellings, on plot 50 by 98.9. The price paid for both parcels was about $400,000. On the easterly lot the bank will erect a twelve-story store and office building, and on the westerly lot a smaller structure for its own use.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 22. -- John Cowen, a farmer living some miles from this place, and his son were drowned this evening in Stony Brook. Cowen and the boy had driven into this place and were on their way home.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 22. -- Considering the fact that there was choppy water and a stiff head wind, the Pennsylvania four rowed a very fast four-mile trial this morning. Coach Ward would not make the time public, but a member of one of the crews said that the time for two miles was considerably under 11 minutes.

There have been a number of confident predictions that the Boers would reconquer South Africa and drive out the British. Some have believed that every Dutchman from the Cape to Zambesi would sooner or later unite in a successful effort to establish an independent Boer republic.
CAPE TOWN, June 22. -- The British steamer La Porte, Capt. Turner, recently foundered near Port Nolloth, Cape Colony.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 22. -- McChesney will arrive in this city to-morrow to start in the World's Fair Handicap of $50,000, at a mile and a quarter, next Saturday. Sam Hildreth must think some of the big son of McDuff-Manola-Mason to send him here, though the bookmakers do not seem to be afraid of him, as they are still laying 12 to 1 against his chances.

WASHINGTON, June 22. -- An effort was made to-day by Detective Price of the New York police force and two local detectives to find J. Morgan Smith and his wife, who are known to be in Washington and are wanted as witnesses in the Nan Patterson case in New York. The effort was unavailing.

Having been for a number of years a constant reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a newspaper which has a high degree of fairness and respectability, I beg to call the attention of the public to a state of affairs within the United States postal service. I refer to the sad condition of the substitute letter carrier.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 22. -- Brought to despair by the drunkenness of her husband, Mrs. Horace Ashely of 14 South Sixth Street, this morning forced a quantity of carbolic acid down the throat of their four-year-old daughter, Anna, and then committed suicide by swallowing the same poison.

The New York Clothing Trade Association, through its Executive Committee, took official action on the clothing strike yesterday and decided formally to stand by its open shop declaration. In the action of the association the strike of the tailors is ignored, as it is admitted that in a day or two the strike of the cutters will make all the tailors idle.

BURLINGTON Vt., June 22. -- The Democrats of Vermont held a convention in this city to-day and nominated E.L. Porter for Governor, selected candidates for the other State offices, and named delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis.

An unusually good field of professional golfers competed yesterday in the special tournament arranged by the Nassau Country Club at Glen Cove. The contest was the first important professional golf tournament of the season, and among the players were Willie Anderson of Apawamis, the open champion, and Alexander Smith of the home club, who holds the Western open championship.

The Principal of the Merchant Venturers' Technical College, Bristol, (Prof. Wertheimer,) has sent the following letter, dated May 5, with the name and address of the firm in question, to the Marquis of Lansdowne:

LENOX, Mass., June 22. -- Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain) has leased Richard Watson Gilder's Four Brook Farm in Tyringham, and will arrive there next week. Because of the recent death of his wife in Florence, Italy, Mr. Clemens will spend the Summer very quietly in the Berkshires.
DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 22. -- Samuel F. Smith, ex-Mayor of Davenport, was arrested to-day charged with the embezzlement of $65,000 of trust funds in his hands. He was held under $12,000 bonds.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 22. -- By the trial in the United States Court at Greensborough of A.J. Davis, B.F. Sprinkle, W.B. Young, and T.M. Angle, one of the biggest swindling schemes ever unearthed in this district has been brought to light. The Government has lost more than $100,000, as a result of the operations of the swindlers, now sentenced to eighteen months in the penitentiary at Atlanta.

We congratulate the authors of the Republican platform upon the evidence their work affords of a beginning of moral regeneration in the Republican Party. They have forborne to repeat that time-worn article of their party's creed, the assertion that the Wilson Tariff act of 1894 was the sole cause of the currency panic of 1893, and content themselves with the mere suggestion of the ancient falsehood.

At the Manchester (England) Arts Club on the evening of June 1 Sir Henry Irving made a speech, already mentioned in the cable dispatches, in which he foreshadowed his retirement from the stage. He said:

ST. PETERSBURG, June 22. -- The imminence of a battle in the northern part of the Liao-Tung Peninsula is admitted by the War Office, and is indicated in to-day's dispatches from The Associated Press correspondents at Liao-Yang, Kai-Chow, and other points.

To go on one's wedding trip and discover in the midst of the honeymoon that a double wardrobe is represented only by a bunch of keys was what befell Mr. and Mrs. Smith-Pike of 68 West Sixty-ninth Street. They have just returned from New Orleans and are planning to have the honeymoon all over again.

"Aristocratic Democrat," who takes it upon his shoulders to defend the officers of the German Army and in doing so compares them with the Danish, confesses through this comparison his ignorance of both armies.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has received two letters referring to the apparatus on two of the Iron Steamboat Company's boats, and these two letters were shown yesterday to General Manager Harrison of the company. The first letter reads.
LONDON, June 23. -- Charles Frohman has accepted from Clyde Fitch a play entitled "Granny," in which the veteran actress Mrs. Gilbert will make a farewell tour of the United States next year.
CHICAGO, June 23. -- Ex-Gov. Frank S. Black of New York placed President Roosevelt in nomination in the following speech:

Gen. T.S. Sharretts of the Board of United States General Appraisers held a further hearing yesterday morning in the appeal of Fondeville Van Iderstine from a heavy advance on importations of glassware, which involves charges of under-valuation. Mr. Fondeville presented further testimony purporting to show that the French manufacturers sold the goods at lower prices to other dealers than to them.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 23. -- President Schurman of Cornell University to-day expressed himself emphatically in favor of married life. In his address to the graduating class, after extolling at length the value of higher education, he said:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 23. -- Under conditions of wind and water which were only passable the Pennsylvania 'Varsity eight covered four miles this morning in approximately 19:45. For two miles the freshmen raced with the 'Varsity and were said to have covered the distance in 9:50, being beaten by one and one-half lengths. These performances have given encouragement to the Pennsylvania contingent.

Mr. ROOT is right. It is no campaign of appearances upon which the Republicans have entered. He would be woefully deceived who judged the temper of the party by the listless spirit of the Convention that yesterday nominated Mr. ROOSEVELT for the Presidency. The gusts and tumults of convention halls, the shoutings and the cheers, are mere surface foam of the sea.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Minister Powell, at Port-au-Prince, in a dispatch to the State Department dated June 23 says:

Eleven Stock Exchange firms discovered, upon trying to get their customary telephone connections with the floor just before the opening of business yesterday morning, that since the day's end Wednesday they had been ruthlessly and without warning "cut out." Eleven queries went straightway to the telephone company's manager in the Broad Street district, and eleven affable replies stated that the company had been ordered to disconnect the wires, and didn't know anything about the matter.

Deputy Controller N. Taylor Phillips last evening went to the Hoffman House to present to David B. Hill the claims of Controller Grout for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination this year. Mr. Phillips did not receive much encouragement.

CHICAGO, June 23. -- United States Senator Reed Smoot of Utah, whose admission to the Senate is bitterly contested on the ground that he is a Mormon, to-day sent President Roosevelt the following message of congratulation on his nomination:

KINGSTON, N.Y., June 23. -- Sheriff Webster and 200 deputies, with trained bloodhounds, are on the trail of four men who waylaid and robbed two employes of the Hudson River Blue Stone Company near Jockey Hill to-day.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 23. -- Sheriff EdWard Callahan of Breathitt County and a posse of forty men and three bloodhounds are searching the mountains to-night for the slayer of Mack White, who was shot from ambush at his home, three miles from Jackson, late this afternoon.

PARIS, June 23. -- The unparalleled vitality of M. Combes again seems likely, in spite of all the pessimistic talk in the lobbies of the Chamber, to carry the Cabinet through its present difficulties.

Yesterday's market was substantially a replica of Wednesday's. There were some variations of eighths in the quotations, and the active stocks were not precisely the same, but for all practical purposes the remarks upon either market should be the same. There was about the same volume, the same dull and hard tone, the same lack of real buoyancy indicative of enthusiastic and unskilled buying by lambs.

Streaks of good batting enlivened the third game between the Brooklyn and Philadelphia teams at Washington Park yesterday, but the absence of vigorous and accurate fielding made the contest far from satisfactory. The poor judgment and base running of the Brooklyns were noticeably bad in the first five innings, three men being easily caught in attempting to steal second, while two were caught off the bases.
WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Concerning the National platform of the Republican Party adopted at Chicago, Chairman Cowherd of the Democratic Congressional Committee said:

The hull of the General Slocum was raised yesterday noon and towed at once to the flats in Flushing Bay, off Riker's Island. There it was beached and pumped partially clear of water. With the next high tide an effort will be made to force the wreck further in shore.

WASHINGTON, June 23. -- Surrounded by members of his family, President Roosevelt received the announcement that he had been nominated unanimously by the Republicans assembled at Chicago for the Presidency at 2:13 this afternoon over the special telegraph wire running from Chicago to the Executive offices.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23. -- Harvard defeated Yale at baseball here this afternoon by the score of 5 to 3 in the first game of the series between the two universities. The runs were the result chiefly of erratic fielding on both sides. Coburn, who pitched for Harvard, was fairly effective, striking out six men, but gave four bases on balls.
CHICAGO, June 23. -- In nominating Senator Fairbanks for Vice President Senator Jonathan P. Dolliver spoke as follows:

The public career of Theodore Roosevelt began before he was twenty-four years of age. He is now forty-five. In the intervening period he has been almost continually before the public. He was nominated in 1881 for Member of Assembly in the Twenty-first New York District. Tammany, Irving Hall, and the County Democracy united on W. Strew to run against Roosevelt.

The passengers aboard the steamboat Monmouth of the Central Railroad of New Jersey's Sandy Hook route, on the 1 o'clock run down the bay, had a treat yesterday when the smart little steamship Prince Arthur of the Munson Line, fresh from the builders' hands and on her trial trip down the bay, tried to wrest the laurels from the fleet bay steamboat.

The largest number of students ever graduated from the College of the City of New York in any one year, received their diplomas at the fifty-second annual commencement of the institution last night in Carnegie Hall. There were 210 members in the graduating class, of whom 165 had conferred upon them the degree of Bachelor of Arts and 45 that of Bachelor of Science.
CHICAGO, June 23. -- The last seconding speech of the President was made by Harry S. Cummings (colored) of Baltimore. He said:

CHICAGO, June 23. -- This was get-away day, and the rush started early. Many delegates went out during the nominating speeches to catch trains bearing them to their homes. The hotels got busy early in the morning, and many visitors packed up in order to save time before going to the convention.

The Republican National Convention has pledged the party to the enforcement of the civil service law. The pledge follows the boast that the law was passed by the Republicans. This statement is not quite candid, since the bill was introduced by a Democratic Senator from Ohio, Mr. PENDLETON, and was supported by Democrats in both houses, while the opposition, like the support, came from members of both parties.
MADRID, June 23. -- Thirty persons were killed last night in a train wreck in the Province of Teruel.
