LONDON, June 27. -- Referring to Admiral Togo's latest triumph, The Times's military correspondent says:

There is no mistaking the trend of prices when they are reviewed from week to week. On a daily movement only the largest fluctuations have much significance, for they alone spring from causes likely to be efficient after the lapse of even a small interval. But weekly comparisons deal with the averages of the daily movements and have a wider meaning.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 25. -- James De Voe of Spotswood has bought an automobile, and his troubles have begun. Mr. De Voe is seventy years old, and has ways of his own. His boast is that he has never lost a cent through speculation, and that he has never come across the fellow yet who is sharp enough to fleece him.

Auto-boat racing, which resulted in such excellent records last week, even if the entries for the Challenge Cup of the American Power Boat Association were few, will be continued to-day with what is expected to be one of the big races of the season. This is the match event for the best two of three races over a thirty-mile course between the latest boats of the Smith Mabley and Hollander Tangeman firms.

A careful revision of the police figures of the dead in the Slocum disaster, together with a comparison with the list kept from day to day by THE TIMES, shows the total identified dead to be 830. Eighty bodies were buried without identification up to yesterday morning, at which time there were seven unburied unidentified bodies.

KIEL, June 26. -- The improved weather this morning brought out large crowd of holiday makers. King Edward and Emperor William did not participate in the regatta, which took place under most favorable conditions, there being a clear sky and a strong westerly wind.

The strike of the east side tailors, following the strike of the clothing cutters against the open shop, was declared yesterday to be complete. Sunday begins the working week in nearly all the contractors' shops on the east side, and, according to the strike leaders, no one was working for the members of the New York Clothing Trades Association except an insignificant number of non-union men.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 26. -- Up to tonight the Japanese report of the loss of three Russian ships at Port Arthur has not been published here, though the authorities have allowed to he printed a statement that the squadron had made a sortie and also the news of the loss of Japanese torpedo boat destroyers.
LONDON, June 27. -- The Times this morning prints a ten-column dissertation on the Russo-Japanese war written by Count Tolstoi in his most violent style.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 26. -- President A.T. Hadley of Yale in his baccalaureate address before the senior class this morning took as his text Kipling's "Recessional." He said, in part:

A game of baseball on the American League grounds, One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street and Broadway, was brought to an abrupt ending in the first inning yesterday morning by the appearance of two policemen and two members of the Washington Heights Property Owners' Protective Association, who have been making a determined crusade against Sunday baseball.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 26. -- It is reported that a serious land fight has taken place near Tashi-Chao, in which the Russians were defeated, but no confirmation of this report is obtainable.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 26. -- Announcement will be made to-morrow at Yale University of the senior appointments, and the list will include thirteen for philosophical orations, nineteen for high orations, twenty-five for orations, twenty-nine for dissertations, fifteen for disputes, thirty for second disputes, twenty-nine for first colloquys, and thirty-five for second colloquys.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 26. -- The Associated Press is able to announce on the authority of M. de Plehve, the Minister of the Interior, that there is no intention on the part of the Russian Government of placing upon the Finnish people the responsibility for the assassination of Governor General Bobrikoff by Eugen Schaumann.
WASHINGTON, June 26. -- The death of Archbishop Guidi will be sad news to Secretary Taft and those officials who met the prelate during the negotiation of the purchase of the friars' lands.

TOKIO, June 26. -- Tokio was galvanized yesterday by a rumor that a Russian fleet of twenty-five ships was outside Port Arthur. With the history of the Vladivostok squadron's recent raid so fresh, the first rumors, which preceded the official account, had had a disturbing effect.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26. -- Many friends of Melbourne MacDowell, the actor, were much alarmed last evening over a letter he sent to Coroner Leland announcing his intention of committing suicide, especially when inquiry at the Windsor Hotel, where he had been staying, elicited the information that he had not been seen at the hotel for several hours.

Senator Thomas C. Platt has made arrangements to remain at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach, for the Summer. It was the intention of Senator and Mrs. Platt to go abroad for five weeks, but passage for Europe on July 12 has been canceled. The senator explained his change of plan in this way yesterday:

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 26. -- Bishop James N. FitzGerald of St. Louis, President of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association, delivered the "opening sermon" in the Auditorium this morning, his text being "Sanctify Yourselves." The audience numbered nearly 2,000. Prior to the sermon the Auditorium choir, led by Director Morgan, sang an anthem and the devotions were conducted by Vice President Ballard, the Rev. John H. Alday, M.D., and the Rev. Henry Wheeler.

CHICAGO, June 26. -- Death in flame and the crash of swiftly moving cars was the fate of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Dixon of Lagrange, whose automobile was run down by an Elgin and Chicago electric car in Austin this afternoon. At the instant of the collision the gasoline tank of the automobile exploded, and the victims, shrouded in flames, were hurled nearly 100 feet.

LARCHMONT, June 27. -- The sudden death of Augustin Monroe, Chairman of the House Committee of the Larchmont Yacht Club, and one of the best-known clubmen of New York, caused much surprise when it was announced to-day. Mr. Monroe died at his villa here at an early hour this morning of rheumatism of the heart, an ailment from which he had been suffering for several months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 27. -- Elihu Root ex-Secretary of War, addressed the graduating class of the Yale Law School to-day on "Some Duties of American Lawyers to American Law." In the course of his remarks Mr. Root said:

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., (State Camp,) June 27. -- The two regiments alternated drills this morning. The Sixty-ninth drilled on the old parade ground overlooking. Annesvile Creek, while the Ninth manoeuvred on the gravel plain to the north of camp. The Sixty-ninth's two battalions were consolidated, and Major Michael Lynch put them through a regimental drill.
CHICAGO, June 27. -- The Rev. David D. Delong, in an address to-day before the Congregational ministers of Chicago, said:

DENVER, Col., June 27. -- The proposition of Lawrence C. Phipps to give his wife the income on $5,000,000, and upon his death bequeath her the principal, provided she relinquishes all claim upon the children and surrenders all moneys and securities as well as the Denver and Pittsburg mansions, has been answered by Mrs. Phipps.

It was a very sensible and logical notion on the part of the National Liberal Club of London to invite Mr. GEORGE HAVEN PUTNAM of this city to address them on "The Fiscal Question in the United States from the Point of View of a Business Man." Mr. PUTNAM is a business man of high standing and long experience, engaged both in the manufacture and importation of books, with important connections abroad.

I was much pleased with your editorial on the Manhattan Bridge this morning, and you are getting on to the inwardness of the change in the accepted design. This proceeds wholly from the bitter, antagonism to anything the late Bridge Commissioner did or proposed, on the part of two of his former subordinates whom he got rid of for insubordination and disloyalty.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 27. -- Emperor Nicholas has received the following telegram from Viceroy Alexieff dated June 27:

By winning another game from Philadelphia yesterday the New York National League team improved its advantage as leader, as Pittsburg stopped Chicago's advance, and rain interfered with the Cincinnati game at St. Louis. In the American League the Greater New Yorks won the second contest from the champion Bostons, and only one game separates the two teams.

Harry Goodstein has sold, through Millard Veit, the eight lots on the north side of One Hundred and Fortieth Street, 300 feet east of St. Ann's Avenue, 200 by 100, to C. D. Max, who will offer the property to builders for immediate improvement. Nine forty-foot, five-story flats are now being erected on this block.

Through the People's Security Company the Asphalt Workers' Association has threatened to appeal to Gov. Odell for the ousting of the Borough Presidents of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx, on the ground that those officials are responsible for violations of the eight-hour law, the alien labor law, and the weekly payment law by the different asphalt companies holding city contracts.

Special Treasury agents searched the steamship Indrawadi yesterday as she lay at her pier in Brooklyn, after she had been cleared of her manifested cargo, which she brought here from China and the Far East, having arrived last Friday, and found $8,000 worth of goods which, it is supposed, members of the crew had intended to smuggle ashore.

That the Cuban reciprocity treaty did not take effect prior to Dec. 17, 1903, the date of its ratification by Congress, was the substance of a decision handed down yesterday by the Board of United States General Appraisers. The decision is written by Judge Henderson M. Somerville.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Francis B. Loomis, the Assistant Secretary of State, has had nothing whatsoever to confirm or contradict the rumor that the body of his brother, Kent J. Loomis, had been washed ashore on the French coast, and in spite of the energetic efforts of the combined foreign and consular service of the State Department, not the slightest clue has yet been obtained with reference to the mysterious disappearance.

In the fastest mile race of the Eastern season, Dolly Spanker, an added starter for the Equality Stakes, at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, brought confusion to the handicappers and form followers by galloping past the winning post, pulled to a big gallop, half a length before the "real good thing" of the contest. St. Valentine, while the odds-on favorite Savable finished far back in the crowd.
Julius, the lunchman in Lemaire's saloon at Gates Avenue and Broadway, Brooklyn, was leaning over a beer keg moaning when O'Brien, the plasterer, walked in.

Thomas, better known as "Eat 'Em Up Jack," McManus, forty-two years old, of 239 East Thirteenth Street, and "Bill" Ward, thirty-five years old, of 286 Bowery, engaged in a fight in East Houston Street, near the Bowery, for fifteen minutes last night, as the result of which McManus was cut from the left eye to the left ear, and Ward had his left ear almost torn off.

KIEL, Germany, June 27. -- Emperor William and King Edward to-day visited the Germania and the Imperial Shipbuilding yards. Subsequently their Majesties were the guests of Admiral von Koester, in command of the First Active Squadron, at luncheon on board the battleship Kaiser Wilhelm II., whence they witnessed a procession of boats.

The yearling thoroughbred horses from the Adelbert, Balgowan, and Edenwald Studs and the produce of H.T. Oxnard's breeding farm were sold yesterday by the Fasig-Tipton Company at Sheepshead Bay before a large crowd of horsemen. The prices realized averaged much lower than in former sales by the same establishment. The horses that brought $1,000 or more were as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27. -- Steamer Mariposa from Tahiti brings news of the scalding to death of fifteen men who were penned in the boiler room of the French cruiser Durance, while the warship was on her way from Papeete to Noumea recently.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 27. -- Republicans believe that Joseph Lincoln Steffens's visit to Milwaukee has more significance than his desire to gather material here for another article on graft for his magazine.

In the last preceding article a plan of tariff reform, embodying free wool, free hides, free coal, free wood pulp, reciprocity with Canada, a revision of the chemical schedule, a simplification of the customs drawback law, and a modification of the internal revenue act, so as to provide cheaper alcohol for use in the arts and manufactures, was outlined.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- A special dispatch to The Philadelphia Record from Wilmington, Del., says:

-- Fourth of July always makes a lot of work, with incidental fees, for the doctors, but with that apparent disregard of self-interest at which the doctors themselves are never tired of exclaiming, the medical journals are all indulging in vehement denunciation of the established method of celebrating the anniversary, as well as giving explicit directions for treatment of the inevitable wounds about to be inflicted upon young celebrators and old ones.

ALBANY, June 27. -- The forty-second annual convocation of the University of the State of New York opened in this city to-night. The opening session, which was held in the Senate Chamber, was attended by a large number of prominent educators from all parts of the State, representing the institutions associated in the university.

LONDON, June 27. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Hamburg says it is reported there that the body of Kent J. Loomis, who disappeared from the Kaiser Wilhelm II. shortly before her arrival at Plymouth June 20, has been washed ashore near Cherbourg, France. There is no confirmation of the rumor.
The Tenderloin has a new saying. The bibulous visitor found that out last night.

No records were broken yesterday in the first race of the Smith Mabley and Hollander Tangeman auto boats for the two-thousand-dollar gold cup at the Larchmont Yacht Club. There was, however, one decidedly unusual feature, and that was the forgetfulness of C.H. Tangeman, who ran the boat of his firm, to carry enough gasoline along to complete the race.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 27. -- Lieut. Gen. Sakharoff reports the following details of the reconnaissance of the Japanese forces made by a Russian detachment on June 22 at Ai-Yang.

TANGIER, June 27. -- In spite of the danger of fresh outrages involved in the present state of affairs, France appears to be doing nothing, though rumors are current of the introduction of an Algerian police force.

With a membership limited to twenty-eight, the Summer school in philanthropic work, conducted by the Charity Organization Society of New York, commenced its seventh annual session last evening in the assembly hall of the United Charity Building, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue. Ex-Tenement House Commissioner Robert W. De Forrest presided.

The incorporation at Albany of the New York Hippodrome with a capital of $1,000,000 is generally taken to mean that the project for the erection of a great amusement structure on the old Sixth Avenue car stables block from Forty-third to Forty-fourth Street, for Thompson Dundy of Luna Park, is about to be carried out.

The hard feelings in Arverne, L.I., because on Saturday the boardwalk was torn up for a length of twelve feet by a number of laborers in the employ of William T. Kemble of the Halcyon Casino Company have been greatly aggravated now, for two board fences six feet high have been stretched across the boardwalk, blocking that favorite thoroughfare.

WITH GEN. KUROKI IN THE FIELD, Feng Wang Cheng, June 26, via Soul, Korea, (delayed.) -- A party of eighteen correspondents and military attaches has been conducted on a tour of the main Japanese works beyond headquarters. It was seen that the greatest care has been taken in building these works, and the attaches remarked that the temporary defenses had been constructed with more pains than most European armies would take under similar circumstances.

Mrs. Margaret Wolf, fifty-nine years old, of 307 East Eighteenth Street, one of the excursionists on board the ill-fated General Slocum, who saved herself by jumping over the side and making her way to the tugboat Wade, died at the Harlem Hospital last night of pneumonia. She contracted the disease as the result of her exposure.

The ill-advised strike of the garment workers against the urgent protest of the wisest and most capable leaders of their organizations is now in full progress. Too late to save them, those who find themselves conducting it are vainly regretting that the issue is one which does not admit of compromise.

It is curious how many disease come from a disordered nervous system which locates disease in some part of the body and the primary cause can often traced to coffee, which first breaks down the nervous system, A Georgian says:

GALE'S FERRY, Conn., June 27. -- The Yale 'Varsity eight from the bow oar to the stroke, are in as nearly perfect physical condition as could be wished for by the most fastidious coach, and as there is little prospect that they will deteriorate between now and the time of the big race on Thursday afternoon, the air of confidence about the ale quarters at Gale's Ferry is not surprising.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27. -- Three persons lost their lives and half a dozen others were injured late to-day as the result of the explosion of a small bundle of fireworks in the storeroom of the Diamond Fireworks Company of 826 Arch Street. The dead are Jacob Jancovitch, twenty-eight years old; O. Berman, twenty-seven years old, and Lena Sempson, twenty-one years old.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 27. -- Lieut. Gen. Sakharoff has sent dispatch to-night which confirms the belief that the great decisive battle of the campaign between Gen. Kuropatkin's main army and the armies of Ken. Kuroki (Nodzu?) and Oku is imminent. The three armies probably aggregate 300,000 men, and their outposts are to-day in touch all along the line.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday dwindled hour by hour until the last hour, when there was again some slight show of activity, bringing the total for the day up to the modest amount of 151,000 shares. Between 1 and 2 o'clock the trading amounted to only 6,000 shares, scarcely enough to maintain the market as a continuous entity.

TIEN-TSIN, June 27. -- A correspondent of The Associated Press has seen a translation of a private letter from an officer high in command under Gen. Kuropatkin to a brother officer, giving a gloomy view of the situation for Russia and making disclosures. The writer said:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 27. -- Poughkeepsie is very lively and crowded to-night with college enthusiasts. All the hotels are filled. The feature of the day's work was the disaster that overtook Pennsylvania this morning. The shell, in landing the crew after practice, was knocked against the float and split through the center.

Thomas F. Ryan, who will attend the Democratic National Convention as a delegate from Virginia, said yesterday that he was strongly in favor of the union of Southern delegates at St. Louis for a candidate who can prevent Republican interference with local self-government in the South.

Frank L. Stewart, who is alleged to have been the last person seen with Henry Baxter Kingsley, the young man who has been missing since Nov. 14 last, was held by Magistrate Pool yesterday afternoon for a hearing to-morrow, an adjournment having been asked for by his lawyer, Henry J. Goldsmith.

LONDON, June 27. -- Mrs. W.N. MacMillan of St. Louis reached London to-day after traversing Abyssinia at the head of her own caravan. She is the first white woman to cross Emperor Menelek's country from west to east.
ALBANY, Ga., June 27. -- Chief of Police R.N. Westbrook this afternoon assaulted the Rev. Dr. Lenn G. Broughton of Atlanta with a rawhide whip. The attack was made in a barber's shop.

TRENTON, N.J., June 27. -- George Rice of Marietta, Ohio, has filed a bill in the Court of Chancery asking for the dissolution of the Standard Oil Company, as being illegal under the Anti-Trust act and also under the New Jersey State law. Mr. Rice is represented by Charles E. Hendrickson, Jr., of Jersey City and James W.N. Newlin of Philadelphia.

SARATOGA, June 27. -- Following the startling disclosures in connection with the affairs of the Citizens' National Bank on Friday, developments to-day have increased the feeling of apprehension here until the whole county is discussing the solidity of other banking institutions in the vicinity. The most important events of the day were the closing of the doors of the First National Bank and the mysterious disappearance of its cashier, William H. Bockes.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Ex-Representative Shafroth of Colorado, who made himself famous by voluntarily withdrawing from the contest for his seat last session, in discussing to-day the outlook in Colorado said:

TASHI-CHAO, Between Kai-Chou and Hai-Cheng, Liao-Tung Peninsula, June 27. -- A great battle seems to be impending. A portion of the Russian Army has assumed the offensive against the Japanese forces commanded by Gen. Oku, and it is reported that Gen. Kuroki is moving along the Russian left flank against Hai-Cheng.
Manager T.H. Thurston of the Astor House yesterday morning received this letter, written on the hotel's paper and dated Sunday:

Mrs. Elihu B. Frost, whose husband is a lawyer at 5 Nassau Street, and Mrs. F. Morris, both of whom live at the Plaza Hotel, figured yesterday afternoon in a lively runaway, which was brought to an end by Police Captain Stephenson in the most approved fashion.

The first Jewish association of marksmen, known as the First Independent American Scheutzenbund, with headquarters at 26 Delancey Streets, haled its President to the Essex Market Court yesterday on a charge of embezzling 74. The case was put over for two days on the promise of each side to produce twenty witnesses and no more.

In order to keep the subsidy question out the campaign the Republican Congress appointed a Merchant Marine Commission to take testimony and hear opinions, a measure of precaution which the Chicago platform "heartily approves." The Merchant Marine Commission is now pursuing its inquiries at Detroit.

Because the management of the New York Roof found it necessary to discharge the Giannini Royal Marine Italian Band on Saturday night, and because the musicians threatened to drown the usurping "turn" with music, Roundsman Daniel J. Fogarty and five policemen were in attendance at the Roof last night.

ST. LOUIS, June 27. -- E.J. Pennington of Mount Vernon, Ill., who is a contestant for the prize in the airship contest to be held at the World's Fair, was arrested today by Detective Cordell on a telegram from the Sheriff at Pittsburg, saying that Pennington is wanted on a warrant charging conspiracy and fraud.

WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Hugh T. Taggart, Assistant United States District Attorney, who assisted in the preparation and prosecution of the cases growing out of the Post Office investigation, will resign at the end of the present month. It is understood that a misunderstanding with United States District Attorney Morgan H. Beach is the reason for his action.

LA SALLE, Ill., June 27. -- A petition requesting the resignation of James H. Eckels of Chicago as a delegate to the St. Louis Convention is being circulated among the Democrats of the Twelfth Congressional District. The petition says:

BOSTON, Mass., June 27. -- The victory of the New York Americans to-day places them where by winning to-morrow's game they will go into first place. In six of the nine inning to-day but three men faced Powell each inning, so masterly was his pitching. The visitors batted Tannehill all through the game.

The heartrending catastrophe on the General Slocum has brought to us the bitter lesson that only by systematic and organized effort on the part of the community itself can similar disaster be averted.

By the public and press in this country it has been assumed that Japan's successes in the war have placed beyond doubt a final victory for the Mikado's men. This assumption rests chiefly on the difficulty and expense involved in reinforcing and supplying the Russian Army in Manchuria over a long line of single track railway, the control of the sea having been generally conceded to the Japanese.
TOKIO, June 27. -- Fuller details have been received in regard to the engagement which followed the attempt of the Russian Pacific squadron to break out of Port Arthur.
WASHINGTON, June 27. -- Representative Lucking of Detroit, Mich., one of the ablest members of the minority and a special student of the ship subsidy question, said to-day:

That the man with skill to sell has the right, moral and legal, to sell it for the best price it will bring in the market in which he offers it is not questioned. If he does not have to sell it he need not; if he does have to sell it there is no reason why he should take less than buyers are willing to pay for it.
KIEL, June 28. -- At a banquet given to-night by Prince Henry, King Edward sat between Emperor William and the Crown Prince.

Declaring in favor of having the city go to the Catskills at once for its much-needed increase in water supply, on the theory that the Dutchess County sources are inadequate, the Aldermanic Committee on Water Supply, Gas and Electricity made its report to the Board of Aldermen yesterday.

The young women graduates of the Normal College who applied to the Supreme Court for a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel William H. Maxwell, the Superintendent of Public Instruction, to issue licenses to them to teach in the public schools, lost a point yesterday in a decision handed down by Justice Greenbaum.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 28. -- Syracuse University scored a magnificent triumph to-day in the annual intercollegiate rowing regatta over the Poughkeepsie-Highland course on the Hudson River. Her eight-oared 'Varsity crew, stroked in grand form by E.N. Packard, Jr., and, at the high stroke of 38 at times, won the big event of the day, the four-mile 'Varsity race, leading Cornell, the favorite against the field, by four lengths.

The writer has been much interested in reading the various communications addressed to you, and published in your editorial columns, anent the relative merits of the eye-bar and cable suspension bridges as advanced for the proposed Manhattan Bridge.
WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Carroll D. Wright, the Chief Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor in the Department of Commerce, has begun an inquiry into the recent labor troubles in Colorado.

The reason that J. Pierpont Morgan recently went abroad, according to excellent authority, was not that his business acumen had been dulled and needed sharpening with a vacation. The excellent authority is a well-known Fifth Avenue jewelry firm. The story came out yesterday.

What, it is predicted, will be the finest apartment house in the city is to be built by the firm of Boehm Coon on the entire block front on Central Park West, between Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets, immediately north of the Dakota. The building itself, exclusive of the site, will cost about $2,000,000.
PARIS, June 28. -- M. Clemenceau, in the course of a scathing criticism of M. de Plehve's optimism with respect to conditions in Russia, says:

PARIS, June 28. -- Gustave Flomm of San Francisco, the passenger of the Kaiser Wilhelm II, who particularly noticed Kent Loomis, to-day furnished to the American officials a formal written statement, which will be forwarded to the State Department at Washington, giving precise details regarding Mr. Loomis up to the moment Mr. Mr. Flamm went ashore.

New York's victory over Philadelphia yesterday and the defeat of both the Chicago and Cincinnati teams gave McGraw's players an increased advantage in the championship standing. The only change in the record was the advancement of Boston over Brooklyn. In the American League Boston defeated the Greater New Yorks, while Chicago won from Detroit, placing the local team and the Chicagoans on even terms for second place.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 28 -- The Yale baseball team defeated Harvard by a score of 6 to 1 this afternoon before a crowd estimated at about 8,000 persons. Except for one inning the playing was not so widely divorgent in quality as the score indicates by figures. The Yale team, however, deserved to win, as they played better ball at all times.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 28. -- The first of four outdoor performances by the Ben Greet company was given this afternoon on the grounds of the Cloyne School, for the benefit of the local Army and Navy Young Men's Christian Association. "As You Like It" was played this afternoon and "A Midsummer Night's Dream" this evening.

The first thing to attract attention to this particular parrot was that it was wrapped in a newspaper tied with a bit of white string, just like an old pair of shoes on the way to the cobbler's. A young woman and a little girl got on an Eighth Avenue car with the parrot last night at Fourteenth Street. Both of them were comely and cool.

The second match auto boat race between Smith Mabley's Vingt-et-Un and Hollander Tangeman's Fiat III., under the auspices of the Larchmont Yacht Club, was decided yesterday over a course of thirty nautical miles on Long Island Sound, starting near Larchmont Harbor, and was won by the Vingt-et-Un, which covered the distance in 1:32:50 elapsed time and 1:32:19 actual time.

CHICAGO, June 28. -- Robert Mitchell of 4,153 Calumet Avenue has summoned the aid of the police, as well as that of private detectives, in an effort to reach his wife, who, he asserts, has stolen his four-year-old daughter, and is being concealed with the child in the home of Mrs. Leach, 682 Sawyer Avenue.

The first appearance in a race this season of the champion race horse of 1903, James B. Haggin's world's record holder Waterboy, was the real feature of the racing at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, though Waterboy ran for an overnight purse, while in another contest horses that raced for the great Spring handicaps met in competition for the Bay Ridge Handicap Stakes.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 28. -- The Harvard crews were out to-day for their usual practice, with all the men in good form and holding their weight well. The 'Varsity and freshmen put their shells into the water about 10:30 A.M. and paddled down stream easily for half a mile. Both eights then turned back toward the boathouse and had three racing starts from the pistol shot.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 28. -- Gen. Kuropatkin, his left flank menaced by Gen. Kuroki's army in the mountain passes, is withdrawing northward, followed along the railway by Gen. Oku's corps.

TOKIO, June 28. -- Intelligence from the front indicates that Gen. Kuropatkin contemplates a great battle in the neighborhood of Tashi-Chao, where he is massing from five to six divisions for the purpose of protecting his left rear against the Taku-Shan army, which threatens Tomu-Ching, eighteen miles southeast of Hai-Cheng.
The plans of Boehm Coon for erecting a twelve-story apartment house on Central Park West, between Seventy-third and seventy-fourth Streets, are referred to in more detail in another column.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 28. -- When the New York delegation to the National Prohibition Convention arrived to-day they made public through the National Committee a letter from Gen. Nelson A Miles which he had written several days ago to John G. Woolley of Chicago.

BOSTON, Mass., June 28. -- Gibson outpitched Hughes to-day, and Boston, by brilliant baseball both at the bat and in the field, maintained its lead in the American League. Both teams were nerved up for the struggle, and the large crowd was very nervous. Collins distinguished himself by his batting and brainy ball playing, and Stahl's headwork in getting three bases on called balls was noticeable.
SHAKESPEARE, anticipating by the divination of genius the modern development of scientific mechanics, observed that 'Tis the sport to see the enginer Hoist with his own petard.

LINCOLN, Neb., June 28. -- Gov. Mickey has received several requests from officers and Sheriffs in Custer County, Neb., for militia to help keep order at Broken Bow and in the surrounding country, where thousands of persons have gathered for the opening of homesteads under the new Kinkaid land law.

Acting under instructions from Tammany Hall, which had sent its orders through Alderman James Gaffney, the Board of Aldermen passed yesterday Mr. Richter's ordinance allowing persons or corporations engaged in the business of sprinkling the streets to contract with the Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity for the water with which to do the sprinkling.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 28. -- Meetings of Alumni, the dedication of a memorial to Horace Tracy Pitkin, a Yale missionary who was killed by the Boxers in China in 1900, and the Yale-Harvard baseball game were the main events on the Yale Commencement programme to-day.

One of the most resounding of the rhetorical torpedoes which the eloquent BEVERIDGE exploded in the Chicago Convention was aimed in the direction of Chief Judge PARKER, and was in manner and form following, that is to say: "No mystery ever was elected President of the United States, and none ever will be."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 28. -- Undergraduates and graduates and friends of Syracuse University made the town ring tonight with a gigantic but informal celebration in honor of the victories of the university crews on the Hudson to-day.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jun 28. -- A mob of 100 men, women, and boys went last night to the home of Mrs. J.R. Hodges and her fourteen-year-old daughter, in Collinsville, just outside the city limits, and hauled Frederick Hughson, a boarder there, out to the street. Hughson is fifty-two years old and a carpenter.

" Scar Faced Charlie," whose last name has been erased from the slates of nearly all his acquaintances and whose official residence is in the One Hundred and Eleventh Street section of "Little Italy," shot and killed the horse of his enemy, Bellidini Coti of 228 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, on June 23.
HAI-CHENG, June 28. -- A heavy engagement is expected to-morrow near the village of Si-Mou-Cheng, fifteen miles south southeast of Hai-Cheng and an equal distance due east of the railway.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28. -- Members of the Harvard Law School Association assembled to-day in Sanders's Theatre for the first general meeting since 1895. Chief Justice Melville W. Fuller presided and introduced Secretary of War William H. Taft, who previously had been elected an honorary member of the association, as the orator of the occasion.

LONDON, June 28. -- Extra demands for money in the market to-day, incidental to the half-year closing and Japanese withdrawals, depleted the supplies, though borrowings from the Bank of England assisted the market materially. Discounts tended to become weaker, owing to the scarcity of hills.

Barring a few spasmodic movements that did not appear to have any relation to the list in general, yesterday's stock market was entirely wanting in animation. The fluctuations, with few exceptions, were very narrow, and the trading at times ceased almost entirely. The total for the day, 86,000 shares, came near enough to the low record of last March to lead to some discussion of what is to come as its sequel.

Mayor McClellan received yesterday a letter from Richard H. Adams, Chairman of the Committee on Buildings of the Board of Education, in reply to a letter written by the Mayor requesting information relative to the progress made by the board toward providing sittings for elementary pupils in the public schools.

All the sparrows that live and love and fight and die about City Hall Park seemed to gather there in convention shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. They were in a state of great excitement, chattering over some wonderful piece of news. Now and then they would swoop down with snrill peeps of triumph toward a prostrate form near the Broadway fountain, peck at it, and carry away bits of orange and black hair.
PAUL SMITH'S, N.Y., June 28. -- Henry Prentice, a unique character, who was known to hundreds of New York visitors here, was found dead in the woods to-day.
GYANG-TSE, June 28. -- Gen. Mcdonold began operations this morning for the capture of the jong by a wide movement down the valley to the west.

HAMBURG, June 28. -- King Edward paid his promised visit to Hamburg to-day and met with a most cordial reception from the authorities and big crowds of the inhabitants. He made a tour of the harbor, which was elaborately decorated.

If such levity were permissible yesterday's stock market might be dismissed in four words -- "nothing doing; enough said." In another column will be found the precise statement of how nearly the day was a record for dullness. This is all the more surprising, since there was news enough to warrant activity if anybody had the courage of his convictions.

WASHINGTON, June 28. -- Following a report by the wireless telegraphy board of the navy a contract was signed to-day with the De Forest Wireless Telegraph Company providing for five of the longest wireless circuits in the world.

Reciprocity with Canada would open vast stores of lumber and timber to American consumers and would work improvement in trade all around, by reason of the wide interchange of commodities and goods involved in the same. It is true that our exports to Canada have very greatly increased in recent years, but the Dominion has been through a "boom" period very much like that experienced in the United States.

We think that Mr. THOMAS F. RYAN of Virginia somewhat mistakes the significance of the Republican declaration as to negro suffrage in the South and the intentions of the men who are running the party of emancipation and moral ideas. There is nothing in the words of the platform that pledges the party to a "Force bill," or, for that matter, to anything else very definite.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 28. -- It is estimated that 30,000 persons have come to St. Louis for the express purpose of attending the forty-third annual convention of the National Educational Association, which convened to-day in the World's Fair grounds.
NIU-CHWANG, June 27. -- H.J. Middleton, The Associated Press correspondent with the Russian Headquarters near Liao-Yang, died on Sunday from enteric dysentery.

The second meeting for the organization of the National ,Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers was held on Monday evening at the Hotel Manhattan, and yesterday it was announced that an Executive Committee had been elected. This committee will meet on July 15 and elect officers for the association.

CHICAGO, Ill., June 28. -- Mayor Harrison and City Clerk Bender to-day begun the task of signing 5,250 judgment bonds in two and a half days. The Mayor and City Clerk locked themselves in Mr. Harrison's office at noon.

It cost Giuseppe Degitio, a young organ grinder, a two-dollar fine to let his monkey climb four stories up the front of a Riverside Drive mansion at One Hundred and Eighth Street. It would have cost him a term of imprisonment had not his little co-laborer come to his aid in making up the amount when they stood before Magistrate Mayo, in the West Side Court, yesterday.

DENVER, Col., June 28. -- Realizing that he must concede something more to his wife and that she will never consent to be parted permanently from her children, Lawrence C. Phipps has agreed to pay her $3,500,000 cash if she will be content with the custody of the little girls two months in each year.

At the Directors' meeting of the "Big Four" Railway system yesterday, at which the regular dividend was declared, the following statement of earnings for the year ending June 30 next, with June partly estimated, was made public:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 28. -- Charles A. Gutke, ex-Member of the House of Delegates, convicted on a charge of bribery and soon to be tried on a similar charge, has made a complete confession to Circuit Attorney Joseph W. Folk, in which he declared that ex-Delegate Charles F. Kelley had told him he had received $50,000 for going to Europe when his presence in St. Louis jeopardized men of prominence.

Yesterday's session, like Tuesday's, was dominated so far as activity was concerned, by Phoenix mining, but Wednesday's jests about it were replaced by solemn outgivings fairly justifying its claim to attention upon the same grounds that properties of larger proportions fill the public eye.
The cross on the above map shows the location of the Keek-Wan series of forts at Port Arthur, said to have been captured by the Japanese on Sunday, and their relation to the other defenses.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 29. -- The fact that no further news of the land operations was received to-night did not serve to relieve the tension which is general thoughout the city. The officials continue to feel confidence in Gen. Kuropatkin's judgment and in his ability to deal with the momentous situation, but the general public is keyed up in expectation of a great battle, and is impatient for news of any sort.

John Wendt, a young clerk of 102 East One Hundred and Sixth Street, is quite certain that Frank Gannon, the janitor of the tenement houses at 604 West Forty-ninth Street, is not entitled to any medals for sharpshooting. Gannon spent last night in a cell of the West Forty-seventh Street Station, charged with having fired two ounces of buckshot into Wendt.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 29. -- The Havemeyer Auditorium was used to-night for the first society kirmess of the Putnam Hill Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, of which Mrs. Henry H. Adams of New York is Regent, given for the benefit of an Israel Putnam museum. Thousands of dollars were represented by the magnificent costumes worn in the dances.

PARIS, June 9. -- Pantheism, which metaphysicians say is going out of fashion, will receive a fillip in the philosophical world from an extraordinary announcement made by M. Jean Becquerel at the Academy of Sciences. The statement in question refers to the mysterious N rays which are emitted by human and other living bodies, and also by certain inanimate substances, in particular by metals. Animals put under chloroform,

McGinnity, pitcher of the New York National League team, participated in his twentieth game of the season yesterday, and by winning scored his sixteenth victory. Of the other four games two were defeats and two ties. By defeating Boston at the Polo Grounds the New Yorks won their thirteenth consecutive victory, and before starting on their second Western trip next week will play five more games at home, three with Boston and two with Philadelphia.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., June 29. -- Judge J. C. Pritchard of the United States Circuit Court to-day filed his opinion in which he had discharged from custody Josephus Daniels, editor of The Raleigh News and Observer, who had been fined $2,000 for contempt of court by District Judge Purnell. The case came up on a writ of habeas

Charles F. Reichers, former President of the United Garment Workers, who conducted the big clothing strike of 1898 on behalf of the clothing cutters, has been made strike leader for the cutters in the present fight, and took formal charge of their strike yesterday morning. As the strike of the tailors is in support of the cutters, Reichers has a general supervision of the entire strike.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20. -- Not in years has New London been so quiet on the eve of a boat race as it is to-night. There is no unusual crowd in the streets, and the hotels are only a little more crowded than usual.

NAGASAKI, June 29. -- For three weeks I have been in Japan, and have had an opportunity of witnessing how the Japanese people received the news of the victories on the Liao-Tung Peninsula and the disasters to transports. Nothing could be more striking than the equanimity and calmness with which news of victory and disaster was alike received.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- It was said at the State Department to-day that there was still no news from any of the department's agents in Europe respecting the whereabouts, of Frederick Kent Loomis, who disappeared from the Kaiser Wilhelm II. on June 20 off Plymouth.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29. -- Vice Chancellor Pitney heard testimony to-day in a suit brought by the People's National Bank of Keyport against William V. Wilson and H.H. Seabrook. Involved in it was the telling of some financial transactions made by Benjamin B. Ogden, who disappeared one night last September while holding the offices of Mayor and Postmaster of Keyport, and while trustee of various estates.
Charles H. Easton Co. have sold for R.R. Horner to Robert W. Maloney the plot of nine lots at the southeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Eighty-eighth Street.

There was another period of liquidation in Broad Street yesterday, which gave rise to several rumors so sensational that only a prompt issuance of an official explanation saved a serious break in the market. Just at 2 o'clock a flood of water came rushing down the street from a spot between the Stock Exchange Building and the entrance to the office of J.P. Morgan Co.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 29. -- There is unanimity among the National Committeemen and politicians from the different States who have already gathered here as to the plans and purposes of Mr. Bryan. The Nebraska leader, they say, will use all of his skill and influence to deadlock the convention.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 29. -- The submarine boat Delfin sank at her moorings in the Neva, off the Baltic Shipbuilding Yard, at 11 o'clock this morning. Lieut. Cherkasoff and twenty men were drowned.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The State Department has taken note of the press reports of the dispatch of warships by France and Germany to Haiti to secure reparation for the attack upon the Ministers of those countries at Port-au-Prince.
DALLAS, Texas, June 29. -- Reports received here to-night are that tornadoes this evening struck New Boston and Denton.

JOPLIN, Mo. June 29. -- The Democratic State Convention to elect thirty-six delegates to the National Convention at St. Louis, to-night selected the following delegates at large: United States Senator William J. Stone, Gov. Alexander H. Dockery, Congressman Champ Clark, and David A. De Armond.

To the New England States the advantages which would result from the scheme of tariff reform discussed in these articles would be incalculable. It could not fail to produce a genuine revival of manufacturing in all the more important branches.

The East River Gas Company, the New Amsterdam Gas Company, and the Consolidated Gas Company, which controls the other two corporations, had a hearing yesterday before Supreme Court Justice McCall on their application for the appointment of a commission to condemn city and State property which the gas combination says that it needs to establish a gas tunnel under the East River.

In a decision written by General Appraiser Fischer, the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday sustained a protest by Charles Grandpierre of St. Louis against the assessment of 25 per cent. duty as printed matter on albums containing canceled and uncanceled foreign postage stamps. It was asserted that they were duty free as stamps.
PARIS, June 29. -- There is reason to believe that measures are likely to be taken soon to provide for the security of foreigners in Morocco.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 29. -- The formal commencement exercises and the annual Alumni dinner were the two chief features of to-day's programme at Yale. During the early morning rain fell steadily, and although toward the hour of the opening of the exercises in Woolsey Hall the downpour ceased, it was decided to abandon the usual commencement procession of candidates for degrees, members of the corporation, faculty, and graduates.
ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- M. Santos Dumont is accused by an afternoon paper of having cut his own balloon or of having caused it to be cut.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 29. -- Harvard's Commencement to-day was held in the rain. The march from the yard to Sanders Theatre, where the exercises were held, took place as soon as possible after the bugle call from Harvard Square, nearby, had announced the arrival of Gov. Bates and his staff.
TOKIO, June 29. -- Unofficial reports received in Tokio state that the Japanese began an attack on the outworks to the extreme east of Port Arthur on the forenoon of last Sunday, June 26.

KIEL, June 29. -- King Edward's visit was brought to an end by a farewell banquet on the German Imperial yacht Hohenzollern to-night. The Birtish royal yacht, Victoria and Albert, with his Majesty on board, will sail for England at daybreak, escorted by the British cruiser squadron.

HAI-CHENG, June 29. -- The Japanese are continuing to advance from Siu-ven and Feng-Wang-Cheng. Gen. Oku is also moving north from Senu-Chen. Gen. Samsonoff is contesting his progress, but is not offering serious resistance.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 29. -- With a silk tie knotted tightly about the neck, the body of a stylishly dressed woman who had been strangled to death was found floating in the Mississippi River near here to-day. The appearance of the body and the manner in which the tie was wound about the throat indicate that the woman was murdered.

A "knock-out," three-alarm, sub-cellar fire yesterday in the Langdon estate's five-story, iron-front building 483 and 485 Broadway, which runs back to 56 and 58 Mercer Street, resulted in the asphyxiation or injuring of fourscore firemen, some of whom, including Battalion Chief William Guerin of the Fifth Battalion, were sent to hospitals, and a property loss of about $122,000, besides stopping car traffic on Broadway for three hours.

For the most part the movements in the active stocks in yesterday's stock market were so narrow that at the end of the day a number of prominent issues had not fluctuated more than a quarter of a point. There were a few exceptions, and it was these that furnished the only interest in the day's trading.

Arverne went to bed happy last night for the first time in almost a week. The gentle swish of the waves on its beach was as music to its soul, for the waters spent themselves beneath a boardwalk of unbroken continuity -- a boardwalk which, since Saturday last, had been bisected by a fence six feet high.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 29. -- Gen. Kuropatkin has issued an army order insisting on the kindest and most humane treatment of Japanese prisoners and wounded, notwithstanding the tales of atrocities committed by the Japanese.

The Coroner's jury in the matter of the slaughter on the Slocum has made a sweeping presentation of persons responsible for the awful loss of life, including the officers of the boat, the officers of the company owning and operating the boat, and the United States Inspector who was charged with the examination of the appliances for extinguishing fire and for saving life.

Plans and pictures of the new Manhattan Bridge, as it will appear when completed, were made public yesterday by Commissioner Best of the Department of Bridges and by Carrere Hastings, the architects of the structure. The most striking features of the new bridge are the towers, which appear to be singularly frail for so great a structure, merely because they are of steel instead of solid masonry.

ORANGE, N.J., June. 29. -- Testimony in a friendly suit brought by George H. Macy, George H. Phelps, Jr., and Mrs. Isis Potter Carter, executors of the estate of Oliver S. Carter, who died June 28, 1901, was taken to-day before Vice Chancellor Emery.

The space accorded me by the courtesy of THE TIMES, in which to respond to the letter of Mr. Edward Lind Morse, in its issue of the 21st inst., is so inadequate to the proper reply to his statements that I am unable to make any allusions to them in detail, and as well, to his charges against myself, for my efforts to place the real status of S.F.B. Morse before the world.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 29. -- The Emperor to-day inspected some of the ships of the squadron destined for the Far East. The High Admiral, the Grand Duke Alexis; the Commander in Chief, Grand Duke Vladimir; Marine Minister Avellan, and many officers of the Admiralty were at Kronstadt to greet his Majesty, who arrived there on a yacht from Peterhof.

The failure of the only cotton mill in the South employing negro labor is significant of nothing except the unwisdom of the attempt to launch a business under adverse conditions, with inexperienced management and untrained labor. The qualities which have generally excluded the negro from the cotton mills have relation to his general unfitness for a monotonous occupation which demands patient industry and steady application.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 29. -- A man, supposed to be George Monroe Sterling of New York City, disappeared from the steamer Adirondack on its trip from New York City to this city last night. The fact was not discovered until 7 o'clock to-night, when attaches of the steamer entered the stateroom he had hired in New York City last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- The game to-day between the tailenders of the National League, Brooklyn and Philadelphia, was not of a kind to arouse much enthusiasm, although at times a good hit would impress the rather limited crowd in attendance. Duggleby of the local team was in poor pitching form, and had he been kept in the game there would have been no doubt about the visitors winning.
VALENTINE, Neb., June 29. -- Last night a large crowd of homestead seekers, by sheer force of numbers, took possession of an east-bound freight train on the Fremont, Elkhorn and Missouri Valley Road.

After he had been in his room alone for an hour, during which time, according to his relatives, no extraordinary sound was heard, Louis Levy, fifty-four years old, a real estate dealer, was found dead late last evening in his home at 1,889 Madison Avenue, opposite Mount Morris Park, with a bullet wound in his heart.

With the announcement yesterday by District Attorney Jerome of the dismissal of Robert S. McLellan, one of his subpoena servers, lately called county detectives, there is a strong impression about the Criminal Courts Building that there is to be a general housecleaning in that department.
CHICAGO, June 29. -- A dispatch to The Daily News from Tokio says:

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 29. -- Impetus was given to-day to the boom for Gen. Nelson A. Miles for the Prohibition nomination for President by a public meeting of the delegates and visitors at the State House, following the adjournment of the afternoon session of the convention.

" Bill," the official mouse catcher of the Morrisania Police Station, was locked up in a cell last night charged with grand larceny. The complainant against the prisoner is Sergt. William E. Egan, who alleges that his feline highness stole a porterhouse steak which the Sergeant was anticipating.

LONDON, June 29. -- United States Ambassador Choate presided to-night at the seventy-seventh anniversary festival of, the Printers' Pension Almshouse and Orphan Asylum Corporation, an institution which aids the widows and orphans of printers.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Henry Oxnard of California, the director of the beet sugar industry in that State, was one of the callers on the President to-day. Mr. Oxnard attended the Chicago Convention, though not as a delegate. He will be a candidate for the Senate to succeed Senator Bard, whose term will expire next March.

The nomination of Judge PARKER on the first or at latest on the second ballot taken in the St. Louis Convention is now expected by close observers of political events. Mr. GORMAN is a close observer. We judge from remarks made by him to newspaper reporters in Washington on Tuesday that he no longer expects the defeat of Judge PARKER. He

George A. Kessler of the firm of George A. Kessler Co. concluded a deal last night for the purchase of the entire stock of the Sea Beach Land Company, including the land occupied by Luna Park. Mr. Kessler, accompanied by Edward Lauterbach, his counsel, went to Coney Island yesterday afternoon in a big automobile for the purpose of consummating the transfer.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 29. -- More than 25,000 people joined in a monster demonstration here to-night in honor of the 'Varsity and freshmen crews of Syracuse University, who won their respective races at the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie, yesterday.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 29. -- Mrs. Elizabeth L. McIlwaine, formerly of New York, secured a divorce from Archibald G. McIlwaine, a prominent insurance man of that city, in the District Court this afternoon. In addition, Mrs. McIlwaine secured an order for heavy alimony for the remainder of her life and the custody of their child Archibald, together with sufficient money to rear it properly.

The withdrawal of Mr. HUGH T. TAGGART of Washington from the prosecution of the cases growing out of the Post Office investigation seems to call for a supplementary investigation of that prosecution. What seem to be statements authorized by Mr. TAGGART have no meaning unless they mean that that prosecution was collusive. His own zeal

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 29. -- The report of the Committee on Synod to the conference of the American Rabbis was read to-day. The committee reported in favor of establishing a synod for the central government of the Church -- the most important step since the foundation of reformed Judaism, the congregations having hitherto been practically independent. The recommendations in the report follow:

KIEL, June 29. -- In to-day's race the German yacht Suzanne won the gold cup given by King Edward, the German Emperor's yacht Iduna was second, and Morton F. Plant's Ingomar of the New York Yacht Club was third. The German Emperor's yacht Meteor III, did not finish and was towed in by a torpedo boat.

ST. LOUIS, June 29. -- No candidates for the Presidency of the National Educational Association, which began its second day's session to-day, have been announced, but indications point to the election of W.H. Maxwell, Superintendent of Schools of Greater New York. His name will be presented to the Nominating Committee tomorrow by New York's delegation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29. -- The Board of Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company to-day declared a dividend of 10 per cent. on the preferred stock and 1 per cent. on the common. This is the first Lehigh Valley dividend in eleven years.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Secretary Cortelyou of the Department of Commerce and Labor has acted decisively in the Slocum matter by sending the following telegram to-day:

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The Treasury statement, which will show the official figures of the Government's operations for the year ending with June 30, will not be issued until to-morrow, but a statement was given out to-day showing the receipts and expenditures for the year, which will not be materially changed by the official statement.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 30. -- After a telegram from Gen. Miles declining the nomination had been read, the Prohibition Convention to-day nominated the Rev. Dr. Silas C. Swallow of Harrisburg, Penn., for President by acclamation.

For nearly half an hour the Third Avenue surface road was blocked last evening at the corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street by a fantastically dressed monkey. The mischief maker was one of the trained creatures which are profitable accompaniments of handorgans, this one being the property of Raphjil Derago, phonetically spelled, who said that he and the monkey "crawled in somewhere on Mulberry Street at night."

PARIS, June 30. -- The arrest of three officers on active service, Lieut. Col. Rollin, Capt. Francois, and Capt. Marechal, in connection with the case against M. d'Autriche has caused a sensation in Paris. The exact charge against them has not been made known officially.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., June 30. -From the drawing room to the prospecting camp is the record made .by two society girls of St. Louis, Madge Pickler and Grace Kepford, daughters of prominent families in the World's Fair City. They have come to Colorado "to develop our claims," as they put it, and are now in camp at St. Peter's Dome, near Pike's Peak, where they expect to spend the Summer.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 30. -- Failing to go to his office for two days, a messenger was sent to the home of William H. Owen, local manager of the Western Union Telegraph office, this morning. No response meeting his knocks at the door it was forced open and the dead bodies of Owen and his wife were found in separate rooms.

Pittsburg, June 30. -- The story that Charles M. Schwab has resigned as a director of the United States Steel Corporation is not believed in this city. Concerning the statement that W.P. Snyder would succeed Mr. Schwab, Mr. Snyder said this afternoon:

In a riot that occurred last night on East Fifteenth Street, between Avenues A and B. Policemen Mills and Ayres of the East Twenty-second Street Station, in spite of severe injuries, aided in quelling the disturbance and arresting the ringleaders.

The report from Paris that the French Government is about to take measures to provide for the policing or Tangier by troops under the direct or indirect command of French offcers may be premature, and there are difficulties in the way which the conservative M. DELCASSE will seriously consider; but soon or late France will have practically to take charge of the safety of foreigners in the principal city of Morocco.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30. -- The working force of the Pennsylvania Railroad's operating department has been decreased 11 per-cent., and all other departments have undergone a 5 per cent. reduction. A statement to this effect was officially made to-day. It was also announced that, beginning to-morrow morning, the reductions will be in force throughout the entire system, both east and west of Pittsburg.

The Johnston estate is preparing to extend the Johnston Building, at Broad Street and Exchange Place, over the adjoining lots at 38 and 40 Broad Street, running through to New Street. These properties, which have been acquired at various times within the last two years have frontages of about 40 feet on Broad Street and 50 feet on New Street.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Postmaster General Payne and Mr. Takahira, the Japanese Minister, to-day signed a parcels post agreement between the United States and Japan. The agreement will take effect Aug. 1.

NEW LONDON, June 30. -- Rain, rough water, and mismanagement made a combination to-day that most effectually dulled the edge of success and enjoyment of the Yale-Harvard intercollegiate rowing regatta over the historic Thames course. One race only of the three scheduled to be rowed took place, the freshman eight-oared contest.

ST. LOUIS, June 30. -- Col. Edward Butler, a prominent local politician, came into court this afternoon in answer to a bench warrant charging him with bribing Charles F. Kelley, ex-Speaker of the House of Delegates. He was released on a bond of $10,000 with John J. O'Brien as surety.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 30. -- W.H. Maxwell, superintendent of instruction in New York City, was to-day elected President of the National Educational Association for the coming year. Twelve Vice Presidents were elected, including A.B. Poland of New Jersey.

Charles F. Murphy, leader of Tammany Hall, came out for Cleveland again in an interview at the Fourteenth Street headquarters at noon yesterday. He said that he was not booming any candidate, but still thought Cleveland the strongest man in the party.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Lou Payn called on the President this morning. This was their first meeting since Mr. Roosevelt as Governor of New York five years ago refused to reappoint Payn Commissioner of Insurance. The latter had been the President's outspoken enemy ever since.

The Boston Americans have made another exchange of players, giving O'Neill, the outfielder, for Al Selbach of the Washington Club. The latter has not appeared in a game for some time, being under suspension by President Johnson of the American League for indifferent playing.

The Hamburg-American Line's flier Deutschland brought many notables to port yesterday. Among them were Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, who have been away since April, much of the time abroad having been spent in automobiling. Mrs. Astor said that her visit to London was the most pleasant she has ever made.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 30. -- The following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin to the Emperor, dated June 29, was received today:

TOKIO, June 30. -- Detailed reports of the capture of Fen-Shui Pass (twenty-five miles from Hai-Cheng) on June 27 show that the Russians were driven from an exceedingly strong position dominating the Shimu-Cheng road. In this engagement the Russian losses were again heavier than those of the Japanese.

Josephine Rugulo, twelve years old, a little girl with motherly instincts, is miserable because the police of the West Twenty-second Street Station will not let her keep a girl baby, two weeks old, whom she found yesterday afternoon in the doorway of her home at 413 East Eighteenth Street. Josephine found the baby on the mat in the hall.

PATERSON, N.J., June 30. -- Max Wollenberg, a haberdasher at 302 Main Street, was shot and killed near his store at 9 o'clock this morning by Edward Lasker, twenty years old, a negro, whom he was chasing, and who, it is believed, intended to rob him. In his flight the negro fired again and again into the crowd of pursuers, and one bullet struck William Kessel in the jaw, incflicting a serious wound.

Caleb A. Burbank, who offered for probate the will of his uncle, Ambrose B. Burbank, under which he is to receive $750,000, was the principal witness called yesterday at the hearing of the contest before Surrogate Fitzgerald. The will, which is being contested by many nephews and grandnieces of the testator, was made in March, 1889.

With a comparatively small audience for such an event the Republican Club, banner organization of the party in this city, fired the opening gun in the local campaign at a mass meeting held in Cooper Union last night to formally indorse the candidacy of Theodore Roosevelt and Senator Fairbanks for President and Vice President of the United States.

The finding of the Coroner's jury in the case of the victims of the Slocum disaster is all very well. Nothing less or different would have met the requirements of the case. For the present the persons named in this verdict as responsible are held under moderate bail. In clue course they will be indicted, no doubt.

There was no evidence yesterday in the office of the Steamboat Inspectors that any attention was being paid to the order of Secretary Cortelyou of the Department of Commerce and Labor relative to a reinspection of the vessels in the Harbor of New York. Inspector General Uhler, who is the head of the bureau in Washington, was in that city.

LONDON, July 1, (Friday.) -- From the highest official sources here and from the Japanese Legation comes the positive statement that nothing whatever has resulted from the interviews between King Edward and Emperor William at Kiel that in any way is connected with the Russo-Japanese war.

Neither SCHAUMANN nor his victim -- if we should not rather say, neither BOBRIKOFF nor his victim -- was fairly cold before the Russian official press had begun to give out that the act of the tyrannicide was the result of a "Swedish conspiracy" and to threaten the proclamation of a state of siege in Finland in order to defeat its further machinations.

t Although the various terms of the State courts do not end until Saturday, most of the courts closed yesterday for the Summer, and will not be reopened until the first Monday of October. Parts I. and II. of the Special Term will remain open, however for the hearing of motions and the granting of writs and orders.

On an open car on one of the west side avenues yesterday the bell rope was in such a condition -- being knotted in several places -- that it was impossible for the conductor to get the attention of the motorman without going forward on the footboard and ordering the stop or start of the car by word of mouth.

-- Mr. W.B. WAY has resigned the position of locomotive engineer for the Liberty Brick Company of Liberty City, Ga., and is now the proprietor and editor of The Liberty City Times. This is news more important than it may seem at first thought, for The Liberty City Times promises, under its new management, to enlarge the possibilities of American journalism and to be the source of much innocent joy.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 30. -- Sheriff Bogardus, accompanied by Deputy Sheriff Close and five special officers, descended upon two alleged gambling houses at West End to-night. At the Melbourne Club, on Hollywood Avenue, five persons, including the proprietor, Thomas Johnson, were rounded up.

GYANG-TSE, June 29. -- Two Tibetans approached Chung-Lo this morning with a flag of truce. They were received by Col. Younghusband, who granted an armistice. The cessation of hostilities till sunset to-morrow was agreed upon, in order to allow time for the presence at Gyang-Tse of Tibetan representatives from Lhasa.

Lightning struck the foremast of the Anchor Line steamship Furnessia during the thunderstorm last night as she was lying at her pier at the foot of West Twenty-fourth Street. The bolt carried away a two-foot section of the topgallant mast, cut the signal halyards asunder, and splintered the signal halyard truck.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- The public and private correspondence of Elihu B. Washburne, gathered while he was Minister to France, has been classified and bound in book form. It will be turned over to the Congressional Library at Washington next week.

Of the three games scheduled in the National League yesterday two were played, Brooklyn's contest at Philadelphia being postponed on account of rain. The New Yorks won for the eleventh time against Boston, and Chicago was successful against St. Louis. Rain interfered with the American League games, the downpour of the early morning making American League Park so unfit that the engagement between Griffith's men and the Washingtons had to be called off.

RICHMOND, Va., June 30. -- According to a letter received here from Louis Gudebrod, the sculptor, he will sue Gutzon Borglum, a fellow artist, for $50,000 on a charge of slander. A letter from Borglum says the suit has actually been instituted.

The second race of the match for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup, sailed yesterday afternoon in a snapping breeze, was a spirited and exciting contest. The thirty-foot yacht Alert, defender of the cup, reveled in the trying weather and won handily notwithstanding an allowance of 5 minutes 49 seconds to the Mimosa, which finished second
AURORA, Ill., June 30. -- Several hundred people to-day besieged the doors of the German-American Bank, the cashier of which, Col. J.H. Plain, by his own confession is short $90,000 in his accounts.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 30. -- With one-half of the play in the fifth Western Golf Association open tourney concluded to-day on the links of the Kent Country Club, National champion Willie Anderson leads the field with a score of 154, just three strokes better than the total of Alexander Smith of Nassau, the Western title holder.

An explosion of leaking gas in the basement of the old Mount Sinai Hospital building at Sixty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue, which is being razed, started a fire yesterday afternoon which caused considerable excitement in the neighborhood and baffled the firemen for nearly an hour. Although there were more than a score of workmen in the building, only one man was hurt.

CINCINNATI, O., June 30. -- Judge Judson Harmon, Attorney-General under Cleveland, returned home to-day from the East, and at once conferred with a number of Democrfatic leaders regarding his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Harmon was adverse to talking, but he said:

NIU-CHWANG, June 30. -- The Russian torpedo boat destroyer Lieutenant Burukoff arrived here from Port Arthur yesterday evening and is berthed alongside the gunboat Sivoutch. The river bank was soon crowded with excited natives, who were told by the Russians that the Japanese fleet had been completely destroyed.
LONDON, June 30. -- The Times's insurance correspondent says:

TORONTO, Ontario, June 30. -- In the course of an interview Prof. Goldwin Smith said he had reason to believe that Grover Cleveland would be nominated for President of the United States at the Democratic convention, and in that case the professor believed he stood a very fair chance of being elected.

To the wheat fields in Kansas and Nebraska, where harvests are waiting for the reaper, the State Free Employment Bureau, at 107 East Thirty-first Street, yesterday sent a vanguard of workers from this city to supply the temporary deficiency in the far Western labor market. There were forty men in this first batch, which will be followed by others weekly during the month of July.

This morning being Saturday and my day off, I made up my mind to go fishing. At the foot of the Madison Avenue Bridge, at One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street, two young men came along and yelled like Indians to a steam yacht's skipper.

The address made at St. Louis by Mr. PHILLIPS, School Superintendent at Birmingham, Ala., is only one of many indications of the movement toward thorough education in the South. Mr. PHILLIPS directed attention particularly toward the very great need of schooling for Southern whites.

On a summons issued yesterday by Magistrate Naumer in the Manhattan Avenue Court, Williamsburg, Alderman Frederick Brenner of the Sixteenth Ward of Williamsburg is to appear on Tuesday in that court and explain his refusal in countersigning an application for a license for a peddler who desired to carry on a fruit business.

ANSONIA, Conn., June 30. -- While crossing the ocean with her daughter, Miss Elise Marion Farrel, Mrs. Farrel, wife of Franklin Farrel, mine owner, sugar grower, and President of the Farrel Foundry and Machine Company, succeeded in effecting a reconciliation between her daughter and David Huyler Gaines of New York.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 30. -- Charles J. Bell of Walden was nominated for Governor on the first ballot by the Republican State Convention here to-day. Charles H. Stearns of Johnson was named for Lieutenant Governor. For Secretary of State F.G. Fleetwood of Morrisville was nominated, and for State Treasurer J.L. Bacon of White River Junction. Horace F. Graham of Craftsbury was named for State Auditor.

Notices have been sent out to the preferred stockholders in the Sweetser, Pembrook Co. corporation, calling them to a meeting to be held this afternoon at the office of Dickman, Luckey Schwartz, 100 Broadway, to devise means to protect their interests. The notice is signed by L. Victor Seydel, John J. Schwartz, and Arthur Finley, as a committee of the preferred stockholders.
The business men of New York City have become convinced within the past few weeks that the abating of the poolroom evil is far from affording the relief which had been hoped for.

Whoever with an unbiased mind contemplates the present condition of the Democratic Party will find matters to provoke his curiosity and excite his wonder. Judging from the make-up of the St. Louis Convention, the delegates to which have all been chosen, Judge PARKER will in all probability receive the nomination on the first or the second ballot.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Representative William R. Hearst arrived here to-day with Mrs. Hearst from Chicago. This afternoon Mr. Hearst repaired to the office of John R. McLean, with whom he was closeted for more than an hour.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, June 30. -- The French cruiser Jurien de la Graviero arrived here to-day. The incident of the stoning of the French and German Ministers is here asserted to have been closed by renewed formal apologies, which have been accepted by the French and German Ministers.
ST. PETERSBURG, July 1. -- The Emperor has received the following dispatch from Gen. Kuropatkin, dated June 30:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 1. -- The Rev. William S. Newson of Califon, was awakened about midnight last night by heavy thumping on his front door. Hastily arising, he hurried down, and had no more than opened the door when a young couple burst in and hagged him to marry them at once, because, as the young woman explained:

Until a very recent date we have doubted the expediency of a currency resolution in the Democratic National platform to be adopted at St. Louis. The gold standard has been established, it will remain; there is no currency issue -- why keep up the pretense that there is such an issue?

Prof. W.M. Flinders Petrie has written a new book on archaeology, called "Methods and Aims in Archaeology." This is a book of reference to those engaged in actual archaeological work, although it has also been written with a view to giving the public a view of the way in which the work is done and how the results are obtained.

The cartoons in John T. McCutcheon's new volume ("Bird Center Cartoons." Quarto. Decorated board covers, linen back. Chicago: A.C. McClurg Co.) have already appeared in the Chicago papers. Together they form a chronicle of social happenings at Bird Center, Ill., in the social circle of which all people are equal.

The annual regatta of the American Yacht Club sailed yesterday off the clubhouse at Milton Point, on Long Island Sound, was one of the most successful yachting events of the season. Nineteen yachts started, and after sailing a beautiful race every one crossed the finish line. The sixty-foot sloops Weetamoe and Neola raced 28 1/2 knots, most of the time scarcely more than a cable's length away, and finished only 47 seconds apart.

The majority of the Democrats of New York, whose names are associated with leadership in their party, are on their way to St. Louis, with trainloads of delegates and observers following and to follow them. The William F. Sheehan party left at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Among them were De Lancey Nicoll, G.B.M. Harvey, Henry D. Macdona, Thomas F. Ryan, and H.P. Whitney.
LONDON, July 1. -- London is giving an especially hearty reception to the American delegation attending the Salvation Army Congress.

So far not a hand has been turned nor a move of any kind made by the local Board of Steamboat Inspectors to comply with Secretary Cortelyou's order respecting the reinspection of passenger steamers in this harbor. As a matter of fact it was plainly stated at the office of the Inspectors in the Whitehall Building yesterday that no such order had ever been received.

Mr. Edward W. Emerson publishes in The Atlantic Monthly for July some pages from Ralph Waldo Emerson's Journal relating to his visit to Washington in January, 1862. It is perfectly safe to say that, to an American reader, no more interesting pages of intimate, frank, unstudied writing of this sort are to be found in the Pepys or Evelyn, in the letters of Cowper or Horace Walpole.
